title: Break for Wiggins
description: Alan Wiggins, who is undergoing therapy at a drug-treatment center, may be able to resume his career without serving a suspension, officials of the San Diego Padres say. Although Wiggins was arrested for cocaine possession in July 1982, he is considered to be a first-time offender under the joint drug agreement adopted by baseball owners and players last May, said Lee MacPhail, president of the Players Relations Committee. Because that program was not in effect at that time of the 1982 incident, Wiggins has been granted amnesty for the month that he spent in a drug-rehabilitation center and subsequent 30-day suspension imposed three years ago.

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MACMILLAN RING-FREE OIL CO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TURNER MIGHT SAVE CBS FROM ITSELF
description: When Ted Turner came a-courtin' to CBS a few years back, this most proud and disdainful of maidens turned him a cold shoulder. Now he's threatening to carry the network off kicking and screaming, and I for one hope he gets away with it.

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FACTORY ORDERS DOWN 0.9% IN MARCH
description: Orders to American factories, driven down sharply by lessened demand for domestically made durable goods, declined by nine-tenths of 1 percent in March for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department said today.

title: 2 Men Held in Louisiana After Kidnapping Girl
description: Two men suspected of kidnapping a woman, beating her boyfriend and shooting passers-by who went to the couple's rescue will be charged with capital murder and kidnapping, the Texas authorities said today.

BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Economic Scene;   Summit Woes: Made in U.S.?
description: HAS the emotional explosion over President Reagan's planned visit to the German military cemetery at Bitburg blown the economic work of this summit conference out of the water?

BENNETT ON FAMILY PLANNING
description: The Secretary of Education, William J. Bennett, says large families with incomes above $60,000 should ''do your family planning a little better or find other means'' than Federal loans to put their children through college.

title: Letter: On Hazardous Waste;   No Need to Delay Burning at Sea
description: To the Editor:

HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Court Refuses to Release Names of Study Subjects
description: A Federal appeals court, saying the work of the Centers for Disease Control sometimes depended on confidentiality, has declined to release the names of women who participated in a study of toxic shock syndrome.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PLUGGING IN THE SOUND Pioneering work on electronic music was done in Europe in the 1950's. It has taken 30 years for these sounds to get to the Hayden Planetarium. They have, however, arrived and will be heard there tonight and tomorrow in the planetarium's first electronic concert, ''Celestial Rhythms.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: From the Zen Community Greystone Bakery, operated by the Zen Community of New York, is a small-scale operation making some 200 different products, including a number of first-rate breads and desserts that are for sale in supermarkets as well as specialty groceries and restaurants in the city.

title: LAST DEADLINE FOR OPPONENT OF APARTHEID
description: A newspaper died in South Africa today.

title: LAWTER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHEVRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter included a foreign exchange gain of $18,000,000.

title: Signal Companies
description: Forrest M. Shumway, chairman and chief executive of the Signal Companies, confirmed today that the company is considering a bid for the Hughes Aircraft Company. Speaking at Signal's annual meeting in San Diego, Mr. Shumway said the company is ''taking a long, hard look'' at the aerospace concern, which is up for sale by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. So far, only Signal and the Allied Corporation have publicly announced their interest in Hughes.

title: HALL, FRANK B & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $2,950,000 from equity loss in Jartran Inc. c-After a loss of $73,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated for a pooling of interests.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Chilean Band Offers South American Pop
description: Los Jaivas has a worthy goal - to create contemporary South American pop music that has traditional roots and the impact of rock, but that doesn't imitate North American forms. The five-man band, formed in Chile in the 1960's and now based in Paris, made its New York debut Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, before a wildly enthusiastic audience that shouted ''Viva Chile'' after the final encore.

title: ISRAEL TO GET ADDITIONAL U.S. AID, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: The Reagan Administration, in response to a pressing request from Prime Minister Shimon Peres, has decided in principle to grant Israel $1.5 billion more in economic aid, Administration officials said today.

title: FILLING BIG HOPES WITH SMALL GRANTS
description: LAST January Wayne Meisel walked 1,500 miles between Maine and Washington, D.C., stopping at 70 colleges and talking to students, faculty members and townspeople about involving undergraduates as volunteers in community improvement. Looking back now, he sees his journey as ''an act of desperation''; he had begun to doubt that he could muster the support and money he needed to turn his idea into a national reality.

title: NEW CRAZE LIFTS SMALL BOTTLER
description: Until three months ago, the A.J. Canfield Company was little more than a small, albeit successful, soft-drink bottler in Chicago. Then came the Diet Chocolate Fudge Soda craze, and things at 61-year-old Canfield's have not been the same since.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Music/Noted in Brief;   Earl Klugh, Guitarist, At the Beacon Theater
description: The pop-jazz electric guitarist Earl Klugh has enjoyed a number of successful albums that feature his cheery melodic playing against various warm orchestral settings. While far from virtuosic, Mr. Klugh's best records have stood as fluent, friendly examples of contemporary guitar-oriented mood music.

title: SHUTTLE CREW ENCOUNTERS SPLENDOR OF THE AURORAS
description: The space shuttle Challenger's crew flew through what one them described as ''spectacular'' rainbows of charged electrons thousands of miles long today in what may have been man's closest look at the northern lights.

title: FERROFLUIDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $213,292. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $31,359 for the quarter and $195,305 for the 9 months.

title: ADIA SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KISSINGER AND LE DUC THO MEET AGAIN, AND BITTERNESS SHOWS
description: It had been more than a decade since Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho sat together in Paris, negotiating an uneasy settlement to an unpopular war. But the bitterness over the end of the Vietnam War is still close to the surface for Mr. Kissinger, whose temper flared Monday night when the former antagonists appeared on the ABC News program ''Nightline.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Beefsteak Charlie's Inc. shareholders voted to change the company's name to Lifestyle Restaurants Inc.

description: b-Net loss

U.S.-TOKYO AIR CARGO PACT IS SET
description: The Reagan Administration, removing a thorn in relations between the United States and Japan, has agreed to give a new Japanese air-cargo carrier, Nippon Cargo Airlines, permission to serve the United States, a senior Administration official said today.

title: 'TREASURE,' A DAUGHTER'S QUEST
description: MARGO (MARGOT KIDDER) is a topless dancer and stripper with a dirty mouth, a clean body and, most important, high principles. She is firm in her refusal to dance bottomless or to strip beyond her G-string. When a rich young rancher offers her $1,000 to dance nude at a private party, she is properly outraged.

title: PAST DIFFICULTIES AT WALKATHON CITED IN REPORTS
description: The March of Dimes walkathon Sunday, in which gangs of youths set upon marchers in Central Park, was not the first such event that has resulted in friction between the promoters of the walkathon and the City Parks and Recreation Department.

LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW WORLD OF PACKAGED FOOD: FOR CONSUMERS, MORE SURPRISES
description: ONE morning recently a shopper paused at the frozen juice section in a large new supermarket in Danbury, Conn. Most of the juice concentrates were packaged in familiar short round cans made of paper and foil with metal lids. One brand, however, came in a plastic container with a pop-off top. With only a moment's hesitation the shopper reached for it.

title: THE BRONX ZOO HOSPITAL JOINS RESEARCH AND CARE
description: Dr. Emil Dolensek traced a meandering path through the network of holding pens, the recovery room and the high-ceilinged operating theater of the new Animal Health Center that opened yesterday at the Bronx Zoo.

title: United Cable Plan
description: The United Cable Television Corporation said that it had started a tender offer to buy back about 16.5 percent of its stock for $40 a share, or a total of $80 million. The company said it wanted to buy a maximum of two million of its 12.1 million shares outstanding because it was an ''attractive investment.'' The shares will be purchased with the proceeds of a $100 million debt issue.

title: ALOHA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MONSANTO WINS DIOXIN LAWSUIT FILED BY SEVEN
description: A Federal jury found today that the Monsanto Company was not responsible for the illness of seven retired employees who said they had been poisoned on the job by dioxin. The jury did allow the damage claim of one of the seven whose illness was linked to another chemical.

title: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Lead Poisoning Traced to Dust Particles
description: To the Editor:

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $164,000 from the early retirement of debt.

title: Market Place;   Growing Retail Merger Trend
description: LAST week, a day after Ames Department Stores and the G.C. Murphy Company announced that Murphy would be acquired by Ames, Ames's common stock shot up $4 a share. It was a surprising rise considering that an acquiring company's stock generally falls while the acquired company's stock rises. In this case, both stocks rose. But analysts explain that the unusual rise in Ames's stock reflected the market's conviction that the deal was a good one for that company as well as for Murphy.

title: OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: The latest year's figures include results of an 84 percent stake in the Armendaris Corp. and a 100 percent stake in DJS Land and Cattle Corp., effective July 31, 1984 and Feb. 1, 1984, respectively.

U.S. NAVY LEASING THREE ISRAELI JETS
description: The Navy has officially accepted delivery of Israeli-built jet fighters for its mock dogfight training. This is the first step of several between the two governments that are aimed at sharing military innovations, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. said Monday.

title: One Killed and 13 Hurt By a Brussels Car Bomb
description: A car packed with explosives blew up shortly after midnight after being set afire near the central railroad station, killing a fireman and injuring 13 people, the police said.

Rewrite the Records In College Scandals

title: P.B.A. FAULTING WARD'S ACTIONS IN TORTURE CASE
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that the Police Commissioner and the news media had overreacted to the allegations of torture in a Queens station house.

title: PALSTIC POUCHES GAIN CACHET
description: ''THE technique of the plastic pouch has the potential for revolutionizing certain segments of the food service industry,'' said Dieter Hannig, director of the food research center of Hilton International.

title: State Nominates 2 For Space Flight
description: Two teachers were selected today as New York's candidates to become America's first teacher in space.

title: SOLDIERS, TANKS AND ROCK 'N' ROLL IN PARADE MARKING FALL OF SAIGON
description: The sun had just risen behind the twin-spired city cathedral today when high-stepping troops and rumbling Soviet tanks began their parade down the Street of April 30 to mark a decade of Communism in what was once known as the Republic of South Vietnam.

title: What Can Be Done About Willowbrook?
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: SHAKESPEARE THEATER 'SHREW'
description: The American Shakespeare Theater is celebrating its 30th anniversary with a return to public performances for the first time in three years, albeit on a limited scale. Zoe Caldwell's production of ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' designed for a student-audience season, is also being given a series of special Saturday evening performances. One could regard it as a sampling of what awaits theatergoers when Stratford is once again in full operation, presumably next season.

title: EASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Oxwell Tool Co. in October 1984 on a pooling-of-interests basis.

description: b-Net loss The company went public in October 1984.

description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

description: The latest figures include the results of Direct Marketing Agency Inc., which was acquired during the third quarter of 1984, and of Caribiner Inc., acquired during the first quarter of 1984. Both companies were accounted for as a purchase.

title: U.S. Plans Record Financing
description: The Treasury yesterday announced plans for a record note and bond financing next week, but the heavy supply was not enough to prevent a modest rise in prices of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds.

title: TRADE GAP EASED A BIT IN MARCH
description: The United States had an $11 billion trade deficit in March, even with a lighter-than-usual influx of oil and automobiles, the Commerce Department said today.

title: JAZZ SERVICE GROUP FORMED
description: WHEN orchestras want to share information, find documentation or plot how to get financing, they can turn to the American Symphony Orchestra League. Opera companies have Opera America; contemporary classical groups have the American Music Center. But another kind of serious American music, jazz, has had no such umbrella organization - until now.

title: S.E.C. STUDIES PICKENS ON DISCLOSURE TIMING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether an investor group headed by T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, violated Federal securities laws that govern insider trading, fraud and timely disclosure of takeover plans, Mesa said yesterday. The Pickens group, Mesa Partners II, is currently locked in a takeover battle with the Unocal Corporation for control of the California oil company.

title: KEANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOSTON GARDEN IS FOCUS OF DEVELOPMENT BATTLES
description: It is an unlovely old building, a squat Art Deco edifice misshapen inside and blighted outside by parking lots and railroad tracks.

title: Dry Fountains
description: Staving off a drought takes psychology as well as conservation. So the city has a simple answer for those who wonder whether they can use water in recirculating fountains, pools and waterfalls in the current drought emergency.

title: QUESTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time credit of $9,200,000, or 51 cents a share, from an accounting change.

description: b-After a tax credit of $1.4 million. The company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: ECONOMICS IS THE TOPIC IN BONN, BUT 'STAR WARS' IS THE ISSUE
description: The dominant political issue for Washington's allies at the Bonn economic meeting is the Reagan Administration's space weapons program. Considerable talk, but no endorsement of the plan, appears likely.

title: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,261,000, or 28 cents a share, from sale of stock in a unit.

title: PICNICS ON A BAG, NOTES IN A BASKET
description: 1.*Bagfuls of Summer The bags of summer are at Henri Bendel. These colorful shopping bags are sold in sets of three different sizes and are covered with acrylic paintings by Rush Brown.

title: BEACON PHOTO SERVICE INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
AN UNLIKELY TARGET OF VENOM
description: His actions have been likened to those of a thief or a rapist. In the political morality play on the disputed Indiana House race, he is depicted as the Democratic hatchet man who manipulated a House recount to steal an election.

title: MEDIPLEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid March 7, 1985.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Rome last Thursday on the naming of 28 new cardinals by Pope John Paul II misstated the ethnic origin of Bishop Jozef Tomko. He is a Slovak.

title: SENATE APPROVES BUDGET PROPOSAL
description: The Republican-controlled Senate narrowly approved the White House budget package today, giving a symbolic victory to President Reagan as he left for the economic summit meeting in Bonn.

title: RAYCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $1,200,000, or 12 cents a share, due to a change in U.S. tax laws. Latest quarter results include a charge of about $2,200,000, or 19 cents a share, for severance costs related to a reduction in employment.

title: ADAMS, RUNNING BACK, NO.1 FOR GIANTS
description: The Giants continued today to beef up their anemic running game. Seven weeks after they signed Maurice Carthon, the Generals' free-agent fullback, they chose George Adams of Kentucky on the first round of the National Football League draft.

title: Polo in the Park
description: Houston Street was never like this before, at least not in memory, but come late September, when most sports fans will be engrossed in the pennant races or harboring high hopes for the football season, Jonathan Burrows will be trying to lure about 5,000 people to, of all things, a polo match down in East River Park. Burrows, who plays regularly at the Meadow Brook Club in Jericho, L.I., believes that in addition to the novelty of polo on East Houston, New Yorkers will be intrigued by the opportunity of seeing a polo-playing maharajah.

title: BITBURG VISIT: IS 'RECONCILIATION' NEEDED? The President's Trip
description: In seeking ''reconciliation'' - between two nations that have been staunch allies for three decades - Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Reagan have rekindled the dark memories and images of Nazi Germany in the United States and stirred others that haunt an emotional debate in West Germany.

title: KERR-MCGEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,440,000 from the sale of securities. c-Includes a gain of $1,992,000 from the sale of securities. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid today.

title: F.D.I.C. CONSIDERS 2 BANK CONTROLS
description: The board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation voted yesterday to release for public comment two new means it is considering for controlling risk-taking by banks.

title: Intermountain Power Sets Refunding Bonds
description: The Intermountain Power Agency, a Utah-based agency, is offering $370 million of refunding revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The agency, which has already borrowed enough money to finish construction of two coal-fired power plants, will use proceeds to refund high-interest-rate bonds it sold in 1981.

title: 3 From Jersey Indicted On U.S. Gun Charges
description: Three New Jersey men were among four indicted today on Federal charges of conspiracy and possession of unregistered silencers.

title: SOUTH AFRICA DETAINS 30 BLACK LABOR ACTIVISTS
description: Riot policemen detained at least 30 black labor activists in central Johannesburg today during a peaceful demonstration called to protest layoffs.

title: DANCE: DONALD BYRD
description: DONALD BYRD burst into the consciousness of the New York dance public in 1983 with a wide-ranging and innovative program of pieces that suggested extraordinary promise. That promise was on the whole unfulfilled in a quasi-minstrel show the following year at La Mama, despite moments of brilliant staging and dance invention.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mrs. Reagan Planning Activities of Her Own
description: Nancy Reagan plans a number of activities of her own during the trip to Western Europe, some of them focused on her interest in the fight against drug abuse.

title: WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Marshall, Too, Spoke of Using Poison Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Armstrong Rubber Co. of New Haven has appointed Paul C. James president of its newly created Armstrong Tire Co.

title: Appeals Court Judge To Retire This Month
description: Judge Ellsworth A. Van Graafeiland will relinquish his position as an active judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on May 11 when he reaches the age of 70.

title: There Is Nothing Just in a System of Quotas
description: To the Editor:

title: THE THEATER: 'CALIFORNIA DOG FIGHT'
description: THEY'RE not kidding over at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: HEIR APPARENT AT BILLY'S ELBOW
description: In displaying his latest collection of Yankee managers like so many wax statues perched on revolving pedestals, George Steinbrenner has outdone himself. In a sense, the principal owner has had three managers lately - one leaving, one arriving, and another waiting in the wings. Yogi Berra has been dimissed. Billy Martin has been inaugurated for his fourth term. And at his elbow, Lou Piniella is now a trainee as a future Yankee manager - ''someday,'' to use George Steinbrenner's vague time frame.

title: Actor to Represent U.S.
description: President Reagan said today that he was sending the actor Fess Parker and his wife as United States representatives to the Australian commemoration of the 43d anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea. The naval battle, a turning point of World War II, is being commemorated in Australia by celebration of Australian-American Friendship Week May 3-10.

title: KOCH SEEKS APPROVAL TO FINGERPRINT ALL DAY-CARE WORKERS IN CITY
description: Mayor Koch today urged the State Legislature to pass a law enabling New York City to fingerprint employees of all day-care centers for children.

title: HEAD OF CAPEZIO FOUNDATION
description: >Ben Sommers, a manufacturer of ballet and theatrical shoes and founder of the Capezio Foundation, an organization devoted to supporting dance in the United States, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital following a heart attack. He was 78 years old.

title: LABARGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $657,791.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX OFF IN NEW SIGN OF A SLOWDOWN
description: The Government's main index for predicting changes in economic trends registered a small but unexpected decline in March of two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WYSE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WALBAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REVITALIZING NEW HAVEN'S LONG WHARF
description: Nearing completion in New Haven is the first structure in a $250 million office, retail and recreational development that is expected to change the face of the city's waterfront and revitalize its historic Long Wharf.

title: MYERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings and the shares outstanding were adjusted for a 2-for- 1 stock split distributed in May 1984.

title: Co-founder's Fight For Compuserve
description: Jeffrey M. Wilkins's daughter Lisa turned 16 on Monday, and the event had more than the usual flavor of independence. The same day Mr. Wilkins, the co-founder and former chairman of Compuserve Inc., offered to buy back the information retrieval company whose sale to H & R Block Inc. he had negotiated in 1980.

title: Municipal Bond Futures Contract
description: The Chicago Board of Trade announced that it expected to begin trading a municipal bond futures contract on June 11, pending approval by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission next month.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Transforming the South into a Socialist society will always be our first objective.'' - Mai Chi Tho, chairman of the Ho Chi Minh City Peoples Committee. [A6:2.]

title: Advertising;   Placing Service Messages
description: A NEW YORK-BASED organization looking to get free broadcast time for a public service message in other parts of the country may well be surprised at the warm welcome.

title: MCDONALD & CO INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: The company said the earnings for the 1984 year are pro forma.

title: Jersey Legislator Indicted in Bribery
description: Assemblyman Angelo J. Fortunato, Democrat of Glen Ridge, has been indicted on charges of soliciting and receiving bribes to obtain jobs for people with the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, state officials said today.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Chamber Music Society At Alice Tully Hall
description: Sunday afternoon's Chamber Music Society concert at Alice Tully Hall was an amiable mixing of good humor and seriousness. The latter came in Mendelssohn's D-minor Trio, certainly one of the most powerful and intensely lyrical pieces in the medium.

title: DATA-DESIGN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bonneville Rate Reduction
description: The Bonneville Power Administration said today that new electricity rates would cut charges for aluminum producers, which had threatened to close Northwest smelters because of high costs.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated for the consolidation of Travelers Express Co. which was previously included in the unconsolidated financial group.

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THE FRUGAL GOURMET EMPHASIZES THE ETHNIC FOR HIS FEASTS
description: ''FRUGAL,'' by Jeff Smith's definition, does not simply mean cheap. ''It means that you use everything and are careful with your time as well as your food products,'' says Mr. Smith, a Methodist minister who, as Public Television's Frugal Gourmet and author of the best-selling book of the same name, now practices what for years he preached.

title: $92 Million Tax Cut Gains in Hartford
description: The State Senate today unanimously approved an array of tax cuts totaling $92.8 million.

title: Gamblers' Changes
description: The Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League will soon have a new majority owner who will buy a 60 percent interest and keep the team in Houston. The team president, Jerry Argovitz, announced yesterday that the Gamblers have tentatively been sold to a group that he declined to identify.

title: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEAD OF STATE DEPT. BUREAU FOR LATIN AREA STEPS DOWN
description: The head of the State Department's Latin American bureau, Langhorne A. Motley, resigned today to return to private life.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Finale of the two- game series. Ron Darling goes against Bob Knepper.

title: A Shorts Story
description: Summer arrived yesterday at 59 West 44th Street.

title: Tank Contract Is $555.6 Million
description: The General Dynamics Corporation's Land Systems division won a $555.6 million Army contract for production of 1,680 M-1 tanks, the Defense Department said. It said half of the production work would be performed in Lima, Ohio; 40 percent in Warren, Mich.; and 10 percent in Eynon, Pa.

title: The Money Race
description: The May issue of Runner's World has a cover story, written by Dick Pietschmann, the magazine's special assignments editor, and his wife, Patti, that is entitled, ''They're in the Money: The 20 Highest-Paid Runners of 1984.'' The ranking, which does not take travel money into account but which includes virtually everything else, was arrived at, the authors say, by ''talking with scores of sources, including current and former runners, agents, managers, shoe and clothing company employees, meet promoters and representatives, and others close to the sport and the numbers.''

title: BINDLEY WESTERN INDUSTRY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid yesterday.

title: Amoco Keeps D'Arcy
description: Sam Van Sickle, senior vice president, marketing, of the Amoco Oil Company, has reported, when asked, that the review of the company's advertising setup is completed and the decision is to stay witht the incumbent, D'Arcy MacManus Masius. Amoco is supposed to spend $25 million for advertising.

title: People
description: * Lee B. Templeton has been appointed executive vice president and chief operating officer at Historical Times.

title: DESIGNED METHODS OF AERIAL MAPPING
description: Virgil Kauffman, a leader in aerial mapping, died Monday at his home in Yardley, Pa. He was 89 years old.

title: Bids
description: No collection of Watergate memorabilia would be really complete without a painting of former President Richard M. Nixon and six of his Administration leaders and White House aides that will be auctioned at Sotheby's in New York today.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Brooklyn Philharmonic In 'Moderns' Series
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic can usually be relied upon to come up with something unusual, and Friday night's program at Cooper Union did not disappoint.

title: BLAME FALLING ON REAGAN STAFF FOR CEMETERY FUROR
description: As President Reagan embarked for Europe today, Democratic and Republican political professionals faulted his staff as contributing to the domestic political tempest and legislative difficulties that have cast a shadow over his 10-day trip.

title: YANKEES LOSE 5TH STRAIGHT
description: This was the second day of the fourth term of Billy Martin as Yankee manager, and there was nothing quiet about it.

title: CONQUEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUILDING BOOM IN LOS ANGELES
description: One of the outdated notions about this city is that it has no real downtown. That misreading was only partially erased by shots of newly erected steel and glass towers during television coverage of the Olympic Games last summer.

title: A CLUB FOR THE DISABLED RUNNER
description: LINDA DOWN ran the London Marathon last week and set a personal record - 8 hours and 17 minutes. Miss Down, who was born with cerebral palsy, runs with crutches and determination. Pat Griskus, an amputee, recently finished the Brooklyn Half-Marathon in 1:39:59, and is training for his 11th triathlon. Both belong to a special group of runners in New York, the Achilles Track Club.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 1, 1985

title: VIDEO ALTERS ECONOMICS OF MOVIE ANIMATION
description: Like Cinderella in the 1950 Disney movie, animated feature films have long been stepchildren, at least to the movie industry.

title: Visitors
description: The delegation's itinerary is fairly typical for Washington visitors with good connections. This morning leading members will testify at a Senate hearing, then the entire group will pose with Vice President Bush for a photograph in his downtown office.

title: STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FLAKEY JAKE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
B Comes Before A
description: Concerned that his outmatched George Washington High School players were being used as fodder for the big guns of the Public School Athletic League's A league, Jim Walsh, the George Washington coach, whose team had not won an A league game in two years, took his team off the field before the kickoff of a game last September.

title: Nuclear Industry Accountability
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERFACE FLOORING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Poland's Fading Amnesty
description: The Polish Academy of Sciences has fired Prof. Bronislaw Geremek, a historian and medievalist. His offense, after 30 years of service, apparently was to accept an invitation to meet with the visiting British Foreign Secretary earlier this month.

title: SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SFM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Even cartoons can convey culinary wisdom, and perhaps profundity, as was the case in a cartoon by the late Ludwig Bemelmans. But I can't recall the observation that accompanied the cartoon. Can you? A.

title: Dividends
description: The White House reports that the First Ladies Conference on Drug Abuse, held in Washington and in Atlanta last week by Nancy Reagan and the wives of 17 other heads of state, has already begun to pay dividends in international activity.

title: PALEY SEES A 'TRAGEDY' IN A HOSTILE SHIFT AT CBS
description: Against a backdrop of vintage radio microphones and 57 years' worth of broadcasting artifacts, awards and memorabilia, William S. Paley, the 83-year-old founder and former chairman of CBS Inc., said yesterday that it would be a ''tragedy'' if either the management or the structure of the company were to be changed as a result of a hostile takeover bid.

title: N.F.L. DRAFT MARKED BY SURPRISES
description: The capricious nature of the National Football League draft was seldom more evident than it was yesterday, when three trades were made and a fourth was completed before the end of the 3-hour-36-minute first round.

title: STERLING CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Assets represent net assets

title: 'CHAMPION,' STORY OF RAY MANCINI
description: ''HEART OF A CHAMPION: THE RAY MANCINI STORY'' isn't as good as it should be, and that's a pity. In theory, it has everything going for it: hopes blighted, hopes redeemed, sentiment and sports. We should care when Ray Mancini wins the lightweight championship, but on television it's just another fight. Hollywood once did this kind of thing better. The ''CBS Wednesday Night Movie'' will be seen on Channel 2 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: MURPHY OF BRAVES TIES R.B.I. RECORD
description: Dale Murphy tied the National League record for runs batted in during April in leading the Atlanta Braves over the Cincinnati Reds, 8-4, tonight.

title: THE RISINGS TIDE
description: There was a heavy onset of Daylight Savings Time over the weekend. On Saturday anchorfolks on Channels 2 and 4 both warned New York that Daylight Savings Time was imminent.

title: STATE'S TOP COURT REJECTS TRUMP TAX APPEAL
description: A challenge to the state tax on real-estate transactions of $1 million or more was rejected today by the state's highest court.

title: Article 205963 -- No Title
description: A weeklong campaign has raised $6 million for public radio stations, the National Public Radio network announced Monday. It said more than 100,000 listeners called in pledges to 207 participating noncommercial stations.

title: Grumman Net Rises 7.5%
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that its net income rose 7.5 percent in the first quarter, but it warned that its full year earnings would fall short of analysts' expectations.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $24,245,000 for the latest quarter and $3,082,000 for year-earlier period.

title: HAWKS ELIMINATE STARS IN 6
description: Darryl Sutter's second goal of the game, with 4 minutes 19 seconds remaining in overtime, gave the Black Hawks a 6-5 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight. Chicago won the Norris Division final in six games and will play the Edmonton Oilers in the Campbell Conference finals.

title: City Investing Shares Sold
description: A 3,137,000-share block of City Investing Company stock changed hands yesterday at $37.50 a share, or $117.6 million, amid Wall Street speculation that the seller was Victor Posner, the Miami businessman.

title: Travelers Reports Gain
description: The Travelers Insurance Corporation said yesterday that operating income in the first quarter rose 6.9 percent, to $73.1 million, or 86 cents a share, from $68.4 million, or 82 cents a share. Net income rose 17 percent, to $89.5 million, or $1.05 a share, from $76.5 million, or 91 cents a share, a year earlier. Travelers, based in Hartford and one of the nation's largest publicly held insurance companies, said that revenues rose 18.8 percent, to $3.8 billion, from $3.2 billion.

title: ARMY TERMS PERSHING 2 MISSILES VULNERABLE TO TERROR IN GERMANY
description: The Army has warned Congress that Pershing 2 nuclear missiles in West Germany are ''extremely vulnerable'' to terrorist attacks and need to be fortified.

title: STEPSON TESTIFIES ABOUT VON BULOW
description: Martha von Bulow's son testified today that twice within hours of his mother's being rushed to a hospital in a coma his stepfather, Claus von Bulow, complained to him about the difficulty of being married to a rich, demanding woman.

title: HOUSE PANELS ACT ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: A bill that would bar investment and trade with South Africa cleared its first hurdle in the House today.

title: NOBLE AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LEADER OF CONSERVATIVE RABBIS ADDRESSES ORTHODOX COUNCIL
description: For the first time in 50 years, a Conservative rabbi today delivered a major address before an association of Orthodox rabbis.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Court Clears U.P.I. Payrolls
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Washington eased the way yesterday for United Press International to pay its 1,298 employees.

title: G.M. to Replace A Plant in Kansas
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would build a new automobile assembly plant in Kansas City, Kan., to produce cars for the 1988 model year.

title: CANADIENS WIN, 5-2, FORCING 7TH GAME
description: Lacking in panache and intensity, the battle of Quebec was evened at three victories apiece tonight as the Montreal Canadiens pinned a 5-2 loss on the Quebec Nordiques.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL TORONTO (AL) - Willie Aikens, designated hitter, was listed for assignment to make room for Jim Clancy, pitcher, who came off the 20-day medical rehabilitation list.

title: Eaton Has Surgery
description: Mark Eaton came through knee surgery ''very well,'' according to a spokesman for the Utah Jazz, who said the 7-foot-4-inch center was expected to be fully recovered by next season. That, however, was little immediate consolation for Coach Frank Layden, who lamented the loss of his dominant defensive player just as the Jazz was gaining the second round of the National Basketball Association's playoffs by defeating the Houston Rockets on Sunday.

title: New Paper on Campus
description: A campus newspaper driven out of business at Columbia University 100 years ago is back to challenge the publication that sent it under.

title: G.E. SCIENTISTS FIND BACTERIA CONVERT PCB'S
description: A team of General Electric scientists on Monday reported that some of the PCB's on the bottom of the Hudson River had been changed by natural bacterial action into less-dangerous forms.

title: IACOCCAS RAISE CUDGEL AGAINST DIABETES
description: Kathryn Iacocca is preparing to do philanthropic battle against a disease that devastated her family's life. In May 1983 her mother, Mary, died at the age of 53 of complications caused by diabetes. ''The only people who really know and recognize the severity of diabetes are those whose lives have been touched by it,'' Miss Iacocca says. ''My father spent more than 20 years with my mom, fighting it; we lived with it from day to day.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages last Wednesday misstated the number of Karyn Tarter's competitors in the New York State weight-lifting championships. There were three, all men, and she defeated two of them.

title: BIRD SCORES 42 AS CELTICS TAKE 2-0 LEAD
description: There was blood on Larry Bird's white Celtic jersey from a blow to the chin he had taken from Bill Laimbeer in the third quarter, and he wore a pad to protect his sore right elbow. But neither the injuries nor the Detroit Pistons could prevent Bird from leading Boston to a 121-114 victory before an appreciative crowd of 14,890 at the Boston Garden.

title: TNP ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOODEN'S 4-HITTER TURNS BACK ASTROS
description: For six innings last night, Dwight Gooden was outpitched by a man twice his age and with half his speed. But the Mets had something in reserve, namely, Clint Hurdle and Danny Heep, and they finally got to Joe Niekro in the seventh and went on to defeat the Houston Astros, 4-1, at Shea Stadium.

title: Extradition Is Blocked For a Suspected Nazi
description: An order allowing Israel to extradite a man accused of having been a Nazi death camp guard was stayed indefinitely today by a Federal judge.

title: Ralston to Sell Fast-Food Unit
description: The Ralston Purina Company agreed yesterday to sell its Jack in the Box fast-food restaurant chain to a group that includes the chain's management. Terms were not disclosed, but analysts estimated that the price was between $450 million and $500 million.

title: TOBACCO ISSUES HIT
description: Stock prices fell for the third consecutive session as investors adamantly refused to fatten portfolios until the economic outlook brightens.

title: SENATE PANEL REJECTS BAN ON CHANNEL SWAPS
description: The Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation today narrowly rejected an amendment to its reauthorization bill for the Federal Communications Commission that would have prohibited public televison stations from swapping channels with commercial stations.

title: Sir Max Aitken Dies; Newspaper Publisher
description: Sir Max Aitken, president of Britain's tabloid Express newspapers and a fighter pilot during World War II, died in London today. He was 75.

title: FOR ONE-DISH MEALS
description: FOR today's style of home cooking, especially among dual-career couples with limited time and those with precious little kitchen space, oven-to-table cookware makes great sense. Delicious one-dish meals can be prepared quickly and easily, and because they are served directly from the cooking utensil, cleanup time is minimal.

title: FOR PERES, PULLOUT HAS MORAL VALUE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that his Government's decision to withdraw its troops from Lebanon three years after the invasion meant a return to Israel's ''values as a nation.''

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Sales for the latest year and quarter exclude sales of Trak Auto West.

title: HEALTH-MOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CIGARS
description: The larger-than-life statue of Sir Winston Churchill in front of the British Embassy depicts the wartime Prime Minister with his right hand raised in the famous V-for-victory gesture and his left at his side, holding both a walking stick and a partly smoked cigar. When the nine-foot bronze statue was unveiled in 1966, the sculptor, William McVey, provided five extra bronze cigars in the event a souvenir-hunter might make off with the original.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PDA ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $75,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,000 for the quarter and $29,000 for the nine months.

title: SOUTHLAND TUMBLES 93%
description: The Chevron Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, and the Southland Corporation, parent of Citgo Petroleum, yesterday reported quarterly earnings that reflected the oil industry's recent volatility.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MARY MCCARTHY, '33, SENDS PAPERS TO VASSAR
description: Folder after folder. Crammed in cardboard box atop cardboard box. Stashed row upon row. On shelf after shelf in the basement of the Vassar College Library.

title: RUSS BERRIE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Blue Jays Drop Aikens
description: Willie Aikens, the Toronto Blue Jays' designated hitter, was designated for assignment to make room for the pitcher Jim Clancy, who came off the 20-day medical rehabilitation list.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'FALSTAFF' BY CHICAGO SYMPHONY
description: A PERFECTLY cast and perfectly performed ''Falstaff'' can easily exist in the theater of the mind, but in what prosaic persons insist on calling the real world, Verdi's final opera can never completely satisfy. That said, I must add that Monday night's performance of this magical work by Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall came as close to perfection as may be expected in an imperfect world. Conductor, orchestra, solo singers and chorus had been molded into the kind of tightly meshing ensemble that one dreams of hearing in ''Falstaff'' and seldom experiences in the opera house.

title: Riddling Wine
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CROWN BOOKS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JEWISH UNITS PLAN CEMETERY PROTEST
description: Jewish organizations in several countries called today for protest demonstrations Sunday at the cemetery for German war dead that President Reagan plans to visit.

title: Warsaw Issues Warning To Polish Dissidents
description: The Polish Government said today that those ''who work against the interests of the state'' could lose their jobs in the same manner as a Solidarity adviser who was dismissed last week from his position at the Polish Academy of Science.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $33,000 for the latest quarter and $761,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: A COMMANDER IS SAID TO DESERT NICARAGUA REBELS
description: A commander of the rebels seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government has deserted his forces and flown to Mexico in hopes of returning to Nicaragua, according to Mexican, Honduran and rebel officials.

title: ONLY THE SOUND OF RAIN AT HITLER'S BUNKER
description: It was 40 years ago today, according to most reliable reports, that Hitler committed suicide in his Berlin bunker in the waning days of the Third Reich.

title: Kansas City Schools Offered More Desegregation Money
description: The State of Missouri will budget $40.6 million, more than four times what was previously proposed, for desegregating the Kansas City schools, according to a plan filed Monday in Federal District Court.

title: U.S. SOLICITOR GENERAL IS QUITING TO JOIN TOP LAW FIRM AND TEACH
description: Rex E. Lee, who as Solicitor General has represented the Federal Government before the Supreme Court for the last four years, announced today that he would resign June 1 to teach and practice law.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results include a charge of $11,140,000 to reflect a refund of revenue that had been collected subject to refund.

title: Required Reading;   'A Fratricidal Attack'
description: Excerpt from ''Servants of the People: The Uncertain Future of the Federal Civil Service,'' a new book by Howard Rosen, published by Olympus Publishing Company of Salt Lake City:

title: ELLIOTT ABRAMS: 'TOUGH' GUY FOR LATIN JOB
description: Elliott Abrams has said that his view of the world is based on one premise. The world is, he once said, ''an exceedingly dangerous place.''

title: Dissenting Voice In Hockey Wars
description: The Islanders' loss in Philadelphia the other night marked the earliest end of the professional hockey campaign in New York since April 24, 1973, when the Rangers bowed out of the playoffs after two rounds, beaten by Chicago. Still, it's a long season. The Islanders, for instance, opened up last Oct. 12, and in the ensuing 6 1/2 months played 90 games, endured 287 periods (including overtimes), skated 5,474 minutes, scored 370 goals, yielded 340 goals, engaged in 90 fights, served 1,753 minutes in the penalty box and were so frequently injured that they lost 295 man-games. There are no statistics available on how much surgical tape was needed, but you get the idea.

title: HOUSE REFUSES TO ORDER SPECIAL INDIANA ELECTION
description: After an angry and partisan debate, the House of Representatives today voted 229 to 200 to reject a Republican proposal for a special election to decide the hotly disputed House race in Indiana's eighth district.

title: 2 Stabbed in Indian Riots
description: Two men were stabbed today and one man died of injuries received in riots in the Indian state of Gujarat over a policy reserving jobs and college places for lower castes. The radio said that the two men were stabbed in Baroda and the man injured in riots on Saturday died in Surat.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,555,000. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $1,814,000.

title: Mickey Katz Is Dead; Star of Yiddish Revues
description: The entertainer Mickey Katz, who concocted the ''Borscht Capades'' revues and made Yiddish-American comedy records, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: DEATH DROPS 27% WITH STATE'S SEAT-BELT LAW
description: The number of drivers and passengers killed in motor-vehicle accidents in New York State declined by 27 percent in the first three months after the state required the wearing of seat belts, the Motor Vehicles Commissioner announced yesterday.

title: LATINS PREFER THE VIETNAM SYNDROME
description: On the 10th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, Americans are pondering the lessons of the United States' tragic involvement in Indochina. It is vital that they do so, particularly given the ominous parallels between the war in Southeast Asia and what is happening today in Central America.

title: KISSINGER IS SUPPORTIVE OF VISIT TO CEMETERY
description: Henry A. Kissinger said today that even though 30 members of his family died in Nazi concentration camps, he is convinced that ''nothing would be served'' by President Reagan's canceling his visit to the West German military cemetery at Bitburg where 49 SS troops are buried.

title: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FIDELITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MISSING CHILDREN AND THE BUSIEST PHONES IN TOWN
description: And the calls poured in. Calls of anguish. Calls of curiosity. Calls of the convinced.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN'S SPACE SUMMIT
description: President Reagan has had a couple of bad weeks on the German cemetery circuit, but for once his European policies have been better than his public relations, and he may get out of the summit meeting in Bonn with the other leaders of the industrial world better than he got in.

title: IN 'TINNED LETTUCE,' A NEW BODY OF GOREY TALES
description: The Throbblefoot Spectre loiters in a distraught manner, a wedding is held in the Church of the Whited Sepulchre and people fall mysteriously from balustrades or fling themselves into Yawning Chasms. This is Edward Gorey land, a crepuscular country near the town of Lesser Evil where everything seems to be taking place in a fen at twilight.

title: SAHARA RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Too Late for Toxic Justice?
description: New York is one of a few states in which people can discover they have been poisoned by a toxic substance and then learn that it's too late to sue for redress. The villain is the outmoded application of New York's statute of limitations. It's surely time for the Legislature to fashion a fairer law.

title: AT 100, THE BOSTON STILL PACKS THEM IN
description: It was a Boston sort of occasion tonight, practical and proud. For $500, a person could come have free drinks, dinner, two hours of music from 101 classical musicians - and not have to wear a black tie. Or, that same person could pay $50, do the same thing with hors d'oeuvres for dinner and still not have to wear black tie.

title: Computers Displayed By Compaq
description: Two companies taking on the International Business Machines Corporation in the office market - the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Xerox Corporation - introduced computer systems yesterday.

title: HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $9,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income which includes a gain of $630,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FISKADORO. By Denis Johnson. 221 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the year-ago quarter include a gain of $9,200,000 from nonrecurring items and tax credits.

title: UNITED STATES STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Allegheny Head Selling Unit Grandfather Built
description: The Lapides family of Baltimore has been in the soft drink bottling business for more than 60 years. But Morton M. Lapides, chairman and president of the Allegheny Beverage Corporation, has had enough, and is giving up that part of his past.

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $14,709,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Ms. Is 13
description: Ms. magazine has turned 13 years old, and a group of supporters gathered the other night to wish it well.

title: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share figures reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in March 1985.

title: Why We Need Genocide Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: S.&P. Reviews Arco Ratings
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation has placed the Atlantic Richfield Company's debt rating under review for possible downgrading.

title: Albert Minns, 65, Dies; A Harlem Jazz Dancer
description: Albert David Minns, a jazz dancer, died of cancer Wednesday at Queens Hospital Center. He was 65 years old.

title: ALPHA-PORTLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $165,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $265,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Korea Wary of U.S. on Trade
description: Some businessmen here have an unpleasant vision. They picture the United States as a boxer taking a trade-protectionist punch at Japan. Only Japan is adroit, and the blow proves to be a glancing one that catches adjacent South Korea on the chin instead.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON BUDGET CUTS
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted a Republican leadership package of $52 billion in spending cuts as the vehicle for floor debate on the budget for the fiscal year 1986.

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Canada Rhino Party Thunders Off Softly
description: Loyal followers of the Rhinoceros Party, deciding their satirical movement should not outlive its founder, put more than two decades of zany political theater to rest today in not-very-solemn ceremonies.

title: 2 SIDES OF ROAD, 2 SETS OF WATER RULES
description: When it comes to the increasingly scarce commodity of water, Mountain Avenue in this Essex County community is the dividing line between the haves and the have-nots.

title: Sudanese Rebels Reject New Military Rule
description: Sudanese rebels fighting for autonomy in the southern Sudan have renewed their denunciations of the new Government, calling the civilian Prime Minister ''a figurehead'' and vowing not to negotiate a truce with the country's military Government.

title: The Task at the Summit
description: Bitburg aside, President Reagan carries a difficult brief to West Germany this week. The annual summit meeting of seven democratic leaders needs to find a way to coordinate economic strategies to head off a protectionist clamor that threatens them all.

title: PHOENIX STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: PRICES OF FARM PRODUCTS DECLINED 1.5% IN APRIL
description: The prices farmers receive for raw products dropped 1.5 percent in April, averaging 9.6 percent below the record high set a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: CROWN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kidnapped Jersey Girl Reunited With Sisters
description: An orphaned New Jersey teen-ager was reunited today with her sisters after being abducted two years ago. She said she was not physically abused, but did not seek help because her captor constantly watched her.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: HBM/Creamer Wins Two New Clients
description: HBM/Creamer is celebrating two new clients. One big (Nestle). And one not so big (Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company).

title: Hearst Corp. Prepares Nationwide Campaign
description: Because it feels that many people that are important to it are unaware of its growth, the 98-year-old Hearst Corporation is prepared to mount its first national corporate campaign in print May 6.

title: PALM BEACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Man Convicted of Rape To Be Set Free on Bond
description: The Illinois Supreme Court set $100,000 bond today for Gary Dotson while the justices consider an appeal of his 1979 conviction for a rape his accuser now says never occurred, and Mr. Dotson is to be released Wednesday, his attorney, Warren Lupel, said.

title: JETS' FIRST PICK IS TOON, WIDE RECEIVER
description: The Jets, who suffered last season with injuries and inconsistency on defense, found in the college draft yesterday a big, healthy player who could hit. They made him their first choice. But he is a wide receiver, not a defensive lineman.

title: NATIONAL BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $305,000 for the quarter and $455,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $96,000 for the quarter and $176,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $108,000 and $165,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The results are expressed in Canadian dollars.

title: REMEMBERING VIETNAM IN REGRET AND GRATITUDE
description: Ten years ago today, Washington was a shaken city absorbing the nightmarish spectacle of the fall of Saigon and the failure of two decades of American military involvement in Vietnam. The scale and finality of the debacle gave pause that day at news conferences and expense-account restaurants all about the capital.

title: MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes net of $647,000, or 33 cents a share from the sale of property.

title: TYLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $107,000.

title: ROCK: ERIC CLAPTON PLAYS IN JERESY
description: ERIC CLAPTON let his hair down and played some rock-and-roll at Brendan Byrne Arena in the New Jersey Meadowlands on Thursday.

title: Witness Found In Mengel Killing
description: A Westchester County salesman said today that he was driving on a state highway moments before Alex Mengel was killed by the police and that he saw a fight inside the car before the shooting.

title: Argentina to Pay $50 Million Interest
description: The Argentine Government said today that it would make a $50 million payment on overdue interest on its debt.

title: KOCH MUTING REMARKS ON THE TRIP TO BITBURG
description: For weeks, ever since President Reagan announced that he would visit a military cemetery in West Germany, Mayor Koch - well known for his blunt attacks on those who displease him - has been temperate, even muted, in his remarks about the President.

title: Last to Finish Is Often Easiest to Select
description: There are two drinking glasses for sale in Louisville this week, each listing 110 horses and a blank to be filled in next to 1985. One is the official souvenir julep glass, a $3, 10-ounce highball glass etched in eight colors and listing the previous 110 winners of the Kentucky Derby. The other is an unofficial fat 16-ounce plastic beer mug, stamped with the names of the 110 who have finished last.

title: CHRISTIAN TOWN IN LEBANON IS BESIEGED
description: Moslem militiamen continued to make sweeping advances against Christian areas in southern Lebanon today, attacking a Christian stronghold in the hills east of Sidon.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS F-20 COMPETITION
description: A House subcommittee voted in a closed session today to require that the Air Force allow the F-20 Tigershark fighter plane to compete for a place in the service's fighter forces next year.

title: A PRIMER AS ECONOMIC DIPLOMACY COMES INTO SEASON
description: It is high season for economic diplomacy. The envoys of trade, currency and world finance have been shuttling from conference to conference, from Paris to Brussels to Venice to Tokyo to Washington, crocheting their communiques and their bland agreements-to-agree, only to do it all over again at the next station.

title: Silent Islanders
description: The Islanders' season is over, but there has been no farewell meeting, and some of the younger players who do not have homes in the area have already gone back to Canada. The senior players have not even gone to the Nassau Colliseum to retrieve equipment.

Conrail Sale Vote

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: OVERHEARD at Bloomingdale's by Joan Wyckoff of East Hampton, L.I., at closing time on a recent Sunday. A trendily dressed male shopper to his two female companions: ''Do you want to go for a Carvel or something more designer?''

title: Off and Not Running
description: While most local political contests seem to get more crowded by the hour, the race for City Hall lost a potential candidate yesterday.

At Home With Iona
description: Pat Kennedy, the Iona basketball coach, is a close friend of George Washington University's athletic director, Steve Bilsky, so when Bilsky began looking for a new basketball coach recently it was only natural that he would mention his search to Kennedy. From that one casual conversation, Kennedy sugested yesterday, came a full-blown rumor that Kennedy was being considered for the George Washington job.

title: INDIANAPOLIS PLANS TO FIGHT FOR ITS QUOTA SYSTEM
description: Five years ago Darryl Pierce was a technician at an electric power plant. Then, even though it meant a pay cut, he joined the Indianapolis Police Department under the city's affirmative action hiring program.

title: KEY WITNESS IN SPY TRIAL DENIES THAT HE HAD AN AFFAIR WITH EMIGRE
description: A retired agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation denied today that he had a sexual affair with a woman being tried as a Soviet spy.

title: CALVIN KLEIN KEEPS IT SMART AND SIMPLE
description: SPORTSWEAR without frills was served up by Calvin Klein yesterday and everybody cheered. The collection was one of the high spots of the current round of fall showings.

description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc. said that its shareholders had rejected an attempt by a dissident to elect his slate of nominees to its board.

title: CONCERT: 'ALLESSANDRO,' BY HANDEL
description: IT would have been difficult to walk out of Carnegie Hall late Sunday night without some understanding of Handel's success in the theater. His ''Alessandro'' - all four hours of it - had just been given. There were no costumes in this concert version, no sets, no extravagant scenery or machines, only minimal lighting effects. Yet Handel has created here an episode of feminine rivalry that operated powerfully at three different levels and reached with grace and immediacy across two and a half centuries.

title: GENERAL AMERICAN INVESORS CO reports earnings for As of March 31

description: The Philadelphia 76ers, who floundered through the regular season because of injuries, are healthy again and charging through the playoffs.

title: WINE TALK
description: Lloyd Flatt is a wealthy businessman whose hobby is collecting and enjoying fine wine. So dedicated a wine buff is he that when he built a new house in the French Quarter here several years ago, he kept his older house, three blocks away, just to hold his wine. From time to time, Mr. Flatt puts on a special tasting. Last weekend was one of those times. Months ago, he began to assemble 37 vintages of Chateau Petrus, the premier wine chateau in the Pomerol district of Bordeaux, then invited 13 wine professionals and dedicated amateurs to join him in sampling them.

Still, many are concerned about the nutrient losses and health hazards that might result from treating foods so that they don't spoil before reaching a table 5,000 miles or 10 months from where or when the food was produced or packaged.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER DOMINICAN WAR, WOUNDS LINGER

Within a short time, more than 22,000 United States troops would be involved in a civil war that came to be known as ''the Dominican crisis.''

title: NORTHBOUND PARK AVE. SHUT AT GRAND CENTRAL FOR REPAIRS
description: The northbound lanes of the Park Avenue tunnel and viaduct from 33d to 46th Street were closed yesterday as the second phase of a $5.8 million rehabilitation of the viaduct around Grand Central Terminal began.

title: Bridge: Wandering and Wondering: Each Can Result in Penalty
description: In tournament play there is a penalty, largely theoretical, for ''wandering.'' A player who wanders around the room between deals might, again in theory, see or hear something at another table concerning a deal he has yet to play.

description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported a first-quarter profit of $58 million, well below the comparable period a year ago. But the company apparently outdid most of its steel industry competitors, which have been reporting widened first-quarter losses.

title: 22 Oklahoma Counties Pass Bar Sales of Liquor
description: Proposals to legalize the sale of liquor by the drink in bars were approved in 22 counties of Oklahoma today, including those containing the state's four largest cities.

description: The Social Security Administration plans to resume reviewing the cases of people receiving disability benefits in mid-July, but it will take up to five years to get through the backlog of cases, the head of the system said today.

The first could be called a small gem, the second an indestructible classic. Cliches have their uses.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FOR the most part, this column is written with an eye to the cost of food. Once in a while, however, a comparatively expensive item such as medallions of lamb deserves mention.

Sale Seen Near For Us Magazine
description: A partnership of Rolling Stone magazine and the Telepictures Corporation is close to completing a deal to buy Us magazine, Jann Wenner, Rolling Stone's editor and publisher, said yesterday. Us is owned by McFadden Holdings Inc. and the Warner Publishing division of Warner Communications Inc. Mr. Wenner, who declined to disclose the price being discussed, said plans are for Rolling Stone and Telepictures to form a separate company to operate Us.

title: Irish Premier Makes Surprise Visit to Ulster
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland paid an unexpected visit to the British-ruled Londonderry today, a city which has a Roman Catholic majority. This was the first time an Irish leader has visited the city in 20 years.

title: R J FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Topics;   On the Record
description: Truth, Black and White The old line that newspapers are black and white and read all over applied literally to The Rand Daily Mail, for 83 years the voice of truth and conscience in South Africa. Until its final edition Tuesday, it provided a multiracial readership with news the Government wished it wouldn't print.

title: HERS
description: YEARS ago I read - in a history of Japanese literature - about a haiku master who advised his disciples as follows: As soon as you finish a poem, go outside and show it to the first old woman you find sitting by your doorstep. Only if she likes and understands it can you begin to assume that your new poem might be worth saving.

Aerosol paints come in a great range of colors and finishes including heat-resistant types.

title: U.S. Personnel Chief Resigns, But Hopes to Regain His Job
description: Donald J. Devine, director of the Office of Personnel Management resigned today to avoid an ''awkward situation'' created when Congress failed to reconfirm him after the expiration of his first term and his former deputy became acting director of the office.

title: Pan Am Hub at Dulles
description: Dulles International Airport will become a major hub for Pan American World Airways next month, a move that is expected to double the use of the airport, officials said today. Beginning June 1, Pan Am will provide flights to 29 international destinations in Europe, the Mediterranean, the Middle East and South America. Daily nonstop service will also leave Dulles for several points in Florida and New York.

description: The General Motors Corporation today offered 8.8 percent financing for six car models, including the Buick Somerset and Oldsmobile Calais, two new models whose sales have not been as high as G.M. had hoped.

The Administration is protecting the President's authority and capacity to act forcefully - even if that means waging war with bananas.

Revenues for the first quarters of 1985 and 1984 include $303,600,000 and $240,800,000, respectively, in revenue of non-consolidated financial services subsidiaries which are accounted for using the equity method. The company said net income for the year-ago quarter was restated in the second quarter of 1984 to reflect changes in Federal income tax regulations applicable to life insurance companies retroactive to Jan. 1, 1984. title: WHAT TRANSCENDS BITBURG

It has taken 40 years to do it, but our leaders finally have managed to set majorities of their countries against each other. Or so it seems. Fortunately, the underlying reality is different, as we can see if we turn from the controversial visit and look at what people in both countries really care about.

description: The formation of an American Jewish organization to offer development aid to suffering non-Jews in Africa, Asia and Central America was announced at a news conference in Manhattan yesterday.

title: CONCERT: SPECTRA ARTS OFFERS OPERA
description: ''ECHOES OF THE SHINING PRINCE,'' a one-act concert opera by Seth Cooper performed at Merkin Concert Hall last Thursday night, is one of those reachings from West toward East that attempt to make different musical languages speak through a single voice. Mr. Cooper played the flute and conducted eight other musicians, including Fusako Yoshida at the koto. The setting by Elizabeth Aldrich from ''The Tale of Genji'' has two singing parts, and they were taken by Miss Yoshida and a soprano, Donna Wade.

FORMER RED GUARDS END A WEEKLONG PEKING SIT-IN
description: A public protest, the first such extended demonstration of dissent for several years, has ended here, with the demonstrators being sent back to Shanxi Province, west of Peking, instead of being allowed to return to their former homes in the Chinese capital.

title: ETHIOPIAN FAMINE VICTIMS FORCED OUT, AIDES SAY ADDIS ABABA
description: The Ethiopian authorities forced about 56,000 famine victims to leave an emergency feeding center in a three-day operation this week, international relief agency officials said today.

title: FROM DE LA RENTA, TAILORED DRAPING
description: THE mood, established with the colorful coats and trousers that opened the collection, was what is often referred to in fashion circles as couture. Oscar de la Renta tucked his mannequins' hair under hoods or turbans and had them wear high-heeled shiny leather pumps to achieve the slickly groomed look that is associated with haute couture clothes in Paris. The styles themselves were meticulously tailored or snugly draped and gloriously colored. The effect throughout was sleek and sophisticated.

title: Gary Dotson Set Free On Bond in Rape Case
description: Gary Dotson, who is fighting to overturn a conviction for a rape that his accuser now says never happened, walked out of prison for the second time in a month today after his mother posted $10,000 cash bond.

title: KODAK AND GENERAL FOODS OFF
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, hard hit by the strength of the dollar abroad, reported that earnings in the first quarter dropped 27 percent, as sales slipped slightly.

title: POVERTY-SCARRED TOWN NOW STRICKEN BY AIDS
description: Just 40 miles from the polo fields and glittering malls of West Palm Beach, in a farm community long locked in penury and squalor, there have been 31 cases of AIDS in the last three years.

title: THE THEATER: 'CROSSING DELANCEY'
description: WHEN one uses the phrase ''in this day and age,'' one is expressing surprise, even shock, that old ways crop up in modern times. The surprising, but not shocking, question raised in Susan Sandler's new comedy, ''Crossing Delancey,'' at the Jewish Repertory Theater, is: Can a matchmaker possibly serve the course of true love?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I, Ronald Reagan, President of the United States of America, find that the policies and actions of the Government of Nicaragua constitute an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States and hereby declare a national emergency to deal with that threat.'' - Presidential Executive Order. [A8:1.]

title: Allegheny Ludlum Fills Top Operating Position
description: The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation announced yesterday that Robert P. Bozzone, an executive vice president since 1976, had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: Crown Zellerbach
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said that a Nevada court had upheld the company's plan to hold its annual meeting on May 9 in San Francisco.

title: Walkout Cited In an 1890 Case
description: In 1890 there was a Congressional walkout over a contested election in the Seventh District of South Carolina that somewhat paralleled today's contretemps over Indiana's Eighth District race, according to Raymond Smock, the House historian. He cited an account in ''Hinds' Precedents of the House of Representatives.''

title: Pickens Asserts Banks Unfairly Cut Him Off

Milton McCrory, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, will defend his title against Carlos Trujillo of Panama in Monte Carlo on July 14. . . . After today's workout at Yankee Stadium, SportsChannel plans to announce the hiring of Mickey Mantle as a broadcaster for the cable television network.

title: CHILDREN AND ART: A NEW APPROACH
description: A CLASS of fifth graders in a public school here is having an innovative art lesson. The subject is collage, but colored paper and paste pots are nowhere in sight. All eyes focus on a screen that projects a print of a famous collage, part of a series the artist called ''Jazz.'' To judge by the number of hands in the air, almost everyone knows the artist's name.

title: CITY BALLET: 'OPUS 19/THE DREAMER'
description: THE New York City Ballet presented one of its most varied repertory programs on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, ranging from a ballet of delicate manners to a dark nightmare and ending with a giddy, all-American romp.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: BEATRIX JONES FARRAND, who is acknowledged as the first of America's eminent female landscape designers, is at last having a major retrospective. An exhibition at Wave Hill gives us a look at the best of the 176 projects she completed in her 50-year career.

title: Bevill Sale To Siebert Is Reported
description: The receiver for Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., the New Jersey-based securities group closed earlier this month, said yesterday that he had agreed in principle to sell the firm's discount brokerage business to Muriel Siebert & Company.

description: A weekly anthology series about ''the bright side of the fairy tale,'' produced by Steven Spielberg and directed by Martin Scorcese, Clint Eastwood and others from the world of feature films, will be among the half-dozen new shows introduced by NBC in prime time next fall, the network announced yesterday.

The two colts will be coupled in the Derby betting, after an announcement this morning that Spendthrift Farm, already a 20-percent owner of Rhoman Rule, had purchased a 12.5-percent interest in Eternal Prince.

Underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company offered the bonds with yields ranging from 5.50 percent in 1987, to 6.90 percent in 1990, 7.90 percent in 1995 and 8.70 percent in 2000. Because the bonds are backed by Princeton's full faith and credit, they are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

title: Firestone Annuity
