The company said that it had purchased a $397 million single-premium annuity to fund the retirement benefits of 25,500 active, deferred vested and retired salaried employees from the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, a unit of the Cigna Corporation.

title: Informatics
description: The Informatics General Corporation, a computer software company, said it was exploring its possible sale to a larger corporation or to an investment group that includes members of management. The company recently rejected as inadequate a $26-a-share offer from Sterling Software of Dallas.

title: Keep an Eye on South Korea
description: Before packing his bags for Europe, President Reagan did his duty for a difficult ally, President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea. What wasn't said spoke loudest at this smoothly managed visit, whose importance should not be lost in the summit shuffle. There was no reference to South Korea's unseemly treatment in March of the returning exile Kim Dae Jung and his American escorts. That was passed over silently as Mr. Reagan toasted South Korea's progress in ''political development,'' the sanitized word for human rights.

title: Fulbright's Last Speech
description: Former Senator J. W. Fulbright had lunch the other day with a group of his former aides and some of the reporters who covered him in his 30 years in the Senate. He was defeated by Gov. Dale Bumpers, now the Senator, in a Democratic primary in Arkansas in 1974 but has stayed in the Washington area. His prime interest is still foreign affairs, as it was when he was chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee for 15 years. Mr. Fulbright, who was 80 on April 9, said he would make the last prepared speech of his public career today at the Forum for World Affairs in Stamford, Conn.

title: JERSEY SPEAKER SAYS POLITICS LED TO MEMBER'S INDICTMENT
description: The leader of the Democratic-controlled Assembly has charged that the indictment of a Democratic Assemblyman was politically motivated.

description: If neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night can stop mail carriers, then it would probably take nuclear war to keep Manhattan's real-estate brokers from completing their appointed rounds.

title: WARNING LABEL ON SNUFF BOXES URGED IN ALBANY
description: Packages of chewing tobacco and snuff should contain labels warning that use of those products may cause oral cancer and other diseases, scientists and doctors told a panel of state lawmakers today.

title: Drinking Age Rise Nearer Hartford
description: The State Senate today approved legislation that would raise Connecticut's legal drinking age to 21 from 20 on Sept. 1.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SERIES
description: THOMAS K. SCHERMAN founded the Little Orchestra Society in 1947, and until his illness curtailed its activities in the 1970's, this chamber orchestra offered much unusual repertory to New York musical life. Mr. Scherman died in 1979, but Monday night Dino Anagnost, his successor as music director of the society, reinaugurated its chamber-orchestra series with a fund-raising concert at Alice Tully Hall; three regularly priced concerts are scheduled for next season in the same hall.

title: Battle Set For Gulf Resources
description: Stock of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, the natural resources company that is the target of a takeover attempt by an international group of investors, sagged in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Analysts said the stock's 75-cent decline, to $16.875, reflects Wall Street's initial belief that the chances of a takeover are slim.

title: Man Held in 2d Rape Of Girl, 15, in 3 Weeks
description: A 15-year old Queens girl was raped for the second time in three weeks yesterday and the police immediately arrested the same man who was accused in the earlier rape.

Bank and C.D. Rates Off
description: Rates for bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit declined for the third consecutive week. Money market fund yields also dropped in the week ended yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE POST-MODERN AURA: The Act of Fiction in an Age of Inflation. By Charles Newman. With a Preface by Gerald Graff. 203 pages. Northwestern University Press. Hardcover, $18.95; paper, $7.95. IN this dazzling yet penetrating study of contemporary art - by which he unabashedly means almost nothing but contemporary fiction - Charles Newman would seem to have committed the ultimate vulgarity. He has reduced contemporary literature in all its variety to nothing more or less than a consumer commodity in the economic marketplace. And, having done so, he has gone on to argue that like all other current commodities from soup to nuts and bolts, literature has been devalued by the phenomenon of climax inflation we have experienced in the past 40 years.

title: Rates Move Down Slightly
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday, surprising some securities dealers who expected that rates would rise in advance of next week's heavy schedule of new offerings by the Treasury.

title: Europe Is Split On 'Star Wars'
description: EUROPEAN business executives are in a quandary about the wisdom of President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' research program and proposals for Europe to join in. Many think the program will have a major impact on the development of a wide range of key communications and materials technologies, but they are deeply split over whether Europe stands to gain or lose by participating.

title: TEXTS OF REAGAN EXECUTIVE ORDER AND MESSAGE TO CONGRESS
description: Following are the texts of an executive order and a message to Congress signed by President Reagan today on his embargo against Nicaragua: Executive Order By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and laws of the United States of America, including the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.), the National Emergencies Act (50 U.S.C. 1601 et seq.), Chapter 12 of Title 50 of the United States Code (50 U.S.C. 191 et seq.), and Section 301 of Title 3 of the United States Code, I, Ronald Reagan, President of the United States of America, find that the policies and actions of the Government of Nicaragua constitute an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States and hereby declare a national emergency to deal with that threat.

title: TIME FOR CARE IN PLANNING AND PLANTING
description: ARTFUL combinations of tall plants and short, with contrasting textures and tones, are essential for small city terraces and yards, where every plant is important. Survey your share of light and wind before making purchases. Where there is only a hint of sun, reliable plant species include inkberry, yew, witch hazel, epimedium, astilbe, hosta and fern; where breezes rarely subside, use Russian olive, black pine, privet, forsythia, Rugosa rose, yucca and barberry.

title: OKLAHOMANS TOAST END OF DRY ERA
description: Whisky flowed and crowds cheered Tuesday night as pro-liquor forces celebrated the approval of the sale of liquor by the drink in 22 Oklahoma counties. The proposal was turned down in 7 other counties, all rural ones.

title: BRIEFING BOOK COVER SHEET
description: When a President travels abroad, he takes with him a thick ring-bound briefing book, with multicolored tabs to direct him through the thickets in his assault on the summit. His top aide prepares a cover sheet summarizing the central purposes and themes of the trip. Here is what I expect that cover sheet on the Bonn economic summit conference says: 1. The Reagan Round. When Lyndon Johnson became President, he asked the National Security Council staff plaintively, ''Can you tell me in one clear sentence what the Kennedy Round is?'' Cutting through the git-GATT-gittle, it was a long negotiation aimed at lowering tariffs and stimulating free trade, a cause that needs a hard new push a generation later.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $31,000.c-Includes a tax credit of $50,000.

title: POP: LITTLE JIMMY SCOTT

The pure, almost feminine soprano voice that made him famous in the 1950's has grown slightly frayed, adding to the dramatic impact of his other-worldly singing.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON BENEFIT LIMITS
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate defied President Reagan and voted today to restore full Social Security cost-of-living increases to the proposed 1986 budget. On this vote, a vote ''for'' was a vote to preserve the increases, and there were 65 votes ''for;'' while a vote ''against'' was a vote to impose a 2 percent ceiling on the increases in each of the next three years, and there were 34 votes ''against.''

description: Uniroyal Inc., one of the nation's largest rubber makers, yesterday ajourned its annual meeting again - its seventh postponement - until this morning, after an outside company's certification of two shareholder votes on revisions of Uniroyal's bylaws remained incomplete.

title: New Conrail Deal Threat
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today threatened to join the ranks of members of Congress seeking to delay an Administration proposal to sell the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

title: Blyleven Is Suspended
description: Bert Blyleven, the Cleveland pitcher, wasn't too happy when he was removed in the seventh inning of the Indians' 8-7 loss to the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday, which, to some observers at least, he made abundantly clear by making what American League officials described as obscene gestures to the Baltimore crowd. Yesterday the league's president, Bobby Brown, suspended him for three games and fined him $250. The Indians said the fine would be paid promptly, but Blyleven appealed the suspension, a move that will keep him in the rotation until a hearing is scheduled later in the season.

title: NEW TUNA BRAND WAVES FLAG
description: Watch out, Charlie the Tuna.

U.P.I. Plans More Layoffs
description: United Press International, which has filed for protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy statutes, will lay off more of its domestic editorial employees, the wire service said today. In a story made available to The Associated Press by U.P.I., the news service quoted Maxwell McCrohon, its editor-in-chief, as saying that ''there will be some further layoffs within a few days.''

title: Selling The New Coca-Cola
description: THIS Sunday is the day that the world's best-selling soft drink introduces its new formulation into the world's most important market. And, surprisingly, there are probably a lot of people who really do not care.

description: The Republican-controlled Senate voted today to preserve Social Security cost-of-living increases, rejecting a proposal that was a key element of the White House budget package.

description: Several top State Department posts, overseas and at home in Foggy Bottom, are expected to change hands soon, according to department officials.

title: LESSONS IN HARD KNOCKS FOR EDUCATION SECRETARY
description: There was no honeymoon for Education Secretary William J. Bennett.

title: OTB Taking Bets On Derby Again
description: The 123 offices of New York's Off-Track Betting Corporation will begin taking bets tomorrow for the 111th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, and this year it will again have an exclusive franchise in the state. The Legislature failed to renew a one-year law that had allowed Derby betting at New York state tracks last year.

title: Traffic Is Snarled by a Crash And Closing of a Tunnel Lane
description: An overturned tank truck on the Cross Bronx Expressway and the closing of an eastbound lane in the Holland Tunnel delayed tens of thousands of rush-hour commuters yesterday morning and backed up Manhattan-bound traffic for miles.

title: SUBURBAN ARCHEOLOGY: BEATING THE BULLDOZERS
description: The dig has begun, but before the first artifacts are examined it is best to note that there are many different kinds of archeologists. Some are driven by pure curiosity and some work to make ends meet.

title: REAGAN'S STANDING DROPS, POLL FINDS
description: President Reagan's standing with the American public has dropped to its lowest point since last July, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

description: A jury today convicted Alton Coleman of aggravated murder in the bludgeoning death of a woman last July in what the authorities called a crime spree.

title: THE YANKEES AND DR. FREUD
description: Sigm. Freud, as the good doctor signed some of his correspondence, departed from this vale of tears nearly half a century ago. Yet his wisdom in many matters lives on. Recently, Dr. Peter Berczeller, who, like Dr. Freud, was born in Austria, and who now practices medicine on, and follows the Yankees from, Second Avenue, wondered aloud what Sigm. might have cogitated about the latest undertaking of the principal owner of the Yankees, the fantastical Herr S.

title: Artillery Battle Rages In Southern Lebanon
description: A fierce artillery battle raged in southern Lebanon today between Christian defenders of Kfar Falous and Moslem militiamen stalled in the approaches to the mountain stronghold. Sectarian fighting was also reported in Beirut.

title: City to Nation: Thanks, With Interest
description: Just 10 years ago, Washington's response to New York City's desperate financial straits was interpreted by The Daily News as an urgent invitation to cease to exist. Washington later tempered its drop-dead attitude, lent the city money and also guaranteed $1.65 billion in borrowings from city employee pension funds. Now New York has paid back all but a legally symbolic $1 million; it's an occasion to offer the nation an accounting.

HELPED DEVELOP SCIENTIFIC POLLING
description: Archibald M. Crossley, one of the founders of modern public-opinion polling, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 88 years old.

title: Minnesota Builder
description: John Mariucci, the assistant general manager of the Minnesota North Stars who is credited with developing the hockey program at the University of Minnesota and extending the sport's popularity in the state, has been named to the National Hockey League Hall of Fame along with Rudy Pilous, whose peripatetic career included stints as a player, scout, coach, manager and owner in both amateur and professional hockey. The 68-year-old Mariucci and Pilous, who is 70, were selected for the builders category of the Hall, which now has a total membership of 249 - 173 players, 67 builders and 9 referees.

title: Warning on AIDS Blood Test
description: A new blood test for AIDS will falsely suggest that thousands of healthy blood donors have the fatal disease, and this could frighten off donors unless blood banks double-check results before releasing them, public health officials warn.

Instead of tackling the grand rooms of a single mansion, they were confronted with luxury apartment spaces, not all of them graceful and some still under renovation.

title: Neighbors Are Cautious
description: Nicaragua's neighbors in Central America reacted slowly and cautiously today to the Reagan Administration's decision to cut off all trade.

title: HARMONIZING OLD AND NEW BUILDINGS
description: IF there is any major price we pay for the current rise of revivalism, or historicism, or whatever the repetition of historical architectural form in new buildings may be called, it is not what is most often feared, a lack of originality. It is possible to be as creative in assembling Corinthian columns and pediments as in the making of a modern building. The real problem is more subtle - it is in the belief, rarely stated explicitly but coming to be more and more of an assumption, that the only way to relate properly to an older building is by reproducing or imitating its architectural forms.

title: Attention-Getter

They said they were studying game films before taking action.

title: Hi-Shear in Talks
description: Hi-Shear Industries, a maker of aerospace technology systems, said a major American corporation had expressed an interest in acquiring the company. Hi-Shear, which did not identify the possible buyer, said it had retained E.F. Hutton & Company and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as advisers. The company's stock was the second-biggest percentage gainer on the New York Stock Exchange today, rising $2.50, to $21.375.

title: Belgian Cancels Polish Visit Because of Ban on Solidarity
description: Foreign Minister Leo Tindemans of Belgium has postponed a visit to Poland next week after being told that he could not meet members of the banned Solidarity movement, a Belgian Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: 'PROGRESS' IMPERILS THE ONLY 'REAL' NEIGHBORHOOD
description: Vassily Aksyonov, his wife, Maya, and their cocker spaniel, Usik, went to their block party last year in Washington's Adams-Morgan neighborhood. ''We met people from all parts of the world - Eastern Europe, Australia, Israel,'' said Mr. Aksyonov, the exiled Russian author whose latest novel is ''The Burn.'' ''There were even some Americans, too.''

title: INFLATION RECORD IN PERU
description: Inflation in Peru soared 12.2 percent in April, bringing the rate for the last 12 months to 143.8 percent, the highest ever, the Government said today. The previous high was recorded last month, when the 12-month inflation rate reached 129.5 percent.

title: Nipon Is Given 3 Years in Jail
description: Albert Nipon, head of a $60 million internationally known women's fashion empire, was sentenced today to three years in jail for bribing Internal Revenue Service agents to avoid payment of more than $1.5 million in personal and corporate income taxes.

title: CUOMO GIVES 1985 GOVERNOR'S ARTS AWARDS TO 12
description: Citing the ''unique creative genius'' of those individuals and organizations that make New York a cultural center, Governor Cuomo gave the 1985 Governor's Arts Awards last night to 12 artists and supporters of the arts who ranged from a Nobel laureate to a neighborhood art program in Buffalo.

title: REED QUITS IN PROTEST
description: In a decision he called sudden, Willis Reed, the former captain and head coach of the Knicks, resigned as basketball coach at Creighton University yesterday after four years, citing the pressures of recruiting as a major factor.

title: C O M B CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THEATER: 'EPISODE 26,' A SPACE SPOOF
description: THE performances of nine actors as 21 characters and a god in ''Episode 26'' inspire a new respect for innocent pleasures. Howard Korder set out to write a burlesque of parts of ''Buck Rogers'' (the 1940's film serial version and various revivals), ''Star Trek,'' ''Battle Star Galactica,'' ''Star Wars,'' comic books and more. The problem with that kind of material is that often the original is funnier than the takeoff. But the members of this troupe send their lines whizzing around so fast that one forgets they are just bits and pieces. So is the set, an inspired junkyard of crumbling electronic equipment that is the palace of Vaknor, ''an emperor of the universe.'' Eric Booth's villainous Vaknor becomes attractive as he is worn down by an incompetent hero and a rabble - while he is able to destroy only one victim, a robot named Dave whose haphazard disintegration is pathetically tickling.

title: STAGE: 'ALMOS' A MAN'
description: RICHARD WRIGHT'S ''Almos' a Man'' is the brief, poetic story of a teen-age black farmhand who thinks a gun would be an automatic certification of his manhood. He buys a pistol, accidentally shoots his employer's mule - and his world crashes around him. In adapting the story to the musical stage, Paris Barclay has expanded, and thereby diminished, the original.

description: Democrats voted today to seat their candidate in a hotly disputed Congressional race and, in a dramatic demonstration of partisan animosity, Republican lawmakers marched out of the House chamber in protest.

title: MORE IN CONGRESS APPEAR TO FAVOR IMPOSING A HIGHER MINIMUM TAX
description: Sentiment in Congress is growing strong for a stiffer minimum tax on corporations and wealthy individuals. Many, by taking advantage of various legal deductions, exemptions and credits, now pay little or nothing in taxes.

description: When Nancy Reagan lands in Rome today, she plans to locate Anna Craxi, the wife of the Italian Prime Minister, at the airport reception and get a progress report on a drug problem that has concerned the two First Ladies for 10 days or more.

title: MUSIC: WILLIE NELSON
description: SINCE becoming country music's most potent symbol of rugged individualism in the late 1970's, Willie Nelson has released so many albums, of such varying quality, that he is not quite the commercial powerhouse of five years ago. But as a concert performer, Mr. Nelson has, if anything, gained in command and confidence. At the second show of a five-night Radio City Music Hall engagement, which ended Sunday, he and his band, the Family, gave a show that distilled the essence of his appeal just about perfectly. That essence might be summed up as a sound that is both homemade and monumental.

description: Any midnight squealing you hear emanating from the National Air and Space Museum tonight is probably right on schedule.

title: TAUB SELLS HIS 40 PERCENT SHARE OF NETS
description: Joe Taub, who has been deeply and often emotionally involved with the Nets since he helped form the syndicate that bought the club in 1978, announced yesterday that he was selling his 40 percent interest to four partners because of a series of mounting frustrations.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Placed Ron Gardenhire, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list.

description: Raymond Bonner, author of ''Weakness and Deceit: U.S. Policy and El Salvador,'' was awarded first prize today in the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Book Awards program.

description: Assets represent net assets.

title: BACKDROP FOR THE DEBATE
description: THE ISSUES ON THE TABLE GLOBAL TRADE TALKS President Reagan will seek an agreement to begin, in early 1986, multiyear worldwide negotiations to remove obstacles to free trade. He might have to settle for preparatory talks or a more vague agreement to begin negotiations promptly.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, MAY 3, 1985

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter reflect a writeoff of $434,000, or 17 cents a share, relating to a footwear operation.

Christians and Moslems Fight On in Lebanon
description: Artillery exchanges between Moslem and Christian militiamen continued here today and in the hills east of the southern port of Sidon as efforts to arrange a cease-fire foundered.

title: CHINA TURNS TO GOLF, WARLIY, TO LURE TOURISTS
description: The Communists who rule China have accommodated to fast food and Coca-Cola and disco. Now they are turning their hand to golf.

JESSE JACKSON SCHEDULES TRIP TO EUROPE TO MARK V-E DAY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson will begin a three-day visit to France and West Germany next week that is to include taking part in commemorations of the end of World War II and a speech to the European Parliament a day before President Reagan addresses the group.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ENTREPRENEURS. The Men and Women Behind Famous Brand Names and How They Made It. By Joseph J.

title: CHIEF'S CROWN, 9-5, HEADS FIELD OF 13
description: A field of 13 3-year-olds, the smallest in five years, was entered here this morning for the 111th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs Saturday. The reason is that Chief's Crown, 9-5 on the morning line and probably a shorter price by post time, will be the heaviest Derby favorite since Spectcular Bid in 1979.

title: Gas Pipeline Giant Agrees to Merger
description: Internorth Inc. of Omaha and the Houston Natural Gas Corporation of Houston, two of the nation's largest gas pipeline companies, announced a $2.3 billion merger yesterday - 24 hours after rumors of the deal spread through Wall Street.

title: THE CASE OF A SALVADORAN JUDGE: DOES VALOR PAY?
description: He is a minor figure who once played a major role in United States policy toward El Salvador.

title: 2 Share Medal In Richardson
description: Dick Siderowf of Century, former British Amateur champion, and John Baldwin of Meadow Brook each shot a par 72 for medalist honors in the qualifying round of the William D. Richardson Memorial Tournament today at the Seawane Golf and Country Club.

title: GENEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company, which in February emerged from bankruptcy reorganization, did not report year-earlier results.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Roberto Duran, the former world lightweight and welterweight champion who retired last year after losing successive fights with Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Thomas Hearns, said he was considering resuming his career even though he is 40 pounds over his middleweight range.

title: CUOMO NAMES 3 TO POSTS INVOLVING DEVELOPMENT
description: In the latest in a series of midterm shifts in his administration, Governor Cuomo announced yesterday that he was nominating the chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, Vincent Tese, to oversee economic development.

title: Beware the Tax-Reform Torpedo
description: Not a politician in Washington opposes making the tax system fairer, so watch out. The moment is ripe for unfair legislation in the name of fairness. Right now, for example, there's a move to write a new minimum tax into the budget. It sounds eminently just but its effect would be sabotage.

title: SENATE VOTES CUT IN REAGAN'S PLAN ON MILITARY PLAN
description: In the second defeat in two days for the White House and the Republican leadership, the Senate today approved an amendment to the 1986 budget package that eliminates any additional money for the military except to keep up with inflation.

title: TERMIFLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $261,000.

title: Needham Harper Tops Andy Award List
description: The Advertising Club of New York sponsored its annual Andy Awards dinner last night at the Grand Hyatt Hotel and Needham Harper Worldwide emerged as the superwinner with six first-place awards.

title: INQUIRY ON JUDGE STIRS RHODE ISLAND
description: The annual festival is under way on Atwells Avenue, the main street of Federal Hill, this city's old Italian neighborhood.

title: Fitness for Youngsters
description: Body building, aerobics and exercise programs for youngsters are three of the topics to be covered this weekend at the New York-National Health and Fitness Expo at the Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I. The event begins today with a daylong series of videotapes and lectures on corporate fitness programs, followed at 5:30 P.M. by a relay race among teams from local corporations. Tomorrow, an exercise session for those aged 4 to 12 is scheduled at 10 A.M.; aerobics programs, including karate, for adults will be offered all day.

title: I.B.M. Outlook
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, despite an anticipated pickup in product introduction during the year, will not be ''immune'' to a United States or worldwide economic downturn in 1986, said James J. Forese, vice president and controller. Mr. Forese, responding to questions from securities analysts, said that if a recession struck the United States, ''our growth projections would have to be changed.''

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Advertising;   A Salute To Direct Marketing
description: THE television advertising for Federal Express has been so visible and so effective that few people realize that the company has a direct mail marketing program as well. And it is as selective as the TV campaign is general, but like the broadcast advertising it is imaginative. It is the work of the Yeck Brothers in beautiful Dayton, Ohio.

title: TAX URGED ON HEALTH PREMIUMS
description: Reversing its position, the Treasury Department is recommending that all workers be required to pay taxes on a small portion of the health insurance benefits their employers pay, Administration officials said today.

title: TRI-COUNTY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $257,000 for the quarter and the year. c-Net loss.

title: TAX PLAN WINS FINAL APPROVAL IN CONNECTICUT
description: The State House of Representatives, by a vote of 151 to 0, today gave final legislative approval to a package of tax cuts totaling $92.8 million.

title: Torrey Wants Arbour to Stay
description: Still upset by the Islanders' elimination Sunday in the second round of the playoffs, General Manager Bill Torrey returned to his office yesterday and said that he wanted Al Arbour to remain as coach.

title: THEY CALL HIM CAP THE KNIFE
description: There he goes again.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 23
DANCE: BALLET WEST REVIVES BOURNONVILLE'S 1855 'ABDALLAH'
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 - Thanks to Ballet West from Salt Lake City, a little-known Romantic ballet by the celebrated Danish choreographer August Bournonville has come to life for the first time since 1858.

title: SACRED BUDDHIST CHANTS AT EAST-WEST FESTIVAL
description: THROUGHOUT the 20th century, East has been meeting West in music, usually to the edification and enlightenment of the West. Contact with the East brought Western composers a different perspective on every aspect of music - tunings, sounds, structures, techniques and the uses of music itself. Tonight and tomorrow, the ''Great Music in a Great Space'' series at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine brings together representatives of traditions half a world apart, in a festival that may suggest some common ground.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased by $2.98 billion, to $208.33 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Happy Debaters
description: Consider the question faced by the speech and debate team at Regis High School: whether to be more excited by having swept the state tournament last weekend, or by the prospect of greater challenges ahead.

title: McGraw-Hill Videotex Talks
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. said that it had held discussions with Tele-Communications Inc., a Colorado cable company, about a possible joint videotex venture, which would provide data for homes and small businesses using cable television.

title: Hello? Hello?
description: Though President Reagan is abroad, contacts between the White House and the outside world continue unabated. Following are some recent insights into how the Administration's fabled communications apparatus operates or, upon occasion, does not operate:

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $1,290,000 for the quarter and $36,240,000 for the year. c-Includes tax benefits of $340,000 for the quarter and $2,500,000 for the year.

title: B.N.O.C. Said To Pay More
description: The British National Oil Corporation has proposed raising the price it will pay its suppliers for the major grade of North Sea oil by 40 cents a barrel, to $27.90, European oil industry sources said today.

title: Amoco to Close Marketing Offices
description: The Amoco Oil Company said that it would close its 3 regional marketing offices, in Kansas City, Kan.; Baltimore and Oak Brook, Ill., and also shut 5 of 15 district offices, as part of a restructuring. Certain operations of the closed offices will be redistributed to the company's Chicago headquarters or to the remaining district offices, Amoco said.

title: UNIROYAL SAID TO GET ETHYL BID
description: Uniroyal Inc.'s board of directors met in a special session yesterday to study a buyout offer from the Ethyl Corporation, according to Wall Street sources, but the negotiations between the two chemical companies were said to have broken off.

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: PICKENS GROUP EXTENDS DEADLINE ON UNOCAL OFFER
description: An investor group led by T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, said yesterday that it is extending the expiration date of its offer for shares of the Unocal Corporation by one week, until May 23.

title: TORIES LEAD IN ONTARIO VOTE
description: The Progressive Conservative Party, which has governed Ontario for 42 years, appeared to have narrowly escaped defeat in an election held today in Canada's most populous province.

title: A Chattem Division Goes to Hill Holliday
description: The consumer products division of Chattem Inc., marketer of pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, toiletries and fragrances, has completed a search that started with 65 agencies and ended with the New York office of Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it would close its Kenosha, Wis., assembly plant next week for one week because of slow sales of the Alliance and Encore subcompact cars built there.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adage Inc., a Billerica, Mass., company that makes computer graphics work stations, has named Brij Prasad executive vice president, product marketing and development.

title: Cases Should Be Resolved in Courtrooms, Not Tried in the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: LEWIS STILL WITHOUT A TRAINER'S LICENSE
description: Carlos (Panama) Lewis had hoped to return to the ring May 26 as the trainer of Livingstone Bramble when the World Boxing Association lightweight champion defended against Tyrone (Butterfly) Crawley. Two things happened yesterday to prevent that.

title: COMMON-SENSE RULES FOR SAFETY IN THE PARK
description: When Sgt. Richard Messemer joined the Central Park precinct four years ago, he noticed a foolhardy disregard for safety among the people at play in the park.

title: HOGAN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $5,700,000 for the discontinuance of the company's international banking software product line and a pre-tax charge of $4,700,000 to increase the company's allowance for doubtful accounts receivable to enhance its integrated loans systems and for other nonrecurring expenses. c-Net income.

title: Struggling Mets Seek Magic
description: At this time last year, the Mets' season began to take on a magic that lasted the rest of the campaign.

title: EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOVIET CALLS REAGAN'S EMBARGO 'PATHOLOGICAL'
description: The Soviet Government's press agency said today that President Reagan was venting a ''pathological hatred for the Sandinista revolution'' in imposing a trade embargo on Nicaragua.

title: CENTRAL PARK AT ITS SPRINGTIME PEAK
description: Few spots in the city are so beloved by New Yorkers as Central Park. It is an 843-acre oasis of forests, meadows and water on an island where people live 64,000 to the square mile. For many of the park's 14 million yearly visitors, it is a place to play, to indulge in hobbies and exercise, to relax, watch people or enjoy an outing with friends or family. It is also a place for nature lovers, lovers of sport, and just plain lovers.

title: Eskimo Sculpture
description: ''Takamit: From the North,'' a display of contemporary Eskimo sculpture and graphics, is at the Pelham Art Center, 153 Fifth Avenue, Pelham, N.Y., through June 29.

title: PALMER CRITICIZES TEE PLACEMENTS
description: Arnold Palmer, competing in the senior division of the MONY Tournament of Champions, shot a par 72 today and then criticized as ridiculous and unnecessary the forward placing of the tees for the senior players in the event.

title: Heavy Seas Delay Godspeed
description: Heavy seas forced the Godspeed, a replica of the 17th-century sailing ship that carried the founders of Jamestown, Britain's first successful colony in America, to tie up in port temporarily today. The captain, George Salley, said the 68-foot wooden vessel, which is retracing the first Godspeed's voyage to the Virginia coast, had been forced to dock at the English Channel port of Newhaven to await better weather. The Godspeed left London Tuesday.

title: There's Still Time for a More Fitting Gesture
description: To the Editor:

title: NICARAGUA REBELS GAIN SOME BACKING
description: House Democratic leaders appeared to be moving today toward reversing their opposition to aiding the rebels who seek the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government.

title: THE BOSS AT BARN 25
description: Not long ago, George Steinbrenner said he was becoming fond of standardbred racing because he could sit in a buggy and exercise the trotters and pacers. Steinbrenner would naturally be attracted to a sport in which he could get out there and flick the whip, at least in practice, rather than have to watch his managers and players fall short of his insatiable dreams.

title: MABERN ON PIANO
description: Two nights of music featuring the pianist Harold Mabern will be presented this weekend by the Jazz Center of New York.

title: Required Reading;   The American Dream
description: Excerpts from House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.'s Alfred M. Landon Lecture on Public Issues at Kansas State University April 22: I began my public life in 1936 on a slogan of ''work and wages.'' I remain convinced that our greatest goal is to give the average family the opportunity to earn an income, to own a home, to educate their children and to have some security in their later years. That is still the American dream and it is still worth fighting for.

title: Biding Time, Learning Lessons
description: Let's talk about the draft.

title: Group Has Little Hope Of an East-West Thaw
description: The International Institute for Strategic Studies said today that there was little hope that either the United States or the Soviet Union would come up with a fresh approach to resolving the problems between them.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about American bank lending to South Africa misidentified one company that chooses to lend neither to private companies nor public agencies in South Africa. It is the Bank of Boston Corporation.

title: Human Switchboard
description: Human Switchboard, a rock band from Hoboken, N.J., will perform tomorrow night at 1:30 A.M. at the Peppermint Lounge, 100 Fifth Avenue, at 15th Street (989-9505). Tickets are $7 before 11 P.M., $11 after. .

title: Johnson & Johnson In a Restructuring
description: In a restructuring of its top management group, Johnson & Johnson yesterday named three members of its 13-member executive committee to head its main business segments worldwide, setting up what some analysts said would be a race for the leadership of the big health-care concern.

title: STREAM INSECTS ARRIVE EARLY
description: Fly fishermen who are wont to make their annual visits to the Catskills this month and next should be aware that the major hatches of aquatic insects upon which trout feed have been substantially altered by the dry and relatively warm weather.

title: Music: Sonatas by Brahms
description: RIMMA SUSHANSKAYA and Joseph Seiger joined forces at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night for a complete performance of Brahms's three sonatas for violin and piano.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about Education Secretary William J. Bennett incompletely rendered one of his remarks in some editions. He said, ''I am not going to deal with the education establishment on the premise that I work for the educational establishment alone.''

title: DEATH OF A MAN FOLLOWS STRUGGLE WITH 3 OFFICERS
description: A young man died at a Queens hospital yesterday after struggling ''violently'' with police officers and paramedics, the police said.

title: YOUNG DAVID'S TANTRUM
description: David Stockman, the boy genius of the Reagan Administration, threw a tantrum the other day before a Senate subcommittee. If senators did not have ''the courage, the foresight, the comprehension'' to ''pull the plug'' on what he called an ''irredeemable'' Amtrak rail passenger system, he saw little hope for deficit reduction or for avoiding a ''whopping tax increase.'' 36.8,0,165.6,2,423.2,0,4 23.2,2>There, there, little man. It won't be as bad as all that, if Amtrak survives. Take Elizabeth Dole's word for it. As Secretary of Transportation, she affirmed last September that she shared the view of Federal Railroad Administrator John H. Riley that Amtrak had made ''great strides'' toward ''modern, cost-efficient intercity rail passenger service'' - running in 1985 ''more route miles than it did in l981 at approximately 28 percent lower funding.'' Mrs. Dole, far from sharing young David's hysteria about what he cutely called a ''mobile money-burning machine,'' had asked for a $765 million Amtrak subsidy for fiscal 1986. But that was before the youthful Budget Director began to drum his heels.

title: Honored Reporter
description: Rarely is there an occasion, Mayor Koch said, that brings together the Board of Estimate, the City Council, reporters, retired reporters, union leaders and union members.

title: VALERO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring after- tax gain of approximately $18,000,000 from the sale of the company's 50 percent interest in the West Texas pipeline system to Internorth Inc.

title: GENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Justice Department to Back A Study of Adult Magazines
description: The Justice Department has approved financing for a study that will try to determine whether Playboy, Penthouse and Hustler magazines influence sexual exploitation of children and delinquency.

title: A HOUSE DIVIDED
description: On one level, the fight that has torn the House of Representatives apart this week is about who really won the election in Indiana's Eighth District. But for both parties that dispute embodies much larger issues of how Congress is operating these days and who will control the House in future years.

title: Unhappy Cabdrivers
description: A sea of yellow spread through Columbus Circle yesterday morning. Then, amid ear-splitting horn honking and epithets hurled at police officers and pedestrians, it moved down Broadway and Seventh Avenue, disrupting every other kind of traffic.

title: ST PAUL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an investment gain of $15,353,000. c-After income of $1,903,000 from discontinued operations and an investment gain of $13,510,000.

title: TNP ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
5 POLICE OFFICERS INDICTED BY JURY IN TORTURE CASE
description: Five police officers from the 106th Precinct in Queens, including a lieutenant assigned to guard against police brutality, were indicted yesterday on charges that prisoners in their custody were beaten and assaulted with an electric stun gun.

title: FARRELL, SWITCHING POSITION, SEEKS JACKSON'S HELP
description: Reversing his position, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrrell Jr. said yesterday that he would ask the Rev. Jesse Jackson to participate in his campaign for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

title: FAR RIGHT LOSES IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa's governing party has retained control of seats in two by-elections, turning aside a challenge by far-right opponents.

title: WILD TURKEY MAKING A COMEBACK
description: After an absence of a century, the wild turkey has been restored to the forests of the Northeast. The birds are prospering, to the surprise of wildlife biologists.

title: FILM: 'MOVERS,' A HOLLYWOOD SATIRE
description: ''MOVERS AND SHAKERS,'' a Hollywood satire costarring Charles Grodin, who wrote the screenplay, and Walter Matthau, is made up entirely of peripheral pleasures that turn increasingly wan as it becomes apparent that the movie has no real story or screenplay.

title: PHONE-MATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RENTALS AND PERMITS: FOR BOATS, BICYCLES, TENNIS, HORSES AND CROQUET
description: Although the steam and electric boats that once plied the lake are no more, rowboats can be rented at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park daily from 9 A.M. till sunset. There is usually no shortage of boats in the fleet of nearly 200, and they rent for $5 an hour (plus a $20 deposit). The boathouse, which has a fast-food counter and will soon have the park's second full-service restaurant, also offers picnic baskets of wine, fruit and sandwiches.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $303,000 for the latest quarter and $256,000 for the year-ago period.

title: N.A.A.C.P. TO PROTEST U.S. CIVIL RIGHTS POLICY
description: The National Association for the Advnacement of Colored People today called on other civil rights groups to join in a demonstration next week at the Justice Department to protest the Reagan Administration's attempts to overturn state and local affirmative action hiring plans.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said comparative results were affected by the reversal of previously accrued compensations costs of $2,115,000 in the year-ago first quarter.

title: SCREEN: CHUCK NORRIS IS A CHICAGO POLICE INSPECTOR IN 'CODE OF SILENCE'
description: CHUCK NORRIS goes upscale in ''Code of Silence,'' as a big-city police inspector who stalks through art galleries and public libraries to catch his prey. Mr. Norris hasn't abandoned his usual fans; this film has a body count as high as that of ''Missing in Action,'' and a climactic sequence in which Mr. Norris, as a one-man army, is helped by a heavily armed miniature tank. But ''Code of Silence,'' which opens today at the UA Twin and other theaters, is Mr. Norris's bid for a wider audience, and it succeeds to a considerable degree. He's still got a way to go, but ''Code of Silence'' amounts to a good-sized leap.

title: PIANO: SIEGEL PLAYS LISZT
description: ALTHOUGH all we know about Liszt as a pianist is what can be deduced from his own compositions and from writers who heard him play and left awestruck accounts of his prowess, he must have exercised a spell over listeners that went beyond any technical explanation. That puts a great burden on modern-day pianists who take up his works, in particular those numerous pieces in which musical substance is secondary to sheer keyboard display.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: PETER WORMSER and William Fellows are in a most enviable position for two young architects just beginning their own firm: New York's most recent public monument - the Vietnam Veterans War Memorial, erected just last week at 55 Water Street - is designed by them.

title: USPCI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'THERE IS A DARK CLOUD HANGING OVER THIS CHAMBER'
description: Representative Sherwood Boehlert says that when he first came to Washington as a Congressional aide in 1964, there was a certain magic about the House.

title: NAPCO SECURITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-or-2 stock split in February.

title: Sanyo Electric Chooses Ally
description: Sanyo Electric of Compton, Calif., which in February consolidated all of its advertising in the DYR agency, has now decided to assign its home appliance business to Ally & Gargano. No budget has been set but $4 million would not be an unrealistic sum.

title: TV TESTIMONY BY CHILDREN
description: The New York State Legislature is considering proposals to allow children who are victims of sex crimes to testify by closed-circuit television at the trials of their accused assailants.

title: A Sears Magazine For Those Over 50
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has 55 million credit card holders and its Allstate Insurance has 10 million customers. Seeking to profit from that wonderful list of consumers, Sears started the Mature Outlook Association for folks over 50, which in a way is similar to the multimillion-member American Association of Retired Persons.

title: COURT NOMINATION IS CLEARED
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee, after weeks of dispute and delay, today unanimously approved the nomination of New Jersey's Public Advocate, Joseph H. Rodriguez, to be a Federal district judge.

title: ART: ISAAC WITKIN'S LYRICAL SCULPTURE
description: MUCH contemporary sculpture is so ambitious to be something else - environment, architecture or furniture, for example - that it's nice to see vigorous work aspiring only to the condition of sculpture. That occasion is provided by Isaac Witkin's new show at Hirschl & Adler Modern, 851 Madison Avenue (between 70th and 71st Streets), through May 18. Witkin may not be the best known of contemporary sculptors, but he is certainly one of the best. Now 48 and exhibiting for more than two decades, the artist - born in South Africa, trained in England and since 1975 an American citizen - long ago worked his way out of esthetic debt to such mentors as Anthony Caro and David Smith and into a powerful lyrical expression of his own.

title: Topics;   Muddled Messages Just an Editor
description: Having ''inherited a different set of aptitudes, values, goals, mores and lifestyles over a period of 10,000 years,'' American blacks now ''insist on preserving their jungle freedoms, their women, their avoidance of personal responsibility and their abhorrence of the work ethic.''

Plan to Sell Britoil Stake
description: Britain plans to sell its remaining 48.8 percent stake in Britoil P.L.C., the North Sea oil exploration and production company, by the end of the year, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, told the House of Commons today. Majority control of Britoil was sold to private investors by the Government in 1982 after the company had been created to hold the British National Oil Corporation's North Sea assets. The Government raised about $775 million in the 1982 sale, one of its biggest in the privatization program that has returned several state-owned enterprises to the private sector.

description: Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today that a four-year study had shown ''enormous strides'' had been made in human heart transplants, but she stopped short of approving Federal payment for the operation under the Medicare program.

title: TV Plans to Present Visit to Bitburg Live
description: The four major television networks plan live coverage of President Reagan's visit to the Bitburg military cemetery in West Germany on Sunday.

description: The battle of Quebec, the Canadiens versus the Nordiques, was put to an end tonight by a Czechoslovak.

description: The Reagan Administration has suddenly become embroiled in disputes with Congress over the fitness of several nominees and appointees as the President moves to fill positions at the start of his second term.

A Critic Loses Her Job
description: Dr. Dyann Waugh, who held a temporary position as an occupational physician with the Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration, was told last week that her contract was being canceled. Dr. Waugh is one of five employees who last month criticized OSHA's decision that the Government should not require farmers to provide field workers with toilets or drinking water.

title: GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a realized investment gain of $282,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Includes a gain of $80,460,000, or $1.79 a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change and a realized investment gain of $487,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: TONY CATEGORY BARRED FOR LACK OF NOMINEES
description: There will be no award for best actress in a musical in this year's Tony Awards because there was only one eligible nominee, the Tony administration committee decided yesterday.

title: The Clincher
description: The big lottery drawing to see who gets the rights to Patrick Ewing will be held a week from Sunday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and it promises, of course, to be one of the biggest sports stories of the year.

title: PEABODY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $9,258,000 for the quarter and $9,526,000 for the 6 months.

title: SCREEN: A TRIBUTE TO GEORGE STEVENS
description: GEORGE STEVENS (1904-1975) is a very American kind of film maker, one who came up through the ranks from assistant cameraman to camerman to director. In his more than 40 Hollywood years, he worked as a gag writer for Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy and later directed westerns, slapstick comedies, musicals, sophisticated comedies, romantic dramas and even one biblical epic.

title: Zellerbach Ruling
description: The Nevada Supreme Court has ruled that the Crown Zellerbach Corporation should go on as scheduled with its May 9 annual meeting, overturning a lower court order that would have required a two-week delay requested by the British financier Sir James Goldsmith. The court also said Sir James's General Oriental Securities Ltd. had no right under Nevada law to inspect the shareholder list, and Zellerbach ''acted lawfully in refusing to produce the records.'' Sir James, who has been trying to take over the San Francisco-based paper and forest products company, owns 8.5 percent of its stock.

title: Arizona Cutback
description: Citing a drop in television revenues following the breakup of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's monopoly on college football telecasts, Dr. Cedric Dempsey, the athletic director at the University of Arizona, said the school was sharply cutting its athletic budget. He said Arizona was imposing 20 percent budget cuts in all athletic programs except football and men's basketball, laying off five staff members, eliminating the women's synchronized swimming team, cutting 28 athletic scholarships and slashing operating, travel and administrative budgets. Dr. Dempsey, who said Arizona lost $300,000 in budgeted television revenues after the Supreme Court ruled that the N.C.A.A. monopoly was unconstitutional, blamed the universities of Georgia and Oklahoma, which brought the lawsuit that led to the decision. ''Their action is the most devastating action ever taken in intercollegiate athletics,'' he said.

title: AN ELEGANT ARRAY OF PICNICS-TO-GO
description: Alfresco entertainment in Central Park can be even more fun if accompanied by a picnic. And if you don't have the time - or inclination - to put together your own, you can turn to one of the many establishments in Manhattan that provide picnics-to-go.

title: PENTA SYSTEMS INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Ford, Korean Unit
description: The Ford Motor Company said that it had held discussions with a South Korean company about importing mini-cars to the United States. The talks were conducted with the Kia Industrial Company, a maker of trucks, vans and engines, Thomas Rhoades, a Ford spokesman, said. He called the discussions preliminary.

title: DATAMARINE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: VALLEY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FAR WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rio Grande Industries Offer
description: Rio Grande Industries, a Denver-based railroad holding company whose principal property is the Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Company, yesterday offered $180 million of debt securities through Morgan Stanley & Company as sole underwriter.

title: Supreme Court Halts Execution in Virginia
description: The Supreme Court today halted the scheduled execution of Willie Lloyd Turner less than six hours before he was to die in Virginia's electric chair for killing a jewelry store owner.

title: No Bargaining
description: When John Bassett, the owner of the United States Football League Tampa Bay Bandits, started handing out conditional contracts to National Football League draft prospects. Those who hoped to play in the N.F.L. could simply use the Bassett offer as leverage in negotiating their N.F.L. contracts.

title: Topics;   Muddled Messages Baby Basics
description: First published in 1945, Dr. Benjamin Spock's book ''Baby and Child Care'' remains the best-selling guide to child-rearing.

title: SNAG ENDS A SHUTTLE EXPERIMENT, BUT RESULTS PLEASE SCIENTISTS
description: Another of the space shuttle Challenger's scientific instruments failed today, but scientists at the space center here were nevertheless elated by the information it had gathered.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch from Beirut on Tuesday about efforts by Shiite militias to control the movements of Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas incorrectly described the guerrillas' involvement in battles last week near Sidon. The Palestinians were reported to have joined Moslems in fighting against Christian militiamen.

title: Bank of Boston to Trim U.S. Securities Activity
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that it was beginning to reduce its activity in Government securities trading, following a strategic business plan to focus its resources on other activities.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE auction of the $11 million collection of Italian, Dutch and French old masters owned by Samuel Thomas Fee, an Oklahoma geologist, will inaugurate Christie's new salesroom next Thursday night at 7. The facility at Park Avenue at 59th Street has been almost doubled to 50,000 square feet with the addition of a new auction room, offices and storage in the Delmonico Plaza, a 24-story commercial condominium adjacent to its main quarters in the Delmonico Hotel.

title: POP: DIANNE REEVES SINGS
description: DIANNE REEVES, the Los Angeles-based jazz-pop singer who made her New York club debut at S.O.B's (204 Varick Street) on Tuesday, has a clear, rangy alto and the inclination to blend many different idioms into elaborate, rhythmically complex set pieces. At the first show of a three-night stand at S.O.B.'s, Miss Reeves was enthusiastically introduced by her mentor, Harry Belafonte, to an invited audience.

title: Rifle Group Criticizes Statement by Cuomo
description: The National Rifle Association yesterday charged Governor Cuomo with making a ''vicious and personal attack'' on its members.

title: MONUMENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1,000 for the latest quarter and $23,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: 100 HELLS ANGEL MEMBERS ARE ARRESTED IN DRUG SWEEP
description: In raids beginning at dawn today in 11 states, more than 100 members and associates of the Hells Angels motorcycle club were arrested on charges of drug trafficking and racketeering.

title: Reed Hunts Job
description: Willis Reed, who resigned Wednesday as the Creighton basketball coach, has begun to shop for a job that will get him back into the National Basketball Association.

title: Bobby Hutcherson
description: The vibraphonist Bobby Hutcherson is leading a quartet - with Kenny Barron on piano, Buster Williams on bass and Al Foster on drums - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: BARNETT NEWMAN'S 'ULYSSES' SOLD AT SOTHEBY'S AUCTION
description: Barnett Newman's ''Ulysses,'' an epic 1952 blue-and-black striped painting, sold last night for a record price at Sotheby's to an American collector who was not identified. The sale of 82 artworks broke auction records for the works of 16 artists and nearly doubled the highest total for such a sale of postwar art.

title: City Housing Bond Offering
description: The New York City Housing Development Corporation is offering $120 million of bonds to finance multifamily housing projects in Battery Park City.

title: TEXAS TEAM SETS A RECORD IN BIRD SPECIES SIGHTED
description: Racing around the vast state of Texas by airplane, van and marsh buggy, a team of bird watchers has just set a North American record for the largest number of different species sighted, or at least heard, in one day.

title: A JAPANESE TOUCH IN EAST SIDE BUILDING
description: The conventional wisdom of the real estate business says that New York City is different from every other place. Its staggering prices, the density of its housing stock and the entangling web of community control and city and state regulation make building here a process that gives out-of-town developers fits and ulcers. Not so, says Katsumi Kiuchi. ''Japan is very much like Manhattan,'' he said. ''Very expensive, very crowded, very strong neighborhood forces.''

title: STOCKS HALT FOUR-DAY DECLINE
description: The stock market broke its four-day slump yesterday, but only barely, as prices closed mixed in a session where takeovers provided the only excitement.

title: Union Carbide to Restart Plant in West Virginia
description: The Union Carbide Corporation plans to restart production of the chemical methyl isocyanate Friday at its pesticide plant in Institute, a company spokesman said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday YO-YO MA IN RECITAL He gave his first public recital at the age of 5, and by the time he was 19 he was being compared with such masters as Rostropovich and Casals. Yo-Yo Ma is now 29, and one of the most sought-after cellists in the world. He gives his only New York recital of the season tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall as part of the Great Performers Series. The program will include Bach's Third Sonata for viola da gamba; the Brahms E minor Sonata; Messiaen's ''Louange a l'Eternite de Jesus,'' from ''Quatuor Pour la Fin du Temps,'' Beethoven's Fourth Sonata for Cello and Piano and Chopin's ''Introduction and Polonaise Brillante.'' He will be accompanied by Patricia Zander. Tickets, from $7 to $14, are available at the box office (874-2424).

title: THE ANXIUOS GERMANS
description: The economic summit conference here has been overwhelmed by the emotions of the German problem. It is a deep irony that the attempt to close a chapter of history 40 years after World War II has only revealed how much the wounds still fester.

title: Japanese Protectionism Is a Global Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: GAS PIPELINE GIANTS AGREE TO A MERGER
description: Internorth Inc. of Omaha and the Houston Natural Gas Corporation of Houston, two of the nation's largest gas pipeline companies, announced a $2.3 billion merger yesterday - 24 hours after rumors of the deal spread through Wall Street.

title: Technology;   'Bugs' That Make Plastics
description: WHEN humans eat a lot of sugar, they put on fat. When Alcaligenes eutrophus and some other forms of bacteria indulge in sweets, they fill up with beads of polyester.

title: STUDY SET ON SECURITY AND SCIENTIFIC EXCHANGE
description: The National Academy of Sciences is about to begin a $750,000 study of the impact of national security controls on the transfer of modern technologies among the nations of the world.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST FEDERAL SAVING & LOAN KALAMAZOO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $215,000 from the receipt of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock. c-Net loss. The company went public on Feb. 27, 1985.

title: Bridget D'Oyly Carte, Leader Of Gilbert <u4and <u4Sullivan Troupe
description: Dame Bridget D'Oyly Carte of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, the guardian of Britain's Gilbert and Sullivan tradition, died Thursday at her home in Buckinghamshire, England. She was 77 years old.

title: TIME ENERGY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest quarter and nine months reflect an accounting change related to how accrued interest is recorded.

title: Ralston Purina
description: The Ralston Purina Company announced that the price for its Foodmaker Inc. restaurant unit, which is being sold to Forstmann Little & Company and members of Foodmaker's senior management, was $500 million. An agreement in principle for the sale was announced Tuesday. The Foodmaker unit owns about 800 Jack in the Box fast-food restaurants, located primarily in California, Texas and Arizona.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $124,000 for the quarter and $570,000 for the year. c-After a tax benefit of $60,000 for the quarter and year. All data restated to reflect March 1 acquisition of Interlan Inc., which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Honored Recipients
description: The Negro Ensemble Company, the newscaster Charlayne Hunter-Gault and three slain civil-rights workers were recipients of the New York Urban League's annual Frederick Douglass Awards last night.

title: HUNTING LIMITS DESIGNED TO HELP EAGLES
description: The Interior Department plans to bar hunting on wide areas of prime waterfowl habitat in five states to protect bald eagles from lead poisoning, department officials said today.

title: How to Ignite Education Reform
description: Teachers paid $80,000 a year . . . teacher juries to decide whether other teachers are competent . . . teachers and students shopping for schools . . . These are a few of the grenades Albert Shanker has been tossing to wake up American education. Some are better than others, but all have merit.

title: TIGERS FIND ROOKIE FITS ROLE AT THIRD
description: It is rather unusual for a young baseball player to move directly from Double A minor league status to a major league roster.

title: UNITED FINANCIAL BANKING COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBS CRITICIZES TURNER VIEWS
description: In rejecting a bid for CBS Inc. by Turner Broadcasting System Inc. last week, CBS's directors based their decision primarily on financial considerations.

title: ISOMEDIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Security Pacific Merger Talks
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it was engaged in ''serious negotiations'' to acquire some units of the Commercial Credit Company, a financial services subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation.

title: VON BULOW TRIAL JUDGE SAYS DOCTOR MAY TESTIFY ON BRUISE
description: In a sharp defeat for Claus von Bulow's defense, the trial judge ruled today that the state could present testimony from an emergency room doctor about bruises he says he saw on Martha von Bulow.

title: RULES SEEM MADE TO BE REWRITTEN
description: Potential candidates are in motion in New Hampshire, some more discreetly than others. Political action committees are snapping to attention. And in Washington the urge to tamper with the nominating process once again has taken hold.

title: SCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $37,080 for the quarter and nine months. c-Net loss.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MAY 3, 1985

title: Net Is Off by 15.4% At Doyle Dane
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International reported first-quarter earnings yesterday and the silver lining was that the earnings per share remained the same as the 1984 period despite a 15.4 percent drop in net income, thanks to there being fewer shares outstanding.

title: HECLA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Ranchers Exploration & Development Co. on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Polish Dissident Given 3-Month Jail Sentence
description: Jacek Kuron, an adviser to the Solidarity movement who publicly urged May Day protest marchers to disperse peacefully, was sentenced today to three months in jail for taking part in the illegal procession with 15,000 people.

title: F.C.C. to Meet With Murdoch
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, is scheduled to meet with members of the Federal Communications Commission today, presumably to discuss the possible acquisition of television stations from Metromedia Inc., an F.C.C. official said.

title: Court to Reconsider Case Of Coast Nuclear Plant
description: A Federal appeals court agreed today to reconsider a ruling last December that upheld the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's operating license for the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California.

title: Stop Brutality - but Also Crime
description: Police Commissioner Ward of New York City, facing the biggest brutality scandal in years, has administered a big dose of a traditional tonic. With an angry lecture to the police brass and the removal of seven senior officers, he demonstrates that he is serious about ''command accountability.''

title: ROPAK WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results reflect the operations of the Capilano group of companies, which were acquired by Ropak West on Feb. 1.

title: Multimedia Starts Recapitalization
description: Multimedia Inc. said today that it had set in motion a plan developed by an investor group of senior management and the founding families to recapitalize the company. The plan would allow shareholders to cash in their shares and, for a small investment, retain some equity in the company.

title: AN UNWISE AND HASTY EMBARGO
description: Having failed to convince Congress to approve military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, the Reagan Administration has used its executive powers to impose a trade embargo. This is a hasty, foolish step. Trade sanctions are unlikely to moderate or topple the Sandinistas and could even produce reactions contrary to United States interests.

title: ELIMINATION OF GRAND JURIES GAINING SUPPORT IN ALBANY
description: A move to abolish the grand jury system in most New York criminal cases is gathering momentum in the Legislature, with support from key members and criminal-justice officials.

title: DYNAMICS VOWS FIGHT IF PENTAGON BARS CHIEF
description: David S. Lewis, chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, told the annual meeting of shareholders here today that the company would fight any Pentagon effort to ban him from doing business with the Government.

title: NICARAGUA SENDS 100 CUBANS HOME
description: One hundred Cuban military advisers left Nicaragua today as scheduled, but officials said their departure did not signify any change in Government policy.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $242,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Net income after an extraordinary gain of $147,000.

title: BALLET: 'ANASTASIA' DEBUT FOR MARTINE VAN HAMEL
description: THERE was admirable dancing in new works and old at American Ballet Theater's performances on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: STAGE: 'OUT OF GAS ON LOVERS LEAP,' AT THE WPA
description: IN the new play at the WPA Theater, ''Out of Gas on Lovers Leap,'' the writer Mark St. Germain asks us to grieve for two pampered rich kids. Myst (short for Mystery) is the out-of-wedlock daughter of an aging 1960's female rock star and an anonymous one-night lover. Her boarding-school boyfriend, Grouper, is the son of an ambitious United States Senator. While Myst and Grouper have plenty of money and psychoanalytic care, they are both miserable, if not suicidal. The source of their angst is their neglectful parents, whom they encounter more often in the pages of People or Rolling Stone than in the flesh.

title: PANEL VOTES TO CONTINUE U.S. SUBSIDY FOR AMTRAK
description: A House subcommittee today rebuffed the Reagan Administration and voted unaminously to maintain the Government subsidy for Amtrak at its current $684 million level for the next two years.

title: ART: EXPLORING A SHOW OF OLD FRENCH DRAWINGS
description: NOTHING is more minor than a minor Impressionist. A minor Cubist can make us wonder if Cubism was really such a good idea. But in French art in the first half of the 19th century, it is still possible to find artists of high quality who are known only to specialists (and sometimes not even to them). Those artists are overdue for resuscitation and, happily for us, they are coming out, one by one.

title: Sniper Holds Police at Bay
description: A man with a rifle barricaded himself into his apartment on the Lower East Side and fired more than 30 shots holding police officers at bay for more than five hours last night and early this morning, the police said.

title: For Every Rule
description: As Roger Maris and Maury Wills taught us in the 60's, as Hank Aaron reminded us in the 70's and as Pete Rose is about to reaffirm in the 80's, records that are unbreakable simply do not exist. Except for the exceptions.

title: Hilton Hotels Wins Legal Ruling
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation won another legal victory in its battle to keep Golden Nugget Inc. from acquiring about 27 percent of its shares.

title: PROTECTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $336,000 for the latest quarter and $236,000 for the year-earlier period. Per share figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in January.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $1,567,000, or 9 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-After income of $457,000, or 3 cents a share, from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $1,188,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Income Unit Shake-Up At Prudential-Bache
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., the Wall Street brokerage house that has lost money two of the last three years, said yesterday that James T. Gahan had been named an executive vice president in charge of the firm's fixed-income group.

title: Out-of-Town Bands
description: The Del-Fuegos, a Boston rock band, will headline a triple bill tonight at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at East 15th Street (477-3728). Tomorrow, the Long Ryders, a country-rock band from California, and Barrence Whitfield and the Savages, a Boston rhythm-and-blues band, will share a double bill. Live music begins at about 11:30 each night; tickets are $10.

title: IN 'BEST OF BROADWAY, 'ORIGINAL STARS SING NUMBERS FROM HIT MUSICALS
description: IT is a truism, indeed a platitude and cliche: They don't make Broadway musicals the way they used to. ''Best of Broadway,'' on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tomorrow night, is a reminder. The original stars perform memorable numbers from more than 20 Broadway hits. The hits may not be the ones you most remember; the numbers may not be the ones you most want to hear. Probably it doesn't matter. Musicals have not flourished on Broadway this season. Any old reminders of past greatness will do.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MITTERRAND BALKS AT REAGAN'S PLAN FOR TRADE TALKS
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France told President Reagan today that he could not go along with a trade plan that is Mr. Reagan's most important goal at the seven-nation economic conference here.

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 14 PLANS FOR COLISEUM SITE SENT TO CITY AND M.T.A.
description: Three proposals to build the world's tallest building are among 14 that have been submitted for redevelopment of the New York Coliseum site, a four-acre parcel on Columbus Circle.

title: MILTON S. EISENHOWER DIES AT 85: SERVED AS ADVISER TO PRESIDENT
description: Milton S. Eisenhower, the diplomat and educator who was president of three institutions of higher learning and an adviser to six Presidents of the United States, including his brother, Dwight, died yesterday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 85 years old.

title: JAPANESE PROTECTIONISM IS A GLOBAL PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTAURANTS
description: PETALUMA is one of the latest in the genre of grand cafes that have been blossoming around town like dogwoods in May. Following the leitmotif of the day, it is an expansive, peach-colored playroom with postmodern touches, a long, crowded bar and an exposed kitchen turning out grilled victuals and pastas at moderate prices. Oh yes, let's not forget the individual (wood-burning oven) pizzas.

title: MARTIN EAGER TO SPUR YANKS
description: Billy Martin got to Yankee Stadium at noon yesterday, but the rain was falling and there was no indication it would subside. So the new manager of the Yankees called off his first mandatory workout.

title: BELLOW IS GIVEN FICTION PRIZE
description: Saul Bellow won the Kenneth B. Smilen fiction award for ''Him With His Foot in His Mouth and Other Stories'' (Harper & Row), and Primo Levi, author of ''The Periodic Table'' (Schocken Books), won the award for biography/autobiography. The awards are sponsored by the Jewish Museum.

title: ART: PRINTS AND DRAWINGS BY MATISSE
description: MAKING a prestigious double-header, a show of prints by Matisse at Isselbacher Gallery, 41 East 78th Street, adjoins a selection of the master's drawings at Maxwell Davidson Gallery, 43 East 78th Street. Both shows were organized in collaboration with Heinz Berggruen, a collector and former dealer in Paris, and both are on view through May 18.

title: The Field for the Kentucky Derby
description: POSTPROB. NO.POS.HORSEJOCKEYTRAINERODDS *2*1Irish FighterPat DayBilly Borders#30-1 *3*2Chief's CrownDon MacBethRoger Laurin#9-5 *1*3a-Rhoman RuleJacinto VasquezAngel Penna#5-1 *4*4Tank's ProspectGary StevensD.

title: Tulane Drops Out
description: Bowing to pressure from other league schools, Tulane withdrew from the Metro Conference yesterday, but its president, Dr. Eamon Kelly, criticized the conference for not supporting Tulane's decision to drop men's basketball in the wake of the point-shaving and recruiting scandals involving several Tulane players. Other conference schools had indicated they did not want a member without a basketball program, and last week the conference's joint committee voted 7-0 to urge Tulane to withdraw rather than face expulsion. ''We are dismayed by the vote but will honor the wishes of the membership and withdraw,'' Dr. Kelly announced, expressing fear than an expulsion would be interpreted as meaning that the league did not share Tulane's concern with balancing academics and athletics.

title: VITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: A.T.& T. TO BYPASS NYNEX UNIT
description: For the first time, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has agreed to bypass one of its former Bell operating company subsidiaries in providing long-distance service to a major corporate customer.

title: U.S. AND GERMAN AIDES IN DISPUTE ON REMARK ATTRIBUTED TO REAGAN
