description: A dispute erupted today after President Reagan was quoted by a West German Government spokesman as saying he ''regretted'' that some Americans believed in collective German guilt for the killing of millions during World War II.

title: MANILA WITNESS SAYS SHE SAW SOLDIER SHOOT AND KILL AQUINO
description: A Filipino woman testified today that she saw a man in a military uniform shoot the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. in August 1983.

title: Carson Renews Pact As Host of 'Tonight'
description: Grant Tinker, chairman of NBC, announced yesterday that Johnny Carson has renewed his contract as host of the network's ''Tonight'' show.

title: SOME TENNESSEANS OPPOSE SITES FOR ATOM WASTE
description: Despite widespread pro-nuclear sentiment in this city that helped build the first atomic bombs, some area residents are opposed to putting a temporary storage facility for the nation's spent nuclear fuel here.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
description: b-Includes tax credits of $6,150,000 for the quarter and $30,000 for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $135,000,000 for the year related to pension funds. c-Includes tax credits of $5,500,000 for the quarter and $16,500,000 for the year.

title: SCEPTRE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $16,600,000 on the sale of investment. Year-ago figures were restated for an accounting change.

title: Dining Out Guide: Mother's Day
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. For Mother's Day (May 12), reservations well in advance are suggested. AMERICAN FESTIVAL CAFE, #20 West 50th Street (246-6699) - v(July 27, 1984) Against a background of gleaming woods, sparkling glass, shiny brass and a floor tiled to look like a patchwork quilt, the restaurant features American antiques and a rotating exhibition from the Museum of American Folk Art - an altogether agreeable atmosphere for Mother's Day. The special menu that day includes such choices as chilled shrimp with champagne sauce, tenderloin of veal with golden oak mushrooms, roast duck with fresh plum sauce and strawberry shortcake. Noon to 8; prix fixe $24.50. CAFE DES ARTISTES, #1 West 67th Street (877-3500) - v(Aug. 13, 1982) This beautiful, antique restaurant has a Mother's Day dinner from noon to 8.

title: SCREEN: THE 'GOTCHA!' GAME
description: ''GOTCHA,'' which opens today at the Loew's Twin and other theaters, is a small but elaborately overproduced comedy-melodrama about an 18-year-old university student (Anthony Edwards) who has fantasies about losing his virginity and about appearing as the star in his own real-life espionage caper.

title: 10 Years at Virginia
description: The University of Virginia football coach George Welsh and the basketball coach Terry Holland have signed 10-year contracts that will keep both in coaching positions for at least five years, the school said Thursday. ''The second five years are a series of one-year coaching agreements,'' said the athletic director Dick Schultz.

title: E.F. HUTTON GUILTY IN BANK FRAUD: PENALTIES COULD TOP $10 MILLION
description: E.F. Hutton & Company, the nation's fifth-largest brokerage firm, pleaded guilty today to an elaborate fraud that let the firm use as much as $250 million a day of bank funds without paying interest.

title: Chaoying Fang, Expert On Chinese Dynasties
description: Chaoying Fang, a major contributor to biographical dictionaries of Chinese history, died Sunday while on vacation in Peking. He was 77 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J.

title: WHO NEEDS THIS BILLY CLUB?
description: The other night when the sports came on the late news, I was piddling around in the kitchen when my wife called out: ''The Yanks fired Yogi and have hired Billy again. You better come and watch this.''

title: Sister of Iran's President Flees to Husband in Iraq
description: The sister of the Iranian President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, arrived in Baghdad today and said at a news conference that she had fled from Iran to join her husband, a dissident, in Iraq.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE will be fun and games at the New York Shakespeare Festival in Central park this summer - quite literally. The second production, which begins previews Aug. 3, will be ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' based on the unfinished Dickens novel.

title: SAN JOSE WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ACCORD IN SUIT AGAINST MANUFACTURERS HANOVER
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has agreed to a tentative settlement of a class action lawsuit challenging its lending practices over the last seven years. A state court judge will review the adequacy of the proposed settlement later this month.

title: BRIDGE: RARE PLAY SELDOM MAKABLE BY THE PERSON WHO NEEDS IT
description: There is a small paradox concerning some rare plays: The player who needs them usually is not capable of making them.

title: Goring May Coach
description: Butch Goring met in Boston yesterday with Harry Sinden, the Bruins' general manager, and stated his preference to retire as a player and become the coach. ''I've said what I'd like, now it's up to Harry,'' said Goring, who said he thought it was just a matter of time before he was named coach. Sinden, who previously said Goring was a serious candidate for the job, told the veteran center he would have a decision for him Monday or Tuesday.

title: Dissidents Win Storer Appeal
description: A Federal Court of Appeals today upheld a regulatory panel's decision to let a group seeking control of Storer Communications go forward with a proxy fight without waiting 30 days.

title: CONSENSUS DEVELOPING IN HOUSE THAT MAY SETTLE DISPUTE OVER MX
description: A diverse group of House Democrats have reached an informal consensus that they say may finally resolve the long, bitter dispute over the future of the MX missile.

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERFECT DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income includes extraordinary gains of $11,000 for the quarter and $53,000 for the year.

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT SAYS HE WANTED EMIGRE TO BE A COUNTERSPY
description: A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that he had coached a Russian emigre on what to say during a planned trip to the Soviet Embassy in Washington in 1982, as part of a plan he had to turn her into a double agent.

title: Bandits Pursue Jet Pick
description: The Tampa Bay Bandits are ''very close'' to signing the Jets' third-round draft choice, Donnie Elder, according to the Bandits' operations director, John Rauch. Elder, a cornerback from Memphis State, visited the Bandits over the weekend, saw them play, ''and was impressed with spring football,'' according to Rauch.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE EVENING HOURS
description: WHO is the strongest woman in the world? What did she do to George Plimpton and Gloria Steinem under the laser lights of Visage? Which two Pulitzer Prize winners ate couscous on the St. Regis Roof? How old is Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern? And what is a ''nasty floral arrangement?''

title: Sun Ra and Big Band
description: The keyboardist Sun Ra is leading his Omniverse Jet Set Arkestra, a big band, tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin tonight and tomorrow at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; Sunday at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: INTEGRATED GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LEONARD COHEN BRINGS BACK HIS 'BLUES'
description: WHEN Leonard Cohen, the Montreal-based poet, songwriter, and novelist, takes the stage of Carnegie Hall Sunday evening, it will be the first North American appearance in 10 years by the composer of ''Suzanne,'' ''Bird on a Wire,'' ''Famous Blue Raincoat'' and a dozen other cult classics. With their haunting long-lined melodies sung in a sorrowful, softly penetrating drone, they belong to a genre that the 50-year-old Mr. Cohen likes to call ''the Jewish blues.''

title: 2 YOUNGSTERS EAT L.S.D. AND UNCLE IS ARRESTED
description: Two Long Island youngsters who ate 89 LSD pills that were left on a living room table were in critical condition today, according to the Suffolk County police, who reported the arrest of the children's uncle on assault charges.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I saw a soldier holding a gun aimed at the back of Senator Aquino's head, and simultaneously I heard a gunshot.'' - Rebecca Quijano, testifying at the trial of 26 men charged with involvement in the murder. [A1:1.]

title: RUSTING AUTOS IN CITY'S PARKS CREATE BURDEN
description: Along the Henry Hudson Parkway in Riverside Park, among the trees, picnic tables and handball courts they sit, the rusted ruins of Buicks, Fords and Chevys, as if they were permanent features in one of the city's favorite public parks.

title: Microsoft Develops Program for Apple
description: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday introduced a spreadsheet program for the Apple Macintosh 512 computer, in a move that Apple Computer Inc. hopes will increase sagging sales.

title: Street Fairs Planned This Weekend and Next
description: There will be street fairs uptown and down this weekend, offering an array of arts and entertainment.

title: SAVANNAH ELECTRIC & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,935,000 from a stock-for-debt swap.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEAWAY FOOD TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Former Employee Set As President of Amax
description: Amax Inc., the financially troubled nonferrous metals producer, announced yesterday they it had tapped a former employee, Allen Born, to become president and chief operating officer. The appointment is effective June 1.

title: NEW VACCINE SAID TO INHIBIT HERPES IN MICE
description: An experimental vaccine developed through genetic engineering methods has protected mice against recurrent herpes virus infections, scientists of the National Institutes of Health reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption from The Associated Press on Wednesday with an article about the dispute over an Indiana Congressional election misidentified politicians at a news conference. Representative John T. Myers of Indiana was at the microphone; Lieut. Gov. John M. Mutz was in the background.

title: CHILDREN'S EVENTS, FROM PUPPETS TO PONY RIDES
description: Central Park is a children's delight, with all kinds of special spots and activities, as well as playgrounds galore - some with jungle gyms and sandboxes, others with wading pools for steamy summer days.

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HUTTON MOVES RESULTED IN INTEREST-FREE LOANS
description: Terms like ''financial system'' and ''banking networks'' may conjure up an image of a spaghetti of wires through which billions of dollars whiz in ultra-efficient electronic impulses.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Pop and Rock at Ritz
description: Sussman Lawrence, a pop band from Minneapolis, and the Mosquitoes, a New York rock band, will share a double bill tonight at the Ritz, on 11th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues (254-2800) . Music begins at about 11:30, and admission is $8.

title: GERMAN ENEMIES OF HITLER WILL BE AT THE BITBURG RITES
description: The West German Government announced today that veterans of the anti-Hitler resistance movement would be present when President Reagan visits a military cemetery in Bitburg on Sunday.

title: CANADIAN MARCONI LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
NEW RULES DRAWING FEWER TO LOW-COST HOME LOANS
description: The scenes had become embarrassing to state officials: thousands of people camping outside banks for days each time the state had offered low-interest mortgages on a first-come, first-served basis.

title: FALL SPORTSWEAR: A WIDE RNGE OF THEMES
description: A nostalgic charm pervaded Ralph Lauren's fall showing. Bits of old lace wrapped around the throat and extending over the wrists, derby hats, pearl chokers, walking sticks and high laced shoes were some of the details that contributed to the Edwardian feeling. The best pieces included tapestry jackets, gray flannel trousers with both cuffs and stirrups and a variety of short, cabled sweaters.

title: LION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A L LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Publisher Named At Country Living
description: Hearst Magazines has named Richard J. Sarno, associate publisher and advertising director of Redbook since 1982, to be publisher of Country Living.

title: Tax-Rule Changes Gain
description: A compromise plan to kill tough new record-keeping requirements for tax-deductible cars and home computers is moving toward final Congressional approval.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $309,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $248,000.

title: Eliza Nichols Is Bride Of Olivier Quennesson
description: The marriage of Eliza Nichols and Olivier Quennesson took place yesterday in Philadelphia. Judge Louis H. Pollack of the Federal District Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Getting the Dollar to Fit the World's Billfold
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: ALLIES LUKEWARM ABOUT 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan, promoting allied support for his space arms program, pledged today not to ''go it alone'' and decide on deployment without consulting allies and holding discussions with the Soviet Union.

title: SELECTERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The U.N. Today
description: May 3, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory body for the 1985 Conference on the Women's Decade - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PAPERCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results include a pre- tax gain of $467,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: ART: DAVID SALLE SHOW AT MARY BOONE GALLERY
description: DAVID SALLE'S new show has a slightly different tone than his previous exhibitions. As usual, his work is loaded with visual puns and composed of appropriated images whose meanings reinforce and cancel one another in a process without beginning or end. In this show, too, at the Mary Boone Gallery, 417 West Broadway, through May 25, Salle is constantly seeing how far he can go - what interests he can offend, whose toes he can step on next.

title: ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago results include revenue of $4,040,000 and net income of $87,000 from a business software unit that was sold Sept. 30, 1983.

title: STATE STEPS IN TO BREAK DEADLOCK PARALYZING SCHOOL DISTRICT ON L.I.
description: In a highly unusual move, the State Commissioner of Education has added an extra member to a Long Island school board in hopes of breaking deadlocks that have paralyzed the district for months.

title: NUGGETS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: The dividends continue to mount for the Denver Nuggets. Tonight, they gained a 2-0 lead in a playoff series for only the second time in their history by beating the pesky Utah Jazz, 131-123, in overtime before 16,317 fans at McNichols Arena.

title: CBS Agrees to Buy 5 Radio Stations
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to buy five radio stations from the Taft Broadcasting Company for an undisclosed price.

title: African Photos
description: ''New World Africans: 19th-Century Images of Blacks in South Africa and the Caribbean,'' an exhibition of 19th century photographs, will be on view through Sept. 7 at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black play includes photographs of people at work as well as studio portraits; among the photographers in the show are the noted Brazilian artist Marc Ferrez. Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. today and tomorrow.

title: White on White: Polar Bears in the Wild
description: As a zoo attraction, polar bears rank right up there with the pandas and orangutans. The uncommon view of these likable behemoths in the wild offered by ''Polar Bear!'' on Channel 2 tonight at 8 o'clock will only add to their allure.

title: The Rhetoric Of Summitry
description: ''GOOD rhetoric,'' a wise economist once said, ''has to precede good policy actions.''

title: FILM: 'PUMPING IRON II: THE WOMEN'
description: ''PUMPING IRON II: THE WOMEN'' displays no real sympathy for the female body builders who are its subject - an attitude that, while perhaps understandable, doesn't make watching the film any easier. These women seem formidably freakish, and the film's director, George Butler, does nothing to dispel that impression with insight or candor. The entire film has an uncomfortable, half-rehearsed quality, as when Mr. Butler's camera just happens to be alongside one of the women when her boyfriend proposes marriage.

title: ASPREY PLANS TO OPEN A 5TH AVE. STOREFRONT
description: Asprey & Company, the 200-year-old British jeweler and maker of expensive gifts, will open a street-front store on Fifth Avenue and 56th Street this fall. It will be competing on the same block with Tiffany & Company, and it will be diagonally across Fifth Avenue from Harry Winston, the international jeweler.

title: WILLIAM JAY SCHIEFFELIN JR., 94, IMPORTER OF WINES AND SPIRITS
description: William Jay Schieffelin Jr., retired board chairman of Schieffelin & Company, a major importer and distributor of wines and spirits, died of heart disease Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Florida Ban on Citrus Sales
description: Agriculture officials, fighting the canker disease that has attacked Florida's citrus groves, have banned the sale of all citrus plants from May 15 through Sept. 1 for residential planting. ''Residential plantings have presented problems in surveying for the presence of citrus canker in Florida,'' said Doyle Conner, state Commissioner of Agriculture, on Wednesday. The bacterial canker, which kills citrus trees, is harmless to humans.

title: QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 8 WELLS FARGO UNITS CLOSING WORLDWIDE
description: Wells Fargo Bank, the nation's 13th-largest bank, said today that it would close its London branch, a key New York office and six smaller offices throughout the world in an effort to streamline operations.

title: THE PARK, AN ALFRESCO SCULPTURE GALLERY
description: A HORSE with flippers instead of hooves only begins the tour. There is also a cast bronze panther crouched on a rock ledge, a South American revolutionary meeting his death in a business suit, and a field filled with boulders placed as carefully as sculpture. In fact, the boulders are placed as sculpture, and the tour takes one through the little-known gallery of sculpture that is Central Park.

title: Diner's Journal
description: WHEN James Beard died earlier this year, friends of the legendary author and cooking instructor followed his wish that no elaborate memorial be held. Next month, however, an impressive array of people in the food and wine world will gather in New York to hold a fund-raising dinner in his honor for Citymeals-on-Wheels, a cause that was close to his heart.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Billy Martin makes his home debut as the Yankee manager, for the fourth time, against another former Yankee manager, Dick Howser. This is the opener of a three-game weekend series. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.). Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. The undefeated Ed Lynch is scheduled to start against Mario Soto, who has a 1.50 earned-run average and whose only loss in five decisions was 1-0 to the Mets last month. The Reds were beaten three times and shut out twice in that series. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.). Braves vs. Montreal Expos, at Atlanta. This game features two hot hitters in Dale Murphy of the Braves and Andre Dawson of the Expos. (Television - WTBS, 5:35 P.M.). Basketball 76ers vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Philadelphia. The four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinal moves to the Spectrum in Philadelphia with the 76ers holding a 2-0 lead after surprisingly winning twice on the Bucks' home court. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.). Trail Blazers vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Portland. Game 3 of the four-of-seven-game Western Conference semifinal. The Lakers are now looking for their sixth consecutive playoff victory.

title: Muskie to Head Institute
description: Edmund S. Muskie, the former Secretary of State, has been named chairman of Georgetown University's Institute for the Study of Diplomacy, succeeding the late Ellsworth Bunker. Mr. Muskie, a Democrat, served as United States Senator from Maine for 22 years.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: JUST as there are star-making roles, there are star-making assignments - and the casting job for ''Desperately Seeking Susan'' was surely one of them. Risa Bramon and Billy Hopkins, whose first feature film this was, did such a memorable job of casting the movie's 56 speaking parts - of which 26 are main roles - that the result has been more work than they can handle.

title: Ethiopian Aide Disputes Reports of Eviction
description: The Ethiopian Government's relief director said today that reports of mass evictions of famine victims from a feeding center this week were groundless.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,991,000 and approximately $1,000,000 in nonrecurring expenses. c-After a loss of $596,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $642,000.

title: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $7,000,000. c-Net loss.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Market Place;   The Slippage At P.&G.
description: A FTER the Procter & Gamble Company recently reported a 27 percent drop in profits for the quarter ended in March, Wall Street analysts promptly cut their earnings estimates for the company's fiscal year, which ends June 30. However, they remain divided on whether shares of P.&G. are attractive for purchase.

title: Rates Show Slight Decrease
description: Interest rates fell slighlty yesterday, with all of the decline occurring before the Federal Reserve announced a $2.7 billion rise in the nation's money supply. That was in line with forecasts.

title: The Out Crowd
description: What do you say we hold a little reunion of people whom George Steinbrenner has dumped as manager, or has at various times considered hiring as manager but whom he hasn't - at least, not yet.

title: COMPUTER DEPOT reports earnings for Year to Feb 2
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $85,000.

title: TANK'S PROSPECT
description: YEAR

title: SS VETERANS FEEL 'REHABILITATED' BY REAGAN VISIT
description: They stood relaxed, shaking hands, introducing wives, these men of Germany's dark past, looking forward to a three-day meeting that began here today.

title: TYLER'S HOT STREAK WINS FOR PISTONS
description: The Pistons turned Terry Tyler loose on the mistake-prone Boston Celtics in the final quarter tonight and the 6-foot-7-inch substitute forward delivered 16 points that paved the way for Detroit to win, 125-117, at Joe Louis Arena.

title: HOUSE PANEL FAVORS PRETORIA SANCTIONS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would bar new private United States investment in South Africa.

title: SOUTH TEXAS DRILLING & EXLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK AREA RAINS FAIL TO EASE DROUGHT
description: More rain fell in the parched New York area in the last two days than in all of April, but it did not ease the drought because most of it fell south of the depleted Catskill reservoirs, the National Weather Service said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;

Separating Oxygen From Other Gases
description: The reversible separation of oxygen from other gases is said to be achieved quickly and at low cost with a novel material and process patented this week by University Patents Inc. of Westport, Conn.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $8,000. c-Net income which includes extraordinary credits of $1,792,000 for the quarter and $1,811,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $974,000 for the quarter and $615,000 for the 6 months.

title: MATRIX SCIENCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a reduction of $810,000 for a tax provision to cover the reversal of DISC deferred taxes.

title: Dynamics Bar Urged
description: The Pentagon's Inspector General has recommended that the chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, David S. Lewis, and two other company officers should be suspended from involvement in Government contracts because of evidence that they lacked ''business integrity and honesty.''

title: U.S. JOBLESS TATE IS UNCHANGED AT 7.2%
description: The nation's jobless rate remained at 7.2 percent in April, the same as in the two preceding months, while the Government's measure of the number of people employed showed a slight decline, the Labor Department reported today.

title: VERMONT UTILITIES TOLD TO GET OUT OF SEABROOK
description: Vermont utilities were ordered today to put their shares in the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant up for sale and to push for cancellation of the project.

title: Tainted Turkey Roasts Recalled in 5 States
description: A Minnesota processor is voluntarily recalling some of the company's turkey roasts distributed in New York, Minnesota, Georgia, Maine, Washington and the District of Columbia, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: KEYSTONE CAMERA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Thatcher Opponents Gain in Elections
description: The Labor Party held on to most seats it won in a 1981 landslide and the Social Democratic, Liberal Party alliance made strong gains today as British voters in county elections registered their growing unhappiness with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government.

title: A TYPICAL BUSY FRIDAY AT AN ATYPICAL BEAUTY SHOP
description: On Fridays, the women are already lined up when the beauty parlor opens at 7:45 A.M. ''They come in pushing and shoving,'' said one of the hairdressers, describing the shop's elderly clientele. ''They go for the chairs and wind up on each others' laps. The ones who have walkers use them like weapons.''

title: MASCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EX-F.B.I. AGENT ACCUSED AS SPY SEEKING DISMISSAL OF INDICTMENT
description: Lawyers for Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who is accused of espionage, charged today that the United States Attorney here told Mr. Miller's psychotherapist that she was required to discuss his case with Federal investigators, thereby violating the confidentiality of that relationship. .

title: LET 'EM MOVE WHEREVER
description: The feeling that the real estate frenzy in Manhattan is out of control keeps getting reinforced. Virtually every week some new evidence affirms the sense that the profits and temptations have become irresistible.

title: TOO BUG FOR N.F.L., PERRY SCALES DOWN
description: William Perry knew he had a big problem as soon as he stepped on the scale. He was in Phoenix two months ago for one of those tryout sessions run by the National Football League, in which eager young bodies, in search of glory, are inspected, directed, corrected, dissected, accepted and rejected.

title: CORRECTION
description: A page of charts yesterday describing the seven nations represented at the summit conference in Bonn failed to specify the time period for the data on imports and exports. The figures were average monthly totals for 1983. Also, in a chart showing patterns of economic growth, the labels for West Germany and France were transposed.

title: TONY AWARDS IN 2D DISPUTE
description: A second controversy has arisen around this year's Tony Awards. The producers of ''Big River'' are asking that the actors playing Huck Finn and Jim be eligible for the award for best actor in a musical even though they are not billed above the play's title - the criterion established for the leading actor and actress awards by the League of American Theaters and Producers, which operates the awards.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Pope to Lead Prayers Over'Insult' to St. Mary
description: Pope John Paul II will lead special prayers in a radio broadcast Saturday night to ''repair the insult'' to the Virgin Mary caused by the film ''Hail Mary,'' according to the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano.

title:
PATENTS;

Cheaper Way to Make Cancer Drug Chemical
description: Two chemists have invented an inexpensive method of manufacturing a chemical component of drugs used in treating cancer.

title: VILLAGE INDEPENDENT DEMOCRATS ENDORSE BELLAMY IN MAYORAL RACE
description: Living up to its tradition as an unorthodox club, the Village Independent Democrats has rejected the recommendations of its district leaders and the ambitions of the Manhattan Democratic leader and endorsed Carol Bellamy for Mayor.

title: Books of The Times;   Out of Work
description: RED BAKER. By Robert Ward. 202 pages. The Dial Press. $14.95. ''I had believed that if you worked hard and kept yourself and your family together, it was going to pay off,'' says Red Baker, the narrator of Robert Ward's new novel. ''And worse, I had believed that it was not only going to pay off in this world but in the next one, too. That was the greatest laugh of all.''

title: THOMSON NEWSPAPERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations $2,718,000 for the quarter and $2,880,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income which is after income from discontinued operations of $104,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $110,000 for the 9 months.

title: HEEP DRIVES IN 5 AS METS POUND REDS
description: With his team plagued by anemic hitting and the training room almost as full as the clubhouse, Manager Dave Johnson brought his Mets here in an urgent search for momentum.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bitburger Pils
description: This is the last day that Bullfeathers, a Capitol Hill watering place popular with Congressional staff members, will feature Bitburger Pils as its ''beer of the month.'' Actually the German import was the selection for April, but it was held over through the weekend in honor of President Reagan's visit on Sunday to the city where it is made. A Bullfeathers spokesman reported that, even at $3 a bottle including tax, Bitburger has ''sold pretty well'' and the publicity involving its birthplace ''definitely put up sales.''

title: THE RED BANANA MENACE
description: What has 58,000 telephones, almost as many people as Houston, Tex., and threatens the security of the United States? 239.2,0,276,2,165.6,0 ,276,2,276,0>As every student of the World Almanac knew immediately after reading the first two clues, the answer is Nicaragua. Those same students know that when the count was last taken the United States had only 191 million telephones to match against Nicaragua's 58,000.

title: Ford to Offer 8.8% Financing
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would offer 8.8 percent retail financing through June 3 on the 1985 1/2 Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx and the 1985 Bronco II.

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Holiday Inns Vote
description: Holiday Inns Inc. said its shareholders had approved two anti-takeover amendments to its bylaws at its annual meeting and also voted to adopt a new name, the Holiday Corporation. In addition, the shareholders approved a reorganization under which Holiday Inns Inc. would become a wholly owned unit of the Holiday Corporation. The company said the new provisions included staggered terms for the 13-member board of directors and a requirement that every shareholder's shares be eligible for the same price in a takeover.

title: Kite Barely Hangs On to Lead
description: Tom Kite posted one of the most unusual rounds of golf on the PGA Tour this year when he parred each of the 18 holes at La Costa Country Club to retain the lead by only a single shot after two rounds of the 33d annual MONY Tournament of Champions.

title: AMERICAN PRESIDENT COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CIRCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TV: HOW THE HIT 'We Are the World' Was Made
description: By now, millions of people have heard and purchased the ''We Are the World'' song and album, and seen the video of the single on television. That means there is a built-in audience for Home Box Office's hourlong documentary about the recording of the song, ''U.S.A. for Africa: The Story of 'We Are the World,' '' which is being shown seven more times this month, including tonight at 10 o'clock.

title: Player Trades Skates for Spikes
description: Kirk McCaskill, a 24-year-old right-hander, was called up from the Edmonton Trappers by the California Angels early in the week, and made his major league debut Wednesday night, when Toronto visited Anaheim. Everything was going rather nicely for a while - McCaskill was working on a two-hitter through six innings - and then the Blue Jays chirped for five runs in the seventh en route to pinning a 6-3 loss on him. But what's a single defeat, even in your debut, when stacked up against the import of baseball history?

title: Not the Cruelest
description: What's that about April showers?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International

title: Officer Is Accused Of Taking Bribes
description: A police officer who has been on New York City's force 22 years was arrested yesterday and charged with taking bribes to protect a gambling operation in Queens from police interference.

title: LIMIT ON TRAFFIC IN CENTRAL PARK RENEWS DEBATE
description: For the 20th year in a row, traffic on the Central Park drives is being barred during selected hours until the end of summer. And for the 20th year in a row, the policy is causing debate, as park users and car users argue over whether the closings are in the city's best interests.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 5,000 European Farmers Hurl Eggs in Food-Price Protest
description: About 5,000 angry farmers hurled firecrackers, eggs and fruit at the gates of the European Economic Community's headquarters here today as agriculture ministers grappled inconclusively with proposed price cuts.

title: TEXACO CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said Canadian reserve oil and gas earnings are included as of the Jan. 2 acquisition date.

title: 16 DISSISDENTS IN SOUTH AFRICA WIN FIGHT FOR BAIL
description: Sixteen prominent opponents of the Government won a protracted legal battle today to obtain their release on bail. They are to be tried later this month on charges of high treason.

title: CHURCH HOMES OFFER ALTERNATIVE TO ABORTION
description: When Paula's father discovered she was pregnant, he said that if she did not have an abortion he hoped her baby would die.

title: IRAN-NICARAGUA CARGO IS REPORTED
description: A shipment of Iranian arms and ammunition has arrived at the North Korean port of Hungnam and is awaiting delivery to Nicaragua, United States officials said today.

title: YANKEES WIN IN MARTIN'S 3D RETURN
description: Billy Martin came home again. He didn't exactly take the city by storm, but his daring, aggressive style of managing - a style that was once branded Billy Ball - seemed to make the Yankees come alive last night at the Stadium. It undeniably made Martin's return something special.

title: 3S.I. Men Charged With Tax Evasion By The Associated Press
description: Three Staten Island men have been indicted on tax-evasion charges for not reporting payments in the $1 million sale of a Brooklyn discotheque, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
DR. ALLEN S. RUSSEK
description: Dr. Allen S. Russek, former professor of clinical rehabilitative medicine at New York University Medical Center, died of pulmonary disease on April 23 at Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital.

title: Z & Z FASHIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Duckwall-Alco Buyout Accord
description: Duckwall-Alco Stores Inc. said it had agreed in principle to a new leveraged buyout at $17.75 a share, or about $88.4 million. The company said a management team led by Robert R. Soelter, president and chief executive, and E.F. Hutton Leveraged Buyout Inc., would take the company private.

title: Pepitone Is Indicted By The Associated Press
description: Joe Pepitone, the former Yankee first baseman and outfielder, was indicted yesterday along with two other men on drug and weapon-possession charges, Linda Sachs, a spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney, said.

title: U.S. AIDE OPPOSES EXCHANGE OF SCIENCE WITH SOVIET UNION
description: A senior Defense Department official said today that ''if it was up to me, I would discourage'' scientific exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: The Festival of India
description: When Indira Gandhi and President Reagan met on her visit to Washington in 1982, they agreed that 1985 would be a year of grand cultural and scientific exchanges between India and the United States. On this side, it is called the Festival of India and it starts Sunday at the National Gallery of Art.

title: Basques Say They Set 6 Blasts in Spain
description: Two bombs blew up in this Mediterranean beach resort and four exploded in the Basque country today in a second day of explosions claimed by the Basque separatist group E.T.A.

title: No Guarantee
description: Another postscript to the National Football League draft:

title: PROBLEM OF DRUGS IS RAISED IN BONN
description: Participants in the seven-nation economic conference here spent much of their time today discussing the worldwide battle against drug abuse.

title: IN BLOW TO TEXAS DEMOCRATS, EX-REP. HANCE JOINS REPUBLICANS
description: The Texas Democratic Party, already reeling from a serious defeat in 1984 and continuing defections in its ranks, suffered another blow today with the announcement by Kent Hance, a popular former Representative, that he too would rather be a Republican.

title: OFFICIALS AT STATE AGENCIES CHARGED IN DRUG-SALES RING
description: Fifteen people - including an Assemblyman's chief of staff and officials in a half dozen state agencies - were arrested today and charged with participating in a drug network made up of state employees.

title: U.N. to Study Reports On Ethiopian Evictions
description: United Nations officials said today that they would investigate reports that 56,000 famine victims were evicted from the country's largest feeding center and sent back to their home villages.

title: SOFT-SHELL CRABS: SIMPLEST IS BEST
description: They are called ''busters'' and ''peepers'' in Louisiana, ''peelers'' in the Chesapeake Bay. For the cognoscenti, those terms denote the most succulent stage in the life of an Atlantic blue crab: when it is molting. And the molting season is upon us.

title: ATTACK ON QUOTAS OPPOSED BY CITIES
description: The Reagan Administration's effort to overturn affirmative action plans in 50 cities, states and counties is meeting widespread opposition.

title: DONNA KARAN STARS ON HER OWN
description: Pandemonium broke loose after the last three models appeared in their sultry black cashmere evening dresses with strapless tops or midriff cutouts. Everyone in the showroom was trying to touch, kiss and congratulate Donna Karan. Closely linked to the Anne Klein organization for all of her working life, the designer introduced the first collection under her own name yesterday. It was an immediate smash hit.

title: NEW CHALLENGE FOR TIGER AIR
description: Wayne Hoffman's vision of Tiger International Inc. was a diversified transportation company that offered air cargo, rail and trucking services all in one stop. But when that system ran into trouble, Mr. Hoffman, the carrier's chairman and chief executive, was forced to dismantle it.

title: STORER'S DIRECTORS BACK KOHLBERG'S BID
description: Directors of Storer Communications yesterday approved a definitive multibillion-dollar buyout offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, but the action did not stop rumblings that a new bidder would soon appear.

title: Northern New Jersey Lives in Fear of Flood
description: To the Editor:

title: O'NEILL IS FIRM ON AID TO REBELS AND SAYS EMBARGO IS PREMATURE
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that he remained opposed to any direct aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and that he believed President Reagan's trade embargo against Nicaragua was premature.

title: Journalists' Group Protests Treatment of Indian Reporter
description: The International Federation of Journalists cabled Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India today to protest what it called the continued harassment of a reporter for The Associated Press, Brahma Chellaney, and to ask for the free exercise of journalism in India.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $490,055.

title: SWEDISH HEART RECIPIENT THRIVES
description: The Swedish man who received an artificial heart a month ago may be recovering more steadily than previous recipients, largely because of his motivation, his doctors say.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. For the fourth time, Billy Martin was named Yankee manager, succeeding Yogi Berra, who was dismissed after the team lost its third straight game in Chicago. 2. The President, referring to the policies and actions of the Sandinistas, ordered an embargo on trade with Nicaragua. Under the terms of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, a President may invoke trade sanctions only under emergency conditions. 3. The Boston Pops. 4. After an exhaustive recount, Representative Frank McCloskey, Democrat of Indiana, was declared the winner in a bitterly contested race for a seat in the House of Representatives. He won by 4 votes out of more than 233,000 votes cast. 5. Declined. 6. Vietnamese rock 'n' roll music, played by a local band on the sidelines of the parade. 7. California, Texas and Florida. 8. Diet chocolate fudge soda. 9. Mark Twain. 10. According to a West German spokesman, President Reagan told Chancellor Helmut Kohl he ''regretted'' that some Americans believed in collective German guilt for the killing of millions in World War II. 11. Auroras, or the northern lights. 12. New York City will refinance virtually all its federally guaranteed debt next month, bringing to a close a chapter of the municipal fiscal crisis of the 1970's. 13. E. F. Hutton & Company. 14. The package is still open to amendment and it will have to be changed significantly to win final Senate approval. 15. Second. 16.

title: THE CITY
description: A summer crime crackdown designed to protect tourists, theatergoers and other visitors to the Times Square area began yesterday, the Police Department said.

title: ENDATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: PRESIDENT'S CEMETERY STOP WILL BE HELD TO 10 MINUTES
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan's visit to a German military cemetery on Sunday would be limited to 10 minutes and would include a wreath-laying ceremony.

title: A City Budget, by Candidate Koch
description: If you didn't already know Mayor Koch was running for re-election again, you could tell it quickly from his new $20 billion New York City budget. It's thick with spending proposals sure to please citizens concerned about education, housing, crime and clean streets - sure, that is, to please almost everyone. But politics aside, the Mayor has his municipal priorities straight.

title: Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. announced it had signed a memorandum of understanding with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation to enter into studies leading to a long-term supply contract for Northern Telecom's DMS-10 digital central office switching system. The studies are scheduled to conclude no later than Dec. 31.

title:
PATENTS;

Award for Patent Aide
description: Rene D. Tegtmeyer, Assistant Commissioner for Patents, will receive the Jefferson Medal from the New Jersey Patent Law Association next Friday at a dinner in Totowa, N.J. He is being honored for his contributions to intellectual law, relating to patents, trademarks and copyrights.

title: HAL LE ROY, DANCER IN CLUBS, MUSICALS AND SEVERAL MOVIES
description: Hal Le Roy, a tap dancer who played Harold Teen in the movies and was known for his boyish manner and nimble footwork, died Thursday at the Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center of complications following cardiac surgery. He was 71 years old and a resident of Maywood, N.J.

title: WEST READY TO PRESS SOVIET AT SESSION ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: The Western countries are preparing to press the Soviet Union anew on human rights at a formal review of progress on the issue, which was enshrined in a 35-nation agreement at Helsinki 10 years ago.

title: Herculean Tasks
description: To no one's surprise, John McEnroe and Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked tennis professionals, were named as the top-seeded players for next week's sixth annual Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills. But with the winners of 118 tournaments during 1984 eligible for the event, other big names were hard to find among the 16 seeded players.

title: ATLANTA GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SLICK VIDEOS SELLING FASHIONS
description: The title of the new three-minute fashion video for Anne Klein II clothes has not been decided. The top candidates are ''Threads of Our Lives'' and ''Dress to Thrill.''

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $51,221.

title: Hockey Title to Czechs
description: Jiri Sejba, a left wing who had scored only one goal in eight previous games, scored three goals today, leading Czechoslovakia to a 5-3 victory over Canada and its first world hockey championship since 1977. The Soviet Union, the world champion from 1978 to 1984, beat the United States, 10-3, to win the bronze medal.

title: Robert Gewald Is Wed To Nina Rao Cameron
description: Nina Rao Cameron, a special counsel for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and Robert M. Gewald, a concert and artists' manager, were married yesterday.

title: Jostling in the Pentagon
description: The four-year term of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., does not end until June 1986. But the maneuvering to succeed him has already begun, with the Navy the most active. The argument heard among sailors in the Pentagon: ''It's the Navy's turn.''

title: Winners of Six Awards Announced by P.E.N.
description: Winners of the P.E.N. awards, honoring excellence among American fiction writers and translators, were announced this week.

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Progress Is Reported On Channel Tunnel
description: Britain and France agreed today to hasten preparations for the long-awaited tunnel under the English Channel.

title: SPAN-AMERICA MEDICAL SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: WORDS TRAVEL FAST IN BONN AND OFTEN STRIKE A NERVE
description: This capital is small and efficient.

title: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $19,000 and an extraordinary charge of $216,000. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $1,457,000 and a tax credit of $2,543,000. e-After net from discontinued operations of $11,417,000 for the quarter and 9 months and a tax credit of $6,815,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRSTSOUTH FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Where Is U.S. Fighting The War on AIDS?
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CHIEF'S CROWN, SOME KEEN RIVALS
description: The 111th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs Saturday should start to get interesting just as the field heads into the far turn.

title: GERALD SHATTUCK
description: Gerald Shattuck, former president of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, which owned and operated the Schrafft's restaurants and confectioneries, died Thursday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $103,000. c-Net income after a capital gain of $613,000.

title: Santucci Opens Inquiry Into Death
description: The Queens District Attorney's office has begun an investigation of the death of a man who was restrained by the police in a body bag as they took him to Queens General Hospital for a medical examination, a spokesman for the office said yesterday.

title: Showboats Down Stallions, 38-24
description: Mike Kelley completed 21 of 28 passes for 211 yards and two touchdowns tonight as the Memphis Showboats defeated the Birmingham Stallions, 38-24.

title: HENRY SELLIN
description: Henry Sellin, former director of the Institute on Federal Taxation at New York University, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A FLEA MARKET BEGETS SOUND AND FURY ON WEST SIDE
description: Schoolyards have long been the legendary battlegrounds of children. But one schoolyard on Manhattan's West Side has become something of a battleground for adults.

title: STERLING PRESSES INFORMATICS LINK By Reuters
description: Sterling Software Inc. said its investment banker, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was ''highly confident'' of its ability to raise the funds needed to finance its proposed $26-a-share takeover of the Informatics General Corporation.

title: BISHOP'S VISIT IS SAD OCCASION AT A SCHOOL FOR FUTURE PRIESTS, SOON TO CLOSE
description: It is a tradition at Cathedral Preparatory Seminary that on the day each year that the Bishop of Brooklyn comes to say mass, he declares it a school holiday and everybody runs happily home.

title: Draft Deadline
description: Basketball players with remaining college eligibility have until midnight tonight to declare whether they will enter the National Basketball Association draft next month. On the eve of the deadline, the suspense was mounting at Oklahoma, where Wayman Tisdale, a junior who has been setting scoring records since his freshman season, was reportedly still trying to make up his mind, and at Creighton, where Benoit Benjamin, the 7-foot junior center, was doing the same.

title: FOR TV DEAL, MURDOCH WILL SEEK CITIZENSHIP
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian owner of a publishing empire in the United States, plans to seek United States citizenship to make himself eligible for substantial ownership in television broadcast properties in this country.

title: SEAGULL ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Ends Oil Tanker Restriction
description: The Transportation Department took steps today that would allow tankers built with Government subsidies to ship Alaskan crude oil, provided their owners repay the subsidies.

title:
PATENTS;

Fireproof Materials
description: Prof. Stephen I. Sallay of Indiana-Purdue University in Fort Wayne, who has worked for years on fireproof materials to be used in furniture and other articles, received his third patent this week on flame-retardant compositions. Besides proving antiflammatory, the materials covered by patent No. 4,514,326 have proved to be excellent insecticides against termites and beetles. An earlier patent by Professor Sallay on detecting and monitoring cancer has attracted attention.

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: RAYMOND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SYMPHONY: CHICAGOANS AND SOLTI IN NEW YORK
description: The third of the Chicago Symphony's concerts this spring, at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday - and Georg Solti's last - offered both the newest and the most conventional music of the five programs. There was the New York premiere of Witold Lutoslawski's Symphony No. 3 (1983), and Brahms's ''Haydn'' Variations and Beethoven's Symphony No. 5.

title: ALLIED STATEMENT BACKS U.S. POSITION IN TALKS ON ARMS
description: President Reagan won endorsement at the seven-nation economic conference today for what were termed the ''positive'' American proposals in arms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Guest Lecturer In Hollywood History
description: The last week of classes at Columbia University is often marked by the appearance of more students on the Low Plaza steps than in the classrooms. But most of the students in James P. Shenton's history course on ethnicity in America showed up for the final lecture.

title:
PATENTS;

A Remote Heart Rate Monitor
description: A HEART rate monitor that can be operated without baring the patient's skin was patented this week by two research scientists at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J. The remote microwave tests could be used to check the heart or respiration rates of pilots undergoing training, without disturbing them.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After a loss of $150,148 from discontinued operations.

title: Delay at Carbide Plant
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, scheduled to resume production today of methyl isocyanate, the chemical that killed more than 2,000 people in India, announced that it would delay the restarting for at least 24 hours because of ''conditions that don't conform to our standards.''

title: WESTWORLD COMMUNITY HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Keep the Job Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're in the black.'' - Paul L. Dickstein, New York City's budget director. [1:2.]

title: Six Are Missing at Sea
description: Three marines and three children who disappeared on a boating trip are ''lost at sea,'' according to the Coast Guard, which has called off its search.

title: Fluor-China Unit
description: The Fluor Corporation, the giant engineering company, said it had begun a joint operating venture with China that calls for the building of three large petrochemical plants in the Shanghai area as its first project. The venture agreement, Fluor's first such contract in China, was formalized in a signing ceremony in China this week. The new company will employ from 250 to 300 Chinese on the Shanghai projects, and up to 40 Fluor engineers, according to Thomas A. Howell, a senior vice president for Fluor.

title: S.B.A. Loans Back Issues
description: ANOTHER investment category has just become available to the individual investor, with the creation of pools of Small Business Administration securities. These Government-guaranteed securities based on S.B.A. loans are not only similar in some respects to Ginnie Maes - mortgage-backed securities issued by the Government National Mortgage Association - but also offer a slightly higher yield.

title: Futures Exchange Seat By Reuters
description: The New York Stock Exchange said a New York Futures Exchange seat sold yesterday for $5,000, unchanged from the last sale. It said the current bid was $5,000 and the current offer was $5,500.

title: TWINS HALTED AT 10 BY RIPKEN HOMER
description: Cal Ripken, playing in his club record-tying 463d consecutive game, smashed a two-run homer in the eighth inning to help the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-7 triumph tonight that ended the Minnesota Twins' winning streak at 10 games.

title: Letter: On 'Gas' Stations;   Divorce the Wells From the Pumps
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO MUSLIM GETS QADDAFI LOAN
description: Louis Farrakhan, leader of a Black Muslim sect based here, says he has accepted a $5 million loan from Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a man he has called ''a fellow struggler in the cause of liberation of our people.''

title: James McAndrews Jr. Weds Louise McClain
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan yesterday Louise Ann McClain, a daughter of Charlene Fertig McClain of Indianapolis and the late Lewis Hendricks McClain, was married to James Joseph McAndrews Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McAndrews of Madison, Conn. The Rev. Ambrose Eckinger performed the ceremony.

title: A.T.&T. Contract
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had won a five-year Federal Aviation Administration contract to build equipment for radio microwave link stations throughout the nation. The contract is part of the Administration's plan to upgrade the nation's air traffic control system. A.T.&T. said its value could approach $200 million.

title: SERVISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Guest Lecturer In Political Theory
description: The students at Marie Curie Junior High School applauded excitedly when Mayor Koch predicted that a woman would be elected to the highest post in city government.

title: Circle K Sale
description: The Circle K Corporation said it had sold 132 stores to the Vintage Companies' Lexington Capital Group Inc. division and had agreed to lease back the land and buildings for 15 years with three five-year options. Circle K said it had sold the land and buildings for approximately $39 million and would use the funds to reduce its bank debt and increase its general operating funds. Circle K operates 2,660 convenience stores in 23 states.

title: Kasten Risky-Product Bill Is a Bad Buy
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTHCARE USA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $497,000 for the quarter and $654,000 for the 6 months, and an estimated loss of $3,400,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income which includes income from discontinued operations of $359,000 for the quarter and $511,000 for the 6 months.

title: PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $1,422,000 for the latest quarter and $4,188,000 for year-earlier period.

title: U.S.-INDIA TECHNOLOGY ACCORD GAINS
description: The United States and India were described today as being close to an accord that would permit India to acquire highly advanced American technology that could sharply improve its military ability.

title: Colin McPhee Subject Of Documentary
description: ''Colin McPhee: The Lure of Asian Music'' - a documentary on the life of the American composer and musicologist - will receive its world premiere Monday, May 13, at 6:30 P.M. at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue at 70th Street. The film, directed by Michael Blackwood, is based on Mr. McPhee's autobiography, ''A House in Bali,'' and was made in the United States, Bali, Germany and England; it includes excerpts from Mr. McPhee's films of Balinese culture in the 1930's. Tickets are $6; information: 288-6400, extensions 280 or 286.

title: POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Caledonia Curfew Ends
description: The 16-week-old curfew in New Caledonia was suspended today, the French High Commission announced. Noting that the curfew had been suspended and not lifted, it said the High Commissioner, Edgard Pisani, acted because the French Pacific island territory was calm. The curfew was imposed Jan. 12 after at least 22 people had been killed in violence since November, when militants stepped up their demands for independence.

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STEPHAN'S ODYSSEY: One Style
description: Sire: Danzig (Northern Dancer-Pas de Nom) Dam: Kennelot (Gallant Man-Queen Sucree) Owner-Breeder: Henryk de Kwiatkowski Trainer: Woody Stephens Jockey: Laffit Pincay <td

title: IOWA ELECTRIC LIGHT & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AWAITING LEADERS:
description: Participants in the economic conference waiting for government leaders to arrive yesterday at Palais Schaumburg in Bonn. From left: Finance Minister Michael Wilson of Canada; Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Foreign Secretary; an unidentified official; Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita, Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe and Trade Minister Keijiro Murata, all of Japan.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATES CLIMB IN NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY
description: The unemployment rates for New York City, New York State and New Jersey increased slightly in April as the job growth that has accompanied the economic recovery slowed, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $9,646,036 from discontinued operations and a gain of $646,366 on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Net income which is after a loss of $3,200,976 from discontinued operations.

title: STANWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $494,000 from the sale of its cellular radio interests in Charlotte, N.C., and Greenville-Spartanburg, S.C.

title: WASHINGTON, RETALIATING, OUSTS 4
description: The Government today ordered the expulsion of two United States diplomats who the police said had taken part in an illegal May Day demonstration in Cracow. [The United States retaliated by ordering four Polish diplomats to leave the country. A State Department official said the action was a reflection of ''grave displeasure'' with the ''unjustified expulsion of our diplomats but also with the Polish Government's bald fabrication of a story to justify their expulsion.''] The action by Poland's Foreign Ministry came after Government and party newspapers published front-page condemnations of the two diplomats for ''brutally exploiting their diplomatic status.''

title: PERU'S WALL STREET: PALTRY PROFIT BUT NO OVERHEAD
description: At the corner of Union Street and the Plaza de San Martin, where Peru's underground economy comes bubbling to the surface, Isabel Prado stands all day with her back to the traffic selling cigarettes - one at a time.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $247,000 from the sale of discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $139,000 from discontinued operations of $139,000.

title: E.P.A. INQUIRY DRAGS ON
description: When Edward C. Schmults agreed to meet with investigators for the House Judiciary Committee in his Connecticut office last year, he was not expecting the nine hours of questioning they had prepared.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington on Thursday about a report of the Chemical Warfare Review Commission misstated the fee paid by the commission to a public relations man, Peter Hannaford, and a lobbyist, John A. C. Gibson. It was $260 a day.

title: FIVE CONCERNS END JOINT ROLE IN STEEL TALKS
description: Five major steel companies have decided to end coordinated bargaining with the United Steelworkers of America, an approach that began nearly 30 years ago.

title: A New View of the Events of That First Easter
description: To the Editor:

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: French Offer Tenneco Aid
description: The French Finance Ministry said today that it would pay close to $4 million in subsidies if Tenneco Inc. takes over the International Harvester Company's French subsidiary, International Harvester France.

title: Bargain Hunting Sends Dow Up 4.97, to 1,247.24
description: Bargain hunting saved the day yesterday on Wall Street, as the stock market rose moderately to salvage the final day of the week.

title: POP: AL COBB'S BIG BAND
description: Al Cobbs's 18-piece band, the C & J Big Band, which has been playing every week for more than a year at Small's Paradise in Harlem, moved to midtown Thursday night to start a series of weekly performances at Frejya, a large ballroom and restaurant at 43d Street and Broadway.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF AUSTIN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest 9 months include a gain of $202,000 from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock dividend.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Burlington Northern Inc., Seattle, said a class action suit had been filed against its Burlington Northern Railroad Co. unit by a bondholder seeking to block the unit's purchase of several issues of outstanding bonds.

title: SUTCLIFFE THWARTED BY PADRES AGAIN
description: In clear memory was the final game of the 1984 championship series almost seven months ago, the game in which the San Diego Padres rallied to beat Rick Sutcliffe and the Chicago Cubs, 6-3, to capture the National League pennant.

title: MACK TRUCKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $568,000. c-Includes a tax benefit of $5,158,000.

title: LEADERS SEEKING ACCORD ON TRADE
description: President Reagan and the leaders of six major industrial allies tried today to reach a compromise that would enable a round of global trade negotiations to begin early next year.

title: CBS Drops Suit Against Boesky
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it had dropped its lawsuit against Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street arbitrager. As part of the settlement, CBS said, Mr. Boesky has agreed not to increase his stake in the company beyond 4.3 percent, the level he is believed to own now, and not to take part, directly or indirectly, in any proxy fight or attempt to take over CBS for the next two years.

title: Safety Patrol
description: Armed with batteries, wires and smoke detectors, 400 youngsters have been visiting the homes of 1,500 elderly people in sections of Queens and the Bronx.

title: LABOR DEPT. STAFF GREETS NEW CHIEF
description: Bill Brock, the new Secretary of Labor, received an emotional welcome today from department employees who applauded him noisily, laughed at his jokes and hoisted a banner reading ''A New Pride.''

title: Bridge;   End-Game Defenders Need A Renewal of Concentration
description: Defenders have plenty to think about in the early stages of the play, but the need for thought diminishes along with the number of cards remaining.

title: WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss includes an extraordinary gain of $4 million from the termination of a pension plan.

title: NEW ZEALAND RUGBY PROTEST
description: More than than 60,000 people demonstrated today in the cities and towns of New Zealand against the national rugby team's proposed tour of South Africa.

title: CORRECTION
description: A movie review of ''Little Treasure'' on Wednesday misidentified its distributor. It is Tristar Pictures, owned in part by Columbia Pictures Industries, which is a subsidiary of the Coca-Cola Company.

title: Salmonella Outbreak Is Tracked to Chicago
description: A report investigating whether raw and pasteurized milk were inadvertently mixed at a suburban Chicago dairy through an illegal valve, causing a six-state salmonella outbreak, is expected in a few days, says Illinois' public health chief.

title: LEADING SOVIET FILM MAKER
description: Sergei Yutkevich, one of the leading Soviet film makers, died April 23 in Moscow, according to Soviet newspapers. He was 80 years old.

title: Temple Seeks To Buy Insurer
description: Temple-Inland Inc., a Diboll, Tex.-based diversified paper products company with interests in financial services, said that it was seeking a definitive agreement to buy the National Fidelity Life Insurance Corporation for about $82 million.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN OF MIAMI, FLA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $492,000 from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock dividend. c-Net income.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL SHARPLY
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday, after the Commerce Department announced employment data for April that suggested the economy was not rebounding quickly from the weak 1.3 percent growth of the first quarter.

title: INFORMATION RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRANSITRON ELECTRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $11,782,000 from the sale of a division and a $4 million pre-tax charge for a reserve on the disposition of property and equipment.

title: KOCH OFFERS PLAN FOR 10% INCREASE IN CITY'S SPENDING
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a $20 billion budget for the next fiscal year that increases spending by 10 percent, adds more than 10,000 city workers and demonstrates, the Mayor proclaimed, that ''times are better.''

title: TEXT OF THE DECLARATION ON MEETING IN BONN
description: Following is the text of the ''Political Declaration on the 40th Anniversary of the End of the Second World War'' made public today at the seven-nation economic conference:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A BIT OF BLIGHTY The British tend to get lost among other ethnics in our polyglot city, but they are here and they, too, have quaint customs that they carry on in the New World. Tomorrow afternoon, one English tradition, not quite an ethnic festival, will be visible from the shores of the Hudson River, off the Upper West Side.

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income.

title: SENATE APPROVES CUTS IN SPENDING ON HEALTH CARE
description: The Senate voted today to cut the Medicare and Medicaid health care programs by $17.5 billion over three years, a reduction that is slightly smaller than proposed in the White House budget package. The vote was 93 to 6. The Senate is working on a package of spending reductions aimed at shrinking projected Government deficits by more than $50 billion in 1986 and nearly $300 billion over three years. Senators will continue to vote next week on amendments to a 1986 budget that is sponsored by the White House and the Senate's Republican leaders.

title: She Has Many Roles In the Theater
description: Susan Tammany is an usher at the New York State Theater. On Tuesday night, Peter Martins's production of ''La Sylphide'' will open at the Brooklyn Academy of Music - with sets and costumes by Susan Tammany.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. Steve Balboni, a former Yankee, had a strong April with Kansas City, batting .269 with 5 home runs and 14 runs batted in, including a grand slam on the final day of the month. (Television - SportsChannel, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. Roger McDowell, 2-0 in relief for the Mets, makes his second start of the season, against Jay Tibbs, who is 0-4. (Television - Channel 4, 1:20 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:15 P.M ) Braves vs. Montreal Expos, at Atlanta (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Basketball Utah Jazz vs. Denver Nuggets, at Salt Lake City. Game Three of the Western Conference semifinals, with the Nuggets ahead by 2-0. (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.) Golf William D. Richardson Memorial Invitational, at the Seawane Club, Hewlett, L.I., semifinal and final rounds of match play, 8:30 A.M. MONY Tournament of Champions and MONY Senior Tourney of Champions, at La Costa, Calif. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Moss Creek Women's Invitational,at Hilton Head Island, S.C., third round. Hockey Oilers vs. Chicago Black Hawks, at Edmonton, Alberta. The defending Stanley Cup champions open defense of their Campbell Conference championship. (Television - USA Network, 8 P.M.) Tennis Shearson Lehman Brothers Pro Celebrity Tournament, preliminary to Tournament of Champions, at West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., opening day. Thoroughbred Racing Churchill Downs.

title: GAS DEREGULATION'S IMPACT
description: The Jan. 1 deregulation of natural gas prices, which some observers predicted would cause price increases, has instead driven gas prices down, intensified competititon among gas transmission companies and contributed to a frenetic spate of takeover rumors and merger agreements in the once-staid pipeline industry.

title: Kean Asks Return Of Murder Suspect
description: Governor Kean signed legal papers today asking for the extradition of a man held in Virginia, so that the suspect can stand trial in New Jersey on charges of murdering a state trooper.

title: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: A brief report by The Associated Press on Wednesday about a concert at Carnegie Hall May 31 to aid relief efforts in Africa gave an incorrect telephone number for tickets. It is 247-7800.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue figures represent gross billings.

title: Women, Children and Cruel Thrift
description: In 1972 Congress created a food program called WIC, for Women/Infants/Children, to improve the diet of poor pregnant and nursing women and young children certified by physicians to be at nutritional risk. The worst thing that's ever been said about WIC is that it is unable to include all those who need its help. If the Administration is sincere about maintaining a social safety net, then it would have to include poor, malnourished mothers and babies.

title: Malpractice 'Crisis' Has a Bright Side
description: To the Editor:

title: IN POETRY CLASS, PUPILS GO BEYOND 'ROSES ARE RED'
description: ''She is always warm like cotton. She is as smart as a computer. Sometimes as mean as a lion.'' These were images Betty Toni, a fifth grader at Public School 192 in upper Manhattan, used in her poem ''My Grandmother.''

title: AIR MIDWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sale by Phillips
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said that it was interested in selling its oil and gas operations in the Netherlands section of the North Sea in addition to its coal and geothermal operations. The company has said that it wants to sell about $2 billion in assets this year to reduce the debt it acquired as a result of a recapitalization after fighting off takeover attempts by Carl C. Ichan, the New York financier, and T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman. A Phillips spokesman said the North Sea operations ''are not substantial, and we are not the operators and we have no employees there.''

title: Lakers 130 Trail Blazers 126
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar hit four free throws in the last 48 seconds to help Los Angeles stave off a late Portland rush.

title: GIANTS' HENDERSON 'BLESSED' TO BE HERE
description: Last Feb. 17, when Tracy Henderson, a 20-year-old wide receiver at Iowa State, arrived at the team's weight room, an assistant coach told him that Jim Criner, the head coach, wanted to talk to him. The talk was brief. Criner dismissed Henderson from the team for what the coach said were ''disciplinary reasons.''

title: MIGLIORE'S FIRST DERBY
description: When things were at their worst for Richard Migliore, he used to reassure people by saying: ''Hey, I'm only 18. I'm going to be doing this for a long, long time, and there will be better years ahead.''

title: Inconvenience vs. Armenians
description: President Reagan's failure to grasp the power of remembrance has gotten him into fresh trouble. He now asks Congress to defeat a joint resolution that would designate next April 24 as a day of remembrance honoring Armenian victims of a genocidal massacre and dispersion in 1915.

title: South African Farmers Challenge Government
description: Three thousand discontented white farmers resolved today to withhold corn crops from South African Government buyers for one week to press demands for higher official prices.

title: APRIL 21-30 CAR SALES UP BY 1.5%
description: Sales of new American-made cars rose 1.5 percent in the April 21-30 selling period, according to a compilation of reports issued today by the manufacturers.

title: RADIO TAKES A FANCY TO COMPACT DISKS
description: Driving to work one day two years ago, Kenneth Haas switched on his car's radio to WCLV-FM, the major classical station in Cleveland. The ''Spring'' concerto from Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' was playing, a piece Mr. Haas had listened to hundreds of times.

title: LET US NOW PRAISE UNFAMOUS MEN
description: Let's push aside the cast of reputable - and conventional - characters that clutter the podiums each year on Law Day, sermonizing on 128.8,0,156.4,2,156.4,0,1 56.4,2>the principles of order that, we are told, are the glue of society. Instead, we should reserve space on this minor, but important, national holiday for the unsung heroes - society's soreheads.

title: Wheelchair-Bound Man Held in Texas Shooting
description: The police said today that a wheelchair-bound man robbed a hamburger stand, rolled to a discount store parking lot and shot a woman, then took two hostages and forced them to hail a taxi for him.

title: Stockmans Have Daughter
description: David A. Stockman, President Reagan's budget director, became a father today. Mr. Stockman's wife, Jennifer, gave birth to a six-pound, six-ounce girl at Washington's Sibley Hospital. The baby, the Stockmans' first, was named Rachel Lauren. Mr. Stockman's office reported that both mother and baby were doing well.

title: BIO-RESPONSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IMMUNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fairleigh Coach Signed
description: Tom Green, the basketball coach at Fairleigh Dickinson, was rewarded with a three-year contract extension yesterday for having led the Knights to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for the first time. Fairleigh Dickinson posted a 21-10 record, its best ever, and won the E.C.A.C. Metro Conference championship last season.

title: VANDAL SLASHES 8 BIG PAINTINGS AT ALBANY MALL
description: A man who ran a nearby shoeshine stand slashed and scrawled slogans before dawn today on some of the huge modern paintings in the concourse of the mall next to the State Capitol, the police said.

title: William G. Lindner, President Of Transport Workers Union
description: William G. Lindner, international president of the Transport Workers Union, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the union's headquarters in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Levittown, L.I.

title: CORRECTION
