description: Because of ''a hole in my glove,'' Roger Wilkins misidentified a fired New York Yankees manager in his article yesterday. The manager was Bob Lemon. Mr. Wilkins sends himself and his editor (a Dodger fan) to the showers.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: An Ethiopian official has been arrested for setting fire to shelters at an emergency relief camp after the forced evacuation of famine victims from the camp, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter include a provision of $827,000 for losses incurred by Air Florida Inc. doing business as Midway Express.

title: THE KOCH BUDGET: WILL IT CAUSE FUTURE PROBLEMS?
description: Mayor Koch called it the second ''good news budget'' in a row - one even more generous than last year's. He promised that ''the best is yet to be.'' He declared that ''times are better.''

title: 2 MORE DOCTORS TESTIFY AT VON BULOW'S TRIAL
description: Two doctors added their testimony today to that of a colleague who said Martha von Bulow was bruised when she was taken to the Newport Hospital on Dec. 20, 1980, in a coma from which doctors say she will never emerge.

title: 76ERS DEFEAT BUCKS AND TAKE 3-0 LEAD
description: Milwaukee emerged from a deep hole against a complacent Philadelphia 76ers team, but the Bucks' splendid recovery fell short tonight and they were left one game from being swept from the Eastern Conference playoffs.

title: YOU, TOO, CAN STRENGTHEN ENGLISH, AND WRITE GOOD
description: ''Of all the books on language being published now, very few, it seems to me, address the real issue, which is not whether it's O.K. to use 'hopefully' at the beginning of a sentence, but whether our language has any life left in it, any flavor or idiosyncrasy.'' - Anatole Broyard The New York Times Book Review Everyone knows what idiosyncrasy in a language means: irregular verbs. Certainly, their idiosyncrasy is important to the language. Why else would irregular verbs be called strong and regular verbs weak?

title: TIME ENERGY SYSTEMS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-After a charge of $817,519, or 14 cents a share, representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change as to how accrued interest is recorded. The year-ago figures have not been restated to reflect the accounting charge.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $203,000 form a patent settlement. c-Net loss.

title: BROKERS DENY CHECK ABUSES
description: Major brokerage houses denied yesterday that they had ever illegally managed their funds so as to overdraw bank accounts. But some industry analysts said the practice might not have been confined to E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. NAMES TEACHERS VYING FOR SPACE VOYAGE
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and an educational group today announced the names of 112 candidates in a search for a teacher to fly on a space shuttle mission in early 1986.

title: PRAIRIE OIL ROYALTIES COMPANY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-earlier net income was restated. The company is also listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: K-TRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Happy Losers
description: Art Berglund, general manager of the United States national hockey team, watched his charges lose by 10-3 to the Soviet Union in Prague yesterday, a result that gave the Russians the bronze medal in the world championship tournament. ''They played for pride and took command right away,'' said Berglund, comparing the drubbers and the drubbees, ''while we looked as if we were happy with our fourth-place finish.''

title: Mobil Debit Cards By The Associated Press
description: The Mobil Corporation said its debit card sales system for gasoline will more than triple by the fall of 1986 in an expansion to 3,600 service stations in 25 states. Unlike credit card transactions, in which a customer charges a purchase and is billed later, a debit card transaction immediately deducts the payment from the customer's bank account through a computerized transaction. Mobil said it was investing $30 million to develop and design its electronic card payment-processing system, which is already operating at more than 1,000 stations.

title: NERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ARMY PLANS FOR 'WHAT IF' LATIN WAR
description: The Army has begun a study to determine the military and civic actions that would be necessary if American troops were ordered into a hostile situation in Central America, officers said today.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: A Little Lightness
description: Even as bitter an episode as the contested Indiana House election produces some lighter moments. When angry Republicans marched out of the House chamber Wednesday after failing to block the seating of the Democratic candidate, they were joined by a member of the opposition, Representative William Clay of Missouri, who explained to his fellow Democrats, ''I never could resist a demonstration.''

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON - Extended for three years the contract of Tom Green, basketball coach.

title: JEZEBEL STANDS OUT IN NEW YORK'S PARADE OF BOATS
description: It is hard to make an impression in New York with a boat.

title: JAZZ: DIDIER LOCKWOOD PLAYS
description: Didier Lockwood, a French jazz violinist who came to the United States two months ago trailing an impressive array of achievements (twice named European Jazz Musician of the Year, two records selected as Record of the Year in Europe, 150 concerts in Europe last year) is leading a trio at Lush Life (Bleecker and Thompson Streets) through tomorrow with two American musicians, the pianist Bill O'Connell and the bassist Harvie Swartz.

title: SUSPECT IS SLAIN DURING STRUGGLE WITH AN OFFICER
description: A 33-year-old man was shot and killed yesterday in New Brunswick, N.J., in a struggle with a police officer who was trying to arrest him for running a red light and striking another officer and a pedestrian with a car, the authorities said.

title: Silcorp Purchase
description: Silcorp Ltd. said it had acquired 21 Pump 'n Pantry convenience stores in Michigan for undisclosed terms.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE COLLECTS DATA ON SOURCE OF DISTANT COSMIC RADIATION
description: Preoccupied as they are with experiments aimed at finding out more about some of the earth's mysteries, the astronauts in the space shuttle Challenger today also reported receiving data on an area that may be 200 million billion miles away.

title: J. QUINCY HUNSICKER 3d
description: J. Quincy Hunsicker 3d, a senior partner of the New York law firm of Kelley Drye & Warren, died Wednesday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 78 years old. Mr. Hunsicker, who specialized in trusts, estates and charitable foundations, had been with the firm and its predecessors since 1932.

title: CABARET: MEG MACKAY SINGS
description: Meg Mackay, the Kansas-born singer and comedienne who has become a popular figure in the San Francisco cabaret and theater worlds, moves boldly between pop, jazz, opera and comedy. Miss Mackay, who made her New York club debut on Wednesday at Don't Tell Mama (343 West 46th Street), is a vivacious redhead with formal vocal training that she displays in an unspectacular but assured excerpt from ''Carmen.''

title: Illinois Doctor Guilty Of Poisoning Co-workers
description: A 30-year-old doctor was convicted today of lacing his co-workers' snacks with arsenic.

title: GALVESTON HOUSTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHAMBER: VERDEHR TRIO PERFORMS AT TULLY HALL
description: The Verdehr Trio, an estimable ensemble made up of Walter Verdehr, violinist; his wife, Elsa Ludewig-Verdehr, clarinetist, and Gary Kirkpatrick, pianist, gave a rewarding concert at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

title: ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $14,930,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $731,000 for the quarter and $1,302,000 for the 9 months.

title: POP: SONGS BY CHRIS CONNOR
description: While Chris Connor's style of jazz singing has been identified more closely with sad cafe ballads than with uptempo swing, the singer, who is in splendid voice at age 57, can be a powerful jazz belter. And in her current engagement at Freddy's Supper Club (308 East 49th Street), she sings with a booming confidence and warmth that give even sad-hearted songs a lift of energy.

title:
PATENTS;

Regulating Calcium
description: University Patents also received this week patent No. 4,514,331 for an invention made by Emil T. Kaiser and Gregory Moe at Rockefeller University in New York on production of artificial calcitonin, a hormone that regulates the amount of calcium in the blood. It is expected to be helpful in treatment of various diseases, including bone cancer. University Patents handles patent rights for a number of research centers around the country.

title: INSTITUTIONAL NETWORKS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $138,000. c-Net loss.

title: WALCO NATL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: LABELS that indicate how well a tire will wear are once again required on all new tires, making comparisons of brands possible.

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $164,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $3,458,000 on the sale of assets of the serologicals unit. c-Net loss which is after income of $1,458,000 from discontinued operations.

title: No Curbs, Honduras Says
description: Foreign Minister Edgardo Paz Barnica, who headed the Honduran delegation here this week, says his country does not plan to restrict the activities of anti-Sandinista rebels operating from camps on the border with Nicaragua.

title: COSMO COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Dollar Climbs Sharply While Gold Retreats By The Associated Press
description: The dollar staged a powerful advance in light trading yesterday, extending a rally in which it now has regained more than half the ground lost in a steep selloff earlier this year.

title: World Medical Group Cancels Plan to Meet in South Africa
description: The World Medical Association says it is canceling plans to hold its annual assembly in South Africa.

title: Navy Commander Guilty Of Lying About Affair
description: A court-martial today found Comdr. James Wyatt 3d guilty of violating the Navy's ''officer and gentleman'' code of conduct by living with an unmarried junior officer and lying to a superior officer about it.

title: Jersey's Advocate Approved as Judge
description: The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Joseph H. Rodriguez as a United States District judge, giving New Jersey its first Hispanic Federal judge and ending an eight-month delay.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS SAID TO GET MISSILES
description: Nicaraguan anti-Government guerrillas have recently acquired surface-to-air missiles and have moved out from their main camp on the Honduran border, according to two Western diplomats and a rebel official here.

title: Low Morale Seen At Salem A-Plant
description: Chronic mechanical failures and losses of power at the Salem nuclear plant have created ''low morale'' among employees, a spokesman for the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Godspeed Returns to Sea
description: The Godspeed, a replica 17th-century sailing ship retracing the route taken in 1607 to Jamestown, Va., returned to sea today after rough English Channel waters forced her ashore for 24 hours.

title: AVM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $72,596, or 5 cents, from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $87,869 from discontinued operations.

title: MODULAR COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NIPPON CARGO: A 7-YEAR WAIT
description: For Yoshiyuki Shibuya, the director and vice president in North America of Nippon Cargo Airlines, last week's decision by the Reagan Administration to allow his company to begin flying between the United States and Japan ended years of agonizing - and costly - waiting.

title: CHIEFTAIN DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CONCERT: NATIONAL CHORALE
description: The National Chorale's Wednesday evening program of American vocal music at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street) was a diverting affair. Under the direction of Martin Josman, this small, centered chorus sang a wide variety of material - early American Moravian music, Southern folk hymns, compositions by Conrad Susa, Irving Fine, Randall Thompson, Dominick Argento and Samuel Barber, and a concluding selection of show tunes by Leonard Bernstein.

title: HEALTH EXTENSION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jersey Man Gets Life for 2d Murder
description: The jury that earlier convicted a Morristown man of abducting and murdering a Morris County woman has sentenced him to life in prison with eligibility for parole in 30 years.

title: Cattle Prices Lead Drop In Livestock and Meats By The Associated Press
description: Cattle futures led a broad selloff in livestock and meat prices yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as traders worried about abundant supplies.

title: Militias Clash in Beirut; Army Units Fight Druse
description: Militias traded mortar and rocket fire in Beirut today as Christian units of the Lebanese Army fought a two-hour tank and artillery battle with Druse fighters in the hills east of the city.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, MAY 4, 1985

title: Judge Sets Bevill Sale
description: A Federal judge agreed yesterday to sell the discount brokerage business of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., the New Jersey-based securities dealer that was put into receivership last month, to Muriel Siebert & Company. The Siebert firm had agreed to the purchase on Wednesday.

title: HOUSING-AID DEBATE FOCUSES ON QUESTION OF U.S. DUTY TO POOR
description: Two decades ago the Government calculated that it could provide adequate housing for the nation's poor with six million new units in 10 years. Since then it has spent well over $100 billion on housing programs that now help more than 15 million people, yet decent housing is still beyond the means of seven million households.

title: Family Settles Suit In Downing of Jet
description: The family of a Dunellen man who was killed when a Korean Air Lines plane was shot down by a Soviet jet fighter has reached a settlement with the airline, an attorney said today.

title: NURSES GET A RAW DEAL
description: A popular misconception about nurses is that if they were smart enough they would be doctors. Medicine is a fine profession, and there are many admirable physicians around, a few of them former nurses. But most nurses, if you can believe it, would rather be nurses.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ohio Bailout Plan Called Insufficient
description: The state may have to put up as much as $34 million more to help bail out the failed Home State Savings Bank, according to the Chemical Bank, which wants to buy it.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This smile signals the start of another new term. Explain. 2. President Reagan declared a state of national emergency to deal with what he called ''an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States.'' To what was he referring and what was the reason for the declaration? 3. An orchestra that holds two world's records, for the largest audience at a classical music concert (400,000 people) and for the most recordings sold (50 million), celebrated its 100th year. What orchestra is it? 4. In a dramatic demonstration of partisan animosity, Republican Congressman marched out of the House chamber to protest a close call. What was at issue? 5. The number of drivers and passengers killed in motor vehicle accidents in New York State (declined/ rose/stayed basically unchanged) in the first three months after the state required the wearing of seat belts, according to the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. 6. As soldiers paraded in Ho Chi Minh City to mark the 10th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, the air was filled with sounds of a distinctly unmartial kind. What kind of music was being played? 7. Half the population growth in the nation since the 1960 census has occurred in just three states - one in the West, one in the Southwest, and one in the South.

title: MELLON RESIGNS AS NATIONAL GALLERY CHAIRMAN
description: Paul Mellon, whose patronage and administrative leadership for almost half a century was pivotal in making the National Gallery of Art in Washington one of the world's leading art institutions, resigned yesterday as a trustee and chairman of the board. The announcement was made following a meeting of the board.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: U.S. TO STUDY IF OTHERS HAD OVERDRAFT SCHEMES
description: A senior official at the Justice Department said today that the department would seek to determine whether other companies, including those in the financial sector, might be engaged in giant check overdraft schemes similar to the one to which E.F. Hutton & Company pleaded guilty on Thursday.

title: JOHNSON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter include the operations of the Maryland Music Inc. unit from Jan. 4, its date of acquisition.

title: Fresh Air, Crickets and Cows
description: ''The time I pack is the time I cry,'' said one youngster as he left his Friendly Town to head home to the city. ''Backstroke, sidestroke, swim in deep water, float in deep water, swim from a far distance.

title: FRANCES TOLER MORRIS BECOMES BRIDE OF ROBERT A. CONSTABLE IN HONOLULU
description: Frances Toler Morris, a vice president of the capital markets division of Paine Webber Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Anthony Constable, a leasing representative for Jones Lang Wootten, a real-estate company in New York. The Congregational ceremony was performed at the Kawaiahao Church in Honolulu by the Rev. William Kaina and the Rev. Felix Joffrian, the bridegroom's brother-in-law.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THESE LATTER DAYS. By Laura Kalpakian. (Times Books, $16.95.) The days of the title are those leading to the millennium - a time of ultimate revelation awaited with fervor by the saints of the Mormon Church.

title: NEW INQUIRY SET ON LICENSE 'DEALS'
description: THE State Commission of Investigation will examine one of New Jersey's traditional sources of patronage, the awarding of motor-vehicle agency contracts, and indications are that this time help is on the way for the harried motorist.

title: SUSAN PUCCILLO MARRIES
description: The marriage of Susan Puccillo, a daughter of Frances Puccillo of Yonkers and Neilan Puccillo of Highland, N.Y., to John D. Vaughan took place yesterday in the chapel at Fordham University in the Bronx. The Rev. Stanley O'Konsky performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Vaughan of Scarsdale, N.Y. His father is a partner in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: The ground is dry; water new trees, shrubs, perennials and vegetable seedlings; mulch cultivated soil to conserve moisture. . . . Apply crabgrass preemergence herbicides to the lawn. . . Use a half-moon edger to define borders and garden areas. Insect Problem Black vine weevil may sound innocuous, but this is the name of one of the most serious insect problems gardeners tackle. The name vine weevil goes back to Europe where the insect, a beetle, was identified as the culprit that attacked grapevines in France and Germany.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch on April 21 from Pristina, Yugoslavia, about ethnic Albanians in Yugoslavia misstated the Communist League's position on the political status of Kosovo Province. The party denounced appeals for full republic status for the province.

title: Reagan Voices Desire For Spin on Autobahn
description: President Reagan, in a chat with a West German reporter, said he would like to get behind the wheel of a car and race down an autobahn, or superhighway, a Hamburg newspaper reported today.

title: Sunken Civil War Ship Found in Florida River
description: The wreck of a 173-foot Civil War troop ship has been found at the bottom of the St. John's River by a Jacksonville dentist.

title: 'PUBLIC' VS. 'PRIVATE' DREDGING DEBATED
description: WHEN is a homeowner part of the public and when does he count among ''private interests?''

title: YALE ADDING KENT STATE WEAPONS TO ARCHIVES
description: Yale University is about to receive two weapons used in the shootings that killed four antiwar protesters at Kent State University in Ohio 15 years ago.

title: GAS LEAKS FOUND INSIDE AMBULANCES
description: STATE Health Department tests of 690 of the 1,500 ambulances in use in New Jersey found that 185, or nearly 27 percent, were leaking dangerous amounts of carbon monoxide into their interiors.

title: THE SURPLUS IN REVENUES SURPASSESS EXPECTATIONS
description: FOR the state government last week, the money was coming in almost as fast as legislators could find ways to give it back to the taxpayers.

title: MARY E. STOCKTON AND FRANK LUPO, ARCHITECTS, MARRY
description: Mary Evelyn Stockton of New York, a daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Robert Sayre Stockton of Chesterland, Ohio, was married yesterday to Frank Michael Lupo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Lupo of Pozzallo, Sicily. The Rev. Robert K. Massie Jr., assisted by the Rev. Kenneth B. Swanson, performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: YUGOSLAVIA OFFERS FINANCING FOR A FACTORY UPSTATE
description: The Yugoslav Government has offered to provide $50 million in credit for a project to convert a portion of a nearly abandoned Bethlehem Steel plant in nearby Lackawanna, N.Y., to an aluminum mill, according to local authorities. The mill would employ as many as 2,000 people.

title: ZUCKERMAN UNDER SURVEILLANCE: FROM 'THE PRAGUE ORGY'
description: Following is a brief excerpt from ''The Prague Orgy,'' the novella-length epilogue to Philip Roth's Zuckerman trilogy (''The Ghost Writer,'' ''Zuckerman Unbound'' and ''The Anatomy Lesson''). The trilogy and epilogue will be published in one volume by Farrar, Straus & Giroux in June under the title ''Zuckerman Bound.''

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Nearly a decade and a half has passed since the opening of ''Sunday Bloody Sunday'' with its story of a middle-aged London doctor (Peter Finch) and a divorced woman (Glenda Jackson) who are having affairs with the same young artist (Murray Head). Yet, nothing seems to have undermined its validity as a study of the travails of adult love in the latter 20th century.

title: SURVIVORS OF VIETNAM LOOK BACK
description: For Lindsey Parker, it was an antidote to loneliness. For Jose Baez, it was a chance to feel pride. And for Michael Applewhaite, it was a time for feeling good - because he returned safely from Vietnam.

title: TISDALE AND BENJAMIN DECLARE FOR N.B.A. DRAFT
description: Wayman Tisdale of Oklahoma and Benoit Benjamin of Creighton, outstanding college junior basketball players, yesterday said they will make themselves eligible for the upcoming National Basketball Association's draft.

title: 24 Die in Attack By Sri Lanka Rebels
description: At least 24 people were killed today in an attack by Tamil guerrillas on a naval base 12 miles north of Jaffna, the major city of Sri Lanka's troubled Northern Province, officials said.

title: LAURIE CONNELL WED
description: Laurie Mulford Connell, the daughter of Philip Graham Connell Jr. of the Village of Golf, Fla., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Laura Bonnefond Connell, was married yesterday to Edward Kerschner 3d, a son of the late Mr. Kerschner Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Deborah Cassidy Kerschner. The Rev. Kenneth A. Wolfe Jr. performed the ceremony at Episcopal Christ Church Ithan in Villanova, Pa.

title: TOPICS
description: I DASH out to the side of the house to get to the pussywillows before the gray, tender, velvet globes become fuzzy yellow balls of premature green leaves.

title: TESTIMONY CHALLENGES CLERICS IN SUICIDE CASE
description: Witnesses for a couple who are suing a fundamentalist church over their son's death have testified that church counselors neglected their duty when they failed to warn the young man's doctors and family about his suicidal tendency.

title: JERSEYAN, 89, TELLS OF HORROR ON THE LUSITANIA
description: William McMillan Adams, now nearly 90 years old, says he still hates to talk about the catastrophic day 70 years ago.

title: LACROSSE PLAYERS SEEK COMPETITION AND CAMARADERIE, NOT GOLD OR GLORY
description: Sometimes Vinnie Sombrotto dreams about what might have happened if he had stuck with baseball or football. Perhaps he would be a slugger like Eddie Murray of the Baltimore Orioles or a quarterback like Doug Flutie of the New Jersey Generals, making millions of dollars in a professional sport.

title: Ring Lardner's Big Book
description: To the Editor:

title: VERONICA LEVY OBERMAYER TO BE WED
description: Veronica Levy Obermayer, a television anchor and reporter at KAMR-TV, the NBC affiliate in Amarillo, Tex., and Douglas Clay Atnipp, a member of the graduating class at the Texas Tech University Law School, plan to be married May 26.

title: An Eyewitness In Manila
description: For almost three months, 25 military men and one civilian have been on trial in Manila for the killing of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the Filipino opposition leader. Since one of the accused, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, the former armed forces chief of staff, is a cousin and close friend of President Ferdinand C. Marcos and the three judges hearing the case are Marcos appointees, some Filipinos were skeptical of the proceedings.

title: FRATERNITY WIGHOUT BROTHERS
description: THE NEEDS OF STRANGERS By Michael Ignatieff. 156 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $14.95.

title: JANE B. EISNER TO WED ROBERT CORBY JUNE 30
description: The engagement of Jane Beth Eisner to Robert Scott Corby, a son of Ruth Corby and Jack Corby, both of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lewis R. Eisner of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Israeli Withdrawal Leaves Christians Under Attack
description: Israel's withdrawal from the port city of Tyre last week left thousands of Christians more open than ever to attack from Moslem forces in south Lebanon. But the Israelis made it clear that their future involvement in Lebanon would be limited to the minimum necessary to insure the security of the northern border area.

title: FRENCH-U.S. FIGHT: TRADE AGREEMENT VIEWED AS POSSIBLE THOUGH BOTH SEEM TO REMAIN FIRM
description: An intriguing contradiction after the first working day of this summit conference is that the Americans and French have not visibly budged from their hard-line and conflicting positions, but a deal on the next stages of trade and monetary talks nevertheless seems in the works.

title: Pension Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: LEHRMAN TAKES TO ROAD FOR CONSERVATIVE CAUSE
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, who crisscrossed the Northeast for 20 years to build the region's largest drugstore chain and then leaped from political obscurity to a narrow loss in the 1982 New York Governor's race, is on the road again.

title: METS BURIED BY 10-RUN SIXTH
description: A day after watching his Mets break out of a hitting slump in a 9-4 victory, Manager Dave Johnson presided over an embarrassing relapse today that affected not only the team's hitting, but its pitching as well.

title: CONSERVATIVES' THEME: THE WEST IS DIFFERENT
description: WASHINGTON, MAY 2 -- About two dozen American, European and Latin American advocates of a though anti-Communist foreign policy spent the last two days here deriding those in the West who find a ''moral equivalence'' between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Week in Review last Sunday on terrorism in Spain misstated the history of American Presidential visits to Spain. When President Reagan goes there this week, he will be the fifth President to visit Spain since World War II.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: May 5, 1985 Fiction *1 THE WANTON, by Rosemary Rogers. (Avon, $3.95.) A pre-Civil War belle's undaunted quest for a true romantic love. *2 THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.50.) A lawyer finds himself caught in a conspiracy to take over the world. *3 TEXAS RICH, by Fern Michaels. (Ballantine, $3.95.) The struggle of a woman from Pennsylvania to be her own person after joining a Texas dynasty. *4 SMART WOMEN, by Judy Blume. (Pocket, $3.95.) Three divorcees, their love affairs and their kids in trendy Boulder, Colo. *5 FLOODGATE, by Alistair MacLean. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) Terrorists threaten to flood the Netherlands unless Britain leaves Northern Ireland. *6 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett Crest, $4.95.) The American space program recounted in fictional form. *7 WARDAY, by Whitley Strieber and James Kunetka. (Warner, $4.50.) Two survivors of the first nuclear war journey across America.

title: Goal of Regional Lotto Near
description: Northern New England's tri-state lotto game, the nation's first regional lottery, will start by September with a possible first-week jackpot of $1 million, lottery directors say. Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont signed a bill this week, making it the last of the three states to join the game; Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire signed a similar bill last week, while Maine gave its approval last year. Lottery officials say Massachusetts' Megabucks game and New York's Lotto have deeply cut into lottery profits, costing the three states about $1 million a week.

title: AFTER RETIREMENT, THE GOODBYES
description: WHY is it that so many older adults who are nearing retirement choose to move great distances, leaving behind family and friends, familiar places and activities, to start all over again in another area?

title: Cable TV
description: For fans of James Cagney, this week amounts to a veritable cornucopia on Cinemax. Not only does the schedule offer an affectionate half-hour profile; it also boasts two films that show off the star in roles embodying the characteristics that won him enduring popularity: the tough guy and the consummate song-and-dance man.

title: 'INTERVENEING AS LITTLE AS POSSIBLE'
description: Should Britain grant permission for export of Andrea Mantegna's ''Adoration of the Magi,'' above, its new owner, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., is ready to carry out the work needed to prepare the tempera-on-canvas work for exhibition.

title: BABETTE H. SONNENFELDT WED TO GARY LUBBEN
description: Babette Hecht Sonnenfeldt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Helmut Sonnenfeldt of Chevy Chase, Md., was married last Sunday to Gary Richard Lubben, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Lubben of Simsbury, Conn. Judge Oscar H. Davis of the United States Court of Appeals in Washington performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Carlton Hotel in Washington.

title: THE FRENCH 'NO': CONCERNS ARE MANY
description: Why did the French refuse to go along with the other six nations at the economic summit conference here and set a firm date next year for the opening of a new round of trade negotiations?

title: THE CHOICE
description: CAROL A. BARKALOW KEEPS the five frayed diaries on the floor by her bed, half expecting that she might turn over one night and scribble in some new thoughts. It was nine years ago when she cracked the binding on the first small red book and wrote, in the meticulous handwriting of someone starting something new and remarkable, ''July 7, 1976 - What a Day!''

title: BLACKS PROTEST CHOKE-HOLD DEATH IN OREGON
description: Many blacks in this city have expressed outrage since a 31-year-old black man died after the police subdued him in a struggle in a convenience store's parking lot.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: A Master Gilder
description: Washington may be one of the few cities in the world these days that can support a full-time master gilder. Bill Adair earns his living by applying gold leaf to furniture and architectural detail, and his most spectacular recent assignment was the ceiling and Corinthian pillar capitals of the $3.5 million Benjamin Franklin Dining Room at the State Department, where he and two dozen artisans trained by him spent 5,000 hours and used up 92,000 gold leaves, which is, astonishingly, less than two pounds of gold.

title: O'NEILL DECISION SPURS STAMPEDE FOR HIS SEAT
description: Over almost half a century only three men have represented the Eighth Congressional District in Massachusetts.

title: APOLLO THEATER CELEBRATES ITS RETURN
description: Dancers whirled down the aisles of the newly renovated Apollo Theater shortly after 8 P.M. yesterday. It was ''Motown Returns to the Apollo,'' a three-hour television special taped by NBC for airing on May 19, with 60 entertainers representing a wide spectrum of pop, soul and jazz talent over the last 50 years.

title: SUZANNE FRISCH WED TO JONATHAN LEVINE
description: Suzanne Gay Frisch and Jonathan David Levine, who are due to receive medical degrees from the University of Vermont May 18, were married yesterday at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in New York. Rabbi Bernard Cohn officiated.

title: MISS SIMMONS HAS NUPTIALS
description: Linda Kathryn Simons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dolph Collins Simons Jr. of Lawrence, Kan., was married there yesterday to Daniel Crosby de Menocal Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. de Menocal of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. L. Matthews performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: A WEEKEND BY THE WATER
description: Of all the places to entertain during the summer months, a house at the beach must rank among the favorites. Usually a relaxed place to invite friends, it is very much so when the host is Jay Crawford, a Manhattan fashion illustrator and the owner of Quadrille, which distributes wallpapers and fabrics to designers and architects. He entertains every weekend during the summer at his small, handsome house on Fire Island, where the living is easy. That's because he lets guests partake in many of the chores. ''I believe in a carefree style of entertaining,'' Crawford said while preparing for the arrival of three guests - Genelle Jenkins, Allyson Nord and John Knott - at his modern and airy beach house.

title: O'NEILL URGES U.S. TO FREEZE TRANSIT AID
description: GOVERNOR O'NEILL waded into the debate on the Federal budget last week, journeying here to ask a Senate committee to freeze 1986 transportation spending at current levels rather than reduce or eliminate funds for Amtrak, commuter rail and bus lines, and highway and bridge projects.

title: PROSPECTS
description: End of Great Expectations Stock investors thrive on great expectations but since the Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record 1299.36 on March 1, their expectations have been anything but great.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;

Dance
description: Lar Lubovitch is many things to many people. The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company, which opens on Tuesday for a week's engagement at City Center, offers a chance to see fine dancing by such standout performers as the delicately lyrical Christine Wright and Bob Besserer, a big, powerful dancer with an air of affecting ease. Mr. Lubovitch is one of the more intelligent choreographers around, and the repertory includes widely varying works of the past 16 years of his career, as well as Charles Moulton's witty ''Nine Person Precision Ball Passing.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JOHN MASEFIELD'S LETTERS FROM THE FRONT, 1915-1917. Edited by Peter Vansittart. (Franklin Watts, $18.95.) In 1915, 15 years before he was named England's poet laureate, John Masefield (1878-1967) went to the Western Front as an orderly for the British Red Cross.

title: ANNE E. RICHARD MARRIES DAVID O. NORDBY, BANKER
description: Anne Elizabeth Richard, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William Joshua Richard Jr. of Indiana, Pa., was married yesterday to David Oliver Nordby, the son of George Oliver Nordby of Sioux Falls, S.D., and the late Mae Henderson Nordby.

title: WHAT'S NEW WITH NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS
description: WHAT looks like, sounds like and acts like a business, but pays low postage rates and no income taxes? Answer: Many charities, schools, churches, museums and other non-profit groups.

title: TRIBUTES ENLIVEN WEEK'S CONCERT SELECTIONS
description: THE musical birthday parties continue apace, providing several attractive concert options today.

title: FESTIVAL IN CAPITAL: A TASTE OF INDIA
description: With the traditional ceremony of ''puja'' at the National Gallery of Art today and the opening of an exhibition of ancient sculpture there Sunday, the yearlong Festival of India gets under way in the United States this weekend, a month before the official opening.

title: Naval Officer Reprimanded
description: A court-martial board decided today to reprimand a 40-year-old Naval officer convicted of living with a female subordinate and lying to his superior about their relationship. Cmdr.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: RIVER RACING Slalom canoe racers will steer through an obstacle course made of 25 red and white poles hung over the Farmington River in Tariffville, Simsbury, from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Saturday. Spectators along the East Granby banks will have the best view as 40 to 50 kayakers, racing singly, battle white water just for the fun of it.

title: MOZART'S MUSIC, THOREAU'S STYLE
description: ''WRITER seeks quiet sanctuary in a noisy world. Responsible, civilized (the only music I listen to is Mozart, and even that not too loud!) writer seeks cottage for pursuing 'Thoreauvian' lifestyle.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE RAPE OF SHAVI. By Buchi Emecheta. (Braziller, $12.95.) The crash-landing of a tiny group of European scientists and intellectuals into Shavi, an imaginary isolated sub-Saharan community, sets into motion the plot of Buchi Emecheta's eighth novel.

title: TIE SCORING MARK
description: Jari Kurri, Charlie Huddy and Glenn Anderson scored two goals each tonight to spark the Edmonton Oilers' record-tying offensive output in an 11-2 rout of the Chicago Black Hawks in the opener of their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: New Pressure On South Africa
description: From at least one corner of Washington, there was mounting pressure on South Africa last week to improve the status of its black majority. The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted 29 to 6 to ban new American investments in South Africa and bank loans to it, to revoke existing computer contracts with its Government and to prohibit imports of gold coins, which are sold to collectors and investors.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Puerto Rico on March 31 described Mayaguez incorrectly. Mayaguez is the sixth largest city in Puerto Rico.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Reds, at Cincinnati. Dwight Gooden, who shut out the Reds the last time he faced them, will start. (Television - Channel 9, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 2:15 P.M ) Braves vs. Montreal Expos, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS 2:05 P.M.) Basketball Pistons vs. Boston Celtics, at Detroit. Game 4 of the 4-of-7 Eastern Conference semifinal series. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) #76ers vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Philadelphia. Game 4 of the other Eastern semifinal. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Utah Jazz vs. Denver Nuggets, at Salt Lake City. Game 4 of the 7 Western Conference semifinal. (Television - WTBS 10:05 P.M.) Football Generals vs Bulls, at Jacksonville, Fla. The last three Heisman Trophy winners will be in this game in the Gator Bowl: Doug Flutie and Herschel Walker of the Generals, and Mike Rozier of the Bulls. (Television - Channel 7, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 2:30 P.M.) Hockey Nordiques vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Quebec. Opener of the four-of-seven Wales Conference championship series. (Television - USA Network, 7:30 P.M.) Rowing Watney's Challenge II Oxford-Cambridge Manhattan Boat Race, on the Hudson from 140th Street to 79th Street boat basin, 1 P.M. The crews consist of alumni.

title: Headliners;   The McCarthy Papers
description: Once some order is made of the boxes of papers in the basement of the Vassar College Library, the life of Mary McCarthy, class of '33, will become an open book. The school recently bought, for an undisclosed sum, Miss McCarthy's letters, manuscripts and other notes, which are sure to occupy scholars and literary types for some time.

title: Monsanto Wins Dioxin Case
description: Recent discoveries about the startling and often unexpected dangers of industrial chemicals have prompted an array of lawsuits from chemical-plant workers, claiming that their employers failed to protect them. Last week, in what has come to be regarded as important test case, a Federal jury in West Virginia found the Monsanto Company not responsible for the illnesses of seven retired employees who said they had been poisoned on the job by dioxin. But the jury did award $200,000 to one of the seven, John Hein, who said his cancer - a bladder tumor discovered during the 10-month trial - had been caused by another chemical produced by Monsanto.

title: PACIFIC CRUISES, NETHERLANDS TOURS
description: A NEW LIBERTE, FACELIFT DONE, SAILS TO TAHITI The ship that once plied the seas as the Moore McCormack liner Brasil vanished. And when it re-emerged after its sale, it was the Holland America liner Volendam. And that, too, vanished.

title: ACTORS SHINE IN 'LET'S GET A DIVORCE!'
description: TELEVISION shows like ''Dynasty'' and ''Dallas'' make the 19th-century domestic triangle in Victorien Sardou's ''Let's Get a Divorce!'' seem vapid in comparison. The Sardou comedy, currently playing at the Arena Players Repertory Company's Main Stage Theater in East Farmingdale, is an elaborate tale, skillfully told, that contains no discernible substance. It's a champagne gala celebrating nothing.

title: IT'S THE ERA OF THE SKIMPY PROGRAM NOTE
description: The other evening at a piano recital in Carnegie Hall I found myself being surveyed. An insert in the program book confronted me with a list of questions, beginning with: ''Do you generally read the program notes provided in Stagebill?'' The three answers offered as options were ''Yes, frequently,'' ''Yes, sometimes'' and ''No, never.'' I was frustrated, as I frequently am by questions in opinion polls, because a sensible reply was not possible. Inasmuch as there were no notes in the program book for this recital, but only a long biography of the pianist, none of the available answers could be checked. It was just this kind of logical impasse that made Alice so exasperated with the White Queen. Of course, a reply to the Carnegie poll might have been possible if the question had been rephrased to ''Do you read the program notes whenever whimsy moves Stagebill to provide them?''

title: 29 ARE DEAD FROM LEGIONNAIRE'S DISEASE IN BRITISH MIDLANDS
description: The death toll in an outbreak of legionnaires' disease in Britain climbed to 29 today, equaling the number killed when the disease first appeared in Philadelphia in 1976.

title: A DAY IN THE SEASON
description: NINE INNINGS By Daniel Okrent. 272 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: Hail the Artist, Ban the Artist
description: To the Editor:

title: TANKING UP Transport Triumph
description: Pickings are slim in the glutted world market for oil tankers. That's why the owners of American-flag carriers want permission to use their ships to haul Alaskan oil.

title: A METROPOLIS OF NO LITTLE PLANS
description: The Continental Illinois Bank nearly collapsed last fall, just as the Chicago Cubs were winning the National League Eastern Division Championship. It is difficult to say which occasion Chicagoans loved better, for the town has a neurotic need for anything stupendous. In Chicago, we may not think the Picasso presiding over the Richard J. Daley Center plaza is art, but we know it's a big Picasso and it's the city's Picasso, and when the Cubs made the playoffs, the sculpture wore a baseball cap just like everything else.

title: BIRDIES STRETCH KITE'S LEAD TO 3 STROKES
description: Tom Kite finally got some birdies again today and increased his lead from one shot to three in the third round of the $400,000 MONY Tournament of Champions at La Costa Country Club.

title: ROBBING THE REICH
description: NAZI GOLD

title: DINNER IN BEIRUT
description: Current and former correspondents recall times that illustrate the meaning of hospitality.

title: 80-20 Pitfalls: Protecting Co-op Tax Benefits
description: THE sharp escalation in commercial rents in Manhattan in the last few years poses a curious dilemma for co-op buildings that rent such space. Instead of being able to enjoy this unexpected bonanza, some boards of directors are finding that it is jeopardizing the co-op's favorable tax status.

title: DOROTHY WILSON PLANS TO MARRY P. B. GALANT
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jordan Wilson of Alpine, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Dorothy Wilson to Peter Brandell Galant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Galant of Tenafly, N.J. The wedding is planned for October.

title: SEIZING AN OPPORTUNITY: THE WOOLWORTH PARCEL
description: THERE were a few loose ends, to understate the matter, when KSB Associates bought another party's contract two years ago to purchase the land under the Woolworth store on the northeast corner of Third Avenue and 86th Street.

title: A NEW TWIST IN THE TRANS-ATLANTIC FARE BATTLE
description: In its flurry of advertising to gain passengers after a recent strike, Pan American World Airways has announced one of the biggest international travel bargains in recent years. It is a midweek fare of $199 one way on nonstop flights from New York to Hamburg, West Germany, and via New York from Boston, Philadelphia and Washington - far below what had been available on any airline previously.

title: SOUNDING OFF: IT'S NO FUN BEING A YANKEE FAN
description: When George Steinbrenner dismissed Yogi Berra as manager last Sunday night, Yankee fans took pen in hand.

title: REACHING OUT WITH A ZOOM LENS JOHN DURNIAK
description: OF all the lenses in photography, the most magical is the zoom. In theory, at least, one zoom can replace a suitcase full of standard lenses.

title: EFFORTS GROW TO COMBAT GRAFFITI
description: FOLLOWING the lead of New Rochelle, six other southern Westchester communities have banned together to combat graffiti by agreeing to enact ordinances that would prohibit the sale of spray paint to people under the age of 18.

title: Black Women's History
description: To the Editor:

title: COURTNEY PYLES WED IN BERMUDA
description: The marriage of Courtney Claiborne Pyles, a daughter of Mrs. Edwards B. Murray of New York and the late Dr. William J. Pyles, to Leonard Casey Kahn took place yesterday at St. Anne's Anglican Church in Southampton, Bermuda. The Rev. Reginald Harvey performed the ceremony.

title: HOW REALISM IN MIME AND ROMANTIC BALLET BEGAN
description: ''Les Enfants du Paradis'' (The Children of Paradise), with its memorable performance by Jean-Louis Barrault as the great 19th-century mime, Deburau, remains one of the finest classics of French film. It is also an exquisitely poeticized rendering of the historical milieu that gave birth to Romantic ballet and to the cultural atmosphere that reigned so vibrantly around French theater in the first half of the 19th century.

title: KATHRYN MASIUS BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Kathryn Kohn Masius to Charles Conrad Rieger Jr., group vice president for consumer products of Figgie International in Richmond, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Lyon Kohn, parents of the bride, in West Hartford, Conn. Judge John A. Berman of the Probate Court performed the ceremony.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF ECONOMIC MEETING
description: In its declaration, the Bonn conference concluded that world economic conditions were better now than they had been for some time, that inflation was down and that recovery was spreading. But to sustain growth, it stressed that major industrial nations needed to strengthen their own economies, halt protectionism, improve world monetary stability, create more jobs and reduce social inequalities.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: AUSTRALIAN CONCERT The Sydney Conservatorium Symphony Orchestra, comprising 80 young musicians from Australia, will present a concert this evening at Somerset County College in North Branch.

title: Bandits Beat Express
description: John Reaves completed 20 of 38 passes and threw for two touchdowns in leading the Tampa Bay Bandits to a 24-14 United States Football League victory over the Los Angeles Express before only 4,912, the smallest crowd of the season at the Coliseum.

title: A BILL IN ALBANY SEEKS ZONES FOR NON-DRINKERS IN ARENAS
description: A bill introduced in the State Legislature would seek to control ''rowdiness, violence and obscenity that accompany public drunkenness'' at large spectator events.

title: Above the Fray
description: Al Toon, the Jets' No. 1 draft pick, said yesterday he wanted to play for the Jets and did not want to concern himself about negotiations involving either the Jets or the United States Football League and his agent. ''I'm going to the Jets' minicamp in a few weeks,'' said Toon, the star wide receiver from the University of Wisconsin, ''even if I don't have a contract.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGET PLAN FALLS SHORT
description: EVEN as the White House budget package moves through Congress, the continuing huge Federal budget deficits present mounting difficulties for the United States and world economies.

title: REDESIGNING HUMAN BONES
description: THERE IS A revolution going on in the field of orthopedic medicine. It is a revolution without fanfare, without the drama of an artificial heart, without the need to rush a vital organ through the night to a dying patient. It is a revolution without a major breakthrough, without a miracle drug, without a Salk or a DeVries as its champion. It is a revolution spread over decades, not days, an accumulation of technique and technology that is changing the way we deal with our musculoskeletal structure, that organization of bones, cartilage, tendons, ligaments and muscles that holds us together and gives us form. These are some of the developments that have resulted directly from this ongoing revolution: Victims of bone cancer, a disease once among the grimmest of killers, now have a fairly high rate of survival. Athletes with serious knee and shoulder injuries are being operated on and returned to action in weeks instead of months. Surgeons are able to design orthopedic prostheses - the artificial implants that take the place of bones in the body - on computers. Researchers are experimenting with the advanced concept of growing new bones by ''tricking'' old bones into reproducing themselves. Osteoporosis - the condition of fragile bones in the elderly - once considered inescapable for older women, is now being arrested and even prevented. The implantation of artificial joints is giving mobility and freedom from pain to hundreds of thousands of people. The number of medical-school graduates opting for a career in orthopedic surgery has doubled since 1978.

title: AUSTIN
description: Austin, the capital of Texas, is unlike Texas. Hilly in an otherwise flat land, socially tolerant and politically liberal in a straitlaced conservative state, it lies on a geological and cultural fault that divides East Texas from West. It is the intellectual and musical capital of Texas, a refuge for poets and film makers, writers and romantics, punk rockers and misfits and everyone else who cannot fit into the Brooks Brothers mold of Dallas.

title: NEW LINES OF THOUGHT
description: It is truly amazing how little trust can be placed in lines of play long entrenched. It would seem that no consensus in the most reliable tomes on the openings can defend against a fresh assault by inspiration and imagination.

title: EFFECTS OF LOSS OF SHADE
description: SEVERAL ecological changes can occur when trees and other vegetation are removed from the banks of lakes and streams, according to scientific references.

title: REPUBLICAN ANGER BOILS OVER
description: ''IN the long run,'' said one Congressman, ''this becomes a very small issue.'' But then, he was a Democrat. Republicans were so angered over last week's seating of Frank McCloskey, a Democrat from Indiana's Eighth District, that they stormed out of the House of Representatives, fuming.

title: SOUNDING OFF: IT'S NO FUN BEING A YANKEE FAN
description: When George Steinbrenner dismissed Yogi Berra as manager last Sunday night, Yankee fans took pen in hand. What follows is a sample of some of the mail - all of it critical - received by The New York Times. Further response is welcome. THIS FAN IS FED UP To the Sports Editor:

title: AMY B. CROCKER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Amy Buchanan Crocker, the daughter of Mrs. Frank Longfellow Crocker and the late Mr. Crocker of New York, was married to Mello Anthony Ewoud van Daalen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. van Daalen of Geneva. The Rev. John G. B. Andrew performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Albert de Beaufort, a Dutch Reform minister.

title: WARM SPELL CALLED KEY TO PEACH CROP
description: JUST one year after extreme cold weather killed thousands of peach buds and trees, farmers in New Jersey feared it was happening again.

title: SOUNDING OFF: IT'S NO FUN BEING A YANKEE FAN
description: When George Steinbrenner dismissed Yogi Berra as manager last Sunday night, Yankee fans took pen in hand. What follows is a sample of some of the mail - all of it critical - received by The New York Times.

title: WHY JACK WELCH IS CHANGING G.E.
description: IT is difficult to imagine spending even one day at the General Electric Company without seeing signs of the turbulence that the nation's ninth-largest industrial concern is going through. Since 1981, when John F. Welch Jr. became chairman, change has come fast, leaving shrunken staffs and shuttered plants in its wake. And the upheaval is far from over.

title: TOWNLEY MCELHINEY TO WED K. S. SHAW
description: Helen Townley McElhiney, director of the architecture, planning and design program of the New York State Council on the Arts, plans to be married June 15 to Kelly Scott Shaw, an assistant vice president in international liability management for the Marine Midland Bank in New York.

title: GOING IT ALONE AT GROVE CITY
description: Grove City College is a small Presbyterian school in Pennsylvania that refuses Federal assistance because, according to its officials, it would ''compromise our independence.'' So the college has declined to sign a statement of compliance with Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 prohibiting sex discrimination by aid recipients. The Government, however, has argued that since Grove City students receive Pell grants, Federal aid for low-income students, the college, as indirect recipient, should toe the line.

title: Of Memory and Forgiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: NO QUICK END TO DROUGHT IS SEEN DESPITE RECENT RAINSTORMS IN EAST
description: Rain fell in the Northeast and Middle Atlantic states this week, but it had little impact on the lingering drought, and officials expressed concern that there were problems ahead for agriculture, tourism, business and everyday activities.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: REAL ILLUSIONS. By Russell Haley. (New Directions, Cloth, $15, Paper, $7.95.) A Yorkshire native who in his youth immigrated to New Zealand, Russell Haley strikes an anomalous pose among contemporary writers of English fiction.

title: A MUMFORD COUP FOR MONMOUTH COLLEGE
description: LEWIS MUMFORD could scarcely be more famous, having written some 30 books and innumerable magazine articles over the last 60 years or so.

title: LEGAL COMMUNITY AND TOP COURT DEBATE LAWYER'S DUTY WHEN CLIENTS LIE
description: Emmanuel Charles Whiteside was about to go on trial for murder. He had stabbed a man dead in an argument over marijuana.

title: 2 TEACHERS TAKE STEP TOWARD SPACE
description: THIS week, David Warner, a former professional football player who is now a teacher in Simsbury, will start producing a videotape presentation that he wants to complete during a ride on a space shuttle.

title: NOW EVEN THE SUBURBS HAVE SUBURBS
description: Once again all over the United States exurban areas around many big cities are booming. Construction and population shifts are transforming many once rural, small-town landscapes in a process that has occurred in successive waves since World War II.

title: THE NEW WAVE FROM RUSSIA
description: I OFFER SOCIAL SCIENCES 121, the ''History of the Soviet Union,'' every spring at the Polytechnic Institute of New York, a small, predominantly engineering university in downtown Brooklyn. During the 1970's, the period of detente , students were curious about the Soviet Union and S.S. 121 always had a large enrollment. So many students signed up for the course, in fact, that I developed a little ice-breaking routine.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

SPRING CLEANING
description: Representatives of many Westchester corporations, together with their friends and families, will be rolling up their sleeves and dirtying their hands on May 19 doing spring farm work at the county's Muscoot Farm in Somers. ''This is a project of the Westchester Corporate Volunteer Council - we wanted to enjoy some special spring events that would bring volunteers from all corporations together,'' explained Carol Monti of Scarsdale, an administrator of community affairs at Con Edison's Westchester Division.

title: ELIZABETH DISARIO WED
description: Elizabeth Frances Disario, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Disario of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Robert Woolf Lighton, the son of Alfred Lighton of Kansas City, Mo., and the late Jean Schoenberg Lighton, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. William Carr, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: GETTING READY FOR VISIT TO BITBURG, WHITE HOUSE KEEPS AN EYE ON TV
description: Wearing a blue trench coat, Jeff Brian, a White House advance man, stood today in the Kolmeshohe cemetery here negotiating one of the most momentous television appearances of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

title: Conceal Not the Blood
description: To the 87 million Americans born since 1945, it must seem strange that the President's visit to the monuments of a distant war in remote Bitburg and Bergen-Belsen should awaken so much passion. By the time these Americans reached awareness, (West) German soldiers were their routine allies, Volkswagen and Mercedes were consumer totems and a President had vowed to defend Germany's former capital like ''ein Berliner.''

title:
DINING OUT;

LOCATION OFTEN PLAYS A MAJOR ROLE
description: THERE are restaurants that create an intense and ardent following, and there are others that have as many detractors as supporters. But there is also a third kind, one that calls forth neither praise nor complaint, but comments like ''Oh, yes, a pleasant restaurant, and the food isn't bad.'' The Gallery falls into this last-named category. Of particular importance is its location: On U.S. 1 and just a stone's throw from the various shopping centers that crowd this area. Add to that the attractive interior - hanging plants, rattan furniture intermingled with comfortable leather-like seats and the large flower paintings - and the accommodating and friendly service, and the Gallery is a pleasant place to stop for lunch or dinner.

title: METROMEDIA SELLS 1 STATION AND TALKS TO MURDOCH
description: Metromedia Inc. agreed in principle yesterday to sell its Boston television station to the Hearst Corporation and it suggested that a far larger deal might be made as early as tomorrow to sell its six other big-city stations to Rupert Murdoch.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page last Sunday about White House security misstated the political affiliation of Representative Michael D. Barnes of Maryland. He is a Democrat.

title: DELUXE SCRAPBOOK OF ILLUSTRATIONS
description: ALWAYS serious about the art of the cartoon, the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook has moved up a notch in seriousness with its current exhibition, ''Masters of Pen and Ink.''

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Byway Farms, Bayport, L.I. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (516) 475-7968. Today - The Junior Essex Troop, Chester, N.J. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (201) 944-3253.

title: TRAPPED MAN FOILS KIDNAPPERS BY PRYING OPEN CAR TRUNK
description: A lawyer kidnapped by three gunmen and locked in the trunk of his Mercedes-Benz said today that he punched out the tail lights as the car sped down the highway and threw tools at passing motorists, but no one came to his aid.

title: TWO ARTISTS WHO PROBE THE MEANING OF LIFE
description: They present themselves as an eccentric couple - a mix of Laurel and Hardy, a pair of traveling salesmen, religious hermits and a touch of Vladimir and Estragon, the existential clowns from Samuel Beckett's play, ''Waiting for Godot.'' They are an entertaining pair, but serious; a sideshow that sometimes seems shockingly true enough to make one ponder the deeper meaning of it all.

title: NOW IT'S FERNANDO BUJONES, DANCER AND CHOREOGRAPHER
description: The ballet world has watched American Ballet Theater principal Fernando Bujones grow up. Starting from his student days at the School of American Ballet to his rapid ascension through the ranks at ABT, it's seen his dazzling technical virtuosity deepen with maturity; it's observed the sometimes outspoken young upstart mellow into a thoughtful family man.

title: MARIJUANA FARMERS FACE A CRACKDOWN
description: YOU won't find it listed in state agricultural reports, but law-enforcement officials are convinced Connecticut, along with other New England states, is producing a cash crop of marijuana.

title: REAL ESTATE'S RELUCTANT TYCOON: John Lie-Nielson;   AN EMPIRE BUILDER WITH A FRUGAL TOUCH
description: IN the early 1960's, John Lie-Nielsen, who by then had already sold highchairs, sorted coins in a bank, sold insurance, run a dance studio and still only reached his late 20's, decided that there was big money to be made in real estate. Mr. Lie-Nielsen, at the time, had small money. In round numbers, he had about $2,000.

title: Tigers Close Stands Again
description: The Detroit Tigers closed their center-field bleacher seats indefinitely for the second time in five years after fans chanted obscenities following tonight's victory over Chicago.

title: THE LEGACY FOR A DAUGHTER LEFT BEHIND
description: I AM searching for something as I look through my many pictures of the past - some neatly arranged in albums, some piled in drawers and boxes, some carefully preserved in my mind. Even though I have so many, I know there are missing ones, so I study the photos and the remembered images, trying finally to understand the mysterious tragedy of my father.

title: Unforgettable Day
description: IT was 48 years ago tomorrow that the dirigible Hindenburg, coming in majestically for a landing at Lakehurst, N.J., exploded and burned in 34 seconds, killing 36 of the 97 people on board. And it is around this time every year, Herbert Morrison says, that he receives calls from newspapers and radio and television stations.

title: 'PIONEERS' GET COLUMBIA CREW AFLOAT
description: WHEN Columbia became the last of the Ivy League schools to admit women to all undergraduate departments, in September 1983, it and Barnard College united to field women's teams in nine varsity sports that previously had only been offered by Barnard.

title: ALFONSIN'S BIGGEST ENEMY MAY BE THE ECONOMY
description: A chill set in over Argentina last week as President Raul Alfonsin delivered his annual address to Congress.

title: FRANCE BLOCKS TRADE TALKS AS SUMMIT CONFERENCE ENDS; REAGAN PRESSES 'STAR WARS'; DISPUTE ON TIMING
description: The world's seven leading industrial nations ended their annual economic summit conference here today with a majority agreeing on the urgency of negotiations to eliminate barriers to free trade, the No. 1 issue here. But they failed to set a date to start the talks because of relentless objections from France.

title: FORMULA MERCHANTS ARE MILKING THE MINI-SERIES
description: If television has its way, the American viewer is going to be bombarded more relentlessly than ever by calculating, audience-research projects skillfully orchestrated by marketplace opportunists. It is the rare television ''special'' nowadays that isn't buttressed with the ballyhoo of supposedly prestigious book tie-ins and massive publicity campaigns. The multimillion-dollar hustle has become a commonplace, a norm for doing business. A height, or nadir, of sorts is reached in ''Lace II,'' a four-hour movie that will be offered on ABC tonight and tomorrow at 9. ''Lace II'' is just possibly the ultimate in electronic swill. Those connected with its packaging will no doubt be giggling all the way to the bank, but few are likely to be silly enough to claim a smidgin of pride.

title: AUCTIONS OF AWFUL ART AID CHARITY IN CANADA
description: The life of Norman S. Watt was transformed in New York 16 years ago when he walked into a shop and gasped at the moonlit landscape, titled ''Luna Di Sera,'' on display.

title: SOUNDING OFF: IT'S NO FUN BEING A YANKEE FAN
description: When George Steinbrenner dismissed Yogi Berra as manager last Sunday night, Yankee fans took pen in hand. What follows is a sample of some of the mail - all of it critical - received by The New York Times.

title: NEW RULES SOUGHT ON NURSING HOMES
description: A New York State task force studying allegations of racial segregation in nursing homes has drafted a series of recommendations that would require the homes to keep a record of patients who are accepted or rejected for admission.

title: Looking for Individualism
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILHARMONIC: DRUCKMAN'S 'PRISM'
description: FRIDAY afternoon's New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall began with Haydn and ended with Dvorak's lovely Cello Concerto; but for better or worse, it was Jacob Druckman's ''Prism'' that sat us up in our seats.

title: P.L.O. Says It Rejected U.S. Envoy's Proposals
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has rejected all the proposals made by an American envoy during a recent Middle East trip, a high Palestinian official said today.

title: JAPANESE SEE A 'MADE IN JAPAN' FUTURE AND FEEL REASSURED BY THAT VISION
description: Half of Japan came here today to stand in line. Or maybe it only felt that way. In any event, there was probably no better place to observe Japanese at leisure en masse than on the endless lines that curved around the cubist, pastel pavilions of Tsukuba Expo '85, the country's celebration of its technological self.

title: ELLEN GERRY, A. W. BREED ARE MARRIED
description: Ellen Lyman Gerry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Alan Whitman Breed, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Breed 3d of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Older age as the prime of life is the celebratory subject of ''Taking My Turn.'' This musical collage by Gary William Friedman and Will Holt, which had an extended run Off Broadway in 1983, is featured on ''Great Performances,'' Friday at 9 P.M. on channels 13 and 49.

title: HOLY LAND HOSPITALITY
description: Providing accommodations for Christian pilgrims in the Holy Land is a tradition nearly as old as Christianity itself. The historian Steven Runciman says that by the beginning of the fifth century the Roman passion for pilgrimages had inspired the building of about 200 monasteries in and around Jerusalem, all for the purpose of receiving pilgrims.

title: THE SUNDAY NIGHT PARTY
description: Once you discover hard-shell crabs, you want to share them with everyone else; they have such a distinctive flavor,'' says Sherley Koteen, who over the years has done just that.

title: PETER MARTINS STAGES HIS FIRST BOURNONVILLE CLASSIC
description: There will be much that is familiar and yet different about the Pennsylvania Ballet's engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music beginning Tuesday. First, there is the company itself. For many years a regular visitor to New York, with semiannual seasons at BAM, the Pennsylvania has not been seen here for three years. It is returning with a new artistic director, the former New York City Ballet principal dancer Robert Weiss, and with a sharply altered artistic profile that includes a substantially overhauled repertory.

title: STATE INQUIRY AFTERMATH: HIGHWAY-REPAIR COST RISES
description: TWO Long Island officials have criticized one facet of the state investigation of allegations of bid rigging on many Long Island highway projects, contending that the inquiry has driven up construction costs.

title: TOWN OF BELL TOWERS
description: The island of Rab in the northern Adriatic shares certain characteristics with other Yugoslav islands: a beneficent year-round climate and scenic beauty, an influx of western European visitors, a variety of sports activities and a naturist or nudist area - the one on Rab extensive enough to have a restaurant and a dock for water skiers. Rab is close to the mainland, its southeastern tip only a mile from the coastal range of the jagged Dinaris Alps.

title: COLLIGIATE'S ARITHMETIC MAKES IT OLDEST SCHOOL
description: One summer day in 1628, the Rev. Jonas Michaelius, the first minister of the Dutch Reformed Church in America, wrote a letter describing, among other things, his efforts to teach catechism to Indian children.

title: NOW THERE'S A 'BOOM BOX' WITH A BUILT-IN CD PLAYER
description: Given enough time, the inevitable always happens. So now we have a ''boom box'' with a built-in compact disk player. The foremost and the hindmost aspects of audio have joined, like a creature swallowing its tail.

title: BRENNAN LAMENTS CHANGES IN AIMS OF COURT
description: The United States Supreme Court appears to have become ''primarily concerned'' with vindicating the will of the majority and ''less interested'' in protecting the individual's constitutional rights, according to an Associate Justice of the court.

title: THE DECLINE OF HISTORY
description: History has been in fashion here for a few days. We have been wallowing in the anniversaries of the wars we failed to avoid, but most of the time, even in Washington, history is a parade of forgotten memories.

title: ARCO'S ANSWER TO T. BOONE PICKENS
description: LAST week may have marked a turning point for the energy industry. Until then, it was not clear who would undertake the necessary restructuring of the industry - management or corporate raiders such as T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company. But Atlantic Richfield's announcement of plans to significantly reduce its investments and assets may have served notice that what the raiders started, management will finish.

title: A Pronounced Difference
description: IF YOU'RE PLANNING to be a newspaper columnist, folks, don't ever have a hometown named Morrisonville or come from a state called Virginia, and I'll tell you why.

title: HOW TO SAY THANK YOU
description: Whether the weekend is spent visiting in a rustic cabin, an elegantly appointed city apartment or an informal house at the beach, a gift from the guest is welcome. Among the ideas on these pages are presents as simple as brightly capped salt and pepper shakers, and as elaborate as a faience coffeepot. (p.52) Clockwise from top: Terra-cotta saucers, made in Sweden, to be used as coasters, ashtrays, hors d'oeuvre plates, etc., $10 each. At Bergdorf Goodman. ''Brighton Beach Chair,'' cotton sling on beech frame, $24.95. At Conran's. Guatemalan cotton napkins, $8.50 each. At Frank McIntosh at Henri Bendel. Glass-and-metal salt and pepper shakers, $1.75 each. At Conran's. (p.54) Below: Table crumber made of horn in Austria, $150. At Barneys New York. Clockwise from top left: Hand-carved horn iced tea or parfait spoons, made in Austria, $19 each. At Barneys New York. Handblown glass bowl for pasta or salad, made in Sweden, $30. At Barneys New York. ''Charlotte Floral'' cotton napkin from the Ralph Lauren Home Collection, $11 each. At Bloomingdale's. Macy's. Royal Velvet bath sheets by Fieldcrest, $30 each. At Bloomingdale's. Macy's. Christofle silver-plated coasters, $75 for set of four.

title:
ART;

SCULPTURE THAT CASTS A SPELL
description: THE dramatic installation of sculpture by Elizabeth de Cuevas on display at Guild Hall in East Hampton is a strong argument for the kind of artist-designed gallery presentation that can often extend and amplify the meaning of the work.

title: TEACHERS: A DEFENSE
description: ON Feb. 24, a verbal vendetta by someone named Jack Hannold appeared on the Opinion Page. The author's sole listed qualification was that he's ''a subscriber to 'The Underground Grammarian.' '' Despite this admirable attribute, the article contained false premises, blatant bias and disregard of fact.

title: Pop Music
description: One of the fascinations of growing older that young listeners cannot appreciate until they get there is hearing the changes that occur in a singer with whose work you were familiar when both the singer and you were young. All too often this involves disappointment as the singer's voice grows cloudy, or disenchantment as what seemed thrilling to one on the threshold of life appears shallow in mature retrospect.

title: VIETNAM FETE: A WHO'S WHO OF THE MISSING
description: Somewhere about midway through a week crowded with events to mark the 10th anniversary of the Communist takeover of Saigon, people started noticing the things that were missing.

title: CHANGE COMES TO THE WATERFRONT, MUCH OF IT FOER THE BETTER
description: Many of the piers along Manhattan's Hudson River shore are rotting and the number of longshoremen who report to work each morning is down to a few hundred. The freighters no longer stand in line off the Battery waiting for a tug to escort them to shore. But like many other industries that used to call Manhattan home, the shipping business has not disappeared. It has moved to the outer boroughs and to the suburbs. And business is booming.

title: BY THE NUMBERS: SEAT BELTS AND SAFETY
description: Do seat belts save lives? The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles provided at least a preliminary answer last week: The number of highway deaths declined 27 percent in the first three months after New York began requiring belts to be worn. The drop - from 252 deaths in the beginning of 1984 to 184 in the same period this year - would result, officials estimated, in a year-end total of 331 fatalities, down substantially from the year before. And this decline comes on top of the one that began in 1982, when the drinking age was raised from 18 to 19, stiffer penalties were imposed for drunken driving and the state began to use money from fines for alcohol treatment and highway safety.

title: GROUP HELPS WOMEN START IN BUSINESSES
description: Early each morning, Pauline Mingo, a working mother of three, drops her 3-year-old at a nursery, the 8-year-old at school and then begins another 12- to 14-hour day as owner-manager of Mingo's World Travel Service.

title: SAUDI ARABIA'S GOSPEL COLUMNISTS
description: Is smoking against Islam? Is it a sin to poison your unmarried sister because she is pregnant? Must women who are too old to be desirable cover themselves when they go out?

title: CHAMBER: POLISH GROUP
description: THE Capella Cracoviensis is a chamber orchestra and chorus from Cracow, Poland, that appeared Thursday night at Symphony Space before a small, mostly Polish-speaking audience. There were reasons for the poor attendance, primarily the last-minute arrival of the group from Poland after considerable doubt that it would be allowed to come.

title: A Plea for Mercy
description: Although Geraldine A. Ferraro has made a lot of money since her defeat in November, business has not been so good for her husband. The conviction of John A. Zaccaro in a realty-fraud case in January was the culmination of his troubles, which began in the spotlight of his wife's Vice Presidential campaign.

title: CHINA'S ATOMIC WEAPON STORY TOLD
description: A Chinese Army Marshal has given the first detailed account of China's abortive efforts to obtain Soviet help in developing its atomic arsenal in the 1950's and 1960's. In it he implies that a Chinese missile with an atomic warhead was launched and successfully detonated at a test range in Western China in 1966.

title: IT'S MORE THAN A STAGE, IT'S A GYMNASIUM
description: ''Forty-one days of one-act plays'' proclaims the flyer for ''Marathon '85,'' the eighth annual festival of new one-act plays that begins this Wednesday at the Ensemble Studio Theater. During that time, a total of 12 plays - three separate programs of four apiece, in rotating repertory - will receive full productions, a taxing schedule for any theater. What the flyer doesn't say is that the marathon comes at the end of a season that has already produced four complete shows (including a musical that briefly played Off Broadway), a series of staged readings called ''New Voices,'' and an Octoberfest of some 60 works-in-progress. This is not unusual for Ensemble Studio Theater. ''At the end of the year, we wind up having done 230 or 240 projects of one kind or another,'' says Curt Dempster, the company's 49-year-old artistic director. ''In June we kind of look around in a dazed state. Nobody knows how it ever gets done.''

title: TENANT VICTORY
description: APHRODITE SCHMIDT, a tenant activist in Harrison, won the right to stay in the apartment she has occupied for 20 years when Town Justice John M. Voetsch ruled late last month that her landlord, Chester Soling, had been retaliating against her when he tried to evict her.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
