description: WHEN a baseball game is rained out, there is always a chance that it will be made up as a double-header, thus giving fans double their money's worth. Not so with an air show. Officers at McGuire Air Force Base in Wrightstown say they would rather break tradition than have aviation devotees disappointed again. The base's traditional air show and open-house program on Memorial Day have been rained out a number of times, and so in the hopes of guaranteeing sunny skies, this year's events have been scheduled for Sunday, Aug. 18.

title: CHINA'S HIGH-TECH TROUBLES
description: UNABLE after a lengthy investigation to diagnose a malfunction in its $160,000 computer system, a Chinese institute in Shaanxi Province took the final, reluctant step of calling in a service engineer from Peking, 725 miles away. The American engineer, an employee of the small United States company that made the computer, quickly discovered the source of the problem: a rat. The animal had been foraying nightly into the computer room and chewing on a sensitive cable. The cable was replaced, the rat's droppings swept away and a six-inch-high wooden plank nailed across the doorway.

title: TIMELY DISPLAY ON BIRDS OPENS
description: KEEPING in step with the bird-watching season, which is now in full swing, the Newark Museum has mounted a timely exhibition, ''Birds Afield: Naturalist Paintings by Pieter D. Prall.''

title: REAGAN PUTS PRESSURE ON CONGRESS AS WELL AS NICARAGUA
description: MOVING swiftly after the House of Representatives rebuffed his latest request for aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan made clear last week that he had not given up pressing for change in Managua. In an action at the start of his European trip that, perhaps not coincidentally, briefly drowned out the furor over his plan to visit the German military cemetery at Bitburg, Mr. Reagan announced an embargo on trade with Nicaragua.

title: Q & A
description: Question: I will be in China for three weeks from Sept. 19 and wonder what the weather will be like and what clothes will be appropriate. Is it necessary to take the usual drugstore items or is it possible to buy tissues, aspirin, film, etc. - D. T., Southport, Conn. Answer:April and May and August through October are China's busiest times, and spring and fall offer the best weather. Conditions vary, of course, because it is a big country, but generally late September and early October in Peking and many other cities are sunny and mild. One Chinese official likened Peking's fall weather to New York's. Farther south visitors might experience some humid weather. In Peking in September the average daily maximum temperature is 78 degrees Fahrenheit and the average daily minimum is 57. The corresponding temperatures for October are 66 and 44. The number of days with measurable rain in September is about 8; in October, 2. In Wuhan, about 650 miles to the south, the average daily maximum in September is 84 degrees and the average daily minimum is 68. For October, the corresponding figures are 74 and 56. In both months there are about 10 days with measurable rain.

title: VON BULOW, AND OTHER SOAP OPERAS
description: Who cares who killed Martha von Bulow (or tried to) - if anyone did?

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN GLEN ROCK
description: Eighteen miles northwest of New York City is Glen Rock, N.J., a Bergen County community of 11,497 residents where children still ride their bicycles home from school for lunch. Watching them pedal along the borough's tree-lined sidewalks is like seeing a Norman Rockwell painting come to life.

title: 2 ISSUES IN MADRID AWAITING REAGAN
description: President Reagan is scheduled to arrive here Monday in what was to be a friendly visit, but in recent days the trip has become complicated by his trade embargo against Nicaragua and by demands by some here to cut American troops based in Spain.

title: MUSEUM CHANGES NAME AND PUTS STRESS ON FUN
description: Samantha Andrews never thought much of museums. She was too short to get a good view of the Renoirs and van Goghs that were hanging too high at most of them. The same was true of the tall sculptures - quite an ordeal for an 8-year-old.

title: NEW TRAFFIC SYSTEM DELAY
description: A $30 MILLION computerized road information network, which was to be in operation at the end of 1983 to help ease traffic congestion on Long Island, will not go into effect until next spring, officials now say.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DOUBLE MAN. By William S. Cohen and Gary Hart. (Morrow, $16.95.) This cloak-and-blather confection by Senators William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, and Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado, is as plausible as any labor done thus far this year in Washington. The book is much like the capital, breathless with self-conceit and silly with ruminations on ''power.'' The hero-senator, Thomas Chandler, would be President except for the machinations of the C.I.A. and K.G.B. in a plot crammed with the high stakes and casuistries worthy of the MX debate. The authors have done President Reagan the favor of accepting his all-purpose foreign policy premise - the elevation of terrorist acts, in this case attempts on the lives of American officials, from violent symptoms of life's complicated travails, to a singular, diabolical problem. This helps the scenario bubble like a large pizza to go, studded with pieces of Kennedy conspiracy, Star Wars, Mafioso patriots, the omniscient source in the shadows - every D.C. cliche but the Federal deficit. The characters are self-important enough to be believable by Washington standards. Senator Tom's beauteous, green-eyed, doubly intriguing staffer, Elaine Dunham, is as tough and unfluffy as one of those business-suit neckties that capital women wear like modern-day wimples. She finally melts and joins with him in a tableau blessedly free of detailed hydraulics. One of the authors' nicer sentences goes: ''Later, back at her place, they made love.'' But the tale lacks the full, Chaucerian aroma and rumblings of life.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE ETERNAL CITY, 1748 EDITION In 1748, the Italian surveyor and architect Giambattista Nolli presented his extraordinarily detailed map of Rome to Pope Benedict XIV. Completed at a time when the city was emerging from a long, vigorous building period, the map has 14 plates, each 22 by 32 inches, and is not only a definitive record of the city, but a benchmark in the history of cartography.

title: LITTLE JIMMY SCOTT SEEKS TO EVOKE A HAPPIER PAST
description: LITTLE JIMMY SCOTT, the jazz singer who mesmerized fans of the Lionel Hampton band during the 1950's with his impassioned treatment of ballads and then largely dropped out of sight, returned to the New York scene last week for the first time in nearly 14 years.

title: TANKING UP Uniform Cheek
description: Efforts to establish a uniform public drinking age of 21 took an absurd turn last week when the Connecticut Senate exempted men and women in uniform.

title: PUTTING HYPNOSIS IN THE FOOTLIGHTS
description: JAMES J. MAPES, an actor, is also a futurist, hypnotist, philosopher, writer and, perhaps above all, showman. He leads seminars in his Wilton home, conducts workshops on self-image for corporate executives and performs a one-man show called ''A Journey Into the Imagination,'' in which he hypnotizes members of the audience.

title: CUBA'S EMERGENCE, AMERICA'S MYOPIA
description: T he big news from Havana this spring, apparently unnoticed by the Nicaragua-obsessed Reagan Administration, is Cuba's rapid emergence from a quarter of a century of political and diplomatic isolation in Latin America.

title: A WEEKEND WITH THE FAMILY
description: As soon as warm ocean winds bathe the tip of eastern Long Island, my wife and I move to a little beach bungalow a few miles from our winter home.

title: FOURCADE IS GETTING SHOT WITH GIANTS
description: John Fourcade played quarterback for a year and a half in the Canadian Football League, then for a year in the United States Football League. Now, when rosters may be smaller and quarterback jobs fewer, he is trying to win a job in the National Football League.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LIFE AND DEATH ON 10 WEST, by Eric Lax. (Laurel/Dell, $4.50.) Ten West is a ward in the U.C.L.A. Medical Center, a cancer research unit where Linda Galbraith, 26 years old and pregnant, learned she had a cancer of the blood and 18 months to live. The treatment was chemotherapy and a risky bone marrow transplant. This report chronicles her case and portrays her family, other patients and the ward's chief clinical physician. Last year our reviewer, Andrea Barnet, said the author was able to provide a story with ''considerable power and compassion and still accurately convey the medical science involved.'' THE FRATRICIDES, by Nikos Kazantzakis. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) This novel's hero, Fa-ther Yanaros, ministers in a mountain village to Communist and anti-Communist factions in Greece's civil war and to children who eat dirt. Albert J. Zuckerman wrote in these pages in 1964 that the author, who also wrote ''Zorba the Greek,'' succeeds here ''in hauntingly evoking the poetry of man's very stench, as he engages in the ultimate combat, a fiercely heroic and inevitably mortal attempt to end man's inhumanity toward his brothers.'' Athena Gianakas Dallas was the translator. THE GODS, THE LITTLE GUYS AND THE POLICE, by Humberto Costantini. (Bard/Avon, $3.95.) In this novel a dozen harmless poets in Buenos Aires meet to read their work to one another. Suddenly they are marked for execution by a paramilitary death squad. Toby Talbot translated this winner of the 1979 Premio Casa de las Americas.

title: Manhattan Oasis
description: IT was little more than a community dump in the section of Manhattan once called Hell's Kitchen. But volunteers in the neighborhood leased the vacant lot from the city for $1 a year and turned it into the Clinton Community Garden.

title: KEY BLACK OFFICIAL IN MICHIGAN SWITCHING TO G.O.P.
description: When William Lucas ran in 1982 as the Democratic nominee for Executive of Wayne County, which includes Detroit and many of its suburbs, he won with 77 percent of the vote. Nevertheless, he is expected to switch next week to the Republican Party and to run next year against Gov. James Blanchard, a Democrat.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THIS LAND IS YOUR LAND: The Struggle to Save America's Public Lands. By Bernard Shanks. (Sierra Club, $19.95.) ''The nation needs a manifesto for the land,'' Bernard Shanks warns, and in this passionate but factual book he provides one.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Stanley Shakespeare, one of Bernie Kosar's receivers at the University of Miami, has signed with the Cleveland Browns, the team expected to get Kosar in a supplemental draft this summer. . . . Pam Shriver, who has been trying for a comeback after three months on the injured list, was seeded first for the inaugural Australian Women's Open, which begins tomorrow. . . . The Boston Globe reported in yesterday's editions that the Boston Bruins would name Butch Goring as head coach tomorrow.

title: COOKING FOR ONE GUEST
description: The allegation that I am the world's greatest misanthrope is not true. However, I rarely entertain more than one weekend guest at a time in my home. It is not for want of beds, nor of space to which I might retire when mind and body demand the comfort of silence. It is simply that I find it a blessing to have the company of just one other human being with whom to walk, to talk and to share the pleasure of music or books. There are fewer beds to make, and my routine in the kitchen is not disturbed by conversation. I am easily distracted by idle chatter in the midst of pastry making or even the stirring of a simple sauce.

title: JUDYTH SCHAUBHUT WED TO EXECUTIVE
description: Judyth Louise Schaubhut, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gordon Schaubhut of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Earl Reginald Smith 2d, a son of Mrs. Earl Reginald Smith of Pawcatuck, Conn., and the late Mr. Smith. The Rev. Ernest L. Fogg of the Central Presbyterian Church in Montclair, N.J., performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Manhattan.

title: Ohio Gets Big Returns On Registration Drive
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

COLLEGE OPTIONS
description: Richard Manley likes to refer to 1968, when he applied to college, as ''the Age of the Dinosaurs.'' Since then, he explains, some informational barriers that had discouraged access by the disabled to higher education have become extinct.

title: PENTAGON SHIFTS ON PENSION TRIMS
description: The Defense Department, in a surprising reversal, is prepared to accept reductions in military retirement pay, according to senior civilian officials in the Pentagon.

title: BEIRUT FIGHTING GOES INTO ITS 7TH DAY
description: Christian and Moslem militiamen, entrenched behind newly erected earthen barricades, traded sniper fire and hurled grenades today on the seventh day of the most recent outbreak of sectarian fighting in the Lebanese capital.

title: ALEXANDER BELL, IT'S ALL YOUR FAULT
description: UNTIL recently, I've been fairly comfortable with the computer age. I like to think of myself as a believer in the positive aspects of this new era; in fact, I even look forward to banking at home and shopping from my favorite chair.

title: COMMUTER RECALLS THE BAD OLD DAYS
description: THERE have been several experiences in my 23 years that I consider to be of a wondrous and almost magical nature, especially when compared with the banal activities that oftentimes make up everyday lives. Getting four out of six LOTTO numbers right and actually catching a cab at rush hour are downright fabulous when one considers buying underwear and throwing out yesterday's trash.

title: JAMIE BECK, CITY AIDE, MARRIES GARY GORDON
description: At Temple Emanu-El in New York yesterday, Jamie Beck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Beck of New York, Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Jupiter, Fla., was married to Gary Gordon, a son of Philip Gordon of Pearl River, N.Y., and Judith Rothstein of Highland Mills, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald Sobol performed the ceremony.

title: ROBERT J. PALME WED TO LESLIE ROBIN LEAVITT
description: Leslie Robin Leavitt, the daughter of Comdr. Jack B. Leavitt, U.S.N., retired, of Greenville, N.Y., and the late Barbara Salkeld Leavitt, was married yesterday to Robert James Palme, a son of Mrs. Richard B. Palme of Flemington, N.J., and the late Mr. Palme.

title: ANNUALS PROVE TO BE A BARGAIN
description: For 20 years I gardened in Southern California and took color for granted. It came to my flower borders and thence to the interior of my house with remarkable ease. From November to April, camellias and azaleas graced the garden and our house. In May and June, roses took over and their perfume made the air sweet. I can't remember much about July (it was too darn hot), but daylilies probably held sway. In August and September the hedge was bright with the blossoms of oleander.

title: CECILIA FERNANDEZ IS WED
description: Cecilia Fernandez, an officer with Citibank in Mexico City, and Douglas Paul Bartner, an associate in Mexico City with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, were married in a civil ceremony in Mexico City last Sunday.

title: MARK NASH BRAUNSTEIN WEDS ANDREA LA BAW
description: Lieut. Andrea Lee La Baw, U.S.A., the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Glenn D. La Baw of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Capt. Mark Nash Braunstein, U.S.A., a son of Col. Howard Braunstein, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Braunstein of Salinas, Calif.

title: UNION STATION FINANCING SET
description: HARTFORD'S Union Station, a 100-year-old brownstone building off Asylum Avenue, has seen better days.

title: Pharmaceuticals
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STARS AND THEIR CURSES
description: DREAMS THAT MONEY CAN BUY The Tragic Life of Libby Holman. By Jon Bradshaw. Illustrated. 431 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95. THE OTHER MARILYN A Biography of Marilyn Miller. By Warren G. Harris. Illustrated. 248 pp. New York: Arbor House. $16.95. ROBERT EDMOND JONES once cautioned theater students, ''Bear in mind the difference between imagination and ingenuity.

title: THE SUMMER WEEKEND
description: For some, summer weekends offer not only a much-needed respite, but also a time for spending undistracted hours with friends.

title: Calling for Change
description: Dr. Thomas Carpenter, the president of Memphis State, said he had been paid $10 a month to play college football and couldn't see any reason why today's college athletes shouldn't be paid even more. ''I played football under scholarship many, many years ago,'' he told an interviewer in Memphis.

title: OF TIME AND THE RIVER AND ENJOYABLE FAILURE
description: The Potomac River runs through here like an act of mercy, and Ken Wilson goes out on it come capital crisis or high water. Spinning rod in hand, he glances up from his boat at the huge steel clot of morning commuter traffic crawling on the bridge across the river, right above a shadowy place where he knows the largemouth bass lurk.

title: WHEN EVERYTHING SEEMED TO WORK
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF NEW YORK CITY By Roger Starr. 258 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95.

title: EMELIN CELEBRATES JEROME KERN MUSIC
description: APPROPRIATELY enough, Jerome Kern wrote the song, ''When the Spring Is In the Air,'' and the musical whence it came, ''Music In the Air.'' More appropriately, Mr. Kern's melodious music is in the air this year, perhaps more than ever.

title: LACK OF OFFICERS IS DEFENDED AT RALLY WHERE 5 PEOPLE DIED
description: A former Police Chief of Greensboro, N.C., has testified in a civil suit that before the shooting deaths of five anti-Klan demonstrators there he knew that Ku Klux Klansmen and Nazis would confront the demonstrators.

title: Children of Alcoholics
description: Excerpts of remarks by Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, to the Senate April 26:

title: A PARIS DEPOT OF FINE DESIGN
description: Sooner or later most visitors to Paris discover the narrow crowded sidewalks of the Rue de Rivoli with their souvenir stands selling models of the Eiffel Tower. If they have come to shop, they are apt to be disappointed; with a few exceptions, the high style and fine craftsmanship, still evident in the architecture of the street, are rare today in its stores. But they need not despair; chic and certitude can still be found right across the street, in a new boutique in the Musee des Arts Decoratifs.

title: The Right to an Ending
description: To the Editor:

title: RENOWNED PIANIST STARTS TOUR
description: The renowned Soviet pianist Bella Davidovich will be soloist with the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in performances this month in Newark, Englewood and Red Bank.

title: MINORITIES ADD TO STRENGTH IN PRO-DEMOCRATIC DISTRICTS
description: Five of the 10 Assembly Districts in New York City with the largest Democratic enrollments have either a black or Hispanic population majority, according to politicians and others who have analyzed the enrollment lists just updated by the Board of Elections.

title: REFUGEE'S HOPES LIE WITH HIS CHILDREN
description: In the spring of 1975 a soothsayer in Vietnam assured Nguyen Dinh Tri that he would enjoy 10 more years of wealth as long as he kept his moustache. Mr. Tri kept his moustache. And within weeks he lost everything and became a refugee.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: SWARMING AND BUMPING Young visitors to the Philadelphia Zoo can now see through the eyes of a frog, swing inside a cocoon, swarm inside a beehive and bump into a dinosaur.

title: A LONELY ROAD AT BONN PARLEY FOR MITTERRAND
description: For connoisseurs of French diplomacy, this year's economic summit meeting has been a classic play, reminiscent of the grand old style favored by Charles de Gaulle.

title: THE MORTGAGE MATCHMAKERS
description: WHEN a major real-estate deal is announced, the spotlight is typically on the buyer and seller, the parcel being sold and the millions being paid. Then, in a footnote of sorts, comes a mention of the company that arranged the financing.

title: STUDY LISTS WAYS TO DETER RAPISTS
description: A study based on observations of 800 convicted rapists suggests new guidelines for how women should react when confronted with an attacker. The new study identifies four major kinds of rapists and offers a strategy to use with each.

title: Crime
description: Harry Kemelman started his Rabbi David Small series in 1964 with ''Friday the Rabbi Slept Late'' and within a dozen years had exhausted the days of the week. There was ''Monday the Rabbi Took Off,'' ''Tuesday the Rabbi Saw Red,'' ''Wednesday the Rabbi Got Wet'' and so on. Having no more named days to work with, in his newest Rabbi Small book Mr. Kemelman has resorted to the indefinite future: SOMEDAY THE RABBI WILL LEAVE (Morrow, $14.95).

title: VIETNAM IN AMERICA
description: The editor's preface to the retrospective on the Vietnam experience twice referred to it as a ''defeat.'' That is a tendentious way to describe what was admittedly an inglorious experience; for we could have exterminated our enemies in Vietnam had we been willing to pay the price.

title:
ANTIQUES;

HISTORY IN A STONE HOUSE
description: IT seems only fitting and proper that the celebration of the settlement of Connecticut, 350 years ago, begin this week with an invitation to visit Connecticut's oldest stone house. The Whitfield House in Guilford is now a state museum. When it was built in 1639 as a home for the settlement's first pastor, it was designed also to serve as a meeting and garrison should such a safe place be needed.

title: CEMETERY PROTESTS REPORTEDLY BARRED
description: Two groups of American Jews said today that West German and American authorities had barred them from protesting President Reagan's visit to a German military cemetery where 49 Waffen SS troops are buried.

title: Grinnell College Plans to Sell Some South Africa Holdings
description: After protests by students over the years, the Board of Trustees of Grinnell College voted yesterday to divest itself of some of its South African investments.

title: JOURNAL FOR THE ELDERLY IS FACING ITS FINAL DAYS
description: UNDER ordinary circumstances, May would have brought a double celebration to the offices of The Connecticut Elder: National Senior Citizens Month and the 10th anniversary of the only publication exclusively serving the state's 570,000 residents over the age of 60.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: FIVE of New Jersey's largest chemical companies have established a pilot training program for emergency personnel who respond to hazardous-chemical fires and other chemical-related accidents.

title: THE TOP COURT WILL HAVE MORE TO SAY ON RELIGION
description: The Supreme Court took off last week for a two-week recess before the stretch run to the end of its nine-month term around July 4. Every case to be decided - 175 of them, the lowest number since 1981 - has been argued and about half are still awaiting decision. While many of the early rulings will be lucky to end up as footnotes in a law text, the decisions to come embody the heart and soul of the 1984-85 term. Like a legislature or any other body that lives by compromise, the Court tends to save the hardest, most contentious questions for last.

title: A LANDLOCKED SEAFOOD SPOT
description: IT is a culinary irony that one of the best seafood restaurants in Connecticut is not along the shoreline, but landlocked in the northwest part of the state.

title: Recent Sales
description: Belmar $60,000 1000 River Road *2* 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old low-rise condominium; wall- *2* to-wall carpeting, walk to beach, maintenance $153; taxes $1,283. Haledon $78,000 376 Central Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Cape; *2* den, laundry room; taxes $1,363. Metuchen $60,000 300 High Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old Cape; greenhouse, *2* basement with bar and wood stove; taxes $1,694. Mine Hill $86,000 25 Pine Street *2* 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old Cape; natural woodwork, *2* 2-car garage, aluminum siding; taxes $2,017. Parsippany $162,000 24 Robert Street *2* 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; *2* tiled foyer and kitchen floors, *2* fireplace, central air conditioning; taxes $2,960. Wayne $150,000 3 Bristol Place *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; new kitchen, *2* finished half-basement, cedar siding; taxes $3,022. OTHER AREAS East Islip, L.I. $175,000 8 Kay Court *2* 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; *2* dining room, den, pool; taxes $4,000. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $121,900 2743 Hyatt Street *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old frame Cape; country kitchen, *2* deck, lake rights, 94-by 102-foot lot; taxes $4,037. Canton, Conn. $83,500 51 High Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 89-year-old gingerbread Victorian; *2* fine molding, 100- by 180-foot lot; taxes $1,341.

title:
ART;

WHERE WATER SPRITES FROLIC
description: IN 1925, an article in House and Garden magazine summarized the prevailing attitude of landscape architects and clients alike toward statuary: ''It is the mission of sculpture in the garden at all times to put the culminating touch to the design.'' How alien this statement is to landscaping practice today, when whole estates may be modified to accomodate and complement a single piece of outdoor sculpture.

title: SUMMER SPIRITS
description: You've heard the old lament: ''I brought my harp to the party, but nobody asked me to play''? The spiritous equivalent is having a bar stocked with things that nobody wants to drink.

title: EXPELLED FOREIGNERS POURING OUT OF NIGERIA By The Associated Press
description: Thousands of illegal aliens, carrying mattresses, clothing and cooking utensils, poured back across the borders to their homelands today, ordered out by Nigeria's military rulers.

title:
ANTIQUES;

THE ASSETS OF MIDWEEK SHOWS
description: WITH only 52 weekends in a year and hundreds of antiques-related events crowding the calendar, some veteran show planners have opted for the attractive alternative of weekday scheduling.

title: BELINDA GAIL VENO MARRIES RICHARD M. BENINCASA
description: Belinda Gail Veno and Richard Mansfield Benincasa were married yesterday at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. Walter Wagoner, a Methodist minister, assisted by the Rev. John Denniston, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is the daughter of Angelo J. Veno of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mrs. Sanford G. Simmons of Greenwich. Mr. Benincasa is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Benincasa of Manhasset, L.I.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The British pop duo Wham has sold millions of records with recycled American-style soul music and boyish, telegenic images. Its seven video clips display two all-but-contradictory images and suggest a third.

title: THE MIDWEST'S BRAWNY CAPITAL
description: My favorite place in Chicago is, technically, not within the city limits. But Chicago being Chicago, being outside the normal boundaries of the law a few feet, or even a couple of yards, becomes a minor technicality. The favored place is where the Kennedy Expressway crosses the Tristate Tollway which crosses the Des Plaines River which crosses U.S. 12 and 45 which cross the railroad tracks which cross the final glide path of so many silver jets thundering their way toward the runways of O'Hare International Airport, the world's busiest aircraft sanctuary.

title: ARE THINGS STILL SAVED FOR 'COMPANY'?
description: A FRIEND of mine was telling me the other day about a bottle of wine that was giving him problems. Not from drinking it, but from not drinking it.

title: JOB BIAS RESULTED IN $3.7 MILLION IN AWARDS OVER 5 YEARS IN JERSEY
description: Employment-discrimination cases resulted in most of the $4 million in discrimination awards and damages obtained by the State Division of Civil Rights in the last five years, according to a new study.

title: TRACY HARRIS WEDS DOUGLAS B. LEVENE
description: Tracy Beth Harris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Harris of Baltimore, was married at the Har Sinai Synagogue there yesterday to Douglas Barrack Levene, a son of Irma R. Levene of Boston and the late Dr. Martin B. Levene. Rabbi Floyd Herman performed the ceremony.

title: GEORGE PERLE IN THE SPOTLIGHT AT 70
description: ''Ever since my first article on 12-tone music was published more than 40 years ago, it has been obvious to almost every critic who has been called upon to comment on my work that I must be a composer of '12-tone' or serial music,'' George Perle wrote recently. ''Forty years ago, that made me 'avant-garde' and today that makes me 'academic.' But the fact is that in all these years I've written only three pieces in which one can discover tone-rows or serial procedures, and of these I've discarded one and the other two have never been published or publicly performed.''

title: EGYPT'S ASSEMBLY BARS FULL ISLAMIC LAW
description: The Egyptian Parliament today in effect rejected calls for the imposition of Islamic law in this predominantly Moslem country.

title: ONE THING NASA CAN'T SETTLE: ASTRONAUTS' STOMACHS
description: THE inventive language of space, filled with such words as blastoff, launch pad, ohms and torrs, gained a new term last week. When Dr. Paul Calla-han, the biochemist in charge of the animal experiments for the current Challenger shuttle flight, was asked how sick one of the squirrel monkeys on board was, he replied ''two garns.''

title: College Mark Set
description: Kathy Hayes set a collegiate record in the women's 5,000 meters tonight in the Oregon Pepsi Relays track and field meet. The Oregon a senior finished in 15 minutes 23.03 seconds, bettering the mark of 15:29, set by Stanford's PattiSue Plumer last year.

title: Far-Reaching Effects Of Health-Benefits Tax
description: In the name of tax reform - and with the purported aim of reducing the national deficit - a frightening horror story is emerging from Washington D.C. It's called a tax on employee health benefits. Few people realize the long-range damage that such a tax would wreak - not only on individuals and families - but on the system of health care that exists in this country, and on the entire economy.

title: May 5, 198512NAL Books, $12.95.) In this pseudonymous novel by Stephen King, a young lawyer finds his body mysteriously wasting away. *2 2 15 IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term.

How to buy real estate with little or no money; revised edition of a 1980 book. 2 WEIGHT WATCHERS QUICK START 3 16 PROGRAM COOKBOOK, by Jean Nidetch. (NAL Books, $17.95.) A cuisine that slims. 3 DR. ABRAVANEL'S BODY TYPE PROGRAM FOR 4 2 HEALTH, FITNESS AND NUTRITION, by Elliot D. Abravanel and Elizabeth A. King. (Bantam, $15.95.) ''A total health program tailored for the individual.'' 4 WHAT THEY DON'T TEACH YOU AT 2 33 HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL, by Mark H. McCormack. (Bantam, $16.95.) ''Street-smart'' notes and tips. 5 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $14.95.) Recipes for delicious dishes prepared at moderate cost.

title: FOR THE AGED, NURSING PLUS INDEPENDENCE
description: TWENTY years ago, designing entire communities for the elderly was an enterprising new idea in housing.

title: DANCING THE MAGIC OF YOUNG LOVE
description: They fell in love when they were teen-agers - young and carefree and eager to throw all their passion into their romance and their dancing. Fernando Bujones said that as a young dancer, new to the School of American Ballet and the city, he would spend infatuated hours watching Marianna Tcherkassky practicing at the barre and rehearsing her dances. ''I was flabbergasted by her gentleness and her beauty,'' he said. Now more than 10 years later, both dancers are principals with American Ballet Theater and they are happily married to other people. Still, the tender feelings Miss Tcherkassky and Mr. Bujones shared when they were younger are recreated when they dance together as Romeo and Juliet.

title: ADJUSTING SECTIONAL GARAGE DOORS
description: OVERHEAD garage doors that roll up in hinged sections or panels are far more popular than the one-piece, canopy-type doors, even though one-piece doors are generally cheaper. Sectional doors are more reliable and less likely to break down or need frequent adjustment. However, spring tension will have to be increased eventually, and rollers or other moving parts will need lubrication or tightening.

title: DIOGUARDI OFFERS A FEW SURPRISES
description: FOUR months into his first year on Capitol Hill, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi has found himself traveling twice as much as when he was an accounting executive, living three days a week in a rented apartment and even voting against President Reagan.

title: MEETING EXAMINES FAMINE IN AFRICA
description: Participants in the seven-nation economic conference here unexpectedly announced their intention today to explore ways to combat hunger in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: SPACE EXPLORATION FROM CHAPTER ONE
description: Enough time has passed, more than a quarter of a century, for the space age now to attract chroniclers who address the historical dimensions of this new power to break the bonds of Earth's gravity and travel out to a frontier unlike any other. There is, it seems, a growing recognition of space flight as an enduring phenomenon that may well transcend all previous human experience.

title: THE SURRENDER AT RHEIMS: A REMEMBERANCE
description: THERE was a brief ceremony in the industrial school at Rheims, and then it was over. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Chief of Staff for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Supreme Allied Commander, presided. With him were Gen. Carl Spaatz of the Air Force, Gen. Frederick Morgan of the British Army, Adm. Sir Harold Burrough of the Royal Navy, Air Marshal James Robb of the Royal Air Force and France's Gen. Francois Sevez. The Soviet Union was represented by Maj. Gen. Ivan Susloparov and his interpreter, Col. Ivan Zenkovitch. Gen. Alfred Jodl and Adm. Hans George von Friedeburg, the German representatives, were escorted in by two British officers. Gen. Kenneth Strong, Eisenhower's head of intelligence, laid the surrender documents before them. Smith asked if they were prepared to sign. Jodl nodded. He and Friedeburg signed, followed by Smith, Susloparov and Sevez.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. LEADER FAULTS DEMOCRATS
description: The local labor leaders sat in silence when Lane Kirkland said the Federal deficit ''will require our children and their children to pay for Ronald Reagan's tax giveaways to the rich.'' They clapped politely when he ticked off labor's recent successes in turning out the vote. Finally, they broke into enthusiastic applause when he attacked those in the Democratic Party ''who joined Mr. Reagan in flailing workers and their unions as 'special interests.' ''

title: Housing Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OUTCOME FOR U.S.: POLITICAL CLASH IS AVOIDED
description: By scaling down his political goals and anticipating worries among the allies over the space-based defense program, President Reagan has avoided a political clash at the seven-nation conference here and has come off better on political than on economic issues.

title: MAKING MUSIC CAN BE HARMFUL TO ONE'S HEALTH
description: Creating musical pleasure is causing musicians a lot of pain. Music may grant cathartic satisfactions few other human occupations can match, but from many it is also exacting a heavy price - in chronic afflictions of muscles and tendons; a heavy incidence of coronary heart disease; and perhaps most worrisome of all, in the debilitating burdens of mental stress, stage fright and the unrelenting pressures to excel.

title: A SAMPLING OF SPECIAL TOURS
description: For music lovers there could hardly be a better time to travel than this summer and fall, considering how much attention is being paid, especially in Europe, to the anniversaries of such musical giants as Bach, Handel, Schutz and Domenico Scarlatti. The coincidence of their anniversaries prompted officials in 23 countries to join together under the banner of European Music Year and to offer visitors not only the usual wealth of music festivals but a few extra events as well.

title: NEW 'PERSPECTIVES' AT MORGAN STANLEY
description: ''I'M not sure I can do this job,'' Byron R. Wien, Morgan Stanley & Company's investment strategist for United States securities, said recently. ''But if I can do it, I will derive more satisfaction from this job than from going somewhere else and being a portfolio manager. When you manage money, you sit in a cell, look at a machine and buy and sell stocks.''

title: JODEE LYNN LA MOTTA WED TO E. J. NOVAK JR.
description: Jodee Lynn La Motta, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. La Motta of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Edward Joseph Novak Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Novak of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Leonard Kotzbauer, the Roman Catholic chaplain of Colgate University, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Tea in London
description: To the Editor: A pox on The New York Times, and other publications that cater to affluent American travelers, for overexposing the delights of tea in London's older and posher hotels (''Trial by Afternoon Tea in London,'' Travel, March 24.).

title: MOSCOW MEMOIR
description: Current and former correspondents recall times that illustrate the meaning of hospitality.

title: IN ROWHOUSE STYLE
description: Further evidence - if any is needed - that the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn is emerging as a rival to areas like Brooklyn Heights and Park Slope in its appeal to young professionals is in the construction of 15 cooperative apartments on Huntington Avenue between Court and Clinton Streets.

title:
ART;

IN STAMFORD, ARTISTS AND THEIR PUBLIC PROJECTS
description: PUBLIC art projects are very much in the news these days, but usually more for the controversies they cause than for any artistic innovation. Yet more and more towns and cities in diverse regions of the country are becoming the recipients of these massive and long-term works. One can speculate that in the future, a brassy conceptual or site-specific project in a park or a plaza will be as taken for granted as any bronze statue of a hero of some forgotten battle.

title: DESIGNED DISGUISE
description: At first glance, the stucco-like facade, strip windows and arched entrance on the one-story building nearing completion at 10 Midland Avenue in Port Chester, N.Y., seem like unremarkable details on a typical suburban office building.

title: Popular Cars Thieves' Target
description: Popular sport and luxury automobiles are the most frequent target of car thieves, who show little interest in either ordinary models or a variety of rare vehicles, the Government says.

title: FORGET THE ZUCCHINI, PLANT SOME UPLAND CRESS
description: For 20 years or more, my wife and I might well have been nominated Mr. and Mrs. Average American Gardener. As novice suburbanites, we began with ''easy'' vegetables. Our first crop of malformed carrots and wizened string beans filled us with the kind of pride and pleasure that a 4-year-old boy feels when he manages to tie shoes all by himself for the first time.

title: Shhhh! People at Work
description: A startling revolution in the working conditions and habits of Federal workers has quietly begun in one small corner of Washington's sprawling bureaucracy. For three weeks, the 250 employees of the Commerce Department's United States and Foreign Commercial Service have been observing Quiet Hour between 3 and 4 P.M. every day.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANTINGS CAN BAR THE UNWANTED
description: PLANTS serve us in many ways. Uses that come readily to mind are as vegetables and fruits to eat, trees for shade and flowers for beauty. Certain other uses, though common, are not often thought about. One is that plants can provide a barrier against unwanted traffic.

title: A CRIITIC'S GUIDE TO THE NOTEWORTHY
description: European summer festivals are best symbolized by Bayreuth in West Germany and Salzburg in Austria.

title: A DRINK WITH DRAMA
description: At this time of year, the question most often asked of anyone in the wine world is:

title: EMIGRES WELCOME APARTHEID BATTLE
description: As resistance to apartheid rises in their homeland, many South Africans in the New York area say they welcome growing American concern over the troubled situation thousands of miles away.

title: A CHANCE TO JOIN THE COUNTY'S SAGA
description: FIRST the good news. If you are a Westchester resident, you have an opportunity to win a guaranteed permanent place on Metro-North. While others are standing in the aisles or battling for a bit of space between four shopping bags and two briefcases, you will be nestled in an aisle seat reserved for you alone. The bad news: You are not going anywhere and you can never get off the train.

title: ELDERLY IN ALTERNATIVE KIND OF HOUSING
description: AT dusk, lights glow in the windows of the tall Victorian house silhouetted against the Hudson River skyline. Inside, in the warm kitchen with its yellow walls and wooden cabinets, a group of elderly people is gathered around the table, reminiscing about old songs, occasionally singing a few remembered lyrics.

title: COLLECTORS STAR AT THE SIEGEL RARITIES SALE
description: Collectors held center stage at the 22d annual Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries' Rarities of the World Sale which took place last month at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York. One of the largest turnouts in recent years produced active bidding in many sections and reasonably strong realizations.

title: Corporate Free Rides
description: To the Editor:

title: A FEMALE BEST FRIEND
description: Michael McGill's requirements for a best friend - a woman but not his wife - would put a strain on most marriages. Most successful marriages are based on a mutual trust that assumes being each other's best friend. Does Mr. McGill need ''another woman'' or a best friend? How about a dog? MARGARET KELLY Evanston, Ill.

title: COMPACT CAMERAS ARE SMALLER AND LIGHTER BUT STILL COSTLY
description: A new aspect of video has sprung into prominence. More and more video fans are discovering an innovative option - the camera.

title: ROYAL REPAST
description: Current and former correspondents recall times that illustrate the meaning of hospitality.

title: TORRINGTON FACTORY IS TARGET OF BUYOUT
description: WHILE one Naugatuck Valley community celebrated a worker buyout last week, another investigated whether it could pull off a similar success.

title: TAKE TWO EROTICIN AND CALL ME IN THE MORNING
description: ALL FOR LOVE By Ring Lardner Jr. 186 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $13.95.

title: 'BIG RIVER' IS FAITHFUL AND FELICITOUS MARK TWAIN
description: Deep in the middle of creating ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,'' Mark Twain wrote to his favorite correspondent, William Dean Howells, about the work in progress: ''I like it only tolerably well, as far as I have got, and may possibly pigeonhole or burn the MS when it is done.'' History proved Twain, at least in this regard, the most modest of gentlemen. ''Huck Finn'' was the most astonishing achievement in his career and, along with ''Moby Dick,'' the candidate most qualified to wear the title of great American novel. Both books have come to occupy a position at the heart of American mythology as well as of American literature. Though each is drawn from a particularly autobiographical experience - Twain's life on the Mississippi, Herman Melville's life at sea - they are generative acts of the imagination.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TAMRART: 13 Days in the Sahara. By Eleanor Clark. (Stuart Wright/Small Press Distribution, 1784 Shattuck Ave., Berkeley, Calif. 94709, $15.)

title: A FLEXIBLE DATABASE FOR BUSINESS
description: IF I have on occasion maintained that personal computers are pre-eminently executive toys, I have not done so to imply they are a waste of time but because they are - or can be - fun. Granted, these machines, especially when running poorly designed or even downright inhumane software, can also epitomize frustration. But what other tool can executives use to play endlessly with the numbers populating their domain?

title: Unseeded Burgin Faces Navratilova for Title
description: Martina Navratilova advanced to the final of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Houston tennis tournament today with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia.

title: Starvation Is Bad Medicine From I.M.F.
description: To the Editor:

title: WILSON'S NEW 'FENCES' NURTURES A PARTNERSHIP
description: It has been one year since August Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' opened at the Yale Repertory Theater here, announcing to the theater world the arrival of a stirring new writer. That Mr. Wilson was 39 years old at the time, a published poet and the author of a half-dozen plays - albeit mostly unproduced - did little to diminish the romance of the moment.

title: S.E.C.'S NEW ENFORCEMENT CHIEF
description: LAST year, when John M. Fedders, enforcement chief of the Securities and Exchange Commission, removed himself from the R. Foster Winans insider trading case because his former law firm was involved in the defense, his deputy, Gary G. Lynch, assumed responsibility for the prosecution. That shift, as it turned out, was prophetic.

title: WILL IT FLY?
description: FLIGHT angles were calculated in geometry class. Symmetry was worked out on a computer. A weather station was set up for the study of wind velocity.

title: POST OFFICE BOXES IN DEMAND
description: WHEN Lew Mortellaro visited the Miller Place Post Office one recent Saturday morning, he accomplished something few of his neighbors have been able to do: he rented a post office box.

title: Syracuse Routs Penn In Lacrosse by 27-9
description: Tim Nelson, college lacrosse's leading career point scorer, had nine assists and five other Syracuse players scored at least three goals each as the No. 2-ranked Orangemen routed Pennsylvania today, 27-9.

title: DEVELOPERS IN THE WINGS AT WHITNEY ESTATE?
description: A VISION of hundreds of homes devouring the lush landscape at Greentree, the sprawling Gold Coast estate of John Hay (Jock) Whitney and his sister, Joan Whitney Payson, in Manhasset, is haunting the North Hempstead Town Board.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PRESS HAS A TOUGH BEAT
description: In South Africa, more than 100 laws restrict the way the press reports the nation to itself. Sometimes, said Percy Qoboza, a black newspaper editor, he and his colleagues spend more time with their lawyers deciding what they may publish than they do at home with their spouses.

title: NEW LIFE FOR UPPER BROADWAY
description: THE feast is movable these evenings and the lights are brighter along Broadway from 84th to 96th Streets, where three new restaurants and a six-theater movie house have opened.

title: SOUNDING OFF: IT'S NO FUN BEING A YANKEE FAN
description: When George Steinbrenner dismissed Yogi Berra as manager last Sunday night, Yankee fans took pen in hand. What follows is a sample of some of the mail - all of it critical - received by The New York Times.

title: YANKEE STAR OF OLD RECALLS GLORY DAYS
description: ONLY the occasional chirping of birds or the infrequent passing of cars and farm vehicles disturbs the silence in the outskirts of this historic Salem County town, especially where Route 581 intersects Witt Drive.

title: A WEEKEND ON A BOAT
description: Our fleet of sailing ships has been alarmingly diminished by my husband since I wrote in this magazine on the ecstasies experienced as the woman who stands behind the man behind the wheel. (I speak here figuratively. Although behind, I am also 10 feet below him, in that paradise called the galley.) Cyrano, Bill's 60-foot schooner and the one true love of his life, was sold awhile ago. The few times a year we were all able to sail her, weighed against the cost of her upkeep, did not make for an affordable equation. A year later, Suzy Wong, his teak yawl, was bought by a charming but obviously seriously demented young couple whose one dream in life was to own and maintain a wooden boat. In fact, they now spend every free hour of what they consider an idyllic existence scraping and painting Suzy - and whatever else one does to an all-wood craft.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANTINGS CAN BAR THE UNWANTED
description: PLANTS serve us in many ways. Uses that come readily to mind are as vegetables and fruits to eat, trees for shade and flowers for beauty. Certain other uses, though common, are not often thought about. One is that plants can provide a barrier against unwanted traffic.

title: THE ART OF POLITICS, CHICAGO STYLE
description: Politics is to Chicago what the running of the bulls is to Pamplona: a rude, energetic, irresistible public spectacle in which nimble movement is essential to the survival of both spectators and participants. Chicago politics is the great American novel, soap opera and contact sport rolled into one, and interested visitors can easily sense its gutty moods on a tour of historically significant sites.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: E.T.: THE BOOK OF THE GREEN PLANET. By William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam, Cloth, $15.95. Berkley, Paper, $3.50.) There's no figuring this E.T. fellow.

title:
EDUCATION WATCH;

THE METHOD IN THIS MATH
description: Michelle Bloomberg's number scroll is now over 77 feet long and growing. Michelle, a second grader at the William H. Ray School on Chicago's south side, has been writing numbers, starting with the number one, in consecutive order on pieces of paper and gluing them together. At last count she was up to 11,290. She carries the scroll rolled up in a plastic bag wherever she goes. Michelle says there's no telling how far the numbers will take her.

title: CONSUMER RATES
WHEN EVERY BUILDING STRIVES FOR THE FOREGROUND
description: By the end of this decade, there may be four mansard roofs of glass looming over Times Square.

title: THE TRIALS OF A HOST
description: At our wedding, Mary promised to love, honor, cherish, even to obey - how quaint it now seems. She made no promise to entertain. She did murmur, ''I never told you that the only thing I can cook is mince and mashed potatoes,'' but the deed was done, and I thought of Peachy, my childhood sweetheart, who could at least make hot chocolate.

title: NOW VIETNAM DEALS FROM STRENGTH
description: Fresh from its string of military successes against rebel forces in Cambodia, Vietnam last week was again self-confidently calling for political discussions on the future of its neighbor.

title: ARE MOVIES A FABULOUS INVALID TOO?
description: Jack Valenti, the jut-jawed president of the Motion Picture Association of America who defends his industry like a Roman senator remembering the Alamo, leaned over a table recently, looked out from under his sheet-rock brow and made a defiant statement.

title: ONCE AGAIN, AN ECONOMIC SUMMIT WITH A LOW YIELD
description: MOST of the presidents, prime ministers, ministers and cabinet secretaries came here for the 11th annual meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies with a seemingly modest goal: to mark a couple of dates on their agendas that would merely commit them to talking some more. But such is the nature of economic summit meetings that even in the setting of dates, the Western leaders came up short.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, MAY 5, 1985 International

title: Kansas Woman Wins $9 Million in IUD Case
description: A jury has awarded nearly $9 million to a Topeka woman who said the use of the Dalkon Shield birth-control device had forced her to undergo a hysterectomy.

title: GOLF COURSE SOUGHT FOR POLICE STATION
description: THE Village of Woodsburgh fought the Nassau County Police Department and last year won the right to establish its own municipal police force. It then planned to put its police headquarters in a trailer at the Woodmere docks until the Town of Hempstead quashed the idea. Now Woodsburgh is rocking the boat again.

title: BRINGING THE 'SPORTING LIFE' HOME
description: ''WHILE I love ideas that are esoteric,'' said Roberta London of Great Neck, ''more than that, I love ideas that grab a lot of people.''

title: New Grucci Home Found in Suffolk
description: SINCE a damp Saturday morning in November 1983, when $700,000 worth of fireworks exploded, leveling their cramped factory in Bellport, the Grucci family has been searching for a permanent facility elsewhere on eastern Long Island.

title: RADIO PSYCHOLOGIST OFFERS AID
description: FROM a radio station in a little house here, Dr. Gwendolyn Goldsby Grant's voice reaches out to the abused, the homeless, the jobless, the hopeless. They listen and, often, their lives take a new and better turn.

title: ELIZABETH CONZEN WEDS J. J. ZELLNER
description: The Marble Collegiate Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Maria Conzen, a daughter of Willibald Hermann Conzen of Verona, N.J., and Salome Bruwer Conzen of New York, to Jesse Joseph Zellner, the son of the late Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Jesse Zellner of Nashville. The Rev. Stanert L. Dransfield performed the ceremony.

title: WORKING MOTHERS AFFECT SCHOOL DAY
description: AS their children reach school age, an increasing number of mothers on Long Island are returning to work. As a result, school districts are facing additional responsibilities and problems.

title: FOR THESE BOYS OF SUMMER, THE GAME IS STICKBALL
description: STICKBALL, the popular city street and schoolyard game of the 1930's, 40's and 50's, is making a comeback in the 80's on Long Island, says Ronald Babineau of East Rockaway. He is the founder and commissioner of the United States Stickball League, which enters its second season on Saturday.

title: NANCY REAGAN AND POPE DISCUSS WAR ON NARCOTICS
description: Nancy Reagan discussed her campaign against drug abuse with Pope John Paul II today, and the Pope called for international cooperation to end the ''enslavement which results from this dependency.''

title: IN DREAMS PERSIST APARTHEID
description: KRUGER'S ALP By Christopher Hope. 279 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $15.95.

title: WHEN THE IDENTITY IS THE CRISIS
description: HOME TRUTHS Sixteen Stories. By Mavis Gallant. 330 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: REV. LUCIA P. BALLANTINE WED
description: The Rev. Lucia Peavey Ballantine and Ron William Walden were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal diocese of New York. He was assisted by the Very Rev. James Park Morton, Dean of the Cathedral, and the Rev. Ledlie I. Laughlin Jr., rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields in New York, where the bride is assistant rector.

title: Gallup Says 58% CallDeficit 'Very Serious'
description: There is a growing public perception that the Federal budget deficit poses a very serious threat to the country and that it should be reduced by cuts in military spending, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Love of the Uncommon It would be difficult to find a more classical characterization of the nature of fiction than this one quoted from Hardy by Irving Howe in his ''Thomas Hardy'' (Collier). Mr. Howe calls it an ''esthetic of incongruity,'' a phrase which might apply to fiction's latest shimmering product. The real if unavowed purpose of fiction is to give pleasure by gratifying the love of the uncommon in human experience, mental or corporeal. This is done all the more perfectly in proportion as the reader is illuded to believe the personages true and real like himself. Solely to this latter end a work of fiction should be a precise transcript of ordinary life: but the uncommon would be absent and the interest lost. Hence the writer's problem is, how to strike the balance between the uncommon and the ordinary so as on the one hand to give interest, on the other to give reality. In working out this problem, human nature must never be made abnormal, which is introducing incredibility. The uncommonness must be in the events, not in the characters; and all the writer's art lies in shaping the uncommonness while disguising its unlikelihood, if it be unlikely. The Intimate Stranger Feminists too have fathers, whom they sometimes have to reconcile with their principles. In ''Fathers,'' a collection of essays edited by Ursula Owen (Pantheon), the novelist Angela Carter describes the odd feeling of being devoted to an inscrutable stranger she has known and lived with all her life.

title: Word-Guessing in America
description: To the Editor:

title: 109TH FRESH AIR FUND APPEAL SEEKS TO AID 13,500 CHILDREN
description: For many children in New York City, summer means stickball in the streets, basketball in concrete schoolyards and fire hydrants spouting water.

title: THE REASSURANCE OF FOREST HILLS
description: THEY painted Bill Tilden's old locker at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills the other day as part of a $1 million rehabilitation now in its final stages at the former tennis capital of this country.

title: WHAT THE CHARTS SAY ABOUT THE HEALTH OF POP MUSIC
description: Pop music is in the throes of a new boom cycle, both economically and artistically.

title: Trauner Beats Darby In Richardson Final
description: Mark Trauner of Metropolis, who resigned as a banker last November to concentrate on golf, defeated Brian Darby of Huntington, 6 and 5, to win the William D. Richardson Memorial Tournament today at the Seawane Golf and Country Club.

title: A TAX INCREASE WOULD WIDEN THE GAP
description: ONCE again, David A. Stockman, the budget director, has come up with a deficit-reduction plan, this time promising reductions of $297 billion between 1986 and 1988. And once again, President Reagan and the Republican leadership have embraced the plan, even though it amounts to nothing more than a prelude to new - and counterproductive - tax increases that will ultimately insure that the budget swings even further out of balance.

title: TOUR OF DUTY: MOVIE MATINEE
description: IT was with a sense of much-delayed satisfaction that I learned recently that Sunday afternoon ''children's matinees'' are no longer presented at the movie theater in my village of Mamaroneck. This sociological deletion in suburban life style came to my attention when I was casting about for activities to undertake with my granddaughter on a Sunday afternoon outing. The discussion of possibilities included taking in a movie, and although that was instantly dismissed, it did resurrect for me memories of a harrowing afternoon when my own daughter was at the very age of my grandchild and my wife had given me the assignment of entertaining her all on my own one Sunday afternoon.

title: MUSIC: ALESSANDRO SCARLATTI
description: DOMENICO SCARLATTI'S 300th birthday celebration seems to have stirred up some unusual interest in his father, Alessandro. The Clarion Concerts under Newell Jenkins, at any rate, brought the elder Scarlatti's oratorio ''Santa Teodosia'' to Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night in what may have been its first performance in modern times.

title: Opposition Federation Formed in Philippines
description: More than 1,000 delegates representing groups in all 13 of the country's regions gathered to join a two-month-old federation today in hopes of ousting President Ferdinand E. Marcos and eliminating American bases from the Philippines.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 81 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 81 food establishments cited for violations of the health code.

title: SARAH CALDWELL, AFTER ILLNESS, PLANS NEW PROJECTS
description: Sarah Caldwell almost died of pneumonia last January, but Boston's 61-year-old opera conductor-director-impresario popped up a few days ago to show that she has survived even though the 1985 season of the Opera Company of Boston did not.

title: DAVID BYRNE: THINKING MAN'S ROCK STAR
description: PEROXIDE AND BLACK LEATHER. THE ELEVATOR at Manhattan's Hard Rock Cafe is crammed with members of rock groups trooping their colors. A live radio broadcast has just ended, and musicians are descending - Cheap Trick, Joan Jett's Blackhearts, and, pressed against the back of the car, a rail-thin man whose short, dark hair makes him look at once adolescent and ascetic. His somber designer suit may be high fashion, but the ballpoint pen protruding from its breast pocket is definitely high-school nerd. Clearly, he doesn't belong in this gaggle of pop notorieties. But, out on the street, two young women squeal and one asks for his autograph. Nonplussed but polite, he scribbles ''David Byrne'' and hastens into the night.

title: NORTHEAST STRUGGLES TOWARD GOAL OF CLEANER AIR
description: When ozone is stirred up in the air over New York City, residents of Bridgeport, Conn., 50 miles downwind, may experience the most discomfort.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: It was only to be expected that these folk tales, passed down by generations of human storytellers, would someday be retold anew by that electronic bard by the hearthside, the VCR. The clear standout in this anthology of short films is ''The Great Fish of Maui.''

title: GREENHAMPTON?
description: NINETEEN EIGHTY-SIX promises to be the greenest of years in the Hamptons, the 40-mile spit of land sometimes referred to as the South Fork. The U.S. Open Tournament will take place next year from June 8 to 16 at the Shinnecock Golf Club, just across from the Southampton campus of Long Island University on Route 27. The club, one of the nation's oldest, has spent two years preparing for this event. The greens will be sheared velvet; the fairways a carpet of chlorophyl, and 15,000 golf fans will join the local population of 60,000 that traditionally triples in the summer.

title: POLITICS AND PROFESSORS
description: About a hundred professors gathered at New York University last weekend for a conference on ''The Politicized Academy.'' They were concerned over what Brigitte Berger, a sociologist at Wellesley, described as ''a general ideological constellation that is antagonistic to basic American institutions, notably those of capitalism and bourgeois culture, and therefore is almost instinctively sympathetic to socialist visions of alternatives to these institutions.'' Dr. Berger decried specifically ''the fanatical dedication, the aggressive ignorance and the plain silliness'' of radical feminist attacks on centuries of culture.

title: Nikolai N. Urvantsev, Soviet Arctic Geologist
description: Nikolai N. Urvantsev, a Soviet Arctic geologist who found one of the world's richest deposits of nickel, cobalt and platinum, died earlier this year, according to information received from Moscow. He was 92 years old.

title: Exalting and Humbling Pleasures of Democracy on the March
description: To the Editor:

title: REGAN CITES PROBLEMS IN NEW YORK'S PRISONS
description: New York State's prison system, which has nearly doubled in size over the last seven years, has severe management and administrative problems, the State Comptroller has charged.

title: CUBS DEFEAT PADRES AS HOME RUNS FLY
description: Home runs by Ron Cey, Ryne Sandberg and Shawon Dunston and successive four-run innings led the Chicago Cubs to a 12-8 triumph over the San Diego Padres this afternoon.

title: CITY BALLET: A REVIVAL OF BALANCHINE 'FIREBIRD'
description: ONE viewer's ''Firebird'' is not another's at the New York City Ballet, which has seen varying choreography and even more various costuming over the past 36 years.

title: GEORGE ST. OFFERING PLAY BY SHEPARD
description: NOW that Sam Shepard has become a movie star in the good-looking, laconic Gary Cooper manner, and a media personality who goes out of his way not to be one, the masses might as well acknowledge that he is one of the American theater's most prolific, prophetic and trailblazing playwrights.

title: LIVING WITH TENANTS: AN OWNER'S GUIDE
description: SINGLE-FAMILY homes in New York generally come in two price ranges: expensive and unbelievably expensive. As a result, people who have believable incomes and who prefer running their own house to cooperative or condominium living often become landlords - they buy a building with one or more rental apartments that help pay the bills.

title: A SCIENCE PROJECT TAKES 2 EGYPTIANS TO ISRAEL
description: Egyptian and Israeli scientists at a conference here were happy to be meeting, so happy that nobody - not the hosts, not the guests and not the American sponsors - brought up the fact that of 12 Egyptians scheduled to attend only 2 had come.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''FERN has earned it,'' said Roberta Anderson about the success of ''Texas Rich'' (Ballantine, New York, $3.95), the novel now ranked sixth on The New York Times's list of paperback best sellers.

title: Hartford Spreads The Wealth
description: Connecticut's treasury is bulging, and state legislators acted last week to cope with a growing surplus. A $92.8 million package of tax cuts sailed through the State Legislature without a dissenting vote, and the General Assembly prepared to consider a variety of bills that would increase state spending. Gov. William A. O'Neill has said he will sign the tax-cut bill.

title: NOW, a Battle
description: It seems certain there will be a battle this summer for the presidency of the National Organization for Women. The incumbent, Judy Goldsmith, intends to seek a second two-year term in the $51,000-a-year job.

title: VIETNAM IN AMERICA
description: I read the special issue on Vietnam with unrelinquished interest. As a Vietnam veteran, I am relieved to see that America is finally describing the soldier of the 1960's and 70's with words like ''honor, valor and sacrifice.''

title: Court Upholds Tax on Trump
description: When Donald J. Trump, the developer, sued New York State over a new real estate tax, he readily acknowledged that he had made a profit from the sale of condominiums in the Fifth Avenue tower that bears his name. What brought him to court, he said, was that the state wanted to collect the tax only if a transaction involved cooperative or condominium units - whether a single apartment or an entire project - and only if the price of the deal reached $1 million or more. Mr. Trump's did. The 10-percent tax does not apply to profits earned from sales in residential subdivisions and those for less than $1 million. That is discrimination, claimed Mr. Trump and his fellow plaintiff, Richard Pellicane, a developer from Long Island.

title: 'The Prague Orgy'
description: Following is a brief excerpt from "The Prague Orgy," the novella-length epilogue to Philip Roth's Zuckerman trilogy ("The Ghost Writer," "Zuckerman Unbound" and "The Anatomy Lesson"). The trilogy and epilogue will be published in one volume by Farrar, Straus & Giroux in June under the title "Zuckerman Bound."

title: KNICKS' TITLE: GOOD AS FICTION
description: THE pro basketball playoffs are in swing, but in this town, Dr. Naismith's game is absent the local connection.

title: Bassett Is Adamant On a New League
description: He lost teams in the World Hockey Association and the World Football League, and now he says he will leave the United States Football League and create a league of his own.

title: HUDSON SHAD TAGGED TO GAUGE EFFECT OF PROPOSED POWER PLANTS
description: IT was a roundup, but instead of chaps and cowboy boots, the workers wore rubber hip and chest waders. Using a 500-foot haul seine and standing in three feet of muddy Hudson River water, they corralled fish off a beach south of the Rip Van Winkle Bridge. The haul seiners were out for shad - about 5,000 would do.

title: SPEND A BUCK WINS KENTUCKY DERBY BY 5-1/4 LENGTHS
description: Spend a Buck ran the fastest first mile in the history of the Kentucky Derby and then had plenty left to hold off 12 rivals and win the 111th edition of the run for the roses today at Churchill Downs.

title: CUBS HELP DUNSTON REFINE GREAT RAW TALENT
description: LAST Wednesday at 10 o'clock in the morning, under a gray sky and with the flags on the Wrigley Field center-field scorebord crackling in the sharp, wicked wind off Lake Michigan, the Cubs' only rookie practiced turning the double play at second base in the quiet ball park before 37,275 empty seats. It was still more than three hours before game time. And only the rookie and the infield coach, Ruben Amaro, and a few other early birds were on the field.

title: Base-Stealer May Run to Minors
description: VINCE COLEMAN may be faster than a speeding bullet and he may be a better base-stealer than even Rickey Henderson, but he also may be back in the minor leagues later this week. If he is, that would really be a test of his ability: Could he maintain his National League lead in stolen bases from the distant sites of the minors?

title: Q AND A
description: QUESTION: The New York Legislature passed property-tax reductions for war veterans. Can these reductions be obtained for co-ops?...G.R.W., Manhattan.

title: Shultz Says He, Too, Struggled Not to Nap
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that, like some of the leaders at the economic summit meeting here, he also had ''a little trouble'' staying awake during the reading of the final communique.

title: UNDERGROUND ART IN BOSTON AREA SUBWAY
description: Joan Mondale, wife of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, dedicated 20 works of public art here today - murals, mobiles and sculpture. But this permanent collection does not grace a gallery or museum. Instead, it adds some flair and tone to three new stops on the nation's oldest subways.

title: VIETNAM IN AMERICA
description: As exemplified by the articles in ''Vietnam in America,'' Americans continue to re-evaluate their answers to questions posed about the Vietnam War. This process is important and necessary, and we must not ignore the answer that the Vietnam War gave us.

title: TRAFFIC WOES FOR PHILADELPHIA
description: The Pennsylvania Department of Transportation has announced a three-year, $175 million plan to rebuild the city's main crosstown link, the Vine Street Expressway. The project is expected to add to traffic tie-ups caused by the Schuylkill Expressway reconstruiton begun earlier this year. The Vine Street Expressway, fed by the Schuylkill Expressway on its west end and Interstate 95 and New Jersey on the east, carries 80,000 cars daily.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SIXKILLER CHRONICLES. By Paul Hemphill. (Macmillan, $16.95.) Midway through Paul Hemphill's novel about a North Carolina country singer and his family, we come upon a Nashville lawyer who fancies himself an amateur songwriter.

title: INDIANAPOLIS DEFENDS ITS HIRING PLAN
description: In the mid-1970's, the Justice Department wanted the Indianapolis Police Department to adopt an affirmative action plan with numerical goals. Now it wants the city to drop the eight-year-old plan, and the department's change of role does not seem to be playing well in Indiana's largest city.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Snakebitten Poodle Is Hero of the Year
description: A white standard poodle named Leo is America's dog hero of the year. The poodle took six bites from a rattlesnake in protecting 11-year-old Sean Callahan and his 9-year-old sister, Erin.

title: FRIENDS ACROSS THE MOUNTAINS
description: CALL this a tale of two coaches.

title: PRIZES, SURPRISES AND CONSOLATION PRIZES
description: IT is not a serious novelist's nightmare (the possibility is so absurd); nevertheless, suppose you fancied yourself a serious novelist (a writer, as they say, of the first rank), and a wire were delivered in your dream (the telephone rang, there was a sudden knock), and this were followed by the formal announcement that you, Julia Peterkin, or you, Marjorie Rawlings, or you, Allen Drury or Michael Shaara or Alison Lurie, had been awarded the Pulitzer Prize in fiction for 1929 or '39 or '60 or '75 or '85. Well, what a pleasant supposition: to receive a prize, a famous one at that, with considerable prestige and the presumption of increased sales as well as other benefits. Why should such a compliment to your art be denied; why should the thought be unlikely, the award embarrassing, the fact nightmarish? Because the Pulitzer Prize in fiction takes dead aim at mediocrity and almost never misses; the prize is simply not given to work of the first rank, rarely even to the second; and if you believed yourself to be a writer of that eminence, you are now assured of being over the hill - not a sturdy mountain flower but a little wilted lily of the valley.

title: MT. LIVERMORE WINS CARTER
description: Mt. Livermore, a 4-year-old son of Blushing Groom-Flama Ardiente, got away quickly and scored an upset victory yesterday in the $116,400 Carter Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: SORRY, YOUR NUMBER'S UP
description: ''DON'T hang up!'' The first time I heard that, instead of the traditional ''Hello?'', I braced for an emergency.

title: 2 WHO HAVE PERSEVERED ON EXHIBITION
description: TWO artists, one from Washington and the other from Winsted, who have perservered through adversities are being exhibited this month at the Washington Art Association.

title: PRESENT DELIGHTS FOUND IN A DISTANT PAST
description: A GROUP of Connecticut residents regularly forsakes the cares of the modern era for the pleasures of a time long past. The residents, members of the Society for Creative Anachronism, have been getting together regularly for the last several years to recreate the Middle Ages ''not as it really was, but as it should have been,'' said James Reynolds, a 32-year-old Norwalk artist.

title: THE HERITAGE OF THE BLACK PRESS
description: BACK in the 1930's, a sizable portion of the American public used to stop everything to follow the radio antics of Amos 'n' Andy.

title: DANA BURNS MARRIES THOMAS HAMILTON, JR.
description: Dana B. Burns, assistant to the president of Becker & Becker, a marketing company in Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas J. Hamilton Jr., a first vice president of the J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company in New York. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: REID PREPARES TO ISSUE GARBAGE-PLANT REPORT
description: WESTCHESTER's special garbage inquiry, a look at conflict-of-interest charges and other issues arising in connection with the county's new resource-recovery plant in Peekskill, is nearing completion, Ogden R. Reid, the man who heads it, said last week.

title: FROM UNTHANK TO GLASGOW AND BACK
description: LANARK A Life in 4 Books. By Alasdair Gray. With illustrations by the author. 561 pp. New York: George Braziller. $20.

title: 400 Attend Funeral Service For Eisenhower in Baltimore
description: About 400 people attended funeral services today for Milton S. Eisenhower, brother of Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANTINGS CAN BAR THE UNWANTED
description: PLANTS serve us in many ways. Uses that come readily to mind are as vegetables and fruits to eat, trees for shade and flowers for beauty. Certain other uses, though common, are not often thought about. One is that plants can provide a barrier against unwanted traffic.

title: A WEEKEND IN THE MOUNTAINS
description: More than 250 miles north of the World Trade Center towers, up the Hudson Valley through Washington Irving's Catskills, past the state capitol, beyond the blueblood playground of Saratoga Springs, on past Glens Falls, Lake George, Ticonderoga and finally, three hours and few pit stops later, the loaded-down station wagon enters piney, isolated mountain country dotted with lazy dog intersections with names like New Russia, North Pole, Ironville, Elizabethtown and Paradox.

title: FORTY YEARS IN THE WASHINGTON WILDERNESS
description: THE OTHER ARAB-ISRAELI CONFLICT Making America's Middle East Policy, From Truman to Reagan. By Steven L. Spiegel. 522 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: FAREWELL FARE
description: As I plan food to serve on Sunday, I always try to come up with combinations that can be cooked, at least partly, in advance - preferably the day before. Experience has taught me that Sunday is the day with the greatest potential for missed schedules and changed plans. Gloomy weather can send everyone scurrying back to the city. Or a glorious day can cause guests to linger long beyond when they had expected to depart. And, of course, it is likely that they won't all leave at the same hour.

title: EMOTIONALLY SPEAKING, IT'S STILL THE SAME OLD STORY
description: The most astonishing fact about movies is how little they've changed over the last 50 years. There have been technological refinements in sound recording, in black-and-white and color film stock, and in camera and projection equipment. The shape of the screen has become a matter of the producer's choice. Characters can now do and say things that would have left earlier audiences aghast, but these things are simply a reflection of changing public manners.

title: VOWS EXCHANGED BY MISS SWIGGETT AND PETER L. GETZ
description: Helen Chinn Swiggett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Swiggett of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., and Peter Leland Getz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Leland Getz of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: EUGENE H. NICKERSON thought his award days were over. The former Nassau County Executive has been a Federal judge since 1977 and, he said, ''When you're in politics you tend to get awards until you're thrown out of office; as a judge I haven't received that many.''

title: PIANISTS, SINGERS AND STRING PLAYERS HEARD
description: THIS week's debuts came in pairs of various kinds: two pianists, two singers, two string players; two new compositions that used Gesualdo's ''Moro, lasso'' as a starting point - and two recitalists who seemed in tune with themselves and their material, and so were a joy to hear.

title: RACE EVENTS AWAIT RUNNERS
description: WESTCHESTER running enthusiasts will have about three dozen events between now and the end of summer in which to test their speed and endurance and, in some cases, provide money for charities.

title: Fishing Gear With a Twist
description: A BLEND of skepticism and parsimony makes me shy from much of the new fishing gear that appears on the market each year, particularly lures.

title: THE NEW ROLE OF RANDOM HOUSE
description: EVERY Tuesday when they are both in town, Robert L. Bernstein, the chairman of Random House, and S.I. Newhouse Jr., his boss, have lunch together in the Grill Room of Manhattan's posh Four Seasons. In their circular banquette, amid the silver and crystal, they sift through memos and reports, talking about what Mr. Newhouse calls ''the more mundane side of publishing'' - such things as warehousing and distribution - while Mr. Newhouse scratches notes on yellow legal pads.

title: Jazz Surprises Nuggets
