description: Wayne Cooper, the Denver Nuggets' center, said he was responsible for allowing Jeff Wilkins of the Utah Jazz to score 12 of his 18 points in the fourth quarter today - a performance that lifted the surprising Utah Jazz to a 131-123 victory over the Nuggets in Game 3 of their Western Conference semifinal series.

title:
WINE;

A TASTING OFFERS SELECTION OF WHITES
description: BECAUSE white wines - now preferred by Americans almost 2 to 1 over reds - are even more popular during spring and summer, it makes good sense to buy bottles early, before the best sell out (especially high-quality, dry products priced under $5 a bottle). However, at even the smallest county shop, consumers are often faced with a bewildering display of inexpensive white wines all labeled ''blanc de blanc,'' ''bianco'' or ''dry white'' - making differentiation a problem for most of us.

title: JAMES BURSIE MARRIED TO GWYNETH WALLACE
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair, N.J., yesterday Gwyneth Olivia Wallace, a daughter of Wilmah Vaughan Wallace of Montclair, N.J., and the late Melvin J. Pauly, was married to James Hugh Bersie, a son of the late Hugh Bersie and the late Susie Bersie of Grand Rapids, Mich. The Rev. Frederick J. Warnecke, assisted by the Rev. Christine Tremaine, performed the ceremony.

title: EVEN BILLY BORE DIDN'T NEED TICKETS
description: DURING his three previous visits as the Yankee manager, Billy Martin always decorated his Yankee Stadium office with some personal memorabilia, mostly photos and plaques. But on his return there Friday night for the fourth time, the blue wall behind his desk and the three white walls were bare except for what has outlived all the managerial changes of the George Steinbrenner regime - a huge photo of Mickey Mantle's home run in 1956 that nearly cleared the facade atop the Stadium's right-field roof.

title: THE STAGE: 'SPLIT DECISION'
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 2 - Boxing stories fall easily into two principal divisions - the fighter, definably the underdog, battling his way to the championship (''Rocky'') and the final countdown for the once promising contender (''Requiem for a Heavyweight''). Wait long enough, of course, and Rocky will face a ''Requiem'' at the end of the series. Kevin Heelan's ''Split Decision'' is a ''Requiem'' in ''Rocky'' country. As directed by Michael Bloom, it is the second opening of the season at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays.

title: Philip Greer, Correspondent And Ex-Financial Columnist
description: Philip Greer, economics correspondent for ABC Radio and a former nationally syndicated columnist, died Friday in Cologne, West Germany, while covering the seven-nation economic conference in Bonn. He was 54 years old and lived in Queens.

title: CROSSING OVER
description: THE SCENE IS ONE OF THE BEST-remembered in movie history: Scarlett O'Hara, desperate for something new to wear, rips the moss-green velvet curtains off the windows at Tara and orders a box of dress patterns from the attic.

title:
DINING OUT;

A SALT-AIR ATMOSPHERE
description: WITH nautical trappings enough to make us swear we smell salt and hear beating surf, Crab Shanty, landlocked though it may be, manages to convey the spirit of the waterfront. Only in its seventh year this landlubber behind tall iron gates and a screen of trees twinkling with pin lights looks crusty enough to pass for a venerable old salt.

title: A HAPPY 'TRICENTQUINQUAGENARY'
description: IT was a 5,009-square-mile birthday party complete with balloons, music and well wishes. The festivities last Wednesday in towns across the state marked the beginning of celebrations of Connecticut's 350th birthday - which the state calls its tricentquinquagenary.

title: A FEMALE BEST FRIEND
description: I read Michael McGill's article with a smile and interest. My dearest friend, a man, moved from Illinois to California several years ago; however, we keep up with each other's lives via letters and the telephone.

title: LYNN MARKS MARRIES CLIFFORD PEARLMAN
description: Lynn Allison Marks and A. Clifford Pearlman, who are lawyers, were married yesterday at the Please Touch Museum in Philadelphia by Judge Richard Klein of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas.

title: N.Y.U. ACTS TO BUILD CONTROVERSIAL DORMITORY
description: Amid continuing opposition from community groups, New York University has filed plans with the city's Buildings Department to build an 18-story dormitory in the East Village and says it wants to begin construction within a few weeks.

title: TOWPATH OF OLD IS YIELDING TO CANAL PROJECT
description: ALONG the old towpath of the Delaware and Raritan Canal here, there is little left but dust and stones, as well as twigs from a couple of thousand trees that, until recently, dotted the area.

title: LESLIE ANNE CORMACK WEDS
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Good Samaritan in Paoli, Pa., yesterday Leslie Anne Cormack, the daughter of Mrs. James H. Boyle of Radnor, Pa., and James A. Cormack, was married to Dr. Barrett H. Childs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon E. Childs of Pompton Plains, N.J. The Rev. Daniel Sullivan performed the ceremony.

title: Singing the Blues In Brooklyn
description: EVEN the sidewalks in the historic districts of many old cities can be special. In these hallowed precincts, no ribbon of bland concrete leads the pedestrian past stately homes dating back 200 years.

title: FOUNDATIONS SEEK LINKS TO CONGRESS
description: After a decade of estrangement, some members of Congress and leaders of the nation's foundations are making overtures to renew their ties.

title: Wiggins Out for Year
description: San Diego second baseman Alan Wiggins returned to cocaine addiction while undergoing treatment at a drug-rehabilitation center and will not return to the Padres this season, team officials said yesterday. The team president, Ballard Smith, said: ''While we have not talked directly to him, the information we have received from his representatives indicates he has had a relapse of his cocaine dependency.

title: Testing for Drugs
description: San Diego State has joined a growing list of colleges requiring student-athletes to submit to drug tests, and according to its athletic director, Mary Alice Hill, the screening program that will begin for the school's 600 athletes this spring will be the most sophisticated in the nation. She said the urine-testing system, similar to the one used at the Los Angeles Olympics, would be able to detect a wide variety of substances and even distinguish between casual and chronic abusers of drugs and alcohol.

title: SOUNDING OFF: IT'S NO FUN BEING A YANKEE FAN
description: When George Steinbrenner dismissed Yogi Berra as manager last Sunday night, Yankee fans took pen in hand. What follows is a sample of some of the mail - all of it critical - received by The New York Times.

title: On Language;   Come as You Are
description: A REMINDER THAT you are expected'' card came in the other day, which struck me as a more sensible memory-jogger than a repeat of the original engraved invitation with a ''To Remind'' written in the corner.

title: EDWARD A. MITCHELL
description: Edward A. Mitchell, business representative for New York Mailers Union No. 6, died of a heart attack Friday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Fairless Hills, Pa.

title: WILL GREGORY MOSHER BRING THE BEAUMONT BACK TO LIFE?
description: When Gregory Mosher was appointed artistic director of the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi Newhouse theaters last week, there was no press conference, only a casual gathering in the law offices of former Mayor John V. Lindsay, who is now the chairman of the two Lincoln Center theaters. And in that low-key setting, Mr. Mosher outlined an inaugural season of five productions in the 299-seat Newhouse rather than the 1,140-seat Beaumont.

title: Union Carbide Resumes Making Toxic Chemical
description: The Union Carbide Corporation resumed production of methyl isocyanate today, marking the first time it has made the chemical, used in insecticides, since a leak of it killed thousands of people in Bhopal, India.

title: Libya Is Said to Urge End of Sudan Rebellion
description: The Libyan Foreign Minister said tonight that Libya had asked the Sudanese rebel leader John Garang to support the new Government in Khartoum, the Sudanese news agency reported.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/HEY, LOOK US OVER
description: SOMETIMES, Ruth Kehoe was saying, making a choice was the hardest part. Here it was, almost lunch hour, and she had spent the morning shuttling between The Cameleon Theatrix, the Columbus Brass Quintet, the Kaleidescope Dancers and a group of Italian Renaissance singers called ''I Giullare di Pizza.'' Almost lunch hour, and she had seen only four performances.

title: Dioxin Holdouts
description: TIMES BEACH, MO., moved a step closer to obliteration last month when the city's aldermen voted to disincorporate as a municipality. Under a $33 million plan approved in 1983, the Federal Government is buying up all property in the small city, 25 miles southwest of St. Louis, because health officials have said it is contaminated with deadly dioxin. The property is to be turned over to Missouri.

title: FREELANCE SCHOLARS FIND A HOME BASE
description: NINE years ago, Judith Liebman left her position as assistant professor of Germanic literature at Yale, to devote herself to writing fiction and poetry full time.

title: STATE U. AT UTICA-ROME FORMING INSTITUTE FOR TELECOMMUNICATIONS
description: The State University of New York has formed a multimillion-dollar Telecommunications Institute to offer degree programs in electronic information, officials said.

title: ART PRESERVATION: A RACE AGAINST TIME
description: When the Getty Museum bought Lord Northampton's Mantegna for $10 1/2 million, last month, some people noticed that it was announced that the painting would go on show in the museum ''after cleaning and restoration.'' ''How can that be?,'' they said. ''$10 1/2 million, and the thing isn't even in good shape? What kind of a mess is that?'' In point of fact, an inspection of this kind is mandatory when a painting has been moved, been through the trade and traveled halfway across the world. But people felt that they had to have an opinion, and they gave it, every last one of them.

title: Mimimun Tax Push in Congress
description: Day by day during President Reagan's European trip last week, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d sent communications back to Washington on the dozens of decisions Mr. Reagan was making about the final details of the Administration's tax simplification plan. Back in the capitol, Congressional Democrats were sending signals too.

title: THE SAILBOAT ADDICTION
description: THERE IS A CLICHE ABOUT MEN and sailboats that, like most cliches, contains more than a little truth. The adage is that the two happiest days in a boat owner's life are the day he gets his boat and the day he gets rid of her. As a man who bought his first sailboat five years ago, fell obsessively in love with her and finally parted with her last summer, I am here to tell you that the second day is at least as satisfying as the first.

title: U.P.I.'S TOP MANAGERS ATTACK AGENCY'S OWNERS
description: The struggle for control of United Press International escalated yesterday as the managers of the financially troubled news service attacked its owners in a 2,500-word article by one of its reporters.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANTINGS CAN BAR THE UNWANTED
description: PLANTS serve us in many ways. Uses that come readily to mind are as vegetables and fruits to eat, trees for shade and flowers for beauty. Certain other uses, though common, are not often thought about. One is that plants can provide a barrier against unwanted traffic.

title: COLLECTIONS NEEDED FOR TOXINS STORED IN HOMES
description: ''HOUSEHOLD hazardous waste'' is the term used to describe certain chemicals that are found in products commonly used in many of the nation's 84 million households. They present the same potential danger to the environment as their industrial counterparts if they are disposed of improperly.

title: DANIEL BOONE'S EMPIRE
description: THE FATAL ENVIRONMENT The Myth of the Frontier in the Age of Industrialization, 1800-1890. By Richard Slotkin. 636 pp. New York: Atheneum. $37.50.

title: A YOUNG FILM MAKER AIMS HIGH
description: FOR a young man who dreams of someday winning an Oscar for writing or directing a monumental film, Ken Copel is very much a realist. ''You just can't sit around and dream,'' said the winner of the first prize for students in last year's Suffolk County Film and Video Competition. ''You've got to create your own luck - make it happen.''

title: CLINIC LETS COUPLES SELECT SEX OF CHILD
description: FOR the couple who have had three sons and want a daughter for their fourth child, a new clinic in Bridgeport could tip the odds in their favor.

title: AMERICAN GUILTY IN CANADA BLAST
description: A Rochester man was found guilty today of three charges of first-degree murder stemming from a bombing at Montreal's main railway station last September that killed 3 people and wounded 47.

title: STATE CHALLENGING PROPOSED CONRAIL SALE
description: IN THE three months since Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth H. Dole announced her plan to sell Conrail to the Norfolk Southern, the Virginia-based railroad, New Jersey political and industrial interests have been thrust into a tug of war with the Federal Government.

title: RENOVATE OR AID POOR? JERSEY CHURCH DIVIDED
description: Each Sunday the collection baskets that are passed around the only Roman Catholic church here take in, according to the church's pastor, an average of $12,000. Many of the parishioners give generously, but others have stopped giving altogether.

title: JOHN STEVENSON
description: John Stevenson, a retired investment banker, died of pnuemonia last Sunday at White Plains Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: PIONEER FAMILIES TACKLE THE WILDS OF CHILE
description: It is a five-h our boat ride between here and what is popularly considered ''civilization,'' or a place where there is running water, electricity and roads that lead to somewhere.

title:
MUSIC ABROAD, 1985;

RECALLING THE SOUNDS OF SUMMER
description: The moon is veiled in delicate clouds , stars are sprinkled like sequins on the black velvet sky. In the town squar e, facing the 17th-c entury churc h of St. Michel, an audience listens spellbound to the incantatory sound s of a solitary violinist playing Bach.

title: RUDY ENTERS DECAY PHASE
description: SCORPIO RISING By R. G. Vliet. 245 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: Stolen Kiss Is No Bargain
description: A kiss is still a kiss, but it will cost a New Hampshire man $110 and four hours of community service. The man, Scott Bowden, 31 years old, received that punishment Thursday in Nashua District Court for stealing a kiss Feb. 19 at an Almy's Department Store. The court said he strolled up to a clerk, Rhona Delisle, grabbed her by the arm and waist, and kissed her on the cheek. Mr. Bowden, who was convicted of simple assault April 11, could not be reached for comment.

title: 'AH ME - BUT EVEWRYTHING IS BEARABLE'
description: SELECTED LETTERS OF E. M. FORSTER

title: OFFENDERS' ONE-WAY TICKET STIRS 2-CITY FEUD
description: Officials here are engaged in a heated dispute with the Police Chief of Santa Monica, Calif., who sent a man with a record of criminal conduct and emotional instability to Miami. Santa Monica paid his $249 air fare.

title: SPACELAB MONKEYS PERFORM FOR WORLD TELEVISION
description: Two frisky monkeys and 24 doomed rats aboard the Challenger space shuttle cavorted for a world television audience today as the seven-member crew neared the end of a scientific mission.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They asked me for discussions in 1986 when the ground isn't fully prepared.

title: New York to Washington: 'So There'
description: New York City expects to pay off almost all of the last $555 million of its Federally guaranteed debt this month, two years ahead of schedule, using the proceeds from the sale of new municipal bonds, a smiling Mayor Koch announced last week. The Federal Government first co-signed the city's notes in 1978 so that New York could borrow what eventually amounted to $1.65 billion; banks and other lenders had refused to extend credit to the city without the Federal guarantees. Because the city has regained its fiscal health, the new bonds will carry an interest rate 2.5 percentage points lower than the old bonds, according to officials.

title: NEW HOME FOR KIN OF AILING YOUNGSTERS
description: AFTER more than four years of planning, finishing touches are being put on Connecticut's first Ronald McDonald House, which will provide overnight accommodations in New Haven for the families of children who are patients at Yale-New Haven Hospital and the Hospital of St. Raphael.

title: STRIKERS REJECT AIR CONTRACT
description: Striking ground workers for Alaska Airlines rejected a contract offer Friday and voted to continue a two-month-old walkout. About 500 members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers in Washington and Alaska voted by a 3-to-1 margin to reject the contract proposal and 84 percent wanted the strike to continue, according to Charles Easley, a union official.

title: TEEN-AGERS FACE EVIL
description: ROBERT CORMIER is a 59-year-old former newspaperman who was born, raised and still lives in Leominster, Mass. His compelling 1974 novel, ''The Chocolate War'' - about a boy's refusal to take part in a fund-raising sale at a New England preparatory school, and the portrayal of social terror and misuse of power in that small institution, which was startling when it was published - remains both controversial and popular.

title: YOU PAY ATTENTION, YOU LEARN SOMETHING
description: OCCASIONAL PROSE By Mary McCarthy. 341 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: No Headline
description: BEYOND THE CHOCOLATE WAR By Robert Cormier. 278 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95. (Ages 12 and up) NO one who has read Robert Cormier's young adult novel ''The Chocolate War'' can forget the anguish of that final fight under the spotlights at the Trinity School. The freshman Jerry, who alone has tried to challenge the corrupt power at the school, is beaten by the beastlike bully Janza, with the student body screaming for Jerry's blood. The confrontation was rigged by Archie, the leader of the school's secret Vigils society, with the tacit approval of the authorities. Worse than the physical and official brutality is Jerry's moral breakdown - he discovers his own pleasure in violence, and in his defeat whispers to the friend who betrayed him: ''play ball. . . . Don't disturb the universe.''

title: TOBI PHILLIPS WEDS GLEN WILSON IN OLD WESTBURY
description: The marriage of Tobi Jane Phillips, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Phillips of Centerport, L.I., and Key Biscayne, Fla., to Glen Wilson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Wilson of the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia, took place yesterday at the De Seversky estate in Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Barton Shallot performed the ceremony.

title: Getting Pershings Out of Sight
description: Complaining that its Pershing 2 missiles in West Germany are sitting ducks for terrorists, the United States Army asked Congress last week for $1.8 million to start protecting them. The missiles have been ''a rallying point for anti-NATO, anti-American, antiwar and antinuclear movements,'' the Army said, and small wonder.

title: The Gipper, in Person
description: Without blush or apology, President Reagan trotted out his old Other Self, the Gipper, the other day, and got the usual reaction from the spectators.

title: Social Events
description: Dinners Around Town May 7 - Be a bit adventurous and come for cocktails and dinner at a Manhattan home. You won't know which home until you buy a benefit ticket for Creative Alternatives of New York, a program of theater workshops for psychiatric patients in New York hospitals. Led by theater professionals, patients improvise characters from myth or their own fantasies to create scenes and even full-length plays. Several patrons of the organization will serve cocktails starting at 6 P.M. followed by dinner for 35 to 40 people in each of several homes. Guests will then adjourn to the Brooks Atkinson Theater to see Rex Harrison and Claudette Colbert in ''Aren't We All?'' Tickets for dinner and performance are $125 ($250 for sponsors) or $75 for performance alone, from 212-650-6636 or 212-650-7177. Having Heart May 7 - There's little doubt that Americans are now far more aware what makes for a healthy heart than they used to be, and no small measure of the new consciousness goes to organizations such as the New York Heart Association. Created by a few doctors 70 years ago, the organization's health education has helped change a nation's living habits. A black-tie benefit for the group starts with cocktails at 7 P.M. at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets, $300, from 212-661-5335. Benefit With Ballet May 7 - The Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center is looking for $300,000 for the center's building program, and a black-tie cocktail party and dinner at the Grand Tier Restaurant at Metropolitan Opera House followed by a performance by the American Ballet Theater of ''Romeo and Juliet'' will help meet the goal.

title: VERBATIM: AT THE CROSSROADS
description: 'There are few programs I can think of that rank lower than Amtrak in terms of the good they do, the purpose they serve and the national need they respond to.

title: RELUCTANTLY, ARTISTS LEARN LAW
description: WHEN a work leaves a Connecticut artist's hands, it often leaves his control.

title: MUSIC AND GAMES
description: A group of creative people including Richard Rodgers, Irving Berlin, Meredith Wilson, William Shakespeare and Lionel Bart would have been surprised to find their work, somewhat modified, in a revue last fall in San Diego. It was ''Padre Tales'' written by Joel Hoersch and Lynn Horobetz and performed at the 1984 Fall National Championships by an amateur group that was always cheerfully energetic and often talented. Their numbers included ''Smokers and Non-Smokers,'' ''I Cain't Say Pass,'' ''Trouble,'' Prince Hammanlet's soliloquy and ''Sneakin' Peekies.'' David Scott was very effective in the last of these, based on the pocket-picking song from ''Oliver!''

title: ANDREA GREEN IS MARRIED
description: Andrea Faith Green, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Green of Randolph, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Edward Barrett, the son of Ann Barrett of Biddeford, Me., and the late John E. Barrett. Elden Salter, the Town Clerk of Andover, Mass., officiated at the Andover Inn. The bride is an independent financial advertising and marketing consultant.

title: Data Bank;   May 5, 1985
IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AROUND THE WORLD IN 78 DAYS. By Nicholas Coleridge. (McGraw-Hill, $14.95.) If Phileas Fogg could dash around the world in 80 days, why shouldn't Nicholas Coleridge be able to duplicate the feat? There is no reason why not, it turns out, except for discontinued shipping routes, idiotic taxi drivers, even more idiotic bureaucrats, monsoons and the British Empire, the dissolution of which has divided one visa into at least 19.

title: CRISIS IN HONDURAS IS GROWING WORSE
description: A month-old political crisis here grew more acute this week as union leaders joined legislators opposed to President Roberto Suazo Cordova.

title: Ma Bell's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Vietnam In America
description: I was very interested in your special issue, ''Vietnam in America: Ten Years After the Fall of Saigon,'' (March 31). I'm 27, have only vague memories of the war and no direct connections to it through family or friends.

title: SUBURBAN REBELS SECEDE ON L.I. AND SET UP THEIR OWN VILLAGE
description: The revolution started because Warren Raymond went to a meeting and made a suggestion. This, as everyone knows, is dangerous. ''If you go to a meeting and make a suggestion,'' he said, ''they always put you in charge of what you suggest.''

title: A Fourth Time for No. 1
description: Some Yankees cursed when they heard the news. One kicked over a trash can. A few cried. Billy Martin can have that effect on people, and no one knows it better than the team's owner, George Steinbrenner, who last weekend rehired his thrice-fired manager after dumping Yogi Berra.

title: THE BIG SHIRT
description: THERE are a lot of shirttails flapping in the spring breezes these days that are not likely to get tucked in. They are part of oversize shirts meant to cover about the same area as a beach blanket.

title: MISS HALL TO WED PAUL KEVIN RISKO
description: The engagement of Katherine Steele Hall, a psychotherapist with the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, to Paul Kevin Risko, an associate in the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, has been announced by Lois Hall of Sparks Glencoe, Md., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo F. Risko of Portsmouth, R.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: LUCKING INTO HARVARD
description: CHOOSING ELITES By Robert Klitgaard. 267 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: A WEEKEND IN THE CITY
description: This should be an all-American weekend,'' Giorgio said over the phone from Torino, shouting because of the bad connection. ''Nothing Italian, niente di italiano - especially the food.''

title: KATHLEEN M. MARKEY WEDS CHAIRMAN OF PERDUE FARMS
description: Kathleen M. Markey, until recently a vice president of Salomon Brothers in New York, was married yesterday to Franklin P. Perdue, chairman of Perdue Farms Inc., the poultry producer in Salisbury, Md., founded by his father, the late Arthur W. Perdue. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel Jr. performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: WORDS, WORDS, WORDS
description: There was a time when we expected the President of the United States to use the English language with a certain respect for its meaning and dignity. No more. The degradation of political rhetoric has gone so far that we are numbed. We react not at all when the President uses words as mere instruments of ideology, mocking truth.

title: MISS RICHARDSON WEDS EXECUTIVE
description: Schuyler Mason Richardson, the daughter of Charles Tiffany Richardson Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Barbara Costello Richardson of Madison, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Nelson Edmonds, a son of Mrs. Philip Colprit of Fairfax, Va., and the late Ralph Edmonds of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Mark Anschutz performed the ceremony at the Leeds Episcopal Church in Alexandria, assisted by the Rev. Llewelyn Fairchild.

title: Youth's Drug Charge Upheld By The Associated Press
description: A former student at Choate-Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, Conn., has been denied a request for the dismissal of cocaine smuggling charges. A New York State Supreme Court judge said Friday that dropping charges against the student, Derek W. Oatis, 18 years old, because he said he was disadvantaged would encourage other youngsters to commit crimes. Mr. Oatis, of Meriden, Conn., was arrested April 23, 1984, at Kennedy International Airport.

title: THE DISAGREEABLE PART OF A MALL
description: THE grounds surrounding an enclosed shopping mall are always patently unfit for human occupation. It is really awful to be between your parked car and the building interior at a place like the back approach to the Westfarms Mall in Farmington.

title: 'PAPER CHASE' STARTS ITS THIRD SEMESTER
description: Television's phoenix is again taking to the air.

title: YANKS ON TOP, 5-2
description: In Oakland it was known as Billy Ball. Now Billy Martin has taken his act to the Bronx.

title: TYLER PROVES VALUE AS PISTON BACKUP
description: Terry Tyler has been described as a ''soldier'' in pro basketball's abundance of superstars and escalating salaries. The Detroit Piston forward rarely misses a practice and has played in 574 consecutive regular-season games over seven years, the longest streak among active players.

title: THE SECOND TIME AROUND
description: In lieu of a party to end all parties, or an exchange of commemorative merchandise neither of us craved, my husband and I chose to celebrate our 25th wedding anniversary by repeating our honeymoon trip.

title: PRINCE'S PARTY
description: Current and former correspondents recall times that illustrate the meaning of hospitality.

title: Shipyard at Sea In Quincy, Mass.
description: THE layoff of 3,100 workers of the 5,267 at the General Dynamics Corporation shipyard in Quincy, Mass., announced this week, has cast doubt on the future of the 101-year-old yard, one of the largest industrial facilities in the Boston area.

title: VISITORS TO NEW YORK THIS WEEK
description: The composer and pianist William Bolcom is an ebullient, energetic man, with a bracing range of musical interests, and both his energy and his catholicity of taste have been in full view in New York this spring.

title:
MUSIC ABROAD, 1985;

WHO'S PERFORMING WHERE
description: The following directory of music festivals is based on a survey of events in Europe, the Middle East, the Caribbean and Mexico judged to be of more than local interest. It contains dates, locations, performers and program information, and where available, the range of prices, but not all information was available at press time. In all cases, programs, performers and other details are subject to change, as are prices, which may also vary due to currency fluctuations.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: DOUBLE DUTCH While Hofstra University may be busy celebrating its 50th anniversary, other, more recent traditions are also being observed on the Hempstead campus. Today is the day of the second annual Dutch Festival, an all-day celebration that salutes the area's heritage - and gives tradespeople a chance to show off Dutch products. Starting at 11:30 A.M. with an opening ceremony on the plaza of Hofstra Hall and then moving on to the Netherlands, a nearby dorm, there will be tours of the plantings of 41,000 Dutch bulbs currently in bloom, exhibits and sales of Dutch crafts and food, lectures on such topics as ''17th-Century Dutch Painting,'' a pop concert by the Hofstra Orchestra at 2 P.M. in front of the Adams Playhouse, and concerts by the Chamber Singers at 3:30 P.M. and the Jazz Ensemble at 8 P.M., inside the Playhouse. Except for the two ''inside'' performances (call 560-6644 for ticket information) and what you buy, everything is free.

title: ANTI-MANAGUA AID IS SEEN AS LIKELY
description: The recent trip to Moscow by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua has caused a shift in sentiment on Capitol Hill and made it more likely that Congress will send some form of military aid to the rebels fighting Mr. Ortega's Government, Congressional leaders say.

title: MISS WELCH HAS NUPTIALS
description: Kathryn Welch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Welch of Dayton, Ohio, was married yesterday to Con Edward Howe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Howe of Palm Harbor, Fla. The Rev. Daniel Warren, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Woodlawn Plantation in Mount Vernon, Va., a property of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, of which the bride is director of regional services.

title: CHINESE FIND IT HARD TO SAY NICE THINGS ABOUT THEIR FORMER ALLY HANOI
description: For a quarter of a century until 1975, this city in southwest China was a major transshipment point for the weapons and materiel that enabled Vietnamese Communist troops to drive French and American forces from Vietnam.

title: ANOTHER DAY OF WORK IS DONATED IN SOVIET
description: Millions of workers across the Soviet Union donated a day of work to the Government today to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the surrender of Nazi Germany in World War II.

title: Entries Way Down At Indianapolis 500
description: There was no shortage of garage space when the Indianapolis Motor Speedway opened for official practice yesterday for the 69th running of the 500-mile race May 26. Speeds are expected to be up again this year, but economics and technology have cut entries to 79 from last year's record 140. And nearly half of the cars in the garage are spares for the 42 drivers attempting to make the starting field of 33.

title: VIETNAM IN AMERICA
description: Regarding Joseph Lelyveld's otherwise excellent article on Vietnam, ''The Enduring Legacy,'' Democrat John F. Kerry, the new Senator from Massachusetts, did not have ''a landslide of his own last November in the midst of the Reagan avalanche.'' Indeed, he defeated Republican Ray Shamie by only about 1.4 million votes to 1.1 million votes.

title: PREGNANCY IS FOCUS OF DIABETES CLINIC
description: SIX years ago, when Nancy Paulus of Hawthorne gave birth to her first child, Brent, her health and the well-being of the baby were jeopardized by diabetes - the disease in which sugar is uncontrolled in the body because the pancreas does not produce insulin.

title: Misericords
description: To the Editor: I read with great pleasure Elaine Block's article on misericords (Travel, Dec. 30), which was forwarded to me.

title: THE HOMELY CABOOSE BECOMES FOCUS OF NEW MEXICO DISPUTE
description: The homely caboose, subject of nursery stories and the focus of children's waving hands, has become the object of debate about railroad safety here.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption today on page 21 of the Home Entertaining section, part 2 of The Times Magazine, incorrectly locates a terrace overlooking New York City. It is in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: VIETNAM IN AMERICA
description: What I find most hopeful about ''The War and the Arts'' (by Samuel G. Freedman) is the current phase of explanation of that war focused on the American soldier. The works of veterans for veterans look and feel and sound like survival guides for those who sense that Vietnam will always be the central experience of their lives - the touchstone by which all other events will be measured. ALBERTO IBARGUEN Hartford

title: CHILES AWAITS A CHANCE TO TAKE THE SENATE'S CENTER STAGE
description: In a series of votes last week, the Senate started taking apart the budget compromise offered by Republican leaders and the White House. As Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, surveyed the damage, he proclaimed that all was not lost. ''A week from now,'' he said, ''we'll put it back together, like Humpty Dumpty.''

title: JENNIFER REVSON MARRIES JOHN KASHON, EXECUTIVE
description: Jennifer Starr Revson, a daughter of Martin Revson of New York and Julie Phelps Revson of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to John Kashou of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ibrahim Kashou of Milwaukee.

title: LEIGH NEWMAN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Leigh Anne Newman, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Jon O. Newman of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Ernest H. Cutler 2d, a son of Elizabeth H. Cutler of Rockledge, Fla., and the late Ernest H. Cutler. Justice of the Peace Peter M. Savin officiated at the Tumble Brook Country Club in Bloomfield, Conn.

title: A Guilty Plea From E.F.Hutton
description: Since Ronald Reagan moved into the Oval Office, his critics say, the Department of Justice has appeared to give higher priority to street crime and drug trafficking than to white-collar wrongdoing. Last week it announced that it had the goods on E.F. Hutton & Company, the nation's fifth-largest brokerage firm.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PLURALIST ERA: American Art 1968-1981. By Corinne Robins. (Harper & Row, $25.95.) Traditionally art history has been viewed as a succession of major movements, one neatly following the other.

title: NOT EASY TO DESERVE
description: THE WHIMS OF FORTUNE The Memoirs of Guy de Rothschild. Illustrated. 337 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: A KINGLY SPREAD
description: Current and former correspondents recall times that illustrate the meaning of hospitality.

title: USE THOSE BIG GREEN (FAVA) THINGS
description: AT this time of year, many people, unless they are of Italian or British descent, are mystified by the appearance of enormous green beans in many vegetable markets. These, called fava or broad beans, are now at their peak.

title: MEDICAL CONDOS
description: Until recently, most professional condominiums have been created through conversions or new construction in places like Manhattan, where space is tight and rents are high.

title: DISKS OFFER A 50-YEAR SPAN OF WAGNERIAN VOICES
description: Recently released recorded Wagneriana includes three versions of ''Tristan und Isolde'' (one complete, one less than complete and one more than complete); a Herbert von Karajan ''Fliegende Hollander''; a recording of Wagner's earliest opera, ''Die Feen,'' and miscellaneous recital scraps and snippets. They're variably interesting as statements of Wagner's music, with ''Die Feen'' the particular prize. But they can be profitably discussed for what they tell us about the evolution of Wagnerian singing during the past half-century.

title: Warsaw Pact Games Due
description: About 25,000 Warsaw Pact troops will stage joint maneuvers in Czechoslovakia on May 25-31, the Tass press agency said Friday. The exercise will take place around Usti, Karlovy Vary, Rakovnik, Mlada Boleslav and Liberec, Tass said.

title: EXTRA-INNINGS DEBATE ON RETURN OF BASEBASLL TO BINGHAMTON
description: There has been talk of a new sports stadium here since 1968 when the old Johnson Field was torn down to make room for a four-lane expressway, ending a half-century of minor league baseball.

title: EASING THE TAX BITE FROM A SUMMER JOB
description: IF your teen-ager is one of the lucky few who have landed a steady job for the summer - say, working on a construction crew or serving up ice cream sundaes at the local soda shop - be sure that he or she is not making an interest-free loan to the United States Treasury at the same time.

title: PHILADELPHIA AGREES TO TAKE CARE OF HOMELESS, SETTLING A LAWSUIT
description: Every law-abiding homeless Philadelphian is supposed to receive shelter and health services from the city as the result of an out-of-court settlement of a suit filed by advocates for the homeless.

title: VANCOUVER DEBATES WORTH OF A WORLD'S FAIR
description: As the glossy brochures tell it, Canada's loveliest city will embark joyfully next May on the celebration of the century.

title: CORDERO: NO SWEAT
description: ANGEL CORDERO tore off the electric-blue blouse and all the rest of his racing outfit and quickly ran a towel over his wiry body. He wasn't about to take a shower and he probably didn't need one.

title: STATE IS SAID TO LAG ON MEDICARE FEES
description: NEW JERSEY has not met the requirements for Medicare to continue paying rates set by the state's Department of Health for hospital outpatient services, according to the head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare.

title: PUTTING MESQUITE ON THE MENU
description: IF Summerfield's Cafe in Cedarhurst does not happen to be the first restaurant on Long Island to grill meats and seafood over mesquite, it is certainly right up there among the trendsetters. This is a very good example of what is emerging as a new style of eatery, informal and lighthearted but serving serious, stylish food.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

A NEW PATCH
description: To ''protect and improve the world'' is a stated goal for the 2.2 million members of Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. Now the Girl Scouts of Westchester-Putnam have provided a new interpretation by initiating the organization's first New York State program for alcohol and chemical dependency awareness. By completing between 8 and 10 of the 13 requirements, any of the 14,000 girls belonging to the two-county council will receive a patch.

title: KATHLEEN COSGROVE, C.P.A., WED TO JOHN A. GENTILE JR.
description: Kathleen Ann Cosgrove, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Cosgrove of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to John A. Gentile Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gentile of Ashtabula, Ohio. The Rev. John W. Lolio performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Motorcade in Minor Mishap
description: A vehicle in Vice President Bush's motorcade was involved in a minor traffic accident today, but the car carrying Mr. Bush was not involved and no one was injured, the police said.

title: IN QUOTES
description: 'CBS is strong; CBS is healthy. . . . To throw this away would be a tragedy.'

title: THE CHURCH TRIES TO KEEP SOLIDARITY AT A DISTANCE
description: On May Day, after thousands marched with forbidden Solidarity insignia in Warsaw and angry young men hurled stones at the police in Gdansk, Joseph Cardinal Glemp, the Primate of Poland, preached at a mass for workers at a church near a Warsaw tractor factory. Few people bothered to come.

title: 3 More People Die In South Africa Violence
description: Policemen shot one black man dead in renewed rioting, and two black children, ages 3 and 5, were killed when blacks threw a gasoline bomb into their home, the police said today.

title: BARBARA W. PEABODY IS WED
description: Barbara Welch Peabody, a lawyer with the New York City Corporation Counsel's office, was married in New York yesterday to Michael Frankau Cusick, a partner in the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & the Family Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's aunt, Marietta Tree.

title: MELINDA J. CODD OF CORNELL WED TO C. C. MULLER
description: Melinda Joan Codd, a daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Martin Codd of New Dorp, S.I., and Christopher Craig Muller, a son of Gladys L. Kirkinis of Union City, N.J., and Burt A. Muller of Centerport, L.I., were married in Ithaca, N.Y., yesterday. The Rev. Philip Murnion, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Sage Chapel at Cornell University.

title: FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA IN NEW YORK DEBUT
description: THE Waterloo Festival Orchestra, under the baton of Gerald Schwarz, its musical director, will give its first New York concert Saturday afternoon.

title: THOSE WHO CAN, TEACH
description: THE couple ahead of me in the grocery store checkout line laughed, and the husband, nudging his wife in the arm, said, ''Well, you know what they say: 'Those that can, do; those than can't, teach.' ''

title: REDISCOVERING CATHEDRAL PARKWAY
description: UNTIL recently, the idea of selling a renovated one-bedroom apartment in a tired old building at 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue for $150,000 would have seemed preposterous to most residents of the mostly middle-income neighborhood. To many of them, it still does, but they're getting used to the idea.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DASHIELL HAMMETT. By Julian Symons. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Cloth, $24.95. Harvest/HBJ, Paper, $12.95.) In this addition to the HBJ Album Biographies, the literary critic and mystery writer Julian Symons argues that Dashiell Hammett (1894-1961) transformed and transcended crime fiction.

title: SEBASTIANI Terror
description: NOWHERE By Thomas Berger. 190 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/ Seymour Lawrence. $14.95.

title: A CORNUCOPIA OF ASIAN FRUIT
description: If the Garden of Eden had been in Southeast Asia, it would have taken more than a mundane apple to corrupt Eve. In a place where people really do eat lotuses, a serpent wouldn't get by on less than a mangosteen and a couple of rambutans. Or maybe a succulent, honey-flavored lamut?

title: LIMITS ON ASBESTOS EYED
description: ELEMENTARY-school children who regularly walk by a Merrick plant that uses asbestos would have an additional law to protect them from exposure to the carcinogen if Hempstead Town has its way.

title: CAMDEN COUNTING ON WHITMAN'S LORE
description: With only seven years to go, the prophecy is a long way from fulfillment, considering that tourists do not flock to this industrial and port city to visit the Whitman home and the adjoining Whitman Library, as they do to the picturesque English town made famous by the birth and presence of William Shakespeare.

title: TERRELL (3-0) WINS FOR TIGERS
description: Walt Terrell pitched a two-hitter through eight innings and Larry Herndon, Barbaro Garbey and Nelson Simmons hit home runs to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 7-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox, ending a three-game losing streak tonight.

title: Affirmative Retreat
description: Not content with agitating against affirmative action, the Reagan Administration has sued Indianapolis for honoring commitments to desegregate its police and fire departments. The action fits a design to dismantle Federal civil rights enforcement long before the nation has overcome past discrimination.

title: STATE EQUESTRIANS OFF TO ENGLAND
description: MASALA, Mazurka, Landtmeister and Calvaro trotted fiercely through water, over rocky and hilly terrain and past tightly grouped clumps of trees, driven intensely by a three-man team in the carriage behind them.

title: A FEMALE BEST FRIEND
description: How odd that Michael McGill could spend an entire article without once mentioning either what he contributes to his female friend or what she expects from him.

title: MIXED-USE PROJECT
description: Residents of Flushing, Queens, who have been witnessing a residential and commercial construction boom in their neighborhood may soon see a major mixed-use building rise on a municipal parking lot.

title: Edward (Ted) Haydon Dies; Ex-U.S. Olympic Track Coach
description: Edward M. (Ted) Haydon, a former Olympic coach and the founder of the highly regarded University of Chicago Track Club, died Friday at Bernard Mitchell Hospital after having been hospitalized for a stroke that he suffered April 16. He was 73 years old. Mr. Haydon, who was inducted into the National Track and Field Hall of Fame 10 years ago, was a coach with the United States Olympic teams in 1968 and 1972, and for the Pan American Games in 1963 and 1979.

title: For National Security, Save All-Weather Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXT OF DECLARATION AT END OF 7-NATION ECONOMIC CONFERENCE
description: Following is the text of the joint declaration made public today at the end of the seven-nation economic conference: [1] Conscious of the responsibility which we bear, together with other governments, for the future of the world economy and the preservation of natural resources, we, the heads of state or government of seven major industrial nations and the president of the Commission of the European Communities, meeting in Bonn from May 2 to 4, 1985, have discussed the economic outlook, problems and prospects for our countries and the world. [2] World economic conditions are better than they have been for a considerable time. Since we last met, further progress has been achieved in bringing down inflation and strengthening the basis for growth. The recovery in the industrial countries has begun to spread to the developing world. The debt problems of developing countries, though far from solved, are being flexibly and effectively addressed. [3] Nevertheless, our countries face still important challenges. Above all, we need:

title: WAR IN A CLASSICAL VOICE
description: ALL OUR YESTERDAYS By Natalia Ginzburg. Translated by Angus Davidson. 300 pp. New York: Carcanet. $14.95.

title: Bill Kunkel, Former Pitcher And Umpire, Is Dead at 48
description: Bill Kunkel, an American League umpire and former pitcher with the Yankees and the Kansas City Athletics, died today in Red Bank after a four-year cancer illness.

title: POETRY AND ITS SMALLEST Audience
description: THE OXFORD BOOK OF CHILDREN'S VERSE IN AMERICA Edited by Donald Hall. 319 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Commemorative coinage was once the poor relation of United States numismatics. Today, it has become a favorite son. Four new United States commemoratives have been issued since 1982 - the first in three decades. Three more seem likely within the next year to honor the Statue of Liberty.

title: E.F. HUTTON ADMITS IT DEFRAUDED BANKS
description: E.F. Hutton will pay fines of $2.75 million plus restitution of up to $8 million after its guilty plea to fraud charges. The big brokerage house said it had engaged in an elaborate scheme resembling check-kiting that enabled money in one bank account to earn interest in another account. Hutton said the scheme had earned it millions of dollars at the expense of commercial banks from mid-1980 to early 1982. According to the firm, the scheme was carried out by branch managers who did not realize that it was illegal or contrary to company policy. Federal officials said there were hundreds of banks involved, many of them smaller institutions that did not have the expertise to detect the scheme.

title: DESERT DELIGHTS
description: Current and former correspondents recall times that illustrate the meaning of hospitality.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map accompanying an article last week about evacuation plans for the Shoreham nuclear plant mischaracterized the significance of the zone lying within five miles. The Long Island Lighting Company believes that planning for evacuation is not needed in the area beyond five miles. However, the plan that the company is currently seeking to implement covers a 10-mile zone, as is required by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: WARD TRIES TO PATCH UP HIS CHAIN OF COMMAND
description: Benjamin Ward, the New York City Police Commissioner, cleaned house last week. With officers under investigation or indictment for charges of torture, unnecessary use of deadly force and hit-and-run incidents, Mr. Ward drove a chain of commanders into retirement and watched approvingly while others were indicted on criminal charges.

title: GARY KRONFIELD WEDS MICHELE LAUREN KLAR
description: Michele Lauren Klar, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Klar of Great Neck, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., and Gary Harris Kronfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Kronfeld of Tenafly, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jerome Davidson at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, L.I.

title: AIDS RISK FOUND LOW FOR HEALTH WORKERS
description: A study of hundreds of doctors, nurses and others exposed at a hospital to acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, shows that even such close contact is unlikely to spread the disease.

title: A FUTURE IN STONE AND GLASS
description: IN the last five years, we've taken a quantum leap from the routine red brick, aluminum- and glass-windowed buildings that are typical of Long Island's commercial and industrial construction heritage between 1950 and 1970.

title: LEWIS CARROLL IS STILL DEAD
description: ALICE THROUGH THE NEEDLE'S EYE By Gilbert Adair. Illustrated by Jenny Thorne. 186 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $11.95.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Mail-Order Bakery Source for Stollen Linden's of Westchester began as a neighborhood bakery in Scarsdale in 1932, later moving to White Plains for 10 years. Now Linden's is in North White Plains and is still supplying brownies and five sorts of cookies to delicatessens, school cafeterias and stores, or to individuals, all at wholesale prices. Student organizations or teams can then resell the packets (one brownie or three cookies each) for fund-raising purposes.

title: COMPELLING FRENCH DESIGNS
description: The works of Jean Dunand, Jean Prouve and Serge Mouilly - three 20th-century Paris-based innovators whose distinctive styles are unknown to most art collectors - are explored in two exhibitions opening this week at the galleries of Anthony DeLorenzo, a New York dealer in 20th-century decorative arts. The Dunand show is uptown at DeLorenzo, 958 Madison Avenue (at 75th Street), and the post-World War II works of Mr. Prouve and Mr. Mouilly are on view in SoHo, at his Downtown Gallery, 86 Wooster St. Both shows open Thursday and will remain on view through June 8.

title: Sailors Take Aim at Admiral's Cup BARBARA LLOYD
description: Rod Davis, an Olympic gold medalist, says he shivers at the thought of sailing in Admiral's Cup trial races that are scheduled to begin next Saturday in Newport, R.I. Davis has spent the winter in Southern California practice racing with 12-Meters, and he's not particularly enthusiastic about leaving those warm waters for the spring chill in Newport. But Davis says it's a regatta he doesn't want to miss.

title: 'CAUSE FOR CONCERN' ON INFANT MORTALITY SEEN BY U.S. AGENCY
description: The United States Public Health Service, in a new study of infant mortality, says that nine states have particularly serious problems and that the data for the nation as a whole are ''cause for concern.''

title: A LIFE LIVED IN REVERSE
description: CHRISTOPHER HOMM By C. H. Sisson 239 pp. New York: Carcanet. Paper, $7.50.

title: INDIAN DATA AT DEVELOPMENT?
description: THE Smithtown Town Board has asked developers of a 10-acre site in Fort Salonga to conduct an archeological study to find out if the site contains important artifacts of Indian life and local history.

title: A FEMALE BEST FRIEND
description: In his article ''A Female Best Friend'' (About Men, March 24), Michael E. McGill states, ''I have some more explaining to do'' to his wife in regard to their relationship.

title: SMALL, SELECT CLUB CONVENES IN HONOR OF IRVING
description: WITHIN the scholarly world of American letters, there are cliques.

title: SALVADOR DEFENSE LAWYER CHARGES COVER-UP IN SLAYING OF U.S. NUNS
description: A lawyer who defended a Salvadoran national guardsman convicted of murdering four American churchwomen said yesterday that he had been forced to take part in a ''conspiracy'' aimed at preventing higher-ranking military officers from being implicated in the case.

title: D'AMBOISE MAKES P.S. 29 FEEL LIKE DANCING
description: The battered old green car pulls up outside P.S. 29, an elementary school in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn. Out jumps a tall, handsome man in blue cotton pants and running shoes, all grace and exuberance in the morning. Jacques d'Amboise, the legendary principal dancer with the New York City Ballet who has been reborn as the Pied Piper of dance, has arrived.

title: MITIGATING ANGER IN DIVORCE
description: LEGAL and mental-health professionals must find new ways to help divorced parents overcome their anger and cooperate with each other on such things as alimony, child custody and visitation rights.

title: ASTRONAUTS STOW GEAR AS THEY HEAD FOR COAST LANDING
description: The seven astronauts aboard the space shuttle Challenger ended experiments today and stowed equipment in preparation for their scheduled landing here Monday at the end of what has been hailed as a highly successful seven-day mission.

title: Dow to End Brine Operation
description: The Dow Chemical Company has agreed to shut down its network of brine wells and pipelines near Midland, Mich., by 1987, company and state officials said Friday. The brine system has been blamed by state environmental experts for repeated spills of salty water that they say threaten public health, crops and animal life. Dow uses the brine in some chemical manufacturing processes.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Unocal Corporation misstated the personal tax impact on the company's management and directors from a possible enlargement of an offer to buy back shares. By increasing the number of shares it is offering to acquire, Unocal could not minimize the taxes they would have to pay on stock profits.

title: Catching Up
description: Of the four players caught up in the 1983 cocaine case while with the Kansas City Royals, three - Willie Wilson, Willie Aikens and Vida Blue - are still part of the major league picture. But Jerry Martin, who flopped with the Mets after serving his prison time and suspension and then arriving in New York last May, is out of baseball.

title: TORTUOUS ROAD TO BUDGET
description: As the Senate resumes debate Monday on the budget, Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, will be maneuvering to keep the White House package from unraveling after losing several key votes last week.

title: Velasquez Rides Nany to Victory
description: Nany, the only New York-bred in the field of six, used a driving finish yesterday to take the $86,700 Vagrancy Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct.

title: Elliott Triumphs With Fastest 500
description: Bill Elliott overcame a deficit of nearly two laps early in the race, caught the leaders and went on to win the Winston 500 today with the fastest average speed for 500 miles in the history of auto racing.

title: Kremlin's Military Chief Calls 'Star Wars' a Threat to Peace
description: Defense Minister Sergei L. Sokolov said today that American ''Star Wars'' research poses a greater hazard to peace than the atomic bomb, and promised to see that the Soviet Union is defended against such a threat.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF SPEECH BY KOHL AT U.S. AIR BASE
description: Following is a transcript of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's speech today at the United States Air Base at Bitburg, as recorded and translated by The Associated Press:

title: COAST FOUNDRY OFFERS HISTORY AS WELL AS CAST IRON
description: Carl Borgh first came to this small town in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada about 100 miles east of San Francisco to have some parts cast by the historic Knight Foundry.

title: The Grass Is Greener
description: The most famous vegetation in all of baseball is the vine on the outfield wall at Wrigley Field. But while the vine is a little scraggly at this time of year - awaiting the heat of late spring for a good bloom - the grass on the infield is thick. Too thick, according to some. When the San Francisco Giants were in Chicago last week, they complained like parents with long-haired kids.

title: CITY OPENS VIETNAM VETERANS' TRIBUTES TODAY
description: Maj. Michael Davis O'Donnell's 1970 poem, written three months before his death in Vietnam, is a soldier's plea for remembrance.

title: Monetary Link to Trade Talks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has been resisting, with some determination, holding an international monetary conference next winter, according to Treasury officials. The matter, broached tentatively by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d last month to line France up behind trade talks, has become the cause of some tension between the Treasury and State Departments.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Breakers vs Houston Gamblers, at Portland, Ore.

title: World War II Romance Revived After 40 Years
description: The World War II romance of an American sailor and a British barmaid has been rekindled after the man and woman found each other through a letter she sent to his boyhood address.

title: 'Dialogue of Americas' Set for This Week
description: Eighty-six writers and artists from Latin America, Canada and the United States will meet in New York tomorrow through Friday for a four-day ''Dialogue of All the Americas.''

title: Taxes From Americans Abroad
description: The General Accounting Office recently ran the Social Security numbers of Americans known to be living and working in six European and Latin American countries through an Internal Revenue Service computer and discovered that many of those people were not bothering to file Federal income tax returns.

title: Newspaper Ad Bureau Re-Elects All Officers
description: Members of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau meeting in Miami Beach yesterday re-elected all of their officers.

title: MCENROE: A NEED FOR RESPECT
description: WHAT set him apart from the others who had secured late- afternoon court time at the Cove Tennis Center was the familiar frown - not necessarily a sign of dissatisfaction, John McEnroe said - the distinctive array of shots, and the gaggle of dreamy-eyed young successors watching intently as the world's best tennis player practiced.

title: DONATIONS INCREASE TO GROUPS STUDYING PREVENTION OF WAR
description: The nation's grant-making foundations in the last three years have tripled their support for organizations working to prevent nuclear war and promote international security, according to a new study.

title: For the City That Stole the Dodgers
description: A couple of spaldeens were handed out this weekend to residents of a certain large California city whose baseball team used to play in Brooklyn. Even so equipped, however, the Californians will never - repeat, never - play stickball.

title: ILLTERACY PROBLEM NEEDS FEDERAL HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHING CANDIDATE A LESSON
description: A year ago, Patrick J. Gillis rang doorbells night after night across Oregon's 20th Legislative District, hoping that his personality and conservative Republican views would propel him into a political career.

title: Backstretch Business
description: With little in the way of racing news or controversy during the week preceding the Kentucky Derby, the buying and selling of horses became a dominant theme around Churchill Downs. About half the horses that would run in the Derby were available for sale or syndication, and the backstretch was buzzing with the talk of deals. The upside and the downside of this risky business were glimpsed in two Louisville scenes:

title: Duccio Faggella Wed To Julie Autumn List
description: Julie Autumn List, a daughter of Shelley List of Venice, Calif., and Dr. Murray List of New York, was married yesterday to Duccio Faggella, a son of Dolores Faggella of Livorno, Italy, and the late Carmine Faggella. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at the Rainbow Grill in New York.

title: Interior Dept. Names 11 Historic Landmarks
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel has designated 11 properties, including four Presidential homes, two ships and a Pullman car, as national historic landmarks.

title: Shultz Says the Nazis Killed One SS Soldier
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that one of the SS members buried at the Bitburg cemetery had been executed for refusing to kill inmates at a German death camp and had been buried in a concentration camp uniform.

title: Man in Recanted Rape Called Hesitant to Undergo Lie Test
description: Gary Dotson, imprisoned for six years for a rape his former accuser now says never happened, is hesitant about taking a polygraph test, his attorney says.

title: Security Traders President
description: John L. Watson 3d, an executive vice president and director of capital markets at Robinson Humphrey/ American Express Inc., has been selected as the next president of the National Security Traders Association.

title: SEARCH BY POLICE HALTS TOURNAMENT
description: Amy Alcott shot a 3-under-par 69 today for a four-stroke victory in the Moss Creek Women's Invitational in a round delayed more than 90 minutes as security officials removed an ''overzealous fan.''

title: NUGGETS TOP JAZZ
description: Alex English scored 40 points as the Denver Nuggets held off a fourth quarter Utah rally to defeat the Jazz, 125-118, and take a 3-1 advantage in their National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff series.

title: ALL THE GUYS WHO WON THE WAR
description: The dancing, singing and drinking had all but ended by 4 in the morning. I stood in Paris's Place de la Concorde looking down toward the Madeleine and suddenly it hit me. It was over, the war was finished, the Germans had been beaten.

title: ART: 'SCULPTURE OF INDIA,' AT THE NATIONAL GALLERY
description: ''THE SCULPTURE OF INDIA: 3000 B.C. to 1300 A.D.'' is an exhibition of manageable size and remarkably high quality that opened to the public yesterday at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and can be seen there through Sept. 2. As its title suggests, it covers a great deal of ground. It includes sculptures that are life-size and must weigh the best part of a ton, and it includes sculptures that would go into an overcoat pocket and barely make a bulge.

title: OUTDOORS: SHAD RUNNING A WEEK EARLY
description: SHAD arrived in the Delaware River nearly two weeks early this year in their annual procreative journey from the sea, and a few of the front-runners have reached Hancock, N.Y., and ascended the river's east and west branches.

title: YANKS TAKE 4TH IN ROW, 6-2;   4 HOMERS TOP ROYALS
description: Dale Berra considered it a routine play, just a basic part of the game that he learned in high school and took with him to the big leagues. But to Billy Martin, it was a revival of Yankee tradition.

title: PREAKNESS DECISION AWAITED
description: The size of the field for the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on May 18 could be anywhere from 5 to 15, all depending on whether Spend a Buck, the Kentucky Derby winner, passes up the Preakness for the richer Jersey Derby on May 27.

title: THIS IS RETIREMENT?
description: DENNIS DIAZ was looking for a family hobby. Something that wouldn't cost him a lot of money, but would allow him to enjoy himself at the age of 38.

title: In New York City, Subways Never Sleep
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Actor in Wings
description: As the only politician with a theatrical background ever to reach the White House, President Reagan is inescapably an inspiration to actors interested in running for elective office. The latest of the these to emerge is Fred Grandy, who has played Gopher Smith, the purser of ''The Love Boat'' on television for eight years.

title: ATLANTA'S YEARS OF PROGRESS TEMPER NEW RACIAL DISPUTES
description: In the 1950's and 60's, when the civil rights movement was challenging the old order across the South, a group of white civic leaders in Atlanta began preaching a gospel of accommodation rather than confrontation.

title: Sir Donald Bailey, 83, Dies; Devised Key Wartime Bridge
description: Sir Donald Coleman Bailey, inventor of the Bailey bridge that played a crucial role in the Allied victory in World War II, died today at the age of 83, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Registration Ends In Jersey Today
description: New Jersey residents who want to vote in the June 4 primary election have their last opportunity to register on Monday.

title: Italian Journalists Settle
description: The Italian journalists' union signed a new contract today to end a bitter wage dispute that provoked several job actions and a three-day walkout. The agreement was announced by the Labor Ministry, which had stepped into the negotiations. It said the employers and the union had agreed to a monthly pay raise of $190 over the next three years.

title: KOHL REMARKS AT CAMP SITE
description: Following, in official translation, is the text of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's remarks today during the visit by Mr. Kohl and President Reagan to the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Standard Inc., a diversified manufacturer, said it had elected to its board Eugene J. Sullivan, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Borden Inc.

title: Navratilova Wins
description: Martina Navratilova played her longest match of the week today, turning back a stubborn Elise Burgin, 6-4, 6-1, to win the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Houston tournament.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE LEADERS SPLIT OVER COMPUTER
description: Two years ago Gov. John H. Sununu, an engineer and former academic dean who understands what microchips can do, asked the Legislature for some money to computerize the system by which the state raises and spends more than $1 billion a year.

title: Purchasers Say April Was Mixed
description: After slowing in February and March, the economy began the second quarter on a mixed note, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.

title: Treasury Sales to Total $34.5 Billion
description: After a five-week lull in long-term Treasury financings, the Federal Government will dominate the credit markets this week with three note and bond auctions, totaling $20.5 billion, as well as a regular weekly sale of Treasury bills, totaling $14 billion.

title: TV Watching Linked To Obesity in Youth
description: Children who watch a lot of television often grow to be overweight teen-agers, a new study has found.

title: Taiwan Bank Investigation
description: Investigators of Taiwan's biggest bank scandal said they had found new evidence on bribery by the Cathay Industrial Group to senior officials of several Government banks.

title: Born Too Soon
description: Had Richard L. Murphy been born after 1944, he would be the right age for a register of noteworthy Americans under 40.

title: No Rain Checks, Either
description: You might call it the ''I-gave-at-the-office'' routine for street thieves.

title: 2 Youths Found Drowned Off L.I.
description: The bodies of two Long Island teen-agers who were reported missing on April 24 have been recovered in the Great South Bay, according to the Suffolk County police.

title: Grinnell College Plans to Sell Some South Africa Holdings
description: After protests by students over the years, the Board of Trustees of Grinnell College voted Saturday to divest itself of some of its South African investments.

title: Deportees from Nigeria Allowed to Cross Benin
description: More than 500 illegal aliens expelled from Nigeria crossed the tiny West African country of Benin by road today after the Government let non-Benin nationals cross its eastern border, witnesses said.

title: Kriek Beats Arias In Four-Set Final
description: Johan Kriek continued his mastery of Jimmy Arias, beating him by 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 today in the final of the $312,000 Alan King/Caesars Palace Tennis Classic.

title: FOR BITBURG, DAY OF ANGER ENDS QUIETLY
description: It was the scene that many had feared. At the main crossroads of this small town, policemen with plastic antiriot shields confronted an advancing crowd of Jews, many of them wearing the badge that accompanied their parents and grandparents to their deaths: a six-pointed yellow star bearing the word Jude.

title: Sharon Szymanski Married in Chicago
description: Sharon Olivia Szymanski, the daughter of Bruna R. Berti of Rosemont, Ill., and Leonard W. Szymanski of Niles, Ill., was married in Chicago yesterday to Thomas H. K. Brooks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Brooks of New York and Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Douglas Cater, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

title: THE TWO SIDES OF BILLY MARTIN: A STUDY IN CONTRAST
description: CONSIDER two stories about two Billy Martins. Lewis Figone, a lifetime friend from California, went to the Oakland A's clubhouse a few years ago to pick up Martin for a planned afternoon hunting trip. While waiting, Figone learned that Rob Picciolo, a reserve infielder, was dropped from the team that day.

title: REPRESENTATIVES WITH AS MUCH TURF AS A SENATOR
description: Constituents regard them as virtual senators and they enjoy an extraordinary amount of coverage from the news media at home. On the other hand, they tend to get poor committee assignments, often find it hard to tend political fences and can feel quite lonely on a controversial vote.

title: Thai Marines Fight Vietnamese at Border
description: Thai marines backed by air strikes have mounted a major operation against Vietnamese who entered this country in pursuit of Cambodian guerrillas, a senior Thai officer said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 6, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Body for 1985 Conference on Women's Decade - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Odds of Being Murdered Are 1 in 133, Study Says
description: Americans generally have one chance in 133 of being murdered over their lifetimes, according to the Government's first study of the risk of violent crime.

title: ABORTION RIGHTS: NEW TACTICS
description: A new chorus is being heard in the ongoing furor over abortion: the voices of women who have had abortions and believe that the right to do so should be preserved.

title: Bobby Hutcherson At Village Vanguard
description: Under Bobby Hutcherson's two mallets, the vibraphone is rarely an instrument for sweet, tinkling tunes. His solos have a steely drive along with their sparkle; Mr. Hutcherson uses the vibraphone's transparency and percussiveness to sketch shifting harmonies under long lines.

title: Gannett Head Denies Talks
description: Allen H. Neuharth, chairman of the Gannett Company, discounted today as fiction ''everything that has been said or written about CBS and Gannett as possible merger or takeover partners'' and ''everything that has been said or written about Gannett and Ted Turner talking about a possible partnership in a takeover of CBS.''

title: Policeman Saves Man From River
description: A man who fell into the Hudson River early yesterday morning was saved from drowning by a police officer who leaped into the choppy water and kept the victim's head up for more than 40 minutes while waiting to be fished from the river by a police boat.

title: NEPAL'S FLEDGLING EXCHANGE
description: It is not easy to run a stock exchange in one of the poorest countries of the world.

title: 'GEORGE STEVENS,' A SON'S TRIBUTE
description: It began in a room at a warehouse in Hollywood, where keepsakes from George Stevens's life were clustered on shelves, huddled under blankets and stored in tin cans that were rusting from age. There was the picture of his mother, an impressionistic sweep of a beautiful woman in a brimmed hat; there were the leather-bound scripts of movies he had directed, including two that had earned him Academy Awards - ''Giant'' and ''A Place in the Sun'' - and there were the horrible, gripping color reels of Dachau on the day the concentration camp was liberated.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: RANDALL JARRELL'S LETTERS: An Autobiographical and Literary Selection. Edited by Mary Jarrell. Assisted by Stuart Wright. 540 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $29.95.

title: 76ERS SWEEP BUCKS
description: For the fourth time in five years, the Milwaukee Bucks will spend the summer pondering what might have been were it not for the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 6, 1985: *2*MONDAY Blair (John) & Co Data-Design Labs Chemed Corp General Motors Cooper Tire & Rubber NCH Corp *2*TUESDAY Adams-Millis Corp MCA Inc Atlantic Richfield Mickelberry Corp General Housewares Monarch Mach Tool Goodyear Tire&Rbr Munford Inc Iowa Elec Pr&Lt Niagara Mohawk Pwr Kansas Pwr&Lt Pioneer Corp (TX) Kansas City Pwr&Lt Squibb Corp Kerr-McGee Corp *2*WEDNESDAY CBS Inc Leggett & Platt Compugraphic Corp Quaker Oats Gerber Products USG Corp Heilig-Meyers USLife Income Fund *2*THURSDAY Beverly Enterprises Int Flavors&Fragrance Carlisle Corp Sabine Corp Carpenter Technology USAir Group Champion Intl *2*FRIDAY Bandag Inc Washington Water Pwr Global Marine Inc

title: 4 Missing in St. Lawrence
description: State police and Coast Guard officials searched the St. Lawrence River today for four Canadians whose 12-foot aluminum motorboat was found Friday, capsized off Grindstone Island in the Thousand Islands. The missing men, all from nearby Gananoque, Ontario, were last seen leaving a tavern in this Jefferson County community Wednesday night, said a Coast Guard spokesman, James Herbst. The men were identified as Brian MacNeil, 37 years old, Shawn Cook, 23, Thomas Tuepah, 24, and Todd Jones, 20.

title: Pacific Resources Fills Key Post After Search
description: The board of directors of Pacific Resources Inc. announced that Robert G. Reed 3d had been elected president and chief executive officer.

title: CLAY TALIAFERRO AND JOSE LIMON COMPANY
description: TALL and powerfully built, Clay Taliaferro had one of the strongest physical presences in the Jose Limon Dance Company. But his was a gentle presence.

title: MURDOCH TV DEAL EXPECTED
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who bought a half interest in the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation in March, is expected to announce today that he will buy at least six television stations from Metromedia Inc. for about $1.55 billion.

title: Stocks Surge In Hong Kong
description: Signs of a boom in Hong Kong's property market set off a rush for shares Friday, pushing the stock market index here to a four-year high.

title: AMERICANS VOICE ANGER ON BITBURG
description: As flags fluttered at half-staff and images of fallen soldiers and victims of war and the Holocaust stirred hearts and memories, Americans marked the 40th anniversary of V-E Day yesterday and voiced sorrow and anger over President Reagan's visit to a German military cemetery.

title: THE TWO CEREMONIES AT BERGEN-BELSEN
description: There were two ceremonies at the Bergen-Belsen memorial today.

title: Karen A. Nones Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Amy Nones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Nones of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Scott London, a son of Elaine London of New York and Herzliya, Israel, and the late Philip London. Rabbi Laura Geller performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in New York.

title: WHY SENATE HAS NOT RATIFIED GENOCIDE TREATY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITONS ASSESS POOR SHOWING FOR TORIES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that her Government would stick to its economic policies despite the poor showing of the Conservative Party in county elections on Thursday.

title: CAR WITH SIX WHEELS AND NO DRIVER LEADING TO NEW GENERATION OF ROBOTS
description: A new car that has six wheels and television cameras, propels itself and needs no driver is in the forefront of what scientists at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh call a new generation of robots.

title: DEMONSTRATION FOR SOVIET JEWS JAMS FIFTH AVE.
description: Tens of thousands of people marched down Fifth Avenue and gathered near the United Nations yesterday in a demonstration of support for Soviet Jewry that participants said was colored by anguish over President Reagan's visit to a military cemetery in Bitburg, West Germany.

title: Alexis Gelber Married To Newsweek Writer
description: Alexis Gelber, a senior editor in New York of the international edition of Newsweek magazine, was married yesterday to Mark Whitaker, a senior writer at the magazine. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Maryland Agrees On Desegregation Plan
description: Maryland has tentatively agreed to a plan aimed at further desegregating its public colleges and universities, a move that could end one of the longest-running such disputes in the country.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S SPEECH AT AIR BASE AFTER HIS VISIT TO THE CEMETERY
description: Following is a transcript of remarks by President Reagan today at the United States Air Base at Bitburg after his visit to a German military cemetery, as recorded by The Associated Press:

title: Why Senate Has Not Ratified Genocide Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Corgi Is Winner
description: A red-and-white Pembroke Welsh corgi, Ch. Walborah's Rugby V. Marjoe, owned by Mary and Joseph Vaudo and handled by Joy Brewster, today was named best of 2,954 dogs at the 56th show of Trenton Kennel Club at Mercer County Park. It was the fifth top award in three weeks for the 3-year-old dog and raises his total of best to 10.

title: INVADERS TRIUMPH
