description: Fred Besana, who was pressed into duty when the starting quarterback Bobby Hebert was injured, passed for three touchdowns to spark the Oakland Invaders to a 21-7 victory over the Orlando Renegades today.Besana entered the game in the second quarter after Hebert suffered a minor head injury.

title: RISING BRUTALITY COMPLAINTS RAISE QUESTIONS ABOUT NEW YORK POLICE
description: For decades, the tough methods used against criminals by a Prohibition-era detective, Johnny Broderick, were widely sanctioned in New York City's police force. Roaming the streets of Manhattan, Detective Broderick clubbed suspected gangsters and hoodlums with a lead pipe wrapped in a newspaper.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page last Monday about a convention of the New York State chapter of the National Organization for Women carried an incorrect listing, based on information from the United States Comptroller General's Office, of states that are acting upon the results of pay-equity studies. The states are Iowa, South Dakota, Minnesota and New Mexico.

title: Catholic Wounded in Belfast
description: The police said a Roman Catholic was badly wounded today by bullets apparently fired at random from a Protestant area of Belfast on the fourth anniversary of the death of Robert Sands, an Irish Republican Army guerrilla who died during a hunger strike at the Maze prison. The victim, whose name was not disclosed, was in serious condition, a police spokesman said. The gunfire, from the city's Shankill Road district, was aimed across the so-called peace line separating the Protestant neighborhood from the Catholic Ardoyne area, said the spokesman.

title: The Narrowing Gap
description: The female of the species may be more deadly than the male, but even males who know their Kipling have long been able to take comfort in the counter-knowledge that when it comes to things like running - and most other athletic endeavors known to man - women are almost always also-rans. Indeed, male athletic superiority has seemed almost a law of nature and is especially apparent among such four-legged athletes as thoroughbreds and greyhounds. Fillies, for example, rarely enter and almost never win the Kentucky Derby (only colts ran in the 111th edition Saturday), and in greyhound racing, males outnumber females by 4 to 1 and almost always beat them to the finish.

title: PISTONS TIE SERIES AS BACKUP HITS 34
description: Vinnie Johnson, Detroit's backup playmaker, is known as the ultimate practice player, but today he performed when it counted.

title: ALL EYES ON LOTTERY FOR EWING
description: IF the gray envelopes were placed end to end, they would just equal the height of Patrick Ewing. But for seven National Basketball Association teams, the order in which those foot-square envelopes are picked next Sunday could mean brighter days ahead - more fans in the stands and more victories in the standing.

title: More Cabs Won't Solve the Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: JOAN FONTAINE TO APPEAR IN ABC FILM
description: On the set of ABC-TV's ''Dark Mansions,'' Joan Fontaine's dressing room is the size of a small banquet hall. ''Of course, we used to have huge dressing rooms like this,'' Miss Fontaine said. ''In the old days they were so lavish that you would bring the paintings from your home to hang on your dressing room walls.''

title: ECONOMIC EFFECTS OF SUMMIT MEETING
description: When the high emotionalism and controversies that marked the summit conference during the past week have faded, what will be the economic consequences of Bonn?

title: Resolved: That Debating Is an Education in Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Progress Slowly
description: In preparation for tonight's eighth birthday party for the Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues, researchers have been digging out statistics on progress in the relatively short time women have been serving on Capitol Hill. Jeannette Rankin of Montana in 1916 was the first woman elected to the House, and about 50 years later Representative Martha Griffiths of Michigan asked the Library of Congress how long it would take to achieve a female majority there if the rate of increase over the intervening years was maintained.

title: DISCORD AMONG SIKHS BLOCKS TALKS
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's attempt to negotiate a solution to the angry dispute with India's Sikhs has stalled because of factionalism and disarray among Sikh leaders.

title: Therese Steiner Weds Dr. Howard Mark Klar
description: Therese F. Steiner, the daughter of Mrs. Frank M. Fox of Cincinnati and Truro, Mass., and Robert L. Steiner of Washington, was married yesterday to Dr. Howard Mark Klar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Klar of Brooklyn. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the couple's New York apartment.

title: Bitburg Bears Remembering
description: It's over, but the Bitburg blunder, too, should not be forgotten. President Reagan's regret at having promised such a cemetery tribute was palpable. He walked through it with dignity but little reverence. He gave the cameras no emotional angles. All day long, he talked and talked of Hell and Nazi evil, to submerge the event.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the obituary of former Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. on April 24 misidentified the court in which Mr. Ervin's son, Sam J. Ervin 3d, serves as a judge. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

title: KITE VICTORIOUS AT 13 UNDER PAR
description: Tom Kite, a 35-year-old Texan who had been struggling on the PGA Tour this year, and Peter Thomson, a 55-year-old Australian who got a second life in golf when the Senior PGA Tour was created, each won a title in the MONY Tournament of Champions today.

title: PRESIDENT CITES A STORY OF PEACE AMID THE TERRORS OF BATTLE
description: To illustrate the theme of reconciliation, President Reagan yesterday cited the story of a German woman who, with the Battle of the Bulge raging nearby, risked her life on Christmas Eve 1944 by taking in seven young soldiers - three Americans and four Germans - who had strayed from their units.

title: Legionnaires' Disease Linked to a Hospital
description: Cooling towers of a new district hospital are believed to be the source of infection in one of the world's worst outbreaks of legionnaires' disease, Britain's top disease expert said today.

title: Thrift Unit Has Loss in Florida
description: The American Savings and Loan Association of Florida reported a net loss of $48.8 million in its second quarter ended March 31, compared with a profit of $3.1 million in the period a year ago.

title: CONCERT: CHICAGO SYMPHONY
description: THE Mahler Seventh Symphony - which the Chicago Symphony played at Carnegie Hall Friday night - is, in its way, an encylopedia of Central European late-Romantic sentiment. Its five movements, stretching over nearly an hour and a half, appeal in turn to our fears and fantasies - with its visions of rustic pleasures, of anxiety and exuberance, all of which emerge, as filtered through Mahler's manic-depressive spirit, intriguingly blurred and uncertainly defined.

title: Pilot and Cameraman Die in Crash of Copter
description: A pilot and television cameraman were killed today when their news helicopter struck a transmitting tower cable and crashed into flames behind a television station here.

title: MOUNTAIN MEN'S TRIAL OPENS IN KIDNAPPING-MURDER CASE
description: Jury selection in the trial of two mountain men accused of abducting an athlete and killing her would-be rescuer last July will begin here Monday.

title: REBELS AND HUNGER STALK PROVINCE IN PHILIPPINES
description: Almost every day here and in most of the surrounding towns one sees the funeral processions that people say have become increasingly common in this province in the central Philippines.

title: Environmentalist Wins Austin Mayoral Race
description: Voters have ousted Mayor Ron Mullen in favor of Frank Cooksey, a lawyer who is an environmental activist.

title: Southeast Asians Hold A Reunion in California
description: About 10,000 Southeast Asian refugees gathered at this Marine Corps base Saturday for a reunion including Vietnamese barbecues, photographs of long-lost friends and exhibits of their life when they arrived here a decade ago.

title: BLESSINGS BESTOWED ON BIKERS
description: ''This blessing is only good up to 55 miles per hour,'' said the Rev. Flavius Gamache as his voice struggled to overcome the throaty rumble of a motorcycle engine and the crackle of a citizens' band radio.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DISENCHANTMENT During and after the shock of the Great Depression, the European Surrealist movement influenced some American artists in their manner of portraying poverty, war, injustice and other iniquities of the age. The work of 11 of these artists is on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street (878-2550).

title: BRAVES' MAHLER WINS NO. 7
description: Rick Mahler scattered eight hits over eight innings to record his seventh victory without a loss, and Terry Harper drove in three runs as the Atlanta Braves beat the Montreal Expos, 6-1, today. Mahler yielded only a second-inning leadoff homer by Dan Driessen. He struck out two and walked two. A throwing error by the third baseman Tim Wallach and a run-scoring single by Harper gave the Braves a 2-0 lead in the first inning against the Montreal starter, Bill Gullickson (3-2). With two out, Gerald Perry doubled, and scored when Wallach overthrew first after fielding Dale Murphy's infield hit. Murphy went to second when Bob Horner walked, then scored on Harper's single.

title: Reagan Joins Kohl in Brief Memorial at Bitburg Graves
description: BITBURG, West Germany, May 5  President Reagan presided over a wreath-laying today at the base of a brick cemetery tower looming over the graves of nearly 2,000 German soldiers, including 49 SS troops.

title: AN INTERNATIONAL FLAVOR FOR KOOL JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: The annual New York Kool Jazz Festival, which will run from June 21 to June 30 in a variety of locations both in and out of New York, will have an international flavor this year.

title: CITY SEEKS CONTROLS ON SCHOOLS' SPENDING OF FUNDS
description: The Koch administration is seeking to limit the discretion of the Board of Education in spending funds provided by the city for reducing class sizes and carrying out other special programs.

title: LEONARD M. ROSS, LAW SCHOLAR, DIES
description: Leonard M. Ross, a ''whiz kid'' of television quiz shows who became a law professor at Columbia University and an economic adviser to President Carter, was found dead May 1 in a swimming pool in Santa Clara, Calif. He was 39 years old. Lieut. Charles Seymour of the Santa Clara Police Department said yesterday that the death ''appears to be a suicide.''

title: A COMEBACK FOR DILLON, READ
description: When T. Boone Pickens began a takeover bid for the Unocal Corporation last month, Unocal mustered the toughest defense it could, leaning on the advice of two investment banks: Goldman, Sachs & Company and Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Mutual Funds Under Hutton
description: WHEN E.F. Hutton pleaded guilty to 2,000 felony counts of mail and wire fraud last week, there was at least the possibility that the huge brokerage firm might have to divest itself of its $10 billion mutual fund business as a result of the plea.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, MAY 6, 1985

title: 2 Shot, 1 Fatally, On Queens Street
description: A 30-year-old man was slain and a companion critically wounded on a Queens street early yesterday in a shooting that apparently grew out of a dispute, the police said. A suspect was arrested last night and charged with murder.

title: FAIRFIELD LIFE OUT OF REACH FOR WORKERS
description: Horrified by housing costs, prospective postmasters here rarely ring twice.

title: May Follows Bearish Form
description: THE stock market began the month of May with an eye seemingly fixed upon history.

title: BALLET: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV IN 'BLACK SWAN' PAS DE DEUX
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV made his first appearance in American Ballet Theater's season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday night by dancing the ''Black Swan'' pas de deux with Susan Jaffe.

title: BULLS RALLY 3 TIMES TO DEFEAT GENERALS
description: Herschel Walker did a lot for the Generals today as usual, but he could not do it all. The Jacksonville Bulls, a rugged opponent, defeated the New Jersey team, 30-20, in a contest the home team broke open in the fourth quarter.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: JAPAN LIST SHOWS GROWING AFFLUENCE
description: To the chagrin of the wealthy and the delight of the curious, Japan's tax agency last week published its annual list of the nation's largest taxpayers.

title: U.P.I.'S OWNERS TO SEEK OUSTER OF ITS MANAGERS
description: The principal stockholders of United Press International said yesterday that they planned to ask a bankruptcy court in Washington this week to remove the chairman, Luis G. Nogales, and other top executives of the financially troubled news service.

title: TRIPLE CROWN: UNEASY FUTURE
description: When Spend a Buck won the 111th Kentucky Derby Saturday, he ran the third-fastest time in the history of the race and scored by the largest margin in 39 years. He is obviously a good colt, perhaps good enough to establish standards on the track or influence the future of the breed when he goes to stud. But if he does not run in the Preakness Stakes May 18, a move his handlers are considering, it could do more to change the course of thoroughbred racing than Spend a Buck ever could as a race horse or a stallion.

title: Debate Over New Fuel Lead Limit
description: On July 1, the nation's oil companies must reduce the lead content in leaded gasoline to five-tenths of a gram per gallon to meet a requirement of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. But, with the deadline just weeks away, a broad debate goes on within the gasoline industry over the immediate impact the reduction may have on consumers.

title: Bridge: A Situation That's 'Simple' May Reveal Its Complexity
description: Some situations that appear simple become complex on close examination. Consider the position in which a defender holds the ace of a suit and dummy, to his left, has a holding headed by K-J. The declarer leads low toward the K-J.

title: DELICATE REAGAN PATH
description: On his mournful pilgrimage to the gravesites of the Holocaust and World War II, President Reagan walked a careful path today, hoping finally to disentangle himself from the most wrenching political episode of his Presidency without abandoning Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: WHEN THE LETTERS STOPPED
description: HALF a century later, Harry Glickman remembers the envelopes he addressed for his mother's letters. At the time, he was a youngster in Portland, Ore., where he eventually created the Trail Blazers of the National Basketball Association, and every so often in those years before World War II, his mother, Bessie, would write to her family in Poland.

title: Pro Arte Quartet Plays Daniel Perlongo Work
description: Daniel Perlongo's String Quartet No. 2 (1983), which opened the Pro Arte Quartet's Thursday evening concert at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a straightforward composition in four adjoining movements, characterized by angular, effective melodies and a certain nostalgia. Mr. Perlongo's work, which recently won the competition of the League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music, is somewhat more homophonic than many recent quartets: Instead of participating in a series of gnarled, contrapuntal clusters, the players trade off - now essaying the composer's clearly defined melodies, now providing equally distinct accompaniment.

title: Common Unit For Clearing
description: ''AFTER years of talk about common processing and clearing of securities, futures and options trading, common sense has finally prevailed and this will soon become a reality,'' Lewis J. Horowitz, president of the New York Futures Exchange, said last Friday. ''We are arranging to have the Options Clearing Corporation process and clear out index futures and options transactions.''

title: Yonkers Record
description: On The Road Again, driven by Buddy Gilmour, set a Yonkers track record for the mile as he rolled to a three-length victory in 1:55 1/5 to win a $50,000 leg of the George Morton Levy Series Saturday night. The time eclipsed the former track mark of 1:55 3/5 that was held by both Skip by Night and George S. On the Road Again paid $2.60 to win.

title: Spaniards in Protests Against Reagan's Visit
description: Hundreds of thousands of people marched in largely peaceful protests across Spain today against President Reagan's scheduled visit here Monday.

title: REAGAN JOINS KOHL IN BRIEF MEMORIAL AT BITBURG GRAVES
description: President Reagan presided over a wreath-laying today at the base of a brick cemetery tower looming over the graves of nearly 2,000 German soldiers, including 49 SS troops.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN TROOPS AND POLICE SEAL BLACK TOWNSHIP OVER UNREST
description: South African troops and policemen sealed off a black township in the restive Eastern Cape region today after widespread unrest in the area.

title: NORDIQUES DEFEAT FLYERS IN OVERTIME
description: Peter Stastny picked up the pass, immediately took a look at the net some 70 feet away, and started thinking. Two strides later, with the blue line approaching, his mind was made up.

title: YANKS TAKE 4TH IN ROW, 6-2;   REDS ARE BEATEN, 3-2
description: The Mets, apparently recovered from Saturday's 14-2 thrashing, defeated the Reds, 3-2, today behind the pitching of Dwight Gooden and Jesse Orosco.

title: FILM RECORDS SEPARETE PATHS TO ADULTHOOD
description: ''What do you want to be when you grow up?'' becomes a provocative question when put to a group of 7-year-old British children and repeated every seven years until they are 28. The result is ''28 Up,'' Michael Apted's award-winning documentary, which has touched audiences in the United States and abroad. It has also given educators and psychologists a rare longitudinal glimpse of the mysterious process of growing up.

title: A Dividend for Trump
description: At first, it looks as if Hilton has not given up the dream of opening an Atlantic City hotel and casino.

title: NONPAYERS HURT LONG-DISTANCE COMPANIES
description: Americans are paying their long-distance telephone bills later and later. And - in what communications industry experts are calling one of the seamier effects of the extraordinary competition that has broken out in long distance - many people are not paying their bills at all. .

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Mark Peskanov, Violinist, in Recital
description: Mark Peskanov, a Soviet emigre who played Handel, Schubert, Felix Kruglikov and Franck Saturday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, has the technical facility to make short work of the standard violin repertory. One never wondered whether he would be able to take the next burst of passagework in tempo and in tune, whether his energy would flag in the long Franck sonata, whether his fingers would falter (just occasionally, but only very slightly, his bow arm did, on a couple of long soft notes).

title: ANOTHER 40 YEARS
description: President Reagan's visit to the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp and then to the German military cemetery here was to symbolize what has changed 40 years after the defeat of the Third Reich.

title: STAGE: CAMILLE SAVIOLA
description: WITH ruffles and flourishes, the pianist Joel Silberman introduces Camille Saviola, the star and creator of ''Secrets of the Lava Lamp,'' a flashy collage of songs and stories at the Manhattan Theater Club. Miss Saviola, a rotund young woman, announces that she will sing the national anthem, and then belts out ''There's No Business Like Show Business'' in a voice not unrelated to that of Ethel Merman.

title: A VONNEGUT STORY: 'DISPLACED PERSON'
description: VIEWERS looking for safe sanctuary this evening from the cheap manipulations of ''Lace II,'' mercifully coming to a conclusion on ABC, need go no further than American Playhouse on Public Television. ''Displaced Person,'' on WNET/13 at 9 P.M., is based on a Kurt Vonnegut Jr. story that was originally published as ''D.P.'' in The Ladies' Home Journal and then put into the author's 1950 short-story collection ''Welcome to the Monkey House.'' It is a small, touching piece, adapted with protective care for television by Fred Barron.

title: HENRY S. FUJARSKI
description: Henry S. Fujarski, a senior vice president in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died of a heart attack Thursday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 47 years old and lived in Queens.

title: END OF JOINT STEEL TALKS LAID TO UNION DECISIONS
description: Erosions in the steel industry's national approach to labor-management contracts led to the decision last week of five major companies to abandon coordination altogether, industry executives say.

title: A SHRINKING AGENCY THAT SURVIVES
description: The Council on Environmental Quality is turning out to be the little agency that would not die.

title: Family Planning: Strict Enough Already
description: Forty years from now, at current growth rates, the world will hold twice as many people - close to 10 billion. Most will be living in desperately poor countries, countries that have slowly come to accept America's advice that slowing population growth speeds up economic progress.

title: Gun Group Cites Bias in Press
description: The new president of the National Rifle Association has taken action against what he calls the news media's liberal bias in favor of gun control.

title: MITTERRAND'S GOALS: 'PRESERVING SKILLS,' 'PROTECTING EUROPE'
description: Fears of a scientific brain drain to American industry and of unrest at home largely explain President Francois Mitterrand's objection at the Bonn summit conference to setting a date for new trade talks and his rejection of Washington's invitation to join the ''Star Wars'' research program, according to French officials and other participants.

title: Reader's Digest Trade Account Is Moving
description: James D. Parry has left Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle, and the Reader's Digest advertising-trade account has elected to follow him. Until now, the assignment has been to promote advertising in the country's largest-circulation magazine.

title: Not Right Enough at Justice?
description: >Rex Lee has spent the last four years serving President Reagan as Solicitor General, the Government's chief lawyer before the Supreme Court. His record of Supreme Court victories ordinarily would entitle him to applause from those of conservative philosophy. For instance, he argued and won in major criminal cases and helped persuade the Justices to allow Pawtucket, R.I., to include a creche in its Christmas display. Then why so little thunder from the right? Because while right-wing, he was not enough so for some within the Administration and on its fringes.

title: GERMAN'S HOMAGE AT MOSCOW RITES
description: East and West German Communist leaders paid homage to the Soviet victory over Nazi Germany in a series of ceremonies and meetings in and around Moscow today, while President Reagan was scathingly denounced for ''paying respects to the Third Reich.''

title: Marilyn Prevost, Student, Wed to Dr. Alec Megibow
description: Marilyn Lois Prevost, the daughter of Mrs. Edward Prevost of Detroit and the late Mr. Prevost, was married yesterday to Dr. Alec J. Megibow, a son of Helen V. Beder of New York and the late Dr. Raymond S. Megibow. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at Garvin's, a restaurant in Manhattan.

title: FALLING INTEREST RATES PREVAIL
description: In advance of the record-sized Treasury borrowings this week, short- and long-term interest rates declined recently as investors and traders focused on weak economic data.

title: Farmer-Labor Nexus
description: American farmers, on the whole, have never plowed much common ground with organized labor. Many farmers tend to see themselves as self-reliant independent operators, rejecting ideas like the 40-hour week.

title: CONCERT: BROKLYN PHILHARMONIC
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonic ended its subscription season this past weekend in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House with three concerts of a program that in many ways reflected real artistic accomplishment. Too bad the last chord ringing in one's ears sounded so awful.

title: 'I AM A JEW...'
description: To President Kennedy's ''Ich bin ein Berliner,'' a powerful and personal statement of identification with people struggling for freedom, President Reagan added: ''. . . I am a Jew in a world still threatened by anti-Semitism, I am an Afghan, and I am a prisoner of the Gulag, I am a refugee in a crowded boat foundering off the coast of Vietnam, I am a Laotian, a Cambodian, a Cuban and a Miskito Indian in Nicaragua. I, too, am a potential victim of totalitarianism.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MAY 6, 1985

title: Karin Nierenberg Bride in Armonk
description: The marriage of Karin Alice Nierenberg and Mitchell Lawrence Weisburgh took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. Nierenberg, in Armonk, N.Y. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Weisburgh of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony.

title: CASE STUDY FOR ELEVATOR ANTIQUARIANS
description: Fred Litwin paced nervously as he watched inspectors load 750 pounds of lead blocks onto his ancient store elevator in downtown Washington.

title: Illiteracy Problem Needs Federal Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Car Underweight
description: Elio De Angelis of Italy won the Grand Prix of San Marino auto race today after the top finisher, Alain Prost of France, was disqualified. The 30-year-old Frenchman, who had crossed the finish line first in a McLaren-Tag, was disqualified because stewards determined that his car was underweight by 4.4 to 8.8 pounds. Formula One racers must have a minimum weight of 1,190 pounds.

title: 'Blue Angel' Premiere
description: Natalia Makarova will star with Roland Petit in the American premiere of Mr. Petit's ''The Blue Angel'' at the Metropolitan Opera House from July 24 through Aug. 3, with a preview on July 23.

title: WARD CHIEF MAY BE ANNOUNCED
description: The Mobil Corporation is expected to announce Monday the appointment of Bernard F. Brennan, currently president of the merchandising division of Household International Inc., as president and chief executive officer of Montgomery Ward & Company, Mobil's retailing subsidiary, sources close to Household said.

title: WHY SENATE HAS NOT RATIFIED GENOCIDE TREATY
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign For Media Planners
description: EUSTACE TILLEY, The New Yorker magazine's foppish symbol, is taking off his kid gloves to better claw some additional advertising from the marketplace. Being off 207 pages of advertising in just the first four months of the year can really be an incentive.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Preservations
description: Vintage Cars The R-10 cars on New York City's IND line are veterans of nearly 40 years of hard traveling. During the last decade they've also been subjected to graffiti vandals; the Eighth Avenue local, in particular, was an assault to the eyes and an insult to the spirit.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We who were enemies are now friends. We who were bitter adversaries are now the strongest of allies.

title: Turkish Cypriots Vote For New Constitution
description: Turkish Cypriots gave overwhelming approval in a referendum today to a new constitution for their self-proclaimed Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.

title: Treasury Official Oversees Embargo
description: The year had already been a busy one for John M. Walker Jr., the top law enforcement official at the Treasury Department. But last week, President Reagan made Mr. Walker's life even more hectic.

title: SPEECH BY REAGAN AT BERGEN-BELSEN
description: Following is the official text of President Reagan's speech today at the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp:

title: EX-OIL BROKER TRADES IN ART
description: IT was not long after Thomas Galdy went into the oil brokerage business that the 1973 Arab oil embargo sent prices soaring. Much the same thing has happened to values in Mr. Galdy's newest commodity: Old Masters drawings.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Was Bill Sharman the best free-throw shooter in N.B.A history?

title: MORENO OUTRUNS RODGERS FOR JERSEY TITLE
description: For pocket money, John Moreno of Pacifica, Calif., works 25 hours a week in the produce department of a supermarket. Today, he put $5,000 in prize money and what he called a modest appearance fee in that pocket by winning the first New Jersey Waterfront Marathon.

title: Iraq Says Its Jets Raided 2 Ships in Gulf
description: Iraq said today that its jet fighters had raided two ships in the Persian Gulf off the Iranian coast, but marine salvage executives in the area said their radio monitors had received no distress signals from any vessel.

title: VOLKWAGEN'S AUDI UNIT EMPHASIZES INNOVATIONS
description: Compet-ing with Japanese automobile companies is like a sword fight with an opponent who keeps honing his weapon to an ever finer edge, observes Ferdinand Piech, the chief engineer for Audi, the West German auto maker.

title: A SEARCH FOR MEANING AT BITBURG
description: BITBURG came and went on television yesterday after dominating coverage of President Reagan's trip to Europe all week. On television, the visit to the German military cemetery was brief, wordless and, from the White House point of view, all that could be hoped: a solemn President simply placed a wreath against the base of a stone tower. There were few glimpses of demonstrators, and none at all, apparently, of SS graves.

title: Kirstein Will Receive Arts Society Award
description: The Municipal Arts Society has announced that Lincoln Kirstein will receive its annual award, given to acknowledge contributions by organizations and individuals to the quality of life in New York City. Mr. Kirstein is the only individual receiving the award this year.

title: BFI COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sister Bernadette Belz, 90, Ex-Prioress General on L.I.
description: Sister Bernadette de Lourdes Belz, former prioress general of the Sisters of Saint Dominic of Amityville, L.I., died yesterday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. She was 90 years old and lived in Rosary Hall in Amityville.

title: Textron Offers 2 Debt Issues
description: Textron Inc. is offering two debt issues totaling $250 million, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. A $150 million issue of 11 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1995 is offered at 99.41 to yield 11.851 percent, while $100 million of 12 3/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 2010 are offered at 99.80 to yield 12.775 percent.

title: Guidelines Issued for Banks Lending Securities
description: Two Federal regulatory agencies issued guidelines today on how banks and other regulated financial institutions can protect themselves when lending securities that they either own or hold in trust for clients.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $54,441,000 for the latest first quarter and $13,132,000 for the year- ago first quarter. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid March 1.

title: Kuwait Appoints New Justice Minister
description: Kuwait today named its Islamic Affairs Minister to replace Justice Minister Sheik Salman al-Duayj al-Sabah, who resigned Sunday after allegations of improper conduct.

title: Continental Head May Replace Olmer
description: The White House is expected to announce shortly that S. Bruce Smart Jr., chief executive of Continental Group Inc. of Stamford, Conn., will replace Lionel H. Olmer as Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration.

title: Careers;   Finding Work for C Students
description: THE A's are all right, and so are many B's, but the C students often have trouble finding jobs after graduation.

title: CURBING NEW YORK'S POLICE
description: The scandal in the 106th Precinct in Queens - four men charged with selling marijuana were allegedly tortured by five police officers with electric stun-guns - is hardly an isolated incident of alleged police abuse. One tragedy of this most recent scandal, which last week led to indictments, is that it has taken so long to focus public attention on the reforms necessary to control the police.

title: AUTHENTICITY OF BIRD FOSSIL IS CHALLENGED
description: A TEAM of six scientists has charged that one of the world's most valuable fossils is a fake, touching off one of the bitterest rows in the history of the British Museum.

title: CENCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $165,000, or 12 cents a share, from discontinued operations. The company said revenue figure for the latest quarter has been restated to exclude discontinued operations.

title: Halley's Comet Record
description: Halley's comet, which will reappear late this year, was seen and recorded by the Babylonians in 164 B.C., according to scientists who have found references to the ancient sitings on clay tablets preserved in the British Museum. The tablets, discovered about 100 years ago, have been a neglected source of astronomical observations, the scientists said.

title: THAYER REPAYMENT BID CITED
description: Paul Thayer, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, and a Dallas stockbroker have offered to pay the Government more than $750,000 to settle civil charges of illegal insider stock trading, according to lawyers involved in the case.

title: Of Mothers and OWL's
description: A lot of brainpower is spent in Washington inventing catchy names. Thus the Older Women's League seems to have a good one in OWL.

title: ACS ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Swiss Watch Exports
description: Swiss watch exports reached $2.5 billion in the first quarter of 1985, up 17.7 percent from a year earlier, and the improvement is continuing in the second quarter, a Swiss watch federation said today.

title: WEST POINT GOES HUNTING FOR RECRUITS
description: The United States Military Academy, which historically has been in the enviable position of choosing from among the top students in the country, now finds itself having to compete with private colleges to attract cadets in a shrinking market of 18-year-olds.

title: COMFORT AT HOME
description: Mollie Parnis closed her dress business in October after 40 years in the same Seventh Avenue building. Retirement didn't appeal to her.

title: KANSAS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KAISER STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including income of $3,741,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income.

title: DOLE MAY DELAY ON BUDGET UNTIL REAGAN RETURNS
description: Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, said today that he might put off the vote on a final budget package until next week, after President Reagan returns from his European trip.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   An Evening of Works By Mario Davidovsky
description: Continuum, directed by Joel Sachs and Cheryl Seltzer, gave over its Alice Tully Hall concert Saturday night to the music of Mario Davidovsky. Mr. Davidovsky, the man, represents an intertwining of European Jewish and South American cultural influences, all tempered and further catalyzed by his many years in America. So it is natural that most of the five pieces played here occupied themselves with reconciling different ways of hearing and feeling.

title: NOVA, AN ALBERTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: ALATENN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Pascual Perez, pitcher, on 15-day disabled list. Recalled Jeff Dedmon from Richmond.

title: Consideration, at Last, for Jurors
description: After years of idle talk, New York's Legislature is about to make clearer the power of trial judges, not lawyers, to run the jury selection process. That could do much to relieve the abuse of jurors that now seems an inevitable, though intolerable, part of the courts' routine.

title: JOURNALISTS DISAGREE ABOUT PRESS CREDIBILITY
description: Senior journalists from four of the nation's largest news organizations expressed strong disagreement here today over whether the press has a serious credibility problem.

title: QUESTION OF SURVIVAL AMONG PUBLICATIONS
description: THE personal computer publishing industry has at last discovered the basic economic rule that no market grows forever. The demand for software, magazines and books devoted to microcomputers and their inner workings is contracting at a rate almost as phenomenal as its growth.

title: ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE: FAMILIES ARE BITTER
description: These are frustrating days for victims of Alzheimer's disease, an incurable mental deterioration that robs some two million Americans of their memories and reasoning abilities.

title: How Proportionalism Could Help Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: MESA DEALS AT CENTER OF INQUIRY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting a broad investigation into possible insider trading involving virtually all of the takeover targets of T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, a recent court document discloses. The investigation is in addition to a narrower S.E.C. investigation of trading in shares of the Unocal Corporation, Mr. Pickens's current target. Mesa disclosed that investigation last week.

title: U.S. MILITARY ADVISERS TO TRAIN COSTA RICAN POLICE
description: United States military advisers will soon begin training Costa Rica's national police force to cope with what officials there say is a threat from Nicaraguan-trained terrorists and insurgents, American officials said today.

title: IS ABSOLUTELY EVERYTHING MADE OF STRINGS?
description: A NUMBER of leading physicists are beginning to suspect that everything in the universe is made of strings.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $68,000 for the latest first quarter and $181,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: LARRY CLINTON, BAND LEADER WHO WROTE 'DIPSY DOODLE'
description: Larry Clinton, a popular orchestra leader, composer and arranger of the big-band era whose tune ''The Dipsy Doodle'' was one of the top hits of the late 1930's, died of cancer Thursday at the University of Arizona Medical College in Tucson. He was 75 years old and lived in Green Valley, Ariz.

title: Warner Offer Is Seen Near
description: Industry analysts said yesterday that a deal might be in the making for control of Warner Communications Inc.

title: GIGA-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Thrift Units Acquired
description: Home Savings of America, of Los Angeles, has agreed to acquire four Ohio thrift institutions that were unable to reopen for full service following the state's banking crisis, a state official said today.

title: GISH BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $6,800 for the quarter and $18,800 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $8,000 for the quarter and $64,000 for the 9 months.

title: WESTON, GEORGE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special gain of $1 million.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bowa Asks for Trade
description: Larry Bowa, the Chicago Cubs' frustrated backup shortstop, has asked to be traded, Dallas Green, the team president and general manager, said yesterday. Green said that Bowa's agent, Jack Sands of Boston, had made the request on his behalf.

title: TWO MORE TONY CATEGORIES DROPPED
description: Two more categories were dropped from the Tony Awards yesterday in an unusual action by the nominating committee. The 11-member committee unanimously voted not to give any award for leading actor in a musical or for choreography.

title: GEMAYEL MEETS ARMY CHIEFS
description: President Amin Gemayel met with senior army commanders today as fighting between Moslem and Christian militiamen in Beirut turned into a full-scale battle for control of the so-called Green Line dividing the city into Moslem and Christian sectors.

title: FIGHT OVER ANIMAL EXPERIMENTS GAINS INTENSITY ON MANY FRONTS
description: THE bitter confrontation between medical scientists and the protectors of animals has escalated to new heights of intensity as the two sides battle over the future of biomedical research.

title: Flying Questionnaires
description: On May 15, each of 5,000 schoolchildren in 10 cities across the United States will release a small helium-filled balloon carrying a questionnaire. The object of the mass balloon launching is to demonstrate weather patterns over the continent by tracking the paths of as many balloons as possible.

title: Mengel Shooting Goes To Grand Jury Today
description: A grand jury will begin hearing testimony in the fatal shooting of Alex Mengel today , according to the Dutchess County District Attorney, William Grady.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUDGE AT VON BULOW TRIAL BARS DOCTOR'S TESTIMONY
description: Judge Corinne P. Grande today barred a Newport Hospital neurologist from testifying that the scratches and bruises he saw on Martha von Bulow in 1980 resulted from a struggle.

title: MHP MACHINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including net foreign currency translation gains of $38,000 for the quarter and $32,000 for the 6 months. c-Net losses after net foreign currency translation losses of $11,000 for the quarter and $6,000 for the 6 months.

title: Pilot Dies in L.I. Crash
description: The pilot of a small private plane was killed when his aircraft crashed at Coram Airpark in this Suffolk County community, the police said. The pilot, who was flying alone, was not immediately identified.

title: YANKEES TO SEEK TRADE FOR GRIFFEY
description: Clyde King, the Yankee general manager, said yesterday that he would attempt to work out a deal this week to accommodate Ken Griffey in his request for a trade. But he said that the outfielder's lucrative contract could stand in the way.

title: BIG WHEEL UNDER THE BIG TOP
description: STANLEY MARCUS, grand seigneur of the Neiman-Marcus retailing empire, celebrated his 80th birthday at the circus. He was a clown at a matinee and ringmaster in the evening.

title: Oenology in Brooklyn
description: ''My expressway runneth over.''

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a securities gain of $993,000. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December 1984. Share earnings for both periods do not reflect a previously declared 3-for-2 stock split payable in June.

title: F.D.I.C. Decides to Disclose Disciplinary Actions
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation voted unanimously today to adopt a new regulation, bitterly opposed by the banking industry, under which it will disclose disciplinary actions taken against the 8,850 banks it regulates.

title: BUSH, IN JERSEY, PRAISES U.S. 'HAND' TO GERMANS
description: Vice President Bush, in a day of political and governmental appearances in New Jersey and New York City, yesterday praised President Reagan for holding out ''a hand to the German people.''

title: Vietnam Was Lost Before Hanoi's Infiltrations
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLNET COMMUNICATIONS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCORD COMPUTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: UCCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $800,000 for the latest quarter and $160,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Hilton Hotels Vote
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said yesterday that a preliminary count of the votes at its annual meeting showed that shareholders approved several provisions that would appear to block a possible takeover attempt by Golden Nugget Inc. John V. Giovenco, Hilton's executive vice president, said an official tabulation would take several days. The annual meeting was adjourned until Thursday, when Mr. Giovenco said the official tally would probably be presented. The anti-takeover provisions include staggered terms for directors, and a requirement that any merger or ouster of directors be approved by a 75 percent shareholder vote.

title: PAPER TO AID NICARAGUA REBELS
description: The Washington Times announced today that it would try to raise privately the $14 million rejected by Congress for assistance to the rebels seeking the overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: DISPUTE AT CITY BALLET SCHOOL POLARIZES BOARD OF DIRECTORS
description: A bitter dispute at the New York City Ballet's school, the School of American Ballet, between Lincoln Kirstein, co-founder of both the school and the City Ballet, and a faction opposed to Mr. Kirstein, has polarized its board of directors. The conflict concerns the school's future administration and Mr. Kirstein's continued role there.

title: SALK AND HIS SCHOLARS MARK 30 YEARS OF FUND
description: Thirty years ago, when Dr. Jonas E. Salk, the developer of the first polio vaccine, was invited to New York for a ticker-tape parade in his honor, he declined and said the money would be better spent on scholarships for medical students.

title: Vietnam Was Lost Before Hanoi's Infiltrations
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GORING IS NAMED AS COACH OF BRUINS
description: Butch Goring, who helped the Islanders win four Stanley Cups, today was given the job of helping the Boston Bruins reverse their fading fortunes.

title: Progress Is Reported in Fighting Rejection
description: Boston researchers experimenting with rats and mice are reporting success in using monoclonal antibodies to battle the body's rejection of transplanted hearts or other organs. One researcher, describing the progress at a conference today, said doctors hope to be treating human patients in three or four months.

title: Rockland Youth Commits Suicide
description: A Rockland County teen-ager committed suicide at his home Sunday by drinking as much as a pint of gasoline, the Rockland County Medical Examiner said today.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $3,028,000 for the latest first quarter and $250,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: MICHIGAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including income of $1.1 million from discontinued operations.

title: Advertising;   Premium Incentive Show
description: BOB SIEMON, who started making jewelry in his garage when he was a teen-ager, for 15 years specialized in adornments of a religious nature. His Master Craft Jewelry now has 75 people turning them out in Fountain Valley, Calif. In recent years he decided that making jewelry for corporate premiums would be a good way to help the company grow. That is what brought him yesterday for the first time to the Premium Incentive Show that opened at the New York Coliseum.

title: Potential Jurors Tell Views on Mercy Killing
description: Potential jurors in the trial of a man charged with killing his terminally ill wife were questioned today on whether he had the right to end her life.

title: XL-DATACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Investment Rises In Partnerships
description: Investments in publicly registered limited partnerships rose to more than $2 billion in the first quarter of 1985, up from about $1.7 billion for the first quarter a year ago, according to Robert A. Stanger & Company, a Shrewsbury, N.J., investment research firm.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE fall showings are over and one message that came through loud and clear is that we should be seeing a lot of black next winter. Black jersey, black cashmere and black velvet were all over the market. It created a sameness in the clothes, sometimes amounting to dullness, though not when handled by strong designers like Calvin Klein and Donna Karan. Oh, there was gold lame for evening, and gold lace as well. And there were enough floral tapestries to furnish a good-size mansion. But seeing the same fabrics in so many shows contributed to the sameness.

title: FEELING WEARY, FLYERS TAKE BREAK
description: The Philadelphia Flyers, after opening the Stanley Cup semifinals Sunday night with a 2-1 overtime loss to the Quebec Nordiques, held a news conference today instead of a practice.

title: Choosing Sides
description: Can't tell the political consultants without a scorecard.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $204,000 for the quarter and $409,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax benefits of $329,000 for the quarter and $327,000 for the 6 months.

title: City Paying for Koch Trip
description: Mayor Koch's trip to the Vatican to attend Archbishop John J. O'Connor's elevation to Cardinal will cost the city some money.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Caere Corp. of Los Gatos, Calif., which makes optical character recognition and bar code equipment, announced that Bob Teresi had been named president and chief executive officer.

title: 8 Ex-Cosmos on Team
description: Rick Davis and Angelo DiBernardo, midfielders, and Jeff Durgan, a defender, are among eight former Cosmos who have been named to the United States team for the World Cup. Also named by Coach Alkis Panagoulias were Chico Borja, David Brcic, Dan Canter, Erhardt Kapp and Mike Fox. The team will gather in St. Louis today to prepare for qualifying games this month against Trinidad-Tobago and Costa Rica.

title: OFFIALS BAFFLED BY EIGHT SLAYINGS
description: Investigators examining the slayings of eight women from Pennsylvania to Mississippi say the victims must be identified before the authorities can hope for leads to the killer or killers.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, MAY 7, 1985

title: TV TIE MAY FORCE DIVESTITURE OF POST
description: Under a rule of the Federal Communications Commission, The New York Post would have to be put up for sale in about a year if its publisher, Rupert Murdoch, decides to keep WNEW-TV, New York's Channel 5, one of the Metromedia television stations he agreed yesterday to acquire.

title: MEDIA HORIZONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $35,690 on the sale of a publication.

title: SAME OLD TRACK FOR ABC'S DERBY SHOW
description: The horse stole the show, if not the race. It wasn't much of a show, unless you like mint juleps spiced with calf-wrestling.

title: TECK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: POLITICS AND TAXES
description: Walter Mondale's campaign promise to raise taxes if elected President was not merely a gamble that failed, costly to him and his party; it's also an indirect but powerful factor in this year's budget battle.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,290,000 for the quarter and $2,415,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $800,000 for the 6 months.

title: Espionage Trial Is Delayed
description: The trial of Svetlana and Nikolay Ogorodnikov, Russian emigres accused of conspiring to commit espionage, was adjourned for one day today because of the illness of one of the jurors.

title: Grey's Net Up 50%
description: Grey Advertising's first-quarter earnings statement shows that revenues were up 22.8 percent, to $49.6 million, from $40.4 million in the period last year, while net income rose 50 percent, to $1.5 million, or $2.33 a share, from $1 million, or $1.59 a share.

title: THEATER: WILSON'S 'FENCES'
description: In ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' the playwright August Wilson took us into a Chicago band room of 1927, where black musicians channeled a heritage of unspeakable suffering into beautiful blues music, and, on occasion, eruptions of self-destructive rage. In ''Fences,'' the new Wilson play at the Yale Repertory Theater, the setting is again the urban industrial North, and the characters are again transplanted blacks from the South, some of whom tote musical instruments. But now the year is 1957, and this time the horns remain silent. For the slum dwellers of ''Fences,'' scraping out a hard-scrabble existence amid the Eisenhower boom, there is nothing to sing about. There is only the rage, bottled up and festering, waiting for release in a cataclysm still to come.

title: Trump Waterfall Cited as Violation
description: The Trump Tower was among the first businesses to be fined by the city for violating emergency water restrictions, officials said yesterday.

title: Fire at Shelter Kills 50 Cats and Dogs
description: Fifty cats and dogs were killed and nine other animals injured early today in a fire at the Elmsford Animal Shelter that investigators said was purposely set.

title: KOHL'S DEBT AFTER BITBURG
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has emerged from President Reagan's state visit to West Germany deeply in debt to the American leader, and momentarily estranged from his principal partner in Western Europe, President Francois Mitterrand.

title: PSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIGURE IN CHICAGO RAPE CASE SAID TO PASS POLYGRAPH TEST
description: Gary Dotson, imprisoned six years for raping a woman who later said the assault never occurred, passed a lie detector test tonight, according to Robert C. Cummins, the polygraph examiner who administered the test.

title: Mets Will Look At Fernandez
description: Making an emergency move to patch up their pitching staff, the Mets yesterday said that Sid Fernandez will be brought up from Tidewater today and will throw on the sideline tomorrow. After that, team officials said that a determination would be made to either to send the 22-year-old left-hander back to the minors or put him on the 25-man roster.

title: Chess: 2 Finish Tied for First Place In Windy City Tournament
description: The Windy City International Tournament held at the University of Chicago was won by James Rizzitano of Sharon, Mass., and Vincent McCambridge, a Los Angeles international master. Each scored 8 1/2-2 1/2.

title: KLUGE: HE BUILT METROMEDIA
description: John W. Kluge's name may not be a household one outside the broadcast industry. But inside the industry, he is known as an entrepreneurial, energetic and shrewd businessman.

title: MERCENARY FREED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Col. Mike Hoare, a white mercenary leader whose career has spanned more than two decades, was released from a South African prison today after serving less than three years of a 10-year sentence for hijacking.

title: Athletes Overpaid
description: A Tennessee audit report said that Memphis State awarded student-athletes $58,940 more than they were entitled to between 1980 and 1984.

title: FOR THE POLES, SOLIDARITY LIVES ON
description: The suppression last week of the largest demonstrations in Poland since Solidarity was declared illegal in 1981 - more than 15,000 people marched peacefully in Warsaw and 2,000 clashed with police in Gdansk -was only the most recent and obvious sign of the regime's efforts to impose neo-Stalinism in Poland.

title: Bridge: Club In Jersey Is One Of Few That Stage A Sectional Meet
description: There are very few clubs in the country that are both willing and able to stage a sectional tournament. One of these is the Essex Bridge Center in West Orange, N.J., which has been doing so for 20 years and is firmly established as the headquarters of the New Jersey Bridge League.

title: EXPEDITORS INTERNATIONAL OF WASHINGTON reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in September 1984.

title: Want a Job?
description: People who would like to work around the White House are advised that there are openings this summer.

title: U.N. UNIT MAKES PLEA FOR AFRICA FOOD
description: Rains have brought relief to some drought-stricken African areas, but food supplies, pledged but not yet delivered, are urgently needed to ''avert a major disaster'' the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today.

title: Multimedia Shares
description: Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Washington Redskins football team, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had purchased a 9.75 percent stake in Multimedia Inc. for a total purchase price of $89 million.

title: MCA Net Off 12.4% in Period
description: MCA Inc., the entertainment company based in Universal City, Calif., yesterday reported a 12.4 percent decline in net income for the first quarter, compared with the comparable period last year. The decline was attributed in part to decreased revenues from its mail-order operations.

title: WESTCHESTER FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $259,000 from a dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank in the form of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock. c-Includes a gain of $387,000 from the sale of investments. The year-ago share earnings are not available because the company did not become public until March 1984.

title: EMBARGO MAY EXEMPT SOME
description: The Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to exempt contracts already signed by American importers and exporters from the economic sanctions that go into effect Tuesday against Nicaragua, officials said today.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $109,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,979,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $346,000 from discontinued operations. The company said year-ago results have been restated for pooling of interests and to present the corporation's underwriting management group as discontinued operations.

title: BLUE CROSS PIONEERS A POCKET MEDICAL HISTORY
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Maryland announced today that subscribers would receive membership cards that can contain the equivalent of 800 pages of information on their medical history. Nationwide adoption, the insurer said, is expected in a few years.

title: Petroleum Reserve Is a Flawed Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Retrial Bid Rejected In New Bedford Case
description: Four men serving prison terms in connection with the 1983 rape at Big Dan's tavern in New Bedford lost their battle for a new trial today, setting the stage for an appeal.

title: METS' VALUES OLD-FASHIONED
description: In contrast to the Bronx vaudeville act that is touring in Minnesota and Kansas City this week, New York's only bona fide baseball team returns to Shea Stadium against the Atlanta Braves tonight. Although struggling with a shaky pitching staff and a battered batting order, the Mets share first place in the National League East, a tribute to operating with old-fashioned baseball values -using a farm system to polish and produce players, not to punish them or to preen them to be dealt elswhere.

title: Pan Am Loss At $140 Million
description: C. Edward Acker, the chairman and chief executive of Pan American World Airways Inc., said yesterday that the carrier would have a loss of about $140 million in the first quarter.

title: Required Reading;   On Communications
description: Excerpt from a commencement address given by Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, at the George Washington University School of Public and International Affairs, May 5:

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Importer Is Promoting Moderation in Drinking
description: At a well-attended and speedy news conference last week, John E. Heilmann, president of Somerset Importers, announced the beginning of an advertising campaign promoting moderation in the use of alcoholic beverages. And that is what he imports.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CHAIM WEIZMANN. The Making of a Zionist Leader. By Jehuda Reinharz. 566 pages. Illustrated. Oxford. $29.95.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Ex-Cowboy's Plight
description: Plagued by personal and financial problems since he retired from football, John Niland, the former Dallas Cowboy lineman, says he is trying to reassemble his life. ''People think I'm a doper or a drunk,'' the 41-year-old Niland said recently.

title: U.S. AND CHINA SEEK ACCORD ON PLANNED PORT CALL
description: The United States and China are engaged in ''delicate negotiations'' to decide whether Navy ships will pay a planned port call at Shanghai next week, a State Department official said today.

title: Smithsonian Seeking Partner for Magazine
description: Unless the Smithsonian Institution finds a business partner, its proposal for a magazine on the history, art, literature and music of American blacks cannot be implemented, the institution's board of regents announced today.

title: HEART RECIPIENT BACK IN HOSPITAL
description: William J. Schroeder, the only person to be released from a hospital after receiving an artificial heart, was returned to the facility today after being described as too weak to leave his bed.

title: SOIL EROSION IS THREAT TO WATER, REPORT SAYS
description: PHILIP SHABECOFF

title: Nassau Settles Case for $2 Million
description: The Nassau County Board of Supervisors today unanimously approved the largest payment ever by the county in a negligence case.

title: DECISION DELAYED ON SPEND A BUCK
description: The owner and trainer of Spend a Buck, who won the Kentucky Derby here Saturday, said this morning that they would not decide until Thursday or Friday whether to run the colt in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico May 18 or hold him out for the richer Jersey Derby at Garden State Park May 27.

title: BLACK LANDOWNERS RESIST APARTHEID'S HARD SELL
description: The wind. It is the wind, rustling the blue gum trees and building across wide plains, that seems to distinguish this place, where people have lived for decades, from another place 60 miles away, where the Government wants them to move.

title: RISE IN BAR KILLINGS ANGERS HOUSTON HISPANIC DISTRICTS
description: Arriving early this morning at a barroom in a Hispanic district where a gunfight had been reported, police officers found on the sidewalk the bullet-riddled body of Adan Alfredo Lazo, a 30-year-old Salvadoran.

title: FULL POWER IS SET AT DIABLO CANYON
description: After two decades, thousands of arrests and a 13-fold increase in its cost, the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant was preparing today to begin full commercial operation.

title: 4 Rebels Are Killed in Peru
description: Four Maoist guerrillas were killed and one was captured in a clash with the police in the remote southeastern province of Andahuaylas, the police said today.

title: INTERSTATE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Music/Noted in Brief;   Leonard Cohen Sings Ballads of Two Decades
description: Although Leonard Cohen, the Montreal-based poet and singer, hasn't appeared in New York for a decade, he has retained a cult following that would be the envy of more successful pop stars. So devoted is Mr. Cohen's flock that his sold-out Carnegie Hall concert on Sunday night had an almost revivalist intensity, as worshipful acolytes deposited flowers on the stage and standing ovations brought the singer back five times for encores.

title: SOME I.B.M. COMPUTERS TO GET FREE SOFTWARE
description: In a surprise move that brought outcries in the personal computer industry today, the International Business Machines Corporation began to provide dealers with free software to accompany some I.B.M. Personal Computer models they sell.

title: Guilty Plea by Butcher
description: Jake Butcher, the Tennessee financier, pleaded guilty in the Federal District Court here today to a third series of bank fraud charges. Mr. Butcher had been accused here of defrauding former United American banks in Lexington and Somerset by siphoning off $4.2 million for business and personal expenses. In all, Federal prosecutors said, the two-time candidate for Governor of Tennessee took $40.8 million from banks that once were part of his $1.5 billion business.

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
VULCAN INDUSTRIAL PACKAGNG LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $118,000 in a joint venture for the latest quarter compared with a similar loss of $306,000 for year-earlier period.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: GENERALS GAINING SUPPORT ON DEFENSE
description: The Generals will be gaining some needed defensive help this week after a 30-20 loss Sunday to the Jacksonville Bulls, a team New Jersey could not stop in the fourth quarter.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes approximately $950,000, or 12 cents a share, from the settlement of two lawsuits.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 7, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DESERT ANT IN INDIA CNSTRUCTS WATER RESERVOIR
description: EVERY desert animal has to cope with a basic problem: the scarcity of water. A species of large black ant in southern India has evolved an ingenious method of harvesting dew.

title: CHANGE COMES TO UNDERSIDE OF THE CITY
description: In the mind's eye, Washington is a city of tourists and cherry blossoms, formal dinner parties on Embassy Row and the pristine elegance of official ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on the Company News page of Business Day on Thursday misstated the value of a transaction involving the Docutel/Olivetti Corporation. A subsidiary of Ing. C. Olivetti & Company will pay $20.2 million for the 54 percent of Docutel/Olivetti's stock that it does not already own.

title: Amtrak Crash Kills a Driver
description: An Amtrak passenger train hit a State Highway Department vehicle today, killing the driver, who apparently had not been looking, the authorities said. None of the 102 passengers or crew aboard the train was hurt in the accident that occurred shortly after 8 A.M., the authorities said. The train, going from Chicago to Seattle and Portland, Ore., was delayed for two hours.

title: ETHIPIAN FAULTS EVACUATION OF CAMP
description: The Ethiopian leader said today that he did not authorize or approve the forced evacuation of tens of thousands of famine victims from a relief camp last week, according to Kurt Jannson, the senior United Nations official here.

title: NICARAGUANS DECLARE WAR AGAINST GRAFT
description: For the last year, authorities here say, work at the Ministry of Health has been unusually rewarding for a handful of dishonest employees.

title: NEW SECURITIES FRAUD CASE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged the Parr Securities Corporation, a discount broker and bond dealer in New York City, with fraudulent securities dealings that are likely to cost its customers about $16 million in losses.

title: PRINCETON UPHELD IN HONOR-CODE CASE
description: A Federal judge upheld Princeton University today in the first court challenge to the school's 92-year-old honor code.

title: EXPOSAIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
White House Intruder Freed
description: A man who took an unauthorized stroll through the White House on Inauguration Day was released from jail today after spending the weekend behind bars. Robert Latta, 45 years old, who is charged with illegally entering the White House on Jan. 20, was arrested Thursday after he failed to show up for a court appearance in Washington. Federal Magistrate Donald Abram today released Mr. Latta on a personal recognizance bond and set a hearing for Tuesday on whether he should be returned to Washington to face charges there.

title: Moseley, Hallgarten Problem
description: The Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Holding Corporation, a Wall Street securities firm, said yesterday that it might have to take a charge against earnings of up to $8 million for the fiscal year ended March 31 because of a possible over-accrual of income in its government securities department.

title: TRADING LIGHT
description: Stock prices made puny gains yesterday in light, uneventful trading.

title: Spinks Bout Set
description: Michael Spinks, the undisputed light heavyweight champ, will defend his title here June 6 against Jim McDonald, it was announced today.

title: ROYALE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $334,000 from the sale of two aircraft and a $67,000 writeoff for the suspension of service to one market.

title: BUILDINGS FRANKLIN MIGHT HAVE FELT AT HOME IN SHINE IN EVERYDAY USE
description: On these luminous May mornings, when the sun filters through the abundant foliage that adorns what William Penn called his ''green country town,'' wide stretches of Old Philadelphia seem as fresh and newly minted as in the 18th century.

title: RUSCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $289,515 from the sale of real estate.c-After a gain of $690,838 from the sale of property and reversion from pension plan.

title: U.S. Thrift Unit Laws
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today sent Congress a package of legislative proposals meant to protect the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation from payouts that would exhaust it resources. The bank board is asking Congress for authority to limit the investment power of state-chartered, federally insured thrift units to the powers permitted federally chartered thrift units.

title: FOE OF BOREDOM: KEITH RUPERT MURDOCH
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher whose empire spans four continents and includes more than 80 newspapers and magazines and a 250,000-acre sheep farm, has often told reporters on the occasion of a new purchase:

title: Gamblers Win
description: Richard Johnson caught a United States Football League record four touchdown passes as the Houston Gamblers rolled to a 45-7 victory over the Portland Breakers tonight.

title: PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN MADRID AND CONFERS WITH PREMIER
description: President Reagan arrived here today amid tight security and the American and Spanish teams immediately went into talks on Nicaragua and the presence of American forces in Spain.

title: JUDICIAL APPOINTEE EAGER TO START JOB
description: Joseph H. Rodriguez, the New Jersey Public Advocate, was checking his desk calendar today, hoping to set an early date for the transition from state ombudsman to Federal judge.

title: BAIRD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Killed, 2 Seriously Hurt In Buenos Aires Blasts
description: At least two people were killed and two others seriously burned in a series of explosions that tore through a gunpowder and ammunition depot in a Buenos Aires port today, officials said. The cause of the blasts was not immediately known.

title: Chile Extends Siege
description: The military Government extended its six-month state of siege today for 90 more days, keeping opposition political activity banned throughout Chile.

title: UNITED TELEVISION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $287,000 from discontinued operations through equity in Warner Communications Inc.

title: 5% Raise Voted In Westchester
description: Westchester legislators today approved a 5 percent raise for themselves and other top county officials, including the County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, whose salary was increased to $91,120 a year from $86,780.

title: Looking for Renoir
description: Seamus Heaney, the Irish poet, was in Washington last week to give a lecture and to read some of his work at the Folger Shakespeare Library. One of the sights he hoped to see was one of his favorite paintings, Renoir's ''Luncheon of the Boating Party,'' which is one of the better-known masterpieces at the Phillips Collection.

title: UNIFORCE TEMPORARY PERONNEL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Peachtree Sold
description: Management Science America Inc. said it had sold Peachtree Software Inc., the last of its microcomputer software units, to the Intelligent Systems Corporation. M.S.A. said the purchase was for cash and notes, but it did not disclose the sale's terms. It also said it had retained certain Peachtree equipment as well as the rights to distribute certain Peachtree software. M.S.A. is a leading provider of software for large-scale mainframe computers manufactured by the International Business Machines Corporation, and its $5.5 million acquisition of Peachtree in 1981 was its most notable effort to penetrate the microcomputer software arena. Intelligent Systems, based in Norcross, Ga., makes add-on products for personal computers and color graphics display terminals.

title: NICARAGUA TELLS WORLD COURT THAT REAGAN'S STATEMENTS CONVICT THE U.S.
description: Nicaragua, pressing ahead with its suit against the United States in the International Court of Justice, submitted a brief last week arguing that President Reagan's own public statements show his policies violate international law.

title: STURDY DRIVE IS A LEGACY OF BERNOULLI
description: DANIEL BERNOULLI, an 18th century Swiss mathematician, discovered the principles of fluid dynamics and thus paved the way for such wonderful 20th century inventions as the airplane, the curve ball and the ''crashless'' computer disk drive.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $482,000, or 12 cents a share, on the early retirement of indebtedness.

title: JETS SEEM EAGER TO USE TOON'S SPEED
description: Al Toon used to hear the crowd boo him at the University of Wisconsin. At least, he thought they were. ''They were shouting, 'Toon. Toon,' '' he said. ''I finally figured out what they meant.''

title: DODGERS TOP CUBS IN 10TH, 5-4
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers got a timely two-run homer by Mike Scioscia in the ninth inning, then rallied for two runs in the 10th to beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-4, today.

title: Summit Failure Isn't Fatal
description: Thanks mostly to France's President Mitterrand, the Bonn summit conference can be certified a failure. Looking even more intently than his partners to his political flanks at home, he refused to schedule a new round of negotiations to reduce trade barriers. His posturing, at a time of mounting protectionism, is unhelpful but also overrated in significance.

title: SHOULD A NATIONAL LOTTERY BE STARTED?
description: The odds are that if Congress set up a national lottery, as several lawmakers propose, Americans' betting habits would change. And so would their television viewing habits.

title: Scattered Sites
description: Track and field involves more than running, jumping and throwing. It also involves getting there, wherever ''there'' is.

title: Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday offered $300 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Nov. 14, 1985, at a price of 100, through various securities dealers. The interest on the floating-rate notes will be adjusted weekly at two-tenths of one percentage point above the average bond equivalent yield set at the weekly auction of 91-day Treasury bills. Interest will be paid at maturity.

title: A Disagreement on Numbers of Missiles
description: To the Editor:

title: DIVERS FIND WRECK OF A GRAND STEAM-AGE FAILURE
description: THE wreck of a ship built in New York more than 130 years ago as an experimental alternative to steamships has been discovered amid the treacherous reefs off British Columbia.

title: Quotation of the Day;
description: ''I think that science is the stuff that pays for itself on these missions.

title: Poland Bans Air Courier For U.S. Embassy
description: Poland today suspended the United States Embassy's air courier service. The move follows an exchange of diplomat expulsions last week.

title: TREASURY PRICES UP SLIGHTLY
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday as securities dealers and institutional investors focused their attention on $20.5 billion of new Treasury notes and bonds to be sold in the next three days.

title: Stockman the Father
description: David A. Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, has so many supporters and detractors in Washington that it does not take much to revive old reports about him.

title: SCHOOL LIBRARIES CALLED ABYSMAL IN PANEL'S STUDY
description: Citing severe shortages of funds, personnel and reading materials, a civic group says that library services in the New York City school system are ''abysmal'' and that the Board of Education and municipal officials have neglected school library facilities.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SUPPLY SIDE The environmental grime and ethnic beauty of the Lower East Side have long provided inspiration for artists, as far back at least as the turn of the century, when the sculptor Jacob Epstein lived in the ghetto and eventually gained a British title. Now there is a three-pronged recognition of the particular art that flourished in a changing Lower East Side during the 1950's and 60's. It is in the form of exhibitions in three local institutions under the overall rubric, ''The Gathering of the Avant-Garde: The Lower East Side, 1948-1970.''

title: A LEADER IN CO-OP BUSINESS
description: Brewster Ives, a major figure for half a century in the development of luxury cooperative and condominium housing in Manhattan, died of a lung ailment Friday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DESIGNERS REDEFINE THE ART OF DRESSING IN SEPARATES
description: The cool classicism of Calvin Klein's clothes rides high over the more complicated eager-to-please-everybody fashion collections for next fall and winter. He focused calmly on jackets, skirts and trousers, with appropriate sweaters and blouses, all in luxurious materials. Just as focused, but a bit wider in scope, was the sleek, sophisticated look of Donna Karan. Body suits in silk or jersey, tights and scarf-wrapped skirts were components of the Karan collection, an unusual conception of the designer who spent most of her working life with Anne Klein. This is the first showing on her own and it includes accessories such as hats and gloves as well as clothes.

title: MIGRATIONSWild Flock
