description: ''Turkey'' has become a pejorative term, reflecting the domestic fowl's ungainly appearance and reputation for dimwittedness. Now the wild turkey is making a comeback, and rehabilitating the genus's image.

title: COST $2 BILLION
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born publisher, and Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, agreed yesterday to buy the nation's largest group of independent television stations from Metromedia Inc. for more than $2 billion.

title: LARGE CUTS SOUGHT IN MISSILE DEFENSE BUDGET
description: A loose coalition in Congress is seeking a sizable reduction in the Reagan Administration's $3.72 billion request for research on a system to defend against a nuclear missile attack.

description: Year-ago results include the effect of businesses sold and disposed of in the third and fourth quarters of 1984.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $937,500, or 13 cents a share. Share earnings reflect a 2.5-for-1 stock split paid April 17, 1985.

title: 'AMERICAN FILM INSTITUTE SALUTE TO GENE KELLY'
description: TONIGHT at 9:30 on CBS, ''The American Film Institute Salute to Gene Kelly'' comes as close as an award show can reasonably get to down-playing the official ceremony.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $382,000 for the latest first quarter and $21,000 for the year- ago first quarter. Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in May 1984.

title: FIBRONICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
6 PUBLISHERS OF JOURNALS SUE TEXACO OVER PHOTOCOPYING
description: Six publishers of scientific and technical journals filed a class-action suit yesterday against Texaco Inc., charging that the oil company had regularly photocopied from their journals without authorization. The lawsuit asks for the ''maximum statutory damages,'' which would be $50,000 for each infringement.

title: SCIENCE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $185,000 from discontinued operations.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $118,000 for the latest first quarter and $81,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Xerox Chief Adds Title of Chairman
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday named its chief executive officer, David T. Kearns, to the additional post of chairman of the copier and office systems company.

title: Man Convicted in Ohio Gets Death Sentence
description: A man convicted in the bludgeoning death last July of a woman was sentenced today to die in Ohio's electric chair.

title: Ham Radios and Leukemia
description: Statistics turned up by Dr. Samuel Milham Jr., an epidemiologist for Washington State, suggest that ham radio operators may be nearly twice as prone to leukemia as the rest of the population.

title: CITY BALLET: A NEW MEMBER OF CORPS STARS IN 'OPUS 19'
description: IT is not often that a new member of a dance company's corps de ballet stars in a part created for Mikhail Baryshnikov. But that is what happened on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater when Jeffrey Edwards, who joined the New York City Ballet this season, played the leading male role in Jerome Robbins's ''Opus 19/The Dreamer,'' which starred Mr. Baryshnikov at its premiere in 1979.

title: Brandt Regrets Reagan Didn't Meet With Him
description: West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party made available a letter today from its chairman, Willy Brandt, to President Reagan, expressing regret that the President did not meet the opposition leader during Mr. Reagan's visit to West Germany.

title: Reliance Stake
description: Reliance Group Holdings Inc., the closely held insurance and financial conglomerate owned by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York businessman, and his family, disclosed that it owned 5.1 million shares, or 5 percent, of Vickers Ltd., the British company that is the parent of Rolls-Royce. A spokesman for Mr. Steinberg said the purchase of the shares was for investment purposes.

title: CONFLICTING MESSAGES FROM ADMINISTRATION
description: PROMINENT educators are charging that the Reagan Administration is using the Department of Education to impose the President's ideology on the schools. Their concern was first triggered when William J. Bennett, the new Secretary of Education, defended proposals for drastic cuts in college student aid; their apprehensions grew when Mr. Bennett assigned advisory functions to people committed to right-wing doctrines.

title: DETROIT & NORTHERN SAVINGS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
More Exposure
description: John McEnroe's Bic razor television commercials - the ones in which he good-naturedly pokes fun at his own testy temperament - have been a mixed blessing, the tennis star says. Although the commercials have helped soften his image, they also have raised his recognition factor, and at this point in his career he doesn't want to be any better known than he already is.

title: COMMUNITY SHARES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. The company switched to stock ownership from a mutual savings and loan in February 1984.

description: Robert W. Allington goes to the White House today to be honored for a career that Horatio Alger might have used as a model.

title: Reagan's Ant Joke
description: Probably no American politician tells more clean jokes in public than Ronald Reagan. Usually, though, you have to be there to hear them, as they get lost in the press of pithier events each day.

title: Us Magazine Is Purchased
description: Rolling Stone magazine and the Telepictures Corporation said yesterday that they had purchased Us magazine from Mcfadden Holdings Inc. and the publishing division of Warner Communications Inc. Terms were not disclosed, although sources close to the situation said the purchase price was around $29 million.

title: Florida Panel Moves to Drop Investments in South Africa By The Associated Press
description: The Florida Senate's Governmental Operations Committee voted 5-to-2 yesterday in favor of a bill that would give the state government five years to move nearly $1.8 billion out of investments the state now has in foreign and domestic companies that do business in South Africa.

title: SLEUTH ON BIRDS AND PLANES
description: Like a Sherlock Holmes of the skies, a biology professor is using a microscope and fallen feathers to learn how birds and low-flying military aircraft collide - and which is at fault.

Struggle Intensifies At Gulf Resources
description: The proxy battle for control of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation between its chairman, Alan E. Clore, and a group of international investors intensified yesterday as the company denounced the insurgents and said it was ''currently negotiating with several prospects'' to sell some of its businesses. The proxy battle broke out last week.

description: Two men talking about clothes:

title: The Qaddafi Connection
description: Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam, asserts wholly innocent motives for accepting a $5 million, interest-free indefinite loan from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya. But however spent, this is a handout from the world's biggest bankroller of terrorists, who hardly wishes the United States well.

description: Columbia Data Products Inc. said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

description: A senior Pentagon official says a ''bureaucratic jungle'' gave rise to conditions that left Pershing 2 missiles in West Germany vulnerable to terrorist attack for more than a year.

title: USED-CAR STICKERS TO INFORM CONSUMERS OF DEALERS' TERMS
description: A new rule, requiring dealers to put window stickers on used cars telling whether it is being sold ''as is'' or if a warranty is offered, takes effect this week.

title: JERUSALEM BOOK FAIR HONORS CZECH
description: The 12th Jerusalem International Book Fair -highlighted by the award of the Jerusalem Prize for Literature to the Czechoslovak author Milan Kundera - opened today with more than 1,000 publishers from 40 countries participating.

title: Learning Lesson In Consistency
description: It is hard to believe that hitting three grand slams in one game could prove troublesome to a high school baseball player, but that is what happened to Marty Burke, a center fielder for Huffman High School in Birmingham, Ala.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Comings and Goings
description: Mike Tomczak, who starred at quarterback for Ohio State and was not selected in the National Football League draft last week, said he would sign a three-year contract with the Chicago Bears as a free agent. . . . North Carolina State refused to comment yesterday on reports that Mike Giomi, who was dismissed from Indiana's basketball team in January, would transfer to State. Mark Bockelman, a State spokesman, said Giomi had not officially transferred. He added that the school was not allowed to comment further until the 6-foot-9-inch forward had signed to attend. Giomi, who would be eligible to play in the 1986-87 season, was dismissed by Coach Bobby Knight at Indiana after admitting he had missed three classes in the second semester. . . .

title: NEW YORK PAYS HOMAGE TO VIETNAM VETERANS
description: In the troubled winter of 1969, a letter arrived in Glendale, Queens, from a 21-year-old soldier seeking small pleasures beside a sun-dappled river in Vietnam.

title: Sator Wary on Rangers
description: Ted Sator, assistant coach of the Philadelphia Flyers, said today he was flattered by recent comments touting him as the next Ranger head coach. But when asked if he had been approached for the job, he said no.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Bach, Debussy Offered In Bottazzi's Recital
description: The pianist Ana Maria Trenchi de Bottazzi was severely injured in an automobile accident in 1962, and was told that her career was over. It took more than a decade of exhausting work (which Miss Bottazzi describes in a book, ''To Live Again,'' published by Dodd, Mead & Company) but she persevered and made her second debut in 1974.

title: Vandalized Art May Be Restored
description: The state may be able to restore five of the eight modern paintings damaged near the Capitol Friday by a man with a knife, an official said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MAY 7, 1985

title: NEW AID PLAN ON NICARAGUA SEEN
description: House Democrats, uneasy over the visit to Moscow by the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, said today that interest was increasing in a compromise with the White House on aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Mark IV Merger
description: Mark IV Industries announced a definitive agreement to acquire the LFE Corporation of Clinton, Mass. Mark IV, which makes a variety of industrial products, said it had accumulated 29.4 percent of LFE's outstanding stock and was now offering $19 a share for the remaining shares.

title: Business and the Law;   Bank Aides And Insurers
description: NORMALLY, when an employee performs sloppy work, it is up to the supervisor to notice the problem, and try to correct it, or, in extreme cases, to dismiss the employee.

title: Topics;   MigrationsHuman Tide
description: Nigeria is expelling its foreign workers again, but this time the military Government, remembering the chaos and cruelty of the 1983 expulsions by its civilian predecessor, is taking a somewhat more humane course. Diplomats from neighboring countries have been consulted, and currency regulations governing the purchase of air tickets have been eased.

K.K.&P. will run a test campaign in print in Washington. The former agency was Marsteller, part of the Young & Rubicam empire.

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that he was ''soberly optimistic'' about the prospects for success in the Geneva arms talks with the United States.

title: Women Say Foreign Service Discriminates Against Them
description: The State Department practices a more subtle form of discrimination against women in the Foreign Service than it did nine years ago, when a group women who are Foreign Service officers filed a sex discrimination suit, a Federal district judge was told today.

description: Community leaders in Ozone Park, Queens, rallied at the 106th Precinct station house yesterday. They charged that wholesale transfers resulting from allegations of police brutality had hurt neighborhood police protection.

title: VALUE OF DRAFT PICKS SOARS IN LOTTERY
description: General managers have estimated that the sixth choice in last year's National Basketball Association draft could have been purchased by another team for $250,000. This year, Scotty Stirling, the league's vice president for operations, once a general manager himself, estimated that each of the first seven choices has become ''virtually priceless.''

title: Columbia to Study Effect of Divesting
description: The trustees of Columbia University voted unanimously yesterday to study the economic consequences of ending the university's investments in American companies that operate in South Africa, as urged in recent student protests.

title: REAL-ESTATE INVESTOR SAID TO FACE PERJURY COUNTS
description: The attorney for Sol Goldman, one of New York City's largest real-estate investors, said yesterday that his client had been indicted for perjury in connection with a grand jury investigation into the illegal nighttime demolition of four buildings in midtown Manhattan last January.

title: Tax Law Proposal Held Little Threat to Bonds
description: Proposals for revising the Federal tax system have created uncertainty for investors in tax-exempt bonds but should not deter continued purchases of bonds, according to a recent study of tax proposals.

This will mark a major step in the huge and proliferating market of stock options that allows investors and speculators alike to trade contracts at a fraction of the cost of the underlying securities.

Arco-Japan Pact
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company has signed an agreement with Japan to study the feasibility of shipping Alaska North Slope natural gas to the Orient, Gov. Bill Sheffield of Alaska said. The study is expected to take 18 months and is the second agreement Atlantic Richfield has reached on studying the shipment of North Slope gas to a Pacific Rim nation. In January, Arco signed such an agreement with eight South Korean companies.
