title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 7:30 P.M. Opener of a two-game series. The Mets can't avoid Dale Murphy, who is on a torrid hitting pace, but they won't have to face Rick Mahler, the Braves' pitcher who is a surprising 7-0. (Television - SportsChannel 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. Ed Whitson goes against Frank Viola, the former St. John's star who is 4-2. Last season Viola was 18-12, the best record by a left-hander in the majors. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770 8:30 P.M.) Basketball Lakers vs. Portland Trail Blazers, at Inglewood, Calif. Fifth game of the four-of-seven-game Western Conference semifinal. The Blazers finally handed the Lakers a loss on Sunday after Los Angeles had won six straight playoff games. But with the series back at the Forum, the Lakers are in good position: They have won 21 in a row at home. (Television - WTBS, 10:30 P.M.) Hockey Nordiques vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Quebec. Second game of the four-of-seven Stanley Cup semifinal series. Quebec, once known only for its free-wheeling offense, showed its defensive ability in beating the Flyers Sunday night in overtime, 2-1. The Nordiques also continued to show their poise at key moments: Sunday's victory made them 4-0 in overtime in the playoffs. The Flyers are hoping that Tim Kerr, the high-scoring right wing, can play. He missed most of the first game because of strained knee.

title: Burroughs Debut
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it had introduced five software packages and expanded the range of products available for sale through its dealer network. The company said the new software packages were for its B25 microcomputer. Three of the packages are made by Burroughs and two by third-party vendors.

title: $30.2 Million Settlement Proposed in 1981 Blast
description: Lawyers today announced a $30.2 million proposed settlement for victims of an explosion at the Aerosol Research Laboratories Inc. plant in 1981 that left five people dead and 18 injured.

title: Black Performers' Group
description: The Afro-American Association of Performing Artists, now being formed, plans to fill the vacuum left by the demise some years ago of the Negro Actors Guild. Black performing artists, including Theresa Merritt and Ben Vereen, held a meeting Monday at the headquarters of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to express support for the new organization. According to Billy Rowe, former theater editor of The Pittsburgh Gazette and an activist in the group, the organization would be both an ''umbrella group and a welfare-type organization,'' and would also contribute to the preservation of black theatrical history.

title: CALPROP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Kirby Higbe Is Dead at 70; Former Pitcher for Dodgers
description: Kirby Higbe, who pitched for five major league teams during a 12-year career and helped the Brooklyn Dodgers win the National League pennant in 1941, died Monday. He was 70 years old.

title: IN STRASBOURG, REAGAN HAS THE FORUM HE SOUGHT
description: Shortly after President Reagan addresses the European Parliament here on Wednesday, workmen will start ripping apart the semicircular parliament chamber as fast as they can.

title: STARS OF 'AREN'T WE ALL' MAKE IT LOOK SO EASY
description: Determined to lure Lord Grenham into wedlock, the good-humored Lady Frinton is not in the least dismayed when she spies the old rogue taking off one afternoon for an assignation with an extremely overdressed and very young woman. Even when they get married, Lady Frinton intends to send her elderly reprobate to Paris, alone, as often as he likes - and to do whatever he likes.

title: Concorde Diverted to Boston
description: A British Airways Concorde supersonic jet bound from London to New York City with 57 passengers and a crew of 11 made an emergency landing here tonight after one of its four engines developed problems over the Atlantic Ocean, according to the Massachusetts Port Authority.

title: G.O.P. OPENS DRIVE FOR 100,000 VOTERS
description: Republican leaders stepped up their political conversion campaign today, announcing plans to try to persuade 100,000 registered Democrats to switch to the Republican Party in the next 100 days while continuing efforts to pick off disenchanted Democratic officeholders.

title: THEATER: STEPPENWOLF PRESENTS 'ORPHANS'
description: IN recent seasons, Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company has introduced New Yorkers to a sizzling, idiosyncratic performance style as brawny, all-American and blunt as the windy city that spawned it. Steppenwolf's specialty is not the development of new plays, but the galvanic staging of existing ones - as exemplified by its productions of ''True West'' and ''Balm in Gilead.'' To that impressive pair can now be added ''Orphans,'' the company's newest offering. It is riveting to watch this evening's three stunning actors - Kevin Anderson, Terry Kinney and John Mahoney - rip themselves apart with a raw ferocity that is Steppenwolf's theatrical answer to the esthetics of rock and roll.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 8, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHORAL MUSIC: ORATORIO SOCIETY
description: ACTUAL participation in performance is losing ground as a form of music appreciation, but it is still the best one, and the Oratorio Society of New York has long provided one of the major forums for it. Monday at Carnegie Hall the society closed its current season with performances of two big works, the ''Dona nobis pacem'' of Ralph Vaughan Williams and Carl Orff's ''Carmina Burana.''

title: BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. VIEW OF EMBARGO
description: The Reagan Administration trade embargo imposed against Nicaragua today will have ''no perceptible adverse impact'' on the United States economy but will punish Nicaragua for ''aggressive and threatening behavior,'' Administration officials said today.

title: FALL SCHEDULES REFLECT NEW TRENDS
description: With the three television networks looking ahead to the fall season, several trends are apparent in the quest for the biggest nighttime audience.

title: AGAINST BITBURG VISIT, GIRL SAYS
description: A 13-year-old Jewish girl cited by President Reagan as supporting his decision to lay a wreath at the Bitburg cemetery honoring ''the future of Germany'' said today that she actually opposed his visit to the military gravesite.

title: FILING-PERIOD EXTENSION EXPECTED IN TOXIC SUITS
description: Key state lawmakers said today that they expected to pass legislation this session that would give people exposed to toxic substances more time to file lawsuits seeking damages.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Senate Panel Urges Approval Of Walters as U.N. Delegate
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 10 to 0 today to recommend confirmation of Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters as the new United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: PRESIDENT ACCEPTS TALKS ON PULLOUT OF TROOPS IN SPAIN
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez agreed today to start discussions leading to the eventual withdrawal of the 12,000 American troops stationed in Spain, according to American and Spanish officials.

title: Navy Relieves Administrator Of 7 Regional Medical Clinics
description: The commander of six Navy medical clinics in southeastern Virginia and one in the Bermudas has been relieved of duty, the Navy said today.

title: HEDBERG IS TRAINING FOR A NEW POSITION
description: While the Rangers continue to search for a head coach, it appears likely that Anders Hedberg will be named assistant general manager or assistant coach. Hedberg, who retired at the end of the season, has been getting a taste of an executive's job in recent weeks by sitting in with Craig Patrick, the team's general manager, during interviews for the head coaching spot. Hedberg, who has said he is not prepared to be a head coach, is with Patrick this week at a convention of college hockey coaches in Marco Island, Fla. ''I have an interest in Anders, but I'm not sure yet what that interest is,'' Patrick said by phone from Florida. ''I'm not planning any announcement right now. I've been interviewing college coaches down here with the realization that we have some positions open, and Anders is with me in all the interviews. And because we didn't have a great year, I'm inquiring about free agents from the colleges. Anders is down here offering a player's insights.''

title: Man Held in Arson At Animal Shelter
description: The man who turned in the alarm for a fire that left 50 animals dead at a Westchester County shelter Monday was arrested this afternoon and charged with setting the blaze.

title: Terrorist Gets 20 Years In Miami Weapon Case
description: Eduardo Arocena, a convicted terrorist, made a speech on the evils of communism and the Cuban leader Fidel Castro on Monday, then heard a judge add 20 years to his already long prison term.

title: Drinking Curbs
description: In response to requests from fans not interested in sitting near beer drinkers, the Chicago Cubs and the Philadelphia Eagles are planning to set up areas of their ball parks as family sections, without alcoholic beverages. According to Dallas Green, the Cubs' president and general manager, Wrigley Field will add 225 seats along the outfield walls and the sale of alcohol will be forbidden in one of the two new sections. Norman Braman, the new Eagle owner, says that three new family sections, totaling 1,367 seats in the upper level of Veterans Stadium, will be off limits for alcohol during football games.

title: REAGAN AIDE DENIES LINK TO SNUB OF BRANDT
description: Richard R. Burt, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, today denied press reports here that he had advised President Reagan against meeting Willy Brandt, the leader of West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party.

title: DEMOCRATIC RIVALS LOBBY FOR ALTERNATIVE BUDGETS
description: Two Democratic Senators who are regarded as political rivals began canvassing their colleagues today for support for competing budget resolutions they expect to bring to the Senate floor Wednesday.

title: Bad Situation Gets Worse in Housing Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Junk Bonds Are Just the Symptom
description: Do all those ''junk bonds'' - corporate debts backed by less than blue-chip credit - threaten the stability of the economy? Some respected analysts think so. And heeding their warnings, Senator Pete Domenici has introduced a bill that would sharply limit such borrowing in the restructuring of corporate finances.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE DANCE: 2 BY A.B.T.
description: SOME dances seem designed to get the stars out onto the stage and the audience cheering.

title: NEW YORKERS ROAR THANKS TO VETERANS
description: Vietnam veterans accepted New York City's thanks yesterday at a bittersweet ticker-tape parade through the canyons of lower Manhattan.

title: A Change of Mind
description: Like many Americans, Archbishop John J. O'Connor has revised his opinions about the Vietnam War.

title: JEWELRY VALET, BRUSH AND AN ORIENTAL ROBE
description: 1. For Holding Jewelry Brookstone's jewelry valet is compact, yet big enough to hold a large collection of valuables. It has three zippered compartments with plastic, see-through windows, plus a removable, snap-on pouch.

title: 6th Man Describes Stun-Gun Assault
description: A sixth person charged yesterday that police officers in the 106th Precinct in Queens had assaulted him with an electronic stun gun to make him confess to drug charges.

title: AMERICAN EDUCATIONAL COMUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE TICKER-TAPE PARADE THEY FINALLY GOT
description: The scene on lower Broadway seemed straight out of black and white newsreels of the V-E Day celebrations held 40 years ago today. A young woman very much live and in color darted yesterday out of the cheering throngs to plant a big, smacking kiss on a soldier, a stranger, Specialist 4 Dennis Johnson, during a ticker-tape parade. ''This was worth the wait,'' concluded the smiling Specialist Johnson.

title: THERE WAS JOY IN ST. PETERSBURG WHEN PILCH CAME TO BAT
description: At the beginning of the week they were a tentative bunch, 65 salesmen, jewelers, doctors, businessmen, orthopedists, lawyers, accountants, restaurateurs, construction and computer executives, dentists, dermatologists and writers. Two were women who called themselves housewives, most were at or nearing middle age and all were wondering whether their decision to come south to play baseball had been wise. By week's end they knew. Their uniforms, replicas of those worn by the Yankees, Giants, Dodgers and Cubs, were smudged with dirt, but they didn't care. The peaks of their caps had been curled to the right arch. The bridges of their noses were sunburned. They chewed bubble gum or tobacco incessantly. They spit a lot. They threw knuckleballs. Their talk was of how many hits they had made, how many catches, who had robbed whom with a great stab, and how if that ground ball hadn't taken a bad hop they would have got the guy at first. When they ran on and off the baseball diamond they gave each other open-palm, high-five congratulatory slaps.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Finale of the two-game series. The Mets go with Ed Lynch, whom they hope will be a dependable starter in light of their recent pitching problems.

title: BROCK MAKES BID FOR TIES TO LABOR
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock used his first appearance before the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council today to try to mend the strained ties between the Reagan Administration and organized labor.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WOMEN are now lifting weights, as the new movie, ''Pumping Iron II,'' graphically depicts, and in gyms, health clubs, basements and bedrooms nationwide, strength training and weight lifting are capturing the bodies and minds of thousands of adults the way jogging did a decade ago.

title: CITY FORMS A PANEL TO STUDY RENT CONTROL FOR BUSINESSES
description: Mayor Koch, joined by some City Council members, yesterday announced the formation of a commission to study the impact of rising commercial rents on small businesses in New York City.

title: Where's Bernie?
description: Bernie Kosar Sr. yesterday denied reports that his son would make an appearance at the Cleveland Browns' minicamp this week, but that's about all he would say.

title: The Slight Difference if Older Workers Stay On
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. PAUL SHERLOCK
description: Dr. Paul Sherlock, an internationally known gastroenterologist and a leader in research on cancer of the gastrointestinal system, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PHILIP SCHARPER, A PUBLISHER, DIES
description: Philip J. Scharper, a leading figure in theological publishing for three decades, died Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y., after a stroke. He was 65 years old and lived in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: SANCTUARY GROUPS SUE TO HALT TRIALS
description: A suit was filed today in Federal District Court here seeking to bar Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d from instituting new prosecutions of people who offer sanctuary to Central Americans seeking asylum.

title: ALGOREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: COURT BLOCKS JOB DENIALS FOR OBESITY
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that a person cannot be denied a job simply because of obesity.

title: MCENROE IS WINNER, 6-4, 6-0
description: The toughest crowd for John McEnroe was not the one he faced in the stadium at Forest Hills last night during his opening match against Vince Van Patten in the Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions. The match was marked by the familiar interruptions in which McEnroe discussed etiquette with some fans who had apparently come hoping to see a side show to the tennis.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 8, 1985

title: CENTRONICS DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest quarter reflect a one-time benefit of a contract adjustment payment of approximately $400,000 received from a customer.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I WAS recently reminded of how few people appreciate the culinary delights of squid when I was buying some from a local seafood store and a shopper standing nearby asked, ''Do you really eat those things?''

title: Accord Reached In Westchester
description: A tentative agreement on a labor contract between Westchester County and 6,000 members of the Civil Service Employees Association was reached at 5 A.M. today after an all-night bargaining session.

title: JUDGE DENIES MISTRAIL SOUGHT BY VON BULOW TEAM
description: Judge Corrine P. Grande refused today to declare a mistrial of the case against Claus von Bulow, a move sought by his lawyers on the ground that the jury had been prejudiced by statements that that Mrs. von Bulow was involved in a struggle the night of Dec. 20, 1980.

title: BOOKS SOLD IN MILLIONS
description: Carter Brown, who wrote some 30 detective novels with American backgrounds before ever having visited the United States, died of a heart attack Sunday morning at his home in Sydney, Australia. He was 61 years old.

title: Another Resignation
description: For the third time in a week Creighton University has lost a major athletic figure. Last Wednesday, Willis Reed resigned as basketball coach, and three days later the school's star center, Benoit Benjamin, said he would forgo his senior season and make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft. Yesterday, Creighton lost its director of athletics, Dan Offenburger, who announced his resignation at an emotional news conference in Omaha.

title: THE CALL OF THE PEST
description: For some people the call of spring is heard in the blood when the shad start to run and the first asparagus with texture more tender than toothbrush bristles appear in the high-rent groceries and the first soft-shell crabs are announced on the menus of expense-account restaurants. But not for me.

title: STAGE: 'ARMAGEDDON'
description: RON LITMAN claws his way out of a large green garbage bag that is sitting on top of a mountain of trash. Filthy, encrusted with all the grime of a life lived on the New York streets, he edges towards the audience, which offers a collective wince. He spots a theatergoer wearing eyeglasses and, quick as a wino, he squirts the spectacles with window cleaner. Mr. Litman is on the attack and he never relents until he has savaged every target in his ''jaundiced-eye view of the world.''

title: ATHLETE TESTIFIES 2 MOUNTAIN MEN SAID THEY SEIZED HER AS COMPANY
description: A biathlon star testified today that two mountain men kidnapped her last summer and told her they wanted female companionship in the wilds.

title: ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago results include revenues of $4,040,000 and net income of $87,000 from a business software unit that was sold Sept. 30, 1983. Corrected from Friday's editions.

title: Dreams of Seoul
description: Ross Donoghue, who after transferring from St. John's became a sub-four-minute miler in 1981-82 at Villanova, is back these days in the land of the Redmen, where he's taking graduate courses in finance at the Business School. And yes, he's still running, though with not quite the same intensity as in his undergraduate days.

title: NEW MIXER ATTACHMENT
description: ONE of the most durable and versatile pieces of kitchen equipment around is the good old KitchenAid mixer. Any serious cook eventually buys one for preparing everything from baked goods to terrines to sauces. The manu-facturer, the Hobart Corporation, recently added a valuable new attachment to its already impressive roster of accessories for the machine.

title: BOYHOOD DREAM BECOMES REALITY
description: IT was like growing up next door to the circus, he says now, and knowing that you wanted to be an acrobat or a clown. Jean-Louis Gerin was born in Talloires, a town on the shore of Lake Annecy that is the site of the Auberge du Pere Bise, considered for decades to be one of the finest restaurants in France. Today, at 27 years of age, Mr. Gerin is a head chef himself as well as part owner of the small, 36-seat Restaurant Guy Savoy in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Neo-Nazi Pleads Guilty In 2 Coast Robberies
description: A member of a neo-Nazi group, the Order, pleaded guilty Monday to a Federal racketeering charge in connection with two robberies of armored cars that netted almost $4 million to finance the group.

title: Already Acquainted
description: Trying to play gracious host on the reviewing stand yesterday outside City Hall, Mayor Koch called out when he spotted Gen. William C. Westmoreland: ''General, General! Let me introduce you to the best reporter in America.''

title: Is Science Teaching Turning Students Off?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Inmates Flee In Westchester
description: Three prisoners escaped from the Westchester County Jail here Tuesday evening, a spokesman for the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said.

title: Papandreou Gains in Bid To Broaden His Powers
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou won legislative approval today for constitutional revisions that shift the President's powers to himself and Parliament. Elections were set for June 2.

title: Personal Wholeness
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Expelled Ethiopians Free to Return to Camp
description: The top United Nations official in Ethiopia said today that the famine victims expelled from the relief camp at Ibnat were now free to return.

title: American Symphony Sets '85-'86 Concerts
description: The American Symphony Orchestra has announced programs and dates for its 1985-86 Sunday concerts at Carnegie Hall, the first season under its new musical director, John Mauceri.

title: Democrats Still Trail G.O.P. In Fund Raising, Despite Gain
description: The Democratic Party more than doubled its fund raising for the 1984 election but remained far behind the Republicans, according to figures released Monday by the Federal Election Commission.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Strategic Planning
description: Holding Water The country's meteorologists agree that weather in the Northeast is getting drier. Official New York should be worrying full time about the consequences.

title: Court Lets Stores End Warnings to Suspects
description: Store detectives are not required to give Miranda warnings to shoplifting suspects when the police are absent during initial questioning, the state's highest court ruled today.

title: BIOSEARCH MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest quarter are after a loss of approximately $275,000 for the company's Entri-Pak with Entrition product.

title: ITALY WILL IGNORE THE U.S. EMBARGO
description: Italy's Prime Minister said today that his country would not join Washington's economic embargo against Nicaragua and that Rome intended to go ahead with a planned $25 million project in that Central American country. The embargo went into effect today.

title: AGENDA AND DISPUTE
description: A major conference on human rights opened here today with delegates from 35 countries still unable to agree on a final agenda for the six-week session.

title: HOW TO HANDLE THE JAPANESE
description: Many of our business frustrations with the Japanese stem from our different perceptions of ''good'' and ''bad.'' Each side has its own code of ethics - and considers itself decent, honest and righteous.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Contaminant Levels The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia recently ruled that the Federal Food and Drug Administration must set tolerance levels for what are called ''environmental food contaminants'' that cannot be avoided entirely.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GATES OF WAR New York Harbor was the greatest Allied port of World War II, the harbor that more than any other sent the cargoes of war to the combat fields in all corners of the globe. The Merchant Marine and Navy men on our ships were in a combat zone menaced by submarines almost as soon as they had said goodbye to the New York skyline and dropped off the Sandy Hook pilot.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURNCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRESS CLUBS: TO MERGE OR NOT TO MERGE?
description: After months of negotiations, the Washington press corps is trying to decide: would a July wedding be nice, or should the whole thing be called off?

title: BOARD CANCELS MEETING IN BALLET SCHOOL DISPUTE
description: A meeting of the board of directors of the School of American Ballet, scheduled for yesterday, was canceled amid a controversy over the future administration of the school. Founded in 1934 by Lincoln Kirstein and George Balanchine and affiliated with the New York City Ballet, the school is one of the country's major institutions for training in professional ballet.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There was a time when it was difficult to accept the lack of recognition.

title: U.S. BID ON PALESTINE TALKS REPORTED
description: The United States has offered to hold talks with a Jordanian-Palestinian group provided that it does not include any members of the Palestine Liberation Organization, State Department officials said today.

title: TALKING LOUDLY AND CARRYING A BIG STICK
description: In the middle of an especially long-winded Congressional hearing on April 24, Joseph H. Sherick, the Pentagon's inspector general, let slip a remark whose aftereffects will take months to clear away.

title: COAST TRIAL CASTS LIGHT ON INTELLIGENCE TACTICS
description: Svetlana Ogorodnikov, a Russian woman portrayed by the United States as a Soviet spy and by her courtroom defenders as a troubled naive person, once gave a Federal agent a Russian doll.

title: PANEL APPROVES PAROLE OF KILLER OF MALCOLM X
description: State parole officials said yesterday that they had approved the parole application of one of the three men convicted of murdering Malcolm X, the black leader, in 1965. The application had been denied twice before, most recently last month.

title: CLASSIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Battles Of Bob Lee
description: Bob Lee, the embattled acting chairman of the New Jersey State Athletic Commission, has been telling friends that he will be leaving the post once the panel is reorganized into a commission with three equal members. At the same time, he is apparently lining up another paying job in boxing administration, but he seems to be engaged in a struggle on that front too.

title: CALIFORNIA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Senate Rejects Labels On Aspartame Volume
description: The Senate today defeated a proposal that would have required bottlers of soft drinks to tell consumers how much of the artificial sweetener aspartame is contained in their product.

title: ABC Rebuffs U.S.F.L
description: Jim Spence, the senior vice president of ABC Sports, said yesterday that although the United States Football League was going to a fall schedule in 1986, ''we're not going with them.'' Asked how he thought the league would do in the fall, especially without a major network contract, he said, ''They'll probably fail.''

title: KOCH BID TO BAR HOMOSEXUAL BIAS UPHELD IN COURT
description: A state appellate court panel yesterday upheld Mayor Koch's authority to bar discrimination against homosexuals by private agencies - including church-run agencies - that do business with New York City.

title: Day of Heavy Shelling In Beirut Fighting
description: Christian and Moslem militiamen shelled each other today with tank cannon, mortars, artillery and rockets in the heaviest barrages in the Lebanese capital in the last 10 months.

title: FRENCH CUISINE IS BECOMING A BIT LESS FRENCH
description: French cooking, which has become renowned worldwide, may not be so French after all. A Government report has found that the country's cooking is prepared mostly by foreign chefs.

title: THE SLIGHT DIFFERENCE IF OLDER WORKERS STAY ON
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Asserts Blacks Failed to Back Jews
description: Mayor Koch complained yesterday that few blacks attended last Sunday's solidarity rally in support of Soviet Jewry. The Mayor said that he could see no blacks in the crowd of about 200,000 and only three blacks on the dais.

title: METS WIN ON CARTER'S SLAM
description: Gary Carter has won these confrontrations before. He has lost them, too.

title: The Next Nuclear Meltdown
description: >What are the chances of a meltdown at one of America's 100-odd nuclear reactors in the next 20 years? Nearly 50-50, or 45 percent, is the surprising figure the Nuclear Regulatory Commission recently gave Congress. How can the commission also declare that it finds the risk acceptable? Are the odds of catastrophe really so bad?

title: TOTAL AID BAN TO NICARAGUA REBELS IS SOUGHT
description: Democratic leaders said today that they were placing top priority on efforts to enact a permanent ban on all military and paramilitary assistance to the insurgents battling the Government of Nicaragua.

title: 'GROTESQUES' AND SIX OTHERS
description: THE FILM FORUM must have looked under many a rock in compiling its new program, and that's a compliment. It can't have been easy to round up short films that share such an exuberantly bizarre sense of humor. Aside from sheer eccentricity, the seven films billed as ''Elvis Gratton and Other Grotesques'' don't have anything in common. All they share is exuberant playfulness, and that's enough.

title: Likely Salmonella Source Reported in Illinois
description: A valve that violated Federal rules by potentially allowing tainted raw milk to mix with pasteurized milk is the ''most likely'' source of the nation's largest outbreak of salmonella, health officials said today.

title: Reagan Says No Thanks
description: President Reagan has passed up an unusual opportunity to pay tribute jointly to the press and one of his favorite heroes, Calvin Coolidge. On May 21 the original 1926 cornerstone of the National Press Building will be relaid in ceremonies celebrating the end of a complete renovation of the building, including the National Press Club in its top two stories.

title: Don Nelson Honored
description: Although they were eliminated from the playoffs by Philadelphia in four games, the Milwaukee Bucks' regular-season record of 59-23 was third best in the National Basketball Association. That, apparently, was enough to earn Don Nelson coach-of-the-year honors. Nelson received 43 1/2 votes from a panel of 78 members of the media who regularly cover the league.

title: AMERICAN EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR MAN ON TOKYO DEATH ROW, TIME IS HANGMAN
description: As today ended, Sadamichi Hirasawa was still in prison waiting to die.

title: COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $38,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $95,000.

title: Honoring Mom and Pop
description: Manhattan has blue-chip corporations. Brooklyn has Monchito's Wedding Center, Gaby's Children's Shop, Natalie's Apparel, Lloyd's Trimmings and Notions, Gregory's French Cleaners and the Raccuglia Funeral Home.

title: IN MANSION'S NEW KITCHEN, MAYOR FLIPS OMELET WITH ELAN
description: THE Mayor's chef, Mitchel London, is thrilled with the new professionally equipped kitchen at Gracie Mansion. Its bright lights and tile floors, wood cabinets and top-quality stainless-steel equipment - two stoves, three refrigerators, a 20-gallon electric stockpot, high-powered dishwasher and heavy-duty ventilation - make it a chef's delight. The kitchen even has separate facilities for kosher food including a microwave oven to heat meals prepared by a kosher caterer, plus two sinks and a special set of dishes.

title: KOCH NAMES PANEL TO RECOMMEND NEW PROCEDURES AT POLICE DEPT.
description: Mayor Koch, faced with a Police Department in turmoil over allegations of police misconduct, yesterday appointed a special advisory committee to conduct an exhaustive examination into every aspect of the department's management.

title: EASTERN LEGISLATORS GAIN BACKING FOR CITY GRANTS
description: Members of Congress trying to save a Federal grant program heavily used by cities in New York, New Jersey and elsewhere in the Northeast said today that they had won support from legislators in the South and Middle West.

title: ALLIED NURSING CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PANEL TRIMS SPACE ARMS PLAN
description: The House Armed Services Committee voted today to cut $1.2 billion from President Reagan's proposal for a space-based defense against missiles, , rejecting proposals to cut more deeply into the program, according to members of the panel.

title: PENN STATION ATTACK CRITICALLY WOUNDS WOMAN FROM OHIO
description: A 31-year-old woman, a visitor from Columbus, Ohio, was repeatedly stabbed in an apparently unprovoked attack by a homeless woman in Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon, the police reported. The victim, Carol Buckhout, was in critical but stable condition early this morning at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: U.S. PUBLISHERS ARE WARNED OF A THREAT FROM EXTREMISTS
description: The publisher of an Argentine newspaper warned strongly here today that some of this nation's news organizations were in danger of becoming like those in Latin America that were controlled by ideological or economic interest groups.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE EUDAEMONIC PIE. By Thomas A. Bass. 324 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95. ROULETTE is one of the few casino games whose outcome - the arrival of a little ball in a numerically designated compartment - depends upon a concatenation of events rather than on a single predetermining one like the shuffling of a pile of cards or the pulling of a lever. This means you have time to figure out and predict the results of roulette. All you have to do is wait for the ball to leave the croupier's hand, then calculate the various Newtonian laws that go into operation (like the coefficients of friction and drag) and place your bets. It's no harder than applying a set of mathematical equations similar to those used by NASA for landing spaceships on the moon. You have 10 to 20 seconds. Simple, right?

title: Golf Grows in China
description: To the Editor:

title: HARVARD WEIGHS GIVING A DEGREE TO THE PRESIDENT
description: Harvard University's 350th birthday party is still 16 months away, but already the event is sending out reverberations that reach to the White House.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WILLIS JACKSON, the robust tenor saxophonist who is playing at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village this week, recalls several epiphanies in a career that stretches back almost 40 years. One is touring with a package show that included the great jazz saxophonist Charlie Parker and his string ensemble. ''That was the biggest thrill I could have had,'' Mr. Jackson said the other day. ''To me, Charlie Parker was the greatest saxophone player that ever lived.'' Another epiphany was playing the classic tenor saxophone solo on ''Money Honey,'' the mid-50's, rhythm-and-blues hit by Clyde McPhapper and the Drifters.

title: OLD GERMANS AND YOUNG: SPLIT IN DEEP
description: For a majority of Germans, the solemn event that will be marked here on Wednesday - the 40th anniversary of Nazi Germany's surrender - is a reminder of the end of their parents' or grandparents' war, a war that is, at most, only a childhood memory.

title: NUGGETS, LAKERS ADVANCE IN WEST
description: The Denver Nuggets held on for a 116-104 victory over the Utah Jazz tonight to win their National Basketball Association series by four games to one. The Nuggets will face the Los Angeles Lakers, who eliminated Portland tonight, in the Western Conference final.

title: UEBERROTH ORDERS WIDE TESTS FOR DRUG USE IN PRO BASEBALL
description: Saying that he wants organized baseball to be a leader in eradicating drugs from society, the commissioner of baseball yesterday ordered all major league personnel except the unionized players to submit to drug tests and urged the players to join the program as well.

title: Dr. Thomas P. Peardon, 85, Barnard Professor Emeritus
description: Thomas P. Peardon, professor emeritus of political science at Barnard College, died Saturday at New Milford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT was warm enough, Pearl Potter of Manhattan decided the other afternoon, for her summer cut. So, there she was at an Upper East Side beauty salon, her brunette tresses being swiftly snipped away, when a woman's head appeared over the partition. A moment later, the woman herself was in Mrs. Potter's cubicle shouting, ''Let me have it, let me have it!''

title: HOW THE HANDLE THE JAPANESE
description: Despite the hullabaloo, not much has happened in recent months to prevent America's trade deficit with Japan from soaring further.

title: West Meets East
description: Granted, all kinds of problems will crop up when you try to create a balanced schedule for two divisions, each of which has an uneven number of teams. But has anyone noticed that, as mid-May approaches, the Kansas City Royals, the Chicago White Sox and the Texas Rangers have yet to play a single intradivision game? For Texas and Chicago, that string won't be broken until May 17, when the Rangers visit Comiskey Park. For the Royals, it extends until May 20, when they open a three-game series at Texas.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Steve Crawford, right-handed pitcher, on 15-day disabled list to make room for Bruce Kison on roster.

title: SCREEN: 'ALMOST YOU'
description: ''ALMOST You,'' the first film to be directed by Adam Brooks, is a romantic comedy that takes the problems of some young, often bored Manhattan achievers almost as seriously as they take themselves, which is far too seriously. Unlike the movies of John Sayles (''Baby, It's You,'' ''Lianna''), who has become the guru for a whole new generation of film makers, ''Almost You'' is not only small scale but short-visioned.

title: STATE TO WIDEN THE ROLE OF JUDGE IN PICKING JURY
description: Legislative leaders have agreed on a measure to permit judges to take over the main role in questioning prospective jurors in New York courts.

title: Bridge: Event Will Help Americans Go to World Championships
description: The cost of sending American representatives to the annual world championships has increased considerably in the past two decades. The financial burden for the American Contract Bridge League is largely covered by the International Fund Game, an annual duplicate event played in clubs throughout North America.

title: Pimlico Loses Star
description: Spend a Buck will forgo a run at racing's Triple Crown by skipping the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on May 18 and instead shoot for a $2.6 million payday in the Jersey Derby at Garden State Park here May 27, Memorial Day, his owner announced today.

title: Auto-Mirror Bashing
description: To the Editor:

title: CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: A DINER WHERE THE 50'S NEVER ENDED
description: A six-foot-tall Coca-Cola bottle painted on the green-and-ivory tiled exterior wall of a building with signs in a window promoting ''Fountain Creations,'' ''Fresh Cut Fries'' and ''Blue-Plate Specials'' should be fair warning. Still, crossing the threshold into Ed Debevic's restaurant, you almost expect to hear Rod Serling ushering people into ''The ''Twilight Zone.'' This is a perfectly preserved slice of life from 1952 or 1953 or 1958. It is definitely not 1985.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE REPORTED IN GOOD SHAPE AFTER TRIP
description: The space shuttle Challenger was reported in good shape at its California landing site today, and the two monkeys that flew on it were healthy and apparently happy to be back here after a week in space.

title: HEALTH AND NUTRITION: THE CONCERNS ABROAD
description: GOVERNMENT studies making the connection between what we eat and how healthy we are have proliferated in recent years. In the face of statistics showing that coronary diseases account for half of all deaths in the United States, many Americans have adjusted their eating habits.

title: A Foggy Bottom Vacancy
description: The promotion of Elliott Abrams to succeed Langhorne A. Motley as head of the State Department's Latin American Bureau has left a vacancy in the key post of Assistant Secretary for Human Rights, which Mr. Abrams has occupied since 1981. Secretary of State George P. Shultz's early attempt to fill the job has already met with refusal; Jose S. Sorzano, who was senior deputy to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick when she was chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has declined the human rights assignment.

title: BOOLE & BABBAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CBS'S FALL SCHEDULE FEATURES 6 NEW SERIES
description: CBS, which has been No. 1 in the audience ratings for the last six years, will bring back the veteran television comedians George Burns and Flip Wilson, as well as a remake of an old television favorite, ''The Twilight Zone,'' for its new prime-time schedule to be introduced next fall.

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $1,098,000. c-Includes investment gains of $758,000.

title: 'NORMANDY TO BERLIN,' BATTLE FOOTAGE
description: ''NORMANDY to Berlin: A War Remembered'' does not live up to expectations. This is particularly disappointing in that the documentary has such a great deal going for it. It offers virtually the only color film surviving from the war in Europe. The filming was directed by George Stevens, a man of intelligence and sensitivity. And the subject remains one of the most hazardous and exciting operations of the century.

title: War - Plain and Simple
description: Americans, through their government and other institutions, sometimes seem to be of more than one mind about past wars and reconciliations. But the Russians, conveniently, recognize no ambiguity when it comes to history.

title: HEART RECIPIENT LISTED AS STABLE AFTER STROKE
description: The condition of William J. Schroeder, the longest-surviving recipient of an artificial heart, ''stabilized overnight'' and the bleeding in his brain apparently stopped after he suffered a stroke Monday, hospital officials said yesterday. It was Mr. Schroeder's second stroke since the mechanical heart was implanted 164 days ago.

title: GUILTY PLEAS ENTERED IN DEMOLITION AT TIMES SQ.
description: A major Manhattan real-estate company and one of its vice presidents pleaded guilty yesterday to charges resulting from the illegal nighttime demolition of four Times Square buildings in January.

title: UPSTATE TALENT EMERGING IN LACROSSE
description: In the past, twin spotlights in college lacrosse were aimed at the Long Island and Baltimore-Washington areas. Now a third area has been added - central New York State.

title: Upstate New Yorker Charged With Sexual Assault on Child
description: An Iowa woman was charged today with endangering her 10-year old daughter by permitting her to accompany a New York medical center official here, where he was accused of sexually assaulting her.

title: Nurses on the Set
description: To stimulate more political activity among its 200,000 members, the American Nurses Association is preparing a 20-minute film featuring appeals by a number of active political practitioners. A crew will be on location in the Capitol today, recording the faces and exhortations of Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts; Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, and Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, and seven House members of both parties. The association expects to begin showing the film at meetings in June, urging nurses to work for candidates of their choice in the 1986 Congressional elections.

title: LOPES STARS AS CUBS BEAT DODGERS, 4-2
description: Davey Lopes had two singles and a sacrifice fly and drove in two runs to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 4-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: New Trial Is Delayed In Recanted Rape Case
description: Gary Dotson's bid for a new trial was delayed today, but his attorney says the results of a polygraph, or lie-detector, test should bolster the chance of executive clemency for the man convicted of a rape his accuser now says did not happen.

title: PUBLIC IS SPLIT ON BITBURG, POLL FINDS
description: After four weeks of intense national debate over President Reagan's visit to the German military cemetery at Bitburg, the American public is equally divided over whether he should have gone, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Harvard's Sociology Department Would Reject Marx and Weber
description: To the Editor:

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: 2 QUIPSTERS PUT MADRID LUNCH GUESTS IN STICTHES
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez presided over lunch today in his Andalusian-style private dining room, where he swapped colorful jokes with the President of the United States.

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $7,700,000.c-Includes realized investment gains of $3,832,000. The company said operating income for the year-ago quarter was restated due to a change in tax laws.

title: A Change of Text
description: Vice President Bush considerably revamped his prepared speech at the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation dinner Monday evening - mainly deleting several paragraphs that said the Federal Government was often heavy-handed in its dealings with localities.

title: CONDUCTOR DISMISSED IN BONN
description: The City of Bonn has dismissed its chief orchestra conductor for having described scenery in the West German capital's opera house as fit for a ''flea pit'' and its director and audience as musically ignorant.

title: Government Reasoning
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: VIETNAM: ANOTHER VIEW
description: A new television documentary on the Vietnam War, produced by a group dedicated to combating what it views as liberal bias in the news media, will get its first semi-public showing this week before officials of the National Endowment on the Humanities, which provided part of the financing for the project.

title: HEALTH AND NUTRITION: THE CONCERNS IN OTHER NATIONS
description: France EVERYONE seems to agree that over the last 5 to 10 years, the French have become more aware of what they eat, but have been slow to change their eating habits. ''The situation here is different from in America, if only because traditionally, eating habits vary from Normandy to Alsace,'' said Dr. Jean-Martin Cohen-Solal, who heads the Government-financed Committee for Health Education. ''And you cannot go against the French people's natural inclinations.''

title: 2 Writers in Belushi Case Cited for Contempt
description: Two journalists were cited for contempt of court today for refusing to testify about separate interviews in which a woman reportedly admitted killing the comedian John Belushi with an overdose of drugs three years ago.

title: FLYERS DEFEAT NORDIQUES, 4-2
description: The Flyers continued their losing ways tonight, but won just the same. With their captain, Dave Poulin, lost to the injured list, where he joined the high-scoring Tim Kerr, the Patrick Division champions used their forechecking game to defeat the Nordiques, 4-2.

title: Giants Pass on Shaw
description: The Giants have told Pete Shaw, who played out his option and became a free agent, that they do not intend to sign him again. However, Shaw's wife, Felicia, said the 30-year-old safety hoped to play one more season with a National Football League team. Shaw played five seasons with the San Diego Chargers and the last three with the Giants. . . . The Giants also signed 18 free agents, including John Fourcade, a Mississippi quarterback who had played in the United States and Canadian Football Leagues, and Jim Colquitt, twice an all-America punter at Tennessee.

title: MEESE SAYS JUSTICE DEPARTMENT ENDORSES CENTER ON CHILD ABUSE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that the Justice Department had endorsed an effort by the National District Attorneys Association to develop a national education and research center on child abuse.

title: IN FEATHERS, SHE OWNS THE CAP
description: As the Government's ranking feather detective, one who has traced evidence of murderers and eagle poachers, Roxie Laybourne is the Miss Marple of eiderdown. But she is not sentimental about birds.

title: REAGAN TO ATTACK SOVIET ON A-ARMS
description: In the major policy speech of his European trip, President Reagan intends to accuse the Soviet Union of undermining nuclear deterrence by preparing to deploy a new multiple-warhead mobile missile that he contends is ''designed to strike first,'' his national security adviser said today.

title: A YEAR AT THE RACES
description: This has been a tumultuous spring for George Steinbrenner, who has dismissed Yogi Berra and purchased a share of Eternal Prince, and it's not even Mother's Day yet.

title: CMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $333,000 from discontinued operations, a gain of $537,000 on the recapture of income taxes, and a gain of $5,358,000 on the elimination of accrued interest on debt. c-After a loss of $367,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $11,700 from the restructuring of company bank debt.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for the latest quarter and 6 months are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend distributed last month.

title: Jackson at Nazi Camp Site
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson visited the site of a Nazi concentration camp near here today and later said, ''You can't see one and come out the same.'' Mr. Jackson, who is on a European tour, visited the camp with a group of Socialist members of the European Parliament.

title: MAJOR HOLDINGS IN TUDOR CITY ARE BEING SOLD
description: The real-estate entrepreneurs Harry B. Helmsley and Alvin Schwartz have signed an agreement to sell their remaining properties in Tudor City on the East Side of Manhattan for an undisclosed price to two buyers who said they were considering converting the apartments to cooperatives.

title: 3 Parties: Democratic, Republican and Literary
description: Being on opposite sides of the aisle poses fewer problems in fiction than in politics, it seems.

title: Unproved Drug Is Attracting U.S. AIDS Victims to Mexico
description: Victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, are crossing the border or turning to the black market to buy an unproved drug made in Mexico, health officials say.

title: SERVED AS PORTUGAL'S PREMIER
description: Carlos Mota Pinto, Portugal's caretaker Prime Minister in the late 1970's and Deputy Prime Minister until February, died of a heart attack today, the Social Democratic Party said. He was 48 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about the capital's seamy side misidentified Washington's Deputy Mayor for economic development. He is Curtis R. McClinton Jr.

title: YANKEES' STREAK ENDED BY TWINS
description: The Yankees eagerly traded Roy Smalley to the Chicago White Sox last July 18, and he departed just as eagerly. He had grown weary of the way the Yankees had shuffled him around the infield and the way they had ridiculed his defensive play.

title: Murray in Minors
description: Dale Murray, released last week by the Yankees, was signed by the Texas Rangers and assigned to their Class AAA farm club in Oklahoma City. Murray, 35, was placed on unconditional waivers by the Yankees April 29 after appearing in three games this year. He had no record and surrendered three runs in two innings.

title: WINE TALK
description: GALLO is to wine what the Statue of Liberty is to New York. It's so famous, everyone tends to forget it's there. By everyone I mean the wine buffs -the collectors, the importers, the enthusiasts who know all the new wineries in Oregon and Connecticut. It's not a bad idea to take a look at Gallo once in a while, if only to get some perspective on what the wine business is really all about.

title: FLY NOW, PAY LATER
description: Leaving aside the bitter arguments over President Reagan's tour of Europe, you have to wonder whether the results of this television diplomacy justify the physical and psychological strain on the President.

title: PETE DESJARDINS
description: Pete Desjardins, an Olympic diving champion in 1928, died Monday. He was 78 years old.

title: BALLET: PENNSYLVANIA DOES NEW 'SYLPHIDE'
description: THE Pennsylvania Ballet opened last night at the Brooklyn of Academy of Music with one of the best programs it has ever brought to New York. Go see it. The accent in the dancing was on uplift throughout the evening.

title: County to Honor Slain Police Officer
description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said today that the county's Medal of Honor would be awarded posthumously to Gary Stymiloski, the police officer believed to have been killed by Alex J. Mengel.

title: South African Dies After Release by Police
description: A black South African labor leader was reported today to have died, purportedly of head injuries, shortly after his release from police custody.

title: REYNOLDS HEARING PUT OFF IN SENATE
description: Confirmation hearings on the proposed promotion of the Justice Department's civil rights chief, William Bradford Reynolds, to the department's No. 3 job have been postponed at the request of Democrats planning to raise questions about the nomination, aides on the Senate Judiciary Committee said today.

title: 2 Plead Guilty In Hasidic Melee
description: Two Hasidic Jews have pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges stemming from a melee between a large group of Hasidim and the police in Brooklyn in September 1983, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: ISRAEL TO REWARD MENGELE'S CAPTOR
description: Israel offered a $1 million reward today for the capture of Josef Mengele, the notorious Nazi concentration camp doctor.

title: Kelly Counting
description: A quick update on Jim Kelly:

title: BELIEVED IN SOUTH AMERICA
description: The principal Israeli police official assigned to the search for Dr. Mengele says that Israel has fingerprints, handwriting specimens and photographs tending to prove he is living in South America.

title: Founder of NASA Unit In California Dies at 89
description: Dr. Smith De France, founder of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's research center at Sunnyvale, Calif., died Monday at his home here. He was 89 years old.

title: HOUSE GETS COMPROMISE ON REBEL AID
description: A group of Democrats introduced compromise legislation in the House today designed to break a deadlock over aid to the rebels seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government.

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Union Carbide Chemical To Be Sent to New York
description: The FMC Corporation said yesterday that it planned to begin daily shipments of methyl isocyanate from West Virginia to upstate New York this week.

title: CITY NOT GETTING NAVY YARD RENT, AN AUDIT FINDS
description: The industrial park at the Brooklyn Navy Yard is poorly managed and is staying in business only by withholding payment of millions of dollars in rent and water charges it owes the city, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

title: Senior or Not?
description: James Herbert Williams of North Carolina has been playing on the Senior PGA Tour this year, and he has won $1,494. But according to an investigation in his native state, Williams may not be a senior at all, but a junior with an obliging friend at the courthouse.

title: Arrow Electronics Names a President
description: Arrow Electronics Inc., a leading distributor of semiconductors and other electronic components, yesterday named Stephen P. Kaufman president and chief operating officer, effective immediately.

title: BUILDING A MUSICAL AROUND A RECORD ALBUM
description: LISTENING to the sumptuously recorded score of ''Chess'' on RCA Records, one has the uneasy sense that the commercial future of the Broadway musical will increasingly depend on this new '' international style'' of pop-rock music-theater spectacle. ''Chess,'' which is expected to be produced by the Shubert Organization, follows the tradition of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' and ''Evita'' in being a show built around a record album. The album, which has been out since January, has sold over a million two-disk sets worldwide.

title: PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Governor of Louisiana And 7 Others Arraigned
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards of Louisiana and seven co-defendants were arraigned today on Federal charges of criminal conspiracy involving state permits for hospital construction.

title: HOME ELECTRICITY RISKS
description: That common household electricity that runs the television, makes the toast and lights the house kills an estimated 1,500 Americans each year, the Consumer Product Safety Commission reports.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV SPEECH ON THE WAR ANNIVERSARY
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Novel About Soldiers Wins Faulkner Award
description: ''The Barracks Thief'' by Tobias Wolff, published by the Ecco Press, has won the $5,000 PEN/Faulkner award as the best work of fiction published in 1984. The novel is set in an army camp, among a group of soldiers about to be sent to Vietnam.

title: Congress;   Byrd: No More Mr. Quiet Guy
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, has talked to the press more in the last three weeks than perhaps in all the previous 12 months.

title: Flyers Shake Their Lethargy
description: The difference, thought Mario Gosselin, was not as great as the Flyers might have said. He agreed they were better, but not so much so.

title: DATAKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $11.1 million for the quarter and a gain of $10.9 million for the year from the disposal of certain assets. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in March.

title: OPTO MECHANIK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALGOREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PEKING TILTS TOWARD MEETING PROTESTORS' DEMANDS
description: A week after criticizing as ''shameful'' the behavior of several hundred men and women who held a sit-in at Peking's Communist Party headquarters, city authorities have begun moving toward accommodating the protesters' demand that they be permitted to resume residence in the capital.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WILFRED AMERICAN EDUCAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOWARD THE BLUNT BISHOP, THATCHER IS IRREVERENT
description: Bishop David Jenkins of Durham is an object of some controversy in the Church of England. Last summer, this was illustrated by the fact that when York Minster caught fire less than 48 hours after his consecration there, some people were of the opinion that the lightning bolt that started the blaze was the angry judgment of God.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $264,327,000 from the sale of assets.

title: Lawyers in Aquino Case Ask to Question Witness
description: Defense lawyers in the trial arising from the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. asked today to cross-examine the woman who is the sole witness who asserts that she saw a soldier shoot the opposition leader in 1983.

title: THEATER: 'BIG MOUTH'
description: ''BIG MOUTH,'' the Talking Band's newest performance collage, is a satirical study of the relationship between political power and social paranoia. Partly inspired by ''Crowds and Power,'' by the Bulgarian Jewish writer Elias Canetti, ''Big Mouth'' alternates between farcical caricatures of paternalism run amok and earnest, anguished tableaux of human oppression. The scenes are linked by musical interludes, both live and pre-recorded, that blend electronic and Latin folk ingredients into an atmospheric, occasionally overbearing soundtrack.

title: BIRD HITS 43
description: After losing two straight playoff games in Detroit because of fourth-quarter heroics by the Pistons' Terry Tyler and Vinnie Johnson, the Boston Celtics needed a hero tonight. Larry Bird got the call in the fourth quarter from Coach K.C. Jones, his teammates and the capacity crowd of 14,890, which chanted, ''Larry! Larry! Larry!''

title: AMERICAN INTEGRITY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SIERRA SPRING WATER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCLEAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2,500,000. c-Net income.

title: Share Economy Wouldn't Increase Productivity
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYERS ARE URGED TO ALTER DRUG PLAN
description: Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, believes the present drug testing program for major league players is not working well enough and has asked that it be changed. His concern about the program was one of the factors that prompted him to institute mandatory drug testing for everyone in professional baseball other than major league players, he said today.

title: Dow Drops 2.98; Oil Issues Decline
description: Stock prices closed slightly lower on Wall Street yesterday, with oil issues taking most of the lumps and the rumor mill for takeovers turning at top speed.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Share Economy Wouldn't Increase Productivity
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WILL GIVE DEVELOPMENT AID TO ETHIOPIA
description: The United States, the largest supplier of aid to victims of the Ethiopian famine, is also planning to provide development assistance because of a change in United States law, according to relief officials here.

title: NO CHANGE INDICATED IN FED POLICY
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, hinted today that the central bank was not prepared to shift to a more expansionary policy despite the marked slowing of economic growth since last autumn. He told a Senate committee today that growth of the money supply had been relatively high in recent months and that the Fed's policy was essentially unchanged.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $4,537,000 on the sale of all stock of Comdial Ltd.

title: VARIETY IN DOORMATS
description: DOORMATS can be found in several sizes and materials. Standard mats of black rubber embossed with the word ''Welcome'' are $7.99 at Kraus Hardware, 1127 Third Avenue (66th Street).

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEALTH-CONSCIOUS COLLEGIANS JAMMING GYMS
description: Twice a week, a philosophy class at Wesleyan University here adjourns to the gymnasium, and Sartre gives way to squash.

title: STAAR SURGICAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Freddie Mac Offering Made
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday offered $375 million of 15-year, 11 1/2 percent participation certificates at a price of 99.17, to yield 11.29 percent, assuming the underlying mortgages have an average life of seven years.

title: MINISCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GORBACHEV SAYS U.S. POLICY GROWS MORE 'BELLICOSE'
description: At a rally of war veterans marking the 40th anniversary of victory over Nazi Germany, Mikhail S. Gorbachev denounced the United States today as the ''forward edge of the war menace to mankind'' and affirmed his fidelity to the ''priceless'' experience of detente.

title: Jets Start Minicamp With O'Brien No. 1
description: For the first time in two years, the Jets have a No. 1 quarterback in minicamp. He is, not surprisingly to those who know Coach Joe Walton, the strong-armed, young Ken O'Brien.

title: Block Rejects Compuserve Bid
description: The board of H & R Block Inc. formally rejected a $72.5 million offer to buy the company's Compuserve Inc. subsidiary.

title: HEART RISK TERMED LOWER WITH FISH IN DIET
description: Eating fish once a week may significantly reduce the risk of heart attack and may even be beneficial to those suffering from rheumatoid arthritis and asthma, researchers said Wednesday.

title: DOUGLAS & LOMASON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
John O'Shaughnessy Is Dead; Directed Plays on Broadway
description: John O'Shaughnessy, a director in the Broadway theater, died Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Luxembourg Is Blacked Out As 2 Blasts Topple Towers
description: Two explosions brought down a string of four high-voltage electric towers on the outskirts of Luxembourg, blacking out most of the city for about an hour and slightly injuring five motorists, the police said today.

title: MORE G.E. CONTRACT CASES DISCLOSED
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating charges brought by former employees of the General Electric Company that the company submitted false or fraudulent claims for work on Government engine contracts at a plant near Cincinnati, according to court documents and the former G.E. employees.

title: Stopping Those Alien Pizzas and Snails
description: To the Editor:

title: BORDER SHOOTING OF BOY STIRS IRE
description: Mexican-American groups here have expressed outrage at the way officials of the Border Patrol and San Diego have handled a case in which a border patrolman shot across the international line into Mexico and wounded a 12-year-old Mexican boy.

title: U.S. AND SAN DIEGO WIN END TO QUOTAS
description: The Reagan Administration and the City of San Diego asked a Federal District Court today to delete numerical hiring goals from an affirmative action plan adopted in 1977 to help women and Hispanic-Americans get jobs with the city government.

title: STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN TRIP: NO TRIUMPHS
description: The clashing reactions of right-wing applause and left-wing protests that greeted President Reagan in the European Parliament today are symptomatic of the political divisions that have marked his entire trip and have deprived him of a clear success on this 10-day diplomatic venture.

title: JUDGE DROPS 281 INDIVIDUAL SUITS AGAINST MAKERS OF AGENT ORANGE
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed suits against Agent Orange manufacturers that had been brought by 281 Vietnam veterans who charged that they had been harmed by the herbicide's use in Vietnam.

title: Advertising;   A Marriage Made in the Backyard
description: UNDER the Mickelberry Group corporate umbrella, LCF&S has been merged into Nadler & Larimer to form Calvillo, Shevack, Goldberg & Partners, which has billings of about $60 million.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Poll Reports Increase In Wearing Seat Belts
description: The use of seat belts has risen sharply in the United States in the last year, according to the Gallup Poll, even though only New York and New Jersey have laws mandating their use.

title: MONEY FUND, C.D. RATES FALL
description: Rates for bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit and yields in money market funds continued their downward slide for the week ended yesterday.

title: ON SUTTON AND HUTTON
description: When G-men nabbed ''Willie the Actor'' Sutton after he had stolen some $2 million in bank deposits during his lifetime, the disguise artist wound up spending 33 of his last 43 years in prison.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MAY 9, 1985

title: HEART PATIENT FACES SEVERE NEUROLOGICAL PROBLEM
description: The damage from William J. Schroeder's latest stroke has resulted from accumulations of blood in two areas of his brain and has created a ''severe neurological problem'' for the longest-living recipient of an artificial heart, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: Suit Seeks Shelter for Poor
description: A suit has been filed in Superior Court here on behalf of seven Ocean County families, seeking a requirement that towns provide adequate housing for the poor and that government agencies be barred from threatening to separate poor, large families because no suitable shelter is available to accommodate all members. The suit was filed by Ocean-Monmouth Legal Services. Judge Harold Kaplan has scheduled a May 21 preliminary hearing.

title: Goldsmith Raises His Stake in Crown
description: Sir James Goldsmith said yesterday that he had increased his stake in the Crown Zellerbach Corporation to 19.6 percent and was seeking to have today's scheduled annual meeting in San Francisco postponed.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 9, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FORDHAM FLASH SURPASSED
description: He does not remember precisely when, or where, he first heard the name. Jack Allen remembered that it was sometime after the beginning of his freshman year at Fordham, which occasionally seems like a long time ago but actually was just last fall. His friends, Tom McManus and Brad Howland, baseball teammates, were playing Trivial Pursuit. They discovered the question:

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Army Grounds 62 Helicopters After Explosion in Honduras
description: The Army has grounded all 62 of its CH-47 Delta helicopters after one of the cargo helicopters exploded in Honduras, officers said Monday.

title: Holum Out as Coach
description: Dianne Holum, who coached the United States speed skating teams in the last two Olympics, has been dismissed from the post and replaced by an assistant, Mike Crowe.

title: No 'Undue' Risk At Indian Point
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission concluded today that the two Indian Point nuclear plants in Buchanan, N.Y., posed no ''undue or disproportionate'' public risk despite the area's high population and past deficiencies in emergency planning.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Monday about members of the House of Representatives who each represent an entire state misstated the number of such members who have the same party affiliation as both their Senate colleagues. There are two: Don Young of Alaska and Dick Cheney of Wyoming, both Republicans.

title: BARBER-GREENE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $177,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,560,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $375,000 for the 6 months.

title: SPAIN TURNS ATTENTION TO NICARAGUAN
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez saw President Reagan off at the airport here this morning and then immediately began preparing for another visitor Saturday, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua.

title: Technology;   Auto Castings: A New Process
description: THE origins of the ''lost wax'' process of casting metal are lost in antiquity. Archeological evidence suggests it was in use as early as 2000 B.C. in the Middle East and some of the finely detailed gold and copper figurines that survive from the period are prized museum pieces.

title: HERS
description: DURING the two years I lived in Arizona and subscribed to cable television, I became addicted to a program that purportedly took its viewers into a real-life family therapist's office for a hard look at what went on there. I was fascinated by the therapist with his imperturbable, somewhat robotic Pooh Bear affect, and by his patients, actors performing scripts based on actual crisis intervention situations, all playing their hearts out as if for the benefit of some imaginary talent scout cruising the cable health station. But finally what hooked me was the language. How I waited for those moments when one of the actor-patients would explode in a howl of outrage and pain, scream out from the depths of a lifetime's repressed anguish, and the therapist, blinking just a bit harder than usual, would smile benignly and say, ''I'm hearing a little hostility here.''

title: The Mayor, the Bishop and the Court
description: In affirming Mayor Koch's ban on discrimination against homosexuals by contractors for New York City, an appellate court has brightened principles that had been tarnished in months of debate. If read attentively by Archbishop O'Connor and others opposed to the Mayor's order, the decision could point the way to settlement of the dispute.

title: Hesketh, Expos Top Ryan, 1-0
description: Joe Hesketh struck out 12 batters tonight and held Houston to four hits to lead the Montreal Expos to a 1-0 victory over the Houston Astros.

description: b-Net income

description: * Craige D. Johnson has been named chief executive officer for the Marschalk Co., Houston.

BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE HOUSE OF THE SPIRITS. By Isabel Allende. Translated from the Spanish by Magda Bogin. 368 pages. Knopf. $17.95. WITHIN a couple of dozen pages, Isabel Allende's extraordinary first novel, ''The House of the Spirits,'' found several ways to antagonize this reader.

title: THEOLOGIAN IN BRAZIL SAYS HE IS SILENCED BY ORDER OF VATICAN
description: The Rev. Leonardo Boff, a Franciscan friar who is a leading proponent of liberation theology, said today that the Vatican had ordered him to keep ''penitential silence'' as punishment for his views. He did not elaborate on the duration of the punishment.

title: HOUSE IN HARTFORD CLEARS BUDGET BILL
description: The State House of Representatives today approved a $3.95 billion budget measure to finance general government activities in the fiscal year beginning July 1. The vote was 146 to 2.

description: After an extensive agency search, the Commodity Exchange of New York selected Della Femina, Travisano & Partners as its agency. The account was formerly serviced by Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle.
