title: THE ONE-TRACK MIND
description: The essence of Ronald Reagan was exposed at Bitburg. Confronted by the most profound questions of man's nature and responsibility, he responded with narrow ideology and distorted history.

title: THEATER: GALLARDO'S 'SIMPSON STREET'
description: THERE are moments during ''Simpson Street'' when Miriam Colon, Iraida Polanco and Marta de la Cruz each seem too big not only for the play but also for any one theater. Together in the intimate space of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater they can create emotional currents that overwhelm one. And often during the evening they make Eduardo Gallardo's play seem somewhat incidental to their performances.

title: U.S. COPYRIGHT PANEL CHIEF RESIGNS IN FUROR OVER BOOK
description: Marianne Melee Hall, chairman of the Copyright Royalty Tribunal, resigned today after a storm of criticism over her work on a book about black Americans that said, among other things, that they insisted ''on preserving their jungle freedoms.''

title: Nicaragua Asks U.N. Council To Condemn Trade Embargo
description: Nicaragua called on the Security Council today to condemn the trade embargo imposed by the United States last week, saying President Reagan's actions constituted an escalation of a ''holy war'' against the Nicaraguan people.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SEEK OPEN AFGHAN AID
description: A senior State Department official said today that the Reagan Administration wanted to send open refugee aid to Afghan rebel groups fighting the Soviet military presence in their country.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $1,042,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss which is after income of $1,794,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SWIFT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NAVAJOS REFUSE TO BOW TO RELOCATION BY U.S.
description: As Roberta Blackgoat's children were born, their umbilical cords were buried in a corner of her sheep corral. It is a tradition that ties each Navajo to the land and to the animals that provide the food and clothing necessary for survival.

title: H & H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Results include the operations of Bi- Co Rental Inc. which was acquired in December.

title: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EMERGING MARKET FOR DESIGNERS
description: Most of the people who turn to interior designers for help with decorating projects are couples with incomes of more than $50,000 a year, according to a recent survey of American designers. The survey report said that the field had expanded from the ''stereotypical older, upper-income client'' to include those who are ''younger and less affluent.''

title: DOCTOR DEALS A SETBACK TO VON BULOW PROSECUTION
description: A doctor who saved Martha von Bulow's life in 1979 testified today that he believed the coma she suffered then resulted from a lack of oxygen but that prosecutors coached him not to say that when he testified against Mrs. von Bulow's husband, Claus, three years ago, The doctor's reversal cast a cloud over the state's case, and Mr. von Bulow's chief lawyer, Thomas P. Puccio, said he would ask the trial judge to dismiss the first of two counts of attempted murder against Mr. Von Bulow. He was convicted in the 1982 trial, but the conviction was overturned by the Rhode Island Supreme Court.

title: State Raise Urged For 7,800 in Jersey
description: Five percent pay raises should be given to 7,800 state workers - more than 90 percent of them women and and members of minority groups - at the bottom of the state's salary scale, a study panel concluded in a report issued yesterday.

title: Book on Mrs. Campbell Gets Freedley Award
description: The George Freedley Memorial Award will be presented to Margot Peters for her book ''Mrs. Pat: The Life of Mrs. Patrick Campbell'' (Knopf), at a cocktail reception today from 5 to 7 P.M. in the Vincent Astor Gallery of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue. Mrs. Peters won the same award in 1981 for ''Bernard Shaw and the Actresses.''

title: Computerland Plans Appeal
description: The Computerland Corporation said today that it had arranged financing that will allow it to appeal a state court decision that awarded a group of investors 20 percent of the company and $141 million in damages and legal fees.

title: RESTORING THE TERRA COTTA ON GRAND OLD BUILDINGS
description: What do the bas-relief Pilgrims on the Batterymarch Building here and the griffin on the Brenton National Bank building in Grinnell, Iowa, have in common? They are both terra cotta, and like many other fired-clay architectural details on buildings, they both needed repair.

title: SUPPORT PROGRAMS HELP THE CHILDREN OF CANCER PATIENTS
description: ''SO often the children of cancer patients end up confused or misinformed or feeling neglected or in the way,'' said Grace Christ. ''When cancer is first diagnosed, adult family members may not be able to focus on the children's questions and anxieties.'' Mrs. Christ is director of the social work department at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: CHAMBER SOCIETY'S SCHEDULE
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has announced its plans for the 1985-86 season, to be highlighted by three commissioned works and a roster of guests including Keith Jarrett, Richard Stoltzman, Salvatore Accardo, Jan DeGaetani and Christopher Hogwood.

title: Required Reading;   Budgets and the Senate Zoo
description: Excerpts from a speech about the budget deficit given by Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, to a conference of local officials from New York, May 7:

title: MUSIC: U.S. COMPOSERS
description: THE Center for American Music offered one of those fascinating-on-paper programs Sunday at Merkin Hall (129 West 67th Street), and perhaps one should express gratitude for the chance to hear some little-known music and leave it at that. Charles Martin Loeffler and Ernest Schelling were major figures in their day (they were born in 1861 and 1876, respectively), and there is every reason to dig up their music and see what it sounds like. Louis Moreau Gottschalk and Edward MacDowell are somewhat more familiar and of proven merit, and Ives is Ives: a good lot gathered, then.

title: New York City Walkathon for March of Dimes Will Go On
description: To the Editor:

title: HEAD OF MONTEFIORE FORCED TO STEP DOWN IN HOSPITAL DISPUTE
description: The president of the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx has resigned after a committee of the hospital's leading department chairmen demanded his ouster.

title: THE BOOM IN RESTRUCTURINGS
description: John Blocker's contract oil drilling company, the Blocker Energy Corporation, was headed for bankruptcy several years ago when the First Boston Corporation advised the company to ask its creditor banks to accept common stock for most of their loans. Converting debt to equity remains a ''funny voodoo kind of thing'' to Mr. Blocker, but all that matters, he said, is that ''we're now alive and kicking.''

title: SUSPECT IN PSYCHIATRIC CARE BEFORE PENN STATION ATTACK
description: The homeless woman charged in the stabbing Tuesday of an Ohio woman at Pennsylvania Station was recently treated for psychiatric problems at two city hospitals and released, officials said yesterday.

title: YANKS LOSE AGAIN AFTER FILING PROTEST
description: Following a game in which Billy Martin said the Yankees looked like ''a circus team,'' the Yankees protested tonight's game with the Minnesota Twins even before it began, objecting to the Big Top under which they were playing.

Article 226351 -- No Title
description: The United States suffered a $28.3 billion merchandise trade deficit from January through March, up 16 percent from the deficit during the last three months of 1984, the Government said today.

title: FED TO CURB OVERDRAFTS AT BANKS
description: The Federal Reserve Board, identifying what it fears may be a new and growing source of instability in the banking system, approved guidelines today for the use of ''daylight overdrafts'' by the nation's largest banks.

description: A group of Senators and Representatives made public today a plan aimed at forcing the Pentagon to use more competition in buying weapons and equipment.

description: The Soviet Union has awarded W. Averell Harriman, a former Ambassador to Moscow, its Order of the Patriotic War, First Degree, citing his ''great personal contributions to the improvement and strengthening of Soviet-American cooperation'' in World War II.

title: TRELLISWORK: A COUNTRY IDEA IN CITY GARDENS
description: IT is the ever-changing play of sunlight and shadow that gives distinction to the trellis, a nearly universal symbol of the country garden. Arches, fences and arbors of latticework have historically been used by landscapers to punctuate a spacious lawn or frame a distant view.

title: Staley Notes Are Zero Coupon
description: Staley Continental Inc., a food processing company, is offering $350 million of Liquid Yield Option Notes due in 1991 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole underwriter.

title: MUSIC: THE PHILADELPHIA
description: FOR those who too readily trade in national stereotypes, consider the following: Riccardo Muti, the very Italian music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, has long proven himself an expert Brucknerian. title: Robert H. Taylor, 76, Bibliophile and Writer
description: Robert H. Taylor, a bibliophile who donated his collection of 7,000 books, manuscripts and drawings in English and American literature to Princeton University in 1971, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 76 years old.

title: CHAMBER: MUSICA CAMERIT
description: VIVID chamber music was made Tuesday at Merkin Hall by the Musica Camerit ensemble, which the pianist Samuel Sanders regularly leads there. As it happened, Mr. Sanders was indisposed and did not appear, but fortunately one of our more interesting young pianists, Jon Kimura Parker, was available to replace him in Alfredo Casella's ''Siciliana e Burlesca.''

title: Mariners' Moore Loses No-Hit Bid in 9th
description: Mike Moore came within three outs of pitching the first no-hitter in Seattle history tonight and then had to have relief help from Edwin Nunez to survive a ninth-inning Milwaukee rally to help the Mariners defeat the Brewers, 4-2.

title: STRONG U.S. PRESENCE AT 38TH CANNES FESTIVAL

description: Earl Hill, an artist and retired art teacher, died Friday at his home in Freeport, L.I. He was 57 years old.

description: A young mountain man on trial on charges that he abducted and wounded an athlete he hoped would become his bride said today that the shooting had been accidental.

title: RECITAL: BEN HOLT, BARITONE
description: BEN HOLT, the Young Concert Artists baritone who appeared as recitalist at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night, has cultivated his voice into a big, bright instrument that can make quite an impact when unleashed. In order to do this, however, he has adopted a vocal production antithetical to clear enunciation of words.

description: With what he hopes is the worst behind him, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward is focusing on how to transform the public outcry over allegations of police misconduct into a mandate for change.

title: I.R.S. Cuts Tax Return Backlog
description: The Internal Revenue Service, troubled for months by computer problems, is whittling away at its backlog of tax returns, and the agency says nearly all taxpayers who filed on time and are owed refunds should receive their checks by the first week in June.

description: A rape case that has become the focus of national attention poses a challenging legal question for two Illinois courts and Gov. James R. Thompson: how to treat the recantation of the purported victim.

description: b-Net income.

title: Read Closely
description: Every so often, in the tons of paper that bureaucracy produces, there appears, almost providentially, something that hits the eye and the imagination, refreshing the office-bound drone by reminding that way out there, somewhere, there are still glorious wide-open spaces with adventurous and singularly American names. Among the wilderness areas that the White House, at the urging of the Interior Department, is asking Congress to protect as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System are these: Great Rift, Idaho; Humbug Spires, Montana; Powderburn, Colorado, and Scab Creek, Wyoming.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TAKING A LIBERTY The Statue of Liberty is a work of art that has inspired thousands of other works of art, and others of sheer commercialism, during the century since Frederic Auguste Bartholdi introduced the giant sculpture that stands guard over New York Harbor. Several hundred of these Liberty take-offs are now on view at the second of three exhibitions honoring the centennial at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street (873-3400).

title: 20 Subpoenaed on L.I. In Rape-Killing Inquiry
description: A Nassau County grand jury has subpoenaed more than 20 residents of Lynbrook, L.I., as part of a police investigation into the murders of two women and the disappearance of a third, all from the same part of Long Island, according to Edward Grilli, a spokesman for the Nassau County District Attorney's office.

title: EL BASCO CAPTURES WITHERS AT BELMONT
description: El Basco, a frequent runner-up at Aqueduct earlier this year, showed a preference for a new track and a new rider while winning the $99,150 Withers Stakes yesterday on the opening card at Belmont Park.

title: BRAZIL, OUTLINING GOALS, MAKES PLEA TO CREDITORS
description: Brazil's new civilian Government today called for repayment terms from its creditors that will permit the country to resume its economic growth.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Belgian Bank Rate Cut
description: Belgium's National Bank today lowered the interest rate it charges for loans to commercial banks to 9.75 percent from 11 percent. The last time the rate changed was Feb. 16, when it was lifted by one percentage point to 11 percent. A National Bank spokesman said the lower discount rate reflected a slight improvement in the Belgian economy, including a drop in unemployment, and the recent stability of the Belgian franc.

title:
THE NEXT STEP IN DEALING WITH NICARAGUA;

USE TRADE AND AID
description: Congressional rejection of all aid to the ''contras'' gave our nation a moment of hope that Washington would embark on a more sensible policy in Central America. That moment is over. Thwarted in Congress, President Reagan has clamped a trade and transportation embargo on Nicaragua. The Administration remains a prisoner of its rhetoric, which characterizes Nicaragua as an aggressor.

title: Olajuwon Fined $1,500
description: Akeem Olajuwon, the Houston Rockets' rookie center, was fined $1,500 after Scotty Stirling, a National Basketball Association vice president, reviewed videotapes of the last Houston-Utah Jazz playoff game and concluded that Olajuwon had, indeed, slugged the Jazz center, Billy Paultz. The referees did not see the punch, but it was shown repeatedly in slow motion over the Houston arena's huge television screen during the game, and Olajuwon admitted throwing the punch. The fine is the equivalent of about five days interest on Olajuwon's $1.2 million annual salary.

ALZHEIMER'S IS STUDIED
description: ''INNOVATION,'' the weekly science, health and technology series, examines Alzheimer's disease tonight. It afflicts millions of Americans, kills some 120,000 people a year and remains, for the foreseeable future, incurable. A television program can't be cheerful about this, but it can be sensible. ''Innovation,'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 P.M., is sensible.

title: 'ALL OF US MUST ACCEPT THE PAST,' THE GERMAN PRESIDENT TELL'S M.P.'S
description: The two Germanys today observed the 40th anniversary of Nazi Germany's unconditional surrender with pointedly contrasting interpretations of the meaning of the historical event.

title: NEXT WAVE'S FESTIVAL'S PLANS
description: The 1985 Next Wave Festival of avant-garde performing arts at the Brooklyn Academy of Music will open on Oct. 1 with a three-week run by the Pina Bausch Wuppertaler Tanztheater, in the academy's Opera House.

title: BILL COSBY'S TRIUMPH
description: ''The Cosby Show'' is that rare commodity - a truly nice development in a medium that seems increasingly preoccupied with trash. You look at the cheap manipulations of a ''Hollywood Wives'' or a ''Lace II'' and you begin wondering about, just for starters, the decline and fall of the West. You look at ''The Cosby Show'' and you feel, most of the time, just plain good. Television life on Thursdays at 8 P.M. on NBC suddenly displays signs of intelligence, insight and a clever sense of humor. For a pleasant, though not entirely representative example there is this evening's episode, which manages to incorporate Lena Horne into the plot.

title: Official Is Indicted In Death by Auto
description: A state grand jury has indicted the suspended administrator of Delran Township, who the authorities said was intoxicated when his vehicle struck another and killed a 24-year-old Rutgers University student.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THURSDAY, MAY 9, 1985

title: Kaiser Aluminum To Sell Subsidiary
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell the Kaiser International Corporation, a subsidiary, and two fertilizer plants to an investment group headed by Thomas K. Singer, president of Kaiser International. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $483,000, or 1 cent a share, on investments. c-After a loss of $1,499,000 on investments.

title: Beber, Silverstein Wins Luxury Car Account
description: Beber, Silverstein & Partners Advertising of Miami and New York is going to be the agency for a new British and Japanese motorcar that is to be imported here by the newly formed Austin Rover Car of North America in Miami.

title: Sell the Dial
description: The communications spectrum, though invisible, is worth untold billions, serving everyone from ham radio operators to Ma Bell. That explains the importance, and desirability, of the Federal Communications Commission's proposal to revise the system for determining who will reap the benefits. The proposed change would substitute auctions for regulatory assignment. It is long overdue.

title: Japan Railway Layoffs
description: The deficit-ridden Japanese National Railways has cut its work force by 61,000 in the fiscal year 1984, but still has 25,500 more people than it needs, the Japanese news agency Kyodo reported today.

title: Candelaria Sounds Off
description: Hit by a series of financial losses, the Galbreath family has been looking to sell the Pittsburgh Pirates, and the way the Pirate pitcher John Candelaria sees it, the sooner the better.

title: Central Ballet of China To Perform in U.S.
description: The Central Ballet of China, a Classical ballet company from Beijing, will make its American debut next year at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was announced yesterday at a press conference.

title: A Long Wait
description: Yes, hockey is regarded as the national sport of Canada. But it is equally true that if both Edmonton and Quebec win the conference championship series now under way, the National Hockey League will have its first all-Canadian Stanley Cup final since Toronto beat Montreal 18 years ago.

title: Little League Suit
description: A Little League outfielder who suffered an eye injury when he was struck in the face by a fly ball three years ago has filed suit against four of his volunteer coaches, contending that they were negligent in switching him from second base to the outfield without teaching him how to shield his eyes from the sun. The suit, filed by Joey Fort of Runnemede, N.J., who was 10 years old at the time of the mishap in 1982, has caused concern among Little League officials that parents will be afraid to serve as coaches.

title: Unocal Partnership Filing
description: As part of its campaign to squelch a takeover by T. Boone Pickens, the Unocal Corporation plans to file a registration statement next week for its previously announced master limited partnership, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: ARTHUR ASHE'S NEW MATCH
description: Under the dimmed glow of crystal chandeliers in an opulent oval ballroom, Arthur Ashe had been applauded, along with more than three dozen other tennis personalities. As slim as a service line, the Davis Cup captain was one of only five players introduced at Tennis magazine's 20th anniversary party as among both the top 20 of the last two decades and the 20 ''most influential'' in the sport in that era. The other double honorees were Bjorn Borg, Jimmy Connors, Billie Jean King and Chris Evert Lloyd.

title: STAGE: 'MY OLD FRIENDS'
description: AT first blush, ''My Old Friends,'' the sparkling little musical play now being done by the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y, might appear to be something for mature audiences. But really, anyone, even juniors under 60, with or without an adult, can relish this charming entertainment about the geriatric set.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MILTOPE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A FLOWER GROWER'S SUCCESS
description: ''You'll never find this place the first time, nobody ever does,'' warned George R. Heublein. And he was right. But hidden among the farms and forests 30 miles east of Portland is Melridge Inc., the world's leading breeder of new varieties of lilies and one of the nation's largest growers of bulbs and flowers. Indeed, many of the lilies grown in the Netherlands are developed here in Oregon, where the mild moist climate is ideal for growing bulb flowers.

title: Brooklyn Poet Tries the Untried
description: Shortly after noon yesterday, Nathan Whiting, a lean, scraggly-bearded 38-year-old poet from the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, slipped out of his running shoes and his sweat socks at Flushing Meadows Park and lowered himself wearily into a folding chair. Then, for the benefit of a visitor, he considered the events of these latest seven days in his life, and he wondered what on earth was to follow. He was dressed in a heavy woolen long-sleeve shirt to protect himself against a chilly breeze, and also - a bit ludicrously, it seemed -in a wraparound plaid skirt. More about that in a minute.

title: Top Ranks Realigned At Boesky Corporation
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York financier, yesterday announced a number of executive appointments at his firm, changes he said were prompted by the company's dramatic growth during the last few years.

title: One for Mom
description: For the last half decade, he had shuttled between the N.H.L. and the minors, and in all that time he had never scored a big-league goal.

title: M-A-COM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $42,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Includes a tax credit of $37,447.

title: Washington Post Libel Appeal
description: Attorneys for The Washington Post today asked the full United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to rehear an appeal in a libel suit by William P. Tavoulareas, a former president of Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: WORLDWIDE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $377,000 for the latest quarter and $14,000 for the year-earlier period. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year- earlier quarter. The company said 1984 results have been restated for mergers on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Boodle Bags Target: Ex-Hospital Patients
description: Armed with research that shows a change in consumer consumption purchasing habits changed by a single overnight stay in a hospital, Stratmar Systems and TLC Magazine, both New York companies, will be out in the marketplace trying to sell package goods companies on their new Boodle Bag Sampling Program.

title: Interpol Aid is Sought In Search for Mengele
description: Israel asked for help from Interpol today in its effort to find and obtain the arrest of Josef Mengele, the notorious Nazi concentration camp doctor, so that he can be extradited.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There were no share earnings for the latest quarter after preferred dividend requirements. c-Includes a gain of $12,925,337 from the sale of 1,400,000 Heritage Communications Inc. shares. d-After a loss of $250,666 on investments.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing James (Buster) Douglas vs. Jesse Ferguson, 10 rounds, heavyweights, at Caesars Palace Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary 8:30 P.M. Douglas of Columbus, Ohio, is 18-2-1 with 14 knockouts.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL DIAGNOSTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STAGE: 'DOUBLES, 'COMEDY BY WILTSE
description: WHEN one of the middle-aged tennis buddies of ''Doubles'' reflects nostalgically on his severed marriage, he finds that what he misses most is watching television with his wife. ''Phyllis and I always liked to watch the sitcoms together,'' the man solemnly recalls, with an air of regret bordering on the Proustian.

title: CADE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SENTENCES GETTING STIFFER
description: The four-year prison terms imposed today on a former Deputy Defense Secretary, Paul Thayer, and his stockbroker for covering up an insider trading scheme are part of a trend in the last 15 years toward increasingly stiff penalties in high-visibility white-collar crime cases.

title: Letter: On Social Security;   Cutting COLA Would Hardly Be Benign
description: To the Editor:

title: THAYER, EX-DEFENSE DEPUTY, GETS 4-YEAR PRISON TERM IN STOCK CASE
description: A Federal judge today sentenced Paul Thayer, a former Deputy Secretary of Defense, to four years in prison and a $5,000 fine for obstructing justice. Mr. Thayer had pleaded guilty in March.

title:
THE NEXT STEP IN DEALING WITH NICARAGUA;

FUND THE 'CONTRAS'
description: Now that the Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega Saavedra has visited Moscow, on the heels of his successful public-relations campaign directed at Washington, foes of the Administration's proposed aid to the ''contras'' should reconsider their rejection of the President's request.

title: REV. DOM BEDE GORMAN
description: The Rev. Dom Bede Gorman, former athletic director at Portsmouth Abbey, a private preparatory school run by the Benedictine Order in Portsmouth, R.I., died Wednesday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence.

title: TELXON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bargain Justice for a Bulldozer
description: Harry Macklowe, a New York builder who knows how to round the corners of his properties, has agreed to ''donate'' $2 million to house the poor to atone for his reckless destruction of a welfare hotel near Times Square. Fearing that the hotel might delay a megamillion-dollar development project, he had ordered bulldozers to attack at dusk, not even bothering to sever the gas lines or to shield pedestrians. Since the criminal laws don't fully reach such banditry and the physical damage to the street amounted to only $20,000, officials count themselves clever for netting an additional $1.98 million in compensation and the company's plea of guilty to a misdemeanor.

title: SCIENCE DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MASSMUTUAL INCOME INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Trade Promotion Tops '84 Marketing Budgets
description: Last year package goods companies put 37.1 percent of their marketing budgets in trade promotion, 35.6 percent in media advertising and the remainder, 27.3 percent,into consumer promotions, according to a survey by Donnelley Marketing.

title: LYNCH SHUTS OUT BRAVES ON 5 HITS
description: There were no Gary Carter-type heroics last night, but the Mets really didn't need any. After Keith Hernandez hit a two-run homer in the first inning, they relied almost entirely on the efficient, no-frills pitching of Ed Lynch, who threw his first career shutout and his second straight complete game in a 4-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves at Shea Stadium.

title: New York City Walkathon for March of Dimes Will Go On
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN LAND CRUISERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SARATOGA STANDARDBREDS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DAWN ADDAMS, 54, ACTRESS IS DEAD
description: Dawn Addams, the British-born film actress who appeared in romantic roles in the 1950's with such stars as Charlie Chaplin, Spencer Tracy and David Niven, died of cancer Tuesday in a London hospital. She was 54 years old.

title: Rates Up on Fed Comments
description: After declining in the week before the Treasury's major financing, interest rates rose modestly yesterday, as securities dealers bid for 10-year notes in the second leg of this week's record Treasury financing.

title: Science, Sakharov and Soviet
description: Five years ago the National Academy of Sciences, the nation's most prestigious scientific organization and chief scientific adviser to the Federal Government, took what it called an ''unprecedented move'' to protest the Soviet Union's harassment of the eminent physicist and Nobel Peace Prize winner, Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: DANCE: PREMIERE BY LAR LUBOVITCH
description: INTELLIGENCE, taste, stylish expertise and a group of extremely gifted and attractive dancers were all at work when the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company opened on Tuesday evening at City Center (131 West 55th Street), where it will perform through Sunday. But most of all, Mr. Lubovitch has created dance so warm and sensuous and pretty he seems to have created a new category: dance to bask in.

title: Tons of Emotion
description: Ticker-tape tonnage cannot measure emotion.

title: Conover Joins Equitec
description: C. Todd Conover, the former Comptroller of the Currency, has been named vice chairman of Equitec Financial Group Inc. The company, based in Oakland, Calif., has about $2.4 billion of assets under management, much of it commercial real estate. Mr. Conover resigned on Sunday as Comptroller, the chief regulator of federally chartered banks.

title: 2 AUTO FACTORIES FACE THREAT
description: The American Motors Corporation has called for early negotiations on contract concessions by the 6,100 workers at its two plants in Wisconsin and has threatened to close the plants if an agreement is not reached by May 24.

title: The Moral Experts on Sex Should Be Heard
description: To the Editor:

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. HALVES ESTIMATE OF RESERVES OF OIL AND GAS IN OFFSHORE AREAS
description: The Interior Department has sharply lowered its estimates of United States offshore oil and gas reserves, according to a study by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.

title: E.P.A. PLANS NEW POLICY ON TOXIC WASTE DISPOSAL
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has announced a new policy that it says will assure safe disposal of materials it is cleaning up from abandoned dumps for toxic waste.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Express Co. said its American Express Travel Related Services Co. subsidiary intends to acquire the closely held Corporate Travel International Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ON PUBLIC GARDENS
description: Public Projects in American Landscape History, Wave Hill, Armor Hall, 675 West 252d Street, Bronx, 212-549-3200.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter reflect a $68,000 profit on the sale of AM International Inc. shares. Results for the latest 9 months include a pre-tax gain of $401,500 on the sale of stock.

title: PRESIDENT ACCUSES SOVIET OF THREAT TO ARMS STABILITY
description: President Reagan, addressing the European Parliament on the eighth day of his 10-day trip to Europe, described the Soviet Government today as a corrupt system whose military policies threatened nuclear stability.

title: Cooper, Rorer Differ on Vote
description: Cooper Laboratories Inc. claimed victory yesterday in a proxy battle with Rorer Group Inc. over an anti-takeover provision Rorer adopted in February. But Rorer took a different view, contending that Cooper's nonbinding proposal to rescind the ''poison pill'' had failed to win a majority of Rorer's outstanding shares.

title: ACTMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 pro forma stock split declared on May 3, 1985 and a preference claim on the 7 percent cumulative preferred stock.

title: Heavy Schedule Greets Official at Treasury
description: After dealing every day with the Federal Government's checkbook, John J. Niehenke, Acting Assistant Secretary for Domestic Finance at the Treasury Department, says he does not have too much trouble coping with his personal finances.

title: STATE OFFICIALS VOW HELP FOR DISABLED
description: ''WE'RE recognizing more and more that we have a special responsibility to these special families,'' said Governor Cuomo, speaking of the families of the developmentally disabled: those suffering from mental retardation, cerebral palsy, autism, brain damage and other afflictions.

title: IN MOSCOW, A BACH MASS AND THE RUMBLE OF TANKS
description: The audience at a performance of Bach's B-minor mass at a concert hall here the other night was caught by surprise during the intermission by a column of T-64 tanks rolling down the street outside.

title: Javits's New Job
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits has joined the Washington office of the New York law firm of Parker Chapin Flattau & Klimpl as special counsel to represent the Association for a Better New York in its fight against one aspect of tax-revision legislation.

title: Federal Express Gives Its Overseas Work
description: Federal Express, the nation's leading air express company, which has just begun international service, has assigned its overseas advertising program in Europe and the Far East to McCann-Erickson.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lots of Overtime
description: The Correction Department went before the City Council yesterday to ask for permission to more than double its spending on overtime this year - from $11.6 million to $24.3 million.

title: Essex County Offering To Finance Annuity
description: Essex County, N.J., completed a set of transactions yesterday involving the sale of bonds to finance the purchase of a group annuity contract from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on behalf of workers whose pensions the county pays.

title: Profits Up 50% At Woolworth
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company reported yesterday that net income in the quarter ended April 30 soared 50 percent, to $6 million, or 17 cents a share, from $4 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales edged up 2.5 percent, to $1.25 billion, from $1.22 billion.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: SALVADORAN CALLS FOR JOINT EFFORT TO DEFEAT REBELS
description: In a speech that appeared to reflect a growing degree of confidence and political sophistication within the army, the Salvadoran Defense Minister has called on civilian politicians to put aside factional differences and work together to defeat leftist guerrilla forces.

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO BACK SMALLER TAX ON GAINS
description: President Reagan, putting the final touches on the tax proposal he plans to send Congress soon, is likely to recommend a new method of taxing capital gains that would eventually be more generous to investors than the current law, Administration officials said today.

title: A RENAISSANCE IN WOODWORKING
description: ON May 25, many of New England's pre-eminent woodworkers will gather in Providence for an all-day round of parties saluting a jolly Danish cabinetmaker. The occasion will be Tage Frid's retirement as professor emeritus in the furniture and woodworking departments at the Rhode Island School of Design. It will also be Mr. Frid's 70th birthday.

title: Thai Forces Drive Out Vietnamese Troops
description: Thai forces backed by air strikes and artillery barrages today repulsed most of the 800 Vietnamese soldiers who had intruded in pursuit of Cambodian guerrillas, a navy spokesman said.

title: ABC BRIEFS ITS AFFILIATES ON POST-MERGER SEASON
description: In the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton yesterday, the management of ABC-TV attempted with artfully choreographed presentations to reassure affiliate stations that the network's fall to third place this season would not extend beyond the current year.

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. WILL TEST CHEMICAL USED IN AEROSOLS FOR CANCER THREAT
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would do a ''priority review'' of the widely used chemical methylene chloride to see if it poses a threat of cancer to humans.

title: ARSENIC LACED WITH THE ART OF STORYTELLING
description: The afternoon is deliciously dark and ominous. A woman waits in a large room by a marble-topped table. She has in front of her a collection of poisons. The strychnine and arsenic and belladonna root seem to give her great cheer.

title: FILMTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FAMILIES SUE OVER LEAD PAINT
description: A lawsuit was filed yesterday against New York City on behalf of the parents of five children who ate paint from the walls of their Bronx apartments and suffered lead poisoning.

title: A SHOWCASE FOR SOUTHERN CRAFTS
description: THE gallery belonging to Piedmont Craftsmen in Winston-Salem, N.C., lies up the street from the Museum of Early Southern Decorative Arts, at the opposite end of the historic Moravian village known as Old Salem. Together, the two institutions bracket not only the restored 18th-century town but also a long tradition of craftsmanship in the Southeast.

title: A Royal Navy Gesture To the Enemy Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY FINDS FOOD SHORTAGES ARE GROWING IN EAST HARLEM
description: The number of East Harlem residents who had no food or money to buy food at any one time increased sharply last year, according to a private group that has studied the problem and found it worsening for six successive years.

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
P.L.O. REBUFFS U.S. ON MIDEAST TALKS
description: Efforts to revive long-stalled Middle East peace talks suffered a setback today when three key officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization said that only declared P.L.O. members chosen by the group's leadership would be permitted to meet with American officials to explore possible peace talks with Israel.

title: Metropolitan Museum Offer
description: To finance new special exhibition galleries and a new wing for modern art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is offering $45 million of bonds this week through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.

title: DAHLBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR CAST AND AUDIENCES OF 'AS IS,' THERE IS EMOTION BEHIND THE LINES
description: They went to hospitals to visit people with AIDS. Sometimes they were there as actors, observing the way the disease ravages the people who have it and the emotions of those who work with it. But many times they went as friends, sitting beside a companion or a colleague, feeling the disease weave its way into their personal lives.

title: JAPANESE PREMIER'S FOES SEIZE ON TRADE CRISIS
description: Rival politicians in the governing Liberal Democratic Party have seized upon the trade crisis between the United States and Japan as an issue on which they hope to challenge Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: Mostek Planning Layoff Of About 2,000 Workers
description: The Mostek Corporation, one of the nation's largest memory-chip makers, said yesterday that because of a worsening semiconductor market it was laying off about 2,000 employees, or a third of the company's United States work force.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $170,000 for the quarter and $661,000 for the 9 months, an extraordinary charge of $6,000 for the quarter, and an extraordinary credit of $8,936,000 for the 9 months.

title: CONCERT: 'JOAN OF ARC' BY HONEGGER
description: ARTHUR HONEGGER loved to write music on religious subjects, but he was more a man of the theater than of the church. The piety, in other words, may not be deeply felt, but it does afford a wonderful excuse to vent a passion for sheer size and melodrama.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 4 percent stock dividend paid in June 1984.

title: HOUSE PANEL BLOCKS FUNDS FOR MEESE'S OFFICE
description: The House Judiciary Committee voted today to withhold money for the office of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d until the Reagan Administration ordered the enforcement of an act designed to promote competition for military contracts.

title: Officeholder in Michigan Switches to the G.O.P.
description: William Lucas, the executive of Wayne County, which includes Detroit and some of its suburbs, formally announced today his shift from the Democratic to the Republican Party.

title: AN UNLUCKY, OVERSHADOWED CHAMPION
description: It is Rocky Lockridge's luck that Larry Holmes fights the day after he does. Undefeated heavyweight champions have a way of overshadowing junior-lightweight titleholders.

title: ZIMMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
description: b-Net income Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES PENTAGON AN INCREASE ONLY FOR INFLATION
description: The House Armed Services Committee tonight approved a 1986 military budget that would allow the Pentagon an increase only large enough to cover inflation.

title: East-West Conference On Rights Ends Dispute
description: East and West resolved their procedural differences today and got down to business at an international conference set up to review progress on human rights.

title: ZONDERVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth-quarter's results are corrected from the May 7th editions and the company said the revised figures reflect the corrected consolidation of figures from its U.K. subsidiary.

title: DANCE: EIGHT BY JOHNSON
description: QUITE an assortment of themes were represented in a program of eight dances offered by Marguerite Johnson Saturday at the Eden's Expressway studio in SoHo.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Who could remain unsuspecting after the burning of the synagogues, the plundering, the stigmatization with the Star of David, the deprivation of rights, the ceaseless violation of human dignity? Whoever opened his eyes and ears and sought information could not fail to notice that Jews were being deported.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $161,000 from a reduction of income taxes resulting from a deduction of research and development expenses reported earlier.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: REMOTE-CONTROL systems for lights and appliances are becoming increasingly popular. They combine the convenience of manual control from one or more locations or, with a timer, automatic control. Such systems also provide additional security by using lights and appliances to fool would-be burglars into thinking the home is occupied, and when used wisely, the systems help save energy.

title: ENDO-LASE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nuclear Power Study
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington said today that President Reagan would join in a ''Cabinet-level review'' of the nuclear power industry in an effort to increase its faltering share of United States energy production.

title: AS BRITAIN CELEBRATES, QUEEN REVEALS A SECRET
description: Uncertain whether to quietly commemorate the official end of World War II in Europe on May 8, 1945, or joyously celebrate it, Britain today marked the anniversary with everything from fireworks and block parties to soul-searching religious services and wreath-layings.

title: TRILOGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LOS ANGELES BACKING EQUAL PAY FOR JOBS OF 'COMPARABLE WORTH'
description: Los Angeles plans to adopt a union contract later this week that embraces the idea of equal pay for city jobs of ''comparable worth,'' an idea backed by many women's groups.

title: Southland Cites Citgo Profit Rise
description: The Southland Corporation said that gasoline retail profits, which amounted to 6.5 cents a gallon in the first quarter, were steadily improving and should help the company post significantly higher earnings in the future.

title: A VERBAL WAR OVER REAGAN IN STRASBOURG
description: As President Reagan left the European Parliament today, a bitter war of words broke out among the assembly's countless political groupings over the significance of his speech.

title: FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Melanesian Is Killed In New Caledonia Riots
description: A Melanesian was shot to death today and 65 other people were injured in violent confrontations between nationalists and opponents of independence for this French Pacific island, Government officials said.

title: FITCHBERG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WESTCHESTER POLICE EXTEND SEARCH FOR 3 ESCAPEES
description: The Westchester County police extended their search today for three inmates who escaped from the county jail Tuesday night by sawing through two iron bars in a window and scaling two walls with a rope made of bedsheets.

title: Books: Injured City
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF NEW YORK CITY. By Roger Starr. Basic Books. 246 Pages. $17.95. WITH a surplus in the year's accounts, an election in the offing and the Governor treating the city like family, spring has been a season for optimism about New York's prospects, and it's useful to have this clever, sometimes eloquent, quarrelsome, sometimes sour book as a corrective.

title: CARAMOOR MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: The 40th anniversary season of the Caramoor Music Festival will begin Saturday, June 29, and continue with concerts on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays through Aug. 24. The opening concert will feature the pianist Rudolf Firkusny and John Nelson conducting the Orchestra of St. Luke's in an all-Beethoven program, including the Seventh Symphony and the Piano Concerto No.3.

title: CUOMO PRESENTS BILL TO MANDATE FIXED SENTENCES
description: Governor Cuomo presented legislation today that would require judges in criminal cases to impose fixed sentences without a chance of parole on felons.

title: BEACON PHOTO SERVICES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Corrected from May 1 editions.

title: BRIDGE: RUSSELL TEAM GOT 369 POINTS IN 64 DEALS IN MONTREAL PLAY
description: In head-to-head team matches in major competition, a winning team is likely to average about two-and-a-half international match points per deal, and a losing team about two. So in a 64-deal match a team will seldom score fewer than 100 or more than 200.

title: EMPI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $57,500. c-Net loss.

title: Murdoch Gets Paper Inquiries
description: Rupert Murdoch, who earlier this week agreed to buy Metromedia Inc.'s television stations with a partner, has received several ''serious'' inquiries about buying three of his newspapers, including The New York Post, his spokesman said yesterday. Howard J. Rubenstein, Mr. Murdoch's spokesman, also said that the Australian-born publisher would not seek a permanent waiver of the Federal regulations that prohibit ownership of a daily newspaper and a television station in the same city.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $162,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: FRESHER COOKER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
$1 Million of Environment
description: David Hockney had been in the night before to paint his swimming pool indigo with white arcs. In a display window in the hall, Armand Arman had stacked 60 wrecked and rusted bicycles and entitled the work ''Rush Hour in Shanghai.''

title: A Spouse Is Missing
description: To the Editor:

title: FINK BLOCKS BOND PLAN TO FINISH JAVITS CENTER
description: A refinancing plan to raise an extra $30 million to finish the new Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan was withdrawn today in the face of opposition by Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink.

title: STAGE: 'SIT DOWN AND EAT,' A MUSICAL
description: THE romantic anxieties of young women in the city are given a musical treatment in Barbara Schottenfeld's ''Sit Down and Eat Before Our Love Gets Cold.'' While searching the Yuppie thicket for eligible heterosexual men, two women - the show's principal characters - sing a lament, ''I'm looking for a boy to love/ Who's not looking for a boy to love.'' At the same time, they keep an eye on the ticking biological clock. For all their liberated feminism, the women dream about home and hearth.

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: TWO BUDGET PLANS LOSE SENATE VOTES
description: The Senate today defeated two Democratic budget alternatives, while the majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, appeared to be making headway in getting votes for a revised budget package.

title: PARTNERS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $5,516,000 for the quarter and year.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Reed Returns to N.B.A.
description: After an absence of six years from coaching in the National Basketball Association, Willis Reed joined the Atlanta Hawks yesterday as an assistant coach. Reed, who resigned last week as the Creighton University coach, was given a one-year contract.

title: Kidnapped U.N. Aide in Beirut Is Reported in Good Health
description: Alec Collett, a United Nations consultant who was kidnapped in March outside Beirut, is ''alive and well and in good health,'' according to a videotape of the man received by his wife.

title: TRIANGLE HOME PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. has elected to its board H. Barclay Morley, chairman and chief executive officer of Stauffer Chemical Co.; Milton Stern, vice chairman of Stauffer, and Robert W. Dixon, former chairman and chief executive officer of Harvey Hubbell Inc.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOAH DEFEATED BY TERRY MOOR
description: Tradition was beaten in straight sets when the grass courts at Forest Hills turned to clay in 1975 and the United States Open found another home in spacious Flushing Meadows three years later. But it is the clay-like Har Tru surface that has given a new generation of players their first look at the stately West Side Tennis Club and created the little twists and turns in plot that have added an air of unpredictability to the Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions.

title: 7 Indians Killed In Hindu-Moslem Riots
description: Seven people were killed and 20 injured in a night of rioting between Hindus and Moslems in the west Indian city of Ahmedabad, officials said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MAY 10, 1985

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales for the year-ago first quarter represent the final shipments to the company's principal customer.

title: NEW YORK LOBBIES TO KEEP TAX BREAK
description: New York has begun using its economic and political leverage in an effort to preserve the Federal income-tax deduction of state and local taxes, which President Reagan is expected to ask Congress to repeal.

title: THEATER: BILL IRWIN'S 'COURTROOM'
description: EVEN if he weren't a brilliant mime and just about the most pliably rubber-limbed hoofer since Ray Bolger, Bill Irwin would still be a joy to watch. This performer is, above all, a clown - a post-modern clown, as the current lingo has it - and an uncommonly sweet and vulnerable one.

title: FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures were restated to include the results of Golin-Harris Communications Inc., which was acquired Jan 1, 1985.

title: AUCTIONS
description: IMPRESSIONIST and modern works valued at more than $65 million - including 17 Monets and 10 Magrittes as well as works by van Gogh, Gauguin, Cezanne, Picasso, Braque, Schiele, Renoir and Dali - are on view this weekend before their sale next week at Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips, Son & Neale.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $715,000 on the termination of a pension plan and a tax credit of $525,000. c-Including a tax credit of $533,000. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: TODAY'S TURKEY AND THE ARMENIAN TRAGEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR SAFETY PROJECTS EXAMINE HUMAN FACTOR
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has drafted a plan to tackle one of the big remaining problems in aviation safety - the performance of pilots and other employees in the industry.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES' MACHINISTS RATIFY NEW 3-YEAR CONTRACT
description: Eastern Airlines' 12,000-member machinists union ratified a three-year contract tonight that included improvements over a contract it had rejected in April.

title: DON'T BE MISLED BY THE BITBURG TRIP
description: Before agreeing to lay a wreath at the Bitburg cemetery, President Reagan should have asked himself whether it was right for the leader of the free world to pay his respects at a graveyard that contained the remains of nearly 2,000 Nazi soldiers, including 49 SS troops. But now, those of us who urged him not to go, and who protested his visit, must ask ourselves whether the visit has revealed indifference on his part to the plight of the Jewish people. I think it has not.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Florida Supreme Court Back a Death Sentence
description: The conviction and death sentence of Theodore Bundy for the 1978 murder of a 12-year-old girl was upheld today by the Florida Supreme Court.

title: TEMPLETON GROWTH FUND LTD reports earnings for As of April 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: VATICAN SAYS ORDER TO BRAZILIAN GIVES TIME FOR REFLECTION
description: The Vatican said today that in ordering the Rev. Leonardo Boff, the Brazilian theologian, to maintain ''a period of respectful silence,'' it was seeking to allow him time for ''serious reflection.''

title: Baseball Goal Within Reach
description: Tim Barker, an outfielder at the University of Central Florida in Orlando, has three games remaining in his senior year, and all he needs is one hit to round out one of the most remarkable seasons in college baseball history.

title: Pop-Jazz: Latins In the Spotlight
description: The Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue at 68th Street, shares its neighborhood with august consulates and cultural centers. Among the activities in its elegant salon, however, has been a series of concerts that is anything but stodgy.

title: TODAY'S TURKEY AND THE ARMENIAN TRAGEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SPLIT ON MOBILE MISSILES
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan has never proposed a ban on land-based mobile missiles, despite his statement Wednesday that a Soviet mobile missile is ''clearly designed'' for a first strike and is ''undermining stability.''

title: Today's Turkey and the Armenian Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATORS APPROVE BUDGET WITH CURBS ON MILITARY FUNDS
description: The Republican-controlled Senate voted early this morning by 50 to 49 for a 1986 budget that would limit the military spending increase to the inflation rate and eliminate the Social Security cost-of-living increase for one year.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium. The Mets lost two of the three games played in Philadelphia last month, and the one they won was by Dwight Gooden, the starter tonight, who combined with Jesse Orosco for a three-hit, 1-0 shutout against Steve Carlton. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.). Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, Mo. (Television - Channel 11, 8:35 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M). Expos vs. Atlanta Braves, at Montreal. (Television -7:35 P.M.). College: College of Staten Island vs. Lehman at Bronx Community College, 3:30 P.M. opening round of the Knickerbocker Conference playoffs. Basketball Pistons vs. Boston Celtics, at Detroit. Game 6 of the Eastern Conference playoffs. (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P.M., tape delay). Boxing Troy Darrell vs. Bruce Jackson, junior middleweights; Mike (the Giant) White vs. Larry Alexander, heavyweights; Tyrone Jackson vs. Juan (Chiqui) Torres, featherweights; 10-round co-features at Felt Forum. The first preliminary is at 7:30 P.M. The undefeated Darrell has 16 knockouts in his 17 pro fights and 11 consecutive knockouts at Felt Forum.

title: Foote, Cone Net Off 40% in Quarter
description: Yesterday, a couple of days after Norman Brown was interviewed, Foote, Cone & Belding Communications issued its first-quarter results.

title: Chicago Board Options CHICAGO, May 9 -
description: The board of the Chicago Board Options Exchange has voted to ask the Securities and Exchange Commission to allow it to trade stocks. The exchange, the only one devoted exclusively to options and the leader in the trading of stock options, said the S.E.C. decision to allow a pilot program in ''side-by-side'' trading of over-the-counter stocks and options in those stocks ''mandates that C.B.O.E. become a stock exchange.''

title: Confrontation and Peace
description: Before the Peace Fountain could be topped off yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, peace had to be declared.

title: Outbreak of Disease Claims 34 in England
description: The toll in the world's deadliest outbreak of legionnaires' disease rose to 34 today and officials were trying to determine if power station cooling towers were spreading the illness.

title: Auctions: New at Christie's
description: Christie's has a glistening new auction room in the Delmonico Plaza.

title: E.P.A. REPORTS AN INCREASE IN OZONE LEVELS
description: Ozone levels increased sharply in the United States in 1983 because of greater industrial activity combined with hot, dry weather, according to a report issued today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Draft Sign-Up
description: Derrick Gervin, a star forward at the University of Texas at San Antonio and the brother of the professional star George Gervin, has applied for the National Basketball Association draft. The 6-foot-9-inch junior, who averaged 25.6 points a game, had been on scholastic probation for the 1984-85 season and needed a 2.2 grade-point average to stay in school.

title: Disney Suit's Trust Upheld
description: A California appeals court has upheld a preliminary injunction issued against an investment group led by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York financier, that requires the $60 million made when the group sold its stock in Walt Disney Productions back to the company be put into a trust until a pending suit is settled.

title: ARCHIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includinbg an extraordinary credit of $205,000.

title: CHB FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
description: b-Including a gain of $140,000 from an adjustment on insurance claims. c-After a charge of $1,172,000 for the quarter and 9 months for the estimated provision for marine personal injury claims. Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in December 1984.

title: Oiler Streak Halted
description: Denis Savard scored one goal and had up two assists as the Chicago Black Hawks snapped Edmonton's 12-game Stanley Cup playoff winning streak with a 5-2 victory tonight.

title: British Telecom In Pact With Mitel
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. has agreed in principle to acquire a 51 percent interest in the Mitel Corporation, a major Canadian maker of telecommunications equipment, the companies said yesterday.

title: HAROLD MAYER, 70, FORMER PROSECUTOR AND RETIRED JUDGE
description: Harold Mayer, a judge and the director of the Box 100 anticorruption program during the administration of Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr., died of heart disease Wednesday at Parkway Medical Center in North Miami, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived in Coconut Creek, Fla., and Floral Park, Queens.

title: Toxic Waste Dump Is Closed by Ohio
description: State regulators said today that they were closing a problem-plagued toxic waste dump until the operator found out more about leaks that were contaminating water under the ground.

title: OFFICER CHARGED AS DRIVER OF CAR IN HIT-RUN CASE
description: A 37-year-old police officer was arrested yesterday and charged with being the hit-and-run driver who struck a young woman riding a bicycle in Brooklyn last week. The woman was not seriously injured.

title: Photography: Off Beaten Path
description: There are always photographs to be seen along Fifth Avenue's ''Museum Mile,'' but some of the most unusual, unexpected and exciting images lie far from the beaten path. Currently, there are photographs on exhibition at a library, a dance center, a foreign government's posh town house and a center for the study of black culture. For the adventurous, there's even a show of photographs in an Upper West Side apartment.

title: BROOKLYN SENATOR BIDS FOR BOROUGH PRESIDENT
description: State Senator Martin Markowitz announced yesterday that he would challenge the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, for the Democratic nomination for the post.

title: UNESCO NEGOTIATES ON BUDGET AFTER U.S. FUND CUT
description: The Director General of Unesco proposed today that money be used from a reserve fund to help make up the loss of Washington's 25 percent contribution to the budget.

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FLEXI-VAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,127,000 from the repurchase of debt. c-Incluing income from discontinued operations of $129,000.

title: CAMACHO PULLS OUT OF FIGHT
description: Nearly three hours into a news conference to publicize what Don King was billing as his ''D-Day Dynamite'' boxing card June 6 in Las Vegas, Nev., Hector Camacho, the main attraction, defused the program by retreating from his fight.

title: POLICE HOLD SUSPECT
description: Three people were killed and three others wounded early this morning after an argument between two men erupted into a shootout at a bar.

title: Continuing an Old War in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK FED CHIEF'S DEALER-RULE IDEAS
description: After persistent prodding from Senators, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, E. Gerald Corrigan, reluctantly outlined today his recommendations on how secondary dealers in government securities should be regulated.

title: Cabaret: Satire And Improvisation
description: Having gone through four cast changes in four years, while honing its light satirical claws to a fine edge, ''Forbidden Broadway 1985'' has become a staple of good cheer on the Upper West Side. The revue that ''toasts and roasts'' recent Broadway shows plays at Palsson's Supper Club, 158 West 72d Street. Created by the writer-director Gerard Alessandrini, it parodies such hits as ''La Cage aux Folles,'' ''Cats'' and ''Evita'' and also uses older Broadway music to comment on the present.

title: DIRECT VOTE FOR PRESIDENT RESTORED IN BRAZIL
description: Seven weeks after the military left power, the Brazilian Congress approved a constitutional amendment on Wednesday restoring a system of direct presidential elections eliminated at the time of the 1964 military coup.

title: AND NOW, LIVE FROM JERUSALEM: KOCH AND KOLLEK
description: The two Mayors opened in Jerusalem this evening, and by all appearances they were a hit.

title: KUNDREA ACCEPTS JERUSALEM PRIZE
description: Milan Kundera accepted the Jerusalem Prize for Literature Wednesday with a speech in which he called the novel ''the imaginary paradise of individuals'' and ''the territory where no one possesses the truth'' but where ''everyone has the right to be understood.''

title: Market Place;   Chris-Craft And Warner
description: STEVEN J. ROSS, chairman of Warner Communications Inc., and Herbert J. Siegel, chairman of Chris-Craft Industries, used to be good friends. So much so that when Rupert Murdoch bought stock in Warner, Mr. Siegel came to Mr. Ross's rescue.

title: AUSTRALIA WARMINF TO FILM MAKERS
description: ''The Coca-Cola Kid,'' the Australian film shown in competition at the Cannes Film Festival tonight, was directed by a Yugoslavian, Dusan Makavejev. Allowing a foreign director the use of Australian money is a new step for the fiercely nationalistic Australian film industry.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch from Strasbourg, France, yesterday about President Reagan's appearance before the European Parliament incorrectedly rendered a phrase of his speech. He accused the Soviet Union of ''undermining stability and the basis for mutual deterrence.''

title: VON BULOW JUDGE HEARS A REBUTTAL
description: The two prosecutors who in 1982 won a conviction of Claus von Bulow on charges of trying to murder his wife testified today that they had never told a Newport doctor to conceal his conclusion that lack of oxygen rather than excess insulin caused Mrs. von Bulow to sink into her first coma in 1979.

title: MAYO CLINIC BID FOR FLORIDA BRANCH STIRS DISPUTE
description: The Mayo Clinic officially takes the first step this week in a project aimed at using modern technology to link what could become a network of regional diagnostic clinics.

title: BROADWAY BUILDER SAVES FACADE OF A 1914 THEATER
description: Preservationists went to work in a hurry last November when they heard that the Reeves television studio on the southeast corner of Broadway and 81st Street, across the street from Zabar's and the Shakespeare and Company bookstore, had been sold to a developer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, MAY 10, 1985

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL I reports earnings for As of April 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Chavez Suspends a Boycott But Renews Call for Another
description: Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers Union, has suspended his call for a boycott of Acme Markets while renewing plans to boycott California grapes after a 10-year hiatus.

title: DUTCH SEASCAPE SOLD
description: Jan van de Cappelle's 1646 seascape, showing Prince Frederik Hendrik visiting the Dutch fleet at Dordrecht, brought an auction record for the artist in a sale of old-master paintings last night at Christie's.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ORION CLASSICS, the division dealing with art-house films and foreign imports, will soon be distributing five new titles that further establish Orion's pre-eminence in the field. The classics divisions launched enthusiastically by most of the major studios beginning with UA Classics five years ago have fallen on hard times. Orion retains autonomy from its parent company and continues to thrive, with Columbia's Triumph its closest competition. Triumph has Lina Wertmuller's ''Sotto Sotto,'' Maurice Pialat's ''Police'' and Jean-Luc Godard's highly controversial ''Je Vous Salue, Marie'' (''Hail, Mary'') on its agenda.

title: No Question
description: Joe Frazier is signed for a fight June 23 against Robert Cleroux, a former Canadian heavyweight champion.

title: REOPENED ETHIOPIA FAMINE CAMP GETS UNEXPECTED FLOW OF REFUGEES
description: An unexpected ''floodtide'' of famine victims are returning to a reopened camp in western Ethiopia, a senior aid official here said today.

title: BOAT CHILDREN FROM VIETNAM ARE GETTING A'S IN ASSIMILATION
description: The 12th grader's report card arrived home the other day from Freeport (L.I.) High School. It read as follows: History, 95; Humanities, 93; Social Studies, 94; Advanced Placement Physics, 91; Math, 99.

title: FLYERS SURVIVE ANOTHER INJURY AND WIN
description: The Philadelphia Flyers aren't exactly cruising to the Stanely Cup final. Tonight, they lost their third key player in three games, but they were propelled to another victory ostensibly by their remaining healthy legs and sheer determination.

title: AT 32, A SHOT AT LAST IN THE MAJORS
description: By the time he turned 32 years old, Tom Seaver had appeared in 354 major league games and won 182 of them. By 32, Steve Carlton had pitched in 382 games and won 168. Nate Snell is 32 now, and he opened this season with just five major league games to his credit and just one victory to go along with a single loss. But Snell, with the likes of Seaver and Carlton, finally is also a major league pitcher, having made the rich staff of the Baltimore Orioles after pitching four years at Tennessee State University and eight years in the minor leagues.

title: MOBIL PRESIDENT TO ASSUME TOP POST
description: Allen E. Murray, the Mobil Corporation's 56-year-old president, will become chief executive in February when Rawleigh Warner Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive officer for the last 16 years, retires, it was announced yesterday.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jets Reshaping Linebackers
description: ''That's terrible, terrible,'' Dan Radakovich was shouting in judgment of Greg Buttle's pass defense.

title: POSTWAR RULE BY THE ALLIES: A FRESH LOOK
description: Documents declassified in recent years present a fuller picture of how the Allied military governments promoted democratic development and other changes in Germany, Italy and Japan after World War II.

title: SENATORS APPROVE BUDGET WITH CURB ON MILITARY FUNDS
description: For four years the question has been when and how President Reagan's military buildup would end. The answer may have emerged in the latest compromise budget plan, even though it was defeated in the Senate early today.

title: Buchanan's Moods
description: It seemed a little anomalous from the beginning for the White House to have a director of communications who did not talk to the press, with the exception of lunch with a friendly columnist. But after three months of not returning telephone calls from reporters, Patrick J. Buchanan has moved into what one of his Reagan Administration colleagues calls ''a more accommodating mood.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Bridge;   Cavendish Club Will Be Site Of International Pairs Event
description: The Cavendish Club's Invitational Pairs Championship, scheduled for tomorrow and Sunday at the club's new premises at 105 East 73d Street, will as usual include many of North America's top-ranked stars in the field of 36 pairs.

title: U.S. CITIES BERKELEY CATALOGUE ON 'SEXIST' COURSE DEPICTIONS
description: A Federal civil rights official has complained to the University of California at Berkeley that its course catalogue contains sexist language, such as ''mankind,'' ''manpower'' and ''man-made.''

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN ADVENTURE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COPA GIRLS ARE STILL PARTYING
description: It wasn't expected that they would all be there for the seventh reunion of the Copa Girls. But Harriet Wright made the party at the Copacabana the other night and so did Sandy Baxter-Capano - the first and last of the women who danced eight to the line at the nightclub from 1940 until 1969.

title: METS GET A TEST OF INJURIES, AND PASS IT
description: Mookie Wilson's shoulder, George Foster's knee, Ray Knight's elbow, Ron Gardenhire's hamstring and Gary Carter's knee, ankle and ribs all had a day off yesterday. But the Mets once more will patch together their wounded tonight when they open a weekend series against the Philadelphia Phillies, with Dwight Gooden's 20-year-old right arm matched against Steve Carlton's 40-year-old left arm in Shea Stadium.

title: Image Overhaul
description: During his four years at Georgetown, Patrick Ewing acquired a reputation, and not without cause, as the country's most protected basketball player. Requests for interviews were always shuffled through layers of people that included Coach John Thompson and Mary Fenlon, the team's academic adviser, and then were usually denied.

title: TAX PLAN TO REFLECT POLITICAL REALITIES, REGAN SAYS
description: The White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, said today that President Reagan had made accommodations to ''political realities'' in preparing his proposals for taxing charitable contributions, capital gains and business depreciation.

title: Vietnam, Off Camera
description: The party is over in Vietnam, where American networks lent their cameras to a self-serving celebration of Hanoi's only real achievement: conquest. Parades make pictures. What got scant attention was the off-camera horror of Vietnam's unrelenting persecution even of former comrades. Some victims risked their lives by talking to The Times's Barbara Crossette and other reporters. Their story is appalling, their fate a major obstacle to any reconciliation with the United States.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AVAILABILITY OF TICKETS
description: Following is the ticket availability, at press time, for Broadway shows on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Occasionally, shows that report being sold out at press time have tickets available because of weather conditions or because of ticket returns:

title: CORDERO FACING A SCHEDULING CONFLICT
description: Officials of Garden State Park yesterday denied reports that the May 27 post time for that track's Jersey Derby would be changed so that Angel Cordero Jr. could ride Track Barron in the Metropolitan Mile at Belmont and then take a helicopter flight to ride Spend a Buck in the Jersey Derby the same afternoon.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corp. is a wholly owned consolidated subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co.

title: There Are Fewer Birds Singing This Year
description: To the Editor:

title: PEKING FOOD PRICES TO RISE SHARPLY
description: Lines formed in Peking today as the city's 9.5 million people stocked up on meat, fish and poultry a day before the steepest food price increases here since the Communists took power in 1949 were to take effect.

title: KEAN PROPOSES INCOME-TAX CUT OF 10% FOR '85
description: Governor Kean today proposed giving New Jerseyans a one-time 10 percent deduction on their personal income taxes this year, up to a maximum of $75.

title: The Rise and Fall of Paul Thayer
description: Paul Thayer, a decorated Navy fighter pilot in World War II, rose from test pilot to chief executive of the LTV Corporation. He became chairman of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and, in 1983, Deputy Secretary of Defense.

title: A TROUBLED WEEK
description: What President Reagan intended as a journey of reconciliation, 40 years after the end of World War II in Europe, became too frequently an occasion for bitterness and recrimination, even among friends, and wound up in a warlike exchange of accusations with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: STARRETT, L S CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes approximately $950,000, or 12 cents a share, from the settlement of two lawsuits. Corrected from the May 7th editions.

title: OPPOSITION IN NICARAGUA SAYS IT IS WEAKENED BY THE U.S. EMBARGO
description: The internal political opposition here is in disarray and has been further weakened by the unexpected imposition of trade sanctions by the United States, according to opposition leaders and diplomats who monitor their work.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Petrofina Inc., Dallas, has elected Kenneth W. Perry senior vice president and Brendan M. O'Connor treasurer.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''I CALL that 'White Sky,' '' said Arnold Scaasi the other evening in the Rainbow Room. ''And that is 'Moonflower.' '' Over there is 'Spring Garden.' No, perhaps I'll change that to 'Midnight Garden.' There, that one? Let's call it 'Black Sky With Silver Water.' ''

title: Can't See the Woods for Oversight Committees?
description: John F. Lehman, the Secretary of the Navy, complained in a recent speech that the number of Congressional ''oversight'' committees he was obligated to report to had proliferated to 32 from 4 in the past decade. This situation, he asserted, amounts to ''Congressional anarachy'' and leaves the authority of the committees ''so diminished, so dissipated and so lessened in effectiveness.''

title: Informatics Talks
description: The Informatics General Corporation, the target of a takeover bid from Sterling Software Inc., said that it was considering a transaction with unnamed parties that could lead to a leveraged buyout of the company. Dan McGurk, head of a special committee that is seeking possible buyers for the company, said that the negotiations involve a deal that would probably include members of the company's management and would result in taking the company private. He also said that the company had held discussions with other parties but had received no other offers.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: What Makes Amtrak Vulnerable to Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: New Lights At Metrodome
description: Forty-nine lights will be installed in the dome of the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome to illuminate the gray fabric ceiling, Jerry Bell, stadium director, said today.

title: TURBULENT TIMES AT HUTTON
description: Not long after Edward F. Hutton opened his stock brokerage in San Francisco in 1904, the firm's resiliency was sorely tested. The San Francisco earthquake of 1906 leveled the city, but the manager of Mr. Hutton's office uncovered its records and made his way to a telegraph office in nearby Oakland to continue placing customer orders.

title: COPYRIGHT PANEL TERMED 'A REPOSITORY FOR POLITICAL APPOINTMENTS'
description: The Copyright Royalty Tribunal, the center of a furor this week when its chairman resigned under fire, has drawn criticism on the ground that its members have little experience in copyright law and were chosen mainly for their political connections.

title: ANTIQUES SHOW AND SALE
