description: Artwork, furniture, jewelry and rare antiques will be among the offerings of more than 100 dealers this weekend at the Park Avenue Antique Show-Sale at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL II reports earnings for As of April 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Martin Demotes Cowley
description: In the world of higher education, it's often publish or perish for professors. In the world of Billy Martin, it's produce or perish.

title: F.B.I. Holds Man In Shots at Planes
description: A man shot and disabled two parked airplanes and may have fired at another grounded plane containing 100 passengers this morning at the Greater Buffalo International Airport, but the authorities said no one was injured.

title: Restaurants: Old and the New
description: The uptown dining scene has been evolving at a frenzied pace in recent years. Sojourns along Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, for example, yield new restaurants of every size, color and gastronomic flag almost weekly. The same is happening along side streets and major avenues on the other side of Central Park. In addition to the two places reviewed in the regular restaurant column today on page C18, La Mirabelle and Ancora, following is a somewhat random selection of personal favorites, both new and established.

title: Miami Files Lawsuit Over Convict's Visit
description: The City Commission voted today to sue Santa Monica, Calif., for giving a convicted sex offender a one-way plane ticket to Miami, where he was promptly charged with indecent exposure and vandalizing a church.

title: Kuechenberg Retires
description: The offensive guard Bob Kuechenberg, the last Miami player remaining from the 1972 Dolphin team that went 17-0, including a victory in the Super Bowl, announced his retirement yesterday. The 37-year-old Kuechenberg played in more regular-season games than any other Dolphin, 190.

title: Uniform Closing Time Urged for Voting Places
description: News executives from the nation's three major broadcasting networks urged Congress today to adopt a law that would require polling places in Federal elections to close at the same time in all states.

title: Economic Scene;   Refiners' Bid For Protection
description: EIGHT years ago the United States imported 8.8 million barrels of oil a day, about 48 percent of its total needs. Alarmed by such heavy dependence on foreign suppliers, President Jimmy Carter started a program of price decontrol and other steps that he said would guarantee that the 1977 import level would never be exceeded.

title: SCREEN: 'REMBETIKO'
description: COSTAS FERRIS'S ''Rembetiko'' has a firmer place in the annals of Greek musicology than it does in filmdom, since it is primarily an attempt to trace the origins of the dolorous, Eastern-influenced popular music for which it is named. Along the way, the film attempts to dramatize some important events in 20th-century Greek history and to offer a biography of a famous rembetiko singer named Marika Ninou. It is least successful when it tries to commingle all three of these threads, since it does this in such a confused and fancifully meandering style. It works best when the characters, all of them musicians, simply play and sing.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,089,000 for the quarter and $2,113,000 for the nine months.

title: Subway-Car Work Is Called a Failure
description: A $60 million program to overhaul 400 20-year-old subway cars was termed a failure yesterday by the inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Chrysler Engines
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would invest $150 million to increase four-cylinder engine capcaity at its Trenton, Mich., plant to more than one million engines a year, from 800,000 engines.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CAVOUR. A Biography. By Denis Mack Smith. 294 pages. Knopf. $18.95.

title: OFFICERS CLEARED BY GRAND JURORS IN MENGEL DEATH
description: A Dutchess County grand jury concluded today that a state trooper was justified in killing Alex Mengel, who was accused of murdering a Westchester County police officer and a Mount Vernon woman.

title: Fine Called 'Insult'
description: The $1,500 fine assessed against Akeem Olajuwon of Houston for striking Billy Paultz of the Utah Jazz in the fifth and deciding game of the playoff series won by the Jazz is an ''insult'' and could lead to more violence on the court, said David Checketts, the president of the Jazz.

title: JUDGES SAYS U.S. NEED NOT AID AGENT ORANGE FUND
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the United States Government could not be forced to contribute to a $180 million fund to aid Vietnam War veterans who say they were harmed by Agent Orange.

title: SLAYING ADMITTED BY MOUNTAIN MAN
description: The father of a 20-year-old man on trial for abducting and wounding an athlete admitted today that he himself had shot and killed the woman's would-be rescuer.

title: MOSCOW, MARKING 1945 VICTORY, GIVES WAR NEW PLACE IN HISTORY
description: The Soviet Union marked the 40th anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany with parades today, after a year of commemorations that have confirmed the ''Great Patriotic War'' as one of the primary events in Soviet history.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $3,320,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,457,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: BROADWAY
description: IF wishing and talking and jetting across the Atlantic can make it so, the newest works by two important English playwrights should be on American shores in a year or so. The two works are the hottest tickets in London: popular with critics and playing to packed houses at the National Theater complex.

title: MAN CONVICTED OF KILLING WIFE WHO BEGGED TO DIE
description: Roswell Gilbert was convicted today of killing his incurably ill 73-year-old wife in what he called an act of love and what the prosecutor called a calculated murder.

title: HOW THE SENATE VOTED ON BUDGET
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate gave tentative approval to a 1986 budget endorsed by President Reagan. A 49-to-49 vote was broken by Vice President Bush, who voted for the package:

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $8 million. c-Including a tax credit of $1 million and a securities exchange gain of $4,057,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have a clear understanding with Mayor Koch. He can't raise money here, but I can raise money there.''

title: BONN TELLS OF RUMANIAN PLAN TO BOMB RADIO
description: The West German Government, in an unusual description of purported criminal activity by Soviet bloc diplomats, today disclosed details of a planned bomb attack on the Munich headquarters of Radio Free Europe.

title: Of Local Talent
description: Unlike other large art museums in Washington with national and international focus, the Corcoran Gallery has tried to devote a share of its attention to local artists and their contemporary work. Ever since World War II, the gallery has periodically held an exhibition of painting and sculpture by residents of the area.

title: RANGER OIL LTD (CANADA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $2,495,000 on the repurchase of some debentures.

title: Interest Rates Down Slightly
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday as the Treasury completed the final portion of this week's Government financings with a $6 billion auction of 11 1/4 percent bonds due in 2015, which sold at an average yield of 11.38 percent.

title: PAN AM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANCE: LAR LUBOVITCH AT CITY CENTER
description: THERE must be something about Lar Lubovitch's choreography that attracts extremely good dancers - for these are the kind of dancers the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company always has. Certainly the troupe's current season, which ends Sunday afternoon, shows off some of modern dance's most polished performers.

title: Telephone Chief Adds Another Title
description: The Southern New England Telephone Company, which provides telephone service to most of Connecticut, said yesterday that its board had elected Walter H. Monteith Jr. chairman. He is already president and chief executive. The change takes place on July 1.

title: NEW FORD PUSH TO AUTOMATE
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it was buying an interest in a small company that it hopes can help provide the technology to coordinate production by computer - allowing Ford to cut back its white-collar factory staffing.

title: GIANTS DEFEATE CUBS ON TRILLO HIT IN 12TH
description: Manny Trillo's two-out single in the 12th inning snapped San Francisco's 24-inning scoreless streak and gave the Giants a 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: Cray Product
description: Cray Research Inc. said it plans to introduce its Cray 2 supercomputer in June.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including net gains of $85,000 for the latest first quarter and $807,000 for the year-ago first quarter on sales of real estate investments.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Willie Aikens, acquired by the Blue Jays from the Royals last year while still under suspension and serving a jail sentence for drug-related offenses, was put on waivers by Toronto for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. . . . Russ Rogers, the track coach at Fairleigh Dickinson University, has been named men's track coach of the United States World Cup team. . . . Len Nardone has resigned as basketball coach at Seattle University after questions were raised about budgeting practices in the men's basketball program. . . . Bernie Kosar, the quarterback of the University of Miami, officially made himself eligible for a special supplemental draft in a letter to Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League. . . . The Boston Bruins' captain, Terry O'Reilly, who is contemplating retirement, met yesterday with General Manager Harry Sinden. ''I don't want to hang on too long,''the veteran of 13 National Hockey League seasons said, adding that he had some thinking to do in the next few weeks.

title: COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
A Balanced Approach At F.C.&B.
description: THE annual report of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications includes a three-page essay entitled ''Analysis and Artistry.'' It deals with the information explosion and the proper utilization of the hemispheres of the brain, with the left handling analysis and the right, creativity.

title: Music to Her Ears
description: Two worlds collided yesterday under a scaffold on Fifth Avenue.

title: Police Seize Books in Korea
description: The police raided 28 printing shops and bookstores in Seoul today, confiscating books and pamphlets described as seditious and supportive of leftist ideologies, officials of the Culture and Information Ministry said.

title: 'Death in California,' 2-Part Thriller on ABC
description: ''Seems like every time I get really happy, something bad happens.'' The words belong to Hope Masters, an aspiring model, daughter of a well-to-do mother and herself a mother on the verge of her second divorce. And she is right.

title: Dance: Mixing Sound and Motion
description: Apart from the well-known Riverside Dance Festival, two noteworthy attractions of the uptown dance scene this weekend are taking place at Aaron Davis Hall at City College and at the Harkness Center.

title: EDMOND O'BRIEN, ACTOR, DIES AT 69
description: Edmond O'Brien, an Academy Award-winning actor whose 35-year movie career took him from leading roles in the 1940's to weather-beaten character roles in the 1970's, died yesterday in Inglewood, Calif. He was 69 years old.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including net realized gains of $10,482,000 for the latest first quarter and $16,169,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Stage: Broadway's Off Broadway
description: The Promenade Theater, an Off Broadway theater on Broadway -that's Upper Broadway between 76th and 77th Street (580-1313) - has become a thriving, twin-stage establishment. Its main theater, called the Promenade, has been a home for such shows as David Rabe's ''Hurlyburly'' and Stephen Sondheim's ''Pacific Overtures.''

title: MORE TESTS NEEDE TO ASSESS CONDITION OF HEART RECIPIENT
description: William J. Schroeder, the world's longest-living recipient of an artificial heart, is absorbing the blood that leaked into his brain this weekend and caused a stroke, but more tests are needed to give doctors a better idea of his condition, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Immune Deficiency Disorder Affects 10,000 in the Nation
description: More than 10,000 cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, have been diagnosed around the country, health officials said today, and the number of victims is expected to double in the next year.

title: ART: A SHOW OF WORKS GIVEN BY PHILIP JOHNSON
description: ''PHILIP JOHNSON: Selected Gifts'' at the Museum of Modern Art is a fascinating and, on at least one count, a provocative affair. It consists of 40 paintings and sculptures by 31 artists, all given to the museum by Mr. Johnson since 1942. The roster of artists includes some - Jasper Johns, Frank Stella and Neil Jenney among them - of whom Mr. Johnson has been a longtime champion. But it also includes many to whom he is not known to have a strong private commitment - Yves Klein, for instance, and Arman, Lucas Samaras, Jim Dine, Agnes Martin, Tom Wesselmann and others.

title: FOR FIGHTER PILOT, REALISM ON RANGE
description: Two F-4 fighter bombers streaking low above the Nevada desert were invisible from above until they flew over a snow-covered dry lake, their gray exhaust smoke showing clearly against the vivid white.

title: Higher Prizes At U.S. Open
description: The total prize money to be awarded at the United States Open tennis tournament this summer will rise by 19 percent.

title: Bomb Kills 3 in Lebanon
description: A suitcase stuffed with explosives blew up today in an apparent suicide bombing in southern Lebanon, killing the woman who carried the suitcase, a member of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army and his wife, Israeli military sources reported. They said that South Lebanon Army soldiers at a checkpoint near Hasbeya became suspicious of the woman at a crossroads nearby and that when they tried to question her, the suitcase exploded.

title: PANEL IS TOLD OF POOR MORALE IN JOB SAFETY ADMINISTRATION
description: Senior officials of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration who disagreed with the agency's policies were told that they were Communists, a House subcommittee was informed today.

title: Two Train Crewmen Indicted In Death of Teen-Ager on S.I.
description: Two crew members of a Staten Island Rapid Transit train that struck and killed a teen-ager last November have been indicted in the case, the Staten Island District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Hilton Voting
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said shareholders had approved several anti-takeover measures ''by wide margins,'' thus apparently blocking a possible takeover attempt by Golden Nugget Inc. The hotel company had said earlier this week that preliminary results indicated that the measures had won approval, but the annual meeting was adjourned until today for the official tally. The measures include an increase in the number of authorized shares to 90 million, from 60 million, and a so-called fair price amendment to insure that all stockholders would be eligible to receive the same price for their shares in any takeover-related dealings.

title: Falkland Airport to Open
description: A new $342 million airport will open this weekend on the Falkland Islands, giving Britain for the first time the ability to fly reinforcements into the disputed South Atlantic colony on short notice, the Government said today. Officials noted that a state of hostility still officially existed between Britain and Argentina, which claims the islands and seized them briefly in 1982 before being expelled by a British task force.

title: EASIER DOES BETTER
description: Despite the protests, President Reagan's trip to Europe worked out as a useful demonstration that the United States still gives prime concern to its Atlantic partners even though its Pacific links have greatly expanded.

title: Thanks From a Vet
description: To the Editor:

title: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOGUCHI AND HIS DREAM MUSEUM
description: AMONG the very few artists whose work is good enough to sustain a museum of its own, even fewer have had the spirit, will and consummate chutzpah to create one. An exception is Isamu Noguchi. After years of planning, the Japanese-American sculptor has realized a dream, to gather his art in a self-created setting that is also a work of art. The opening tomorrow of his Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum in Long Island City is a feat that surprises no one who knows this dynamic octogenarian, and a very special event in the cultural life of New York. It places permanently before us some 500 sculptures, models and photographs that range across the prolific 60-year career of one of the most versatile and inventive artists of our time.

title: PHILIP MORRIS CREDIT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue figures represent financing revenues.

title: Boules in the Park
description: Drumsticks twirling, trumpets swirling, the Chasseurs Alpins, the French military mountaineer corps, descended in full cry into Central Park yesterday. ''We surrender!'' cried Robert G. Wallace, holding a Perrier bottle aloft.

title: REMARK BY REAGAN ON LINCOLN BRIGADE PROMPTS IRE IN SPAIN
description: A remark by President Reagan about the Spanish Civil War in an interview more than six months ago created a furor during Mr. Reagan's visit to Spain this week.

title: Chase Econometrics
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has renewed negotiations with McGraw-Hill Inc., for the sale of Chase Econometrics, one of the nation's leading economic forecasting and consulting concerns, spokesmen for both companies confirmed yesterday.

title: FILM: 'RUSTLERS,' A SPOOF
description: HUGH WILSON'S ''Rustlers'

title: 5 on Spofford Staff Held in Drug Sales
description: Five employees of the Spofford Juvenile Center, including a counselor and a recreation director, have been arrested on charges of selling cocaine to other center employees, officials said yesterday.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS WARNS INVESTORS
description: Most shareholders in the Continental Illinois Corporation are likely to see their investment wiped out, the bank holding company said today.

title: BellSouth-I.B.M
description: The BellSouth Corporation's Advanced Systems Inc. subsidiary said it had agreed to market in nine Southeastern states products made by the International Business Machines Corporation. BellSouth said it would sell I.B.M. System/36 products as an authorized value-added remarketer and I.B.M. Personal Computers as an authorized value-added dealer for a variety of voice and data applications. A similar agreement with the Digital Equipment Corporation was announced earlier this year.

title: DUCK'S BREATH TROUPE: HUMOR FOR YUPPIES
description: In 1975, before they became public radio's unconventional funny men, they were just graduate students in Iowa. ''Saturday Night Live'' was in its first season, ''Monty Python'' was hitting its stride in this country, and the men called themselves the Duck's Breath Mystery Theater.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: LAWYERS usually are well-represented in dining rooms of the better restaurants around the country. To get an idea of where they like to go for business-related meals, the ABA Journal, published by the American Bar Association, sent a questionnaire to 8,000 lawyers asking: ''Where do you take important clients to lunch or dinner?'' In New York City, the choices were Lutece, the Four Seasons, Tavern on the Green and Windows on the World.

title: JUDGE ALLOWS INQUIRY INTO DENIAL OF RESUSCITATION
description: A judge ruled yesterday that the State Health Commissioner could proceed with a public hearing on charges that New York Hospital improperly withheld emergency lifesaving measures from an 87-year-old patient who suffered a heart attack and died last year.

title: CHAD THERAPEUTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
One of 3 Escapees Captured by Police
description: Westchester County and state police today captured one of three inmates who escaped Tuesday night from the County Jail in Valhalla, N.Y., after sawing through iron bars in a window and scaling two walls with a rope made of bed sheets.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
YOUTH IS MATURING LATER
description: This is a pivotal time in the lives of millions of American adolescents and their parents. It is that time of year when high school seniors find out where they have been accepted for college and parents discover what it will cost to send them there. In most cases, the four-year bill will run between $20,000 for the cheapest state colleges and nearly $70,000 at the most expensive private ones. Faced with such burdens, parents have every reason to ask: is it worth it?

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $7 million on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: Wheeling Steel
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation yesterday proposed substantial wage and benefit cuts for its employees, as a way to help the company out of bankruptcy proceedings, according to the United Steelworkers of America. The proposal is intended to reduce the company's labor costs to $15.20 an hour from $21.40 an hour, according to Russell Gibbons, a spokesman for the union. Ken Maxcy, a spokesman for the company, declined to comment.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: AT JOURNEY'S END, REAGAN'S NOT TOO TIRED TO JOKE
description: ''Someone suggested you were tired,'' President Reagan said with a smile this morning to a cluster of photographers and reporters crammed in the office of Prime Minister Mario Soares. ''Take the rest of the day off.'' After nine hectic days in West Germany, Spain and Portugal, with a stopover in France, Mr. Reagan was asked if he was exhausted. Breaking into a grin, spreading his hands in a gesture that made the answer obvious, the 74-year-old President replied, ''Youth is on my side.''

title: Parr Cited In Closing
description: Kenney & Branisel Inc., a small government securities dealer that formerly owned the Parr Securities Corporation, has stopped trading and has withdrawn from the market after Parr's collapse earlier this week.

title: PISTONS BUOYED BY LOSS
description: Emerging from the shower Wednesday night after the Celtics had beaten the Detroit Pistons, 130-123, in Boston Garden, Cedric Maxwell greeted reporters by saying: ''What was everybody worried about? They made it a little tough, but I told you they couldn't beat us.''

title: ART: FROM YOUNGERMAN, FIBERGLASS SCULPTURES
description: THREE years ago, Jack Youngerman created a stir by unleashing works unlike any he had done before. Called ''relief paintings,'' they mainly took the form of large whorls carved from polystyrene and painted in piercing, prismatic colors. Later on, the artist made the shapes more angular and reduced the number of colors, but otherwise he appeared set on a course.

title: Fairs and Festivals This Weekend
description: Village Schoolmart, P.S. 41, Greenwich Avenue, between West 10th and 11th Streets, tomorrow and every Saturday, from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Crafts, handmade and vintage clothing, antiques, jewelry, houseware, records.

title: El Salvador to Get 3 More C-47 Planes
description: The United States has sent the Salvadoran Air Force three additional C-47 airplanes capable of being converted into gunships, according to a spokesman for the United States Embassy here.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After gains from redemptions of debentures of $141,000 for the quarter and $360,000 for the year.

title: 'MALICE IN WONDERLAND,' A CBS FILM
description: LOUELLA PARSONS and Hedda Hopper, once the gossiping terrors of Hollywood, are being given the screen biographies they deserve. Less than an inch deep, ''Malice in Wonderland,'' on CBS-TV at 9 P.M. on Sunday, is as silly as any of their newspaper columns.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Home State Sale Gains
description: The Ohio Senate narrowly passed a bill today permitting the use of state funds to complete the sale of the failed Home State Savings Bank to Chemical New York Corporation. Senator David L. Hobson, the Senate sponsor, conceded that the bill stopped short of the $125.2 million Chemical had requested in state funds to help complete the deal. The House cut the state outlay to $92.1 million, and the Senate did not restore the reduction.

title: Rallying Round the Amtrak: Deficits and All
description: When the Reagan Administration began choosing Federal programs it wanted to eliminate to help reduce the deficit, its selection of Amtrak as easy pickings would seem to have been a logical choice.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Streetwise Streetwork
description: Jose is 21; Carmen is 17. They are an appealing young couple, proudly showing off snapshots of a beautiful baby daughter and full of hope for their future together. They are also the measure of success for a remarkable, if obscure, program of the city's Victim Services Agency.

title: Canada Gains In Cup Qualifier
description: Canada took a major step toward qualifying for soccer's World Cup in Mexico next summer, defeating Haiti, 2-0, Wednesday night in Port-au-Prince to advance to the final regional qualifying round.

title: INTER-CITY GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Players Are Punished
description: Lewis-Clark State College of Idaho has canceled its last three regular-season baseball games to punish players who attacked hecklers following a game with Washington State University, President Lee Vickers said.

title: THE BALLET: NEW LOVERS IN 'ROMEO'
description: THE American Ballet Theater presented yet another pair of lovers Wednesday afternoon in its popular new production of Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the Metropolitan Opera House. And in Bonnie Moore, a medalist at the International Ballet Competition in Varna, Bulgaria, who joined Ballet Theater last summer, the company has found a Juliet of exquisite gifts and extraordinary promise.

title: PEPOLE
description: * Claude Fromm has been promoted to senior vice president at TBWA Advertising.

title: FEW BIDDERS FORESEEN IF MURDOCH SELLS POST
description: If Rupert Murdoch puts The New York Post up for sale, as expected, the list of bidders is likely to be short and the price relatively low, industry analysts said yesterday.

title: SENATOR BRINGS A VOTE FROM HIS HOSPITAL BED
description: Senator Pete Wilson, Republican of California, provided a note of drama in a tension-filled evening in the Capitol as he left his hospital bed in order to cast his vote for President Reagan's 1986 budget.

title: PEROT FORMALIZES OFFER ON MUSEUM
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer executive who earlier said he would use $70 million of his own money to relocate the Museum of the American Indian from New York to Dallas, yesterday said he would try to raise the funds from private and public sources.

title: House G.O.P. Presses Drive
description: House Republicans have opened a new round of ''guerrilla warfare'' against the Democratic leadership, attacking the way the daily account of House and Senate actions and debates are printed in the Congressional Record.

title: Hospital Is Accused Of Selective Life-Saving
description: Two legal advocacy groups accused an Oklahoma children's hospital Wednesday of withholding life-saving treatment from severely handicapped infants whose families were deemed unable to care for them properly.

title: IRREGULARITIES IN STATE LEASES CITED BY PANEL
description: Investigators have uncovered evidence of irregularities in the leasing of three office buildings in New York City by the State Office of General Services, officials of the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Transmedia Card At Hicks & Greis
description: Want another piece of plastic for your wallet? Here comes the Transmedia Network of Miami, whose Transmedia Executive Card promises, for a special rate of only $25 a year, to give you a 25 percent discount on a variety of goods and services.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Motley's Canaries
description: When prominent Government officials decide to leave their jobs without warning, they usually offer such prosaic reasons as making more money in the private sector or spending more time with their families.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE restaurant tidal wave that has been rolling across Manhattan has finally lapped upon the rough and rocky shores of upper Broadway, from about 80th Street northward. La Mirabelle, a little pearl of a French restaurant ensconced in a thread-worn aristocratic hotel residence on West 86th Street, is a far cry from the splashy pastel grilleries that are becoming ubiquitous on the Upper West Side. La Mirabelle is about as chic as a pair of brown brogues, and any inquiry about mesquite would probably yield the response ''Eat lots of garlic and they won't sting you.''

title: The District Of a New Columbia
description: The problem, the Mayor's office here says, is that Government has given this town a bad name.

title: AMF Anti-Takeover Device
description: In response to a hostile takeover bid by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs, AMF Inc. notified shareholders yesterday of its own offer to buy back shares if Mr. Jacobs or any other party acquires control of the company on an unfriendly basis.

title: $67.5 Million of Bonds Offered by Mesa, Ariz.
description: Mesa, Ariz., remarkable for its rapid growth and the absence of a real estate property tax, is offering $41.1 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Northern Trust Company and $26.4 million of utility revenue bonds through Salomon Brothers.

title: PACIFICORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOW RISES BY 10.49 IN TECHNICAL RALLY
description: Wall Street staged an impressive technical rally yesterday as it continued on its up-one-day, down-the-next journey. Technology and aerospace issues rose strongly.

title: Arab Cooperation Urged
description: The third Arab Energy Conference ended in Algiers today with appeals for more intensive Arab cooperation in the energy sector and an end to restrictive practices by industrial states.

title: RECITAL: JEAN FONDA, PIANIST
description: The disappointments of Jean Fonda's recital at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night did not lie in his competence as a pianist - although in Beethoven's Sonata (Op. 110) and the Schumann ''Symphonic Etudes'' Mr. Fonda often seemed clutching on for dear life rather than holding technical problems firmly in hand.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Art: In Galleries, A Personal Touch
description: Above 57th Street, art changes. The galleries tend to be quieter. The works they show are less driven by the relentless, sometimes frantic rhythms of New York City. Apart from galleries like Knoedler, Xavier Fourcade and Willard, we are not likely to encounter work in uptown galleries that has the scale, hipness and self-consciousness identified with so much mainstream New York art since World War II.

title: Dining Out Guide: New American Cooking
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AN AMERICAN PLACE, #969 Lexington Avenue, at 71st Street (517-7660) -

title: HORATIO ALGER STORIES BROUGHT ALIVE FOR STUDENTS
description: Several company presidents, chief executive officers and board chairmen who, in the best tradition of Horatio Alger's stories, raised themselves up by their bootstraps, gave some Manhattan high school students a lesson yesterday in how to do what they did.

title: 'Real Thing' Closing
description: ''The Real Thing,'' the Tony award-winning play by Tom Stoppard, will close after its matinee Sunday at the Plymouth Theater. The drama, directed by Mike Nichols, will have had 566 regular performances and 16 previews.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 10, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Sperry, Tandy Mexican Pacts
description: Two large American computer concerns, the Tandy Corporation and the Sperry Corporation, said yesterday that they had signed agreements with Mexican companies to produce personal computers there for the Latin American market.

title: SHULTZ URGES A PALESTINIAN ROLE IN TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, asserting that Palestinian participation in negotiations with Israel was ''essential'' for a lasting Middle East settlement, said today that he would discuss with Israeli and Arab leaders in coming days the names of Palestinians who might be acceptable to all sides.

title: BEETHOVEN LETTER AUCTIONED
description: A letter from Ludwig van Beethoven to the woman identified by recent research as his mysterious ''Immortal Beloved,'' was sold for the equivalent of $67,100 yesterday, Sotheby's auction house said.

title: Williams Project
description: A $26 million project to use existing petroleum products pipelines to bring fiber optics communications to a large area in the Middle West was announced today by officials of the Williams Companies.

title: Senate Vote Sends Budget to O'Neill
description: A $3.95 billion state budget that would increase spending by about 8 percent in the fiscal year beginning July 1 was given final legislative approval today by the State Senate. The vote was 35 to 1.

title: GRAHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Extradition of Smuggling Suspect Is Sought
description: Justice Department and Customs Service officials said today that they were seeking to extradite from Britain a West German citizen charged with illegally exporting high-technology equipment to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries.

title: LEBANON MILITIA REJECTS CHIEF
description: Christian militia leaders shunted aside their chief tonight, under pressure from Syria, and replaced him with Elie Hobeika, the man Israel blames for massacres at two Palestinian refugee camps in 1982.

title: PRETORIA CANCELS SETTLEMENT PLAN
description: The authorities have announced what appears to be a reprieve for an estimated 700,000 blacks living in 52 townships once threatened by forced uprooting to tribal homelands.

title: HOUSE PANEL AGAIN REBUFFS REAGAN ON AID TO THE REBELS
description: The House Intelligence Committee, meeting in secret session, rebuffed President Reagan today and voted to continue a ban on all military assistance to the rebels in Nicaragua for an additional year.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $1.8 billion, to $210.13 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Crown Zellerbach Claims a Victory
description: The management of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation claimed today to have won an ''overwhelming victory'' in a proxy fight against the financier Sir James Goldsmith.

title: The High Cost of Encouraging Foreign Investors
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNSHINE-JR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Kennedy Center Aide Gets California Post
description: The director of operations at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Thomas R. Kendrick, was named today as executive director of the Orange County Performing Arts Center in Southern California.

title: SEASON IS SHORTER FOR STRIPED BASS
description: The 1985 season for taking striped bass in New York State marine waters - May 8 through Nov. 30 - opened three weeks later and closes 15 days earlier than last year.

title: SCREEN: 'THE EIGHTIES'
description: ''The Eighties'' was shown as part of the 1983 New York Film Festival with the title of ''The Golden Eighties.'' Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2, 1983. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. IN the first section of Chantal Akerman's ''Golden Eighties,'' a number of actors are seen on videotape, rehearsing lines that are intentionally absurd. The camera studies the auditioners intently as they invest meaningless dialogue with unwarranted passion (''Actually red is not my color, you see,'' one woman declares emotionally in a clothing store). They seem to be speaking about a broken love affair, a tryst that takes place in a shop's dressing room, and the glories of Canada, among other things. The screenplay is by Miss Akerman and Jean Gruault, whose motives here are no less obscure than those of their characters.

title: Baldrige's Trip
description: Despite attempts by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger to postpone a key stop on the trip, Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige is to take off today on a 13-day foreign mission that will include the first high-level trade talks with the Soviet Union since 1978. Among the subjects on the agenda is possible expanded trade between the two nations in nonstrategic materials, include sale by the United States of oil-drilling technology.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amerada Hess Corp. stockholders have approved a package of six bylaw amendments intended to make an unfriendly takeover more difficult.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AS POLES RECALL WAR'S SUFFERING, GOVERNMENT STRESSES SOVIET AID
description: The Polish Government marked the 40th anniversary of the end of the war in Europe today by stressing the Soviet role in the defeat of the Nazis.

title: Suspect in a Rightist Group Denies Racketeering Counts
description: A purported member of a neo-Nazi group suspected of the machine-gun slaying of Alan Berg, a radio talk show host in Denver, pleaded not guilty Wednesday to two Federal counts of racketeering.

title: Roof of Pool Collapses Near Zurich, Killing 13
description: The roof of a public swimming pool in this suburb of Zurich collapsed today, killing at least 13 people and injuring five, the police said.

title: Man Gets Immunity But Later Is Charged
description: The police granted diplomatic immunity to a local restaurant owner here after the man, when stopped on the road, pulled out leather-embossed documents and identified himself as an attache from Malta, an official said.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
OPENING OF DISCO CHALLENGED
description: Plans to open a multimillion-dollar discotheque on the East Side next week were challenged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday by a citizen who questioned the involvement of two men who have been prominent promoters of the venture.

title: An Attention-Getter
description: ''It's meant to attract attention,'' asserted one of a half-dozen young men with shaved heads talking amicably with curious passers-by at Broadway and 50th Street. It was doing just that.

title: BILL TO SPLIT GETTY TRUST IS SIGNED IN CALIFORNIA
description: A bill permitting the division of the Getty trust has been signed into law, but it is unclear whether disputing members of the family have agreed to a formula for sharing the $4 billion family legacy.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY REAGAN IN LISBON LISBON, May 9 (AP) - Following are excerpts from a speech today by President Reagan to the Portuguese Assembly of the Republic:
description: For us, a long journey is ending now, but one fruitful in results and rich in memory. World leaders in summit conference, the youth of modern Germany, warm welcomes at the European Parliament and in Spain -all these things we have seen and been grateful for.

title: Election Projection Protection
description: We promise that we will not project, predict, suggest, hint, or characterize the outcome of Presidential elections in any state until the polls have closed in that state. With words to that effect, the television networks have now closed the back door on a problem that has repeatedly shadowed election nights - the danger of unduly influencing voters who have not yet gone to the polls.

title: REAGAN, IN LISBON, SAYS COMMUNISM IS ON THE DECLINE
description: President Reagan told the Portuguese Parliament today that he had ''heard the voice of the 20th century'' on his visit to Europe and that Communism was losing out to democracy.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: Results are for 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 14 and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: PHILHARMONIC: SALMINEN SINGS 'BORIS' EXCERPTS
description: ON a day when the Soviet Union was celebrating its own hermetic version of VE-Day, the New York Philharmonic added a splash of color to the occasion by presenting a concert made up of two of the great monuments to Russian patriotism. Perhaps it was planned that way as a generous hands-across-the-Elbe gesture, though no mention of the World War II anniversary was made in the program book's extensive list of credits. More likely it was happenstance. In any event, political connotations aside, the pairing of Prokofiev's ''Alexander Nevsky'' and excerpts from Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov'' made for an evening of stirring sounds.

title: RISE IN OIL IMPORTS IS FORESEEN
description: Oil industry executives said today that reduced estimates of recoverable oil and gas reserves off Alaska and other areas of the outer continental shelf mean that oil imports will increase in the future.

title: Paraguay TV Said to Permit Appeal in Hunt for Mengele
description: Serge Klarsfeld, a French Nazi-hunter, said yesterday that Paraguay had agreed to publicize the hunt for Josef Mengele on television.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: THE Spanish guitar has conquered far more territory than the Spanish kings. It is portable, adaptable, dulcet and polyphonic - no wonder the guitar has become the international instrument. The tunings may change, and a player might use fingers, fingerpicks or plectrum; a microphone or electronic pickups may amplify the music beyond the reach of natural, hollow-body resonance. But the basic principles of strings and frets, plucking and strumming, have affected musical cultures almost everywhere.

title: Sports of The Times Passing the Course
description: Sometime early today, a senior at Villanova University will type the final footnote of his final paper of his final class of his final semester. The paper will be entitled: Drama in Sports Commentary.

title: ILLINOIS HEARINGS OPEN IN '77 RAPE CASE
description: A man who has spent six years in prison on a rape conviction and the woman who now says she falsely accused him publicly appealed to Gov. James R. Thompson today to end what the prisoner called ''the nightmare of his imprisonment''by releasing him.

title: MARYLAND THRIFT UNIT HAS A RUN
description: One of Maryland's biggest savings and loan associations suffered a run on deposits yesterday after its management was changed and reports were published hinting that the institution might be in trouble.

title: AMC ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCREEN: 'SECRET PLACES'
description: ''SECRET PLACES,'' set in the late 1930's and early 1940's, is a small, decently acted, very solemn English movie about two very dissimilar teen-age schoolgirls and their friendship, which almost - but not quite - turns into a wartime romance.

title: TEMPLETON WORLD FUND LTD reports earnings for As of April 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: TEMPLETON FOREIGN FUND reports earnings for As of April 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WHAT'S UP UPTOWN: CRITICS EXPLORE THE LATEST
description: Have you ever shopped for records at midnight on West 66th Street? Discovered a block that now has 10 movie theaters? Browsed through the new used book stores in the West 80's and 90's? Strolled through the latest art galleries on Madison Avenue? Or sampled African delicacies on Manhattan's newest restaurant row?

title: STAGE: 'FEAST OR FAMINE'
description: ON screen, in slow motion, an apparently disembodied hand reaches out toward a loaf of bread, plucks a piece of it, then withdraws. The bread seems to affix itself magnetically to the fingers. The sequence, repeated several times, reminds one of a robot arm adjusting a rocket in space. The point, well taken, is that there is a mechanistic as well as a ritualistic aspect to eating. As Sondra Segal, the author and star of ''Feast or Famine,'' says, ''Food was my first language.''

title: Chairman to Step Down At Western Airlines
description: Lawrence H. Lee, whose leadership of Western Airlines is widely credited with reviving the carrier's fortunes, told the company's annual meeting yesterday that he would step down as chairman at the end of the year.

title: Music: Glass First, Schutz's Birthday
description: Godfrey Reggio's ''Koyaanisqatsi'' is, to put it mildly, an unusual film. There is no dialogue and no plot as such; instead, ''Koyaanisqatsi'' is an extended, Spenglerian meditation on contemporary civilization, accompanied by the brightly hypnotic music of Philip Glass.

title: AIDE TO REAGAN SAYS SUMMIT MEETING IS PROBABLE
description: President Reagan's chief of staff today discounted a tough exchange of speeches by the President and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, on Wednesday as political ''positioning'' with their allies and asserted that there ''probably'' would be a summit meeting between the two leaders despite the polemics.

title: KATYUSHAS AND MISSILES IN RED SQUARE
description: Military equipment from World War II and new weapons displayed for the first time mingled today in Red Square as the Soviet Union marked the 40th anniversary of victory over Nazi Germany.

title: Pan Am Lost $138.7 Million
description: The Pan American Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $138.7 million in the first quarter mainly as a result of the monthlong strike by the Transport Workers Union that severely disrupted service.

title: Warner Unit May Get Bid
description: The Motown Record Corporation said it was considering buying the recorded music division of Warner Communications Inc.

title: INQUIRY WORRIES BASEBALL
description: Baseball people, on both the management and the players' union sides, are increasingly concerned about what the current grand jury drug investigation in Pittsburgh may produce. Today, Don Baylor, long active in players' union activities, said he thought the outcome could be devastating to some players.

title: CONSOLIDATED PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 10
description: b-After an extraordinary tax charge of $54,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $140,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income. d-Including a tax credit of $207,000.

title: LEARNING TO SHARE: COED SUITES ON CAMPUS
description: When someone asks Monica Marks, a Barnard College senior, if she had any uneasy moments living in a coed apartment this semester, she recalls ''the mask incident.'' It occurred one day when she rubbed a white cosmetic mask onto her face, forgot about it and walked into the kitchen where she surprised one of her male suite mates.

title: THACKERAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $285,000 for the latest quarter and $29,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: JAPAN AGREES TO PARTICIPATE IN U.S. SPACE STATION
description: The United States and Japan have signed an agreement calling for cooperation in the preliminary design of a space station to be built by the United States, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: ICAHN HAS 20% STAKE IN T.W.A.
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, disclosed yesterday that a group he controls owned 20.53 percent of Trans World Airlines Inc. and might seek control.

title: Statoil-Exxon
description: Kaare Kristiansen, Norway's Oil and Energy Minister, said he expects the Government to approve the purchase by Statoil of two Exxon Corporation subsidiaries, Esso Invest A.B. and Esso Chemical A.B. of Sweden, for $260 million. The deal will give the state-owned Statoil all of Esso's 422 retail gasoline stations in Sweden, representing a market share of 9 percent, and an ethylene factory in Stenungsund, Sweden.

title: Munitions Truck Crashes
description: Homes and businesses north of here were evacuated for about five hours today while soldiers from Fort Knox and other workers removed a shipment of mortar shells from a truck that crashed today on I-65. The wreckage was moved to an isolated stretch of Route 31-W, where shells were loaded on another truck. The driver and a passenger were injured, the police said.

title: BRASILIA GOT THE CAPITAL, BUT THE BEACHES STAY PUT
description: It was 25 years ago that Rio de Janeiro was cruelly stripped of its title and left to live off its grace and beauty. Yet a secret yearning to be Brazil's capital lives on here.

title: SYNCHRONIZING THE CLOCKS: EXTRA SECOND FOR JUNE 30
description: Take heed: The 61-second minute is coming.

title: Ford Layoffs
description: The Ford Motor Company said it will place 2,000 hourly workers at its Atlanta assembly plant on temporary layoff beginning next week while the plant is being converted to build the company's new midsized front-wheel-drive cars, the Ford Taurus and the Mercury Sable.

title: WYNEGAR SHOT BEATS ROYALS
description: The fifth spot in a team's batting order generally is given to a player who can hit some home runs and drive in runs. Butch Wynegar does not fit that description, but Billy Martin has put him in the fifth spot when the Yankees have faced a left-handed starting pitcher.

title: O'Grady Takes a 3-Shot Lead
description: Mac O'Grady, exuberant on the course but silent off it, shot a two-under-par 69 today to take a three-stroke lead after two rounds of the $500,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: Loans for Your Broker
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTROL LASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Glenn Jusuf, a Banker, Weds Nurilmi Padang
description: Nurilmi Padang, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Achmad D. Padang of Fresh Meadows, Queens,, was married yesterday to Glenn Jusuf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sufri Jusuf of Colombo, Sri Lanka. Mahmoud Ileiwat, an imam from the Islamic Center of New York, performed the ceremony at the Padang home.

title: Plant Again Using Deadly Chemical
description: Production of pesticides resumed today using the deadly chemical methyl isocynate at an F. M. C. Corporation plant where a leak had forced the evacuation of a nearby school when a malfunctioning pump spilled 40 gallons of the chemical and released fumes.

title: Walk in the Park
description: Early risers with a fondness for athletics and for Central Park have a treat in store tomorrow morning. Then again, so do late risers of the same persuasion.

title: J. H. Holloman Dead; Ex-Oklahoma U. Head
description: J. Herbert Hollomon, a former president of the University of Oklahoma, died Wednesday, college officials confirmed today. He was 66 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, MAY 11, 1985

title: Letter: On Indiana Politics;   The House Seats the Winner
description: To the Editor:

title: Los Angeles Squatters Evicted by the Police
description: A dozen ragged residents of a squatters' community of cardboard shacks were arrested for trespassing today as squads of police moved in to evict them and hundreds of onlookers chanted, ''There's no place called home.''

title: DESIGN OF HOLOCAUST MUSEUM UNVEILED
description: The United States Holocaust Memorial Council today unveiled plans for a $30 million museum and archive to document the slaughter of millions of Jews and members of other ethnic groups by Nazi Germany.

title: Briefing On Hutton Case Held
description: Justice Department prosecutors said today that they had no evidence that high-ranking executives of E.F. Hutton & Company had participated criminally in the complex, multimillion-dollar fraud to which the company pleaded guilty last week.

title: NO WORD ON SKHAROV ACTION
description: Andrei D. Sakharov had declared today the deadline when he would quit the Soviet Academy of Sciences unless it took action on his behalf, but the day passed with no news from the academy or Mr. Sakharov's supporters.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income

title: REAGAN DEFENDS LIMIT ON INCREASE IN MILITARY FUNDS
description: President Reagan said today that he had agreed to the limit on military spending in the budget approved by the Senate early this morning after receiving a promise that he could come back for more money if he found that the national security was being harmed.

title: EMC INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a realized investment loss of $5,036,000. c-After a realized investment gain of $469,784.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BROWN, ROBERT C. & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REUTERS CONSIDERS MAKING BID TO BUY U.P.I.
description: The managing director of Reuters confirmed yesterday that the London-based news service was considering making a bid for United Press International.

title: STAGE WAS SET FOR DRAMA AT CAPITOL
description: The tie-breaking vote arrived by limousine, but the key vote came by ambulance, and, as finales go, even Cecil B. De Mille could not have staged a more dramatic climax to the Senate's battle of the budget.

title: Here Comes WAND
description: A nother nuclear disarmament lobbying group is setting up shop in Washington.

title: LEVITT IS SAID TO WEIGH A BID FOR VILLAGE VOICE
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the American Stock Exchange, is among those considering making a bid to purchase The Village Voice, the New York-based weekly owned by Rupert Murdoch, a source close to Mr. Levitt said yesterday.

title: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for 12 wks to April 20
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,100,000 on the future sale of the assets of the company's geophysical data acquisition crew operations. c-Net income.

title: HECK'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The present Holy Father is almost charismatic. His way of being with people - and I've experienced this myself - is to enable them to realize that in spite of the differences of opinion, we are called upon to be one church.

title: Flood Bursts Brazilian Dam
description: More than 7,000 people were left homeless when floodwaters burst a dam in northeast Brazil on Thursday and swept through a half-mile-wide strip of land. Civil Defense sources said today that 2.6 billion cubic feet of water was released when the dam gave way.

title: A SEARCH FOR STARDOM IN LOUNGES OF NEW CLUB
description: ''I,'' the young woman proudly announced, ''am an audio engineer.''

title: VON BULOW JUDGE REJECTS MOTION TO DISMISS CHARGE
description: Lawyers for Claus von Bulow lost their fight to dismiss one of the two assault charges against him today, but they won permission for a Newport doctor to tell the jury that he thought lack of oxygen rather than an insulin injection caused the defendant's wife's first coma, in 1979.

title: PIONEER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a stock split effected in the form of a 200 percent stock dividend paid June 15, 1984.

title: CELTICS TOP PISTONS TO WIN SERIES IN 6
description: This has not been an easy playoff season for the defending champion Boston Celtics. They captured a series-clinching 123-113 victory tonight over the pesky Detroit Pistons, but left one important question unanswered: How much do the Celtics have left?

title: STAKES HIGH IN ITALIAN LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: If ever anyone could claim to have an office with a view, it is Ugo Vetere, the Mayor of Rome.

title: WRITER OF FANTISIES
description: Theodore Sturgeon, a leading figure in American science fiction, died Wednesday of lung ailments in Eugene, Ore. He was 67 years old.

title: REAGAN HAILS BUDGET PLAN AS A 'SIGNAL'
description: President Reagan hailed the Senate budget compromise today as an important ''signal'' to financial markets and sought to explain why he had accepted changes on military spending and Social Security that he had earlier called unacceptble.

title: Even in Exile, a Yankee Fan Is Never Sad
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Continental Illinois Corporation incorrectly described the shareholders who would be affected if a portfolio of bad loans assumed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation incurred losses beyond a certain level.

title: Mideast Prisoner Swap Is Reportedly Planned
description: A Palestinian commando group is to exchange three Israeli soldiers next week for 1,800 Palestinians and Lebanese held by Israel, Palestinian sources said tonight.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized capital losses of $19,351 for the latest first quarter and $303,071 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: 3 NATIONS JOINING TO HUNT MENGELE
description: The United States, West Germany and Israel announced a coordinated effort yesterday to track down and prosecute Josef Mengele, the elusive Nazi death-camp doctor.

title: FOOD IS LOWER
description: Rising energy costs sent the Producer Price Index up three-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department said today. Food prices, however, fell at the sharpest rate in a year.

title: SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN'S LISBON NEWS CONFERENCE AND WASHINGTON REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's news conference in Lisbon yesterday, as recorded by The Associated Press, and a transcript of his statement on his arrival in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SUPRADUR COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Beirut Fighting Rages After a Brief Lull
description: Christian and Moslem militiamen continued their battle for control of Beirut today despite selection of a new Christian militia leader in an effort to halt sectarian warfare.

title: A LITERARY DIVERSION
description: More than 250 people spent their lunch hour the other day listening to John Irving read from his latest novel and talk about abortion, literary criticism and writing.

title: SPARKMAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. LIST FOR BOOK FAIR IN MOSCOW IS DISPUTED
description: Four months before the Moscow International Book Fair is scheduled to open in the Soviet Union, the 300 American books picked to be displayed at the fair, and listed in an accompanying English-Russian language catalogue, have been criticized as ideologically unbalanced.

title: MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CNN Drops Sandi Freeman
description: Sandi Freeman, whose nightly program ''the Freeman Report'' has been one of the Cable News Network's mainstays for the last five years, and who has interviewed a long parade of authors, heads of state and movie stars, this week joined the former CNN commentator Daniel Schorr as the latest CNN employee to have an unrenewed contract.

title: Resignation at Tulane
description: Roy Danforth, former basketball coach at Syracuse and Tulane, has resigned as assistant athletic director in charge of fund raising at Tulane. Danforth said he had been told that the Green Wave Club - the fund-raising arm of Tulane's athletic department - would henceforth be operated by the development office, which handles nonathletic fund raising.

title: DIVIDED DUTCH CHURCH AWAITS POPE
description: Pope John Paul II is to arrive in the Netherlands on Saturday for the start of a pastoral visit, and Roman Catholic leaders say he will find a deeply divided church that includes large elements actively hostile to the Vatican's positions on key issues.

title: Overcoming A Mental Block
description: Sid Fernandez, who bombed at spring training, then blossomed anew at Tidewater, and who makes his season debut for the Mets against Philadelphia this afternoon, talked the other day about overcoming mental problems - much more than mechanical ones - in his effort to get back to the bigs. ''Pitching,'' he said, ''is almost 80 percent mental.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about uptown art shows and an accompanying map key gave an incorrect address for the Center for African Art. It is at 54 East 68th Street.

title: Greek Archeologists Unearth Vast Palace
description: Archeologists digging at Pella, the birthplace of Alexander the Great, are unearthing a vast building complex that may be the largest ancient palace in the Mediterranean.

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR SHOPPERS IN PARIS, DOLLAR STILL BUYS MORE
description: Everyone who goes to Paris does some shopping - or at least that is what everyone back home assumes. And the dollar, although it may not command quite as many francs as it did earlier this year, is still strong enough to make some French prices bargains.

title: 2 Plead Guilty in Plot to Kill Ex-Husband to Get Insurance
description: A Queens woman and a 73-year-old man from Merrick, L.I., pleaded guilty today to charges stemming from what authorities said was a plot to kill the woman's ex-husband and collect a $200,000 insurance policy on his life.

title: SNYDER OIL PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Indianapolis 500 pole-position qualifying. Tom Sneva won the pole position last year but failed to defend his title as Rick Mears won the race. (Television -Channel 7, 5 P.M.) Monza 1,000 Endurance Race, at Monza, Italy. Formula I race featuring Niki Lauda and Alain Prost (Television -ESPN, 1 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 1:20 P.M. Sid Fernandez, promoted from the minors, is scheduled to start today's game, and the Mets are hoping he can fill in for the injured Bruce Berenyi. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. pregame and 1:15 Radio - WHN 1050, 1:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, 4:05 P.M. Dennis Rasmussen, who won the opener of the series in Yankee Stadium last weekend to start the Yankee sweep of the Royals, starts the middle game of this three-game set. (Television -Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.) Basketball Los Angeles Lakers vs. Denver Nuggets, at Inglewood, Calif. Game 1 of the four-of-seven Western Conference Championships. The last time the Lakers lost a game at home was Jan. 30. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Football Invaders vs. Los Angeles Express, at Oakland.(Television - ESPN 6 P.M.) Stallions vs. Portland Breakers, at Birmingham. This is the second game of a U.S.F.L. television doubleheader. (Television - ESPN 9 P.M.) Tennis Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions, at West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. Semifinal round, 12:15 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M. live.)

title: RIVER OAK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FOSTER PARENTS CONTRADICT WOMAN WHO SAYS RAPE 'DIDN'T HAPPEN'
description: By their bursts of sustained applause during a clemency hearing, most members of the audience left no doubt what they wanted: a full pardon for Gary E. Dotson, the man who has spent six years in prison for a rape that his accuser now says never happened.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRAWING CARDS The National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, opens an exhibition this weekend, through June 23, of 60 drawings and watercolors by John Singer Sargent (1856-1925), who was a member. His fame as a painter has caused his assiduity as a draftsman to be overlooked.

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERCAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $410,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $770,000 from discontinued operations. The revenue figure for the year-ago quarter has been restated to conform with the 1985 presentation.

title: BALLET: PENNSYLVANIA CHANGES 'SYLPHIDE' CAST
description: One of the greatest surviving examples of Romantic choreography was paired with a contemporary choreographer's interpretation of Romantic piano music at the Pennsylvania Ballet's performance Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The authentically Romantic choreography proved more persuasive than the contemporary impressions of Romanticism.

title: POLE SAYS U.S. SPONSORS SUBVERSION
description: The Interior Minister, in a speech to Parliament assessing the state of public order, today accused the secret services of the United States and other Western countries of sponsoring political subversion in Poland.

title: BUDGET IMPROVEMENTS CITED BY NEW YORK AREA OFFICIALS
description: Officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut said today that they were pleased the Senate had spurned many of the deepest cuts in aid to local governments proposed by President Reagan. But they expressed concerned about reductions in urban programs and in the Senate's hint of further cuts.

title: UNITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $737,443 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: ZEUS COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $175,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to April 14
Lesson in Honor
description: For 92 years, Princeton University has required students to subscribe to an honor code. They pledge not to cheat on exams and to report anyone who does. A student panel adjudicates violations. The code, says William J. Brennan 3d, a university lawyer, is ''an integral part of Princeton and the way Princeton defines itself.'' Thanks to a Federal judge in Newark, it will remain so.

title: RABBINICAL GROUP BARS 51 ISRAELIS
description: Fifty-one members of Israel's Parliament ''are no longer welcome as speakers or honorees'' at the 850 Conservative Jewish congregations in the United States, the Rabbinical Assembly announced yesterday. Those banned include Ariel Sharon, Minister of Trade and Industry, and Yitzhak Shamir, the Foreign Minister.

title: CURBS GIVE WAY TO WELCOME FOR MULTINATIONAL COMPANIES
description: Just a decade ago, multinational companies were widely viewed as a scourge of the third world. Alarmed by the companies' intrusions into local politics and overwhelmed by their economic might, many countries nationalized foreign holdings or placed tight restrictions on new investments.

title: 'Honeymooners' at Museum
description: With a program that began yesterday, men and women who want to become raiders of the lost ''Honeymooners'' can line up at the Museum of Broadcasting, which has received permission to show 17 of the excavated episodes Jackie Gleason found in his vaults this year. The museum will switch its program once every two weeks, and allow visitors to commune with Ralph and Alice Kramden and Ed and Trixie Norton through Sept. 26.

title: 'Comparable Worth' Passed
description: An agreement that will give special raises to more than 3,000 city workers in jobs held largely by women was tentatively approved today by the City Council. The agreement was based on the concept of ''equal pay for comparable worth,'' which argues that jobs held largely by women are underpaid in relation to jobs held mostly by men that require comparable ability. Final approval requires a second Council vote.

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Eastern Hails Union Vote
description: Eastern Airlines said today that it was out of danger of falling into technical default on its $2.5 billion debt now that members of the machinists' union had approved a revised three-year labor contract.

title: V-E DAY, MOSCOW: 'TIME TO Live!'
description: Germany surrendered twice, on May 8, 1945, in Rheims, France, and again on May 9, in Berlin. The news reached the Soviet people early on May 10, a day none of us in the United States Embassy in Moscow will forget.

title: MOSCOW SAYS REAGAN'S TOUR OF EUROPE WAS MAJOR BLUNDER
description: President Reagan's 10-day tour of Western Europe was a major blunder serving only to highlight differences between the United States and its allies, the official Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: TRAVEL AGENTS' BONUS OFFERS
description: Several years ago Ed Anderson, a partner in Altamonte Travel, watched in frustration as steady customers switched to other travel agencies. And there were plenty to switch to - about 17 agencies in a two-mile radius, he estimated. They included such large nationwide agencies as Ask Mr. Foster and Thomas Cook, just around the corner from Mr. Anderson's agency in Altamonte Springs, Fla., a suburb of Orlando.

title: THE SCREEN: 'RAPPIN' OPENS
description: Cannon Films has been turning streetwise, urban phenomena like break-dancing and rap music into fodder for the landlocked beach movies of the 80's. In ''Rappin','' which opened yesterday at the UA Twin and other theaters, the mood is so synthetically good-natured that the music has almost none of the rude, confrontational quality that otherwise makes it popular. But even if ''Rappin' '' has a standard plot and a carefully integrated cast that does a lot of smiling, most of it is likable enough. And in Mario Van Peebles (Melvin's son), who plays the starring role of John (Rappin') Hood, it has a handsome and affable leading man.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PASQUALE FOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special charge of $913,000 on the sale of an investment. c-Including a special gain of $6,421,000. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: A Bomb Scare Empties Mission
description: The Police evacuated the United States Mission to the United Nations and an adjoining office building and sealed off four blocks of First Avenue last night because of bomb threats. A search of the mission found no bomb.

title: South African Unions Call For 2-Hour Strike
description: Forty black trade unions called today for a nationwide two-hour strike to protest the deaths of two black activists from head injuries, hours after their release from police custody.

title: EXPENSE FORCES STATE TO END NEW YORK CITY PRISON PLANS
description: Plans to build a maximum-security state prison in New York City were abandoned today by the Cuomo administration.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ'S ADDRESS IN ISRAEL
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz at the Yad Vashem memorial:

title: Who Is Watching the 'Star Wars' Money?
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Panel Reports Abuse In Heart Pacemaker Industry
description: Nearly a third of the expected 110,000 pacemaker implants for elderly Americans this year may be unnecessary, according to a Senate report that found the industry rampant with ''fraud, waste and abuse.''

title: Loser in Indiana House Race Drops Suit Against Congress
description: The Republican loser of a bitterly contested Congressional race in Indiana's Eighth District has dropped a Federal lawsuit against Congress, party officials said Thursday.

title:
PATENTS;

Changing Appearance Of a Building's Walls
description: A New York patent attorney and his son, who is an examiner in the Patent Office, received a patent this week for a building with hollow transparent walls that will permit quick changes in its appearance. Patent No. 4,515,150, granted to John J. McGlew and John J. McGlew Jr., explains that the hollow walls may be filled with a fluid that can be altered in color and transparency.

title: MAURICE ADAMS
description: Maurice Adams, an Australian newspaper correspondent in the United States and a past president of the Foreign Press Association in New York City, died of cancer Thursday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: KAHLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $2,000 for the latest first quarter and $25,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: SHULTZ, IN JERUSALEM, LAUDS ISRAEL AS A SYMBOL OF VICTORY OVER EVIL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz laid a wreath today at Israel's memorial to the six million Jews killed by the Nazis and declared that ''Israel is the true witness to the Holocaust and the truest symbol of the victory of good over evil.''

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary foreign tax benefit of $122,351, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: PAR PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a net realized investment loss of $8,000. c-Net income including a net realized investment gain of $285,000.

title: The High Hard One
description: In the spring of 1947, the Brooklyn Dodgers were in Panama playing a series of exhibition games against their top farm team, the Montreal Royals. On the Royals was an infielder named Jackie Robinson, who was certain to earn promotion to the Dodgers soon and break the color barrier in major-league baseball.

title: OLYMPIC ROWER SETS SIGHTS ON '88
description: The boats will return to Lake Quinsigamond in Worcester, Mass., tomorrow, and Andrew Sudduth will return, too. The heavyweight crew from Harvard University will try to regain a championship at the 40th Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges Championship Regatta, the Sprints. Sudduth, a 23-year-old senior, will attempt to complete a cycle.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
A Vault of 19-1 1/2 Sets U.S. Record
description: Joe Dial of Oklahoma State soared 19 feet 1 1/2 inches at the Big Eight outdoor track meet today to break the United States record by half an inch.

title: WITCH HAZEL STILL MADE IN OLD-FASHIONED WAY
description: The white-columned building on North Main Street is a nearly pristine preserve of Connecticut's commercial past.

title: Your Money;   Taxing Utility StockDividend
description: FOR the last three years, shareholders of most utilities have been able to avoid paying taxes on income up to $750 annually - and $1,500 for married couples filing jointly - from common stock dividends reinvested through a dividend reinvestment plan. But many of these stockholders are not aware of the special tax treatment that these reinvested dividends get when they are sold.

title: Go to Spain and Turn Left
description: One of history's improbable detours carried President Reagan to Iberia this week. Forty, thirty, even twenty years ago, democracy seemed a forlorn dream in Spain and Portugal, Western Europe's last citadels of tyranny. But even under Franco and Salazar, the yeasts of freedom were fermenting. After their deaths, with vital help from Europe's parliamentarians, a new leadership has made Iberia safe for stable, democratic rule.

title: Muse Air Shift
description: The Muse Air Corporation, a Dallas-based regional airline, said that it will cut its Dallas departures to 22 a day, from the current 30, on June 4. At the same time, it will increase its departures from Houston's Hobby Airport to 44 a day, from 31. It said it would bring two McDonnell Douglas Corporation DC9-51 jets into service in connection with the service shift.

title: Books of The Times;   Rhyming Computer
description: THE PENGUIN RHYMING DICTIONARY. By Rosalind Fergusson. 530 pages. Viking. $20. ''The Penguin Rhyming Dictionary'' comes into the world trailing clouds of technological glory. At long last, as Rosalind Fergusson explains in her preface, mere human contrivance has given way to the clinical efficiency of a computer. In compiling the ''Dictionary,'' she began by extracting a list of words and their phonetic transcriptions ''from a standard dictionary data base.'' Then the computer took over, having been programmed to sort the words into phonetic order, ''working from the end of the phonetic transcription back to the beginning.''

title: HOLES IN THE LAW
description: Lawlessness has acquired a new definition in New York City: a condition of being without laws.

title: NEW VIETNAM DEBATE: TRAUMA AS LEGAL DEFENSE
description: The war in Vietnam, which ended for the United States a decade ago, is being recalled with increasing frequency and vividness in courtrooms around the country as veterans charged with crimes cite their traumatic Vietnam experiences as their prime defense.

title: A DIVIDED A.D.A.
description: Already at odds over whether the meeting should even be held, the New York chapter of the Americans for Democratic Action could not agree Thursday on a mayoral candidate to endorse.

title: REAGAN, BACK IN U.S., SAYS TRIP TO WESTERN EUROPE WAS A SUCCESS
description: President Reagan returned to the United States today at the end of his European tour after urging ''significant reductions in nuclear arms'' and voicing eagerness for a meeting with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: CITY TAKING BIDS FOR 149 VACANT HARLEM BUILDINGS
description: After years of negotiation with community leaders, City Hall has started its most ambitious plan yet to solve one of Harlem's most visible problems. This week, the city began accepting sealed bids on 149 buildings in Harlem that have long represented shelter for crime but housing for no one.

title: Bills Sign Jones
