description: The veteran wide receiver Bobby Jones, who has played for the Jets and the Cleveland Browns, has signed a free-agent contract with the Buffalo Bills. Jones, who has appeared in 81 N.F.L. games over six seasons, was placed on waivers last fall after a contract dispute with the Browns.

title: SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
FEDERAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Patents;

Electronic Learning Device
description: AN electronic learning aid for children, with the trademark of Speak & Spell, was patented this week for Texas Instruments Inc. of Dallas. The device looks like a colorful, hand-held calculator or radio.

title: Determination
description: She showed up at a tournament in Orlando, Fla., not long ago, and then again when the women's tour moved on to Houston. She looked familiar (tall, regal, with ash-blond hair), and so did her play (a powerful forehand that clipped the corners and a serve that had zip).

title: New Offer for Conrail
description: A group of investors is prepared to offer firm commitments to buy Conrail and keep it independent, a investment firm told members of Congress today, adding a new wrinkle to the controversy over Government plans to sell the railroad. Representatives of Morgan Stanley & Company said the firm would lead ''a diverse group of responsible investors'' in underwriting the purchase of Conrail. Meanwhile, the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed today that it had decided to examine the Reagan Administration proposal to sell Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

title: You, Too, Can Be a U.S. 'Prosecutor'
description: A Congressional investigating committee, after extensive hearings and inspection of thousands of documents, found evidence of fraud in military contracts, including shoddy workmanship, sweetheart deals, noncompetitive contracts and kickbacks. The investigation lead to legislation to improve Government procurement procedures - the False Claims Act of 1863.

title: PENTAGON MAY SEEK INCREASE LATER
description: Senior Pentagon officials said today that Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger planned to urge Congress at some time in the future to restore some of the cuts in military spending to which President Reagan agreed Thursday.

title: IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $8,000 for the latest first quarter and $112,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Let Teachers' Panels Evaluate Principals
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 FIRE OFFICIALS SHIFTED AFTER DISCOVERY OF BEER
description: All eight supervisors assigned to two Bronx fire companies were transferred and face disciplinary action after department investigators found 67 bottles of beer stocked in a basement soda machine.

GOODEN STRIKES OUT 13 AND WINS ON A 3-HITTER
description: The Philadelphia Phillies got the message last night with the first pitch Dwight Gooden threw.

Good Old Area Code 412
description: There are all kinds of pride in and around Washington, including family pride, military pride and national pride. But pride of area code is an unusual form.

MAJOR BUDGET PROVISIONS
description: Deficits - Anticipated deficits would be reduced by $56 billion in the fiscal year 1986 and by a total of $295 billion in 1986-88.

title:
PATENTS;

Sports Bag Converted Into a Backpack
description: A multiple-use sports bag that can be converted to a backpack has been invented by Carole Cohen of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., who has trademarked it Secret Sac.

title: MOTHER CHARGED IN BABY'S SLAYING
description: A woman who last fall issued tearful pleas on television for the return of her baby after a reported kidnapping was arrested in Bloomington, Ind., today and charged with the infant's murder.

title: OHIO FERRO-ALLOYS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS FEAR: STRONG DOLLAR
description: The country's biggest corporations said today that they were worried about the ''staying power'' of the economic expansion because of the adverse impact of a strong dollar and intense foreign competition.

title: Umpires to Vote
description: The seven-man board of directors of the Major League Umpires Association plans to vote by telephone conference call today on whether to join the mandatory drug-testing program ordered by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth.

title: Global Marine
description: Global Marine Inc., an offshore oil drilling concern, said its board had voted to omit its quarterly dividend on common stock until it returned to profitability. The company cited the downturn in the offshore drilling market, and said it expects greater losses and lower cash flows than it had previously predicted.

title: RELIVING DAYS OF YORE
description: Ten years in New York is like 40 years anywhere else, and having just passed that milestone, I have been busy posing all over town for photo opportunities.

title: STEREO VILLAGE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
QUESTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shekels
description: S enator Bob Packwood says he carries a shekel with him wherever he goes, and would like his supporters to do likewise, as a reminder that ''the security of our nation depends on the survival and future of our democratic ally in the Middle East,'' that is, Israel.

title: BRIEFS
description: Ameritech Mobile Communications Inc., Schaumburg, Ill., a subsidiary of American Information Technologies Inc., said it had signed an agreement with Cantel Inc. of Montreal to provide cellular mobile phone access to Ameritech customers in Canada.

title: MEDICAL CARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $308,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,179,000 from an accounting change.

title: BUDGET VOTE LIFTS BOND PRICES
description: The bond market was engulfed by a wave of optimism yesterday when prices rose as much as 1 1/2 points in response to a Senate budget vote that would reduce next year's deficit by an estimated $56 billion.

title: Arbour to Reveal Plans
description: Al Arbour, the Islander coach, has called a press conference at Nassau Coliseum Monday morning to announce whether he will continue behind the former champions' bench. ''I've made a decision, but I'll tell everyone on Monday,'' said Arbour, who plans to meet with Bill Torrey, the Islander general manager, over the weekend ''to hash things out.''

title: SHIP THAT COULDN'T SET SAIL SOON WILL
description: Since she was completed in late 1983 the Elizabeth II has been moored prettily at a pier in this village of 900 people on Roanoke Island.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, MAY 11, 1985

title: Hanoi Sends Troops To Cambodian Border
description: Vietnam has sent a fresh battalion of 600 soldiers into combat with Thai soldiers near the Thai-Cambodian border, Thailand's naval commander said today.

title: Testimony Completed In Mountain Man's Trial
description: Testimony in the murder trial of a young mountain man accused of kidnapping an Olympic athelete and killing her would-be rescuer was completed today, and closing arguments were set for Monday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. There is much more to this card than meets the eye. Explain. 2. Hecklers in the audience booed, laughed and shouted ''Nicaragua.'' What were the circumstances? 3. Senator Pete Wilson of California received a standing ovation as he entered the Senate chamber in a wheelchair. What were the circumstances and what affect did his presence have on the proceedings? 4. A ceremony in lower Manhattan illuminated a translucent glass-block wall, 70 feet long and 16 feet high. What wall is it? 5. Telephone rates around the country are going up because of ''long-distance hoppers.'' What are they? 6. Peter V. Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, announced that all baseball personnel, with one significant exception, would have to undergo testing for drug abuse. What exception did he make and what was the reason? 7. ''To be a little bit alone in Bonn does not mean being alone in the world,'' said a participant at the economic summit conference in West Germany who had isolated himself from the rest of his colleagues. Who is he and on what two issues did he dissent? 8. A number of leading physicists are beginning to suspect that everything in the universe is made of tiny (blobs/dots/rods/strings). 9. The nominating committee for the Tony Awards voted to drop three categories: leading actor in a musical, leading actress in a musical and choreography from this year's presentations.

title: NEW PRICE OFFERED FOR MULTIMEDIA
description: Jack Kent Cooke, the entrepreneur and owner of the Washingston Redskins football team, raised his offer for Multimedia Inc. yesterday to $65 a share in cash, or $1.09 billion.

title: SIKHS SAID TO KILL 59 AND WOUND 150 IN INDIA ATTACKS
description: At least 59 people were killed and 150 wounded in attacks and bombings by Sikh extremists Friday night and today, officials said. The casualties were inflicted in buses, a train, and crowded neighborhoods in the Indian capital and four northern states.

title: MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Deal Completed For Share of Jazz
description: Larry H. Miller, a Salt Lake auto dealer, today formally closed his $8 million deal to buy half the Utah Jazz franchise, turning over checks to Sam D. Battistone, the managing partner of the Jazz.

title: XEBEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first-quarter's net reflects an unusual pre-tax credit of $378,000.

title: Yugoslav Judge Jails 11
description: A judge sentenced 11 Croatians today to terms of up to 15 years and said Croatian, Serbian and Albanian nationalists had united in a struggle against Communist rule in Yugoslavia. The 11 Croatians were part of a group tried on charges of involvement in bomb attacks as part of a campaign for an independent nation of Croatia.

title: Now Compromise on Taxes, Too
description: President Reagan has taken two giant steps toward a responsible budget by accepting the defense and Social Security cutbacks in the Senate budget resolution. His retreat on both should surprise no one, given his pattern of asserting rigid stances and then backing away. But his new steps are impressive nonetheless. Do they mean he's ready to take the third step? Adding taxes to this deficit-reduction package would make it even stronger.

title: DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVES
description: The talk was of economic development and church-state relations when Governor Cuomo met Garret FitzGerald, the Prime Minister of Ireland, in the Governor's office at the World Trade Center yesterday.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GODARD HAS A BAD DAY IN CANNES...AND TRIES TO WITHDRAW 'HAIL MARY' IN ITALY
description: A festival that has so far been nearly as drab as the weather at this supposedly sunny seaside resort was briefly enlivened today when a middle-aged man threw a cake topped with shaving cream at the director who used to be the intellectual hero of the French film industry, Jean-Luc Godard.

title: Mayor Bradley Confers With Bishop Tutu
description: Mayor Tom Bradley, emerging from a meeting with Bishop Desmond Tutu, the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, vowed today to dismiss his commissioners if they refused to back his plan to end investments of city funds in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: AMERICAN PHYSICIANS SERVICE GROUP.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $43,005. c-After an extraordinary loss of $17,998 related to taxes.

title: SENATE BUDGET VOTE: SIGNALING SHIFT AWAY FROM ADMINISTRATION'S PRIORITES
description: The first round of the budget battle that ended early this morning on Capitol Hill indicates that the center of gravity in the Senate has moved a bit from the right toward the middle and that a majority of the lawmakers strongly disagree with some of the basic priorities of the Reagan Administration.

title: FORTUNE SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29

title: MOTHER'S DAY A PRESENT FOR FLOWER DISTRICT
description: All week long, John Hadges's telephone has been ringing with orders for lilies by the dozen, baby's breath by the case, Gerber daisies by the box. Tomorrow is Mother's Day, maybe the biggest flower-giving day of the year, and that has meant a week of controlled frenzy for New York's flower district, centered on 28th Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, and the people who work there.

title: Storage Fights Asset Claim
description: The Storage Technology Corporation and its finance subsidiary have asked the Federal Bankruptcy Court to rule that creditors of the subsidiary do not have a priority claim to Storage's assets. In December, Bankruptcy Judge Jay Gueck gave the computer hardware maker access to $140 million in customer obligations held by its subsidiary, the Storage Technology Finance Corporation.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said net income for the year-ago 9 months includes a gain of $255,218, or 21 cents a share, recovered against the claim on a 1977 contract. Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: Alcoa Plans 2 Divestitures
description: The Aluminum Company of America plans to make two divestitures in the near future as it redeploys some of its assets, Charles W. Parry, chairman, said yesterday after the company's annual meeting in Atlanta.

title: Dolph Sweet, 64, Actor, Dies; Did Stage, TV and Film Work
description: Dolph Sweet, who starred as the police chief in the television comedy series ''Gimme a Break,'' died of cancer Wednesday at Tarzana Hospital here, said Matt Bozek, a spokesman for NBC-TV.

title: BOMARKO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $324,000 for the quarter and $563,000 for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

title: Lilac Day in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, at Eastern Parkway, will celebrate Lilac Day tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. with a free lecture and tour by Daniel Ryniec, the gardener in charge of the Louisa Clark Spencer Lilac Collection's more than 150 varieties. The program is sponsored by the Exxon Corporation and the New York State Council on the Arts. Information: (718) 622-4433.

title: APRIL SALES DOWN 3.5% AT CITY'S BIG RETAILERS
description: Sales at New York City's big department stores fell sharply in April, according to a spot-check taken yesterday. In the city, their sales dropped an average 3.5 percent from April 1984, one of the worst drops for any month in years. Sales of the stores throughout the metropolitan area were also lower, declining 1.7 percent, according to the spot-check.

title: CBS AND NBC CLAIM SEASON VICTORY
description: Who won this television season? The world will little note nor long remember it, but two networks differ philosophically on the question.

title: Indians' Hall Injured
description: A Cleveland Indians outfielder, Mel Hall, will be hospitalized for four to five days and has been put on the 21-day disabled list after suffering injuries in a car accident in the parking lot of the hotel in Arlington, Tex., where the team is staying for a series against the Rangers. Hall and the Indians' traveling secretary, Mike Seghi, were injured Thursday night, the club said, when the car they were in was struck by another vehicle.

title: PUBLISHERS EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEIST, C. H. CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pretax loss of $270,000 on the sale of aircraft.

description: Many of the top-ranked players who are entered today and tomorrow in the Cavendish Club Invitational Pairs Championship will also compete in the subsequent team event Monday and Tuesday.

description: A convicted gang leader today retracted his earlier testimony that Taiwan's former military intelligence chief had ordered him to murder a Chinese-American writer in the United States.

title: JERSEY AGENCY TO ADD LANES ON TURNPIKE
description: New Jersey Turnpike officials today announced plans to widen a 35-mile stretch of the toll road from New Brunswick to its northern end, at a cost of more than $1 billion.

title: In Korea, Democracy Is Still an Illusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Icahn's Move Called Puzzling
description: Carl C. Icahn's large investment in Trans World Airlines left airline analysts puzzled yesterday as to how he could use the holding to make a profit in the way he has with other companies.

title: ALBANY ACTS TO CUT LOAD OF STATE'S HIGHEST COURT
description: The state's highest court would have a greater right to limit the cases it handles under plans the Cuomo administration and legislative leaders are putting the final touches on.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $34,000 for the quarter and $54,000 for the 9 months.

title: MAHLER LOSES FIRST
description: Vance Law drove in three runs with a bases-loaded double tonight as the Montreal Expos defeated the Atlanta Braves, 5-0, and handed Rick Mahler his first loss after seven triumphs.

title: KEEPING SWIMMING POOLS CLEAN
description: SARAH WARD doesn't like it when her hair turns green. Nor, as she contemplates the opening of her family's pool in Watchung, N.J., for the season, does she care for other problems frequently associated with poor swimming pool maintenance: itchy skin, red eyes and the possibility of having more than a token number of bacteria as company.

title: At the Naval Academy
description: President Reagan is to be the commencement speaker at the United States Naval Academy on May 22. His address will mark the first time a President has attended the Annapolis graduation since an alumnus, Jimmy Carter, chose to travel the 32 miles from Washington to Annapolis to talk to the graduating class in 1978.

title:
PATENTS;

Apparatus Improves Separation of Mail
description: An improved apparatus for separating mail with printed addresses, which can be read by automation equipment, from pieces that have been addressed by hand and cannot be so read, is covered for the United States Postal Service by patent No. 4,516,264, issued this week.

title: COURT OVERTURNS A LAW FAVORING NEW YORK WINES
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday banned the sale of so-called wine coolers - wine diluted with fruit juice - in New York State's supermarkets and groceries and struck down as unconstitutional the state law authorizing their sale.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HORIZONS RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Electrifying
description: A lot of people nowadays take rural electrification for granted, but not the people at the National Museum of American History. Today in the museum's Electricity Hall will be the exhibit ''An Electrifying Change: Rural Electrification: 1935-1985.'' There will be elucidations, demonstrations and oral histories at the museum, all to mark the signing, 50 years ago, by President Roosevelt, of the executive order that electrified the land. At that time, less than 10 percent of the nation's farms had central station electric service. Today rural America is electrified by nearly 1,000 local systems, according to the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association.

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $360,000. c-After a tax benefit of $107,000.

title: U.S. Crop Projections
description: Farmers will produce more corn and soybeans but less wheat and cotton than they did last year, according to projections released today by the Agriculture Department. The projections, based on yield trends and normal weather assumptions, were described as ''highly tentative.'' Except for winter wheat, official Agriculture Department production estimates for the major field crops will not be issued until later.

title: REPAIRS TO SLOW FLUSHING LINE RIDERS
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that riders of the No. 7 Flushing line could expect four and a half years of delays and overcrowding as a major reconstruction of the line's tracks begins on Monday.

title: MCENROE ADVANCES IN 3 SETS
description: By now, Claudio Panatta should be in Bari, Italy, telling his father and older brother Adriano - the former Italian Stallion of tennis - all about how he almost beat John McEnroe at Forest Hills. Claudio would have preferred to tell this story of their dramatic three-set match in a long-distance telephone call, which would have meant the return home had been delayed by his continued presence in the Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions. But losing gallantly as he did to the world's No. 1 player, wasn't anything to be ashamed of either.

title: TALE OF QUICK SELLOUT OF A SUMMER DRESS
description: It was just a summer cocktail dress - black-and-white linen with satin trim - but it turned out to be as elusive as it was attractive.

title: Judge Rejects Second Trial For Man Who Killed Ill Wife
description: A judge today denied bond and refused to order a new trial for a man convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison for killing his terminally ill wife of 51 years.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock split in March.

title: MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings are not available since the company has no outstanding publicly held common shares.

title: WESTCOAST TRANSMISSION CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Welcome to New Kid OnLiterary-Talk Block
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating the Bronx
description: The Bronx Celebrates,'' a free exhibition of artworks by Vito Acconci, Michael Goldberg, Al Held, Alfred Leslie, Larry Rivers, Ann Sperry and George Sugarman, who all grew up in the Bronx between 1920 and 1950, is at the Art Gallery at Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue.

title: Varian Layoffs
description: Varian Associates said it would lay off about 235 workers at its semiconductor equipment manufacturing operations in California and Massachusetts. The company said it would lay off about 105 people in Palo Alto, Calif., and about 130 people in Massachusetts, in New Bedford and Woburn and on Cape Ann. Varian said it was responding to an industry slowdown.

title: Disciplinary Panel at Harvard
description: Harvard University after a surge in campus protests has reactivated a committee that in the Vietnam War era disciplined students accused of disrupting ''essential processes.''

title: Black Elected Officials Increased to 6,056 in '84
description: The number of black elected officials increased by 6.2 percent nationwide last year, a report made public today showed.

title: DOCTORS SEEK THE CAUSE OF HEART RECIPIENT'S STROKE
description: William J. Schroeder underwent additional brain tests today to determine the cause of his latest stroke, which has left him with a severe neurological problem.

title: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Talks Held On Selling Thrift Unit
description: State officials are sponsoring negotiations for the acquisition of one of Maryland's biggest thrift institutions, which has experienced a two-day run on deposits.

title: DINING CHOICES FOR HEALTHIER FOOD
description: Restaurants have certainly come a long way from the days when they agreed, but only under duress, to provide a plain piece of broiled fish without butter for the few diners who requested such food. The waiters generally behaved as if the patron was suffering from some fatal disease and so indulged them, but usually not without making it clear that such a demand caused a lot of trouble. There still are restaurants that will not honor requests for steamed vegetables or an entree without sauce, because, as I was recently told, ''We cannot serve the chicken without the sauce - the chef will not tolerate it.''

title: Ethiopian Welcomes U.S. Shift in Aid Law
description: Ethiopia's senior relief official said today that his country welcomed a change in American law that will allow the United States to provide Ethiopian famine victims with development aid.

title: JERSEY MURDERER SENTENCED TO DIE
description: A 28-year-old man who pleaded guilty to strangling a woman must die by lethal injection, a Superior Court jury decided today.

title: SWEDEN LOCKS OUT PUBLIC EMPLOYEES
description: The Swedish Government imposed a lockout on 80,000 white-collar civil servants this morning after the breakdown of negotiations to end a week-old partial strike by their union.

title: A. MITCHELL BARNES
description: A. Mitchell Barnes, a championship contract bridge player, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Our Military Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Gates Learjet
description: Gates Learjet's president, B.S. Stillwell, said the company would recall at least 100 workers as it resumed production of its 50 series business jet, which has been halted since September.

title: Augustyniak Feels Stress of His Injury
description: Glumly, Mike Augustyniak watched the Jets' minicamp end today. A normally easygoing person, he pretended to accept the locker-room joking about his most recent injury, but he admitted that it bothered him that he felt like an outsider.

title: LESSONS OF THE VIENNA PEACE TREATY
description: As the East-West meeting of foreign ministers unfolds in Vienna next week, the participants will undoubtedly be dwelling on such matters as summitry and arms control and not on the occasion that brings them to Austria. But that occasion - the 30th anniversary of the signing of the Austrian State Treaty, on May 15, 1955 - commemorates an event that marked the first and only time the Soviet Union has consented to a major readjustment of the lines of demarcation established in Europe by World War II.

title: Johncock Retires
description: Gordon Johncock, a veteran of 20 consecutive Indianapolis 500-mile races and the winner of the closest Indy finish in history, yesterday announced his retirement from racing, saying that it was ''not as much fun as it used to be.'' Johncock, 48 years old, made a surprise announcement at a hastily called news conference at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, where he had been practicing all week for Saturday's start of qualifications for the May 26 race.

title: Nigeria Will Not Extend Expulsion Deadline
description: The military Government will not extend the deadline today for 700,000 illegal aliens to leave the country, but will not use force against those unable to leave in time, the Interior Minister said.

title: Semiconductor Outlook
description: Worldwide shipments by American, European and Japanese semiconductor makers will be down in 1985 but will resume growth at a compound annual rate of more than 16 percent through 1987, according to a report released by the Semiconductor Industry Association.

title: Jilda C. Manikas Is Married To R.R. Auray Jr. in Darien
description: At St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Jilda Catherine Manikas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dean Manikas of Washington Township, N.J., was married to Robert Roy Auray Jr., the son of Mr. Auray of Basking Ridge, N.J., and the late Mary Theresa Auray. The Rev. Henry A. Albeke performed the ceremony.

title: POLITICAL RETHINKING IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: In a state that has long been heavily Democratic, three prominent current or former Democrats may run as Republicans in next year's election for the top three offices in Massachusetts.

title: FORMATION OF 4 INNER PLANETS LINKED TO REPEATED COLLISIONS
description: The inner planets of the solar system appear to have been formed in a planetary Armageddon in which contenders for ultimate survival, some of them three times larger than Mars, repeatedly collided with one another until only one survived in each of the present planetary orbits, according to a newly published analysis.

title: Dr. Nancy Graham Is Wed
description: Dr. Nancy Ormsby Graham, vice president of nursing at Lenox Hill Hospital, and Dr. Irving Abrahams, an attending dermatologist at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, were married in New York yesterday.

title: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AN ARTISAN RETURNS FOR ANOTHER SEASON
description: ''Hi, Mr. Shine!'' customers greeted Oliver Pierce, who was too busy concentrating on buffing and polishing to pay them much mind.

title: DROP CIGARETTE ADVERTISING
description: After years of futile pleading with cynical tobacco companies to at least stop using sex, beauty, sports and the ''good life'' as come-ons in cigarette advertisements, the health community is beginning to understand that this will never happen. In fact, the idea is catching on that any form of cigarette advertising is a deadly influence and should be eliminated.

title: DOW CLIMBS 13.91 MORE: GAINS ON DEFICIT CITED
description: News that Congress and President Reagan had taken a big step toward trimming the Federal budget deficit sent Wall Street stock prices sharply higher yesterday, with some broad indexes hitting record levels as investors reasoned that less Government spending would mean lower interest rates.

title: UNR INDUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,050,000 for estimated costs related to bankruptcy. c-Net income after gain from discontinued operations of $129,310 and a tax credit of $215,000.

title: U.S. BLOCKS NICARAGUA APPEAL
description: The United States blocked parts of a Security Council resolution tonight that called for an end to the recently imposed American trade embargo against Nicaragua.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $955,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BROADVIEW FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
POLICE WARNED OF GROUP'S THREAT
description: The Police Department warned all its officers yesterday that they ''may be executed'' if caught by members of a group that the department said had been robbing banks in the metropolitan area to finance the establishment of a separatist community in the South.

title: Lewis Runs 100 Meters In 9.98 at Modesto Meet
description: Carl Lewis won the 100-meter dash tonight, in 9.98 seconds - his second- best legal time - at the Modesto Invitational. Lewis's best time of 9.97 was set at this meet in 1983.

title: FESTIVE AIR FOR EWING LOTTERY
description: In Seattle, the SuperSonics have proclaimed today ''St. Patrick Ewing Day.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DINOSAURS ARE DIFFERENT Written and illustrated by Aliki. 32 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $11.50. (Ages 4 to 8) THE fascination dinosaurs exert on children confounds truly rational explanation, but it is probably a form of what used to be called atavism. We have all seen artists' renderings of the great lunkers, sad of eye and defeated of brain, shambling off toward extinction while tiny, bright-eyed primitive mammals, knowing they are going to inherit the earth, scamper in hordes around the feet and under the noses of the doomed monsters. The scene is repeated all day long as unleashed children swarm about the dinosaurs' remains in the American Museum of Natural History and other great dinosaur collections. And it is repeated all over this book, Aliki's latest contribution to the ''Let's-Read-and-Find-Out Science Book'' series.

title: Papandreou's Politics
description: As an American of Greek ancestry, I have had the privilege of serving in Greece as a member of the United States Embassy in Athens from 1954 to 1957 and from 1970 to 1975. I observed many of the developments mentioned or alluded to in Henry Kamm's article.

title: HOW BIG IS THE TRADE GAP REALLY?
description: STATISTICS can be used, as Mark Twain observed, the way a drunk uses a lamppost: to lean on, rather than for illumination. And trade statistics with Japan, which generate heat as well as light, can cast illumination in all shades, depending on which figures are used.

title: Investments In South Africa
description: Many legislative bodies on local, county and state levels are presently considering legislation that would have their government entities divest funds from banks that do business with South Africa (''Defiance in South Africa,'' by Alan Cowell, April 14). The purpose of the legislation is to send South Africa a message that elected officials in legislative bodies all over the country deplore apartheid and that we are not going to do business with banks that support South Africa.

title: SINGING A SONG OF CITY HALL
description: Take the incumbent Mayor's political autobiography and turn it into a musical revue? People who ought to know about such things told Charles Strouse that it was a crazy idea. Whether they were right or not, ''Mayor'' is already An Event - even before tomorrow's opening.

title:
ART;

FIVE TOWNS ART: BROAD CHOICES
description: THIS year's juried exhibition at the Five Towns Music and Art Foundation in Woodmere is a good deal larger than the previous offering, with 160 works chosen from 526 submissions. The jury - the critic Lisa Liebman and Aladar Marberger, director of the Fishbach Gallery in Manhattan -has picked a staggering variety of two-dimensional pieces, ranging in style from meticulous realism to geometric abstraction to action painting, with a healthy sampling of sculpture rounding out the show.

title: GIVE BASEBALL ITS PLACE IN THE '88 OLYMPIC GAMES
description: BASEBALL is in many ways the most American of sports. But it may surprise many to know that it is also one of the most international. As such, it deserves to be in the Olympic Games, and it deserves to be in as an official gold-medal sport in the 1988 Games in Seoul.

title: A Rose Solution
description: Frank J. Prial's most informative article on wine, ''What Goes With What'' (April 7), lamented that there are ''. . . some foods that simply do not take to wine at all. Many people find ham too salty.''

title: COSMAIR MAKES A NAME FOR ITSELF
description: TWO years ago, a little-known American cosmetics company called Cosmair quietly began buying up the supply of customized aerosol cans in Europe, where they were used to package a break-through hair styling foam called mousse. It was a product that had not yet reached America's shores and when Cosmair introduced its Free Hold mousse here six months later, its can strategy paid off: Cosmair got a running start in the market, preventing rivals from posing a challenge for several months until the can supply could be replenished.

title: Is Bitburg a Harbinger of a Fatal Inflexibility?
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYER GIVES TUNXIS TEAM 2 PITCHERS IN 1
description: WITH only four pitchers on his squad of 12, Dick Raposa, the head baseball coach at Tunxis Community College in Farmington, needs a pitcher who can do double-duty.

title: A Hartz Tower
description: Until now Hartz Mountain Industries, the New Jersey-based company that rose to prominence as a manufacturer of birdseed and pet food, has focused most of its real-estate development efforts in the Meadowlands.

title: Brooklyn Tours; Gentrified Homes
description: The fruits of gentrification in two Brooklyn neighborhoods will be on display next Sunday in house tours of the Park Slope and Fort Greene sections of the borough.

title: Health History At a Single Scan
description: Americans are likely soon to be carrying their medical records in their wallets. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Maryland said last week that new cards going to subscribers next year could contain such information as the extent of the bearer's health insurance, a copy of an electrocardiogram, a chest X-ray, a list of medicines being taken, the names of the physicians, a digitalized photograph and more.

title: A New Summary of Renter Rights
description: THE State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which last year assumed jurisdiction over rent-regulated apartments in New York City, has revised a summary of the legal rights of rent-stabilized tenants and soon will direct landlords to incorporate it in new leases.

title: CAST ADRIFT ON A SEA OF TROUBLE
description: IN A recent article (''Age 18: When Help for the Troubled Is Cut Off''), Sandra Gardner raised the two issues that were the most complicated and intractable in the four years that I was director of the Division of Youth and Family Services, the state's social-service and child-welfare agency.

title: THE BATTLE OF THE BUDGET: ROUND TWO
description: The budget plan the Republican Senate passed at 3:08 A.M. Friday is the second revision President Reagan has agreed to in the blueprint he sent Congress in February. Here are the main elements of the package. The Democratic House will start work on its own plan this week.

title: Headliners;   The Wrong Credentials
description: For some people in Washington, the resignation last week of Marianne Mele Hall as chairman of the Copyright Royalty Tribunal was not enough. They wanted to know how the 34-year-old lawyer, confirmed by the Senate last month, was nominated in the first place for the panel, which sets royalty rates for cable television.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WILT ON HIGH. By Tom Sharpe. (Random House, $13.95.) Henry Wilt, the beleaguered hero of this book, the third in a series by the English writer Tom Sharpe, is the former Head of Liberal Studies at a sodden institute of higher learning whose course offerings include ''ethnic needlework.''

title: CHANGES IN APPROVAL PROCEDURES
description: LAST year's changeover from New York City to state administration of the rent-regulation laws, and the continuing wave of cooperative and condominium conversions, are altering the procedures that landlords and investors must follow to get rent increases.

title: Verbatim: Rights Record
description: 'Rather than weakening the civil rights law (the Administration has) breathed new life and new meaning into the civil rights laws for every individual in this country.' rrWilliam Bradford Reynolds, rrcivil rights chief of the Justice Department, in response to reporters' questions after the postponement of confirmation hearings on his nomination to the department's No. 3 job. rr 'They are catering to the worst instincts of the American public, but they are hiding it behind mushy-mushy, goody-goody words: ''color-blind,'' ''sex-blind,'' ''equity, fairness and justice,'' when in fact it is designed to perpetuate injustice and inequality.' rrBenjamin L. Hooks, rrexecutive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, denouncing the Department of Justice last week.

title: Zora Neale Hurston
description: To the Editor:

title: FACING WARS' HORRORS WITH COMPASSION
description: FORTY years ago this spring -I am reminded by newspaper articles, old photographs, reports of remembrance gatherings, televised reminiscences - the Allies surrounded Berlin, President Franklin D. Roosevelt died and the Third Army liberated Buchenwald.

title: CAMBRIDGE
description: To the Editor: One would have hoped that Professor Rowse, even though a (mere) Oxonian, had known that in Cambridge, Queens' College had three founders (Andrew Dokett; Margaret of Anjou, wife of Henry VI; and Elizabeth Woodville, wife of Edward IV) that included two Queens, and that therefore the apostrophe comes after the letter ''s.'' This, of course, is different from Oxford's single-queen (Phillipa, wife of Edward III) Queen's College.

title: LIFE ABOUNDING IN ST. LOUIS
description: BETSEY BROWN By Ntozake Shange. 207 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title:
INVESTING;

BUYING INTO THE MUTUAL FUND COMPANIES
description: STOCKS of publicly owned investment companies have been star market performers for more than a year. They have far outpaced the market averages - not to mention the mutual funds that these companies manage and sell.

title: 2 Good Models Made Even Better
description: IT is encouraging when a manufacturer takes an excellent product and makes it better. When it is a car that you were fond of to begin with, it is especially noteworthy. And when it happens with two cars instead of one, it is downright heartening.

title: IRELAND, WITH CORPSE
description: THE HALF-MOTHER By Emma Tennant. 176 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $14.95.

title: METS TOP PHILS FOR 3D SHUTOUT IN ROW
description: The wave of classic pitching continued yesterday at Shea Stadium when Sid Fernandez and Roger McDowell combined on a one-hitter that froze the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-0, for the Mets' third straight shutout and fifth straight victory. But the wave of injuries reached a new and dangerous peak when Darryl Strawberry tore ligaments in his right thumb. He will be lost to the team for at least five weeks.

title: PRINCETON MUSEUM: SONNABEND SHOW
description: THERE are a number of reasons to link the artists on view in the current exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum:

title: Jamie C. Fagan Weds Katharine T. Bliss in Maine
description: Katharine Trowbridge Bliss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Bliss Jr. of South Freeport, Me., was married yesterday at the Bowdoin College Chapel in Brunswick, Me., to Jamie Campbell Fagan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan C. Fagan of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Glen E. Rainsley, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Dobbs Wed To F. R. Newman
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Kathleen Ann Dobbs, the daughter of Josephine A. Dobbs of Seattle and the late Lieut. Comdr. Gilford R. Dobbs, U.S.N., was married to Frederick R. Newman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Newman of La Grange, Ga.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Children's Services, Farmington, Conn. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (203) 236-4511.

title: INTELLECTUALS QUESTION REAGAN'S VIEWS OF HISTORY
description: American intellectuals across the political spectrum have concluded that President Reagan, in his visit to West Germany last week. muddied the definition of totalitarianism and abandoned the historical lessons of the 20th century.

title: CORRECTION
description: An identification box accompanying a book review by Hugh Leonard on April 21 incorrectly stated the title of a book by Mr. Leonard. The correct title is ''Home Before Night.''

title: Jennifer Cartmell Married in Jersey
description: Jennifer Banks Cartmell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Cartmell of Rumson, N.J., and Tequesta, Fla., was married yesterday to Charles Francis Hays, the son of Rachel L. Hays of Great Bend, Kan., and the late Orville E. Hays. The Rev. George J. Willis performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson.

title: Thai Jets Strafe Vietnamese Troops
description: Thai jets strafed Vietnamese troops entrenched in Thai territory and Hanoi reinforced its force with 800 soldiers, Thai military officers said today.

title: IN ALBANY, A PROPOSAL TO RECONSIDER THE ROLE OF GRAND JURIES
description: It has been more than three centuries since New York's first grand jury indicted William Dwyer, the colonial tax collector, for improper performance of his duties. That indictment fulfilled one of the two functions of a grand jury: the job of ordering a suspected criminal to stand trial. The same citizens also took the occasion to perform the other role of a grand jury, that of watchdog over the government. The jurors lamented ''the great, manifold and insupportable grievances under which the province still doth groan.''

title: REAGAN HAS HIS EYE ON CONGRESS AND THE CALENDAR
description: FOR a President re-elected amid record popularity only six months ago, the days threaten to dwindle to precious few in which Ronald Reagan can effect his long promised ''second revolution.'' The President's strategists appeared to have this in mind. Even before returning to face this week the protracted budget struggle, Mr. Reagan allowed them to make a major compromise in an attempt to keep that issue, with its millstone of a deficit problem, clear of the tax revision that they hope to be his crowning domestic achievement.

title: Intensified Hunt For Mengele
description: The United States, West Germany and Israel agreed last week to cooperate in the search for Josef Mengele despite strains over President Reagan's visit to a German military cemetery last Sunday. Earlier, Israel offered a million dollars for Dr. Mengele's capture, partly out of indignation at the visit.

title: HIS KIND OF GUY
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Panel Cites Rising Highway Deaths
description: A Federal panel said today that 47,824 Americans died in transportation accidents in 1984 as rising highway deaths reversed a three-year decline.

title: FROM THE ORIENT, LACKING SPICE
description: NATURALLY, you would get to Hunan Taste in Greenvale by driving, but where do you park? The parking lot of this fairly new and relentlessly busy Chinese restaurant is always full. Fortunately, there is a large shopping center lot on the opposite side of Northern Boulevard with plenty of room in the evening.

title: BROOKLYN SCHOOLS ATTRACT ACHIEVERS
description: Coney Island and Bushwick, both scenes of urban blight, are not the sort of neighborhoods where exemplary schools are normally found. But the two sections at opposite ends of Brooklyn in fact boast remarkably successful schools that some educators believe offer an example to districts elsewhere.

title: Chessye Hill Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Scott Hill of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Chessye Foss Hill to Frederick S. Moseley 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moseley 3d of Hamilton, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: IN ETHIOPIA, REFUGESS TELL OF UPHEAVAL
description: Getu Abeje, a tall, 65-year-old farmer with a gray beard and chipped, yellow teeth, said the soldiers used megaphones to announce that everyone was to leave the camp.

title: STUDY TAKES ISSUE WITH PRETORIA'S PUBLICITY DRIVE
description: An analysis of South Africa's effort to influence world opinion says almost all of it is aimed at Britain and the United States and is designed to promote a false image of stability and reform.

title: Christina Ravelo Marries a Lawyer
description: The Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Maria Christina Ravelo, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raul Alejandro Ravelo of Sunset Hill, S.I., and Steven Michael Amundson, a son of Dorothy M. Amundson of La Crosse, Wis., and the late Raymond C. Amundson. The Rev. John B. Clermont performed the ceremony.

title: Shultz Looks For Palestinians
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said last week in Lisbon that Palestinian participation in Middle East talks was ''essential'' for a lasting peace. But which Palestinians? At the end of President Reagan's 10-day visit to Western Europe, Mr. Shultz went to the Middle East to help solve the Palestinian puzzle.

title: Guilty Plea in Meat Sales
description: The former owner of a Delaware County meat company has pleaded guilty to charges that he purchased uninspected beef from a pet food company and sold it to hospitals, school districts and military installations. The man, Vincent Perry Sr., 50 years old, the former owner of the Summit Beef Company, could receive 26 years in prison and an $80,000 fine.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

PESTICIDE DISPOSAL
description: They come out this time of year, when the weather turns warm and the flowers begin to bloom. Sometimes they take refuge in a basement, sometimes in a garage and sometimes they just hover around the gardens and the grass. To the unwary they can be dangerous, even life-threatening. They are pesticides, one of the trappings of suburban life.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: ANNAPOLIS HAT SLOP While seniors prepare for graduation from the military academies at West Point and Annapolis May 22, plebes look forward to other rites, sedate at one institution, zany at the other, that will free them from the bonds of their lowly status. In their first year, West Pointers must, among other things, walk 120 steps a minute wherever they go, keep off Flirtation Walk (where other cadets take their dates) and refrain from socializing with members of the upper class. At Annapolis, plebe requirements include knowing what movies are playing in town and negotiating dormitory halls by jogging down their center.

title: MYSTERIES INSIDE ENIGMAS INSIDE PILLS
description: THE ENCYCLOPAEDIA OF MEDICAL IGNORANCE Exploring the Frontiers of Medical Knowledge. Edited by Ronald Duncan and Miranda Weston-Smith. Illustrated. 253 pp. Elmsford, N.Y. Pergamon Press. $17.95. OVER the last 100 years, man's desire to protect himself against the vagaries of disease has produced the vast and teeming literature of the medical sciences. No subject is too insignificant to merit its own textbook, no special interest too obscure to sustain its own journal. From The Lancet to the International Journal of Hyperthermia, medicine has produced an abundance of facts.

title: MARTIAL ARTS: NEWEST L.I. KICK
description: YEON Hwan Park commands a lot of respect in East Meadow. While he doesn't look particularly dangerous, he can smash through a three-inch slab of marble with his fist.

title: QUINCE BLOSSOMS AND THE HUMMINGBIRDS
description: For the past 20 years, hummingbirds have been coming back to my garden. When the flowering trees and shrubs start to bloom, I wait patiently for my quince to open. It never fails and when the quince tree blooms, the hummingbirds are back. It's a time of thrill and excitement. The joy of seeing hummingbirds after a year's absence is like meeting old friends. Of all the birds that frequent my garden, they are my favorites. Every year I plant perennials and annuals to provide them choice food for the whole summer.

title: SOLTI'S 'FALSTAFF' WAS WONDERFUL - AND GIULINI'S WAS TOO
description: Sometimes it seems that the whole trend of modern scientism and technology in music is to restrict human possibilities, to draw an ever tighter circle around a familiar work until interpreters have so little latitude that differences can be detected only by microscopic analysis by specialists. To some extent this tendency is the inevitable result of education and not to be despised. After all, isn't the ability to make subtle interpretative differences apparent in a Beethoven sonata one mark of the cultivated musician? And isn't the ability to discern such differences one mark of the discriminating listener? The improved schooling of musicians and audiences, the wide availability of recordings and scores, the universal circulation of music via radio and even television - all these factors can be seen as positive contributions to the musical climate.

title: Data Bank
Dinosaur Park Is Planned
description: Massachusetts is wrapping up a deal to buy a park full of dinosaur footprints, according to the State Director of Forest and Parks. The park, the privately owned Granby Dinosaur Museum and its adjoining two acres in western Massachusetts, has as many as a thousand footprints, ranging from less than an inch long to more than 40 inches, a state official said. It will be operated in conjunction with the nearby Holyoke Range State Park, the director, Gilbert A. Bliss, said.

title: Tea in London
description: To the Editor: As an inveterate tea drinker, on a recent trip to London I enjoyed the custom at all of the places Israel Shenker described in ''Trial by Afternoon Tea in London'' (Travel, March 24.), but it was more than worth the wait at Brown's. For my money and taste, Brown's rates six super stars for its delicious delicacies graciously served in an authentic British atmosphere.

title: CLIFFORD TRUSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pere-Lachaise
description: To the Editor: Paul Lewis's ''Promenades in Europe's Parks'' (Travel, April 7) brought back memories of afternoon walks in the parklike Pere-Lachaise Cemetery. On Sunday afternoons many fashionably dressed people wander through its wooded paths - some with a single rose or bouquet to lay at the grave of one of the many famous people buried there.

title: Lori Douglass Engaged To Dr. K. D. Hutchins
description: Acting Justice Lewis Lloyd Douglass of State Supreme Court and Mrs. Douglass of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Anne Douglass, to Dr. Kenneth Duval Hutchins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hutchins of Philadelphia.

title: MOM'S COMMAND TAKES COMELY BY 4-1/2
description: Mom's Command broke to the lead and never looked back to score a front-running victory in the $91,950 Comely Stakes for 3-year-old fillies yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: FLASH FIRE KILLS 40 IN BRITISH STADIUM
description: Forty people were reported killed today when a flash fire swept through a wooden grandstand at a soccer match in the northern English city of Bradford.

title: Robin J. Rand Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ted Rand of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Robin Jennifer Rand, to Alan Scott Feldberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Feldberg of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I.

title: COMPETITION: A PENTAGON BATTLEFIELD
description: STUART F. PLATT is playing a businessman's game of cat and mouse.

title: A SLICE OF LIFE AND CRUMB CAKE
description: MAY is the month when the stationery shops abound with cards of pink and purple lined with lace and fringed with ribbon. Their muted tones are expected to evoke equally muted and pastel-like memories of life with Mother.

title: HONG KONG'S HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: A Canadian banker recently told of a visit from a Hong Kong businessman who said he had come to Vancouver to buy property but could spare only a week.

title: HEEDING THE WRITING ON THE BLACKBOARD
description: While a high school band played on the steps of the State Capitol and hundreds of students waved placards and balloons, Gov. Joe Frank Harris last month signed into law a four-year program intended to improve the quality of Georgia's public schools.

title: DEFIANCE IS INDEFENSIBLE
description: EVERY so often in the summer of his suspension, Vida Blue would go to the Oakland Coliseum, where he once was baseball's most gifted young left-handed pitcher. But instead of strutting to the mound, he sat in the bleachers. He wore old jeans and an old A's green cap with the yellow peak pulled down to where sunglasses hid his eyes and his shame. After having spent 81 days at a Federal correctional institute in Fort Worth for cocaine possession and having been discharged from a 28-day drug-recovery program in Tustin, Calif., he had been suspended for the remainder of the 1984 season.

title: Poet-Teachers to the West
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Jamie Stern Wed To Jeffrey M. Weiner
description: Dr. Jamie Rhonda Stern and Jeffrey Marc Weiner were married yesterday at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel by Rabbi Sanford Jarashow, assisted by Cantor Robert Applestone. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Stern of Massapequa Park, L.I. Her husband is a son of Sondra Weiner of Massapequa and the late William Weiner.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BIRTHRIGHT. By Joseph Amiel. (Atheneum, $17.95.) Beautiful and raised amid incredible wealth, Deborah de Kronengold is a woman of substance who has scruples and sometimes wears lace.

title: TEMPERS ARE RISING WITH PROPERTY VALUES
description: A man who worked for the Legislature in Albany was kicked out of his apartment last month by his landlord, who wanted the space for his daughter. At work the next day, he told his colleagues in the Capitol about his plight. This was their reaction: Legislators and staff members from upstate listened sympathetically and asked if he needed help to move. Those from New York City listened sympathetically and asked if he had a lawyer.

title: CRIME
description: A man in a subway car shoots a punk and disappears. The news media make a big thing of it. The Mayor of New York demands that the killer be brought to justice. But public opinion is strongly on the side of the killer. Sound familiar? It should. You read about it in Brian Garfield's ''Death Wish,'' published in 1972, and then millions saw the film starring Charles Bronson. But those two were make-believe. In the case of Jerry Oster's SWEET JUSTICE (Harper & Row, $13.95), life seems to have imitated art. The book was written before Bernhard Goetz shot those youths in a New York subway car when he thought, or claims he thought, he was being threatened.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SOME THINGS FOR MOM There are ways to make mom happy on Mother's Day, and then there are other ways. One way may be by saving money. So today, from noon to 5 P.M. while everybody else pays to see such special exhibitions as ''On the Road: Carriages and Costumes'' and ''William Sidney Mount: Works From the Collection,'' mothers can get into the Museums at Stony Brook on Route 25A for nothing. The price is $2.75 for other adults; $2.25 for students and the elderly; $1.50 for children 6 through 12; under 6, free.

title: Padres' 3-1 Victory Puts Cubs 1 1/2 Back
description: Garry Templeton and Steve Garvey cracked solo home runs and Eric Show and Rich Gossage combined on a three-hitter tonight to give the San Diego Padres a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs, who fell to third place and 1 1/2 games behind the Mets in the National League East race.

title: DETERMINED TO LEAD
description: POPE JOHN PAUL II IS FOND OF THE WORD ''contradictions.'' It is a useful word to describe not only the Church he leads, but who he is, how he thinks and what he does.

title:
ART;

BOLDNESS A FEATURE OF NEWARK SHOW
description: THE fifth New Jersey Biennial at the Newark Museum is no haven for reticent or timid artists. Rather, the most striking art here takes its cue from the attitude of neo-Expressionism, which is still dominant in the art world.

title: COTTON IS KING
description: COTTON SWEATERS are now basics in many warm-weather wardrobes. But such was not always the case, since traditions, even woolen ones, die hard in men's dressing.

title: NUMBERS GAME ON A HIGH LEVEL
description: ON THIS page on March 24, Sanford Weinreb assailed those state legislators who are supporting a Federal Constitutional Convention for the purpose of proposing an amendment that would mandate a balanced budget. He called us ''irresponsible,'' our position ''frightening'' and our attitude ''cavalier.'' (Mr. Weinreb is executive director of the American Jewish Congress's New Jersey region, which is based in East Orange.) As the prime sponsor of a resolution in the State Assembly to have New Jersey join the call for such a convention, I am eager to answer Mr. Weinreb's objections. First, some background. The United States Constitution requires that Congress call a Constitutional Convention at the request of two-thirds (or 34) of the state legislatures. Thirty-two already have taken this action, and several more have adopted resolutions in one house or the other.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: NATURE, AS IS ''It ain't broke, so don't fix it!'' is the motto of Tom Wood, director of the 400-acre Teatown Lake Reservation in Ossining. To keep the wildflower and nature preserve at its best, ''When things are doing well on their own you do nothing,'' Mr. Wood said.

title: ESSEX WOMAN MADE A JUDGE
description: JUDGE Rosemary Gambardella of the Essex County community of Glen Ridge does not consider herself a role model for women throughout the state. The idea, indeed, stuns her.

title: Choosing Places To Ski All Year
description: These days, summer camps tend to be specialized. There are camps for soccer, tennis, baseball, dancing, singing, computer science and losing weight. Why not skiing, one might ask. The obvious answer is there is no snow in summer.

title: IN QUOTES
description: 'I have destroyed a life of achievement based on trust and integrity . . . I don't like myself as much as I used to.'

title: POLITICAL POSTURING TIES LEADERS' HANDS
description: TWO summit meetings have been held in Bonn. The first, in 1978, is still remembered for its controversial decisions. The second, in 1985, will be remembered, if at all, for its lack of such decisions. The earlier spirit of cooperation that led to importnt agreements has largely evaporated, leaving a residue of parochialism and political posturing that virtually insures that nothing of substance is achieved.

title: ETHIOPIA HAS TROUBLE LEAVING BAD ENOUGH ALONE
description: There was trouble at Ibnat almost from the start. Months ago, foreign relief workers complained privately that local officials were hindering their efforts to provide food, blankets and shelter to the silently starving, destitute peasants gathering at the small city in the Gondar region, not far from the source of the Blue Nile. The lack of cooperation was thought to be based on suspicions that supplies were being diverted to anti-Government rebels active in the area.

title: Patricia Ann O'Leary Marries Robert McLaughlin
description: The marriage of Patricia Ann O'Leary, a daughter of Barbara B. O'Leary of McLean, Va., and Robert L. O'Leary of Oakton, Va., to Robert Brian McLaughlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. McLaughlin of Greenwich, Conn., and Williamstown, Mass., took place yesterday in Nashua, N.H. The Rev. Daniel St. Laurent performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church.

title: Resignation to Relief
description: Dick Tamburo, who resigned under pressure two months ago as athletic director at Arizona State, said he had been ''sleeping late'' these days and ''enjoying life,'' but he would seek a similar job soon.

title: THE LEFT-OUT FEELING OF YANKEE CHANGE
description: I WAS so saddened to learn of the latest Yankee managerial change. I felt so left out. I can forgive George Steinbrenner almost any deed.

title: NEW CASSETTES: MOZART TO BOGART
description: (Available at selected stores or from Video Arts International, Inc., P. O. Box 153, Ansonia Station, New York, N. Y. 10023) The Caine Mutiny Starring Humphrey Bogart, Fred MacMurray, Van Johnson, Jose Ferrer; directed by Edward Dmytryk, 1954 RCA/Columbia Home Video 125 minutes. $59.95 When a big novel like Herman Wouk's ''Caine Mutiny'' is compressed into two-hour movie form, the audience had better read between the lines.

title: ON PHYSICS AND BIOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTONIO GAUDI'S VISIONS IN BRICK AND STONE
description: Nearly 60 years have passed since the death of the architect Antonio Gaudi, but in Barcelona his legend remains very much alive. His portrait and his buildings appear on postcards in virtually every Barcelona souvenir shop, as well as in every bookshop and museum. There is no other city that honors and, indeed, so identifies with the work of a single architect.

title: EXPERIMENTS IN THE GARDEN
description: ALTHOUGH INNOVATIONS IN ART and architecture often are met with a good deal of skepticism, they nevertheless are expected, if not eagerly anticipated, in both professions. Experiments in landscape design, however, are less common, perhaps because gardens are in a constant state of evolution. They are, after all, at the mercy of nature, and it takes time and patience for plants to mature. And in this country, landscapes are generally thought of in traditional terms: either being compared to the formal Renaissance gardens of Italy and France or to the natural designs of such great English gardeners as William Robinson and Gertrude Jekyll.

title: Louis Malle And 'Alamo Bay'
description: John Culhane notes that a number of viewers have found Louis Malle's new film ''Alamo Bay'' to be '' 'anti-American' - and, particularly, anti-Texan.'' However, nowhere in the article is it mentioned that an essential tie binding these ''Anglo'' fishermen together - their ''belonging,'' to use Mr. Culhane's word and theme - is the fact, established in the film's opening hitchhiking scene and repeatedly borne out, that these men are veterans of the Vietnam War, which gives quite a different, credible and far larger dimension to their outrage and that of the film itself. WILLIAM GADDIS Wainscott, N.Y.

title: When the Russians Were Our Allies
description: To the Editor:

title: BOURNONVILLE'S 'ABDALLAH' REVIVED AFTER 127 YEARS
description: ''Abdallah,'' the 1855 ballet by August Bournonville that Ballet West from Salt Lake City recently presented in Washington, was never a success in the Danish choreographer's own day. He felt that better performances would have proved how worthy it was. Now, thanks to a major reconstruction by Toni Lander and Bruce Marks, Ballet West's young dancers bring the ballet back to life on new and valid terms, though the production is more of a curiosity than a major work of substance. Mainly, it is an excuse for transformation scenes and Bournonville-style dancing. Miguel Garcia, who was once with American Ballet Theater II and the National Ballet of Canada, performs outstandingly as Abdallah in the first cast; Lee Provancha Day, once in the corps of American Ballet Theater, dances and acts graciously as Abdallah's sweetheart, Irma.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WHEN BIOLOGY BECAME DESTINY: Women in Weimar and Nazi Germany. Edited by Renate Bridenthal, Atina Grossmann and Marion Kaplan. (Monthly Review, Cloth, $27.50.

title: Carl Goldfischer, Susan Eddy Wed
description: Susan Jackson Eddy, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harrison P. Eddy 3d of New York and Pleasant Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Carl S. Goldfischer, a son of Dr. Sidney Goldfischer of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Mrs. Goldfischer. The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Millbrook (N.Y.) Golf and Tennis Club.

title: BARKLEY REVITALIZES HIMSELF AND 76ERS
description: ONE moment you're overcome with joy, the next you're moved to tears.

title: MUSIC: BEGGAR'S OPERA
description: The main requirements for success in putting across an English theater song are a clear, steady voice (preferably but not necessarily of pleasant quality); intelligible diction; a lively feeling for the flow and flavor of words, and the knack of establishing rapport with an audience. Some of the singers in the Opera Ensemble of New York's production of 'The Beggar's Opera' have some of these attributes, but one did not come away with the impression that they had been sought out when the show was cast or zealously pursued as it was rehearsed.

title: Services Available For Troubled Youth
description: A March 17 article stated that there were no agencies in New Jersey to assist emotionally disturbed youngsters once they became 18 years old. It cited a lack of career planning or job counseling services.

title: Alfonso Ossorio, A Pilot, Marries Hillary Spizzirri
description: Hillary Hale Spizzirri, a daughter of Mrs. Thomas A. Greene of Greenwich, Conn., and Richard D. Spizzirri of New York and Sagaponack, L.I., was married yesterday to Alfonso Herman Miguel Ossorio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Eric Ossorio of Greenwich. The ceremony was performed at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, by the Rev. John Olofson and Msgr.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: STATE and local taxes have been rising so rapidly in New Jersey that its residents now pay the seventh-highest levy among the 50 states, according to a study by the Tax Institute of Washington, a nonprofit research group that monitors fiscal affairs.

title: Intrapreneurs
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

IT'S MAYTIME AND THERE'S MUCH TO DO
description: WITH the spring gardening season well underway, it would seem appropriate to review the tasks at hand both as a reminder of work to be done and to make suggestions.

title: INSIGHTS INTO SELF-DECEPTION
description: THE WOMAN spoke about her father only after being reassured she would not be identified, because, in his time, the man had been famous. Even now, some 25 years after his death, the woman's voice was halting as she talked about her father's alcoholism and about how her family had somehow managed not to know how troubled he was:

title: Reliving a Nightmare
description: The woods of southwestern Montana were an ideal training ground for Kari Swenson, a star athlete in the biathlon, which combines skiing and riflery. But last July 15, the quiet trails became the setting for tragedy.

title: Indians' Dispute Lingers On
description: In 1974, Congress thought it had finally settled the century-old land dispute between the Hopi and Navajo Indians. But today, the feud is as bitter as ever.

title: Chicago: Suburbs Getting 33-Story Tower In Their Battle With the Loop
description: AS downtown Chicago comes to terms with the evolution of the Midwest economy away from the smokestack industries of the past, glittering new office complexes are springing up in its suburbs to lure corporate tenants out of the Loop, the city's prestigious and long-dominant commercial mecca.

title: NEW CASSETTES: MOZART TO BOGART
description: FOLLOW THE FLEET Starring Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers, Randolph Scott, Harriett Hilliard, Astrid Allwyn; directed by Mark Sandrich, 1936 RKO Home Video 110 minutes. $34.95 A fine, clear print does wonders for home-viewing of this amiable, formula Astaire-Rogers musical, with the personable pair snugly dug in as Hollywood's reigning dancers of the 1930's.

title: NEW VOICES AND OLD VALUES
description: IN ''Floating,'' the title story of Marian Thurm's first collection of fiction, a young woman named Lynn finds herself, at the age of 23, married, pregnant and living in a house in the suburbs with a swimming pool. Twenty years ago, her story might have appeared in Good Housekeeping or McCall's, and at its center would have been a tiff with her mother-in-law, who was secretly jealous of Lynn and her baby. Lynn's mother or father would have shown up at the last moment and made everything better. The daydream enviability of her life would have been taken for granted - weren't mar-riage, children and a house with a swimming pool, after all, everything a young woman could want?

title: PLANNERS PROJECT POPULATION SHIFTS
description: WESTCHESTER'S population, set by the 1980 census at 866,599, is projected to grow by less than 2 percent to 877,700 in 1990, level off during the first part of the next decade, then experience a continual decline, reaching a low of 844,900 by 2010.

title: Article 233672 -- No Title
description: It was midnight in the Bronx, and as a car slowed down an off-duty police officer standing about 10 feet away fired four shots from a 9-millimeter pistol. One bullet hit the driver in the arm and another struck a passenger in the chest.

title: GHANAIANS, EXPELLED BY NIGERIA, RETURN HOME TO START OVER
description: The stands and playing fields of the sports stadium here have served in recent days as a joyless transit station for thousands of poor, tired and anxious Ghanaians ordered out of Nigeria in a mass expulsion of illegal aliens.

title: On Predicting Murphy's Stats
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PIANO: SHELLEY GROSSMAN
description: SHELLEY GROSSMAN'S evening of piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night was the work of a strong personality able to express itself in unequivocal terms. Mr. Grossman's broadenings of tempo in Beethoven's Sonata in E (Op. 109) may have approached eccentricity at times, but one felt that he believed in them and knew exactly why he did so.

title: A Yankee Fan No Matter What
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fay S. Roosevelt Is Affianced
description: Fay Satterfield Roosevelt and Julian Potter Fisher 2d plan to be married Aug. 24, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Julian Kean Roosevelt of Centre Island, L.I., have announced. Mr. Fisher is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter R. Fisher of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Miss Linton To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Linton of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Roberta Helen Linton to Mark Cohen Bennett, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Hodax of Boston.

title: INCREASE IN SUITS STRAINS BUDGETS OF MANY CITIES
description: Officials of cities around the country say they are being swamped by a surge of multimillion-dollar court judgments that are straining their budgets, forcing cutbacks in services and in some cases threatening bankruptcy.

title: SPEAK UP AGAINST THE SMOKERS
description: BECAUSE of recent publicity on the risks of inhaling tobacco smoke, most of the medical information presented here is well known. But because smoking is an established social custom, the ill effects of which are of a long-term nature, not as immediately evident as the often tragic results of drunken driving or the smog of air pollution, the public must be continuously reminded of the proven dangers of inhaling tobacco smoke.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City. Home runs by Billy Sample, Rickey Henderson, Don Mattingly and Ken Griffey helped Phil Niekro, today's Yankee starter, beat the Royals in Yankee Stadium last Sunday. (Television - Channel 11, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2:30 P.M.) Expos vs. Atlanta Braves, at Montreal (Television -WTBS, 1:35 P.M.) College: New Orleans at Texas (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Basketball Celtics vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Boston. First game of the four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference championship. At halftime, the Patrick Ewing lottery will be held. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Boxing Kenny Baysmore, champion vs. Roger Mayweather, 12 rounds, United States Boxing Association junior-lightweight championship, at Tyler, Tex. The undefeated Baysmore makes his fourth defense. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Football Generals vs. Baltimore Stars, at Giants Stadium, 2:30 P.M. The Stars are the defending league champions, and this is the second meeting for the teams this season; Baltimore won the first, 29-9. (Radio - WMCA, 570, 2:30 P.M.) Showboats vs. Houston Gamblers, at Memphis. (Television - Channel 7, 2:30 P.M.) Hockey Black Hawks vs. Edmonton Oilers, at Chicago. The fourth game of the Campbell Conference final. (Television - USA Network, 9 P.M.) Flyers vs. Quebec Nordiques, at Philadelphia, 7:05 P.M. Game 4 of the Wales Conference championship.

title: Arbour to Return
description: Al Arbour, head coach of the Islanders for the last 12 years, will return next season as coach, according to a report in Newsday yesterday.

title: Dianne M. Lewis Engaged To Lieut. J. A. Catalano Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. George P. Lewis of Middletown, R.I., of the engagement of their daughter Dianne Marie Lewis, to Lieut.

title: WATCHING AND WAITING IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: At Marx is a large and solid man of Afrikaner stock from the Orange Free State who grows corn for a living and once held views that endured. These days, he says, his visions are changing fast. ''All the farmers in the past were Nats,'' he said, using a common abbreviation for the National Party, which used to sustain a monolithic Afrikanerdom. ''And, you know, the Afrikaner is a slow thing to change.'' But now, he said, with corn farmers locked in a price war with the Government and the authorities talking of racial change, ''they have come to realize that there is something wrong with this Government.''

title: THE MINI - FOR POCKET OR PURSE
description: IN 1898, George Eastman introduced the Folding Pocket Kodak camera. It was 6 inches long and 1 1/2 inches wide when folded and it produced a negative measuring 2 1/4 by 3 1/4 inches. In those days, anything smaller than 8 by 10 inches was considered highly portable. The Pocket Kodak was the forerunner of all roll-film cameras.

title: A Change of Image
description: AS FREQUENTLY noted here in the past, I used to work hard at being Humphrey Bogart. The trench coat, the cigarette cupped in my gun hand while I coolly appraised beauties I wouldn't hesitate to send up for 20 years if they knocked off my partner, the snap-brim hat that could double as an umbrella if I had to wait in a Paris downpour sometime for a scrumptious Mrs. Victor Laszlo who would never appear - I worked at the full construction.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Jealous Eye Does beauty rub off on people who live with it? In one of the essays in her ''Occasional Prose'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich), Mary McCarthy says the answer seems to be negative. She doesn't find museum curators, for example, enhanced by the proximity of art. She points out, though, that we do appear to be jealous and possessive about certain esthetic experiences.

title: THE NEW WOMEN OF KARNAK
description: I HAVE ALWAYS BEEN DRAWN to Egypt. When I was 5 years old, I used to stand outside the travel agency and wonder how I could get there. An archeological dig was more than a dream for me; it was my fantasy.'' Mrs. James Hopkins Smith Jr. shook her auburn curls and laughed. Her blue eyes were delicately outlined in black kohl, like the stylized paintings of the Egyptian queens on the walls of the tombs of the Pharaohs we were about to visit. We were in a taxi speeding across the sand dunes toward the City of the Dead, known as the Valley of the Kings and the Valley of the Queens, just across the Nile from the site of the city of Thebes, capital of ancient Egypt at the height of its power.

title: Electromagnetic Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Turecamo Weds
description: Margaret M. Turecamo, a daughter of Helen Jean Turecamo of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Bartholomew J. Turecamo, was married yesterday to John Murray Carroll, the legal counsel to the Democratic National Committee in Washington. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. Mr. Carroll is a son of Florence Murray Seid of Detroit and the late John A. Carroll.

title: 'SCAPINO' PROVES A DELIGHT
description: AN Italian menu - minestrone, macaroni, ravioli -sung to a snappy tune is the opening number in ''Scapino,'' the fun-filled frolic currently romping away at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst. ''Scapino,'' a liberal adaptation of Moliere's ''Les Fourberies de Scapin,'' and written by Jim Dale and Frank Dunlop, is performed in a zany commedia dell'arte style.

title: ONE GARDENER'S LOVE AFFAIR WITH A PRIMROSE PATH
description: I was conditioned to love primroses by an English mother who used to describe their nests of crinkled foliage and the luminous pale yellow flowers with wistful eloquence. But my affair with these exquisite plants really began when I saw them growing in the wild by the banks of a Yorkshire stream.

title: TAX DEPT. IN NEW YORK SAYS IT IS ISSUING REFUNDS FASTER
description: New York State is issuing income-tax refunds at a faster rate this year than any year in the past, according to a spokesman for the Tax Department.

title: FOR HIRE: LAWMAKER, P/T, EXP'D
