description: UNITED States Representative Sam Gejdenson plans to give new meaning to the concept of constituent service by offering himself for half a day each month as an unpaid hand to businesses in his eastern Connecticut district.

title: Spoken in Japan
description: Hoping for a balance of culture more favorable than the balance of trade, the Smithsonian Institution is exporting one of its most popular products to Japan: lectures. A team of 10 experts, headed by Dr. Robert McC.

title: SUCCEEDING IN THE ARMS CONTROL NEGOTIATIONS
description: Many people ask me if there is a chance for success in the arms control negotiations in Geneva. The answer de-pends upon whether the two sides genuinely want agreement or whether they are mainly interested in scoring propaganda points. This question has yet to be resolved.

title: Lyn Herrlinger Wed to Peter Feldman, Executive
description: Anne Herrlinger, a daughter of Mrs. Richard Packard Rorick of New Canaan and Litchfield, Conn., and Edward Franklyn Herrlinger 2d of Cincinnati and Reading, Jamaica, was married yesterday to Peter Michael Feldman, the son of Mrs. Murray David Feldman of Palm Beach, Fla., and Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Mr. Feldman. Judge Walter M. Pickett Jr. of the Connecticut Superior Court performed the ceremony at Mrs. Rorick's home in Litchfield.

title: TWO BOOKS CAST LIGHT ON A DIM SUBJECT
description: UNEASY PARTNERSHIP, BY STEPHEN D. COHEN, BALINGER PUBLISHING CO., CAMBRIDGE, MASS. 219 pages TRADE WAR, BY STEVEN SCHOLSSSTEIN, CONGDON & WEED, NEW YORK. 268 pages.

title: BIDDERS AND CONGRESS JOIN IN THE FRAY
description: THE Pentagon's internal push to foster competitive bidding is not holding off outside critics. It is not satisfying much of Congress. Nor is it appeasing companies that want to share in a defense Budget that yielded returns on equity of nearly 26 percent for the top Pentagon contractors over the last five years. Increasingly, militant lobbyists and legislators say the military is moving neither fast enough nor far enough.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DEAD BIRDS SINGING By Marc Talbert. 170 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Company. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up) CONSIDER Matt. His father was killed in the war before he was born.

title: LONG AGO, A MOTHER HELD TIGHTLY TO HER CHILD'S HAND
description: HOW could I - just a child -have been expected to understand the tightness of the grip with which my mother held my hand when we walked together?

title: Everton Beaten
description: Everton, the newly crowned English League soccer champion, suffered its first defeat of the year today, losing by 1-0 to Nottingham Forest. On the final Saturday of the league season, Oxford United clinched the Second Division championship, beating Barnsley, 4-0, and Manchester City assured itself of a return to the First Division One, defeating Charlton Athletic, 5-1.

title: Janice Bloch Engaged To Dr. Malcolm Roth
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald C. Bloch of New York and Belmont, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janice Lisa Bloch to Dr. Malcolm Zachary Roth, the son of Mrs. Emanuel Salzberg of Hewlett, L.I., and the late Morton Roth. An October wedding is planned.

title: FAMILY SEEKS A MERCY DEATH ACCORD
description: A group of lawyers, doctors from around the country, a priest, an anguished family and a judge met in a courtroom here today to begin the delicate process of working out a new legal precedent in the emotional area of mercy-killing.

title: C.I.A. LINKED TO BEIRUT BOMB
description: Members of a counterterrorist unit trained and supported by the Central Intelligence Agency instigated a March car bombing that killed 62 people near Beirut and prompted the cancellation of the covert C.I.A. training, The Washington Post reported in Sunday's editions.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TURNING POINT: Roosevelt, Stalin, Churchill, and Chiang-Kai-Shek, 1943: The Moscow, Cairo, and Teheran Conferences. By Keith Sainsbury. (Oxford University, $24.95.)

title: Fred DeJohn Jr. Wed To Shelley M. Branson
description: The marriage of Shelley M. Branson, a daughter of James T. Branson Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Joan Crowley Branson, to Fred DeJohn Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. DeJohn of Howell, N.J., took place yesterday at the National Arts Club in New York. The Rev. Douglas Bachman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: CHURCH COUNSELING DEFENDED IN SUICIDE CASE
description: The leader of a fundamentalist church, in defending the church against a couple's civil suit contending that pastoral counselors helped cause the suicide of their son, has testified that his church's counseling was a simple program of Bible study for church members.

title: WHEN FANTASY ENDS
description: From his first day in office President Reagan has pressed two policies above all others: higher military spending, lower taxes. Last week the two confronted each other, eyeball to eyeball, in the mind of the President. Mr. Reagan blinked on military spending.

title: G.O.P. URGES 2 PROGRAMS USING SURPLUS
description: THE General Assemby, having doled out tax cuts for consumers and businesses, turned its attention last week to sharing some of the economic good times with the state's 169 cities and towns.

title: FILIMING A WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Dallas: A Monumental $260 Million Entry In a Fiercely Competitive Market
description: THE elaborate multimedia sales presentation for the Crecent, a mixed-use project being constructed in Dallas, begins with a portentous voice proclaiming, ''Texans are winners - Texans know what it takes to win,'' and ends with Frank Sinatra singing, ''Here's to the Winners.''

title: Priestly Ads
description: WITH an artist's representation of the face of Jesus and the message ''If you're thinking of spending the rest of your life with Him, spend several months with us,'' the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York began a Madison Avenue ad campaign in September to attract men to the dwindling ranks of the priesthood.

title: PSYCHOHISTORY OF A PURITAN
description: HAROLD ICKES OF THE NEW DEAL His Private Life and Public Career. By Graham White and John Maze. 263 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

title: THE STARS THAT ELUDE ITALY
description: Each year restaurant owners, chefs and the growing ranks of food fanciers eagerly await the thin shower of stars that Michelin, the French tire company, bestows in its red hotel and culinary guidebooks.

title: THE SMART BUILDING
description: Tradtionally, office tenants bought space from developers, telephone service and electricity from public utilities and computers from a manufacturer. Now they are beginning to get all those necessities from their landlords. who are building into their newest office structures the capacity to deliver technologically advanced services.

title: LYME DISEASE HOTLINE OFFERS ADVICE, ASSURANCE
description: ALONE except for some bats floating in jars of formaldahyde and a few that are stuffed, Vivian Kiggins sits in her long, narrow White Plains office talking on the telephone, trying to convince a caller that it is all right to venture into northern Westchester. She hangs up the phone with a sigh, uncertain as to whether she has been successful.

title: Westchester: A Barter Deal Yields Transit Improvements
description: A BLACK-GLASS 17-story tower, the second-largest office building in Westchester County, is nearing completion as a result of a barter arrangement between White Plains and a Boston developer.

title:
GARDENING;

IT'S MAYTIME AND THERE'S MUCH TO DO
description: WITH the spring gardening season well underway, it would seem appropriate to review the tasks at hand both as a reminder of work to be done and to make suggestions.

title: HUBRIS ON THE RIGHT
description: THE LAST FIVE YEARS HAVE MADE Washington into America's conservative citadel. From the Reagan White House to Capitol Hill, ideological stalwarts crusade against Big Government with near-religious fervor. Once-ambitious liberals can do little but try to defend old agencies and programs against the onslaught. Shaken and muted, they find themselves asking: How much longer and how much further can this rightist surge, this latter-day Thermidor, go?

title: Anne Bingham Wed To Benjamin Collins
description: Anne R. Bingham and Benjamin Nolan Collins, both 1978 graduates of Swarthmore College, were married yesterday at the Zion Episcopal Church in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Dawson Teague performed the ceremony.

title: Pop Music
description: The career of the 21-year-old pop-soul singer, Whitney Houston, is a fascinating study of how a musical tradition is reshaped as it is handed down from one generation to another. Miss Houston, who will be at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday, is the daughter of Cissy Houston, a founding member of the Sweet Inspirations, the pop-gospel quartet that arranged and sang backup vocals on many of Aretha Franklin's 60's hits. The young Miss Houston grew up singing in her mother's New Jersey church choir, and at 15 she joined her mother's nightclub act as a background vocalist. Soon the two women were sharing lead vocals.

title:
GARDENING;

NOW THAT ITS MAY, THERE'S MUCH TO DO
description: WITH the spring gardening season well underway, it would seem appropriate to review the tasks at hand both as a reminder of work to be done and to make suggestions.

title: MORE TO TALKS THAN MEETS THE EYE
description: I worked once for a man to whom juniors would come seeking approval for journeys to foreign capitals. He would receive such applications with a wrinkle of distaste and would silently point to a poster on his office wall. The poster dated from World War II, when everything in Britain from travel to food was restricted. It read, ''Is your journey really necessary?''

title: CAMBRIDGE
description: To the Editor: Professor Rowse omits, I venture to point out, two salient points to consider when trying to compare Oxford with Cambridge, both as towns and as universities.

title: BUILT TO LAST, BUT NOT TO NEGLECT
description: WALLS made of brick, stone or cement block look as if they will last almost forever - and in fact most will last a lifetime and are more maintenance-free than most other structural materials. But they do have one potential weakness: The mortar joints between the individual bricks, stones or blocks can sometimes crack, crumble or otherwise deteriorate.

title: Relief Pitchers Work Part Time
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'INCREDIBLE FIND' GETS A ONE-DAY PREVIEW AT UCONN'S MUSEUM
description: CARL RETTENMEYER stands surrounded by owls. There is a large snowy white and a pair of smaller brown screech owls. Some owls stare from under hooded eyes. Some stand guard over nests of eggs, while others are poised for flight, their prey clasped in the talons.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A SPILLOVER INTO RELATED INTERESTS
description: ANTIQUES events are not just for collectors anymore. Antiques are fashionably in.

title: Baseball Faces A Drug Problem
description: Not too many pennant races ago, an illegal substance was something a pitcher smeared on the ball. Nowadays, it generally refers to something a ballplayer smokes or snorts. Last week, as a grand jury in Pittsburgh was reportedly concluding a drug investigation centered on the Pirate clubhouse and several players were awaiting trial or undergoing treatment, Peter V. Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, called current antidrug efforts inadequate and said mandatory tests were needed.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission says that a milestone has been reached in addressing New Jersey's hazardous-waste disposal problems.

title: BOOKMARKS: HOW TO LEND BOOKS AND KEEP FRIENDS
description: WOODY ALLEN is home alone one night when the cars roll up outside, shining in searchlights. A voice over a loudspeaker says: ''We have your house surrounded. This is the Public Library!'' They've come for the overdue books. When the little old librarian starts to lob grenades, Woody comes out, hands over his head. They take him to the main branch and confiscate his eyeglasses.

title: IVORY TOWER WITH ELECTRIC FENCE
description: KAPITZA, RUTHERFORD, AND THE KREMLIN By Lawrence Badash. Illustrated. 129 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $20.

title: BUYING ANTIQUES ABROAD
description: Americans are pursuing bargains in antiques and 20th-century collectibles in Europe these days with greater earnestness than ever before. The favorable dollar and the current passion for period objects have converged to create a major boom abroad.

title: Why Nicaragua Was Labeled a 'Threat'
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: JOSE ORTIGA, who made his New York debut last weekend at Carnegie Recital Hall, has surmounted physical handicap to become a sensitive and skillful pianist. Mr. Ortiga, who was born in Spain, began his musical studies at the Madrid School for the Blind, and later worked with Andrade de Silva. He presently combines recording activity and master classes with concert engagements throughout Europe.

title: Long Island: Bustling Mitchel Field Gets A Glowing Atrium Project
description: IF everything goes according to schedule, Atria West, one of the newest entries in the Mitchel Field commercial office market, will be ready for occupancy in August. Designed by the Spector Group of North Hills, the six-story building is a joint venture of the Lincoln Equities Group in Brooklyn and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: Y.M.C.A. LOSING LEASE ON BUILDING IN BROOKLYN
description: The gymnasium is small, just wide enough for the basketball court that fills it, and the paint is peeling from the walls of the exercise room. But the building in Brooklyn Heights has been home to the Brooklyn Central Branch of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York for 15 years.

title: Eileen Barrett Is Wed To Jeffrey Rosenwald
description: Eileen Theresa Barrett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Barrett of Woodside, Queens, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Roy Rosenwald, the son of E. John Rosenwald Jr. of New York, Palm Beach, Fla., and Kings Point, L.I., and Carol Rosenwald of New York and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Kenneth Gorsuch performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: A Long Look At Island Life
description: It is about time the United States Supreme Court recognizes us as part of the United States! [''Long Peninsula: The Shape of Things to Come,'' Opinion Page, April 14.] In celebration, we took the Long Peninsula (or should it be Peninsular?) Rail Road to Long Peninsula City and had a delicious meal of Long Peninsula duckling with Long Peninsula potatoes.MR. AND MRS. ERNEST G. WOHLWILL Jamaica, Queens

title: Murdoch Takes To the Airwaves
description: In the course of a few weeks, Rupert Murdoch has gone from being merely a press baron to a movie mogul and, now, a television impresario. In typically dramatic fashion last week, the Australian publisher and Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, agreed to buy the nation's largest group of independent television stations from Metromedia Inc. The price: more than $2 billion.

title: Steinbrenner Isn't the Worst
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Poll Finds Many Women Seek Marriage Plus Jobs
description: While most American women view the traditional role of mother and wife as ideal, an increasing number are now interested in pursuing a full-time job as well, according to a Gallup Poll made public yesterday.

title: FRESH AIR FUND HOSTS RECALL CITY CHILDREN'S 'FIRSTS'
description: The women gathered in Judy Langan's living room, hosts for the Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Towns program, were remembering ''firsts'' - the first time Anna swam in the ocean, the first cow Terence ever milked, the first time Shondu walked barefoot in the grass.

title: A HEPBURN FILM WITH A MESSAGE
description: If Katharine Hepburn and the roles she plays in films are sometimes inseparable in the public mind, she herself finds ways of closely identifying with her parts. In a recent conversation about her new film, ''Grace Quigley,'' she likened the zealousness and idealism of the title character to her vision of life as a young girl growing up in Connecticut. She lived then, and still lives today, in a small summer community on Long Island Sound settled by conservative families from Hartford.

title: LEAKY PIPES AND WASTEFUL HABITS MAKING NEW YORK DRY SPELLS EVEN DRIER
description: Although this has been a particularly parched spring, New York City's shortage of water has been aggravated by wasteful habits of consumption and by leakage through aging pipes, officials and experts say.

title: CITY BALLET: REPRISE OF 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' returned to the New York City Ballet Thursday night with probably the most hilarious performance in the ballet's 23-year history.

title: FOLK FESTIVAL TIME IN BRITAIN
description: Whether you come via Newton Poppleford, Honiton or Lyme Regis, the passage into Sidmouth, about 170 miles southwest of London, gets narrower and narrower until it becomes hard to believe the steep green hillsides between which the old Devonshire resort is wedged will ever let you reach the seaside. There's plenty of opportunity as you crawl along in your car or bus to take a good look at everyone who is out and about. For most of the vacation season, it's a respectable if casually dressed lot, just what you might expect in a well-kept community where Queen Victoria summered as a baby and a sizable part of the population is retired.

title: Nuptials for Carolyn Cooke
description: Carolyn Jean Kent Cooke and William Tracy Prickett were married yesterday by the Rev. David Randolph at Christ United Methodist Church in New York. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Pete Rozelle of Harrison, N.Y., and Ralph Kent Cooke of Los Angeles. Mr. Prickett is a son of Irvin Walter Prickett 3d of Medford Lakes, N.J., and the late Margaret Jane Watts Prickett.

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor: After reading the articles on the ''new'' China, and the letters about Chinese hotels in the Feb. 10 Travel section, I can only wonder why anyone would go to China in a few years.

title: FUGITIVE IN $1.6 MILLION BRINK'S HOLDUP CAPTURED
description: Marilyn Jean Buck, one of the last fugitives in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery in Rockland County in 1981 in which two police officers and a guard were slain, was captured yesterday in a suburb north of New York City.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: AN INTERRUPTED LIFE: The Diaries of Etty Hillesum 1941-43. (Washington Square Press/Pocket Books, $3.95.) In 1941, nine months after Hitler invaded the Netherlands, Etty Hillesum, a 27-year-old Dutch woman began a diary. Terrence Des Pres wrote in these pages that this sample of ''survivor testimony'' offers ''a story of spiritual growth such as I have seldom seen anywhere, least of all in accounts of the shut-down world of the Holocaust.'' It is not about war and Nazi terror, he added, but ''about Eros and the soul.'' Published here in 1984, it was translated by Arno Pomerans. THE ONLY PROBLEM, by Muriel Spark. (Wideview-Perigee/Putnam, $8.95.) This 1984 novel is an account of the perils that surround our unsuspecting lives, and that metaphysical component customary in Muriel Spark's fiction - in this case, a disputation on the Book of Job. The major characters are Harvey, a rich Canadian living in France, and Effie, his wife, who plants bombs in supermarkets and department stores as a member of the Front de la Liberation de l'Europe. Our reviewer, Anita Brookner, termed the narrative ''unnerving and as expert as her readers have come to expect from this most excellent of storytellers.'' RED OCTOBER: The Bolshevik Revolution of 1917, by Robert V. Daniels. (Beacon Press, $10.95.) Published in 1967 - 50 years after the Russian revolution - this work reconstructs and analyzes day-by-day events of October 1917. The author concludes that the revolution succeeded against incredible odds, defying any rational calculation that could have been made in the fall of 1917.

title: His Kind of Guy
description: To the Editor:

title: VACANCIES SOFTEN MARKETS ACROSS COUNTRY, BUT THE RATE OF ABSORPTION BUOYS OPTIMISTS
description: HOUSTON has 31 million square feet of vacant office space, enough to satisfy projected tenant demand for about 3 1/2 years.

title: Bridge: The Lead-Directing Double Can Be a Two-Edged Sword
description: Players who throw in a lead-directing double in the middle of the opponents' auction must be aware that they are wielding a double-edged sword.

title: Freedom for a Mercenary
description: By any measure, Col. Michael Hoare is hardly ready for the rocking chair. After all, in 1982 the South African mercenary was the leader of a small band that tried to overthrow the leftist Government of the Seychelles and was defeated only after a 20-hour gun battle.

title: China
description: To the Editor: Two comments on your portfolio, ''Discovering China, Past and Present'' (Travel, Feb. 10):

title:
GARDENING;

IT'S MAYTIME AND THERE'S MUCH TO DO
description: WITH the spring gardening season well underway, it would seem appropriate to review the tasks at hand both as a reminder of work to be done and to make suggestions.

title: On Discipline And Maturity
description: It was with dismay but not too much surprise that I read ''An Encounter With Juvenile Crime'' by Phyllis Krasilovsky [Opinion Page, April 21] . And while I sympathize with Mrs. Krasilovksy, I also feel sorry for the child who was not reprimanded by his parents, made to apologize for his actions and asked to help pay for repairs to the statue.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies last Sunday about a dispute between the owners and managers of United Press International misidentified one principal stockholder. He is Douglas F. Ruhe.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Medley of All Sorts Of Party Features Bruce McNichols, who plays soprano saxaphone, banjo and toy whistle, is leader of the Smith Street Society Jazz Band and a co-partner in an Elmsford production company, Muskrat Productions, with Chicken Joe Hanchrow, who plays tuba, bass and piano; his wife, Lynne McNichols, has been a vocalist with Smith Street for 15 years.

title: THE COMMUNIST WERE STUNNED TOO
description: THE FALL OF SAIGON Scenes From the Sudden End of a Long War. By David Butler. Illustrated. 510 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: REMOVAL OF BATES DISPUTED
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's decision not to offer a new term of office to his controversial Social Services Commissioner, Charles W. Bates, drew mixed reactions last week from politicians, welfare groups and union leaders.

title: NEW APARTMENTS IN JERSEY CITY
description: Until a few years ago, the towers of the Jersey City Medical Center dominated the skyline of the port town. But in 1983, after incurring $18 million worth of debt, the hospital filed for bankruptcy and closed some of its buildings.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: UCONN BASEBALL Northeastern college baseball teams are saddled with a short season and frequently a wet one. ''This year we had a lucky spring,'' said Chuck Steedman, assistant sports information director at the University of Connecticut. ''Only two games were rained out. Last year we had eight games rained out, snowed out or frozen out.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Sports Section last Sunday on the women's rowing team at Columbia incorrectly identified the college from which a coach, Joe Wilhelm, was graduated. He rowed for four years at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: CABARET VOLTAIRE AT THE RITZ
description: Cabaret Voltaire played its first New York concert Thursday at the Ritz - a few years too late. The British trio's first records, at the end of the 1970's, were innovative amalgams of electronic rhythms, political messages and noise.

title: STATE ENSEMBLES PRESENTING FINALES
description: IN the next two weeks, three orchestras and at least half a dozen choirs are to present their seasonal finales.

title: Nuclear Power: The Safety Issue
description: Apologists for the nuclear industry, like Morris Seldin [''In Defense of Nuclear Power,'' Letters to the Long Island Editor, April 14] , continue to falsely assert that no one has ever died or been seriously injured since the advent of commercial nuclear power. Yet, over the past few years, both here and abroad, the nuclear industry has had to pay millions of dollars in claims for compensation for atomic workers who died of cancer many years after they left the employ of the industry.

title: TELLING LIFE'S STORY THROUGH PHOTOS
description: I HAVE discovered a remedy for the messy clutter of daily existence, the complexities of human relationships, the general chaos (to this agnostic, anyway) of life on earth.

title: COLLEGES STRIVING TO BE GOOD NEIGHBORS
description: SENSITIVE to their tax exemptions and conscious of the desirability of being in thriving cities, the four national private colleges in the state - Yale and Wesleyan Universities and Trinity and Connecticut Colleges - have been increasing their contributions to their communities. And they are being asked to do more.

title: A 20th-Century Bible
description: To the Editor:

title: BUILT TO LAST, BUT NOT TO NEGLECT
description: WALLS made of brick, stone or cement block look as if they will last almost forever - and in fact most will last a lifetime and are more maintenance-free than most other structural materials. But they do have one potential weakness: The mortar joints between the individual bricks, stones or blocks can sometimes crack, crumble or otherwise deteriorate.

title: Ownership of an Octagon House
description: This letter refers to the interesting article ''Legacies of the Octagon Movement'' [March 24] .

title: LENOX HILL HOSPITAL ADDS WAVE OF CALM
description: ''IF you are like many New Yorkers you tend to walk around feeling tense all day. When you come home there may be other stressful demands. When you go to bed, the turmoil of the day plays back in your mind, and you have problems getting to sleep. Sometimes you even wake up in the morning with a lurch, feeling tense. Now is the time to let all that tension go. Now is the time to learn to relax.''

title: THE JOYS OF DISCOVERY
description: ONE OF THE INCESSANTLY GOOD things about the kitchen is the ''discovery'' of interesting departures in the use of sauces. A while ago, we were experimenting with different ways to broil fish and decided to go about it by smearing the tops of each fillet with a small amount of mayonnaise. The fillets emerged from the oven with a fine texture and an interesting coating created by the blend of egg yolk, oil, mustard and lemon juice (or vinegar) that had gone into the making of the mayonnaise. It was such a success that we decided to vary the technique by blending drained capers with the mayonnaise before applying it to the tops of the fish.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: TEN, NINE, EIGHT. Written and illustrated by Molly Bang. Puffin/Viking Penguin. Paper, $3.95. (Ages 2 and up) The first paperback edition of a delightful bedtime book that counts backward from 10 clean toes to one sleepy child.

title: Art
description: Among the German painters who have lately made an international mark, there are many who come on strong. They paint big, and they paint loud.

title: New York-Miami Race Will Test Boats
description: Consider a powerboat race in which the winner claims a half-million dollars, and in which it doesn't matter how the boat gets from Point A to Point B - in this case, from Miami to New York City - as long as the boat isn't picked up by a tractor-trailer and driven there.

title: THE NEW VAUDEVILLIANS STIR UP SOME SERIOUS FUN''
description: The scene is an Off Off Broadway theater on the West Side, and the work-in-progress is a political satire called ''The Courtroom'' whose characters are judges and lawyers, court stenographers and police officers. Suddenly, however, a mute baggy-pants clown is doing a loose-limbed but intricate soft shoe number at center stage. The court stenographer launches into a frenetic volley of tap-dancing; a trio of lawyers begins to juggle. The jury box is peopled with lifesize puppets, and a ventriloquist's dummy makes an appearance at the clerk of the court's desk. There is even a break dancer who draws an admiring murmur from the audience when he finishes his number by spinning with spectacular flourish on his head.

title: Kean's Latest Tax-Cut Plan
description: Governor Kean offered another proposal for a one-time tax cut for New Jerseyans last week, an income tax reduction, but Democrats in the Legislature immediately attacked the idea as an election-year gimmick. They called instead for a permanent reduction in property taxes as a way to spread around a budget surplus that, according to one Democratic lawmaker, could reach $1 billion next year.

title: FILIMING A WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL HIS LOSSES WERE HIS GAIN
description: THE CALL By John Hersey. 701 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: ANTONY TUDOR RECREATES A NOSTALGIC BALLET
description: There is a rehearsal going on backstage at the Metropolitan Opera House, where tomorrow American Ballet Theater will present a revival of Antony Tudor's ''Dim Lustre,'' a ballet absent from the company's repertory for 29 years. Dancers swirl through a waltz in huge, cross-stage diagonals, darting so fast through the close-knitted fray that it seems a miracle they do not collide.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN CHAPPAQUA
description: ALTHOUGH Horace Greeley attained immortality when he advised the young men of his day to go west and grow up with the country, he ignored his own advice and spent the last 20 years of his life in in Chappaqua, N.Y. There, the New Hampshire native sought to ''steal from the city's labors and anxieties and to relive as a farmer the memories of his childhood's humble home.''

title: New Jersey: Corporations Become Developers To Benefit From a Strong Market
description: AT its peak of activity, the American Cyanamid Company's chemical-manufacturing complex in Bridgewater spread over 600 acres and employed more than 5,500 workers who produced dyes, pigments, plastics and chemicals by the trainload.

title: HUBBUB OF LIFE ABOARD THE 'CLIPPER' MAKES AMTRAK THREAT SEEM FAR OFF
description: ABOARD THE YANKEE CLIPPER - Outside Washington's Union Station an army of commuters, briefcases in hand, strode smartly toward their offices, meeting Monday morning head-on.

title: Ruins Are Discovered In Honduran Jungle
description: A team of young explorers may have discovered the ruins of a legendary lost city in the jungles of Honduras, Press Association, a British news agency, said.

title: FILM: '20 YEARS LATER'
description: ''Twenty Years Later'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times April 5. The film opened yesterday at the Film Forum, 57 Watts Street.

title: AGAIN, SIGNS OF PRESIDENTIAL 'SECOND-TERM BLUES'
description: There's a popular belief - usually shared by Presidents - that when they win a second term they are home free and can dictate a national agenda of their own choosing. Not so. Experience shows that second-term Presidents more often than not run into heavy weather -even if they win by landslides.

title: LOFT CONVERSIONS TAKING A NEW TACK
description: FROM their 16th-floor loft on West 27th Street in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, Robert Petrucci and his partner, Ray Bailey, have witnessed a small revolution. Between 1981, when almost all the building's tenants were manufacturers of one sort or another, and last June, when the second-to-last-one moved out, the 18-story loft building has been transformed.

title: Bear Story
description: COLORADO residents of a development in a remote area called Bellyache Ridge had a big complaint: too many black bears on the loose.

title:
STAMPS;

NATIVE FLOWERS ARE THE PRIDE OF MANY NATIONS
description: Philatelic flora is cultivated by the nations of the world on their stamps. It will be of particular interest to armchair gardeners or rainy day shut-ins.

title: O'GRADY POSTS A 69, LEADS NELSON BY 3
description: Mac O'Grady successfully fought through gusty winds today to shoot a 2-under-par 69 and maintain a three-shot advantage after three rounds of the Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: ANTI-NAZIS RIOT AT SS REUNION
description: The police fired water cannon and tear gas today at rioters who screamed ''Nazis out!'' and threw stones, paint and eggs at a hotel where veterans of the Nazi SS were holding a reunion.

title: Lisa M. Diserio Becomes Bride Of Mark Wolff
description: The marriage of Lisa Michelle Diserio, manager of special events for CBS Sports, to Mark Stuart Wolff, an associate producer-director for CBS Sports, took place yesterday at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Leo J. Daly, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner performed the ceremony.

title: 50 YEARS LATER, A 2D CHANCE
description: Elma Becker and Jack McCauley did not need much rehearsing before they took their matrimonial vows today. They first went down the aisle together more than 50 years ago.

title: RENOVATIONS PUT OFF AT CHURCH IN JERSEY TORN OVER THE ISSSUE
description: Plans for church renovations that divided a Roman Catholic congregation in Ridgewood, N.J., when one group of parishioners said the $200,000 needed for the work would be better spent on the poor have been indefinitely postponed, according to the pastor.

title: HOW FAR SHOULD FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS BE ALLOWED TO GO-GO?
description: For the third year in a row, Congress is trying to pass banking legislation, and again the debate pits House regulators against Senate deregulators. The House has concluded extensive hearings; last week, the Senate began its round, with many of the same witnesses. On the House side, the concerns are loophole-closing and regional banking; on the Senate side, new powers for banks, such as underwriting municipal revenue bonds. The biggest debate is whether this year's bill will provide the way into nationwide interstate banking.

title: The Prices of Spices
description: Among the many things that the Government tracks are the prices of spices.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: BYPASSING THE BUSY SIGNAL
description: Ten thousand times a day, by the airline's count, callers reach a busy signal when trying to make reservations on People Express. To ease the crush, the airline has begun a service that allows a caller with a Touch-Tone telephone (or another phone that works on the same tone principle) to make reservations through the company's computer, bypassing clerks.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Sound Housing The indicators are still sending mixed signals about the economy's direction. But one sector, housing, is flashing a clear green light, according to David Ernst, vice president of Evans Economics Inc. in Washington.

title: IMPROVING WRITING TO START AT THE TOP
description: TEACHERS of a variety of disciplines at Bristol Central High School will have their writing skills sharpened this summer so that they can get better writing and thinking from their students next fall.

title: THE YANKEES SWALLOW A 'POISON PILL'
description: GEORGE Steinbrenner is wrecking the New York Yankees. Or is he?

title: WORKERS STRIKE AT 11 CEMETERIES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Workers at 11 large cemeteries in the New York City area went on strike yesterday, setting up pickets at cemetery gates as funeral processions rolled in.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NONE OF THE ABOVE: Behind the Myth of Scholastic Aptitude. By David Owen. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) The Educational Testing Service (E.T.S.) has always been a tempting target for muckrakers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SPANISH DOCTOR. By Matt Cohen. (Beaufort, $16.95.) In this historical novel about the danger of renouncing one's true identity, Avram Halevi, a Marrano (a Spanish Jew forced to convert to Christianity), wanders through the madness of medieval anti-Semitic Europe hoping to avoid the destiny of his people.

title: PRINCETON AIRPORT GETS A NEW OWNER
description: THE piercing roar of the airplane's twin engines interrupted New Jersey's chief aviation official in the middle of her speech.

title: Nancy Eiges Married To James M. Shepard
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday Nancy Ellen Eiges, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Eiges of Woodmere, L.I., was married to James Madison Shepard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Duncan Shepard of Murphy, N.C. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: VOLLEYBALL CHAMPIONSHIP ''It's no longer a double-tap, sissy girls' game,'' said Dolores (Curlie) Faber, a physical education instructor at Nassau County Community College. Volleyball, she said, has changed dramatically in the last 20 years, and this week Long Islanders will get a chance to see how aggressively the game can be played.

title: WHEN TO CHANGE TACTICAL WEAPONS
description: How many times must one suffer with the same opening before removing it from one's repertoire?

title: Dorothy West Is Married
description: Dorothy Kemper West, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph O'Neal West of Wellesley, Mass., was married there yesterday to Peter Wilmot North, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilmot Beale North of Southbury, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Samuel Shoemaker Johnston performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church. Mrs. North and her husband are with the Bank of Boston, where she is an assistant vice president of the New England group and he a construction lender in the real-estate division.

title: How the Lottery Works
description: Here is the way the National Basketball Association's first college draft lottery will work:

title: Social Events;   Parties That Benefit
description: Theater Club May 13 - Now in its 13th year, the Manhattan Theater Club has become a significant producer of works by American and foreign writers as disparate as ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' and ''Crimes of the Heart.'' The club's annual fund-raiser will start with cocktails at 7 P.M. at the Waldorf-Astoria followed by dinner and an evening of entertainment by performers from several Broadway and Off Broadway musicals. Tickets, $200, from 212-288-2500. Urban Design Awards May 14 - Founded in 1892, the City Club of New York is the city's oldest civic group and has been giving awards for 20 years for excellence in urban design and architecture. Mingle with the men and women who design the city, starting with 7:30 P.M. cocktails in the Whitney Sculpture Garden at the Philip Morris Building at Park Avenue and 42d Street followed by dinner across the street at the Grand Hyatt. Tickets, $250, from 212-206-8816. University's Birthday May 15 - Hebrew University opened its doors on April 1, 1925. Now with 17,000 students from around the world on its four campuses in Israel, it has become a leading teaching and research center, aided over the years by groups including the American Friends of Hebrew University. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick will be the guest speaker and Howard Cosell will receive an award at a celebration starting with cocktails at 6 P.M. followed by dinner at 7 at the Pierre. Tickets, $300, from 212-472-0040. Health Award May 16 - The National Center for Health Education was founded in 1975 as a result of a recommendation by the President's Committee on Health Education for a private-sector organization working with professionals and volunteers to make Americans more health-conscious.

title: Deborah Ann Gill Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Gill of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Gill to Kurt John Hilzinger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin D. Hilzinger of Royal Oak, Mich.

title: The Real Essence Of Feminism
description: I was deeply moved by Mary Ann McGuigan's April 28 Speaking Personally piece, ''The Best-Laid Career Plans Have a Way of Going Awry.'' Hers was my story, too; I put my career on hold after the birth of my second child.

title: Timothy Davis Fiance Of Barbara Schwebel
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jack P. Schwebel of New Rochelle, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Barbara Schwebel to Timothy Spenser Davis, a son of Prof. and Mrs. David Davis of Columbia, Mo. A September wedding is planned.

title: Mark Fenn Marries Dr. T. Linda Chi at Wellesley
description: Dr. T. Linda Chi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ruey K. Chi of University Park, Md., was married yesterday to Mark W. Fenn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Fenn of Riverside, Conn. The ceremony at the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College was performed by the Rev. Constance Chandler-Ward, the college chaplain and an Episcopal priest.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

GOALS AND AMBITION
description: THE young men grew up with the game. They played it as toddlers, watched it from the stands, idolized its superstars. It was the sport of their homelands. But when the time came to leave for greener pastures - America's greener pastures - the game was their ticket out.

title: Diane Fox Bride Of Blair Wheeler
description: Diane Dixon Fox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Dixon Fox of Oklahoma City and East Orleans, Mass., was married in New Haven yesterday to Blair Francis Wheeler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ephraim Wheeler of Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan. The Rev. Roddey Reid performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Battell Chapel at Yale University, from which the bride graduated cum laude in 1983 and the bridegroom graduated in 1981.

title: BROOKE SHIELDS V. MCCALL'S ET AL.
description: IN HER BOOK ''ON YOUR Own,'' actress, model and role model Brooke Shields, now already 18, explains why she has refused to have an affair: ''Like me, there are plenty of college girls who don't want to be bogged down with demanding involvements. . . . We're more concerned with getting ahead.''

title: EVEN FOR THE SWISS, IT'S TIME FOR ANOTHER LOOK AT THE WAR
description: As their neighbors have been marking the 40th anniversary of the end of World War II, the neutral Swiss have been quietly undergoing a reassessment of their role during the conflict.

title: IN NEW YORK, BICYCLE RIDERS GET SOME AID
description: New York City is moving to eliminate sewer grates with parallel bars as a street hazard that can trap a bicycle tire and hurl the rider over the handlebars.

title: Prince Abdul-Mohsen, Saudi Governor, Dies
description: Prince Abdul-Mohsen bin Abdulaziz, a brother of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia who held the key post of governor of Medina, died Friday night, the official Saudi Press Agency reported. He was variously said to be 58 or 60.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

THE NORWEB SALE
description: Foreign coins, which have been somewhat overshadowed, are back in the news.

title: REAGAN VISIT AIDS PREMIER IN LISBON
description: The greatest immediate beneficiary of President Reagan's just-completed visit to Portugal as the guest of President Antonio Ramalho Eanes has been the President's archrival, Prime Minister Mario Soares, according to Portuguese political commentators.

title: NICARAGUA SAID TO TRIPLE IMPORTS FROM SOVIET
description: Nicaraguan imports from the Soviet Union tripled last year as the Sandinistas' relations with the United States deteriorated, recent Soviet foreign trade statistics show.

title: CARTER ON POLE FOR INDY RACE
description: Pancho Carter and Scott Brayton, driving March racers powered by experimental Buick V-6 engines, led the qualifying today on the first day of time trials for the Indianapolis 500.

title: The Problems Of Adoption
description: As a mother who surrendered her daughter for adoption 19 years ago and as a writer who has written extensively on the subject of adoption, I would like to correct the error in a letter by a prospective adoptive parent, Linda Mulrean [Letters to the Long Island Editor, April 7] .

title: ,PVOES DEVE:P< AM 'OFF BROADWAY'
description: Although American independent filmmakers are hardly a new phenomenon, it is only in the past two years that they have represented a serious commercial alternative to Hollywood movies. And a prime reason for the success of recent titles like ''El Norte,'' ''Stranger Than Paradise,'' ''Choose Me,'' ''The Brother From Another Planet,'' ''Stop Making Sense,'' and ''Blood Simple'' is a new group of distribution companies - which are increasingly becoming involved in production -committed to American independents. Indeed, the mushrooming and the quick establishment of such companies on the American film scene is irretrievably changing the movie industry.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rene Arnoux, who ws dropped by Ferrari last month, was hired as the new driver for the revived Toleman Formula One team, which is reportedly ready to re-enter Grand Prix racing. . . . The National Sports Festival will ask Dick Hill, the director of athletics at Southern University, to take over as co-ordinator for the festival's track programs. Hill is replacing Bill Maxwell, who resigned last week. after the events were moved from Louisiana State to Southern.

title: PRIVATE COURTS WITH BINDING RULINGS DRAW INTEREST AND SOME CHALLENGES
description: A student who was raped on a college campus sought compensatory damages from the college and the company that ran its security system. Lawyers produced witnesses who took their oaths. A robed judge, sitting at a bench in front of a large American flag, decided the case on the basis of Pennsylvania law.

title: INVESTING IN GOLD
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE NIGHT, REMEMBERING MY MOTHER
description: DARKNESS surrounded me as I sat straight up in bed. My face was wet from the tears of my terrible dream, and I was still shaking from the struggle in my heart. ''Come back,'' I prayed. ''Why do you always leave me? I just want to talk to you - to be with you for a little while.''

title: McEnroe, Lendl Advance to Final
description: It has become the most heated tennis rivalry, perhaps lacking the contrast in style and temperament of John McEnroe vs Bjorn Borg or the fire of McEnroe vs Jimmy Connors, but it is the match most anticipated, nonetheless.

title: A $700 Million Plan for Jersey City's Shore
description: LIKE most of the Jersey City waterfront, the area known locally as Harsimus Cove, with its spectacular views of the lower Manhattan skyline, has effectively been off limits for most of this century. The railroads controlled the land, and their tracks, gates and guards blocked the shoreland from the rest of the city.

title: Susan Anne Lyon Of I.B.M. Is Bride Of Steven Hailey
description: Susan Anne Lyon, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert Emil Lyon of Tiburon, Calif., and the late Mr. Lyon, was married yesterday to Steven Hailey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hailey of Lyford Cay, the Bahamas. Justice Alvin Schlesinger of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the River Club in New York.

title: YALE COOPERATIVE IS IN ITS 100TH YEAR
description: AN advertisement in the Yale Daily News on April 10, 1922 asked: ''Have you been in the Co-op today? Buy your white flannels and knickers before leaving for vacation.''

title: MUSKETEERS INVADE METUCHEN
description: IS IT nobler to leave bad enough alone or, by butting in, worsen it? That is the question raised by the Forum Theatre Group's production of ''The Three Musketeers,'' which continues through next Sunday.

title: FORMATION OF FRATERNITIES IS ON THE INCREASE AT YALE
description: In increasing numbers, male students at Yale University are forming and joining fraternities.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: MOON JELLY Aurelia aurita Size: 6 to 10 inches.

title: DROUGHT AN ISSUE IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: THE lack of rain that is causing drought conditions in the Northeast is having its greatest impact in New Jersey, where the problem has become a factor in the campaign for governor.

title: PERE-LACHAISE
description: To the Editor: Your fine article about the superb new Liverpool Flower Gardens recalled a recent visit to my native city and the satisfaction that it had transferred a large portion of the unsavory appearing and unused Mersey shoreline.

title: SINGER SITE TO BECOME INDUSTRIAL CENTER
description: FOR more than 100 years, the Singer Company here meant a way of life for the blue-collar neighborhood that surrounded it.

title: DEVELOPERS TURN SIGHTS TO CITY'S OUTER BOROUGHS
description: FOR years, the New York City suburbs have been Manhattan's primary competition for white-collar jobs in the metropolitan region.

title: Press Freedom And Suffolk Resolution
description: As a journalist at a Long Island newspaper group, I am outraged to read of Suffolk Legislator Patrick Heaney's request to have all Suffolk community papers print opposing sides on matters of ''public importance'' [''Journalists Assail Suffolk Resolution,'' April 21] .

title: Rape Sentences
description: AFTER three men pleaded guilty in November 1983 to raping and torturing a woman in Anderson, S.C., Judge C. Victor Pyle in Circuit Court sentenced them to 30 years in prison and then offered them an unusual bargain. He said he would suspend the sentences if the men agreed to undergo castration.

title: OCEAN WINNING BATTLE OF BARRIER BEACH
description: FEDERAL officials say it now appears inevitable that the barrier island at Westhampton Beach will be breached, causing tens of millions of dollars in damage.

title: GLIMPSING JAPAN'S HIDDEN FACE
description: April and May, the season of the cherry blossoms, and September and October, the time of the maple colors, are traditionally thought of as the ideal times to visit Japan. But the traveler who seeks to get to know something of the people of Japan as well as the usual tourist sights may prefer to submit voluntarily to the humidity of summer or the rigors of winter. Merely by being in the country at the wrong time of year such a traveler can become part of a community - the community that forms in opposition to an uncomfortable climate.

title: Frances Mossiker Dies; Author and Historian
description: Frances Sanger Mossiker, a historian who wrote her first book at the age of 55 and became one of the few foreigners to be honored by the French for books about France, died Thursday at the Baylor Medical Center of a heart ailment. She was 79.

title: CONCERT TO HONOR ESSEX COMPOSER
description: THE music of the composer and pianist Edwin Finckel of West Orange will be featured in a benefit concert Friday evening at Millburn Junior High School.

title: IN THE PRESIENT'S WAKE, A EUROPE AS DIVIDED AS EVER
description: WHEN President Reagan came to Europe 12 days ago to confront it with big decisions on participation in his Strategic Defense Initiative and on such economic issues as protectionism and trade regulation, the United States's allies were intrigued observers. They were looking to gauge the President's strength, to see for themselves a man they thought might be slipping, particularly when his communications magic seemed to be flagging. Second-term American Presidents become lame ducks in Cologne as well as Kankakee; their limp, if signaled, can turn into an international message of political caution.

title: 2 INFLUENCES IN AMERICAN CERAMICS IN SOLO SHOW
description: SOLO shows in different parts of the state are offering, in depth, the works of two ceramic artists.

title: OBSERVANCES MARKING THE CENTENNIAL OF STATE FOREST PRESERVE OPEN
description: A series of centennial observances of the founding of the State Forest Preserve in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains has begun and will continue for the rest of the year.

title: SENATE'S BUDGET VARIES FROM EARLIER PROPOSALS
description: The Federal budget proposal approved Friday by the Senate would eliminate the 1986 cost-of-living increase for Social Security and other retirement benefits, and it would trim Medicare, Medicaid and Federal aid to college students, but not by as much as President Reagan proposed.

title: Shantytown Razing Blocked
description: Two dozen protesters of apartheid today blocked the dismantling of a shantytown on the Cornell University campus.

title: PUZZLING OUT PER-UNIT SUBSIDIES FOR RENTAL PRODUCTION
description: IN about six months, Jeffrey Stern and his partner, Henry Hewes, expect to break ground for a 70-unit rental apartment building on Atlantic Avenue and Third Street in downtown Brooklyn. It is one of the eight projects chosen by the city in the first round of awards in a new rental-housing program.

title: SWEET TASTE OF PASTRY IN BRUSSELS
description: The line at the counter of the Wittamer pastry shop on a recent Saturday morning stretched out to the sidewalk. This in itself wasn't unusual in Brussels, where crowds often converge on weekends at the more esteemed food stores. But at Wittamer, generally considered the city's leading patisserie, the waiting customers are wearing cashmere and designer tweeds and have double-parked their Mercedes-Benz cars on the nearby cobblestone streets.

title: GIFT-GIVING BY ALUMNI: THE ARTS AND SCIENCES
description: The Dartmouth Hub Club, one of 130 Dartmouth College alumni associations, gathered for a monthly lunch one day this spring at the Union Oyster House in downtown Boston. The session had nothing explicit to do with fund-raising. Yet Dartmouth officials in Hanover, N.H., have no doubt that the spirit of giving and the urge to eat with former school chums spring from the same instinct.

title:
DINING OUT;

DENVILLE: PREDICTION PROVES RIGHT
description: WHEN we first visited The Italian Chalet in Denville about five years ago, not only did the restaurant have a different name (it was called The Red Shingle), but it also had a different appearance. With its bright tile roof and roadhouse lack of pretension, it was a Howard Johnson's look-alike; however, it was the honest, reasonably priced Italian-American food that made The Red Shingle a magnet for area residents.

title: U.S. Let Off On Agent Orange
description: A Federal court judge ruled last week that the United States Government could not be forced to contribute to a fund set up to aid the families of Vietnam War veterans who say they were harmed by Agent Orange. But he added that a refusal to contribute ''may be cruel to the veterans who served their country and feel that the Government has turned its back on them in this litigation.''

title: PARIS ATTEMPTS TO REASSERT ITSELF AS A CREATIVE FORCE
description: In the 19th century, Paris was the capital of Europe, the crowning jewel of the Continent, the Rome of the modern world. It staked its claim on its buildings, its economic prowess, its social standards and its arts. And after the city had played host to nearly half a dozen universal expositions between 1855 and 1900, no one doubted the fact.

title: The Need to Protect L.I.'s Aquifer
description: It is most unfortunate that the bills introduced in 1981 to protect Long Island's sole-source aquifer [''Bills Seek to Protect Aquifer,'' March 24] have not yet met with success in Congress.

title: PRINCETON IN BASEBALL SURGE
description: Tom O'Connell began coaching the Princeton baseball team April 5, 1982, on a chilly, damp afternoon at Columbia's Coakley Field. The coach watched with dismay as his team's shoddy play handed Columbia both ends of a doubleheader.

title: Patricia Sicular to Be Wed To an Orthopedic Surgeon
description: Patricia Ann Sicular, an agent with the Ford Model Agency, and Dr. Robert D. Haar, an orthopedic surgeon in Manhattan, plan to be married June 8. Mr. and Mrs. Leon H. Sicular of Sands Point, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Haar of Fair Lawn and West End, N.J.

title:
ART;

SCULPTURE INSPIRED BY THE SITE
description: IN recent years, sculptors have shown so much interest in creating outdoor pieces closely dependent on nature that we can regard this as a trend of some significance. Such work uses elements of nature to complete the artist's concept. Whether it tries to incorporate sun, sky, earth, a particular configuration of trees or even a distant mountain, the site is always linked to the intended message.

title: CYNDI LAUPER IN 'GIRLS JUST WANT FUN'
description: ''Girls Just Want to Have Fun,'' which opened Friday at the National and other theaters, is not the current film that captures the spirit of Cyndi Lauper's hit record; ''Desperately Seeking Susan'' is. Although supposedly ''inspired'' by the record, ''Girls Just Want to Have Fun'' doesn't even use Miss Lauper's own version of the song. It is performed by someone named Deborah Galli, although the movie doesn't go to undue lengths to emphasize that point.

title: Bethany Kandel, A Writer, Weds
description: The marriage of Bethany Lynn Kandel, a freelance writer, to Gary M. Fishman, vice president and director of the New York office of Donald Reynolds Associates, a Los Angeles public relations concern, took place last night at Windows on the World in Manhattan. Rabbi Joseph H. Gelberman performed the ceremony.

title: NICARAGUANS MAKING PLANS FOR EMBARGO
description: From tractors to turbines, most of the equipment and machinery used at the sprawling San Antonio sugar plantation here was made in the United States. Nonetheless, administrators say they do not believe the new American trade embargo will hurt them much.

title: UTILITY PROTESTERS VISIT ALBANY
description: A DELEGATION of 700 county residents led by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a Republican, and County Legislator Paul J. Feiner, a Democrat, visited Albany last week to see about getting cheaper electric rates for Westchester.

title: IN THE CHINESE ROOM
description: MINDS, BRAINS AND SCIENCE By John Searle. 107 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $10.

title: Cambridge
description: To the Editor: A. L. Rowse's glowing tribute to Cambridge University (''Cambridge Through Oxford Eyes,'' Travel, March 17) evoked my memorable visit in 1981. His designation of King's College Chapel as ''an architectural monument . . . Cambridge's greatest jewel'' delighted me; one of life's small satisfactions through the years has been the occasional discovery that a cherished private opinion is shared by an outstanding authority.

title: New Outbreak Of Killings In India Blamed on Sikhs
description: Sikh extremists last week were blamed for coordinated attacks that killed dozens of Hindus and wounded about 150 people in New Delhi and two states of northern India. It was the worst such outbreak since hit-and-run murders by Sikhs last year touched off clashes in which thousands of Sikhs were killed.

title: MAKING DATABASES MORE ACCESSIBLE
description: OF the three basic software applications that dominate the business world, the popularity of database programs has lagged far behind word processing and spreadsheet applications. Despite a database's enormous potential for manipulating business information, it is only now slowly coming into its own.

title: LAMENTS OF A SPRING WITHOUT THE ISLANDERS
description: SOMETHING'S wrong on Long Island. It's May and the Islanders aren't playing.

title: NEW CASSETTES: MOZART TO BOGART
description: Wham: The Video CBS/Fox 32 minutes. $19.98 The British pop duo Wham has sold millions of records with recycled American-style soul music and boyish, telegenic images.

title: A Wary Bachelor
description: Roderick Thorp appears to be not simply ''a wary bachelor,'' but an intolerant one as well (''A Wary Bachelor,'' About Men, March 31).

title: REAGAN SALUTES U.S. MOTHERS AS 'COMMUNICATORS OF VALUES'
description: On the day before Mother's Day, President Reagan saluted mothers as making a ''unique contribution'' to the nation.

title: WARDEN ASSESSES HER BEDFORD HILLS JOB
description: ELAINE A. LORD's doctoral thesis on female prison inmates lies buried in a heap of papers on a table in her cottage. These days, she wonders when she will get around to finishing it.

title: IN BARCELONA, A CELEBRATION OF SINGULAR STYLE
description: Barcelona has always marched to its own drummer. It is the city identified with such individualistic spirits as Picasso, Miro, Gaudi and Columbus.

title:
ABOUT MEN;

NICKNAMES
description: I WON'T ANSWER TO ROSE beak any more. Or Karate Joe.

title: IN SALADS, NOW ALMOST ANYTHING GOES
description: SALADS have become an essential component of dining at any season, but as summer approaches they assume greater importance. A lunch may be only a salad. For a refreshing warm-weather first course one thinks of salad, and the right salad can replace a hot vegetable to accompany the main course. Many of the salad ingredients are available all year, but their price, abundance and condition are best in summer.

title: AID CUTOFF AVERTED
description: WESTCHESTER Legal Services appears to have won its battle with County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who wanted to cut off funds to the private agency because it was suing the county on behalf of some of its indigent clients.

title: Topics;   FEEDING HABITS
description: Methuselah's Recipe How can you live longer? Semi-starve yourself and take a lot of exercise is one approach. But there are catches: You have to start when young, and the recipe is proven only with laboratory rats.

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor: Harrison E. Salisbury's article ''Capturing Old Echoes in the New Peking'' indeed captures the uniqueness of China; Stanley Carr's sidebar article, ''Options for Today's China Hands,'' points out one of the reasons this uniqueness is being obliterated. It is not entirely due to ''industry and Communism'' as Theodore H. White describes it, but also due to foreign tourists, who for reasons I cannot fathom, travel all the way to China and yet desire and expect hotels that look like American chains and serve gourmet French food!

title: DOCENT TRAINING TURNS OUT VOLUNTEERS WHO LIGHT THE WAY
description: THE 40 women were not in a good mood. Members of a Brandeis University study group from Essex County, N.J., they were having lunch at the Hudson River Museum as part of the day's outing that would include touring the museum. The food, however, was slow in coming, because of a mixup in arrangements, and tempers were plainly turning sour.

title: SPEAKERS FOR ALL TASTES FEATURED AT GRADUATIONS
description: COMMENCEMENT season opens today with exercises at the University of Bridgeport, and ends June 9, when the last of more than 20,000 state graduates marches down the aisle at the University of New Haven.

title: EROS BY THE XINGU
description: ANXIOUS PLEASURES The Sexual Lives of an Amazonian People. By Thomas Gregor. Illustrated. 223 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: BUILT TO LAST, BUT NOT TO NEGLECT
description: WALLS made of brick, stone or cement block look as if they will last almost forever - and in fact most will last a lifetime and are more maintenance-free than most other structural materials. But they do have one potential weakness: The mortar joints between the individual bricks, stones or blocks can sometimes crack, crumble or otherwise deteriorate.

title: KENYA PLANS DRASTIC STEP TO HALT RHINOCEROS POACHING
description: Kenya has adopted a drastic, last-ditch strategy to save the endangered black rhinoceros from poachers.

title: Required Reading;   A Future Decided By a Flip of a Coin
description: Excerpted from ''Giant Steps: The Autobiography of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar'' by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Peter Knobler, published by Bantam Books.

title: Los Angeles: For Downtown, An Ambitious Mixed-Use Project
description: THE first of California Plaza's three glass-encased office towers is now visible on the expanding downtown skyline of Los Angeles, but the project, the most ambitious mixed-used urban development in the West, still has not signed up its first tenant.

title: Q AND A
description: Who Is the 'Tenant'? Question: My mother-in-law has occupied a rent-stabilized apartment for 20 years. I have paid the rent for five years and my daughter has lived there on occasion. When my mother-in-law dies, can I retain it for myself or my daughter? . . . I. I. A., Flushing, Queens Answer: Although you have been paying the rent, your mother-in-law is probably the tenant of record, according to Martin A. Shlufman, deputy counsel for rent administration for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. An immediate-family member can remain only if it was his or her primary residence; staying there ''on occasion'' does not qualify. House-Rule Violations Question: What recourse does a co-op board have with respect to a tenant-shareholder who persists in flouting such house rules as the requirement that bicycles be transported via service elevators, or that no more than two washing machines be used at a time? . . . L. R. M., Manhattan Answer: Violations of the house rules are a default of the lease, says Marc Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, and you can seek an injunction in State Supreme Court to stop the conduct or terminate the lease and bring an eviction proceeding in Housing Court. He noted that a court might hesitate to evict on such grounds, and suggested that the agent or board remind the offender of the rules in writing and then discuss them with him. Primary Residence Question: My husband and I and our children live in a rent-stabilized apartment.

title: CASH FLOWS COUNT MORE THAN GOODS
description: MORE than a handful of economists on both sides of the Pacific say it is dirty pool to lay all the blame for the American trade deficit on the Japanese. It is more the fault, they say, of Americans who persist in spending their money rather than saving it.

title: Paralysis Risk Seen
description: Paul Johns, the wide receiver of the Seattle Seahawks, said the club would not let him play because of his high risk of paralysis.

title: THIS O'NEILL PLAY DESERVES REVIVAL
description: REVIVALS of ''Desire Under the Elms,'' the play Eugene O'Neill wrote when he was living in Ridgefield, are rare. The current Hartford Stage Company production ought to change that.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the article ''Town Fights Sand Miners'' on April 21, it was incorrectly stated that Northeast Mines Inc. of Kings Park had been temporarily restrained from operating by the State Department of Environmental Conservation. Also, according to Peter R. Newman, lawyer for Northeast, the company did agree to purchase an adjacent 31-acre site but the seller could not deliver the title.

title: Officials Seek a Way to Halt Run on Maryland Thrift Unit
description: Officials met today to seek a way to stop a run on Maryland's second largest privately insured thrift institution, as a computer breakdown forced the thrift to turn away long lines of customers.

title: CAMBRIDGE
description: To the Editor: I doubt that anyone has ever written a better article on Cambridge than Professor Rowse, and I wish I might have had it to read before visiting the university for the first time in 1944, albeit I did not go there primarily to survey the academic scene. His last, short paragraph about the American military cemetery did, however, poignantly recall memorable experiences of World War II.

title: Now, Mobile Hustings
description: If you're afraid politics is becoming increasingly less personal and more mechanical in the electronic age, wait till you see the Rapid Deployment Force. That is the name two young innovators from Connecticut have given the mobile campaign headquarters they have developed for the 1986 elections and are prepared to lease for $1,000 a week each to some four dozen determined candidates.

title: TRAFFIC BILL SEEKS TO PROTECT HORSES
description: WHILE the General Assembly's Transportation Committee has wrestled with such modern problems as infrastructure repair and toll removals, it has also taken time this session to deal with a more old-fashioned transportation problem: horses.

title: 'MOB' TRIALS IN BOSTON SET TO OPEN AFTER DELAY
description: After months of delay, the first of a series of trials involving what prosecutors describe as Boston's organized crime family is scheduled to begin on Tuesday.

title: Boycott Predicted
description: South Africa is barred from Olympic competition because of its official policy of apartheid, and Harry Edwards wants to make sure things stay that way. Edwards, the organizer of the protest by some black athletes at the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City, said he would lead a boycott of the 1988 Seoul Games if South Africa were allowed to compete.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RED SCARE! Right-Wing Hysteria, Fifties Fanaticism and Their Legacy in Texas. By Don E. Carleton. (Texas Monthly, $18.95.) In this vigorously researched local history, Don E. Carleton, the director of the Barker Texas History Center at the University of Texas in Austin, examines the ''Red scare'' in Houston during the 1950's.

title: A FRIEND AND STEWARD OF THE ARTS STEPS DOWN
description: When it became known, a few weeks ago, that Paul Mellon had decided to step down as chairman of the trustees of the National Gallery of Art and retire from the board, the news took a while to sink in. The name of Mellon was, after all, inseparable from the very idea of the National Gallery. It was Andrew W. Mellon who had had the idea, got hold of the land, built the building and seen it well and truly launched. By his wish, his name was not on it, but everyone knew that his was not only the imagination but the pocketbook behind it.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

SERVICE AWARDS
description: In two different ceremonies last week, contributions to the community and to the arts were celebrated. The real-estate developer Carl Austin, State Senator John E. Flynn and the civic leader Joyce Michaelian were honored at Westchester Community College's 13th annual Medallion Awards dinner, while Roy R. Neuberger and the General Foods Corporation received the 1985 Arts Awards from the Council for the Arts in Westchester.

title: OTTO KLEMPERER BROUGHT LISTENERS TO THE HEART OF MUSIC
description: The late Otto Klemperer literally embodied a vast amount of 20th-century musical history. Born 100 years ago this Tuesday, Klemperer began his career as a protege of Mahler and Hans Pfitzner, conducted first performances of works by Schoenberg and Stravinsky, and, in his last years, took great interest in the latest syntactic innovations of Pierre Boulez and Karlheinz Stockhausen. He made his first records in 1924 (dim, acoustic 78's of works by Beethoven, Bruckner and Schubert) and his last in the early 1970's, nearly 50 years later, in an era of stereo spectaculars.

title: STEVENS SIGNS AGREEMENT TO WIDEN ITS USE OF COMPUTERS
description: THE Stevens Institute of Technology has signed an agreement with the Digital Equipment Corporation of Maynard, Mass., that will provide the institute with $22 million of computer equipment over a three-year period.

title: Former Deputy At Defense Gets 4 Years in Prison
description: There were appeals for leniency from prominent defense industry executives, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, current and former heads of the Joint Chiefs of Staff - even a former Commander in Chief. His lawyer called him ''a great patriot'' who had been repeatedly decorated in World War II. And the defendant himself pleaded that he had suffered enough, that ''the last two years have been a living nightmare.'' To no avail. Last week, a Federal judge sentenced Paul Thayer, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, to four years in prison for obstructing justice.

title: NUGGET'S LONG-SHOT HILTON BID
description: IT is Wednesday afternoon and Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman, president and chief executive officer of Golden Nugget, the casino-hotel corporation, is having a typically busy week. It began in Las Vegas, where he and his friends, Sylvester Stallone, the actor, and Samuel Belzberg, the Canadian financier, watched Marvin Hagler knock out Tommy Hearns. It will end in Atlantic City, where he will check up on the Golden Nugget's establishment on the Boardwalk.

title: TIMES SQ. PROJECT SEEN AS CHALLENGE
description: A few days before Governor Cuomo chose him to oversee the proposed redevelopment of Times Square and 42d Street, Robert T. Hall toured the area.

title: FILIMING A WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSTAGES, HEROES AND SPIES ARE THE FOCUS OF A NEW SERIES
description: To some, the word escape may conjure up thoughts of prison breaks or hopping a weekend train to the Hamptons, but a British-made series new to American viewers provides a more politically oriented interpretation. ''Escape,'' a trio of hour-long programs from the British Broadcasting Corporation that begins Wednesday evening at 8 on the Arts and Entertainment Network, reconstructs three acts of rescue, flight and disappearance taken from international headlines.

title: Second Thoughts On Contra Aid
description: Some Democrats in the House have been having second thoughts about their side's rejection of aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, particularly after uneasily watching Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega Saavedra solicit help in the past two weeks in Moscow and other Communist capitals. Most of the Democrats were still opposed to military aid, as shown by last week's votes in the House Intelligence Committee to reject an Administration request for $28 million for military supplies and to extend the ban on such aid another year.

title: TESTIMONY CHALLENGES WOMAN WHO RECANTED RAPE CHARGE
description: The clemency hearing of Gary E. Dotson, jailed for raping a woman who now says the assault never took place, ended today with testimony challenging the woman's new assertions.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

THE MEDIUM AS A CONTINUUM OF ART
description: West Coast photography news has recently been dominated by the Getty Museum, which in one sensational purchase of four leading photography collections ensured that Los Angeles will become an important international center of photographic studies. Meanwhile, however, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has been readying a series of three exhibitions of photography from its own collection, the first of which opened last Friday. Between them they demonstrate that the San Francisco Modern is and has been for some years a photographic institution of international scope and standing.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Is car-train transportation, similar to the Auto Train between Virginia and Florida, offered in Europe? If so, how can I find out about it? - R. M. B., Los Angeles Answer:There's an extensive network of car-train services, notably in France, Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain, West Germany, Italy, Austria and Yugoslavia. The services are primarily long distance. Some are on night trains, enabling drivers to sleep aboard overnight and continue driving the next morning, and several run from one country to another. Reservations must be made well in advance, and usually they must be made directly with the national railroads in the country or countries involved. A table devoted to car trains appears in the ''Thomas Cook Continental Timetable,'' which costs $15.95 at the Traveller's Bookstore, 22 West 52d Street, New York, N.Y. 10019 (212-664-0995). Information is also available from some of the individual railroads that maintain offices in this country.

title: Connecticut: Out of the Past Comes a New Source of Space
description: TOWERING over the sleek new buildings that make up an increasing amount of commercial space in downtown New Britain, the 80-year-old red-brick mill buildings of the Fafnir bearing factory are giant reminders of the city's grimier industrial past.

title: 'POETRY IS A KIND OF UNCONSCIOUS AUTOBIOGRAPHY'
description: NOT long back at a cocktail party, a lady, being polite, asked me if I was going to write an autobiography. I was startled, never having thought of such a thing, and I seemed to hear my rude answer so clearly that, for a fraction of a second, I thought I had actually uttered it: ''Hell, no - I've done that already.'' But I pulled myself together and managed to mumble something by way of a negative.

title: GETTING AT THE ROOTS OF MIAMI'S VICE
description: A highspeed boat makes a post-midnight dash through an ocean inlet into the waters of Biscayne Bay, chased by a Coast Guard helicopter. Eight miles later the boat is abandoned; 1,909 pounds of cocaine are found aboard.

title: DROUGHT RAISES FEARS OF SOUTHEAST'S FARMERS
description: Thomas Godowns stepped into the shade of a large tree before looking across his field of withering wheat. Then he squinted up at a bright sky flecked with nothing more hopeful than wisps of white clouds. He shook his head.

title: BAYLOR GRAND SLAM BOOSTS YANKS, 11-3
description: Complacency has not set in among the Yankees when they play Kansas City, but ineptness permeated the Royals today and the Yankees' winning streak over them goes on.

title: Help to AIDS Victim Brings Phone Threats
description: A couple who opened their home to an AIDS victim with as little as six months to live say they have no fear of catching the disease, but they have received telephoned threats from neighbors.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BACH IN PRINCETON

title: TEMPLE CREW WINS
description: Temple University won the featured race for varsity heavyweight eights at the Dad Vail Regatta today, gaining the Tom Conville Cup for the third successive year.

title: A FIERCE FIGHT OVER FOOD
description: ''WHERE are the oranges? Where's the beef?'' Those are insistent demands from American trade negotiators, who keep trying to stir the Japanese into removing barriers against farm products. If the Japanese regularly dined on (American) beef teriyki washed down with a glass of (American) orange juice, trade tensions much reduced.

title: IN SHORT:FICTION
description: THE WORD OF A GENTLEMAN. By Peter Niesewand. (Stein & Day, $15.95.) ''The Word of a Gentleman'' opens with three men throwing a woman from a cliff to her death on the rocks below.

title: POPE, ON DUTCH TRIP, FIRMLY CALLS FOR CHURCH UNITY
description: Pope John Paul II today began his pilgrimage to the Netherlands, and its divided Roman Catholic Church, with firm calls for unity and fidelity to Rome, warning that ''freedom cannot be abused.''

title: Third-World Cardinals
description: To the Editor:

title: AT PEPSICO, VICTORY IS DECLARED
description: THE people over at Pepsico's headquarters were talking about Coke last week. About how Pepsi-Cola had ''licked'' its No. 1 competitor. And how the sweet taste of victory tastes a lot like Pepsi. The quiet types let their bodies do the talking: offering thumbs up signs and winks as they passed each other in the cavernous marble hallways of the company's seven-building 10-acre site here.

title: Patricia Wilcock Is a Jersey Bride
description: Patricia Lynn Wilcock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bray Wilcock of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stephen Charles Schram, a son of John Schram of New York and Betty Schram of Memphis. The Rev. David B. Earnest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: BALLET: BALANCHINE 'SERENADE'
