description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Serenade'' is, in its way, a ballet about youth - created, as it was, for Balanchine's first American dancers and incorporating incidents from the ballet classroom. The dancers of the Pennsylvania Ballet certainly did not look like students on Thursday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the company performs through Sunday.

title: IS TV UNPATRIOTIC OR SIMPLY UNMINDFUL?
description: This is the charge: that the television networks are left, liberal, unpatriotic, or a sebaceous mixture of all three. CBS is the usual target, although ample censure is left over for NBC and ABC. Didn't Ted Turner say that ''the greatest enemies America has ever had, posing a greater threat to our way of life than Nazi Germany or Tojo's Japan, are the three television networks''? Didn't Senator Jesse Helms speak about network people who, ''if they do not hate America first, certainly have a smug contempt for American ideals and principles''? Censure grows; fervor rises, while the networks, for the most part, stand on their injured dignity. In fact, the argument is too serious to be left to partisans of either side.

title: The Secret of Redemption
description: All the rhetoric and wreaths did, finally, convey some meaning. Europe remains divided almost exactly as it was when the Soviet and American Armies stopped 40 years ago. And the victors persist in the antagonisms that instantly appeared. ''An iron curtain is drawn down upon their front,'' Churchill cabled to Truman on May 12, 1945; the chance to spread freedom across all Europe was slipping away.

title: Free Spirits At Dover, Del.
description: THREE Wilmington sixth graders came away from a night at the Delaware Governor's mansion last week with ''inconclusive evidence'' but with a spooky feeling that they had not been alone.

title: Who Goes Hungry In East Harlem?
description: The East Harlem Interfaith Welfare Committee has kept track of hunger in the Manhattan neighborhood north of 96th Street and east of Fifth Avenue since 1979. And every year the organization, which represents seven religious voluntary agencies, has reported dramatic increases in the number of East Harlem residents who have endured hunger at one time or another.

title: Norfolk, Mass., Stirs Issue
description: A ruling by the Massachusetts State Auditor, John J. Finnegan, has touched off a controversy over who should pay for state-ordered improvements in municipal landfills.

title: FOR MARVIN GAYE, LIFE - THROUGH SONG - GOES ON
description: ''Dream of a Lifetime'' isn't the album to put in Marvin Gaye's time capsule. Seen uncharitably, it's a collection of leftovers and outtakes - an attempt by Columbia Records to recoup its reported $2 million contract with the singer, who was shot dead by his father on April 1, 1984 after making one Columbia album.

title: Hillary Morgan Becomes Bride
description: Hillary Ann Morgan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Morgan of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to J. Stuart Bardwell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nuel J. Bardwell of Skaneateles, N.Y. The Rev. Charles Kavanaugh performed the ceremony at St. John and St. Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: EXPRESSWAY DECISION IS DUE
description: ALTHOUGH his two top Atlantic County political allies are at odds over the matter, Governor Kean is still expected to make his recommendation this week on the post of executive director of the New Jersey Expressway Authority.

title: AGAINST GENERALS, FADING STARS SHINE
description: So much has gone wrong for the Baltimore Stars, formerly of Philadelphia, that the defending champions reflect as well as any the woes besetting the United States Football League this season. They have been struggling on and off the field.

title: APPEARANCES CAN BE MISLEADING
description: Some situations that appear simple become complex on closer examination. Consider the position in which a defender holds the ace of a suit and dummy, to his left, has a holding headed by king-jack. The declarer leads low toward the king-jack.

title: Nigeria Sends Them Packing
description: Ever since world demand for their oil slumped three years ago, Nigerians have felt too poor to tolerate throngs of needy foreigners in their midst. But poor is a relative term in drought-ravaged West Africa and the neighbors keep coming and overstaying their 90-day Nigerian visas.

title: 'TUNA' IS SUM OF LESSER PARTS
description: CLOSING the current Hartman Theater season with ''Greater Tuna'' is clearly an economic rather than an esthetic choice, and a convenient one at that. The Virginia Museum Theater in Richmond had a packaged production ready to be shipped, and here it is.

title: Jersey Wine
description: VINTNERS in New Jersey said a year ago that they hoped to make the Garden State a national contender as a wine producer. They conceded that it was a long row to hoe.

title: NEW DOWNTOWN SPACE PROMPTS FEARS OF SURPLUS
description: DOWNTOWN Manhattan is bracing for a big bulge of commercial office space beginning this year, and brokers from Broad Street to Bayonne are crunching numbers over it.

title: 450 MILES: 'A LOT OF PLACES TO RIDE'
description: More and more Washingtonians are spinning their wheels these days.

title: WHEN THE TENANT IS ALSO THE DEVELOPER'S PARTNER
description: WHEN I. B. M. announced in January that it was becoming both an equity partner and the major tenant of a Manhattan developer who was putting up an office building on East 55th Street, the move took some observers by surprise.

title: LIFTING THE LID OFF CONTAINMENT
description: CONTENDING WITH KENNAN Toward a Philosophy of American Power. By Barton Gellman. 172 pp. New York: Praeger Publishers. $21.95.

title: BIG ART IN A SMALL FRAME
description: Snowy peaks and a golden carriage, a great private art collection and tax-free discount stores, all in the last surviving fragment of the Holy Roman Empire. It sounds improbable, but ask the inhabitants of that fortunate valley and they'll tell you there is nothing fictional about their country or about the Prince who rules them. Indeed, Liechtenstein, that odd survival of a remote past, prides itself on its modernity: behind the picturesque chalets, silicon chips are being manufactured, while the Bank of Liechtenstein is one of the busiest, most sophisticated financial institutions in Europe.

title: Lynn beats twins again, 4-2
description: Fred Lynn hit Curt Wardle's first pitch for a three-run homer with none out in the ninth inning tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a dramatic 4-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: SINGERS FILL SCHEDULE OF CONCERTS IN THE AREA
description: THE concert schedule suggests that almost every singer in Westchester and surrounding counties may be busy today or next weekend: at least seven choral concerts are scheduled, plus sundry entries in the musical-comedy and operetta spheres.

title: Court Upholds Mayor's Order On Homosexuals
description: Mayor Koch last week won the assistance of a state appeals court to outmaneuver the Salvation Army, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese and Agudath Israel of America over the issue of discrimination against homosexuals. The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled that the Mayor had not only the authority but also the duty to prohibit those who do business with the city from exhibiting bias against homosexuals.

title: PLAN TO TAX YALE LAND
description: PROPOSALS to tax at least some parts of what are now tax-exempt institutions in the city, particularly Yale University, are before the New Haven Board of Aldermen.

title: TAX REVENUES...AND DEBATES
description: To the Editor:

title: LOBBIES WITH STELLAS: THE DEVELOPER'S CHOICE
description: ''WE have this monumental lobby and we wanted to find a way to augment it,'' explained Mortimer B. Zuckerman, developer of the 47-story office building going up at 599 Lexington Avenue, at 53d Street. ''The only artist who was powerful enough to do it was Frank Stella.''

title: Poor Mother, Poor Baby
description: Once, no mother could expect to see all her babies reach their first birthdays. Now, most of us take it for granted that our children will live to bury us. Yet suddenly, America's steady progress in preventing infant deaths has slowed. What better time than Mother's Day to ask why?

title: PICKING UP A EUROPEAN CAR BARGAIN
description: BEFORE starting a yearlong European sabbatical, Warren and Micheline Myers, teachers at the Groton School in Groton, Mass., visited a local Volvo dealer and ordered a sedan, which they later picked up in Paris. Their advance planning saved them more than $1,000 on the price of the car, sales tax, plus the money they would have spent to rent a car in Europe - and Volvo picked up the costs of shipping the car home.

title: Causes of the Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: East East Village?
description: Directly across the street from Stuyvesant Town, on the corner of First Avenue and 14th Street in an area of Manhattan that is increasingly being referred to as the East Village, a developer is transforming two former furniture warehouses into a 40-unit condominium.

title: NEW CASSETTES: MOZART TO BOGART
description: Bill Cosby, Himself CBS/Fox Video 104 minutes. $59.98 Beyond the central fact that this video cassette is roll-on-the-floor funny, it gives us greater understanding of the engine that has powered ''The Cosby Show'' into its dominant position in commercial television.

title: THE PAST IN THE PRESENT TENSE
description: NEW AND SELECTED POEMS #1923-1985. By Robert Penn Warren. 322 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $19.95. Paper $9.95. From the deep and premature midnight Of woodland, I hear the first whip-o-will's Precious grief, and my young heart, As darkling I stand, yearns for a grief To be worthy of that sound.

title: A DIRE LONG-RANGE FORECAST
description: As global nightmares go, the greenhouse effect has managed not to keep policy makers awake nights devising plans of action. Scientists see an assortment of theoretical catastrophes just over the horizon, but the more dire their predictions, the more difficult it seems to find an appropriate response.

title: QUALITY OF CITY SCHOOLS TESTED IN TRIAL ON RESIDENCY
description: THREE parents, dissatisfied with schools in Hartford, face felony charges for enrolling their children in suburban schools.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Bridge column on page 40 of the Arts and Leisure section today inadvertently duplicates one that appeared last Monday. A fresh column appears in this section, on page 58.

title: LEADERSHIP OF DEMOCRATS IS CHALLENGED
description: A SIMMERING dispute within Democratic Party ranks was forced into the open last week when Arnold I. Klugman, the leader of the New Rochelle Democratic Committee, announced that he would seek to replace Thomas E. Carty as the party's county leader when his term expires in September.

title: Eye Problem Revealed
description: Carl Butler, the running back from Michigan State, was released by the Atlanta Falcons after completing a physical that revealed he had a glass eye. The 5-foot-11-inch, 222-pound Butler reported to the Falcons' minicamp with other rookies last Friday.

title: GIFTED ACTORS GLITTER IN A TRIFLE FROM THE 20'S
description: There are plays and then there are playgrounds.

title: CROSSCURRENTS IN EARLY DESIGN
description: Ferment in design at the turn of the century produced an extraordinary amount of creativity and similarity in the furnishings and graphics that emerged in Vienna, Glasgow, London and Chicago. The revival of interest in the giants of the period -Josef Hoffmann and Koloman Moser in Vienna, Charles Rennie Mackintosh in Glasgow, Charles Robert Ashbee in London and Frank Lloyd Wright in Chicago - has uncovered evidence proving how freely these men borrowed from one another. Surprisingly, this cross-fertilization does not seem to have diminished individuality.

title: HOBOKEN MAYOR STEPS UP PACE OF CAMPAIGN
description: Mayor Steve Cappiello, who has held the top position in City Hall for the last 12 years, has taken to the streets in his effort to win a fourth four-year term as Mayor of this Hudson County community on Tuesday.

title: L.I. STARS WINNER IN TRACK
description: Two Long Island runners, Kathy Franey of Massapequa High School and Bill Going of Chaminade in Mineola, posted the best times in New York State this year for the 1,600-meter run at the 18th annual Loucks Games today.

title: Artist Is Married To Louise White
description: Louise Dawson White, a graphic designer, and Charles Louis Marburg, an artist, both of New York, were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Garrison, Md. The Rev. William Baxter performed the ceremony.

title: Jean Hastings Cameron Is the Bride Of Mark D. Smith, an Army Captain
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday, Jean Hastings Cameron, a daughter of Mrs. Richard R. Dailey of New York and Lyme, Conn., and William C. Cameron of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married to Capt. Mark Donald Smith, U.S.A., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Smith of Lancaster, Pa. The Rev. Susan C. Harriss performed the ceremony.

title: MARSH IS BULWARK OF FLYERS' DEFENSE
description: After nearly seven professional years, thousands of blocked shots, bruises from head to toe, and even a goal now and then, Brad Marsh has a one-sided look to his job.

title: Papandreou's Politics
description: ''The Politics of Anti-Americanism'' (April 7), Henry Kamm's excellent analysis of Andreas Papandreou, lacks only a precise statement of the Prime Minister's political motivations - i.e., a small country can criticize the United States to gain political advantage at home while maintaining (and even enhancing) the economic advantages of association with the United States. As a Greek nationalist and politician, Mr. Papandreou can hardly be faulted for taking this approach.

title: NICARAGUAN PRESIDENT PRAISES MOSCOW AS A FRIEND
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua today sought to explain his trip to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe by saying that Moscow had been a friend in providing aid to make up for American damage to the Nicaraguan economy.

title: SUBURBANITE TO GOAT-RAISER: A JERSEY ODYSSEY
description: In her first life, Gail LeCompte was a ''die-hard suburbanite.'' She lived in a trim little house in Ridgewood, played tennis and bridge, and belonged to the women's club. Then came the now-familiar ephiphany.

title: ITALIAN ELECTIONS COULD EVENTUALLY LOSEN CRAXI'S GRIP
description: When Italian voters go to the polls today and tomorrow, their decisions will affect Pope John Paul II, Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, the largest Communist Party in the West and the Christian Democrats, who have governed their country for more than four decades.

title: NUCLEAR BACKERS COUNSEL COHALAN
description: WHILE Suffolk County continues its legal battle against the licensing of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, on the ground that an evacuation of the area surrounding the reactor could not be organized in a nuclear emergency, recent indications are that County Executive Peter F. Cohalan has sought the advice of two nuclear proponents on how to handle the problem.

title: VOYAGING FAR AND WIDE IN SEARCH OF MELVILLE
description: In scholarly and literary circles, it's Herman Melville time. Moreover - and for no particular reason other than it's nice to celebrate something in the month of May by mayoral proclamation even if the author was born in August 1819 and ''Moby Dick'' was first published in November 1851 - this is Herman Melville Week in New York. Well, why not? Melville wasn't born with a silver harpoon in his hand in Nantucket but right here, at 6 Pearl Street, in Lower Manhattan.

title: HONORING A 'ONE-MAN SCHOOL OF JOURNALISM'
description: AT a time of year when many students are eager to put distance between themselves and their teachers, there is one group of students happily anticipating a reunion with their professor.

title: Chinese Rat Control: A Recipe for Success
description: Marinated rat steaks and rat-skin shoes are popular in some areas of rural China and are a good way to help control the pests that are said to consume 15 million tons of grain a year, a newspaper said today.

title: 15 Bombs Explode In Northern Corsica
description: Corsican guerrillas seeking independence from France carried out about 15 bombings in northern Corsica on Friday night, the police said today.

title: DRUGS SEEN AS PERIL TO GAME ITSELF
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth wants baseball players to submit to drug tests because of a fear that players who become dependent on cocaine are potentially vulnerable to gamblers seeking inside information or seeking to control the results of games, he and other officials say.

title: LIFEGUARD SHORTAGE REPORTED
description: OFFICIALS say there aren't enough lifeguards to go around on Long Island, and as a result some public pools and portions of beaches may have to be closed down this summer.

title: Youth Dies in a Six-Story Fall From Greenwich Village Roof
description: A 19-year-old youth fell six stories to his death yesterday as he was trying to lower himself from the roof into a window of his father's Greenwich Village apartment, the police said.

title: Cable TV
description: Some vintage films don't seem to tarnish. And Saturday offers three diversions on cable at 8 P.M. There's Eisenstein's Soviet classic ''Alexander Nevsky'' (1938), which will be shown over Arts & Entertainment (repeated at midnight, bless 'em).

title: SALVADORAN REBELS, IN NEW TACTICS, ARE KIDNAPPING OR KILLING MAYORS
description: In a sharp shift in tactics, leftist guerrillas have killed 2 newly elected mayors, kidnapped 8 others and burned 32 mayors' offices in recent weeks, according to a Salvadoran Army spokesman and Government officials.

title: FOR THE WHALES, THE TIDE FINALLY SEEMS TO BE TURNING
description: ...the moot point is, whether Leviathan can long endure so wide a chase and so remorseless a havoc; whether he must not at last be exterminated from the waters, and the last whale, like the last man, smoke his last pipe, and then himself evaporate in the final puff.

title: Mary Lindsay Peek Is Wed
description: Mary Lindsay Peek and Paul Gerard Roland were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield, N.J., by the Rev. G. David Deppen with Msgr. Raymond J. Pollard, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: 'Comparable Worth' at Work In Los Angeles
description: The advocates of ''comparable worth'' won a big victory last week when Los Angeles agreed to give raises to 3,900 clerks and librarians, mostly women, to bring their salaries up to those of jobs held mainly by men.

title: There Goes the Offshore Solution
description: Ever since President Nixon launched Project Independence more than a decade ago, the goal of insulating the United States from another energy shock has been somewhere on Washington's agenda.

title: Atlanta: Rapid-Transit Station Is the Hub Of Burgeoning Buckhead Area
description: WHEN the $225 million Atlanta Plaza opens its first office tower later this year, it will be the first commercial project in the thriving Buckhead area specifically oriented to the rapid-transit station completed there last December.

title: Lauren M. Ginter Married in Jersey
description: The marriage of Lauren Michelle Ginter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawence U. Ginter of West Chester, Pa., to Robert Arnold Jackson 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Jackson of Lawrenceville, N.J., took place yesterday at the Presbyterian Church of Lawrenceville. The Rev. H. Dana Fearon 3d performed the ceremony.

title: WORLD WAR II'S 'FORGOTTEN FORGOTTEN' GATHER
description: In this year of 40th anniversary commemorations of the end of World War II, several hundred of the self-described ''forgotten forgotten'' gathered here recently to reminisce about a part of the war they feel has been neglected: the China-Burma-India theater.

title: Stephenson Triumphs
description: Jan Stephenson of Australia won the $50,000 Hennessy Cup Ladies Golf Tournament today, beating Laura Davies, a rookie pro from Britain, by five strokes.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: BUILT TO LAST, BUT NOT TO NEGLECT
description: WALLS made of brick, stone or cement block look as if they will last almost forever - and in fact most will last a lifetime and are more maintenance-free than most other structural materials. But they do have one potential weakness: The mortar joints between the individual bricks, stones or blocks can sometimes crack, crumble or otherwise deteriorate.

title: TENNIS TRADITION, WITH LOVE
description: ONCE upon a time, Dick Gould said, there was an attitude about Stanford University's sports teams ''that you can't win because you're all intellectuals and you can't sacrifice.'' Then, Gould added, ''the 1967 swimming team won the nationals, and no sport requires greater dedication than swimming. That blew that theory out the window.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: May 12, 1985 Fiction

title: INDIA SIEZES 1,500 AS DEATHS MOUNT IN BOMB ATTACKS
description: About 1,500 people were reported in custody today in northern India in connection with bombings that have killed more than 70 people since Friday.

title: GARDEN WHERE BIBLICAL PLANTS COME TO LIFE
description: And Abraham tarried and planted a tamarisk, and Reuben brought Leah mandrake, and the Philistines bound Samson with ropes braided from a plant for which no English name exists.

title: BY WIRE, BY PHONE, A WATCH ON THE WORLD
description: The calm of the national Military Command Center, a hushed, dimly lit cavern the size of a small high school gymnasium deep inside the Pentagon, was broken by the telephone call from the Pacific Command in Hawaii.

title: RECONCILIATION AMONG THE RUINS
description: THE HOUSE OF THE SPIRITS By Isabel Allende. Translated by Magda Bogin. 368 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. WITH this spectacular first novel, Isabel Allende becomes the first woman to join what has heretofore been an exclusive male club of Latin American novelists. Not that she is the first contemporary female writer from Latin America (I think immediately, for instance, of Luisa Valenzuela and Cristina Peri Rossi) - but she is the first woman to approach on the same scale as the others the tormented patriarchal world of traditional Hispanic society and to argue that the enraged class violence in Latin America is a debate among men who are not only deaf but who have fixed and unalterable ideas on all subjects. And she has done all this in an absorbing and distinguished work that matches her predecessors' in quality as well as scope.

title: Peter Kenny Marries Linda C. Sterling
description: Linda Carol Sterling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arturo G. Sterling of New York, and Peter Christopher Kenny, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. James Kenny Jr. of Summit, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert J. Tomlian performed the ceremony at St. John Nepomucene Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: DODGER SHUFFLE KEEPING LASORDA BUSY
description: THE vendors say you can't tell the players without a scorecard, but even a scorecard may not help a fan keep up with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: NEW HAVEN'S KOSHER MARKET CLOSES
description: COUNTLESS restaurants and other stores have come and gone along Whalley Avenue in New Haven over the last 25 years, but the Crown Supermarket was different. It stubbornly upheld two dying traditions: those of the neighborhood grocery and the kosher supermarket.

title: Ex-Police Officer Acquitted
description: A former police officer was acquitted by a jury of charges that he extorted payoffs to protect illegal gambling. The man, Edward Quinn, a 44-year-old former Philadelphia police lieutenant, was the third officer acquitted in the last two years in a police corruption investigation that has resulted in 22 convictions and guilty pleas.

title: Marcy Lynn Steinbrecher Weds Alan Jeffrey Puklin
description: At Temple Israel in Westport, Conn., last night Marcy Lynn Steinbrecher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Steinbrecher of Weston, Conn., was married to Alan Jeffrey Puklin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Puklin of Hamden, Conn. Rabbi Robert Orkand officiated.

title: 'GREATER TUNA' NOT UP TO STANDARDS
description: CLOSING the current Hartman Theater season with ''Greater Tuna'' is clearly an economic rather than an esthetic choice, and a convenient one at that. The Virginia Museum Theater in Richmond had a packaged production ready to be shipped, and here it is.

title: May 12, 1985
description: Weeks This Last on Week FICTION Week List 1 THINNER, by Richard Bachman. (NAL Books, 1 11 $12.95.) In this pseudonymous novel by Stephen King, a young lawyer finds his body mysteriously wasting away. 2 CHAPTERHOUSE: DUNE, by Frank Herbert. 5 4 (Putnam, $17.95.) A new world rises from the Old Empire's ashes in this volume of the ''Dune'' series. 3 INSIDE, OUTSIDE, by Herman Wouk. 4 8 (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A traditionalist Jew's quest for identity in glittery contemporary America. 4 IF TOMORROW COMES, by Sidney Sheldon. 2 16 (Morrow, $17.95.) A young woman destroys the crime lords who got her an undeserved prison term. 5 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom 3 8 Clancy. (Naval Institute Press, $14.95.) A Lithuanian submarine driver defects to the United States with the Soviet Union's most advanced nuclear secrets. 6 FAMILY ALBUM, by Danielle Steel. 7 10 (Delacorte, $16.95.) A married couple with five children cope with the crises of contemporary America. 7 THE CLASS, by Erich Segal. 10 3 (Bantam, $17.95.) What happened to five members of the class of 1958 after they left Harvard Yard. 8 THE LONELY SILVER RAIN, by John D. 6 6 MacDonald. (Knopf, $15.95.) A yacht's disappearance, a debutante's murder and other puzzles Travis McGee must solve to save his life. 9 QUEENIE, by Michael Korda. (Linden 8 4 Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The glamorous career of Dawn Avalon, whose life was not unlike that of the late Merle Oberon. 10 GLITZ, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House, 11 14 $14.95.) The escapades, romantic and melodramatic, of a cop on the lam after a murder in Miami. 11 PROOF, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, 9 8 $16.95.) A young wine merchant gets caught in a scam involving murder and vengeance. 12 2MEN AND ANGELS, by Mary Gordon. 12 2 (Random House, $16.95.) The nature of love and motherhood reflected in a household dominated by two women. 13 A CREED FOR THE THIRD MILLENNIUM, 1 by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A man and a woman set out to salvage a spiritually exhausted America in the not-too-distant future. 14 THE SICILIAN, by Mario Puzo. 23 (Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A fictional life of Salvatore Giuliano, the Sicilian bandit of the 1940's. 15 THE FINISHING SCHOOL, by Gail 11 Godwin. (Viking, $16.95.) A young girl's relationship with an older woman leads to her mentor's downfall. Nonfiction 1 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee 1 28 Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of the automobile executive from immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 2 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell 3 6 Cowan and Melvyn Kinder. (Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Two clinical psychologists analyze the successes and failures of modern women in looking for acceptable men. 3 BREAKING WITH MOSCOW, by Arkady N. Shevchenko. 2 11 (Knopf, $18.95.) The autobiography of the highest-ranking Soviet official ever to defect. 4 LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo Buscaglia. 5 37 (Slack/Holt, $13.95.) Suggestions for ''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the fullest.'' 5 ONCE UPON A TIME, by Gloria 8 2 Vanderbilt. (Knopf, $16.95.) Memories of the first 17 years of a ''poor little rich girl.'' 6* THE COURAGE TO CHANGE, by Dennis 4 13 Wholey. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) Conversations with two dozen people about their problems with alcoholism. 7 THE SOONG DYNASTY, by Sterling 6 4 Seagrave. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) The tangled lives of Charlie Soong and his six children, who shaped much of China's modern history. 8 THE BLOOD OF ABRAHAM, by Jimmy Carter. 7 3 (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) The problems of the Middle East and what can be done about them, as seen by the former President. 9 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard 9 36 Bach. (Morrow, $16.95.) The author of ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull'' tells of his search for love. 10 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom 1 Peters and Nancy Austin (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 11 ''SURELY YOU'RE JOKING, MR. FEYNMAN,'' 10 9 by Richard P. Feynman. (Norton, $15.95.) A Nobel laureate in physics recounts his curious misadventures inside and outside his profession. 12 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 11 129 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse and drawings. 13 MOSES THE KITTEN, by James Herriot. 30 (St. Martin's, $9.95.) A waif kitten is adopted by a pig; illustrated. 14 SON OF THE MORNING STAR, by Evan S. Connell. 15 22 (North Point, $20.) A biography of Custer that is also a history of the Plains Indian wars. 15 NO MORE VIETNAMS, by Richard Nixon. 1 (Arbor House, $14.95.) The former President's view of 10 years of change in American foreign policy. Advice and Self-Help 1 NOTHING DOWN, by Robert G. Allen. 1 23 (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) How to buy real estate with little or no money; revised edition of a 1980 book. 2 DR. ABRAVANEL'S BODY TYPE PROGRAM 3 3 FOR HEALTH, FITNESS AND NUTRITION, by Elliot D. Abravanel and Elizabeth A. King. (Bantam, $15.95.) ''A total health program tailored for the individual.'' 3 WEIGHT WATCHERS QUICK START PROGRAM 2 17 COOKBOOK, by Jean Nidetch. (NAL Books, $17.95.) A cuisine that slims. 4 WHAT THEY DON'T TEACH YOU AT HARVARD 4 34 BUSINESS SCHOOL, by Mark H. McCormack. (Bantam, $16.95.) ''Street-smart'' notes and tips. 5 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. 5 6 (Morrow, $14.95.) Recipes for delicious dishes prepared at moderate cost.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Although Jessica Lange had already made such films as ''King Kong,'' ''How to Beat the High Cost of Living'' and ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' it was not until the release of ''Frances'' in December 1982 that she emerged as a major actress.

title: BASIC SUMMER WHITE
description: One of the most flattering of summer shades, white continues to be popular in a variety of silhouettes and fabrics. How better to dramatize a healthy tan.

title: DECONSTRUCTION FOR THE MASSES
description: EASY PIECES By Geoffrey H. Hartman. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $20.

title: Vested Interests In Allentown
description: THE Police Department in Allentown, Pa., says it will outfit its canine corps with bulletproof vests this month.

title: DEMOCRATIC LEADERS IN SOUTH FAVOR REGIONAL PRIMARY IDEA
description: Southern Democratic Party officials today expressed support for selecting the party's 1988 Presidential candidate in regional primaries.

title: NEW CASSETTES: MOZART TO BOGART
description: MOZART'S MARRIAGE TO FIGARO'

title: AT LAST BLUSH
description: THE SCENE IS Slag Heap, a moderate-sized winery somewhere in Northern California. It is night; the tanks and barrels and bottling lines are cloaked in silent darkness. A single lamp flickers in the office of Whitney Nebbiolo, the owner.

title: ALDA FILM RAISES A STIR ON EAST END
description: IT is an irony not lost on some local officials and residents that the plot of Alan Alda's new movie, ''Sweet Liberty,'' revolves around the effect a film company has on the daily life of a small town.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: STUDENT VACATIONS, HIGHLAND HORSES
description: Hosteling: From Cape Cod To Denmark Around this time of year, visions of vacations dance in the head of many a student.

title: EXORCISING THE 20TH CENTURY
description: HITLER IN HISTORY By Eberhard Jackel. 115 pp. Hanover, N.H.: University Press of New England. $11.95. IMAGINING HITLER By Alvin H. Rosenfeld. 121 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $15. HITLER has been dead for 40 years, and yet he is alive - in the debates of historians and in the conscience and fantasy of people everywhere.

title: PHILADELPHIA TRANSIT HIRING
description: The Philadelphia area mass transit agency plans to add about 120 employees to improve service and safety on its commuter rail lines. The Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority said Thursday that it would be adding engineers, conductors, passenger attendants and tower personnel over the next 14 months.

title: AGENT TELLS OF '79 THREATS BY KLAN AND NAZIS
description: A Federal undercover agent has testified that he knew before the shooting deaths of five anti-Klan demonstrators in 1979 that Ku Klux Klansmen and members of the American Nazi Party unit he had infiltrated would confront the demonstrators.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO BACK TAX BREAK FOR CHARITY GIFTS
description: President Reagan is likely to propose that taxpayers be permitted to continue deducting the full market value of property like stocks, real estate and works of art that they donate to charity, according to Administration officials.

title: Louis Malle And 'Alamo Bay'
description: In the article ''Louis Malle: An Outsider's Odyssey'' (April 7), John Culhane gives a good account of the paradoxes an intellectual encounters.

title: Kate Nearpass Wed to Warren Ogden
description: Kate Ann Nearpass, the daughter of Dr. Charles Nearpass of College Park, Md., and the late Bonita Spooner Nearpass, was married yesterday to Warren Russell Ogden, the son of Robert F. Ogden Jr. of Convent Station, N.J., and the late Martha Turner Ogden. The Rev. Dr. John G. Hamilton performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church of College Park.

title: Honoring Lowenstein
description: Americans for Democratic Action has established a program of Lowenstein fellowships to enable college students to get a month of experience with politics and government in Washington and to honor a past president of the organization, former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein, Democrat of Nassau, who was fatally shot in 1980. The A.D.A. will announce the names of the first six fellows at a conference in Washington June 7-9, and the winners will spend their month in the capital next January.

title: Jill and Robin Edwards, Sisters, Become Engaged
description: A July wedding is planned by Jill Sara Edwards and Robert F. Hoffman and a November wedding is planned by Robin Lillian Edwards and Dr. George Alan Marzelli. Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Edwards of Bryn Mawr, Pa., Key Colony Beach, Fla., and Stone Harbor, N.J., have announced their daughters' engagements.

title: IN CHINA THESE DAYS, AN ONLY CHILD IS THE ONLY WAY
description: When Han Xu, China's newly appointed Ambassador to the United States, was asked last month about the problems that divide the two countries, import limits on Chinese textiles and American arms sales to Taiwan were high on his list. Mr. Han did not even mention another difference, one on which an understanding with the Reagan Administration is perhaps the most remote of all.

title:
DINING OUT;

ENDEARING TOUCHES IN IRVINGTON
description: WHEN complaints come in about a restaurant whose kitchen philosophy we have understood and admired, we take particular notice. If the place has any kind of reputation at all, something more serious than the chef's night off is often the cause, and re-evaluation is in order. Thus our recent visits to The Cookshop revealed ingredients decent enough, but dishes once memorable for their culinary craft and finesse seemed artless and roughhoused; and, perhaps to justify the prices (once modest enough to make the food seem a bargain, now in league with places that offer a good deal more by way of amenities and comfort), frankly burly, give-'em-their-money's-worth portions daunted even those diners brought up according to the bylaws of that diabolical invention of determined parents - the Clean Plate Club. This is not to say that a good meal can't be ordered here. Our criticism holds more disappointment that bulk has replaced grace, salt has supplanted herbs and the cook's timer sometimes runs slow.

title: HOW TV CONTAMINATES POLITICS
description: LAST November Connecticut voters elected four men and two women to the House of Representatives in Washington. While the next Congressional election is still a year and a half away, it is probable these six will run again. And as incumbents they will begin their campaigns with huge advantages over their opponents, who are as yet unknown.

title: LIKE THE HORSELESS CARRIAGE, THE CD NEEDS TIME TO MATURE
description: In our particular bailiwick of sound reproduction, my favorite conservative pronouncement was made in 1926 when electrical recording began to replace the time-honored tin horn. At that time, Sir Compton Mackenzie - erstwhile editor of the prestigious British journal The Gramophone - declared that ''the use of electricity in sound recording seems an unneccessary and dangerous complication.''

title: CHUCK NORRIS: THE PUBLIC HAS MADE HIM A STAR
description: In his first film role reported in this newspaper 11 years ago, Chuck Norris was acting in karate-chopping support to star Bruce Lee in ''Return of the Dragon,'' directed by the late Mr. Lee from a screenplay, according to our records, about the troubles of a Chinese restaurant in Rome. Those troubles didn't have to do with misdirected egg-roll deliveries but with the efforts of what's now genteelly called ''organized crime'' to move in on the Chinese restaurant business.

title: CELTICS ENCOURAGED BY DEPTH IN MATCHUP WITH THE 76ERS
description: It is the most passionate rivalry in sports. But it has been three years since the Boston Celtics and the Philadelphia 76ers last squared off when it mattered most - in the playoffs.

title: LEARNING THE HARD WAY
description: SELLING OUT By Dan Wakefield. 300 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: MODEST PLEASURES IN RIDGEFIELD
description: SOCIOLOGISTS might well ponder why certain towns seem to be blessed with a string of successful restaurants, while other towns nearby are culinary wastelands.

title: CHINATOWN PLANNING COUNCIL CELEBRATES 20 YEARS OF SERVICE
description: Chinese-Americans are increasingly aware that economic and educational successes ''do not guarantee social well-being,'' according to Chor-Weng Tan, the dean of the School of Engineering at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When freedom does not have a purpose, when it does not wish to know anything about the rule of law engraved in the hearts of men and women, when it does not listen to the voice of conscience, it turns against humanity and society.'' - Pope John Paul II. [3:3.]

title: NEW YORK FOOD OUTLETS CITED FOR VIOLATIONS OF HEALTH CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 46 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: WHY A 41-YEAR-OLD STILL CALLS HER MOTHER MAMA
description: IT says here that we are going to visit Mama on the 18th. My 11-year-old son was looking at the calendar hanging on the pantry door.

title: REAGAN AND GORBACHEV
description: There's an interesting paradox in the brief two-month relationship between President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.

title: MOTHER, DAUGHTER, DAUGHTER'S DAUGHTER
description: TAP-TAP-TAP. The sound of my mother's heels on the sidewalk. Coming closer to the car, faster, faster. Oh, joyful sound! She is coming back. Now I don't have to wait anymore. Now I can stop my game of finding the alphabet in the trees out the car window. I have gotten up to G, but I can't find a G in the twisting branches.

title: ISRAEL NOW BACKS U.S.-ARAB MEETING
description: A senior Israeli official said today that Prime Minister Shimon Peres had no objection to the United States' meeting with a Jordanian-Palestinian group if this would promote direct talks with Israel.

title: STATE SYMPHONY GOING ON PUBLIC RADIO
description: THE first in a series of seven concerts by the New Jersey Symphony will be heard this week on national public radio.

title: 2 FAMILIES KEEP ARCHIE IN STEP WITH ERA
description: ON an industrial side street of this tree-lined town, tucked between storage warehouses and beverage shipping plants, the two-story brick and cement headquarters of Archie Enterprises looms, unassumingly. Downstairs, old artist page proofs depicting the ageless Archie comic-book characters lie stuffed in manila envelopes amid an assortment of employees' sports cars and twine-wrapped piles of cartoons.

title: Philadelphia: Rouse Towers Aim to Break Mold And Revivify Center City Streets
description: FOR 91 years, the huge bronze statue of William Penn high atop the City Hall bell tower has dominated the Philadelphia skyline, both visually and developmentally: An unwritten tradition has decreed that no building could reach higher than his broad-brimmed Quaker hat, 491 feet above street level.

title: Anne Harrison Is Married to a Banker
description: Anne Lee Harrison, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Alexander Harrison 3d of Hopewell, Va., and Old Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Edward Allingham Armstrong Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Armstrong of Richmond. The Rev. Charles Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattington Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ROUGH TRANSLATIONS. By Molly Giles. (University of Georgia, $13.95.) The title of Molly Giles's first collection of short fiction reflects her attempt to capture in layered phrases and fresh, sharp dialogue the timely theme of human connections gone bad, broken or missed altogether.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CHILDREN OF THE FOREST. By Kevin Duffy. (Dodd, Mead, $14.95.) A fresh, first-hand report on the Mbuti pygmies of Zaire's Ituri Forest, ''Children of the Forest'' confirms the picture of a remarkably fair, free and happy society presented a generation ago in Colin M. Turnbull's ''Forest People.''

title: MOVIES, MUSIC AND THE NOVEL
description: To the Editor:

title: GAMBLERS FACING 'LAUNDERING' EDICT
description: UNDER new rules designed to curb money laundering, gambling casinos in Atlantic City will begin this week to report to the Treasury Department all cash transactions of more than $10,000.

title: PHILADELPHIA PINS HOPE ON CHAGALL EXHIBITION
description: Forty years ago a senior member of the Museum of Modern Art, Rene d'Harnoncourt, helped assemble an exhibit of Marc Chagall's work that made the painter a household name in the United States.

title: Nopersonclature
description: At times, sexism in society seems easier to deal with than sexism in language. Every now and then, someone discovers yet another word ending in ''-man'' and calls 911 for a semantic policeperson. Nomenclature, this tendency might be called, and in the newest case, Paul Grossman, an official of the U.S. Department of Education, is calling on the University of California to clean up its language.

title:
ANTIQUES;

COUNTRY AND FORMAL FURNITURE TO BE OFFERED AT WOODBRIDGE
description: BY station wagon or van, 130 dealers from throughout New England will travel to Woodbridge Saturday to take part in the 12th annual Woodbridge Outdoor Antiques Festival. The show will be set up on the Old Center School grounds, facing the village green, and will run from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Sotheby Sale: Island in Sound
description: Sotheby's International Realty in Manhattan is offering a three-acre island with a lighthouse and attached red-brick home, a caretaker's cottage and a boathouse, all five minutes by boat from Fishers Island and less than an hour by seaplane from New York and Boston.

title: A DANCE SHOW TO AID DANCE
description: BALLET greats, captured in distinctive and unusual moments, make up a photographic exhibition in Ossining that opened yesterday and continues through June 30. Taken by four major dance photographers - Lois Greenfield, Paul Kolnik and Linda and Jack Vartoogian - the works can be seen at Elizabeth Galasso Fine Art Leasing at 191 Main Street.

title: A Victory For the Obese
description: Catherine McDermott was turned down for a job with Xerox 11 years ago because she was nearly 100 pounds overweight. She has been fighting that decision ever since, and last week she won when New York's Court of Appeals ruled that under state laws against discrimination, a person cannot be denied a job simply because of obesity.

title: Two Records Broken At the Princeton Relays
description: Meet records were broken today by Albert Lane in the 110-meter high hurdles (13.55 seconds) and Reggie Henderson in the 400-meter dash (46.58 seconds) in the fifth annual Princeton-Adidas Relays. Lane is a former national collegiate champion from Missouri and Henderson is a former Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America champion from George Mason.

title: HEAVY COST-CUTTER WITH A LIGHT TOUCH
description: LAST summer, when Lee L. Morgan, the recently retired chairman of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, asked George A. Schaefer if he would accept the post of chairman, Mr. Schaefer requested two weeks to think it over.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, MAY 12, 1985

title: 'SCARE TACTICS' ON SHOREHAM
description: HERBERT JAFFE, a director of the Association of Investors in New York Utilities, recently wrote an Opinion Page article entitled ''We Need the Electricity From Shoreham'' [April 28] , in which he contended that without Shoreham's power Long Island faces a shortage of electricity that could cause selective brownouts.

title: THE ART OF BUYING
description: Acquiring works of art in other countries used to be so much easier. Americans with money would just go to Europe, checkbook in hand, and pick up things they liked. It was all cash-and-carry. Now, it's more like cash-and-wait-and-wait-and-wait. The nations of Western Europe are not so quick to divest themselves of their most prized cultural objects, and they've institutionalized a vast series of roadblocks for art collectors. Along with your checkbook, bring a sense of humor.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MARLON BRANDO: The Only Contender. By Gary Carey. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) From the beginning of his career on the New York stage in 1944, Marlon Brando captured the public's imagination.

title: Lakers Trounce Nuggets in Opener
description: Byron Scott scored 13 of his 27 points in the first 7 minutes today as the Los Angeles Lakers rolled to a 139-122 victory over the Denver Nuggets in the first game of the Western Conference final playoffs.

title: Diana Greene Married To Mark Hall, Lawyer
description: Diana Stuart Greene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Braddock Greene of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Allen Hall, a son of Larry C. Hall and Elinor Hall, both of Nashville. The Rev. George Zabriskie performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FUNERAL MARCH By chronicling changes in cemetery design over a 60-year period in Paris, THE ARCHITECTURE OF DEATH: The Transformation of the Cemetery in Eighteenth-Century Paris (MIT, $37.50) explores the transformation of ideas about death. Richard A. Etlin, who teaches architectural history at the University of Maryland's School of Architecture, discerns several stages in that shift.

title: STEEPLCHASE MARK SET
description: Kieran Stack of Iona scored an impressive victory in the 3,000-meter steeplechase in the 52d annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association championships yesterday at St. John's University.

title: THE ONLY THING EXPLODING IN COOKSTOWN IS THE ECONOMY
description: Things were so quiet in Cookstown last week that when a child's black shoe was found in the street it was front-page news.

title: THE PLUM-TREE HORSE
description: IT wasn't until a few weeks ago that it was warm enough to take my morning coffee outside.

title: FREEHOLD STUDENTS RUN ITS TV STATION
description: DON'T look for the likes of ''Dallas'' or ''Dynasty'' on Channel 39. The cable-television station is given over to more-important matters involving Freehold Township, such as high school sports, taxes, school closings and local elections.

title: Tornadoes and Storms Strike Across Middle West States
description: Tornadoes and heavy thunderstorms ripped across several Middle West states yesterday, uprooting trees and damaging buildings.

title: Pamela Hochschartner Is Married in Andover
description: Pamela Marie Hochschartner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert A. Hochschartner of Manchester, N.H., was married yesterday to Robert M. Dann 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Dann of Painted Post, N.Y. The Rev. Allen Hinand, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in the Cochran Chapel at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.

title: TAX REVENUES...AND DEBATES
description: To the Editor:

title: TAX BONUS EYED BY L.I. ASSESSORS
description: THE Kings Park School District has received a $550,000 tax bonus as a result of a state court decision permitting local assessors to set tax rates on state land in some school districts.

title: THAYER SENTENCED TO 4 YEARS IN PRISION
description: Paul Thayer was sentenced to four years in prison and a $5,000 fine for obstructing justice in an S.E.C. investigation into insider trading. Mr. Thayer, a former Deputy Secretary of Defense as well as former chairman of the LTV Corporation and a director of other companies, also settled a civil lawsuit by agreeing to repay $550,000 of the trading profits earned by people he tipped about pending corporate takeovers. His Texas stockbroker, Billy Bob Harris, received the same criminal penalties. Legal experts say the outcome of the case indicates a tougher attitude toward white-collar crime.

title: A Fan's Loyalty Is Indestructible
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. MAGISTRATE REJECTS REAGAN POLICY ON BENEFITS
description: A Federal magistrate has rejected the Reagan Administration's contention that it may disregard court precedents relating to the Social Security disability program.

title: LONDON HIT BOWING AT L.I. SCHOOL
description: HOW is it that a new musical conceived and created by a big-league lyricist and librettist, and that proved to be a British hit, is trying out in a Farmingdale high school instead of heading straight for Broadway?

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE BERKSHIRES
description: The Berkshires - which really means a county in Western Massachusetts but has come to represent an amalgam of the good things of summer - outdoor music, undemanding weather, charming villages and country cream - is one of the most popular vacation areas in the Northeast.

title: A G.I. Remembers How It Was
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Humes Has Nuptials
description: St. Hugo of the Hills Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Janice Anne Humes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gale Stewart Humes of Bloomfield Hills, to George Vanderneth Merrill, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Merrill of New York. The Rev. Clement J. Esper performed the ceremony.

title: BUTTONS SHOW THEIR BRASS
description: BUTTONS - more precisely, big buttons, lots of them - are popping up on jackets. They come in almost as many formations as a professional football team does: single rows, double rows, even triple rows. Other innovations are the V-formation bellhop special and what might be called the W-formation - two parallel rows that widen at the top. Not surprisingly, the most popular color for these buttons is gold, or brass, and they are frequently attached to a jacket of navy blue.

title: Lutheran Synod Ousts Pastors for Political Acts
description: Two Lutheran ministers whose political activities on behalf of the unemployed have split their congregations must step down as pastors, a church synod has ruled.

title: CHESTER GOULD, CARTOONIST, DIES AT AT 84
description: Chester Gould, who created Dick Tracy, the durable comic-strip detective who began fighting outlandishly colorful criminals in 1931, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at his home in Woodstock, Ill. He was 84 years old and had been in ill health after having suffered a heart attack recently.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DAYS BETWEEN STATIONS. By Steve Erickson. (Poseidon, $15.95.) Sometime in the not too distant future, the planet Earth is rapidly going to the dogs. Los Angeles is swept by sandstorms that darken the sky and send dunes crawling up the buildings. A pall of smoke hangs over Paris, where the lights have gone out and bonfires burn out of control. The canals of Venice have inexplicably dried up, and the streets, smelling of garbage, are periodically plunged into deep fog. The landscape is fabulous, bleak; the lovers who travel through it, Michel and Lauren, are just the opposite - romantically alienated and drunk on their own eroticism. There is a healthy dose of cinematic surrealism in the Los Angeles writer Steve Erickson's moody first novel, along with a decidedly unhealthy dose of overwrought ''Fleurs du Mal'' bad dreams. Lauren, wife of a Vietnam veteran and world-class cyclist named Jason, stumbles into an adventure with the estranged, degenerate Michel (or Adrien - a victim of amnesia, he isn't sure which). Tortured by the past he cannot remember, with only a reel of film for a clue, he makes a voyage via flashbacks to Paris of the 1920's, where his grandfather is filming an epic of the death of Marat. With the magical ease of a movie that floats back and forth in space and time, the author at one point sets Lauren adrift on a houseboat from the Seine out onto the Atlantic, through the straits of Gibralter to meet Jason in the desiccated Venice.

title: CONSUMER RATES
RENT LAWS BENEFIT AFFLUENT OWNERS SAY
description: A NEW study of the effects of rent control and rent stabilization sponsored by the major New York City landlords' association has concluded that the systems do a bad job of protecting poor tenants while providing undeserved benefits to higher-income groups.

title: E.P.A. IS EXPECTED TO END A POISON BAN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday is expected to end a 13-year-old ban on the use of a powerful poison used to control livestock predations on public grazing land in the West, according to an agency official.

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor: My experience with the V.A.T. refund and getting the subsequent reimbursement check cashed has been vastly different from those of the writers of the letters that have recently appeared in your paper.

title: THE CHIPMUNK PERIL
description: THIS is nothing against Gulf and Western, one of the most cuddly conglomerates you could ever hope to meet, or against my hometown of New York, or against the New York Knickerbockers, who have given me many enjoyable hours, none of them in the last 12 months.

title: 9 Killed in Beirut In 12 Hours of Fighting
description: Christian and Moslem gunners in the capital pounded each other's residential districts with mortars, rockets and tank fire for 12 hours early today, killing 9 people and wounding 38.

title: NEW ISSUE FOR POPE: REBUFF BY JEWS
description: In his first statement after arriving in this country today, Pope John Paul II alluded to one of the most difficult issues to arise in the weeks and months preceding his trip to the Netherlands, the refusal of Dutch Jews to meet with him.

title: Labor Dispute Threatens To Disrupt Sweden
description: Sweden began today to plan for wide disruption of schools and government services on Monday. The move comes after the breakdown of negotiations to end a pay dispute between the Government and the country's largest white-collar civil service union.

title: Recent Sales
description: Belle Mead $161,000 60 Knickerbocker Drive *2* 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; fireplace in *2* family room and living room; 1+ acre; taxes $2,750. Bridgewater $132,500 45 Ivy Lane *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old split-level; game room *2* in basement, deck, 2-car garage; 1 acre; taxes $2,437. Hewitt $125,900 40 Comanche Lane *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old bilevel; *2* lakefront, patio, deck; taxes $2,660. Hopatcong $82,000 41 Holiday Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2* 3-zone heat, deck, attic fan; taxes $1,800. Millburn $200,000 147 Glen Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2* deck, family room; taxes $2,825. Mount Olive $106,900 2 Francis Terrace *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old bilevel; *2* 2-car garage, fireplace; taxes $2,381. OTHER AREAS Scarsdale, N.Y. $235,000 24 Carman Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 49-year-old frame-and-stone colonial; *2* playroom, den, porch, eat-in kitchen; 60- by *2* 100-foot lot; taxes $4,258. Greenwich, Conn. $269,500 638 Steamboat Road *2* 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old cooperative apartment in *2* colonial-style brick building; on waterfront, boat slips, *2* indoor parking; monthly maintenance including taxes $760. Freeport, L.I. $128,000 170 Mt. Joy Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; pantry, *2* study, fireplace, breakfast nook, finished basement; taxes $3,900.

title: BUDDHIST BELLS RING OUT AS RURAL TEMPLE OPENS
description: The sweet smell of incense and the tinkle of bells drifted through this wooded corner of Putnam County today at the dedication of a Buddhist temple at the Chuang Yen Monastery.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: MUSIC: MICHAEL GORDON
description: THE music of Michael Gordon starts with the systematic thinking, economy of material and rhythmic drive associated with minimalism, and adds his own offbeat humor. On Wednesday at Roulette (228 West Broadway), the Michael Gordon Philharmonic revealed a composer who joins minimalist theory with punkish extensions, in music that is pugnacious, witty and substantial.

title: BRIEFING;Sculpture Census
description: You may not have had occasion to consult it yet, but the National Museum of American Art has an index of 250,000 paintings executed in the United States from the time of the nation's settlement until 1914, the only such census that exists. Now this unit of the Smithsonian is about to launch a similar effort to record basic information about every piece of sculpture in the country.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Car Bomb in Teheran Kills at Least 15
description: A car bomb exploded in Teheran during the rush hour this morning and the Government radio said 15 people were killed and at least 50 wounded.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;CELTICS THWART 76ERS, 108-93
description: Even in the opposing locker rooms, no one dared dismiss the importance of the rivalry. The Boston Celtics may have taken a 1-0 lead in the Eastern Conference final playoff series today, but they kept reminding everyone that it was early, that the opponent was Philadelphia, not Cleveland. That one game does not make a series.

title: ALL IS POISED FOR HINTS OF TAX PLAN
description: Recommendations have been made to the President,'' a Treasury official says. ''The President has been digesting same. He is on a very fast schedule.''

title: REMARRIAGE: BIGGER READY-MADE FAMILIES
description: Big families are back. ''Everyone seems to know someone with three kids who's married someone with four kids,'' said Judy Isphording, a fifth-grade teacher in Columbia, Md. She should talk. Two years ago, when she married Steve Isphording, her son and daughter joined his five children to make a family with seven children.

title: F.C.C. Chief Wants New Term
description: Mark S. Fowler, who this month began the last year of his term as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, is carefully spreading the word that he would like another four-year term. He says he wants to finish his aggressive telecommunications deregulation agenda, which includes elimination of the so-called Fairness Doctrine and promotion of international competition.

title: POLISH FARMERS CALL FOR UNION
description: Hundreds of farmers from across Poland applauded calls for the revival of their outlawed Rural Solidarity union at a Roman Catholic mass on the fourth anniversary of the union's birth today.

title: ADVERTISING;Epstein Raboy Gets 2 Assignments for TV
description: The only thing that the two new assignments to Epstein Raboy Advertising have in common is that each will be for television only.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE;EXPOS BEAT BRAVES; 4TH SHUTOUT IN ROW
description: David Palmer pitched shutout ball for eight innings today and Jeff Reardon finished up to give the Montreal Expos their club-record fourth consecutive shutout, a 4-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Miss Owsley Wed To Scott Spector
description: The marriage of Irene Owsley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Owsley of Thomasville, Ga., to Scott Lee Spector, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Spector of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Cosmos Club in Washington. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony.

title: SENTENCE IS COMMUTED IN ILLINOIS RAPE CASE
description: Gov. James R. Thompson today commuted the sentence of a man jailed six years for a rape his accuser now says never happened.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MAY 13, 1985

title: A Bad Idea Worries Puerto Rico
description: In the name of tax reform, the Treasury wants to eliminate a longstanding benefit to Puerto Rico that has generated more than half the manufacturing jobs on the island. Since the effect would make Puerto Rico poorer and more dependent on Federal aid, this seems only penny-wise.

title: PART OF OUR LIFE-SUPPORT SYSTEM'
description: Following, as made public by the White House on Friday, is an exchange of letters between President Reagan and Michael K. Deaver, his deputy chief of staff, on Mr. Deaver's departure to open his own public relations company. Dear Mike: You know I've accepted your resignation orally but I suppose I have to put something down on paper - after all, this is Washington. The only place I haven't accepted it is in my heart, and there I never will.

title: Elizabeth A. Nicklas Marries Jonathan P. Ribner
description: Elizabeth Ann Nicklas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Nicklas of Orchard Park, N.Y., was married yesterday in Stony Brook, L.I., to Jonathan Paul Ribner, a son of Roslyn G. R. Reichler of Belle Terre, L.I., and the late Dr. Irving Ribner. Judge Morton Weissman of the Suffolk County Court performed the ceremony at Sunwood, the former Ward Melville summer residence now owned by the State University of New York at Stony Brook, where the bridegroom's father was chairman of the English department.

title: IN COVENTRY, A SPRING RITE IS CONDUCTED
description: Frank V. Trzaskos held up his right hand and won a nod from the moderator.

title: PHILADELPHIA POLICE BARRICADE GROUP'S HOUSE
description: The police today blocked off the rowhouse headquarters of a group that was the focus of a violent confrontation in 1978 and ordered nearby residents to evacuate the neighborhood. [Most of the residents were reported to have evacuated by 11 P.M., and negotations with the group were said to have bogged down.] Over the years residents have pressured city officials to enforce sanitation, health and building codes at the house, where members of the group called MOVE have set up a rooftop lookout tower and have boarded up their windows.

title: ESSAY;FRIENDLY DISPOSITION
description: At a luncheon last fall, Robert Fomon, the hard-charging chairman and chief executive officer of E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., went up to Attorney General William French Smith. He wanted to discuss the investigation that had been going on for over three years into the massive check-kiting operation run by Hutton's cash-management manipulators.

title: A FEAR FOR THOSE LEFT BACK IN NIGERIA
description: Hundreds of Ghanaians expelled from Nigeria sat here today in the withering heat, near the dusty border-crossing with Togo, surrounded by bulging plastic bags and mattresses that represent their worldly possessions and rickety minibuses that will take them to their home regions miles away. But the talk among them was not of a homecoming but of their compatriots who still remain in the country that is forcing them to leave.

title: OUTDOORS: A FISHERMAN'S NIGHT IS QUIET BUT LIVELY
description: IF you are truly serious about fishing, you will inevitably have to decide whether to give it precedence over social and domestic engagements.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I think I'm capable of handling any challenge. Coach John Thompson has prepared me well for anything. I wasn't particularly hoping for one particular team. I just wanted to get this over with.'' - Patrick Ewing. [C6:6.]

title: FLORIDA JOURNAL;A BRIDGE, BIG INSECT AND TAXES
description: Five years ago this month the Summit Venture, a 608-foot freighter, was sliding through a Tampa Bay shipping channel in a blinding squall when she struck and collapsed a central piling on the Sunshine Skyway Bridge.

title: DEMOCRATS PLEDGES NO TAX INCREASE IN '86 BUDGET PLAN
description: The House Budget chairman pledged today that his committee would write a spending plan cutting the Federal deficit by more than $50 billion in 1986 without raising taxes.

title: MAINE SUES OVER APPLIANCE SERVICE CONTRACTS
description: In a case that could affect the way retailers around the nation sell product warranties, the State of Maine has sued Sears, Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, over its marketing techniques.

title: TOP MEDICAL SCHOOL DROPPING STANDARDIZED ADMISSION TEST
description: In a step designed to broaden the education of future physicians, the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine has announced that it will no longer require applicants to take the Medical College Admissions Test, which is heavily weighted to assess scientific knowledge.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, MAY 13, 1985

title: Strawberry Out 6 Weeks
description: Darryl Strawberry has been placed on the disabled list yesterday and will undergo surgery this morning to repair torn ligaments in his right thumb. The Mets said he would be lost for at least six weeks. The 23-year-old outfielder was injured Saturday when he made a diving catch of a liner to right field in the game with the Philadelphia Phillies. The operation will be performed in Roosevelt Hospital by Dr. James Parkes, the team surgeon, and Dr. Dick Eaton, a hand specialist. Strawberry will wear a cast for four weeks, and will need at least two weeks more of recovery time after that.

title: KNICKS, FANS ALREADY EXCITED ABOUT EWING
description: About an hour before the beginning of the National Basketball Association's special lottery for the seven top draft picks, Jack Krumpe said he wasn't sure he would remain at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf Astoria until the nationally televised selections were completed.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Inquest in Oregon Rules Man's Death a Homicide
description: A public inquest jury has ruled that the death of a man that resulted from the use by the police of a ''sleeper'' neck hold was a homicide.

title: ATARI IS FACING NEW DOUBTS
description: The Atari Corporation made an unexpected appearance at the Comdex personal computer trade show here to convince a skeptical industry that the company was viable and that its new products would soon come to market.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Dorinda Elliott Marries Alan Ignatius
description: Dorinda Elliott, a daughter of Osborn Elliott and Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler of New York, was married yesterday to Alan Paul Ignatius, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Ignatius of Washington. Bishop Robert R. Spears Jr., who is retired from the Episcopal diocese of Rochester and is associate to the rector of St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion.

title: ADVERTISING;AC&R Campaigning For Quality Care Inc.
description: Quality Care Inc., which provides a variety of in-home health care services through a national network of 165 offices, has gone to AC&R Advertising to see what advertising can do.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;BP North America Unit To Be Led by Gas Chief
description: British Petroleum P.L.C. announced that Colin Webster, currently managing director and chief executive officer of BP Gas International Inc., had been named president of British Petroleum's fast-growing BP North America Inc. subsidiary.

title: POE AND MELVILLE JOIN POETS' CORNER
description: Two giants of 19th-century American literature, Herman Melville and Edgar Allan Poe, had their names inscribed in stone last evening at a dedication service held in the Poets' Corner of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: AUSTIN ELECTION SIGNALS DISCONTENT WITH GROWTH
description: After more than three years of runaway growth, this booming capital appears ready to pause to catch its breath.

title: Robert H. Beaser Wed To Catherine S. Banat
description: Catherine S. Banat, the daughter of Gabriel Banat of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and the late Rosette Banat, was married yesterday to Robert H. Beaser, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Beaser of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony at the Center for Inter-American Relations in New York.

title: SEX ROLES MODIFIED IN CHANGING OF ADS
description: Someone told Joseph Famolare Jr., a third-generation Italian maker of shoes from Boston, that sexy advertisements would sell his clunky, wavy-soled shoes. But soon after the leggy photographs appeared in magazines across the Northeast, the shoe executive was besieged with letters from women's groups criticizing the advertisements for what was seen as sexual inequality.

title: The Worth of Women's Work
description: In what is billed as a victory for the concept of ''comparable worth,'' the city of Los Angeles has agreed to raise the pay of workers in municipal jobs traditionally held by women. That probably is a victory for social justice and surely one for common sense.

title: Hitchhiking Man, 21, Is Slain Within Earshot of Companion
description: A 21-year-old hitchhiker was shot to death early this morning on the New England Thruway in the Bronx shortly after he and a companion split up to increase the chance of catching rides with passing automobiles, the police said.

title: TV REVIEWS;IN 'HEART OF THE DRAGON,' THE MEANING OF 'EATING'
description: WHAT is China? Who are the Chinese? ''The Heart of the Dragon,'' a 12-part series of one-hour shows, will not explain everything, but it may go a long way. The series examines not so much events as conditions. Current experience takes precedence over history. We are meant to see what people are doing now. The series, which began last week, continues tonight with an episode called ''Eating.'' It will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Catching Up
description: Most of the very best basketball players coming out of New York-area high schools this year have now made decisions as to where they will be going to college, and local coaches came up with a good share of them. Darryl Lucas of Wyandanch (L.I.) High and Joe Paterno of Christian Brothers Academy in Lincroft, N.J., both forwards, will enroll at Fordham. Seton Hall lured John Morton, the high-scoring guard from Walton in the Bronx, and Gerald Green, another guard, of Westinghouse Vocational in Brooklyn. Greg (Boo) Harvey, the guard from Andrew Jackson in Queens whose grade-point average didn't measure up, will follow in Walter Berry's footsteps and attend San Jacinto, the junior-college basketball power in Texas. Gary Massey, a forward from St. Raymond in the Bronx, signed during the early commitment period last fall with Villanova, where he will be joined by Kenny Wilson, a guard from St. Anthony's in Jersey City. Still undecided are Darryl Walker, a forward from All Hallows in the Bronx, who is considering Seton Hall, Iona, Missouri and Wichita State, and Marco Baldi, the 6-11 center who played at Long Island Lutheran. Baldi went home to Italy last week, still pondering offers from St. John's, Maryland and Southern California. He is expected back tomorrow with his decision made.

title: KOHL LOSES BADLY IN KEY STATE VOTE
description: The conservative Christian Democratic Party, led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, suffered a stinging defeat today in elections in North Rhine-Westphalia, the home of the industrial Ruhr valley and the most populous state in West Germany.

title: MARYLAND WILL RUN THRIFT UNIT
description: Officials meeting in an emergency session have decided to appoint a state conservator to manage Maryland's second-largest privately insured thrift institution, which has been jeapordized by a three-day run on deposits.

title: Yugoslavia Debt Talks
description: Yugoslavia and its creditor banks have agreed to resume debt refinancing talks at the end of May, the official news agency Tanjug reported Saturday. Efforts to negotiate a multiyear package on repayment of $3.4 billion in debt due between 1985 and 1988 broke down in New York on April 12.

title: CHIEF JUDGE ASKS GRADUATES TO RENEW DEMOCRATIC SPIRIT
description: New York State's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, urged graduating students at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University today to improve American democracy by renewing its institutions.

title: James Vincent Hayes, An Antitrust Lawyer
description: James Vincent Hayes, a trial lawyer specializing in antitrust matters and a past president of the New York County Lawyers Association, died Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: ABORIGINAL ACTORS, AT LONG WHARF, ARE ADJUSTING
description: The first conflict Ernie Dingo had was in signing a contract. ''It is a European way of life,'' said Mr. Dingo, an actor who was born and raised in the Australian bush. ''In the Aboriginal world, your word is your reputation, it is your contract.''

title: KEY VON BULOW DECISIONS KEPT OUT OF PUBLIC EYE
description: The trial of Claus von Bulow on charges of trying to murder his wife is one of Rhode Island's most heavily publicized events. But in its first weeks a number of key decisions about the conduct of the case have been made out of public earshot.

title: KEEP A FIRM EYE ON 'STAR WARS'
description: A central component of the proposed defense budget for fiscal 1986, under consideration in Congress now, is a staggering 166 percent increase in funding for the Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars.'' This requested increase, to $3.7 billion, raises serious questions about the direction that Star Wars research will take and its impact on our national security.

title: 3 HELD IN PLANNING OF NEW DELHI BLASTS
description: Police officials announced today that they had arrested three Sikhs suspected of having helped plan a series of bombings in the capital that killed at least 45 people.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAILER: His Life and Times. By Peter Manso. 718 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Peru Debt Assessment
description: The Peruvian Economy Minister, Guillermo Garida Lecca, told reporters today that he doubted commercial bank creditors would attach Peruvian assets at present since such a move would risk straining ties with the incoming administration.

title: Plant Closing By Convergent
description: Convergent Technologies said Friday that it would close a manufacturing plant for a week in June and reduce vacation time by a week for all employees to improve performance at the struggling computer concern.

title: ARTISTS' HAVEN REACHES OUT FOR HELP
description: Time moves slowly at Yaddo, the 400-acre retreat at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., that for almost 60 years has sheltered artists beneath its towering pines. Saul Bellow, Eudora Welty, Katherine Anne Porter, Aaron Copland and William Carlos Williams are among the several thousand writers and composers who have forsaken family and friends, television and telephones to work undistracted for up to two months at a time.

title: DANCE: 'GRAND PAS,' A BUJONES BALLET
description: Grand Pas Romantique,'' the ballet Fernando Bujones has choreographed for American Ballet Theater, should make a pleasant showpiece for the company. Since Mr. Bujones is one of the world's great classical dancers, it is not surprising that he has concentrated on a style that harks back to the 19th-century ballets in which he himself excels.

title: Baldrige's China Pledge
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that China and America ''have great potential together'' and promised to help accelerate Western screening procedures for United States high-technology equipment destined for China.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Tableau for a Vacant Lot
description: When spring arrived at the northeast corner of 96th Street and Third Avenue, it came in the form of chickens and tulips.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Dozens of Mud Slides Imperil Colorado Homes
description: State officials are concerned about dozens of mud slide areas in the mountains. They fear that with a wet season coming on, the slumping mountainsides might absorb enough water to make them slip down the slopes, destroying homes and roads and blocking creeks.

title: U.S. AIDE SEEKS LIKELY LANDMARKS
description: Carolyn Pitts likes to sneak into buildings, moving undetected from basement to roof as she leans back to look at a carved ceiling on one floor and a stained-glass window on another.

title: CUOMO TELLS GRADUATES TO BE POLITICALLY ACTIVE
description: Governor Cuomo exhorted graduating students at the University of Rochester today to become involved in the country's political system and pointed to the example of South Africa's Nobel laureate, Bishop Desmond M. Tutu.

title: DANCE: KOREAN NATIONAL TROUPE PERFORMS
description: THE glimpse of Korean culture offered by the Korean National Dance Theater - a 60-member group based in Seoul and produced here by Kazuko Hillyer - was an enjoyable one presented by a company of attractive dancers and musicians. There were musical numbers that gave a sense of how traditional instruments sounded and were used. The dance was pretty and lively, and maintained a pleasant balance between popular art and traditional culture. And the dance-drama that completed the program had a great many moments of poignant story-telling.

title: ARTISTS' WORKS DECORATING A DISCO
description: There, amid the writhing bodies, is the art: works by Alex Katz, David Hockney, Michael Heizer, Sol LeWitt, Larry Rivers, Jennifer Bartlett and many more of today's leading contemporary artists.

title: Bridge: Canadians Among Leaders In Event at Cavendish Club
description: Four players living near the Canadian border were in the lead at the midpoint of the prestigious Cavendish Club Invitational event in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Futures/Options;Eurodollars At Philadelphia
description: STILL another dimension was added to the booming Eurodollar market last Friday when the Philadelphia Board of Trade, a new unit of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, began trading its version of Eurodollar options.

title: BRIEFING;The Name's the Same
description: It probably won't affect the delicate balance of power in the Middle East, but the chief representative of the Arab League in Washington, Clovis Maksoud, has acquired a new credential: honorary citizen of Clovis, N.M.

title: Eastwood Wins
