description: Bob Eastwood, given new life when Payne Stewart blew a two-shot lead on the final hole, won the Byron Nelson Classic today when the shaken Stewart made a second consecutive double bogey on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff.

title: Cruelty to Animals in Orbit
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ MEETS HUSSEIN ON PALESTINIAN ROLE IN TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz opened talks tonight with King Hussein of Jordan on what he called ''the hard problem'' of finding Palestinians to negotiate with Israel who are acceptable to all sides in Middle East peace efforts.

title: REGULATION CALLED A BOON FOR CLEAN WATER, BUT POLLUTION REMAINS ATHREAT
description: As Congress moves to renew and adjust the water pollution laws, the state of the nation's waters is improving but still troubled, according to experts on all sides of the issue.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Finance Is Forte Of T.W.A. Head
description: C.E. Meyer Jr., president and chief executive officer of Trans World Airlines Inc., is described by those who know him as a man who, above anything else, knows a thing or two about money and about running an airline.

title: I.B.M., NAVY STILL IN CONTRACT FIGHT
description: The Navy and the International Business Machines Corporation remained locked in a stubborn dispute last week over I.B.M.'s performance on a $1.7 billion contract to build an advanced computer system for submarines.

title: YANKEES DEFEATED, 6-5;DARLING IS VICTOR OVER PHILLIES, 3-2
description: They were bruised, they were battered, and they were starting about two months without Darryl Strawberry, who will undergo surgery on his right thumb today. And they even surrendered a run after 29 innings of scoreless pitching.

title: I.M.F. PACT WITH BRAZIL ON ADDITIONAL FINANCING
description: Brazil and the International Monetary Fund have agreed to negotiate fresh economic goals for the country in exchange for a new loan, Brazilian Finance Minister Francisco Dornelles said Saturday.

title: MUSIC: ASPEN GROUP PLAYS FRANK ZAPPA WOODWIND QUARTET
description: A CONCERT at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday served to introduce the Aspen Wind Quintet, one of the two winners of the 1984 Naumburg Chamber Music Award. The group played very well, deft and fluent if with a sometimes slightly too reticent flutist. Its members are Barli Nugent, flute; Claudia Coonce, oboe; David Krakauer, clarinet; Timothy Ward, bassoon, and Kaitilin Mahony, horn. But the newsworthy item about the program was the premiere - actually four-fifths of a premiere - of a newly commissioned woodwind quintet by Frank Zappa.

title: WORKING PROFILE: REPRESENTATIVE ROBERT H. MICHEL;FORGING ALLIANCES TO GET MINORITY'S PLANS PASSED
description: Representative Robert H. Michel is a prospector, but his goal is votes, not gold.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 13, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Divinity School Awards Moon Honorary Degree
description: Shaw Divinity School has awarded an honorary doctor of divinity degree to the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, founder of the Unification Church, praising Mr. Moon's commitment to Christianity.

title: MANUSCRIPT IS DATED TO 7TH CENTURY
description: A piece of parchment used for decades to wrap two 16th-century English volumes in the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington has been identified as a fragment of a seventh-century manuscript, one of the earliest examples of Irish handwriting in existence.

title: RIGHT TO PICK EWING GOES TO THE KNICKS IN N.B.A.'S LOTTERY
description: The Knicks won the grand prize in pro basketball's draft lottery yesterday and now have the rights to the nation's most renowned college basketball player - Patrick Ewing.

title: U.S.F.L.;Bandits Defeat Bulls
description: The running back Gary Anderson ran for one touchdown and passed for another today to lead the Tampa Bay Bandits to a 21-10 victory over the Jacksonville Bulls.

title: Required Reading
description: How Much New Federalism Excerpt from ''Significant Features of Fiscal Federalism,'' a study published recently by the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, an independent Government agency:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Audio-Video Affiliates Inc., Dayton, Ohio, a holding company with interests in home entertainment and consumer electronics equipment, has named Ronald E. Durbin to the new position of chief financial officer.

title: Vuckovich Idled
description: Pete Vuckovich, the 1982 Cy Young Award winner, has been placed on the 21-day disabled list, the Milwaukee Brewers announced today. Vuckovich, who is suffering from a strained right shoulder, has a 1-2 record this season with a 6.14 earned run average in six appearances. He sat out last season after a rotator-cuff injury in 1983.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Short Game
description: If you've seen enough of gimmick basketball and yearn to see the game played the way God and James Naismith intended it to be played, Ben Hatskin may be your man. Hatskin, the former chairman of the World Hockey Association, is the founder of something called the International Basketball Association, and if he gets it off the ground the professional league should have an instant appeal for those who've seen one slam dunk too many.

title: F.B.I. ASSERTS FUGITIVES HAD A NETWORK OF 'SAFE HOUSES'
description: The fugitive life of Marilyn Jean Buck and Linda Sue Evans was supported by a network of underground accomplices and ''safe houses'' in New York City, New Haven, Baltimore and other locales, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Washington Watch;Regulations After E.S.M.
description: WHEN E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, hemmed and hawed last week, trying to avoid making specific recommendations to a Senate banking subcommittee on regulating Government securities dealers, he reflected a current problem among officials pondering the question.

title: LEBANESE GROUP LINKED TO C.I.A. IS TIED TO CAR BOMBING FATAL TO 80
description: A car bombing in a Beirut suburb that killed more than 80 people on March 8 was carried out by people hired by a Lebanese counterterrorism unit that had been working with the Central Intelligence Agency, Congressional and Administration sources said today.

title: PACIFIC BOOM LURES AIRLINES
description: The Pacific still has a magical allure for the airline industry. It is the market that has grown the fastest in recent years and is expected to continue to outpace other parts of the world for the next decade as such nations as China begin to open to tourists and business travelers.

title: It Is Time to Take Another Look at the Fuel-Economy Law
description: To the Editor:

title: January Triumphs
description: Don January finished with a pair of birdies for a five-under-par 67 that gave him a victory in the $200,000 Dominion PGA Senior Invitational tournament today.

title: JAPAN OPENING UP TOBACCO MARKET
description: The president of Japan's former tobacco monopoly trooped over to the Ministry of Finance the other day bearing two blown-up stock certificates. He bowed, handed over the two million shares that represent his company's capital and Japan Tobacco Inc. was officially declared a private company.

title: Dial 1 (800) OPINION?
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY CRITICIZES JOBS PROGRAM IN CITY
description: A city program to combat unemployment, conducted under the Federal Job Training Partnership Act, is neglecting New York's most disadvantaged youths, according to a report by a New York public policy consulting organization.

title: Secret Nazi Societies Protect Mengele
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Cookies and Balconies: A West Side Relocation
description: David's Cookies has closed its shop at 311 Columbus Avenue, of all places, leaving Upper West Siders to wonder whether the boutique wave has crested.

title: The Public's Right to Tune In Crime Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK HAWKS BEAT OILERS, 8-6
description: Steve Larmer scored two goals and added an assist as Chicago beat Edmonton, 8-6, to even the Campbell Conference finals at 2-2 tonight.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Happy Returns
description: If Spend a Buck wins the Jersey Derby at Garden State Park on May 27, the young colt's career earnings will climb to just about $4 million. Dennis Diaz bought him 16 months ago for $12,500. He is considered to be worth at least $12.5 million as a stallion, which means Diaz could conceivably realize $16.5 million if he sold him sometime soon. That would be a return of about 1,300 times the initial investment.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;End of a Parking Dream
description: Claiming a stake, having one's own little bit of land. This is the stuff of the American dream.

title: Borg Triumphs
description: Bjorn Borg showed some of his old form as he beat a fellow Swede, Anders Jarryd, by 6-4, 6-3, today in the final of a $200,000 tennis event comprising eight men and eight women.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: ADVERTISING;Purchase and Start-Up In Computer Magazines
description: In the boiling arena of computer magazines, there were both an acquisition and a start-up announced last week.

title: When to Run
description: A few of the speediest players in major league baseball were asked which outfielders they feared most when attempting to take an extra base on a play that will undoubtedly draw a throw. Their answers:

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Fed Officials Draw Criticism
description: The secrecy that surrounds adjustments in the Federal Reserve's monetary policy has not crumbled, but there is widespread agreement among credit market participants that some Fed officials are talking more than ever about the economy and monetary policy.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Israeli Officer Punished For Prisoner Privileges
description: An officer of the Israeli Border Police was punished today for giving special privileges to Jews accused of terrorism who are on trial in Jerusalem's District Court.

title: SOME LOSERS IN N.B.A. ARE LOSERS ONCE MORE
description: While the Knicks rejoiced, elsewhere around the N.B.A., from Beverly Hills, Calif., to Marietta, Ga., the air went out of a lot of parties.

title: GOD IS A KNICK FAN
description: UNTIL yesterday, Dave DeBusschere had never won anything in a drawing. ''At least nothing big,'' he would recall. ''I think I got a set of club head covers at a golf tournament once, that's all.'' And when he arrived at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf Astoria he was presented with a Knick button that had a blue-dyed rabbit's foot attached to it, but he shrugged and handed it to an onlooker. At the National Basketball Association Draft Lottery that would determine Patrick Ewing's future, if not his own future, Dave DeBusschere preferred to depend on the power of a small prayer he had said at the 9:15 mass yesterday at St. Joseph's Church, not far from his Garden City, L.I. home.

title: PUBLISHERS' PARTY REFLECTS CHANGES IN PRESS
description: The nation's newspaper publishers would seem to have had excellent reason to be cheerful as they ended their annual convention here this week.

title: Drugs in the Dugout
description: Big-league baseball is a fantasy land where even players of middling talent command million-dollar salaries. It's about to get a harsh dose of reality. A Federal grand jury in Pittsburgh is reported on the verge of indictments in a drug investigation that already has involved about a dozen players as witnesses. Some could end up as defendants or unindicted co-conspirators.

title: TV REVIEW;'EUROPEANS,' BASED ON JAMES NOVEL
description: AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE'' is certainly one of public television's more distinguished showcases for quality programming. And, predictably enough for public television, the series is not without financing problems. One device it has developed for survival is the financing of independent films already in production and needing more money for completion. ''American Playhouse'' then gets first television rights to the film after it is released theatrically. In this manner, the series has acquired such worthwhile films as ''Testament'' and, next week, ''El Norte.''

title: THE REAL DRUG BATTLEFRONT
description: The State Department recently reported the continuing spread of marijuana, cocaine and heroin production throughout the world. As it has each year, it found grounds for cautious optimism. The optimism is unjustified. Efforts to cut source-country drug production are unlikely to succeed; even if they succeeded, they would do little to reduce United States drug consumption.

title: ADVERTISING;Accounts
description: Ayerst Laboratories to Saatchi & Saatchi Compton for Posture calcium supplement.

title: HOUSE PANEL CHIEF SEEKING TO BAR KEY WESTWAY FUNDS
description: The Congressional efforts to block Westway gained a key ally today as a House committee chairman said he would introduce a bill to bar spending of Federal highway funds on an essential element of the project.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Opener of a two-game series. The Twins snapped Billy Martin's four-game winning streak as manager last week in Minneapolis, and swept both games by 8-6 scores. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta. Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez provided the firepower when the teams played last week at Shea Stadium. Carter hit an eighth-inning grand slam off Bruce Sutter to win the first game, and Hernandez hit a two-run home run in the second game to help the Mets sweep. (Television - SportsChannel and WTBS, 7:40 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:35 P.M.) Other Events GOLF: Manufacturers Hanover Business Women's Invitational, at Wykagyl Country Club, North Avenue and Quaker Ridge Road, New Rochelle. A field of 128 will compete in this second annual better-ball, one-day tournament. Among those entered are Donna DeVarona, Diana Nyad and Nancy Lieberman. Registration begins at 9 A.M. Tournament begins around 11:30 A.M. HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, midnight). THOROUGHBRED RACING: Belmont, 1 P.M. (Television -Sportschannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M.). Garden State, 8 P.M.

title: DUTCH CATHOLICS CRITICIZE THE POPE
description: Pope John Paul II ran into a storm of criticism when he met Dutch Catholics today, while riot policemen clashed with demonstrators outside protesting his visit.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS;BIGGEST COURT PRIZE: PATRICK EWING
description: On Jan. 11, 1975, Patrick Ewing, then 12 years old, became the fifth of Carl and Dorothy Ewing's seven children to arrive in America from their homeland, Jamaica. He was tall, slim and athletic. The most popular sport in Jamaica is soccer, and perhaps because of his height, Patrick was a goalie. He had never played basketball. In fact, he had never even seen a basketball.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 13, 1985:

title: Sybil L. Soffen Is Married To Derek Miller in Jersey
description: Sybil L. Soffen and Derek B. Miller were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin C. Soffen, parents of the bride, in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Rosenberg performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen B. Miller of Denver.

title: HEAVY SUPPLY OF ISSUES EXPECTED
description: In the wake of strong demand for last week's record $20.5 billion of new Treasury notes and bonds, securities dealers expect a heavy supply of new corporate and tax-exempt issues this week.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AUSTRIA NOW The development of the arts in Austria did not stop with the arrival of Strauss and Kokoschka. For those who have not caught up with new waves on the blue Danube, enlightenment is on hand with an ambitious Austrian avant-garde festival that starts today and features, through next Sunday, 14 events in several arenas in Manhattan.

title: ARGENTINA SHAKEN BY BANK FAILURES
description: The Argentine central bank closed the country's 11th-largest bank late last week in what was the most serious in a rash of recent bank failures.

title: Eliminate Incentive for Malpractice-Suit Delays
description: To the Editor:

title: EATING WHEREVER, WHENEVER
description: At a Perry Ellis fashion show, a woman is eating a hero sandwich while watching the thousands of dollars in clothes go by. On a Broadway bus, a woman with an irritable child starts pushing french fries into its mouth. As a cab stops for a light in Greenwich Village, the driver dives into a bag of barbecued chicken.

title: Sara Rudner, Dancer, Wed To Edward C. Marschner
description: The marriage of Sara Rudner, a dancer and choreographer, and Edward C. Marschner, a partner in the New York law firm of Fox, Glynn & Melamed, took place yesterday at the couple's home in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

title: FULL SPEED AHEAD FOR NASCAR'S BIG HERO
description: IT looked like bad news for Bill Elliott, the red-haired country boy who has been smoking the competition on this year's Grand National stock-car circuit. Coming back onto the track after an oil line blew at Alabama's Talladega Raceway last Sunday, Elliott's super-performance Ford Thunderbird was two laps - nearly five full miles - behind the leader Cale Yarborough.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Sterling Drug Elects Chairman and President
description: John M. Pietruski, who in February became chief executive officer of Sterling Drug Inc. in addition to being its president, has been elected chairman, the diversified pharmaceutical and consumer products company said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline on a review yesterday incorrectly characterized the cast of ''Girls Just Want to Have Fun.'' Cyndi Lauper did not appear in the film.

title: Colorado Women Protest Slaying of Battered Wife
description: About 100 women marched to call attention to the problems of battered women after the funeral Friday of a woman who wrote a newspaper article predicting that she would be slain by her estranged husband.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Has a defenseman ever been voted the outstanding player in the Stanley Cup playoffs? Has the honor ever gone to a member of a losing team?

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch by The Associated Press in The Home Section on Thursday about hazards of electricity in the home gave an incorrect telephone number for the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The correct number is 800-638-2772.

title: FIELD FOR INDY 500 IS INCREASED TO 29
description: The field for the Indianapolis 500 field was increased to 29 today with the successful qualifying of two more cars, leaving four more needed to complete the field for the race on May 26.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;3d South African Death Linked to Police Custody
description: A newspaper reported today that a third person in less than a week had died either in police custody or hours after being released from custody.

title: YANKEES DEFEATED, 6-5;RIGHETTI FALTERS AGAINST ROYALS
description: After soaring in their last 10 games against the Kansas City Royals, the Yankees fell down and went boom today. Dave Righetti fell down twice, once figuratively and once literally, setting up the runs that gave the Royals a 6-5 victory.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Parents Say Their Son Didn't Skip School a Year
description: Attendance records at Kennedy High School show that one student who is now a junior failed to show up for most of his sophomore year, but the young man's parents insist that that is wrong.

title: ALLIES IN EUROPE ARE APPREHENSIVE ABOUT BENEFITS OF 'STAR WARS' PLAN
description: Allies in Western Europe seem increasingly worried by military and political dangers they see for their countries in President Reagan's strategic defense initiative, popularly known as ''Star Wars.''

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;THE RUSSIANS IN LONDON
description: From the talk of London, Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev are going to give President and Mrs. Reagan, the great masters of TV-manship, some racy competition if they arrive as expected in New York in the fall. In fact, word has filtered through from Moscow that the Soviet leader has a hankering to include a visit to the Reagan ranch at Santa Barbara, which would turn the ''informal summit'' into a grand-tour performance.

title: California Yachts Leading in Trials
description: Three California boats in contention for a spot on the United States Admiral's Cup team continued to dominate trial races today as a fleet of 39 sailed an inshore course, then left on a 100-mile overnight race.

title: MANILA PLAINCLOTHES UNIT IS FOCUS OF A FUROR AFTER KILLING 14
description: A plainclothes Government force has killed at least 14 criminal suspects in the last week, setting off a sharp debate between authorities who say the force is effective in fighting crime and critics who charge that it disregards civil rights.

title: QUELLING THE PHILIPPINE INSURGENCY: NO EASY TASK
description: Wearing camouflage fatigues, combat boots and a pistol strapped to his ribs, Brig. Gen. Jaime Echeverria stands at the front lines of the Government's campaign to halt the rapid growth of the Communist insurgency in the Philippines.

title: FLUTIE SPARKS VICTORY
description: Not much had been seen or heard lately of Doug Flutie while Herschel Walker made the big plays for the Generals. But they needed Flutie near the end today, and the little man came through.

title: CONSERVATIVE JEWS ORDAIN A WOMAN
description: Amy Eilberg became Rabbi Amy Eilberg yesterday as Judaism's Conservative movement ordained the first woman to become a rabbi in its 100-year history.

title: 25 YEARS LATER, SLIVER OF QUEENS IS AGAIN FIGHTING A STADIUM PLAN
description: Twenty-five years ago, the government tried to take their land. Robert Moses, the master builder, wanted the little triangle of factories, scrap yards and storage lots to make way for the World's Fair and a stadium for a new ball club called the Mets.

title: Briarpatch' Honored By Mystery Writers
description: Briarpatch'' by Ross Thomas (Simon & Schuster) was named the best novel of the year by the Mystery Writers of America at the group's annual Edgar Allan Poe Awards ceremony in New York on Friday night. The award for best first novel went to ''Strike Three, You're Dead'' by R. D. Rosen (Walker & Company.) These were among the other winners: ''Grandmaster'' by Warren Murphy and Molly Cochran (Pinnacle Books), best paperback original.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Some Tories Organize To Oppose Thatcher
description: More than 30 Conservative Party Members of Parliament announced today that they had formed a group to oppose the policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the party leader.

title: Market Place;Stocks Follow Bonds Upward
description: LATE last week, the Dow Jones industrial average awoke to the fact that the bond market, which often points out the direction for equity prices, had been in a rally phase since early April. The result was a delayed-reaction spurt that, on Thursday and Friday, added 24.40 points to the Dow average. For the week, the average rose 26.94 points, to 1,274.18.

title: ADVERTISING;Gentlemen's Quarterly Names a Publisher
description: Jack Kliger must have performed well as West Coast manager of Gentlemen's Quarterly before he quit for another job because S.I. Newhouse Jr., chairman of Conde Nast Publications, has reached out to grab him for the newly vacant publisher's chair at GQ.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE;VIOLA WINS NO. 6 AS BUSH'S SLAM LEADS TWINS OVER ORIOLES
description: Randy Bush hit a grand slam and two doubles and Frank Viola (6-2) hurled a four-hitter to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 7-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today.

title: SCHOOL INTEGRATION IN BUFFALO IS HAILED AS A MODEL FOR U.S.
description: Four years after a Federal judge ordered forced busing, the Buffalo public schools have come to be considered a national model of integration.

title: Baby Hammocks Recalled
description: A manufacturer has recalled 5,000 baby hammocks after at least one infant died in the device. The $30 Century Crib Cuddles, made by a subsidiary of Gerber Products, are designed to help newborns sleep in cribs. The company, Century Products, based in Stow, is exchanging the Crib Cuddles for a new model.

title: STRONG THINKING IS LYNCH'S FORMULA
description: IT being Mother's Day, Frank Cashen quoted from no less an authority than his own mother regarding the Mets' precarious place in the world.

title: BRIEFING;Aspiration Within Grasp
description: The last thing most politicians are willing to do is flatly predict victory for their candidate or their cause before the votes are counted. But Representative Jim Wright of Texas, a Democrat, seems so nearly assured of advancing from majority leader to Speaker of the House of Representatives after Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. retires after 1986 that he's talking pretty openly about it.

title: SPEND A BUCK'S ABSENCE COSTS PREAKNESS MUCH OF ITS GLITTER
description: Will the Preakness Stakes next Saturday be remembered as the race that Spend a Buck skipped or as the start of another colt's climb to the 3-year-old championship? That depends in part on how good a race it will be, but it also now appears that whoever wins the Preakness may have to wait until the fall for a shot at toppling Spend a Buck from atop the division.

title: ADVERTISING;People
description: Joan Rothberg, Mark Morris and Geoffrey Cousins elected to the board of Ted Bates Worldwide.

title: YOUNG FOLK OF 'PEYTON PLACE' KEEP UP THE TRADITIONS
description: IN case anyone was wondering, the young folks in Peyton Place are living up to the town's traditions. Viewers of ''Peyton Place: The Next Generation'' will find this evening, on Channel 4 at 9 o'clock, that the kids are steaming things up in cars, indoor swimming pools and motel rooms. They may be showing a bit more flesh than Mom and Dad did between 1964 and 1969 when ''Peyton Place'' was a three-times-a-week television hit, but the impulses and results are pretty much the same.

title: BRIEFING;Pow-Pow, Ralph Nader
description: Ralph Nader, it sometimes seems, has made a career out of being reviled and persecuted, but this was too much even for him. One of the consumer advocate's associates wrote to the book publisher Prentice-Hall in March, proposing a book on female activists and identifying Mr. Nader as sponsor of the project. Back from the publisher's outside submissions editor came the following letter:

title: TOP U.S. EXECUTIVES DISCUSS TRADE
description: Akio Morita, chairman of the Sony Corporation, told the American business leaders here today that as an engineer and inventor he had always believed that things could be improved.

title: STADIUM FIRE TOLL NOW 52 IN BRITAIN
description: The death toll in a fire that swept a soccer grandstand in Bradford on Saturday has risen to 52, most of them children or the elderly, the police said tonight.

title: Santucci Weighs Shift In Inquiry on Torture
description: Saying his investigation of stun-gun torture cases in Queens has been ''stifled'' by the unwillingness of police officers to come forward, District Attorney John J. Santucci said he may call police witnesses to testify before a Federal, rather than state, grand jury because of more favorable immunity rules.

title: Why 'Star Wars' Isn't Negotiable
description: To the Editor:

title: RELATIONSHIPS;TREATING PARENTS AS CHILDREN
description: IT comes as a surprise to many adults: All this time, and without their help, their parents managed to make it to age 60, 70, 80 and beyond.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;NORDIQUES WIN, 5-3; SQUARE SERIES AT 2-2
description: The key for the Flyers all season has been Pelle Lindbergh. More than team speed, more than fierce forechecking, more than the acumen of their rookie coach, Mike Keenan, the little man from Stockholm has been the focal point of Philadelphia's success.

title: PROFITS WEAKENED IN QUARTER
description: Buffeted by the strong dollar and an economic slowdown, corporate profits in the first quarter were disappointingly low, according to economists.

title: Advertising;Kenyon, Esty Gain Accounts
description: THE quiet of the spring afternoon last Friday ended in a surprising flurry of account switches, the biggest of which were Kenyon & Eckhardt becoming the new agency for Ponderosa Steakhouse and the William Esty Company taking over the Travelers Insurance Company account.

title: Civics Lesson for Mr. Meese
description: The Secretary of Education, William Bennett, complained recently that schoolchildren don't know how a bill becomes law or that a President can't declare a law unconstitutional. Now it appears that the problem extends as high as the White House. President Reagan has declared unconstitutional a key provision of a law he signed last year, and Attorney General Meese has instructed Government agencies not to obey it.

title: Gasoline Prices Rising
description: Dan Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter, said today that a nationwide survey of 17,500 gasoline stations compiled Saturday showed the overall price of all grades of gasoline was $1.23 per gallon, an 8.8 cent increase since Feb. 8.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article May 3 about the Tony Awards misstated the category in which Betty Buckley of ''Cats'' won a Tony. She was voted the best featured actress in a musical in 1983.

title: UNOCAL MEETING: CLOSE VOTE LIKELY
description: The Unocal Corporation's annual stockholders meeting, postponed by a court order from April 29, is set to convene here Monday morning, but it is not expected to decide the outcome of an attempt by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, to gain control of the nation's 12th-largest oil company.

title: EASTWOOD TOP EVENT AT CANNES
description: Clint Eastwood lay on the deck of his borrowed yacht, a bottle of beer in his hand and his feet on a polished wood table. No matter how ''Pale Rider'' - the movie that has brought him to the Cannes Film Festival - is received Monday, his presence here is the main event of the festival.

title: HARVARD EXCELS IN EASTERN ROWING
description: Harvard reigned supreme today on Lake Quinsigamond, winning five of the six grand finals of this 40th anniversary Eastern Sprint Championships Regatta.

title: LENDL TOPPLES MCENROE
description: There were occasions when John McEnroe tumbled to the ground, after lunging for a sizzling, sharply angled backhand. And there were times when he looked like a man on a rack, stretched to his limit in trying to return ground strokes that Ivan Lendl kept just out of his reach.

title: Whitworth Captures 88th Title
description: Kathy Whitworth, who has won more tournaments than any other golfer, withstood the challenge of several younger players to capture the 88th title of her career in the $200,000 United Virginia Bank Golf Classic today.

title: Shearson to Cut Jobs
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., a subsidiary of the American Express Company, said Friday that it would dismiss about 60 employees in its commodities department in New York and Chicago because it is deemphasizing its activity in traditional agricultural commodities. A Shearson spokesman said the employees hold ''junior-level positions,'' such as junior analysts, traders and operational staff. Shearson's commodities unit has about 650 employees. Commodities operations accounted for 6 percent of Shearson's 1984 revenues.

title: A ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY SALES AND PROFITS AT 267 COMPANIES
description: Revenues Net Income Jan.-MarchChangeJan.-MarchChange #1985From '84#1985From '84 ($

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Direct Foreign Car Imports
description: A bruising battle is expected as a bill moves through Congress that would stop American consumers from importing foreign luxury cars directly instead of buying them from dealers in this country. Proponents say the legislation will improve auto safety. Opponents say it is anti-consumer and anti-competitive.

title: ADVERTISING;Discover Goes To Emmerling
description: Discover magazine, the Time Inc. science entry, has decided to transfer its $1 million trade advertising account to John Emmerling Inc., which is already serving its sister publication, Money magazine.

title: Pension Off the Cavalry Charge
description: No one wants to be ungenerous to those who risk their lives in military service. But under the shelter of that proper sentiment, the military pension system has grown beyond all proportion. It has racked up future due bills of $564 billion, in the service of manpower goals more suited to the age of the cavalry charge than a modern army. Congress has at last mustered the courage to look this runaway sacred cow in the eye.

title: AMGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OLD REPUBLIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $712,316 for the latest first quarter and $301,397 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: 4-STATE PANEL DECLARES A DROUGHT EMERGENCY
description: The Delaware River Basin Commission today declared a drought emergency in parts of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware.

title: Arbour's Decision: It's One More Time
description: This is how Al Arbour creates the suspense year after year. Early in the season, he is asked if he will be back and he says he doesn't know. Later he says he isn't sure, and then after the season ends, he says he needs time to think.

title:
BUSINESS AND HEALTH;

Plans to Tax Health Benefits
description: WITH the nation's health bill climbing past $400 billion, employers will spend $90 billion this year for group health insurance. In one of the more controversial of its expected proposals, the Treasury would like to tax part of the $90 billion for the first time. Some of it would be added to employee income as a base for withholding Federal, state and local income taxes as well as Social Security payroll taxes.

title: PUBLISHERS DENY BIAS IN U.S. LIST
description: A committee of American publishers rejected complaints yesterday that the list of 300 books selected for display at the Moscow International Book Fair in September was ideologically unbalanced.

title: Virus and Depression
description: Immunologists in West Germany, working with biologists and psychiatrists at the University of Pennsylvania, have found evidence that certain psychiatric disorders might be related to a rare virus disease of sheep and horses.

title: ANDOVER CONTROLS reports earnings for 12wks to March 31
Swiss Wholesale Prices
description: Wholesale prices in Switzerland rose one-tenth of 1 percent in April from March, and were up 3.4 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. The 12-month rise was down from increases of 3.5 percent in March and 4.4 percent in February.

title: Casinos Report Revenue Increase
description: The 10 operating casinos in Atlantic City reported an overall increase in revenues of 8.4 percent last month, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission said Monday.

title: KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been restated where necessary to give retroactive effect to the 3-for-1 stock split declared April 1 on both classes of common stock.

title: STATE LAWMAKERS TO EXTEND RENT REGULATIONS TO JUNE 5
description: Rent-regulation laws covering more than 1.2 million tenants in the New York metropolitan area are due to expire at midnight Tuesday, but legislative leaders have agreed to extend the laws until June 5 as discussions over their long-term fate continue.

title: APPARENT HOAX SETS OFF SEARCH FOR PLANE AND 5
description: A daylong sea and air search off the South Shore of Long Island for a small plane with five people aboard was called off last night and described by Federal officials as an apparent hoax.

title: Filipino Soldiers Kill 17 Communist Rebels
description: Government troops killed at least 17 Communist rebels in 24 hours in the southern and central Philippines, military officials and news reports said today.

title: LILLIAN E. BOSCOWITZ
description: Lillian Emerson Boscowitz, who through her sponsorship of charity affairs raised more than $1 million for the George Junior Republic, an institution for problem teen-agers in Freeville, N.Y., died Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: SANDS REGENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $131,000.

title: Governor Thompson's Justice
description: In commuting the rape sentence of Gary Dotson, Gov. James Thompson of Illinois has found a wise way out of a vexing problem of justice. Buffeted by public puzzlement and advice, he calmly resolved this anomalous case with fairness to the complainant, the prisoner, the legal system and the society it is supposed to serve.

title: Florida Housing Mortgage Bonds
description: The Florida Housing Finance Agency is offering $150 million of mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2016 through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: NUI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LITTLE PROGRESS REPORTED AS PILOTS AND UNITED TALK
description: Negotiators for United Airlines and its pilots' union met yesterday for the first time in a month, but a union spokesman said little progress was made on the two main issues that separate them: pay and the length of time newly hired pilots could be kept at lower salaries than the present 5,200 pilots are paid.

title: DR. MILLER EXAMINES HUMOR
description: Jonathan Miller began his lecture last night by finishing off a thought he had begun at his lecture the previous evening. For the average speaker, conducting a decent discussion on a single topic is enough of a challenge. But for Dr. Miller, a veritable master of the art of conversation, picking up where he had left off seemed as effortless as a tailor's resumption of sewing after a momentary distraction. He carefully pulled his words as if they were still attached to the previous night.

title: THE TREASURY'S TROJAN HORSE
description: It would be ironic if the Administration's understandable and commendable zeal for income tax simplification resulted instead in a plan that sharply intensified inequities, undermined our Federal system of government and destabilized competitive economic relations between the states. There is such a Trojan Horse in the Treasury's ''tax reform'' plan - and, judging by the political climate at the Treasury and the White House, it is at our gates.

title: COLONIAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
4 DEVELOPERS ASKED TO SUBMIT PROPOSALS FOR QUEENS STADIUM
description: The State Urban Development Corporation has asked four developers to submit proposals for construction of a domed sports arena near Shea Stadium in Queens.

title: Ruling Backs Carter Stores
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.'s purchase of some of its own stock in a successful attempt to fend off a takeover bid was upheld by a Federal Court of Appeals today, rejecting a challenge by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Abraham Beame Looks Back
description: IT would be a bit much to suggest that former Mayor Abraham D. Beame looks back on New York's fiscal crisis with nostalgia. Yet he remembers ''the roughest years the city ever had'' as a time when ''people from all sectors - business, the unions, civic and religious leaders - cooperated with one another'' and ''there was a minimum of tensions.''

title: Bond-Warrant Link by Intel
description: The Intel Corporation is offering $215 million of units consisting of zero coupon bonds due in 1995 and warrants to buy common stock though underwriters led by L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. The financing, which underwriters said was attracting both equity- and debt-oriented investors, was said to be the first of its kind.

title: EWING OPENS UP TO NEW MEDIA
description: Making the transition from four years as a collegian to the unpredictable pressures of surviving and thriving in the so-called ''real world'' is a challenge that thousands of graduates will face this spring. But no one's progress will be charted, monitored and critiqued more than that of Patrick Ewing, the 7-foot center whose commanding presence is expected to transform the Knicks into a championship contender.

title: PRIMA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a $600,000 writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: COEUR D'ALENE MINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: DIGITAL'S BID FOR A COMEBACK
description: Not too many years ago, a small start-up computer company with only $70,000 in seed money stunned competitors with an inexpensive, versatile machine that introduced computers to thousands of new users.

title: Stingley Honored
description: Darryl Stingley, the former New England Patriot wide receiver who has been confined to a wheelchair since suffering a spinal injury in a preseason game in 1978, received an honorary degree from Springfield College during commencement ceremonies over the weekend.

title: Straus Ponders Bid for Voice
description: Straus Communications Inc., the owner of WMCA-AM radio in New York, is considering making a bid for The Village Voice, the weekly newspaper owned by Rupert Murdoch, according to its chairman, R. Peter Straus.

title: Season Of the Field Trip
description: They descend upon the capital each spring, hundreds of thousands of high school students, emerging from late-night plane rides and two- and three-day bus rides to view the nation's monuments and the workings of government.

title: Prodigal Water Users
description: The drought emergency didn't seem to deter many New Yorkers over the weekend. At Manhattan Plaza, Ninth Avenue and 43d Street, an employee was watering the shrubbery at 1 P.M. His leaky hose was watering the pavement.

title: Slaying in Basque Region
description: Basque separatists are suspected in the assassination of a policeman in downtown San Sebastian, the authorities said today. Maximo Antonio Garcia, 29 years old, was shot three times in the head late Sunday by three assailants who fled on foot, the police said. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack in this city in the Basque region.

title: France Might Broaden Trade With Nicaragua
description: France is willing to broaden commercial relations with Nicaragua despite the newly imposed United States trade embargo, a spokesman for President Francois Mitterrand said today.

title: PRIMO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOP STUDENTS FIND SHORTCUT TO TEACHING
description: LAST year at this time, Carlos R. Caraballo was a senior at Automotive High School in Brooklyn, where he was one of the most adept students at auto mechanics, especially chassis work. Today, even though he has graduated, Mr. Caraballo is still at Automotive High, but now he is an assistant teacher and shows others how to do such tasks as repair a front-end suspension or reline a set of brakes.

title: 2 Officers to Head Lyon When It Goes Private
description: Lyon Metal Products Inc., which has been fending off takeover attempts for much of the last year, yesterday named two executives who will run the company after a plan to take Lyon private is successfully completed.

title: ALLIANCE WELL SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
3 Bombings Are Felt In New Caledonia City
description: Three bomb blasts within six hours rocked this capital of New Caledonia last night, blowing a hole in the Court of Justice, sinking a yacht in the marina, and damaging the entrance to a Melanesian school.

BRINK'S SUSPECT HELD WITHOUT BAIL AFTER SHE REFUSES TO ENTER A PLEA
description: Marilyn Jean Buck, charged with conspiracy and racketeering in connection with the 1981 Brink's holdup in Rockland County, refused to enter a plea in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday and was ordered held without bail.

description: Is it a gremlin from the Kremlin?

ARMS SALES TO THIRD WORLD LAG
description: The dollar value of arms delivered last year from industrial nations to the developing world was the lowest in nearly a decade, a new study by the Congressional Research Service said today.

title: Coach Coming Home
description: After a 10-year hiatus, Tom Sullivan is coming home. Sullivan, who played basketball at Fordham and served as coach at New Hampshire College for the last nine seasons, is expected to be the choice when Manhattan College names its new coach today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, MAY 14, 1985

title: FORMASTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 'LADY FROM YESTERDAY,' TO BE BROADCAST ON CBS
description: A RULE of commercial television: When a program is underwritten by a single sponsor, the presentation's message is likely to be inspirational or, at the very least, upbeat. Such is the thoroughly predictable case with ''The Lady From Yesterday,'' being broadcast tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS as part of the ''General Foods Golden Showcase.''

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GRADUATES OF PACE HEAR D'AMATO'S CRIME VIEWS
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato last night called for an attack on crime and illegal drugs to restore the country's ''domestic tranquillity.''

title: Cap No Bar To Ewing
description: After the Knicks officially draft Patrick Ewing on June 18 and begin their negotiations to sign him to a longtime contract, they will not be hampered by the salary cap restriction established in the labor agreement between the National Basketball Association and the players' union.

title: INNOVATIONS'S SPARK BRIGHTENS ATLANTA SHOW
description: THE various computer shows such as Comdex, Softcon and the West Coast Computer Faire have often set the tone for the industry. In the recent past that tone has sounded like a dirge.

title: Renegades Edge Gunslingers by 1
description: Reggie Collier accounted for three first-half touchdowns tonight and the Orlando defense held off a furious second-half rally as the Renegades beat San Antonio, 21-20.

title: $1.5 Million Ad Campaign
description: How does a candidate whose recognition level is considerably south of celebrity cure his problem?

title: BELLAMY OFFERS AN ALTERNATIVE BUDGET
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy, calling Mayor Koch a ''poor budget maker,'' put forward an alternative proposal yesterday, including $228 million in spending for service improvements.

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for 16wks to April 6
SHOPS CLOSE IN NEW DELHI IN A STRIKE TO PROTEST WAVE OF BOMBINGS
description: A strike to protest what the opposition called the Government's failure to prevent Sikh attacks in northern India last weekend closed markets and businesses throughout New Delhi today. Sporadic violence was reported.

title: Deficit Reducers Must Tackle Corporate Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: SHADOWY TRADE IN FLOWER BULBS WORRIES CONSERVAITONISTS
description: BY merely buying flower bulbs for their gardens, botanists warn, some Americans have unwittingly abetted the trade in endangered species. Conservation-minded consumers who would not dream of buying cheetah pelts or parrots may instead be depleting rare plants by planting cyclamens, snowdrops and anemones that were uprooted from fields in western Asia.

title: READY FOR GRADUATION
description: They walked into the sunlight, the teacher and the pupil, and the only props missing were the cap and gown and the strains of ''Pomp and Circumstance.'' Patrick Ewing was being graduated from college basketball to professional basketball, from a fairly regulated world to a laissez-faire world, and he gave every indication that he was ready for the world.

title: Ewing Proves to Be Popular
description: At various times yesterday -the day after the Knicks won the draft rights to Patrick Ewing -hundreds of people stood in lines and studied the plastic bubble in the rotunda of Madison Square Garden that contains the seating arrangements. After checking seat locations, they began filling out applications for season tickets.

title: CHARLOTTE CHARLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Circumstantial Case' Depicted in Infant Death
description: Prosecutors have a ''strong circumstantial case'' against a woman accused of bludgeoning her 4-month-old daughter to death, the assistant attorney general said today.

title: MUSIC STAR PROMOTIONS UNDERGO CAUTIOUS TURN
description: When Michael Jackson pulsed down the stairs to make his now-historic Pepsi commercial and his hair caught fire from a flying spark, Mr. Jackson and Pepsico Inc. reaped enormous publicity.

title: BUSINESS GAIN ON TAXES LIKELY IN REAGAN PLAN
description: The plan to revise the Federal income tax system that President Reagan intends to submit to Congress next week will probably be somewhat more favorable to business and less favorable to individuals than the proposal the Treasury Department presented last fall, Administration officials said today.

description: b-After a capital loss of $2,000 and a tax credit of $20,000. c-Including a capital gain of $18,000.

title: A FEW GOOD MUSICIANS
description: In the tense days of the Iranian hostage crisis, an embattled President Carter would sometimes pause outside the East Room of the White House to catch the United States Marine Band in rehearsal.

title: Forgotten Facts in the Hudson War
description: New York City and Northern New Jersey are battling over Federal aid and it comes as no surprise for Representative James Howard to enlist on the New Jersey side, assailing the Westway project on the New York side. Mr. Howard has represented New Jersey for 20 years, rising to chairman of the Public Works and Transportation committee. What's surprising is that so reputable a figure would go into battle while weighted down with forgotten facts.

title: LASERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $27,117. c-Net loss.

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bloomingdale's said Barry Marchessault had been promoted to senior vice president in its catalogue division.

title: GENERAL METAL & ABRASIVES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cruise Trade Gives New York Port a Lift
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'MAYOR,' KOCH IN A CABARET VERSION
description: WHILE Mayor Koch has been called many things by his fans and detractors, adjectives like ''genial,'' ''mild'' and ''sweet'' have generally not been among them. It's those words, however, that most accurately describe both ''Mayor,'' the modest new cabaret musical adapted from Mr. Koch's memoirs, and the character it places center stage. Although lightly critical of the Mayor -and lightly sprinkled with amusing segments - this 90-minute show does transform New York's brash, archetypal political street fighter into a cuddly, if egocentric, hero (Lenny Wolpe) with a sparkling white smile that could rival that of Bert Parks.

title: PERFECT FIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Spot Quiz
description: When Rusty Staub lumbered mightily toward the right-field line and caught up with a fly ball to help preserve the Mets' 18-inning victory over Pittsburgh two weeks ago, Chuck Tanner was amazed. ''It was a great catch,'' the expansive Pirate manager said later.

title: EX-STATE AIDE TELLS OF PAYMENTS FROM LANDLORDS
description: A former state official involved in the relocation of offices from the World Trade Center told the State Commission of Investigation yesterday that he later worked as a consultant for two of the New York City landlords with whom he helped negotiate multi-million-dollar leases.

title: IN HARSH LIGHT OF REALITY, THE SHUTTLE IS BEING RE-EVALUATED
description: IF the high hopes of five years ago had been realized, today might have seen the 37th launching of a space shuttle. Everyone in the program, the engineers and managers and their political overseers, would have been congratulating one another on how well the fleet of four re-usable spaceships was fulfilling the promise of providing a revolutionary means of dependable, frequent and economical access to space.

title: Lilco in Pact With Banks
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has concluded agreements with its bankers to assure solvency until the end of June 1986, the chairman, William J. Catacosinos, said today at the company's annual meeting.

title: JERSEY TRACKS JOIN TO OFFER TOP RACES
description: Officials of New Jersey's five race tracks anounced today that they were submerging their differences to band together and offer a rich, new series of thoroughbred and harness races. The plan seems designed to challenge New York for the leadership of horse racing in the East.

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $125,000 for the quarter and $686,000 for the year.

title: Conspiracy Trial Opens for 9
description: Jury selection began in Manhattan yesterday for the Federal trial of nine defendants accused of conspiring to carry out armed robberies and jailbreaks growing out of the 1981 Brink's armored car robbery in Rockland County.

title: Rutgers Group Declares End To Protest Over South Africa
description: Organizers of a sit-in at Rutgers University announced today that they would end a monthlong protest of the university's investments in companies that trade with South Africa.

title: Chess: 2 Finish Tied for First Place In the Linares Tournament
description: The powerful Linares International Tournament in Spain ended in a tie for first place between two grandmasters, 36-year-old Robert Huebner of West Germany and 34-year-old Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia. Each scored 7-3 in the 12-man round-robin competition.

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BATTLE OF BRITAIN THREW NAZI TIMETABLE OFF
description: To the Editor:

title: NO WARRANT NEEDED FOR MOTOR HOME
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the search of a motor home without a warrant. The Court ruled that although the vehicle in question possessed ''some if not many of the attributes of a home,'' for which a search warrant is almost always required, it more closely resembled a car, which the police may search without a warrant.

title: 2 in Arkansas Enter Plea In 1960 Prisoner Death
description: Two former city police officers pleaded not guilty today to murder charges in the death 25 years ago of a jail inmate.

title: GOLDALE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that the contribution to earnings by Edward A. Viner & Co. was $285,000 in the latest quarter.

title: Ex-Sperry Executive Is Moving to Datapoint
description: John C. Butler, a veteran executive of the Sperry Corporation, has been named chief operating officer and a director of the Datapoint Corporation, the financially troubled computer maker based in San Antonio.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allison Manufacturing Corp., North Hollywood, Calif., said it had bought the Nobur Manufacturing Co. and the Spira-LOC Co. from the Cleveland Twist Drill division of the Acme-Cleveland Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

title: JURY DECLARES MOUNTAIN MAN GUILTY OF KIDNAPPING ATHLETE
description: A young mountain man was convicted late today on charges of kidnapping and assaulting an athlete.

title: DIVISIONS BETWEEN RACES PERSIST IN NEW YORK CITY, POLL INDICATES
description: In the way New Yorkers socialize and think about issues of equality, and in their housing, whites and blacks in the city remain deeply segregated, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV poll.

LANGUAGES SPARKING ENTHUSIASM
description: WHEN I asked the Mexican-American sixth graders in a French class at the Tafolla Middle School why they were studying French, one girl answered, ''Because most rich people know French.'' A classmate added, ''Because it's interesting and I don't know it.''

title: READING SCORES IN CITY'S SCHOOLS HIT THEIR HIGHEST LEVELS IN YEARS
description: The number of New York City public school pupils reading as well or better than their counterparts around the nation has reached a new high, the Board of Education said yesterday.

title: Springsteen Weds
description: Bruce Springsteen, the rock star, was married early today to Julianne Phillips, a 25-year-old actress and model. Mr. Springsteen, 35 years old, eluded the fans, reporters and photographers who had staked out the house and church of his bride's family since Friday in this Portland suburb. About 50 relatives and friends witnessed the half-hour ceremony, according to the bride's relatives.

title: CALCULATED DESTRUCTION IN THE GALAPAGOS ISLANDS
description: FOR many of us, the word ''conservation'' evokes images of truck caravans hauling bamboo shoots to starving pandas, dauntless mountaineers scaling cliffs to rescue condor hatchlings, naturalists bottle-feeding gorilla orphans. Conservation connotes kindness to nature's creatures.

title: 10K Race Is Run In Twilight Zone
description: Doreen Ennis-Schwarz of Nutley, N.J., one of the leading female road runners in the East, was invited to compete Sunday in the G. Fox & Company 10-kilometer road race in Hartford. She accepted, and thereby set in motion a series of coincidences so improbable as to be downright eerie.

title: Bridge:   Canadian Experts Dominate Cavendish <u1<u1Club <u1<u1Competition
description: Canadian experts dominated the Cavendish Club's invitational pairs competition, which ended Sunday night at the club's new premises at 105 East 73d Street. The winners were both Canadian, and two of their compatriots were close challengers. By contrast, the visitors from Europe and South America did badly, with only one player over average.

description: THE PENNYSLVANIA BALLET used to perform annually at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the programs it has just presented there after an absence of several seasons strongly suggest we need to see the company from Philadelphia more regularly.

description: b-Includes a realized gain of $5,138,000, or 10 cents a share, on investment. c-Includes a realized gain of $2,190,000, or 4 cents a share, on investment.

title: Battle of Britain Threw Nazi Timetable Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Looks, Bad Image
description: Attractive women may be at a disadvantage in the business world, while for men good looks are an asset, according to a new study published in the current Journal of Applied Psychology.

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $90,000. c-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $87,000.

title: Export Ban Called Costly to Soviet
description: Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense, made public today a report asserting that the United States had prevented the Soviet Union from saving more than $6.6 billion by blocking the sale of advanced technology.

title: STEVIE WONDER OFFERS MUSICAL APPEAL AT U.N.
description: It was an occasion for hand-clapping and standing ovations that heads of state only dream about, as the singer Stevie Wonder turned the normally stolid United Nations General Assembly Hall into a combination rock concert and revival meeting yesterday.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS FIGHT U.S. MILITARY ACTIVITY
description: A lawsuit challenging the legality of United States military operations on Tinian Island in the Western Pacific has been filed in a Federal court here on behalf of a 17-year-old student who owns land on the island.

title: CHARLIE BROWN CELEBRATES 20TH ANNIVERSARY ON THE AIR
description: HAVING survived 20 years of television, Charlie Brown, Snoopy and the rest of the gang look remarkably well preserved, as fresh as they did when they first showed their faces in the cartoon show on CBS in 1965. This milestone is being celebrated on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock tonight with ''It's Your 20th Television Anniversary, Charlie Brown.''

title: Banker Sues E.S.M. Auditor
description: Marvin L. Warner has filed a $1.15 billion lawsuit against Alexander Grant & Company, the accounting firm that audited the since-collapsed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., a lawyer for Mr. Warner said today.

title: Topics;   Going Public
description: Hello, Mother Remember the nurse who was on duty the night that Gloria Stivic gave birth to Archie and Edith Bunker's grandson Joey? She said about her sister Berenice, ''The whole world should only know what kind of a woman my sister is,'' and the whole world knew exactly how she felt. There was Berenice, a truly rotten human being, and who knew? Nobody.

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $638,000.

title: Medicus Intercon Wins Top Spot in Health Care
description: It appears that Sudler & Hennessey has been toppled from its No. 1 position as the biggest specialty agency in the health care field. And they have been toppled by Medicus Intercon International, which acquired the ADA Group in London, pushing its worldwide billings to a projected 1985 figure of $160 million from $136 million last year. S.&H. clocked $137 million in 1984.

title: Conner Leading Sailing Trials
description: Dennis Conner and his crew outsailed the Admiral's Cup trials fleet today by winning the third race of the selection series here, a 100-mile overnight race that was sailed in rain and fog.

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $40,300.

title: PROTESTS GO ON
description: Pope John Paul II, still beleaguered by protesters, condemned apartheid today and called for a stronger World Court and an international bill of rights.

title: Dow Rises 3.32 as Volume Slackens
description: Trading activity slowed substantially yesterday on Wall Street, but the stock market still managed to rise for the third consecutive session as investors continued to debate the impact of recent developments on the Federal budget deficit.

title: AFTER ORMANDY, ORCHESTRA LOOKS AHEAD
description: In a symbolic generational passage that raises tantalizing questions about this city's cultural future, the Philadelphia Orchestra Sunday night bade a solemn musical goodbye to the late Eugene Ormandy.

title: Some Caution On Drug Issues
description: DRUGSTORE chains, a market sector long favored by investors for brisk earnings growth, are feeling the bumps of competition these days. As a result, security analysts are becoming more selective in their recommendations of drug chain stocks.

title: AS ARMS BUILDUP EASES, U.S. TRIES TO TAKE STOCK
description: A new political reality has begun to sink in at the Pentagon: The biggest peacetime military buildup in modern American history is coming to an end, and the nation is asking whether it has been getting its money's worth.

title: THE ORDEAL OF A 'HUMAN EXPERIMENT'
description: For all but the first 18 of the 173 days that William J. Schroeder has lived with an artificial heart, he has suffered from serious brain damage. And a second stroke that occurred last week has left the longest surviving artificial heart recipient unable to speak and bedridden with his right arm and leg paralyzed.

description: Selma Diamond, the comedy writer whose nasal voice and crack timing made her a successful actress as well, died of lung cancer yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, according to the hospital. She was 64 years old.

title: PROVINCETOWN-BOSTON AIRINE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MUSIC: DAVIS AND TORONTO ENSEMBLE
description: THE reputations of conductors are generally made nowadays under the worst of conditions: that is, while they are guest-conducting orchestras with which they have little intimate connection. The globe-trotting leader tends to settle for something less than the best that the orchestra is capable of, either because he does not know what that best is, or because of rehearsal limitations. And the musicians themselves are likely to regard any guest-conducting engagement as a time to relax. That is why it can be so enlightening to hear a conductor working with his own orchestra, or at least one with which he has developed a long-term relationship. On the top international level, there is not much that separates one orchestra performance from another except the rapport that exists between the leader and the led.

title: FRONTIER MAY BUY ITS SHARES
description: In a step that could lead to the first privately owned major airline in the nation, the board of directors of Frontier Airlines yesterday approved the sale of 25 of the carrier's planes to United Airlines for $265 million and held out the possibility of using the money to buy out shareholders.

description: In an attempt to improve chances for Congressional approval of a lower minimum wage for teen-age workers, Labor Secretary Bill Brock is considering modifying the Reagan Administration proposal.

title: Master Mechanic
description: Don Sutton's victory over Boston on Sunday was the 283d of his career, a figure that ties him with Jim Kaat for 21st place in big-league history. Later, pondering the lasting significance of that kind of achievement, in an era in which more sensational pitchers have often overshadowed him, Sutton said: ''I hope that when they vote for that little place in upstate New York, they'll remember Jim Kaat and me. We may not be nuclear scientists, but we should be remembered as pretty good mechanics.''

title: BRAVES END MET STREAK
description: The Atlanta Braves finally scored a run tonight after 37 innings in which they did not score a run. It wasn't much of a run and, in fact, it was a disputed run. But it became the run that sank the Mets, 1-0, ending the Braves' four-game scoreless streak, the Braves' five-game losing streak and the Mets' six-game winning streak.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NOTES OF AN ANATOMIST. by F. Gonzalez-Crussi. 134 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. FRANK GONZALEZ-CRUSSI, who was born and raised in Mexico, is currently professor of pathology at Northwestern University. All the essays in ''Notes of an Anatomist'' are colored to a greater or lesser degree by his professional experience, and in one of them, ''The Dead as a Living,'' he wonders openly what effect years of performing autopsies can have had on his personality. Pathologists deal with morbid conditions; they become habituated to cutting open and cutting up. Isn't their vision, he asks, bound to be correspondingly ''unbalanced, skewed and asymmetrical''?

title: Umpires Agree To Tests
description: Major league umpires have agreed to the mandatory drug-testing program announced by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth last week, leaving the players as the only group in baseball not covered by the plan. Donald Fehr, acting executive director of the Players Association, criticized the umpires' action, saying it was ''astounding because they don't know any details'' of the program.
