description: Debt Issues

title: British Face Debts
description: Five hundred of Britain's wealthiest people met today to discuss huge losses they face because of large damage awards to asbestos victims in the United States and misappropriated insurance funds at Lloyd's of London. They are among 1,500 Lloyd's members who each must pay up to $625,000 in cash to cover $162.5 million in present and future losses incurred by five syndicates that underwrote product liability insurance for large American corporations. The insurance exchange holds the members liable for losses equal to their wealth.

title: Careers;   Advances Cited in Job Security
description: COMPANIES have been losing more cases involving the ''termination at will'' concept applied to management workers. But at the same time, an increasing number of prestigious growth companies have adopted employment security programs that apply to management.

title: No Headline
description: Thinking of tradition and sensing an opportunity to move into New York, Lamar Hunt, the founder and president of World Championship Tennis, kept Forest Hills alive after the United States Open moved from the West Side Tennis Club to Flushing Meadows in 1978. But a tournament calendar that has since reached the saturation point, and lucrative prize money everywhere have prevented the Tournament of Champions from becoming a significant event on the men's tour.

title: P & F INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $18,000.

title: PEREZ'S PINCH SLAM GIVES REDS VICTORY
description: Tony Perez's pinch grand slam off the reliever Dave Rucker sent the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight. The loss was the Phillies' seventh straight.

title: Jehovah's Witnesses Were Hitler's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon Layoffs
description: The Exxon Corporation unit that coordinates the company's international supply and transportation of crude oil will lay off between 25 and 50 employees June 1, according to Thomas Hayes, an Exxon spokesman. Mr. Hayes said the employees work for the Exxon International Company, which has a staff of 500 and is based in Florham Park, N.J. He said the dismissals generally stemmed from the sharp decline in recent years of the volume of crude oil shipped by the company, and specifically from the company's closing of its refinery in Aruba in March.

title: A NEW BRAND OF LUNACY FOR SALE
description: ''YOU'RE from New York City?'' asked Racter, a garrulous prose synthesis computer program, in a recent interview. It was unclear from the start who was interviewing whom. ''Now I remember! I once knew a Hortense Lewis from New York City. You must be related, no?'' )No!

title: Midshipmen Drug-Free, Navy Says Tests Show
description: After almost three years of tests for drug use at the Naval Academy, midshipmen have a perfect record.

title: BALLET: 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: SIR KENNETH MacMILLAN'S ''Romeo and Juliet'' is as much acting as it is dancing, if not more. And so one hopes for that miraculous pair of performers who can project emotions as convincing as their pirouettes. It is a great deal to ask, perhaps, in a time when ballet is so technically demanding and competitive a profession.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $1,112,000.

title: A Reunion At Radio Network
description: WHEN Dick Clark's United Stations bought the two RKO Radio networks in March it partly ended an embarrassing interlude for Gencorp, the RKO parent. Most people in broadcasting know about that.

title: U.S. DROPS CHARGE ON TAXICAB LIMITS
description: The Federal Trade Commission has withdrawn its challenge to a Minneapolis ordinance that permitted the city to set taxi fares and limit the number of cabs on the street.

title: Coors Reshuffling Is All in the Family
description: The Adolph Coors Company, the nation's fifth-largest brewer, continues to prove that blood is thicker than water - or beer.

title: FLEXWATT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split that was distributed January 18.

title: Getting His Hit
description: When this column checked in with Tim Barker the other day, the Central Florida outfielder was trying to cope with some self-imposed pressure, get at least one more hit and thus break the N.C.A.A. single-season record, which he had already tied: 137, set last year by Chris Gwynn of San Diego State. So what happened?

title: BRITISH SEEK CAUSE OF STADIUM BLAZE
description: The police said today that smoke bombs were thrown at the Bradford soccer stadium on Saturday before a fire swept through the main grandstand, killing 53 people.

title: SAVANNAH FOODS & INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bomb Threat Halts Auction
description: The auction last night of Impressionist and modern art at Phillips, Son & Neale, 79th Street East of First Avenue, was interrupted by a telephoned bomb threat that led to evacuation of the building. After police declared the premises safe, the sale of the 60 remaining artworks was rescheduled to 2 P.M. today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OUT OF ASIA The Asian Pacific American Heritage Arts Festival opens today at La Mama's Twitas Hall, 6 East First Street, and it promises to be a colorful and pleasant way of becoming more familiar with the ways and culture of the growing number of Asians in New York.

title: ANTI-JAPANESE PROTESTS FLARE OVER ARREST OF SOUTH KOREAN
description: A spurt of anti-Japanese protest has arisen in South Korea after the arrest of a Korean resident of Japan who refused to be fingerprinted for an identity card.

title: The Constitutional Rights of Clients Who Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This declaration is absolutely necessary. Ground-water levels in the basin are the worst on record.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture on Saturday with an article about Massachusetts politics was printed erroneously. It showed Edward Harrington, a Massachusetts lawyer, not the Edward Harrington who is a former United States Attorney and possible candidate for Massachusetts Attorney General.

title: How Grows Your Garden?
description: The National Grange is cultivating one of the smallest plots of arable land in North America, right in the heart of downtown Washington. It is a 10-by-4-foot plot dug out of the sidewalk in front of the Grange's office at 1616 H Street, just two blocks from the White House.

title: GENERAL'S ONE, TWO WHIPSAW
description: The Generals' ability to whipsaw a defense with the differing talents of Herschel Walker and Doug Flutie was exemplified in the winning drive against the Baltimore Stars on Sunday.

title: BEL FUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Body of 18-Year-Old Found in Car Trunk
description: The body of an 18-year-old Queens woman was found in the trunk of her car on a street in Nassau County Sunday, and after an autopsy was performed yesterday authorities said she had been strangled.

title: Visit by a U.S. Warship To China Is Postponed
description: United States officials said today that a warship visit to China had been postponed because of a dispute over whether the vessel would be nuclear-armed.

title: Not All Paving Stones Are Cobblestones
description: To the Editor:

title: TRENDS FOR FALL DRESSING: WOOL JERSEY IS A FAVORITE
description: The new fashions are comfortable to live with in the trend-setting collections for next fall and winter. They are not dramatically different enough to make a woman unhappy with the clothes she already owns, and yet are sufficiently distinctive to make her want to add some new pieces.

title: DEPORTEES IN NIGERIA BREAK OUT OF CAMP AND HEAD FOR BORDER
description: Tens of thousands of illegal aliens ordered out of Nigeria broke loose today from a transit camp and headed for the Nigeria-Benin border, witnesses said.

title: CONTROL LASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: STARTED U.S. BRANCH OF JEWELRY BUSINESS
description: Luca Buccellati, who introduced his family's silver and jewelry business to this country in 1952, died at his home in Manhattan last Thursday after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: CARE PLUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $33,013. c-Net loss.

title: Alexander's Names Officers
description: Alexander's Inc., the New York department store chain, yesterday named two executive vice presidents, Roger A. Barrer, 59 years, and Louis Powell, 62, to a newly formed office of the president.

title: BUFFTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OPTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBS CHARGES ZIFF-DAVIS OVERSTATED DIVISION NET
description: CBS Inc. is accusing the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company of overstating the earnings of the magazines it sold to CBS earlier this year, and the broadcaster is threatening to sue for damages.

title: LEECH LEAVES FOSSIL RECORD DESPITE ABSENCE OF SKELETON
description: ANIMAL bones are rarely preserved as rock fossils, a fact that leaves major gaps in the fossil record and greatly complicates the study of evolution. But far bigger gaps result from the extreme scarcity of fossils left by soft-bodied animals without skeletons or shells.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC ADMITS FALSIFYING BILLING ON MISSILE
description: The General Electric Company pleaded guilty today to defrauding the Air Force by filing 108 false claims for payment on a missile contract. It was fined $1.04 million, the maximum allowable, and ordered to pay back the $800,000 that was falsely billed.

title: Citicorp Request
description: The Federal Reserve Board invited comments on a revised application by Citicorp to underwrite and deal in municipal revenue bonds and other securities.

title: ART COMPLEX PLANNED IN NEW TOWER
description: In what is perhaps the largest partnership ever forged between art and real estate in Manhattan, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday that it plans to integrate three art galleries and numerous major sculptures, murals and designed plaza spaces into its new midtown corporate headquarters.

title: PICKENS UPHELD ON UNOCAL
description: A Delaware judge, rejecting an appeal by the Unocal Corporation, today upheld an earlier ruling that an investor group led by T. Boone Pickens must be included in the company's offer to repurchase 29 percent of its stock for $72 a share in new debt securities.

title: ABC, Capital Cities To Sell Stations
description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. and the American Broadcasting Companies, as expected, said yesterday that they would sell 4 television stations and 15 radio stations, including WABC-AM and WPLJ-FM in New York City, to satisfy the regulatory requirements of their proposed $3.5 billion merger.

title: Maximum of 9 5/8% On Colorado Issue
description: The Colorado Health Facilities Authority yesterday offered $62.7 million of refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9 5/8 percent for bonds due in 2015 through underwriters led by Miller & Schroeder Municipals Inc.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Four Season Solar
description: Ross Roy/Colarossi Griswold has been named agency for the Four Season Solar Products Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., and will be doing the creative work while its parent company, Ross Roy of Detroit, handles the media.

title: BUDDY EBSEN VISITS FAN CLUB AND NIXON JOINS IN THE SALUTE
description: The members of the Barnaby Jones Luncheon Club had been waiting four years to meet the man who played their silver-haired hero on television. The other day, Buddy Ebsen finally came to lunch.

title: ALTERCATION MAY END RUN AT CIRCLE REP
description: The Circle Repertory production of ''Angelo's Wedding'' by Julie Bovasso may be closed because of disputes with the playwright that include an altercation at the theater during Saturday night's performance. The play, about an Air Force veteran trying to determine his true parentage, began previews last week and is scheduled to open on May 23.

title: 'CHAOTIC' CONDITIONS FEARED AT U.N.'S PARLEY ON WOMEN
description: A panel preparing a United Nations-sponsored conference on women's issues completed its work last week, leaving a dispute between representatives of Western and third-world nations undecided. Western diplomats predicted the conference would be ''chaotic'' and ''disastrous.''

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. John Montefusco, sidelined by several ailments, makes his first start of the season for the Yankees, replacing Joe Cowley in the starting rotation.

title: Indy Driver Hurt
description: Danny Ongais, severely injured at Indianapolis Speedway in 1981, suffered bruises on both knees yesterday when his March-Cosworth hit the wall during practice. Ongais, who will be 33 a week from today, emerged from the car without help. X-rays revealed he had suffered no fractures.

title: CSM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXCEL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $306,000 litigation expense incurred during arbitration proceedings.

title: NICARAGUA, LAND OF VERSE, REVERSES 'DIVINE' POET
description: Poetry seems to be on the lips and in the soul of every Nicaraguan, and, especially here in Leon, everyone knows why.

title: FED LENDING TO SAVINGS UNITS
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the central bank was lending money to privately insured Maryland thrift institutions that have been experiencing heavy withdrawals.

title: Memphis State Inquiry
description: Billy J. Murphy, former athletic director at Memphis State, testified yesterday before a Federal grand jury looking into charges of sports betting.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Approves News Agency Benefit Accord
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge gave approval today for United Press International to pay $190,000 to the Prudential Insurance Company for employee health benefits through May 31.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income which includes a gain of $4,306,000 from the recovery of excess provision for future losses of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $190,000.

title: BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHEFS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Reflects a loss of $1,425,248 on the sales and closing of restaurants. c-Reflects a loss of $116,598 on the sales and closing of restaurants.

title: Hitchhiker Slain Near Expressway
description: A 21-year-old Yonkers man who was hitchhiking on the Bruckner Expressway was shot to death early yesterday on the northbound service road near the Country Club Road exit in the northeast Bronx, the police said.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE big guns of Seventh Avenue have had their say about next fall's clothes, so it's time to see what the lesser lights are suggesting. A visit to the Soho Showroom seemed in order. It now represents not only the downtown scene but other parts of the world also, including California, Japan and Europe.

title: City Bonds Are Priced; Yields at 5 1/2% to 9 3/4%
description: To finance the hiring of additional police officers and increase other services, New York City is selling $586 million of long-term bonds this week. Proceeds of the sale will be used to repay before maturity all but $1 million of the federally guaranteed city bonds sold to public employee pension funds during the financial crisis of the mid-1970's.

title: Pepitone Denies Guilt
description: Joe Pepitone, the former Yankee first baseman who was arrested on drug and weapons possession charges last March, pleaded not guilty yesterday. ''I'm innocent'' the 44-year-old Pepitone said at his arraignment, repeating his assertion that he had been ''in the wrong place at the wrong time.''

title: TWO KINDS OF DEFICIT
description: ''Social Security is running a surplus. Social Security is not part of the deficit problem. It is totally financed by a payroll tax . . . totally dedicated to that one program. If Social Security spending were reduced you could not take that money saved and use it to fund some other program.'' - President Reagan, at his news conference on Jan. 18, 1985. Yet the Senate has voted, and Mr. Reagan has accepted, a one-year abstention from cost-of-living increases for Social Security recipients. This ''freeze,'' they claim, will reduce the Federal budget deficit by $6 billion in fiscal 1986 and about $22 billion over three years.

title: F.B.I. SAYS IT FOILED PLOT BY SIKHS TO ASSASSINATE GANDHI IN THE U.S.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had foiled a plot by Sikh terrorists to assassinate Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India during his visit to the United States next month.

title: POLICE DROP BOMB ON RADICALS' HOME IN PHILADELPHIA
description: A state police helicopter this evening dropped a bomb on a house occupied by an armed group after a 24-hour siege involving gun battles.

title: RESTAURANT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
PACIFIC INTERNATIONAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kohl Blames Joblessness And Turnout for Loss
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today blamed high unemployment and a low voter turnout for his party's decisive defeat in the North Rhine-Westphalia state election.

title: Primates Endangered
description: The United States affiliate of the World Wildlife Fund announced a $1 million fund-raising campaign today aimed at saving primates, the monkeys, apes and other animals that are the closest relatives of humans.

title: HOUSE BUDGET PANEL HEAD FACES FORMIDABLE TASK
description: After months of preparation, Representative William H. Gray 3d, the new chairman of the House Budget Committee, moves to the center of the Capitol Hill stage this week.

title: REPORT SAYS ELDERLY PATIENTS WERE SUBJECTED TO DRUG TESTS
description: Elderly nursing home residents, some of them senile or illiterate, have served as unwitting guinea pigs for experimental new drugs, according to a report issued today by a group of elderly people.

title: VON BULOW CASE: INSULIN AT ISSUE
description: Claus von Bulow's wife had an unusually high insulin level when she fell into an irreversible coma in 1980, a chemist testified today at the retrial of Mr. von Bulow on charges that he twice tried to kill his wife with insulin.

title: A 'Today' Show Special Is Set for Prime Time
description: NBC's ''Today'' show will move to prime time this summer for a single night.

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OPTROTECH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOUTH AFRICAN UNION STORMS APARTHEID'S BASTIONS
description: It was gold that drew whites to war with one another many decades ago on the uplands of the Reef, in the Transvaal region of South Africa.

title: CONGRESS DIVIDED OVER FARM POLICY
description: As a Senate committee prepares to begin drafting what many members of Congress had hoped would be the most innovative farm bill in a generation, the lawmakers say there are sharp disagreements over farm policy.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cigna-Citizens Eurodollar Credit
description: The Cigna Corporation, an insurance company, and the Citizens and Southern Corporation, a bank holding company, yesterday announced the arrangement of credit facilities to back their borrowings in the Eurodollar market through Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd.

title: TV MOMS AND CHICKEN DINNERS EMPLOYED IN BLUE-LAW BATTLE
description: If you are a Sunday carpenter in Houston, you can buy a hammer, but no nails. You can buy a wooden ladder, but not an aluminum one, a truckload of lumber, but not a power saw.

title: Laker Airways Suit
description: Lawyers for 12 defendants have offered Sir Freddie Laker $8 million to settle his portion of an antitrust suit in which he charges they conspired to fix prices to bankrupt his trans-Atlantic airline, but Sir Freddie has balked at the offer. According to a transcript of a closed hearing in United States District Court last Wednesday, Sidney S. Rosdeitcher, representing British Airways, told Judge Harold S. Greene that settlement offers had been made to the parties involved, including Sir Freddie and the liquidator for Laker Airways. The settlement offered had been agreed to by all the defendants at a meeting in Geneva last month.

description: b-After a tax charge of $18,000.

Of Outside Income
description: Fulfilling a rite of late spring, Congressional staffs are rushing to meet the Wednesday deadline for filing reports on how much outside income members of Congress made in 1984. Outside income is one of the most sensitive, and potentially volatile, issues on Capitol Hill.

title: SHULTZ, CITING MIDEAST 'MOVEMENT,' SAYS KING WILL VISIT REAGAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that King Hussein of Jordan would meet this month with President Reagan in Washington to help keep alive what he found was ''a genuine sense of movement'' in the Middle East toward new Arab-Israeli negotiations.

title: THE TORTURER'S MIND: COMPLEX VIEW EMERGES
description: IN the realm of human evil, the figure of the torturer whose acts of brutality are carried out in the service of the state is a special puzzle.

title: ST. JOHN'S LEAVING ON EUROPEAN TOUR
description: It may look like a pleasure trip and feel like a pleasure trip, but Lou Carnesecca insists that St. John's 18-day trip to Spain and Italy will be more on the order of a working vacation.

description: Don Mattingly must be the perfect student because he did just as told. He went into the exaggerated crouch. He tilted back, far back, on his left foot and then he struck.

title: Director of Le Monde Presents Rescue Plan
description: Andre Fontaine, the top official of Le Monde, presented a long-awaited rescue plan today for the financially troubled newspaper. The plan involves salary reductions of 10 percent and the loss of 250 jobs, journalists said.

description: New York State is shutting down the historic site it maintains at the upstate house where Ulysses S. Grant spent the last year of his life and died.

description: Voters handed a setback to the Communist Party and bolstered Prime Minister Bettino Craxi's five-party coalition in regional elections that ended today.

description: Nine years after Joe Namath played his final game for them, the Jets will retire the quarterback's famed No. 12. He will be the first Jet to have his number retired.

description: Clarence Coggins, a 60-year-old veteran of radical causes, including the militant black-power movement of the 1960's, sat in the back room of a city building the other day amid the latest of the high-tech tools of political organizing.

description: Representative James J. Florio, a Democrat from the city of Camden, in southern New Jersey, flashed some Area Code Pride recently.

description: A second Maryland savings and loan association was placed under the protection of a conservator tonight, and the Governor implored depositors statewide not to panic.

description: Many people in the lunchtime crowd along State Street looked bemused, bewildered and even bewitched as they were lured by an enormous fiberglass sculpture of a cowboy lassoing a red-eyed steer; a tall, hammered-steel swan, and four stuffed bears roaming around several overturned file cabinets.

title: HUBCO EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $41,435. c-Net loss.

title: Butterfly Is Safe, Court Rules
description: A Federal agency's determination that an endangered species of butterfly would not be harmed by construction of 3,000 homes on the San Francisco Peninsula was let stand today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

title: ASSAULT DEFENDED
description: Firefighters found the bodies of six people today in the charred rubble of a radical group's house that had been leveled in a police assault that set fire to the surrounding neighborhood and destroyed more than 50 homes.

title: NICARAGUAN LEADER PREDICTS U.S. WILL BROADEN EMBARGO
description: Vice President Sergio Ramirez Mercado said today that he expected the United States to impose further economic sanctions against Nicaragua.

title: Inland to Write Off About $35 Million
description: The Inland Steel Company said today that it would take a charge of about $35 million, or $1.39 a share, in its second quarter, to cover the costs of closing a Minnesota iron ore mining and processing operation in which it is a part-owner.

title: America, Through Whose Eyes?
description: The task is a challenge, and a wonderful one -to show visitors at the forthcoming Moscow International Book Fair ''America Through American Eyes.'' And because America's publishers didn't want to be pushing their own books, they formed an eight-member committee of writers and members of the New York and Philadelphia public libraries and asked it to come up with a list.

title: BALLET SCHOOL PRESIDENT GETS SUPPORT IN DISPUTE
description: Lincoln Kirstein, president and co-founder of the School of American Ballet, who has become involved in a dispute over its future administration, received a statement of support yesterday from the executive committee of the school's board of directors.

title: OPENING MARKETS FOR FOOD ABROAD
description: The United States urgently needs an agricultural policy in tune with today's and tomorrow's international markets. We must take a hard look at new conditions - global and domestic - that have emerged since we last hammered out an agricultural policy a quarter-century ago.

title: TIED TO PRIEST CASE
description: The top Polish official responsible for the security police at the time of the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest resigned today from the Politburo and from the Central Committee, apparently with encouragement from the top leadership.

Let's Cancel Private Bank Insurance
description: Only weeks ago, Ohio's privately insured savings and loan associations buckled under a wave of scandal and depositor panic. Two of these institutions have been taken over by the conservators of the insurance fund, and by order of the Governor, withdrawals from the others have been limited to $1,000 a month.

title: Case of the Missing Bullets
description: The House Administration Committee is accustomed to dealing with knotty problems, everything from the purchase of art works for the Capitol to the disposition of old Government papers. Comes now a new challenge: the Case of the Missing Bullets.

description: b-Net losses.

title: MORE ANGUISH FROM THAT TRIP TO GERMANY
description: Perhaps the final embarrassment for White House strategists over President Reagan's recent visit to West Germany and the military cemetery at Bitburg has been the blistering defeat suffered by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party in regional elections Sunday.

title: CONCERT: GUITAR FESTIVAL
description: A FESTIVAL of guitar music that will keep Carnegie Hall and/or Carnegie Recital Hall filled with the sound of guitarists through this Friday began last Friday with a sampling of what is in store for the rest of the weeklong gala.

title: Real Estate;   Relocating Jersey City Companies
description: IT would be hard to name an old city with more ambitious revitalization projects than Jersey City, but business gentrification has its costs and hardships just as residential gentrification does. The upgrading of factories into office and residential spaces there, as well as rising rents, has been forcing out some manufacturing tenants.

title: Richardson Talks Are Less Certain
description: Two weeks ago, Micheal Ray Richardson was only the length of a ballpoint pen from signing a new four-year, $2.9 million contract with the Nets, a reward for the best season of his career. But people familiar with the talks say that the distance has since widened considerably.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect a gain of $6,294,000 relating to taxes.

title: Bond Prices Show a Sharp Rise
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, as investors snapped up Government securities in the belief that a cut in the discount rate may be imminent. Market participants said that trading was heavy throughout the day.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THEIR mood was Mexican. So when Kimberly Hollifield and Shana Deitchman of Hoboken, N.J., emerged from the PATH station on Ninth Street near the Avenue of the Americas one recent night, they hopped into a cab and instructed the driver, ''Take us over to Caramba's on lower Broadway - you know where that is?'' The driver nodded yes.

description: May 15, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on International Development Strategy - 3 P.M. Trusteeship Council - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Economic Committee - 10:30 A.M.

title: DOLE OF KANSAS
description: Bob Dole of Kansas has emerged from the latest battle of the budget as the most interesting and promising character in the Senate.

title: SENATORS OPEN DEBATE ON FOREIGN AID BILL FOR '86
description: The Senate began debate today on a $12.8 billion foreign aid authorization bill that is expected to set off a new battle over assistance to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: JUDGE WITHHOLDS INJUNCTION
description: For the last five days, Steve Rubell and Ian Schrager fought in Manhattan Supreme Court to have the Palladium open on time. Yesterday, only hours before deadline, a judge gave them at least a partial victory.

title: Chicago Railroad Studies Options
description: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company, which learned Monday that the Interstate Commerce Commission had approved its request for permission to diversify outside the transportation industry, said that it was already pursuing such a course.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
25 INVESTORS JOIN IN NEW CONRAIL BID
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, as expected, announced today that it had assembled a group of 25 investors to offer to purchase the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail for $1.2 billion in cash and other considerations. Its investor coalition ranged from the CSX Corporation and Citicorp to Harvard, Princeton and Columbia and several major pension funds.

title: Head of Shelter for Refugees In Texas Arrested at Border
description: The director of a shelter for Central American refugees has been arrested at a border checkpoint when a Nicaraguan was found in the trunk of her car, the authorities say.

title: Car Sales Declined 8.6% In First 10 Days of May
description: Despite incentive programs, sales of new American-made automobiles fell 8.6 percent in the first 10 days of May, compared with that period last year, the manufacturers reported today.

title: COMPO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After a pre-tax provision of $5,031,000 relating to the consolidations of certain footwear operations. c-Net income which includes a pre- tax gain of $5,021,000 for the 6 months from the sale of a facility.

title: Layoffs at Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it would lay off about 100 employees at its Carrollton, Tex., plant, near Dallas, where the now-canceled Macintosh XL computer was made.

title: SAGE ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HINCKLEY'S PARENTS HAVE NEW MISSION
description: It has been a while since the name John W. Hinckley Jr. was news. His father, John Sr., who is more comfortable being called Jack, very much liked it that way. So did Jo Ann, his mother. They agree that for a long time they abhorred the notoriety that dogged them, linking ''the very name Hinckley with unpleasantness,'' Mr. Hinckley said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE OLD SOUTH There's a wonderful and generous whiff of the Old South these days at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street (581-2474). ''Southern Folk Art'' has 90 items - paintings, sculpture, furniture, pottery, textiles -made between 1743 and 1915 by Louisiana Cajuns, North Carolina Moravians, Texas Germans, Kentucky Shakers, and people of all derivations.

title: TOSHIBA, OLIVETTI IN ALLIANCE
description: Ing. C. Olivetti & Company S.p.A. of Italy and the Toshiba Corporation of Japan, two leading makers of office equipment and electronics, have formed an alliance that will offer each broad marketing advantages.

title: Liberty and Power
description: It is as powerful a symbol as the city has, but the local utility does not provide its power. Yesterday, however, the Statue of Liberty recovered from a weekend blackout - with a little help from Con Edison.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $191,000 for the latest first quarter and $123,000 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: Going to China
description: The People-to-People Sports Committee, the nonprofit organization that shipped the Brooklyn College soccer team to Nepal not long ago, announced yesterday that the C. W. Post baseball squad would tour Peking and Tianjin in a 10-day, five-game series against university teams there. The Chinese seem to believe that baseball stands a good shot at becoming an official Olympic sport in 1988, and, given their inexperience at it, they want to start learning a thing or two.

title: GROUPS CALL ACTION 'POLITICAL'
description: Several human rights lawyers have been arrested recently, bringing protests from attorneys' groups and opposition politicians who assert that President Ferdinand E. Marcos's Government is trying to intimidate rights lawyers and to frighten opponents.

title: Production in Italy
description: Industrial production in Italy rose 5.8 percent in March from February, but was down 1 percent from a year earlier, the Government reported today. It said industrial output during the first quarter was down five-tenths of 1 percent from the 1984 period.

title: RUSSIANS SAID TO STEP UP AIR AND ARTILLERY ATTACKS INSIDE PAKISTAN
description: The Soviet Union has stepped up its air and artillery attacks inside Pakistan in recent months in what Pakistani officials say is an attempt to undermine support here for Afghan rebels.

title: FLYERS TRIUMPH, LEAD SERIES BY 3-2
description: The Flyers moved within a game of reaching the Stanley Cup finals tonight with a dramatic 2-1 victory over the Quebec Nordiques. The winning goal was scored by Murray Craven with 4 minutes 49 seconds remaining.

title: CANNON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the Nicaraguan poet Ruben Dario gave an incorrect location for the National Theater named for him. It is in Managua.

title: Fire Disrupts Flushing Line
description: Service between the last two stops of the No. 7 subway line in Flushing, Queens, was halted for 45 minutes yesterday when a smoky fire broke out in underground power cables near Roosevelt Avenue and Main Street. The fire, which started shortly after noon and was brought under control two hours later, spread smoke into the Main Street subway station, forcing its evacuation at 1 P.M. and disrupting service between it and the next stop west, the Willets Point-Shea Stadium station, until 1:45 P.M.

title: 3 Syrians Convicted of Spying For the Israelis Are Hanged
description: Three Syrians convicted of spying for Israel were hanged at dawn today.

title: Grant and Graffiti
description: At the same time the state is closing the Ulysses S. Grant house in northern Saratoga County, Grant's Tomb has received a face lift, in readiness for the July 23 centennial of his death.

title: LINCOLN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $3,865,000. c-Net loss after a capital loss of $1,604.

title: RETAIL SALES IN APRIL UP BY 0.9%
description: Retail sales climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department said today. The report was greeted by the Reagan Administration and some economists as an encouraging sign that the economy is reviving after a sluggish first quarter.

title: Refrigerators And the Homeless
description: Nothing is simple at the Martinique Hotel, even when everyone agrees on something as basic as the need for refrigerators.

title: FORMER AIDE TO CAREY DENIES ARRANGING FOR LEASE BY STATE
description: A former state official testified yesterday that he had no part in arranging a multimillion-dollar state lease for a New York City landlord.

title: DOW DOWN 4.20 IN HEAVIER TRADING
description: After a three-day rally, the stock market took time off yesterday for some profit taking, with blue-chip and technology issues the sellers' favorites.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said year-ago share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 11.

title: Nuggets Wallop Lakers by 136-114
description: Alex English scored 40 points tonight as the Denver Nuggets routed the Los Angeles Lakers, 136-114, and evened their Western Conference championship playoff at one victory apiece. The Lakers, who had their home winning streak snapped after 24 victories, were plagued by turnovers and poor shooting throughout.

title: CONGRESS GETS BILLS TO RAISE ECONOMIC STATUS OF WOMEN
description: A bipartisan group of lawmakers today introduced legislation designed to enhance the economic status of women.

title: BERRA, MATTINGLY FINED FOR CONDUCT
description: Dale Berra and Don Mattingly were fined $1,000 apiece by the Yankees yesterday after having been arrested last week in separate incidents in Kansas City that involved indecent conduct in public.

title: THE 92 GROUP: MODERATE REPUBLICANS LAY PLANS
description: Probably the last thing Capitol Hill needs is one more group, or caucus, or coalition. But in a crowded field, the 92 Group is already gaining some visibility and recognition.

title: CITY LANDLORDS LOBBY FOR END TO RENT LIMITS
description: More than a thousand New York City landlords descended on the State Capitol today, rallying, marching and protesting against rent regulations.

title: THREE HOMERS IN FOURTH HELP ROYALS BEAT ORIOLES
description: Frank White, George Brett and Jim Sundberg blasted home runs in the fourth inning tonight to power the Kansas City Royals to a 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Beirut Gunmen Seize A U.N. Relief Official
description: An official of the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees in Lebanon was kidnapped today in West Beirut, an agency spokesman said.

title: G.E. Credit, Tiffany in Deal
description: Tiffany & Company, the New York jeweler, said yesterday that it had reached a major financing agreement with the General Electric Credit Corporation.

title: American General
description: The American General Corporation, a Houston-based financial services holding company, is offering $300 million of 6 7/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures in the Eurobond market at a price of par through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. The convertible subordinated debentures due 2000 may be converted into American General common stock at a price of $40.50 a share. American General common stock closed yesterday on the Big Board at $33 a share.

title: Report Is Inconclusive On Fatal Train Crash
description: A Federal safety panel reported today that it was unable to identify who was responsible for the head-on collision of two Amtrak trains in New York City last year that killed one person and injured 140 others.

title: KOCH PROPOSES NEW ZONING FOR APARTMENTS
description: The Koch administration proposed a package of zoning changes yesterday intended to make it easier and less costly for developers to build apartment houses citywide.

title: Icahn Increases T.W.A. Stake
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, has increased his stake in Trans World Airlines to 7,560,400 common shares, or 23 percent of the airline's shares outstanding, from 20 percent, he said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Oilers Romp, 10-5; Lead, 3-2
description: Edmonton's record-shattering trio of Wayne Gretzky, Jari Kurri and Paul Coffey combined for 15 points tonight in a 10-5 rout of the Chicago Black Hawks. The victory gave Edmonton a three-games-to-two lead in the Campbell Conference final.

title: Market Place;   Mobile Home Stock Woes
description: MOBILE home stocks have occasionally contended with negatives ranging from swollen dealer inventories to high interest rates. More recently, the group has felt the effect of a Veterans Administration investigation of possible ''invoice padding,'' according to Wall Street analysts.

title: AS CUOMO'S CHIEF ADVISER, DEL GIUDICE WIELDS POWER FROM OUTSIDE SPOTLIGHT
description: Every weekday morning at about 7:15, Michael J. Del Giudice gets what he describes as ''my wake-up call.''

title: MAN WHO KILLED CLERK PUT TO DEATH IN TEXAS
description: Jesse de la Rosa, who was convicted of murdering a convenience store clerk in a robbery in 1979 that netted only a six-pack of beer, was executed by injection early today.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Impressive in Drill
description: Despite the absence of three defenders and a key forward, things have been going relatively well for the World Cup soccer team of the United States, which plays a qualifying match against Trinidad-Tobago Wednesday night at Busch Stadium here.

title: AFTER THE INFERNO, TEARS AND BEWILDERMENT
description: Two women and three children were sitting on a cot, clinging to one another in the Red Cross emergency shelter. Their cries of anguish filled the room. The once-tidy row houses on Osage Avenue, where the family had lived, were nothing but rubble and wisps of smoke.

title: CONCERT: COPLAND MUSIC
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonic's Meet the Moderns concert at Cooper Union Friday night presented music by, for and about Aaron Copland. Two of the six pieces were by the American composer; others had been commissioned in his honor by the ASCAP Foundation and Meet the Composer.

title: Ratings Raised On G.M. Units
description: The debt rating affecting $25 billion of securities of the General Motors Corporation and its General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the GMAC Overseas Acceptance Corporation subsidiaries has been raised, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
THE BATTLE ON STEEL IMPORTS
description: In the face of the Reagan Administration's commitment to roll back foreign penetration of the American steel market, imports have continued to rise, prompting Congress and the industry to voice fresh concern.

title: Christian Democrats No. 1 With Italian Voters
description: The Christian Democrats have re-emerged as Italy's No. 1 vote-getters, overtaking the Communists in the capital and chipping away at the big-city power bases of the West's largest Marxist party.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: T HE notion that women should ''take it easy'' for most or all of the nine months of pregnancy is now widely recognized to be a medical myth, and impractical besides. But how much activity, and which activity, is safe for both mother and unborn child?

title: Goetz Attorneys Seek Voiding of Indictment
description: The attorneys for Bernhard H. Goetz, contending that a judge exceeded his authority when he authorized a second grand jury to consider charges in Mr. Goetz's shooting of four men on a subway, asked a state appeals court yesterday to bar their client's prosecution for attempted murder.

title: Knotty Job for Vterinarian
description: Some veterinarians may think they have seen everything, but Ray S. Youmans can top most - he had to untangle a half-dozen young squirrels that got their tails in a knot. ''I never saw anything so weird in my life,'' said Carol Robbins, who spotted the animals in a backyard tree here and took them to Dr. Youmans in Brunswick. The doctor said the 6-week-old animals might have got pine pitch on their tails.

title: MET GIVEN $1 MILLION FOR ARMOR
description: The arms and armor department of the Metropolitan Museum - best known for its wide hallway filled with heraldic banners, suits of armor and jousting knights on horseback - announced yesterday that Dr. Armand Hammer had given it $1 million to begin a fund-raising effort aimed at renovating the galleries.

title: CRADDOCK-TERRY SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After a loss of $650,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,146,000 for the quarter and $1,092,000 for the 6 months.

title: CELTIC RALLY OVERCOMES 76ERS
description: Julius Erving did not need many words to explain the Philadelphia 76ers' plight tonight. Emerging from the shower, the 76ers' usually talkative elder statesman said: ''I have but one statement to make. The Philadelphia 76ers didn't show up in the third quarter and it takes four to win a game.''

title: 3 GROUPS SAY U.S. DISTORTS ITS REPORTS ON RIGHTS SITUATION
description: The State Department continues to paint a ''rosy portrait'' of human rights conditions in some friendly countries and an ''unrealistically grim portrait'' of practices of regimes opposed by the United States, three human rights groups said yesterday.

title: Nebraska Finance Mortgage Bonds
description: The Nebraska Investment Finance Agency yesterday offered $100 million of single family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: Kitchen View
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said its Atlanta International Insurance Co. subsidiary would cease underwriting.

title: Tax-Preparer Rule Stricter
description: Intensifying the Internal Revenue Service's campaign against ''abusive'' tax shelters, Commissioner Roscoe L. Egger Jr. said today that individual tax preparers would be held responsible for clients' tax returns that contain credits from questionable tax shelter schemes.

title: PANEL CONDEMNS REAGAN ORDERS TO IGNORE CONTRACT REVIEW
description: By a bipartisan voice vote, the House Government Operations Committee today condemned as a violation of the Constitution what it called the Reagan Administration's ''suspension'' of a provision of a Federal contracting law.

title: MADRID ADMITS AN INTELLIGENCE AGENCY SPIED ON OPPOSITION PARTIES
description: Spanish officials have acknowledged that a Government intelligence agency has infiltrated opposition political parties.

title: EARL C. BEHRENS
description: Earl C. Behrens, political editor of The San Francisco Chronicle for more than 50 years, died Monday at Veterans Hospital. He was 93 years old.

title: COMMEMORATING LEWISOHN STADIUM
description: The rededication of Lewisohn Plaza at City College turned out to be a family reunion yesterday as the distinguished descendants of Adolph Lewisohn, the philanthropist, gathered for lunch and reminiscences.

title: NEW-LOOK PALLADIUM REOPENS
description: DESPITE the threat of legal action, two openings, not one, took place at the new Palladium discotheque on East 14th Street last night. Hundreds showed up for an 8:30 P.M. ''preview'' of the nightclub. At least 3,000 more were expected for what was billed as the ''premiere'' at 11.

title: TELERATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PENTAGON BUYING: NEED FOR BUSINESSLIKE BUSINESS
description: The Pentagon says it is beginning to act more like a private business as it spends record sums to buy goods and services.

title: COURT UPHOLDS RULE ON SEX HARASSMENT SUITS
description: The Federal appeals court here today let stand a three-judge panel's decision making it easier for workers complaining of sexual harassment to win lawsuits against supervisors and employers.

title: BOMB WAS NOT INCENDIARY
description: The bomb the police dropped Monday night on the house of an armed radical group in Philadelphia was an explosive device made by the city bomb squad, Philadelphia officials said today.

title: Are Our Supercarriers Too Big for Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: MOYNIHAN OPPOSES CRITICISM OF BOOK LIST
description: The dispute over the American books selected for the Moscow International Book Fair in September moved into the United States Senate yesterday with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan demanding that the chairman of the National Endowment for Democracy apologize to the committee of American publishers for saying the list was ideologically unbalanced.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a realized investment gain of $22,289,000. c-Includes a realized investment gain of $21,446,000.

title: ROCKWOOD HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Koch and Cultural Pursuits
description: Mayor Koch may have been around bureaucrats too long.

title: 3 PRINCETON EATING CLUBS FAULTED IN REVERSAL OF RULING ON SEX BIAS
description: The three all-male eating clubs at Princeton University violated state laws by discriminating against women, and the university abetted the discrimination, the State Division of Civil Rights ruled today.

title: Super in Name
description: The Miami Dolphins' wide receiver Mark Duper has been known as ''Super Duper'' since his high school days in Louisiana.

title: GAINS REPORTED ON USE OF LASER FOR SPACE ARMS
description: What appears to be an important advance in developing an X-ray laser space weapon powered by a nuclear bomb has been made by scientists at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Federal scientists said yesterday.

title: BOROUGHS ASKING FOR BIGGER SLICES OF BUDGET
description: The Bronx asked for more yesterday.

title: RB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $467,000 for the quarter and $1,275,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary gain of $251,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income including equity in an unconsolidated affiliate of $107,000 for the quarter and $302,000 for the 9 months.

title: PHILLIPS IS PUTTING MORE ASSETS UP FOR SALE
description: Continuing its attempt to pare the huge debt accumulated in two bruising takeover battles within the last year, the Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it would sell several of its less valuable assets and offer early retirement to 10 percent of its United States work force.

title: ONCE GARBED IN ORANGE
description: I went out to buy slacks and came back with a jacket instead. I didn't really need a new jacket. I needed slacks, and now that I have a jacket I don't need, I still need slacks.

title: Hanoi Rushes Weapons To Cambodian Border
description: Vietnamese troops have rushed Soviet-built tanks and heavy artillery to the Thai-Cambodian border to support their sustained intrusion into southeastern Thailand, military officials said today.

title: TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $114,000 for the latest quarter and $69,000 for year- earlier period. The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend in December 1984.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain from deferred income taxes that were reduced by $557,000 as a result of tax legislation regulating DISCS.

title: JEAN DUBUFFET, PAINTER AND SCULPTOR, IS DEAD
description: Jean Dubuffet, widely regarded as the most important artist to emerge from France at the end of World War II, a master of French prose and the recipient in recent years of large-scale sculptural commissions the world over, died of emphysema in Paris on Sunday. He was 83 years old.

title: KOCH REJECTS BOMBING TACTIC
description: Mayor Koch, reacting yesterday to the use of explosives to end a siege at the headquarters of a radical group in Philadelphia, criticized the Philadelphia police for bombing the house.

title: CHIEF IS REPLACED BY GENERAL NUTRITION
description: Gary A. Daum, president and chief executive officer of General Nutrition Inc., a health food and vitamin retailer that has been having legal problems, said yesterday that he had been dismissed.

title: Sipe to Start Sunday
description: Brian Sipe, the Jacksonville Bull quarterback who was knocked out of the lineup with a separated shoulder in the season opener, looked sharp enough in his return against Tampa Bay Sunday to reclaim the starting quarterback position against the Houston Gamblers next Monday. ''Brian never lost his job,'' said the Bulls' coach, Lindy Infante, who had started Ed Luther.

title: BALLET THEATER: REVIVAL OF TUDOR'S 'DIM LUSTRE'
description: ONE of the most eagerly awaited revivals of the American Ballet Theater season has been Antony Tudor's ''Dim Lustre.'' Created by the English-born choreographer for the company in 1943, the ballet returned to the company for the first time in 29 years Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Nike Benefits By Campaign
description: When Blue Ribbon Sports of Beaverton, Ore., marketer of the Nike sport shoe, went to Chiat/Day in Los Angeles a year and a half ago for a corporate ad campaign, it knew it would be getting some great creative work. Jay Chiat's shop already had that reputation, enhanced no doubt by the great advertising it was turning out for Apple computer.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section on April 24 about the growing popularity of rowing gave an incorrect address for the Empire State Rowing Association. The correct address is c/o Karekin Arzoomanian, 250 West 57th Street, Suite 1825, New York, N.Y. 10107.

title: HEALTH CARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PT COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SCIENTIFIC SYSTEMS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: OPTELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Great Aspirations
description: The most famous product of the city of Liverpool besides the Beatles is its soccer team. The Red Devils have dominated English soccer for the last decade and are in the final of the European Cup this month for the fifth time in nine years.

title: Lockheed's Chief Plans to Retire
description: Roy A. Anderson, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Lockheed Corporation, yesterday confirmed his intention to retire from the big aerospace company at the end of the year. Analysts said his successor would likely be Lawrence O. Kitchen, the company's president.

title: MCDOWELL DAZZLES IN RELIEF
description: The Atlanta Braves scored another run tonight, their second in a week, but this time it wasn't enough because the Mets scored three off Rick Mahler and beat the Braves, 3-1.

title: HINES, EDWARD LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $715,000 for the latest first quarter and $570,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: EQUAL RESTRAINTS ON PROSECUTION AND DEFENSE ARE INAPPROPRIATE
description: To the Editor:

title: WORKED FOR U.S. IN MIDEAST
description: Cornelius Van Hemert Engert, a retired diplomat who was one of the State Department's foremost experts on Middle Eastern affairs, died of pneumonia Sunday at the Washington home of his son. He was 97 years old and had been living in Washington.

title: GRIFFEY SLAM IN 7TH WINS
description: Their pitching had deserted them once again, so had their baserunning. But the Yankees seem able to overcome anything these days.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 15, 1985

title: SHULTZ, IN VIENNA, TALKS TO GROMYKO
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko agreed today to strengthen the framework of Soviet-American relations, even though sharp disagreements remain on arms control and international issues like Central America.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Equal Restraints on Prosecution and Defense Are Inappropriate
description: To the Editor:

title: President Is Named At Mars Consulting
description: John L. Lesher, a veteran management consultant and the president and chief operating officer of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc., will leave the firm to become president of Mars & Company Consulting Inc., effective next Monday.

title: All the Tea in China: Price Soars by 400%
description: The price of tea in China has soared up to 400 percent this year because an abnormally cold and rainy spring seriously cut production, the Government reported today.

title: BASIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income which includes an extraordinary gain of $3,500,000.

title: FEDERAL FARM CREDIT BANKS FUNDING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest quarter reflect a provision of $70,300,000 for loan losses and net loan losses of $42,000,000. Results for the year-ago quarter reflect a provison of $21,000,000 for loan losses and net loan losses of $16,000,000.

title: Balloon Day
description: As 500 helium-filled balloons are launched from a school playground in Southeast Washington early this afternoon, 4,500 more will rise simultaneously from the hands of schoolchildren in nine other communities from Pittsburgh to Minneapolis to Seattle as part of an educational weather experiment and an observance of National Science Week. Each balloon will carry a bright orange card, with the top filled out by the launcher and the bottom to be completed by the finder and mailed to the American Geological Institute in Alexandria, Va. Then the institute will map the course of all recovered balloons for which touchdown reports are received for all the participating schools, showing how weather patterns distributed the multiple launching in different ways in different parts of the country.

title: MARYLAND LIMITS ALL WITHDRAWALS FROM THRIFT UNITS
description: Gov. Harry R. Hughes, invoking emergency powers, tonight ordered the 102 privately insured savings and loan institutions in Maryland to limit depositors' withdrawals to $1,000 a month.

title: MANNY'S MUSIC STORE TURNS 50
description: Not all of the 5,000 musicians whose photographs line the walls of Manny's showed up. But 500 or so of them -some packing their axes (guitars) and synths (synthesizers) - arpeggiated over to the Rainbow Grill atop the RCA Building for the occasion.

title: Consumer Debt Rise Is Slowed
description: Outstanding consumer installment credit increased by $8.34 billion in March, seasonally adjusted, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $67,682 for the latest first quarter and $107,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: WIESENTHAL LISTS MENGELE SIGHTINGS
description: Simon Wiesenthal, the Nazi-hunter, says that Josef Mengele, the German death camp doctor, was sighted in Paraguay as late as last July.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
REAGAN VISIT FIERCELY DEBATED IN BONN
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought today to fend off criticism of his handling of President Reagan's recent visit, contending that it ''further strengthened the relationship between both nations that has emerged over many years.''

title: SCHIELE OIL PAINTING SOLD AT AUCTION OF MODERN ART
description: Egon Schiele's 1917 oil painting ''Summer Landscape'' brought the highest price of Sotheby's auction of 119 Modern and Impressionist art works last night. It was one of the few major successes of a sale in which 53 of the 119 offerings did not find buyers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Englehard Corp., Edison, N.J., which manufactures specialty chemical and metallurgical products, elected to its board Marion H. Antonini, a group vice president at Xerox Corp.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ZUCKERMAN BOUND. A Trilogy and Epilogue. By Philip Roth. 784 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $22.50. I N bringing together in one volume his last three novels (''The Ghost Writer,'' ''Zuckerman Unbound'' and ''The Anatomy Lesson'') and a new comic novella, titled ''The Prague Orgy,'' Philip Roth has presumably completed the saga of his fictional hero, Nathan Zuckerman. It is the story of how an earnest young student of literature grows up, writes a scandalous best seller and experiences the debilitating effects of fame. And it is also a story about the unforeseen consequences of art, the strange, predatory relationship that exists between literature and life, and an American writer's anomalous sense of vocation.

title: Sharon Offer Assailed
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation is being criticized by a debenture holder for threatening in a mailing to file for bankruptcy unless 80 percent of the holders accept a securities swap. Martin Horwitz, who owns $2.4 million of Sharon's $330 million in 13.5 percent debentures, called it ''unfair'' that the plan provides that Victor Posner, Sharon's controlling stockholder, retain his 70 million shares of stock, while interest paid to bondholders would be cut to $46.50 a year, from $135, per $1,000 bond.

title: SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $193,000.

title: ALAMO SAVINGS ASSOCIATION OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOLDSMITH INCREASES CROWN STAKE
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier who has battled with the management of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, said late yesterday that he had increased his holdings to slightly more than 20 percent of Crown, thereby placing into effect the company's anti-takeover provisions.

title: DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Informatics Vote
description: The Informatics General Corporation said a preliminary count of votes submitted at the annual meeting showed that shareholders had rejected its two anti-takeover proposals. The software company said shareholders did re-elect the two directors nominated by the company. Informatics has been engaged in a proxy contest with Sterling Software Inc., a Dallas-based company that owns 9.3 percent of Informatics' stock.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $241,573 from discontinued operations.

title: STAGE: ELLEN BARKIN IN 'EDEN COURT'
description: IF it really were possible to give the kiss of life to a corpse, the actress Ellen Barkin would be the one to do it. In ''Eden Court,'' the moribund play that has brought her to the Promenade Theater, Miss Barkin is tantalizingly alive from her bouncing blond ponytail to the long legs that gyrate wildly and involuntarily every time an Elvis Presley record plays on stage. Then there is that gleaming, empathic face. If one of Miss Barkin's fellow actors is crying, her brow weeps along with the sufferer. Let someone else laugh, and her eyes dance upward in joy like the tiniest and lightest of balloons. Better still is Miss Barkin's own, mellifluously deep-seated laughter, which may be even more musical than Elvis's golden oldies.

title: ADOBE OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TAFT BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PAULA HUGHES, 53, SECURITIES BROKER
description: Paula D. Hughes, first vice president and director of Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc., died of lung cancer Monday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 53 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SHIITE IN BEIRUT LINKS BOMBING TO U.S. AND ISRAEL
description: A Shiite religious leader who was apparently the target of a car bombing here last March said today that he had information that the bombing was the work of American, Israeli and Lebanese intelligence agencies.

description: b-Earnings per share for Unilever NV c-Earnings per share for Unilever PLC All figures are in U.S. dollars.

title: PHILS ROUT REDS, 7-1; END SKID AT SEVEN
description: Juan Samuel and Mike Schmidt belted home runs to support a three-hitter by Charles Hudson and Don Carman as the Philadelphia Phillies ended a seven-game losing streak with a 7-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

title: CHURCH TEACHINGS ON SEX WON'T CHANGE, POPE TELLS DUTCH YOUTHS
description: Pope John Paul II, who has been trailed by young protesters in his four days in this country, responded today to what he called ''blunt criticisms'' by rejecting calls for changes in Roman Catholic sexual rules.

title: BASF GETS INMONT FOR $1 BILLION
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its Inmont Corporation to BASF A.G., the big West German chemical company, for $1 billion in cash.

title: Son of Coast Police Chief Held in Armed Robbery
description: The son of the Los Angeles Chief of Police has been arrested for the armed robbery of narcotics from a suburban drug store, the authorities say.

title: WARNER AMEX SAYS IT HAS RECEIVED OFFERS
description: After weeks of rumors, Warner Amex Cable Communications confirmed yesterday that it had received several proposals to purchase ''all or part'' of its operations, including its share of MTV Networks Inc.

title: OFFICIAL SAYS U.S. LEADS IN ARMS TECHNOLOGY
description: The Administration's top official on developing space-based defenses said today that the United States ''is ahead and continuing to move ahead'' of the Soviet Union in defense technology.

title: UNIVERSAL DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR MOSES, AN UNLUCKY OUTDOOR START
description: Edwin Moses, the world-record holder and Olympic champion in the 400-meter hurdles, was scheduled to open his outdoor season last Sunday in Sao Paulo, Brazil. He did, sort of.

title: U.S. MOVES TO AID MARYLAND THRIFT UNIONS
description: Federal regulators mobilized an all-out effort today to make Federal deposit insurance available as soon as possible to Maryland's 102 privately insured thrift institutions.

title: BELDEN & BLAKE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRITAIN'S NEW GENERATION OF CHEFS COMES OF AGE
description: THE culinary groundswell that began in Britain a decade ago with a handful of excellent restaurants has now entered a second and broader phase. The first establishments, among them Le Gavroche and the Dorchester Hotel, both in London, are run by chefs from the Continent, but many more recent restaurants are staffed with home-grown talent and are spread around the countryside. Young chefs such as Nicholas Gill, Allan Garth and John Webber, who are English, and Raymond Blanc, who is French-born, have carried the message of fresh, creative cuisine to the counties too. Nowadays, Leicestershire, Oxfordshire, West Sussex and Devon, among others, can claim excellent restaurants of their own. Britain now has 2 restaurants with three Michelin stars, 4 with two stars and 24 with one star.

title: URGENT CARE SYSTEMS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains on the disposition of rental properties and mortgages of $1,309,000, or $1.10 a share for the quarter and $1,495,000, or $1.26 a share for the 6 months. c-Includes gains on the disposition of rental properties and mortgages of $48,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,000 for the 6 months. Results include Gould Investors proportionate interest in BRT Realty Trust.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $5,123,000. c-Net loss which is after income of $230,000 from discontinued operations. The company said revenues for the latest quarter include $37,900,000 from the sale of Tampa Palms, Fla., property.

title: 3 Sign With Giants
description: Greg Hill, a University of Maryland wide receiver who led the Atlantic Coast Conference in receiving last year with 820 yards on 51 catches, signed with the Giants, along with two other free agents. They were Victor James, a former wide receiver at Colorado who played for Chicago and Denver in the United States Football League, and Phil Mack, a defensive tackle from Lamar University.

title: Israeli Labor Bloc Wins 67.3% in Union Vote
description: The Labor alignment won 67.3 percent of the votes in trade union elections Monday, according to provisional results published here today.

title: PARENTS STAGE A SIT-IN OVER SCHOOL TRANSFER PLAN
description: More than 50 Brooklyn parents occupied their local school superintendent's office yesterday to protest a plan to convert a neighborhood elementary school to a magnet school for exceptionally bright pupils and transfer their children to other schools.

title: Olajuwon's Debut
description: From the perspective of ordinary mortals, he does look a bit like something from outer space, so it should come as no surprise that Akeem Olajuwon, the 7-foot center for the Houston Rockets, has won a part in a science-fiction movie. For all his dominating presence, however, the part in the movie ''Kill-Bots'' will be a small one, as a security guard at a robot factory, and Olajuwon, who makes more than $1 million a year playing basketball, will be doing it mostly for fun.

title: ROCKY MOUNT UNDERGARMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOOD NOTES
description: Lebanese Specialties Two Lebanese doctors in their 30's may seem to be an unlikely partnership for a takeout food shop. But at Bennies, the match has produced a fine combination of the familiar and the rare. While Bennies, at 321 Amsterdam Avenue (75th Street) and in Greenwich Village at 37 Seventh Avenue (13th Street), has the usual curried chicken and pasta salads, the menu also includes Lebanese favorites such as smoky chicken, a salad of cold chicken, potatoes and avocado flavored with the lemony tang of sumac ($4.50 - all prices are for a half-pound); mudadarar, a savory mixture of lentils and rice garnished with browned onions ($2.95); burghul, or cracked wheat, simmered in a tomato-onion sauce ($2.95), and a well-seasoned mixture of vegetables such as eggplant, zucchini and tomatoes, baked in olive oil, that recalls ratatouille ($3.75). Dr. Bennie Hamadi, one of the partners, calls the dish ''vegetables Roberta'' after his grandmother, who used to make it in her mountain village.

title: Ali in China
description: Muhammad Ali, visiting Peking at the invitation of the Chinese Government, put on the Ali shuffle and jabbed his way through five one-minute rounds in a makeshift ring yesterday before about 500 students at the Peking Physical Education Institute. Ali, 43 years old, did not seem affected by his Parkinson's Syndrome, but one boxer said: ''The coaches told us only to hit him in the stomach. We were warned he is not in good health.''

title: A RAMBLE ON THE NONCAMPAIGN TRAIL WITH KOCH
description: On a day when the mayoral candidate Carol Bellamy was trying to attract some attention to her budgetary concerns, and the other main challenger, Denny Farrell, was talking up banking reform, Mayor Koch opened off Broadway.

title: Japan Alters the Way It Fingerprints Aliens
description: The Government today modified its rules for the mandatory fingerprinting of resident aliens, but the attempt to calm protests drew criticism from foreigners and their Japanese sympathizers.

title: Northrop Fighter Crashes
description: The Northrop Corporation said that an F-20 Tigershark jet fighter crashed today, killing the pilot, during a flight over Goose Bay, Labrador. The plane was in a practice run before the Paris Air Show, which opens May 30.

title: Whither Ellingwood?
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and Herbert E. Ellingwood, chairman of the Merit Systems Protection Board, were classmates at Yale in the early 1950's, deputy district attorneys together in Alameda County, Calif., from 1960 to 1966, legal aides to Gov. Ronald Reagan in Sacramento together from 1969 to 1974 and counselor and deputy counsel to President Reagan in the White House in his first term.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL SEATTLE (AL) - Optioned Harold Reynolds, second baseman, to Calgary of Pacific Coast League and recalled Darnell Coles, third baseman, from Calgary.

L E MYERS CO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LAKER TRUST SUIT DEAL IS EXPECTED BY MONDAY
description: British Airways and the other 11 defendants in an antitrust suit filed by the liquidator of Laker Airways are optimistic that they will have an out-of-court settlement ready by Monday to present to a United States judge in Washington, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: ESSELTE BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $484,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $455,000.

title: GAMBLING INQUIRY GROWS IN MEMPHIS
description: A Federal grand jury here is investigating possible ties between gambling at an exclusive country club and the Memphis State University basketball program, and is reportedly making inquiries into a late-season Tiger loss to Detroit and the loss to Villanova in the Final Four.

title: SEARCH FOR BODIES, AND FOR REASON, IN SMOKY RUINS
description: In the smoky mist of a smoldering neighborhood, firefighters searched today through mounds of charred rubble at the ruined headquarters of a mysterious, militant organization that has been a source of controversy here for more than a decade.

title: New Polaroid Film
description: The Polaroid Corporation said it planned to introduce in the next year a new instant color film, which it said would provide sharper and brighter photos with a wide range of color and better color fidelity. A spokesman said the film, still under development, had not yet been named. The film employs a combination of Polaroid dye developer and new imaging chemistry, with a new dye and film structure, Polaroid said.

title: PARALLELS: 1783 AND 1985
description: What the United States is doing to Nicaragua, England did to the United States after the Revolutionary War.

title: Age Is Relevant
description: Monday night postscript, Part 1:

title: Stonewalling the Disabled
description: By late last year the Reagan Administration's war on the disabled had become a national embarrassment, and Congress passed a reform bill prohibiting further abuse. The new law was silent, however, on a crucial part of the Administration offensive: ''nonacquiescence'' with rulings of the Federal courts. Now the conclusions of a Federal magistrate are likely to neutralize this weapon too. The real question is why the Administration continues to struggle against decency.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the year-ago quarter include a gain of $15,700,000 from the investment in Houston Natural Gas Corp.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Opener of a three-game series. The Rangers took the first two of three games in Texas in Billy Martin's first series in his fourth stint as Yankee manager. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.). Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. Opener of two-game series. Dwight Gooden, who beat the Astros at Shea Stadium last month, goes for his sixth victory. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Dennis Cruz vs. Dwight Pratchet, 12 rounds for Cruz's North American Boxing Federation superfeatherweight title, at Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8 P.M. This is the first defense for Cruz, who is from the Bronx, since he captured the title from Guy Villegas last Dec. 7. He is 20-1 with 17 knockouts. Pratchet, from Gary, Ind., has a 12-6 record with 5 knockouts. Soccer United States vs. Trinidad-Tobago, at St. Louis, World Cup Concacaf Region qualifying round-robin game. The United States is in the group with Costa Rica and Trinidad-Tobago. This is the first game for the United States in the round robin. Several former Cosmos are on the United States team, including Rick Davis, Angelo DiBernardo, Jeff Durgan and the goalie David Brcic. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M., live. Channel 41, 10:30 P.M., tape, the SINcommentary will be in Spanish, the ESPN commentary in English.) Other Events HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. The New Jersey Sires Stakes, a pace for 3-year-old fillies, is the feature.

title: Union Resolution Loses at Pan Am
description: Employees failed in their bid at the Pan Am Corporation's annual meeting to put as many as five union-nominated representatives on the board of directors and to authorize granting additional stock to workers.

title: MESOPOTAMIA: CRADLE OF HAUTE CUISINE?
description: IMAGINE a cuisine offering a hundred styles of soup and 18 kinds of cheese. A place where 300 types of bread are made with different flours, spices or fruit fillings and can be ordered in special shapes ranging from a heart to a woman's breast. A place where trufflelike fungi are harvested for the table and pickled grasshoppers are served for snacks.

INVACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: The Cavendish Club team event that began in New York Monday night is probably the strongest Swiss team contest ever held. About three-quarters of the contestants have won major national or international titles, and most of the others are rising stars who can be expected to do so in the future.

description: The two top officers of the United States Navy salvage ship Recovery have been temporarily relieved of command after the recovery of nine Soviet-made automatic weapons said to have been taken from Grenada, the Navy said today.
