title: Economic Scene;   Scrutinizing Bonn Outcome
description: LESS than two weeks ago President Reagan joined the leaders of the world's six other industrial democracies in Bonn to tackle the problems of an uncertain world economy. As the dust settles over their declarations, the Bonn summit conference, like its 10 predecessors, may fade into the oblivion of economic history, to become just another reference point for next year's meeting, to be held in Tokyo.

title: POP LIFE
description: SEVERAL of the performers who traveled the Southern ''chitlin circuit'' in the 1960's, riding in tour buses and Cadillacs from town to town to play in clubs and auditoriums, were regal presences. Bobby (Blue) Bland's seemingly effortless command of the most sensual blues inflections made him a perennial headliner; Solomon Burke would appear in a kingly crown and scarlet cape, and project his imposing voice until the rafters rang. But there was never any real doubt that of all these performers, Sam Cooke was the true aristocrat.

title: HOW FIXED-PRICE CONTRACT GREW: $104 MILLION MISSILE COST TRIPLED
description: Ompal S. Chauhan, an Air Force official, told Congress last month that ''numerous changes'' on a fixed-price, $104 million contract with the Hughes Aircraft Company for Maverick air-to-ground missiles had resulted in a total contract price of $341 million.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CAPITAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Topics;   Epilogues
description: Credit for Loyalty When Roger Jepsen of Iowa lost his bid for re-election to the Senate last year, he said, ''As for me, the good Lord has something better . . . and it's time to get on with it.'' That turned out to be a job arranged by the Reagan Administration.

title: DEMOCRATS REACH ACCORD ON BUDGET
description: Democrats on the House Budget Committee agreed today on a 1986 budget that would save $56 billion and allow no increase in the military budget, its chairman, William H. Gray 3d, said tonight.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BLACK IS MOURNED
description: With the army and the police standing guard, more than 25,000 blacks attended the funeral today of a union leader who died after being in police custody.

title: EASED TAX PLAN ASKED FOR HOUSING
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, today urged President Reagan to modify parts of the Treasury's tax revision proposal to soften the impact on rental housing.

title: Article 240040 -- No Title
description: ''When you grow up in Newark with a name like Herbert, you better be ready to fight,'' Herbert Stanley Hodge was saying today at Pimlico Race Course. ''So I became Hodgey, and that became Hajji because of that Nat King Cole song, 'Hajji Baba.' Everyone of my horses has 'Hajji' in his name.''

title: PBS OFFERS DOCUMENTARY ON THE LIFE OF MELVILLE
description: EDUCATIONAL television is a term that has a somewhat repellent aura about it, conjuring up an image of pedants preaching to millions instead of the more limited classroom audiences to which they are usually restricted. Yet educating (one dare not use the elitist word ''uplifting'') audiences is one of the great contributions envisioned by those who saw in television a tool to broaden the horizons of the masses.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 8, 1985 The Economy Maryland's Governor ordered limits on depositor withdrawals at the state's 102 privately insured thrift institutions. The limits, of $1,000 a month, are intended to stem a run on deposits that began last week at Maryland's second-largest thrift institution. Governor Hughes, acting three months after a similar crisis in Ohio, said he would ask the legislature for the right to declare a full bank holiday if needed. [Page A1.] Federal regulators are undertaking an all-out effort to make Federal deposit insurance available to the Maryland institutions. [D19.] The crisis has focused renewed attention on private insurance of thrift institutions in the four states besides Ohio and Maryland that have such insurance. Retail sales climbed 0.9 percent in April. The decline in March was also less drastic than originally reported - 0.7 percent rather than 1.9 percent. The White House and some economists said the report indicated that the economy was reviving. [D1.] Sales of new American-made cars fell 8.6 percent in the first 10 days of May, compared with that period last year. That results were slightly below what most auto industry analysts had been expecting. [D13.] Consumer credit rose by $8.34 billion in March. [D13.] Aides gave President Reagan three tax alternatives for reducing the 50 percent top rate that applies to individuals, according to Administration officials. [D1.] The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development urged the President to soften the tax proposal's impact on rental housing.

title: BUSH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-No comparable year-ago revenue figure was given. The company completed its initial public offering on April 24.

title: NORLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the latest first quarter and $70,000 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: CBS Sues Ziff Over Report
description: CBS Inc., stepping up its dispute with the Ziff Corporation, yesterday sued the publisher in state court for reportedly making misstatements in a profit report before CBS acquired 12 magazines from Ziff last year.

title: KIN OF MURDER VICTIMS SEEK CHANGES IN LAWS
description: Seated at the kitchen table, Edwin Shelley flipped open his attache case and pulled out the standard ammunition of a lobbyist: lists of legislators, drafts of bills, abstracts of studies and letters typed on letterhead stationery.

title: Sparrow Breaks Toe
description: The pattern of injuries that plagued the Knicks during the regular season has continued into the offseason. Rory Sparrow, the playmaker, broke his right big toe Sunday in an accident at his home in Paterson, N.J. Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks' team doctor, will place the foot in a cast today at Lenox Hill Hospital, and it will remain in a cast for one month.

title: BIG BOARD ELECTION
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had elected four members to its 23-member board of directors. The new members are Barber B. Conable Jr., a former Republican Congressman from upstate New York and now a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington; Lee L. Morgan, former chairman of the Caterpillar Tractor Company; Richard R. Shinn, former chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and William A. Schreyer, chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $4,420,000 from termination of a pension plan. c-Net loss including income from discontinued operations of $229,000.

title: Some of the Oppressed The President Omitted
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Index Declines
description: A key index of the semiconductor industry's health stalled in April after a modest three-month rise, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today. The index, called the book-to-bill ratio, slipped last month to an estimated 0.77, from 0.80 in March, the trade group said.

title: IN SAUDI OASIS OF CALM, SOME SEE SEEDS OF UNREST
description: When Saudi officials are asked if their kingdom is stable, they answer that Saudi Arabia has little violent crime, no suicide bombers and a royal family close to the people.

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 MASKED MEN ROB A CARRIAGE IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A pair of masked gunmen held up two passengers in a horse-drawn carriage in Central Park early yesterday, the police said.

title: Carousel Day
description: Today is the day when one of Washington's most popular attractions opens its season. This one has nothing to do with the White House, cherry blossoms, the F.B.I., printing money or spacecraft.

title: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Dominates One Show
description: REFLECTING a rare display of creative commitment, the Chiat/Day main office in Los Angeles last night won five gold awards at the One Show with its work for a single client, Nike. The award was given for advertising in three different media - television, magazine and outdoor billboards.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 86 CIVILIANS KILLED IN SRI LANKA REBEL ATTACK
description: At least 86 civilians, including five Buddhist nuns, were killed today when Tamil guerrillas disguised as soldiers drove into the Sinhalese heartland and staged one of the most violent attacks of their separatist campaign, the Government said.

title: Here Comes William Lucas
description: The Republican Party is predictably unwilling to let the dramatic shift in political allegiance of a prominent black Democratic official be celebrated exclusively in his home city of Detroit.

title: CHEMIST TELLS OF HIGH INSULIN LEVELS ON VON BULOW SYRINGE
description: An expert in chemical analysis testified today that the level of insulin on a hypodermic needle ostensibly used to inject Martha von Bulow was so high - ''off the scale,'' he said - that the test had to be repeated.

title: A KARATE ADVENTURE, 'BLADE IN HONG KONG'
description: ALTHOUGH television is notoriously partial to action-adventure series, the medium has somehow been unable to exploit the distinctively cheap thrills that for years have been luring younger audiences to karate movies. The films of Bruce Lee must be among the biggest moneymakers of all time. The basic format is a model of simplicity. Set in some ''exotic'' locale, preferably Hong Kong, the throwaway story strings together a series of violent scenes featuring the heroes triumphing over bands of villains whose motives are never quite clear. They don't have to be. The action is all. It is not that television doesn't try to get a piece of this lucrative market. Tonight at 9 o'clock, for instance, CBS is offering ''Blade in Hong Kong,'' a TV movie that obviously, if invited, would hang around to become a weekly series. The blond, blue-eyed hero is Joe Blade, played by Terry Lester, a soap-opera star (''The Young and the Restless'') who looks the way Ricky Schroder may look when he grows up, if his luck holds.

title: Minstar-AMF
description: Minstar Inc., which is controlled by the investor Irwin L. Jacobs, said it intended to press forward to eliminate what it described as a ''poison pill'' and other measures adopted by AMF Inc. Mr. Jacobs, who has offered $23 a share for AMF's 12 million shares outstanding, said he hoped to have AMF's actions declared invalid. Minstar said that if it failed to eliminate the hostile AMF measures, it would not purchase shares under the tender offer.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: O VER the years, I have often been asked if serving two or more deep-fried foods at the same time would be considered bad menu planning. Invariably, my answer is no, not for home-style cooking, at least.

title: PRIVATE INSURANCE IN SPOTLIGHT
description: The Maryland thrift crisis has focused renewed attention on private insurance of thrift institutions.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CANNES SANS SUN OR HIT
description: With the sun having finally arrived and the Cannes Film Festival half over with no film declared a hit, the subject of most conversations on the steps of the Film Palace is how the jury will vote.

title: THE MOZZARELLA MAN MAKES HOUSE CALLS
description: ''THEY started calling me Mozzarella Joe,'' said Giuseppe Cuomo, as he began kneading fresh mozzarella cheese early one morning in the kitchen of Alo Alo, a new Italian restaurant at 61st Street and Third Avenue. Mr. Cuomo comes in twice a day, every day, to make mozzarella at Alo Alo and at the DDL Bistro in Trump Tower. His daily rounds also take him to La Colonna, Positano, Mezzaluna and several other restaurants around Manhattan.

title: Mountain Man Is Guilty Of Kidnapping Athlete
description: A young mountain man was convicted late Monday on charges of kidnapping and assaulting an athlete.

title: U.S. AIDES OPPOSE CAR FUEL CONSUMPTION GUIDES
description: Officials of the Reagan Administration today told a Senate panel that the Administration opposed legislating higher passenger car fuel conservation standards, saying such standards were no longer ''relevant'' to the nation's present energy situation.

title: ISSUERS DISRUPT TRADING IN MORTGAGE CERTIFICATES
description: Trading in $110 million of mortgage pass-through securities was disrupted yesterday, after the three major issuing agencies instructed their transfer agents not to complete trades until disputes surrounding the ownership of the securities have been settled.

title: CHANNEL 13 PURCHASES ITS BROADCASTING SPACE
description: WNET/Channel 13, the New York area's major public television station, has bought its nine-floor broadcasting facility in the former Henry Hudson Hotel building, John Jay Iselin, president of the station, announced yesterday.

title: SALE OF HUGHES AIRCRAFT MAY SPAWN FOUNDATION
description: Bids from prospective buyers of the Hughes Aircraft Company will be opened somewhere in New York City tomorrow morning in the presence of the trustees of the sole owner of the company, the Howard Hughes Medical Institute.

title: FISH FULL OF PENCILS, SIDE-OF-A-WRIST WATCH
description: 1. For Wishful Anglers Would the student in your household rather be fishing? A shop called Farfetched has an answer - a pencil holder shaped like a fish.

title: SENIOR PARTNER IN LAW FIRM
description: Grayson M-P. Murphy, for many years a partner in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, died of cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: New Trial for Man Freed In Rape Case Is Opposed
description: Prosecutors today filed a motion oppposing a new trial for Gary Dotson, who is seeking to prove himself innocent of raping a woman who now says the rape never occurred.

title: Pennsylvania
description: A $106 million issue of Pennsylvania general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 4.50 percent for bonds due in Dec. 1, 1985, to 6.80 percent in 1990, 7.80 percent in 1995, 8.60 percent in 2000 and 8.70 percent in 2004 through underwriters led by Citibank. The bonds are rated A by Moody's and A+ by S.&P.

title: Illinois Offer
description: Illinois yesterday offered $100 million of general obligation bonds in serial form with yields ranging from 5 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6 3/4 percent in 1990, 7 3/4 percent in 1995, 8.35 percent in 2000, 8.60 percent in 2005 and 8.70 percent in 2010 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch. The bonds are rated Aaa by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P.

title: LOCAL VOTING IN ULSTER HOLDS SEEKS OF CHANGE
description: A quiet struggle is going on that could affect the future of this province far more profoundly than the violence that is commonplace here.

title: Challenging Beef
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
S.B.S. Sees Profit
description: Satellite Business Systems, a venture of the International Business Machines Corporation and the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, could be profitable this year for the first time, said its chairman, Marvin Mann. He said S.B.S. would probably increase revenues 70 percent to 80 percent this year, from $290 million in 1984. S.B.S., a discount long-distance telephone company, was founded in 1975.

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DETECTIVES AND DRUGS
description: After one of the Yankees' games in Kansas City last weekend, several players gathered for dinner at Longbranch, a restaurant owned by Lou Piniella, the batting coach. Not far away, the players recognized three former Federal Bureau of Investigation agents hired by George Steinbrenner to check the travels of Yankee players - a deterrent, according to the principal owner, to the drug problem that has infected so many major league players. The three detectives had been sighted earlier that week by some Yankee players at a Minneapolis restaurant and in the club hotel there.

title: U.S.I.A. OFFICIAL IS NAMED
description: President Reagan announced the appointment today of Marvin Stone, a former editor of U.S. News & World Report, as deputy director of the United States Information Agency to succeed Leslie Lenkowsky.

title: Let's Try Constructive Engagement in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: WINE TALK
description: D OES the term nonalcoholic, when it appears on a wine bottle or beer can, mean completely free of alcohol? Not necessarily, according to the law. Hardly ever, according to the National Council on Alcoholism.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CONCERT: WATERLOO FESTIVAL AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THE Waterloo Festival Orchestra has made its reputation over the last 10 summers operating beneath a tent across the river in New Jersey. Saturday afternoon it came indoors - playing for the first time in Carnegie Hall and, for that matter, in New York. The concert was free to the public, and the public in large numbers took advantage of the fact.

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $52,000, or 1 cent a share, on the sale of real estate. c-After losses on the sale of real estate of $8,000 for the quarter and $24,000 for the 6 months.

title: THEATER: 'SALLY'S GONE'
description: IN ''Sally's Gone, She Left Her Name,'' at the Perry Street Theater, Russell Davis offers symptoms of a suburban family in crisis, while closely guarding diagnoses. This family needs help - from the playwright as well as from social and psychiatric counseling services. Each of the four characters is unable, or unwilling, to reach the others. At the same time, the play itself suffers from a kind of emotional withdrawal.

title: Tennessee State Put on Probation
description: Tennessee State University has been placed on probation for one year for violation of eligibility rules, primarily involving its football program, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.

title: A PROFESSIONAL JUICER
description: O NE of the delights of summer in the city is the freshly squeezed fruit juice sold by sidewalk vendors. While carts in New York offer primarily orange juice, those in other cities around the world, particularly in Mexico and South America, offer all kinds of cooling fruit juice combinations. Part of the fun is watching a vendor hack open fresh fruit and place it in a tall metal device with conical jaws. When the jaws are shut, juice is forced out the bottom and seeds are trapped in a filter.

title: TAX AIDES PUT CHOICE TO REAGAN
description: President Reagan met today with his chief tax policy advisers from the White House and the Treasury Department and was given three alternatives for reducing the 50 percent top tax rate that applies to individuals, according to Administration officials.

title: Opportunity on the Connecticut Turnpike
description: To the Editor:

title: NOVO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN AND CONGRESS: KEY TESTS FOR HIS POLITICAL SKILL
description: As Congress enters a critical period for President Reagan's legislative agenda, lawmakers from both parties continue to fear and respect Mr. Reagan's ability to generate public support for his ideas and shape the debate on Capitol Hill.

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: 1984 share earnings restated to reflect sock split, effective June 25, 1984.

title: That Town in Germany
description: There is apparently more to be said about Bitburg. Next Tuesday the West German Ambassador to the United States, Gunther van Well, will address the Board of Governors of B'nai B'rith International in Washington. The title of his speech: ''Jews and Germans - After Bitburg.''

title: Cardinals Crush Padres, 14-4
description: Jack Clark homered, doubled and drove in four runs, and Andy Van Slyke drove in three tonight in leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 14-4 rout of the San Diego Padres.

title: Jacobs Raises Stake in Castle
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that he had increased his stake in Castle & Cooke Inc. to 13.5 percent, from 12.3 percent of the company's 25.8 million outstanding shares. Mr. Jacobs also said that he had sold his stake in Gulf and Western Industries, though he did not provide any details. He had purchased less than 5 percent of the company last month.

title: U.N. AIDE KIDNAPPED IN BEIRUT
description: A United Nations official was kidnapped in Moslem West Beirut today.

title: NISSHIN IN TALKS
description: the Nisshin Steel Company, Japan's sixth-largest steel manufacturer, is negotiating to acquire the Thinsheet Metals Company, a leading American manufacturer of basic materials in the field of electronics, the company reported. The company said negotioations were under way to take over Thinsheet, of Waterbury, Conn., whose production of intergrated circuits is ranked third in the United States. Nisshin did not give further details, but the leading economic daily, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, said Nisshin Steel had agreed to pay $20 million for the concern.

title: Despite the Analysts, Mitterrand Is Not de Gaulle
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ARMCHAIR: COMFORT COMES IN MANY SHAPES
description: CHOOSING a comfortable armchair is a project that requires thought. Real comfort has as much to do with your own sitting habits as it does with the chair's shape.

title: I.L. SALOMON
description: I. L. Salomon, a poet and translator, died Sunday in Rochester. He was 85 years old.

title: Princess Yasmin Aga Khan Married to Basil Embiricos
description: Princess Yasmin Aga Khan and Basil Embiricos were married yesterday in a civil ceremony at her apartment on Central Park West. Justice E. Leo Milonas of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court officiated.

title: ARTS AND LETTERS PRIZES PRESENTED BY ACADEMY
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters presented its 1985 awards for distinguished service to the arts yesterday to Rhode Island Senator Claiborne Pell, sponsor of the law establishing the National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities; to William Shawn, who has served as editor of The New Yorker for 33 years, and to a number of other creative artists.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES DECLINE MODESTLY
description: Short-term interest rates declined modestly yesterday but not enough to prevent an increase in note and bond yields.

title: NEW ITEMS FOR PETS
description: CAT owners who want to coordinate their pet's accessories can order custom-made cat scratching posts in any fabric from the Animal Nutrition Center (1398 Second Avenue, between 72d and 73d Streets). The cost varies depending on material and size of the scratching post. The store also carries many ready-made scratching posts, ranging in price from $9.99 to $120.

title: BLAST IN PAKISTAN HAS OFFICIALS JITTERY
description: The only visible clue that something out of the ordinary happened here recently is a pile of rubble and a couple of crumpled mud huts in a dusty ''training camp'' run by refugees from Afghanistan in a nearby village.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pro Sports on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: DESPITE THE ANALYSTS, MITTERRAND IN NOT DE GAULLE
description: To the Editor:

title: COLUMBIA GRADUATES 7,173 AFTER A BRIEF APARTHEID PROTEST
description: Columbia University graduated 7,173 students yesterday in ceremonies interrupted briefly by the walkout of about 200 students and faculty members opposed to the university's investments in companies operating in South Africa.

title: RAYMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $2,720,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MALAYSIA'S SCRAPPY CHIEF: A MAN OF MANY PARTS
description: Malaysia is the quiet country in the heart of Southeast Asia, with no border wars or large-scale terrorist movements.

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a foreign exchange gain of $5,000,000. c-After a foreign exchange loss of $45,000,000.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: MUSIC: GLASS AND 'KOYAANISQATSI'
description: THE composer Philip Glass has recently enjoyed an incredible public acclaim. On Friday night, nearly 6,000 people paid up to $20 for the privilege of listening to Mr. Glass, a choral group called the Western Wind and the Philip Glass Ensemble play and sing the soundtrack to Godfrey Reggio's film ''Koyaanisqatsi'' during two separate screenings at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: WHITE DEFENDANT'S CONVICTION DISMISSED ON RACIAL GROUNDS
description: A white defendant won a decision yesterday overturning his conviction in a Bronx arson case on the ground that the prosecutor had excluded several whites from the jury for racial reasons.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Music: Noted in Brief;   Charol Society In 2 Modern Works
description: No two 20th-century choral works could be more different than Stravinsky's ''Symphony of Psalms'' and Honegger's ''King David.'' The ''Symphony'' resurrects the spirit of early polyphony in a way that is solemn, austere, yet touchingly beautiful.

title: ARTIST'S STYLE WINS HIGH PRAISE -- AND REJECTION
description: One of the paintings now at the Mary Boone Gallery from the exhibition of works by the artist David Salle depicts realistically a woman in a bathing suit tanning herself, with - seemingly senselessly - the jolly head of a Santa Claus at her elbow.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, announced the completion of its $225 million purchase of Servomation Corp. from City Investing Co.

title: SUPERDOLLARS AND SUPERDEBT
description: The rapid transformation of the United States from the world's largest creditor to potentially its first trillion dollar debtor is taking place virtually unnoticed. For the first time since World War I, our liabilities to foreigners exceed foreign liabilities to the United States. If our trade deficit continues at anything like its present level, we will overtake Mexico and Brazil to become the leading debtor nation sometime early next year. Before the next Presidential election, our foreign debt could outstrip the total debt of all developing countries.

title: 5% BILLION ALLIED DEAL FOR SIGNAL
description: The Allied Corporation, one of the most rapidly expanding automotive and aerospace companies in the nation, announced the biggest industrial merger in history yesterday, agreeing to buy the Signal Companies, another major aerospace producer, for nearly $5 billion in cash and stock.

title: DOCUTEL-OLIVETTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Football Beckons Georgetown Star
description: You've heard of Kirk McCaskill, the pitcher who made it to the California Angels this season after a career in professional hockey. And you've also taken note of Renaldo Nehemiah, the speedball hurdler turned San Francisco 49er receiver. Now make way for Gene Smith, whose transformation, if successful, will also defy long odds: Smith, the captain of Georgetown's 1984 national-champion basketball team, has never played a single down of organized football, but he is nonetheless trying to latch on with the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $48,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $137,000 for the quarter and $311,000 for the 6 months.

title: ELECTROSPACE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Share earnings reflect a 25 percent stock dividend in September 1984.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We should not forget the time it took to reach agreement on the Austrian treaty.

title: Million-Dollar Musings
description: The head of one Government agency under the Justice Department is musing on the amount of time Congress has spent in consideration of $14 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels. ''Our funding has not been the subject of a Senate hearing in years,'' he said. ''No one in the Senate has even asked me how we've spent our budget, and we get hundreds of millions of dollars.''

title: Do Drink the Water
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington wants people in the city, and in the rest of the world, to believe that the Distict of Columbia has the best drinking water. So as Mayor of the host city of the forthcoming annual conference of the American Water Works Association, he has challenged six cities and Canada to a water ''taste-off'' when the conference opens June 23.

title: BERKSHIRE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUN, SURF AND THE BRASSY SONG OF THE BOARDWALK
description: The season of the sun is at hand, and the purveyors of neon and noise are crowing again. To hear them tell it, no place - midway or gaudy promenade - is quite as loud and bright and brassy as theirs.

title: A Voice in the Tunnel
description: The high-pitched voice echoed past the Metropolitan Opera's stage door out into the street. A diva warming up? A soprano auditioning?

title: A VENDOR OF CRAFTS IN PAPIER-MACHE
description: THE weather has warmed and William H. Stevens is about to hit the streets again. It might be a couple of weeks before he settles in at 78th Street and Fifth Avenue and sets up his folding snack table laden with one of the oddest, most eclectic collections of small decorative sculptures around.

title: DANCE: MEREDITH MONK'S 'QUARRY'
description: A CHILD wakes up and cries that she is sick. In other rooms of the house, people work and talk. Passers-by stroll in the street. Yet the child keeps crying that she is sick, that all parts of her body ache. Soon, it becomes clear that there is sickness not only in this child, but in the body politic as well.

title: A STATE HEARING SET ON ACTIONS BY CITY'S POLICE
description: The chairman of the State Senate Investigations Committee said today that he would hold public hearings on the operation of the New York City Police Department because of recent charges of brutality.

title: MARYLAND DEPOSIT RUN EASES
description: The run on Maryland's privately insured savings and loan associations eased today. But the $1,000-a-month limit on withdrawals imposed late Tuesday by Gov. Harry R. Hughes caused widespread confusion.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRINTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
EMPLOYERS OFFER MORE CHILD CARE
description: Only 1,800 of the nation's six million employers offer child-care services to their workers, but that is a threefold increase in two years and could portend the ''employee benefit of the 1990's,'' a private research group says.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: REAGAN APPROVES PRIMARY ELEMENTS OF TAX OVERHAUL
description: President Reagan today approved the main elements of an ambitious plan to revise the Federal income tax system, Administration officials said, but the White House delayed the public release of the plan until May 28.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, 1:05 P.M. Dennis Rasmussen is scheduled to pitch the finale of the home stand, after which the Yankees start a 10-game trip that opens in Anaheim, Calif., against the Angels tomorrow.

title: KOHL IS PLANNING RISKY ENCOUNTERS
description: The Government said today that Chancellor Helmut Kohl would hold to two politically risky encounters: an address to a gathering of Silesian Germans in June and a visit to Bonn in early July by Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the Paraguayan leader.

title: BANKERS TRUST CUTS PRIME RATE
description: The Bankers Trust Company cut its prime lending rate yesterday by half a percentage point, to 10 percent. The move, which analysts expect other major banks to follow soon, means that the prime rate will be at its lowest level since 1978.

title: U.S. DEFENDS DISPUTED HUTTON DECISION
description: The Justice Department is mounting a determined defense of its decision not to prosecute individual officials in E.F. Hutton & Company's bank fraud in the face of persistent criticism that flared anew today on Capitol Hill.

title: Stars, Anyone?
description: ''It is the stars, the stars above us, govern our conditions,'' wrote Shakespeare, and John Donne advised, ''Go and catch a falling star.'' In this spirit the National Museum of American History is opening an exhibit today of old astronomical charts, some of which depict a geocentric universe. The exhibit, which will last until Aug. 23, comprises ''39 rare and beautiful depictions of star patterns and planetary systems,'' the museum says.

title: MAUDE DOUGLAS TWEEDY
description: Maude Douglas Tweedy, a voice teacher for more than 70 years, died May 7 at her home in Manhattan after contracting pneumonia.

title: U.S. Says Arafat Statement Makes No Specific Progress
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it saw no specific progress toward Middle East peace talks in a new statement by Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes charges from losses incurred by the company's affiliate, TII Computer Systems Inc., of $134,000 for the quarter and $266,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes charges from losses incurred by the affiliate of $195,000 for the quarter and $637,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago 9 months' net also includes a tax credit of $30,000.

'Wedding' at Circle Rep Is Canceled for a Week
description: This week's performances of ''Angelo's Wedding'' at the Circle Repertory Company have been canceled.

description: b-After extraordinary charges of $268,000 for the latest first quarter and $34,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: A Rare Night in May
description: Sixty chiefs of staff from the House of Representatives are to visit the Soviet Embassy tonight for what they expect to be a rare evening.

Women and Law
description: A class visit to State Supreme Court and the city's Law Department left one Brooklyn high school student uncertain about opportunities for a legal career.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Tuesday about the upstate house where Ulysses S. Grant died - in Moreau, in northern Saratoga County -misstated the visiting hours. At present, visitors can tour the house only by appointment, which can be made by calling (518) 584-2000. From May 25 through Labor Day, the house will be open Wednesday through Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. After Labor Day, the house will be shut.

title: Close Race for Salomon Against First Boston
description: There was no burning rubber or roaring engines, but Wall Street was the scene of an unusual car race yesterday as the First Boston Corporation and Salomon Brothers competed to become the first to publicly offer securities backed by automobile loan receivables.

title: BMT TRAIN DERAILS, INJURING 21 AND DISRUPTING 5 LINES
description: A BMT subway train bound for Coney Island derailed yesterday morning, injuring 21 people and causing two fires that interrupted service on five lines between Brooklyn and Manhattan throughout much of the day.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: NEARLY everyone needs a basic assortment of tools around the house or apartment, because it can be so hard to find someone to do repairs when necessary, especially small jobs. However, tools are of little help if they cannot be found when needed.

title: Dunlop to Sell U.S. Tire Unit
description: Dunlop Holdings P.L.C. said that it had agreed to sell its United States tire operations to a group including management for $118 million, plus the repayment of $60 million in loans.

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $702,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $675,000. Results for the latest quarter include the operations of The Cotton Bakery and Coast to Coast Resorts, both acquired in the first quarter of 1985. Results for the year-ago quarter include the operations of Langendorf, which was sold in the fourth quarter of 1984.

title: Bidder for Theater On Pier 84 Sought
description: The city is seeking a developer to build a 6,000-seat performing-arts center, with restaurants and perhaps a marina, on a pier overlookng the Hudson River at 44th Street, city official said yesterday.

title: Connors and Lendl Win Contract Suit
description: A judge awarded a total of more than $1 million today to Jimmy Connors, Ivan Lendl and two other tennis players who sued a promoter after he failed to pay them for playing in an exhibition two years ago.

title: Bradford Trust
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the clearing activities of Bradford Trust Company, the commission told a House subcommittee. A Bradford division at one time acted as clearing agent for several Government securities dealers that have since failed. The S.E.C. made the remarks in written answers to questions submitted by the House Government Operations Committee's Monetary Affairs Subcommittee,

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $324,000 and a tax credit of $2,069,000.

title: Son of Police Chief Pleads Not Guilty to Armed Robbery
description: The son of the Los Angeles Police Chief pleaded not guilty today to robbing a pharmacy of $5,000 worth of drugs and to taking jewelry from a house in an unrelated theft.

title: CARE AND FEEDING OF THE HARDY LILAC
description: LILACS are at their peak now. In honor of their flowering, the International Lilac Society is holding its annual meeting in New York. Members will gather at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden tomorrow for an all-day discussion and tour of the Louisa Clark Spencer Lilac Collection.

title: GOODEN STRUGGLES BUT WINS SIXTH
description: Al Rosen, the president of the Houston Astros and a man who hit 192 home runs in the big leagues, put it this way:

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE MEETS ON BUDGET
description: The House Budget Committee today began writing a 1986 Federal budget that would preserve 11 of the 12 domestic programs the Senate has voted to eliminate.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GENEVE CAPITAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $220,994 for net income applicable to minority shareholders and realized investment gains of $234,087. c-After a charge of $2,196,837 for net income applicable to minority shareholders and realized investment gains of $662,502.

title: Hedberg Gets Post
description: Anders Hedberg received a job with the Rangers and an award from the National Hockey League yesterday. But two other Rangers, the assistant coaches Carol Vadnais and Wayne Thomas, appeared headed to the unemployment line.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SECRET GARDENS: The Golden Age of Children's Literature. By Humphrey Carpenter. 235 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95. SOME readers of children's books, most notably Dorothy Parker, have deplored the saccharine sentimentality of A. A. Milne's outlook on childhood. But Humphrey Carpenter, the English critic, points out that Milne is actually kidding. If his light verse and his Winnie-the-Pooh books have an overriding theme, it is the ''ruthless egotism'' of children. The point of ''Vespers'' (''Hush, hush, whisper who dares . . .'') is not that Christopher Robin is saying his prayers but rather that he is not praying. The Beautiful Child would rather think about what fun it was in the bath tonight than about God.

title: Bridge;   Becker Squad Takes First In Cavendish Team Event
description: A team with three of the country's strongest partnerships held on to win the Cavendish Club Teams in New York Tuesday night.

title: Everton Wins Soccer Trophy
description: Everton won its first European soccer trophy tonight with a 3-1 victory over Rapid Vienna in the 25th final of the European Cup Winners Cup. It was the second triumph in nine days for Everton, which has already won the English League title and on Saturday seeks a unique triple for British soccer when it plays in the Football Association Cup final against Manchester United at Wembley.

title: ISRAELIS ILLEGALLY GOT U.S. DEVICES USED IN MAKING NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: The State Department has known since early this year that Israel had illegally acquired electronic devices that would be critical in making nuclear weapons but avoided making that an issue with the Israeli Government, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Touche Reacts to Suit
description: The accounting firm of Touche Ross & Company said that it had reconfirmed that the information provided by its client, the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, to CBS Inc. during CBS's purchase of 12 magazines was fair.

title: BRADY, W H CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
POLL FINDS MINORITY GROUPS UNHAPPY WITH CITY SERVICES
description: Many black and Hispanic New Yorkers say that they are dissatisfied with their local schools and hospitals and that they are treated unfairly by the police and the courts, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV Poll.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. LABOR TIES WITH ISRAEL ARE STRAINED BY EL AL STRIKE
description: A small strike, barely noticed by most Americans, has created a severe strain in the long relationship between Israel and the American labor movement, to the point where the Israeli Prime Minister has now intervened to force a settlement.

title: PENTAGON TAKING RENEWED PRIDE IN ITS PERSONNEL
description: The recruiting and retention of able men and women in the armed forces have been hailed as the single most notable achievement in the Reagan Administration's four-year military buildup, although warning signs have recently come over the horizon.

title: 3 Mile Island Cover Removed
description: Crews at Three Mile Island today lifted a 55-ton cover off the damaged Unit 2 nuclear reactor, clearing the way for removal of the radioaoctive fuel later this year.

title: THEATER: 'CEREMONIES'
description: IN revival at the Negro Ensemble Company, Lonne Elder 3d's ''Ceremonies in Dark Old Men'' retains its emotional and dramatic vitality. As directed by, and starring, Douglas Turner Ward (recreating his 1969 role as Russell B. Parker), the play begins what promises to be a valuable series of N.E.C. reinvestigations of the recent black theatrical past.

title: Dodgers Demoted
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers will send Bob Welch, a starting pitcher, and their regular shortstop, Dave Anderson, to the minor leagues for the purpose of rehabilitation. Welch, who has appeared in only one game this season because of a sprained medial collateral ligament in his right elbow, is going to Vero Beach of the Florida State League, effective next Tuesday.

title: Money Fund Rates Fall
description: Rates and yields for bank money market accounts, certificates of deposit and money market funds dropped for the week ended yesterday. With Bankers Trust announcing that it was cutting its prime rate, and the anticipation of more banks following suit, Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, said: ''The drop should impact falling deposit account yields, as well, by stimulating lower lending rates. When that happens, banks will bid more aggressively to replace deposits, and consumers will begin earning more on accounts.''

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After tax credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $190,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Action on Information Bill
description: A Senate Judiciary subcommittee today approved revisions to the Freedom of Information Act, but the panel's chairman, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, says full committee consideration will be delayed.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Vienna yesterday about the reported sighting of Josef Mengele, the German death camp doctor, in Paraguay last July misstated the birthplace of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the Paraguayan leader. He was born in Encarnacion, Paraguay; his father was born in Bavaria.

title: PRODUCTION OFF BY 0.2% LAST MONTH
description: Output from the nation's factories, mines and utilities declined two-tenths of 1 percent last month, continuing the essentially trendless pattern that has prevailed since early last summer, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: INFERNO'S AFTERMATH: BLOW TO THE POLICE
description: Although Mayor W. Wilson Goode has accepted full responsibility for Monday's bombing of the Move headquarters and the fire that destroyed more than 60 homes, the spotlight of criticism appears to be focusing not on him but on the police.

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev flew to Leningrad today to visit a factory and talk with workers.

description: Daimler-Benz cleared the last hurdle to acquiring a majority stake in the Dornier aerospace group today when Claudius Dornier, the last family member to withhold approval, agreed to go along.

description: The faces come and go, most of them preserved only in the framed team pictures that hang in the office at Fort Lauderdale Stadium and in memories of bus rides across Florida. They spend a summer together and then decisions are made. Some will advance. A very few - five? three? two? - may advance to the top.
