title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Music: Noted in Brief;   David Zinman Leads Baltimore Symphony
description: David Zinman went to Carnegie Hall not long ago with the Rochester Philharmonic - which he is leaving this year - and Sunday afternoon he turned up again, this time with the Baltimore Symphony, whose musical directorship he assumes in the fall.

title: WESTERN TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Unocal Talks End, Pickens Aide Says
description: Representatives of the Unocal Corporation and a group of investors headed by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, met Tuesday and today, but ended the talks without an agreement, a Pickens spokesman said.

title: Do You Know This Police Officer?
description: To the Editor:

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: The share earnings do not reflect a 4-for-3 stock split declared in April and payable May 30.

title: Leontyne Price Gets City's Top Arts Award
description: The soprano Leontyne Price was given New York City's highest cultural award, the Handel Medallion, on Tuesday, and sang a few bars of ''I Love New York'' as she accepted it.

title: State Department;   Who's Who Now the Old-Boy Network Is Dead
description: Before the Vietnam era, the important relationships inside the State Department and Foreign Service flowed principally from family background and Ivy League school connections. Then, in the mid-1960's and early 1970's, working on and in Vietnam became the central link for the inside power-brokers.

title: Hughes Lead By G.M. Seen
description: The General Motors Corporation is considered the front-runner in the bidding to acquire the technology-rich Hughes Aircraft Company, Wall Street sources said today. Bids are expected to range between $4 billion and $6 billion.

title: ANTISATELLITE WEAPON FACING DELAYS AND SHARP COST INCREASES
description: Technical problems with the Air Force's new antisatellite weapon have caused a steep rise in its cost and delays in its testing, according to a Pentagon official.

title: HERS
description: ONCE I met a woman who grew up in the small North Carolina town to which Chang and Eng, the original Siamese twins, retired after their circus careers. When I asked her how the town reacted to the twins marrying local girls and setting up adjacent households, she laughed and said: ''Honey, that was nothing compared to what happened before the twins got there. Get the good gossip on any little mountain town, scratch the surface and you'll find a snake pit!''

title: 'BROTHERS' SUCCESS HINTS AT CABLE'S NEW ROLE
description: At a time when the networks rarely order more than 22 episodes of a series, Showtime's recent order of 50 new episodes of ''Brothers'' - the critically acclaimed situation comedy about a family adjusting to the revelation that the youngest of three brothers is homosexual - is an unusual vote of confidence. It also underscores cable television's new role as a supplier of dramatic and comdedy series.

title: OLDEST KNOWN DINOSAUR BELIEVED FOUND IN U.S.
description: The skeleton of what is believed to be the earliest known dinosaur, a creature the size of a small ostrich, has been discovered in Arizona's Painted Desert by scientists from the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Georgia Thrift Plan
description: Georgia's 10 privately insured savings and loan associations are planning to become federally insured banks or savings and loans before the end of the year, a state banking official said today. The state-chartered institutions, which have combined assets of $101 million, are now insured by the 10-year-old Georgia Credit Union Deposit Insurance Corporation. Robert Moler, Deputy Banking Commissioner, said that the proposed changes were ''motivated by marketing concerns about the difficulty in explaining private insurance.''

title: A'S POUND BREWERS WITH 19 HITS, 19-3
description: Mike Davis cracked two home runs, drove in six runs and scored four, and Dwayne Murphy also connected in a 19-hit attack as the Oakland A's crushed the Milwaukee Brewers today, 19-3.

title: CITIZEN OF THE WORLD
description: Rupert Murdoch, the multimedia baron from Australia, became an Establishment figure here when he bought The Times of London. Before that, he created a stir when he bought The New York Post, founded in 1801 by Alexander Hamilton.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MUSIC: 'FARCE,' BY BARAB
description: SEYMOUR BARAB'S ''Tour de Farce,'' a pair of one-acters at the After Dinner Opera last Sunday night, is not opera in the ominous sense of that word. Mr. Barab writes his own words - they are mostly in verse and often funny -and shapes a continuous flow of pleasant music for them to ride on. The style lies somewhere between Gilbert and Sullivan and Cole Porter, with little ethnic gestures thrown in as needed; and though this music makes no pretense of depth or intensity, one is impressed at how naturally it appears - seemingly without doubt or hesitation.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of MRJ Inc.

title: CUT IN PRIME RATE SPURS STOCK RISE
description: Stock prices closed higher on Wall Street yesterday as investors reacted positively to a cut in the prime lending rate by Bankers Trust. The performance of the closely watched Dow Jones industrial average was distorted, however, by a sharp decline in the price of the Allied Corporation's stock.

title: 2 Piers Offered For Concrete Plant
description: The city yesterday offered to provide a midtown waterfront site to a bidder willing to build a concrete plant, a plan intended to reduce the cost of concrete in Manhattan by increasing competition.

title: A KID-GLOVE INQUISITION FOR SCHOLARS
description: Each year, in a tall rose-yellow parlor in a house built on Beacon Hill when Thomas Jefferson was President, a gentle but deadly serious inquisition takes place, and some of America's brightest college seniors are glad to come to be grilled.

title: NO HAZARDS FOUND IN 2 CONTRACEPTIVES
description: MORE than 3,500 physicians who specialize in women's health were told yesterday that two popular forms of birth control - spermicides and birth control pills containing progesterone - do not cause birth defects or spontaneous abortion.

title: PREVIN IN SERIES ON MUSIC
description: EPISODE SIX of Andre Previn's survey of the symphony looks at how well the form has survived in the 20th century. There are excerpts from Vaughan Williams's Fifth and Roy Harris's Third, but the principal evidence presented here is the ever-popular Symphony No. 5 of Dmitri Shostakovich, which the London Philharmonic, conducted by Mr. Previn, plays in its entirety. The program was produced by the BBC last year as part of its ''Sounds Magnificent'' series and will be seen tonight at 8:30 on the Arts and Entertainment channel.

title: Northrop Backs Tigershark Jet
description: Thomas V. Jones, chairman and chief executive of the Northrop Corporation, said that Tuesday's crash of an F-20 Tigershark jet fighter would not deter the company from promoting the plane to prospective buyers, including the Air Force. The crash, which killed the pilot, David Barnes, was the second of an F-20 in eight months and leaves only one Tigershark in operation.

title: Losing Days
description: So now it's Calvin Schiraldi, the latest in a considerable list of Mets to suffer tears, breaks, cuts, scrapes or any number of other aches and pains since the season opened. Here is a listing of man-games lost to illness or injury by the teams in the Eastern Division of the National League, through Tuesday night's play (regular or platooned players only, including starting-rotation pitchers):

title: A GLOBAL ATTACK ON TERROR
description: The controversy over the United States' alleged involvement with anti-terrorist fighters in Lebanon has revived the question of how best to combat international terrorism. It is a sobering reminder of the West's failure to act in concert against terrorists.

title: But Will It Still Be Tax Reform?
description: There's a great spate of news about President Reagan's tax reform plan these days, except it's not news at all. It's trial balloons and speculation, yet enough to warrant a News of the Leaks in Review. What's happening, and can it be taken seriously? The bewildered reader can try applying four tests to the reports.

title: CONTINENTAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
K N ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After securities gains of $93,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Drug Test Guidelines Listed
description: If Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's mandatory drug-testing program turns up anyone who has used drugs, the person will not be penalized the first time, Ueberroth told major league clubs yesterday.

title: BROADHURST WORK COMPLETED
description: After a six-month-long, $2 million renovation, the Broadhurst Theater at 235 West 44th Street was opened yesterday at a celebration attended by Mayor Koch and prominent members of the theater and architectural preservation communities. The theater will reopen to the public on June 11 with ''The Odd Couple.''

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including net realized gains on investments of $8,412,000 for the latest first quarter and $9,791,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Frank Westmore, 62, A Film Makeup Artist
description: Frank Westmore, who did makeup for many Hollywood films, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Burbank, Calif. He was 62 years old.

title: Technology;   The Plastic Pollution Fight
description: AMID the seaweed and broken shells, a small stretch of beach on Long Island Sound recently yielded several clear plastic soda bottles, an assortment of plastic bags and a dented plastic milk jug. Despite the continuing action of wind and weather, all remained largely intact and are likely, experts say, to remain that way for several years.

title: STAGE: ONE-ACT PLAYS, 'MARATHON '85'
description: THE Ensemble Studio Theater, always a bustling home for new and established voices in the American theater, has now reached its annual fever pitch. ''Marathon '85'' - the E.S.T.'s eighth yearly festival of one-act plays -has gotten under way with the first of three programs (four plays apiece) to perform in repertory over the next month. As usual with the marathon, the opening bill, called Series A, is long, uneven and bracingly acted throughout. Yet even the minor offerings - one of them by David Mamet - seem like petty inconveniences once we've seen the two gems that conclude the evening.

title: UTILICORP UNITED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was formerly the Missouri Public Service Co.

title: THE ILLS OF PIANO COMPETITION
description: THE program notes at Merkin Concert Hall the other night included a startling statistic.

title: CITY BALLET: 'FIREBIRD'
description: LEONID KOZLOV and Valentina Kozlova, who are husband and wife, made promising, if not totally successful, debuts in ''Firebird'' at the New York City Ballet's performance Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said that the latest quarter net was increased by about $1,134,000 because of a change in the estimated income tax rate expected for the full year.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There are no share earnings because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in both periods.

title: LIBERAL PARTY CHIEFS CONSIDER BACKING KOCH
description: Liberal Party leaders who rejected Mayor Koch as a mayoral candidate four years ago say they are considering endorsing him this year.

title: VENTREX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
photo of Dr. Stanley Stuber;   Dr. Stanley Stuber, 81, Clergyman and Author
description: The Rev. Dr. Stanley I. Stuber, a Baptist clergyman, author and leader in interdenominational church affairs, died on May 7 at the Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center of complications after heart surgery. He was 81 years old and lived in Wyckoff, N.J.

title: WORTHEN BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: MENTORS HELP SHAPE FUTURES FOR STUDENTS
description: GEMMA DEL SIGNORE is a 20-year-old business major at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N. Y., who has been taking the train to Manhattan quite often this semester. She is trying to learn the ropes of the banking business.

title: TRI-CHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a credit of about $190,000 reflecting the favorable impact of a sales tax audit previously charged to earnings.

title: Vehicles Are Recalled By Two Auto Makers
description: The Ford Motor Company has recalled 135,600 vehicles for repair, including 119,000 mid-size 1981 models with a potential pollution problem, the company has announced.

title: VAN GOGH'S 'ELYSIAN FELDS' IS SOLD
description: Vincent Van Gogh's oil-on-burlap painting ''Elysian Fields,'' painted in 1888 at Arles, brought the highest price last night in Christie's auction of 61 Impressionist and modern art works. But of those, 25 did not sell.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THURSDAY, MAY 16, 1985

title: VON BULOW JUDGE SEES RISKS IN CASE
description: Judge Corinne P. Grande has told the lawyers prosecuting Claus von Bulow that she was ''holding this case together with bailing wire'' and risked being reversed on appeal by denying a defense request for a mistrial.

title: Variety of Bonds In Texas Offering
description: The Austin, Tex., Housing Finance Corporation is offering $47.3 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. The bonds, insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: DAY OF WILDFLOWERS
description: The Day of the Wildflowers, Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, 212-757-0915 or 914-786-2701.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $122,000 for the latest first quarter and $507,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Calling All Bipeds With $100
description: A menagerie of the capital's leading bipeds are to gather today for a fund-raising party devoid of politics and dedicated to wild animals.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pre-tax gain of $446,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: It's Not Over . . .
description: The Yankees' starting pitchers have been under fire of late, and not without cause. Entering play last night, they had a record of 10-12, and they had managed to complete only four games.

title: MONCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $2.1 million loan loss provision and a reduction in net interest income from non-accrual loans.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including pretax gains of $17,691,363 for the quarter and $20,491,523 for the 9 months from sale of the company's Reprotech unit.

title: CONCERN AND PATIENCE MINGLE IN SAVINGS LINE
description: Today marked the fourth day that Ruth Newman waited outside a suburban branch of the Old Court Savings and Loan Association, trying unsuccessfully to withdraw enough cash from her account to meet necessities.

title: LITTLE ROCK BANK LOSS
description: The Worthen Bank Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Arkansas, yesterday reported a first-quarter loss of $68 million, primarily resulting from a $52 million liability by its Worthen Bank and Trust Company in connection with the collapse of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., a New Jersey securities company.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday misidentified the team that won the soccer double in England in 1971. It was Arsenal.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $846,316 for the latest quarter and $386,521 for year-earlier period. The latest quarter net also includes a gain of $537,209 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The share earnings reflect the 2-for- 1 stock split paid April 1, 1985.

title: Federal Judge Dismisses Suits on Indian Claims
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed three lawsuits seeking the return of land to descendants of early Indian owners.

title: CENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
1 Dead and 2 Hurt In Holdup at Plant
description: One man was fatally shot and two others were wounded yesterday in a gun battle between the owners of a Brooklyn wholesale clothing and knitwear manufacturer and two men who the police said were trying to rob them.

title: Reform New York City Board of Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains from the sale of assets of $201,000 for the quarter and $223,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a gain of $792,000 from the sale of assets.

title: Letter: On Punishment;   The Best Available Deal for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: NO U.S.-SOVIET GAIN ON A SUMMIT TALK
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that although both the United States and the Soviet Union favored a meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, ''we have not been able to settle on when or where that will take place.''

title: Peking Extends Parole To U.S.-Trained Lawyer
description: China said today that it had paroled a Hong Kong-born, Harvard-trained lawyer sentenced to 15 years for spying two years ago.

title: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $51,000 for the latest quarter and $33,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: SYMPTOMLESS VICTIMS MAY SPREAD AIDS FOR YEARS
description: The virus of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, may persist without causing symptoms in the infected person for more than four years and still be transmissible through blood transfusion, scientists reported yesterday.

title: 80 ARRESTED IN CAIRO
description: Egyptian and Israeli officials opened talks in Cairo today aimed at resolving outstanding disputes, as Egyptian riot policemen broke up a large anti-Israeli demonstration here.

title: DIRE THRIFT OUTLOOK
description: Although the recent runs on savings and loan associations in Ohio and Maryland have been confined to privately insured institutions, they reflect problems in the savings industry as a whole that may threaten its very existence.

title: OAK HILL SPORTSWEAR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $37,000.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 16, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Trusteeship Council - Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: AS DUARTE BEGINS A VISIT TO U.S., OPTIMISM RETURNS TO EL SALVADOR
description: For the first time in five years of conflict, many Salvadorans and foreigners here are beginning to voice a cautious assessment that El Salvador may have halted its slide into a worsening civil war and that a degree of recovery is now possible.

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $13,189,000 and a gain of $22,790,000 from the sale of properties. c-Includes a tax credit of $4,400,000.

title: ZALE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1.8 million for the latest quarter and $1.3 million for the year-earlier period.

title: U.S. WINS CUP QUALIFIER ON LATE GOAL
description: The United States crept one step closer to the 1986 World Cup finals tonight with a 2-1 victory over Trinidad and Tobago in a qualifying match before a crowd of 15,823 at Busch Stadium.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $280,000. c-Operating income. d-Net income which is after realized investment gains of $50,000.

title: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST OLD COURT
description: The Old Court Savings and Loan Association, whose problems touched off the Maryland thrift crisis, has been charged with an array of irregularities and illegalities.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $742,000. c-After an extraordinary credit of $874,000. d-After an extraordinary gain of $1,823,000. e-After an extraordinary gain of $2,247,000. The company said its earnings for the latest quarter and 9 months include sales of Jonathan Logan Inc., which was acquired effective Sept. 1, 1984, of $87,721,000 and $215,987,000, respectively. The contribution of Jonathan Logan to net earnings after related interest costs on the purchase price amounted to about $3.1 million and $5 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: HAZELTON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $47,000 for the quarter and $210,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $160,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss after a loss of $541,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Dunston Sent Down
description: Shawon Dunston, the 22-year-old, Brooklyn-born rookie who got off to a jittery start after winning the Chicago Cubs' shortstop job over the veteran Larry Bowa, has been sent to the minors. Dallas Green, the general manager, and Jim Frey, the manager, gave Dunston the news Tuesday night after he watched from the bench as the Cubs beat the Dodgers, 8-3, in Los Angeles.

title: POPE IN PLEA FOR THE HUNGRY
description: Pope John Paul II called on the Common Market today to use its large farm surpluses to help the hungry of the third world and ''to overcome a flagrant inequality'' between rich and poor countries.

title: NISSAN PICKS CRAY COMPUTER
description: The Nissan Motor Company said yesterday that it had ordered a $6.5 million supercomputer from Cray Research Inc. of Minneapolis. The transaction has been closely monitored by United States trade officials as an indicator of Japan's intentions concerning the purchase of American-made high-technology products, Within hours, another Japanese car maker, the Toyota Motor Corportion, said it was purchasing a supercomputer from Fujitsu Ltd., one of three Japanese companies trying to enter a segment of the computer market that has been dominated by United States manufacturers.

title: Swedish Price Increases
description: Swedish consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April from March, and were up 7.8 percent from the period a year earlier, the Government said today. It said prices rose 2.7 percent in the first four months of the year, compared with an increase of 3.1 percent in the 1984 period. Inflation in all of 1984 was 8.2 percent.

title: Midcon Increases Its Credit Line
description: The Midcon Corporation said that it had increased its credit line to $2.5 billion, from $900 million, saying that the money could be used for acquisitions. The action by Midcon, a natural gas pipeline company based in Lombard, Ill., stirred up new takeover speculation in that industry.

title: CONCERT: THE CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: IT is an odd sandwich that is richly nourishing top and bottom but full of nothing but empty calories in the middle. Last night's concert by the Cleveland Orchestra under Christoph von Dohnanyi, who is in his first season as music director, served up just such a meal last night at Carnegie Hall. Between slices of Bartok (his Divertimento for String Orchestra) and Brahms (his First Piano Concerto), we were asked to chew on one of the few weak pieces that Janacek ever wrote, the noisy and tawdry essay in pre-Soviet Realism known as ''Taras Bulba.''

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $23,730,652 relating to the restructuring of debt.

title: ARMS SPENDING DRAWS CRITICISM AT BARNARD RITE
description: A civil-rights activist and founder of the Children's Defense Fund yesterday told the members of the Barnard College class of 1985 that they were ''graduating into a nation and world that have lost their moral bearings.''

title: ALDEN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to March 30
Pact for Devil Coach
description: A record of 22 victories, 48 losses and 10 ties may not seem like much of a season in the National Hockey League, but that was the best the Devils had since moving to New Jersey three years ago. And it was good enough to win a vote of confidence for their rookie coach, Doug Carpenter, who signed a two-year contract yesterday.

title: Supreme Court;   Of Tents With Wheels And Houses With Oars
description: Is a home on wheels more like a house or more like a car? And why should the Supreme Court of the United States care? Among the great constitutional issues that compete for the Supreme Court's attention, the status of motor homes might not appear particularly urgent. Yet the Justices wrestled with the question for more than six months before deciding, in a 6-to-3 opinion issued Monday, that a motor home more closely resembles a car and may therefore, unlike a house, be searched by the police without a search warrant.

title: Bid for Conrail Stirs Wall Street
description: Wall Street was abuzz yesterday about Morgan Stanley & Company's $1.2 billion offer made on Tuesday for the Government's 85 percent stake in Conrail.

title: BRONZES OF GARDENS PAST FLOURISH IN L.I. SHOW
description: GARDEN statuary, once the rage among the propertied rich, now has a very bad name. The monumental statement is what is wanted on today's rolling acres, not playful ornaments. So low, in fact, has the concept of garden statuary sunk that if we think of it at all, we tend to conjure up such misbegotten kitsch as plastic flamingos, cement birdbaths, stucco elves and bronze toads.

title: HOUSE PANEL FINDS ARMS MAKERS ROUTINELY BILLING U.S. IMPROPERLY
description: A House Armed Services subcommittee reported today that the weapons industry had routinely billed the Government for improper overhead expenses, sometimes abetted by Federal contracting officers who allowed the claims after Pentagon auditors challenged them.

title: TOP OFFICIAL TELLS CHURCH COUNCIL THAT IT'S TIME TO MEND ITS WAYS
description: Like a minister preaching to a congregation that has strayed, the new chief executive of the National Council of Churches told its governing board today that the council had to confess its organizational sins and mend its ways.

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,131,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Farm Export Give-Away Planned
description: The United States will give away $2 billion worth of surplus wheat, corn and dairy products over the next three years to entice foreign countries to buy American when they shop for farm products.

title: One Man's 'Reform' . . .
description: In politics, if you wait long enough, the ''reformers'' are fair game to be ''reformed.''

title: Inventories Down 0.1%, Sales Up 0.4% in March
description: Business inventories fell one-tenth of 1 percent in March, the first decline in two years, as sales rose a modest four-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: PUBLIC TO GET FULLER VIEW OF DR. KING
description: Scholars working with the King Center for Nonviolent Social Change here have embarked on a 15-year project to assemble and publish 12 volumes of the speeches, sermons and private letters of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The King papers project will be formally announced at a news conference Thursday by Coretta Scott King, widow of the slain civil rights leader, who is president of the King center. The first volume of the papers will be published within four years.

title: SENATE VOTES A $12.8 MILLION FOREIGN AID BILL
description: The Senate approved a $12.8 billion foreign aid bill by an overwhelming majority today after agreeing not to take up the issue of aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: BALLET: 'LA SYLPHIDE'
description: CREATED early in the 19th century, ''La Sylphide'' was the first Romantic ballet. Its ethereal woodland creatures - unearthly females whose attraction proved lethal to the men they lured from the hearth - were to populate and motivate the ballet for a good 50 years, and even help to develop the airborne pointwork of the ballerina. Among the many versions of the ballet is one by the Danish choreographer August Bournonville, staged in 1836 and danced to music by Hermann von Lovenskjold. And Erik Bruhn's production of the work for the American Ballet Theater is one of the liveliest and most charming ballets in the company's repertory.

title: Senate Urges Dollar Action
description: The Senate today approved an amendment to the foreign aid bill calling on the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Board to undertake ''moderate'' intervention in the foreign exchange market to bring the dollar down from its ''astronomical'' highs.

title: Goode Rebuts Koch's View
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia said today he would keep his police commissioner and did not care that Mayor Koch of New York disagrees. ''Ed Koch should run his city and leave mine alone,'' Mr. Goode said in defending the city's handling of a confrontation that ended with 61 houses burned and at least 11 people dead. Mr. Koch had criticized the decision to drop a bomb on a house where armed members of a radical group were holed up.

title: NOW WE SEE IT
description: After the Reagan landslide last November, there was good reason to expect a more ideological second term. The zealots who had been the President's most fervent supporters wanted their due. But who could have foreseen that the move to the extreme would be so nasty, brutish and quick?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about President Reagan's recent trip to West Germany misidentified the home state of Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the state in which Bitburg is situated. Both are in Rhineland Palatinate, not North Rhine-Westphalia.

title: Cable TV Service Bars 'Violence' Documentary
description: Officials of a county cable television service have decided not to broadcast a documentary recounting last summer's mass killings in a local McDonald's restaurant.

title: Market Place;   Turning Away Fund Buyers
description: IN the sales-oriented mutual fund business, it is considered a badge of honor when an organization stops potential customers from buying its merchandise. As of yesterday, the Vanguard Group of Investment Companies suspended the sale of shares to new investors in two of its top-performing funds, the Windsor Fund and the Explorer Fund. ''Our sole intent is to reduce the flow of new cash invested in these two popular funds,'' said John C. Bogle, chairman of Vanguard, in Valley Forge, Pa. ''Trees don't grow to the sky and there's simply a point at which a fund can grow too large. We believe it is in the best long-term interests of existing shareholders to control the future growth of these two funds.''

title: Computers in Shelters
description: To the barren spaces of city shelters for the homeless comes a fancy new addition - the computer.

title: CHOLERA IS REPORTED CURBED IN ETHIOPIA
description: Officials of a French doctors' group said today that they had successfully contained an outbreak of cholera at an Ethiopian famine relief camp.

title: Questions About a Bombing
description: The pictures of bare, smoking walls, now published around the world, make a sick joke out of a comment by Philadelphia's Mayor, Wilson Goode. The police's plan to evict the offensive Move group was, he said, ''perfect, except for the fire.'' People far from West Philadelphia are left to wonder how any modern police department could blunder so catastrophically. Official explanations only raise more questions.

title: OFFICIALS SAY BOMBING WAS CAREFULLY PLANNED
description: As the hours dragged on with officers pinned down by fire from a fortified bunker on the roof of a radical group's house, police officials weighed alternatives and then decided Monday evening to bomb the pillbox-like structure.

title: YANKEES WIN ON ERROR IN 10TH
description: The Yankees have already lost one manager this season and last night they may have helped dispatch another.

title: SCHOLASTIC APTITUDE TEST'S VALUE CHALLENGED ANEW
description: A new book critical of the Scholastic Aptitude Test is stirring a fresh round of debate about the examination, a key element in college admissions.

title: PHILADELPHIA TOLL AT 11 AS OFFICIALS DEBATE FIRE CAUSE
description: Searchers found five more people dead today in the rubble of a radical group's fortified house, which was destroyed Monday after an explosive charge was dropped on it by the police.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed August 10, 1984.

title: FLEMING COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
Advertising;   Turning Clients Into Stars
description: HOW many well-paid, powerful corporate chief executive officers sit in the privacy of their homes in front of one of their color television sets and secretly covet the celebrity of Lee Iacocca, Frank Borman or Frank Perdue and lust to star in one of their own company's commmercials?

title: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Schools Assailed On Repair Work
description: The teaching of vocational education and science in city high schools has been hindered by broken and old equipment, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said in an audit released yesterday.

title: CLUB MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Corrected from Tuesday's editions.

title: DRY-GOODS STORE, UPDATED: CUSTOM FABRICS BY THE YARD
description: THERE is nothing really avant-garde about most of the products or the design of the space, but the big, spanking-new Gear store is sure to send many people reaching for tape measures and thinking about all the things in their homes that need replacing, freshening or replenishing.

title: 'HE REMINDS ME OF VIOLA'
description: He is arguably the best left-hander in baseball now, but many people still think of him as the other pitcher in a college game five years ago. He's a Cy Young-award candidate on a team known primarily for its hitters in a domed stadium known for its home runs. As such, Frank Viola of the Minnesota Twins is the best pitcher not enough people know. But sooner or later, they will. Of all the assessments of the 25-year-old left-hander, Johnny Podres, the Twins' pitching coach, expressed it best when he asked if Frank Viola reminded him of any pitcher of the past.

title: KEY FIGURES IN ILLINOIS RAPE CASE APPEAR ON TV
description: In dramatic, face-to-face appearances together on the three major television networks, Gary Dotson and Cathleen Webb restated yesterday that he did not rape her in 1977.

title: FEDERAL INSURANCE STRICTER THAN PRIVATE SYSTEMS
description: As Maryland's privately insured thrift institutions rush to secure Federal deposit insurance, they will find that the eligibility requirements of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation are more rigorous then they have been accustomed to.

title: AWNINGS CAN HELP SHADE SUMMER SUN
description: 'AWNINGS are a very smart way to decrease or increase the effect of the sun throughout the year,'' said Richard Gerardi, director of the Weatherization Assistance Program of the New York State Department of State in Albany. ''By properly addressing the sun's effects during different times of the year, you can change the temperature inside by 10 to 15 degrees.''

title: 'TICKET TO SEOUL,' JOURNALISTS' FREE TRIP
description: WHEN Kenneth Ellis, a producer at KQED, a public television station in San Francisco, was invited to a two-week, all-expenses-paid trip to Asia by the World Media Association, an arm of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, he asked himself, ''Why would the Moonies take journalists to Asia?'' So, Mr. Ellis relates in a rather self-satisified way at the outset of ''Ticket to Seoul,'' he decided to go on the trip but pay his own way. The documentary, on Channel 13 tonight at 10 o'clock on the ''Intercom'' series, is the result.

title: LANGUAGE AND THOUGHT
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIVE PLAN FINAL WEEKS' DRIVE IN JERSEY GOVERNOR'S PRIMARY
description: With the June 4 primary election less than three weeks away and the candidates' polls showing a high undecided vote, the five contenders for the Democratic nomination for governor are setting their campaign strategies for the final days in an effort to lure voters to their side.

title: TRANSFORMING DARK COURTYARDS INTO BRIGHT SPACES
description: MANY of the tall apartment and loft buildings in New York with beautiful facades in front have bleak prospects in the back: narrow, unadorned light wells and courtyards. Paved in concrete and walled in brick, they may bring air and some light to rear apartment rooms, but often are otherwise unrelieved. While people in individual apartments may deal with a bad view by various window treatments, one alternative is to treat the problem at its source.

title: PRISONER IN TEXAS DIES FOR MURDER
description: Jesse de la Rosa, telling his stepmother he loved her and asking forgiveness for his sins, was executed by lethal injection early today for killing a convenience store clerk for six cans of beer in 1979.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL LINKS ARMS CONTROL TO SOVIET ACTION ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: A United States delegate to a human rights conference here warned the Soviet Union today that the conclusion of an arms-control agreement and other improvements in relations were ''inextricably linked'' to Moscow's performance on human rights.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $602,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $183,000, a charge of $29,000 from reversal of tax credit and a gain of $1,441,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Raising Money Without Alumni
description: Ask the director of development at the City University Law School about building a scholarship fund with the help of the alumni, and she laughs at the question.

POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,905,000 from the disposal of a plant.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $61,000.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Derrell Thomas, a switch-hitting, 34-year-old free agent who plays infield and outfield, was acquired by the Philadelphia Phillies from the Miami Marlins of the Class A Florida League. Kiko Garcia, an infielder, was released to clear a spot for Thomas. . . . Larry McWilliams, the Pittsburgh Pirates' starting pitcher, has been lost indefinitely because of a shoulder problem that has bothered him all season. . . . Bill Walsh, who announced before the Super Bowl that he had agreed to remain as the coach of the San Franciso 49ers for four more seasons, finally got around to signing his new contract. He will be getting a reported $800,000 to $1 million a year, which would make him the highest-paid coach in sports.

title: POLL FINDS LIBERALIZED SEX VIEWS
description: FOR the first time in nearly two decades, more than half of American adults consider premarital sex acceptable, according to the latest Gallup Poll. However, the majority of people 50 years old and older and the majority of those whose formal education ended in grade school still disapprove of premarital sex.

title: Sharon, NVF Losses
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation and the NVF Company, two concerns controlled by Victor Posner, the Florida financier, yesterday reported that their first quarter losses increased sharply from the comparable period of 1984.

title: Times Officer Is Retiring
description: Charles B. Brakefield, a vice president of The New York Times Company and the president of its broadcast group, is retiring on June 30 and will form a broadcasting and advertising consulting firm in Memphis, the company said yesterday.

title: 2 Thrift Units Merge
description: The People's Savings and Loan Association and the Mutual Savings and Loan have announced a merger agreement that would create a new institution with $1 billion in assets. People's Savings sought the merger following several years of losses on investments in housing developments, Robert Pratt, senior vice president at People's, said Tuesday.

title: Utilities Challenged On Donation Policy
description: The State Public Service Commission has been ordered by a state judge to defend its policy of allowing utilities to charge customers for the companies' charitable contributions.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including an investment gain of $1,419,000. c-Net income after an investment loss of $516,000.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in March.

title: ACQUISITION FITS ALLIED'S STYLE
description: Arriving at the Signal Companies' New York offices in a gray pinstriped suit, Edward L. Hennessy Jr., the Allied Corporation's chairman and chief executive, greeted Forrest N. Shumway and Michael D. Dingman, Signal's top officers, both of whom had shucked their suit jackets, with the mock-serious plaint, ''Why do I have to look so formal and these guys look like they're from California?''

title: OPENING THE HOUSE: REFLECTIONS
description: A HALFHEARTED rain set the scene the morning I started for the country to open the house. As the bus eased into the tunnel, the bushes came to mind - the pathetic little things I had planted last fall. Had they made it through the winter? Then, with a sort of gagging sensation, I knew I had forgotten the key.

title: FRIONA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Progress Reported In Airline Contract Talks
description: United Airlines and its pilots union, faced with a Friday strike deadline, are moving toward a contract agreement, a Federal mediator said today.

title: HURTLING LIMOUSINE INJURES 24 OUTSIDE A FUNERAL HOME
description: A limousine for a funeral cortege hurtled into mourners outside a Bronx funeral home yesterday, injuring 22 of them, the police said.

title: Blades of Grass
description: Formula of the Week:

title: CRYSTAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Music: Noted in Brief;   Light Opera Des ''Naughty Marietta
description: The Light Opera of Manhattan's current production is ''Naughty Marietta,'' and though it never rises above the ordinary, the ordinary clearly offered a lot of pleasure to the audience that filled the Eastside Playhouse Saturday afternoon.

title: Memphis State Blues
description: The Memphis State basketball program, already linked to a gambling investigation centered on a suburban country club, has come under attack by the Memphis chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MAY 16, 1985

title: Fairchild Officer Gets 2 Key Posts
description: Emanuel Fthenakis, an executive vice president of Fairchild Industries, has been elected president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Edward G. Uhl, who remains chairman and chief executive of the aerospace and communications company.

title: A Birthday Revue
description: The Capitol Hill Arts Workshop is presenting ''Happy Birthday, Jerome Kern,'' a musical revue marking Kern's 100th birthday year, on Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights in the auditorium of Christ Church in Southeast Washington. The workshop, a nonprofit organization, fosters the talents of children from low-income families. The show, a fund-raiser, features a number of Federal workers as well as residents of the Capitol Hill area.

title: Thrift Insurance Head Putting in Long Days
description: Charles C. Hogg 2d has not slept much lately, and his telephone rings all the time. As president of the Maryland Savings Share Insurance Corporation, the private fund that insures 102 thrift institutions in the state, he has been putting in long days.

title: DEMOCRATIC PANEL IS FORMED TO LURE VOTERS BACK TO PARTY
description: Democratic leaders unveiled a policy commission today to guide the party's search for a new message and image as it struggles to regain voters lost to the Republican Party in recent election years.

title: TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HORSES OF QUESTIONABLE TALENT LURED
description: It seems as though some Pied Piper of Pimlico has been playing the Eastern seaboard the last few days, luring 3-year-olds of questionable talent to Baltimore for the 110th Preakness Stakes Saturday. A field that once numbered six or seven is now up to 11 or 12 and counting. For practical purposes, though, it still looks like a three-horse race among Chief's Crown, Eternal Prince and Tank's Prospect.

Sore Elbows No Handicap for Celtics
description: The talk in Boston is of sore elbows, but the players who have them are not talking.

title: Criticism Of S.E.C.
description: The chairman of a House panel today chastised the Securities and Exchange Commission for not heeding ''red flag'' improprieties by a New Jersey securities firm years before its collapse this April.

title: Will Horwitt, 51, Sculptor; Worked in Wood and Steel
description: Will Horwitt, a sculptor of monumental wood and steel sculptures, died last Thursday of lymphoma at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City. He was 51 years old and lived in the TriBeCa section of Manhattan.

title: 2 Flee Prison in Chicago; Big Manhunt Under Way
description: Two convicts, including the killer of a prominent doctor, escaped from a downtown prison overnight by breaking a sixth-floor window and lowering themselves to the ground with an extension cord.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN THE PARK Bryant Park, particularly at noon, when the public flocks to it, outnumbering the idlers who have become park fixtures, is a pretty, classical oasis in midtown Manhattan, between 40th and 42d Streets and Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. It is a comparatively small greensward but one that you could easily spend an hour studying, with a knowledgeable guide.

title: Why G.E. Became a Pickpocket
description: General Electric is a household word. It's the nation's largest maker of electrical appliances. Its management techniques are studied worldwide. Its automated factories are models of advanced design. Yet this week it pleaded guilty to defrauding the Air Force of $800,000 by forging workers' time cards on a contract for upgrading the warheads on Minuteman missiles.

title: ASSOCIATED-ALLIED
description: the Associated Dry Goods Corporation and the Allied Stores Corporation said they were having preliminary talks on the sale of Associated's Powers Dry Goods division, Minneapolis, to Allied Stores.

title: QUANTUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Called up Bryan Clark, left-handed pitcher, from Maine affiliate and sent down Jerry Willard, catcher, to Maine.

title: FEAR OF CRIME SEEMS TO STRAIN RACE RELATIONS
description: New York is a city charged with fears about crime, and the fears tend to constrain relations between people of different races, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV Poll.

title: CITY INVESTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. The company said results for the latest quarter include gains of $360,000,000 on the sale of subsidiaries pursuant to the company's plan of liquidation. This was offset by the addition of $170,000,000 to property and casualty insurance reserves and a provision of $280,000 for anticipated losses and expenses to be incurred in completion of the company's liquidation.

title: Toll in Sri Lanka Rises To 146 in Rebel Attack
description: Officials said the death toll rose to 146 today in an attack by Tamil separatist guerrillas on Anuradhapura and a nearby wildlife sanctuary. They said that in a backlash, Tamils were being killed and their homes burned.

title: A LONGTIME OFFICIAL OF BAR ASSOCIATION
description: Paul B. DeWitt, the former executive secretary of the City Bar Association, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bank Change Approved
description: The Comptroller of the Currency has approved an Atlanta telecommunications company's application to buy a Florida bank and turn it into a limited-service bank. The Comptroller's office said that the law governing bank ownership changes is specific and gives the agency no grounds for rejecting Continental Telecom Inc.'s purchase of the Southern National Bank of Pompano Beach, Fla., despite a Federal court order against approving further charters for such operations.

title: DINING OUT GUIDE: LINCOLN CENTER AREA
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE LUXEMBOURG, #200 West 70th Street (873-7411) -

title: Mutual Oil-China
description: Mutual Oil of America Inc. said it had signed an agreement worth an estimated $450 million with China to develop four projects on the Nantou peninsula supporting offshore oil and gas development in the South China Sea. The projects are: an oil refinery; two to four deep-water berths for 50,000-ton vessels; a 47-kilometer railroad, and an information center.

title: JOHN T. CLANCY, 82, EX-BOROUGH CHIEF
description: John T. Clancy, former Borough President of Queens and then the borough's surrogate from 1962 until 1971, died, following a stroke, at St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla., on Tuesday. He was 82 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: FURTHER BOMBINGS EXPECTED IN INDIA
description: Indian law enforcement authorities were reported today to have concluded that several hundred Sikh extremists were still at large here and abroad and that they were almost certain to try to carry out more bombings and shootings in the weeks ahead.

title: POP RECITAL: BOBBY SHORT
description: BOBBY SHORT, who packed the 92d Street Y on Monday for one of his rare recitals, exudes more of a certain kind of bonhomie than any other supper-club performer in New York. Leading his trio through a long and challenging program that included a great deal of Cole Porter, some Stephen Sondheim and some little-known songs from the heyday of black vaudeville, Mr. Short was grace and cordiality incarnate.

title: U.S. SUES ON PENTAGON LAUNDRY BILLS
description: The Justice Department sued two executives and their Florida company today on charges of defrauding the Pentagon on laundry contracts.

title: Article 245650 -- No Title
description: Americans contributed more than $74.25 billion to philanthropic causes last year, an annual record, it was reported yesterday.

A Big Man Makes Rounds
description: There is still nothing in writing, even at this late date, but barring a late and extraordinary change of heart, Marco Baldi is headed for St. John's.

title: EXPERIMENTAL PLAN SET AT EAST HARLEM SCHOOL
description: When Deborah Meier, principal of Public School 171 in Manhattan, read Theodore R. Sizer's ''Horace's Compromise: The Dilemma of the American High School,'' she was so impressed she decided to call Dr. Sizer to let him know.

title: OILERS CLINCH SERIES AS KURRI SCORES 4
description: The highest scoring playoff series in National Hockey League history, which not long ago was an unpredictable struggle between Edmonton and Chicago to reach the Stanley Cup final, was transformed tonight into Jari Kurri's stage.

title: PEC ISRAEL ECONOMIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago revenue figure is reclassified. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 8, 1985.

title: THE BEAT PICKS UP IN JAZZ AND FOLK
description: ALONG with tulips and azaleas and the greening of Central Park, mid-spring in New York traditionally brings with it the quickening of a pop-jazz scene. This weekend, the wealth of talent representing a variety of musical fronts, in both clubs and concert halls, offers unusually rich pickings for devotees of folk music and mainstream jazz.

title: AUCTIONS
description: MOST of what is left of Jack and Belle Linsky's vast holdings in porcelains, paintings, bronzes, jewelry and furniture - perhaps $2 million worth - will be auctioned at Sotheby's next week. The Linskys, who both came to this country from Russia as children, made their fortune in a stationery business that included Swingline, the manufacturer of staplers. They collected for more than four decades, until Mr. Linsky died in 1980. Then Mrs. Linsky decided to donate most of the collection - about $60 million worth - to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where it went on view in its own galleries a year ago.

CALIFORNIAN INDICTED IN EXPORT OF TRIGGERS TO ISRAEL
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a California businessman today on charges of illegally exporting to Israel over a period of three years 800 devices that can be used to trigger nuclear weapons.

title: Salvadoran Judge Slain
description: Three young men shot and killed a 51-year-old Salvadoran military judge, Jose Rodolfo Araujo, as he was leaving his daughter off at school here today, the police said. The police said they suspected left-wing guerrillas.

title: U.S. Cites Warning to Iran
description: A senior State Department official said today that Iran ''is on notice'' that it will suffer consequences, including possible military attack, if any of the Americans being held hostage in Lebanon are executed.

title: Clubs Claim Huge Losses
description: The 26 major league baseball clubs lost perhaps as much as $42 million last season, Lee MacPhail, president of the Players Relations Committee, said yesterday. MacPhail released the loss figures in support of the owners' contention in their labor negotiations with the players that they have severe financial problems.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES CLERGY MALPRACTICE SUIT ON COAST
description: A $1 million clerical malpractice lawsuit stemming from a suicide was dismissed today by a judge who said the case was groundless and might have had a chilling effect on religious freedom.

title: U.S. Facing Steel Loan Bill
description: The Federal Government is facing an $85 million bill for loans it guaranteed to the ailing Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation as part of a Carter Administration aid program, a spokesman for the Economic Development Administration said today.

title: U.N. AIDE IS FREED BY BEIRUT CAPTORS
description: A United Nations official was freed unharmed tonight, 36 hours after he was kidnapped by gunmen in Moslem West Beirut, officials said.

title: BUCHANAN SEES POLITICAL GAIN FOR G.O.P. IN REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: The White House communications director, Patrick J. Buchanan, predicted today that President Reagan's planned tax overhaul, if adopted, would alter the nation's political landscape and align middle- and working-class families with the conservative movement.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring writedown of $8.8 million for the quarter and 9 months on certain heloicopter facilities and unconsolidated aviation subsidiaries.

title: SCREEN: 'SMORGASBORD' OPENS
description: JERRY LEWIS'S ''Smorgasbord'' is aptly titled, being a mostly cold buffet of random Lewis routines in which the director-star falls off slippery furniture, cracks up automobiles, fails at suicide and can't even walk across the floor of his psychiatrist's office without taking a header.

title: On Soldiers Who Die In the Wrong Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: BROADWAY
description: THE full name of the new musical is ''13 Days to Broadway (Formerly 10 Days to Broadway),'' but Russell Baker, who wrote the book, said, ''I assume it'll never get to Broadway.'' Mr. Baker, a columnist for The New York Times and the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of ''Growing Up,'' has always had a despairing view of life. That's perfect for a musical spoof about a flop to end all flops, particularly when it was inspired by his own experience as the writer of a musical that expired in Toronto on the way to Broadway six years ago.

title: DOCUMENTARY ON NEW 'WEST SIDE STORY' ALBUM
description: THE album is released and now, dovetailing neatly with the publicity and the generally favorable reviews, television has a documentary on how it was made. ''Bernstein Conducts 'West Side Story,' '' produced by the BBC in association with Video Music Productions and Unitel, Munich, can be seen at 9 o'clock this evening on WNET/ Channel 13. It is a judiciously edited but intriguing, and sometimes amusing, glimpse of artistic temperaments at work. The star, at all times, is Leonard Bernstein.

title: MUSIC: A NEW GREEK WORK
description: THE METROPOLITAN GREEK CHORALE, an organization devoted to commissioning and performing classical, folk, sacred and popular Greek works, celebrated its 20th anniversary at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night with the world premiere of ''Saviors,'' a new ''Cantata Fantasmagorica'' by the troupe's music director, George Tsontakis.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including a gain of $118 million resulting from a tax law change that eliminated the tax liability on certain earnings of the company's domestic international sales corporation.

description: The jazz pianist Ahmad Jamal will appear through Sunday at Lush Life, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (228-3788). Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 8:30 and 10:30 P.M. Sunday. There is a $12.50 cover ($10 Sunday) and $6 minimum.

title: CANADIAN BATTLE RAGES OVER LOVELY TIMBERED ISLE
description: The fog-shrouded rain forests of Meares Island climb 2,600 feet from the cold waters of Canada's Pacific coast.

title: MET YIELD TWO HITS BUT LOSE
description: For the second time in four games, the Mets were shut out tonight by 1-0, and it happened in a painful way: They got five hits off Mike Scott while the Houston Astros were getting only two off Sid Fernandez and Tom Gorman.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is difficult enough to raise children in New York City, and for the very people charged with educating and protecting them to be involved with drugs is a disgrace.'' - District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan. [B2:6.]

title: STANDARD BRED PACERS & TROTTERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $145,000 for the latest first quarter and $85,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: A SENSE OF TIMING HELPS AN EAST 75TH ST. BUILDER
description: Jeffrey Katz learned a painful lesson about timing a few years ago. Mr. Katz, a 38-year-old real estate developer who is now completing his first large construction project in Manhattan, had converted an old garage in Greenwich Village to condominium apartments.

title: John H. Backer, 82, Historian; Wrote on Postwar Germany
description: John H. Backer, a historian and former Government official who wrote extensively on the postwar period in Germany, died Wednesday in Arlington, Va., following surgery. He was 82 years old and lived in Washington.

title: DOW ADVANCES BY 4.53, to 1,278.05
description: The stock market continued its interest rate-induced climb yesterday, with the rally broadening into secondary stocks but continuing to bypass many of the blue-chip issues.

title: SCREEN: AUSTRALIA'S 'SILVER CITY'
description: ''SILVER CITY,'' which opens at the Cinema Village today, addresses a little-known chapter in Australian history, the arrival in the late 1940's of a large group of immigrant workers. The film concerns Australia's Polish community, circa 1947, and was directed by Sophia Turkiewicz, who lived with her mother in a hostel like those depicted in the film. But Miss Turkiewicz adopts neither a documentary style nor a quality of personal remembrance in describing the immigrants and their experience. Instead, and rather surprisingly, her film works as a kind of well-bred soap opera.

title: DECOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results are restated to reflect deferred income of $50,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $169,000, or 6 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: MANHATTAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $537,000 for the latest first quarter and $32,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a gain of $732,849 from the sale of property.

Final Evidence Given In G.M. X-Car Case
description: Lawyers for the General Motors Corporation and the Government hauled their final boxes and binders of evidence into Federal District Court today and officially rested their cases in the 14-month-old trial of charges that G.M.'s 1980 X-cars have unsafe brakes.

title: SILVER STATE MINING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COLIN MACLAREN, SCOT, SOLDIER AND REPORTER FOR THE TIMES
description: Colin Shaw Maclaren, a Scottish Highlander whose career took him from fighting Afghan tribesmen on British India's Northwest Frontier to 38 years as a reporter for The New York Times, died Wednesday at the Booth Memorial Medical Center in Flushing, Queens. He was 86 years old and lived in Flushing.

title: SPIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: A headline yesterday with a Washington dispatch about the Senate's approval of a foreign aid bill misstated the amount of aid. It is $12.8 billion.

title: HOLMES SPARRING IN RENO COURTROOM
description: The woman with the subpoena for Larry Holmes carried a picture of the heavyweight champion, to make sure she could identify him. After serving the subpoena, she asked Holmes to autograph the picture for her son.

title: STUDY SHOWS RISE IN LANDLORDS' COSTS IS EASING
description: The cost of operating rent-stabilized apartment buildings in New York City rose by 5.4 percent in the past year, slightly less than the increase calculated for the year before, according to a study presented yesterday to the city's Rent Guidelines Board.

title: COMPUTER MICROFILM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CAGE'S 'FOUR WALLS' Antedating the Minimalist movement of the 1960's by two decades, John Cage originally wrote ''Four Walls,'' a dance and music drama, for Merce Cunningham in 1944. Embodying Cage's innovative principles of silence, repetition and processes of gradual change, the piece reflects the composer's preoccupation with disturbances of the mind at a turning point in his life, shortly before he discovered Asian philosophy and Zen Buddhism. Tonight the Asia Society will present the New York premiere of ''Four Walls,'' with new choreography by Sin Cha Hong, the Korean dancer and founder of the Laughing Stone Dance Theater Company. Also featured will be Margaret Leng Tan, one of Asia's leading pianists, and Andrea Goodman, an original member of Meredith Monk's Vocal Ensemble. The performance is at 8 P.M. in the auditorium at 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. Tickets are $20. Information: 288-6400.

title: AMERICAN HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company converted from a non-profit to a for profit corporation in February 1984. Hence there were no comparable year-ago share earnings.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Net income for the latest quarter and 9 months was increased by $5,000,000, or 15 cents a share, due to a previously announced $47,000,000 gain representing the proceeds from the consummation of an exchange insurance program established with the Argentine Central Bank in October 1982. This gain was partially offset by the company's provison for the restructuring of selected domestic and international operations and the writedown of certain assets to net realizable amounts. The after-tax impact of the writedown was $42,000,000.

title: Signal Chief's Mergers Work for Shareholders
description: Forrest N. Shumway, chairman and chief executive of the Signal Companies, says the Allied Corporation's proposed $5 billion acquisition of his company is ''a natural get-together.''

title: A KING'S RANSOM IN GOLD AT THE MET
description: AROUND 100 years ago, two men of mature years were making the Grand Tour of European houses. Decoration in those days often ran amok in the area of ostentation, and after a long evening somewhere in Central Europe one of the two travelers said to the other, ''That house was really too much.'' ''Not for me,'' the other replied. ''I can stand a great deal of gold.''

title: COUSINS HOME FURNISHINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Dotson Denied Early Hearing
description: The Illinois Supreme Court today denied Gary Dotson's request that it hear his appeal of a lower court ruling upholding his conviction for the rape of a woman who now says she was not attacked. As a result, his appeal of a ruling on April 11 by Judge Richard Samuels of Cook County Circuit Court will be heard first in an intermediate appellate court.

title: How to Reduce World Fertility
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * BellSouth Corp., Atlanta, said customers of Southern Bell and South Central Bell would be sent a ballot listing all the long-distance companies in their area so they can sign up for service by simply marking their choice.

title: APRIL STARTS OF HOUSING UP BY 1.6%
description: Housing construction begun in April climbed to its highest level in a year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: ART: HANS HAAKE SHOW AT JOHN WEBER GALLERY
description: HANS HAACKE is at it again, examining irreconcilable truths. And they must be truths, for the artist never seems to have been hauled into court for his efforts. On the other hand, he hasn't gone unchallenged either, as when his 1971 exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum was canceled lest it offend New York real-estate interests. Presumably the artist did what he usually does, which is to examine the patterns in corporate activities by means of facts and figures already published. In any case, Ada Louise Huxtable, then architecture critic of The New York Times, saw one of the banned works in another show and pronounced it ''a marvelous black real-estate joke, deadly serious like all good black jokes.''

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company said that comparable year-ago results are not meaningful because the company was merged with First Global Inc. and acquired control of TransOhio Financial Corp last July.

title: MUSIC: CHRISTOPHER O'RILEY
description: Christopher O'Riley is one of the few pianists appearing before the public today who senses that conventional piano recital programs can seem pretty dreary to regular concertgoers. Appearing at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night, he broke from tradition by presenting largely familiar works in unfamiliar order with the most refreshing results.

title: INFOVIEW INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company was in the research and development stage last year and had no revenue.

title: DIXON TICONDEROGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $387,146 for the quarter and $483,477 for the 6 months. Results for the latest periods include income of $574,356, or 50 cents a share, from the sale of a Jersey City office building. Year-ago periods include income of $1,269,026, or $1.11, from the sale of Jersy City factory buildings.

title: A 'Monstrosity' Is Set to Open To Public Tours
description: If the Georgian architecture of the White House suggests the gleaming idealism of the nation, the neighboring mass of Victorian wiles and granite known as the Old Executive Office Building projects the Republic's flamboyant, mongrel heart.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: TEXAS REACHES ACCORD TO END PRISON DISPUTE
description: The State of Texas today signed an agreement that it said was aimed at ending the bitter 13-year legal battle waged against it by the state's 37,700 prison inmates.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SLAYING SUSPECT RECALLED CRIME, DETECTIVE SAYS
description: A police detective testified yesterday that the man accused in the killing of a 23-year-old drama student last year said he killed her when she refused to submit to his sexual advances.

title: Walk in the Village
description: The 20 blocks around the novelist Edith Wharton's home at 14 West 23d Street will be the focus of a walking tour sponsored by the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation on Sunday at 1 P.M. The tour, which will encompass Greenwich Village, Gramercy Park and Madison Square, will highlight points of interest in the author's life and work.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a writedown of $2,300,000 on the company's investment in an affiliated real estate company, and a profit of $1,500,000 from crude oil sales from its overseas oil interests that were sold this month. c-Net income.

title: Jackson Is a Witness For Ex-Campaign Chief
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson testified today that he trusted and respected his former campaign manager, who is standing trial on charges that he had an unlawful interest in a public contract.

title: THE RUMORS ABOUT HILTON
description: WHY, investors on Wall Street are asking themselves, has the stock of the Hilton Hotels Corporation been rising steadily in the last few days when the casino and lodging company seems to have successfully fought off the unwelcome advances of Stephen A. Wynn and his Golden Nugget?

title: Transactions
description: WEDNESDAY BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Called up Bryan Clark, left-handed pitcher, from Maine affiliate and sent down Jerry Willard, catcher, to Maine.

title: Topics;   All in the Family Budget Priorities
description: The cutting of Federal spending is much in the news, but so far there hasn't been a word about budget cuts for a significant Federal expenditure: Congress. Why? Because -surprise, surprise - there's been no cut.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $448,000 and a gain of $69,319 from income from a non-consolidated subsidiary. c-After a charge of $1,399,044 from the retirement of convertible debt, a tax credit of $362,200, and income of $920,350 from discontinued operations.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day on Monday listing companies' quarterly sales and profits misstated the percentage drop in sales for Pitney Bowes Inc. It was 2 percent, from the first quarter of 1984.

title: The Taste of Congressional Fudge
description: Some 68 million Americans consume diet soda and other low-calorie products. In place of sugar those foods contain saccharin or aspartame, artificial chemicals that tickle the sense of sweetness. Shadows lie over both substances. It's far from proved that they really help people lose weight. And despite years of tests, doubts remain as to whether either is wholly safe.

title: Hush Puppies Review
description: The Hush Puppies Footwear division of Wolverine World Wide Inc. announced plans to review ad agencies. The current agency - Wells, Rich, Greene/New York - is among the list of candidates under consideration. Neither the names of the agencies nor the media billings were disclosed.

title: ARBITRATION FOR TEACHERS AND CITY
description: After more than nine months of bargaining, the city and its teachers union have agreed to submit their dispute to binding arbitration under the so-called last-offer procedure.

title: HUNT IS WIDENED FOR TWO KILLERS AFTER ESCAPE FROM CHICAGO PRISON
description: A nationwide hunt was under way today for two convicted killers who escaped from a Federal prison here Tuesday night.

title: PHILADELPHIA NAVY YARD AGAIN STAVES OFF KNIFE
description: Senator Arlen Specter's letter in late February to John F. Lehman Jr., the Secretary of the Navy, was unabashedly blunt. Mr. Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican who faces re-election in 1986, said he was ''very much concerned'' about reports that the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard could lose almost 3,000 jobs in personnel cutbacks.

title: HOW TO CUT DEFENSE COSTS
description: After four years, President Reagan's defense buildup has been halted by a recalcitrant, divided Congress. The Senate has decreed that increases in military spending should not exceed the inflation rate, and the House may be even more harsh. Meanwhile, revelations of abuses by defense contractors, most recently General Electric, have added to the Pentagon's woes. What all of this means is that the Pentagon will be under increasing pressure to squeeze more out of each taxpayer's dollar.

title: G.M. Rehirings
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would recall 1,500 hourly workers from indefinite layoff, effective Monday, to handle increased production at vehicle-assembly and components-manufacturing plants. The auto maker said the callback leaves 18,500 workers on indefinite layoff with rehire rights.

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Hairy Eagle
description: ''He doesn't look bald to me,'' observed Michael Steinhaus. ''He has hair on his head.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, MAY 17, 1985

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IN its 25 years of exemplary service, Lutece has become something of a culinary cathedral to New Yorkers and visitors from around the world - indeed, the name itself is a metaphor for superior dining. Carrying such a burden is a mixed blessing. As with a great painting or sculpture, a legendary restaurant must continually satisfy inflated expectations of the public, many of whom come with magnifying glasses, searching for imperfections.

title: MEXICAN GOLFER GIVING THE TOUR HER BEST SHOT
description: Guillermina Rodriguez-Hardin never thought 10 years ago that she would become the first native of Mexico to play on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour. When she was in her early teens she could not understand why her mother and father spent so much time playing the game she called ''a disease.''

title: 'White-Collar' Crime Hearing
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee said today that it would hold hearings on the Justice Department's handling of ''financially sophisticated white-collar crime,'' including the recent prosecution of E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: Psychologist Held On Sexual Charges
description: A psychologist who had been employed by Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens Village was arrested yesterday and charged with sexual misconduct with patients, the police said.

title: FILM: FROM SHINODA, 'MACARTHUR'S CHILDREN'
description: MASAHIRO SHINODA'S ''MacArthur's Children,'' which opens today at the Cinema Studio, is an extremely peculiar film about the United States occupation of Japan, as reflected in the experiences of the citizens on one small, ideally pretty island in the Inland Sea. The people of Awaji haven't been fire-bombed into submission. The island hasn't been physically damaged, though everyone has suffered emotional losses.

title: Wallace Spurns Request For Extradition to Texas
description: A disabled man wanted by the Texas authorities for leaving that state in violation of his probation got a chance at a new life Wednesday when Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama blocked his extradition to Dallas.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from debt restructuring of $15,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss The latest quarter also includes a writedown of certain drilling rigs of $8.5 million.

CANOEISTS TO STUDY IN CLASS, ON WATER
description: Brooklyn's Metropolitan Canoe and Kayak Club is offering a series of basic river canoeing courses this year, the next beginning with a classroom session on May 29, followed by a weekend visit (June 1-2) to Lake Sebago in Harriman State Park.

title: EARTHWORM TRACTOR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect 10 percent stock dividend in January.

title: Intermountain Power Refinancing 2 Issues
description: The Intermountain Power Agency, a Utah organization that is constructing two coal-fired plants to supply electricity to southern California, is offering about $250.7 million worth of bonds to refinance 11 3/4 and 11 7/8 percent bonds it sold in 1981.

title: Adjustable Rate On New Preferred
description: Morgan Stanley & Company said that it had priced a new preferred stock issue for Dollar Finance Inc.
