MARYLAND'S UNFLAPPABLE CHIEF
description: When guards at the Maryland penitentiary staged a sickout last October to protest a colleague's being stabbed to death, Gov. Harry R. Hughes thought long and hard about how to respond.

title: 17 in Health Care Named In Coast Drug Case
description: Seventeen people, including local physicians, pharmacy owners and clinic operators, were indicted today on charges of illegally dispensing prescription drugs, according to Robert Bonner, the United States Attorney here.

title: U.S. WARNS 90 EXHIBITORS ABOUT TERRORIST THREAT AT PARIS AIR SHOW
description: The United States Embassy in Paris has warned the Commerce Department and American companies planning exhibits at the Paris air show late this month to expect terrorist attacks.

title: Arizona Rock
description: The Meat Puppets, a rock group from Arizona, will perform tomorrow at 1:30 A.M. at the Peppermint Lounge, 100 Fifth Avenue, at 15th Street (989-9505). The rock band Hope will open the show at 11:30 P.M. Tickets are $7 before 11 P.M., $11 afterward.

title: THE DANCE: DAVID GORDON COMPANY
description: DAVID GORDON is an experimental modern-dance choreographer whose work is increasingly seen in ballet companies. Three new works danced by his own troupe, the David Gordon/Pick Up Company, suggests he can best be understood as an avant-gardist of the 1960's who has systematized his work for the 1980's.

title: Agony or Ecstasy?
description: Chanting ''You can't erase original sin'' and ''God is already clean,'' more than 50 students and teachers from the Art Students League demonstrated yesterday in front of the Italian Consulate, at 69th Street and Park Avenue.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK WORCESTER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
YANKS STAGE ANOTHER COMEBACK
description: Something has taken hold of the Yankees. Maybe it's their natural talent shining through. Maybe their opponents are giving them their way. Or possibly - and this is a theory not all Yankees like to hear - Billy Martin really is making a difference.

title: SUNRISE SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (LALK WORTH, FLA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. c-After a charge of $1,532,000 from the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in the method of recognizing certain loan fees.

title: Erroneous Report of Death Of Nazi Doctor Traced to '46
description: An American prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials reported Josef Mengele dead in 1946, according to the Jack Anderson column.

title: FINALCO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
O'Meara Shares Lead With a 66
description: Mark O'Meara, trying to overcome a case of jet lag after a trip to Japan, posted a 4-under-par 66 today to share the first-round lead with Willie Wood, Jim Thorpe and Corey Pavin in the $500,000 Colonial National Invitation.

title: P.S.C. SAYS LILCO'S CAPACITY WON'T MEET PEAK DEMAND
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has insufficient generating capacity to meet this summer's high power demands and will probably have to resort to unusual steps, including voltage reductions, the State Public Service Commission said today.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. The Mets, returning to Shea for a 10-game homestand, send Ron Darling out seeking his fourth victory. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. California Angels, at Anaheim, California. Phil Niekro is scheduled to start as the Yankees make their first West Coast swing. The former Yankee Reggie Jackson is playing every day in right field for California. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 10:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Chicago Cubs, at Atlanta (Television -WTBS 5:35 P.M.). Basketball Nuggets vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Denver. Game 3 of the Western Conference championship series. On Wednesday night, the Nuggets handed the Lakers their first defeat in the Forum since January 30, evening the series at 1-1. (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P.M. tape.) Boxing Mark Breland vs. Vince Dunfee, welterweights; Meldrick Taylor vs. Nery Reyes, lightweights; Tyrell Biggs vs. Grady Daniels, heavyweights; Francisco Luis Ortiz vs. Henry Lugo, lightweights, and Francesco Damiani vs. Larry Roberson, heavyweights. At Stateline, Nev., featuring five Olympic medalists in six-round co-features. Breland, still looking for his first pro knockout after three unanimous decisions, heads the card.

title: ARMY IN LEBANON DENIES BOMB LINK
description: The Lebanese Army high command denied today that its intelligence service was involved in setting off a car-bomb explosion in the southern suburbs of Beirut last March in which 80 people were killed and 200 wounded.

title: A.T.&T. Selects Olson as President
description: James E. Olson, who began his career in telecommunications by cleaning manholes and splicing cables, has been named president and chief operating officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, effective June 1.

title: KEEPING TRACK OF THE RAVIOLI
description: Last year, a quarter of a million people visited the fair on Day One, a half-million on Day Two.

title: The Kirkpatrick Ms.
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the newest star in the Republican political firmament, has made an agreement with Simon & Schuster to write a book on her personal life and her views on domestic and international politics for an advance against royalty payments of $900,000.

title: Three Deny Charges
description: E. J. (Doc) Kreis, the former Vanderbilt strength coach, and two other men, a Nashville pharmacist and his assistant, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they illegally distributed nearly 100,000 doses of steroids to athletes at Vanderbilt, Clemson and Colgate between 1982 and early this year. When the indictments were handed up in April, Kreis resigned and Vanderbilt announced mandatory random drug tests for all student-athletes. One of the defendants, M. (Woody) Wilson, the pharmacist, has said he sold steroids, which are artificial hormones used to improve strength, to as many as 50 Vanderbilt football players, 31 of whom were named as unindicted co-conspirators.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN HEALTHCARE MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Justice Dept. View on Pan Am
description: The proposed acquisition by United Airlines of the Pacific routes of Pan American World Airways could ''have an adverse effect on competition,'' the Justice Department said today.

title: Moses Is Sidelined
description: Edwin Moses, the Olympic champion and world record-holder in the 400-meter hurdles, learned yesterday that he had a sprained ligament in the right knee.

title: MUNCHER'S GUIDE TO SURVIVAL ON NINTH AVENUE
description: Anyone with an iron will and nutritional common sense can survive the Ninth Avenue Food Festival.

title: BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $676,000 frrm discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $297,000 from discontinued operations. The company said that on April 19 it signed a letter of intent to sell its film processing group to Colorcraft Corp. Results of operations of this group are included as a discontinued operation in the latest quarter.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue figures include insurance and finance revenues of $1.8 billion for the latest first quarter and $1.6 billion for the year-ago first quarter.

description: b-After interest expenses of $739,000 for the quarter and $2,615,000 for the 9 months, and special charges of $1,212,000 for the quarter and $5,245,000 for the 9 months. c-After interest expenses of $835,000 for the quarter and $2,117,000 for the 9 months, and special charges of $1,299,000 for the quarter and $1,299,000 for the 9 months.

title: HEALTHWAYS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: USE OF CAPACITY DOWN BY A SHARP 0.5% IN APRIL
description: The operating rate for American industry fell five-tenths of a percentage point last month, the steepest drop since last September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PHILADELPHIA MAYOR SAYS HE FEARS 'ATTEMPTS AT REVENGE' BY RADICALS
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode said today that ''we're far from out of the woods'' in dealing with the radical group Move, whose battle with the police Monday led to the burning of more than 50 houses.

title: S & M COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'MARVIN AND TIGE,' FINDING HAPPINESS IN ATLANTA
description: ''MARVIN AND TIGE,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, is of the piercing sweetness that causes toothaches. The film, financed and photographed in Atlanta, is about the unlikely, revivifying friendship between Marvin (John Cassavetes), an alcoholic dropout, the male equivalent of a bag lady (bag gentleman?), and Tige (Gibran Brown), a spunky, illiterate, 11-year-old black boy who lives by his wits.

title: PLAYED WICKED WITCH IN 'OZ'
description: Margaret Hamilton, the actress whose role as the cackling Wicked Witch of the West in ''The Wizard of Oz'' unnerved generations of children, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at a nursing home in Salisbury, Conn. She was 82 years old.

title: Bail Denied
description: All the swagger was gone yesterday when Denny McLain appeared before Judge Elizabeth A. Kovachevich of Federal District Court in Tampa and pleaded for freedom on bail: ''I'll do anything you want.

title: KEAN TIGHTENS LIMITS ON WATER USE IN JERSEY
description: Governor Kean declared a drought emergency throughout New Jersey today and announced additional restrictions on water use in the 93 hardest-hit communities. The cutbacks, he said, are intended to reduce consumption by 25 percent.

title: 4 SCHOOL WORKERS ARRESTED IN SALES OF DRUGS TO AGENTS
description: A teacher and three other school employees were arrested yesterday at a Manhattan public school and charged in the sales of cocaine, heroin and marijuana to undercover police officers inside and outside the school.

title: AMUSEMENT PARK OWNERS GO ON TRIAL FOR FIRE THAT KILLED 8
description: Jury selection began this week in the manslaughter trial growing out of the fire one year ago at the Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson Township, N.J., that killed eight teen-agers.

title: SEAPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BEARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOVIET, ONCE AGAIN, PROCLAIMS MEASURES AGAINST ALCOHOLISM
description: After an intensive, months-long publicity campaign against the Russian addiction to vodka, the ''green serpent,'' the Government today announced a package of stiff measures against alcohol abuse.

title: I.R.A. Party in Ulster Gains in Elections
description: The Irish Republican Army's political wing ran more strongly than expected in municipal elections, and hard-line Protestants also gained, according to projections today based on a partial vote count.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes a favorable tax adjustment of approximately $2,300,000.

title: Bomb Explodes in Peru At Home of U.S. Envoy
description: Several bombs exploded in the Peruvian capital Thursday night, one outside the United States Ambassador's residence, the police said.

title: LIBERAL PARTY, LOOKING FOR A LIFT, IS IMPROVING RELATIONS WITH KOCH
description: Ridden with dissension, virtually bankrupt and with its vote dropping, the Liberal Party is considering the endorsement of a frequent antagonist, Mayor Koch, to help it survive and remain an official party, Liberal Party officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: Woman in Pie Tossing Gets 30-Day Sentence
description: A woman convicted of breach of the peace for hiring an actor known as Tickles the Clown for a pie-in-the-face prank at her daughter's graduation was sentenced today to 30 days in jail and fined $1,000.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: RICHARD BENJAMIN'S new ''restoration comedy,'' as he describes it, is ''The Money Pit,'' currently shooting at the Astoria Studios in Queens and on the North Shore of Long Island. It's a romantic comedy about a young couple who ''buy a house that nobody should buy,'' Mr. Benjamin said.

title: Sports of The Times;   'Derby Rates, Chief'
description: According to a number of racing people, the tradition of the Triple Crown is facing its greatest menace since hoof-and-mouth disease because Dennis Diaz has succumbed to the siren call of a possible $2 million bonus from a New Jersey race track rather than run his horse, Spend a Buck, in the Preakness tomorrow.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $175,000 from the sale of securities. c-Includes a tax credit of $230,000. The company said that year-ago first quarter results have been restated to reflect the 1984 fourth quarter reversal of a portion of an income tax benefit from a tax credit. Results for the latest quarter include Artra's interest in R. N. Koch Inc. since February 8, when that company was acquired by Apeco Corp. which is 55.9 percent-owned by Artra.

title: HOW HUTTON SCHEME WORKED
description: Back in December 1981, John McMurtrie, president of the Northern Central Bank in Williamsport, Pa., had no reason to be suspicious of as prestigious a customer as E.F. Hutton & Company - that is, not until he looked hard at the bank account maintained by the local Hutton branch.

title: PILOTS STRIKE AT UNITED, WITH AIRLINE PLANNING A LIMITED SCHEDULE
description: The Air Line Pilots Association struck United Airlines shortly after midnight today in the union's first major attempt to limit efforts by the nation's airlines to pay newly hired pilots less than veteran pilots.

title: BSN Rebuffed
description: The BSN Corporation said it had made a $151 million offer to acquire the Wilson Sporting Goods Company unit from Pepsico Inc., but the offer was rejected. BSN said it was pursuing discussions on acquiring some Wilson divisions, but it had no assurance that its proposals would be accepted.

title: CARNEGIE HALL TO CLOSE FOR 7 MONTHS NEXT YEAR
description: Carnegie Hall announced yesterday a fund-raising drive for $50 million - $27 million of which has already been pledged - for the completion of the hall's renovation. It also named the developer who will build the multi-use high-rise structure on the 12,500-square-foot lot immediately east of the hall.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the year-ago quarter include a gain of $1,000,016, or 16 cents a share, on the distribution of assets. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 1-for-3 reverse stock split effective today.

title: Where Are the Birds of Yesteryear?
description: To the Editor:

title: A PHILHARMONIC BENEFIT VIENNA WOULD HAVE LOVED
description: By the time the ball master, Hans Janitschek, declared the Viennese evening in Damrosch Park over early yesterday morning, not one of the 900 footsore waltzers doubted that he or she had been part of a very special evening, perhaps the party of the spring season.

title: Let the Banks Branch Out
description: Big banks are eager to eliminate the legal barriers to branching outside their home states. Congress still hesitates out of concern for local bankers who might be hurt by the competition. The concern is misplaced. Whatever the consequences for local bankers, interstate banking is a good deal for their customers.

title: Working Profile: George P. Shultz;   No Headlines, No Fanfare: This Is Shultz
description: On the flight home from his latest inconclusive meeting in Vienna with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, Secretary of State George P. Shultz was musing about the value of such sessions.

title: Foreign Fund Warning
description: House Democrats today warned the Reagan Administration that if it did not get Republicans strongly behind a money bill for international development agencies such as the World Bank, the bill would not be passed and the United States would not meet its international commitments.

title: LACKLUSTER FIELD IN RICH PREAKNESS
description: A field of 11 3-year-olds led by Chief's Crown was entered this morning for what is at once an unusually rich and poor Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Saturday. The purse of $545,700 is the largest in the race's 110-year history, but a field that lacks the first two finishers in the Kentucky Derby and is filled with outclassed runners is one of the weakest ever.

title: CORRECTION
description: The preface to The Times Magazine's special issue about Vietnam, on March 31, misidentified the building shown in a famous photograph of the rooftop evacuation of Americans by helicopter in 1975. The site was also misidentified in a picture caption on April 30 with a Vietnam chronology. It was a Saigon apartment building, not the United States Embassy.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Lid on Knick Ticket Cost
description: Despite the heightened interest in tickets since they won the draft rights to Patrick Ewing five days ago, yesterday that they will not raise ticket prices for next season.

title: PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Our Oil Troubles Are Not About to Go Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece Will Not Let British Ship Refuel For Allied Exercise
description: The Greek Government has barred a British ship taking part in NATO exercises from refueling in Greece, a move described by NATO sources here today as ''unprecedented.'' The ship was compelled to sail on to Izmir, Turkey, to obtain fuel.

title: 2 Britons Seized On Drug Charges
description: Two Britons were being held without bail yesterday on charges of trying to smuggle seven pounds of pure heroin into the United States, officials said.

title: SALVADOR LEADER, AT WHITE HOUSE, CLAIMS WAR GAINS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador told President Reagan today that his country had achieved at least a partial turnaround in the military situation and he called for new negotiations with the leftist rebel leaders.

title: SIMPLE PLEASURES FOCUS OF CENTRAL PARK BENEFIT
description: On any weekend from spring through fall, Central Park is alive with all manner of activity, from folk dancing at King Jagiello's statue to concerts and plays and races of every sort. And each May for the last two years, the organizers of the fund-raising ''You Gotta Have Park'' have added a weekend of special events to those activities and asked visitors to donate a dollar apiece for restoration work on the park.

title: MUSIC: BACH ON ORGAN
description: ONE of the happier celebrations of Bach's tricentennial year is a complete survey of the master's organ music, currently under way at Columbia University's St. Paul's Chapel and the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village. The 16 weekly concerts, which take place Thursday evenings uptown and Sunday afternoons downtown, each with a different organist, will continue through June 30; this listener attended the second offering in the series - a Sunday afternoon program featuring John Weaver at the Church of the Ascension.

title: Bangladeshis Vote Despite Call for Boycott
description: Voters turned out in large numbers today to choose local council chairmen in 252 rural subdistricts, despite a call for a boycott by the main opposition parties, local officials said.

title: Power Shift
description: The American League East has acquired a reputation as the best division in baseball, and it's a reputation that has been built with no lack of evidence.

title: U.S.F.L. Is Suing ABC
description: The United States Football League sued ABC yesterday for the remaining $7 million of the $15.4 million ABC is scheduled to pay for televising its games this season.

title: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Cargo Equipment Corp., Rancho Dominguez, Calif., says J.R. Firestone has resigned as president and director.

title: Miami Offender Ordered Back to Santa Monica
description: A sex offender who was sent to Miami by a police chief in California was ordered returned to California today.

title: VICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: CHASE SETS CONDITIONS ON ITS OFFER TO MARYLAND
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation offered today to acquire several of Maryland's financially troubled savings and loan associations, but only if the state granted it full-service banking privileges.

title: IN ETHIOPIA, FOOD ROTS ON THE DOCKS
description: In this Red Sea port, the breeze now carries the sharp smell of rotting grain.

title: MODULAIRE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STAGE: 'CHOPIN IN SPACE' AT THE ARK
description: PHIL BOSAKOWSKI is a cunning humorist. There are enough verbal, visual and musical jokes in his ''Chopin in Space'' to keep you thinking for a long time about passion, inspiration, politics, religion, history and - since this is an affectionate tribute to the playwright's Polish origins - nationality. The play is really a tumbling procession of blackouts; it would be difficult to be funny about such subjects in any other format. And the very versatile members of the cast in the production at the Ark Theater, as they pop in and out of different characters in two centuries, do keep the laughter coming.

title: Time Inc. Circulates A Picture Week Issue
description: For those who were appalled about what the introduction of People magazine did to the class image of Time Inc., wait till they get a look at Picture Week, a new test entry, 3,000 copies of which have been printed to get reaction from the advertising community.

title: PARKWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEISMIC ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Josephine Miles Dies; A Poet and Professor
description: Josephine Miles, a poet and member of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, died Sunday at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 73 years old.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Tandon Layoffs
description: Tandon Corporation, responding to competitive pressure in the microcomputer industry, said it plans to phase out one plant and reduce staff at two others. Over the next six to eight weeks it will phase out operations at a circuit board plant in Simi Valley, Calif., and lay off 250 employees. A total of 120 employees will be laid off on Friday at another Simi Valley plant and one in Chatsworth.

title: WHO'S AFRAID OF WHAT?
description: A group of neo-conservative intellectuals recently gathered in Washington to examine the question whether there is a sort of ''moral equivalence'' between the United States and the Soviet Union. Not unexpectedly, speaker after speaker denounced the notion that there is no moral difference between the two superpowers.

title: VOLLEYBALL MAGIC OF 'MR. C': 172 STRAIGHT VICTORIES
description: Nine years ago, when Columbia High School here needed another girls' sport to satisfy Federal requirements, Eugene Chyzowych, the gym teacher, was called on to coach volleyball.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTAS ARE CURBED
description: Honduran Army officers said today that the Government had ordered the United States-backed Nicaraguan rebels to abandon three base camps near the Nicaraguan border and to resettle elsewhere.

title: L.I. STUDENTS APPLAUD CUOMO'S BANTER
description: The loudest applause came when Governor Cuomo announced that he was dismissing school for the day.

title: GUEST SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BEHIND MILITARY BUDGET RISES: POLITICAL AIMS OF LAWMAKERS
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo recalls visiting the headquarters of the Rockwell International Corporation, the prime contractor for the B-1 bomber. There he saw a map of the nation, with strings radiating from the plant to every subcontractor building a part of the bomber. The strings covered the entire map.

title: OAK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $5,457,000 from discontinued operations.

title: 'Beaning' Is Suspected
description: The police in Trumbull, Conn., said they are investigating an accusation that a high school pitcher purposely struck a batter in the head with a pitched ball. David Greene, a catcher for Fairfield Prep, was struck by Steve DeBartolomeo of St. Joseph in the sixth inning of a game Monday.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jordan Top Rookie
description: Michael Jordan, the former University of North Carolina star who transformed the Chicago Bulls into a playoff team, has been selected by a panel of 78 sportswriters and broadcasters as the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year. Jordan, named last year's college player of the year but only the third player selected in the 1984 draft, drew 57 1/2 votes to 20 1/2 for Akeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets, last year's top draft choice out of the University of Houston, who was the only other rookie to receive votes.

title: FOR BIGGS, DURGS WERE THE TOUGHEST FIGHT
description: Tyrell Biggs, very much at ease talking about his five-month trip from Olympic heavyweight boxing champion to rehabilitation center for drugs and alcohol, looked at the collection of beer bottles on the table in front of him and tapped one.

title: PHILANTHROPY: WOMEN APPEAL
description: Women working in the field of philanthropy are campaigning to improve their situations and to get more grant money to organizations for women and girls.

title: Jackie Curtis, 38, Performer And Writer for Warhol Films
description: Jackie Curtis, a playwright, director and performer, died of a drug overdose Wednesday, according to the New York City Medical Examiner's office. He was 38 years old.

title: Judge Refuses Bail For Brink's Figure
description: A judge yesterday ordered Marilyn Jean Buck to be held without bail on Federal charges involving the 1981 Brink's robbery in Rockland County.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MISSION INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a realized investment gain of $951,000 and a pretax gain of $37.5 million from the loss portfolio transfer which was a part of transactions with American Financial Corp. c-Net loss after a realized investment loss of $775,000.

title: PENSION INSURANCE GROUP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NINTH AVENUE, THE GORUMET'S SUPER BOWL
description: THE Ninth Avenue International Festival of Food, New York's annual two-day celebration of the gastronomic diversity of the neighborhood and the city, swings into action at 11 A.M. tomorrow when the broad thoroughfare becomes a teeming food market for almost every ethnic group that has ever passed through this town.

title: Reagan Gift List: Dog and Gun
description: President Reagan accepted gifts last year that included a pistol, a chain saw, two riding crops, four hearing aids and a black sheep dog named Lucky valued at $400, according to a financial disclosure form released today.

title: STAGE: 'BETTE AND BOO' BY DURANG AT THE PUBLIC
description: CHRISTOPHER DURANG'S comedy, ''The Marriage of Bette and Boo,'' is so speedy and chipper that it could almost be mistaken for a Bob Fosse musical. The large cast is always on the run, scurrying frantically among the fast-sliding crimson panels of Loren Sherman's sleek set to perform 33 scenes in two hours. Most of those scenes contain jokes; a few contain songs; all of them, as impeccably directed by Jerry Zaks, boast a choreographic pizazz. Throw in the bright lighting (by Paul Gallo) and the high comic sheen of the performances, and ''Bette and Boo'' looks like pure cheer.

title: Reading of Whitman
description: To celebrate Walt Whitman's 166th birthday, which falls on May 31, the Aching Rivers Theater Company will present a free reading of ''Specimen Days'' tomorrow, from noon to 10 P.M., at the First Unitarian Church, 108 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn Heights. More than 25 readers are expected to participate. Information: 581-6470.

title: MEREDITH MONK, TWO DECADES LATER
description: After 20 years of writing, choreographing, composing, directing, filming, dancing and singing, in multimedia performances with from one to 85 people, Meredith Monk has taken 1984-85 as a season to look back.

title: 2 Accounts Lost At Ally & Gargano
description: Ally & Gargano has lost two accounts, and no explanations were given.

title: RADICAL GROUP'S HOMES UNDER WATCH
description: Two teams of police officers sat in cars outside a barricaded house on 56th Street here this afternoon, taking notes on activity in the neighborhood of neat brick row houses.

title: ACCOUNTING OFFICE REPORTS CHEMICAL WAR DEFENSES INADEQUATE
description: Defensive measures against chemical warfare attack now available to the Army, Navy and Air Force are seriously deficient, according to a new study by the General Accounting Office.

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $29,146,609 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: CONGRESS VOTES TO END RULE ON CAR RECORDS
description: The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a bill repealing a law that requires keeping daily records on the use of tax-deductible vehicles and home computers. Businessmen and farmers had assailed the rule as useless Government intervention.

title: Altered State
description: Unlike a number of other pro football players, Robin Cole, the Steeler linebacker, says he has never tried steroid use, for fear of the side effects. Now, in light of the massive quantities that Steve Courson, a Pittsburgh teammate, acknowledged taking in a recent article for Sports Illustrated magazine, Cole believes he has evidence: ''It might even be affecting their brains.''

title: Save Social Security From an I.R.S. Fate
description: To the Editor:

VINTAGE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30

title: Fairs and Festivals This Weekend
description: Ninth Annual Ukrainian Festival, East Seventh Street, between Second and Third Avenues. Today, from 4 to 11 P.M.; tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 11 P.M.; Sunday, 1 to 10 P.M, rain or shine. Entertainment, arts and crafts, homemade food. Sponsored by St. George's Ukrainian Catholic Church, which will benefit from the proceeds. Information: 674-1615. Ye Olde Village Fair, Barrow and Commerce Street, between Seventh Avenue South and Hudson Street; Bedford Street, between Morton and Christopher Streets, tomorrow, noon to 10:30 P.M. Arts and crafts, clothing, jewelry, entertainment, raffle, food. Raindate: Sunday. Sponsored by the Bedford-Barrow-Commerce Block Association. Proceeds will benefit the community. Information: 675-4264 or 924-6065.

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $22,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss which is after an extraordinary tax charge of $24,000. d-Includes a tax credit of $20,000.

title: Largest Farm Project In Ethiopia Is Halting
description: The largest development project in Ethiopia is grinding to a halt because the food used to pay workers has been held up in port and at warehouses, a senior official of the world food program said.

title: Treasury Bonds Make Another Sizable Gain
description: Treasury bond futures posted their second significant advance of the week today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Economic Scene;   The Struggling Steel Industry
description: IN 1982, the American steel industry stumbled into quicksand. After having one of its best years ever in 1981, the industry lost $3.4 billion in 1982 as shipments plunged 30 percent. And the losses continued in the next two years.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $5,946,000. c-After a capital loss of $1,527,000.

title: LAURENTIAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOUGHTIE'S FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: U.S.-SOVIET HESITATIONS
description: There's little doubt that the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, intends to visit the United Nations in New York this fall. And it's hardly likely that he would go to the United States without meeting President Reagan.

title: Bradford Trust
description: The Bradford Trust Company, a New York financial institution, denied that the bank is ''the specific target'' of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: THE NIGERIAN EXODUS: OLD RIVALRIES EMERGE
description: Thousands of Ghanaians expelled from Nigeria are coming home to a country that is of two minds about their return. They face an economic landscape offering the most fragile hope that they may not have to leave again in search of the good life.

title: Thai Troops Force Vietnamese Soldiers Out
description: Thai soldiers drove intruding Vietnamese soldiers back into Cambodia today in intense fighting along Thailand's southeastern border, military officials said.

title: VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Premiere of Anthem
description: Lee Hoiby's new anthem ''The Lord is King'' will have its first performance at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 3 P.M. tomorrow.

title: TEECO PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the results between the two periods are not comparable since the partnership's principal object is to sell or otherwise dispose of its assets and distribute the proceeds to its unit holders.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: BUTZI MOFFITT couldn't have been happier. ''Look at them, aren't they smashing?'' she asked Chiqui Woolworth, pointing to the peonies, lilies, lilacs and decorative white birds in the Terrace Room and Grand Ballroom of the Plaza, where the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center held a black-tie dinner-dance Tuesday.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS DEMOCRATS' PLAN FOR 1986 BUDGET
description: The House Budget Committee today approved a 1986 budget plan that could create a major confrontation with the Senate and the Administration over the military budget and cost-of-living increases for Social Security.

title: Potter Advances
description: Barbara Potter of the United States outlasted Lea Antonoplis, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, tonight to reach the quarterfinals of the $110,000 National Technics Women's Indoor Tennis Championship.

title: PRICES ON BONDS MOVE UP
description: Bond traders shrugged off disappointing economic news yesterday and pushed prices higher.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JAZZ: DIRTY DOZEN BRASS BAND
description: WITH the Dirty Dozen Brass Band on its stand, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, is jumping with rhythm this week through Sunday as it rarely has before. The Dirty Dozen, an eight-man group from New Orleans (its name comes from the Dirty Dozen Social and Pleasure Club, whose members originated the band in 1977) made its New York debut last July at the Kool Jazz Festival and drew such an enthusiastic response that it was quickly booked into Tramps and the Village Gate.

title: SCREEN: 'RETURN TO WATERLOO'
description: ''RETURN TO WATERLOO'' is a slender but assured 58-minute film by Ray Davies of the Kinks, who with that venerable rock band has for 20 years been writing and singing about the matters he now addresses on film. Closely akin to several rock opera albums of the Kinks, ''Return to Waterloo'' uses the added visual dimension to contribute dancing commuters, singing schoolboys and cartoonish businessmen to Mr. Davies's familiar portrait of suburban malaise.

title: Unocal Hearing In Delaware Court
description: A Delaware Supreme Court panel heard two hours of arguments today and promised a decision Friday on an attempt by the Unocal Corporation to exclude T. Boone Pickens and his partners from the company's repurchase of 29 percent of its stock at a premium price.

title: REAGAN TAX PLAN SEEN AS MIXTURE OF POLICY CHANGES AND LOOPHOLES
description: One day after the disclosure of its main elements, President Reagan's tax revision plan drew mixed reviews from members of Congress, tax reformers and interest groups here.

title: SEA CONTAINERS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss by Sealink U.K., acquired in July 1984, of $19,278,000. c-Net income including a gain of $6,387,000 from the sale of container assets. Revenues for the latest first quarter include revenue from Sealink U.K. of $49,684,000.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SYNTECH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VALENTINE PICKED AS TEXAS MANAGER
description: Bobby Valentine, the third-base coach for the Mets for the last two years, said tonight that he had accepted the job of manager of the Texas Rangers.

title: FLUTIE FACING BIG TEST
description: Doug Flutie has been contributing to the success of the Generals more with his quick feet than his passing arm, somewhat to his chagrin. In the next game, on Sunday in Denver against the Gold, he will have to make his mark as a passer rather than a runner, and he welcomes the opportunity.

title: ART: EXHIBIT OF 'SIGNS' AT THE NEW MUSEUM
description: SIGNS'' is concerned with word messages, punctuation marks, billboards, road markers and other familiar means of visual communication. The larger subject of the show, at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, south of Houston Street, through July 7, is communication itself. Each artist takes visual signs, detaches them from their familiar contexts, dissects them, shakes them around, rearranges them and, in some instances, tries to mold them into building blocks for something new.

title: The Anderson Fracture
description: John B. Anderson, the former Congressman and 1980 Presidential candidate, got some firsthand experience with the crime issue this week. About 4:30 A.M. Sunday, he was awakened by his dog barking and found a burglar downstairs in his dining room.

title: James da Schlesinger
description: Over rolls and coffee at Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies yesterday morning, James R. Schlesinger was introduced as ''the Leonardo da Vinci of Washington,'' reflecting his far-ranging leadership in the past at the Defense Department, the Atomic Energy Commission, the Department of Energy and the Central Intelligence Agency.

description: b-Net loss.

Bol May Turn Pro
description: Manute Bol, the 7-6 center from the Sudan who led the University of Bridgeport to a New England Collegiate Conference championship as a freshman last season, may be on the verge of signing with the Rhode Island Gulls of the new United States Basketball League.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TopicsAll in the Family;   Sibling Conflict
description: In the heart of every habitue of garage sales there beats the hope of treasure hidden somewhere among the saucerless cups and cupless saucers. But when a treasure tagged at $5 showed up in Muskegon, Mich., in 1982, no one recognized it.

title: Strong Words at Greenbrier
description: Top advertising agency executives, grown accustomed to such once-unheard-of practices as speculative presentations, farming out their media-buying chores and comparative advertising, were pulled up short today by the president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, who characterized those activities as ''malignancies which are attacking the agency body.''

title: POPE CELEBRATES FEAST IN BRUSSELS
description: Pope John Paul II celebrated the feast of the ascension of Jesus into heaven before cheering crowds here and in Luxembourg, and declared that Christians ''made idols of earthly realities'' by accepting secular values.

title: INDUSTRY HAILS TAX PROPOSAL
description: Business representatives applauded President Reagan's tax plan yesterday, a day after it became known that the President favored lower capital gains tax rates, among other changes.

title: WESTERN MICROWAVE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nuclear Commission Votes To Close Talks to the Public
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3 to 2 today to change its rules so that staff briefings and discussions could be held in secret.

title: RECITAL: ARRAU AT FISHER HALL
description: CLAUDIO ARRAU, as many recent accounts attest, can make it seem as though time has stood still for him. That the 82-year-old pianist did not do so in his Monday night recital at Avery Fisher Hall may be ascribable in part to the grueling demands of his program; he chose Beethoven's ''Adieux'' and ''Appassionata'' sonatas and Liszt's B minor - but he may be unable to choose otherwise.

title: BRIDGE: One Team Gets Advantage In National Qualifying Play
description: The position of favorite in a sport or recreation is usually assigned on the basis of past record and expected performance.

title: 18 REBELS REPORTED SLAIN IN SRI LANKA
description: The police killed 18 Tamil separatist guerrillas in a cave in the Eastern Province, a Government official reported, and rumors of new guerrilla attacks swept the capital.

title: Park Slope Artists
description: The public has been invited to visit any of 90 private studios in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn this weekend by the Park Slope Artists Council.

title: U.S. FARM EXPORT PLAN SEEMS AIMED AT EUROPE
description: The Reagan Administration's $2 billion farm export subsidy plan is likely to be of more benefit as a new weapon against European Common Market exporters than as a means of immediately improving the American farm economy, according to agricultural export analysts.

title: Jersey Thrift Units 'Sound'
description: In New Jersey, where 24 small savings and loan associations have no insurance, state banking officials said yesterday that the institutions were ''extremely sound'' and in no danger of failing.

title: SCREEN: JULIE HAGERTY IN 'GOODBYE, NEW YORK'
description: PART comedy, part travelogue, Amos Kollek's ''Goodbye, New York'' has an easygoing charm that, among Israeli films, is rare. Mr. Kollek, who wrote and directed the film and also plays a leading role, presents witty impressions of Israeli life as seen through the eyes of a reluctant American visitor named Nancy Callahan.

title: MEETING ON DRUGS SPURNED BY PLAYERS
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth and the Major League Baseball Players Association continued their skirmish yesterday over his mandatory drug-testing program, with the players association rejecting Ueberroth's request to discuss the program with union leaders next week.

description: b-Net income.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: THE finger foods called tapas that are served at nearly every bar in Spain as a before-dinner warmup are just becoming known on this side of the Atlantic. Felipe Rojas-Lombardi started serving them at his restaurant, the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street), several years ago, and the new restaurant El Internacional (219 West Broadway) offers an intriguing selection at its colorful and convivial bar.

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A & CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
Fee Ruling on Ford Suit
description: A Federal judge in New York has ordered two lawyers, Roy M. Cohn and Allan M. Pollack, to return $230,000 in fees received from a Ford Motor Company shareholder suit against Ford's former chairman, Henry Ford 2d. The lawyers received the fees in 1980.

title: TRIBUNE IN TV DEAL FOR $510 MILLION
description: The Tribune Company yesterday joined the parade of companies making media acquisitions, announcing that it had agreed to purchase KTLA-TV, an independent station in Los Angeles, for $510 million in cash.

title: HUMAN TESTS OF 2 VACCINES AGAINST MALARIA ARE PLANNED
description: Scientists are planning the first tests in humans this summer of two experimental vaccines against malaria, the parasite disease that is one of the world's most important unsolved health problems.

title: LAWRENCE HUGHES IN TOP JOB
description: The Hearst Corporation, in a major realignment of its book publishing operations, has named Lawrence Hughes president of the newly formed Hearst Trade Book Group. Mr. Hughes, who has been president of William Morrow & Company for 19 years, will coordinate the publishing programs of the Hearst-owned Morrow, Arbor House and Avon Books.

title: JACOBS VS. ARASKOG AT ITT'S MEETING
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, today again asked the ITT Corporation to consider splitting itself into three or four companies whose stocks would be distributed to current ITT shareholders.

title: AVAILABILITY OF TICKETS FOR THE THEATER THIS WEEKEND
description: Following is the ticket availability, at press time, for Broadway shows on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Occasionally, shows that report being sold out at press time have tickets available because of weather conditions or because of ticket returns:

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
T.W.A. Asks U.S. For Icahn Inquiry
description: Trans World Airlines Inc., in a new attempt to block a threatened takeover, filed an application yesterday with the Transportation Department asking it to investigate whether Carl C. Icahn was fit to hold a certificate to run an airline.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oscar Mayer Realigns Its Top Management
description: The Oscar Mayer Foods Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Foods Corporation, said it had reorganized its top management to ''handle the rapid expansion and increased complexity of its business.''

title: No Headline
description: Internorth Inc. and the Houston Natural Gas Corporation said they filed suit against the Valero Energy Corporation after Valero threatened to seek an injunction against Internorth's offer for Houston Natural. Internorth also said it planned to divest itself of its half interest in a Texas natural gas pipeline jointly owned with Valero. An Internorth spokesman said Houston Natural and Valero competed in the same south Texas gas markets.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $61,000.

title: JAPANESE SAY SOVIET JET VANISHED OFF SAKHALIN
description: A Soviet aircraft described as an Aeroflot plane disappeared today over the Sea of Japan off the Soviet coast, the Japanese Government reported.

title: INSULIN PROBABLY CAUSED COMAS, DOCTOR ASSERTS IN VON BULOW TRIAL
description: A Harvard Medical School expert on blood sugars testified today that Martha von Bulow's comas in 1979 and 1980 were both almost certainly caused by insulin injected into her.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $104,000 for the quarter and 9 months and a tax credit of $123,000 for the quarter. c-Including a tax credit of $100,000.

title: HEPBURN STARS IN 'GRACE QUIGLEY'
description: A LOT of talented people have labored long and fruitlessly to make something presentable of ''Grace Quigley,'' a movie you might not want to take home to meet the folks, not because it's so rude and unpredictable, which it unhappily isn't, but because it's so thoroughly muddled and unintentionally sad.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Swenson, a 31-year-old linebacker who was once a mainstay of the Denver Bronco defense, has decided to retire. . . . Bruce Skinner, executive director of the Fiesta Bowl game, said the bowl has signed a new five-year contract with NBC-TV and will be the fifth postseason college football game to offer teams more than $1 million each. The Rose, Orange, Cotton and Sugar bowls already offer $1 million or more.

title: THREAT TO CLOSE AUTO PLANT WORRIES KENOSHA
description: Fumes from solvents in the paint line at American Motors Corporation's waterfront plant waft through the downtown area here when the wind blows in from Lake Michigan. All day big trucks rumble over city streets, carrying car bodies from the lakefront plant to the company's main factory nearby, where they will be finished, becoming Alliance and Encore subcompact automobiles.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $695,000 on the sale of discontinued operation. c-Net income which includes income of $728,000 from discontinued operations, a gain of $13,011,000 on the sale of discontinued operations, and a tax credit of $1,193,000.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue figures represent bullion revenues.

title: Justices on the Road
description: Once a year when the Justices of the Supreme Court file financial disclosure statements, the curtain lifts just a little on one of the most secretive institutions in Government. The reports disclose only the rough outlines of personal financial holdings, but they indicate, as no other information source does, how active some of the Justices are in traveling the country and making free speeches.

title: ITT Net Up 42.9% In Quarter
description: The ITT Corporation, aided by strong gains in all its divisions, yesterday reported a 42.9 increase in earnings in the first quarter.

title: POP: CALYPSO AND SOCA SHOW AT FELT FORUM
description: CALYPSO and soca, the wry dance music of the English-speaking Caribbean, are ready to go international. That was the message of the 8th annual Mother's Day Caribbean All-Stars Festival, three shows Saturday and Sunday at the Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue at 33d Street.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $19,000.

title: Senate Confirms Walters
description: The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Vernon A. Walters, a veteran diplomatic troubleshooter, to succeed Jeane J. Kirkpatrick as the United States chief delegate to the United Nations. The Senate acted by voice vote and without debate.

title: Posner Companies
description: A group of companies controlled by Victor Posner, the Miami investor, disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that they sold their 8.4 percent stake in the City Investing Company for $117 million, or $37.50 a share.

title: SENATORS VOTE TO STRENGTHEN THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT
description: The Senate today adopted a bill to reauthorize and strengthen the Safe Drinking Water Act. The voice vote was unanimous.

title: WILL THE FARMER EVER STOP WAILING?
description: Year in and year out, in good times or bad, the American farmer rushes to the forefront of public attention, wailing about his dire lot and clamoring for all manner of Government support.

title: Panel Votes to Expand Fund on Toxic Wastes
description: The Senate Finance Committee, over strong dissent from the Reagan Administration, voted today for a vastly enlarged toxic waste cleanup campaign financed by a new excise tax on manufacturers.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Fined
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Laker center, was fined $500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for what he called ''a rather stupid incident on my part,'' a scuffle with Danny Schayes of the Nuggets during a playoff game Tuesday night in Inglewood, Calif. The fine is in addition to an automatic $250 fine imposed on Abdul-Jabbar for being ejected.

title: 'Deadly Intentions,' Psycho-Gothic Melodrama
description: It takes her a while to get around to it, but shortly after her baby is born, Katherine Raynor concludes that her husband, Charles, is not a safe person to live with. Nothing turns on this young doctor like taking pictures of his wife when she is being frightened by a spider or chased by an alligator. He does other unsettling things, such as waking her out of a sound sleep by leaping upon her with shrieks and howls, tossing the pet kitten across the room and trying to kill the baby. ''Charles is so unpredictable,'' says Katherine.

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FLYERS ADVANCE TO CUP FINALS
description: Flawlessy, the Philadelphia Flyers raced into the Stanley Cup finals tonight with a 3-0 victory over the Quebec Nordiques, winning their four-of-seven Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series, four games to two.

title: MCI Makes Cheating Claim
description: The MCI Communications Corporation today accused the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of cheating in the war for long-distance customers.

title: Topics;   All in the Family Speaking of Abortion
description: Every year more than a million American women choose to end their pregnancies, and do so safely and lawfully. Countless others made the choice years ago, before abortion was legal, and many of them have terrible stories to tell.

title: CAVCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Harvester Earnings Up
description: The International Harvester Company, the nation's largest producer of medium- and heavy-duty trucks, reported net income of $59 million, or 42 cents a share, in the quarter ending April 30.

title: MEESE PRAISES PHILADELPHIA MAYOR
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d says Mayor W. Wilson's Goode's handling of the situation in Philadelphia this week was ''a good example for us all to take note of.''

title: SPEED KEY FACTOR IN CUP MATCH-UP
description: In the end, Doug Crossman called it a ''blessing'' that the Flyers had the chance to play the Quebec Nordiques. He knows what's coming. ''The Nordiques were an offensive team,'' said the Philadelphia defenseman, following the Flyers' 3-0 victory over the Nordiques Thursday night, a triumph that propelled the Flyers into the Stanley Cup finals. ''And now we'll see how we do, an all-around defensive team, against an explosive offensive team.''

title: FINE ART ACQUISITIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $20,000.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-After a loss of $5,735,000 from discontinued operations.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. READY TO AID A HOSTAGE MISSION
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was ''prepared to facilitate'' efforts by the Rev. Jesse Jackson to win the release of five Americans who have been abducted in Lebanon. But it also repeated its firm opposition to meeting the demands of the terrorists holding the captives.

title: Mostek to Lay Off 140 Workers
description: The Mostek Corporation, a United Technologies Corporation unit, said it would lay off about 140 people at its semiconductor plant and test facility in Blanchardstown, Ireland, because of the continuing downturn in the industry.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THE DANCE: MEEHAN AND TROUPE
description: There were interesting moments in all three works the Nancy Meehan Dance Company presented last Saturday night at St. Mark's Church. Yet none was interesting as a whole.

title: Your Money;   Foreign Stock Investments
description: INVESTING in foreign securities or currencies obviously poses an additional risk to those who select this forum. It adds the possibility of price changes associated with another nation's economy or industries to the traditional market risks associated with any American investment.

title: BRELAND STOPS DUNFEE
description: Mark Breland suggested it was his ''old remedy, my yoga and relaxation.'' But it was nothing more mystical than cracking left hooks and a final right hand to a weak opponent tonight that enabled the golden star of the 1984 Olympics to at last score his first knockout as a professional.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Ed Lynch, a 1-0 loser last time out, is scheduled to start for the Mets. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. California Angels, at Anaheim, Calif. Reggie Jackson turns 39 years old today. (Television - Channel 4, 3:15 P.M.) Radio - WABC 770, 3:20 P.M.) Basketball 76ers vs. Boston Celtics, at Philadelphia. Game 3 of the four-of-seven Eastern Conference Championships. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Golf United Hospitals Senior Classic, at Malverne, Pa. Yesterday's opening round was rained out, so the tournament has been reduced to 36 holes. (Television -ESPN, 3 P.M.) Ladies P.G.A. Chrysler Plymouth Charity Classic, at Chatham, N.J. Second round. Colonial National Invitational, at Fort Worth, Third round. (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M.) #75th annual Travis Memorial, at Garden City Golf Club, Stewart Avenue and Cherry Valley Road, Garden City, 8 A.M., round of 16 and 1 P.M. quarterfinal round. This match-play tournament is named after Walter J. Travis, first American to win the British Amateur in 1904. He was a member of the Garden City Club. Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, 1 P.M. Heatherten at 2-1 and Life's Magic at 3-1 are the early favorites to win the $100,000 added Shuvee Handicap for fillies and mares 3 and up at 1 1/16 miles. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M.) Pimlico. The $350,000 added Preakness for 3-year-olds at 1 1/16 miles.

title: PUBCO CORP DEBTORS-IN-PROCESSION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $515,000 for the latest first quarter and $210,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 14. 1. This was the reaction as the sixth was announced. Who was sixth and what were the circumstances? 2. A recent event in North Rhine-Westphalia, in the Ruhr valley, may be the final embarrassment for White House strategists over President Reagan's visit to West Germany. Identify the event and explain. 3. President Reagan's tax plan would reduce the number of tax brackets for individuals from more than a dozen rates, ranging up to 50 percent, that are now in effect. How many brackets would there be and what are they? 4. According to Federal law, the term ''nonalcoholic'' may appear on wine bottles or beer cans only if the beverage inside is completely free of alcohol. True or false? 5. Invoking emergency powers, Gov. Harry R. Hughes issued an order to stem a run on deposits in privately insured savings and loan institutions in Maryland, started last week by allegations of fraud at the state's second-largest thrift institution. What did he order? 6. Rioters hurled stones, eggs and smoke bombs as Pope John Paul II encountered the worst violence in any of his 26 foreign journeys. In what country did the riots occur and who were most of the demonstrators? 7. In commuting the prison term of Gary E. Dotson, who was convicted of a rape the accuser now says never happened, Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois said he (believed/did not believe) the recantation. 8.

title: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ISRAELIS DENY KNOWING OF EXPORT BAR FOR DEVICE USABLE IN A-BOMB
description: Israel obtained the 800 electronic devices from the United States that can be used to set off nuclear bombs without knowing there were any restrictions on their export, according to the Israeli Defense Ministry and the man who owned the Israeli company that imported them.

title: NIEKRO LIFTS YANKS TO FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: Before the game, Billy Martin talked about the need for good pitching. His concern was genuine: the Yankees hadn't received a complete game from a starting pitcher since May 5.

title: ELEVATOR MAN EXCELS IN HIGH-TECH AGE
description: The subject of replacing Bernie Molosh with an exciting new high-technology, space-age elevator - a Computerized Vertical Transportation System! - comes up every year or so at meetings of the co-op board at 20 East 74th Street. Residents always let out anguished cries and the proposal is voted down.

title: CUSTOM LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the year-ago quarter include the sale of in-house business graphics systems for approximately $400,000.

title: Drivers Clog Streets In Protest in Teheran
description: Thousands of people, many with bouquets of flowers in their cars, snarled traffic here today after a call for protests by the exiled former Prime Minister, Shahpur Bakhtiar.

title: NEW THREAT ISSUED IN BEIRUT
description: An anonymous caller saying he spoke for the shadowy group known as Islamic Holy War issued a new threat today to American diplomats in the Middle East.

title: Louisiana Execution Stayed
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit today blocked the execution of Sterling Rault Jr., asking attorneys to submit additional briefs based on the convict's appeal. He had been scheduled to die in Louisiana's electric chair early Saturday for killing and burning the body of a woman who the police said was involved with him in an embezzling scheme.

title: MOUNTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JONES'S 7-UNDER 66 LEADS TOURNAMENT
description: Rosie Jones shot the best round of her career today, going five under par over the last five holes at the Fairmount Country Club and finishing with a seven-under-par 66. That gave her a three-shot lead in the first round of the 10th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association's Chrysler-Plymouth Classic.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SCREAMS FOR A SPIKING HUNK
description: He started the match on the bench, as any tardy player would. But the screams from the largely female crowd at Nassau Community College yesterday made it obvious that the brown-haired, handsome man in the U.S.A. warm-up jacket was no ordinary volleyball player.

title: The 'Battle of the Last Colony'
description: The 638,000 residents of the District of Columbia have finally lost a seven-year struggle for ratification of a Constitutional amendment that would have given the district full voting representation in Congress: two United States Senators and a single Representative in the House. But that does not mean that the ''battle of the last colony'' is over.

title: IN ACRID BRAZILIAN FACTORY ZONE, A FEAR OF DISASTER
description: The factories on this swampland have turned the nearby town into a place of superlatives: in Cubatao, pollutants in the rain have reached some of the highest levels known in the world; the air is considered unfit for humans on a record number of days, and more cases of cancer, stillbirths and deformed babies are reportedly recorded here than anywhere else in Brazil.

title: NATIONAL GOLD DISTRIBUTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JAPAN'S WOMEN WIN SCUFFLE IN EQUALITY WAR
description: Equal employment rights for women, at least in theory, came to Japan today, but some people wondered whether this resolutely male-oriented society would even notice.

title: CORRECTION
description: A film review of ''Silver City'' yesterday misidentified the theater where it is playing. It is the Coronet, Third Avenue and 59th Street.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $326,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: COIT HENDLEY JR.
description: Coit Hendley Jr., associate editor of The Washington Times, died at home here Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, the newspaper said.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'SCHEMES AND DREAMS' ABOUT FILMS AT CANNES
description: Want to buy worldwide rights to a movie? There are more than 400 films for sale here and 2,500 people willing to buy or sell at virtually any hour of the day or night.

title: MUSIC: AUSTRIAN AVANT-GARDE
description: ''Beyond the Sound of Music: New Austria/New York'' is a five-day arts festival with a two-day preface designed to present a range of Austrian avant-gardism to the New York public. Sponsored by the Austrian Institute, the Kitchen and the Styrian Autumn, the festival got under way formally Wednesday night at the Ohio Theater in SoHo, following two days of literary readings at the Deutsches Haus.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. Dave DeBusschere showed elation as the sixth envelope in the seven-team lottery was opened by David J. Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Rupert Murdoch in Business Day on May 7 incorrectly described a chance encounter between Mr. Murdoch and John W. Kluge, chairman and president of Metromedia Inc. It did lead to Mr. Murdoch's proposed purchase of Metromedia Inc., but the two men had in fact known each other before that occasion.

title: Jacobs Group Adds To Castle Holding
description: A group of companies controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis-based investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in Castle & Cooke to 3.63 million common shares, or 14.1 percent of the total outstanding.

title: TENTATIVE PACT IS ANNOUNCED ON CONTROL OF U.P.I.
description: A tentative agreement aimed at ending arguments over control of United Press International and speeding its sale was announced today by officials of the news agency.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EVANS PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $4,460,000 from discontinued operations.

title: AMERICAN PACESETTER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Cadet Plan Would Raise Quality of Police
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,000-Mile Race Is Long Enough
description: If you want to know how a runner feels when he has just finished a 1,000-mile race - when he has just won a 1,000-mile race, at that - then Don Choi has two words for you: Never again.

title: Ancient Women's Rites Remain Mysteries
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times;   Chasing Mirages
description: THE BUS OF DREAMS. By Mary Morris. 236 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

title: Allied-Signal Units
description: Some businesses of both the Allied Corporation and the Signal Companies are likely to be sold after the two companies merge, and such divestitures ''could be significant,'' Allied said today. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Allied said it expects to review all Allied and Signal lines of business following the merger. As part of the merger agreement, Allied began an offer today for up to 22 million Signal common shares, or about 20 percent of the total outstanding, for $45 a share.

title: AERO SERVICES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Talk on Easter Island
description: Sergio Rapu, the anthropologist and governor of Easter Island, will explore the ''Archeology of Easter Island'' in a lecture at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, today at 2 P.M. Admission to the lecture is free after admission to the museum by contribution. Information: 873-1300.

title: GIANT PORTLAND & MASONRY CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOOD SPORT AT THE BANK
description: Going to the bank nowadays is more fun than it used to be. For one thing, you never know whether the bank will run out of money before you get there.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW DELHI TRIAL STARTS FOR 3 IN GANDHI ASSASSINATION CASE
description: Behind the walls of a maximum-security prison, in a small, makeshift courtroom, the trial of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's accused assassin and two suspected conspirators got under way today.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Seized Again in Connecticut
description: For the second time in five weeks, a former assistant state's attorney has been arrested and charged with receiving bribes.

title: AUTO UNION DEFIES CONCESSIONS PLEA
description: Employees of the American Motors Corporation have voted overwhelmingly against the company's request for immediate concessions, favoring instead the negotiation of a revised contract, union officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about E. F. Hutton & Company's check-fraud scheme misstated the average daily sum that Hutton overdrew from its banks.

title: Icahn Raises T.W.A. Stake
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, disclosed yesterday that he had increased his stake in Trans World Airlines Inc. to 8.2 million shares, or 25 percent of the company's shares, from 23 percent, and added that he would ''actively explore strategies for obtaining control.''

title: MUTUAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
8 WHO PROTESTED SOUTH AFRICA ARE ACQUITTED
description: Eight people accused of trespassing at the South African Consulate here were acquited today in a trial that apparently was the first undergone by defendants arrested in the past six months for protesting South Africa's policy of racial separation.

title: ESTEBAN FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
POP: PHIL COLLINS PERFORMS
description: Phil Collins cuts an odd figure for a pop star. A romantic balladeer who is not conventionally handsome, he further undermines his mystique with the droll humor of an English music-hall comedian.

title: UNOCAL BAR TO PICKENS IS UPHELD
description: The Delaware Supreme Court said today that the Unocal Corporation could exclude a group of investors led by T. Boone Pickens in the company's offer to purchase 29 percent of its stock. The ruling was interpreted as giving managements of companies incorporated in Delaware a significant new tactic for warding off unwanted corporate raiders.

title: DOW UP 7.29, TO 1,285.34, AS INTEREST RATES FALL
description: Helped by declining interest rates, the stock market continued to rally yesterday in heavy trading as blue-chip issues joined a celebration begun by secondary issues earlier in the week.

DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: The artists say the Bronx was a halcyon place when they grew up there some 40 years ago. While they all now live in Manhattan, their Bronx days remain potent memories.

title: HOUSTONIAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S.F.L. Stops Suit Against ABC
description: A day after the United States Football League filed suit against ABC seeking $7 million that the league says the network is withholding from its $15.4 million television contract, the two sides agreed yesterday to submit the dispute to arbitration.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss which is after a charge of $241,573 from discontinuedoperations.

description: b-Net income.
