Quotation of the Day
description: ''Senator Specter's and my job is to help these people get on with their lives.

title: CARDIOSEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Israel's Hand in the Nuclear Jar
description: Israel's response to the evidence that it illegally acquired 800 nuclear-bomb triggers from the United States is that it didn't know the shipments needed a license . . . that it cannot reveal why it needed the devices but would swear in writing the purpose was nonnuclear . . . and that it will, if asked, return the large number of switches not yet consumed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, MAY 18, 1985

title: Joseph Fuchs to Get Award
description: The violinist Joseph Fuchs will be presented with the first annual Jan Peerce Award for Distinguished Service to the Arts tomorrow at Queens Borough Hall, 120-55 Queens Boulevard, Kew Gardens. Ceremonies will begin at 1:30 P.M., with the Queens Borough President, Donald A. Manes, presenting the award at 2 P.M.

title: CITY HOLDS SPELLING BEE WITH A SPANISH FLAVOR
description: Standing nervously at the microphone, 10-year-old Jaime Perez took a deep breath and then pronounced the letters, one by one. ''P-A-L-A-D- accented I-N,'' he said, slowly but firmly, the last letter nearly drowned out by a sudden eruption of cheers and applause.

title: Democrats Oppose Caucuses
description: Democratic Party leaders, trying to overcome criticism that the party caters to special interests, stripped official recognition today from caucuses representing homosexuals, Asians, progressives and some other groups.

title: CONCERT: YVES HENRY PIANO RECITAL
description: Yves Henry began his recital at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night with unusual promise. Schumann's ''Symphonic Etudes'' showed not only the smooth virtuosity we associate with French pianism at its best but also a real ability to stage-manage musical line.

title: Badges for Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: LAND OF LINCOLN SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Retirement Request
description: Jack (Hacksaw) Reynolds, the 15-year linebacker whose inspired play helped the San Francisco 49ers win the 1982 Super Bowl his first season with the club, has been asked to retire and become an assistant coach, but at the age of 37 he is looking for another team. ''Jack's a legend in this game,'' declared his agent, David Fishof, who said that several clubs had expressed an interest in the stocky linebacker.

title: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: 5 Arrested on Drug Charges
description: Five people, including a Navy recruiting officer, were arrested today on charges of cocaine possession with intent to distribute. The five were arrested by Federal Drug Enforcement Agents and were arraigned tonight before United States Magistrate F. Owen Egan. The arrested included Navy Petty Officer Ronald Gaskin, 30 years old, of Manchester, and Doreen Tracy, 22, of East Hartford, the daughter of a police officer there, authorities said.

title: VISITORS BACK NEW YORK IN TAX-DEDUCTION BATTLE
description: President Reagan's tax reform proposal to eliminate Federal income-tax deductions for state and local taxes was criticized by members of a Congressional delegation on an informal three-day visit to the city.

title: DATA SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Of Coins of the Realm
description: Some Washington skirmishes are fought, some perils avoided, some modest victories proudly gained almost unnoticed. The threat that some United States coins would be produced abroad never became a major issue, but it got the attention of Representative Frank Annunzio, the chairman of the House Consumer Affairs and Coinage Subcommittee.

title: PUBLIC BROADCASTING CHIEF RESIGNS AMID DISPUTE
description: Edward J. Pfister, the president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, has resigned, saying there is growing political interference in the organization.

title: AIDE TO REAGAN LISTS 3 BRACKETS IN TAX PROPOSAL
description: President Reagan has decided that, under his tax revision proposal, only families with more than $70,000 of taxable income would be subject to the highest tax rate of 35 percent, a senior Administration official said today.

title: PAY-FONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: CITY ART DEALER CHARGED IN CASE OF SEX TORTURE
description: A Manhattan art dealer was arrested yesterday and charged with kidnapping, torturing and sexually assaulting a young man in his gallery on East 57th Street last September.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs;   Lakers Triumph
description: James Worthy scored 28 points and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar added 27 tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 136-118 victory over Denver and take a 2-1 lead in the four-of-seven Western Conference championship series.

title: TWINS DOWN JAYS ON RUN IN 11TH, 7-6
description: Tom Brunansky's run-scoring single in the bottom of the 11th inning lifted the Minnesota Twins to a 7-6 victory tonight over the Toronto Blue Jays Friday night.

title: U.S. OFFERS EMERGENCY AID TO REBUILD IN PHILADELPHIA
description: After walking through the two fire-devastated blocks near the ruins of a radical group's compound, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Samuel R. Pierce Jr. pledged $1 million in Federal aid today to help the city rebuild the neighborhood and vowed additional aid to provide emergency housing.

title: L.I. School Board To Retain Makeup
description: The State Commissioner of Education yesterday rescinded his May 1 order to add a ninth member to a deadlocked Long Island school board.

title: Goldman, Sachs To Sell Building
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it would sell its world headquarters, at 85 Broad Street in New York's financial district, to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for $310 million.

title: PANEL ON BUDGET HEARS REQUESTS FOR MORE FUNDS
description: Having completed a week of budget hearings throughout the city, the Board of Estimate and the City Council will turn now to analyzing requests from city commissioners as they prepare to approve a budget for the next fiscal year, which starts July 1.

title: CABARET: TOM MCDERMOTT
description: Tom McDermott, a 28-year-old stride pianist from St. Louis who has gone down the Mississippi to settle in New Orleans, is making his first New York appearance, through May 25, at the New York home of stride piano, Hanratty's, on Second Avenue near 92d Street.

title: MOBIL IS SPRUCING UP WARD
description: Montgomery Ward & Company, the 113-year-old retail giant based in Chicago, is being dolled up and trimmed down by a parent eager to get rid of a barely profitable operation.

title: FIRE VICTIMS SUFFER FROM LOSS OF ANCHORS TO LIFE
description: In the daytime he sits on a stoop looking at the burnt-out shell that was his home. At night he tosses and turns, sleeping fitfully in a strange bed.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK TESTING LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss which is after a tax credit of $11,700.

title: HOSPITALS TO RECEIVE $450 MILLION UNDER ALBANY'S PLAN TO CUT COSTS
description: Health insurers will pay $450 million, far more than expected, to private and public hospitals in New York State over the next two years as part of a state-run program meant to contain hospital costs, according to state officials.

title: Basketball For the Disabled
description: Marty Lyons and a dozen of his New York Jets teammates are planning to play basketball, not football, tonight. And they will be in wheelchairs.

title: VEGETABLE GARDENS ARE FOR THE BIRDS
description: At the risk of committing heresy, I want to state my biggest summer gripe: I hate vegetable gardens.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Large increases in military spending have for many years failed to yield comparable increases in weapons delivered to the armed services, and some critics of Pentagon practices believe that basic changes are needed in the incentives that influence those who buy and make weapons.

title: Susan Karp Manning Weds John W. Lango
description: Susan Karp Manning, the daughter of Estelle G. Karp and the late Walter Karp of New York, was married yesterday to John W. Lango, a son of the late John A. Lango and the late Estella Lango of Tujunga, Calif. City Clerk David N. Dinkins performed the ceremony at the Municipal Building in Manhattan.

title: An '88 Button Already
description: In Washington it is never too soon to think of the next Presidential election campaign, especially for people who work for a potential candidate.

title: Nurturing A Neighborhood Group
description: Block associations and tenants groups sprout as rapidly as the ills they are trying to cure. And once the problem subsides, they often die.

title: California Thrift Unit
description: The American Savings and Loan Association had a deposit outflow of more than $1 billion in April, the third consecutive month of such losses, according to figures released by the thrift institution's parent corporation. The loss of deposits was included in a quarterly report filed by the Financial Corporation of America with the Securities and Exchange Commission and was released by the company on Thursday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. shareholders have approved the acquisition of Reed Stenhouse Cos. of Toronto.

title: RESEARCH PLANNED ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: The Pentagon announced today that the General Electric Company, the State University of New York at Buffalo and the Naval Research Laboratory here would form a consortium to study ''novel materials'' for a proposed defensive shield against missiles.

title: OHIO THRIFT UNIT'S SALE IS SET BACK
description: The Ohio Senate defeated on a tie vote of 16 to 16 today a measure that would allow the sale of the failed Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati to the Chemical New York Corporation. The measure had been approved in the House earlier in the day by a vote of 63 to 25.

title: WHEN CHILDREN PLAY WITH MUD PIES
description: ''Politics ruins the character.'' - Otto von Bismarck, 1881 Mayor Koch and New York's Liberal Party have been calling each other names since 1977, when the Liberals - who had regularly supported Mr. Koch as a Congressman and City Council member - backed Mario Cuomo instead in the mayoral election that Mr. Koch won. It's been a marvelous blood feud to watch.

title: Emma Clurman, a Consultant, Marries
description: Susan Emma Clurman, a daughter of Mimi M. Clurman and Richard M. Clurman, both of New York, was married yesterday to John Goldthwaite Dockendorff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Noyes Cornell Dockendorff of New Canaan, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla. Justice E. Leo Milonas of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Union Club.

title: NEW YORK F.B.I. CHIEF TAKING SECURITY POST
description: Lee F. Laster, who has run the New York office of the F.B.I. in such a low-key style that many people thought his deputy was the boss, said yesterday that he was retiring at the end of the month because ''there comes a time for all of us.''

title: BUDGET DEBATE: CONSENSUS IN CONGRESS
description: The budget debate in Congress has illuminated a surprising consensus between both parties on broad questions of deficits and taxes despite the persistence of old differences over Social Security.

title: PLM FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PERPETUAL AMERICAN BANK F S B reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Perpetual American Bank was not publicly traded in the year-ago period. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,810,000. d-Net loss.

title: Leatrice Joy, 91, Dies; Actress in Silent Films
description: Leatrice Joy, a leading silent-film actress, died of acute anemia Monday at the High Ridge House nursing home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 91 years old.

title: Lonnie Smith Traded
description: Lonnie Smith was beaten out for an outfield job with St. Louis this spring, and yesterday the Cardinals traded him to the Kansas City Royals for John Morris, a minor league outfielder. Smith, 29 years old, has a .298 average in five full major league seasons.

title: 30 IN MICHIGAN SUFFER FROM SYMPTOMS LINKED TO LEGIONNAIRES' DISEASE
description: At least three people were hospitalized in critical condition today and 27 more were sick in what health officials said was apparently an outbreak of legionnaires' disease. The officials said they did not expect any new cases.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $7,000. c-Net loss.

title: ONLY ON FRIDAYS: PUBLIC CAN BUY AT FLYING FOODS
description: A small crowd gathered around the woman at the back of the warehouse, next to the temporary fish counter. People stood transfixed as she dexterously filleted several fresh sardines with her hands, just as she used to do in Sweden.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income which includes a gain of $58,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: ENCORE COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-The company went public in March and is on a fiscal year which ends in October. Hence no year-ago or 6 month results are reported.

title: Returning the Football
description: It took court orders in two states to get Virgina Tech's great defensive tackle, Bruce Smith, into the Independence Bowl against Air Force last December, but neither the school nor Smith got much to show for it. Virginia Tech, which lost to Air Force, 23-7, got a small trophy, a metallic football surrounded by a cluster of players, and Smith, who had been declared ineligible for postseason play by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, got a watch, a sweater, a carry-on bag and a hat.

title: Steinberg Buys More Hall Shares
description: Frank B. Hall & Company, an insurance brokerage based in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., said yesterday that a group controlled by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York financier, had bought 1.9 million Hall shares, raising its stake to 20.5 percent of the company's shares.

title: SOLDIER IN SRI LANKA KILLS SIX
description: An ''emotionally upset'' corporal opened fire on Tamil civilians at an army camp in Anuradhapura today, killing 6 people and wounding 16 before being shot to death by his commanding officer, the Government said.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PKS-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Milt Jackson in Village
description: The vibraphonist Milt Jackson is leading a quartet, including Cedar Walton on piano, through tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: FIFTH AVENUE CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Two Overshadow Field for Preakness
description: Three days of rain, gray skies and a wet Pimlico track have set an appropriately gloomy mood for the 110th Preakness Stakes here Saturday.

title: CRESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $108,000 for the quarter, gains from the company's Energy Services Group of $4,540,205 for the quarter and $4,432,205 for the 9 months, and a loss from discontinued operations $1,940,848 for the 9 months.

title: MARYLAND ENACTS LAWS ON THRIFT UNITS' CRISIS
description: Maryland lawmakers passed and the Governor signed emergency legislation early this morning aimed at ending the crisis among this state's 102 privately insured savings and loan associations. Depositors have drained more than $600 million from the institutions in a series of runs that began last week.

title: GREENWOOD RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that there were no share earnings after preferred dividend requirements.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DEFINING POLITICS AT CITY HALL
description: Is it government? Or is it politics?

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,855,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of investments.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Marjorie R. Arnold Wed To Eugene D. Biddle Jr.
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Marjorie Rawl Arnold, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bailey Arnold of Clinton, S.C., was married to Eugene Dorr Biddle Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Biddle of Fort Worth, Tex. The Rev. David Stokes performed the ceremony.

title: HOUSTON OIL FIELDS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HALLEY'S COMET NEARS, PRESAGING PROFITS
description: At this moment, Halley's comet is 454 million miles away, somewhere near Jupiter. Though still invisible to the naked eye, it is already bringing visions of profit to many here on earth.

title: CITY BALEET: 'CORTEGE HONGROIS'
description: George Balanchine's ''Cortege Hongrois'' is a mix of character or folk dance and classical ballet that remains unblended. On Thursday at the New York State Theater, new dancers took over lead roles in a high-spirited performance by the New York City Ballet that almost made a virtue of the ballet's oddities.

title: JACKSON CAMPAIGN MANAGER CONVICTED BY CLEVELAND JURY
description: Arnold R. Pinkney, manager of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's bid for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination, was convicted today by a Cuyahoga County jury of having an unlawful interest in a public contract.

title:
PATENTS;

Gain in Soft Contact Lenses
description: FOUR patents granted to a subsidiary this week give the National Patent Development Corporation of New York control of a rapid method of making soft contact lenses. A machine using the spin-cast process can produce the lenses at a rate of one every 10 seconds.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FMI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There were no share earnings for the latest quarter after preferred dividend requirements.

title: TROUBLED LTV SETS BROAD CHANGES
description: The LTV Corporation, reeling from huge losses, announced a series of drastic measures today that are intended to bolster its steel operations and the company's overall financial health.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS ITS LOAN RATE TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: The Federal Reserve, in a forceful step to support a flagging economy, approved a half-point cut in its lending rate today, to 7 1/2 percent. The new level is the lowest in almost seven years.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Refiners Are Coming
description: Though the world is awash in crude oil, the American Independent Refiners Association warns of a new era of foreign blackmail if its members are not protected against foreign competitors. The trade association, which represents only small refiners, is pressing Congress for an import quota to guarantee domestic refiners a market for a fixed percentage of their production capacity.

title: Harlem Rodeo
description: The Budweiser Black Championship Rodeo will feature bareback bronco riding, bull riding, calf roping, steer wrestling, barrel racing and a rodeo clinic today and tomorrow, from 3 to 6 P.M., at Colonel Young Park, 143d Street and Lenox Avenue, Harlem, rain or shine. Tickets are $10; $8 for those 13 and under; available at Ticketron, 977-9020, or at the rodeo. Information: 675-0085.

title: Millions Blacked OutBy South Florida Fires
description: A noontime power failure caused by brush fires west of Fort Lauderdale cut off electricity today to millions of residents of southeastern Florida on a day of record temperatures.

title: Suffolk Urged To Buy Tracts
description: The Suffolk County Planning Department has recommended that the county buy 4,000 acres of pine barren from private owners in the eastern part of Brookhaven, Riverhead and Southampton to protect the ground water and watershed of the area.

title: AUTOMATED MEDICAL LABORAORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $196,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Includes a tax credit of $32,000, or 1 cent a share.

INTERMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income which includes income from discontinued operations of $403,000 for the quarter and $1,044,000 for the year and a gain of $3,081,000 for the year from the sale of stock in a subsidiary.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $157,000 for the quarter and $413,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary credit of $2,344,000 for the 9 months.

title: CHARGIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

description: b-After a charge of $120,000 for the quarter from a reduction in the utilization of a tax credit and a tax credit of $465,000 for the year. c-Net income which includes a tax credit of $234,615. d-Includes a tax credit of $1,089,115.

title: No Parole for Manson Figure
description: Charles Watson, who led followers of Charles Manson in murdering the actress Sharon Tate and six other people in 1969, was denied parole today by the States Board of Prison Terms.

title: REPUBLICAN LEADERS IN SENATE ATTACK BUDGET PLAN OF HOUSE PANEL
description: The Reagan Administration and Senate Republican leaders, using unusually sharp oratory, today attacked the 1986 budget drafted by the House Budget Committee this week, and Senate leaders professed to be doubtful the two branches could reach a compromise.

title: SCREEN: 'SECRET OF THE SWORD'
description: ''The Secret of the Sword'' is a Saturday morning kiddie cartoon stretched out to feature length, which by some lights is an awfully long time. It stars He-Man and She-Ra, who are much loved by a large segment of the under-5 population and by parents who don't mind the martial attitudes they affect or the sexual stereotypes they embody.

title: SATELCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ISSUES IN STRIKE BY THE PILOTS
description: The Participants United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, was struck yesterday by the Air Line Pilots Association, which represents the airline's 5,200 pilots. The airline normally carries about 120,000 people a day, or 15 percent of the national passenger load.

title: AVALON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $400,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $226,000.

title: More Red Faces
description: With all the embarrassing news to which they have been subjected in recent months, the Cosmos can't really use any more, and they're certainly not eager to make any themselves. But that's what happened when Peppe Pinton, the team's managing director, announced early this week that he had obtained the services of Rick Davis for a series of international matches this summer, an acquisition that, in Pinton's view, marked ''a very proud moment for the Cosmos soccer club and for soccer in America.''

title: ASTRADYNE COMPUTER INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income which includes a tax credit of $78,200.

title: PLEXUS RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: General Chain's Exit
description: Lieut. Gen. John T. Chain Jr., the highest-ranking military officer holding a top State Department post, is leaving Foggy Bottom. He is giving up the job of director of the Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs, which involves serving as liaison officer between the State Department and the Pentagon, to return to the Air Force and is scheduled to receive his fourth star.

title: BAKER COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter include the operations of 'Newport Beach-714' which was not in operation during the year-ago period and which accounted for approximately $100,000 of the latest quarter's loss.

title: Reaching New York's Highest Court
description: New York's highest court is the misnamed Court of Appeals. ''Supreme Court'' justices operate two tiers below, subject to two rounds of appeal. Even quirkier is the fact that the highest court operates at the mercy of the intervening Appellate Division, which can force a case onto its calendar.

title: UNITED AIR STRIKE CANCELS FLIGHTS THROUGHOUT U.S.
description: A strike by United Airlines' pilots forced the cancellation of hundreds of flights yesterday at 89 airports. The degree of travel disruption varied.

title: 2D DOCTOR SAYS INSULIN CAUSED VON BULOW COMA
description: The likelihood that alcohol caused Martha von Bulow to collapse into a coma is ''zero,'' an expert in metabolism and blood disorders told a Providence jury today.

title: Even Those Accused of Child Abuse Have Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Losing Patience
description: The trading of Lonnie Smith yesterday isn't the only change that the St. Louis Cardinals are undertaking. Tired of waiting for Darrell Porter and Neil Allen to round into form, Manager Whitey Herzog is planning a reduced role for both, and he thinks he has a very good reason. ''Patience is a great thing,'' Herzog says, ''but sometimes patience gets you fired.''

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income which includes income of $177,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $113,000.

title: GRIFFIN BELL RETAINED BY HUTTON
description: The E.F. Hutton Group Inc. has retained a former Attorney General of the United States, Griffin B. Bell, to determine which individuals had personal responsibility for the extensive check fraud scheme to which Hutton's brokerage subsidiary pleaded guilty on May 2, the company said yesterday.

title: C. Melvin Patrick Dies at 70 Aide to Borough Presidents
description: C. Melvin Patrick, a journalist who became executive assistant to Hulan E. Jack, the first black Borough President in New York City, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Medical Center from complications after an operation last month. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 4 Men Charged With Murder In Gun Battle at Bar in Jersey
description: Four men have been charged with murder in connection with a gun battle last week at a tavern in Union City, N.J., that left three people dead and three others wounded, the Hudson County Prosecutor announced today.

title: BRIDGE: BERGEN TEAM MOVES AHEAD IN SEMIFINAL OF INTERNATIONAL
description: With 16 deals left to be played here tonight, a six-man team led by Marty Bergen of White Plains was virtually assured of victory in the semifinal stage of playoffs to determine the United States team in the 1985 world championships.

title: HIGH PLAINS OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WRITING PRENUPTIAL CONTRACTS
description: IF June is the month for weddings, then May is the month for prenuptial agreements. Or so says Jacalyn Barnett, director of the marital division of the law firm Shea & Gould.

title: Soviet Lets 166 Jews Leave
description: The number of Soviet Jews allowed to leave the Soviet Union in April climbed to 166, the highest monthly total in almost two years, a resettlement agency said today. The emigres arrived in Vienna and 66 moved on to Israel, according to a news release from the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration.

title: ONE-PARENT FAMILIES INCREASING, STUDY SAYS
description: More than a quarter of all the families with children in the United States have only one parent present, the Census Bureau reported this week.

title: I.R.A. POLITICAL WING MAKES GAINS IN ULSTER VOTE
description: Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, has won seats on 17 of 26 district councils in local government elections in Northern Ireland.

title: NETWORK SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $125,729.

title: $190,000 Misspent By Campus Group
description: The Evening Student Government Association at Hunter College has overspent its budget by more than $190,000 during the last three years, according to Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the college president.

title: SALVADORAN SEEKS TO SHOW WIDE U.S. SUPPORT
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, after his discussions with President Reagan on Thursday, began a series of meetings and appearances today designed to demonstrate support from politicians and institutions in the United States.

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $202,000. The company is listed on the Philadelphia, Midwest and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: Cable Project
description: A $600 million trans-Atlantic fiber optic telecommunications project planned by Cable and Wireless P.L.C., and Tel-Optik, a private United States company, has been approved by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Westchester Says Fewer Ride Buses
description: Westchester County buses lost riders during the first three months of the year, carrying 7.13 million fares, 4 percent below the figure for the first quarter of 1984, the County Transportation Commissioner, R. Raleigh D'Adamo, said Thursday.

title: NATIONAL COUNCIL OF CHURCHES PUTS NEW EMPHASIS ON THEOLOGY
description: With three days of spirited gospel music, lively worship services and renewed calls for ecumenism, 263 delegates here tried to re-emphasize the Christ in the National Council of Churches of Christ.

title: OXOCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After writedowns of certain assets amounting to $30,891,426. c-Net income.

title: New Trial Ordered In '63 Arkansas Slaying
description: A third trial is needed for James Dean Walker, in the 21-year-old slaying of an Arkansas police officer, to remove a ''stain on our criminal justice system,'' the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit ruled today.

title: JERSEY CANDIDATE TO USE A MUSIC VIDEO IN RACE
description: Politicians, searching for new ways to reach voters, have begun to adopt television's most recent innovation: the music video, Hoping to attract the attention of baby boomers, who in last year's Presidential election favored the Republican Party, a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in New Jersey has produced a two-minute political video, complete with Bruce Springsteen-style music.

title: TAX REAL ESTATE FAIRLY
description: Can you imagine an income tax system in which taxpayers did not have to tell the Internal Revenue Service how much money they made? And can you imagine then requiring the Federal Government to estimate taxpayers' incomes and deductions by looking at how they dressed or where they lived, and, after that, sending tax bills based on those estimates? And, finally, would it be fair and sensible if anyone whose tax bill turned out to be too high could sue for a refund while those whose bill was too low just smiled and kept the money?

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: A BIPARTISAN BUDGET
description: Republican and Democratic legislative leaders were all smiles today as they crowded around Gov. William A. O'Neill to watch him sign into law a budget and tax cuts for Connecticut.

title: Teamster Union Strikes Yosemite National Park
description: Shuttle bus drivers and other members of the teamsters' union walked off their jobs here today, but supervisors filled in and no services were reported interrupted.

title: KROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LITTLEFIELD, ADAMS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR AN ART TRUCE IN FOLEY SQUARE
description: A good deal of self-serving rhetoric has been generated during a deplorable conflict in the art world. The adversaries are Richard Serra, a Minimalist sculptor, and several thousand people who work in the offices and courthouses around Foley Square in downtown Manhattan.

title: STRIKE ADDS TO SWEDISH WOES
description: Sweden's welfare state has long been held up as a model among labor and Socialist leaders. Just this week, on the eve of his visit here, Spain's Socialist Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, described Sweden as an example he would like to emulate. But an increasing number of Swedes are wondering why.

title: 11 REASONS TO RUN IN THE PREAKNESS
description: Spend a Buck will not run in the Preakness Stakes here today because his owner wants to take a shot at a $2.6 million payday in the Jersey Derby at Garden State Park on May 27 instead of giving his colt a chance to win the Triple Crown. Dennis Diaz, the owner, argues that the jackpot is a unique opportunity, that he is unimpressed by the tradition of sending the Kentucky Derby winner to the Preakness and that the money means more than the Triple Crown.

title: A Few Stanzas For the Young Set
description: We must read aloud to children!'' said Donald Hall, poet and editor of the ''Oxford Book of Chidren's Verse in America.'' ''This is the way people learned to read for hundreds of years, with the assistance of other people's voices.''

title: 2 Banks Cut Prime Rate; Bonds Rise
description: Two major New York banks, Citibank and Chase Manhattan, said late yesterday that they would cut their prime lending rates by half a point, to 10 percent, effective Monday.

title: Agreement On Interferon
description: Hoffmann-LaRoche Inc. and the Schering-Plough Corporation have reached an agreement allowing them to sell their leukocyte interferon products, believed to be useful in battling some cancers, free from liability for infringement of patent rights.

title: POPE DEFENDS CONCEPT OF A 'JUST WAR'
description: Pope John Paul II, commemorating those who died on the battlefields of Flanders, warned today against ''unilateral slogans'' and ''simple sentimentalism'' in the pursuit of peace.

title: Odessa Threatens the Best
description: It was 27 years ago that James Segrest ran for Abilene Christian, a small college in the plains of west Texas that set two world records in the sprint relays at Modesto, Calif.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY PIZZA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TEAMSTERS ACCEPT A NEW CONTRACT
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced today that its rank and file had ratified a new three-year contract with the trucking industry.

title: Bomb Left in Cab Injures the Driver
description: A gypsy-cab driver was seriously injured when a homemade bomb left in a black purse in his cab exploded when he opened it while driving down Columbus Avenue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the police said.

title: EGYPTIANS AND ISRAELIS AGREE ON TERMS FOR IMPROVING TIES
description: Egyptian and Israeli negotiators concluded three days of talks here today by agreeing to present to their Governments a package of measures intended to improve relations.

title:
PATENTS;

Video Signal Advance Sharpens the Picture
description: A method of coding and decoding video signals to create a high-definition television system was patented this week by William E. Glenn, director of the research center maintained in Dania, Fla., by the New York Institute of Technology.

description: To the Edirtor:

title: GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: The company said that results for the latest quarter include a charge of $3,500,000 for the settlement of two antitrust lawsuits with a competitor.

description: b-Includes a gain of $800,000, or 2 cents a share, from an insurance settlement. c-Net income.

description: To the Editor:

title: Two Envoys' Exits
description: The American Ambassador to Ireland is leaving Dublin, and the Irish Ambassador to the United States is leaving Washington.

title: Soprano and Baritone Win Naumburg Prize
description: Dawn Upshaw, soprano, and Christopher Trakas, baritone, will share first prize in this year's Walter W. Naumburg Vocal Competition in Concert Repertory. Finals were held Thursday morning and afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

title: Cyanamid Unit Bid
description: Finland's state-owned chemicals company, Kemira Oy, said it would pay $100 million for the American Cyanamid Company's titanium dioxide business, including the manufacturing plant at Savannah, Ga.

title: M S E CABLE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Machines That Help Make Apartheid Run
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKE SNARLS FLIGHT PLANS IN CHICAGO
description: About 9 A.M. today the lines at the United Airlines counters at O'Hare International Airport here were three times their usual length as confused and worried passengers queued up to find out whether their flights had been canceled.

title: A System to Improve Nuclear Safeguards
description: Nuclear power plants have protective systems that can shut down the reactor in an emergency.

title: Church of Scientology Loses $39 Million in Fraud Lawsuit
description: A jury today awarded $39 million to a woman who says the Church of Scientology defrauded her with claims it would improve her eyesight and make her more intelligent.

title: RATLIFF DRILLING & EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $103,000 for the quarter and $266,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $91,000 for the quarter and $159,000 for the 6 months.

title: EXPLOSION IN JAPANESE COAL MINE LEAVES 62 DEAD AND OTHERS HURT
description: An explosion in a coal mine shaft a half-mile underground killed 62 workers, and rescue teams have recovered all of the bodies, the police reported today.

title: POLICE PLAN AUCTION OF UNCLAIMED ITEMS
description: More than $100,000 worth of stolen gold jewelry, silverware, watches, and stamps that were recovered and remain unclaimed will be auctioned May 28 by the Police Department, officials said yesterday.

title: All Holocaust Victims Must Be Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: OCCUPATIONAL MEDICAL CORP OF AMER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Juilliard Chairman
description: June Noble Larkin was elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Juilliard School at Lincoln Center, it was announced this week. She succeeds Peter S. Paine, who will remain a trustee of the school. Mrs. Larkin is chairman and vice president of the Edward John Noble Foundation, vice president of the Museum of Modern Art, a trustee of the Museum of Broadcasting and the New York Philharmonic, and director of the Cultural Assistance Center, the New York Regional Association of Grantmakers and the Arts Coalition of the Empire State.

title: REXON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
APECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $733,000. c-Net loss.

title: South Korean Students Mark '80 Kwangju Riots
description: Students demonstrated throughout South Korea today, often fighting with the police, on the fifth anniversary of an uprising against martial law in which nearly 200 people were killed.

title: DANCE: NEW 'SYLPHIDE' BY BALLET THEATER AT MET
description: Martine van Hamel and Kevin McKenzie stepped into Erik Bruhn's staging of ''La Sylphide'' for American Ballet Theater Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Miss van Hamel makes for a seductive, womanly sylph.

title: INTEGRITY FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss which is after a net realized investment gain of $1,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $103,000.

title: ATE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Chrysler, G.E. Credit Pact
description: The Chrysler Corporation today announced a joint venture between its Chrysler Financial Corporation subsidiary and the General Electric Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company, to finance real estate, equipment and machinery purchases.

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $5,314,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $4,926 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $9,313 for the quarter and $18,949 for the 6 months.

title: Ghana Sends Protest To Nigeria Over Aliens
description: Ghana sent a formal protest to the Nigerian Government today over what it said was the brutal treatment of illegal immigrants who are being expelled from Nigeria.

title: AW COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $9,000. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid March 1.

title: CONFERTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WALKING IN HARLEM There is fine, solid, even ornate architecture in Harlem, much of it built to house the middle-class gentry who lived there at the turn of the century. It is still there, more decrepit in appearance, perhaps, but no less durable and no less worth going out of one's way to see. This opportunity is now at hand on three consecutive Saturdays at 2 P.M., starting today.

title: METS WIN IN 12 ON HIT BY CARTER
description: It took 3 hours 35 minutes, in rainand in chill, but the Mets flashed their remarkable knack for survival once more last night when they caught the San Francisco Giants in the seventh inning and beat them in the 12th, 3-2.

title: MAXXAM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $200,000. c-Includes income of $1,480,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Announced that Bud Harrelson, the team's shortstop from 1965-77 and who has been the manager of the Columbia Mets in the Class A South Atlantic League, would become third-base coach.

title: PASQUALE FOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Indy 500 Hall Adds 4
description: Three drivers who gained fame by winning the Indianapolis 500 at record speeds and one who got recognition for not winning the race at all have been named to the 500's Hall of Fame. They are Joe Boyer, the co-winner in 1924; Floyd Roberts, who won in 1938; Parnelli Jones, the 1963 winner, and Henry Banks, the 1950 national driving champion.

title: CHECK TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CHESS REMATCH PLAN OFFERED
description: The International Chess Federation today recommended that the replay of the world title match between Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov be held in Marseilles, France, and be limited to 24 games.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, MAY 18, 1985

title: No Headline
description: There used to be traffic jams on Main Street.

title: PHILHARMONIC: STRAUSS'S 'SYMPHONIA DOMESTICA'
description: WHAT more appropriate music for an evening within the family of the New York Philharmonic than the ''Symphonia Domestica''? Richard Strauss's grand, almost palatial, music hardly fits the average household, but the way the Philharmonic and its conductor, Zubin Mehta, chose to play it on Thursday night made this piece sound very comfortable in Avery Fisher Hall's wide spaces and bright acoustics. There were two other works here - Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 3 and the Mozart Sinfonia Concertante in E Flat (K. 297b). Both featured soloists from within the body of the orchestra.

title: NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
description: STRATEGIES FOR RECOVERY: RUNNER More than loyalty to a particular brand, there's loyalty to a specific shoe. One of the most common pieces of advice you see in running magazines is ''If it's not broke, don't fix it.''

title: A TRANSLATOR SPILLS THE BEANS
description: ATRANSLATOR has been commissioned at 5 cents a word to render a 500-page Czech novel into English. He has three months to perform his task. The author is hot - the winner of a prestigious literary prize or a recently jailed dissident.

title: Merrill Lynch
description: ''Getting Merrill Lynch Moving Again'' (March 31) stated that Merrill Lynch's revenues from corporate underwriting fees had increased from $30 million five years ago to $40 million last year. While this figure is technically accurate, it does not reflect the generally accepted measures of overall performance for investment banking firms.

title: CANADIANS TRIUMPH
description: There is no regularly scheduled bridge event in the world remotely resembling the Cavendish Club invitational pairs. Almost all the players are of international caliber, and some come for the occasion from Europe and South America. Bidding boxes, table screens and sliding trays are employed, as in world championships. The scoring method is unusual, with international match points calculated by computer across the field. There are large entry fees, cash prizes and a Calcutta pool. And money is raised for charity: nearly $12,000 last weekend for the Center for Medical Consumers.

title: LIGHTHEARTEDMUSIC MAKES A RETURN
description: Charm is a quality rarely encountered in our brassy age of hype and glitter. Although the social landscape may apppear bleak, however, all is not lost. One final bastion of charm does remain to delight those who crave its airy pleasures: light music, or more precisely, light-hearted music. When performed with good taste and an appropriate sense of style, music of this nature affords a splendid antidote to the rudest shocks that modern civilization can heave at us. Obviously the time is ripe for charm to return, for recently there has been a spate of recordings of lighthearted repertory from the 17th century to the present day.

title: BOMBING IN BEIRUT HAS TROUBLING ECHOES
description: Bombings are virtually a normal occurrence in Beirut - there had been one in the same neighborhood about a week before - but even by local standards, the explosion on March 8, the Moslem Sabbath, was massive. At least 80 people were killed and 200 wounded in the densely populated Shiite neighborhood. The explosion went off on the doorstep of Sheikh Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the fiery preacher who is widely believed to be the inspiration behind the rapidly growing fundamentalist Party of God movement. Several of his bodyguards were killed, but he was untouched; he had stopped to speak with an elderly woman follower, varying his routine by minutes.

title: MacArthur in the Philippines
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAIN OF DEATH IN SRI LANKA
description: Two years ago yesterday, Sri Lanka declared a state of emergency in its fight to subdue the Tamil separatists. Yet, as a new chain of violence showed last week, the conflict between the Sinhalese majority and the minority of largely Hindu Tamils is, if anything, worse than ever.

title: AGENTS DESCRIBE INQUIRY ON ANTI-KLAN GROUP
description: Two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have testified that the bureau began an investigation of the Communist Workers Party two weeks before five members were shot to death in 1979 march to protest the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Kidnapping Conviction
description: Daniel Nichols, a 20-year-old mountain man from southwestern Montana, was convicted last week of kidnapping and assaulting a woman last July. A jury acquitted Mr. Nichols of a murder charge, however. Mr. Nichols and his 54-year-old father, Donald Boone Nichols, were accused of kidnapping Kari Swenson as she jogged along a trail.

title: A STOREFRONT SERVING WITH STYLE
description: THE new restaurant realism, a marriage of form and function, is typified by the aptly named My Kitchen Bistro in Forest Hills, Queens. This storefront is no bigger than many a kitchen, and a good third of the space is given over to the ranges and counters, open to view, at which the cooking takes place.

title: POKING ALONG NEW HAMPHIRE ROADS
description: Out-of-state tourists, passing through the small New Hampshire town I've lived in for most of these last 12 years, and consulting their guidebooks for points of interest, would doubtless make their way to our town's one and only officially recognized historical landmark - the home of our nation's 15th President, Franklin Pierce. I cannot tell you what they would find there, because - although my husband and I live just three miles from the Pierce homestead - we have yet to visit it. I hear the walls bear original stenciling of the sort we paid more than a few dollars to see, passing through Beaufort, S.C., recently. But visiting 19th-century houses run by local historical societies is what one does when traveling in unfamiliar parts.

title: STUDY OF INSTRUMENT IS FACTOR IN BOEING TRIAL
description: A report made in December 1978 on a faulty cockpit instrument has emerged as a potentially important element in a negligence suit resulting from the crash of an Air India Boeing 747 in 1978.

title: Four Books on Investing
description: SEX AND MONEY: Behnd the Scenes With the Big-Time Brokers. By John D. Spooner. 258 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

title: YUGOSLAV, PREPARING FOR U.S. TRIP, ACKNOWLEDGES ECONOMIC DECLINE
description: Two weeks before a visit to the United States, Prime Minister Milka Planinc says a faltering economy has brought Yugoslavia ''to the point of a rather dangerous limit of what people will tolerate.''

title: YOUNGSTERS VENTURE INTO THE UNKNOWN: A HOSPITAL VISIT
description: Marcy Busch had a cast put on her arm the other day. But 4-year-old Mary didn't have any broken bones. She was visiting the White Plains Hospital Medical Center with her nursery-school class and learning about making casts was part of the tour.

title: STATE MILK OUTPUT FELL IN 1984
description: New York State's dairy farmers produced slightly less milk in 1984 than they did in 1983 because of a temporary Federal program that paid some of them to cut production, according to figures released by the State Crop Reporting Service.

title: PRECISION SAILING
description: THERE IS NO SENSATION QUITE LIKE that of being lost at sea. It has happened to most sailors at one time or another, and when it does, biological anxieties are suddenly awakened. Things you tend to take for granted suddenly loom in the mind as . . . well, problematic. For instance, propulsion. There is never all that much fuel aboard a sailing vessel, and if the waters are calm and the wind neglectful, you begin to ask yourself whether you will run out of fuel. To be sure, it does not much matter whether you do if you do not know in which direction to head.

title: MUSIC: ENSEMBLE FROM ST. CECILIA
description: THE three works that the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra presented Thursday night at Carnegie Hall were written within the span of little more than a decade, but represent very different phases in their creators' careers. Two of Giuseppe Verdi's ''Quattro Pezzi Sacri'' - the ''Stabat Mater'' and ''Te Deum'' - opened the program, works written in 1896, when the composer was already past 80.

title: ODESSA SETS RECORD
description: Odessa College used six first place finishes, including a national junior college record of 39.31 seconds in the 400-meter relay, in today's final day to score a meet-record 190 points, twice as many as the runnerup.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: KIT BRANDON, by Sherwood Anderson. (Arbor House, $6.95.) This was Sherwood Anderson's last novel, published in 1936; he died in 1941. The heroine is an illiterate Appalachian girl who strikes out on her own, works, marries, bootlegs and gradually, as she examines her life, acquires a workable philosophy. Stanley Young commented here that in this work, unlike his previous novels, Anderson ''begins to suggest possible answers, possible faiths, possible staffs to cling to.'' FIRST LADY FROM PLAINS, by Rosalynn Carter. (Fawcett Gold Medal, $3.95.) Jimmy Carter, Jody Pow-ell and Hamilton Jordan had also written on their White House experiences when Rosalynn Carter's account appeared last year. But our reviewer, Phil Gailey, said her book was probably more useful than theirs to readers who wanted to understand Jimmy Carter. The most interesting and valuable parts of the book, he said, flowed from her access to power. ''Mrs. Carter has written what may turn out to be the best human account of the Carter Presidency that we are likely to get.'' THE VIEW FROM POMPEY'S HEAD, by Hamilton Basso. (Arbor House, $6.95.) Anson Page, hero of this 1954 novel, is a New York lawyer who returns to his Southern home town to unravel an embezzlement, and unearths the mysteries of his own life. Our reviewer, John Brooks, called it ''the most pleasantly and sensibly romantic novel to come my way in a long time.'' LEMON SWAMP AND OTHER PLACES: A Carolina Memoir, by Mamie Garvin Fields with Karen Fields.

title: THEIR COUNTRY 'TIS OF THEM
description: WAYLON By R. Serge Denisoff. Illustrated. 375 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. Paper, $10.95.

title: HOW FOUR FAMILIES CHARTED THEIR OWN COURSES
description: WHEN all the talk of investment strategies and tactics is past, what remains for each investor is a highly personal decision about how to proceed. People form strong ideas about what to do and where to do it from advice they receive, books they read, people they talk to, how their parents, aunts and uncles invested - perhaps even by gazing out the window. Some people make only the safest investments, with predictable returns; others prefer to take a risk with the hope of striking it rich. More still strike a balance between the two extremes. Here are four strategies, each, by the investors' own account, successful.

title: POOR WOMEN
description: WORKING YOUR WAY TO THE BOTTOM The Feminization of Poverty. By Hilda Scott. 192 pp. Boston: Pandora Press/Routledge & Kegan Paul. $8.95.

title: President Makes Plea On Funds for Military
description: President Reagan said today that he would be ready to take his case to the American people if he was unable to reach a ''suitable compromise'' with Congress on military spending.

title: BUILDING HISTORY ON YALE CAMPUS
description: Your correspondent, Paul Bass, is incorrect when he states in his article about Dwight Hall [''Campus Group Is Community Provider,'' April 21] that ''for 99 years the Gothic building has sent thousands of student volunteers into the surrounding community.''

title: THE BRITISH TURN OUT DUDS, TOO
description: Even for the British, television is far from being a daily diet of ''Jewel in the Crown'' success. A prime case in point is ''Strangers and Brothers,'' the current offering on public television's Masterpiece Theater, Sunday evenings at 9. Like Granada TV's ''Jewel in the Crown,'' this is adapted from an ambitious literary work - nothing less than C. P. Snow's cycle of 11 novels, running to more than 3,000 pages, under the umbrella title of ''Strangers and Brothers.'' It has been adapted for the British Broadcasting Corporation by Julian Bond, a relatively distinguished veteran of mini-series credits. It has been produced by Philip Hinchcliffe with a clear concern for the source material. And yet, for all that, ''Strangers and Brothers'' is a dud, almost painfully so. British television, it seems, is only human.

title: LION IN A KALEIDOSCOPE
description: MAILER His Life and Times. By Peter Manso. Illustrated. 718 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: NICARAGUAN OPPOSITION CHIEF ASSAILS U.S. TRADE EMBARGO
description: The Nicaraguan opposition leder, Arturo Jose Cruz, has criticized the United States trade embargo against Managua and called for an end to both United States and Soviet bloc aid to rebels in the region.

title: THE CURSE OF THE MASSES
description: Vodka is the national drink of the Soviet Union, consumed without restraint on virtually every special occasion, on many lunch hours and on more than a few street corners. It is also the national scourge, blamed for everything from hurting productivity to reducing the birthrate.

title:
STAGE VIEW;

HOW THEY GET THAT SHOW ON THE ROAD
description: It is just before dawn in Minneapolis, and the convoy of tractor trailers that form the road company of ''La Cage Aux Folles'' is ready to move on. Some 300 costumes are packed and loaded, along with 3,000 lightbulbs, a seven-foot crucifix and a statue of a kangaroo. Somewhere among the crates sits Le Clanche Du Rand's trunk, with a picture of the new husband she sees only when her schedule allows. Ronald Dennis's slippers, shaped like green pea pods, are tucked somewhere too, a comforting reminder of home. So are are Annie Sullivan's dog biscuts, though Bernie, the spaniel who eats them, will travel by air with the cast and crew.

title: Nothing to Read
description: New York City's school officials are elated over the latest annual reading test: 57 percent of pupils in grades 2 through 9 scored at or above the national median level, the best result in years. That good news, however, makes the bad news even more dismaying: School libraries have become abysmal.

title: AMORY HUBBARD BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Amory Ann Hubbard, the daughter of Thomas Bassett Hubbard of New York and the late Ann Amory Hubbard, was married in New York yesterday to Richard Temple Millard, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Millard of Pebble Beach, Calif. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, pastor of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. S. B. Bourne.

title: MINING FOR PROFITS IN THE JUNGLES OF BRAZIL
description: IT seemed to be a recipe for disaster: A state-owned company in a financially squeezed, developing nation embarks on a huge iron-ore export project when demand for metals is tumbling worldwide. ''So what are we doing entering an industry that is in decadence?'' asked Eliezer Batista, president of Brazil's Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, adding cheerfully: ''That is some question when you're spending $4 billion.''

title: IS THIS THE WAVE OF THE FUTURE?
description: Nobody can tell for sure whether Sony has opened the doors of the future or a can of worms. When the company last month declared its intention to produce video equipment in the controversial new 8-millimeter format, reaction in the trade was hopeful surprise mixed with instant skepticism. Who, it was asked with a fair degree of unanimity, needs a third video format incompatible not just with VHS but also with Sony's own Beta?

title: CALIFORNIA
description: To the Editor: I have to agree with Wallace Turner's statement in his article on drives in Northern California (Travel, April 21) that State Route 1 north of San Francisco offers glorious scenery; however, his suggestion of driving north on U.S. 101 to Cloverdale means missing many miles of spectacular coastline scenery.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It happened so quick I couldn't do anything but run. All of a sudden it just exploded around me - the car, the gas tank and everything.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Chicago on May 5 gave an incorrect toll-free telephone number for the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. The number is 800-621-6906.

title: BUYING AN APARTMENT: THE FINANCES
description: IN the last three years, more than 39,000 rental apartments in New York City have been converted to cooperatives or condominiums, creating a new class of property owners and a new consciousness about the opportunities for owning property. Those shopping for an apartment -and tenants in buildings undergoing conversion - must weigh the finances of buying an apartment and answer certain questions before stepping up to the dotted line. Consider the finances in two hypothetical cases. John and Mary are in their early 30's, have two young children and a combined household income of $60,000. They have $25,000 in savings and rent a three-bedroom apartment in the Bayside section of Queens for $850 a month. They're thinking of buying a $110,000 three-bedroom co-op in Forest Hills. Monthly maintainance charges at the co-op are $550 a month, of which 40 percent is tax deductible.

title: IOWA, NATIONAL MENACE
description: If Nicaragua is ''an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States,'' what do you call Iowa?

title: 'STATEMENT' ON 23D
description: There is no denying that West 23d Street is shedding its seedy image as Chelsea, the neighborhood around it, emerges as an area of choice for upwardly mobile Manhattanites. Still, it was a bold move for the developers of a new condominium at 118 West 23d Street to commission Der Scutt, the architect responsible for Trump Tower, to design their new building, which will go up on a block that is only begining to feel the impact of the area's gentrification.

title: BY WORDS PROCESSED
description: DIGITAL FUTURE The Personal Computer Explosion -Why It's Happening and What It Means. By John Case. 192 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $12.95.

title: BORDER PATROL IS TROUBLED BY ATTACKS ON AGENTS
description: The Border Patrol is alarmed over what appears to be a slow but steady rise in violent attacks on its agents as they try to impede the flow of illegal immigrants along the far western section of the United States-Mexican border.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Johannesburg in The Week in Review last Sunday about white people in South Africa incorrectly attributed a conclusion that they were feeling politically insecure and buffeted by economic difficulties. That observation was made by a commentator in the Sunday Times of Johannesburg.

title:
MUSIC;

YOUTH SYMPHONY TO OFFER PRIZE PROGRAM
description: FOR THE second time in three years, the New Jersey Youth Symphony has won first prize in a Belgian music festival and competition.

title: KINDERGARTEN COMPETENCY
description: Excerpts from a column by Leon E. Greene in the May issue of Principal, a magazine published by the National Association of Elementary School Principals:

title: LESLIE JONES HAS NUPTIALS
description: Leslie Ann Jones, a daughter of Mary Philbrick Jones of Summit, N.J., and Carlisle Jones of New York and Lawrenceville, N.J., was married yesterday to John Sherrad Brittain Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brittain of Philadelphia and Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Raymond Downs performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit.

title: DEVELOPERS WOO STRUGGLING MARINA OWNERS
description: IN the spring, sunrise comes to Long Island at about 6 o'clock, one hour after William Lieblein starts his workday at Port of Egypt Marine in Southold. Bulkheads and docks need to be repaired after a winter of ice damage. Hulls need to be scraped and painted. Plumbing and electric lines to marina slips need to be restored.

title: PRESERVING OLD NEW ENGLAND
description: They are like pearls on a string, which laid on a map would approximate Interstate 95 from Branford, Conn., to Wiscasset, Maine - 21 of them in all, although with a little detouring the total comes to 24. They are the properties of the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities, so methodically arranged geographically as to suggest that the governing factor in acquisition and public accessibility was the convenience of visitors calling by car.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Democratic chairman of a state with four electoral votes does not command much influence in high party circles unless the state happens to be New Hampshire. Because the earliest and thus, presumably, one of the most influential Presidential primaries is held on his turf, George Bruno, the state chairman, sometimes gets special treatment from Democratic leaders around the country, seeking his friendship or avoiding his territory.

title: GRAHAM CRUSADE IN HARTFORD
description: TO those religious leaders who have been involved in the preparations for it, this afternoon's opening of the Southern New England Billy Graham Crusade represents only a small outward sign of what they hope will be spiritual rebirth in the region.

title: Good Novelists, Good Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising a Point On College Play
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CASTRO BUILDS RELATIONS WITH SOUTH AMERICA
description: After more than two decades of rejection and isolation, Fidel Castro is building new relationships in South America, dispelling many old suspicions and succeeding in dimming his image as a threatening revolutionary, many diplomats say.

title: STAMFORD SCHOOL AIMS FOR THE TOP
description: CAROL SUMNER says she will always remember the words of her teacher, George Balanchine, who was the co-founder of the New York City Ballet.

title: HOSTAGE BID BY KUWAITIS SAID TO FAIL
description: An offer by Kuwait to free 17 prisoners in return for the release of kidnapped Americans has been turned down by the Islamic Holy War organization because the fundamentalist group found the terms of the exchange unacceptable, Arab diplomats here said today.

title: FLORIDA WILDFIRES THREATEN TOWNS ON ATLANTIC COAST
description: Wildfires described as the worst in Florida's history leaped highways today and menaced populated areas on the north-central Atlantic coast of the peninsula.

title: TANK'S PROSPECT WINS PREAKNESS
description: Tank's Prospect charged down the stretch at Pimlico Race Course today to snatch victory from Chief's Crown in the final stride and win the 110th Preakness Stakes by a head. The winner's time of 1:53 2/5 for a mile and three-sixteenths under Pat Day was one-fifth of a second faster than Gate Dancer's official track record set in last year's Preakness and equaled Secretariat's disputed and unofficial 1973 record.

title: ANGST GOES EAST
description: TOKYO WOES By Bruce Jay Friedman. 187 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $14.95.

title: IN RYE, THE FUTURE OF THE JAY MANSION IS CLOUDED BY SUITS
description: THE Jay Mansion in Rye has a past that makes it a treasure to preservationists, but its future is in jeopardy.

title: I.R.A.'S FOES BITTER OVER ITS GAINS IN ULSTER VOTE
description: The success of the Irish Republican Army's political wing in Northern Ireland's local government elections has brought expressions of disappointment from Dublin and renewed assertions by British officials that they will not meet with its elected representatives.

title: D. R. MORRIS WEDS DR. MELISSA LARSEN
description: Dr. Melissa Ellen Larsen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Larsen of West New York, N.J., was married in Washington yesterday to Davyd Roy Morris, a son of Dorothy Pond Morris of Palo Alto, Calif., and Kenneth R. Morris of Sebastopol, Calif. The Rev. William E. Foreman performed the ceremony at the National Presbyterian Church.

title: CONTRACTS FOR CONSTITUENTS
description: 'There's no way to eliminate the desire of representatives to get as much for their states as possible.

title: Jury Convicts Swiss Banker Of Having Diverted Millions
description: Robert Leclerc, a Swiss banker, was found guilty today of diverting millions of dollars from his private Geneva-based bank into secret accounts.

title: PUTTING THE CHIPS ON ISAAC NEWTON
description: THE EUDAEMONIC PIE By Thomas A. Bass. 324 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

title: MORE FUNDS SOUGHT BY LEGAL SERVICES
description: ALTHOUGH at least 233,000 New Jerseyans may have needed and qualified for free legal help in civil cases in 1984, a report by Legal Services of New Jersey has found that only 34,614 were served.

title: HOW-TO-VOTE TAPE IS SENT TO SCHOOLS
description: LEASA MISKELLA, a senior at Bunnell High School in Stratford, had just watched the Secretary of the State on a television screen discussing the importance of voting.

title: Braves' Mahler Wins 8th
description: Rick Mahler drilled a three-run double in the second to support his eighth pitching victory, the most in the majors, as the Braves beat the Chicago Cubs today, 4-3.

title: Dance
description: Dancers may have their esthetic differences. Yet dancers manage to get along remarkably well together, the dance world often seems ''one world'' and choreographers freely borrow from various styles and influences.

title: SELF-CONTROL: DIRECT INVESTING
description: SEVENTEEN months ago Carmine Arena, a concert pianist and teacher, made his first real-estate investment, a five-story apartment building in the West 100's in Manhattan for under $125,000. Since then, he said, he has been ''overwhelmed'' with offers of up to 10 times that for the property.

title: BAGGAGE CHARGES
description: To the Editor: Paul Grimes's Practical Traveler article, ''Why Baggage Charges Can Soar'' (Travel, April 14), was a painful reminder of our experience with Bangladesh Airlines. A friend and I - both bike tourists -took a round-trip flight between Athens and Bombay in early 1984.

title: STAGE: 'BE HAPPY FOR ME,' A FIRST PLAY
description: ''BE HAPPY FOR ME,'' at the Judith Anderson Theater, looks like a familiar sitcom, but Philip Bosco, Priscilla Lopez and David Groh, the principals in the cast, and John Ferraro, the director, have given it some bite. They often manage to free the characters from the cliches of Jerry Sterner's first play, setting them loose to tickle the audience and even to disturb it a little.

title: AMERICA'S CRIME WITHOUT CRIMINALS
description: E.F. Hutton & Company's plea of guilty to an intricate criminal scheme to obtain interest-free use of millions of dollars by intentionally writing rubber checks has focused attention on corporate crime and the inadequacies of the law-enforcement process. Critics took the Department of Justice to task for securing only restitution and fines from E. F. Hutton without prosecuting the individuals who masterminded or managed the swindle.

title: 2 DIOCESES PLAN FUND DRIVE TO HELP AGING NUNS
description: There is a labor problem at the Mary Louis Convent in Queens that some employers might envy. The nuns refuse to stop working, even though they are officially retired and no longer draw any salary.

title: A Saint's Choice
description: It's not that he has anything against New Jersey, but to Dave Waymer, the Saints cornerback, playing there cannot compare to playing in New Orleans.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Of Prices and Profits Inflation watchers should be pleased Tuesday, when the Government releases its monthly report on the Consumer Price Index. April's rise in the C.P.I. is expected to be just three tenths of 1 percent, which translates into an annual inflation rate of about 4 percent.

title: DAKAR'S MARKETS: STRATEGIES FOR BUYERS
description: All of Dakar is a marketplace. Take a few steps outside any hotel in the Senegalese capital and you encounter a vendor offering colorful designs, made, he says, of butterfly wings.

title: Italian Court Convicts 16 As Sardinian Separatists
description: Sixteen people were convicted today of involvement in a plot to make Sardinia independent from Italy.

title: CAN'T WE LEARN FROM THE PAST?
description: EACH TIME a public issue arises, we ignore history, repeating mistakes and heaping more on top.

title: Lewis Jumps a Windy 28-9 1/4
description: Carl Lewis is still chasing Bob Beamon's long-jump record. During a frustrating afternoon at the U.C.L.A.-Pepsi invitational track meet today, fickle winds and a minor muscle pull helped thwart Lewis in his historic attempt at a mark that has stood since the 1968 Olympic Games.

title: No Dream Situation
description: AFTER A LAYOFF OF many years, I recently resumed dreaming. I didn't plan to. It just happened. If there had been a choice, I would have said, ''No, I did dreaming a long time ago and didn't much like it, thanks. I'd rather just sleep on through.''

title: OPIATES OF THE UNEMPLOYED
description: RED BAKER By Robert Ward. 202 pp. New York: The Dial Press/ Doubleday & Company. $14.95.

title: JEAN HOFFMAN MARRIES FEDERAL BANK ANALYST
description: Jean Elizabeth Hoffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Hoffman Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jay Murray Prior, a son of Mrs. Normand Prior of Enfield, Conn., and the late Mr. Prior. The Rev. Joanne M. Swenson performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Chappaqua.

title: TO CANADIANS, SHE STANDS IN FOR MONARCH
description: Four times a year, Jeanne Sauve sits down to write what she calls a ''rather personal'' letter to the Queen of England, informing her about the state of affairs in Canada.

title: PROPOSALS ON JURIES
description: GOVERNOR KEAN is expected to receive for his approval within the next month legislation proposing the first major revisions in the New Jersey petit jury system in 73 years.

title: BILL SEEKS TO BAN SOME BULLETS
description: LEGISLATION designed to ban ''cop-killer'' bullets is caught between members of Congress and a powerful gun lobby.

title: M.C.I. Increases
description: To the Editor:

title: ALISON WRIGLEY IS MARRIED IN CALIFORNIA
description: Alison Elizabeth Wrigley and Geoffrey Claflin Rusack were married yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church in Pasadena, Calif. The bridegroom's father, Bishop Robert C. Rusack of the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles, performed the ceremony.

title: McCullough Wins Hammer in IC4A
description: Buffeted by winds that gusted close to 30 miles an hour, the 109th outdoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America got under way here today with finals in four events and qualifying rounds in 10 others.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PUSH TO ADJOURN
description: WITH the General Assembly approaching adjournment, it was time last week to finally decide the fate of some matters, about which lawmakers had been arguingsince the session began in January.

title: Finale for a Packer
description: Gary Lewis, the Green Bay Packer tight end who was sidelined last season with a blood-clotting problem, said he had come to the end of his career. ''It looks like I'll have to hang it up,'' he said after consulting with specialists in Green Bay, Wis.; Rochester, Minn., and Dallas.

title: NEW PROTESTS RECALL 60'S IN BERKELEY
description: One by one recently, names that recall the social turbulence of the 1960's have appeared, as if from the back pages of history, on the arrest logs of Berkeley's Police Department.

title: SPORTING WITH NABOKOV
description: INVENTING IVANOV By Roberta Smoodin. 295 pp. New York: Atheneum. $15.95.

title: LONDON, IN A FOG
description: Adam, who witnessed my unpacking, was incredulous. You went to Europe to buy hairpins? he said. Yes, as a matter of fact, I did. In the United States they are unavailable, and in Canada they are absurdly expensive. I also went to England to see the Queen and to eat nursery puddings and tea sandwiches. I saw the Queen. I never did find the nursery puddings, and I was stupefied by the owner of the classic old-lady tearoom of my dreams in Freshwater who in response to my request said, ''I never understand what Americans mean by the word pudding.'' A waitress in a tiny town in Wales said, ''We really don't have puddings, but if you like I can take the gateau and smash it into a pudding.'' The only tea sandwich I was ever to see was a single pinwheel on the return flight to America, and when I asked for tea sandwiches at Harrods, the salesperson said several times: ''Cheese sandwiches? Cheese sandwiches?''

title: 11 Named for Hall
description: Eleven people, including the only man to have won both the running long jump and high jump in the same Olympics, have been nominated for three slots in the National Track and Field Hall of Fame, according to The Athletics Congress. It will announce the new inductees next month after balloting by 600 writers, officials and Hall members. Among the candidates in the athlete and coach-contributor categories are the late Ellery Clark, who won the two jumping events at the 1896 Olympics; Abel Kiviat, the 93-year-old distance runner who is the oldest living American Olympic medalist; John Thomas, the two-time Olympic medalist and former world champion in the high jump; Fred Hansen, the 1964 Olympic pole-vault champion; Ron Laird, who won 65 American race-walk titles between 1958 and 1976, and Bud Wilson, a San Jose coach whose pupils included the Olympic champions Lee Evans, Tommie Smith and John Carlos, and Martha Wilson, the eight-time United States long-jump champion, who is the only woman in the group.

title: NATO Delegates Split On 'Star Wars' Proposal
description: French, Norwegian and Danish delegates to a NATO meeting today criticized the United States-proposed ''Star Wars'' antimissile system on the grounds it could unhinge the peace in Europe.

title: 'ORPHANS' IS A STUDY IN THE STEPPENWOLD STYLE
description: By vote of the American Theater Critics Association, the Steppenwolf Theater Company has been named the winner of the 1985 Tony award as outstanding regional theater, an exceedingly timely selection that recognizes the special character of this youthful Chicago company. Steppenwolf is the first Off Broadway-size troupe to receive the award, and, by definition, it is also one of the most egalitarian choices. Basic to the structure of the company is the fact that there is no single artistic director, but a revolving and collaborative leadership. Just as members take turns at heading the theater, actors and directors switch roles between productions. This has led to a creative ensemble of actor-directors, including, most prominently, John Malkovich, Gary Sinise and Terry Kinney, each of whom is a theatrical double-threat.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: May 19, 1985 Fiction

title: LEVERAGE, AND PRIDE OF OWNERSHIP
description: THE allure of real estate as a personal investment arises basically from the wonders of leverage.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOME FIRES. By Charlotte Mayerson. (Arbor House, $15.95.) In a novel as subtly illuminating and nostalgic as firelight, Charlotte Mayerson explores the interracial friendship of two independent working women -one the other's servant - who both marry late, finding the ostensible men of their dreams not at the age of 20 but at nearly 40.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

ALL FOR ''THIS FIERCE LOVE'' OF BACH
description: LATIN purists may scoff, but as far as Mary Heurtley is concerned, Musica Convivia means ''a feast of music.'' That's ''myoosica, not moosica,'' she insisted. ''I like it anglicized.''

title: THE TEST THAT PROVES THE PICTURE
description: FOR the serious photographer, automatic exposure control is not to be trusted; what counts is the final image on the finished print or transparency. A hand-held exposure meter may give inaccurate readings. A built-in meter may be susceptible to weak batteries. Even a camera's shutter speeds may not be accurate. There are dozens of problems that can affect picture quality.

title: FOREIGN-BORN INMATES BURDEN STATE PRISONS
description: A growing number of inmates in the state prison system are foreign-born, and a majority of them could be deported to save the state the cost of incarceration, the chairman of the New York State Senate Crime and Correction Committee said yesterday.

title: TOWN REVERSES ITS FORTUNES
description: SHELTON, an old industrial city that has been transformed into a corporate boomtown in just eight years, is now vying with Danbury as the new focus for development in southwestern Connecticut.

title: PERSONALITY BEHIND THE PORTFOLIO
