description: MAE WEST once remarked, ''At 20, you need good parents. At 30, you need a good personality. At 40, you need good investments.''

title: THE SENATOR AND THE ROOKIE
description: THE night two months ago when Georgetown eliminated Loyola of Chicago from the National Collegiate basketball tournament, Willis Reed and Dave DeBusschere, teammates on the Knicks' championship teams in 1970 and 1973, happened to be watching the game on television together. On the screen, Patrick Ewing suddenly raised the ball over his head, freezing the center guarding him, then took a quick crossover step and easily put the ball into the basket.

title: JEWEL OF A LOOK: PILING ON PEARLS
description: THE prevailing rule of pearl wearing is that there cannot possibly be too much of a good thing. Abundant evidence of this can be found these days on the sidewalks of midtown Manhatan.

title: IN AN EVEN POSITION, TRY ROCKING THE BOAT
description: Tranquil level positions are, for most players, not easy to play. They don't excite or inspire and there are problems singling out reasonable objectives.

title: BABYING GROWN-UPS
description: BABIES aren't the only ones being pampered these days. In growing numbers, adults are opting to care for their skin and hair with soaps, shampoos, powders, lotions, creams and oils marketed for the diaper set. Government estimates indicate a small decrease in the birth rate from l982 to l983, but baby soap and shampoo sales increased more than l4 percent and baby lotions and oils gained almost 24 percent. Johnson & Johnson, the nation's leading marketer of toiletries for infants, says that 70 percent of its baby powder is used by adults. Behind this boom is the perception that baby products are milder than others. With certain exceptions, however, this is not necessarily the case.

title: CONSUMER RATES
ALICE W. LEE MARRIED TO JOHN M. GROTON 3d
description: Alice Wetmore Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Lee of Princeton, N.J., and John Mansfield Groton 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Groton Jr. of Stonington, Conn., were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton. The Rev. Jean R. Smith performed the ceremony.

title: SHUTOUT FOR GALE
description: Rich Gale, a former Boston Red Sox hurler, scattered four hits in the Hanshin Tigers' 2-0 victory over the Yomiuri Giants in Japan League baseball today. Gale, in his first season in Japan, picked up his fourth victory against two defeats.

title: ERIN LEIDER IS MARRIED
description: Erin Leider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Leider of Miami, was married yesterday to Paul Eric Pariser, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Pariser of Freeport, L.I. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Water Club in Manhattan.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: OFFICIALS of the Ciba-Geigy Corporation in Toms River said last week they were still reviewing a 52-page permit issued by the state that will allow the company to continue discharging toxic wastes into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WHILE the world celebrated the 40th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe earlier this month, residents of Point Pleasant Beach recalled, as one longtime resident put it, ''the days when the war was visible from our own front beach.''

title: FRANK CAPRA'S FILMS LEAD FRESH LIVES
description: Frank Capra, who became a Hollywood legend by making movies about the common man often battling forces greater than himself, is battling a segment of Hollywood that is trying to give a new life to one of his best loved films, ''It's a Wonderful Life.''

title: JACKSON STRESSES BLACK-JEWISH TIES
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, recently returned from a trip to West Germany and France, says the time has come to reaffirm the ''community of suffering'' shared by blacks and Jews and the ''collective capacity'' of the two groups when they operate as a coalition.

title: The Right Time For Shot Clock
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 28 Nobel Prize Winners Urge Warsaw to Free 3 Dissidents
description: Twenty-eight winners of the Nobel Prize have signed an open letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, protesting the imprisonment Feb. 13 of three Polish dissidents.

title: THE ART OF REVIVING BALANCHINE BALLETS
description: A few years ago, the reentry of a George Balanchine ballet into the repertory of New York City Ballet was a matter-of-fact event, one met by varying degrees of pleasure, dependent upon the popularity of the particular work and on the length of time elapsed since it was last seen. Today, two years after the great choreographer's death, such revivals inspire a keener anticipation. Balanchine himself said ''Ballets have short lives,'' but City Ballet is making a concerted effort to see that as many Balanchine ballets as possible achieve longer lives. During the current New York season, six different Balanchine works are returning to the active repertory - ''Cortege Hongrois,'' ''Firebird,'' ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' ''La Valse'' and ''Valse Fantasie,'' in addition to ''Apollo,'' which has been out of the repertory only about a season.

title: GRUENWALD TO FOCUS ON MUSEUM FUNDS
description: DR. Donald Grunewald has a very brief job description. ''I'm a professional beggar,'' he said. ''That's how I earn my living.''

title: SCORN FOR MORALISM
description: GRAVE NEW WORLD By Michael A. Ledeen. 244 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: GLOBE OFF AGAIN
description: The on-again, off-again New Globe Repertory Company, which was scheduled to open its ''Spring 1985'' season at Port Chester's Embassy Theater on May 9, is off again.

title: Tigers Topple A's, 9-6
description: Darrell Evans belted his fourth home run in four games, a three-run shot in the first inning, and Alan Trammell added a home run to power the Detroit Tigers to a 9-6 victory over the Oakland A's today.

title: Rookies Help Fill Indy Field
description: Three rookie drivers, Raul Boesel of Brazil, Jim Crawford of Scotland and John Paul Jr. of the United States, were among the seven drivers who qualified today to fill out the 33-car field for next Sunday's Indianapolis 500.

title: NEW ENGLAND POWER: TIGHT SUMMER
description: New England's supplies of electricity will be tighter in the next few months than in any summer in a decade, according to utility executives.

title: EDUCATORS IN NEW YORK REGION DEBTE COURT'S RULING ON STUDENT SEARCHES
description: Many educators and school officials in the New York region say the United States Supreme Court ruling regarding student searches has done more to confuse them than to clarify when a search is justified.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ARTISTRY AND ARTISANRY The six-year-old Woodstock-New Paltz arts and crafts fair, which draws about 30,000 people each spring, will go on under tents, rain or shine Saturday through Memorial Day. Exhibiting in the juried show are more than 220 artists and artisans.

title: TAX REFORM: DON'T COUNT ON IT, BUT DON'T IGNORE IT
description: OVER the next several months, Congress will be considering a major overhaul of the Federal income tax, a move that could dramatically alter the relative merits of many types of investments. Real estate, for example, stands to lose some of its investment luster if depreciation and other real-estate tax benefits are scaled back. Tax-exempt municipal bonds would become less valuable, if personal income-tax rates were lowered, while corporate bonds, savings accounts and other fully taxable investments would become relatively more attractive. Any decision to curtail the existing preferential tax treatment of long-term capital gains would reduce the after-tax return on collectibles, precious metals and other investments whose principal return is capital appreciation.

title: FOILED BY MOTHER NATURE
description: MY friend Murray seems to know almost everything about everything, so when he remarked the other day as we were driving down Grand Boulevard in Baldwin, ''Migosh! Winter is here already,'' I had to give the idea serious thought. It was only the end of April, but maybe Murray knew something I didn't.

title: ARGENTINA PUTS DOLLAR HOLDINGS UNDER A FREEZE
description: Argentine officials said today that the Government had frozen all dollar accounts for 120 days.

title: RODNEY DEVINE, BUSINESS CONSLTANT, AND EUGENIE HOFFMEYER ARE MARRIED
description: The marriage of Eugenie Hoffmeyer, who is archivist and director of public relations for Edward Larrabee Barnes Associates, an architectural firm in New York, to Rodney Williams Devine, a business consultant, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation in New York. The Rev. J. Douglas Ousley performed the ceremony.

title: SARAH,PLAIN AND TALL
description: SARAH, PLAIN AND TALL By Patricia MacLachlan. 58 pp. New York: A Charlotte Zolotow Book/Harper & Row. $8.95. (Ages 8 to 10) THIS is an exquisite, sometimes painfully touching little tale of a lonely, widowed late 19th-century prairie dweller, his two children and the laconic Sarah Elisabeth Wheaton, who comes from Maine to share their life.

title: COSTA RICANS AT ODDS OVER U.S. ARMY ADVISERS
description: The arrival here this month of United States military advisers to train the Costa Rican police has added to a growing debate about whether the United States is urging this country to militarize against its will.

title: MISSED FACTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN'S HAVEN FOR WILDFOWL
description: At the door that opens into the Wildfowl Trust at Slimbridge in western England one of the rarest birds in the world pecks impatiently at the glass waiting to greet visitors. This is the Hawaiian nene, a small brown goose with a soft voice, whose Polynesian name means ''let's sit together and talk.'' At Slimbridge its friendliness is a bonus, but in its native Hawaii its habit of trying to make friends with humans and other predators brought it close to extinction. There are now more nenes at Slimbridge than in the wild in Hawaii.

title: Briefing;   THE MOSCOW WATCH
description: Kremlinology, a knack for reading a lot into a little, is a venerable trade in Washington, providing gainful employ for a variety of Government and academic analysts and some writers. The Central Intelligence Agency is among the most serious analysts, so serious that each year the agency's Directorate of Intelligence puts out a report on where the highest-ranking Soviet leaders spent their time, day-by-day, in the past year.

title: HELP FOR ADOPTIVE PARENTS
description: I am writing in regard to Dr. Ellen Frank's article [''The Struggle to Have a Child,'' April 28] . I want to inform her and other readers about an organization that has been of tremendous assistance to my husband and myself in achieving our goal of having a child.

title: FOLLOWING A WIFE'S MOVE
description: As Gordon Mott admits, he and others have been professing equality between men and women for a decade. But many, including Mr. Mott, are unable to let go of those well-learned, strictly defined rules of the sexes: man is breadwinner; woman is bread maker.

title: Padres Are Facing a Decision
description: IF there's a team out there that needs a second baseman who stole 70 bases and scored 106 runs last season, one may soon be available. Alan Wiggins is expected to be ready to return to the San Diego Padres in the next couple of weeks, and if he is, the Padres will have to make a decision.

title: A PASSION TO MAKE MUSIC
description: ''YOU just get them all over the place.'' Hugh Prestwood of Greenport was talking about ideas. ''You get them from relationships. You get them from interesting phrases you hear somebody say.''

title: TV'S ONE-MAN BAND MAKES COMPUTER MUSIC
description: His fingers dance on a keyboard and produce a violin solo. He programs a computer and the sound is from a drum. Another touch of the buttons calls up an orchestra. Meet Jan Hammer, one-man electronic band.

title: DEMAND GROWING FOR HIGH-TECH SPACE
description: FOR years, developers all over northern New Jersey have strived to make their office buildings resemble what corporations would find in New York. Where once they were small, cheap and usually ugly, now suburban office buildings are taller and can contain upwards of half a million square feet of not necessarily inexpensive space inside sophisticated exteriors of marble, glass and granite.

title: THE CHANGING FACES OF POLITICS IN ARIZONA
description: Beneath a sweltering sun, bulldozers are knocking down cactus and sagebrush to make way for still more homes on the desert floor near the booming cities of Arizona.

title: The Halls Of Boston Latin School
description: Equal in significance to the racial integration of Boston Latin School was the school's sexual integration (''The Halls of Boston Latin School,'' by Lee A. Daniels, April 21). In September 1967, Juanita Ponte and I were the first two women appointed to the school's academic faculty.

title: MARY DAVIDSON IS WED IN TEXAS
description: Mary Frances Davidson and Andrew Bishop Bartle were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Littlefield, Tex., by the Rev. Jon Riches. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Davidson of Littlefield.

title: INCENTIVES FOR BUYING A HOME
description: THERE is a mystique to home ownership in American culture, but in the 1970's the mystique was bruised. With inflation rampant, homes suddenly became a ''tangible'' that could be purchased essentially for their investment value. House-buying was promoted as a hedge against inflation, and in many markets people bought for speculation above all.

title: Sports of The Times;   Wayne Lukas: Be Prepared
description: ABOUT an hour before post time yesterday, D. Wayne Lukas suddenly realized that he had not thought of everything. He is a trainer who likes to have a reason for everything, who adorns his barns with flowers and fresh paint, and who can plan a seven-minute nap when he needs to sleep.

title:
CASE STUDY: A ONETIME HIGHFLIER;

NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
description: STRATEGIES FOR RECOVERY: SMALL RETAILER Nike built the company on our backs. We took their product back in 1976 and said this is the best thing out there and we worked real hard to sell it.

title: Recent Sales
CHINA GETS HIGH MARKS ON SETTLING REFUGEES
description: Of the millions of Vietnamese who have fled their country by boat or on foot since the Communist victory in 1975, few have attracted less attention around the world than the 280,000 who came north to China.

title: PEEKSKILL HONORS AARON COPELAND
description: WITH two very different works by Aaron Copland bracketing the evening - ''Jingo,'' a quirky little movement from his ''Statements for Orchestra,'' and the milestone Piano Concerto - the world-renowned composer was saluted last weekend at the Paramount Center for the Arts. Mr. Copland heard Mayor Richard E. Jackson Jr. proclaim ''Aaron Copland Week in Peekskill,'' he accepted the Distinguished Service Award of Westchester from County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke ''for all the pleasure and contentment your music has brought to us,'' and he received the first Cultural Award Medallion bestowed by the Paramount Center itself.

title: THE CRAFT OF WRITING ABOUT CRAFTS
description: IS THERE such a thing as craft criticism? That was one of the questions floated and tossed about at a recent Boston University seminar on crafts criticism sponsored by the school's Program in Artisanry and the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Bowl Makes Move
description: The Bluebonnet Bowl has decided to end a 17-year association with the Astrodome and return its New Year's Eve game to Rice Stadium in Houston, where the first game was played in 1959. Jack Busiek, the president of the Greater Houston Bowl Association, said that Rice Stadium's 20,000 additional seats and a favorable rental agreement from Rice were strong factors in the move.

title: BOOKS: FRESH ADVICE
description: THE ZURICH AXIOMS: Investment Secrets of the Swiss Bankers. By Max Gunther. 164 pages. New American Library (Plume). $6.95.

title:
ANTITRUST'S LOOSER GUIDELINES;

REAGAN'S HANDS-OFF POLICY IS WORKING
description: FOR years, Government authorities saw corporate mergers and joint ventures as an economic toxic substance, tolerable in small doses but hazardous to our economic health in larger ones. The Government routinely attacked mergers between companies with small market shares,and a sympathetic Supreme Court admitted that its hostility toward mergers was based not so much on economic concerns as an overriding fear of excessive economic concentration.

title: IN SHORT: NON FICTION
description: SUCH A VISION OF THE STREET: Mother Teresa - The Spirit and the Work. By Eileen Egan. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Three years ago, at age 72 - and against the advice of leaders of the Roman Catholic Church - Mother Teresa spent several days crossing and recrossing Beirut's infamous Green Line to rescue more than 60 mentally ill children from the Moslem sector of that war-ravaged city.

title: J. H. LILLIAN WED TO DEBORAH KASE
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York yesterday Deborah Ruth Kase, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan G. Kase of New York, was married to Jonathan Henry Lillian, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Lillian of Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE DUNWICH HORROR AND OTHERS. By H. P. Lovecraft. Edited by August Derleth and S. T. Joshi. (Arkham House, $15.95.) H. P. Lovecraft still occupies the position of high priest to a cult of the weird-obsessed.

title: STATES ARE FOUND MORE RESPONSIVE ON SOCIAL ISSUES
description: Civil rights groups and lobbyists for the poor, long accustomed to seeking solutions in Washington, say they now often get a more favorable response from state and local officials than from the Reagan Administration.

title: ENDING CURBS
description: To the Editor:

title: REVELATIONS OF SELLING WITHOUT A BROKER
description: SOME of my best friends are real-estate agents. Yet I decided to pass up their professional services when I put up for sale a small parcel of undeveloped land I had invested in four years earlier.

title: THE LIFE AND UNTIMELY DEATH OF A HOUSE
description: I STAND in the middle of the kitchen and cry, thinking only that my house is dying. Although the emotional ties with my former spouse have evaporated and the courts have legally buried our marriage, two decades of my life somehow remained intact.

title: AN EXILE IN LITERARY AMERICA
description: In his article, Vassily Aksyonov poses the question: ''What is a director to do when Academy Awards are often conferred on the basis of box-office receipts?'' For the last four years, the winners in the best-picture category were not, except in one instance, outstanding financial successes.

title: LANDFILL SITE MAY CONTAIN INDIAN GRAVES
description: THE proposal by the Town of Southbury to place a new landfill near Lake Zoar has aroused all the usual concerns about the environment, esthetics and property values. It has also aroused archeological, historial and cultural concerns: The 114-acre tract involved might once have been a 17th-century Indian village and burial ground.

title: BELFRY'S 'BUS STOP' HAS ITS MOMENTS
description: IN 1950, William Inge made a promising Broadway playwrighting debut with ''Come Back, Little Sheba.'' In 1953, when he won the Pulitzer Prize for ''Picnic,'' the promise was fulfilled -for a time.

title: REACHING OUT TO SOMEONE WITH AIDS
description: ONE NIGHT RECENTLY, JIM Sharp and Edward Dunn spent a few hours together discussing the nature of God, mortality and eternity. Edward, who has pronounced opinions on most subjects, says he has no answers on this one. Lately, however, he's been asking more questions. Jim, a transplanted Texan and regular churchgoer, will tell you tongue in cheek that his idea of heaven, ''based on my childhood beliefs,'' is ''a canasta game with lots of coffee and cigarettes.'' But he's been asking more questions, too. He's concluded, he says, that God will not give him more than he can handle.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Beach Boys: An American Band Vestron Video 104 minutes. $79.95 This video cassette chronicles -through interviews, home movies, TV clips, performance footage and some rather glib narration - the history of five young men from Southern California whose melodies won them a world following.

title: JERYL TARDIO, K. H. MALLOY MARRY IN RYE
description: Jeryl Ann Tardio, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil J. Tardio of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Kenneth Henry Malloy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Malloy of Purchase, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Murphy, assisted by the Rev. James Henges, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: MEMORIES OF THE 'SISTERHOOD': NOTHING'S AS STRONG AS FAMILY
description: THEY called their club the ''Sisterhood,'' and it met monthly for most of my childhood, rotating meetings from house to house in the Bronx and Brooklyn. Membership was automatic (they were seven sisters) and exclusive (none of their four brothers or their brothers' wives ever became members).

title: Music
description: George Russell has been a leading catalyst and idea man for contemporary music since the late 1940's, when he was the first jazz composer to embrace both Afro-Cuban rhythms and the innovations of Igor Stravinsky. All of the music's most important subsequent developments, from modal improvisation to electronics, African polyrhythms to free form, atonality to jazz-rock, have taken cues from Mr. Russell's pioneering work.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN DUBLIN
description: Visitors to Dublin will soon be marveling at the most elaborate and expensive restoration job performed on any historic building in Ireland, at the 300-room, 17th-century Royal Hospital in Kilmainham, overlooking the Liffey River.

title: NEW YALE DEGREES FOR OLDER STUDENTS
description: FOR most Yale students, college was a natural step after high school. But for a handful of others, a college degree is the fulfillment of a lifetime dream after years away from school.

title: 'MAN' HAS NO SEX, IN USAGE ANYWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL FUNDS OFFER CACOPHONY OF INNOVATION
description: SETTING investment goals before choosing a mutual fund can help avoid what experts say is the most common mistake made by mutual fund investors: choosing a fund solely on the basis of recent performance. ''Typically, the investor who concentrates on past performance looks at the latest results and buys the fund with the best record,'' said Norman G. Fosback, a stock-market analyst and editor of Mutual Fund Forecaster, a monthly newsletter. ''The problem with past performance is that it's often a poor indicator of what to expect in the future.''

title: NEW, IMPLANTABLE PUMP IS A MAJOR WEAPON IN THE WAR AGAINST PAIN
description: FOR 17 years, Louise Robinson battled cancer with dignity and quiet courage. But last December, sobbing so hard that she could hardly speak, Mrs. Robinson called her doctor to say that she could no longer stand the pain.

title: NEW ATTACK ON WESTWAY
description: Members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation last week lobbed a legislative bombshell onto Westway, the $2 billion highway and development project designed to run along the western edge of Manhattan from 42d Street to the Battery. A bill introduced by Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of the Committee on Public Works and Transportation, would prohibit the use of Federal funds to create 169 acres of landfill in the Hudson River for the project.

title: TEEN-AGE MOTHERS GET AID IN STUDY
description: An experimental program to encourage pregnant teen-agers and teen-age mothers to avoid getting pregnant again was largely successful in its 12 months of operation, but a year later its effect was found to have been transitory, the sponsors said.

title: 'IT DIDN'T NEED NO HELP NO WAY'
description: ON Saturday, May 25, 1935, only a few weeks before high summer, a fatigued, fat and 40-year-old Babe Ruth connected for the last of his 714 major league home runs. (Ruth had 730 in all, counting his 15 World Series home runs and one in the 1933 All-Star Game.) The terminal blast, also Babe's final big league base hit, came off Guy Bush, the pitcher known to the sports press as the Mississippi Mudcat. It was one of three homers that the Babe, playing in his only season with the Boston Braves, hit that afternoon at Pittsburgh's Forbes Field and was a rousing valedictory display of Ruthian power.

title: DOUBLE HOMICIDE
description: AS spring break began at the State University College at Buffalo on March 29, Lisa Eisman and Kim Vaccaro, 20-year-old roommates at the school, climbed aboard a tractor-trailer and set out on the first leg of a hitch-hiking trip to Florida.

title: The Truth Has Few Believers for Fight
description: The Truth is never easy to find in boxing, but there he was, looking much like a fighter in what, except for the casino 100 feet away, looked much like an old-fashioned fight camp.

title: THE DAPPER DANS, REACHING FOR THE PERFECT NOTES
description: And now, ladies and gentlemen, the Dapper Dans of Harmony, under the direction of George Avener. One, two, three, four:

title: Pickens on Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: P.S. FOR SALE
description: New York City has for some time been the municipality's largest property owner, with holdings that range from single-family houses and apartment buildings to warehouses and parking lots. It even owns a farm on Staten Island.

title: FOR 118 TEACHERS, SPACE HAS A SPECIAL ATRACTION
description: One is a former football player with a passion for galaxies, another an amateur radio operator who has taught children throughout the world. Others are an archeologist turned futurist and an admitted ''space nut'' who writes about sports.

title: MUSIC-TV MIXED MEDIA IN 'PASSION OF PASSION'
description: THE shifting world of downtown mixed media appeared in a new guise Thursday night at the Cafe La Mama with the first performance of ''The Passion of Passion.'' Actually, this collaboration between the composer Peter Gordon and the video artist Kit Fitzgerald is a work in progress, with the complete piece scheduled for presentation next month in Paris. What one heard and saw on Thursday lasted slightly less than one hour - apparently about three-quarters of the finished work -and seemed to have some defects, notably a large-size projection screen in the back that remained resolutely dim.

title: WARREN ANDERSON: A PUBLIC CRISIS, A PERSONAL ORDEAL
description: WARREN M. ANDERSON, the chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, has not taken his wife Lillian out to dinner much in the past five months. ''I kind of felt that if somebody caught me laughing over in the corner over something,'' he said, ''they might not think it was appropriate.''

title: DEMOCRATIC GROUP SEEKS MAINSTREAM
description: The first grass-roots outing of a group of moderate Democrats bent on helping their party rediscover ''mainstream America'' began Friday with a breakfast of quiche and croissants in Tallahassee.

title: STUDY FINDS ACIDITY OF PRECIPITATION IN STATE 30 TIMES NORMAL
description: THE first statewide study of acid precipitation in New Jersey shows the average acidity of rain, sleet and snow to be at least 30 times greater than normal.

title:
GARDENING;

KEEPING AN OLD FAVORITE IN BLOOM
description: GERANIUMS have long been a favorite garden subject. Actually, the plants that we most commonly call geranium are really pelargoniums.

title: JOSEPH P. FLYNN WED TO LAURIE ANN SMITH
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I., yesterday Laurie Ann Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Smith Jr. of Manhasset and West Lovell, Me., was married to Joseph P. Flynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Flynn of Chestnut Hill and Dennis Port, Mass. The Rev. Frank N. Johnston performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Fleming, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: PICKING THE WINNERS ON WALL ST.
description: WHEN he was 12 years old, Richard Fentin thought he had found the perfect stock in which to invest - a burger chain that was to be the ''next McDonald's.'' That company, whose name Mr. Fentin does not even remember, is no longer putting chopped beef into buns.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF GODFATHER'S
description: IN 1973, William M. Theisen's Omaha beer parlor, Wild Willy's, was doing a booming business with the pizza place next door: Through a passageway between the two establishments, bar patrons were able to order pizza to go with their beer - and even Mr. Theisen became hooked on the thick, rich pies. Soon, he and his neighbor joined forces to form Godfather's Pizza - and when the 27-year-old Mr. Theisen bought out his partner shortly afterward, he was full of big plans for his favorite pizza.

title: CASTLE OFFERS WORKS OF NORMAN LEWIS
description: BORN in 1909, Norman Lewis died in 1979, three years after his retrospective at the City University Graduate Center. His was a distinguished career both as teacher - notably at the Art Students League - and as a painter represented in numerous museums here and abroad.

title: SELECTIVE OPTIMISM ON STOCKS
description: WHAT'S ahead for stock prices the rest of this year? One favorable omen is that no year ending in ''5'' has ever produced a decline in the Dow Jones industrial average, as far back as 1885. And when President Reagan visited the New York Stock Exchange's trading floor this spring, he declared: ''We're going to turn the bull loose.''

title: DEBORAH JAMES, EDITOR, MARRIED TO HENRY C. CAREY
description: Deborah S. James, a daughter of Mrs. John W. James of North Tarrytown, N.Y., and the late Mr. James, was married yesterday to Henry C. Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Carey of Philadelphia. The Rev. Charles Robitaille performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown.

title: MARTEL BRIDGE TEAM IN LEAD IN WORLD TITLE QUALIFICATIONS
description: Two powerful bridge teams began play here this afternoon, each hoping to earn the right to represent the United States in the 1985 world team championships scheduled in Sao Paulo, Brazil, in October.

title: RECORD'S FIRST PROFITS WILL GO TO THE HUNGRY
description: USA for Africa collected the first proceeds last week from sales of the recording ''We Are the World'' - a check for $6.5 million - and pledged to spend the money on long-term solutions to starvation. The check, representing profits from the hit single's March sales in the United States, brought to $10.8 million the cash collected to help feed the hungry in Africa and the United States, according to Ken Kragen, the charity group's organizer.

title: GILBERT COLGATE 3d WEDS CAROL YOON
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday, Carol Pamela Yoon, a daughter of JoAnne Dillman of Norfolk, Conn., and the late Dr. Ill Lyong Yoon, was married to Gilbert Colgate 3d, a son of Mr. Colgate Jr. and Marlene S. Colgate, both of New York. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy performed the ceremony.

title: 3 Yachts Are Named For the Admiral's Cup
description: A week of trials ended today with the three top boats named to represent the United States in the Admiral's Cup in Britain beginning July 29.

title: ANNE M. LANTZIUS BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Anne Maria Lantzius, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Louis Lantzius of Vancouver, British Columbia, and Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday to Edward Matthews Strauss 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Strauss Jr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title:
ART;

PICTURESQUE WATERCOLORS FROM AN ENGLISH MASTER
description: PAUL SANDBY (1730-1809) has been called the ''Father of the English Watercolor,'' but that name is not without its liabilities. A lot of mediocre landscape views have been wrongly attributed to him.

title: INVENTING THE FUTURE
description: SO FAR, 1985 HAS BEEN A PRETTY rotten year for Sir Clive Sinclair. It began with theatrical promise as the balding, red-haired British inventor was the host at the introduction of his long-awaited electric vehicle. A bevy of young women dressed in stylish gray jump suits and creamy turtlenecks drove a fleet of the sleek little vehicles around an indoor circuit to thundering rock music and flashing cameras while Sinclair, a shy man who prefers opera and a good technical debate to numbing bass riffs and press extravaganzas, looked happily on, trim and dapper in a perfectly tailored blue suit.

title: FREE, BUT NOT EXACTLY CLEAR
description: Gary E. Dotson got his freedom last weekend, but not the clean record he wanted and said he deserved. Cathleen Crowell Webb again failed to persuade Illinois authorities that he did not rape her on the evening of July 9, 1977, contrary to her testimony at the time.

title: SCIENCE FICTION FROM RAY BRADBURY
description: An unassuming computer salesman is driven to desperation by the bickering and badgering of his ever-present wife. So far, the story seems stale enough. But as soon as you know that the author of the tale is Ray Bradbury, the science-fiction writer whose classics of the genre include such titles as ''The Martian Chronicles,'' ''The Illustrated Man'' and ''Fahrenheit 451,'' then you can also be quite sure that the narrative will soon take a corkscrew twist. And, indeed, it happens apace: For the handy sum of every cent in his savings account, the computer salesman has himself replicated as a robot that can take his place with his wife whenever he wants some time to himself.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 700,000 PROBLEMS

title: Broadcast TV
description: Ordinarily, January is not a month that brings exceptional films. But January 1984 was different, furnishing a surprise in the form of ''El Norte,'' which will be broadcast this week on Channel 13's ''American Playhouse'' series on Monday at 9 P.M.

title: THE OLDEST OF DINOSAURS?
description: The skeleton of a 200-pound, 7-to-8-foot-tall dinosaur that roamed what is now Arizona's Painted Desert about 225 million years ago may be three to four million years older than any dinosaur previously found in North America, scientists at the University of California at Berkeley announced last week.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HURRAH FOR THE NEXT MAN WHO DIES. By Mark Goodman. (Atheneum, $14.95.) Imagine being trapped in a train compartment with the football heroes of Princeton's class of 1914 - Hobart Amory Hare Baker, Justin Emory Blasingame Runcible, Britton Spratling - as they recount each bloody detail of their gridiron glories.

title: FRESH AIR FUND OPENS UP NEW VIEWS OF FMILY AND COMMUNITY
description: James Somwar, 10 years old, spent two weeks on a Maine farm last year. He is not sure where it was, but he knows ''it was far.''

title: SUSAN L. BUCKLEY WED TO JOHN A. MCCREIGHT
description: Susan Louise Buckley and John A. McCreight were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Philadelphia by the Rev. James A. Trimble.

title: THE RICH TASTE OF SALMON
description: THERE is nothing quite like the taste of trout or salmon cooked within minutes of being caught. At this time of year both experienced fly fishermen and small boys (the latter equipped with nothing but a rod and a can of worms) like to test their skills in the brooks and streams. If these amateur fishermen are out of luck, the local fish store will probably now have Atlantic salmon, which is the finest, or salmon from Washington State, and even fresh brook trout for sale.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT 76ERS, LEAD SERIES BY 3-0
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have lost the cohesiveness they showed in their sweep of the Milwaukee Bucks in the Eastern Conference semifinal, and the Boston Celtics have found the togetherness they lacked in their semifinal.

title:
ART;

ANIMALS AND IDEAS LARGE AS LIFE
description: FROM era to era, artists have felt a challenge to find more valid, more timely and, above all, more original ways to use real life as a theme. Among contemporary American realists, the New York painter Don Nice ranks as one of the most innovative, and the current 20-year survey of his work at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island provides a good opportunity to see some of his most important paintings.

title: HOW A CONTROVERSIAL CONTRACTOR BUILT AN EGYPTIAN EMPIRE
description: WHEN Anwar el-Sadat was President of Egypt, Osman Ahmed Osman, Egypt's richest businessman, was never far from his side. It was Mr. Osman - dealmaker, banker, builder of Egypt's Aswan Dam - who accompanied Mr. Sadat on his historic trip to Jerusalem in 1977. It was Mr. Osman who watched videotaped movies with him late into the night. And it was Mr. Osman who helped Mr. Sadat promote Egypt's reopening to private enterprise, and to the West.

title: CHANGES REFLECTED IN CAMPUS PROTEST
description: IT almost seemed like the turbulent 1960's all over again: students making demands of college officials, then occupying a key campus facility to drive home their message.

title: CORRECTION
description: The photographs accompanying the article on the centennial celebration of the Adirondack Forest Preserve in the April 21 issue of The New York Times Magazine should have carried the following copyright line: From the book ''The Adirondacks'' Copyright c 1985 by Nathan Farb, to be published by Rizzoli. All rights reserved. The Times Magazine regrets the error.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SEVEN NORTH. By Neil Ravin. (Seymour Lawrence/ Dutton, $16.95.) If escalating insurance costs don't slow hospital admissions, the hospital horror novel may.

title: AN ISRAEL-EGYPT GET-TOGETHER
description: Israel and Egypt, despite substantial opposition inside both countries, seemed to be moving last week toward more normal relations, which they hope to settle at a meeting this summer of Prime Minister Shimon Peres and President Hosni Mubarak. The two leaders have tried to breathe new life into Egyptian-Israeli relations, which worsened after the high expectations generated at Camp David in 1979. Egypt had moved to repair its strained Arab ties by distancing itself, particularly after Israel bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor in 1981 and invaded Lebanon in 1982.

title: PACT REACHED ON U.S.-CHINESE MINE PROJECT
description: Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced a contract agreement today on long-delayed plans to open a $600 million coal mine in Shanxi Province in northern China.

title: LOPEZ LEADS TOURNEY BY 2
description: Nancy Lopez, looking for her first victory of the year and the 30th of her pro career, moved into a two-stroke lead today in the second round of the L.P.G.A.'s 10th annual Chrysler Plymouth Classic.

title: BRIEFING
description: Representative Samuel S. Stratton, alluding to the Bitburg furor, says he hopes the celebration of the 40th anniversary of the official end of World War II will not be ''marked with a measure of controversy'' as was the commemoration of the end of the war in Europe. Mr. Stratton, a Democrat who is dean of the New York Congressional delegation with 27 years' service, urged the other day that the White House and Congress not ''forget that the final end of the Second World War was not in Europe; it occurred on Sept. 2, 1945, when Gen. Douglas MacArthur accepted the Japanese surrender on the deck of the U.S.S. Missouri.'' Mr. Stratton should know. He was a member of the MacArthur staff, working as an intelligence and Japanese language officer and winning two Bronze Stars.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: MARY E. McDERMOTT and the Rev. Lillian E. Lindeman are not exactly the typical college graduate, Class of '85.

title: Data Bank;   May 19, 1985
COURT FIGHT SEEN ON PRINCETON CLUBS
description: Following a ruling by a state agency that Princeton University's three all-male eating clubs unlawfully discriminate against women, those involved in the case are preparing for a lengthy legal battle and assessing the decision's implications.

title: GROUP OFFERS HELP TO POOR IN THE BRONX
description: The idea was copied from the British, and the aim is ''problem-solving,'' says Carolyn McLaughlin, director of the Citizens Advice Bureau in the Bronx, at 2050 Grand Concourse.

title: A NEW PROGRAM TO TREAT YOUNG ALCOHOLICS
description: THE seven teen-agers sat in a circle. Wearing jeans, flannel shirts and sneakers, most chain-smoked cigarettes, creating so much smoke that the windows had to be wide open on the brisk April afternoon. Those without cigarettes twisted their fingers as they talked about themselves or listened to the others.

title:
GARDENING;

KEEPING AN OLD FAVORITE IN BLOOM
description: GERANIUMS have long been a favorite garden subject. Actually, the plants that we most commonly call geranium are really pelargoniums.

title: AND NOW THE AGE OF THE BAREFOOT PSYCHOTHERAPIST
description: To the Edior:

title: UPGRADING QUEENS GARDEN APARTMENTS
description: POORLY maintained landscaping tells the tale of deterioration in garden apartments at a glance. So do broken stoops and cracked and peeling doorways.

title: VILLA FAVORITA
description: To The Editor: Some months ago the Travel section carried an article on notable museums to visit in Europe (''Treasures in Surprising Places,'' March 10). Among those recommended was the Pinacoteca Thyssen-Bornemisza at Villa Favorita in Castagnola di Lugano, Switzerland.

title: 5 WILL GET CITY SCIENCE AWARD
description: Five scholars who have worked in acoustics, biology, particle physics, pharmaceuticals and mathematics will be the first recipients Tuesday of the Mayor's Award of Honor for Science and Technology.

title: EXCELLENCE IN EDUCATION FOR EVERYONE
description: IT HAS been 10 years since New Jersey, in the midst of chaos, lawsuits and court-imposed school closings, passed a major education reform act.

title: Talking Penthouses;   Sorting Out Rules In Co-ops
description: OWNERS and operators of cooperatives soon learn that the roofs of their buildings can be far more than just protection against the elements: They also are valuable but often controversial assets.

title: CITY'S MINORITY POLITICIANS FACE A RECOGNITION PROBLEM
description: When Laverne Patterson, a 38-year-old black woman from Queens, was asked to name the two or three most important white leaders in New York City, several names immediately came to mind: Mayor Koch, Governor Cuomo and Victor Gotbaum, who heads the largest municipal employee union.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: AUTO RACING Indianapolis 500 qualifying, at Indianapolis Speedway. This is Bumping Day, in which drivers try to break into the field of 33 by dislodging the slower drivers who have qualified previously. Johnny Rutherford bumped his way into 25th place on the final day in 1974, then won the first of his three 500's. (Television - Channel 7, 6 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Angels, at Anaheim, Calif. (Television -Channel 11, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770 4 P.M.) Braves vs. Chicago Cubs, at Atlanta. (Television -WTBS 4:05 P.M.) Basketball 76ers vs. Celtics, at Philadelphia. Fourth game of four-of-seven Eastern Conference playoff final. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Nuggets vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Denver. Fourth game of Western Conference final, with the Lakers ahead, 2-1. Boxing Rocky Lockridge, champion, vs. Wilfredo (Bazooka) Gomez, World Boxing Association junior-lightweight title fight, at San Juan, P.R. Lockridge, 36-3, from Mount Laurel, N.J., has defended twice since winning the title Feb. 26, 1984, from Roger Mayweather. Gomez, the former World Boxing Council superbantamweight and featherweight champion, is 41-2-1. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Alfredo Layne vs. Tomas Rodriguez, 10 rounds, junior lightweights. The winner will meet the Lockridge-Gomez victor in a mandatory title fight. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.) Football Generals vs.

title: PATRICE MARCHAND BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Patrice Marie Marchand and William Michael Bradbury, who are to receive M.D. degrees May 30 from the University of Connecticut Medical School, were married yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Martin Ryan.

title: DIVIDING THE TURF
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DARK TRUTH ABOUT GREEN THUMBS
description: AFTER years of sham, pretense and hypocrisy, I'm coming out of the closet. I hope my courageous act will help others (and I know there are others) to do the same. I don't have a green thumb. After buying at least one plant a month for as long as I can remember, I should be surrounded by about 500 pots of greenery. Actually, counting one dead cactus, I have 15. The other 485? They were merely replacements.

title: CANDLE IN AN ICY DRAFT
description: WHAT THE LIGHT WAS LIKE By Amy Clampitt. 110 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. THE acclaim that has greeted Amy Clampitt's work is the more surprising in that its special characteristics are among those routinely disparaged by mainstream contemporary taste. Instead of ''natural speech'' and Hemingway terseness she gives us baroque profusion, the romance of the adjective, labyrinthine syntax, a festival lexicon. She is as ''literary'' and allusive as Eliot and Pound, as filled with grubby realia as William Carlos Williams, as ornamented as Wallace Stevens and as descriptive as Marianne Moore. Moore's Socratic tone, her appetite for fact and abrupt leaps of association have shaped Miss Clampitt's talent, and so has Hopkins - the accumulation of sensory ecstasies, the Saxonism of his diction and syntax, the multiplied coinages. All of this amounts to saying that Miss Clampitt is found among the famous eccentrics of style, like Milton, Dickinson, Mallarme and Stevens who write in a special poetic dialect of their own confection.

title: RESISTING 'CENTRAL AMERICANIZATION'
description: When the United States ordered an economic boycott of Cuba in the early 1960's, it quickly persuaded every Latin American country except Mexico to join its campaign to isolate the Castro Government. But when the Reagan Administration imposed a similar embargo on Nicaragua last month, Latin America was outspokenly critical.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: LARDNER IN WESTPORT Ring Lardner Jr. has written a zany political farce, but he may change it one way or another after he hears from people who attend it May 31 in Westport, Conn.

title: JUDGE TO REHEAR WESTWAY DISPUTE
description: Another round in the legal battle over Westway begins tomorrow, focusing on the validity of the landfill permit granted three months ago by the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: ON APARTHEID: WESLEYAN'S ACTION
description: I WAS deeply moved by the anti-apartheid protest at Wesleyan last month. In its simple dignity it honored a noble cause - ending the horrors of an evil system. Hundreds of students effectively conveyed their deep concern over the deplorable conditions and recent tragic events in South Africa. And they made abundantly clear their strong desire to disengage their university from that situation.

title:
DINING OUT;

RUTHERFORD: DIFFERENT ITALIAN LOOK
description: ITALIAN restaurants used to be easy to identify because of their heavy decor and predominantly red color scheme. This is no longer the case. Recent trends in restaurant design have affected many new Italian restaurants, resulting in light, airy dining rooms often decorated in pastels.

title: GANDHI OFFERS BILL TO RAISE PENALTIES FOR TERRORISM
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government introduced a sweeping measure in Parliament today that would increase punishment for those convicted of carrying out bombings, shootings and other terrorist activities.

title: DRIVE IS ON TO SAVE U.S. COASTAL FUNDS
description: EFFORTS are now under way in Congress to maintain Federal financing to coastal states for local waterfront revitalization projects, 25 of which are on Long Island, and for state programs designed to curb coastal erosion and preserve tidal wetlands.

title: NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
description: This article is one of an occasional series of journalistic case studies, modeled on a technique widely used in business schools to examine management problems. After a brief review of a company's history - in this case Nike Inc. - several interested outsiders offer their solutions to its recent problems. CAN the runner who stumbles still win the race?

title: Gura, 37, Dropped
description: Larry Gura, the 37-year-old Kansas City left-hander who turned in two 18-victory seasons before losing his edge in recent years, was cut yesterday to make room for Lonnie Smith, the outfielder obtained from St. Louis. Gura, a one-time Yankee who went to the Royals in exchange for the catcher Fran Healy in 1976, helped them win the American League pennant with an 18-10 record in 1980 and had another big year in 1982, when he was 18-12.

title: POLICE CADET IS CHARGED IN FATAL 3-CAR PILEUP
description: A three-car pileup on the Gowanus Expressway before dawn yesterday left one man dead, another injured and a police cadet facing a criminal charge of driving while intoxicated, the police said.

title: SWEDEN'S WELFARE STATE SHOWS SIGNS OF FATIGUE
description: Sweden's ruling Social Democrats have just had about as bad a week as any political party can stand only four months away from a national election.

title: INVESTING TO EASE THE TAX BITE
description: CONSERVATIVE investments with favorable tax treatment can be an important part of overall financial planning, particularly for building a retirement fund or accumulating money for the children's educations. Indeed, they can appeal to any investor who does not want the risk associated with shelters -either investment risk or risk of running afoul of the I.R.S.

title: FLURRY OVER RENT CONTROL
description: A landlord demonstration, a legislative deadline and countless discussions in the State Capitol last week did not alter a fundamental principle of New York politics: rent regulations are popular with millions of voters.

title: LAS VEGAS, LOVE IT OR LEAVE IT
description: HEAT By William Goldman. 244 pp. New York: Warner Books. $15.50. FINALLY, the wonderful thing about William Goldman's novels is this: they create a world in which we would like to live. That world is the world of Invention. This stuff is satisfying. Here in his new novel, ''Heat,'' we have a Tale of America. We have The Glider, a hit man from Tahoe who is a double for Fred Astaire; Baby, ruler of the Vegas Combination; Rainbeaux Wylie, ambitious woman; Cyrus Kinnick, computer millionaire from Boston; Ashley and Darryl Paxton, two media evangelists who've now turned to God.

title: Leeks on St. David's Day
description: To the Editor:

title: COACH RESIGNS
description: Jim Bates, head coach of the San Antonio Gunslingers of the United States Football League, resigned yesterday morning. Gil Steinke, the team's former head coach who became vice president for football operations, took over Bates's duties for last night's game against the Oakland Invaders, who defeated the Gunslingers, 24-21.

title: CAN A CORPORATION COMMIT MURDER?
description: For years, the courts rejected the notion that a corporation could be charged with a crime. Since it had no mind, it could not be said to have had intent. Gradually it was accepted that a corporation can be held criminally liable for the conduct of agents acting as employees, or for violations of antitrust or regulatory laws. But the idea of corporate ''personhood'' stopped short for murder - the killing of one person by another.

title: HIS LONG ORDEAL BY LAUGHTER
description: ZUCKERMAN BOUND A Trilogy and Epilogue. By Philip Roth. 784 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $9.95. PHILIP ROTH'S ''Zuckerman Bound'' binds together ''The Ghost Writer,'' ''Zuckerman Unbound'' and ''The Anatomy Lesson,'' adding to them as epilogue a wild short novel, ''The Prague Orgy,'' which is at once the bleakest and the funniest writing Roth has done. The totality is certainly the novelist's finest achievement to date, eclipsing even his best single fictions, the exuberantly notorious ''Portnoy's Complaint'' and the undervalued and ferocious ''My Life as a Man.'' ''Zuckerman Bound'' is a classic apologia, an aggressive defense of Roth's moral stance as an author. Its cosmos derives candidly from the Freudian interpretation of ambivalence as being primal, and the Kafkan evasion of interpretation as being unbearable. Roth knows that Freud and Kafka mark the origins and limits of a literary culture, American and Jewish, which has an uneasy relationship to Talmudic Judaism and its waning culture. Freud's psychologizing of every religious and moral impulse, and Kafka's imaginative despair as to whether these same impulses ever could find realistic embodiment again, have combined to render problematical the Jewish tradition's hopes for human nature. I suspect that Roth knows and accepts also what his surrogate, Zuckerman, is sometimes too outraged to recognize: breaking a new road causes outrage in others and suffering in himself. Perhaps that is the Jewish version of Emerson's American Law of Compensation: nothing is got for nothing.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BACH AGAIN It's called ''Bach-A-Thon '85 Celebrating 300 Years,'' and today's concert at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Bay Shore more than lives up to its title. It's long, beginning at 3 P.M. and running until after 10 P.M. And in touching on Bach's contributions to organ, chamber and choral music, it certainly is inclusive. The day begins with four half-hour performances by the organists Carol Weitner, Rachel Kasianowicz, Susan Lindsay and Anne Wilson. At 5 P.M., the South Bay Ensemble da Chiesa and Soloists, conducted by Mark Engelhardt, takes over with the ''Brandenburg'' Concerto No. 5 and other chamber works. Finally, at 8 P.M., the Long Island Symphonic Choral Association, led by Gregg Smith, contributes the Mass in B Minor. The church is at 500 South Country Road, and admission is $4 for the organ recitals and chamber concert and $7, or $5 for students and the elderly, for the mass. For information, call 665-0051.

title: Flutie Enthusiastic In Longest Season
description: When the Generals meet the Gold here Sunday, Doug Flutie will be playing in his 28th football game in the last nine months. That includes the Boston College season, the Cotton Bowl game, two postseason all-star events in Hawaii and Japan, one preseason game for the Generals and their 12 regular-season contests.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Philadelphia last Sunday about private concerns that decide legal disputes misidentified a judge who has heard such cases, and the court on which he previously served. He is Marvin E. Frankel, formerly of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: POPE, ON HIS BIRTHDAY, URGES CHRISTIAN UNITY
description: Pope John Paul II celebrated his 65th birthday today before cheering crowds with talk of Christian unity and a stern warning to youth against the exploitation ''of our weaknesses and our passions.''

title: PARTS OF JERSEY ARE ORDERED TO RATION WATER
description: Governor Kean ordered a cut in water use last week so that New Jersey's supply would dwindle less quickly. Mr. Kean imposed rationing on 93 northern communities whose reservoirs are most significantly threatened by drought. He also extended to almost half of the state's municipalities a drought emergency that he had declared in April for only the hardest-hit communities.

title: Korean Air Line Crew Thwarts a Hijacking
description: Crew members on a Korean Air Lines jet overpowered a passenger who had threatened to blow up the plane unless it flew to North Korea, an airline official said.

title: NURTURING THE BODY
description: KEEPING ONE'S BODY IN ''IDEAL'' SHAPE, the professed ambition of growing numbers of women, takes more than good intentions. It takes commitment.

title: TAKING HANDS TO HEART
description: HANDS that are both well cared for and used in graceful gesture convey elegance, self-esteem and good grooming.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN PEEKSKILL
description: FINANCIALLY battered and almost forgotten, the old blue-collar Hudson River town of Peekskill, N.Y., is making a comeback.

title: VOWS EXCHANGED BY MISS BENSON AND T. J. TOMAI
description: Elizabeth W. Benson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Benson of Woodbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas J. Tomai, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Tomai Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J. The ceremony in the North Congregational Church was performed by the Rev. Wallace C. Matsen, a Congregational minister, and the Rev. George Reilly, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Vassar Names an Official
description: James M. Montoya has been appointed director of admissions at Vassar College, the president of Vassar, Virginia B. Smith, has announced. Mr. Montoya, formerly director of admissions at Occidental College in Los Angeles, will take up his new duties July 1.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Beethoven, Schumann and Brahms Performed by Alexis Weissenberg, Teresa Berganza and Pierre Amoyal Sony Video 55 minutes. $39.95 No one has really figured how to make concert music on the television screen look less boring than it usually does.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A MEETING WITH THE GENERAL
description: TODAY is the anniversary of the meeting in Wethersfield 204 years ago when Gen.

title: Gorbachev Assails U.S. On the Indian Ocean
description: The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who will meet with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India in Moscow next Wednesday, has accused the United States of staging a military buildup in the Indian Ocean and of ''scuttling'' moves toward making the area a zone of peace.

title: An Exile In Literary America
description: In making his case against the contemporary literary scene, it appears that Vassily Aksyonov is somewhat naive and disingenuous (''An Exile in Literary America,'' April 14).

title: AUSTRALIAN WRITING TODAY: RIDING OFF IN ALL DIRECTIONS
description: THE National Book Council created a furor late last year when it issued its list of the Best Ten Books of the last decade and included none by women - this at a time when the emergence of a formidable number of women writers is one of the few significant movements in contemporary Australian literature. Then the judges of the nation's premier literary prize, the Miles Franklin Award, declined to award it, although Elizabeth Jolley, David Malouf, David Foster, Nigel Krauth and John Hooker, to name a few, have published novels recently and thus were eligible. David Williamson and half a dozen other dramatists have been drawn into writing scripts for the growing film and television mini-series industries. The editor of a short story anthology noted in his preface that contemporary Australian short fiction is fragmentary, materialist, unpolitical. And a recent survey by the Australia Council found that the average earnings of authors from their writing was $6,700 (Australian) a year. Finally, in the national elections last year, Patrick White, the Nobel Prize-winning novelist, gave his vociferous support to the newly founded Nuclear Disarmament Party, whose main candidate was Peter Garrett, the shaven-headed lead singer of the rock group Midnight Oil.

title: 4 Indiana Girls Charged In Slaying of Woman
description: Four girls have been charged in the stabbing death of an elderly woman, and the prosecutor says he will seek the death penalty against one.

title: OPTIONS INDEXES ARE PROVING THE HOT GAME IN TOWN
description: OEX...XMI...SPX...NYA...NDA...XVL...

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

AS HIS WORLD TURNS
description: SCOTT WENZEL doesn't like Bruce Springsteen. Couldn't care less about Madonna.

title: DELAYS TROUBLE BUYERS OF NEW HOUSING
description: LAST spring, James and Luci Mayes put down a deposit on a new $154,000 house in Suffolk County that the builder promised to complete by last July 30. A lot of emotion was riding on the transaction: The house was also to be the new home for Mrs. Mayes's two young sons from a previous marriage, who had been living with grandparents for three years.

title: TRUMP AND CITY DISPUTE PART OF $1 BILLION PROJECT
description: A dispute has broken out between Donald Trump, the developer, and New York City over the reconstruction of a West Side subway station promised as part of the proposed $1 billion Lincoln West housing project.

title: METS LOSE TO GIANTS IN 10 INNINGS BY 8-2
description: The Mets' good luck in extra-inning games wore off last night as their bullpen, unscathed in recent outings, was pummeled in a six-run 10th inning by the San Francisco Giants for an 8-2 loss.

title: NONESUCH RANGES FROM BACH TO BERG
description: The Nonesuch label has been through several changes of command over the years, and the mix of productions may have changed each time, but it has never been less than varied and innovative. Now, under its current director, Bob Hurwitz, the shape of the immediate future seems, once again, to be nothing less than varied and innovative.

title: LOANS HELP DEVEOP PRODUCTS
description: WHEN the 100-employee Bicron Electronics Corporation of Canaan was asked two years ago by one of the largest manufacturers of engines to develop a new solenoid, a wire coil to control small gasoline engines, it almost had to decline.

title: RALLY PRESSES REVIVAL OF STEEL PLANT
description: Hundreds of workers, unionists and townspeople rallied here today in a continuing campaign to save the Dorothy Six blast furnace at the huge, shuttered United States Steel works here.

title: A LONG ARABIAN NIGHT
description: AT the Darien Dinner Theater, a tumultuous day in legendary Baghdad turns into a long, uneventful Arabian night, rather than a magical and mystical evening's musical adventure.

title: IN PURSUIT OF MUSIC IN VERMONT
description: High above the Winooski River Valley in central Vermont the smells are a mix of spruce sap and early morning dew, and the sound on the ridge is music. It's Bach, African kalimba and folk-dance fiddling. The players, in homespun wool jackets and high leather boots, stand in a farmyard beside a cedar-shingled outbuilding. Their audience is a row of hickories with bright green leaves, a jagged line of mountains across the valley and a few vacationers from nearby Montpelier.

title:
ANTIQUES;

FOLK ART SOUTHERN STYLE
description: There's a healthy representation of snakes, grotesques and steamboats in the exhibition ''Southern Folk Art,'' which opened last week and remains through Aug. 25 at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street. These images are among the few recurring regional hallmarks in the 90 paintings, sculptures, furniture, pottery and quilts on view in this pioneering show. The museum describes it as the first comprehensive exhibition ever organized of folk art from south of the Mason-Dixon line.

title: IN SHORT: NON FICTION
description: LUCIANO BERIO: Two Interviews With Rosanna Dalmonte and Balint Andras Varga. Edited and translated by David Osmond-Smith. (Marion Boyars, $19.95.) Igor Stravinsky's books of conversations with Robert Craft have served as prototypes for books of interviews with such composers as Pierre Boulez and Karlheinz Stockhausen in Europe and Elliott Carter and John Cage in America.

title: BLAIR MACKENZIE BRIDE OF BRADLEE VAN BRUNT
description: Katherine Blair MacKenzie, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. MacKenzie Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Bradlee Van Brunt, a son of Mrs. Raymond E. Dykema Jr. of Milwaukee and the late George Russell Van Brunt. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, assisted by the Rev. Peter H. Pierson of Christ Episcopal Church in Sheffield, Mass.

title: WIRETAP TAPE HEARD IN A CASE U.S. LINKS TO ORGANIZED CRIME
description: Testimony began Friday in the first of three trials involving allegations of organized crime in Boston, with the Federal Government playing tape recordings of demands for money and expressions of concern over witnesses appearing before a grand jury.

title: THE WAR TO END ALL WARS STARTED ON A BATTLEFIELD IN CORTLANDT
description: ''ACCURST be he that first invented war,'' was the sentiment penned by Christopher Marlowe in 1590, and Western civilization has been paying lip service to it ever since. In the 1960's war was declared unhealthy for children and other living things, and that slogan was seen adorning posters nationwide. Yet, when one goes beyond the slogans and dreams of the pacifistic few, are we not truly a nation that prefers to march to the beat of a different and more warlike drummer? Who among us would sacrifice an opportunity to see ''Star Wars'' for a special showing of ''Brother Sun Sister Moon''? Our heroes are Clint Eastwood, John Wayne and Bernard Goetz, our national motto is ''Make My Day,'' and weaponry is our grossest national product.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Markdowns Are Down On Seasonal Shoes Shoe Bazaar of Hartsdale and Briarcliff, along with the Norwalk, Conn., and Stamford, Conn., stores, will hold its semiannual sale - when an additional 20 percent is taken off on seasonal national brand and imported shoes, routinely sold below department store prices - from Tuesday through Thursday to coincide with tomorrow's opening of the Compo Shopping Center Shoe Bazaar in Westport, Conn.

title: WHEN IS A HOME NOT A HOME? WHEN IT'S A CAR
description: Is a motor home more like an ordinary home or a motor vehicle? The Supreme Court ruled last week that it all depends on the mobility of the mobile home: if it can be easily driven away, then it is more like a car and may be searched by the police without a warrant.

title: IRAN IS ADAMANT ON GULF WAR
description: Saudi Arabia's Froeign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, opened two days of talks here today in a meeting with the Iranian foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati.

title: THE HALLS OF BOSTON LATIN SCHOOL
description: Lee Daniels's account of his years at Boston Latin School was entertaining, but even Theodore H. White's Latin School of the 1930's had badly deteriorated. I graduated from the Latin School in 1915 and this year will be my 70th reunion.

title: COMPETENCE WAS THE RULE AT THE PHILHARMONIC
description: The New York Philharmonic's 1984-85 season, which comes to a close this week, will not go down in history as a particularly memorable one. Solid, professional readings by solid, professional musicians were in abundant supply, as usual. But looking back, even at this short distance in time, I find it difficult to recall more than a couple of performances with great fondness or in great detail. To some extent, this was the inevitable outcome of ramshackle programming. In a season that celebrated major anniversaries of Bach, Handel and Berg the Philharmonic made desultory and not very imaginative gestures of tribute to those important figures. But commemorative programs aside, too many concerts gave the impression of having been planned by the same committee that designed Cyndi Lauper's hairdo. Whatever his other merits as music director may be, Zubin Mehta has not demonstrated remarkable talent as a program builder.

title: Therefore, He Quit
description: Edward J. Pfister, the president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, wanted to go on a business trip to the Soviet Union to buy and sell programming. But the corporation's board of directors vetoed the idea.

title: THE BALLET: CLEVELAND IN 'RENARD'
description: MEMBERS of the Cleveland Ballet collaborated with the Cleveland Orchestra in a pleasant version of Stravinsky's ''Renard,'' Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall. The production was choreographed by Dennis Nahat, the Cleveland Ballet's director, and conducted by Christoph von Dohnanyi, the orchestra's music director; both deserve congratulations.

title: SOUTH KOREAN FOE OF CHUN WARNS OF AN 'UPRISING'
description: A South Korean opposition leader said last week that President Chun Doo Hwan could face a ''serious uprising'' and possibly the disruption of the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul in 1988 unless he is willing to accept changes to the Constitution.

title: MARGARET MAASS WEDS WILLIAM JANSEN
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday Margaret Lees Maass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Maass of Madison and Barnegat Light, N.J., was married to William Holt Jansen, a son of Elizabeth Holt Jansen of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Jansen. The Rev. Dr. George E. Chorba 3d performed the ceremony Daryl M. Mathers was her sister's matron of honor.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE PULL OF THE EARTH. By Alfred Alcorn. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) This promising but flawed first novel of Massachusetts farm life in the 1950's is true to its New England literary roots.

title: G.E. ADMITS FRAUD ON MISSILE WORK
description: Washington's crackdown on defense contractors who file fraudulent claims resulted last week in another big fine for the General Electric Company. In a Federal court in Philadelphia, G.E., the nation's sixth largest military contractor, unexpectedly admitted that its space systems division had defrauded the Air Force.

title: THE FED MOVES TO SUSTAIN GROWTH
description: IN the summer of 1983, even as he was accepting reappointment to a four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, most people figured there was little chance that Paul A. Volcker would remain on the job much longer. Personal and financial pressures were expected to lure the 57-year-old chairman to a lucrative corporate post. He would leave with applause still ringing in his ears for having almost single-handedly rescued the country from double-digit inflation.

title: SRI LANKA RAID LEAVES GRIEF AND NEW FEAR
description: They are still digging graves at Anuradhapura. Men shovel away the red earth as women in white, the Buddhist color of mourning, congregate silently for the next burial.

title: A CURRENCY PLAY CALLS FOR SKILL
description: THE dollar's paroxysms on foreign-exchange markets have thrilled, confounded, excited and frustrated investors recently, depending on their holdings. The violence of exchange rate fluctuations, especially this spring, has affected everything from stocks to gold and has added luster to some investments that individuals once neglected.

title: NASA PLANS ATTEMPT IN AUGUST TO REPAIR SATELLITE
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is planning an attempt in August to repair the communications satellite that failed after its deployment by a space shuttle last month.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline on a film review last Sunday incorrectly characterized the cast of ''Girls Just Want to Have Fun.'' While the film takes its title from a song sung by Cyndi Lauper, she was not associated with the film.

title: MISS LANDY WED TO KEVIN A. LEIN
description: Barbara Lee Landy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Landy of Falls Church, Va., and Kevin A. Lein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Powell A. Lein of Old Tappan, N.J., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior in New York by the Rev. Michael Perry.

title: Heisenberg and the Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE New Community Corporation, a nonprofit organization formed in 1968 to build affordable rental housing in Newark, has converted a 105-year-old stone church into offices.

title: COMPUTER ANALYSIS USED TO DISTRIBUTE HOMES FOR DISABLED
description: A COMPUTERIZED information system, believed to be the only one of its kind in the state, is being used in an effort to insure that group homes for the mentally disabled are distributed fairly throughout the county.

title: THE CLASS OF 1985
description: Most of the young men and women graduating from college this year were born in or around l963, the year President John F. Kennedy was murdered.

title: ABIGAIL E. COLLIER WED TO C. F. FLOE
description: Abigail Everett Collier, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gordon Collier of New York and Millerton, N.Y., and Charles Pennell Floe, a son of Beverly Brooks Floe of Belmont, Mass., and Dr. Carl Frederick Floe of Boston, were married last evening. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: EXERCISING FOR A HAPPY FACE
description: THERE ARE exercises to strengthen the heart, tighten the stomach and strengthen the biceps, but what about physical fitness from the shoulders up? Should a person exercise to improve the face, neck and breathing?

title: The Shifting 'Gold Coast'
description: For more than two decades, Washington's black elite lived in an enclave in the Northwest corner of the city. If one was a doctor, lawyer, senior Government official or connected to Howard University, one hoped to or was even expected to live in ''the Gold Coast.''

title: WHAT A TRILLION BOUGHT
description: Four years ago there was a consensus to rebuild defense. Three of five Americans believed that defense spending should be increased. Without 15 minutes of debate, Congress agreed to the bold goal of a 600-ship Navy. Since 1981, the Pentagon has been given $1.1 trillion, a third more than in the previous four years.

title: A THIN 'PARK'
description: THE county may buy a piece of land 16 miles long. A weed-choked strip 30 to 60 feet wide, it is part of the right of way of the old Putnam Division of the New York Central Railroad that once ran between Putnam County and New York City carrying commuters and freight.

title: IRISH LEADER CITES ULSTER PERIL
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald opened the annual conference of his Fine Gael Party today with a warning that society in Northern Ireland will disintegrate unless a political settlement is reached soon.

title: BROKERS LURE BUSINESS WITH DISCOUNT MERCHANDISE
description: WHEN Richard and Laurie Crisalli went looking for a house, they never expected their real-estate broker to help them get a discount on a color television set. They were also surprised to learn that the broker could save them money on bedroom furniture, dishwashers, refrigerators, lawn sprinklers, video-cassette recorders, microwave ovens and paint for their new house, a Cape Cod in Massapequa, L.I.

title: DEIDRE COULSON WED TO CRAIG MACNAB
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday Deirdre Coulson, a management associate with the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, was married to Craig Macnab, a vice president of Lazard Freres & Company. The Rev. Jane Henderson performed the ceremony.

title: 2 THEATERS HOLDING CABARET BENEFITS
description: FOR TWO of the state's major regional theaters, life may not be a cabaret, but cabaret-style entertainment could be life-saving - or, at least, fund-raising.

title: ISRAEL'S DEFENSE AS GOOD AS EVER?
description: YOU ARE NEVER VERY FAR FROM THE sights and sounds of war in Israel. A tank waddles into a field beside the highway that leads from Jerusalem to Tel Aviv.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Persistence of Religion Even in the Middle Ages, with the church at the height of its power, religion was far from an all-or-nothing affair. In ''Without God, Without Creed'' (Johns Hopkins), James Turner shows how people can flout their faith and have it too.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: ABE BURROWS, BROADWAY WRITER-DIRECTOR, IS DEAD
description: Abe Burrows, the librettist, director, author and comic who wrote a score of shows for Broadway, including ''Guys and Dolls'' and ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,'' died of pneumonia Friday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and had been ill for several years.

title: Following A Wife's Move
description: Gordon Mott's problems over his wife's transfer to Paris were quite amusing (''Following a Wife's Move, About Men, April 14). Having been supported through childhood by a working, widowed mother, I ''embraced the notion of career women'' with less difficulty than he; today, neither my wife nor I could accept being ''kept'' by the other - let alone the diminished standard of living that would entail for us.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: LIBBY, OSCAR & ME. Written and illustrated by Bob Graham. Bedrick/Blackie. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 8) A droll story imported from Australia, about a little girl named Emily with a wonderful imagination, many disguises and two fine companions, Libby, her cat, and Oscar, her dog. 101 QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ABOUT DANGEROUS ANIMALS.

title: BUDGET BLUEPRINT
description: MUCH was made of the partisanship in last week's budget deliberations, and of the fight ahead between the Republican Senate and the Democratic House over their different blueprints for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. In a longer view, however, the areas of agreement between the plan approved Thursday by the House Budget Committee and the Senate's earlier resolution were as striking. Both proposals would reduce the deficit by more than $50 billion, an achievement considered politically impossible only last year. And neither would reach the bottom line by raising taxes.

title: FINK SEEKS TO LIMIT NEW YORK-SOUTH AFRICA LINKS
description: Taking the initiative on the sensitive issue of state dealings with South Africa, Stanley Fink, the Assembly Speaker, has proposed a stringent set of restrictions.

title: End of Long Streak
description: Luck appeared to be a key factor Friday night when Jack Perconte, the Seattle Mariner infielder, snapped one of the longest streaks in baseball - 990 times up without a home run, the major-league record for active players other than pitchers. Perconte lost his chance at reaching the 1,000-mark on something of a fluke in the first inning of the Mariners 11-3 loss to the Baltimore Orioles.

title: ABIGAIL JANE FRANKLIN WEDS DERALD PLUMER
description: Abigail Jane Franklin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Franklin of Garrett Park, Md., was married yesterday to Derald Gene Plumer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jackson Plumer of Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Thomas B. Allen performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Six Are Killed in Car Crash
description: Six young people heading home from a fire department carnival were killed when their car crashed into a tree at a rural intersection, the police said today.

title: MISS MASTERSON PLANNING TO WED ANDREW S. CECIL
description: The engagement of Mary Jo Masterson and Andrew Stuart Cecil has been announced by Mrs. Joseph Patrick Masterson of Eggertsville, N.Y., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Cumming Cecil of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for July 27.

title: CONFISCATING CARS
description: THE District Attorney of Brooklyn, Elizabeth Holtzman, promised a new weapon against drunken drivers guilty of felonies. She said in October that she would seize their cars.

title: LIBRARY DUSTS OFF HIDDEN TREASURE
description: A collection of Chinese porcelain, donated to the Bridgeport Public Library in 1949 and kept mostly under wraps since then, is at long last on display there. The collection consists of 136 pieces, including a vase from the Ming Dynasty of 1368-1644.
