title: WASHINGTON AND MOSCOW HAVE THEIR OWN IDEAS ON TRADE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union will open trade talks tomorrow at the highest level since relations turned sour after the Russians invaded Afghanistan in 1979. Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige and Soviet Foreign Trade Minister Nikolai S. Patolichev will meet for two days in Moscow to try to iron out some of the many difficulties and discuss kinds of trade that might be expanded.

title: IN FEAR OF THE FOLKS NEXT DOOR
description: LONG ISLANDERS are growing more and more asocial. This may be caused by our dependence on cars, or by city planners who no longer think of villages or communities, but only of real estate. Or perhaps it is a natural reaction of people who move out from urban areas and now want to have the illusion of living in a solitary vacuum.

title: STUDENTS RALLY IN WASHINGTON AGAINST LOWER TEEN-AGE PAY
description: Several hundred high school students gathered in the rain on the steps outside the Labor Department Friday to protest a bill backed by the Reagan Administration that would let employers pay teen-agers less than the Federal minimum wage for summer work.

title: SORTING OUT THE CAUSES AND CONSEQUENCES OF A DISASTER
description: IN the aftermath of one of the worst disasters in Philadelphia's history - a fire that destroyed two blocks of a mostly black neighborhood after the police dropped a bomb on a rooftop - many blacks asserted that it never would have happened in a white neighborhood.

title: KATHRYN FENTON WEDS WILLIAM EVAN KOVACIC
description: Kathryn Marie Fenton, a daughter of Mrs. George J. Fenton of Trumbull, Conn., and the late Mr. Fenton, was married yesterday to William Evan Kovacic, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Evan C. Kovacic of Uniondale, Pa. The Rev. Edgar J. Farrell performed the ceremony at St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Hamden, Conn.

title: THE GLORY OF CARNEGIE HALL
description: ON A RAINY AFTERNOON not long ago, the Detroit Symphony held a rehearsal in Carnegie Hall that was open to the hall's benefactors. There were young mothers, infants in their laps, and businessmen on long lunches. There were also a number of older women, with gray hair and skin like parchment.

title: HOW TO CHOOSE A WORD PROCESSOR
description: WORD processing has become as common ss the written word, or so it would seem from the amount of space devoted to this aspect of personal computing in magazines and newspapers. However, the attention probably has more to do with the fact that reporters use these programs in their work - and they assume that everyone else finds them equally indispensable - rather than with the widespred implementation of word processing software. My guess is that only a small percentage of the business community that might profit from word processing actually use that software.

title: PARTNERSHIP: OWNERSHIP WITHOUT PAIN
description: TO many people, real estate is an attractive investment because they can see it, even kick it. But few people have the time or expertise to be a developer or landlord. The solution often lies in real-estate partnerships, which have become extraordi-narily popular in recent years. A partnership lets an investor own a share of a real-estate project without the headaches of building and managing it. And the returns can be attractive, as they come in three forms: tax breaks, income from rentals and appreciation in property value.

title: Ginnie Mae's Popularity
description: SINCE the postwar housing boom began, a mortgage has been the key to the dream of home ownership for millions of Americans. Indeed, mortgages totalling an estimated $2 trillion are outstanding, so widespread is their use. Given this mammoth market, it is little wonder that, in today's aggressive financial environment, mortgages have taken on new meaning. They have been bundled, repackaged and reshaped into modern investment vehicles.

title: THE MAGAZINE THAT'S ARIZONA
description: The inaugural issue of Arizona Highways consisted of 28 pages and sold for only a dime. But with articles about expansion joints used in concrete pavements, and with advertisements for crushed stone and highway paint, the magazine's horizons seemed somewhat limited.

title: Topics;   Beastly Behavior Highwaymen
description: A wonderful book called ''Time and Again'' by Jack Finney tells about going back in time to the New York City of a century or so ago, when farms lay just past the Dakota on 72d Street and rapid transit featured horse-drawn trolleys. Modern New York got a sour taste of that past one morning last week when two gunmen, faces covered with bandanas, held up two passengers in a horse-drawn carriage in Central Park.

title: Hobart Triumphs, 15-8, For Sixth Lacrosse Title
description: Mark Van Arsdale scored four goals and had five assists as Hobart College captured its sixth straight Division III lacrosse championship today, beating Washington College, 15-8.

title:
ANTIQUES;

THE OLD AND THE NEW IN QUILTS AND DECOYS
description: THE value of antiques as a resource for inspiring contemporary craftsmanship along both innovative and traditional lines is especially evident when examples from cherished private collections are placed on public view alongside new works in the same idiom.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

BRONZE LINCOLN CENT BRINGS A RECORD PRICE
description: A bronze 1943 Lincoln cent, one of perhaps a dozen such pieces in existence, brought $20,350 at an auction April 27 in Minneapolis. That is believed to be the highest price ever paid at auction for a coin regarded as a minting error.

title: Bombings in U.S. Rose Last Year, F.B.I. Says
description: Bombings in the nation increased 17 percent last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today, but deaths from such incidents fell 50 percent and fewer attacks were traced to terrorists.

title: LEARNING TO LOVE SPRINGFIELD, MASS.
description: At first glance the landscape around Springfield, Mass., an industrial city on the Connecticut River about 100 miles west of Boston, is, to put it bluntly, boring. So is much of Springfield's streetscape and much of what might be called its timescape, more than 300 years of history in which little of great significance happened. In a state filled with historic and beautiful sites, Springfield attracts few tourists. Sporty New Yorkers, speeding north to ski in Vermont, drive right through it, but all they see from the highway are tacky buildings, parking lots and a few skyscrapers. Arty Bostonians heading west to Tanglewood don't even get close enough to see that much. ''Springfield?'' people say. ''Oh, yes. I've driven through it.'' And then they change the subject.

title: RAMPS
description: To the Editor: Apropos of Linda Jeffries's article, ''Ramp Feasting in West Virginia,'' (Travel, March 31): my husband and I have gathered and eaten ramps for years. Yes, they do grow in Vermont.

title: THE CASE IN FAVOR OF A CONTROVERSIAL SCULPTURE
description: In recent years no work of art has been the source of as much controversy as Richard Serra's public sculpture ''Tilted Arc.''

title: BROWSING ON CONNECTICUT'S ANTIQUES TRAIL
description: From the old towns of Stonington and Essex near the Connecticut shore to the hills of Litchfield County, the state is studded with fine antiques shops. Some specialize in a single kind of antique, but most carry both furniture and decorative accessories.

title: DANCE: PAUL SANASARDO COMPANY IN FATAL BIRDS'
description: FOR 25 years, Paul Sanasardo has been a modern-dance choreographer whose deeply Expressionist esthetic, combined with an admirable integrity, has obviously influenced others.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Can you direct us to any resorts in the United States that include sailing in their weekly rates rather than renting the sailboat as an extra? - E. D., Princeton, N.J. Answer:Almost all resorts that offer sailing either provide boats at extra cost or are associated with a company that makes separate sailing arrangements. An exception is Caneel Bay on St. John in the United States Virgin Islands, which offers a Best of Both Worlds program, combining a sailboat with accommodations. The seven-night package includes four nights at the resort, three meals a day and use of sports facilities, and three nights aboard a sailboat without crew. With a 35-foot Hinckley Pilot, the package costs $794 a person; with a 40-foot Hinckley Bermuda, it costs $824 a person (both through Oct. 31). Both sleep one or two couples. Either land or sea stays may be extended by paying one-seventh of the weekly rate for each extra day. For the Bermuda, a captain is available for $100 a day extra, a cook/mate for $80 a day extra. Arrangements can be made through St. John Water Sports (809-776-6256), which also offers a two-week package for four (a week at the hotel and a week at sea with captain and cook) for $1,290 a person. Caneel Bay is represented by RockResorts (212-586-4459 or 800-223-7637).

title: Mecir Ousts Wilander, 6-2, 6-4
description: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia upset top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-2, 6-4, today to advance to the final of the $350,000 Italian Open Tennis Championships.

title: EIZABETH SYKES BECOMES THE BRIDE OF BRUCE CARP
description: Elizabeth Sykes, until recently director of network affairs for Warner Brothers Television in New York, was married yesterday to Bruce V. Carp, a managing director of Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York. Rabbi Jacob Shankman performed the ceremony at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: City Officials Identify 2 Bodies in Compound
description: Two of the 11 bodies recovered from the ruins of the Move compound here were identified last night as Frank James Africa, 26 years old, and Rhonda Harris Africa, 30, according to Health Commissioner Stuart Shapiro.

title: DELAWARE BASIN TO ADD TO ITS RESERVOIR CAPACITY
description: The agency that monitors and regulates the water supply system in the Delaware River basin has approved plans to build one new reservoir and expand three existing ones, which would add space for 61 billion gallons of water to the 362 billion gallons of capacity now available.

title: 43 STORIES IN MIDTOWN
description: One of the most ambitious mixed-use projects being created in midtown Manhattan west of Fifth Avenue is now under construction at Broadway and 56th Street.

title: COLUMBUS SAILS AGAIN, ON A SEA OF INTERNATIONAL FUNDING
description: It takes boundless dreams and mounds of money to carry out such visionary enterprises as the discovery of America or, nearly 500 years later, the making of a six-hour mini-series, ''Christopher Columbus,'' to tell about it. The paths of these two highly different endeavors intersect tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. on CBS when the story of Columbus will be seen by millions of viewers in the living rooms of the New World whose presence the Great Navigator revealed to Europe.

title: HOW CREIGHTON'S DREAMS CAME APART
description: In Skinner Mall, on the Creighton University campus here, a pair of trolley-car tracks run on an old red brick road, separating the low-slung, modern Kiewit Physical Fitness Center (where the athletic department offices are situated) from the century-old Gothic church and the administration building. The tracks and the brick street are remnants that preserve a sense of history for this quiet, small (enrollment 5,913) but distinguished Jesuit school that was founded in 1878.

title: Heisenberg and the Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: EDNA ST. VINCENT MILLAY'S MAINE
description: All I could see from where I stood Was three long mountains and a wood; I turned and looked the other way, And saw three mountains and a bay Opening of ''Renascence''

title: VERNON DUKE AND COLE PORTER - NOW AND THEN
description: When a singer who is virtually unknown in this country records an album of songs by Vernon Duke, she is hitching her wagon to a star. It can be a helpful ride for her - certainly she will have good material. But it can also be dangerous because she invites comparison with established singers who have successfully drawn on Mr. Duke's catalogue of songs, and she can be overshadowed by the public perception of the high quality of those songs and by their familiarity.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in this seciton last Sunday, with an article about why baseball should be an Olympic sport in 1988, misidentified the manager of the Japanese baseball team at last summer's Games in Los Angeles. He was Reiichi Matsunaga.

title: LILCO STOCKHOLDERS TOLD MORE TROUBLE IS ON THE HORIZON
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company, which has had several scrapes with financial catastrophe over the last 15 months because of its failure to open the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, now has agreements in place with its banks that will guarantee solvency until June 1986, the company's shareholders were told at the annual meeting in Brookville last week.

title: NOW, FOOD AT THE GOODSPEED
description: FOR years theatergoers attending the memorable offerings at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam have lamented the lack of equally appealing dining amenities nearby. Fortunately, with new ownership at The Gelston House, all that has changed. Now excursioners have the opportunity for a theater-cum-dining experience of the first order.

title: HORSEBACK RIDING
description: To the Editor: The reader who wanted to know of an inn on the East Coast that offered unlimited horseback riding (Q & A, Travel, April 7) should be made aware of the inn on Little St. Simons Island, in what are called the Golden Isles off the coast of Georgia.

title: IN SHORT: NON FICTION
description: NORMANDIE: Her Life and Times. By Harvey Ardman. (Franklin Watts, $22.95.) Gluttons for detail - mind-numbing detail - should be transfixed by this history of the most luxurious ocean liner ever to sail the seas: the measurements of the berth on the Loire River in France where the Normandie was built, her cost in today's dollars, the width of the tiled platform that surrounded the on-deck swimming pool, the number of initialed bar glasses stolen by souvenir hunters on the ship's first docking in New York, the number of Estonian kroons in the pocket of a stowaway on a day when 14 stowaways were found, the number of leads the F.B.I. investigated in its attempt to determine whether sabotage was responsible for the fire at the Manhattan pier that led to the ship's demise in 1942.

title:
ART;

EASTERN FORMS, WESTERN TIES
description: OVER the years there have been many fruitful exchanges between the cultures of the Orient and the Occident, in the visual arts no less than in philosophy, fashion and industry. Western painters have long admired and emulated the artwork of the East, but it is perhaps less well known that Western styles and techniques have exerted considerable influence on Oriental artists.

title: PRIZE WINNERS IN CAR STEREO
description: Just as they do for home stereo equipment, the editors of Audio-Video International - a leading trade publication - bestow annual ''Grand Prix'' citations on outstanding new entries among car stereo components. Reflecting the results of a nationwide poll of 531 car-stereo dealers and installers, these honors represent a statistically derived critical assessment in a field otherwise lacking comprehensive review. The list of winners also provides a handy shopping guide for quality-conscious listeners who consider music an essential travel accessory.

title: AN EXILE IN LITERARY AMERICA
description: Our diplomats and negotiators should all read Vassily Aksyonov's article.

title: HONDURAS BORDER SCENE OF CLASHES
description: Hostilities along the Nicaragua-Honduras border have widened dramatically in recent weeks, according to American military and diplomatic officials here, with Nicaraguan troops crossing the border for the first time in force to pursue rebels operating from Honduras.

title: PHILADELPHIA OFFICIALS VARY IN EXPLAINING SIEGE TACTICS
description: Two weeks ago, when he finally decided the time had come to evict a small group of radicals from a house in West Philadelphia, Mayor W. Wilson Goode recalls, his main goals were to avoid a riot and police casualties.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MUSIC IN MONTCLAIR Bucky Pizzarelli, the jazz guitarist, will present a concert Thursday evening at the Montclair Art Museum.

title: THERAPY: WHEN AND HOW SHOULD IT END?
description: THE slightest rumble of the furnace created images of his house burning down; he constantly checked the oven, just in case it had been left on.

title: On Language;   THERE, THERE
description: THERE'S NO THERE there'' was Gertrude Stein's classic slander of the city of Oakland, Calif. That was the last time a sentence was started successfully with a pronominal, impersonal there.

title: 9,000 Black Gold Miners Strike in South Africa
description: Nine thousand black South African gold miners went on strike today in a dispute over the dismissal of two members of the workers' union, mine officials said.

title: CONCENTRIC CAMPAIGNS
description: Kenneth A. Gibson has run the city of Newark as Mayor for 15 years. For the past six of those years, Peter Shapiro has been all around him as Executive of Essex County. Though their territories overlap and though their offices are only a few blocks from each other, they have never been friendly neighbors. This spring they have been running against each other for the Democratic nomination for governor, scrapping for many of the same hometown votes.

title: SIMPLIFYING THE NATION'S DIVORCE LAWS
description: THE emotional wrench of a divorce is only exacerbated by quarrels over who gets the house or the children's dependency exemption. The cheering news is that last year's tax act completely overhauled the tax consequences of divorce and separation, so couples divorcing today ''should have fewer arguments, at least over things like how property is transferred and how alimony is structured,'' says Dean P. Schuckman, executive financial services partner with the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse.

title: SAILBOAT RACE FOR THE FUN OF IT
description: ONE of the rules of the Sunfish Connecticut River Classic Race-Cruise, to be held this year on June 1 and 2, is ''Don't take it too seriously.''

title: TV: SIX-HOUR CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS' ON CBS
description: CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS is one of those giant historical figures who tend to get lost in the mists of popular myth. What did he do? He discovered America, of course. Hooray! But he did not discover the land that most of us ''norteamericanos'' think of as America. His travels were generally limited to the islands now known as the Dominican Republic/ Haiti, Cuba, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. To this day, 500 years later, the man and his achievements are subjects of scholarly dispute, right down to such basic details as his true nationality and the authentic site of his burial place.

title: KELLY BURNS HAS NUPTIALS
description: The Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Richmond was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kelly Marie Burns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Burns of Spring Lake, N.J., and James Fulton Massengill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton E. Massengill of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Edward Pritchard, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony.

title: 'KISMET' IN DARIEN: DULL ARABIAN NIGHT
description: AT the Darien Dinner Theater, a tumultuous day in legendary Baghdad turns into a long, uneventful Arabian night, rather than a magical and mystical evening's musical adventure.

title: NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
description: STRATEGIES FOR RECOVERY: PROFESSOR I know of no more complicated administrative challenge than that faced by Phil Knight and his associates. It is absolutely the most complex senior manager circumstance that I've ever bumped into. The president of General Electric has a far simpler task even though G.E. is 50 times as large.

title: Q AND A
description: RENTING TO A RELATIVE Question: I own a condominium that I rent to my daughter for 80 percent of fair-market value. I deduct 20 percent that would have gone to a management fee and take her reliability into consideration. I heard there was a tax-court case that established this procedure. Can you tell me more? . . . J. M. F., Stamford, Conn. Answer: You are referring to Lee A. Bindseil v. Commissioner. This was not a decision, but a 1983 tax-court memorandum regarding a house rented by a son to his parents at $250 a month. An Internal Revenue Service witness found the fair rental value was $450 a month. Though the judge held the rent was too low, he said an owner may discount the fair rental value by 20 percent to reflect the gain realized by avoiding a management fee and renting to trustworthy tenants.

title: SEEING THE NEW LIGHT
description: PEOPLE usually spend most of their time indoors under light that is quite dim -a kind of perpetual twilight. It may be adequate for reading and routine activities at home and at work, but researchers now find that this low level of light can throw a person's body rhythms out of kilter and seriously affect physical and mental well-being. What they recommend is to get outdoors daily for a good dose of bright light. Plain daylight, which is easily a hundred times brighter than typical indoor lighting, is all it takes. Direct sunlight is neither necessary nor advisable; its only known benefit, vitamin D synthesis, requires no more than 15 minutes of exposure every other day on an area as small as the back of the neck.

title: HOMOSEXUAL FOSTER PARENTS DEBATED
description: Last spring a Boston couple in their 30's, responsibly employed, churchgoing people without children, applied to the State Department of Social Services to become foster parents.

title: TALKS PLANNED AS STRIKE CUTS MOST UNITED FLIGHTS
description: United Airlines canceled most of its flights again yesterday as a strike by the airline's 5,300 pilots entered its second day, but both sides agreed to resume negotiations Monday.

title: MINDY DAVIS WEDS G. G. MONTGOMERY
description: Mary Melinda Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Davis of Bethesda, Md., and George Geoffrey Montgomery, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George G. Montgomery Jr. of New York, were married yesterday at the Westmoreland Congregational Church in Bethesda. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gordon Forbes, assisted by the bride's uncle, the Rev. James Cernohlavik.

title: JAPANESE ART FINDS ITSELF IN A MEETING OF PAST AND PRESENT
description: The new art of this country is not new at all. And that is what makes it Japanese.

title: NEW RULES BREED WASTEFUL MERGERS
description: PUBLIC policy is always fertile ground for irony. Today, for example, the economic landsacpe is strewn with merger fiascos, but current antitrust policy toward these combinations is increasingly lenient. ''Economic efficiency'' is now the ''only goal'' of merger policy, according to a former Justice Department official. As a result, the merger wave of the 1980's surges ahead, reaching a new peak last week with the Allied Corporation's $5 billion planned union with the Signal Companies, the largest industrial merger ever (outside the oil industry). This preoccupation with economic efficiency ignores Congressional intent and judicial precedent. The legislative history of the antitrust laws contains almost no mention of efficiency, production or price. Rather, there is an insistent Jeffersonian concern for the small entrepreneur - for social, not economic reasons. Thus, the Supreme Court has always ruled that efficiencies cannot save an otherwise illegal merger.

title: MOONLIGHT FLOWERS
description: Due to lack of space, our garden must serve as a recreational ground. It is shared with both children and pets, but there are plans afoot for something - if not grander - at least, more romantic.

title: PRIMARY CANDIDATES STEP UP THE PACE
description: THE final three weeks of the campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor have arrived, and the five major candidates will be throwing everything they have left into the fray and watching to see if it is having the desired effect.

title: A DEADLIER FORCE FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: Government scientists announced last week what appears to be an important advance in the development of an X-ray laser space weapon powered by a nuclear explosion.

title: ICE AGE OF THE SPIRIT
description: THE BLUE MAN And Other Stories. By Adolf Muschg. Translated by Marlis Zeller Cambon and Michael Hamburger. 141 pp. New York: George Braziller. $12.95.

title: TAX-EXEMPTS TOP THE LIST FOR AVID BOND SHOPPERS
description: INTEREST rates continue to slide, but with inflation remaining quiescent individuals are still pouring money into the bond markets. In the past year, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds have declined by more than a percentage point, to 11.75 percent. The drop in long-term tax-exempt municipal issues has not been so sharp - as of April 11, the Bond Buyer's 20-bond index stood at 9.39 percent, down from 9.97 percent a year earlier.

title: 'BLATANT AND CONTINUOUS'
description: Alabama never had a black state trooper until, in 1972, Federal Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. ordered an end to what he called the ''blatant and continuous discrimination.'' He told the state to hire equal numbers of blacks and whites until blacks were roughly a quarter of the force.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PEN, SWORD, CAMISOLE: A Fable to Kindle a Hope. By Jorge Amado. Translated by Helen R. Lane. (Godine, $15.95.) The Brazilian poet Antonio Bruno has just died in Paris, after hearing a radio bulletin announcing the fall of the city to the Nazis.

title: EMBARKING ON AN ALL-AMERICAN CRUISE
description: From the Atlantic to the Pacific, opportunities are increasing for Americans to tour their country by water.

title: Cable TV
description: With the enchanting Claudette Colbert back on Broadway in a light comedy hit, a rare TV showing of ''Three Came Home'' (1950) this week on cable is a reminder of the actress's range. Indeed, this fine, moving screen drama set in a Japanese prison camp in Borneo during World War II is a peak in Miss Colbert's long and distinguished Hollywood career.

title: NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
description: STRATEGIES FOR RECOVERY: ANALYST I think they should continue to do what they are doing, and do it better. The challenge will be that the athletic footwear market is mature within the United States. What do you need in a mature market? A hot new product to excite people to go out and buy it.

title: RESTORING HISTORY
description: IT rolled out of a Boeing plant in Seattle in January 1944, a Flying Fortress of World War II, and in three months the plane, named Shoo Shoo Shoo Baby by its crew, was dodging flak over Europe.

title: AN EXILE IN LITERARY AMERICA
description: Vassily Aksyonov has aimed and shot straight at the problem with all the arts in our country by likening the establishments behind them to general stores.

title: FOR WEDDINGS: MANOR, SHIP OR LOFT
description: THE days of barefoot-in-the-park weddings may be over, but many couples still want an alternative to the traditional walk-down-the-aisle ceremonies that have taken place for generations in churches, synagogues and hotel ballrooms. They want a setting that is unusual, one that is memorable for its beauty, history, natural scenery or even sheer novelty. For couples who are looking for such a place, there are numerous choices in Philadelphia, Boston, Washington and New York City.

title: SARA A. CARTMELL WED TO A LAWYER
description: Sara Aikins Cartmell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Madison Cartmell of Manchester, N.H., was married yesterday to William James Tennis, a son Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tennis of Baltimore. The Rev. David S. Hoag performed the ceremony at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., assisted by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman.

title: COTTAGE ENCLAVE FIGHTS TOWN
description: FROM a bluff overlooking Long Island Sound, the ramshackle cottages along West Meadow Beach in Stony Brook appear to huddle together, as if in closeness they might find protection from the wind and sea that ravage the slender peninsula on which they sit.

title: KIMMBALL WHEELER WED TO JORGE MESTER
description: The marriage of Kimball Wheeler, a mezzo-soprano, and Jorge Mester, a conductor, took place yesterday at the Arrow Park estate in Monroe, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Eugene Merlet, a Capucin Franciscan priest and founder of the Pro Musicis Foundation.

title: SERVICE AT ST. JOHN THE DIVINE MARKS 200TH YEAR OF DIOCESE
description: In the towering gothic Cathedral of St. John the Divine, nearly 1,300 worshipers celebrated the 200th anniversary of the Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday with prayers and hymns.

title: SEEKING HELP FOR HEAD INJURIES
description: JANE SPANBOCK makes a great first impression. A small, vivacious young woman with curly brown hair and big eyes, she smiles often as she carries on a breezy conversation. Within a few minutes, though, subtle clues begin to signal that something is amiss.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 14 WHIFFENPOOFS The Whiffenpoofs, the gentleman songsters of Yale, will assemble for their 75th annual commencement concert at 8:30 P.M. Wednesday in Sprague Hall on College Street. A Whiffenpoof, for the record, is a creature with wings of mint leaves, the head of a horse and tail of a serpent sitting on a swizzle stick.

title: THAT WINDFALL FOR SHOREHAM SCHOOLS
description: The article ''Shoreham Schools' Tax Woes'' [April 14] seems to lack perspective: For years the Shoreham-Wading River School District has enjoyed a tremendous economic windfall, and now they face the very real prospect of losing it. Isn't the important issue here really the ''woes'' of the surrounding school districts?

title: AFTER BITBURG, AN ELECTION GIVES KOHL THE BLUES
description: Whether Ronald Reagan's recent visit to Bonn and the Bitburg cemetery helped or hurt was in dispute, but there could be little doubt last week that Helmut Kohl, the West German Chancellor, was in trouble. In last Sunday's legislative elections in North Rhine-Westphalia, the country's most populous state, Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats slipped nearly 7 percentage points to 36.5 percent, while the opposition Social Democrats won a 52.1 percent majority.

title:
INVESTING;

OIL ISSUES BUBBLE, DESPITE THE ANALYSTS
description: INVESTORS might be forgiven for doubting the wisdom of analysts who follow oil stocks. For the past 18 months, many of these analysts have kept their thumbs turned down on the industry. Yet, because of takeovers and other corporate restructurings, the oil stocks have outperformed the market by a wide margin.

title: BRUSTEIN IN CAMBRIDGE: ADVENTUROUS SUCCESS
description: Things are looking up for Robert Brustein these days. When nearly half the audience for his American Repertory Theater production of Robert Wilson's ''Civil Wars'' walked out during one preview performance, Mr. Brustein noted, ''At least they didn't throw their programs at the ushers, the way the audiences did at 'Lulu' a couple of years ago.''

title:
CASE STUDY: A ONETIME HIGHFLIER;

NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
description: STRATEGIES FOR RECOVERY: LARGE RETAILER The key to the business is change, keeping attuned to the marketplace. It appears now that fashion and style and different uses are going to play an increasingly important role in the merchandizing of shoe companies.

title: Fullerton Is Awarded P.C.A.A. Football Title
description: California State at Fullerton has been awarded the Pacific Coast Athletic Association's vacated 1984 football championship.

title: ENCYCLOPEDIC MEDICAL CARD SHOWS THE WORTH OF YOUNG IDEAS
description: The senior management consultants gathered in a seventh-floor office and discussed the high-technology activities that had brought them national attention recently, smiling when it was noted that the most senior of the senior consultants was 26 years old, the most junior 19.

title: BO JACKSON HAS A CHOICE: FOOTBALL OR BASEBALL
description: DECISIONS, decisions. Bo Jackson has to make another one.

title: Quakes at Volcano On Anniversary of Blast
description: Mount St. Helens spat gas and was shaken by a series of small earthquakes today while nearby residents held a parade to commemorate the anniversary of the volcano's eruption five years ago.

title: St. John's on S.I. Holds 115th Commencement
description: A total of 372 undergraduate and graduate degrees and three honorary doctorates were awarded yesterday at the 115th commencement exercises of St. John's University's Staten Island campus.

title: ACCURSED WITH INFALLIBLE TASTE
description: RANDALL JARRELL'S LETTERS An Autobiographical and Literary Selection. Edited by Mary Jarrell with Stuart Wright. Illustrated. 540 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $29.95.

title: OYSTERS, AUSTRALIAN STYLE
description: In Sydney restaurants, local oysters, small succulent, faintly pinkish-gray morsels that bear little resemblance to the steak-sized Blue Points of Long Island, occupy pride of place at the top of the menu.

title: OF CONDOS, CO-OPS AND VOLATILITY
description: IN 1980, Gretchen V. Talbot, a 56-year-old former resort developer, bought a year-round residential condominium in Stuart, Fla., for $80,000. Three months later she was offered $130,000 for it. ''In my wisdom, I thought that if I waited another six months, I'd get $160,000,'' Mrs. Talbot said. ''Now I can't give it away for $90,000. I thought I knew what I was doing, but I apparently didn't.''

title: TO FORGIVE AND FORGET LIVE AND DEAD SINNERS
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSAN SCHWARTZ MARRIES
description: Susan B. Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Schwartz of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Craig B. Derene, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris Derene of Stamford. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y. The bride is a systems engineer with the International Business Machines Corporation in New York.

title: A MUSICAL THEME FOR EUROPE'S ISSUES
description: The Council of Europe has declared 1985 as European Music Year. In keeping with this declaration, the member countries of the European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations are devoting their annual Europa issues to the music theme.

title: DEBRA BECKER IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Becker of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Lynn Becker, to Kenneth Scott Greenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Greenbaum of Merrick, L.I. The future bride expects to graduate from Adelphi University May 23. Mr. Greenbaum, the owner of Eurosound Security Systems in Bellmore, L.I., graduated from the Nassau Community College and attended the New York Institute of Technology.

title: 2 DEMOCRATS VIE FOR HENRY'S POST
description: SUFFOLK County District Attorney Patrick Henry called a news conference a few days ago at his offices in Hauppauge to announce the arrest of the owner of a home heating oil delivery company on charges of cheating customers by short-weighting their deliveries.

title: KEEPING POWER TOOLS HUMMING
description: OUTDOOR power tools speed up many chores, as well as eliminating a great deal of tedious and strenuous labor. However, in order to keep them working efficiently and to prolong the life of the tool as much as possible, all power tools - mowers, hedge trimmers, weed trimmers, tillers and similar equipment - need periodic maintenance and regular tuneups.

title: CONSERVATISM FINDS ITS TV VOICE
description: The United States Government should overthrow the government in Nicaragua ''and we should try to do it openly.'' The Reagan Administration should ''tell all the Americans to get out of Libya and then specifically get the American oil companies out.'' The shooting of U. S. Army Major Arthur Nicholson by Soviet troops in East Berlin was ''murder'' that should prompt the Administration to demand ''some satisfaction or some penalty.''

title: BEACH CONDOMINIUMS FOUGHT
description: THE last substantial undeveloped oceanfront property on Long Beach Island is the prize in a dispute between a builder who wants to put up a 156-unit condominium complex and the Atlantic Beach Estates Property Owners' Association, which wants single-family homes.

title: The Beauty Of Taekwondo
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BASQUE TAXI DRIVER SLAIN
description: The police found a taxi driver shot to death outside Bermeo today after a man identifying himself as a member of a Basque separatist organization telephoned a travelers' aid office and took responsibility for the shooting. He described the victim, Juan Jose Uriart Orue, as an informer.

title: PEIRRE BOULEZ IS SCHOENBERG'S ARDENT ADVOCATE
description: When Pierre Boulez departed as music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1977, he hardly abandoned conducting. Along with his composition and administration of his new-music facility in Paris, he has led the Ensemble InterContemporain and a few other European ensembles in the music he loves best.

title: VERMONT PLANS A STATE PARK ON ISLAND IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN
description: This 120-acre Lake Champlain island will become Vermont's 43d state park in July, when $250,000 in state funds become available for its purchase.

title: BEASTLY BEHAVIOR Real-Life Mouse
description: In ''The Purple Rose of Cairo,'' a movie hero comes down off the screen to explore life in a New Jersey town blighted by the Depression. In one pointed scene, the screen figure puts up his dukes to fight a real-life opponent only to be thrown down and savagely kicked.

title: Storm Trysail Club: For Survivors Only
description: The Storm Trysail Club is not your ordinary yacht club. There is no clubhouse, no dock, and no sundeck on which to dry sodden foul-weather gear. It is an honorary club, quartered at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and to join it, a person must be able to prove that he has weathered a storm at sea.

title: C. N. JAMISON JR. WEDS LISA JONES
description: All Saints Episcopal Church in Washington was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lisa Fairchild Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bowdoin Jones of Washington, to Charles Newman Jamison Jr., the son of Vivian Shaw Jamison of Westbury, L.I., and the late Mr. Jamison. The Rev. Henry S. Irvin, assisted by the Rev. John Carleton Hayden, performed the ceremony.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: May 19, 1985 Fiction

title: TULANE STORY: PRESIDENT TELLS OF CHANGES NEEDED
description: LAST month, in the wake of allegations of point shaving and illegal payments to players, Tulane University in New Orleans dropped its men's intercollegiate basketball program. Dr. Eamon M. Kelly, president of the university, said that the action was necessary to ''reaffirm the university's primary mission as an academic institution.'' In a recent question-and-answer session with Edward B. Fiske, Education Editor of The New York Times, Dr. Kelly discussed the real and potential conflicts between academic standards and bigtime athletics. Dr. Kelly declined to discuss any individual students for reasons of confidentiality. Following are excerpts from that interview:

title: BANK JITTERS BREAK OUT IN MARYLAND
description: The condition of the country's privately insured savings and loans association has worried banking experts for some time. In March, Ohio declared a bank holiday, the first since the Great Depression, to stem a run on financial institutions.

title: LEBANON CHRISTIANS CLOSE ISRAEL OFFICE
description: Lebanon's main Christian militia force announced today that it was closing its office in Jerusalem in a move designed to end 10 years of collaboration with Israel.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;

MARYLAND SUFFERS THRIFT UNIT JITTERS
description: The turmoil in Maryland's privately insured thrift institutions began to ease after the state imposed a $1,000-a-month limit on withdrawals at all 102 savings and loan associations involved. A run had started with reports of trouble at Old Court Savings, then spread to Merritt Commercial Savings after similar reports there. Long lines of depositors had started to form at other institutions before the withdrawal limit was imposed. As a more permanent solution, two big New York banks may buy the troubled units, and an expedited conversion to Federal insurance was being pursued. Coming two months after the Ohio banking crisis, the Maryland episode was seen as a near-fatal blow to the private insurance systems in four other states. None of them experienced runs, but one of them, in North Carolina, has decided to seek the protection of the F.D.I.C.

title: PETER MAAG - A CONDUCTOR WHO LEARNED TO BE PATIENT
description: Peter Maag, the Swiss conductor best known for his Mozart - Glenn Gould is said to have thought him one of the great Mozarteans -has concentrated on big pieces in his association with the American Symphony Orchestra. Last year, the Verdi Requiem; this afternoon Beethoven's Ninth. Mr. Maag likes it here and likes the orchestra, which he discussed affectionately during his visit last month to lead Britten's song cycle ''Les Illuminations.'' ''You sense the players' readiness,'' he says with satisfaction. Although the A.S.O. is asserting its national identity in 1985-86 with an all-American roster that necessarily excludes Mr. Maag, he will be back. Plans are already being laid for a return engagement that, he hopes, will presage a long collaboration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, MAY 19, 1985 International

title: MUCH ADO ABOUT MOZART ON NEW COMPACT DISKS
description: The compact disk's demanding ear tests Mozart and his interpreters in a series of recent recordings on CD. Six releases offer four piano concertos, four symphonies, music for winds and two of Mozart's earlier choral works.

title: Triptych Is First Filly To Win 2,000 Guineas
description: Triptych became the first filly to win the Irish 2,000 Guineas at the Curragh today.

title: A TASTE THAT COUNTS
description: FROM MY EARLIEST CHILDHOOD, I HAVE questioned the cynical notion that ''there's no accounting for taste.'' I think there is every accounting for taste, and it may range from a simplistic, altogether obvious liking for a sweet dessert to a highly specialized, much more complicated passion for a decidedly exotic and aromatic platter of assertive cheeses.

title: PARONOMASIAMANIA
description: THE PRICK OF NOON By Peter De Vries. 233 pp. Boston: Little Brown & Company. $14.95.

title: NUPTIALS FOR ANN RIDER AND A. J. HILL, LAWYERS
description: Ann Sherwood Rider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Decker Rider of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Anthony John Hill, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hill of Hamilton, Ontario. The Rev. Stanley Lyon Houston, retired minister of the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: SO FAR, IT'S LESS THAN A VINTAGE YEAR
description: If the rest of 1985 measures down to the first four months of the year, the movie business could be dead by Christmas.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: PENN'S HAT TIPS IN PHILADELPHIA IN Philadelphia, tradition holds, nothing rises higher than Billy Penn's hat. In Philadelphia, tradition is serious business.

title: PROJECT FOR TEEN-AGE MOTHERS FALTERS
description: IN an effort to address the problems of growing numbers of teen-age mothers in Port Chester, the Teen-Age Parenting Program financed by the United Way through the Port Chester/Town of Rye Council of Community Services was developed late last year.

title: TAPPING INTO HOME EQUITY
description: A YOUNG businessman passes his neighbors' substantial-looking homes and explains that one neighbor took out a loan for business and another to add a room to his house. He himself took out a loan and bought a fancy car, which he exhibits when he gets to his driveway.

title: About Men;   A MOWER OF LAWNS
description: OUR HOUSE SITS ON A HILL, WITH the remains of an old barn still attached to the back, and our lawn runs in a wide, slightly irregular shape on the two long sides of the buildings and in a narrow square across the front, between the house and the street.

title: New Uses for an Old High School
description: EMPTY and unused since the late 1970's, Haaren High School, the seven-story brick and limestone Flemish-Renaissance structure on 10th Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets, is getting a new look, a new use and a new name.

title: JACKSON ON SPELLING, KENNEDY ON YALE
description: To the Editor:

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Some Shelter, Please A Few Whiffs May 20 - In 1912, Cole Porter wrote his first complete show for Yale Dramat, the undergraduate theatrical association, and, 13 years later, Yale became one of the first American universities to offer training for professional theater careers with the establishment of the Yale School of Drama and the University Theater. The drama school and the undergraduate association, which are celebrating their 60th and 85th anniversaries, respectively, this year, will benefit from a salute to Cole Porter at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Present will be Lena Horne, Cy Coleman, the Whiffenpoofs of 1985 and others, followed by supper for benefactors and Sapphire Circle Patrons at the Starlight Roof at the Waldorf-Astoria, where the composer lived for many years. Tickets for the performance begin at $15 and for the dinner at $500, from 212-772-7431. A Hard Shell May 20 - The Museum of American Folk Art will have a dinner-dance in the summer garden of the American Festival Cafe at Rockefeller Plaza to celebrate Terrapins, Tortoises and Turtles, the exhibition that opens May 21 at the museum at 125 West 55th Street. The guest of honor is George, a 184-year-old tortoise owned by Barbara Johnson, a trustee of the museum. Geoffrey Holder will premiere a new dance, the Tortoise Wamble, at the benefit, which begins at 8 P.M. Tickets are $100 for members and $150 for nonmembers, from 212-581-2474. Some Fellowship May 20 - Robert Motherwell, the artist; Arthur Miller, the playwright, and Stanley Kunitz, the poet, are some of the patrons of the eighth annual New York Benefit for the Fine Arts Work Center in Provincetown, Mass.

title: OPPORTUNITIES IN PARTNERSHIPS
description: ALTHOUGH the Internal Revenue Service is cracking down on tax shelters it considers abusive - those structured to take maximum advantage of the tax laws but with little or no economic merit - there are still numerous offerings with both investment merit and tax benefits.

title: IN SHORT: NON FICTION
description: UP FOR GRABS: A Trip Through Time and Space in the Sunshine State. By John Rothchild. (Viking, $15.95.) Flamingos are to Florida as crabs are to Maryland.

title:
DINING OUT;

TOUCH OF NORTHERN ITALY IN HARRISON
description: SITUATED in a sparkling white Colonial house surrounded by well-tended lawn, hollies and flowering shrubs, Emilio is now in its sixth year of turning out some interesting dishes from a cuisine favoring Italy's north. At the entrance to the dining rooms, beside the commodious bar, a cornucopious still life of such delectable items as crinkled morels, porcini, chanterelles or other wild mushrooms; glowing red and yellow peppers; beefsteak tomatoes; zucchini blossoms; samples of the restaurant's famous homemade pasta (made daily by Emilio Brasesco's wife, Lidia) makes an irresistible lure to the tables beyond.

title: THE GAME'S AFOOT ON DISKS
description: Anyone for murder? The mystery story, which has been with us in its present form for almost a century and a half and helped while away the night hours for innumerable insomniacs, can now be heard as well as read. A number of reputable British actors have been busy at the microphone recording them, bravely attempting to simulate the French accents of the Belgian sleuth Hercule Poirot, the Parisian C. Auguste Dupin, and the tough-guy American tones of Raymond Chandler's private eye Philip Marlowe, as well as all types and classes of Englishmen. The results are certainly entertaining, the only real disadvantage being that you can't riffle back through the pages to clear up a missed point in the puzzle; pressing the rewind button on a cassette player or trying to find your way back through the grooves of a phonograph record is much too hit or miss a business.

title: CHATEAU FOR A ROYAL FAVORITE
description: Deep in the country, but not very far from Versailles, one of the most charming chateaus of the Ile de France enshrines the memory of an uncrowned queen. Madame de Maintenon, the commoner who married the Sun King, saw to it that her house reflected her complex personality; and Maintenon today remains an eloquent comment on the way she made her way to the top.

title: KEEPING AN EYE ON WASHINGTON
description: THE economy. Tax reform. Interest rates. The price of oil. The dollar. And, of course, the twin monster deficits in foreign trade and the Federal budget. These are the uncertainties, extraordinary both in their number and potential for disaster, that have lead many professionals and do-it-yourselfers these days to throw up their hands in despair of finding a profitable investment strategy. Too many imponderables, each related in ways unfathomable to the most sophisticated computer program, have produced in many a sense of near helplessness.

title: BARBARA SCHICK WED TO DAVID MCDONOUGH
description: Barbara Ann Schick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Schick of Maitland, Fla., and David Michael McDonough, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. McDonough of Sea Girt, N.J., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., were married yesterday. The ceremony at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Oxford, Md., was performed by the Rev. Lawrence J. Seyler, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr.

title: Salmon Controls Attract Support
description: THE decision by John Fraser, Canada's Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, to continue stringent regulations aimed at rebuilding Atlantic salmon populations is applauded by Wilfred Carter, executive vice president of the Atlantic Salmon Federation.

title: LOOKING FRESH IN SUMMER
description: FOR SUMMER, makeup and hair care can be vexing matters. Whether one seeks a look of pale delicacy, a tanned robustness or a polished healthiness, whether one's hair is curly, straight or in between, nature often conspires to thwart the best-intentioned of beauty aims. For one thing, there is perspiration; for another, the risk of overexposure to sun, chlorine and salt. As a result, whether working or water-skiing, women are continually seeking makeup that will not wilt under sweltering summer skies.

title: PLANNERS OFFER MODEL PORTFOLIOS
description: INVESTING comes down to four ''P's,'' says George E.L.

title: FARRELL CONCEDES PROBLEMS MARSHALING BLACK SUPPORT
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., expressing concern about his Democratic mayoral campaign, has acknowledged that his support in the black community is still ''not gluing together.''

title: Overseas Banking
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH JERSEY ARTISTS SEEK GREATER RECOGNITION
description: A DOZEN representatives of art galleries, nonprofit art institutions and a museum have banded together to focus the eyes of the state - and, specifically, the eyes of the State Council on the Arts - on the state of the visual arts south of Trenton.

title: THE POPE PLAYS TO A TOUGH AUDIENCE
description: Pope John Paul II's visit to the Netherlands last week was a papal journey like no other. Everywhere else, the Pope has been met by large and enthusiastic crowds. In the Netherlands, the crowds were small, the welcome lukewarm if not cold; people were talking back to the Pope. Through his extensive travels, John Paul had turned television into an important asset. This time, the pictures flashed around the world were of angry protesters clashing with the police.

title: IN SHORT: NON FICTION
description: PASTORALE: A Natural History of Sorts. By Jake Page. (Norton, $13.95.) ''So much of what passes for intellectual discussion these days is about differences and change, but what strikes me as stunning are similarities and continuities,'' writes Jake Page, who moved from Washington to a rural Virginia town where he is a keen observer of man and nature.

title: ALUMNI AID CAREER EFFORT
description: WHILE most other schools its size have fewer than 25 career counselors, the University of Connecticut now has more than 500, thanks to a program that recruits alumni to help students learn about job opportunities.

title: JAMAICA
description: To the Editor: The article by Joseph Treaster, ''Carefree or Careful in Jamaica'' (Travel, April 7) brought to mind our recent trip to the island and our shared experiences. My family and I made Ocho Rios our headquarters in March of this year. We were advised not to travel into Kingston. Indeed, the car rental agencies did not allow their vehicles to be driven there. In the words of one friendly fellow we met on the beach, ''You've got big ugly cities in your own country, so why go to Kingston?'' Nevertheless, we missed not seeing the metropolis, which has many lovely and historic areas and buildings, as well as some excellent art galleries, not to mention a bustling night life. We spent more time in the rural areas of the country's northern coast.

title: WARSAW, TOO, PAYING HEED TO THE POLLS
description: Public-opinion polls, once regarded by Communist theorists as indications of false consciousness, are playing an increasingly important role in political decision making in Poland.

title: RACING'S BIG LEAGUE TRAINER
description: There are trainers in thoroughbred racing who have won Triple Crown races, but there was no other trainer in the Preakness today who could say he once batted 7-for-9 in a doubleheader for the Washington Senators.

title: CHOLERA REPORTED IN 2 MORE ETHIOPIAN CAMPS
description: A disease believed to be cholera has broken out in two more Ethiopian relief centers, according to Western relief workers and diplomats.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

NAME THE RACOON
description: What do you call a 5-foot 10-inch, 150-pound talking racoon? Anything it wants! Or anything you want.

title: A TALK WITH MILAN KUNDERA
description: HIS FACE IS SHADOWED BY THE DEEPENING PARIS TWI-light; only the eyes stand out, an intense blue. He speaks slowly, in cultivated French, with a strong Slavic accent. ''Only a literary work that reveals an unknown fragment of human existence has a reason for being,'' he says in the extended question-and-answer interview that follows. ''To be a writer does not mean to preach a truth, it means to discover a truth.''

title: HOW WE LOOK TO OUR FRIENDS
description: THIRD WORLD INSTABILITY: CENTRAL AMERICA AS A EUROPEAN-AMERICAN ISSUE By Fernando Moran, Irving Kristol, Michael D. Barnes, Alois Mertes and Daniel Oduber. Edited by Andrew J. Pierre. 156 pp. New York: Council on Foreign Relations. Paper, $5.95. CENTRAL AMERICA AND THE WESTERN ALLIANCE Edited by Joseph Cirincione. 238 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. $26.50.

title: A TASTE FOR RISK
description: THE PORK BUTCHER By David Hughes. 123 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $11.95.

title: BOOK EXAMINES 'FAMILY ROLES' AT WORK
description: PAULA BERNSTEIN's parents divorced when she was a baby. She grew up with her mother and grandmother; when she was 14 years old, her mother died. She was an only child. But, as she recalls it, she was saved from loneliness by an after-school job as a newspaper reporter. At work, she found camaraderie and, more than that, a sense of family. At work, she found people who filled the roles of father, mother, sister, brother.

title: SAUDIS TO INSTALL $4 BILLION AIR DEFENSE SUSTEM
description: Saudi Arabia has embarked on a $4 billion project to set up the most technologically advanced integrated air defense system outside of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet bloc.

title: NINA V. LAWRENCE TO WED A BROKER
description: A September wedding is planned by Nina Valerie Lawrence and Charles Lockwood Halsey, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Clitherall Lawrence of Greenwich, Conn., have announced.

title: A FEW WORDS OF CAUTION ON SCHOOLING THE VERY YOUNG
description: Should children start school at an earlier age? Lots of people these days are saying yes. The education commissioners of New York and Connecticut want public schools to lower the age of compulsory schooling from 6 to 4. At least five states have recently made kindergarten attendance compulsory, and pressure is growing for schools to meet the day-care needs of working mothers.

title: WHERE THE 18th CENTURY MEETS TODAY
description: THE future seemed bright for the West Indian planters.

title: BROKERAGE BY COMPUTER GROWS
description: SOON, investors may be picking their brokers more for their software than for their advice.

title: Airplane Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: Manchester United Wins Soccer Title
description: A brilliant goal by Norman Whiteside 20 minutes into overtime with his team a player short gave Manchester United a 1-0 triumph over Everton today in the Football Association Cup final.

title: THE GIRLS IN THE LIFE
description: THE INVISIBLE CHILDREN Child Prostitution in America, West Germany and Great Britain. By Gitta Sereny. 254 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 5 about Yale University's acquisition of some weapons used in the killing of four Kent State University students in 1970 incorrectly described some of the victims.

title:
GARDENING;

KEEPING AN OLD FAVORITE IN BLOOM
description: GERANIUMS have long been a favorite garden subject. Actually, the plants that we most commonly call geranium are really pelargoniums.

title: THE FINGER LAKES: 250 MILES BY BIKE
description: According to Iroquois legend, the Finger Lakes were formed when the Great Spirit placed his hand on the land and left behind water-filled fingerprints. In truth, the great hand that formed the lakes was a series of glaciers that scoured the land, carving troughs as they went. The deepest of the troughs filled with water, forming the 11 long, narrow lakes that fan out in an area of New York State south of a line drawn from Rochester to Syracuse. Other glacial remnants include gorges and waterfalls as well as the less dramatic drumlins, cigar-shaped hills of glacially compacted material that runs north and south between the Finger Lakes and Lake Ontario.

title: BLOCK THAT VIETNAM MYTH
description: Soon after the end of the First World War, Gen. Erich von Ludendorff and some reactionary nationalist leaders invented a myth to explain Germany's defeat. The German Army, thoroughly beaten in the field after the failure of the March 1918 offensive, had, they asserted, really won the war. But then, like Siegfried in the heroic German sagas, it had been ''stabbed in the back'' by the politicians.

title: MASAI MARA
description: To the Editor: In September 1984, my husband, 15-month-old son and I stayed at Lewa Downs and Governor's Camp, Masai Mara (''Kenya as It Was,'' by Michael Korda, Travel, April 7).

title: YANKS TOP ANGELS FOR SIXTH STRAIGHT
description: Billy Martin was smiling. ''That, ladies and gentlemen,'' he said when reporters assembled in his office late today, ''is baseball at its best.''

title: CONSERVATIVES PRESSURE G.O.P.
description: THE longstanding alliance between the Republican and Conservative Parties in Suffolk County is being threatened this year by a Conservative demand, reiterated last week, that Republican county legislators agree to support a resolution that would permit a referendum this November on whether the County Legislature should be abolished.

title: THE HORRORS OF SECULAR HUMANISM
description: A new amendment slid quietly into the Education for Economic Security Act last year. It prohibits the use of Federal magnet school funds for ''any course of instruction the substance of which is secular humanism.''

title: CAMOUFLAGE
description: LIKE A SECOND (and more perfect) skin, a covering of corrective makeup can conceal a wide variety of flaws. On the face, dark under-eye circles, scars, freckles, capillaries, mild sunburn, birthmarks and pigmentation irregularities can be painted over so that they seem to disappear. On the body, too, makeup can be used to hide stretch marks, varicose veins and even tattoos, especially during the summer, when swimsuits reveal more than they conceal.

title: FROM THE AGED, LESSONS TO LEARN
description: I GUESS it's an occupational hazard for those of us who work with the aged. ''It must be depressing'' is a frequent comment I hear when I identify myself as a gerontologist. The old, it appears to many, would distress even the most sympathetic individual and ''Well, thank God somebody takes an interest in them.''

title: IN QUOTES
description: Ohio concerned me a lot, but I didn't think it would happen a second time.

title: PATRICIA ANN DORADO WED TO WILLIAM MCANDREW JR.
description: Patricia Ann Dorado, an account executive at Wyse Advertising, and William Robert McAndrew Jr., the news informastion manager for press and publicity at NBC, were married yesterday at the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: THE PRICE COLLEGES PAY FOR THE WIN-AT-ALL-COSTS ATTITUDE
description: AS the sports pages - and the front pages - have made depressingly clear, it's been a losing season for college athletics. The past months have seen drug controversies at Arizona State and Clemson, point-shaving charges at Tulane and recruiting scandals and investigations all over the country. Last week there were fresh reports that a grand jury was investigating possible links between local gambling activity and the Memphis State basketball program. So this month seemed an appropriate time for a conference at Louisiana State University that among other things looked at what has gone wrong with big-time college sports and why. Among the participants were State Senator Ernest Chambers of Nebraska, who has introduced a bill to pay college athletes as if they were university employees; Dr. Harry Edwards, associate professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley, who organized the protest by some black athletes at the 1968 Olympics, and Dr. James H. Wharton, Chancellor of L.S.U. and a prime mover in the adoption of new rules governing academic standards for student athletes. Excerpts follow.

title: HOUSTON'S GOLFING DYNASTY: RECRUITING AND HARD WORK
description: COACH Dave Williams takes his University of Houston golf team to the national championship meet at the Grenelefe Golf Course in Florida Wednesday with one of the best records ever compiled in college sports: 15 national championships. And the school doesn't even have a golf course.

title: Ali in China
description: Muhammad Ali performs his magic these days with cards and other props, but for a while last week the former heavyweight champion was back in the ring, to spar informally with some Chinese boxers during a stop in Peking. Mr. Ali, who is 43 years old, suffers from Parkinson's Syndrome, which sometimes causes his speech to be slurred and his body movements to be slowed. But dressed in gray slacks and a white shirt, he jabbed his way through five one-minute rounds at the Peking Physical Education Institute, part of an 11-day trip to China at the invitation of the Government. Later, he signaled the end of a news conference by yawning loudly, standing up and performing a magic trick for his enthusiastic Chinese audience.

title: Greeks Report Finding Core of Terrorist Group
description: The Greek police, investigating an officer's shooting, say they have uncovered the nucleus of a terrorist group. Authorities say one member of the group was once active in the Socialist Party.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Viennawalks By J. Sydney Jones. 289 pages; with photographs by the author. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $10.95. Four figures on the 140-year-old Austria Fountain in the Freyung Square at Vienna's center represent the major rivers of the Hapsburg monarchy when Metternich was running it - Danube, Po, Elbe and Vistula. Today's Austria controls only a stretch of the Danube, but reminiscences of the empire of yesterday still flavor its capital.

title: HOYD AMMIDON 3d, A BANK TRAINEE, AND PAMELA J. LIPSCOMB WILLMARRY
description: Announcement has been made by Jack Carlton Lipscomb of Manassas, Va., and Barbara Millnitz Lipscomb of Centerville, Va., of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Jill Lipscomb to Hoyd Ammidon 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ammidon Jr. of Houston, formerly of Princeton, N.J. An August wedding is planned. Miss Lipscomb graduated magna cum laude from the School of Geological Sciences of Virginia Polytechnic Institute, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

title: INDIA FINDS ITSELF CAUGHT IN A VICIOUS CYCLE OF NEW VIOLENCE
description: For the first time since the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, the army patrolled the streets of this capital city last week. The people of northern India had reason to wonder whether acts of terrorism by Sikhs would soon become routine.

title: C. R. WOLF WEDS MISS KRIMENDAHL, GRADUTE STUDENT
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Knowles Krimendahl, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Frederick Krimendahl 2d of New York and East Hampton, L.I., to Christopher Robin Wolf, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rene Arthur Wolf of Memphis and McCoy, Colo., took place yesterday. The Rev. Willoughby Newton performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CALENDARS
description: HORSE SHOWS Today - The Academy of St. Joseph, Brentwood, L.I. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (516) 333-0663.

title: DIESEL EXHAUST CALLED PERIL IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Exhaust from diesel-powered buses and trucks is a serious and growing threat to health and the environment in New York City, according to a report by a national environmental group.

title: THE EDUCATION OF ILKA WEISSNIX
description: HER FIRST AMERICAN By Lore Segal. 287 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: FOOD OUTLETS IN NEW YORK VIOLATE CODE
description: The New York City Health Department last week released a list of 97 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: BULGARIA'S CHIEF PROSECUTOR PUTS TOLL IN BOMBINGS AT 30
description: Two weeks before a visit to the United States, Prime Minister Milka Planinc says that a faltering economy has brought Yugoslavia ''to the point of a rather dangerous limit of what people will tolerate.''

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Good Neighbor Sam Starring Jack Lemmon, Romy Schneider, Dorothy Provine, Edward G. Robinson; directed by David Swift, 1964 RCA Columbia Home Video 130 minutes. $59.95 Just one well-meaning lie leads to a host of comic complications in this amiable farce derived from a novel by Jack Finney, the author of ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers'' and ''Time and Again.''

title: LETTING UP ON FUEL ECONOMY
description: Responding to the Arab oil embargo, Congress mandated 10 years ago that American automobile makers gradually double the fuel efficiency of their passenger cars, until they reached an average of 27.5 miles a gallon by the 1985 model year. Now, it appears that the Reagan Administration may relax those standards.

title: DROUGHT GROUP HEARS PLEAS
description: A LARCHMONT woman asked the Westchester Drought Emergency Task Force for a time variance so her automatic sprinkler system could start at 2 A.M. instead of 7 A.M.

title: NUCLEAR PEACE: L.I. CAN LEAD THE WAY
description: Scientists assure us that even a one-sided major nuclear attack will devastate our air, earth and water with fire storms, radiation and nuclear winter. History teaches war is madness. Either we quit the arms race now, or the atomic age will end in nuclear holocaust that life, not just mankind, may not survive.

title: LUXURY PLUS
description: Greenwich, Conn., where homes and condominiums are among the most expensive in the metropolitan area, has long been a symbol of suburban affluence. But the asking prices of $2.1 million and up for three homes being built on speculation on a 3.5-acre piece of the former Isbrandtsen estate may raise some eyebrows even there.

title: WITH PIECES IN PLACE, REAGAN IS SET TO FIGHT FOR OVERHAUL
description: WHEN President Reagan announced in his 1984 State of the Union Message that he had directed the Secretary of the Treasury to study how to overhaul the Federal income tax system, skeptics dismissed it as a ploy to keep tax questions out of the Presidential election campaign.

title: A FEROCIOUS AND GLEEFUL INTELLIGENCE AT WORK
description: The visitor to the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis is warned, even before he even gets inside the building, that there is something peculiar about the retrospective of work by Jennifer Bartlett that can be seen through July 21. The Center is surrounded, that is to say, by objects that are both true and untrue to our experience. There are houses, boats, tables, chairs, boulders and serpentine walls. They look right, and some of them are very seductive. But, at the same time, they aren't right. They are philosophical essences - more real than real, one might almost say -but denial, as much as affirmation, is built into their nature.

title: FOR SOMETHING TRULY DIFFERENT, THE KNOT GARDEN
description: One of the more fascinating aspects of working with garden plants is the discovery of how versatile they can be if given half a chance. Planning a knot garden is a case in point. Of course, satisfactory results depend as much on the gardener's sense of adventure and persistence as they do on the willingness of the plants to adapt to peculiar and unnatural training.

title: Chung Takes 400 Title
description: When Curtis Chung was driving to the Eddy Games here this morning with Bob Coltrust, the assistant track coach at Brooklyn's Grady High School, he felt depressed. He mentioned that he did not like to run in the rain.

title: AT YALE, A SCHOLAR PRODUCES SMALL MAGAZINE PROVIDING VIETNAMESE REFUGEES WITH A VOICE
description: Huynh Sanh Thong, who edits a small journal here, receives so many poems, stories, personal histories and essays that he cannot possibly publish everything that hopeful writers send him.

title: INCREASED ATTACKS ON 'BOAT PEOPLE' REPORTED
description: Refugee officials here say they have been receiving reports of a new surge in pirate attacks on Vietnamese ''boat people,'' often marked by the ramming and sinking of the vessels and the kidnapping and raping of young women.

title: SEEING THE LIGHT ON BLIND DATES
description: IT happened at a wedding. What better place for the perennial matchmaker to flourish? I had all the right credentials: I was bright, attractive, stylish, thirtyish . . . but, foremost, was a single female.

title: MARYBETH WESTON, EDITOR, WED TO LEWIS BERGMAN
description: Marybeth Little Weston, former garden editor of House and Garden magazine, was married yesterday to Lewis Bergman, former editor of The New York Times Magazine.

title: A WEALTH OF NEW TALENT SPARKS THE DANCE SCENE
description: The oft-heard lament nowadays is that the age of great dancing is past. Yes, there are individuals who stand out, but the galaxy of stars once taken for granted seems to have been replaced by a field of efficient technicians. Of course, we say, some of today's young dancers can execute the kinds of turns and jumps that their predecessors could not. But where are the Margot Fonteyns of yesteryear, the Erik Bruhns and Allegra Kents, the Bolshoi men who hurtled through the air or the dominating modern-dance presences from Martha Graham on down who needed only to step on a stage for eyes to remain riveted upon them for hours?

title: THE FAMILY HOUSING CRISIS
description: MY son called recently to ask if he could move back home. His roommate was getting married and now the couple needs a place to stay, so my son had been asked to move out.

title: OUTLOOK FOR YOUNG BLACK MALES CALLED BLEAK
description: Speakers and panelists at the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund's annual Civil Rights Institute last week painted a gloomy picture of economic and educational progress for most blacks in recent years.

title: DESPITE THE MOVIE, THERE'S LITTLE TO LAUGH AT IN BUSHMANLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NON FICTION
description: THE LONG SURRENDER. By Burke Davis. (Random House, $19.95.) Burke Davis, that fine chronicler of the Confederacy, tells the story of a little-known aspect of the Civil War and handles it with an eye for narrative detail that turns history into storytelling.

title: WHAT IS BEHIND THE TAKEOVERS?
description: THERE is a singular parallel between corporate and family life that has emerged more clearly as a result of recent news reports involving corporate takeover battles.

title: BETTING ON 'HUSBANDS AND LOVERS'
description: THE jacket flap of the novel ''Husbands and Lovers'' reads: ''Carlys Webber Arnold has it all - a spectacular career, a handsome and successful husband, plenty of money, her own special style. Suddenly the irresistible George Kouros walks into her life, arousing desires even she didn't know she possessed. From that moment on, her life will never be the same. And neither will yours.''

title: RADIOACTIVE GAS IN SOIL RAISES CONCERN IN THREE-STATE AREA
description: A natural environmental hazard of uncertain but potentially grave dimensions has been discovered beneath the meadows of eastern Pennsylvania.

title: Leeks on St. David's Day
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW BID FOR CONRAIL
description: With the Reagan Administration's proposed sale of Conrail to Norfolk Southern stalled in Congress, Morgan Stanley & Company came in last week with a bid from 25 investors. Though the Transportation Department was cool, some members of Congress were not.

title: DEPARTING PLANNER LEAVES RECORD OF REHABILITATION
description: V.J. FERRANDINO says he is resigning as Mount Vernon's Commissioner of Planning and Community Development at the end of this month, but Mayor Ronald A. Blackwood has another version: ''he's not leaving as such; he's changing course.''

title: RIGHTS GROUP LEADER CALLS REAGAN 'RACIST'
description: A black civil rights leader called President Reagan a rectionary racist Friday in what was billed as the opening shot of a major public relations assault on the President's rights record.

title: ROUNDTABLE: 3 EXPERTS' CHOICES
description: Is this the time to buy stocks or debt instruments? Would real estate be a safer choice? Or with the yawning Federal deficits and clouded outlook for tax-law changes, is it prudent to stay in cash? These are tough questions to answer. To help investors map their own investment strategies, Fred R. Bleakley of The New York Times invited three experts to share their views: James E. Conway, president of the Ayco Corporation, an executive consulting subsidiary of American Express; John T. Haggerty, national director of personal financial planning for Prudential Bache Securities, and Sylvan M. Cohen, president of the Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust. Mr. Bleakley and Jan M. Rosen of The Times questioned the experts.

title: SALVADOR PUTS GUERRILLAS ON THE DEFENSIVE
description: AFTER a five-year war that produced striking military and political gains, Salvador's leftist guerrillas seem to have stumbled. Popular backing for the estimated 5,000 armed guerrillas no longer seems to be growing and improved army tactics have forced them onto the defensive. Guerrilla commanders who once vowed to seize power in a few years now speak of a decades-long war of attrition. Rebel units that formerly sought out and defeated army battalions are now avoiding contact and concentrating on sabotage and political intimidation.

title: 2 AUTHORS BATTLE OVER COMPETING BOOKS ABOUT UTAH MILLIONAIRE'S MURDER
description: One of the most bizarre crimes in recent years, the 1978 murder of a multimillionaire plotted by the victim's New York socialite daughter and carried out by her son, is the subject of two books scheduled for publication next month. But already the books have ignited one of the most bitter publishing feuds in memory, with the authors and the victim's widow accusing each other of ''deception,'' ''misrepresentation,'' ''checkbook journalism'' and ''unethical conduct.''

title:
GARDENING;

KEEPING AN OLD FAVORITE IN BLOOM
description: GERANIUMS have long been a favorite garden subject. Actually, the plants that we most commonly call geranium are really pelargoniums.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ON TO STALINGRAD The photographs in THE ONSLAUGHT: The German Drive to Stalingrad (Norton, $24.95) - a chronicle of the Nazi advance on Stalingrad that began in 1941 as seen through the cameras of three German soldiers - fail to capture what the book's well-translated (by Arnold J. Pomerans) text describes as a brutal struggle against starvation, bitter cold, disease and the Red Army. The photographs, neither journalism nor propaganda, do not convey the desperation of the German troops.

title: FOREST INBVENTORY MAY AID REESEARCH
description: THE Forest Inventory for New Jersey, the first such comprehensive inventory in 14 years, may tell researchers and state officials how acid precipitation affects woodlands.

title: BRITANNIA LETS GO
description: THE BRITISH EMPIRE IN THE MIDDLE EAST 1945-1951 Arab Nationalism, the United States, and Postwar Imperialism. By Wm. Roger Louis. Illustrated. 803 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $55.

title: MALL FAIRS SHOW OFF THE STATE
description: AS A way of bringing state government to the people, the Office of Management and Budget is continuing its traveling exhibition of 40 displays on departments, agencies and commissions.

title: ISLAM AWAITS ANNUAL ONSET OF RAMADAN
description: Speculation has begun about the onset of Ramadan, the holy month of Islam during which Moslems abstain from food, drink, gambling, cigarettes and sex from sunrise to sunset.

title: People
description: * Burton Vaupen was appointed executive vice president, chief financial and chief administrative officer at Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Elizabeth Brown Dubbs was named senior vice president for business affairs.

title: Paraguay Currency
description: Zhe World Bank's vice president for Latin America and the Caribbean, David Knox, urged swift Government action to raise exports and help stop the decline in monetary reserves. Mr. Knox, who arrived Thursday for a four-day stay, suggested in a Friday meeting with Finance Minister Cesar Barrientos and Commerce Minister Delfin Ugarte Centurion that Paraguay modify its rate of exchange policy.

title: Providing Prenatal Care for Bronx Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Futures/Options;   A Bonanza In June Bond Calls
description: TREASURY bond options investors who were long on faith and bought the expiring June calls before the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate late Friday are expected to reap huge rewards today.

title: ARTILLERY BATTLES RAGE IN LEBANON DESPITE SEVERAL CEASE-FIRE MOVES
description: Heavy fighting continued in Beirut today despite moves announced Saturday by the main Christian militia that were widely interpreted as a gesture of conciliation.

title: Peru Arrests 2,000 After a Bombing Wave
description: The police said today that they had arrested about 2,000 people in a search for Maoist guerrillas who mounted an urban offensive over the weekend.
