title: Limit Political Parties, Justices in Israel Urge
description: The Israeli Supreme Court called on Parliament today to enact an election law to bar parties deemed undemocratic.

title: MUSIC OUT OF ARCHIVES INTO THE AIRR
description: By day, Keith Young, a soil scientist at the Department of Agriculture, is part of the cacophony that is the Federal bureaucracy. But in his free time, he slaps his stand-up bass and, in vocal and string harmony with an engineer cuddling an autoharp, a retired Air Force major clawing a banjo, two housewives whipping dulcimers and a computer specialist picking a mandolin, makes the years roll back for audiences who fall under the musical spell of the Mill Run Dulcimer Band.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: ''I was the only new kid in the bunk.

title: THE PALLADIUM: AN ARCHITECTURALLY DRAMATIC NEW DISCOTHEQUE
description: Arata Isozaki is at once a great eminence of Japanese architecture and a source of some of its freshest thinking. And all sides of Mr. Isozaki are visible in the Palladium, the expansive new discotheque on East 14th Street that opened last week.

title: PHILADELPHIA ACTION CALLED 'LAST RESORT' AGAINST MOVE'S THREATS
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode said today that the radical group Move had threatened to destroy its neighborhood with ''gas, fire and bullets'' if the police attacked the group's barricaded house.

title: Dr. Anne R. Bass Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Anne Ruth Bass, the daughter of Mary P. Bass and Hyman Bass, both of New York, was married yesterday to Maxwell Gould, the son of Lola Dunn and Stanhope Gould, both of New York. Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony at the Faculty House of Columbia University, where the bride's father is a professor of mathematics.

title: Celebrity Tennis Tourney
description: The White House is scheduling a celebrity tennis tournament for next Saturday, right on the grounds, with all proceeds to benefit Nancy Reagan's program to combat drug abuse.

title: AN EVENING AT THE THEATER TO HELP AIDS RESEARCH
description: For Lorne Michaels, the creator and original producer of the ''Saturday Night Live'' television show, last night was ''Sunday Night Live.''

title: Thon Taken Off Roster
description: Dickie Thon, batting .207 while trying to overcome the blurred vision that resulted when he was hit by a pitch last season, was placed on the 15-day disabled list at his own request today.

title: DUARTE ADDRESSES NORTE DAME CLASS
description: Returning to the University of Notre Dame 37 years after his graduation, President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that by struggling against repression, social injustice and a Marxist-led insurgency he had done the work the university sent him out to do.

title: On the Wrong Track
description: It isn't the first time that someone shopping for an antique has been stuck with a contemporary object.

title: 3 Israelis Are Arrested In Slaying of an Arab
description: Three Israelis suspected of killing an Arab cab driver last month near Jerusalem were arrested here on Friday, a police spokesman said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Froz Fruit, from Paleta International of Brooklyn, and the Froz Fruit Corp. of Gardenia, Calif., to Drossman Lehmann Marino Reveley.

title: U.S. Advances, 1-0, In Cup Qualifying
description: The United States moved a step closer to qualifying for the 1986 World Cup soccer tournament when it defeated Trinidad and Tobago today, 1-0, on a first-half goal by Paul Caligiuri.

title: Stadium Fire Toll Rises to 53
description: The death toll at a British soccer stadium fire last week rose to 53 today. A hospital spokesman said William Stacey, 72 years old, died from burns suffered in the blaze at Bradford's main grandstand during a game last Saturday.

title: PROBLEM OF TOXIC EMISSIONS
description: In Parkersburg, W.Va., a million pounds of a Government-listed carcinogen are released into the air each year from a chemical plant owned by the Borg-Warner Corporation.

title: 5 in Row for Elliott
description: Bill Elliott continued his remarkable string of Nascar victories today by capturing the Budweiser 500 at Dover Downs Raceway.

title: LOPEZ WINS 30TH ON L.P.G.A. TOUR
description: Nancy Lopez birdied two of the last three holes after making excellent approach shots today and thus gained her first victory of the year and her 30th since she joined the Ladies Professional Golf Association in the summer of 1977.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Graig Nettles and Goose Gossage, former Yankees, make their first trip back to New York this year and meet up with Dwight Gooden, going for his seventh victory.

title: Getting Statue Right
description: If you have any worries about the authenticity of the restoration of the Statue of Liberty, prepare to shed them now. The French concern that is making a new torch for the statue, Les Mettaliers Champenoise of Bezannes-les-Reims, was stumped when it came to reproducing the railing of the small balcony just below the flame.

title: INTEREST RATE DROP EXPECTED
description: Interest rates, which have been trending downward for some months, are likely to fall even further in the wake of Friday's vote by the Federal Reserve's board of governors to lower the discount rate by half a point, to 7 1/2 percent, credit market analysts say.

title: FOR REMEMBERED G.I.'S, THUMBS UP SIGN IN CHINA
description: Four decades ago this old city in southwest China was one of the hubs of World War II, familiar to thousands of Americans who helped Chiang Kai-shek's ''Free China'' survive invasion by Japan.

title: ST. JOHN'S UNIVERSITY: CUOMO CITED AS A ROLE MODEL
description: The president of St. John's University, the Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, told 1,500 graduates yesterday that they had to believe in themselves because ''the community, the nation, the world needs what you have.''

title: RACING OFFERS 3-SIDED PUZZLE
description: Seven months ago in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile, Chief's Crown, Tank's Prospect and Spend a Buck crossed the wire in that order. Fifteen days ago in the Kentucky Derby, Spend a Buck was a runaway winner, with Chief's Crown third and Tank's Prospect seventh. Saturday, in the Preakness Stakes, Tank's Prospect beat Chief's Crown by a head and Spend a Buck stayed home.

title: TUTU URGES UNITY IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Churchmen in South Africa, including Bishop Desmond Tutu, led tens of thousands of worshipers in hymns and prayers for black political unity today after clashes between rival organizations opposed to white minority rule.

title: TO BLACKS, THE SUBURBS PROVE BOTH PLEASANT AND TROUBLING
description: In significant and increasing numbers, blacks have been moving from the older central cities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to the suburban areas.

title: GETTING AN EARFUL FROM SOVIET RADIO TELEPHONES
description: About 25 years ago, the United States began eavesdropping on top officials of the Soviet Union in Moscow as they chatted with each other on their car telephones.

title: BROADWAY ECONOMIC SEASON IS CALLED WORST IN A DECADE
description: Despite the production of several acclaimed dramas, Broadway is concluding its worst economic season in a decade, as indicated by both statistics and emotional reaction in the industry. What remains uncertain, and hotly debated in theater circles, is whether the slump is part of Broadway's cyclical nature or the harbinger of a long-term decline.

title: Clergyman's Death Laid To Legionnaires' Disease
description: A Detroit clergyman has died after contracting Legionnaires' disease and health officials are awaiting the results of blood tests on 30 suspected victims, all of whom attended a banquet at a hotel.

title: Negro Ensemble Honored
description: The Negro Ensemble Company will receive the third annual Edwin Booth Award for its efforts in producing and promoting black theater. Douglas Turner Ward, founder of the company, will accept the award at a ceremony at 5 P.M. today at the City University Graduate School Ph.D. Program in Theater, 33 West 42d Street.

title: Caren Schorr Wed to Andrew Glickson
description: At Temple Shalom in Norwalk, Conn., yesterday Caren Elayne Schorr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Schorr of Bayside, Queens, was married to Andrew Asher Glickson, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Justin Glickson of Norwalk. Rabbi Jacob Lantz, assisted by Cantor Mark Lipson, performed the ceremony.

title: SMALL AND MEDIUM HOPES
description: The anniversary of victory in Europe has come and gone and there is still a certain tension in the East.

title: Hail the Managers
description: Some of the most experienced players in major league baseball were asked to identify the managers they admire most, excluding their current ones, and to tell why. Their responses:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many times has a member of the losing team been voted the most valuable player in the National Basketball Association playoffs? Has anyone earned the honor more than once?

title: GOVERNOR OF ILLNOIS GETS A DOUBLE TEST OF HIS POLITICAL METTLE
description: Earlier this month Gov. James R. Thompson dominated the airwaves for three days as he conducted a widely publicized clemency hearing for a convicted rapist and generally received good reviews.

title: When E. F. Hutton Cheats . . .
description: E. F. Hutton's confession to an elaborate fraud against hundreds of banks was a triumph for Federal investigators but raises vexing questions. Is the crime, a form of check-kiting, really all that serious; don't a lot of people do the same thing all the time? Second, if the offense is serious, why isn't the Government trying to put anyone in jail?

title: STATE UNIVERSITY AT STONY BROOK: FRIEDAN CRITICIZES PRESIDENT
description: In her commencement address at the State University of New York at Stony Brook today, Betty Friedan, the author and advocate for women's rights, accused the Reagan Administration of regressing from the gains made in democracy over the last 20 years.

title: PHILADELPHIA PRAYS FOR FIRE VICTIMS, AND FOR ITSELF
description: Just before 11 A.M., a single bell began tolling in the tower of St. Carthage Roman Catholic Church, which has been sheltering refugees from the devastation of Osage Avenue and Pine Street, three blocks away.

title: HOWE ANCHORS DEFENSE
description: MIKE ROGERS was there. Blaine Stoughton, too. But Mark Howe can't remember everyone in that photograph now, some five years later. They were playing for the Hartford Whalers then, all in their mid-to-late 20's, and all were impressed to see and touch the Stanley Cup. It was a promotional tour, Howe remembers, the National Hockey League's way of showing the fans in Hartford what the cup looked like, how the names like Beliveau and Richard are repeatedly etched in silver, how its patina glimmers in even the dimmest light.

title: '85-'86 Concert Series At the 92d Street Y
description: The 92d Street Y's new music season, which opens on Oct. 9, will offer more than 70 concerts, including two new music appreciation series -''Musically Speaking,'' for adults, and ''Family Concerts,'' for children.

title: RETIREES' FLORIDA DREAMS TURNED TO ASHES
description: John Schander kicked at the ashes at his feet, before him the charred shell of his retirement home. His broad shoulders shook, and he brought his hands up to his mouth and sobbed openly and bitterly.

title: Nuptials for Ellen Marks And Stephen M. Raphael
description: The marriage of Ellen Marks, a partner in the New York law firm of Raphael Marks & Goldman, to Stephen M. Raphael, the senior partner in the firm, took place yesterday at Windows on the World. Judge George H. Jurow of the Family Court performed the ceremony.

title: KURRI: A QUIET WEAPON
description: THE Edmonton Oilers were milling around in one of the hockey episodes in which grown men attempt to squeeze into the smallest possible space. The Oilers and the Chicago Black Hawks were not fighting, but they were not friendly either. Some of them were grabbing, and some were raising their sticks, and most of them were just doing a lot of loud and angry talking.

title: 76ERS TRIM DEFICIT AS BARKLEY STARS
description: Julius Erving called it ''a day for young legs.''

title: EGYPT BANS COPIES OF '1,001 NIGHTS'
description: An Egyptian judge approved the confiscation today of 3,000 copies of an unexpurgated edition of ''A Thousand and One Nights,'' on the ground that the centuries-old Arabic classic contained obscene passages that posed a threat to the country's moral fabric.

title: CHINESE RIOT AFTER SOCCER DEFEAT
description: Thousands of Chinese soccer fans went on a rampage outside a Peking stadium tonight after China lost a match to Hong Kong.

title: TWINS ROUT BLUE JAYS
description: Pete Filson supplied three-hit relief over seven and two-thirds innings and Tom Brunansky and Tim Teufel hit bases-empty homers today, leading the Minnesota Twins to an 8-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: INTERGROUP STUDIES SALE
description: National Intergroup Inc., coming under pressure from its largest shareholder to increase the company's value, said yesterday that it had directed its investment bank to help it consider the sale of some of its assets.

title: OF PRIVACY, PURCHASES AND PESTS
description: The way Hal Brockman sees it, the situation might be the basis for a science fiction monster movie. You could call it ''The Invasion of the Mudbugs.''

title: HIGH SCHOOL SELECTION CRITICIZED
description: The system by which New York City students select public high schools to attend is confusing, secretive and inefficient, according to a study by a civic group.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have concluded that New York State should adopt a comprehensive and responsible strategy to demonstrate the abhorrence of our residents to the pernicious system of apartheid.'' - Governor Cuomo. [A1:4.]

title: ISRAELI ENGINEER SAYS HE GOT SWITCHES USED IN ATOM ARMS
description: An electronics engineer at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem said tonight that he bought krytron switches from an American manufacturer for the school's Physics Department in 1976.

title: Ecuador Oil Quota
description: Ecuador, under pressure from other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to stick to its petroleum quota, said Friday that it would be economic suicide to cut back on production levels. Fernando Santos Alvite, Deputy Minister for Natural Resources, told reporters that Ecuador's adherence to the 183,000-barrel-a-day production quota set last October by OPEC would mean a loss of $1.2 billion a year. According to official figures, Ecuador produced 276,545 barrels a day in March.

title: OUTDOORS: EARLY RETURN OF SUCCULENT WEAKFISH
description: THE first weakfish of the year have already been caught in Long Island's Peconic Bay system, and George Cottral of the Port of Egypt Bait Station in Southold is pleased that they have shown up in all sizes, from 1-pound specimens to so-called ''tide runners'' of more than 15 pounds. The presence of various year classes bodes well, he feels, for more of the fish in the years ahead.

title: BRIDGE: BERGEN TEAM IN COMEBACK IN THE INTERNATIONAL PLAYOFF
description: The International Team final playoff continued here this afternoon and evening with a six-man team headed by Marty Bergen of White Plains leading by 21 international match points. There was one 16-deal session remaining to be played.

title: C.I.A. Chief Said to Urge Manila to Move Up Vote
description: Newsweek reports in its current issue that William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has told President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines that the White House wants Manila to hold an election before Mr. Marcos's term expires in 1987.

title: Market Place;   Index Option Trading Begins
description: WITH a touch of pardonable pride, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange started trading Friday in the first index option geared to the over-the-counter market. ''We're not unhappy about being the first out of the box with this new product,'' said Robert Gilmore, a senior vice president of the exchange.

title: Article 252610 -- No Title
description: The New York metropolitan region would lose $2 billion in public and private investment for development projects and 25,000 jobs in the next three years if the Reagan Administration is successful in ending a program of grants for depressed areas, a civic group warned yesterday.

title: Computerized Signs In Grand Central
description: A glance yesterday at the giant train board in Grand Central Terminal was puzzling. For example, it showed that the ''-:31'' from Tarrytown, due to arrive on both upper level track ''AA'' and lower level track ''AAA,'' had been canceled.

title: How to Teach Africa's Starving a Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Lord Is Married
description: Mary Grace Lord, a political cartoonist for Newsday, and Glenn Horowitz, a rare book and manuscript dealer, were married yesterday. Judge Sara Schechter of Manhattan Family Court officiated at the home of Carter and Susan Burden. The bride, a graduate of Yale University, is the daughter of Charles Carroll Lord of Long Beach, Calif., and the late Mary Pfister Lord. Mr. Horowitz, a graduate of Bennington College, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Horowitz of New York.

title: JAZZ: TRIBUTE TO MEL LEWIS
description: MORE than a dozen musicians who have played in the bands led by the drummer Mel Lewis, which is now in its 20th year of Monday night performances at the Village Vanguard, played in a tribute to Mr. Lewis at a ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert at the N.Y.U. Loeb auditorium on Friday evening.

title: A Fresh Look at Getting Older
description: New York's Governor Mario Cuomo has formed a Task Force on Aging to explore a subject that many Americans haven't much thought about. That's because, until recently, few Americans lived long enough to be called ''elderly.''

title: Nina Mostoff Is Bride Of Richard S. Binstein
description: Nina Valerie Mostoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan S. Mostoff of Falls Church, Va., and Richard Steven Binstein, a son of Mark P. Binstein of Oradell, N.J., and Vivian Goldsmith of Englewood, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Harold S. White performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Washington.

title: L.I.U. AT SOUTHHAMPTON: WALTERS CALLS WAR UNLIKELY
description: The new United States Representative at the United Nations, Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, told graduating students at the Southampton campus of Long Island University today that ''the world has grown too wise to embark on something as risky'' as war.

title: SRI LANKA BUYS ARMS TO FIGHT REBELS
description: The Sri Lanka Government, faced with increasingly violent, mobile and well-armed guerrilla groups, is turning to Israel, China and Pakistan for new weapons, supplies and expertise to meet the threat, officials here say.

title: Addendum
description: Ms. magazine will raise its advertising rates 8 percent with its August issue.

title: Linkup of Allied Joske's Stores Seen
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, is expected this week to announce the consolidation of its three Joske's department store groups in Texas.

title: Article 251847 -- No Title
description: The Treasury Department is scheduled to sell $23 billion worth of bills and notes today and on Wednesday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FLIP OF A COIN The ominous headlines about bank problems have absolutely nothing to do with the exhibition of coin banks, those mechanical coffers that seduce children to save at home, now on view at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street (621-0636). As a matter of fact, the 64 cunning contrivances belong to the Goldome Bank's Collection of Cast-Iron Mechanical Banks.

title: The Bums' Rush
description: After 15 home games, the Detroit Tigers are ahead of the pace that drew 2.7 million fans in 1984, the second-best total in American League history. The average is 27,079, and it's all the more impressive if you believe that attendance has been negatively affected by an edict from Jim Campbell, the team president, to close the 11,200 center-field bleacher seats at 52,806-seat Tiger Stadium.

title: WOMEN IN STATE JOBS GAIN IN PAY EQUITY
description: Under a contract ratified last week by New York State's largest union, more than 50,000 women who work for the state are to receive millions of dollars in special pay increases sometime after next April to help raise their salaries to those of men in jobs of comparable worth.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 20, 1985 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WALKER EXCELS, BUT GENERALS FALL, 28-24
description: The Generals and the Denver Gold went up and down the field trading 80-yard touchdown drives in the second half today. But when their last turn came, the Generals faltered and lost, 28-24.

title: Topics;   Some Things Change Friendly French
description: For years, Americans returning from France have told of curt or rude responses to imperfect French.

title: APOLLO AMATEUR NIGHT RETURNING THIS WEEK
description: There was no showcase like it for the black talent that ''they never heard of south of 59th Street,'' said the man who began the Wednesday amateur night contests at Harlem's Apollo Theater half a century ago. Ralph Cooper ticked off a few of the unknowns who subsequently rocketed to international fame from the Apollo talent shows: Sarah Vaughan, Ella Fitzgerald, James Brown, Leslie Uggams, the Jackson Five, Frankie Lyman and the Teenagers.

title: REAGAN'S BREZHNEV DOCTRINE
description: If Ronald Reagan were a paid agent of the Soviets, he couldn't do any better for them than he is doing in Central America. He has managed to blur the distinction between the foreign policy goals of the United States in the Americas and those of the Soviet Union everywhere else. This is an achievement for which Leonid I. Brezhnev's successors should be truly grateful.

title: Irish vs. Jews
description: The way Dan Doyle sees it, one good ethnic idea deserves another. And as busy as he is arranging the first Shamrock Games, designed to draw Irish athletes from round the world to Ireland this summer, Doyle is already planning his next venture into ethic athletics: an Irish-Jewish championship series for 1986.

title: Syracuse in Final
description: Emmett Printup scored at 1 minute 20 seconds of overtime to give Syracuse a 14-13 victory over North Carolina today in the semifinals of the Division I lacrosse tournament. The Orangemen (14-1) will meet Johns Hopkins for the title Saturday in Providence, R.I. Hopkins advanced by defeating Virginia, 11-8, in the other semifinal at Baltimore.

title: Oil Lotteries Repayment
description: A Florida ''filing service'' company, accused of luring investors into the Government's oil lotteries by exaggerating their chances of winning valuable oil and gas leases, has agreed to repay them $700,000.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Answer From Above
description: The hard business of the soft-drink industry was the topic of conversation.

title: Officers for 1991 Named In Allied-Signal Merger
description: Michael D. Dingman, currently president of Signal Companies Inc., is slated to become chief executive officer in 1991 of the corporation to be formed by the merger of Signal and the Allied Corporation. Mr. Dingman believes that such advance planning, publicly disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, is basic to the success of the transaction.

title: Ellen Tumposky Wed
description: Ellen Tumposky and John Sims, both editors at The Daily News, were married in their New York home yesterday by Rabbi Joel Goor.

title: SAILING IS KOLIUS'S OBSESSION
description: John Kolius answered the telephone: ''America II Challenge . . .''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, MAY 20, 1985

title: O'CONNOR SAYS AID FROM CITY IS NOT ESSENTIAL
description: Archbishop John J. O'Connor said yesterday that the Archdiocese of New York was prepared to operate social programs without any government money if the state's highest court upheld Mayor Koch's authority to bar job discrimination against homosexuals in all programs covered by city contracts.

title: 'I CAN'T USE IT AS AN EXCUSE'
description: THE right index finger is swollen to double the size at the first knuckle, and it does not bend. Those who are familiar with Larry Bird's medical history say the finger has been somewhat disfigured since a college softball game many years ago, but sometime on Saturday afternoon the finger was sprained again.

title: LAKERS TAKE 3-1 SERIES LEAD
description: The ball was bouncing above the basket like a beach ball being passed above a crowd. Hanging in the balance was a victory in the fourth game of what has become a bruising Western Conference championship playoff series between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Denver Nuggets, two teams that have built their reputations on finesse, not by flexing their muscles.

title: Modest Hope for Soviet Trade Talks
description: The United States Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, opens two days of talks with senior Soviet trade officials Monday, in the first such top-level trade encounter in seven years.

title: PRANGING ON TAKEOFF
description: The conservative movement called Thatcherism is about two years ahead of the conservative movement called Reaganism. In the late 70's, that waving of the future from the mother country had American right-wing hard-liners all rubbing their hands in anticipatory glee; now it should have us cracking our knuckles in worriment. The latest Gallup Poll shows the Conservatives here running third, behind the Labor Party and the loose grouping of center parties. With Mrs. Thatcher needing all the support she can get from Conservatives, a small internal revolt is under way: The Conservative moderates, called ''the wets'' by stalwarts scornful of their tearful sentimentality, have formed a splinter group to bang their spoons on Mrs. Thatcher's highchair, demanding she take the spending route to pump up the sagging economy.

title: Advertising;   Four A's To Honor Clients
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 18 - When it closed down its 67th annual meeting here today, the American Association of Advertising Agencies announced an advertising award program. Well, sort of.

title: UNOCAL BUYBACK RULING IS LIMITED, LAWYERS FEEL
description: Law experts said yesterday that a Delaware Supreme Court ruling on Friday, which allows the Unocal Corporation to exclude a group of investors led by T. Boone Pickens from a Unocal stock buyback offer, is not so sweeping as it might seem.

title: ISRAELI CABINET APPROVES STEPS TO HELP ECONOMY
description: The Israeli Cabinet met for 12 hours today to discuss the country's deteriorating economy and agreed on 20 measures, including a $300 tax on foreign travel and restrictions on trips abroad by Cabinet members.

title: Border Was Quiet When Israel Invaded Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: A PLAN TO MAKE CYCLING SAFER
description: It was early on a weekday morning in mid-April and Terri Miller, a 26-year-old all-American swimmer, was training for a triathlon, riding her bicycle on the outskirts of Tallahassee, Fla. She was pedaling along U.S. 90, a four-lane highway that - like most roads in Florida - has no shoulders, so she was competing with cars for space.

title: PAVIN FIRES 266 TO WIN COLONIAL
description: Corey Pavin, who led or shared the lead all the way, shot a solid, two-under-par 68 today for a four-shot victory in the Colonial National Invitation tournament.

title: Nicklaus Watches Son Take Title
description: Jack Nicklaus 2d captured the North and South Amateur golf championship today with a 2-and-1 victory over Tom McKnight of Galax, Va., as his father, a past winner of the tournament, watched from the gallery.

title: Deborah Longley, Physician, Is Wed
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Dr. Deborah Gay Longley, a daughter of Maryellen Turnbull Longley of Darien and the late F. Alan Longley of Manlius, N.Y., was married to Dr. Kirkham B. Wood, a son of John Gibbon Wood of Portola Valley, Calif., and the late Sara McManus Wood. The Rev. Kevin Bean performed the ceremony.

title: ARGENTINA FACES NEW FINANCIAL TEST
description: A high-level Government official sat in his office last Friday and painted a convincing scenario in which Argentina would once again recover from a financial crisis.

title: YANKS BEATEN
description: The Yankees, who had won six games in a row playing the kind of baseball that has become Billy Martin's trademark, had little to offer today in support of Ed Whitson, their struggling right-hander.

title: A WHITE HOUSE MUSICAL GETS TRYOUT AT NO. 1600
description: A young woman is told by her father that she cannot smoke in the house and so she goes up on the roof to have her cigarette. The roof is on the White House, the father is President Theodore Roosevelt and the young woman is his daughter Alice, who charmed Washington for 50 years.

title: Y.M.C.A. Runner Wins Marathon
description: Placido Cruz-Martin of the West Side Y.M.C.A. won the 49th annual Yonkers Marathon this morning in 2 hours 35 minutes 4 seconds. The 33-year-old runner won $500 for his victory as cash prizes were awarded for the first time. Eileen Brennan of Yonkers, second last year, took the women's title in 3:08.46 and won $500.

title: WESTWAY-GIANT BOONDOGGLE
description: Thanks to the fancy footwork of the developers of Westway and the proponents of the proposed 4.2 mile highway on the West Side of Manhattan, what normally would be a local transportation issue has mushroomed into a national controversy. The highway is just the surface of what promises to be, if allowed to proceed, a multibillion dollar boondoggle.

title: Topics;   Some Things Change Early Education
description: New parents cherish the day their toddler climbs quietly out of bed alone on a weekend morning and turns on the television cartoons. That means more sleep for mom and dad.

title: NOAH, IN FOUR SETS, WINS ITALIAN FINAL
description: Yannick Noah of France used a strong serve to defeat Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2, 7-6, today in the final of the $350,000 Italian Open tennis championships.

title: EX-PRINCIPAL DANCER WITH BALLET THEATER
description: Toni Lander, a Danish ballerina who became internationally known as a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater and London Festival Ballet, died of cancer yesterday in Salt Lake City. She was 53 years old.

title: BUFFALO CONCERN GIVES POP SOUND TO PLAYER PIANOS
description: With razor blades and Scotch tape, 88 black and white keys and a new computer, Rudy Martin makes music - a music that tickles the ivories and sets toes wagging and fingers snapping.

title: RETURN OF CUBA FROM U.S. IS 'GOING WELL'
description: A number of Cuban refugees who have been returned here from the United States because of histories of criminal offenses or mental illness are ''back at home and living completely normal lives,'' according to a senior Cuban official.

title: Hungry Africa's Dangerous Year
description: Rains now soaking southern and eastern Africa promise some relief from the three-year drought, the worst in a century. But better weather won't help farmers who've consumed their seed and cattle. It won't fertilize exhausted soil, or atone for policies that foolishly drove farmers off the land. Perversely, better weather may yield just enough food to relax the world's concern.

title: Washington Watch;   Private Deposit Insurance Bills
description: DURING the Ohio thrift crisis earlier this year, talk about doing away with private deposit insurance was measured and careful. But after Ohio's troubles subsided, regulators began to speak out. Now, in the wake of thrift troubles in Maryland, there appears to be almost a unanimity of opinion that private insurance does not work and that something should be done either to legislate it out of existence or greatly limit its uses.

title: FLYERS AND OILERS IN SHARP CONTRAST
description: The Flyers, like magicians, revel in making the ice disappear. They virtually take it away from their opponent, forecheck in their offensive end, cut down the passing lanes through the neutral zone, and barricade, if necessary, at the blue line.

title: JERSEYAN TAKES TRAVIS MATCH PLAY
description: Jim Kilduff has applied for membership to the Plainfield Country Club, and the New Jersey club will be considering his application on Tuesday. Today the 27-year-old insurance broker added substantially to his credentials when he won the 75th Walter J. Travis Invitation here at the Garden City Golf Club.

title: Nuclear Plant Reopens After 24-Hour Shutdown
description: Technicians at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant Sunday restarted the Unit 1 reactor, 24 hours after a malfunctioning transformer sparked an automatic shutdown.

title: UNITED SEEKS TO REPLACE STRIKERS AS SUPERVISORS PILOT SOME FLIGHTS
description: United Airlines, which normally flies 1,550 flights a day, flew only about 200 yesterday as a strike by its 5,300 pilots entered its third day.

title: Alison Andrews Smith Wed to A. R. Anrather
description: The marriage of Alison Andrews Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Kellum Smith Jr. of New York and Chatham, Mass., to Andrea Riccardo Anrather, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Luigi Maria Anrather of Verona, Italy, took place yesterday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Allison G. Stokes, a United Church of Christ minister and Vassar College chaplain, performed the ceremony at the College Chapel.

title: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT: CLASS IS WARNED ON INSULARITY
description: In his final speech as president of the University of Connecticut, Dr. John A. DiBiaggio told graduating seniors today that New England residents ''far too often seem too willing to settle for something less than which they are capable.''

title: ISRAEL IS EXPECTED TO SET 1,000 FREE IN EXCHANGE FOR 3
description: Israel is expected to free more than 1,000 Palestinians and other prisoners on Monday in return for three Israeli soldiers captured during the Lebanon conflict, according to diplomatic sources here and in the Middle East.

title: Lauren Greenblatt a Bride
description: Lauren Beth Greenblatt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Greenblatt of New York and Manhasset Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Elliot Klein, the son of Helen Klein of Rochester and the late Albert Klein. Cantor Ephraim Steinhauer performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, L.I. The bride and bridegroom are associates at the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.

title: REMEMBERING JESS OWENS'S OTHER BID DAY
description: BY the nature of the sport, records in track and field come and go, victims of the continuing progress of athletes and the improved conditions in which they compete. But one record that has withstood the test of time is Jesse Owens's record for setting records, and it will be 50 years old this week.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: LTV Picks Chiefs Of New Steel Units
description: The LTV Corporation has tapped three executives with a total of 78 years of experience in the steel industry - Paul N. Wigton, Russell W. Maier and Claude F. Kronk - to head the new operating companies being formed from its LTV Steel unit.

title: Russian Ambivalence And Austria's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY VIETNAMESE IN LIMBO BECAUSE OF PAST
description: A decade ago she was a multilingual lawyer qualified to practice on three continents. Now she sells embroidered blouses to Soviet-bloc tourists in a souvenir shop.

title: GOMEZ CAPTURES TITLE
description: Wilfredo Gomez of Puerto Rico came on strong in the final four rounds today to gain a split decision over the defending champion, Rocky Lockridge, and capture the World Boxing Association junior lightweight title.

title: U.S. Station to Begin Broadcasting to Cuba
description: Radio Marti, the Reagan Administration's project to broadcast news to Cuba, will go on the air Monday, according to Florida's two Senators.

title: JOHN PAUL, IN BELGIUM, URGES 'NOBLE WAR' FOR SOCIAL JUSTICE
description: Pope John Paul II today condemned ''racism and xenophobia'' and issued strong pleas for social justice, warning against ''a national and international economy which is only concerned with profit.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MAY 20, 1985

title: Topics;   Some Things Change Present Value
description: How much is being Vice President of the United States worth? John Nance Garner, who held the job under President Franklin Roosevelt, said something to the effect that the job ''isn't worth a pitcher of warm spit.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CIDER HOUSE RULES. By John Irving. 560 pages. Morrow. $18.95. THE rules referred to in the title of John Irving's new novel are the rules that are posted by the light switch in the cider house of Ocean View apple orchard on the coast of Maine where about half the action of Mr. Irving's story is set. ''Please don't operate the grinder or the press if you've been drinking,'' one of them typically reads.

title: New Faces at Labor
description: Taking control of an agency means having your own people in top positions. Many are wondering how soon Bill Brock, the new Secretary of the troubled Labor Department, will name all his top players.

title: Venezuela Debt Pact Reached
description: Venezuela and a committee of its creditor banks agreed Friday on the final terms of a rescheduling accord to stretch out payments on most of its $35 billion foreign debt.

title: MUSIC: AT CARNEGIE, DOHNANYI AND THE CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: SATURDAY evening at Carnegie Hall with Christoph von Dohnanyi and the Cleveland Orchestra was both satisying and instructive. Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony showed, for example, how the submission of performing ego in the service of style can make the most familiar piece sound fresh and strong. Schoenberg's Six Songs with Orchestra (Op. 8), on the other hand, left us a little wiser, perhaps, about the mystery of Schoenberg's legacy and why its inheritors value it as little as they seem to.

title: Democratic Identity (Cont.)
description: Evidence continues to mount that active elements of the Democratic Party are groping for a new identity. On Capitol Hill, a group of staff members for Democratic Senators and Representatives have organized the New Democratic Forum to discuss issues and new approaches periodically with some of their bosses and journalists over breakfast.

title: RALLIES BECOME A FACT OF CAPITOL LIFE, BUT EFFECT ON LEGISLATORS IS ARGUABLE
description: They brandish signs, march on the Capitol, mob legislators' offices. And then they are gone - taken back home by the chartered buses that brought them here only hours before.

title: BALLET: 'BACK PARTITA' AT MET
description: THERE are moments when Twyla Tharp's ''Bach Partita'' looks like the classical ballet version of rubbing stomachs while patting heads. And it's danced to music for unaccompanied violin - hardly the most accessible of dances or scores. But several new dancers brought new color to the ballet when they took over roles in a performance of the piece by the American Ballet Theater on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: BALLET: STUDENT SHOWCASE
description: UNLIKE most of its recent annual performances, the School of American Ballet's ''workshops'' on Saturday presented no new works. Instead, the 300th anniversaries of both Johann Sebastian Bach and Domenico Scarlatti were cited as cause for celebration in a bill that included ''Concerto Barocco,'' the great Bach ballet Balanchine composed in 1941, and ''Sonate di Scarlatti,'' which Peter Martins created in 1979.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 20, 1985: *2*MONDAY Century Tel Entprise Sears Roebuck & Co Connecticut Nat Gas Utah Pwr & Lt San Diego Gas Elec *2*TUESDAY Amstrong Rubber Halliburton Company Briggs & Stratton Hayes-Albion Corp Certain-teed Corp Natl Presto Industries Coleman Co Ohio Edison Co Duquesne Light Public Serv El & Gas Federal-Mogul Corp Savannah Elec & Pwr Gannett Co Webb (Del E) Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Bowater Inc Marion Laboratories E G & G Inc Northern States Pwr First Virginia Banks Pennsylvania Pwr & Lt Johnson Controls Reading & Bates Corp Key Banks *2*THURSDAY Beneficial Corp Ex-Cell-O Corp Burroughs Corp Loctite Corp Combustion Eng'nring Mass Merchandisers Emhart Corp Russ Togs *2*FRIDAY Albertson's Inc Kansas City So Indus Bairnco Corp Lowe's Companies General Electric South Jersey Industries Harris Corp (Del) Waste Management

title: RUTHERFORD RETURNS TO INDY LINEUP
description: Johnny Rutherford, the three-time winner, led four drivers who bumped their way into the 69th Indianapolis 500 today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Borg-Warner Corp., Chicago, has appointed Richard Curran to the new position of chairman and chief executive officer of Borg-Warner Automotive Inc.

title: Paying Up at the I.M.F.
description: Even as the United States was severing trade links with Nicaragua, or maybe because of it, the Sandinista regime was quietly paying up arrears, totaling about $20 million, to the 148-nation International Monetary Fund.

title: STAGE: 'THE COUNT OF MONTE CRISTO,' AT THE KENNEDY CENTER
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 -

title: OIL AND GAS TAX BREAKS MAY STAY
description: Although it will probably be another day or two before the Administration makes its final major tax-overhaul decision, heavy lobbying by oil and gas interests appears to have been largely successful in fending off threats to crucial tax breaks.

title: New Coalition Backs Bellamy's Candidacy
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy last night won the endorsement of the New Democratic Coalition in her campaign for mayor.

title: OLD COURT: FAST GROWTH, BUT HIGH RISK-TAKING
description: In many respects, Jeffrey A. Levitt - the guiding force behind the Old Court Savings and Loan Association, whose problems triggered the Maryland thrift crisis - represents the new breed of executive that has filtered into the nation's thrift institutions over the past few years in the era of industry deregulation.

title: WIDE OLIVETTI NET ADDS A TOSHIBA TIE
description: An accord announced last week between Olivetti, the leading European office automation group, and Toshiba, one of Japan's largest electrical and electronic companies, has sparked speculation of an emerging arrangement that some experts say could produce a powerful new alliance in world electronics.

title: Pretoria Catches Up
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: TCHERKASSKY APPEARS IN BALLET THEATER'S 'SYLPHIDE'
description: ALL sylphs may be airy, but not all sylphs are alike. That was demonstrated by recent cast changes in American Ballet Theater's production of ''La Sylphide'' at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: RECITAL: SERGIU SCHWARTZ, VIOLINIST, PERFORMS
description: SERGIU SCHWARTZ, a young violinist from Israel, gave a Merkin Hall recital Saturday evening that was enjoyable as far as it went, but did not go far enough. His technique is sure, and he inclines rather more to sweetness of tone than many of his peers.

title: AS BLAZE SPREADS, FLORIDIANS HOPE FOR HEAVY RAINS
description: Florida officials said today that only a drenching rain could end a threat to populated coastal areas as fires continued on thousands of acres of scrub forests and grasslands.

title: MILITARY RECEIVED $18 BILLION EXTRA, ASPIN CALCULATES
description: Because the Reagan Administration overestimated inflation, Congress appropriated $18 billion to $50 billion more than needed for Defense Department programs in the last four years, according to Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: NEW WAY TO INVEST IN CHINA'S GROWTH
description: A French brokerage house and a British investment bank have come up with a new way for Western investors to share in the planned development of China, the world's biggest single market with almost one billion consumers.

title: AS MISSING-CHILDREN CAMPAIGN GROWS, SORROW OF THE PATZ FAILY LINGERS
description: Julie Patz knows there are mothers -good, concerned women - who cannot look at milk cartons that bear the faces of missing children, who avert their eyes rather than acknowledge that such a thing could happen to them.

title: REFORM JEWS SEEKING CLOSER TIES TO CATHOLICS
description: The leadership of the nation's 780 Reform Jewish congregations voted yesterday to reach out to Roman Catholics on the local level in an effort to foster better understanding between Catholics and Jews.

title: 27 Street Gang Members Are Arrested in 5 Raids
description: Twenty-seven members of the most organized street gang in the city, including a suspect in a triple homicide, were arrested Saturday in a series of raids, the authorities said.

title: Ueberroth Responds to Poll
description: The baseball Commissioner, Peter Ueberroth, said he was ''not amused'' by recent suggestions that he run for the Republican nomination for Senator from California. A survey released by the California Poll last week showed that Mr. Ueberroth, who was the chief organizer of the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, was preferred by voters among a dozen potential candidates for the Republican nomination.

title: THE THEATER: 'ROMMEL'S GARDEN'
description: ON a mission in the North African desert during World War II, an American private accidentally steps on an antipersonnel mine planted by Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's troops. If he removes his foot, we are told, the mine will explode and kill him and his companion, a tough-talking sergeant. Therefore, he stands still, and then, gingerly but unconvincingly, allows the sergeant to take his place on the firing line.

title: AT CANNES, A NEW BREED OF MOGUL
description: It is 7:30 A.M. and six film salesmen from Producers Sales Organization are sitting in a row like children lined up for a piano recital.

title: COPYWRITER FREE TO USE HUMOR SINCE CHEESE ADS
description: SOLEMNITY is not a quality normally associated with the advertising business, but for years Joy Golden felt that her comedic talents were stifled by demands to be serious about lipstick and mascara. So last year, when TBWA Advertising asked the copywriter to ''do comedy'' for one of its accounts - Laughing Cow cheese from France - she leapt at the chance. ''I saw the intrinsic madness of someone going into a store and asking for a little round laughing cow in a red net bag,'' she said.

title: Princeton Wins
description: Princeton's women's crew won the varsity eight's final of the seventh annual Eastern Association of Women's Rowing College's championship regatta on Lake Waramaug today.

title: Abdi Leads Mason
description: Abdi Bile Abdi, a 21-year-old former soccer player from Somalia, led George Mason University to its second team title in three years today in the 109th outdoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.

title: TEEN-AGE DRINKING EXAMINED
description: TOMORROW night's ''One Too Many,'' on ABC at 8, was originally produced as an Afterschool Special, one of those periodic hourlong afternoon specials the network schedules for younger audiences. But Squire Rushnell, vice president of children's television, says ABC decided ''the program should be seen by the entire family and by the largest possible audience.'' The switch to prime time is more than justified.

title: Church Sued Over a Suicide Says It Will Change Training
description: A Protestant church that was sued for clergy malpractice because a young member committed suicide says it will reform its counselor training programs, even though the lawsuit was thrown out of court, the pastor, the Rev. John MacArthur, said Friday.

title: POLLSTERS CITE SURVEYS INDICATING CONFIDENCE IN THEIR WORK
description: Two of the nation's leading polltakers say their surveys show that the public is pretty well satisfied with the accuracy and usefulness of public opinion polls. But as they discussed their findings with their colleagues, they sounded as if they did not trust their own results.

title: Robert Stern, Film Maker, Weds Nancy Fran Brodie
description: Nancy Fran Brodie, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Brodie of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Felix Stern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf Stern of New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Water Club.

title: Nancy Petschek Wed To Stephen Eric Kohn
description: The marriage of Nancy Helene Petschek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Petschek of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Stephen Eric Kohn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Kohn of Roslyn, L.I., took place yesterday at the Jewish Community Center of White Plains. Rabbis Maurice Davis and Lee Friedlander officiated.

title: Police Mental Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Common Market Leader Attacks U.S. and Reagan
description: The European Economic Community Commissioner, Claude Cheysson, accused the United States today of developing imperialist attitudes and President Reagan of being tactless in relations with Western allies.

title: Scientology Church Protest Draws Hundreds to Oregon
description: Hundreds of members of the Church of Scientology converged in Portland on Sunday to protest a $39 million fraud judgment against the church..

title: A Hunger for Culture, But Little Tasting
description: SoHo was alive with crowds drawn to sun-filled streets and an aura of art and glamour. One young man decided to take in an exhibit of new paintings by Arakawa but could not find the Feldman gallery amid the lively springtime activity.

title: PADRES HAWKINS WINS 8TH
description: Andy Hawkins pitched seven innings to raise his record to 8-0 while Terry Kennedy and Graig Nettles cracked four hits apiece during a 17-hit attack today that carried the San Diego Padres over the Montreal Expos, 8-3.

title: Enough Talk of U.S.-Japanese Trade Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL CARE PLANS CREATED IN THE 60'S KEEP WIDE SUPPORT
description: Of all the Great Society programs enacted two decades ago, Medicare and Medicaid, which provide health benefits to the elderly and the poor, probably retain the strongest bipartisan support.

title: Dial Vaults 19-2 1/2
description: Joe Dial, who last weekend broke the American pole-vault record, broke it again today when he cleared 19 feet 2 1/2 inches during the Oklahoma Invitational track meet.

title: GOLF HALL TRIPS LOPEZ
description: AS she strode off the 18th green after winning the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic yesterday, Nancy Lopez deserved to walk into the L.P.G.A. Hall of Fame - but she was tripped by two fuddy-duddy rules.

title: Bloomingdale's Opens Catalogue to Outsiders
description: For the first time, Bloomingdale's will open its national catalogue pages to outside advertisers.

title: British Polaris Missile Malfunctions in Test
description: A British Polaris nuclear missile malfunctioned during a routine test flight after it was fired from a submarine off Cape Canaveral today, the Defense Ministry said.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES STATE SELL STOCK IN CONCERNS TIED TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: New York State should eliminate billions of dollars of investments in companies that do business in South Africa and should sharply limit all dealings with such concerns, Governor Cuomo said today.

title: 'The Cider House Rules'
description: The rules referred to in the title of John Irving's new novel are the rules that are posted by the light switch in the cider house of Ocean View apple orchard on the coast of Maine where about half the action of Mr. Irving's story is set. ''Please don't operate the grinder or the press if you've been drinking,'' one of them typically reads.

title: RECORD AND MONEY SPUR ON HOLMES
description: Record Quest Helps

title: An Impressionist Coup
description: The National Gallery is so excited about its forthcoming exhibit of French Impressionist painting that it is holding a live announcement teleconference this afternoon, linking its East Building in Washington and the Fine Arts Museum in San Francisco and starring, among others, the French Ambassador, Emmanuel de Margerie, in the east, Mayor Dianne Feinstein in the West and officials of the corporate sponsor, the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, at both ends.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Engineer Charged
description: A warrant for the arrest of the engineer of an Amtrak train that struck a car at a crossing here April 17, killing a woman, was issued today, officials said.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET IN TWO BY BALANCHINE
description: ''MONUMENTUM PRO GESUALDO'' and ''Movements for Piano and Orchestra'' are two of George Balanchine's most exquisitely wrought ballets. And they were danced as such by Suzanne Farrell and Sean Lavery in an unforgettable performance by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,225,000 from discontinued operations. The company said results for the latest quarter were aided by $1,200,000 from Waldenbooks which was sold to K-Mart Corp. in mid 1984 and reported as a discontinued operation.

title: NATION'S 'TWO-TIER' ECONOMY
description: America's economy has developed a split personality - languid in manufacturing but dynamic in the services sector - that complicates efforts to stimulate production, economists say.

title: Pianist David Syme Is Heard in Recital
description: In his piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon, David Syme made himself most felt in music that was relatively simple to play but stylistically difficult.

title: A Concert of Works By Medieval Women
description: The enterprising early music groups Music for a While and Concentus Laurentius devoted most of their Friday night concert at St. Michael's Church (225 West 99th Street) to medieval works by women, notably the remarkable 12th century abbess Hildegard of Bingen.

title: Ex-Policeman Sentenced In Puerto Rico Case
description: A former police officer involved in the killings of two young advocates of Puerto Rican independence received a maximum sentence today of 25 years to be served in a psychiatric prison.

title: MAYOR AND BELLAMY SKIRMISH ON TACTICS BEING USED IN RACE
description: Warming up for the mayoral primary campaign, Mayor Koch contended yesterday that City Council President Carol Bellamy was using ''gimmicks'' to get attention, and Miss Bellamy countered that she had succeeded in smoking Mr. Koch out of his supposed moratorium on politics.

title: British Economy Gains
description: Britain's gross domestic product rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter from the last quarter of 1984 and was up 2.3 percent from the first quarter of 1984, the Central Statistics Office said today. The agency said the coal strike reduced output in the first quarter by about 1 percent.

title: TIMES DANCE CRITIC 35 YEARS
description: John Martin, dance critic of The New York Times from 1927 to 1962, died Sunday at the Westly Nursing Home in Saratoga, N.Y. He was 91 years old.

title: Ailing Sutcliffe Out
description: Rick Sutcliffe, the Chicago Cubs' pitcher who won the Cy Young award last year, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday with a tear in his left hamstring. Sutcliffe, a right-hander who posted a 16-1 record with the Cubs after having been acquired from Cleveland last June 13, injured his leg in the second inning of Sunday's loss in Atlanta as he ran to first base in an attempt to avoid being doubled up after hitting a groundball.

title: Getaway in a Truck That Takes Away
description: Q . What has four wheels and flees?

title: Harlem Dance Theater At the Met in June
description: Tickets are now on sale for Dance Theater of Harlem, which opens at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 17 for two weeks.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allied Stores Corp., as expected, said that it would consolidate the Houston, San Antonio and Dallas divisions of its Joske's unit into one division, with headquarters in Dallas.

title: REGAN OPPOSES CUOMO ON SOUTH AFRICA MOVE
description: Saying that getting rid of stock in companies that do business in South Africa could put state pension funds on a ''precarious footing,'' Comptroller Edward V. Regan spoke out today against divestiture legislation proposed by Governor Cuomo.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Witkin of Times Honored
description: Richard Witkin, transportation editor of The New York Times, was honored by the Aviation/Space Writers Association today for outstanding achievements in aviation journalism. He received the Lauren D. Lyman Award, named for a former New York Times aviation editor who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1936, at a National Press Club luncheon. The award, established by the writers' association in 1972, is sponsored by United Technologies Corporations.

title: Great Western
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation said it had agreed to buy the Citadel Holding Corporation in a stock swap valued at about $109 million. Great Western, parent company of Great Western Savings, is California's third-largest thrift institution. Citadel, based in Glendale, is the parent of the state's 19th-largest thrift unit, Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: Takeover Talk About Apple
description: SINCE its start in 1976, Apple Computer Inc. has reveled in its role as the most independent company in a valley of free spirits. Its cutoffs-and-T-shirts approach to computer design, in fact, has become one of its greatest selling points against the staid International Business Machines Corporation, Apple's nemesis.

title: Circle Rep Closes Show In Dispute With Author
description: Circle Repertory Company has canceled its production of ''Angelo's Wedding'' because of conflicts with the author, Julie Bovasso, it was announced yesterday by Marshall W. Mason, artistic director of the theater.

title: NO NEW LEGIONNAIRES' CASES LIKELY
description: Health officials here say they do not expect any new cases of Legionnaires' disease in an outbreak traced to a banquet April 27 at a suburban hotel, but they say there may be some people who are unaware of the cause of their pneumonia-like symptoms.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $31,865,000 for the quarter and $33 million for the 6 months. c-Net income which is after losses from discontinued operations of $1,132,000 for the quarter and $2,271,000 for the 6 months and an extraordinary credit of $1,898,000 for the 6 months.

title: JUST WILD ABOUT FLOWERS
description: IT may come as something of a shock to the rest of America, but Manhattan's glossy pacesetters are finally discovering foxglove, hollyhocks and columbine. Yet when it comes to flowers and gardens, they are still mostly babes in the woods, and no wonder.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about arguments over control of United Press International left unclear the affiliation of an executive who said Reuters had expressed interest in acquiring only the photo and radio news networks of U.P.I. The executive was at U.P.I.

title: DANCE: MIXED-MEDIA WORK OFFERED BY AUSTRIAN GROUP
description: MINIMALIST form was combined with Expressionist social comment in ''The Warrior,'' the mixed-media dance work created by Jorg Schlick, Andi Beit and Gunther Skreiner that was offered Saturday night at the Ohio Theater, 66 Wooster Street. The performance was part of ''Beyond the Sound of Music,'' a series of Austrian musical and theat rical events presented under auspices of the Austrian Institute, the Kitchen and Styrian Autumn.

title: Taiwan Bank Changes
description: A Government committee set up to revise Taiwan's economic policies, today recommended further relaxation of the banking rules, a Finance Ministry official said. He said the committee also discussed measures to upgrade Taiwan's banking system to cope with the country's rapid economic development.

title: Revco, Odd-Lot Dispute Heats up
description: Revco D.S. Inc. said that the former owners of its Odd-Lot Trading Inc. subsidiary had violated an indemnification agreement and that it would seek to recover ''millions of dollars.'' The company named Bernard A. Marden and Isaac Perlmutter, saying the former owners violated their merger agreement by engaging in business activities that directly competed with those of Revco and Odd-Lot.

title: People's Savings
description: David Deutsch Associates has become agency for People's Savings Bank of Bridgeport, Conn., the largest savings bank in New England.

title: Japanese To Direct Syracuse Symphony
description: Kazuyoshi Akiyama, a conductor of the Tokyo Symphony Orchestra and a former conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra in New York City, will become the principal conductor of the Syracuse Symphony Orchestra in September, orchestra officials said today.

description: b-Net income.

title: 4 POLICE OFFICERS KILLED IN ULSTER BY A BOMB PLANTED BY THE I.R.A.
description: Four police officers were killed near the Irish border today by a bomb that exploded near their armor-plated car as it sat parked near a derelict customs post. The Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the attack.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The operation is over and was successful. We don't like trading lives like this, but at least 1,153 people who were prisoners yesterday are free today.''

description: AGATHA CHRISTIE. A Biography. By Janet Morgan. 393 pages. Illustrated.

description: Birdwatchers have sighted a pair of of peregrine falcons nesting on a cliff in northern Vermont.

description: The list has grown more formidable as the playoffs have progressed. First there was Bryan Trottier, then Peter Stastny and now Wayne Gretzky will be looking Ron Sutter in the eye.

title: Leucadia Starts Proxy Fight
description: The Leucadia National Corporation began a proxy fight yesterday to place four directors on National Intergroup Inc.'s board and to institute a recapitalization plan that Leucadia asserts would increase National Intergroup's value to shareholders.

Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the effects of operations that were discontinued subsequent to March 31, 1984.

title: Detroit Edison
description: The Detroit Edison Company said it expected commercial operation at its Fermi 2 nuclear power plant to begin in late October, when the plant reaches 75 percent of full power capacity, rather that in June, as was projected last summer. Because of the delay, it said, the estimated cost of the project had been raised to $3.58 billion, from $3.38 billion. The utility cited extensive testing for the delay.

title: PEKING COUNCIL MEETS OVER SOCCER RIOT
description: Peking's municipal Communist Party committee met in emergency session today in the wake of the country's worst sports riot in years, a rampage that developed after Hong Kong eliminated the Chinese team from contention for the World Cup next year.

title: STAGE: ANDREW JOHN PLAY, 'RETURN OF HERBERT BRACEWELL'
description: THE title character in ''The Return of Herbert Bracewell,'' played by Milo O'Shea, is an octogenarian actor with selective recall. Standing in his cluttered New York attic, he unwinds his memory and re-enacts minor moments in his middling career. A turn of the century character actor, he is someone, we are later told, ''who was relatively unnoticed but always there.'' The reminiscences are tedious.

title: TWIN CITY BARGE & TOWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VIETNAM'S DEFORESTATION BRINGS NEW ALARM
description: VIETNAM faces an environmental catastrophe brought on by three decades of warfare and continuing abuse of the land by a rapidly growing population, an international conservation group has concluded in a new study.

title: YANKEES RELYING ON FISHER
description: When Billy Martin first saw Brian Fisher pitch, he was struck instantly by one attribute: an imposing 93-mile-an-hour fastball. Not long after, Fisher was transformed from a future starting pitcher for the Yankees to their top right-handed reliever.

title: 40 Held in New York Protest As Duarte Receives Award
description: Forty people in a group of 500 protesting United States policies in El Salvador were arrested last night at the Time-Life Building in Midtown Manhattan where President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador was receiving the ''Man of the Year Award'' from the Notre Dame Club of New York.

title: STRONG EVIDENCE OF ANTARCTIC OIL
description: AN analysis of sediment from the floor of Bransfield Strait, north of the Antarctic Peninsula, has yielded ''unambiguous'' evidence of oil deposits, according to researchers on the West German ship Polarstern. The report brings substantially closer the day when a critical decision must be made on how to dispose of resources on and near the Antarctic continent.

title: PROSECUTORS SEEK TO BLOCK VON BULOW'S STATEMENT
description: Prosecutors in the case of Claus von Bulow tried today to keep the jury from learning that the defendant had voluntarily given a long statement to state police officials after they told him in April 1981 that they suspected him of trying to kill his wife.

EASYGOING FURS OPEN SHOWS
description: Giorgio Sant'Angelo describes them as nontortured furs. He means the furs are from ranch-grown animals, not trapped ones. In the collection for Robert Sidney that opened the fur season in New York on Friday, he concentrated on two types of ranch-bred animals, fox and mink.

description: Documents captured from a Salvadoran rebel leader recently indicate that the leftist guerrilla officials are attending courses in the Soviet Union, Vietnam and Bulgaria.

title: & WOUNDED BY GUNFIRE IN CHAINATOWN
description: Seven people, including a 4-year-old boy and four teen-agers, were wounded in bursts of gunfire on a busy Chinatown street last night, and the police later said the shootings were an apparent outbreak of gang warfare.

title: CARL LEWIS'S SHOW: SPORTS IN A VACUUM
description: With its remarkable instincts for finding events to lure viewers, ABC-TV gave us a handsome effort in the blending of sports and show-biz with its Carl Lewis spectacular last Saturday.

title: OWNERS ASK CURB ON FREE AGENCY
description: Baseball club owners, seeking a way to stop the 10-year salary spiral, proposed yesterday a payroll formula that would limit a team's ability to acquire players as free agents or through trades. The players' response was instantly negative.

So when Seidman, as part of his duties for NFL Films, was assigned the task of writing, editing and producing the Jets' 1984 highlight presentation, he had to do a little scrambling, just like a quarterback.

More and more companies in the financial services industry such as Merrill Lynch & Company and the First Boston Corporation, along with management consulting firms such as McKinsey & Company and Booz, Allen & Hamilton, seek top-grade students to take these positions, which often carry the title of research associate or associate consultant.

description: Governor Cuomo today proposed legislation to increase the state's monitoring of the costs of building power plants.

title: South African Trial Opens
description: The police arrested a dozen demonstrators outside a court today at the start of a trial of 16 people accused of treason by backing a revolutionary group aimed at overthrowing the Government. The trial was adjourned until July 11 after a 30-minute hearing.

title: STOCKS UP BY 19.54 TO A RECORD 1,304 AS CREDIT IS EASED
description: The stock market surged yesterday in an enthusiastic response to lower interest rates, propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to its first close above the 1,300 level.

title: ICEE USA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Muddling Forward, Italian Style
description: In Italy, everything is changing even as everything remains the same. The broad contours of politics have barely shifted in a generation. A third of the country votes Communist, another third Christian Democrat, and smaller parties led by Socialists divide the rest. Maneuvering among these blocs is Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, the first Socialist to form a Government since before Mussolini. Somehow he has kept a five-party coalition in harness; more implausibly, it is muddling forward.

title: BLUE CROSS MAKING REFUNDS TO FEDERAL EMPLOYEES
description: The Blue Cross-Blue Shield plan that provides health insurance for Federal employees said today that the subscribers' medical costs had declined so much in the last year that it was planning to refund $754 million in premiums.

title: Goldsmith Letter On Zellerbach Plan
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier who has sought control of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, expressed reservations about aspects of the company's restructuring plan. In a letter to William T. Creson, chairman, president and chief executive of the San Francisco-based paper and forest products company, Sir James stated a preference for spinning off Crown Zellerbach's timberland holdings through an independent operating corporation instead of a liquidating partnership.

title: JOANNE WOODWARD AS AN ALZHEIMER'S VICTIM
description: BARBARA WYATT HOLLIS is a college instructor and a poet. Part of her charm is a kind of breezy eccentricity. She is married to George, who runs his own successful business. They are grandparents and very much in love. And then, suddenly and irreversibly, Barbara begins drifting away from herself and from everyone around her. She is a victim of Alzheimer's disease. This is the story that is told gracefully and powerfully in ''Do You Remember Love,'' the television movie on CBS at 9 this evening. Joanne Woodward and Richard Kiley play Barbara and George, and they are wonderful.

A DARK-HORSE FILM WINS TOP PRIZE AT CANNES
description: Americans took three of the major awards at this year's Cannes Film Festival. However, the top prize, the Golden Palm, given to the best film in the festival, went to a Yugoslav movie, ''Papa Is on a Business Trip'' (''Otac Na Sluzbenom Putu''), directed by Emir Kusturica. ''Papa Is on a Business Trip,'' a comedy-drama about an affable philanderer who is imprisoned during Tito's postwar crackdown on Stalinism, was chosen unanimously by the jury, a rare occurrence at this festival.

title: 2 Plead Guilty in Lion Case
description: Two former officers of the defunct Lion Capital Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to charges of grand larceny in connection with a scheme in which 24 New York State school districts and other investors lost $40 million.

But it continued to assert that it does not intend to depart from its policy of severe budget austerity, linked to anti-inflationary monetary policies.

title: BACK TO IMMIGRATION
description: Congress is once again coming face to face with the enormous task of reforming our immigration laws. Last year's near-miss - the last-minute defeat of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill - makes it virtually certain that Congress will try again seriously this year. To improve the chances this time around, it is crucial to understand the reasons for last year's failure - above all, the tendency in Congress to respond to the wishes of the vociferous few rather than the needs of the whispering many.

title: Sears's New Card
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced that American Airlines, Budget Rent-A-Car, Denny's Restaurants, the Hospital Corporation of America and ''a fifth major company, in the hotel industry,'' would be the first to honor the retailer's new Discover Card. The credit and financial services card is scheduled for test-marketing in Atlanta this year and nationwide distribution next year. Edward R. Telling, Sears's chairman, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Atlanta that the five were expected to join with Sears in developing ''a variety of merchant-related incentives.''

When you look at it another way, of course, you can conclude that it is the Giants, like any number of poor clubs, who consistently come out the losers in close games. Whichever way you want to look at it, here are the standings of all the teams in terms of average margin of runs per loss, through Sunday's play:

title: Sipe's Passing Helps Bulls Win

Gilmour ranks third on the career list, behind Herve Filion, who has more than 9,000 victories, and Carmine Abbatiello. . . . Paul Phipps, general manager of the Denver Nuggets, is leaving the club immediately and his position has been eliminated. Phipps's primary responsibility this season was office administration and marketing.
