description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, announced today, as expected, that he would run for re-election in November.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $70,368 for the quarter and $73,868 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $41,332 for the quarter and $159,825 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary credit from the early retirement of debt of $324,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago revenue figures have been restated for discontinued operations. Year-ago share earnings have also been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 6, 1984.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $37,000 and a net gain of $91,000 on the retirement of debt. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $840,000 and a tax credit of $113,000.

title: 2 MOSLEM GROUPS BATTLE IN BEIRUT
description: Palestinians and Shiite Moslem militiamen fought fierce battles here today, and the Lebanese police said about 60 people were killed and 270 wounded.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Friday about plans for a new experimental high school program in East Harlem misidentified the position now held by the program's new director and misstated the site. The director, Deborah Meier, is now director of an alternative school at P.S. 171, not principal there. The experimental program is to be offered at the newly designated Jackie Robinson Educational Complex, a former junior high school at 106th Street and Madison Avenue.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $244,000. Share earnings reflect preferred dividend requirements.

title: A POLE'S APPEAL FOR AN OPEN TRIAL
description: Following are excerpts from a letter smuggled from jail by a Polish dissident who faces trial this week on charges of inciting public unrest.

title: YOUNG FLYER'S BLESSING: HOCKEY IN MAY
description: At the time of year when only the most fortunate of hockey players can go to work, Joe Paterson was reminded late yesterday morning of the sudden and happy turn his professional existence has taken. Paterson was driving to the practice rink of the Philadelphia Flyers, to prepare for the beginning of the Stanley Cup final series against Edmonton, when he passed a jogger. ''And I thought at this time of year, if I was home,'' Paterson said, ''I'd probably be doing some light workouts, getting ready for next season.''

title: 'MA RAINEY' WINS AWARD
description: The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday picked August Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' as the best new play of the 1984-85 season. In a meeting held yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel, the critics also decided not to vote in the categories of best foreign play and best musical.

title: IIS INTELLIGENT INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A YEAR AFTER MUSHROOM CLOUD, THE MYSTERY LINGERS
description: NOT since the great Siberian blast of 1908 or the flash recorded over the South Atlantic by a Defense Department satellite in 1979 has there been an explosive event as stubbornly mysterious as the mushroom cloud that appeared over the sea 200 miles east of Japan shortly before midnight April 9, 1984.

title: NEW YORK MARINE & GENERAL INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCERT: Y CHAMBER SYMPHONY
description: THE Y Chamber Symphony, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz, closed its 1984-85 season with a program devoted largely to American music. One applauds the orchestra's endeavors - would that all domestic ensembles cared so much about their native musical heritage.

title: First Rainout of Season
description: Heavy rains forced the cancellation of tonight's game between the Milwaukee Brewers and the Cleveland Indians, marking the first rainout after 458 games in the majors this season.

title: INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN MEDCARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ABE BURROWS IS EXTOLLED AT MEMORIAL SERVICE
description: Abe Burrows's life, Adolph Green recalled, was full of ''energy, humanity, confidence, insecurity, humor, fretfulness and intelligence.''

title: GUILFORD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHIEF CONSOLIDATED MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific and Intermountain stock exchanges.

title: FOUNDERS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rates Continue Their Retreat
description: Interest rates declined yesterday, as traders and investors continued to react to the cut in the discount rate announced by the Federal Reserve late Friday.

title: RMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
For Puerto Rico, the Issue Is Statehood
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture on Saturday with an article about military spending was published erroneously. It showed Dr. Stanley I. Weiss, a former official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, not Stanley A. Weiss, chairman of American Minerals Inc. and president of Business Executives for National Security.

title: JOSEPH W. BISHOP JR., LAW PROFESSOR AND AUTHOR
description: Joseph Warren Bishop Jr., the Sam Harris Professor of Law at Yale Law School and the author of many works on politics, military law and social issues, died Sunday at his home in New Haven. He was 70 years old.

title: Shelter in the Park
description: A rustic structure in a pastoral setting of rugged rocks, white pines and azaleas, it might be more at home on an alpine trail. But Cop Cot is just north of Central Park South and the Avenue of the Americas, in Central Park.

title: V.A. Rate Cut on Homes
description: The Government said today that it was lowering the maximum interest rate on federally backed Veterans Administration mortgages to 12 percent, from 12.5 percent.

title: NORTHVIEW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SYSTEMS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Bridge: Martel Pulls Out a Victory In International Team Play
description: After a match of wild oscillations, a team headed by Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., nosed through to victory in the final playoff here in the early hours of this morning and so qualified to represent the United States in the world team championship in Sao Paulo, Brazil, in October.

title: 3 More Cult Victims In Bombing Identified
description: The authorities today identified three more bodies of members of the radical group Move who died in last week's fiery bombing of the cult's headquarters.

title: BUCHANAN OPENS FIRE
description: Patrick Buchanan came out of the closet firing. In one of his first interviews since becoming White House communications director, he described President Reagan's tax reform proposals as a ''program for Main Street'' that could bring ''the working class, the middle class'' massively into the Republican Party.

title: NEW FOCUS ON MULTIPLE PERSONALITY
description: PETER, in his late 30's, is a smooth talker who seduces women for their money; his motto is ''Pleasure is where it's at.'' Paul, his twin, is kind and decent, and prides himself on caring for people in need.

title: MORELAND ACT DATES BACK TO 1907
description: The investigating commission that Governor Cuomo said he would name to look into police violence takes its name from a turn-of-the-century state legislator, Sherman Moreland.

title: Sadler and Gleason Win Derwent Actor Awards
description: Bill Sadler of ''Biloxi Blues'' and Joanna Gleason of ''Joe Egg'' were selected the winners of the 41st annual Clarence Derwent Awards, given to ''the most promising female and male actors on the metropolitan scene.'' Mr. Sadler plays Sergeant Toomey in Neil Simon's comedy, while Miss Gleason portrays Pam in Peter Nichols' drama.

title: Bozell & Jacobs Quits Jockey Shorts Account
description: Bozell & Jacobs, which over the last nine years has made some famous athletes more famous by publishing their photos in Jockey shorts, yesterday reported that it had resigned the business of the Kenosha, Wis., company.

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF THE ROCKES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Sale by Champion
description: The Champion International Corporation said that it had agreed to sell its six folding carton plants and two of its paperboard mills to a private group that includes the manager of one of the plants. Analysts estimated the sale price was about $100 million. The sale continues a divestiture program begun after Champion acquired the St. Regis Corporation last year.

title: Ballads, Jigs and Reels By an Irish Folk Band
description: For many Irish folk bands, ballads are breathers between speedy jigs and reels. The Fureys and Davey Arthur - four Irish brothers and a Scot - reversed things Friday at Town Hall; they played dance tunes dutifully and ballads with heart.

title: SENATE MOVES TO TIGHTEN CONTROLS ON MILITARY PURCHASING PRACTICES
description: The Senate tonight responded to mounting criticism of military spending practices by approving without dissent an amendment to make significant changes in the way the Pentagon does business.

title: SIX DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE OFFER PLAN TO CUT DEFICIT
description: Six Democratic members of the House of Representatives today offered a budget proposal that would eliminate the 1986 cost-of-living increase in Social Security benefits, raise corporate taxes and reduce future deficits by substantially more than the budget resolution approved by the Senate.

title: New Warner Editor
description: Nansey Neiman, editor in chief of Warner Book's hardcover division since 1983, has been appointed publisher of Warner's hardcover, trade paperback and mass market imprints. Before joining Warner in 1980, she was executive editor at Ballantine Books and senior editor at Avon Books.

title: DATRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOO SATHER; MAKE HIS DAY
description: Glen Sather remembers the crash of the wave against Peter Pocklington's speedboat, and how he pitched over and out, into the whirling river. He remembers going under the foaming rapids, with his helmet filling with water, but even then he was in control.

title: CONSUMERS FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $44,005 on the sale of investments. c-After a gain of $144,069 on the sale of investments.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUSTICES WIDEN REVIEW OF STATE ABORTION CURBS
description: The Supreme Court today expanded its continuing review of state efforts to restrict access to legal abortions.

title: Seoul Students Burn a Car
description: About 200 students from Chonnam University in Kwangju burned a car today during a demonstration against the detention of nine student leaders, witnesses said. Thousands of students have staged daily demonstrations in the past week to mark the anniversary of an insurrection in Kwangju five years ago.

title: OCILLA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $310,000 for the quarter and $114,000 for the year. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $124,000 for the quarter and $208,000 for the year.

title: THRIFT UNIT PRACTICES DEBATED
description: The run earlier this month on the Old Court Savings and Loan Association, based in Baltimore, has again focused attention on financial institutions that pay depositors unusually high interest, and then invest in projects viewed by some as risky.

title: IMATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company was in the development stage in the year-ago quarter and had no revenues at that time.

title: House Votes Tombstone Bill
description: The House today approved by voice vote and sent to the Senate a bill that would require upright tombstones in veterans' cemeteries except when families request flat markers. About 70 percent of the grave markers being placed in national cemeteries are flat, according to the House Committee on Veterans Affairs. Upright markers would be easier to find, especially in snow, and are more symbolic of soldiers in ceremonial formation, according to the panel.

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BRUCE, ROBERT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-No comparable year-ago share earnings were reported because the company went public in November 1984.

title: PRIVATELY OPERATED PRISON IN TENNESSEE REPORTS $200,000 IN COST OVERRUNS
description: In a bold experiment aimed at saving money, Hamilton County turned over its jail to a private company last fall.

title: DISKS REMEMBER MORE AND MORE
description: THE name of the game with personal computers, as with race cars, is performance. Increasing complexity in such applications as spreadsheets and data base managers has resulted in a demand for computer memory capacity far in excess of what only a year ago was considered more than ample. In terms of archival memory, the kind in which you store your programs and data, floppy disks simply cannot provide the performance a hard disk can.

title: TENSOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $151,667 for the latest first quarter and $105,246 for the year- ago first quarter.

MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Regular Evaluations Are Essential in Special Ed
description: To the Editor:

title: Bid for Gulfstream
description: The Gulfstream Land and Development Corporation said that shareowners who hold 24 percent of the company's stock had received an offer of $37 a share, or about $41 million, from an individual whose identity was not disclosed.

title: STARTING SCHOOL LATER
description: AT a time when many people have been sending their children to school at an earlier age, a growing number of parents are deciding to have their children start school a year later.

title: LAWMAKERS LIST FINANCIAL STATUS
description: John Glenn, who earned $1,149 a month as an astronaut when he orbited Earth, is firmly in the United States Senate's millionaire's club, alongside such wealthy members as Edward M. Kennedy, Claiborne Pell, John Heinz, John C, Danforth and John D. Rockefeller IV.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,602,874 on the sale of land and buildings. c-Includes a DISC tax credit of $525,000.

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Jesse Jackson to Appeal
description: Jesse Jackson said today at a news conference that he was prepared to go to the Middle East if he could visit four Americans held hostage by terrorists. Mr. Jackson, who placed newspaper advertisements in Beirut on behalf of the hostages, said he would also use Lebanese radio and television.

title: FLORIDA GETS RAIN AND DANGER EBBS
description: Rain from thunderstorms cooled major wildfires burning in northeastern Florida today, raising hopes that the four-day threat to populated coastal areas was ending.

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The 'Freedom' to Guzzle Gas
description: ''Free-market factors,'' not Government, asserts the Reagan Administration, should determine how much gasoline America's cars consume. Therefore the Transportation Department wants to lower the current average standard of 27.5 miles per gallon, which Ford and General Motors are unable to meet. It also wants Congress to enact a looser standard for future years.

title: Bride's Publisher
description: Elliot Marion has been named publisher of Bride's magazine, a Conde Nast publication, succeeding G. Thomas Grenier, who is leaving to pursue other interests. Mr. Marion, 60 years old, joined Conde Nast in 1962, serving as advertising director for Bride's, and then as beauty advertising manager for Glamour. Most recently, he was advertising director for Mademoiselle.

title: DEFECTIVE WARNING SYSTEM TIED TO 'SILENT' HEART DISEASE
description: EVERY year, 450,000 seemingly healthy Americans drop dead in their tracks from massive heart attacks that strike without warning. Many of these people jogged, played tennis and watched their weight with never an inkling that their coronary arteries had become progressively clogged and that their hearts were in mortal danger.

title: WESTINGHOUSE TO CLEAN UP 6 TOXIC WASTE DUMPS IN INDIANA
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has agreed to clean up six sites near Bloomington, Ind., where it had dumped polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's.

title: Jargon of the Week
description: ''Supply-side demography.'' According to a study released by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research, this is a developing theory stating that unchecked population growth may be good for the world. People called ''supply-side demographers,'' according to the study, note that ''every baby comes equipped with two hands as well as a mouth.''

title: ENS BIOLOGICALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income which includes a special gain of $622,495.

title: SEABROOK MAY SEEK INVESTORS
description: The 16 owners of the Seabrook nuclear plant, facing orders by utility regulators in three states to limit further investments, will investigate bringing in new, non-utility investors to help finish the reactor, the group announced today.

title: THE FRATERNITIES SHOW SIGNS OF NEW STRENGTH
description: ''DISGUSTING,'' said the Yale sophomore. ''One of the reasons I wanted to go to Yale was that fraternities weren't a big thing here.''

title: BALDRIDGE MEETS WITH GORBACHEV
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev met for more than two hours today with the United States Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, and told him it was ''high time'' to improve Soviet-American cooperation.

title: Teen-Age Sexual Abuse
description: As many as one in five adolescents may be victims of some sort of sexual abuse, although fewer than half of them will ever tell an adult about it, according to a newly published Government report.

title: Anti-Government Priests On Rise, Warsaw Says
description: The Communist authorities said today that the number of anti-Government priests had grown since the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest, and they appealed to Roman Catholic Church leaders to prevent unrest.

title: HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. In the year-ago periods net income was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

description: b-Includes income of $400,000 from discontinued operations.

title: WICAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $492,667 from discontinued operations.

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REGAN TAKING CONTROL OF PRESIDENT'S SCHEDULE
description: In the aftermath of the dispute over President Reagan's visit to a German military cemetery, the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, has quietly assumed control over President Reagan's schedule, White House officials said today.

title: E & B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, MAY 21, 1985

title: SCHERER, R P CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $351,000 for the quarter and $805,000 for the year. c-Net income which includes a tax credit of $446,000.

title: IMEX MEDICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GANDHI, DUE IN SOVIET, GOES AS FRIEND
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, who initially struck many diplomats as potentially pro-Western in outlook, has embarked on a new campaign to strenghthen ties with the Soviet Union and reassure the public of his devotion to socialism.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ON THE ROAD WITH THE POPE
description: Few people are as determined to be themselves as Pope John Paul II. Yet there are few leaders in the world who manage to be so many different people in the course of a day.

title: BLACK YOUTHS IN SUBURBS: MANY SAY THEY FEEL AT HOME
description: Kate Clark remembers at the age of 10 being so angry with her parents for taking her away from her friends and her home in Harlem when they moved to Westchester County ''that I don't think I spoke to them for a whole year.''

title: B. Altman Conversion Advancing
description: A conversion of the B. Altman & Company site in Manhattan appears to be shaping up, with a condominium-office structure fronting on Madison Avenue and the retail entrance on Fifth Avenue. The store would be reduced to about half its present size.

title: KOHL, AT NATO PARLEY, SEEMS COOL TO 'STAR WARS'
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that his Government faced no ''agony of choice between Paris and Washington'' on the issue of space weapons research. But he adopted somewhat aloof tones toward the American undertaking.

title: MAY ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DECIDING WHO MAY PUBLISH NEWS FIRST
description: The Supreme Court's ruling today that the First Amendment right to publish newsworthy material must sometimes yield to the right of copyright holders to do so first appears to impose only a minimal hindrance on the news media.

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
BANKAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $896,000, or 12 cents a share, on the sale of investments. c-Includes a gain of $10,023,000, or $1.31, on the sale of investments.

title: Settlement Houses Aid Latchkey Children
description: To the Editor:

title: President of KTLA-TV Calls Sale Price Cheap
description: Anthony B. Cassara, president of KTLA-TV in Los Angeles, conceded that, for most purchasers, the $510 million the Tribune Company agreed last week to pay for the station would be a ''full'' price.

title: Reagan's Travels
description: President Reagan is expected to make several trips to promote the tax revision program he is scheduled to announce next Tuesday in a nationally televised speech. Some of his key advisers want him to go to plump for it in Williamsburg, Va., in upstate New York and somewhere in the South, probably Texas. The itinerary is likely to be discussed today at the last scheduled White House meeting before the announcement of the program.

title: Bruins' O'Reilly Quits
description: Terry O'Reilly, the Boston Bruins' tenacious right wing, retired yesterday after 14 years. The 33-year-old O'Reilly, who missed 100 games over the last four seasons because of knee, shoulder and other injuries, said: ''I really thought I was losing a step and could not contribute the way I used to, and I thought it would be a detriment to the players and to the team if I tried to fool myself.''

title: Iran Gives Squatters Right to Land They Took
description: Iran's Parliament has approved a bill intended to resolve a dispute over land ownership caused by the breakup of big estates after the 1979 Islamic revolution.

title: SATELCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Coach Under Fire
description: The Alabama State board of trustees has asked for the resignation of Jim Parker, the football coach, after the National Collegiate Athletic Association was reported to have said that 16 ineligible players practiced or saw game action in violation of rules last season.

title: ISRAELI COALITION SEEMS IMPERILED
description: The prisoner exchange carried out today provoked demonstrations and appeared to be growing into a controversy that could shake the coalition Government.

title: THRIFT UNIT'S 'JUNK BONDS'
description: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills owned approximately $2 billion in high-yielding, low-grade securities at the end of March, considered one of the biggest holdings of ''junk bonds'' of any thrift institution in the nation.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $590,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $478,000.

title: ANGICOR LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNITED AND ITS PILOTS CONFER, BUT WITH NO WORD OF GAINS
description: Negotiations resumed here today between United Airlines and its 5,200 striking pilots, after a weekend of labor silence and partial operations that taxed the rest of the nation's airline industry.

title: MINCOMP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Ketchum Continues To Grow
description: KETCHUM COMMUNICATIONS, which is in the top 25 American ad agencies but aspires to the top 10, is having the best first half-year in its 62-year history.

title: Mandatory Seat Belt Bill Is Rejected in Maine
description: A mandatory seat belt bill supported by Gov. Joseph E. Brennan was rejected today by a vote of 108 to 39 in Maine's House of Representatives, and an aide to the Governor said it would be virtually impossible to revive it.

title: BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MAVERICK RESTAURANT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a merger in August 1984 with Rax of Florida Inc.

title: S.E.C. Refuses to Curb Anti-Takeover Actions
description: At the urging of the Reagan Administration and Wall Street officials, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted today not to seek legislative restrictions on the use of several anti-takeover tactics.

title: A French Connection
description: Vice President Bush and Emmanuel de Margerie, the French Ambassador, are joining in an event to raise money for a local tennis charity, the Washington Area Tennis Patrons Association. The two are honorary chairmen of a celebrity tennis program that is not to be confused with the celebrity tennis program to be held at the White House next weekend.

title: Singapore Output Off
description: Manufacturing output in Singapore fell 2.4 percent in the first quarter from the period a year earlier, the Ministry of Trade and Industry said today. The agency attributed the decline mainly to the depressed petroleum and transport-equipment markets. Oil-rig construction activities also fell.

title: THREE YOUNG DESIGNERS WITH THE LOOK OF SUCCESS
description: Marc Jacobs's designs are young and irreverent, Anne Hall's are creatively classic and Michael Kors's are simple and minimal. The fall fashion collections they presented recently have won plaudits from viewers and orders from stores such as Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman-Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Drexel Burnham Names 2 To Posts
description: Herbert J. Batchelor, a managing director of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was named yesterday to head the firm's burgeoning corporate finance department.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.00-10.50** Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Saturday about the United Airlines pilots' strike misstated bargaining positions of the two sides. The company would pay newly hired pilots an average of 48 percent less over five years than they would get under the current contract; the union would limit the reduction to 13 percent.

title: 9 KILLED AS ILLEGAL FIREWORKS SHED EXPLODES IN OHIO
description: A shed full of what the local authorities said were illegal fireworks exploded today, killing nine people and leaving two big craters.

title: SIX DEMOCRATS IN JERSEY FOCUS ON TOXIC SITES
description: Two weeks before the June 4 Democratic gubernatorial primary, the six candidates charged today that the Kean administration had failed to pursue aggressively the cleanup of toxic wastes. But they divided on how they would attack the problem.

title: PHILIPPINE LONG DISTANCE TELEPHONE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rogers on Waivers
description: Steve Rogers, a right-hander, won 158 games in 12 seasons with the Montreal Expos, but now he does not fit into their pitching plans. That was the way Murray Cook, the general manager, put it after the Expos' 9-1 victory over the Dodgers yesterday in Montreal.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Difference
description: What does the loss of Rick Sutcliffe mean to the Cubs? Consider these team statistics, covering every game from June 14 last year, the day after Chicago acquired him from Cleveland, through Sunday:

title: CARING FOR PARENTS IN OLD AGE IS EXPLORED
description: FOR many people, the late years can be happy ones, with social activity and security and, most of all, sufficient good health to insure a happy last chapter to living. For many, many others, it is less than that. ''What About Mom and Dad?,'' tonight's ''Frontline'' program at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, is not only about these others but about their children, now in middle age or even older, who must make decisions about their care.

title: WESRAY TO ACQUIRE WILSON SPORTS UNIT
description: The Wesray Capital Corporation, the investment concern headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, agreed yesterday to buy the Wilson Sporting Goods Company from Pepsico Inc. Terms were not disclosed, but analysts said the sale price was about $150 million, or about Wilson's book value.

title: TRANS-NATIONAL LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOYT'S 4-HITTER BEATS GOODEN AND METS
description: When the evening began, the Mets had the best of all possible worlds: First inning, bases loaded, nobody out, Gary Carter batting, three balls and no strikes. Not bad.

title: NATURE'S BOUNTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LONG-DISTANCE PLAN FOUGHT BY A.T.&.T.
description: The Federal Communications Commission is considering a proposal that could result in millions of telephone customers being assigned a long-distance company in instances where the customers do not choose one voluntarily. The commission itself initiated this matter in March and expects to decide it within a few weeks.

title: RESTON, VA., AT 20: IDEALS AND DANGER?
description: When Fran and Jim Grady first considered moving out of Washington and joining the Reston pioneers in 1965, they felt they were taking a risk. ''My reaction was, 'Way out there?' '' Mr. Grady recalled. ''It was considered a great gamble.''

title: Acting Comptroller Sets Different Tone
description: During the last decade of his 31-year career at the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, H. Joe Selby has closely served three comptrollers. ''I feel like I've been a caretaker for the last 10 years,'' he says.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TOUR'S END One could say, if one were a dyed-in-the-wool New Yorker, that the Acting Company has taken a suitable length of time, since last July, getting its acts together before bringing them to New York. If one were more objective, one would say that this professional touring repertory company, starting today, is merely playing the last town in a long tour.

SEACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
NORTH CANADIAN OILS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include operations of Bankeno Mines Ltd., which was acquired in September 1984.

title: Whither Ruwe?
description: Our next man in Reykjavik is likely to be a former assistant to Richard M. Nixon. The White House is expected to nominate as Ambassador to Iceland L. Nicholas Ruwe, who in recent years has been Mr. Nixon's chief of staff and spokesman in his New York office. Mr. Ruwe, who has also worked in the Presidential campaigns of Ronald Reagan, would succeed a career foreign service officer, Marshall Brement, who has been Ambassador to Iceland since 1981.

title: MALARTIC HYGRADE GOLD MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ISRAEL FREES 1,150 TO OBTAIN RELEASE OF LAST 3 SOLDIERS
description: Israel freed 1,150 Palestinians and other prisoners today in exchange for the last three Israeli prisoners of war still in Palestinian hands.

title: HONDURAN, IN DISCUSSIONS IN U.S., IS EXPECTED TO ASK SECURITY PLEDGE
description: President Robert Suazo Cordova of Honduras arrived here today for two days of discussions with President Reagan that are expected to be dominated by requests for increased United States commitments to Honduran security.

title: Deadly Childhood Disease
description: A new and perplexing disorder that affects children up to the age of 10 and is fatal in about 70 percent of cases has been identified in Brazil. A special task force of specialists, including some from the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, has been formed to track down new cases and seek their cause.

title: NOBEL INSURANCE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MAKING OF A SCENE IN NEIL SIMON'S ''BILOXI BLUES''
description: The antics of Act II, Scene II of Neil Simon's hit play, ''Biloxi Blues,'' in which Rowena, the peachy and slightly impatient prostitute, takes Eugene Morris Jerome over the threshold of manhood, draws one of the biggest audience laughs in a very funny comedy.

title: Common Market Date Set
description: Foreign ministers of the European Community today confirmed June 12 as the date for signing the treaties for the accession of Spain and Portugal, due to join the group on Jan. 1, 1986, diplomats said. The June 12 date was agreed to in principle last month but Britain later called for another date on the ground that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher would be host to President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico. Today Britain dropped its objection.

title: DISNEY IN SHIFT, TO SELL 'PINOCCHIO' ON CASSETTES
description: In a departure from the protective tradition of the cartoon empire that Walt Disney built and ran until his death in 1966, Walt Disney Productions has decided to put ''Pinocchio'' on videocassette tape and sell it for $79.95.

title: IEC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Cobb Falls for First Time
description: Earnie Shavers, Ken Norton, Michael Dokes and even Larry Holmes could not do what Eddie Gregg, the heavyweight champion of New York, accomplished tonight on the Holmes-Carl Williams undercard.

title: CARDILLO TRAVEL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GALAXY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $784,406 from an exchange of debt.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $80,000 for the latest first quarter and $100,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: New York Fed's Dealer Guidelines
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday issued voluntary guidelines covering the capital adequacy of securities dealers in government securities. Although the guidelines are voluntary, they may become mandatory if Congress approves legislation to regulate the government securities market.

title: COMPUTER PERIPHERAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOLMES RUNS RECORD TO 48-0 ON UNANIMOUS DECISION
description: Larry Holmes, on his quest for history, ran into the future tonight and almost stumbled. But in a fight that should restore some luster to the heavyweight division, the venerable 35-year-old champion overcame what sometimes look like a 25-year-old version of himself and scored a unanimous decision over Carl (The Truth) Williams.

title: British Petroleum Offers Eurobonds
description: BP Capital, a subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company, is offering $100 million of 10 1/2 percent Eurobonds due in 1994 and $182.46 million face amount of zero coupon Eurobonds due in 1995 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International. Both issues are guaranteed by British Petroleum, and both have delayed-payment features.

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: THE Gap has just published its first catalogue and mailed out more than a million copies. It's in color, with photographs of young men and women cavorting in the sun wearing the company's colorful sportswear. But it's not a mail-order catalogue. It simply shows highlights of what can be found in the more than 500 Gap stores across the country.

title: 5 Troops in Sri Lanka Killed by a Land Mine
description: Five anti-terrorist commandos were killed and at least two were seriously wounded late Monday when a land mine exploded under their vehicle near the eastern port of Batticaloa, according to officials here.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RICHMOND TANK CAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WHAT BANKS SEE IN MARYLAND
description: The recent run on privately insured savings and loan associations in Maryland has had little if any impact on consumer banking in that state. Indeed, the market is considered not only viable but attractive, especially for major banks in New York, according to bankers and bank analysts.

title: STRIPED-BASS STUDT DEBATED AS TRIAL ON WESTWAY STARTS
description: A complex study of striped bass was the focus of testimony yesterday at the opening of a trial to decide whether a Federal judge should continue to prohibit construction of the Westway project.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Works by Composer Born in Turkey
description: Deniz Ulben, a Turkish-born composer in her early 20's, has a vivid imagination and fresh lyric gift. The six solo and chamber works played yesterday at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street) do not, perhaps, reveal a mature creative voice fully formed - but they pleased a warm audience, seemed to please a lively group of performers, and left one more curious than not to hear how Miss Ulben's work will develop.

title: Withdrawal Curb May Ease
description: Gov. Harry R. Hughes is to propose on Tuesday ''hardship exemptions'' to his $1,000 monthly limit on withdrawals from Maryland's privately insured savings and loans. The changes are to be presented at a special session of the Legislature.

title: CENTRAFARM GROUP NV reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results were translated on the basis of the March 31 exchange rate of 3.460 Dutch Guilders to the U.S. dollar.

title: HORN IN BID TO ACQUIRE FOOD CHAIN
description: Ending nearly two months of speculation, the Horn & Hardart Company today announced a proposal to buy all the shares it does not already own of Diversifoods Inc. for $369 million in cash and stock.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MAY 21, 1985

title: STIFEL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-Net loss.

title: STUDY FINDS NAUTILUS LACKS AEROBIC BENEFIT
description: DON'T retire your running shoes is the message two experts in sports medicine offer to users of the increasingly popular weight-training ''circuits.''

title: FEDERAL TRIAL STARTS FOR 9 ACCUSED OF PLOT TO FREE 2 BRINK'S PRISONERS
description: A Federal prosecutor told a jury yesterday that nine men and women had banded together as ''the Revolutionary Communist Military Command'' with the object of freeing two men imprisoned for their roles in the Brink's armored-car murder and robbery case.

title: CUOMO TO ORDER REVIEW OF POLICE ACROSS THE STATE
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that he would appoint a special commission vested with sweeping investigative and subpoena powers to examine the use of force by police departments in the state.

title: 70 Are Moved From Atoll Used in '54 Atomic Test
description: The Greenpeace environmental group today moved 70 people from Rongelap Atoll, which was contaminated by a nuclear test in 1954. The islanders were ferried 100 miles to Majetto Island, according to Dick Dillman of Greenpeace Radio in San Francisco.

title: Required Reading;   Of Life After the House
description: Excerpts of remarks by Representative Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, in welcoming those attending the 15th annual spring meeting of Former Members of Congress in the House chamber, May 13:

title: ASTRONOMY SOFTWARE
description: THE last time Halley's Comet came to visit, some scientists warned that the Earth would pass through the comet's tail of deadly cyanide gas and that all life would be snuffed out. It was a bonanza for the gas mask industry.

title: HEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE POSSIBLE IS POSSIBLE
description: This is the season of college commencements, the season when older people are called upon to give addresses to the graduates containing some directions to ''life'' and when the graduates, though they are not called upon, give us back something much more important - optimism. 358.8,0,165.6,2,156.4,0 ,441.6,2>I attended a couple of these commencement exercises in the last week, and I took away more than I gave.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $258,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $43,000 on the early extinguishment of debt. c-After a loss of $27,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $237,000.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOW LOPEZ WON WITH IRON SHOTS
description: Nancy Lopez has won 30 tournaments in nearly seven and one-half years. That is more than any other pro golfer in that period, including the men. One reason is the large number of pure shots she hits.

title: The War Is Over
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY 0.6%
description: The personal income of Americans rose six-tenths of 1 percent in April, following an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Chess: Tournament in Yugoslavia Won by Soviet Grandmaster
description: This year's running of the traditional Sarajevo International Tournament in Yugoslavia was won by Smbat Lputian, a 27-year-old Soviet grandmaster. With a 10 1/2-4 1/2 score, Lputian surpassed Ulf Andersson, a 33-year-old Swedish grandmaster, by a half-point.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUPREME COURT DECISION AND DISSENT IN FORD MEMOIR CASE
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that The Nation magazine infringed upon the copyright in publishing part of Gerald R. Ford's memoirs. Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the opinion. Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote a dissent, which was joined by Associate Justices Byron R. White and Thurgood Marshall.

title: RADIO MARTI GOES ON AIR AND CUBA RETALIATES BY ENDING PACT
description: A new United States broadcasting service aimed at Cuba went on the air shortly before dawn today, and the Cuban Government responded sharply by suspending a major immigration agreement with the United States and threatening other measures.

title: LEISURE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOBEL LAUREATE PLUNGES EVER DEEPER INTO THE ATOM
description: FRESH from winning last year's Nobel Prize in physics, Carlo Rubbia has turned his special genius to one of the biggest challenges of his career: creating an innovative atom smasher that will propel CERN, the 6,000-person European Laboratory for Particle Physics, into the scientific discoveries of the next century.

title: SANDINISTA SAYS SOVIET WILL MEET ALMOST ALL NICARAGUA'S OIL NEEDS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced today that the Soviet Union had agreed to supply 80 to 90 percent of Nicaragua's oil needs this year.

title: BIRD AND PARISH SAY THEY'RE FIT TO PLAY
description: Larry Bird and Robert Parish said they were O.K. If they are, the Boston Celtics should be, too.

title: U.S. Files Against Quotas in Chicago
description: The Justice Department today sought to overturn hiring and promotion quotas for members of minorities in the Chicago police and fire departments.

title: CIRCLE FINE ART CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PICKENS TO END BID FOR UNOCAL
description: Ending a bitter takeover pursuit, T. Boone Pickens said yesterday that his investor group would withdraw its bid for control of the Unocal Corporation in return for a tentative agreement that will allow a portion of its shares to be included in a lucrative exchange offer.

title: THE SCREEN: SHORT FILMS ABOUT YOUTH
description: THE two short live-action films on the Film Forum's new bill address similar themes, and one of them approaches its subject with a powerful visual style. ''Vacant Lot,'' a 30-minute, black-and-white film by Ken Selden, has the kind of fluid, energetic camera work that suggests Mr. Selden would be at home with more ambitious material. As it is, his film, which traces the interaction of three budding delinquents in Somerville, Mass., has its own distinctive attitude toward its characters and their random aggression.

title: Foul Ball
description: The political fallout from that bitterly contested 1984 Indiana House election even extends to the Congressional Softball League. Monday night on the Mall the National Republican Congressional Committee, supplemented by the office of Representative Bill Lowery of California, played a grudge match against the office of Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who headed the inquiry that recommended seating the Democratic contender from Indiana. The Republicans won 7 to 6, but one Republican participant warned that the score was so close that the Panetta forces could be expected to demand a recount, appointment of a special investigating commission and, ultimately, a vote on the House floor.

title: Koch Sees Both Sides of Subway
description: When Mayor Koch descended to the platform of the Lexington Avenue subway at the Brooklyn Bridge station yesterday, a pleasant No. 4 train waited with open doors.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Sweet ritual morning cellophane muffins and red-eye tea a yellow vitamin cleanses the night away. And the day stretches before me an inflatable toy to be filled or compressed distorted one way or another. CARRIE HARMON A LOVELY sunny Saturday afternoon. The man and woman, when Bessie R. Doenges sees them, are strolling along Columbus Avenue near 72d Street, arms entwined. Soon their voices turn stormy; loving glances become angry ones. Nearby, a cab stops for a light and suddenly the woman is dashing into it, slamming the door with a loud bang. ''Where are you going?'' the man cries after her. She lowers the window. ''To the East Side!'' she shouts as the cab drives off.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: New Pates One might think that the French are taking over New York, at least as far as the making of pates, terrines and other types of charcuterie are concerned. And one might almost be right.

title: EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a reversal of a $79,000 extraordinary gain from a tax credit. c-After an extraordinary gain of $473,598 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: TEXAS SCRAMBLES FOR REVENUE AS OIL GLUT CUTS STATE FUNDS
description: The way things are going in Texas, college students at state schools will soon see their tuition triple, professional wrestlers will pay $15 instead of $10 for their licenses and paroled convicts will have to pay the state $10 a month to supervise their parole.

title: Books of The Times
description: ome of you will be shocked by what I report here, others moved,'' says one of T. Coraghessan Boyle's narrators, by way of prefacing his story about a torrid love affair between Dwight D. Eisenhower and Khrushchev's wife, Nina. ''Still others - the inevitable naysayers and skeptics - may find it difficult to believe. But before you turn a deaf ear, let me remind you how unthinkable it once seemed to credit reports of Errol Flynn's flirtation with Nazis and homosexuals, F.D.R.'s 30-year obsession with Lucy Mercer, or Ted Kennedy's over-mastering desire for an ingenuous campaign worker 11 years his junior. The truth is often hard to swallow.''

title: MSA REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company began operations in April 1984.

title: GREEK CANDIDATES GET WARM RECEPTIONS
description: A drive along the main roads and byways between Athens and Salonika, Greece's second city, finds that, with national elections scheduled in early June, candidates and their supporters are in full cry from speaker's platforms on town squares, storefront election headquarters and local coffeehouses.

title: FROM 4 DESIGNERS, MINK PLUS
description: BILL BLASS believes in straightforward styling for luxury furs, as do many other designers showing their fall and winter fur collections this week. In the collection he presented for Mohr, Mr. Blass focused on traditional long hairs, such as fox, lynx and fitch, plus standard symbols of opulence such as mink, sable and fisher.

title: Philadelphia Unit Begins an Offering
description: A $245 million issue of 10 1/2 percent pollution control revenue bonds for the Philadelphia Electric Company was offered yesterday at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Two Jolson Films
description: The 100th anniversary of the birth of Al Jolson will be celebrated with screenings of two films on May 28 at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street.

title: COMMONWEALTH FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $467,000, or 17 cents a share, from a stock dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank and a nonrecurring gain of $1,331,000 on the sale of mortgage-backed certificates acquired in a merger. c-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $2,901,000 on the sale of mortgage- backed certificates acquired in a merger.

title: How Laws Are Made - Sometimes
description: Where do ideas for new Federal laws or regulations come from?

title: KINCAID FURNITURE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Bridge: Eastern Regional Site Poses Problem of Transportation
description: For bridge players, busing is not a controversial subject but simply a surprising one.

title: WINE THAT BLUSHES, BEER THAT COOLS
description: THIS is the beginning of the summer wine season. What exactly is a summer wine? It has a lot to do with wide green lawns; the thwock of tennis balls; white slacks and cotton dresses, and Chinese lanterns along the edge of a moonlit lake. It is not a product, summer wine - it is a romantic idea, gauzy and delicate and probably, at its best, not exposed to harsh reality. In fact, more than a few cynics say the best summer wine is beer.

title: Raymond Dickinson, 95, Dies; Headed Y.M.C.A. in New York
description: Raymond L. Dickinson, former president of the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York, died Monday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Rossmoor, N.J., until last June, when he moved to the Holly Manor Nursing home in Mendham, N.J.

title: STRONG DOLLAR CITED
description: The growth of the nation's economy all but stopped during the first three months of this year after nearly two years of vigorous expansion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: LACANA MINING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Giant in Familiar Role
description: For most of his eight seasons in the National Football League, Don Hasselbeck has been a tight end in waiting. Today, when the Giants opened a five-day minicamp at Giants Stadium, Hasselbeck was here, a newly signed free agent and again backing up a highly rated player.

title: Vienna Agency Bought By Grey Advertising
description: Gould Cargill, an ad agency in Vienna with $7 million in billings, has been acquired by Grey Advertising, becoming its 116th office, in 47 cities and 28 countries.

title: NICARAGUA SEEKS CANADIAN TRADE
description: Nicaragua is increasing trade with Canada to try to replace some of the trade lost because of the United States embargo.

title: FLAIR LACKING IN CELTICS-76ERS
description: Although the rivalry between the Knicks and the Boston Celtics still exists in the minds of many, in reality pro basketball's No. 1 feud is between the Boston Celtics and the Philadelphia 76ers, especially in the playoffs.

title: There's No Room for Nuclear Utilities to Relax
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHETHER you find ''fast food'' acceptable depends to a great extent upon what you mean by fast food and whether you fancy a particular item. To my mind tuna or sardines eaten out of a can constitute fast food, and perfectly reasonable food at that. Under the same rubric I would also include hamburgers, as long as they are properly prepared, and french-fried potatoes, which, though not to my taste, were once a mainstay of the French kitchen.

title: HIS NEXT MOMENT OF TRUTH
description: Larry Holmes will have at least one more fight, maybe two - the first with himself over whether he should prolong his career, the second with his wife, Diane, should he decide to continue.

title: KIMBARK OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Added Incentive
description: Mike Rozier, the running back who signed a United States Football League contract with the Jacksonville Bulls after failing to win a contract from the Houston Oilers of the National Football League last year, said he still wanted to play for the Oilers one day and hoped his performance against the Gamblers Monday night would help his cause. ''I came to Houston to prove to the fans I'm ready to run for them . . . whenever,'' he said after gaining 86 yards on 20 carries to pass the 1,000-yard mark for the season.

title: Lay Minister Convicted In Attacks on Clinics
description: A Lutheran lay minister was convicted tonight of conspiring to bomb 10 abortion clinics in Maryland, Delaware, Virginia and Washington, D.C., from January 1984 through January 1985.

title: URBAN SURVIVAL COURSE: INWARD BOUND
description: THE Inward Bound program has been designed to summon up those reserves of self-reliance that lie dormant in the humdrum, everday life of the humdrum, everyday person. Successful completion of the Inward Bound course results in mastery of survival skills, a renewed perspective on life and a significant reduction in the contents of the wallet.

title: Rain Helps Florida Contain Brush Fires
description: High wind whipped small brush fires into larger ones on Florida's southwestern coast today, but rain left the rest of the state ''generally in good shape'' after thousands of acres were burned, officials said.

title: Civil Canine Liberties
description: Probably only in Washington, where confidentiality of personal records has become a cause with civil libertarians, would local government (in suburban Montgomery County, Md.) distribute with dog license renewal applications a second paper reading: ''If you wish to have information regarding your pet's license made available for public inspection, please complete this form . . .'' Otherwise, total pet privacy will prevail.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES, WITH RESERVATIONS, U.N. GENOCIDE TREATY
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to send the United Nations treaty against genocide to the Senate, adopting reservations insisted upon by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, who has led opposition to the treaty in the past.

title: SHONEY'S SOUTH INC reports earnings for 16 wks to April 21
FISH FILLET DINNERS, DONE IN A FLASH
description: FILLETS of fish - especially sole, flounder or fluke, but also skinless, boneless portions of almost any other fish - are a boon to cook and diner alike. To the cook, they promise a speedy release from bondage to a hot stove; to the diner, they offer the prospect of good eating that does not threaten to stick in their throats.

title: PRESIDENT SHIFTS TO AN MX FORCE OF 50 FOR NOW
description: The Reagan Administration today offered a compromise on the MX missile that would temporarily limit deployment to 50 weapons.

title: BATTLEFIELD BECOMES AN ISRAELI VINEARD
description: ISRAEL'S newest wine is a unique blend. The formula is something like this: Israeli grapes, grown on former Syrian territory by Israeli kibbutzniks, turned into wine by a California vintner with the help of Orthodox Yemeni Jews working with Italian equipment and French barrels.

title: DELETED FROM BOOK: GIFTS TO ALFRED E. SMITH
description: A prominent New York lawyer gave Alfred E. Smith more than $400,000 in cash and stock options while Smith was Governor of New York in the 1920's, according to a chapter dropped from the lawyer's recently published autobiography.

title: On the Bus: Good Cheer . . .
description: Here are two stories about the M5 bus. This is a nice one:

MECHTRON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for the retroactive effect of a 5-for-4 stock split in July 1984 and a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1984.

title: YANKS ROUT SEATTLE ON 15 HITS
description: Their manager has an admitted distaste for indoor stadiums and artificial turf, but the Yankees seem to like them. Tonight, New York made the game academic after the first inning, scoring four times and eventually routing the Seattle Mariners, 11-1, at the Kingdome.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF ISRAEL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FEDERAL JUDGE WEIGHS PAROLE FOR CUBANS STILL HELD BY U.S.
description: Federal District Judge Marvin H. Shoob says he will consider paroling some of the 1,900 Cuban prisoners still being held at the Federal penitentiary here because of Cuba's suspension of its immigration agreement with the United States.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 2.9 MILLION SHARES
PCB'S IN NEW YORK WATERS - THE IMPACT AND THE OUTLOOK FOR STRIPED BASS
description: Last month, New York State extended what had been a ban on commercial fishing for striped bass in the Hudson River to include New York Harbor and both shores of western Long Island because of contamination by PCB's.

title: SHIITES AND P.L.O. CONTINUE BATTLES
description: Palestinians and Shiite Moslems battled for a third day here today, and the top Shiite leader said the Palestine Liberation Organization would not be allowed to re-establish the power base it had in Lebanon before the Israeli invasion three years ago.

title: U.S. MAY SOON STOP TAKING REFUGEES FROM THAI CAMPS
description: State Department officials said today that the United States would soon stop processing Cambodian refugees in Thailand for resettlement in this country.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Victor Hugo Centennial To Be Marked at N.Y.U.
description: The 100th anniversary of the death of Victor Hugo will be marked today with a series of events sponsored by La Maison Francaise at New York University, 16 Washington Mews. Music inspired by Hugo masterpieces is the subject of a discussion beginning at 3 P.M.; admission is free.

title: FLYERS DOMINATE OILERS TO TAKE 1-0 SERIES LEAD
description: Glen Sather came to town with his defending champion Edmonton Oilers and immediately proclaimed the Flyers the favorites to win the Stanley Cup. A smokescreen, said the Flyer coach, Mike Keenan.

title: WHAT CENTRAL AMERICAN DEMOCRACY?
description: President Reagan and most of his critics now agree that protecting United States interests in Central America requires promoting democracy. Unfortunately, this admirable objective is based on a dangerous myth that can only burden our policy with unrealistic goals and increase pressure for deeper military involvement once less drastic measures prove inadequate.

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $2,100,000.

title: SATAYS, FOR WELL-DONE GRILLS
description: IN Malaysia, the word satay refers to foods such as beef, lamb, chicken and seafood that are put on skewers and grilled, usually over hot coals.

title: REGINE'S IN CAIRO AND ISLAMIC LAW: A POTENTIAL CONFLICT
description: Two days after Regine's, Cairo's chicquest new discotheque, had its gala opening here, Egypt's Parliament voted to ''systematically and scientifically'' review the country's laws to eliminate those inconsistent with Islamic law.

title: PROPERTY INVESTORS OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MALIBU GRAND PRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nat Weinberg Is Dead; Ex-U.A.W. Economist
description: Nat Weinberg, for many years the chief economist of the United Automobile Workers, died of cardiac arrest Sunday in Washington. He was 71 years old.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Iraqi Attacks in Iran Break Lull in Gulf War
description: Iraqi airplanes attacked installations inside Iran today, shattering a lull of several weeks in Persian Gulf war strikes on nonmilitary targets.

title: HONDURAS IS TOLD U.S. WILL DEFEND IT
description: President Reagan, reaffirming treaty commitments, said today that the United States would take ''appropriate measures'' to defend the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Honduras ''against Communist aggression.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 22, 1985 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Includes a gain of $6.6 million, or 14 cents a share, on the sale of the Boston store division.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Beach Bag Jenny B. Goode has an all-purpose beach bag covered with pink drawing-room chintz. Made of cotton, this La Gioconda bag has an outside pocket with a button-down flap.

title: CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Dueling Banjos
description: Funny Coincidence Department, Logging Division:

title: HEALTHFUL FROZEN DESERTS
description: IN the beginning there was ice cream and sherbet, and for some, cups of shaved ice flavored with syrups. Ice milk came later. Then about five years ago, when the phrase ''eating healthy'' started gaining currency, frozen yogurt entered the market.

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BEST BUY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Spoleto Festival Set
description: Spoleto Festival U.S.A. begins a 17-day run this weekend with a diverse schedule of opera, chamber and orchestral music and jazz as well as dance, theater and the visual arts. This year the festival, founded by the composer Gian Carlo Menotti in 1977 as the sister of the Italian event of the same name, has encountered money problems that have forced some substitutions in its program. Mr. Menotti is to attend the opening ceremony on Friday.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets send Ron Darling, one of the few pitchers on the staff not bothered by ailments, in the finale of the three-game series. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Mariners, at Seattle. The Yankee starter, Dennis Rasmussen, struggled against Texas last week. He is 2-1. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Denver Nuggets vs Los Angeles Lakers, at Inglewood, Calif. Fifth game of the Western Conference final series. Trailing by 3-1, the Nuggets try to survive in the face of injuries and the Lakers' home advantage. (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P.M.) Philadelphia 76ers vs. Celtics, at Boston, 8 P.M. The Celtics have overcome nagging injuries to take a 3-1 lead in the Eastern Conference final. (Television -WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Boxing Johnny (Bump City) Bumphus vs. Rich Beranek, 10 rounds, welterweights, at Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8 P.M. Bumphus, 25-1 with 17 knockouts, the former World Boxing Association junior-welterweight champion, has won three straight since losing his title to Gene Hatcher and moving up in weight class. Beranek, from Rapid City, S.D., is 15-5 with 7 knockouts. Golf Dodge Open, at Rockaway River Country Club, Denville, N.J., 8:30 A.M. and 1:30 P.M. Second day of pro am. After today, the amateurs drop out and the top 40 pros come back tomorrow for the final 36 holes of medal play.

title: Advertising;   D.D.B. Changes Its Name
description: IN a highly unusual move, Doyle Dane Bernbach International ran its annual report as an insert in the May 20 issue of Adweek, a trade publication. If Barry E. Loughrane, who is rounding out his first year as chief executive, wanted to make a statement about the improved health of his company, that certainly was a way to do it.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: WHITNEY ADDITION IS PLANNED
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art announced yesterday plans to more than double its space by putting up a 10-story, $37.5 million building that would rise south of and directly above the museum's home at Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

title: REBUILDING THE RIVERSIDE DRIVE VIADUCT
description: At more than 200 places along the filigree arches of the Riverside Drive viaduct, workers have put in steel buckles and cables to hold the structure steady. In other areas, the emergency repairs look more amateurish: Wooden boards have been used to prop up the concrete roadbed.

title: PINETREE COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHRONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Blood-Pressure Screening Draws a Crowd
description: A line snaked around the northeast corner of 50th Street and Fifth Avenue yesterday, a larger crowd than normal for the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral. Between 11 A.M. and 6 P.M., about 70 people an hour were having their blood pressure taken, free, at a screening center set up by the Urban Health Institute at St. Clare's Hospital, and Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

title: GENETICALLY ENGINEERED CANCER DRUG IS PATENTED
description: The Cetus Corporation was granted a patent today on a new genetically engineered drug that scientists say may eventually offer treatment for various cancers and diseases.

title: MEL BARISIC
description: Mel Barisic, former secretary-treasurer of the National Maritime Union, died of a heart attack May 9 at his home in New Suffolk, L.I. He was 63 years old.

title: REAGAN POUNDS TABLE IN FRUSTRATION ON NICARAGUA
description: President Reagan, pounding his fist on a table, voiced anger and impatience today over Congressional obstacles to his Nicaraguan policy.

title: LAWYER OPENS PRIMARY RACE AGAINST MORGENTHAU
description: C. Vernon Mason, a defense lawyer who has frequently criticized the police and prosecutors, announced yesterday that he would challenge the renomination of District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary.

title: Grand Old Repenters
description: The White House is planning a sort of group political conversion ceremony this summer at which President Reagan will welcome a number of former Democrats into the Republican Party.

title: GANDHI IN SOVIET ON FIRST OFFICIAL VISIT
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India arrived here today for his first official visit abroad and began talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: MUSIC: MORDECAI SHEHORI, A PIANIST, IN RECITAL
description: DID somebody say the other day that all young pianists are faceless automatons?

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Net loss.

title: Tulane Star Gets Offer
description: He is not expected to attract much interest in the National Basketball Association draft, but John Williams, the star Tulane center who has pleaded not guilty in connection with the school's point-shaving scandal, may be getting a chance in professional basketball, at least for a while. A spokesman for the Rhode Island Gulls of the new United States Basketball League said that Williams, a 6-foot-10-inch center who was Tulane's high scorer last season, was close to signing with the team. The league's season ends in August, well before Williams is expected to go on trial in New Orleans.

title: There's No Room for Nuclear Utilities to Relax
description: To the Editor:

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: S.M.U. Moving To the Fast Lane
description: Ted McLaughlin is already starting to feel the pressure, and so would you if you had what he has.

title: RENEWAL OF WEST 42D ST. TOWER IS NEARLY COMPLETED
description: One of the key parts of the $1.6 billion Times Square redevelopment project is a huge merchandise mart on Eighth Avenue where manufacturers would be able to show new products for merchants and buyers. While the entire redevelopment project is being held up by court challenges, a nearby forerunner of the merchandise mart, used in recent years as an office bulding, is undergoing a $10 million renovation.

title: Budget Plan Scrapped By Secretary of Labor
description: Secretary of Labor Bill Brock today scrapped budget proposals to downgrade regional offices in three cities and to cut 196 Federal jobs, saying such moves would hurt his department's enforcement activities.

title: The Right Reform Is Capitalism
description: ''I'm tired of reading about the scandals, and I'm tired of going home and apologizing for them,'' fumed Senator Dale Bumpers about the way the Pentagon buys weapons. But he and 88 colleagues then voted for a remedy that will change little. The only cure for the disease still seems too radical for Congress. It's called capitalism.

title: DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WILLIE HORTON: HOSTILITY TO TRANQUILLITY
description: When Billy Martin managed the Detroit Tigers and Willie Horton played for the team, the two men didn't get along as well as they do today, now that Martin is the Yankee manager and Horton is his ''tranquillity coach.''

title: In Pursuit of Kosar
description: It worked for Doug Flutie, so it should come as no surprise that Bernie Kosar, the University of Miami quarterback who is expected to be picked by the Cleveland Browns in a supplemental National Football League draft, is flirting with the United States Football League. Dr. John Geletka, the dentist who is serving as Kosar's adviser, said he had been approached by the Portland Breakers and would meet with the team's principal owner, Joe Canizaro. ''Portland says they have a dire need for Bernie,'' Geletka said. ''He could save the franchise.''

title: New York Street Trees Are Endangered
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 22, 1985

title: PROTECTING SKIN FROM SUN'S RAYS
description: THOUGH some people have already got a start on a seasonal tan, the Memorial Day weekend marks the unofficial opening of sunbathing season for millions of Americans who equate tanned skin with beauty and health or who spend many hours a week working or playing in the searing summer sun.

title: ABC OFFERS A FILM, 'RIGHT TO KILL?,' BASED ON FACT
description: CONTINUING on its binge of fact-based TV movies, all of them graphically depicting some sort of sociopathic behavior, ABC is now offering, at 9 o'clock this evening, ''Right to Kill?'' Based on a true story, Joyce Eliason's script deals with a teen-age boy who, with the help of his sister, shot his father to death to protect his family from the disturbed man's physical abuse.

title: Shells on Way to Britain Use Polish Explosives
description: Britain is to import artillery shells from a Belgian company that uses Polish explosives, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today.

title: PAPERBACK SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company was in the development stage during the year-ago first quarter and had no revenues at that time.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
Ratings Cut In Aluminum
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday reduced its ratings on $1.9 billion of debt securities issued by four major aluminum companies.

title: KEEPING PICNICS FRESH
description: THE outdoor picnic season officially gets under way this weekend and with it the challenge of keeping foods fresh and cool while preventing uninvited insects from joining the festivities. The airtight, hard-plastic cooler pictured here, sold by the Lee Bailey shop at Henri Bendel, is useful to take along. It comes in four sizes, ranging from 4 3/4 inches wide by 7 inches long and 2 inches deep to 6 1/2 inches wide by 10 inches long and 4 1/2 inches deep. The two-section lid can be removed, which makes it easy to load and unload.

title: PANEL WOULD EASE RULES ON COLLEGES
description: The House Education and Labor Committee voted today for legislation that would overturn rules prohibiting federally assisted colleges and universities from taking any punitive steps against employees or students who have had abortions.

title: FOR RADIO MARTI, CHEERS IN MIAMI, SCORN IN CUBA
description: There was joy in Miami today, outrage in Havana and rising debate on the benefits to the United States of the Government's new broadcasting service directed at Cuba.

title: Circumlocution Office Is Where to Find It
description: To the Editor:

title: PILOT DIES AND 2 ARE MISSING
description: A single-engine plane plunged into the Niagara River this morning. Two passengers were missing, and divers found the body of the pilot in the afternoon.

title: THE LAST FOREVER
description: Some things should be forever, yet so few are. Permanence, permanence - above all, permanence! The human race requires it.

title: THE NEW SCHOOL AWARDS DEGREES TO 519 STUDENTS
description: More than 500 students of the New School for Social Research received degrees yesterday during the school's 49th commencement exercises at the First Presbyterian Church on Fifth Avenue at 11th Street.

title: ENERGY OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: GEORGE WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Never again will Israel be able to condemn any other country which will be blackmailed into freeing terrorists who have killed Jews -whether it is in France, Germany or England.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CITY SHARING Few, if any, Chicagoans or New Yorkers, highly chauvinistic types, would dream of conceding that their hometowns have anything in common. Yet, the traveling exhibition that opens today at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street (873-3400), tells a story of similarities.

title: PETRA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
Furstenberg Beer Ad Uses 1904 Rave Review
description: The trade ad for Furstenberg beer, which is being marketed in this country by the Guinness Import Company, features a rave review of the beer by Adolphus Busch of the St. Louis brewery that bears his name.

title: SEAHAWK OIL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Georgia Takes N.C.A.A. Tennis
description: Philip Johnson downed U.C.L.A.'s Brett Greenwood today to give Georgia a 5-1 singles victory and the National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis championship.

title: Waiting for Gorbachev, Waiting for Reagan
description: A State Department official was talking today about the confusion over whether Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, might come to the United States this fall and, if so, whether he would see President Reagan while in this country.

title: RANGEL SEEKS F.B.I. DENIAL OF MEMO ACCUSING HIM
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, called on the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday to repudiate a memorandum that claims he received money in exchange for political favors.

title: SCREEN: SYLVESTER STALLONE RETURNS AS RAMBO
description: ABOUT two seconds after he has been dropped into the middle of Vietnam to look for American prisoners of war, Rambo (Sylvester Stallone) is accosted by a large snake, dangling from a tree. Rambo simply turns and, with what appears to be no more than a flick of the wrist, strangles it. A few seconds further on, he meets his beautiful young Vietnamese underground contact, and maybe four minutes later he has found the P.O.W.'s.

title: Power Agency Refunds '81 Bonds
description: The Northern Municipal Power Agency, based in Minnesota, is offering $222.7 million of electric revenue bonds to refund bonds sold in 1981 when it paid interest rates as high as 11 7/8 percent.

title: 6 KILLED, 5 LOST AS OIL RIG CAPSIZES IN LOUISIANA INLET
description: A drilling rig with 22 people aboard flipped over and sank in a murky, remote bayou late Monday night, killing at least six people and leaving five missing and feared dead. Two crewmembers were rescued from inside the barge's hull.

title: SRI LANKA PRESIDENT CALS FOR DISCUSSIONS ON REBEL VIOLENCE
description: The President of Sri Lanka has called a meeting Wednesday of leaders of all the country's religious organizations to discuss the rising level of violence surrounding the demands by Tamil separatists.

title: ANDERSON 2000 INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JAPAN PROTESTED CONVICTS RELEASE
description: The Japanese Government said today that it had urged Israel last week not to free a Japanese guerrilla as part of the mass exchange of prisoners conducted Monday.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
HOUSE PANEL HOLDS HEARINGS ON ADVERTISING FOR ALCOHOL
description: A House subcommittee today heard conflicting testimony about whether there is a link between the advertising of alcohol and its consumption and abuse.

title: RULING BACKS PENALTIES IN GROUNDLESS LAWSUITS
description: A Federal appeals court in New York ruled yesterday that plaintiffs who bring suits that are groundless or have no chance of success can be ordered to pay the legal fees of the defendants.

title: ART AND MONEY IN A BALLET CONFLICT
description: The current conflict between Lincoln Kirstein's supporters and those who have recently challenged his authority in the School of American Ballet - which he and George Balanchine established before founding the New York City Ballet - has raised issues faced by arts groups throughout the nation.

title: 7TH IS STILLBORN
description: Seven babies, one of them stillborn, were delivered here today to a woman who had taken fertility drugs in what was apparently the largest multiple birth in the United States.

title: Swedish Offer Links Bonds and Warrants
description: Taking advantage of hopes that interest rates will continue to fall, Sweden yesterday offered $300 million of 30-year bonds with warrants allowing investors to buy another $300 million of identical bonds before next year.

title: JERSEY PRO LEADS BY 2
description: Billy King, an assistant golf professional at the Rutgers University golf course, made four consecutive birdies today on his way to a provisional lead in the rain-interrupted first round of the 22d Dodge Open Charity Classic. King's 68 was four under par for the Rockaway River Country Club.
