title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
COLORADO MOUNTAIN COMMUNITIES BRACE FOR MUD-SLIDE THREAT
description: Springtime in the Rockies this year has brought meadows in bloom with dandelions, as usual, but also meadows that are sliding down into the valleys and blocking streams, threatening some communities with flooding.

title: FOXMEYER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. BIDS LATIN NATIONS LURE PRIVATE CAPITAL
description: Reagan Administration officials called on Latin American governments today to speed change in economic policies to attract more private capital as the way to guarantee future stability and ease the debt crisis.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,320,000 for the quarter and $4,657,000 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $797,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $462,000 for the 6 months, and an extraordinary gain of $2,686,000 for the 6 months. The company has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code since Nov. 4, 1983.

title: BOSTON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Hostage Crisis for Mr. Reagan
description: Work with anybody who may be able to help . . . use private and unpublicized channels . . . keep hoping for the best. That's not an exhilarating formula. It prolongs the agony for the families of four Americans and two French citizens cruelly held hostage by terrorists in Lebanon. It leaves unresolved the dilemma of how to negotiate with terrorists while not rewarding them. And it does not explain the Administration's passivity in responding to Iran's tacit approval of hijacking.

title: DISPUTE RISES IN COLOMBIAN DRUG EXTRADITION PLEA
description: Seven years ago, on a remote airstrip in Colombia, the police seized a DC-4 airplane loaded with marijuana as its crew fled into the jungle. On board they found a passport in the name of John L. Tamboer, a United States citizen from Portland, Me.

title: Rhode Island Opens Hearing on Chief Justice
description: The Chief Justice of Rhode Island's Supreme Court went before a judicial disciplinary panel today for a closed hearing on unspecified charges involving his admitted friendships with reputed members of organized crime.

title: Judge Bazelon Is Retiring
description: Judge David L. Bazelon, a social activist who has sat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia for nearly 36 years, 16 of those years as chief judge, said Monday that he would retire from the bench.

title: BROOKLYN MUSEUM PLANS PAID TV SPOTS
description: One would think that the natural promotional course for a museum to take to increase attendance would be some small-space newspaper ads and a radio spot or two, especially in free public service time. But paid television, hardly.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Of Black and White And a Red, Red Budget
description: When Representative William H. Gray 3d was running for chairman of the House Budget Committee, some Democrats privately raised a troubling question: Could a Congressman representing a predominantly black district be an effective chairman and a credible party spokesman on budget issues at a time when rising deficits required fiscal austerity and threatened many programs needed by his district?

title: FUROR IN ISRAEL
description: Many of Israel's top experts on terrorism say they believe the prisoner exchange carried out Monday was a blunder that has dealt long-lasting damage to Israeli strategy on counterterrorism.

title: Control Data Cutback
description: The Control Data Corporation said today that it would lay off 100 workers June 1 at its computer disk factory here. Weak demand was cited.

title: JUDGE CRITICIZES ARMY RECORDS ON WESTWAY
description: Judge Thomas P. Griesa complained yesterday about ''a very serious failure'' by the Army Corps of Engineers to maintain adequate records of the procedure that led to granting a landfill permit for the Westway project.

title: HOT LINE TO CUBA
description: The Reagan Administration is stuck with so many unavoidable problems these days - budget deficits, trade deficits, etc. - that it's a puzzle why it insists on punishing itself with additional avoidable problems.

title: INJURY-RIDDEN METS WELCOME RAINOUT
description: After 217 games, the National League finally had a rainout last night: the Mets against the San Diego Padres in Shea Stadium. And that was fine with Dave Johnson, the manager of the Mets, who made three more roster moves earlier in the evening in a somewhat frantic effort to cope with the siege of injuries wracking the team.

title: Gerald Ford's Own Words
description: The Supreme Court's ruling that The Nation magazine infringed the copyright on former President Ford's memoirs may prove more an oddity than a landmark. It may have seemed portentous for free expression; might have centered on a dramatic moment in Presidential history; and could have addressed the expropriation of history by officials. Ultimately, however, the case turned on a narrower question: Did the magazine use too much of Gerald Ford's literary originality, too many of his own words? To which the Court gave a narrow answer: Yes.

title: BLUE JAYS TOP WHITE SOX ON RUN IN 9TH
description: Jeff Burroughs singled home George Bell with the winning run with one out in the ninth inning tonight to give the Toronto Blue Jays a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: ENVOY WANTS STRONGER BONDS BETWEEN JEWS AND GERMANS
description: In an appearance before the B'nai B'rith International board of governors, the West German Ambassador said today that he hoped the dispute surrounding President Reagan's visit to the German military cemetery at Bitburg might inspire renewed efforts to strengthen ties between his country and American Jews.

title: FUROR GROWS IN ISRAEL OVER JAILED JEWS
description: Demands mounted today for the release of imprisoned Jewish terrorists in the aftermath of the release of 1,150 Palestinian guerrillas in exchange for three Israeli soldiers.

title: OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $811,000 from an accounting change.

title: A-Test Is Laid to Israel And South Africa
description: South Africa and Israel conducted a joint nuclear weapons test in 1979, a private lobbying group said today, and a member of Congress called for a new investigation of the report.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $252,000 for the latest first quarter and a loss of $10,650 for the year-ago first quarter from equity in affiliates.

title: PENNEY, J C CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
STAGE: 'RAT IN THE SKULL,' FROM BRITAIN
description: AUDIENCES who have sampled the Public Theater's recent English plays - ''Tom and Viv,'' ''Virginia'' and ''Salonika'' - might well believe that London dramatists are a hopelessly nostalgic lot, lost in the mists of Bloomsbury and the trenches of World War I. But the United Kingdom has a tempestuous present as well, and it has playwrights who are willing to bring the raging battles to the stage. Ron Hutchinson is such a writer, and his ''Rat in the Skull,'' the latest import at the Public, is a raw descent into the morass of Northern Ireland. An authentic and savage political play, it provides a most welcome antidote to its genteel English predecessors of the season.

title: Employee Convicted In Rape of 5-Year-Old
description: A former Bronx day-care worker, one of the seven employees charged last September with sexually abusing children, was convicted late Monday of raping a 5-year-old girl.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,225,000 from the sale of Waldenbooks to K Mart Corp. in mid-1984. Waldenbooks was recorded as a discontinued operation. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Television Did Not Invent Mass Voyeurism
description: To the Editor:

title: SEAL FLEET INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PASSPORT TRAVEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: SEWN INTO A CORNER
description: Must our apparel and textile industries be shredded by foreign competition?

title: RAINS POUND NEW YORK AREA
description: Heavy rains, in some places laced with hail, lashed the metropolitan area yesterday, knocking out power to thousands of homes and flooding roadways during the evening rush hour.

title: Bank Ruling Is Reversed
description: In a decision that could have far-reaching effect on so-called limited-service banks, a three-judge appeals court in Atlanta has reversed a 1984 decision by the Federal Reserve Board that permitted the United States Trust Company of New York to operate a limited-service bank in Florida, banking spokesmen said today.

title: How to Account for Inflation
description: Anyone who knows how much inflation there will be in military equipment costs between now and 1988 is urged to get in touch with Congress, so it won't keep giving the Pentagon more money than it needs. Chairman Les Aspin of the House Armed Services Committee calculates that in four years, the Defense Department has received at least $18 billion, perhaps $50 billion, extra by overestimating inflation.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
THE PINBALL CAPITAL OF THE WORLD CRIES 'TILT!'
description: ''They can't do this,'' said Steven Epstein, proprietor of the Broadway Arcade. ''This is not just some . . . some sleazy pinball joint!''

title: MURDER TRIAL OPENS IN CASE OF AN OFFICER KILLED IN BROOKLYN
description: A prosecutor charged in court yesterday that a 19-year-old man executed a Transit Authority police officer with her own gun in a weed-filled lot in Brooklyn last September.

title: SOME TOP WINE NAMES TO DO A LITTLE DECANTING
description: SOME 70 of the world's most prominent wine producers were invited to a dinner at Windows on the World last night to begin a two-day event called the New York Wine Experience. The gathering is being sponsored by The Wine Spectator, a monthly consumer publication.

title: FILM: PRYOR IN REMAKE OF 'BREWSTER'S MILLIONS'
description: RICHARD PRYOR is the star of ''Brewster's Millions,'' which opens today at Loew's State and other theaters. But the role could easily have been played by any of a number of actors; in fact it has been, by Fatty Arbuckle (in 1921), Jack Buchanan (1935) and Dennis O'Keefe (1945), among others. Mr. Pryor's presence necessitates some slight rewriting, as in the explanation of how the eccentric white millionaire played by Hume Cronyn can consider Mr. Pryor's Montgomery Brewster his only living relation. But all in all, the film does nothing to accommodate Mr. Pryor's singular comic talents.

title: A DARING AND SENSITIVE DESIGN
description: There can be few urban design problems in New York more difficult than adding to the Whitney Museum of American Art, a building whose essential architectural idea is its own aloofness. The architect Marcel Breuer seemed so determined to set his stern granite building apart that he put a moat in front of it and erected a high concrete wall beside it, all the better to cut the museum off from the Madison Avenue streetscape in which it sits.

title: Ex-Editor and Wife Are Slain
description: A retired newspaper editor and his wife were found stabbed to death Sunday night in their home in this Cleveland suburb.

title: BRIDGING ULSTER GAP: A STREET TOO WIDE FOR CLERIC
description: The aging stone First Limavady Presbyterian Church is so close to the new Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King that when a bomb demolished the Catholic church in 1981, it broke the stained glass windows in the Protestant church as well.

title: DISCO REVIVAL MAY BE IN THE MAKING
description: IS pop music in the throes of a disco revival? The fact that 8 of the top 10 singles on Billboard's pop singles chart are strongly dance-oriented would suggest exactly that. In many people's minds, the term ''disco'' still brings to mind an anonymous female voice gasping over a relentless mechanical thud. Mid-80's disco, by contrast, is rhythmically more varied and texturally more sophisticated. The beat isn't as heavy, and the instrumentation is inflected with interesting electronic crosscurrents.

title: POWERTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
AIR POLLUTION REPORTED DAMAGING U.S. PARKS
description: Air pollution in the National Parks is damaging wildlife and vegetation, reducing visibility and damaging monuments and buildings, the National Park Service reported today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Recalled Daryl Sconiers, first baseman, from Midland of Texas League. Placed Rod Carew, first baseman, and Doug DeCinces, third baseman, on 15-day disabled list Monday.

title: CARY L. CALDWELL
description: Cary L. Caldwell, a social worker in the New York City Department of Social Services for 18 years before retiring in 1982, died of cancer May 9 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RESIDENTS OF CHINATOWN TRY TO EXPLAIN SHOOTING
description: Chinese community leaders and residents offered a variety of explanations yesterday for the shooting that broke out on a crowded Chinatown street Monday night, apparently involving members of rival youth gangs.

title: PRE-PAID LEGAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $55,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $265,000 for the year.

title: READINESS FUNDS A TARGET DESPITE OFFICERS' PLEAS
description: The military programs bill being debated in the Senate today would cut funds for military readiness despite pleas from operational commanders that such programs be protected.

title: Cordero's Decision
description: He had hoped to do both, but a scheduling conflict made that impossible, and now Angel Cordero has made the hard choice. Cordero, who rode Spend a Buck to victory in the Kentucky Derby and two other key races, has decided to pass up the promise of a quick windfall aboard the colt at the Jersey Derby at Garden State next Monday in favor of the prospect of a long-range bonanza.

title: Key Rates
description: ** Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ABORTION CHOICE DEFENDED IN CAPITAL
description: A little more than a year ago Rabbi Shira Stern lay on a New York hospital bed, waiting miserably for the beginning of the induced contractions that would abort her defective, five-month-old fetus. Her husband turned on the television set for distraction, and there was President Reagan addressing a convention of religious broadcasters, attacking abortion and lamenting the ''15 million children who will never laugh, never sing, never know the joy of human love.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GREASY LAKE & OTHER STORIES. By T. Coraghessan Boyle. 229 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: POPE, UNFAZED BY CRITICS, ENDS TRIP
description: Pope John Paul II ended his often stormy journey through the Low Countries today much as he started it, confronting face-to-face criticism of his traditionalist views.

title: Back From Utah
description: Reports of the permanent retirement of Thomas R. Mathews to his ski lodge in Utah turn out to be premature. Mr. Mathews, known in the capital as the first information director of the Peace Corps, chief aide to John Gardner in founding the Urban Coalition and Common Cause and as a founder of Craver, Mathews, Smith & Company, which does direct-mail fund-raising for liberal causes and candidates, has agreed to return as head of the executive committee of Ernest Wittenberg Associates, a public relations concern. Just before he left for Utah, Mr. Mathews was press secretary to John B. Anderson in his 1980 Presidential campaign.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
GENERAL DYNAMICS DRAWS PENALTIES ON NAVY DEALINGS
description: Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. announced today that he was suspending the signing of all new contracts at two major divisions of the General Dynamics Corporation because of ''pervasive'' business misconduct.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,000,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $5,000,000 for the quarter and $9,000,000 for the 6 months ,and an extraordinary credit of $6,000,000 for the 6 months.

title: There's No Room for Nuclear Utilities to Relax
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Deane Beaman, commissioner of the PGA Tour, said that the Tournament of Champions, held May 2-5 this year, would be switched to early January next year, making the tournament in Carlsbad, Calif., the first stop on the 1986 tour. . . . Chico Borja, a standout on the United States national soccer team, suffered a strained knee in the team's victory over Trinidad-Tobago last Sunday and will miss this Sunday's World Cup qualifying game against Costa Rica.

title: LAWYERS FOR VON BULOW CHALLENGE RHODE ISLAND ON TRIAL PREPARATION
description: Claus von Bulow put the State of Rhode Island in the witness box at his trial today.

title: Split the Indian Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Protest in South Korea
description: Riot policemen fired tear gas today to rout about 200 students staging anti-Government protests in Seoul, witnesses said. The students hurled firebombs and stones at a police post, smashing windows, they said. No arrests or injuries were reported.

title: Classical Trap
description: Does Shakespeare mix with sports?

title: NEW WOLLMAN RINK DELAY IS FEARED
description: After five years of construction, the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park may have to be torn up and rebuilt again because its new refrigeration system is leaking, apparently because of ''stray electrical currents'' in the ground.

title: RELIABLE INVESTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $159,498 for reorganization expenses. c-After an extraordinary charge of $25,764.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Bolivia Raises Cost Of Bread by 75%
description: The Bolivian Government said today that it was raising the price of bread by 75 percent, and unions denounced the move.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: The company said results for the year-ago quarter include a gain of 3 cents a share from discontinued real estate operations.

title: A FATIGUED HOLMES PONDERS HIS FUTURE
description: The Truth hurt. For 15 often exciting and grueling rounds, Carl (The Truth) Williams hurt Larry Holmes, leaving the winner and still heavyweight champion with a horribly swollen face. Now, in the joyless and quiet aftermath of his 48th straight victory, another truth was dawning on Holmes:

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary income of $892,000.

title: NUCLEAR AGENCY DEFENDS CHANGE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission came under Congressional criticism today for amending its regulations to permit secret meetings without public notice and without a stenographic transcript.

title: 'CHILLER,' TALE OF YOUNG MAN AND LIFE AFTER DEEP FREEZE
description: ''THE problem ain't freezin' them; it's thawin' them,'' says a character in ''Chiller,'' a tale about a young man who is returned to life after 10 years out of it, to the distress of everyone he encounters. The speaker is a guard at a high-tech mausoleum called ''They Shall See Tomorrow,'' where quick-frozen corpses wrapped in aluminum foil are stored in cryogenic chambers awaiting the medical millennium when science will have figured out a way to bring them back to life. Cryogenics, as every science-fiction buff understands, involves tampering with profound matters and bodes no good.

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: The company said its year-ago first quarter ended on April 28, 1984.

title: Antismoke Plea
description: With the San Diego Padres in town for a series against the Mets, Steve Garvey made his way yesterday to a Manhattan news conference whose purpose was perfectly in keeping with his squeaky-clean image: promoting ''In Control,'' the American Lung Association's newest effort to help smokers kick the habit. ''In Control,'' designed by Dr. Nina Schneider of the U.C.L.A. Medical School, is billed as the first video program to assist sworn-off smokers, and the narrator on the cassettes is none other than Steve Garvey, who says that he has never taken so much as a puff himself but who is always encouraging his parents to quit.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
. . . And a Bad Break
description: Just one more passenger wanted to get on the M5 bus yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday, in a listing of the average margin of runs per loss for each of the major league teams through Sunday, misstated the figure for the Chicago Cubs. It was 2.2.

title: A Master's Maps
description: An unusual collection of maps that combine the precision of cartography, the colors of nature and third-dimensional depth added by the artist has been acquired by the Library of Congress. The 32 maps, called the Natural Color Relief Series, are the work of Hal Shelton of Colorado, an 80-year-old artist, geologist and cartographer, and are valued at more than $1 million.

title: Theater for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENCE ADVISER OPTIMISTIC ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: ''Unequivocal proof'' of the feasibility of destroying intercontinental missiles in flight could be demonstrated in three years if the research was ''properly streamlined,'' President Reagan's science adviser said today.

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $4,890,000 for the quarter and $5,596,000 for the year.

title: OILERS PERPLEXED BY LOSS OF OPENER
description: There were no cries of desperation from the Edmonton locker room tonight, no concern that this might have been it, that the defending Stanley Cup champions had finally met an unstoppable opponent.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES FLORIDA INTERNATIONAL -Named David Rice athletic director.

title: THE FOLDING SCREEN AS ART FORM
description: THE folding screen works within a room as a fan does against the face: It hides, softens and flatters, and folds away easily after a party or a flirtation. A screen can be used coyly; it can keep a secret; or it can simply be beautiful. And, like a fan, a screen can be the occasion for a painting.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IN THE NAME OF EUGENICS. Genetics and the Uses of Human Heredity. By Daniel J. Kevles. 426 pages. Knopf. $22.95. AT a superficial glance, one might judge the subject of eugenics to be a dead one.

title: 9.18% Top Yields Set in Refunding
description: The Southern California Public Power Authority is offering $214 million of new bonds to refund bonds it sold in 1982, when it paid interest rates as high as 11 1/2 percent. The 1982 bonds were sold to finance the authority's share of the Palo Verde nuclear power project.

title: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Per Royal Dutch Petroleum share. c-Per Shell Transport & Trading share. Both Royal Dutch Petroleum and Shell Transport & Trading are listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DYNAMICS HEAD PLANS TO RETIRE BY END OF 1985
description: The chairman of the embattled General Dynamics Corporation, David S. Lewis, said yesterday that he would retire from the giant military contracting company by the end of this year.

title: COMPTEK RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NODAWAY VALLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid April 12, 1985.

title: FRANK SINATRA, DOCTOR OF ENGINEERING
description: Francis Albert Sinatra, a native son of this city who is known in the different eras of his career as ''the Voice'' and ''Old Blue Eyes'' and ''the Chairman of the Board,'' is coming home again.

title: 2 WOUNDED IN A CLASH IN INDIA
description: The Indian police fired on a crowd in Gujarat state today, wounding at least two people, after a man was stabbed to death during rioting and arson.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Strike Action Expected
description: With baseball's labor picture looking gloomier than at any other time since negotiations began last November, the executive board of the Players Association will meet in Chicago today to discuss what action the players could take to emphasize their position. The board is expected to vote to authorize a strike or to take a strike- authorization vote among all 650 major league players.

title: Lightning and a Castle
description: It was timeless: the squat profile of Castle Clinton silhouetted by hairline cracks of lightning in purple skies over the harbor.

title: Redmen to Play in N.C.A.A.
description: Because St. John's 150-pound second baseman managed to hit his first home run of the season in the 11th inning Monday, the Redmen are on their way to their first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament appearance since 1981.

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: PHYSICIANS ALERTED TO RISKS OF ABUSE
description: ALTHOUGH violence is a common experience for American women, some physicians overlook it in treating their patients because they do not recognize the emotional and physical signs of rape, wife-beating and child abuse.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a realized investment gain of $26,328. c-Net income.

title: SSC&B: Lintas Shift
description: SSC&B: Lintas Worldwide, one of the three worldwide agency networks of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has restructured itself at the top. From now on there will be an international and a United States unit, both reporting to William V. Weithas Jr., 56 years old and chairman and chief executive based in London. Kenneth L. Robbins, 49, formerly the head man stateside, is going to London as deputy chairman in charge of international, while Spencer Plavoukos, 48, and former chief operating officer in the United States , will be chairman and chief executive of SSC&B, the domestic unit.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Mariners, at Seattle. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 10:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Tidewater Tides, at Norfolk, Va. The Mets take a break to play their Class AAA farm club in an exhibition. Golf Dodge Open, at Rockaway River Country Club, Denville, N.J. Final 36 holes for the pros, 8:30 A.M. and 1:30 P.M. PGA Memorial, at Dublin, Ohio, opening round. This is Jack Nicklaus's tournament, and he won it last year in a playoff against Andy Bean. Ladies P.G.A. Corning Classic, at Corning, N.Y. Opening round. The purse has been increased by $100,000, to $250,000, and JoAnne Carner will be back to defend her only 1984 title. She played the final round without a bogey last year and won by four strokes. Hockey Flyers vs. Edmonton Oilers, at Philadelphia. Game 2 of the Stanley Cup championship series. Philadelphia has not lost to the Oilers in the last nine meetings, an unbeaten string of 8-0-1 that includes a three-game sweep of the regular-season series and a 4-1 victory in Game 1 of this series on Tuesday night. The Oilers will have to overcome the Flyers' fierce checking game, which held Wayne Gretzky to no shots on goal Tuesday night. (Television - USA Network, 7:30 P.M.) Other Events BASKETBALL: Long Island Knights vs. Connecticut Colonials, at C. W. Post, Greenvale, L.I. United States Basketball League exhibition game, 7:30 P.M. FOOTBALL: Gold vs. Oakland Invaders, at Denver.

title: GARBAGE PLANT IN WESTCHESTER MEETS AIR RULES, REPORT SAYS
description: Westchester County's new refuse-to-energy plant in Peekskill meets all existing air quality standards, according to a report based on a five-month investigation of the county's garbage program.

title: 4 More Bodies Found In Capsized Oil Rig
description: Divers found four more bodies today in the dark interior of a capsized oil rig, bringing to at least 10 the number of victims. Rescuers held out hope that the last worker still missing had escaped or otherwise survived.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Eaton Corporation's AIL division won a $193 million contract from the Air Force for the expanded advance purchase of B-1B aircraft defensive avionics components, the Defense Department said. It also said Hughes Aircraft had received $136 million from the Army for 655 Tow and Tow 2 missile subsytems and support equipment.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Interest Rates Post 2d Consecutive Rise
description: After two months of sharply declining interest rates, credit market participants were reminded from several fronts yesterday that the economy might have enough vigor to put upward pressure on rates later this year.

title: FLOUROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
YARDNEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Winans Case Summations
description: Except for a verdict, the final words in the securities fraud trial of a former Wall Street Journal reporter, R. Foster Winans, were heard yesterday as lawyers presented their closing arguments before Judge Charles Stewart in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Witness Testifies In Officer's Death
description: A witness testified in court yesterday that she saw a man ''hovered over'' the form of a transit police officer in a vacant lot in Brooklyn in which the officer was later found shot to death last Sept. 21.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
ABORTION LIMITS REJECTED IN BILL
description: The House Judiciary Committee today rejected efforts to limit abortion rights as part of a bill that supporters said would restore civil rights enforcement powers that the Supreme Court curbed last year.

title: 20,000 IN SRI LANKA SAID TO BE EVICTED
description: A local leader in northern Sri Lanka asserted today that Government troops had ordered about 20,000 Tamils to leave the area within two weeks for security reasons.

title: Judge Bazelon Is Retiring
description: Judge David L. Bazelon, a social activist who has sat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia for nearly 36 years, 16 of those years as chief judge, says he will retire from the bench. The 75-year-old judge, who was appointed to the court in 1949 and has held semi-retired senior status since 1979, said Monday that he would continue to help write opinions on cases he has already heard but would hear no new cases. He said at a judicial conference in Williamsburg, Va., that he had been having problems with his memory and felt it best to step down.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 23, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: INVESTIGATORS IN VON BULOW'S CASE DEFENDS ROLE ON MISSING WITNESS
description: A state police officer said under cross-examination today at the trial of Claus von Bulow that he had not asked European police officials to find Mr. von Bulow's former mistress, Alexandra Isles, because such a search would have been ''asinine.''

title: MIES BUILDING REJECTED IN LONDON
description: Ending years of debate, Britain's Environment Minister today rejected a plan to build a 290-foot office tower designed by the late Mies van der Rohe next to Mansion House, the Lord Mayor's official residence, and across the street from the imposing neo-classical facade of the Bank of England.

title: Bridge: Richard Egan Remembered For His Mischievous Humor
description: The New York tournament scene lost one of its most enthusiastic players when Richard Egan died last month after a long illness.

title: WIDCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STANCHING SALVADOR BLOOD
description: When Jose Napoleon Duarte, the President of El Salvador, returns home from a visit to the United States this week, he will find his country at a crossroads. President Duarte faces a clear choice - to proceed with political negotiations or to continue a devastating civil war.

title: Nicklaus Aims To Keep Title
description: Jack Nicklaus, last year's winner and the only golfer to have won two Memorial tournaments, will lead a field of 99 invited players for the 10th annual event Thursday.

title: Sperry Is Said To Deny Mergers
description: The Sperry Corporation has told a small group of analysts that it is not negotiating a merger with any other company at this time. Earlier this year, Sperry, a New York-based computer maker, discussed a merger with the ITT Corporation, but the negotiations broke off.

title: Longtime Copywriter Helps Newcomers
description: Without a doubt, Whit Hobbs, longtime successful advertising copywriter (and proud of it), was one of the favorite speakers at the recent three-day annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. It was a good dose of nostalgia mixed with plugs for his recently finished book, ''I Love Advertising,'' subtitled ''Especially the Energetic, Talented People.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE COMPANY (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Woman Top Graduate In Coast Guard Class
description: The Coast Guard Academy graduated 191 cadets today with a woman at the head of the class, the first woman to lead a class since the academy became coeducational in 1976.

title: Ferenc Molnar, 89, Is Dead; A Leading West Coast Violist
description: Ferenc Molnar, a founding member of the Roth Quartet and long the principal violist of the San Francisco Symphony, died on May 10 in Walnut Creek, Calif., where he lived. He was 89 years old.

title: Broque Opera Offers A 45-Minute 'Alice'
description: The Broque Opera's production of Robert Chauls's ''Alice in Wonderland,'' which received its New York premiere Sunday afternoon at the Triplex Theater (199 Chambers Street), is a clever, fast-moving 45 minutes of entertainment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MAY 23, 1985

title: GASOLINE SUPPLY UP FOR DRIVING SEASON
description: The nation's gasoline supplies have rebounded from their low levels of the winter and, as the summer driving season opens this weekend, most analysts expect that the replenished stocks will undermine or even halt a 12-week surge in retail gasoline prices.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WOOD moldings, which come in dozens of styles and sizes, are used not only to finish and trim many projects around the house but also to accent or dress up drab flat surfaces such as doors, walls, cabinets and furniture.

title: BRIEFS
description: Central Pacific Corp., Bakersfield, Calif., said that its principal subsidiary, American National Bank, had agreed to sell its mortgage banking operations to Goldome Realty Credit Corp., a unit of Goldome Federal Savings Bank, Buffalo. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have always acted in the best interest of the Navy and my country during my 64 years of military service.

title: CAT AND MOUSE
description: Anatoly Shcharansky is now in his ninth year as a Soviet prisoner: the price of speaking out for the right of Jews to emigrate. Through those years his wife, Avital, has kept his name and fate before us.

title: City to Offer Raise For New Teachers
description: The Koch administration will submit a ''substantially higher'' minimum salary for teachers to an arbitration panel, the city's chief labor negotiator, Robert W. Linn, said yesterday.

title: MIAMI'S BAYFRONT PARK IS FOCUS OF NEW DESIGN FOR DOWNTOWN
description: Miami's Bayfront Park, once a civic showcase that declined into a hangout for derelicts, may soon bloom again under the guidance of the Japanese-American designer-sculptor Isamu Noguchi.

title: SEVERE SETBACK IS SEEN FOR INTERSTATE BANKING
description: The push toward interstate banking has been dealt a severe setback this week by an appeals court ruling involving the Federal Reserve Board and the U.S. Trust Company of New York, bankers and Federal regulators said today.

title: Topics;   Unfortunate Deletions 1,001 Censors
description: An Egyptian judge, shocked at obscenity in the ''Thousand and One Nights,'' recently banned an unexpurgated edition and fined its publisher.

title: L.C.&F. Adds Liquor Client
description: Like Benton & Bowles, whose good fortune is elsewhere in this column, Laurence, Charles & Free yesterday also filled a client category vacant since March. Its vacancy was marked ''distilled spirits'' and is being filled through the National Distillers Products Company.

title: President's Memorial Day
description: President Reagan will place a wreath Monday at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery before flying to Florida for Memorial Day appearances at Walt Disney World's Epcot Center and in Miami, The White House announced today. Mr. Reagan will attend an event sponsored by Disney, ''The President's Inaugural Bands Parade,'' before attending a fund-raising reception in Miami.

title: Chemical Chooses Head for Ohio Unit
description: The Chemical New York Corporation has named William M. Duncan, a senior vice president and head of worldwide consumer lending operations for Chemical Bank, to head the company's proposed Ohio banking subsidiary.

title: Florida Rains Quell All but Five Major Fires
description: As heavy rains Tuesday doused blazes that had rampaged across much of Florida, the authorities said they thought arson might be involved in many cases.

title: NEW VENTURES LAG IN JAPAN
description: All day long, researchers wander in and out of their glass-walled laboratory here, running the experiments that turn out several new inventions each day. They have no regular assigned hours and no dress code, and work on a bonus system with only modest fixed salaries. Outside, they can see what looks like a Japanese-style doghouse, complete with tiled roof and four cats, a tribute to the company president's affection for cats.

title: COMFED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $467,000, or 17 cents a share, from a stock dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank and a nonrecurring gain of $1,331,000 on the sale of mortgage-backed certificates acquired in a merger. c-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $2,901,000 on the sale of mortgage- backed certificates acquired in a merger. Corrected from yesterday's editions in which the company was incorrectly identified as Commonwealth Federal Savings Bank.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
description: b-After a loss of $10,900 from discontinued operations and a gain of $925,300 on the sale of discontinued operations. Share earnings do not reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid on May 31.

title: Medicine and Politics
description: Noam Chomsky, the original choice as the Cornell University Medical College speaker at commencement Tuesday, voluntarily withdrew after some graduating students wrote to him that his views on Israel and Zionism ''would deeply offend a large proportion of students.''

title: TOYS 'R' US INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in January.

title: Books: Royal Commander
description: MOUNTBATTEN. By Philip Ziegler. 784 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95. THERE can be few more difficult jobs than writing an authorized biography. Tribute must be paid Philip Ziegler for a balanced, detailed picture of Earl Mountbatten of Burma; a picture that reveals the subject's strengths, which were many, and his weaknesses as an admiral, a supreme commander and a man.

title: Transco to Buy Kaneb Units
description: The Transco Energy Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire most of Kaneb Services Inc.'s coal operations and reserves, for $245 million, including the assumption of $7 million in debt.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,914,000 for the quarter and 9 months and pre-tax charges of $27,000,000 for the quarter from the company's previously announced reorganization. c-Net income which includes an extraordinary gain of $741,000 for the 9 months.

title: NEW FAUCET SETS FOR THE BATH
description: FAUCET and spout sets for the bath come in almost every material and color imaginable. Sets by many manufacturers are at Davis & Warshow, 1033 Third Avenue, near 61st Street. Among them is a new design by Grohe, made of white enamel and costing $209 for the set. A more elaborate crescent spout faucet by Suite 10 pours water to give the impression of a waterfall, and comes in brass or chrome, or a combination of both; prices start at $400. Kohler has recently introduced the Multi-Swivel spout - the neck of the faucet turns in any direction. In chrome it costs $98.60, in brass $127.85.

title: WILL 'M.D.' MEAN 'MORE DOLLARS?'
description: A fundamental shift is occurring in American medical care. It is a shift of extraordinary economic proportions that threatens to transform the ethical foundations of medical practice.

title: Nurses Taking Charge
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PALESTINIAN-SHIITE FIGHT FOR BEIRUT CAMPS INTENSIFIES
description: Palestinian guerrillas deployed in the Lebanese mountains fired volleys of rockets into Beirut's southern suburbs today in an effort to relieve the pressure on three Palestinian refugee camps, which have been under attack by Shiite fighters since Sunday.

title: ROLFITE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORPS AIDE SEES NO ALTERNATIVE TO THE WESTWAY
description: A top official of the Army Corps of Engineers testified yesterday that there was no ''practical alternative'' that would satisfy the ''overall goals'' of the Westway project.

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,313,000.

title: A B-1 Bake Sale?
description: The Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, also known as Sane, has been opposed to military spending for decades and keeps devising new ways to attract publicity. Today Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado is to appear at what Sane is calling its First Annual Pentagon Bake Sale, in the Cannon House Office Building. On sale will be edible B-1 Brownies, Star Wars Crisps, MX Macaroons and Peanut Cluster bombs. The ultimate goal of all this, a leaflet says, is to see the day ''our schools get all the money they need and the Air Force has to hold a bake sale to buy a bomber.''

title: New Option Trading
description: The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange said yesterday that they would begin trading put and call options on over-the-counter stocks June 3. For the Big Board, the issues are Apollo Computer, DSC Communications and Intergraph Corporation. The Amex will trade those plus Apple Computer, Cipher Data Products, Intel Corporation, Lotus Development Corporation, Mylan Laboratories, Network Systems Corporation and Tandem Corporation.

title: Polish Students Protest Effort to Curb Autonomy
description: Hundreds of students at Warsaw University staged a protest rally today against plans by the Communist authorities' to limit student self-government and to exert more official control over courses and teaching methods.

title: Projects of a Provoking Sort
description: Asked a second time, Alfred S. Regnery still would not answer the question.

title: Chase Won't Sell Econometrics Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said today that it had ended talks with McGraw-Hill Inc. over the proposed sale of its Chase Econometrics subsidiary, and it will retain and expand the economic forecasting firm.

title: AS THOUSANDS PROTEST, CITY BACKS TRASH PLANT
description: As thousands of Hasidim demonstrated against the construction of a garbage-burning incinerator in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, city officials said yesterday that an independent consultant had reported that the proposed plant was safe.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CONCERT: TENOR AND BARITONE
description: WHILE Sunday evening's joint concert at Carnegie Recital Hall by the baritone Hernan Pelayo and the tenor Charles Gavolan was not quite the ''extraordinary experience'' promised by their handbills, the program did offer some diverting moments.

title: New Federal Judge in Jersey
description: Joseph H. Rodriguez Jr. was sworn in today as a Federal District Court judge.

title: YORK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $57,000 for the quarter and $108,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $31,000 for the quarter and $50,000 for the 6 months.

title: INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Drexel's Added Fee: $15 Million or Zero
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has already earned $15 million for helping T. Boone Pickens line up financing in his bid, now aborted, for control of the Unocal Corporation.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,621,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: FREQUENCY CONTROL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $35,000 for the quarter and $107,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: MURPHY, G C CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-After a charge of $2,376,000 for fees and expenses related to the termination of a proposed Esop transaction.

title: Macy's Net Off 12.6% in Period
description: R.H. Macy & Company reported yesterday that its quarterly earnings in the latest quarter dropped 12.6 percent as sales increased 5 percent.

title: LONGER PERIOD FOR TOXIC SUITS WINS BACKING IN STATE SENATE
description: After five years of withholding their support, the leaders of the State Senate today reversed themselves and proposed legislation that would give people exposed to toxic substances more time to file suits seeking damages.

title: Squabble on Slopes
description: After months of squabbling, the United States Ski Team and its downhill star, Bill Johnson, the Olympic gold medalist, may have come to a final parting. Johnson, who had a bitter dispute with the team over the division of proceeds from a movie based on his life, has indicated that he will join a professional tour, according to Harald Schoenhaar, head of the team's racing program.

title: YOUTH SEIZED
description: Seven people were killed here early today when a fire swept through a three-story frame house, trapping the residents in their bedrooms.

title: GANDHI STRESSES INDIA-SOVIET LINK
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi ended two days of talks here today with praise for Soviet support of India and criticism of some American policies.

title: AHEAD BY 4-0, METS LOSE
description: Terry Kennedy's line drive kicked up the dirt near the perimeter of the infield, and the second baseman Kelvin Chapman flung himself to his right. The ball scooted with one quick hop under Chapman's elbow, and that was how the Padres completed their comeback last night.

title: SAUDIS KEEP THE FAITH, FENCE IN THE FOREIGNERS
description: ''Islam is the official religion,'' reads the service directory at the Hyatt Regency Hotel here. ''Churches of other religious denominations do not exist in the kingdom.''

title: BINGO KING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Teen-Age Pregnancies Up, Births Down, Report Shows
description: United States health officials say the birth rate for teen-age girls is going down but pregnancy rates continue to increase.

title: Ex-Midway Executive Leads Takeover Move
description: Kenneth T. Carlson calls himself one of the originators of no-frills airlines.

title: Republicans File Suit Over Indiana Election
description: Lawyers for the Republican Party filed suit today on behalf of 32 voters whose uncounted ballots might have decided the disputed Eighth District Congressional election that eventually was awarded to the Democratic incumbent.

title: THEATER: MASSINGER'S 'NEW WAY'
description: THE Acting Company, America's coast-to-coast classical theater, is making an all-too-brief stop in New York, performing three plays in repertory through this weekend at Marymount Manhattan Theater. The series began Tuesday with a robust production of Philip Massinger's Elizabethan comedy, ''A New Way to Pay Old Debts,'' staged by the company's artistic director, Michael Kahn.

title: ROSE'S STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
L.I. TEACHERS GO TO COURT ON TESTS FOR DRUGS
description: Union leaders and officials of a Long Island school district were in State Supreme Court today, debating the district's new policy requiring all new teachers and those seeking tenure to submit to tests for drug use.

title: Eastern Air Adds Key Post
description: Eastern Airlines has named Joe Leonard, a senior vice president, to the new post of executive vice president and general manager of airline operations.

title: POPE'S VISIT TO LOW COUNTRIES: CLASH OF VALUES
description: The visit of Pope John Paul II to the Low Countries, which ended Tuesday, is likely to prove important for the future of the Roman Catholic Church, not just for the way the Pope received criticism, but also for the course he outlined in the face of the attacks.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amfac Inc., a diversified company based in San Francisco, has appointed Richard L. Griffith executive vice president and chairman of its Agriculture and Property Group, to be renamed Amfac Hawaii Inc.

title: CLASSICAL STYLE, SHERBET TONES
description: A YEAR and a half ago, when Baker Furniture asked the interior designer John Saladino, above, to design a new furniture collection, he came up with the Facade Collection - 60 pieces that include upholstered furniture and lacquered cabinets, above, as well as metal tables, below. ''The furniture is meant to be classical and sympathetic to any given environment,'' Mr. Saladino said.

title: WOODS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TREATMENT FOR BLEEDING IN PREMATURE BABIES
description: Doctors can prevent brain hemorrhages, a common complication among premature infants with breathing disorders, by using a drug to paralyze them temporarily for their first three days of life, a new study shows.

title: Comparable-Worth Problems in the Marketplace
description: To the Editor:

title: ETHIOPIA DEBATES HOW TO FEED ITSELF
description: In the months since the famine in Ethiopia became known around the world, the primary concern has been to find ways to get food from outside to the millions of starving people here.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: INJURY RESEARCH IS URGED
description: Injuries cost more money and kill more young people than any other health problem, but are given short shrift when research money is distributed, according to a new study.

title: ALL THE PRESIDENT'S POPCORN
description: The American tradition of ''Saturday night at the movies'' is alive and well at the White House.

title: Dissident Pastor Seized In Church After 8 Days
description: The police broke into the barricaded Nativity Lutheran Church today and arrested a dissident minister who had been holed up inside for eight days.

title: DISTURBING PORTENT IN RECORD-BUSINESS STATISTICS
description: AMID the celebratory statistics for the record business in 1984, there was a disturbing portent. As sales and profits went up, the number of new releases dropped by one-quarter.

title: FERTILITY DRUG: SINGLE BIRTH IS INTENDED
description: The company that produces the fertility drug used by a woman who gave birth to septuplets said yesterday that in normal use the drug helped infertile women to have single births.

title: UNION SQUARE PARK REOPENS WITH A LUSH GRANDEUR
description: Union Square Park, once a symbol of the city's grandeur and in recent years a symbol of despair, opened its newly lush, green lawns to the public yesterday after a $3.6 million restoration.

title: READE, WALTER ORGANIZAION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the latest first quarter and $27,000 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: FIRST CHINA EUROBOND OFFERING
description: A syndicate of 10 Western banks, led by Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest commercial bank, has initiated the first Eurobond issue ever guaranteed by the Bank of China, even though nearly $100 million of pre-revolution Chinese government-backed bonds are still in default.

title: GIANTS ARE TRYING GOODE AT NEW SPOT
description: Conrad Goode remembers hearing about Kevin Belcher's serious highway accident last January. What he did not know then was that the accident might have propelled him into Belcher's job as the Giants' starting center, a vast improvement over Goode's 1984 status as a seldom-used rookie offensive tackle.

title: LAWMAKER MAY CONSIDER CUT IN MINIMUM WAGE
description: The chairman of the House Labor Committee said today that he might accept a Reagan Administration proposal for a lower minimum wage for teen-age workers if he and Labor Secretary Bill Brock could agree on a larger package of measures to combat youth unemployment.

title: McEnroe, Connors Quit
description: John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors, who had objected to signing a pledge to obey a code of conduct for United States Davis Cup players confirmed yesterday what had long been expected. McEnroe announced that he would not play on this year's team, and Connors said he would never play on the team again, according to a report by The Associated Press.

title: CREAMTION IS URGED IN CHINA IN A CAMPAIGN TO SAVE LAND
description: After a lull of a few years the Government has returned to the offensive on an issue that stirs deep feelings among many of China's one billion people: cremation or burial for the dead.

title: Bulgarian Puts the Death Toll In Terrorist Attacks at Eight
description: The chief Bulgarian prosecutor has said that terrorist attacks have left eight people dead and nine injured, the press agency Tanyug said today.

title: Sather May Shake Up Oilers
description: Glen Sather wasn't saying, but his actions were talking for him.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
POP:SONGS BY MORRISON
description: It's a pity Van Morrison doesn't tour more often. On record, his recent songs tend to blur together, but Sunday at the Beacon Theater (Broadway at 74th Street), they held the audience rapt. As in a gospel performance, Mr. Morrison's singing lends earthly drama to ruminations about abstract, spiritual hopes.

title: HOUSE REJECTS 3 ALTERNATIVES TO BUDGET PLAN BACKED BY DEMOCRATS
description: The House of Representatives today decisively defeated three alternative budgets as it moved toward a vote on the Democratic leadership's 1986 spending plan.

title: Chevy Chase Unit
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced that it had granted Federal deposit insurance to the Chevy Chase Savings and Loan Association. Chevy Chase, the largest thrift institution in the Maryland Savings Share Insurance Corporation, is the first member of the private insurance fund to get Federal deposit insurance, a bank board spokesman said.

title: REAGAN LAUDS MILITARY AT ANNAPOLIS
description: Facing Congressional demands to spend less than he wants for the military, President Reagan told the graduating class of the United States Naval Academy today that an increasingly powerful military was the best deterrent to war.

title: Accounts
description: Avon Products Inc. has assigned a special project to MCA Advertising. People

title: INJURY SEEN TO SHOE INDUSTRY
description: The International Trade Commission held unanimously today that the domestic shoe industry had suffered serious economic damage from rising imports - a finding that could lead to import curbs and higher retail shoe prices.

title: SWEDISH CHAIN TO OPEN AMERICAN STORE
description: It is a well-known name in Europe, with more than 60 stores selling its line of inexpensive Scandinavian furniture. It is one of the largest furniture chains in the world, with more than $1 billion in sales each year.

title: BLUE JAYS OVERWHELM WHITE SOX BY 10-0
description: Dave Stieb and two relievers combined on a four-hitter and George Bell drove in three runs tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays crushed the Chicago White Sox by 10-0.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page April 20 about public-library circulation of videotape cassettes misstated the policy in New York City. The New York Public Library and its branches indeed lend tapes; they have a total of about 1,850 available.

title: LLOYD REBELLIOUS 'NAMES'
description: For nearly 300 years, Lloyd's of London has sold insurance backed, ultimately, by individuals. Organized into underwriting syndicates, groups of investors reaped profits when premiums outpaced claims - and promised to be personally liable, without limit, if too many disasters occurred.

title: MACY, R H & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: The 9 months results are for 40 weeks for the latest period and 39 weeks for the year-ago period.

title: Canadians Buy Fahnestock
description: Nesbitt Thomson Inc. of Canada has agreed to acquire Fahnestock & Company, one of the oldest investment banking and brokerage firms in the United States.

title: STUDY FINDS POVERTY AMONG CHILDREN IS INCREASING
description: Two Government agencies sounded an alarm today about the problem of poverty among children, saying it had ''grown deeper and more widespread'' in the last decade.

title: TELECONFERENCING SYSTEMS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: JONAS H. OTTENS
description: Jonas H. Ottens, a former partner at Salomon Brothers, died Monday at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home, York Avenue and 72d Street.

title: THE CENTER GRABS HOLD
description: Pundits search for patterns. If three seemingly isolated events can be linked, the ''triangulation trick'' may be played and great movements may thus be discerned.

title: GLENZ LEADS DODGE BY FIVE STROKES
description: The first two days of the Dodge Open have resembled the filming of a movie - a scene here, a shot there, some dialogue inserted, and it all comes together in the editing room. Similarly, 30 of the 60 professionals in this tournament played their second round today before completing their first one.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THURSDAY, MAY 23, 1985

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $145,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,161,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income which is after a loss of $81,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Nuclear Plant in Last Tests
description: The Wolf Creek nuclear power plant today began its first self-sustained nuclear reaction, the Kansas Gas and Electric Company announced. The company said the step was the beginning of the last series of tests before the $3 billion plant begins commercial operations, planned for September.

title: Buddhists More Active
description: The Buddhist establishment of Sri Lanka appears to be moving toward a larger role in politics and national security in an effort to force a resolution of the increasingly violent problem of Tamil separatism.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Carl Lewis, bothered by a tender right hamstring from a cramp he suffered while long-jumping in the Pepsi Invitational last Saturday, has withdrawn from the Bruce Jenner Classic Saturday at San Jose, Calif., where was entered in the 100- and 200-meter dashes. . . . E. Gordon Gee, president of West Virginia University, said he had decided to keep the school in the Atlantic 10 Conference, despite pressure from fans and some athletic officials to seek a stronger affiliation, either by replacing Tulane in the Metro Conference or forming a new, all-sports Eastern league. . . . David Rice, former Fordham football coach who has been the school's athletic director since 1979, has resigned to become athletic director at Florida International University in Miami. . . . Willis Reed, the former Knick captain who recently resigned as coach at Creighton to become an assistant with the Atlanta Hawks, underwent abdominal surgery on Tuesday and was reported in good condition at a hospital in Omaha. Reed suffers from diverticulitis, an inflammation of the intestines. . . . Steve Shutt, the high-scoring Canadien left wing and a 13-year veteran who was traded to the Los Angeles Kings last year, said he was retiring after the Kings had returned his contract to Montreal.

title: Air Crash Kills Pilot of Plane As Helicopter Lands Safely
description: An Army helicopter from the Fort Riley military base and a private single-engine airplane collided over an open field today, killing the pilot of the civilian craft, the authorities said.

title: GRADUATE CADETS INCLUDE REFUGEES
description: Two cadets who were born in South Vietnam and fled the Communist takeover threw their white caps into the air today and graduated with 1,008 classmates from the United States Military Academy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE COLLECTORS More people, probably, collect photographs than collect paintings. The pictures, though, are usually those that document the family, and most are stowed in storage spaces until a big moment demands their presence. Among the affluent, the big collectors of paintings and similar art may outnumber the big collectors of photographs. Yet New York is fortunate to have two exhibitions of collectors' photos on view at the same time.

title: Gas Project Talks in Snag
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation today broke off negotiations on further Government subsidies for the $2.1 billion Great Plains coal gasification project, threatening the future of the nation's first large commercial synthetic fuels plant.

title: Program of Songs
description: ''Some Enchanted Evening,'' a program of pop and original songs, will be presented by John Braswell on May 28 and 29 at Cafe La Mama, 74 East Fourth Street. Mr. Braswell, who has worked in musical productions Off Broadway, is a professor in the drama department at Sarah Lawrence College.

title: A Peacemaker Is Slain After a Traffic Dispute
description: Three men were shot, one fatally, yesterday after they broke up a fight between two drivers over a minor traffic accident in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn and one motorist later returned in anger, the police said.

title: CONVENIENT FOOD MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 21
Three State Workers Cleared in Drug Case
description: Charges against three of 14 state employees accused of cocaine possession have been dropped and the employees will be reinstated in their jobs with back pay, state officials said today.

title: ADVANCED GENETIC SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AFFORDING A CHILD: PARENTS WORRY AS COSTS KEEP RISING
description: SLIGHTLY more than 20 years ago, Elizabeth Lewin gave birth to a daughter. ''I didn't think once about how much it would cost to raise a child,'' Mrs. Lewin says now. ''It wasn't even an issue.''

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Jeanne Stark, Pianist, Plays a Lyrical Bach
description: The pianist Jeanne Stark opened her Saturday afternoon concert at Carnegie Recital Hall with Bach's Partita No. 2 in C Minor. This was not the charged, pointillist Baroque playing exemplified by the late Glenn Gould, nor was it the ponderous, romanticized Bach of an early generation.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER IN REVIVAL OF 'COPPELIA'
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER has revived its rollicking production of ''Coppelia,'' beginning with a perfect cast of principals - Cynthia Gregory and Fernando Bujones.

title: CALENDAR: DISPLAYS OF CERAMIC WORK
description: Architectural Ceramics: Eight Concepts, American Craft Museum II, International Paper Plaza, 77 West 45th Street, 212-391-8770.

title: HERS
description: LAST Christmas, my husband and I gave each other something we will always have: a Chapter 208 1B divorce on the ground of irretrievable breakdown. For this relatively unoriginal idea, no expense was spared. One week after the decree, we happened to run into each other at the bank, where we were applying for loans so we could pay the last two of our five progressively pitiless lawyers. When the loan officer asked us if we knew one another, I was reminded of a story. It seems that a famous actress met a man at a party one evening, extended her hand and said, ''You look very familiar to me. Have we met?'' to which he replied, ''Yes, I was once your husband.'' Now that our shared history was expunged from the record, we too were that odd pair of former spouses related by divorce.

title: Seoul Students Occupy U.S. Cultural Center
description: A group of university students today broke into the United States cultural center in Seoul, South Korea, taking over one floor of the building in what American officials described as an unarmed protest.

title: 172 ARE WOUNDED
description: A car bomb exploded in predominantly Christian East Beirut today, killing at least 50 people and wounding 172, according to radio reports tonight.

title: Securities Backed By Co-op Loans
description: The first public issue of mortgage-backed securities to include co-op loans was offered yesterday by the Manufacturers Hanover Mortgage Corporation, through underwriters led by First Boston Corporation.

title: CUOMO PROPOSING STATE GUIDELINES ON TERMINALLY ILL
description: Two new rules that would establish guidelines for halting life-sustaining medical efforts for terminally ill patients were proposed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Alleghany to Buy Chicago Title
description: The Alleghany Corporation will acquire the Chicago Title and Trust Company from the Lincoln National Corporation, for about $128 million, the companies said. Alleghany agreed to pay Lincoln $60 million in cash, plus a six-year $68 million note paying a market rate of interest.

title: Firefighter and Victim
description: As he crawled blindly through Apartment 4, all that Warren Forsyth knew was that he could hear someone moaning.

title: ASSEMBLY VITES NEW PLATES
description: After queries about artistic merit and color schemes, the State Assembly voted 118 to 12 today to issue new license plates adorned with a decal of the Statue of Liberty for the state's 9.2 million vehicles.

title: OFFICER'S WISH FULFILLED
description: Why would a man of 63 who has been No. 2 at a major corporation, who only recently finished building his retirement home, and who suffered an ulcer but is now in good health, take on the chore of heading a huge military contractor that is in poor standing with the Pentagon?

title: STUDY SAYS EXERCISE MAY MAKE WOMEN TEMPORARILY INFERTILE
description: Running and other hard exercise may make many young women temporarily infertile, even though they may not realize it because the menstrual cycle seems normal, a new study suggests.

title: McDonald's Converts Drive-In To Museum
description: The first McDonald's Museum was dedicated Tuesday at the site where 30 years ago Ray Kroc opened his first drive-in restaurant in a Chicago suburb.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Beirut yesterday misstated the religious affiliation of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. He is an Alawite.

title: FRONTIER CUTBACKS
description: Frontier Holdings Inc. said it was cutting its Denver-based work force of 366 by about 50 management and non-contract personnel and about 10 clerical workers in a move to become more cost effective.

title: Industry Uncertain On Newsprint Costs
description: After four recent postponements of price increases, the newsprint industry is wondering whether the latest rise, scheduled for July 1, will take hold.

title: CARLING O'KEEFE LTD reports earnings for Year to Mar 31
Koch and His Man
description: Mayor Koch added law enforcement to his duties yesterday.

title: A NEW ENGLAND WALLPAPER SHOW
description: ''We hope to dispel the myth that New Englanders were prim and uncolorful,'' said Richard C. Nylander, the curator of collections for the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities. Mr. Nylander was discussing the current show, ''Off the Walls: Historic Wallpapers in New England,'' an exhibition of 200 wallpapers from New England homes from 1700 to 1920 at the the Museum of Our National Heritage in Lexington, Mass. A companion show, ''New England Furniture: Colonial Era,'' is now on display at the DeCordova and Dana Museum and Park in nearby Lincoln, and both exhibitions are sponsored by the preservation society.

title: ENCOR PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NORTHEAST SAVINGS FEDERAL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,978,000.

title: PHILADELPHIA GETS AN INQUIRY PANEL
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode appointed a commission today to investigate the city's handling of last week's fiery siege of a house occupied by armed radicals.

title: NEW DIRECTORY FINDS DECLINE IN NUMBER OF U.S. CATHOLICS
description: The nation's Roman Catholic population dropped slightly in 1984, with the Archdioceses of Boston and New York leading in the decline, according to the latest Official Catholic Directory.

title: NEW MEXICO & ARIZONA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Down the River
description: Chris Daniels is a senior at Hamilton College in upstate Clinton, N.Y., who serves as the coach of both the men's and women's rowing teams there.

title: B.&B. GETS FAST-FOOD ACCOUNT
description: BENTON & BOWLES has become the agency for Rax Restaurants, the fast-food chain based in Columbus, Ohio, that claims to have pioneered the fast-food salad bar, the stuffed potato and the greenhouse ambiance. But more important, it plans to double its ad spending in the next 12 months, to $10 million.

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a pretax charge of $106,000 representing equity in the loss of an affiliate.

title: No Easy Answer
description: The Detroit Tigers suffered the fifth loss in their last seven games Tuesday night, due largely to six and one-third innings of no-hit ball by California's Kirk McCaskill, and afterward Manager Sparky Anderson had no easy answers: ''I don't know if it was the kid's pitching or our hitting. It's getting hard to tell.''

title: No Halt in Boston Harbor Suit
description: A Federal District judge today rejected a state request to block action in a lawsuit brought by the Environmental Protection Agency to force cleanup of Boston Harbor.

title: MILLICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 10.00-10.50** Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Best Sixth Man
description: He was a starter for a good part of the season, but to a few dozen basketball writers and broadcasters, 27-year-old Kevin McHale of the Boston Celtics is the quintessential sixth man. For the second year in a row, the forward was named winner of the Sixth Man Award honoring nonstarters who make key contributions.

title: Filling the Language Gap With Esperanto
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Clears Officers In 'Sleeper Hold' Case
description: A grand jury today decided against indicting two white police officers in the death of an off-duty black security guard who was subdued through use of a ''sleeper hold.''

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WHY CODERO PASSED UP BIG PAYDAY
description: Angel Cordero Jr.'s decision Tuesday did not add up. He was passing up a possible $260,000 payday aboard Spend a Buck in the Jersey Derby next Monday to honor a commitment to ride Track Barron in the Metropolitan Handicap. Victory in the Metropolitan would be worth only about $15,000 to Cordero, and he would be unlikely to earn $100,000 more on Track Barron all year. However, three factors weighed against the money, making his choice at least understandable.

title: PAIN AND BRAVERY AT A CLINIC FOR ILL CHILDREN
description: Andrea Caley, who is considered a trouper, came in a white knit cap in her brother Daniel's stroller - the cap because she had lost her hair, the stroller because she was tired. Her mother, Kristin, had Daniel, a package of homemade cereal candy for the staff, and a smile. Her 4-year-old sister Roberta pushed the stroller.

title: MARINERS' YOUNG STOPS YANKEES, 4-1
description: The Yankees knew they could not keep winning here forever. In their last six games in the Kingdome, they played as if it were their second home. But their offense tonight lasted just one inning, and they lost, 4-1, to the Seattle Mariners.

title: NAVY SAYS IT KNEW OF LEWIS'S PLANS
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. said today that the retirement of the chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation did not affect his decision on how to discipline the company over its dealings with the Navy.

title: Stocks Off Again on Profit Taking
description: The stock market suffered another bout of profit taking yesterday, but the Dow Jones industrial average managed to close above the 1,300 level despite an excursion below that support area that lasted much of the session.

title: CONSERVING WATER BEGINS AT HOME
description: ALTHOUGH a slight drip in a single faucet may be neglected for some time because it seems nothing more than a minor nuisance, the fact is that the droplets can add up to hundreds of gallons of wasted water over a few months.

title: NEW ZEALAND LEADER WON'T MEET SHULTZ
description: Prime Minister David Lange of New Zealand has informed the United States that he will not meet with Secretary of State George P. Shultz during the secretary's Asian trip in July, State Department officials said today.

title: CELTICS AND LAKERS REACH N.B.A. FINAL
description: Larry Bird stripped Andrew Toney of the ball with five seconds remaining tonight at Boston Garden to put the Celtics in the championship round.

title: Walters Is Sworn In
description: Vice President Bush swore in Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, as chief United States representative at the United Nations today. General Walters succeeds Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, who resigned the post to return to private life.

title: Two Laotian Refugees Perform at Museum
description: The Society for Asian Music offered New Yorkers a rare chance to hear music from Laos last weekend. Both the khene (mouth organ) player Phomma Vilay and the singer-dancer Khambong Pongdara were refugees from the Pathet Lao who came to the United States by way of Thailand. Sunday's concert, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, included duets and khene solos.

title: BILL TO EASE RESTRICTIONS ON ARCHEOLOGICAL IMPORTS IS DISPUTED
description: A proposed bill that would ease import restrictions on archeological artifacts from foreign countries drew sharp criticism today from museum and Government officials who said it could encourage looting.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANT NOW TO ENJOY LATE-SUMMER COLOR
description: WITH the end of the spring planting season in sight, thought might be given to late summer, when garden color often is sparse. August-blooming trees, shrubs and perennials should be planted now - before hot weather arrives - to increase the likelihood of flowers this summer.

title: Inertia Benefits Bell Investors
description: AN example of how simple shareholder inertia can pay off handsomely in the market is seen in the performance of the components of the ''old'' American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock.

title: Required Reading;   Das Weisse Haus
description: Excerpts from the May 17 issue of Frankfurter Allgemeine Magazin, translated from an article by a West German correspondent, Leo Wieland, describing his impressions of a White House press conference:

title: ALTEX OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
E.E.C. Refinances $1.8 Billion Issue
description: The European Economic Community is refinancing its outstanding $1.8 billion issue of floating-rate notes with a new $1.8 billion issue of floating-rate notes that will bear a slightly lower interest rate. Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., underwriter for the record-sized $1.8 billion note issue sold in July 1983, is also leading the underwriting group for the second financing.

title: DAYETT'S SLAM PACES CUBS, 7-4
description: Brian Dayett, a pinch-hitter, got his first major league grand slam today, drilling the first pitch he saw in the sixth inning to help the Chicago Cubs beat the Cincinnati Reds, 7-4.

title: SIX SURVIVING SEPTUPLETS WEAKEN, BUT DOCTOR SAYS THEY'RE 'FIGHTERS'
description: The condition of six babies born prematurely to a California teacher worsened slightly today, the doctor in charge of their care said. The smallest baby, a boy, was said to be at the greatest risk.

title: Rev. Victor Wierwille, Founder of The Way
description: The Rev. Victor Paul Wierwille, founder of The Way International, died Monday near New Knoxville, Ohio, the headquarters of his unorthodox ministry.

title: CONWEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBS Will Consider Takeover Bars
description: CBS Inc., indicating a possible shift in strategy in its battle against Ted Turner's hostile takeover bid, said yesterday that it ''intends to examine'' the possibility of acquisitions, divestitures or a recapitalization of the company.

title: TEXAS HOUSE ACTS IN DISPUTE ON SPORTS RULE
description: Disturbed by court interference in the emotional matter of athletic championships, the Legislature today asked Texas judges to exercise ''judicial restraint'' in dealing with new eligibility rules and let the teams play ball.

title: REAGAN COMPROMISE EFFORT ON MX COLLAPSES IN SENATE
description: Reagan Administration attempts to find a compromise formula that would continue deployment of the MX missile and stave off a likely defeat in the Senate collapsed tonight.

title: OAK PARK: A WRIGHT HOUSE TOUR
description: Meg and Peter Klinkow were not exactly thrilled that 5,000 sightseers would be trampling through their living room and dining room on the third weekend in May.

title: Topics;   Unfortunate Deletions Mover and Shaker
