description: With the departure of James Larocca for a private-sector job, New York State loses a Transportation Commissioner of radiant sincerity and a determination to digest every footnote and cross every ''t'' on his way to accomplish the tasks that governors of the state have assigned him.

title: Several Banks Cutting Rates on Consumer Loans
description: Several banks have begun to reduce their interest rates on consumer loans following the recent easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve System.

title: Out of Town Dream Team
description: There are now 60 or so former Yankees and Mets playing in distant locales around the major leagues, and as a group they're doing just fine this season. In fact, the best 25 of them would make up a legitimate pennant contender, and perhaps a legitimate world-beater.

title: Norway Oil Price Cut
description: Eight of Statoil's 10 contract customers have agreed to a May petroleum price of $27.20 to $27.50 a barrel, down from just under $28 a barrel in April, industry sources said today.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $411,000.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
The Trenton-Albany Summit
description: Angered at attempts by New York City to block Federal development money for the New Jersey waterfront, Garden State officials vow to sabotage Westway. New Yorkers enraged at the provocation threaten revenge with a legal attack on New Jersey's chemical industry, which sometimes pollutes New York air.

title: SALVADORAN RIGHT, HURT IN VOTE, SEEMS ADRIFT
description: They still occasionally inveigh against the coming Communist invasion and speak emotionally of unspecified threats to the fatherland. But according to many politicians and foreign diplomats here, some of the steam seems to have gone out of El Salvador's right-wing political parties.

title: Cuomo and Son
description: The Manhattan District Attorney does not let his assistant district attorneys dabble in politics. And Governor Cuomo has been suggesting that his son would leave the D.A.'s office, which he joined a year ago, to start thinking about the 1986 gubernatorial campaign.

title: 8 ACCUSED OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused a printing company clerk, her husband and six others with earning $157,244 through illegal insider trading, using advance knowledge of stock tips appearing in the publications of Value Line Inc., the investment advisory service.

title: U.S. AIDES EXAMINE REFUGEE PROGRAM
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were looking at the possibility that some of the 15,000 Cambodian refugees in Thailand who have been ruled ineligible for admission to the United States might deserve a second evaluation.

title: MCI-A.T.&T. Suit
description: A Federal jury began deliberations over what damages the MCI Communications Corporation should receive from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for being denied access to long-distance telephone lines in the 1970's.

title: Blaring at, and From, Fidel
description: Radio Marti, the Reagan Administration's pet project for annoying Fidel Castro, has done just that. After months of delay, the station made its debut on Monday, Cuba's Independence Day. Instantly and angrily, Mr. Castro retaliated by suspending the only agreement Cuba has reached with this Administration. The gate is now closed to legal emigration from Cuba and to the repatriation of 3,000 ''excludables'' with criminal records whom he dumped on Florida in the 1980 Mariel exodus.

title: HBO DRAM REUNITES WARTIME LOVERS
description: EVERY so often a production comes along that is so flat it seems to defy normal visibility. No amount of twisting or squinting can keep it from fading before your very eyes. ''Reunion at Fairborough,'' an HBO Premiere Film, is precisely that. The unsettling experience of watching it can be sampled on Home Box Office's pay-cable channel this afternoon at 12:30 or on Monday at 8 P.M.

title: NATO COOL TO U.S. PROGRAM FOR MODERN CHEMICAL ARMS
description: Defense Ministers of the Atlantic alliance agreed today on a program to improve nonnuclear defenses and reduce reliance on nuclear arms, but avoided a United States proposal for production of new chemical weapons.

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-After unusual charges of approximately $2.7 million taken in the fourth quarter primarily to recognize excess and obsolete inventory and to write down certain fixed assets. These charges were partially offset by a gain of approximately $2 million on the sale of the company's Kings Highway manufacturing plant.

title: ACCORD GAINED ON FEES IN PORT FOR CONTAINERS
description: Union, industry and port officials yesterday announced a new agreement that is expected to make New York more competitive with other ports by revising the way fringe benefits for longshoremen are financed.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOODS DISTRIBTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BROADCASTERS ASKED TO SAVE FILM FOOTAGE
description: A coalition of film and television industry executives, museum officials and film archivists voted today to urge the nation's television broadcasters to impose a temporary moratorium on the destruction of all film and video footage while the coalition develops criteria to determine which material should be saved for future generations.

title: SEAMAN IS CHARGED WITH HELPING FATHER SPY
description: A Navy seaman on the aircraft carrier Nimitz was charged today with aiding his father in smuggling secret documents to the Soviet Union.

title: LASER PRECISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Treaties Can't Abridge Rights of Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Owners Set Rosters at 45 Players
description: National Football League owners voted today to reduce team rosters from 49 players to 45 for the 1985 season.

title: Management Lineup Attracted Bid by Telesis
description: The Pacific Telesis Group, which announced on Tuesday that it had signed an agreement to acquire Communications Industries for $431 million, was after more than just the paging services and cellular telephone operations the Dallas-based company provides.

title: WESTERN STEER-MOM 'N' POP'S reports earnings for Year to Feb 22
How to Save the Thrifts
description: Depositors in many privately insured savings and loan associations have found out the hard way that their money was not in good hands. In fact, the go-go lending policies that have undone thrift institutions in Ohio and Maryland are quite common in federally insured savings and loans too.

title: E.T. Pitches In For Special Olympics
description: After the motion picture ''E.T.'' was released, its director, Steven Spielberg, received hundreds of letters from the parents of retarded children, who apparently felt a special affinity for the lost and friendless alien.

title: PEOPLE
description: Donald B. Weber has been named senior vice president, director of client services, at Rumrill-Hoyt/Rochester.

title: Tiny Brace for a Big Man
description: The knee brace is lightweight, but then again, it's from California.

title: DANCE: DANCEAFRICA
description: ''THE Grand Celebration'' was the name given to this year's DanceAfrica series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Judging from Sunday afternoon's performance, no better name could have been found.

title: MEADOW PLANTINGS NEED PREPARATION
description: STEPHEN KENNEY'S advice to the would-be meadow gardener: ''Expect trouble.''

title: INNOVATIVE FINNISH DESIGNER
description: Tapio Wirkkala, the sculptor and designer who was one of the pioneers of postwar Scandinavian design, died Sunday at the age of 69 at his home in Esbo, Finland. The cause of death was not announced.

title: EAST PARK REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results include gains on real estate investment sales of $345,000 in the latest quarter and $91,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: Union Pacific To Buy Katy Line
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said that it would acquire the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad from Katy Industries, for $108 million.

title: Let Us Negotiate Realistically at Geneva
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW SHEET PATTERNS SAIL INTO SUMMER
description: LAST week, hundreds of department store buyers from across the nation came to Manhattan for the semiannual bed linen introductions by major manufacturers.

title: HIGH COST OF TV ADS FOR JERSEY CANDIDATES IS SHAPING THE MESSAGE
description: The absence of statewide television stations in New Jersey presents unusual obstacles for political candidates trying to convey their message with television commercials. The high cost of the commercials and the state limit on funds to pay for them forces the candidates to create clear-cut images, no matter how stark or bizarre.

title: NORTH AMERICAN WATCH CORP reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $135,000.

title: South African Police Move to Quell Rioting
description: South African police and soldiers moved into the black township of Duduza today to quell days of rioting that claimed four lives.

title: American Embassy in Cairo Is Sealed Off in Security Drill
description: Security forces staged a mock attack today on the United States Embassy, and armed policemen sealed off several blocks surrounding the mission, witnesses and embassy sources said.

title: Ex-Officer Is Slain In Barbershop
description: A 64-year-old retired police officer was shot to death in a Brooklyn barbershop yesterday afternoon by one of two men who apparently intended to rob the shop, the police reported.

title: ROCK: GROUP RECALLS 60'S
description: IF there's going to be a garage-rock revival, Katrina and the Waves are ready to lead it. The four-piece band, featuring the Kansas-born singer Katrina Leskanich and the British guitarist-songwriter Kimberley Rew, romped through assorted 1960's rock styles Monday at the Ritz (119 East 11th Street), recreating Memphis soul, folk-rock, garage-band stomps and Chuck Berry rock-and-roll with a contagious party spirit.

title: DATRON CORP reports earnings for Year to Mar 31
The Best Water
description: When he said the other day that Washington's drinking water was the best in the world and challenged other cities to a contest to prove his point, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. must have known there is no pleasing everyone. A District of Columbia water consumer, Raymond M. Glasscote, writes that his family of three recently paid a six-month water bill of $191. This led him to conclude that ''if it is true that you get what you pay for, then the Lord knows Washington OUGHT to have the best water anywhere.''

title: INFRARED GAINS BROADEN USE
description: WHEN the Japanese Grand Kabuki theater company opens at the Metropolitan Opera in July, the audience will be bathed in an invisible light containing millions of bits of information.

title: A Reagan Flashback
description: Every so often, President Reagan is reminded that his celebrity began when he was an actor, and he does not hesitate to talk about such memories. The other day, at a dinner at the Washington Convention Center, he told his audience, ''Nostalgia had seized me with the presence of Bob Hope here.''

title: Apple Is Closing San Jose Unit
description: Apple Computer Inc. has decided to close its disk-drive manufacturing operations in San Jose and has laid off 80 employees who worked there, a company spokesman said today. The 80 employees had been making hard disk drives for the now discontinued Lisa computer, and had been scheduled to produce a future hard disk drive for the Macintosh, as well as an electronic filing system, known as a file server.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Whither Sukhodrev?
description: For 25 years, the man standing behind and slightly to the side of the Soviet leader has been Viktor Mikhailovich Sukhodrev.

title: The Descendants of Turks and Armenians Alike Deserve Better
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIWEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Protesters Loot Markets During Strike in Peru
description: Protesters looted food markets and smashed the windows of 50 cars in a 24-hour general strike in the northern city of Chimbote, police sources said today.

title: F.C.C. ACCUSED ON MINORITY ISSUE
description: Advocates of a greater minority role in broadcasting say that the Reagan Administration's opposition to racial preferences and its aggressive deregulation policies are diminishing the chances for minorities to expand their ownership of radio and television stations.

title: CUSTOM LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $112,764 from the conversion of $763,500 in convertible subordinated debentures into cumulative convertible preferred stock.

title: DELAY IS SOUGHT ON 3 MILE ISLAND
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania and the state's two Senators urged the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today to postpone a vote on the resumption of nuclear power production at Three Mile Island.

title: 57 Are Hurt in Gas Explosion
description: A butane gas explosion destroyed a cafe crowded with lunchtime customers today, injuring 57 people, the civil governor's office said.

title: Indiana Youth Guilty In Ax Murder of Parents
description: A jury found Dale Whipple, 18 years old, guilty but mentally ill Tuesday in the ax murder of his parents on New Year's Day.

title: VISITING VOZNESENSKY TELLS OF SOVIET MOOD
description: Andrei Voznesensky's voice rose and fell melodiously, sometimes sonorous, sometimes staccato, as he recited one of his poems, many of which are known from one end of the Soviet Union to the other.

title: $110 Million Ohio Issue In Book-Entry Form
description: The Ohio Public Facilities Commission is offering $110 million of bonds, with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7 percent in 1990, 8 percent in 1995 and 8.70 percent in 2000, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: C.D. YIELDS TUMBLE
description: Yields on certificates of deposit tumbled in the last seven days, along with other interest rates, in the largest weekly drop for six-month C.D.'s since they were deregulated in October 1983.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Emoting Among the Tulips
description: Most visitors to the capital never see, or even hear about, Dumbarton Oaks Gardens, which is all right with Washingtonians who cherish it as a little-known respite from bureaucracy's babble. The gardens, in Georgetown, are a few acres of trees, flowers and benches set in spots called Crabapple Hill and Melisande's Alley.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
SITUATION WANTED: ROCKY PROFESSION
description: About this time last year, John McCarthy, class of '84, sat down to discuss his future. The representatives of prestigious companies were making their annual parade to the campus of Williams College to inspect the annual assortment of intelligent, ambitious prospects. One interview was all it took.

title: Aleksandr Mikulin of Soviet; Designer of Aircraft Engines
description: Aleksandr A. Mikulin, a Soviet pioneer in aircraft engine design before the jet age, died May 13, according to Moscow newspapers received in the United States. He was 90 years old.

title: American Said to Help Seize Guerrilla Leader in Salvador
description: An American working on private contract to the Salvadoran Air Force accompanied the Salvadoran military unit that captured a senior guerrilla commander last month, according to Salvadoran officials and a United States Embassy spokesman.

title: DR. VINCENT DeP. LARKIN
description: Dr. Vincent DePaul Larkin, a pediatrician and director of special projects at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, died of cancer Monday at the hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: LEICHTER TO END GOLDIN CHANLLENGE
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter, citing a lack of campaign funds, told various politicians yesterday that he would drop his primary challenge to the renomination of City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: TORONTO DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ORTEGA'S BAD TRIP
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua may never take a trip more ill advised than his recent pilgrimage to Moscow, immediately after the House of Representatives voted down all proposals for any form of aid to the ''contra'' guerrillas trying to overthrow the Sandinista Government.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Turner's CBS Bid
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. will watch closely any actions taken by CBS Inc. to thwart a takeover bid by Turner's chairman, Ted Turner, a spokesman said. ''We hope that any action they may take will not be motivated or have the effect of frustrating the ability of their shareholders to consider our offer,'' Art Sando said. ''If we believe any action they may take is so motivated or has that effect, we will respond accordingly.''

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: ADVANCED ENERGY CONCEPTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WILDFLOWERS INSPIRE ARMORY PARTY
description: Outside the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street on Wednesday evening, there was morris dancing, an ancient English ritual traditionally done in the spring to make crops grow and flowers bloom. There was also Mike Wehrmann, who had just gotten Lady Bird Johnson to autograph a large color photograph of the White House inscribed with the signatures of other First Ladies.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE TO TEST LASER FOR MISSILE SHIELD
description: In a test of one element of prospective antimissile technology, a laser beam will be fired from Hawaii next month at a reflector on the space shuttle Discovery, the Defense Department said today.

title: Arco Stations Sale
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said negotiations to sell a substantial number of its 2,000 stations east of the Mississippi River had begun, but it declined to name potential buyers.

title: STAR TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Billing the U.S. For Trinkets
description: As the debate over military costs has heated up, particular scrutiny has been given to arms contractors who try to charge the Pentagon for such overhead items as personal travel, entertainment and advertising.

title: CHEVRON SELLS GULF UNIT STAKE
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 60.2 percent stake in Gulf Canada Ltd. to Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the largest office developer in North America and a major landlord in New York City, for about $2.18 billion. Canadian officials said they believed it to be the largest acquisition in Canadian history.

title: PROFESSIONAL INVESTOR INS.  reports earnings for Qtr to march 31

OUTDOORS;

Taste for Mushrooms Stirred
description: There are always a few daring souls in every community who feel that the danger of making a mistake while gathering edible fungi is more than offset by the gustatory pleasures such an endeavor yields.

title: AT HEARING, WARD DEFENDS QUALITY OF OFFICERS
description: The city's new crop of police officers are superior to previous generations of officers in educational background and training, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: Mediator Calls Talks At United 'Cooperative'
description: Negotiators in the week-old strike by 5,000 United Airlines pilots returned to the bargaining table today after 15 hours of ''earnest and cooperative'' talks that ended shortly before dawn, a Federal mediator said.

title: TRUCE AGREEMENT IN U.P.I. FIGHT IS STALLED ON QUESTION OF CONTROL
description: An agreement intended to bring a truce in the conflict between the owners and managers of United Press International has run into difficulty, and when or if it will be signed is uncertain, according to one of the principal co-owners.

title: WIFE IS CONSIDERED AS A FEDERAL JUDGE, SENATOR ROTH SAYS
description: The White House has begun background checks on Jane Richards Roth, the wife of Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, in preparation for her nomination to be a Federal judge, the Senator said today.

title: CUT OF $56 BILLION IS VOTED BY HOUSE IN DEFICIT FOR '86
description: The Democratic-controlled House of Representatives today approved a Government budget outline that would reduce the projected deficit in the fiscal year 1986 by $56 billion.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IF you are planning to travel abroad this summer, you might want to carry along the 1985 edition of Relais & Chateau, a concise, colorful guide to 342 comfortable, and occasionally luxurious, hotels around the world. The $10 guide emphasizes France, however there are listings all over Europe, as well as the United States, Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean, South Africa, Australia and the United Arab Emirates.

title: Rock and Reggae
description: The Del-Lords, a New York rock-and-roll band, and Steppin' Razor, a reggae group, will perform tonight at the Peppermint Lounge, 100 Fifth Avenue at 15th Street (989-9505). Live music begins at 11:30 P.M. Tickets are $7 before 11 P.M., $11 afterward.

title: Big Board Union Protest
description: About 100 clerical workers from the New York Stock Exchange demonstrated after the close of trading yesterday against automation that they say threatens their jobs. The employees are members of Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees International Union, which has threatened to go on strike soon if its demands are not met.

title: Honduran Chief Justice Is Freed From Prison
description: A Supreme Court Chief Justice jailed in a dispute between the Honduran President and Congress was released Wednesday.

title: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Campaign For Nynex
description: THE TV spot opens on a little fellow eating his breakfast cereal at the kitchen table, while off camera, or in the misty distance, his father frantically searches for the Yellow Pages directory.

title: 200 Soviet Workers At U.N. Called Spies
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that about 200 of the 800 Soviet citizens working for the headquarters of the United Nations are actually intelligence agents who have been allowed to travel freely in the United States.

title: DRIVE TO LOCATE RISK AREAS FOR RADIOACTIVE GAS URGED
description: Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency have proposed a major Federal effort to locate areas of the country where radon, a naturally occurring radioactive gas that causes lung cancer, poses risks to public health.

title: ENVOY SAYS SHARON TOLD U.S. OF PLANS TO INVADE LEBANON
description: The United States Ambassador, Samuel Lewis, whipped up a political storm here Wednesday night when he reported that Ariel Sharon, the former Defense Minister, gave American officials ''hypothetical details'' of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon some six months before it occurred.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., said it had received 2,958,133 G.C. Murphy Co. common shares in response to its tender offer at $48 a share, and the offer had been extended until May 29.

title: Phibro Shares To Be Sold
description: The Minerals and Resources Corporation Ltd. of Hamilton, Bermuda, said yesterday that it plans to dispose of 10 million shares of Phibro-Salomon Inc. stock, currently valued at about $400 million, as part of its plan to redeploy its assets.

title: CAIRO BOM PLOT SAID TO BE FOILED
description: Egypt's Interior Ministry said today it had ''thwarted a plot'' involving Libya and a Syrian-based terrorist group to detonate a truck bomb at an embassy here. It did not identify the target of the purported plot, but the police and other Egyptian officials said it was the United States Embassy.

title: Topics;   Implications, Speculations Burden of Proof
description: The mere naming of someone in an internal F.B.I. memo carries ''no implication of guilt.'' So says the F.B.I. in response to questions about a 1978 agency document in which Representative Charles Rangel of New York was said to be engaged in influence-peddling.

title: Jamal at Lush Life
description: The jazz pianist Ahmad Jamal will appear through Sunday at Lush Life, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (228-3788). Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 8:30 and and 10:30 P.M. Sunday; there is a $12.50 cover ($10 Sunday) and a $6 minimum.

title: Quartet and Saxophone
description: The tenor saxophonist Pharoah Sanders will lead a quartet tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785) . Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; 10, 11:30 and 1 A.M. Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Panel in Rhode Island Delays Judicial Inquiry
description: A judicial ethics panel investigating Rhode Island's top judge and his friendships with underworld figures announced today that it was suspending its work for four weeks.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture on the first page of Business Day yesterday, with an article about Lloyd's of London, was published erroneously. It showed Princess Michael of Kent, not the Duchess of Kent.

title: PROSECUTION IN AQUINO MURDER TRIAL SAYS IT HAS NO MORE WITNESSES
description: The prosecution, expressing confidence that it would win convictions in the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., moved today toward formally resting its case.

title: Iranians Expel Reuters Man; Say He Sent Biased Reports
description: Iran expelled a Reuters correspondent today, accusing him of sending biased and sometimes false reports.

title: Everton Wins
description: English League champion Everton beat Liverpool, 1-0, today in a soccer match between the European Cup Winners' Cup and the Champions' Cup holders. Paul Wilkinson scored the goal. Liverpool defends the Champions' Cup against Juventus of Italy next Wednesday.

title: No Comparison
description: How fast is Roger Clemens's fastball? When he tied Minnesota in knots Wednesday night en route to a 4-3 Boston victory, at least one of his pitches was clocked at 97 miles per hour, and afterward, Manager Billy Gardner of the Twins said, ''Clemens was the hardest thrower we've seen.''

title: Stewart Is Fined $500 by Rangers
description: Tom Grieve, the Texas Rangers' general manager, fined the relief pitcher Dave Stewart $500 today and offered an apology on behalf of the club for remarks Stewart made after the team's' 6-3 loss to Kansas City Wednesday night.

title: SUPER SKY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kirk-Jackson Talks
description: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Paul G. Kirk Jr., and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the black political leader who ran for President last year, held a secret meeting this week in an effort to compose their differences. But the big news was that the substance of their discussions remained secret after the session.

title: HOLME'S QUIP CRITICIZED AS A LOW BLOW
description: Larry Holmes did not dignify his quest for Rocky Marciano's record when he suggested on national television that Marciano's 49-0 mark was padded by victories ''over his brother.''

title: Delay on Trade Effort
description: International talks aimed at paving the way for global trade negotiations next year are unlikely before September, trade officials said today.

title: ACCO WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid last September.

title: GAP STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Canucks Coach Resigns
description: Harry Neale has officially resigned as coach and general manager of the Vancouver Canucks after leading the team through its worst season ever, according to a club spokesman.

title: Suspect Charges Officers Beat Him
description: The man accused of stabbing a 23-year-old drama student to death last December on an Upper West Side roof testified yesterday that police officers had beat and kicked him and forced him to write a confession to the murder.

title: Admiral Rickover and the Trinkets
description: Secretary of the Navy John Lehman is trying to unravel a convoluted piece of history that still ensnarls the nuclear submarine program. He has fined General Dynamics and censured former Adm. Hyman Rickover for taking $67,628 in gifts during the 17 years he supervised the company's construction of nuclear submarines. ''This fall from grace over these trinkets should be viewed in the larger context of his enormous contribution,'' Mr. Lehman notes.

title: Last Major Florida Fire Out
description: Firefighters succeeded today in choking off a stubborn 5,400-acre fire that threatened to burn across the main highway across south Florida. The fire was the last of 354 that killed two firefighters, destroyed 200 homes and blackened 175,000 acres of woods and brush in a week-long rampage.

title: SCREEN: A CHESS MATCH
description: IF you still suspect that chess, even though it's as much a way of life as it is a game, would not be an ideal subject for a fiction film, there's nothing in Richard Dembo's ''Dangerous Moves'' that's likely to change your mind.

title: JERSEY CANDIDATES DIFFER ON BILL ON TEACHERS' PAY
description: The candidates for the Democratic nomination for governor differed on a proposal to make $18,500 the minimum starting salary for teachers but agreed on most other issues Wednesday night at a forum at Rutgers University.

title: FATHER SAYS MULTIPLE BIRTHS WERE NOT AIM OF TREATMENT
description: The father of the septuplets born in California said yesterday that he and his wife had not sought a multiple birth when they went to a fertility clinic for treatment.

title: Back to Washington
description: Former Congressmen and Cabinet officers, they say, never go back to Pocatello.

title: Energy Agency Rejects Plea To Halt Shipments of Waste
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington yesterday rejected a request by a delegation of seven Congressmen from New York City and Westchester County that his agency suspend shipments of radioactive waste through their areas.

title: BIBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Stake in Carbide
description: The Bass brothers of Fort Worth have lowered their stake in the Union Carbide Corporation to 3.5 percent, from 5 percent of the shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass brothers said that between May 6 and May 20 they sold about 1.1 million Union Carbide common shares for prices ranging from $37.17 to $39.07 a share, for a total of about $41.5 million. The filing did not indicate any reason for the sale of the stock in the chemical company.

title: F.B.I. PREDICTS ADDITIONAL ARRESTS IN SPY CASE OF SAILOR AND FATHER
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it expected more arrests in what some officials described as one of gravest security breaches in the history of the Navy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny International Inc. has named William H. Vogt president of Springfield Instrument Co. of Hackensack, N.J., a unit of its North American consumer group.

title: CONCERT: ORCHESTRA PRESENTS WORKS FROM NORWAY
description: MOST countries promote their culture abroad simply by exporting the appropriate representatives to the appropriate locales. The Norwegians, on the other hand, have come upon a more efficient way of making New York conscious of their country's music - by making New Yorkers do a lot of the work.

title: PERSONAL EXEMPTION WOULD GO TO $2,000 IN REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: In the tax revision plan President Reagan submits to Congress next week, he will propose that the personal exemptions that taxpayers can take for themselves and their dependents be nearly doubled next year, Administration officials said today.

title: Empty Swing
description: Everybody says that the Mets will start hitting consistently one of these days.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $3.12 billion, to $213.26 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Witness Is Shot Before Testifying
description: A man scheduled to testify next week in a major counterfeiting trial, was shot and critically wounded yesterday as he sat in his car in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. The Mets open a four-game series with the Dodgers, their first meeting with the team this year. Orel Hershiser, the young Dodger pitcher, goes for his fourth victory without a loss. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif. Rickey Henderson, the Yankee outfielder who came from the A's in the offseason, makes his first return to Oakland, along with his former manager with the A's, Billy Martin, now the Yankee skipper. This is the opener of a four-game series that runs through Monday night. (Television - Channel 11, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 10:30 P.M.) Boxing James (Buddy) McGirt vs. Allen Braswell, 10 rounds, junior welterweights, at Felt Forum, 7:30 P.M. Iran (The Blade) Barkley vs. Randy Smith, 10 rounds, middleweights, is the semifinal. McGirt is from Brentwood, L.I. Since his first fight, which was a draw, he has won 18 straight, 17 by knockout. Braswell, from Brooklyn, is 15-9-2 with 12 knockouts. (Television -MSG, 7:30 P.M.) Irving Mitchell, champion vs. Calvin Grove, 12 rounds, for the United States Boxing Association featherweight title, at Atlantis Casino Hotel, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 9 P.M. David Braxton vs. Tony Cerda, 10 rounds junior middleweights, and Troy (Schoolboy) Wortham vs. Eric Martin, 12 rounds, welterweights at Las Vegas, Nev.. This is a nontitle bout for Braxton, the NABF champion who is 34-1.

title: Timely Adjustment Helps the Oilers
description: To listen to Mike Krushelnyski, the switch was an adjustment, not a demotion. It was a tactical move, not a banishment. The facts said he was being diplomatic.

title: Better-Off Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW 42-STORY STRUCTURE OFF MADISON SQUARE PARK
description: The courthouse of the Appellate Division, New York State Supreme Court, First Judicial Department, on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue at 25th Street, is a building of distinction. It looks like a small marble palace, with extravagant sculpture representing Force, Wisdom, Justice, Power, Study and various historic luminaries.

title: UPPER EAST SIDE COUNTS ITS HOMELESS
description: More than 100 volunteers fanned out through the Upper East Side Wednesday evening to count the homeless who live in the area. Peering into construction sites, poking around under the Queensboro Bridge and walking down every flight of steps they could find, the volunteers came up with a very rough count of 200 people.

title: U.S. Trust Plans Appeal
description: The U.S. Trust Company of New York said today that it planned to appeal a court ruling this week that the company's bid to open a limited-service bank in Florida was illegal.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Going Out Guide on Tuesday gave an incorrect location for the Acting Company. It is at 420 West 42d Street.

title: TVI ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THE SCREEN: JAMES BOND
description: AS lavishly escapist as they are, the latest James Bond films have become strenuous to watch, now that the business of maintaining Bond's casual savoir-faire looks like such a monumental chore. The effort involved in keeping Roger Moore's 007 impervious to age, changing times or sheer deja-vu seems overwhelming, particularly since so much additional energy goes into deflecting attention away from him and onto the ever-stronger supporting characters whose presence is meant to rejuvenate the Bond formula.

title: PRESIDENT HONORS SINATRA AND MOTHER THERESA
description: Frank Sinatra and Mother Teresa, along with 11 other renowned individuals, were awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom at a White House ceremony today that President Reagan said made it ''fun to be President.''

title: Peterson Dismissed
description: He'd been with the club for 30 years, but with the team languishing in last place, attendance lagging and morale sinking, his days were numbered. Yesterday they ran out for Harding (Pete) Peterson, the 55-year-old executive vice president and general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates. He was dismissed by the club's president, Dan Galbreath.

title: Multimedia Rebuffs Cooke
description: Multimedia Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected a sweetened buyout bid of ''more than $65 per share'' from Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Washington Redskins football team.

title: IDEAL MATCH-UP IN N.B.A.
description: The Boston Garden is a place for banners and signs. The antiquated arena is filled with them, makeshift carboard signs and sheets by which loyal fans show their feelings.

title: FILM: 'SHOOTING PARTY,' END OF AN ERA
description: SOMEWHERE toward the middle of ''The Shooting Party,'' set on a great English estate in the autumn of 1913, Sir Randolph Nettleby (James Mason), the host for the fashionable country weekend, has a brief encounter with Cornelius Cardew (John Gielgud), a somewhat mad activist on behalf of the Doctrine of Universal Kinship.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE spring social season reached a frenzied peak this week, just in time for some respite on Memorial Day. New Yorkers danced in ballrooms all over town, nibbled blinis at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations and even went to a coming out party for a tortoise.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes after-tax income of $2,917,000 from the sale of Trimed Corp. and Dynatech Fluid Technology Corp. Year-ago results are restated to reflect an acquisition which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: RIPLEY CO.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BALLET BOARD SUPPORTS KIRSTEIN
description: The board of directors of the School of American Ballet voted unanimously yesterday to support Lincoln Kirstein, founder and president of the school, following a dispute over the school's future administration. The board's resolution - which also recognized Mr. Kirstein's authority to dismiss Mary Porter, the school's director of development - was voted in a meeting held yesterday afternoon at the school.

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The U.N. Today
description: May 24, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: MONENCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: UPSHAW'S HIT LIFTS BLUE JAYS IN 9TH, 6-5
description: Willie Upshaw hit a two-out, two-run single in the ninth inning tonight, rallying the Toronto Blue Jays to a 6-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: DEPLETED METS LOSE NO-HITTER TO FARM
description: If they can round up enough able-bodied men, the Mets will open a four-game series against the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight in Shea Stadium. And they prepared for it with one of their strangest performances of the season last night: They held their Tidewater farm club to no hits in seven innings, but got no runs themselves and lost on a pair of errors, 1-0.

title: SHIITE-PALESTINIAN WARFARE RAGES FOR 5TH DAY IN BEIRUT
description: Fierce fighting continued for a fifth day today in and around three Palestinian refugee camps, the object of a drive by Shiite Moslem militiamen.

title: Newest Navajo in Town, Oldest Game in the Nation
description: FRANCIS X. CLINES

title: ART: CALDER WORKS ARE SHOWN AT THE PACE
description: ''CALDER'S CALDERS'' is not a good title for the exhibition of sculpture from the Calder estate that can be seen at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, through June 8. Calder was too large as an artist, and as a human being, to be stuck with a title that can only remind the visitor of ''Picasso's Picassos.'' Besides, Picasso was a hoarder of genius. What he kept for himself related to the private economy of an immensely complex and inter-echoing output. He kept what he needed, what he couldn't bear to let go, and - coincidentally -what in many cases would eventually put Picasso scholarship on a completely new track. That was not the way that Calder's mind operated.

title: ART: A 'HOUSTAN SCHOOL' EMERGES
description: WE'RE too Manhattan-centric to accept it, of course, but regionalism is in, and our status as art world capital is diffusing to other turfs around the country. We may have hatched the New York School, but after it there came the Washington Color School, the Bay Area School in San Francisco, the Chicago School, the Los Angeles School. And now, there has emerged the Houston School, a ''major regional art center'' that serves as a magnet for talents from the entire Southwest and expresses not so much a style as a -well, sensibility. That, at least, is the thesis of the critic Barbara Rose, who with Susie Kalil, a Houston art writer, assembled ''Fresh Paint,'' the first ''major'' exhibition of painting by Houston artists, for the Museum of Fine Arts in that city. It has now arrived at P.S. 1 in Long Island City (through June 23).

title: ARES-SERONO INTERNATIONAL HOLDING S A reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are given in U.S. dollars.

title: Lawyer Sentenced For Contempt
description: The chief lawyer for a teen-ager being tried for murder in the slaying of a Transit Authority police officer was declared in contempt of court yesterday and sentenced to 30 days in jail.

title: Modifications to 2 Satellites Delay Next Shuttle Launching
description: The launching of the next space shuttle has been delayed from June 12 to no earlier than June 17 because of a potential problem with two of the four satellites the Discovery is to carry, officials said today.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Apartheid Protesters Arrested at Princeton
description: As many as 88 demonstrators at Princeton University were arrested today in a move to end a blockade outside an administration building protesting the school's investments in companies with ties to South Africa.

title: MUSIC: DEBUT BY AN OBOIST
description: THE oboist Pamela Epple has long since established herself as one of the more capable wind players in New York. Miss Epple, a founding member of the chamber ensemble Tafelmusik, also performs regularly with such groups as the American Symphony Orchestra, Musica Sacra and the Philharmonia Virtuosi. Monday evening's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall, accompanied by the pianist Cameron Grant, marked her formal solo debut.

title: ART: A RARE EXHIBITION OF MODERN SWISS ART
description: AFTER recent showings of contemporary German, Italian, French, Spanish and Australian art, we now have Swiss art - sort of. ''Fri.Art'' is the first large exhibition of contemporary Swiss art in New York in 15 years. It is, however, a very particular exhibition, selected by Michel Ritter, a film installation artist living near Fribourg, one of the Swiss cities that helped finance the show - which helps to explain its title ''Fri.Art.''

title: Failure of Trade-and-Aid Approach to Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: Gunslingers Are Paid
description: The San Antonio Gunslingers yesterday made good on an April 30 payroll debt to players, avoiding the placement of more than half the team on waivers, the United States Football League Players Association said. An arbitrator, after examining a players' grievance, ruled Wednesday that 30 players whose April 30 paychecks had bounced would become free agents if the Gunslingers' owner, Clinton Manges, did not make good on those paychecks by May 31. The Gunslingers still have not been paid for the two weeks ending May 14 and a new grievance will be filed next week if that payroll is not met, according to John Macik, assistant director of the players association.

title: CLOSED TRIAL ON FOR 3 SOLIDARITY AIDES
description: Three activists in the outlawed Solidarity trade union movement went on trial behind closed doors today on charges of inciting public unrest.

title: Baseball Strike Is Asked By Union
description: Believing the action is necessary to induce the club owners to ''begin to bargain realistically,'' the executive board of the Major League Baseball Players Association, as expected, voted unanimously today to authorize a strike but set no strike date.

title: WHO WOULD SPEAK FOR PALESTINIANS?
description: Who would represent the Palestinians in talks with Jordan and Israel over the future of the West Bank and Gaza? Many Palestinians are wondering just that - wondering which of us would be acceptable to the United States and on what grounds. We have always known that we were a special people; only recently have we understood just how special.

title: BALLET: JEROME ROBBINS
description: JEROME ROBBINS'S ballets seem to exist, in general, in some suggestion of a time or place. ''In the Night'' is one of the few that doesn't.

title: FOR ANITA O'DAY, 50 YEARS IN SONG ARE MARKED
description: ANITA O'DAY, who made her reputation as a singer with the big bands of Gene Krupa and Stan Kenton in the 1940's, will be back in front of a big band tonight at Carnegie Hall to celebrate her 50th year as a performer.

title: MORGAN KEEGAN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Katy's Stock Falls Sharply
description: A day after Katy Industries announced the long-awaited sale of its Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad, the company's stock plunged $12.875 a share, to $22.875, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: STAGE: A MUSICAL ABOUT DEVELOPERS
description: IT'S a brave company that tries to make musical comedy out of the depredations of Manhattan real estate developers, and the ultimate failure of the effort in ''Savings,'' being presented at INTAR Stage Two, is not surprising. In fact, the success of its first act is a nice surprise. The opening number, ''There Goes the Neighborhood,'' is a biting and very funny lampoon of pride, bigotry, vanity and low-class snobbery, and another four that mock yuppies, health food and aerobic exercises are good old-fashioned show numbers. Some of the lyrics are more than merely clever, and Leon Odenz's music is as mellow as old brandy. But not always mellow - Heaven has seldom been so uproariously besieged as when Georgia Galvez and Carmen Rosario petition the Virgin Mary in Spanish and English for help against a gouging landlord.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MAY 24, 1985

title: Rare Books Collection
description: A collection of books about design, some dating to the 16th century, are on view through Oct. 6, at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Fifth Avenue at 91st Street.

title: DANCE: SAEKO ICHINOHE
description: PESSIMISTS fear that when cultures intermingle, they may be corrupted. But optimists can argue that cultures may be enriched by such minglings. Saeko Ichinohe was optimistic in ''Tokyo - New York Style,'' the program she offered Wednesday afternoon at the Asia Society to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the ''sister city'' arrangement between Tokyo and New York City.

title: DEEP IN A SOUTH AFRICAN MINE: WHAT PRICE GOLD?
description: The cage door closes like a trap and the dark descent, in the direction of the earth's core, begins at a brisk 30 miles per hour.

title: Cambodia Offers Talks On Refugees in Thailand
description: The Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government offered today to start negotiations with Bangkok to solve the problem of Cambodian refugees in Thailand.

title: Low Bidder Fails to Get Transcontinental Bonds
description: The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation created a stir in the corporate bond market yesterday when it failed to award the bonds to the securities firm whose bid was most favorable to the company.

title: HIGH RATES, HEFTY BORROWING
description: The Treasury has been paying less lately for the money it borrows. So have municipalities and corporations. But many consumers using credit cards or taking out personal loans have been forced to pay interest rates as high as, or even higher than, six months or a year ago.

title: Julius Erving Looks Ahead
description: He'll always be Julius Erving, but at age 35 he's not Doctor J anymore. He got his nickname in the Harlem playgrounds because of the way he ''operated.'' But he doesn't make the incision for the Philadelphia 76ers now. In the 76ers' elimination from the National Basketball Association playoffs by the Boston Celtics, he averaged only 14 points. Over the five games, he had a .324 field-goal shooting percentage and a total of only 26 rebounds. All those numbers seemed to be symbolized by a frozen moment in the final seconds of Wednesday night's final game.

title: DODGE PLAYOFF WON BY MONTCLAIR PRO
description: Jack Kiefer, a teaching pro at the Montclair Golf Club, won the Dodge Open today with a birdie 4 on the first hole of a four-man playoff at the Rockaway River Country Club.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
GRADUATES TOLD ABOUT DANGERS TO ENVIRONMENT
description: The vice president of the New York Botanical Garden and the director of its Institute of Ecosystem Studies told graduates at Rutgers University today that they were leaving academic life to enter a world being destroyed by human indifference to the environment.

title: Charles Evers Defeated In Mayoral Runoff Vote
description: Mayor Kennie Middleton has defeated Charles Evers by 11 votes in a ballot recount, blocking the civil rights activist's bid to win back the mayoralty.

title: Fannie Mae Rate Down
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association's yield requirement for 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage loans it buys from lenders is 12.1 percent, the lowest in two years, it said today.

title: STAGE: 'STARVING CLASS' BY SHEPARD IS BACK
description: TOWARD the end of Sam Shepard's ''Curse of the Starving Class,'' a father offers his insight into the family. It is, he tells us, not ''just a social thing,'' but ''a reason of nature that we were all together under one roof.'' Elemental and animalistic roots keep Shepard's embattled clan - mother, father, son and daughter - locked in a lacerating embrace. The family is, in the author's final, terrifying image, like a cat and an eagle tearing each other apart in the sky, but unable to release their hold on one another.

title: Latin Dance Music
description: The pianist Eddie Palmieri will headline a night of Latin dance music Sunday at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues (254-2800). Mr. Palmieri will lead a band including the trumpeter Chocolate Armenteros and the singer Ismael Quintana; also on the program are Manny Oquendo's band Conjunto Libre and Louie Ramirez and the Ray de La Paz Orchestra. Live music begins at 10 P.M.; tickets are $17 in advance (from Ticket World, 307-7171) and $22 at the door. The information number is 757-0030.

title: The Simpson-Nobody Bill
description: Illegal aliens keep pouring across the border, stirring broad bipartisan concern. Three years ago, Congress responded by taking up an immigration reform bill. Simpson-Mazzoli, it was called, personifying the bipartisanship of the sponsors, Senator Alan Simpson, Wyoming Republican, and Representative Romano Mazzoli, Kentucky Democrat. The bill sailed through the Senate but failed in the House for lack of time.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: NEW YORK HOME PRICES SURGE
description: Home prices in New York City and its suburbs are rising faster than anywhere else in the nation, to the point where they now exceed those in many parts of the nation's customary pacesetter, California.

title: STAGE: EQUITY LIBRARY REVIVES 'NIGHT MUSIC'
description: IT is just possible that the best musical in town is playing at 103d Street off Riverside Drive, where the Equity Library Theater is offering a scintillating production of Stephen Sondheim's ''Little Night Music.'' This virtuoso display of wit in waltz time began its memorable Broadway run in 1973, and among the incidental pleasures of seeing it now are the hints of the musical and literary themes that have engaged Mr. Sondheim's talents in the years since.

title: NOVELL INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b - Includes an estraordinary tax credit of $225,000 c - Includes extraordinary tax credits of $73,000 for the quarter and $103,000 for the 6 months.

title: ART: JOHN SINGER SARGENT DRAWINGS ON VIEW
description: THE status of John Singer Sargent (1856-1925) was questionable from the moment he achieved it. Whistler thought his work ''neither better nor worse than that of the usual academician,'' Pissarro called him ''an adroit performer,'' Mary Cassatt found him ''a buffoon.'' Speaking for a younger English generation, William Rothenstein said: ''We all acknowledged his immense accomplishment as a painter to be far beyond anything of which we were capable. But the disparity between his gifts and our own we were inclined to discount, by thinking we had qualities that somehow placed us among the essential artists, while he, in spite of his great gifts, remained outside the charmed circle.''

title: SCOTTS SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $42,000 for the latest first quarter and $32,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday, with an article about New York State license plates, incorrectly described a design for new plates. It is one of six being considered.

title: FROM SI KAHN, SONGS THAT SERVE A CAUSE
description: AFFIRMATION and gentle wit are hallmarks of the work of Si Kahn, a leading member of the current generation of activist folksingers. Mr. Kahn will be singing to raise funds for the Copper Relief Fund of Tucson, Ariz., when he makes a rare New York appearance tonight at 8 at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, in a concert sponsored by the Labor Heritage Foundation and the United Steelworkers of America. But he is as likely to salute ''old friends who come back as lovers'' and mourn the children of Poland or victims of the Holocaust -''who never grow old'' - as he is to sing about the kinds of deprivation experienced over the last two years by the striking copperworkers in Arizona and Texas.

title: Forgotten Images Of Black Movies
description: In their own lifetimes, many of the actors seen in the exhibition ''Classic Black Movie Posters'' probably never played to an integrated audience like the one that came to Marylou's Restaurant, 21 West Ninth Street, the other night.

title: VON BULOW WINS RULING ON EX-LOVER'S TESTIMONY
description: A transcript of testimony that Claus von Bulow's former mistress gave against him in 1982 cannot be used against him in his current trial for attempted murder, Judge Corinne P. Grande ruled today.

title: Back to Colorado
description: Brig. Gen. Richard F. Abel, recently retired as chief of public affairs for the Air Force, will be on familiar territory in his new job in civilian life. On June 1 he becomes director of public and legislative affairs for the United States Olympic Committee in Colorado Springs. Earlier in his military career, he was coach of the Air Force Academy football team in the same city.

title: AUCTIONS
description: WHILE a record number of art works were offered for sale in the three-week period of major auctions that ended last week at Sotheby's and Christie's, bringing in higher price totals than ever before, all was not well at the two galleries.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rep. James Howard, Democrat of New Jersey, introduced legislation that would require colleges to graduate 75 percent of their athletes on scholarship or lose the tax-deductible status of donations to their athletic departments.

title: Adelphi President to Retire
description: Dr. Timothy W. Costello said farewell today to the graduating students of Adelphi University, noting he would be joining them soon as ''an honorary alumnus of the Class of 1985.'' He is retiring next month after 13 years as president of Adelphi.

title: CONCERT: KUPFERMAN
description: MEYER KUPFERMAN is a composer who does everything he can to see that the music he writes gets performed. This includes putting on concerts himself, and at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night he presented yet another one.

title: SIMONS AND HINKLE IN MEMORIAL LEAD
description: If Jim Simons and Lon Hinkle approach greens tomorrow the way they did today, they could score well over par and find it difficult to maintain a position anywhere near the lead they shared after the opening round of the 10th annual Memorial Tournament.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effected in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend to holders of record on March 29, 1985.

title: Patience
description: Mike Schmidt has hit rock bottom, his average at .189 as he strains to break free of the worst start of his career.

title: INTERLAKE DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Year to Mar 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Carlson Assumes Top Posts at BMC
description: Robert J. Carlson, who resigned last September as president of the United Technologies Corporation under circumstances that are still unclear, yesterday was named chairman, chief executive and president of BMC Industries.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday REMEMBERING AL JOLSON Al Jolson was born 100 years ago this weekend, and the man who stopped the show and the nation with the way he put across such songs as ''April Showers'' and ''Swanee'' will be remembered in a big way. Today, a Jolson Film Festival moves into the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 45th Street, and through Tuesday, it will screen more than a dozen films in which he starred, as well as others, some not seen publicly before, about his life. Today's program consists of ''Rose of Washington Square'' at 10:30 A.M., ''Hallelujah I'm a Bum'' at 1 P.M., ''Big Boy'' at 3 P.M., ''Hollywood's Famous Feet'' (narrated by Jolson) at 4:30 P.M., ''Memorial to Al Jolson'' (narrated by Jack Benny) at 5 P.M. A ticket covering all the films costs $25. There will also be talks, a banquet Saturday at the hotel and events at the Jewish Museum and the Museum of Broadcasting next week. Information: 661-9600 (Jolson reservation desk). U.S.-SOVIET FILM EXCHANGE The First Soviet-American Film Retrospective starts today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue at 57th Street (757-2131), an indication that whatever else is in dispute, there are still some cultural ties between the powers. The festival, through next Thursday, celebrates the 40th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe. Appropriately, the eight Soviet and seven American films, deal with war and get equal time on each double bill (two Soviet short films are paired with one American). Today, ''At Dawn It's Quiet Here,'' a 1972 Soviet film, is shown at 2 and 7 P.M., with the 1943 ''Armored Attack'' (originally ''North Star'') at 5:30 and 10:15 P.M. Saturday, the 1984 Soviet ''A Wartime Romance,'' a love affair at the front, with humor (at 2 and 7 P.M.) is teamed with William Wyler's 1946 ''Best Years of Our Lives'' (Fredric March and Myrna Loy) at 3:45 and 8:50. Sunday: ''Shore,'' a 1984 film about a romance between a Soviet officer and a German woman (2 and 6:45 P.M.) is seen with the American 1953 classic ''Stalag 17.''

title: Article 003087 -- No Title
description: The six surviving Frustaci septuplets and their mother gained ground over all today as the medical staff reported four of the babies had shown improvement and the mother was doing ''very, very well.''

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Vanguard Quintet
description: The trumpeter Lester Bowie will lead a quintet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: MCGRATH RENTCORP reports earnings for Qr to March 31
Pakistani Mosque Attacked
description: At least 2 people were killed and 12 wounded today when two hand grenades were hurled at a mosque in the southern town of Sukkur, the police said.

title: Fair Warning
description: Bill Carr, the athletic director at the University of Florida, said yesterday that he had sent letters to 15 school boosters who had been linked to football recruiting violations by the N.C.A.A., warning them to keep their distance from Florida athletes. Carr said the letters were sent in accordance with sanctions imposed by the N.C.A.A. last fall, when it put the school on probation for two years. Among the boosters who received the letters, Carr said, was George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, who had been cited for what Carr called ''a very, very minor'' infraction five years ago, providing lodging and $30 in spending money for two young athletes who worked at the Yankee training camp in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Paper Operations
description: The Champion International Corporation said it had decided to restructure its kraft-paper manufacaturing operations, shut a multiwall-bag plant and start engineering on a project to add white-paper manufacturing capacity.

title: TWO-PART NBC DRAMA OF SWITCHED IDENTITIES
description: TEARS welling in her eyes as she copes with her teacher husband's inadequate salary and two bratty children, the beautiful housewife cries, ''I need to get away from New Jersey.'' She gets her wish, with a vengeance, in ''Deceptions,'' the four-hour TV movie that begins this Sunday at 9 P.M on Channel 4. The second half can be seen on Monday at 9. The Melville Shavelson script is based on the novel by Judith Michaels, who is really the husband-and-wife team of Judith Barnard and Michael Fain.

title: 3 CITY OFFICERS ARE INDICTED IN PARK AVE. HIT AND RUN
description: A police sergeant and two officers were indicted yesterday in a hit-and-run accident on Park Avenue two months ago that killed an elderly psychologist and seriously injured a doorman.

title: INVESTMENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SMOKING IS SAID TO IMPAIR FERTILITY IN WOMEN
description: Women who smoke are less fertile than nonsmokers and it takes them longer to become pregnant when they try to conceive, according to a new report.

title: Topics;   Implications, Speculations Away From Home
description: With the 1985 baseball season about a quarter gone, the early speculation about a Subway Series remains plausible. The Mets still lead the National League East and the revived Yankees are gaining ground in the American League East.

title: How Justice Department Collected the Data for Its Rape Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Calls Getty Plan 'Fair'
description: A Superior Court judge today called the proposed settlement of the $4 billion Getty trust ''fair, just and reasonable'' to all 26 beneficiaries, and gave the one dissenting attorney a week to reconsider and sign the proposal.

title: Of Libido and Harassment
description: Judge Robert H. Bork of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia is at or near the top of most lists of likely appointees to the Supreme Court in the event of a vacancy in President Reagan's second term. As a result, the judge's current pronouncements from the bench receive more than ordinary attention from the bar, notably his argument in a recent dissent that Congress did not intend Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, barring discrimination in employment based on sex, to be applicable to cases of sexual harassment.

title: Bally Contracts
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said it had been awarded contracts to provide instant tickets, computer software and counseling for starting lotteries in California and Iowa. The California contract is for one year with two six-month options.

title: SIGNS OF CHANGE ALONG THE CONNECTICUT TURNPIKE
description: The golden arches of McDonald's this week replaced the orange roofs of Howard Johnson's at the 10 food-and-fuel stops along the Connecticut Turnpike.

title: 4 Men Charged in Blast In Fireworks Plant Freed
description: The four men charged with the involuntary manslaughter of nine workers in an explosion at an illegal fireworks factory Monday were set free today on $25,000 bond each.

title: JOB SAFETY AGENCY ACCUSED OF LAXITY
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has been ''grossly inadequate'' in protecting the health and safety of workers hired to control and clean up toxic waste sites, according to a House committee, A report by the House Government Operations Committee, unanimously approved by members from both political parties, said OSHA's record of enforcement in the hazardous waste industry ''can only be described as dismal.''

title: FINANCING WOES SLOW EXPANSION OF CABLE LINKS
description: Difficulties in obtaining financing have become the latest and most serious obstacle to the long-delayed expansion of cable television into the boroughs outside Manhattan, city officials said yesterday.

title: Carter Slowed at Indy
description: Pancho Carter, the record-setting pole-sitter for the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday, had what were described as ''minor problems'' that kept him under 200 miles per hour in today's final tune-up. This was the day for fine-tuning, known as Carburetion Day, and Mario Andretti was fastest at more than 209 m,p.h.

title: T.W.A. ASKS BAR TO ICAHN BID
description: Trans World Airlines turned to Washington yesterday to fight off an unwanted takeover offer from Carl C. Icahn.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ADMITS SPY MISSION AFTER ANGOLA ACCUSES IT OF A RAID
description: South Africa acknowledged today for the first time that it had sent military reconnaissance teams into the northern part of neighboring Angola, and said it had lost contact with one group on an espionage mission.

title: 2 Indicted in California In Auto Import Scheme
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted two men on charges that they falsified documents to import 2,000 European luxury cars into the United States.

title: SHULTZ IN WARNING ON COMBAT TROOPS FOR LATIN REGION
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that if Congress failed to aid the anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua, the United States would eventually have to make ''an agonizing choice'' whether to involve American troops in combat in Central America.

title: CUOMO AND KOCH AGREE ON HOUSING Home prices in New York City and its suburbs are rising faster than anywhere else in the nation, according to a new study. Page D1.
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch announced agreement yesterday on spending $1.2 billion in the next 10 years to build and rehabilitate 75,000 apartments for low-to-middle-income New York City residents.

title: 'Seeking to Forget Makes Exile Longer'
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $58,490. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $64,085.

title: JUSTICE AIDE QUERIES PICKENS RULING
description: The Justice Department's top antitrust official said today that the Delaware Supreme Court, in a decision last week, might have gone too far in protecting a company from a hostile takeover attempt.

title: U.S. CAR SALES UP 18.2% IN MID-MAY
description: A fresh round of buying incentives lifted sales of new American-made automobiles 18.2 percent in the May 11-20 period, the manufacturers reported today.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: YOU approach the unmarked entrance and press a small buzzer. The door opens slowly and you are greeted by a young man in a navy blue blazer and bow tie who looks like a recent graduate of an English school for butlers. He asks your name, nods knowingly and beckons you to enter. The foyer is formal and tastefully understated, with a little mahogany bar and, on either side, cozy, compact dining rooms that sparkle like polished crystal goblets.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SLAM BY PHELPS BEATS NIEKRO
description: The rumors began in spring training and persisted when Billy Martin took over as manager last month. In their search for a left-handed power hitter, the Yankees were looking at Ken Phelps of the Seattle Mariners.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE theater bug has bitten two well-known film names. Brian De Palma and Edward Pressman are collaborating on a musical version of De Palma's 1974 cult film, ''Phantom of the Paradise,'' and plan a Broadway opening early next year. Mr. Pressman, whose credits include ''Badlands'' and ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' will produce, and Mr. De Palma, of ''Carrie'' and ''Blow Out'' fame, will direct.

title: TECHNICAL COATINGS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $25,000. c-Net income.

title: JOSEPH A. DUBBS
description: Joseph A. Dubbs, a retired partner in the Chicago law firm of Keck, Mahin & Cate, died of complications from cancer Monday at Hinsdale (Ill.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Hinsdale.

title: Liv Ullmann Is Subject Of 'Film on Film'
description: Liv Ullmann is one of the world's most fascinating actresses, with a face as changeable as an autumn sky. Sven Nykvist, Ingmar Bergman's great cinematographer, became at times so lost in that face, ''so touched by her performance,'' he said, that he forgot ''to pan and tilt and do other technical things'' with his camera.

title: 6 Guilty of Tax Fraud In Sale of 'Ministries'
description: Six defendants accused of tax evasion through the sale of ''ministries'' in the Life Science Church were found guilty yesterday by a Federal jury in Manhattan.

title: Crocker Deal
description: Stockholders of Midland Bank P.L.C. have approved the London-based bank's plan to raise its stake in the San Francisco-based Crocker National Corporation to 100 percent, from 57 percent. And, the Delaware Chancery Court approved a previously announced settlement in a case brought by some Crocker shareholders that provides for Crocker to pay them up to $1.75 million and an equal amount in attorneys' fees and expenses.

title: MAN SOUGHT BY ISRAEL IS IN NEW YORK
description: A man sought for questioning by Israel in connection with a terrorist bombing that maimed two West Bank mayors five years ago is living in the New York area, where he is directing a city-financed social welfare agency.

title: New Speigel President Named as Part of Shift
description: Spiegel Inc., the catalogue marketing company based in Oak Brook, Ill., has selected a senior vice president, Jack Shea, to become president and chief operating officer in November, a spokesman for the company confirmed yesterday.

title: Coaches Admonished
description: Citing sanctions imposed on the Georgia basketball program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the school's athletic director, Vince Dooley, called on his coaches to do ''a better job in the future'' in preventing recuiting violations and said the basketball program would be monitored closely to assure compliance. The N.C.A.A. found that Georgia had illegally recruited Cedric Henderson, a Bulldog star who decided to attend Georgia after previously committing himself to two other schools, and that Henderson had participated in a violation by accepting improper transportation from a Georgia assistant.

title: Rumsfeld to Become G.D. Searle Chairman
description: G.D. Searle & Company announced yesterday that Donald H. Rumsfeld, president and chief executive since 1977, had been named chairman.

title: GROUP OF 10 REPORTED TO BACK CURRENCY PLAN
description: The United States and 10 other wealthy nations have agreed on a modest revision of the world's monetary system, according to officials involved in the negotiations.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MUSIC: KERN'S 'ADELINE' IS REVIVED
description: ''Sweet Adeline,'' the sixth and last of the concert versions of Jerome Kern musicals to be presented at Carnegie Recital Hall and Town Hall as part of the Kern centennial celebration, proved in its two performances on Sunday and Monday at Town Hall to be the least effective of the series.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''By no means did we set out to have twins or triplets or more than one child.

title: People
description: * Paula Bolouri, Philip Brushaber, Jud Chapin and Henry Lewczyk have been elected senior vice presidents at Bozell & Jacobs, Dallas.

title: Ceramic Sculptures
description: An exhibition of ceramic sculptures based on architectural designs is on view through August at the American Craft Museum, 77 West 45th Street.

title: UNITED STATES SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
No Headline
description: Great Western

title: CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
3-State House Vote On '86 U.S. Budget
description: Following were the positions of representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut today when the House approved a Federal budget for the fiscal year 1986. A ''yes'' represents a vote in favor of the budget plan and a ''no'' represents a vote against it; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: Good Example
description: What the Mets need, of course, is some instruction from the baseball team at the University of Michigan.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $202,000 for the quarter and $129,000 for the 6 months.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $2,246. c-Net income which includes a tax credit of $38,692.

title: A Lesson in Etiquette, Subway-Style
description: Scene: the Rockaway Parkway subway station, first stop on the LL, the BMT's Canarsie line.

title: G.M. STEEL COSTS MAY FALL 3%
description: The General Motors Corporation is nearing agreements with its steel suppliers that are expected to cut its steel costs by about 3 percent for the next model year, steel company officials and industry analysts said today.

title: China-Portugal Talks To Open on Macao
description: China and Portugal announced today that they would open talks soon on the return of Macao to Chinese rule.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HERBERT CROLY OF THE NEW REPUBLIC: The Life and Thought of an American Progressive. By David W. Levy. 335 pages. Illustrated. Princeton. $32.50.

title: 'HORROR STORIES' AND PENTAGON'S BUDGET
description: A wave of disclosures about business misconduct in the weapons industry has combined with fears of an uncontrollable budget deficit to all but stop the Reagan Administration's drive for additional funds for its military buildup.

title: New York Artifacts
description: What do a 1903 photograph of New York City by Alfred Stieglitz and a red beret worn by a youthful member of the Guardian Angels have in common? Both items have been added to the collection at the Museum of the City of New York in the last four years, and will be on view with other recent acquisitions at the museum, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. Also featured in the collection are photographs by Ruth Orkin, prints by Larry Rivers and some of the tools used to build the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: U.S. PANEL STRONGLY ENDORSES ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: The artificial heart, embroiled in argument over costs and ethical questions since it was first used, has received a sweeping endorsement from a committee of experts appointed to study its potential impact on society.

title: Ex-Senator's Foot Removed
description: Former Senator Warren G. Magnuson's right foot was amputated today because of a circulation problem, a hospital spokesman said. The 80-year-old former Democratic Senator from Washington, who served five terms before being defeated five years ago by Slade Gorton, a Republican, was admitted Sunday to the Veterans Administration Medical Center here, according to the spokesman, Ray Tufts. He said Mr. Magnuson ''is now under observation and doing as well as can be expected.''

title: Who Will Remember the Korean War Vet?
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET MIDAIR COLLISION KILLS 80
description: A Soviet airliner collided with a small military plane over the western Ukraine this month, killing about 80 people, informed Soviet sources said today.

title: Mixed Day for Interest Rates
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with slight declines for most Treasury issues, and modest increases for other debt securities.

title: PARCELLS OPPOSES 45-MAN LIMIT
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants is unhappy with the action by National Football League club owners Wednesday in restoring the roster limit to 45 players. So are many of his players, especially those whose jobs would have been more secure had the limit remained at 49, as it was since the 1982 players strike.

title: Market Place;   Tending Assets For Colleges
description: AS president of the Common Fund, which tends $853 million in endowment assets invested for 250 colleges, universities and independent schools, George F. Keane is responsible for overseeing some of the nation's most successful money managers.

title: OILERS TRIUMPH, TIE SERIES AT 1-1
description: Revamped and revitalized, the Edmonton Oilers tonight evened the Stanley Cup final playoff series by mirroring their opponent's game plan on the way to a 3-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum.

title: DANCE: FRESH TALENT PERFORMS IN 'COPPELIA'
description: THE perfect ballet for children this season is American Ballet Theater's lighthearted revival of ''Coppelia'' - a production that will be on view again next week. Adults are in for good escapist entertainment as well, as a set of debuts and cast changes proved on Wednesday night and afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The afternoon performance, led by Marianna Tcherkassky as Swanilda and Danilo Radojevic as Franz, for instance, was top-notch on every level.

title: FOX-STANLEY PHOTO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
S & K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
High-Tech Trade Rules
description: The Commerce Department today announced final regulations that will govern export licenses authorizing multiple shipments of computers or other strategic, high-technology goods to friendly countries. Officials said they believe the rules were less restrictive than an earlier version, and thus more acceptable to business.

title: CONCERT: HERMAN HONORS ELLINGTON
