description: More than four decades ago, when Woody Herman was still looking for the formula that would give his band the successful identity that it finally achieved in the mid-40's, Mr. Herman gave open evidence of where his musical affections lay. Whenever he could, he beefed up his band at recording sessions with such Duke Ellington stars as Ben Webster, Ray Nance, Juan Tizol and Johnny Hodges. On Sunday he finally had an opportunity to pay full-scale tribute to the late Mr. Ellington and his music when the current Herman Herd played for the Duke Ellington Society's annual concert at the Schimmel Center for the Arts of Pace University.

title: Explosion Forecast Soon For Mount St. Helens
description: Seismic activity beneath Mount St. Helens rose to high levels today as the volcano in southwest Washington approached what scientists said could be an explosive eruption.

title: EAST VILLAGE DINING LURES THE ART CROWD
description: There is no need to dress up or make reservations weeks in advance. The prices are not outrageous and diners don't have to fight their way through masses of people. At least not yet.

title: RELEASE OF PALESTINIANS IS DEFENDED BY RABIN
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin indicated today that Israel really had no choice but to agree to the exchange last Monday of 1,150 Palestinian prisoners and convicted terrorists for 3 captured Israeli soldiers.

title: Dining Out Guide: Dim Sum
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAM FUNG, #20 Elizabeth Street (964-5256) -

title: The Annual Foreign Aid Dance
description: Since it has no voting constituency, foreign aid is perhaps the most vulnerable of all spending issues that come before Congress. And this year it seems that the perennial drama over how the United States will assist foreign countries is being played out with more than usual passion.

title: NEW INQUIRY INTO '81 SALVADOR KILLINGS PREDICTED
description: United States and Salvadoran officials say they intend to reopen an investigation into the 1981 killings of two American agrarian advisers and the head of the Salvadoran land-redistribution institute here. They added that they expected an army officer to be indicted in the case.

title: PROUD AUSTRALIAN A HIT AS TV ENVOY
description: An ocker, according to the Macquarie Dictionary, the guide to Australian English, is ''the archetypal uncultivated Australian working man,'' who is ''boorish, uncouth and chauvinistic.''

title: TWO HOUSING DEVELOPMENTS APPROVED FOR WEST SIDE SITE
description: After more than two decades of debate and lawsuits, the Board of Estimate yesterday approved a plan to build two housing developments on one of the last remaining urban renewal sites on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Unions in Argentina Hold Nationwide Strike
description: Peronist-led labor unions held a nationwide strike today, paralyzing much of the country's industry but failing to win widespread support in the commercial sector.

title: CHATPER 11 FOR INDIANA ELECTRICITY GROUP
description: An association of electrical cooperatives in northern Indiana yesterday filed for protection from its creditors yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. It said it was unable to make payments on some $500 million that it borrowed from the Federal Government for its share of the Marble Hill nuclear power plant, which was canceled last year.

title: Sales Set Record For Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, announced yesterday that declining interest rates have led to record sales of participation certificates totaling $1.614 billion so far this month. Participation certificates are a kind of mortgage pass-through security backed by pools of mortgages that Freddie Mac purchases from other financial institutions, such as savings and loan associations.

title: Going Out With Style
description: After 15 years as one of professional basketball's most workmanlike players, Dan Issel wanted to go out in style. And he did, ending his career Wednesday night with a play that brought his 10 seasons at Denver full circle to the five he had spent with Kentucky of the American Basketball Association: a successful 3-point shot.

title: Economic Scene;   How Budget Plans Differ
description: WITH the passage yesterday by the House of Representatives of a budget resolution, the struggle over budget cutting, the most important issue facing the national and international economy, is coming to a head.

title: Great White Father Is Still Relocating Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE GETS NEW VERSION OF IMMIGRATION BILL
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson today introduced a new version of his comprehensive immigration bill that would delay the granting of legal status to illegal aliens until after the United States had better control of its borders.

title: PLESSEY CO PLC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
FOR A MEMORABLE MEMORIAL WEEKEND
description: MEMORIAL DAY weekend is traditionally a time for getting out of New York for the year's first prolonged session of sun-worshiping or communing with nature. With the throngs gone, so is talk about the Hamptons or that little shack in the woods. A quieter, more spacious-seeming New York waits to be enjoyed by those who elect to stay in the city. And this holiday weekend offers many opportunities to take in something new or different, or reinvestigate some city ritual.

title: Stocks Continue to Retreat
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed below 1,300 yesterday for the first time this week as profit takers again took the stock market lower in an orderly retreat.

title: SUPERFUND, SUPERBUST
description: The Superfund, created in 1980 to deal with toxic-waste sites, is doing far less than a super job. When the Superfund law -the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act - was enacted, it was to provide funds, mainly from special taxes on the chemical and petroleum industries, to clean up hazardous dump sites, especially abandoned ones.

title: Outside Backing For a Bronx Challenge
description: Assemblyman Jose Serrano, who is challenging the renomination of the Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon, has put out a news release proclaiming that 16 state legislators have endorsed him.

title: Canada Proposes Business Spurs, Tax Surcharge
description: The Canadian Government today announced a variety of measures intended to promote business investment. It also proposed temporary tax surcharges on businesses and individuals to reduce its projected deficit, but they were not as extensive as some economists and business executives had hoped.

title: Of War and Peace And the Press
description: ''We're trying to encourage more serious, disciplined thought,'' explained Dr. John Brademas, president of New York University, ''on the role of the media in covering war and peace.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, MAY 24, 1985

title: China to Purchase 8 Jets From Boeing
description: China has agreed to buy eight new passenger jets from the Boeing Company for $350 million and is likely to buy even more, Hu Yizhou, director general of the national airline, CAAC, said today.

title: VANN BEGINS RACE TO UNSEAT GOLDEN
description: Declaring that Brooklyn's problems and its solutions are ''not black or white,'' Assemblyman Albert Vann declared his candidacy yesterday for Brooklyn borough president, challenging the renomination of Howard Golden.

title: SENATE, IN PACT WITH PRESIDENT, VOTES 50 MX'S
description: The Senate tonight approved an amendment that would severely restrict President Reagan's original proposals for production and deployment of the MX missile.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: Because of transmission problems at The Associated Press, the 52-week highs and lows do not appear in the Nasdaq national market list.

title: MACABRE MIDEAST DANCE
description: The faint glimmers of hope for peace talks in the Middle East have been stamped on again. The continued intricate infighting among Arabs and Israel's unexpected indulgence for convicted terrorists has spoiled the climate all round.

title: Team Next Door
description: Three Tulane basketball players who found themselves without a team when the school dropped the sport in the wake of the recent point-shaving scandal won't be traveling far to continue their collegiate athletic careers. They have signed to play at the University of New Orleans, according to Benny Dees, the New Orleans coach. The crosstown transfers are two freshmen, Elden Irving and Michael Smith, who saw limited duty last season, and Theron Cojoe, a 6-foot-6-inch forward who never got a chance to play for Tulane.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC() reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Governor Clears Deal for Saints
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards today signed a 21-year agreement with Tom Benson to keep the Saints in New Orleans in exchange for a state sales tax exemption and $2.5 million in concessions on revenues at the Superdome.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
60 STUDENTS IN SEOUL OCCUPY U.S. OFFICE
description: About 60 South Korean students peacefully occupied a United States Government office here today. They vowed to stay until the American Government apologized for what they said was its complicity in the suppression of a 1980 political uprising.

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $271,000 for the quarter and $432,000 for the 9-months. c-Includes tax credits of $340,000 for the quarter and $565,000 for the 9-months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sellers's Widow Wins $1 Million Movie Suit
description: The actress Lynne Frederick was awarded $1 million in damages today in a suit in which she contended the movie ''Trail of the Pink Panther'' insulted the memory of her late husband, Peter Sellers.

title: City Officer Indicted In Assault at a Diner
description: A New York City police officer was indicted yesterday on assault and other charges stemming from an incident in which, authorities said, he carried his former girlfriend out of a Brooklyn restaurant and assaulted two men who tried to help her.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 1:20 P.M. The backup game will be the Chicago White Sox vs, the Kansas City Royals. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:15 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif. (Television -SportsChannel, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.) Mariners vs Detroit Tigers, at Seattle. Nostalgia buffs will appreciate the CBS Radio Network's revival of the Baseball Game of the Week on Saturdays. (Radio - WCBS 880, 9:50 P.M.) Braves vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Football Breakers vs. Memphis Showboats, at Portland, Ore. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Hockey Oilers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Edmonton, Alberta. The defending-champion Oilers return home for the third game of the four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup final series. Series is tied, 1-1. (Television - USA Network, 8 P.M.) Indoor Soccer Blast vs. San Diego Sockers, at Baltimore. The fourth game of the four-of-seven-game Major Indoor Soccer League championship series. San Diego leads, 2-1.(Television - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M.) Lacrosse Syracuse vs. Johns Hopkins, N.C.A.A. Division I championship at Brown University, Providence, R.I. This is a second national title rematch between the teams: Syracuse beat Johns Hopkins in 1983 and last year the Orangemen lost. During the regular season Syracuse lost an 8-6 decision to Johns Hopkins in Baltimore.

title:
PATENTS;

New Technique Aids Chemical Processes
description: Chemical processes, such as the production of alcohol by fermentation, may be made more economical and efficient by a technique patented this week.

title: St. John's Loses In Regional
description: South Carolina connected for eight homers, two by the left fielder Rob Reinhart, to score a 13-6 victory last night over St. John's in Columbia, S.C., and remain the only undefeated team in the double-elimination National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern Regional.

title: PROFIT DROP EXPECTED BY APPLE
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it expects its revenues and earnings for the current quarter to drop below levels of the last quarter and below the expectations of Wall Street analysts. The company also suggested that further layoffs and product consolidations were in store.

title: Wykagl Pair Wins Wilson
description: Despite bogeying three of the final four holes, Greg Rohlf and Paul Petrarca of the Wykagyl Country Club of New Rochelle, held on to win the 14th annual Wilson Cup with an 11-under par 133 today at the Scarsdale Golf Club.

title: DODGERS HOLD OFF METS
description: Remember when the Mets always seemed to be winning at home, and winning the close ones anyplace? Well, no more. Last night, they lost their third straight game, their fourth in six games on their current home stand, and it was a close one: 4-3 to Orel Hershiser and the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: THE IN FOODS: FANCY AND FAST
description: Crabmeat salad, tortellini salad, oriental chicken salad, creamy cole slaw and more than two dozen other salads filled the sleek glass display cases at the Orval Kent Food Company booth.

title: CALMAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MID PACIFIC AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: DOCTORS GIVE REST 50-50 CHANCE
description: The smallest of the six living Frustaci septuplets, a boy called Baby F, died early today after his lungs failed.

title: Letter: On School Policy;   When Parents Applaud Sex Education
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: WOODWIND QUINTET
description: The New York Woodwind Quintet's Wednesday evening concert at Symphony Space was an event both celebratory and nostalgic - celebratory in that it introduced a deft, idiomatic wind arrangement of Brahms's Quartet in G minor (Op. 25) by the flutist Samuel Baron; nostalgic in that it marked the clarinetist David Glazer's last local appearance as a member of the group. Mr. Glazer, who joined the quintet in 1951 and now plans to retire, has distinguished himself not only as one of the best team players around, but also as a soloist and instructor; his presence will be missed.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MEMOIRS

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, MAY 25, 1985

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
KENOSHA AUTO PLANT TALKS SET
description: The American Motors Corporation said today that it would open contract talks with the United Automobile Workers ''on or before June 3,'' aimed at keeping open the nation's oldest car assembly plant in Kenosha, Wis.

title: THE CANDY LADY DISPENSES SWEETS AND SYMPATHY
description: An old man lazing away a warm, sunny day in May on a park bench in Harlem glanced down at his wristwatch, gave a little smile and said, ''Watch this.''

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring after-tax gain of $2,600,000 from the sale of the company's Handyman Texas distribution center. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,900,000 from the sale of the company's Fashion Conspiracy office and distribution center in San Diego.

title: Would Appeals Judges Review Applications?
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Corp. Outlook Given
description: The Financial Corporation of America will probably lose money in the current quarter, but may be profitable in the last half of the year if interest rates go no higher, its chairman said yesterday.

title: SRI LANKA LEADER PLANS CRACKDOWN
description: Sri Lanka's President said today that he intended to establish martial-law courts to deal with what he called ''a breakdown of law and order.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about Federal budget action in the House of Representatives misstated the vote on an alternate budget offered by the Republican leadership. It was 329 to 102, with 79 Republicans voting no.

title: THERE'S SUBSTANCE TO THE BRAGGING IN 'RIVER CITY'
description: This county seat of 30,000 people has always had a powerful sense of its own importance.

title: WHEN SILENCE IS POISON
description: It's called the ''code of silence'' or the ''blue wall of silence.'' It is the corrosive tradition inside police departments that secretly decrees that cops do not turn in, or testify against, other cops who are guilty of misconduct or crime.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. Cuba retaliated after the first broadcast of Radio Marti, a new United States service aimed at Cuba. 2. Children. 3.

title: G.M. Plans Outlay Of Over $9 Billion
description: The General Motors Corporation will spend more than $9 billion on product development and new factories this year, Roger B. Smith, company chairman, told shareholders today at G.M.'s annual meeting.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Icahn Disputes T.W.A.
description: Carl C. Icahn and C.E. Meyer Jr., the president of Trans World Airlines, clashed in court yesterday as lawyers for the nation's fifth-largest airline sought to block the financier's $600 million tender offer for the company.

title: INSPIRATION FOR NEW FERRIES
description: About a year ago, New York City officials, in search of a new design for two ferryboats they wanted to add to the Staten Island line, found just what they were looking for. On the Lake of Constance in West Germany.

title: ENSTAR INDONESIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $7,440,000.

title: Reagan Signs a Tax Bill
description: President Reagan signed a bill today doing away with a requirement that taxpayers claiming deductions for cars and home computers keep day-to-day records, calling the measure ''just a part of what I hope will be a larger tax reform later.'' The bill was a case of Congress admitting it made a mistake. Mr. Reagan agreed with the lawmakers that the requirement, enacted last year, was unnecessary and burdensome.

title: Gregorek Wins
description: John Gregorek of Athletics West posted the fastest 3,000-meter time in the world this year, finishing in 7 minutes 47.85 seconds at the Twilight Track and Field Meet at Hayward Field Thursday. Gregorek, a Olympian in the steeplechase last year, outkicked Richie Harris, who finished second in 7:48.50.

title: DANCE: TWO MINIATURES FROM PETER MARTINS
description: In 1946, Jerome Robbins choreographed a work called ''Afterthoughts'' for a concert, using Stravinsky's ''Suites 1 and 2 for Small Orchestra.''

title: PRESIDENT ACCUSES HOUSE OF PUTTING DEFENSE 'AT RISK'
description: President Reagan said today that the Democratic budget for 1986, by permitting no increase in the military budget, would place the nation's defense at risk. .

title: F.B.I. AGENT CLEARED IN UNARMED MAN'S DEATH
description: A Manhattan grand jury yesterday exonerated an F.B.I. agent who shot an unarmed 20-year-old man to death last Christmas after the agent tried to arrest him and a friend for breaking into a parked car.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Herb Brooks, the former Ranger coach who has been negotiating to take over the Minnesota North Stars, may have another coaching job to consider. According to The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, he has been approached by the Vancouver Canucks as a possible replacement for Harry Neale, who was dismissed this week as coach and general manager. . . . Lou Duva, the boxing manager, has appealed the $5,000 fine levied against him by the Nevada Athletic Commission after traces of ephedrine, a drug used to relieve nasal congestion, were found in the urine of a Duva fighter, Livingstone Bramble, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, after his victory over Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini in February.

title: GUARDING AGAINST ABDUCTION
description: AS concern over the plight of missing children has grown in the past year, so too has the list of products offered to worried parents as ways to protect their children from abduction or, should they disappear, to help parents find them again.

title: LYON METAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STEADY FED POLICY WAS VOTED
description: The Federal Reserve's main policy body voted at its March 26 meeting to keep monetary policy essentially unchanged, according to minutes of the session published today.

title: Return Game
description: After a quarter of a century's absence, the baseball ''Game of the Week'' returns to network radio today.

title: William Ware Is Dead at 37; Top Aide to Chicago Mayor
description: William Ware, chief of staff for Mayor Harold Washington, died of complications resulting from pneumonia Thursday in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Hospital in New York.

title: 50 Rembrandt Works To Go on First Display
description: Fifty Rembrandt drawings, some of which have not been seen in 100 years, will be taken from protective darkness and displayed at the Rijksmuseum here next month.

title: 'MISHIMA' DISPUTE AT TOKYO FESTIVAL
description: On Friday the first Tokyo International Film Festival will begin, a 10-day splurge of new and old movies, representing Japan's unabashed hope of crashing into the big time cinema business.

title: Judge Reduces Award In a Toxic Shock Case
description: A Federal district judge today reduced a punitive damage award against the tampon maker International Playtex to $1.35 million from $10 million.

title: French Steel Pact
description: France's state-owned steel company, Usinor, signed a preliminary deal worth $425 million to supply steel products to the Soviet Union, the company's managing director, Rene Loubert, said.

title: Westway Judge Says Trial Was Avoidable
description: Federal Judge Thomas P. Griesa said yesterday that the current Westway trial would have been unnecessary if the Army Corps of Engineers had conducted a two-winter study of striped bass in the Hudson River.

title: Youth Is No Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan to Fill Economic Post
description: President Reagan, as expected, said today that he would nominate Thomas Gale Moore to be one of three members of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: FLYERS THINK OILERS WILL STRESS OFFENSE
description: Methodically, just the way his team had been picked apart by the Oilers, Coach Mike Keenan of the Flyers listed the reasons why he thinks he will see a different Edmonton style Saturday night when the Stanley Cup playoffs continue.

title: Maine Utility Pact
description: The Central Maine Power Company said it and the Maine Public Utility Commission staff and the Public Advocate had jointly recommended to the full Public Utility Commission a settlement agreement by which Central Maine would write off $85 million in canceled plant investments in Seabrook One, a nuclear power plant. The write-offs include a $4.3 million loss on Pilgrim Two, $2 million on Sears Island, $14.8 million on Seabrook Two and $63.9 million on Seabrook One through year-end 1984.

title: Keep Probing Grand Juries
description: Can New York, like half the states, do without the grand jury? Hearings in the Legislature suggest a good case for sharply limiting its use, but much more investigation is needed to find a workable substitute.

title: 1.5 MILLION TAX RETURNS DELAYED IN PROCESSING
description: The Internal Revenue Service, still suffering the effects of computer problems that plagued it earlier this year, said today that some taxpayers might have to file duplicate returns to get their refunds.

title: 3,000 GRADUATE AMID TRADITION AT YALE CAMPUS BYL
description: Yale University graduated more than 3,000 students and awarded 12 honorary degrees today at its 284th commencement.

title: Hayes in Hospital
description: Woody Hayes, the former Ohio State football coach, was hospitalized for observation last night after suffering what an Ohio State University Hospital official called ''a slight stroke.'' Hayes, 72, was reported in good condition. ''He has suffered a slight stroke with weakness on his right side, but he is alert and he is moving his right side,'' a hospital statement said.

title: Triple Play
description: Public officials who travel a lot risk having their local spotlight stolen by stay-at-homes. Mayor Koch takes his spotlight with him.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Fuel Technologies Inc. said it and Savannah Foods and Industries had signed a stock purchase agreement that gives Savannah the right to acquire 50.5 percent of American Fuel's outstanding common stock over the next five years.

title: SENATE VOTE BACKS TEST OF ANTISATELLITE WEAPON
description: The Senate voted today to let the Reagan Administration start testing antisatellite weapons in space this summer.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Includes income of $852,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Look at the Amount, Not the Percent, of Toxic Emission
description: To the Editor:

title: Brennan Honored
description: Last month Justice Williiam J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court spoke at New York Law School in Manhattan at a symposium on the separation of church and state. The school and its dean, James F. Simon, were impressed. So yesterday Mr. Simon and two students, Noreen Krashogor and Sherri Donovan, went to Justice Brennan's chambers to present him the school's first ''Defender of Individual Liberties Award.''

title: DOLLAR CLIMBS BROADLY; GOLD RETREATS IN U.S.
description: The dollar staged a broad advance against major European currencies in light trading late yesterday.

title: U.S. Seeking Explanation
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was seeking a full explanation from the South African Government about the military mission into Angola.

title: Is $56 Billion Enough?
description: The House now agrees with the Senate that $56 billion is the right amount of reduction in next year's budget deficit. That's a big, oddly precise number, but who says it's right?

title: NEW YORK DOCTOR HELD AS FUGITIVE IN BRINK'S CASE
description: A New York City physician, on the run for two years since his indictment for treating suspects in the Brink's robbery and killings in Rockland County, has been arrested, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday.

title: ENGINEER IN STEALTH SECRETS CASE GIVEN LIFE TERM
description: An aerospace engineer who admitted trying to sell Stealth bomber secrets to the Soviet Union was sentenced to life in prison Thursday.

title: Winning One for a Silent Constituency
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.& T. ERRS ON BELLSOUTH CUSTOMERS
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had notified it that as many as 41,000 business customers might have been improperly assigned to A.T.&T. long-distance service.

title: BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Texas Court Permits School Baseball Playoffs
description: The State Supreme Court today stayed a lower court decision against a rule that keeps public school students who fail any class from taking part in extracurricular activities.

title: Solidarity Activists' Trial Is Recessed in Gdansk
description: The presiding judge recessed the trial of three Solidarity activists today because one of the defendants, Adam Michnik, was ill, witnesses reported. The three are charged with inciting public unrest.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 44. 1. A major immigration agreement with the United States was suspended by the Cuban Government. Why? 2. According to a Government study, they make up 26.8 percent of the total population of the United States, but 39.2 percent of all poor people. Who? 3. A chapter dropped from a lawyer's autobiography disclosed some unexpected information about a former governor of New York. Explain. 4. Larry Holmes had to face ''The Truth'' this week. What happened? 5. That Broadway is concluding its worst economic season in a decade is largely traced to the absence of a new hit musical. How many musicals have opened this year? How many are still running? 6. The day after his company was penalized by the Navy for fraud and deliberate overcharges, the chairman of one of the country's largest military contractors announced that he would retire by the end of this year. Who is he, what is the company and who will succeed him?

title: WIENER ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Year-ago results are for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1983. Oceaneering International acquired Solus Ocean Systems Inc. on Jan. 9, 1984 and changed its fiscal year-end to March 31 to reflect more accurately the operations of the combined companies.

title: AGENTS SEARCH HOME OF SUSPECTED NAVY SPY
description: Swinging sledgehammers, Federal agents pounded away today inside the home of John A. Walker, the retired Navy warrant officer who has been charged, along with his son, with selling Navy secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: FOR THE CREDIT BLUES, SOME TIPS FROM THE F.T.C.
description: Many of this spring's college graduates will soon be finding that one of the things they have not earned in the past four years is a good credit rating.

title: No Headline
description: The company had just finished off the prosciutto and melon, the pasta and the beef, when Archbishop John J. O'Connor edged back his chair and stood to say a few words about his new auxiliary bishop.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Net income.

title: Libya Denies Planning To Blow Up Embassy
description: Libya today denied Egyptian charges that it was behind a plot to blow up an embassy in Cairo with a truck bomb.

title: MEXICAN TREAT FOR HOLIDAYS
description: Mexican cooking and its variations, Tex-Mex, California-Mex, New Mexico-Mex, have a large following in this country. It long ago left the confines of the Southwest and traveled north and east, where guacamole and tortilla chips have become favored treats.

title: Hospital Corp.
description: The Hospital Corporation of America said it had tentatively agreed to acquire United Medical Plan Inc.'s 4.1 million outstanding shares for about $24 million. United, with headquarters in Richmond, is the state's largest health maintenance organization, composed of 13,000 enrollees and 1,200 participating physicians. In addition to its Richmond operation, United also operates in Norfolk and Newport News, Va., and has 4,000 members in Houston.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have reached a point where it is doubtful whether continuing your current actions can really contribute to the goals which you seek.

title: DOW UP 5.26 TO 1,301.97 IN PRE-HOLIDAY TRADING
description: Stock prices gained slightly yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped back above the 1,300 level. But activity was light as investors made an early getaway for the Memorial Day weekend.

title:
PATENTS;

To the Computer
description: A WORD recognizer patented this week for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., is expected to make it easier to talk to computers. Patent No. 4,519,094 was granted to Michael K. Brown of the robotics principles research department and Lawrence R. Rabiner, who heads acoustics research.

title: CAVENHAM USA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax provisions of $527,000 for the quarter and $1,067,000 for the year. c-After tax benefits of $1,000,000 for the quarter and $15,000,000 for the year. Cavenham (USA) owns Grand Union Co.

title: PILOTS AND UNITED RESOLVE KEY ISSUE
description: United Airlines and its 5,000 striking pilots resolved their dispute today over a proposed two-tier wage scale, but were still negotiating a back-to-work agreement in the eighth day of the walkout, a mediator said.

title: Stadium President
description: Sportsplex, the domed stadium recommended to be built adjacent to Shea Stadium in Flushing Meadows, Queens, is still just a gleam in developers' eyes.

title: VICTIM OF SPINAL INJECITON DIES
description: A 21-year-old woman, paralyzed and comatose after a doctor mistakenly injected an anticancer drug into her spinal column, died today, officials at a hospital here said.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SEEKS SOLDIERS' RETURN
description: South Africa today requested an urgent meeting with Angola to discuss the return of South African soldiers reported killed or taken prisoner in what appears to have been an abortive covert mission in northern Angola. There was no immediate word of an Angolan reply.

title: Q&A: Mark S. Fowler;   An F.C.C. for the Common Man
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Mark S. Fowler, has a zeal for deregulating the telecommunications and broadcast industries that has generated an abundance of support and opposition.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income. Results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interests.

title: CURBS IMPOSED ON HOMOSEXUALS AS FOSTER PARENTS
description: The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, after two weeks of intense public debate, announced a new policy today that would essentially prohibit what had been possible in every state: the placement of foster children in the care of homosexuals.

title:
PATENTS;

A Cancer Care Drug And Protein Advance
description: Patents were received this week by two large biotechnology companies. The Cetus Corporation in Emeryville, Calif., announced a patent covering a drug potentially valuable in the treatment of various forms of cancer and infectious diseases.

title: MEDICARE-GLASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NEWEST OILER GETS HAIRCUT AND HELMET
description: In accordance with the rules and regulations of his new league, The Ringer wore a helmet Thursday night for his first appearance with the Edmonton Oilers. For Esa Tikkanen, this was a very good thing for two reasons.

title: PROSECUTORS GET 3 DAYS TO FIND VON BULOW WITNESS
description: Judge Corinne P. Grande this afternoon gave state investigators the three-day holiday weekend to find a missing witness against Claus von Bulow and told the defense to be ready to present its side of the case when court resumes Tuesday.

title: SUSPENSIONS BY NAVY
description: The Navy, responding to a widening fraud investigation in Louisiana, said today it had suspended 11 individuals and five companies from doing business with it or any other agency.

title: HYNES IS NAMED SPECIAL PROSECUTOR
description: Charles J. Hynes, who brought a series of major cases a decade ago as the state's nursing-home prosecutor, was appointed yesterday as special prosecutor for investigating corruption in New York City's criminal-justice system.

title: OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT AGREE ON CONTROL OF U.P.I.
description: The owners and management of United Press International reached agreement today on a plan intended to settle questions of control of the financially troubled news agency and set procedures for negotiating U.P.I.'s sale.

title: 11th Rig Victim Is Found
description: Divers have found the body of the 11th and final victim of a capsized oil rig in a remote Louisiana bayou. ''Our divers found the final body under a pipe rack on the outside of the rig,'' Aubrey Authement, a Terrebonne sheriff's spokesman, said Thursday. Stormy weather hampered the search as divers groped through the wreckage in the waters of the Bayou Chene, a major channel for offshore drillers and suppliers, while boats and aircraft joined in the search in breaks in thunderstorms.

title: BLUE JAYS CAPTURE 5TH VICTORY IN ROW
description: Lloyd Moseby hit a two-run homer, and Ernie Whitt belted a three-run shot in a five-run third inning to help the Toronto Blue Jays defeat the Cleveland Indians, 7-6, tonight and extend their winning streak to five games.

title: INFORMED TO STUPEFACTION
description: Doctor, my attention span is fading and I'm worried because I can't remember what yesterday's big sensation was, so I just looked it up in the newspaper, and it was about people killing each other in Beirut. I'd seen it on the TV news the night previous, too. Great action film of men with guns pumping bullets at something, I didn't catch what it was, though I got the impression there were people in or behind it, whatever it was, but come on now, doctor, isn't there great action film every night of bullets being pumped?

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SOVIET REPORTED TO RECALL ENVOY OVER SPY AFFAIR
description: Government officials said today that a retired Navy communications officer and his son had provided prosecutors with details of how they smuggled secret documents to the Soviet Union.

title: Activist Is Denied New Trial In 1975 Reservation Killings
description: A judge has refused to grant a new trial for Leonard Peltier, an American Indian activist convicted of murdering two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation eight years ago.

title: UNDERCOVER DRUG AGENTS ARE INCREASING IN SCHOOLS
description: When Scott Pallito, president of the senior class, sold a gram of cocaine to a young man hanging around the Howell High School parking lot, Mr. Pallito thought he was dealing with a transfer student.

title: YANKS REGROUP AND BEAT A'S
description: All the cameras and microphones were pointed toward Rickey Henderson and Billy Martin, the two native sons who were returning home. But the Yankees, fighting a two-game losing streak, seemed oblivious to the distraction. They regained their sluggish offense, scoring six runs in the fourth inning and easing past the Oakland A's, 10-3, tonight.

title: Bernard G. Gronert, Ex-Editor Of Columbia University Press
description: Bernard G. Gronert, former executive editor of the Columbia University Press, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Little Silver, N.J.

title: THE EARLY DEATH OF A BEDEVILED GENIUS
description: The legend of Lenny Ross began at Yale Law School in 1963.

title: ABC and 67th Street
description: In a dispute with the American Broadcasting Companies, residents of West 67th Street have won a small victory - a hot line that responds to complaints, many resulting from the concern's building project on West 66th Street between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West.

title: Irwin's 136 Leads Memorial by Four
description: Hale Irwin played the difficult Muirfield Village Golf Club course about as well as humanly possible for the first two rounds of the 10th Memorial Tournament - so well that he set a course record by not having a single bogey in 36 holes.

title: END OF ONE DREAM FOR KREEGER, AND HIS SONS
description: At 38, Douglas Kreeger walks around the city, a merchant without a store, trying to turn off the instincts that made him successful for 13 years. ''It's like deprogramming my head after all that time,'' he said.

title: Defendant Questioned On Brutality Charges
description: The man accused of murdering the actress Caroline Isenberg admitted under cross-examination yesterday that he had not told prison officials or his first lawyer that the police beat him and threatened to kill him in order to coerce a confession.

title: BIG APLLE CIDER IS NOT FOR ME
description: It's a wonderful place to visit, but I wouldn't want to live there - or, ''The First 101 Reasons Why New York Is Not So Terrific.'' 1. Apartment rental prices 2.

title: BESICORP GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb. 28
description: b-Net income which includes an extraordinary credit of $225,000, or 1 cent a share, from a tax credit. The company said year-ago results are restated after an adjustment for re-phasing of profits on certain long- term construction contracts.

title: Litton Bids For 35.8% Of Its Stock
description: In a move to restructure its capitalization, Litton Industries yesterday offered to exchange debt securities valued at $87.60 a share for 15 million common shares, or 35.8 percent of its outstanding stock. The offer carries a price tag of more than $1.3 billion in securities.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, MAY 25, 1985

title: D. H. HOLMES CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
EVANGELICAL GROUP SETS PRAYER PROTEST OF FEDERAL POLICIES
description: Hundreds of Christians plan to fan out across the capital on Tuesday, kneel down in Government offices and keep praying until they are arrested.

title: Korea Has Reformed Its Electoral System
description: To the Editor:

title: Jews Press Freed Arabs To Leave West Bank
description: Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank have stepped up a campaign to oust convicted Arab terrorists who were released in the exchange last Monday of 1,150 Palestinian prisoners for 3 captured Israeli soldiers.

title: SOME WHITES ARE RETURNING TO MEMPHIS SCHOOLS
description: Like a lot of other schools in Memphis, Grahamwood Elementary saw white enrollment decline sharply after 1973, when mandatory busing was put into effect as part of a citywide Federal desegregation plan.

title: ROSE BRANDT
description: Rose Brandt, a founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University in the Bronx and the widow of William Brandt, founder of the Brandt movie-theater chain, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Boca Raton, Fla. She was 96 years old.

title: SHIITES IN LEBANON STEP UP FIGHTING WITH PALESTINIANS
description: The battle for control of three Palestinian refugee camps grew more intense today, with Shiite Moslem militiamen and Lebanese Army troops flattening buildings with tanks and bulldozers, and Palestinian defenders mounting ambushes from tunnels.

title: Cobb's New Life In a New League
description: The new United States Basketball League is a modest seven-team outfit that seems very unlikely to ever go the big-time route undertaken by that other out-of-season venture, the U.S.F.L. But for Ernie Cobb it is a chance to play the sport that he insists he still loves. ''It just gives me an opportunity to express myself,'' he says. ''I take the game like an artist.''

title: HEAD OF AGENCY FOR JOB SAFETY RESIGNS HIS POST
description: Robert A. Rowland resigned today as head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, saying his ''mission has been accomplished.''

title: COMBINED RISKS MULTIPLY ODDS AGAINST SEPTUPLETS
description: The least unusual thing about the birth of the Frustaci septuplets was their early arrival. More than 340,000 babies are born prematurely in the United States each year, about 9 percent of all births.

title: A Reagan Lesson
description: The other day in the Rose Garden at a ceremony marking the start of the Government's summer jobs program, President Reagan started out sociologically, almost platitudinously.

title: McDonnell Hughes Unit Penalized on Army Bills
description: The Army announced today that it had halted overhead payments to the Hughes Helicopter division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation because of ''serious'' accounting irregularities.

title: Problem Solved
description: Eleven of the golfers who qualified for this year's MONY Tournament of Champions will be automatically qualified next year because of a ruling that resulted from the change in the tournament's dates.

title: Producer of Sex Films Convicted of Pandering
description: A producer of sexually explicit films has been convicted on five counts of pandering, under a tough 1982 state law that prohibits hiring people for sex acts.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: Results reflect the acquisition of Purity Supreme Inc. as of Aug. 8, 1984.

title: DATRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Mar 31
description: Corrected from Thursday's editions in which the company's results were attributed incorrectly to Datron Corp., a holding company based in Minneapolis that isn't related to Datron Systems Corp.

title: CUITE RETIRING AFTER 16 YEARS AS COUNCIL'S MAJORITY LEADER
description: Thomas J. Cuite, majority leader of the City Council, announced yesterday that he would not seek re-election this year, a decision that will trigger a significant political power shift in city government.

title: CRACKER BARREL OLD COUNTRY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Tulane Star Signs
description: John (Hot Rod) Williams, the Tulane basketball standout, signed a $15,000 contract with the Rhode Islande Gulls of the United States Basketball League yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Chooses Head Of New York Office
description: John L. Hogan, a special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office in Philadelphia, has been selected as head of the bureau's New York City division, F.B.I. Director William H. Webster announced yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;

Removing Fly Ash At Coal-Burning Plants
description: An improved method of removing highly resistant fly ash from the smoke of coal-burning power plants has been developed for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Man Wearing Mask Charged In Carriage Holdups in Park
description: Decoy police officers in a horse-drawn carriage early yesterday arrested a man with a bandanna over his face and charged him with a string of carriage robberies in Central Park.

title: MAKING LITTLE WATER GO A LONG WAY IN JERSEY
description: Residents of 93 communities in northeastern New Jersey have come up with a variety of ways to try to stay within the daily water allotment of 50 gallons a person imposed by state officials last week.

title: Adelphi Gains In Softball Series
description: Adelphi, behind the two-hit pitching of Julie Bolduc, downed Utah, 1-0, today in the losers bracket of the Women's Softball College World Series.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After tax provisions of $900,000 for the quarter and $2,280,000 for the year. c-Net loss after tax benefits of $1,000,000 for the quarter and $15,000,000 for the year. Grand Union Co. is a wholly owned subsidiary of Cavenham (USA).

title: BLAME THE JOCKEY
description: Every business and household should have one: a highly expendable employee who, when anything goes wrong, can take the blame and get the ax. The usual job title is scapegoat, but in racing it's called a jockey.

title: KOREAN STUDENTS CONTINUE U.S. OFFICE SIT-IN
description: The police broke up demonstrations today by hundreds of youths at five universities in support of 60 students occupying a United States Government office here.

title: Books of The Times;   Family in Decline
description: LIVES OF THE SAINTS. By Nancy Lemann. 144 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. ''Then I climbed the sharp hill that led to all the years ahead'' - the epigraph that Nancy Lemann has chosen for her first novel comes from Evelyn Waugh, and it turns out to be a fitting choice indeed. If the first portion of ''Lives of the Saints'' recalls such early satirical works as ''Vile Bodies'' and ''Decline and Fall'' - a giddy, madcap chronicle of giddy, madcap people - it's second half aspires to be nothing less than an American version of ''Brideshead Revisited.'' In chronicling the dissolution of an aristocratic and gloriously eccentric family, ''Saints'' - like Waugh's famous novel - becomes a lovely, grave elegy for lost innocence, for lost youth and a vanished world.

title: CORRECITONS
description: A dispatch from Boston on Tuesday about the proposed extradition of a New England drug defendant to Colombia misidentified the court hearing the case. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

title: GENERAL MAGNAPLATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
description: b-After a provision of $6,600,000 for closure of production facilities.

title: CHINATOWN YOUTH ARRESTED IN SHOOTING THAT INJURED 7
description: A 15-year-old gang member was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting seven people in Chinatown on Monday during a dispute between gang members, the police said.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $414,000 for the quarter and $739,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a charge of $3.5 million from the discontinuance of certain crane product lines.

title: BOUTON CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Net income which has been restated after the discovery of an inventory overstatement that reduced net by $153,000.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a provision for loss on returnable bottles of $17,600,000. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Stake in Asarco
description: The Australian investor Robert Holmes a Court has increased his stake in Asarco Inc. to 9.9 percent of the New York-based minerals concern's shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Holmes a Court said that between Monday and Thursday he bought 305,400 Asarco common shares for prices ranging from $23.50 to $24.25 a share, or a total of $7.3 million. In previous S.E.C. filings, Mr. Holmes a Court said his purchases of Asarco shares were for investment purposes only.

title: BEIRUT: SYRIA'S ROLE
description: Diplomats and Lebanese sources say the latest bloodshed in Beirut appears to be part of an effort by Syria to impose its will on fractious Lebanon by proxy.

title: U.S. and Japan Opposed Poison-Gas Protocol
description: To the Editor:

title: Cotton Prices Decline; Grain and Soybeans Off
description: Cotton futures prices fell yesterday on the Cotton Exchange in New York. Prices fell to new lows midway through the trading session, but recovered some of the losses before trading ended.

title: LEUCADIA: SUCCESSFUL LONER
description: Little known and publicity shy, the Leucadia National Corporation, a New York-based investment and insurance company, has apparently found its niche in the world of corporate takeovers.

title: SOVIET CHALLENGES POPE PLOT CHARGE
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it had created what it called a Committee for the Defense of Sergei I. Antonov, the Bulgarian who is to go on trial in Rome on Monday on a charge of plotting to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981.

title: Bridge: $50,000 Is Raised for Charity In U.J.A.-Federation Event
description: The world's most successful bridge charity event was played Thursday night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street in Manhattan, raising some $50,000 for the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies Campaign.

title: Sakharov Is Reported To Stage Hunger Strike
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and dissident, was on a hunger strike last month but has ended it and is in better health, a close friend said today.

title: A Move to Treasury
description: Robert M. Kimmitt, a deputy assistant to the President for national security affairs who is a key figure on the National Security Council, is changing jobs. Mr. Kimmitt, who worked as the executive secretary of the Securty Council and thus ran most of its day-to-day operations, is moving in the next few weeks to the Treasury Department. His new job will be chief counsel to the Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d.

title: 'Doonesbury' Satire Of Film Is Withheld
description: Six installments of the comic strip ''Doonesbury'' that satirize the anti-abortion movie ''The Silent Scream'' will not be distributed, a Universal Press Syndicate official said today.

title: Recruiting Dispute
description: The controversy surrounding the recruitment of the Georgia basketball star Cedric Henderson took a new turn yesterday when the University of Georgia released school documents asserting that Henderson had made false accusations against a Georgia assistant at the request of a Louisville athletic representative. According to the documents, which constituted Georgia's response to the National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation that led to sanctions against the school this week, Henderson, then a highly recruited high school star, told N.C.A.A. investigators last June that a Georgia assistant had paid him $1,200 to sign a letter of intent to attend Georgia.

title: Stolen Dali Paintings Are Recovered Intact
description: Eighteen paintings by Salvador Dali stolen last June from a Newport Beach gallery were found in good condition in the bedroom of a home here, the sheriff's office said.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. IS CHALLENGING POLICE TEST IN NASSAU COUNTY
description: The Justice Department said today that Nassau County's test for police officers violated Federal rules that bar discrimination in hiring.

title: Tough Job for McEnroe
description: John McEnroe, who once again hopes to become the first American to win the French Open since Tony Trabert in 1955, had an unlucky day when the pairings were drawn for the clay-court tournament, which begins Monday. If the seedings hold through the opening rounds, to get to the final McEnroe, the tournament's top-seeded player, would have to beat three top Swedish players who excel on the demanding clay surface: Henrik Sunstrom, who would face McEnroe in the fourth round; Joakim Nystrom, seeded seventh, who would be his quarterfinal opponent, and Mats Wilander, seeded fourth, who would face him in the semifinals.

title: RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Feb 24
description: b-After a tax credit of $400,400. c-Net income which includes a tax credit of $107,660.

title: Rules of I.R.S. On Donations
description: WHEN deductions for donations to charitable, religious, educational or other philanthropic institutions are claimed, they must be supported by evidence in case the tax return is audited. And now the Internal Revenue Service has issued final regulations concerning the details of these substantiation requirements.

title: UNDERCUTTING EDUCATION
description: The State University of New York is being strangled by government regulation and public apathy. If SUNY is to achieve its potential as a great university system educating some 370,000 students each year, its supporters will have to engage in battle in the political arena to an unprecedented degree.

title: Sports Fans
description: For Washington sports fans, there's not much to cheer about these weekends. The local basketball and hockey seasons are finished, and pro football is still months away.

title: NAZI HUNTER, IN A PROTEST IN PARAGUAY, DEMANDS MENGELE'S ARREST
description: A Paris-based Nazi hunter led a small demonstration here today to demand the arrest and extradition of the Auschwitz death-camp doctor, Josef Mengele, who she says is being protected by Paraguay's rightist regime.

title: Tennessee Protests
description: The Southeastern Conference executive committee may have certified the University of Florida last month as the conference's 1984 football champion, but officials at the University of Tennessee say they will try to reverse the decision at the annual league meetings next week. ''There comes a time when you have to take a stand - and winning by the rules is what it's all about,'' said Bill Healey, a Tennessee trustee, who disclosed that Tennesse would move to have Florida stripped of the title because of the string of recruiting violations that led the N.C.A.A. to impose sanctions against the school last year.

title: Death, Out of the Closet
description: ''Pulling the plug'' may seem a cruel phrase for giving up on the fight to save a terminally ill patient, but the touch of callousness often arises from an understandable desire to distance a terrible and irrevocable decision. When is it time to disconnect the tubes, or remove the respirator, or say no to resuscitation? When is it time to let the dying go? Governor Cuomo of New York and his Task Force on Life and the Law, a panel of lawyers, doctors, educators and clergy, offer two thoughtful answers.

title: GULF BROADCASTING
description: An investment group headed by the New York-based Mutual Shares Corporation bought 2,373,117 common shares of the Golf Broadcasting Corporation, or 5.36 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: CBS PREPARES TO COUNTER TURNER BID
description: For more than a month, CBS has been assembling information gathered by at least four law firms as part of its attempt to thwart a takeover by Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcast and cable entrepreneur.

title: RYAN OF ASTROS TOPS CUBS, 6-2
description: Bill Doran had three hits and scored three runs, and Nolan Ryan hurled a seven-hitter today to as the Houston Astros defeated the Chicago Cubs, 6-2.

title: A CROWD OF ROCKEFELLERS AT FOUNDERS BALL
description: The Rockefellers were out in full force Thursday night. The occasion was something of a novelty in New York's social world: The first major dinner-dance ever held for the 84-year-old Rockefeller University.

title: CHIEF OUT AT TEXAS INSTRUMENTS
description: The president and chief executive officer of Texas Instruments Inc., J. Fred Bucy, resigned yesterday in what industry sources suggested was a forced ouster over the electronic company's publicized business failures in the last three years.

title: PANEL SAYS TOBACCO LABELS MUST SWITCH QUARTERLY
description: When Congress passed a law last year requiring that new health warning labels on cigarettes be changed quarterly, it meant four times a year, the Federal Trade Commission ruled unanimously today.

title: COMPUTER RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DR. ROWLAND L. COLLINS
description: Dr. Rowland L. Collins, professor of English at the University of Rochester and an authority on Old English literature and the Victorian period, died May 17 at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester.

title: NICARAGUA BISHOP SAYS U.S. EMBARGO HURTS
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Managua said here today that the United States trade embargo against his country would worsen its already strained economic situation.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOME NAZIS GOT OFF EASY
description: Large rewards have recently been offered for information leading to the capture of Josef Mengele, the ''angel of death'' of Auschwitz-Birkenau. But what of other Nazis and their close collaborators who have found a safe haven in the United States?

title: USED-CLOTHES DEALERS TIED TO SALVATION ARMY PAYOFFS
description: Two exporters of used clothing have been charged in Federal District Court here with paying kickbacks to Salvation Army officers to assure a steady supply of old clothes for shipment to Asia, Africa and Europe.

title: John Aloysius Corroon Jr. Marries Julie B. Baker
description: Julie Beth Baker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Paul Baker of Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday to John Aloysius Corroon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Corroon of New York. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Transactions
description: THURSDAY BASEBALL PITTSBURGH (NL) - Dismissed Harding (Pete) Peterson as executive vice president and general manager.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A RIGHTS PARLEY IN OTTAWA
description: Anton Koslov traveled from New York City to Ottawa recently to tell anyone who would listen about his father.

title: GLOSSER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: The company said results include charges for expenses related to store closings of $420,000 in the latest quarter and $125,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, as some securities dealers said there was a noticeable increase in investor demand from the levels of the three previous days. Speculative trading activity was light in advance of the long weekend.

title: HOW TO STOP RAIDS
description: To the Editor; No one has bothered to ask the 42 million Americans who own shares in public corporations how they feel about hostile takeover bids. For myself, if someone wants to buy a corporation in which I own shares, let them bid for it and see if I think the price is a fair one.

title: OILERS OUTLAST FLYERS
description: The Edmonton Oilers regained some of their offensive touch in the Stanley Cup final tonight, racing to a 4-1 lead and holding on for a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers. Edmonton now leads the four-of-seven-game series, 2-1.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE TOUCH OF TREASON. By Sol Stein. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) This terse thriller flies like a bullet to its inevitable conclusion: winning, whether it concerns a court of law or a raison d'etat, takes precedence over justice.

title: MUSIC IN AMERICA IS A GROWTH INDUSTRY
description: Just a few decades ago, professional music-making in the United States was concentrated in a few large cities, most of them on the East Coast. Today, regional dispersion is a fact of our musical life. New performing arts facilities spring up everywhere. Important symphony orchestras and opera companies exist all over the country. The growth of sophisticated smaller groups - chamber-music and recital series, early- and new-music specialists and the like -follows close behind.

title: When the Two Bills Met at Forest Hills
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

THE DAMAGE VIRUSES CAN DO
description: AMONG the many maladies that act to the detriment of the plants in our gardens are the viruses. Viruses have been described by some pathologists as genes that have gone wrong. Much like a gene, the virus affects the physiology of a cell. However, this effect is abnormal and not to the advantage of the plant.

title: JERSEY PLANS TO CRACK DOWN ON PARKING-TICKET SCOFFLAWS
description: People who fail to pay parking tickets in New Jersey will soon run the risk of stiff penalties, including the loss of their driver's licenses.

title:
ART;

HARONY ACHIEVED, THEN CUT SHORT
description: THE Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton begins its 21st season with a handsome exhibition in memory of John Day and Haydn Stubbing, two artists who were frequent exhibitors there. Although there are also works by several other artists on view, the galleries devoted to Mr. Day and Mr. Stubbing are the focus of the presentation, and while the two display quite different sensibilities, their works are strangely complementary.

title: MAKING OF A MEGAMOGUL
description: ARROGANT AUSSIE The Rupert Murdoch Story. By Michael Leapman. Illustrated. 288 pp. Secaucus, N.J.: Lyle Stuart. 4.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: VIRGINIA DARE: Stories 1976-81. By Fielding Dawson. (Black Sparrow, Cloth, $14. Paper, $8.50.) At first glance, Fielding Dawson might be thought an experimentalist.

title: For Friedan, a Life on the Run
description: BETTY FRIEDAN, founder of the modern women's movement, said she has tried hard this spring to get some work done on her fourth book, which is about aging. She has been working on it for five years. But there are always ''distractions,'' she said: a trip to Nicaragua, where she met with leaders of women's groups; a trip to Munich, West Germany, to protest President Reagan's visit to the Bitburg cemetery, and a commencement address at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, where she received an honorary degree. Whenever things get too hectic, the 64-year-old feminist leader does what she has been doing for the last five years: ''Hotfoot it out to Sag Harbor,'' where she owns a 165-year-old white saltbox house on Glover Street. ''That house saves my life,'' she said. ''Buying it was the smartest thing I ever did.''

title: In Nicaragua
description: Let me commend you for Mario Vargas Llosa's realistic picture of Nicaragua and what is going on there (''In Nicaragua,'' April 28).

title: 15 Hurt in Pakistan Clashes
description: Crowds angered by power cuts and by a water shortage during a heat wave clashed with soldiers and policemen here today, and at least 15 people were injured. Trouble began in the Nazimabad, Liaqatabad and Gulbahar districts on Thursday when people became infuriated over power cuts that shut off electric fans in temperatures around 107 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: FROM SHERLOCK TO MODERN VILLAIN
description: Last year, the tall, debonair British actor who seemed to be getting most of the attention - and most of the roles - on both sides of the Atlantic was Jeremy Irons. This year, it's Jeremy Brett.

title: Drew Can't Raise Bail
description: Unable to raise the $10,000 bail, John Drew, the former Utah Jazz forward, remains in Salt Lake City County jail after being arrested Friday on a charge of issuing bad checks. Drew, waived by the Jazz in midseason after a recurrence of a drug problem, will get no help from his former team, according to the Jazz president, David Checketts, who said team officials had discussed the matter and decided not to bail Drew out.

title: SMALL STAFFS
description: To the Editor:

title: HARTFORD: A CITY BORN OF BRAINS AND GRIT
description: LET'S hear it for Hartford, as this old Yankee town prepares to celebrate 350 years young. If you count the Dutch fort erected in 1633, Hartford goes back even farther than the 1635 settlement. Indeed, the Rev. Thomas Hooker's venerable village is older than the nation. But as parents often are, Hartford has been taken for granted.

title: President Meets Cambodian Portrayed in 'Killing Fields'
description: President Reagan met Friday with Dith Pran, a Cambodian whose ordeal under the Khmer Rouge and subsequent escape is portrayed in the film ''The Killing Fields.''

title: Chicago's Midway
description: To the Editor: There was a significant omission in the May 5th article and accompanying map for ''The Midwest's Brawny Capital.''

title: APRIL PERMITS RISE BY 40%
description: APRIL was the best month for Connecticut's housing industry in more than five years, according to figures released by the State Department of Housing last week.

title: EGGS BY FABERGE
description: Peter Carl Faberge, Russian jeweler to the Romanovs, is best remembered for his Imperial Easter eggs. These pre-Revolutionary extravaganzas, commissioned by Alexander III and Nicholas II from the mid-1880's through 1917, combined toys, clocks and automatons with jewels, semiprecious stones, enameling and gold. Faberge executed 54 or 57 of these bejeweled prizes, one of which - the 1900 Cuckoo Egg - will be the first auctioned in America when it comes up for sale at Sotheby's on June 11.

title: Social Events
description: Boating and Other Parties For Decades of Help May 28 - When they founded the Northside Center for Child Development in 1946, Dr. Kenneth B. Clark and Dr. Mamie Phipps Clark were young psychologists concerned with the stresses of poverty on children. The Harlem-based center now provides psychological, educational and support services to children, ages 3 to 16, and their familes, serving about 1,000 people each year. The 70-year old Dr. Kenneth Clark will be honored, along with his late wife, at a black-tie benefit for the center at the Hotel Pierre, starting with cocktails at 7 P.M., followed by dinner and entertainment. Tickets, $175, from 212-860-1616. A Century of Summers May 29 - Since its founding 108 years ago, the Fresh Air Fund has become a New York institution. This summer, 13,000 New York City youngsters will head for four camps and homes in 326 communities in 13 states and Canada for weeks of outdoor activities not available at their own homes. To support the fund, a dinner at Sardi's will begin at 6 P.M., followed by a special preview of the new musical ''Singin' in the Rain,'' adapted from the movie by Betty Comden and Adolph Green and directed and choreographed by Twyla Tharp. Tickets for dinner, $27, and $85, $95 or $110 for orchestra tickets, from 212-832-8056 Party on Fifth Avenue May 29 - There will be games for the youngsters and cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and games for the adults from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. at the F.A.O. Schwarz store, Fifth Avenue at 58th Street, for the benefit of the New York City Committee, Arts With the Handicapped.

title: PAPER SAYS ISRAELI OUTLINED INVASION
description: A Labor Party newspaper has printed what it says is the American diplomatic summary of a meeting between Ariel Sharon and Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, on Dec. 4, 1981, during which the Israeli minister is said to have outlined plans for an invasion of Lebanon.

title: A SERENADE TO LEELANAU
description: Remember the picnics we had at the springs, The sails in the moonlight, the Sunday night sings, The calm of the lake in the dawn's early light; Leelanau, Leelanau, land of delight. S o goes the first verse of a favorite song in Michigan's Leelanau Peninsula, and the singers - year-round residents, summer people and weekend visitors alike - sound as if they mean every word. Just look around, they say proudly. And they often add: but don't tell anybody else.

title: Radio Marti Is on the Air
description: The Reagan Administration last week began daily broadcasts to Cuba, touching off an exchange in which policymakers on both sides seemed to be tuning out.

title: NEW YORK TO CHECK MEDICAID ELIGIBILITY THROUGH COMPUTER
description: New York State plans to spend $22 million, mostly in Federal funds, over the next five years to set up a system of plastic identification cards with computer-encoded tapes for Medicaid recipients.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSE APPROVES A SEAT-BELT BILL
description: Connecticut would join New York and New Jersey in requiring people riding in the front seats of cars to wear seat belts, under legislation approved Friday by the State House of Representatives.

title: MONUMENTS OF A DISCONTINUED CITY
description: RENAISSANCE PARIS Architecture and Growth 1475-1600. By David Thomson. Illustrated. 214 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. Cloth, $37.50. Paper, $15.95. THERE is not much Renaissance architecture left in Paris. Unlike Renaissance Rome, Venice or even Antwerp, Renaissance Paris has practically vanished. Nevertheless, the royal palace of the Louvre, started under Francis I and built for his successors, has played a decisive role in the shaping of the city, although the Renaissance building as it was conceived by the original architect, Pierre Lescot (1515?-78), is almost buried and lost in a vast complex of museums and offices that developed over four centuries. Right now, in fact, the plans of I. M. Pei for yet another addition (a glass pyramid) to the great monument have created a violent controversy.

title: SEOUL PROTESTERS LEAVE U.S. OFFICE
description: South Korean students today ended a four-day occupation of a United States Goverment office, leaving voluntarily without receiving the American apology that they had demanded.

title: TRANSIT NEEDS A TOUCH OF THE MARKET
description: QUESTIONS have been raised recently about whether the private sector is willing or able to finance and operate transit services. But the key issue is not whether the private sector can by itself carry out the projects, but whether many of these projects can or should be undertaken without significant private involvement. In my judgment, the answer is no.

title: VANISHING SONGBIRD TRAIL LEADS TO TROPICS
description: To the Editor:

title: CAR BOMBER FAILS IN ATTEMPT TO KILL LEADER OF KUWAIT
description: A suicide driver rammed a bomb-laden car into the motorcade of the Kuwaiti leader today, killing himself, two bodyguards and a passer-by in an unsuccessful assassination attempt, Kuwaiti officials said.

title: A Smoke-Free Diet
description: SINCE USING this space recently to de-scribe the miseries afflicting me since I stopped smoking 361 days ago, I have been inundated with expert opinion. Almost all the experts agree that the constant strangling sensation I suffer in neck and waist is not the result of a mysterious shrinkage of clothing, as I suppose, but is caused by food-fueled expansion of the fatty tissues.

title: GOVERNMENT FORESAKES POOR, CUOMO TELLS FORDHAM CLASS
description: Governor Cuomo told the 140th graduating class of Fordham University in the Bronx yesterday that they were entering adult life in a nation that had forsaken its poor through a ''policy of governmental euthanasia.''

title: 28 CONSECRATED 'PRINCES OF THE CHURCH'
description: Pope John Paul II consecrated 28 cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church today in an outdoor ceremony grand in pageantry and resonant in tradition.

title: 'WE HAVE HAD MANY SUCCESS STORIES IN THE DEFENSE DEPARTMENT'
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW WAY OF LOOKING AT CRAFTS
description: IT WILL be interesting to watch the evolution of a new series of museum exhibitions that will replace the New Jersey Artists Biennial.

title: PIANO RECITAL: NINA TICHMAN
description: NINA TICHMAN'S piano recital Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street) was blessed with the kind of physical confidence that liberates the mind and heart of the performer. And Miss Tichman has much to say.

title: STATE PREPARES FOR ROAD PROJECT
description: THE State Department of Transportation is mounting an educational effort to prepare motorists for the long-awaited $800 million widening of Interstate 91 from Hartford to Massachusetts.

title: HE WORKS HARD AT BEING JAMES BOND
description: James Bond's hotel room at the Pierre is something of a disappointment. There are no beautiful women with funny names sprawled on the bed. No frosty vodka martinis, stirred or shaken, on the coffee table. And, alas, no Doctor No. There is only a polite, middle-aged British gentleman offering a chair and a glass of Perrier. It is hard to get used to Roger Moore without the usual archvillains and glamorous accouterments.

title: DOES SHAE'S MALE ANIMAL SPEAK TO MODERN MAN?
description: In ''Arms and the Man,'' George Bernard Shaw debunks the myths of war as noble and heroic and of love as chivalric and uplifting. His ideas were controversial when the play was written in 1895, but today, after two World Wars, Sigmund Freud and the dawn of the nuclear age, they are no longer startling. Shaw, nearly a century later, is an iconoclast whose icons are already largely broken.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS ARE HOLDING TALKS ON AIRLINE SAFETY
description: The United States, the Soviet Union and Japan have been negotiating on air safety to avoid a repetition of the downing of a South Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter in 1983, American officials said today.

title: Position of Ueberroth On Drugs Is Applauded
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;

THE DAMAGE THAT VIRUSES CAN DO
description: AMONG the many maladies that act to the detriment of the plants in our gardens are the viruses. Viruses have been described by some pathologists as genes that have gone wrong. Much like a gene, the virus affects the physiology of a cell. However, this effect is abnormal and not to the advantage of the plant.

title: FOR NORWALKERS, TOUR FINDS THE DIVERSITY IN THEIR HOMETOWN
description: WIDE-EYED and anxious, the tourists fidgeted in the bus seats and talked excitedly about the journey that lay ahead.

title: LITTLE WORDS THAT EXCLUDE
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE APPROVES A BUDGET PLAN, NEW CHAIRMAN PASSES TEST
description: THE approval by the House of Representatives last week of a 1986 budget package was confirmation that the Congress was moving seriously toward deficit reduction - and by means that include a freeze on military budget increases. It was also a striking expression of a rare phenomenon in a usuaally fractious House: Democratic unity.

title: HOW TO STOP RAIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Action photos;   VALENZUELA OUTPITCHES GOODEN, 6-2
description: Fernando Valenzuela outpitched Dwight Gooden and won the duel of the titans yesterday, as the Los Angeles Dodgers overpowered the reeling Mets, 6-2, and sent them to their fourth straight defeat.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch last Sunday from Belgrade, Yugoslavia, about recent bombings in Bulgaria, and its headline, misattributed the death toll. Reports of 30 deaths came from diplomats and Bulgarian citizens; a Bulgarian prosecutor, Kostadin N. Lyutov, gave some casualty figures but not a total.

title: TV'S PERSPECTIVE IS DEBATED To the Editor:
description: The question John Corry raises in his essay ''Is TV Unpatriotic or Simply Unmindful?'' [May 12] is a good one.

title: MISS KOHNSTAMM WEDS DAVID BEAL
description: The marriage of Emily Kohnstamm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lothair Kohnstamm of Pound Ridge, N.Y., to David Curtis Beal took place yesterday at the First Parish Church in Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Robert Walsh performed the Unitarian ceremony.

title: DEBORAH F. FRENCH TO WED
description: Deborah F. French, a sculptor and fashion editor, plans to be married June 28 to Evangelos Tsangaris, a professional photographer. Mr. and Mrs. William T. French of Darien, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ilias Tsangaris of Athens.

title: Looking at the Police
description: The Governor also announced last week that he would appoint a commission to investigate police brutality and examine broadly the use of force by police departments in New York. Mr. Cuomo said his action was prompted by recent allegations of brutality by police officers in New York City and other parts of the state. The problem, he said, has become ''insistent and pervasive.''

title: TODAY
description: Auto Racing The 69th annual Indianapolis 500. Rick Mears, who won in 1979, is the defending champion. But this year Pancho Carter has the pole position and Mears qualfied 10th. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. to midnight, tape.) Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif. (Television - SportsChannel, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 4 P.M.) Braves vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Atlanta (Television - WTBS, 2:05 P.M.) Boxing Milton McCrory vs. Luis Santana, 10 rounds, welterweights, at Miami. Nontitle bout. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Football Generals vs. Bandits, at Tampa Bay. Both teams are coming off defeats last week, and the Generals have lost two of their last three games. (Television - Channel 7, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 2:30 P.M.) Soccer Costa Rica vs. United States, at San Jose, Costa Rica. After winning both of its games with Trinidad-Tobago, the United States has a 1-point lead in the group and needs only a victory today or a split of the two games scheduled with Costa Rica to advance. (Television - Channel 41, 12:45 P.M. ESPN, midnight, tape.) Track and Field The Metropolitan Athletics Congress Outdoor Championships, for men and women, at St. John's University, Utopia and Grand Central Parkways, 9:30 A.M.
