Al Oerter, the four-time Olympian, will defend his Met title in the discus throw, and Craig Masback will be dueling Ross Donoghue in the 1,500 meters.

title: THE MATCHMAKER OF SEEING EYE DOGS AND MASTERS
description: Richard Krokus is a compassionate man with an inexhaustible well of patience. Thus, it is somewhat of a surprise to hear him wisecrack, ''Doctors who go blind often continue to practice, although, of course, they don't do surgery.''

title: RAILROAD OPENS FOR WEEKEND RUNS
description: THE Housatonic Railroad did not get official approval to operate its run from Canaan to West Cornwall until two days before its May 18 opening. But at 10:30 A.M. a week ago Saturday, the rail line's 45-ton diesel set forth on the 13.4-mile trip with 40 passengers on board to inaugurate its first full tourist season.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS MOVE AGAINST DRUGS
description: ''WHEN my kids go to a party,'' said Archibald Montgomery 3d, headmaster of Kent Place School in Summit, ''I say, 'If you take liquor or drugs, I'm going to dismiss you. You can say that your headmaster is a Fascist.' ''

title: MARK SILVERMAN AND MISS LYNCH TO MARRY IN FALL
description: Mrs. Melvus George Furney of Rowayton, Conn., and Robert Franklin Lynch of Paget, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Landa Lynch, to Mark Bartholomew Silverman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Syd Silverman of White Plains. An October wedding is planned.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FILMS AND AN OPERA
description: The Best Years of Our Lives Starring Fredric March, Myrna Loy, Teresa Wright, Dana Andrews, Virginia Mayo, Harold Russell, Hoagy Carmichael, Gladys George, Steve Cochran; directed by William Wyler, 1946 Distributor 172 minutes.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ IN MONTCLAIR Marlene VerPlanck came to pop and jazz from the world of backup vocalizing and jingles (she used to be the voice of Campbell's Soup). But that was a while ago.

title: Scots Top England, 1-0, In Soccer at Glasgow
description: Scotland scored a 1-0 victory over England today in the 103d international soccer meeting between the two countries.

title: VOICES FROM SPAIN SALUTE THE ZARZUELA
description: Among the three best known 20th-century Spanish composers - Frederico Moreno Torroba, Manuel de Falla and Joaquin Turina - Torroba stands highest in the hearts of his countrymen. His zarzuela ''Luisa Fernandez'' has been performed no less than 8,000 times since its premiere in 1932!

title: Head of OSHA Quits His Post
description: During his 10 months as head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Robert A. Rowland encountered more than a few workplace hazards of his own.

title: STUDY FINDS SCHOOLS MADE NO PROGRESS IN REDUCING DROPOUTS
description: The New York City public school system made no progress in the 1983-84 academic year in preventing students from dropping out of school, according to a Board of Education report.

title: IN NICARAGUA
description: Mario Vargas Llosa describes in his article how Commander Tomas Borge Martinez, Minister of the Interior, on a visit to a prison farm, gives a pardon to a former Somoza guard. He cuts five years off of a 10-year prison sentence and gives orders for his immediate release.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CHINA COMES TO BOSTON Using a needle slimmer than human hair, a Chinese embroiderer will create two different images at the same time, one on each side of sheer silk gauze.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: COME SING, JIMMY JO By Katherine Paterson. 197 pp. New York: Lodestar Books/ E. P. Dutton. $12.95. (Ages 10 and up) DURING the late 1930's, the best thing about a family visit to my cousin Mary Louise's house in Goldthwaite, Tex., was her mother's poems. Aunt Virginie grew up in West Virginia and had memorized old rhyming stories. One was about a little boy whose father died. The boy wrote him a letter in care of heaven, put a stamp on it, ran out to mail it and was hit by a carriage and killed. The poem concluded, amid a heavy flow of tears from little listeners, that the letter was getting special delivery.

title: DR. ROSE IS WED TO K. HAL PURDY
description: Dr. Elizabeth Rose, a daughter of Jerome and Naomi Rose of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to K. Hal Purdy, a son of Janice W. Rush of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Malcolm Mills Purdy of Livingston, N.J. Mayor William Walker of Hopewell, N.J., performed the ceremony at Prospect Gardens at Princeton University.

title: A CAMP COUNSELOR'S QUALIFICATIONS
description: ALWAYS on the lookout for possible summer jobs for my college-age children, I recently spotted an ad in the local paper for camp counselors. The ad listed several subjects in which the applicant should be an expert or at least knowledgeable. After a few minutes of contemplation I realized that what the camp really wanted was not an 18- or 20-year-old student, but an experienced mother. And after a few more minute's contemplation, I realized that I was eminently qualified for the position.

title: BLACK-AND-WHITE FILM STILL POPULAR
description: REMEMBER these - Panatomic-X, Plus-X, Verichrome Pan, Super-XX Pan and Royal-X Pan? They're black-and-white films and, believe it or not, still available and being sold along with a lot of others. Indeed, according to industry statistics, photographers are not only interested in black-and-white film but the demand for it is steady.

title: TOPICS
description: SHOPPING is my problem. I didn't even know I had it until my mother and daughters started making remarks like ''Where were you? We just turned around for a minute and you were gone,'' or ''How many stores are you going to this time?'' But none of this got through to me until my mother confided in me something my daughter said, ''If she ever became wealthy or won a lottery, she'd never last, she'd be dead within a month.''

title: Gandhi Stresses Ties With Moscow
description: Rajiv Gandhi chose the Soviet Union last week for his first official trip abroad since becoming Prime Minister of India last November. In addition to an elaborate welcome, Moscow responded with trade credits of $1.15 billion for goods and services to develop India's energy and industrial resources.

title: YANKS LOSE ON WALK
description: At first, everything seemed in order: a walk with the bases loaded and two outs in the ninth, a run to decide the game, an 8-7 Oakland A's victory over the Yankees.

title: Brooklyn Slaying
description: THE case was initially likened to the 1964 slaying of Kitty Genovese, whose screams were heard by at least 38 people in Queens, none of whom called the police.

title: IN CHAGALL'S WORLD, COLOR WAS ALL - BUT NOT ENOUGH
description: The timing of the Marc Chagall retrospective at the Philadelphia Museum of Art could hardly be better.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ALTHOUGH a new book about land use and environmental planning in the Pine Barrens stresses over and over what the authors call the ''disruptive and destructive'' effects of misinformation about what comprises more than 20 percent of the state's land area, there is nothing pedagogic about its content or approach.

title: 3-YEAR-OLD PERINATAL CENTER ON VERGE OF EXPANSION
description: THE graduating class at the Regional Neonatal Intensive-Care Unit of the Westchester County Medical Center will hold its usual, lively graduation exercises on Wednesday.

title: NEW 'PRINCES OF THE CHURCH'
description: Twenty-eight churchmen became Cardinals today. Here are the new ''princes of the church'':

title: CARNIVALS TO SHAPE OUR CULTURE
description: ALL THE WORLD'S A FAIR Visions of Empire at American International Expositions, 1876-1916. By Robert W. Rydell. Illustrated. 328 pp. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. $27.50. FOR me, the World's Fair will always be the New York World's Fair of 1939. A little train took me, an 8-year-old from New Jersey, along the sunny land of General Motors' ''Futurama,'' where someday-to-be interstate highways bypassed the world. On my toes in the perfumed French pavilion I looked into glass cases holding, in the intoxicating luxury of deep blue velvet, the jewels of queens; at the exhibit called ''Bring 'Em Back Alive,'' the great white hunter Frank Buck smiled down at me. I still remember the wonderful tiredness at the end of a day more satisfying than most since. I have never known the need to see another world's fair, and I had no idea at the time that I had been subjected to a ''hegemonic assertion of ruling-class authority.''

title: AN EDUCATION FOR BANKERS AND EXECUTIVES
description: ON most days at the Center for Financial Studies on the campus of Fairfield University, students are doing what students typically do: attending lectures, studying, congregating in small groups with other students, sharing meals and making plans for a late-afternoon squash game. The students at the center, however, are more likely to be bankers, corporate executives, manufacturers and other men and women in a variety of continuing-education programs.

title: RECOVERING ROMANTIC GEMS FROM UNFAMILIAR TERRAIN
description: For better or worse, no one can deny that Romantic music constitutes the bulk of our concert programs and looms largest in the hearts of audiences. Yet this devotion to the 19th century has not been matched by an urge to delve into unexplored corners of the Romantic repertory. The Baroque revival of the last three decades makes a striking contrast: it progressed rapidly from the works of Vivaldi and Telemann to nearly forgotten figures such as Pachelbel and Zelenka. Romanticism, perhaps because it never went out of fashion, has not been so fortunate. How ironic it is that, despite our evident affection for 19th-century music, we have been content to repeat the same warhorses, only rarely venturing into unfamiliar terrain.

title: FORGING A NEW SHAPE FOR STEEL
description: WHEN the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation entered bankruptcy proceedings last month, it may have appeared that the rest of the industry would benefit by getting rid of some big competition. But Wheeling-Pitt is far from dead. In fact, if it can escape liquidation and reorganize successfully under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws, the nation's seventh-largest steel company may be reborn, with much lower costs, as a formidable competitor. With its stock holding up at 8 1/4 as of Friday, company shareholders seem to be betting that a comeback is in the cards.

title: ESTABLISHING A 'FLIP TAX'
description: Question: Our co-op board wants to institute a ''flip tax.'' Do the shareholders have to approve the tax? If so, what percentage is required? . . . L. S., Manhattan Answer: If ''flip taxes,'' or transfer payments, are not authorized in the proprietary lease, the lease must be amended, which requires a vote of the shareholders, says Marc Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.

title: THE CHINESE STUMBLE ON THE ROAD TO PERSONAL FREEDOM
description: For more than five years, at a pace that has astonished people who knew Mao Zedong's China, the makers of the country's ''second revolution'' have proceeded to dismantle the rigid system imposed by Mao. Deng Xiaoping has established the elements of a society that takes man largely as is, instead of trying to remold him. Energies have been liberated that have placed one of the world's poorest nations on a fast track toward modernity.

title: EXPIRING LEASES SOFTEN THE MARKET
description: A COMPANY looking for office space in northern New Jersey these days has an abundance of choice. Developers built 20 million square feet of new space last year and they are at work now on 14 million square feet more - 8 million scheduled for completion this year. There are dozens of new buildings, freshly painted and never occupied, just waiting for the right tenant.

title: A LESSON IN SNOBBERY AND SCHOOL BOARDS
description: IT is often the smarter kids in school who ask the most questions. They are the ones who realize that they do not know everything and that it makes good sense to take advantage of whatever expertise the teacher may have to offer. In the adult world, however, a lot of presumably smart people would sooner consult a soothsayer than a schoolteacher - even when the questions at hand involve public education.

title: FOR SUMMER THIRST-QUENCHING: LOOK TO PITCHERS AND PUNCHES
description: AS a category of alcoholic beverage, the wine cooler, a takeoff on sangria and a newcomer on the scene, is bound to be more popular than ever this summer. The drink is a blend of citrus juice and wine and can be as refreshing a warm-weather quaff as its name implies.

title: ELIZABETH KEARNS AND VAN YOUNG EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Elizabeth C. Kearns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David T. Kearns of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Van G. Young, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Young of Atlanta, and formerly of New Canaan. The Rev. Paul L. Sartorio performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church of New Canaan.

title: LARRY BIRD A JOY, EVEN WHEN AILING
description: EVEN a Bird with his wing in disrepair is a joy in the eye of a basketball junkie. His shooting limb is in shambles - the index finger of his right hand is sprained and he has bursitis in his right elbow - yet Larry Bird remains as many-splendored as a peacock. With the Boston Celtics entering the National Basketball Association championship series tomorrow against the Los Angeles Lakers, Celtic fans are aware that even Bird must play more soundly than he did against the 76ers, if the Celtics are to beat the powerful Lakers.

title: THE CRAFT OF THE PLAYWRIGHT
description: WHEN DAVID RABE'S first play, ''The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel,'' was performed at New York's Public Theater, Neil Simon was already up to play No. 11 - ''The Prisoner of Second Avenue'' - and counting. Since that year, 1971, both men have consolidated their reputations - Mr. Simon as America's most successful and prolific playwright, Mr. Rabe as one of the most provocative.

title: FUND DRIVE FOR FORT MCHENRY
description: Inspired by the campaign to restore the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor, a group of business people and civic leaders say they hope to raise more than $27 million in the next three years for repairs to Fort McHenry, where ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' was written.

title: VERBATIM: TEACHERS' DRUG TESTS
description: 'You can't have role models who use cocaine.' rrHenry P. Read, rrSuperintendent of the Patchogue-Medford School District on Long Island, testifying in support of a requirement that new teachers and teachers seeking tenure submit to drug tests. rr 'It is demeaning and unnecessary. We object because it's sort of like a witch hunt.' rrAnthony Conetta, rrPresident of the local teachers union, which sued to block the policy.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RAINY DAY MAN. By Rita Garitano (Norton, $14.95.) Staying with this intense novel to its final pages is painful to the point of catharsis.

title: NOW, THE PC IS LEARNING TO READ
description: TYPISTS have become word processors, mice can manipulate blocks of text on the computer screen and modems allow an endless stream of information to flow into the computer over telephone lines. But when all is said and done, almost everything having to do with personal computing still begins with the keyboard.

title: Express to Play Finale At Junior College Site
description: The Los Angeles Express, ownerless and attendance-poor, will play its final game of this United States Football League season at Pierce College in nearby Woodland Hills, it was announced today.

title: REAGAN PRESSES CAMPAIGN FOR TAX SIMPLIFICATION
description: President Reagan today billed his plan to simplify the Federal income tax as ''one of the most compelling issues of our time'' and one that would benefit American families.

title: KELLY MCGUIRE IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Robert J. McGuire of Parlin, N.J., and Margaret Nelson of Whitestone, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter Kelly Rita McGuire to Brian Patrick McKeon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John McKeon of Massapequa, L.I. The wedding is planned for Aug. 24.

title: Music
description: Compared to Gilberto Gil and a handful of his colleagues in Brazil, pop in the English-speaking world can seem downright isolationist. Since the late 1960's, when he began merging the devilishly smooth rhythms and harmonies of Brazilian pop with the punch of rock, Mr. Gil has kept his ears open; reggae, African music and the latest North American pop all echo in his songs, yet his music retains a distinctly Brazilian playfulness. Mr. Gil and his band will be performing Wednesday at Carnegie Hall.

title: PERSPECTIVES: S.R.O.'s;   HOW FRANCISCANS WOULD USE MACKLOWE'S $2 MILLION
description: TWO Franciscan priests who serve the poor in the East 20's have an urgent real-estate problem. Under the pressure of an Aug. 15 deadline, they must develop a plan acceptable to the city to acquire, reconstruct and begin operating some property -probably an old hotel - for about 100 dependent lower-income single adults.

title: THOUSANDS IN STATE GET DEGREES
description: CAPS and gowns have seemingly replaced button-down shirts, blouses and designer jeans as the garments of choice these days on state college campuses, and ''Pomp and Circumstance'' has moved to the top of the charts, as graduating seniors await commencement exercises and the awarding of degrees.

title: AN EX-DRUG DEALER RECOUNTS 'JOURNEY'
description: MOST students admit that a cornucopia of drugs is available to them and most know where to get them, but they rarely share that information with an adult.

title: WHAT HAPPENS WHEN BEER AND WINE AND TELEVISION MIX?
description: CONGRESS is once again dealing with the dispute over beer and wine advertising on television and radio. Should it ban such advertising as it banned cigarettes in 1970 on the ground that potentially harmful products should not be sold over the public airwaves? Should it require television and radio stations to broadcast messages about the adverse effects of alcohol?

title: SABINA P. GOLDING, AN AIDE IN SENATE, IS BREIDE OF JOSHUA M. JAVITS, A LAWYER
description: Sabina Paula Golding and Joshua M. Javits were married yesterday in the New York home of the bridegroom's parents, former Senator and Mrs. Jacob K. Javits. Sol Wachtler, the Chief Judge of New York State, officiated.

title: POSITIONAL PLAY: QUIET BUT DEADLY
description: Positional play often gives the impression of being so leisurely that one can hardly rely on it as a means of winning a game. Its regimen of slow, indirect maneuvering is easily taken to be an indication that nothing is happening, that a draw is in the offing.

title: MORE SKELETONS IN A FAMILY CLOSET
description: IN P. J. Barry's recent Broadway play, ''The Octette Bridge Club,'' eight aging sisters confront their family skeletons. His latest play, ''Baby Grand,'' which is currently receiving its world premiere at the Long Island Stage in Rockville Centre, is also about siblings, their rivalries and their family skeletons.

title: MORE THAN 'LAW AND ORDER,' 2 CARDINALS SAY
description: It was a formidable, even intimidating, sight.

title: FARM FAMILY'S RESPITE: SUNDAY OF SUN AND HOPE
description: In farm country, this is the season of hope. The spring rains have fallen softly and generously on the plowed fields. Soybeans are sprouting through the thin crust, young corn stretches like strands of jade across the land and sturdy stalks of winter wheat are heavy with grain.

title: TINY BOXES OF REMEMBRANCE
description: COLLECTORS who look for a place to browse among their favorite antiques each weekend will probably spend a good part of Saturday on the grounds of the Community Center in Ridgefield.

title: KILLINGS SOAR IN 'WILD SOUTH' OF THE PHILIPPINES
description: The southern island of Mindanao has long had a reputation as ''the Wild South'' of the Philippines.

title: Cost of 718
description: STATEN ISLAND raised the option of secession. Brooklyn businesses would have to pay $600 each for new stationery, the Borough President estimated.

title: Article 006879 -- No Title
description: A Federal District Court jury awarded Helen C. Byron, a former follower of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, $1.64 million Friday in compensation for a loan that was never repaid.

title: 42-YEAR TORY RULE SEEMS TO BE ENDING IN ONTARIO
description: Ontario's two opposition parties have combined to try to end the four-decade-old reign of the Progressive Conservative Party over Canada's most populous and economically powerful province.

title: INDONESIANS TRY TO SORT OUT PATH FOR FUTURE
description: To hear Indonesians talk about it, a struggle is on for the soul of this Asian country.

title: THE LONG WAY: LAND'S END TO JOHN O' GROATS
description: JOHN HILLABY; JOHN HILLABY, president of Britain's Backpackers' Club, is the author of ''Journey Home'' (Holt, Rinehart & Winston) and other books on walking.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FROM THE BRONX Yitzroch Loiza Grossberg was born in the Bronx in 1923 and attended P.S. 32, P.S. 78 and Evander Childs High School before becoming a jazz saxophonist and a painter who re-named himself Larry Rivers. Some of his works, along with those by a number of other born and/or bred Bronx artists, will be on exhibit through June 9 at the Herbert H. Lehman College Art Gallery, at Bedford Park Boulevard West in the Bronx.

title: TRANSIT COPS SHOULD BE CITY COPS
description: The wisdom of merging the New York City Transit Police with the regular police force has long been obvious. Over the years, however, mere wisdom has proved no match for jealousies between City Hall and the Transit Authority.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FILMS AND AN OPERA
description: The Women Starring Norma Shearer, Joan Crawford, Rosalind Russell, Virginia Weidler, Mary Boland, Joan Fontaine, Paulette Goddard; directed by George Cukor, 1939 M-G-M/UV 132 minutes. $39.95 The venom of this classy catfight-frolic, adapted from Clare Boothe Luce's 1936 stage hit, still gleams with a marvelous tonic effect.

title: Howell Misses Yanks
description: Broadway, Times Square, the Statue of Liberty, Yankee Stadium. Jay Howell misses them. He misses the bright lights and the Bronx. And the pinstripes.

title: BEING OLD OLD
description: SOME YEARS AGO I published a little book, ''The View From 80,'' that has been pretty widely read by my coevals.

title: 'Literature by Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: LEBANON BATTLE SPREADING EAST TO BEKAA AREA
description: Fighting that has been raging between Palestinian and Shiite Moslem forces for a week in the south of Beirut spread to eastern Lebanon today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE VIEW FROM COYABA. By Peter Abrahams. (Faber & Faber, Cloth $19.95. Paper, $8.95.) Four decades after writing ''Mine Boy,'' a gritty chronicle of black travails in Johannesburg that is widely regarded as the first modern African novel, Peter Abrahams has produced one of black literature's most ambitious works to date.

title: ITS TRUE, ILITERACY HITS TEECHERS
description: Not long ago I wrote a letter requesting a recommendation from a distinguished professor. As I was about to stuff the letter into an envelope, I glanced at it and saw that I had written ''it's place'' instead of ''its place.'' I had substituted a contraction for a possessive!

title: SACRED HEART CATHEDRAL WILL BE RENOVATED
description: THE Cathedral of the Sacred Heart here will undergo a $2.5 million renovation, the first since the massive stone church on Ridge Street was dedicated in 1954, almost 85 years after the cornerstone was laid.

title: BONUSES CALLED GOLDEN TARNISH
description: A HORSE and a race-car driver can become very rich this holiday weekend, symbolizing the blossoming of a new gimmick on the American sports scene - bonus money, instant-wealth earmarked to guarantee the appearance of an attractive competitor who gives an event charisma and credibility.

title: THE HUM IN HER BLOOD
description: LOW TIDE By Fernanda Eberstadt. 173 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: JENNY M. FORSELL TO MARRY SEPT. 1
description: Announcement has been made by Charlotte Bonnier of New York and Stockholm of the engagement of her daughter Jenny Mathilda Forsell to Howard Alan Wolfson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Wolfson of Roslyn, L.I. The future bride is a daughter also of Goran Nils Forsell of Stockholm. A Sept. 1 wedding is planned.

title: Setting Precedents
description: Becoming a judge is often the crowning achievement of a career, and the swearing-in ceremony pays respect to that personal accomplishment. But last week, one of the three new members of New York City's Criminal Court turned what is usually a sedate occasion into an emotional collective celebration.

title: Q. & A. ON ASYLUM: SOME OF THE INS AND OUTS OF WHO GETS IN
description: The United States has a history of offering refuge to people fleeing persecution, but in recent years the Government has turned down thousands of applications from citizens of foreign countries seeking asylum here. The denial of asylum to many Salvadorans, in particular, has stirred protests in recent weeks from members of Congress and church groups. The following questions and answers review the confusion and controversy. Question. Who qualifies for asylum? Answer. Under the Refugee Act of 1980, an alien may qualify for asylum if he has ''a well-founded fear of persecution'' in his homeland ''on account of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group, or political opinion.'' It is common to speak of political asylum, but the law does not restrict asylum to cases of political persecution. Q. How many people get asylum? A. The Immigration and Naturalization Service granted 8,278 applications and denied 32,344 last year as it made a major effort to reduce its backlog of cases. Most of the successful applications came from citizens of Iran (5,017), Nicaragua (1,018) and Poland (721).

title: MASSACHUSETTS SCHOOL MAY TRY A WINDMILL
description: Officials at the Hoosac Valley High School hope to generate part of their own electricity with a windmill financed by an $89,000 grant from the State Office of Energy Resources.

title: EUROPEAN PROJECT PICKS UP SUPPORT
description: A French plan to develop new European technologies, initially announced as a reaction to President Reagan's effort to develop a space-based missile defense system, has begun to take shape in the last few days, with Britain and West Germany indicating that they will take part.

title: Reaves, Walker Playing Key Roles
description: John Reaves, the Bandits' passer, and Herschel Walker, the Generals' runner, can be expected to play the major roles here tomorrow in the game between Tampa Bay and New Jersey.

title: CREATIVITY AND CUSTOMER VALUE
description: There was virtually nothing in Cary Reich's portrait of General Motors' chairman, Roger Smith, regarding the presumed objective of all of Mr. Smith's creativity: customer value. That is because, out of all Mr. Smith's reorganizations, acquisitions, joint ventures and robotics, there is very little indication that the cars produced are going to be safer, less polluting, more fuel-efficient, less repair-prone and fairly priced as modern technology can practically make them be.

title: ESCAPE FROM A WORLD OF SILENCE
description: NOBODY can understand why I love noise.

title: TRIAL BEGINS FOR A TOP JUDGE IN CHICAGO BRIBERY OPERATION
description: Accusations that he took thousands of dollars in return for fixing cases, dropping tickets and allowing a ''hustler's bribery club'' of corrupt lawyers to solicit clients opened the Federal trial of one of Cook County's highest-ranking judges.

title: KATHERINE CRONIN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Katherine Ann Patricia Cronin, a daughter of William Henry Cronin Jr. of New York and Mary Sparko Cronin of Stratford, Conn., was married yesterday to Beverly Scott Hutter Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hutter of Lynchburg, Va. The Rev. Patricia Smith performed the ceremony at St. Columba's Episcopal Chapel in Middletown, R.I.

title: ALISON COLE WED TO D. W. WESTFALL
description: Alison Katharine Cole and Donald Wilson Westfall were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. Victoria Erickson of the United Church of Christ.

title: ISRAEL MAKES A BITTER DEAL, NEW BATTLE JOLTS LEBANON
description: ISRAEL, which will complete its withdrawal from Lebanon in the next two weeks, took another step last week to put a divisive war behind it. It traded 1,150 prisoners, mostly Palestinian, for three Israelis captured during the invasion, and in so doing unleashed another national debate that endangered the Cabinet.

title: THE VETERANS OF ABORTION FIGHT BACK BY SPEAKING UP
description: The bitter debate over abortions seems to have taken another dramatic turn.

title: Major Blackout in Chile Attributed to Terrorists
description: An explosion in the nation's main power station blacked out 80 percent of Chile Friday night. The Government said today that terrorists opposed to the military Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet were responsible.

title: Vietnamese Force Kills 5 Thai Soldiers
description: A Vietnamese force killed five Thai soldiers and a civilian in a one-hour clash with Thai border patrols in northeast Thailand, provincial officials said today.

title: TRADES THAT MIGHT HAVE DIED
description: PROBABLY the most significant sports events in New York this past winter involved baseball: The Mets acquired Gary Carter from Montreal and the Yankees obtained Rickey Henderson from Oakland. The stunning trades ignited talk and excitement among fans that lasted throughout the winter. In the Mets' case, Carter's arrival triggered a surge in the sale of tickets.

title: Brochures
description: To the Editor: May I say a hearty ''Amen!'' to Paul Grimes's Practical Traveler piece in the April 21st issue. Travel brochures can indeed be misleading.

title: 'Literature by Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Literature by Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Jet Pilot Killed in Crash After Trying To Avoid Boats
description: A Navy jet crashed in San Diego Bay today, killing the pilot who stayed at the controls to keep the jet from hitting several boats and a nearby ammunition and fuel dump, the Navy said.

title: Jurors in Oklahoma Sentence Killers to Die
description: Jurors today sentenced two men to die by lethal injection for murdering four people in a bank robbery last December.

title: CHANGE OF PACE ON THE DIAMOND
description: THE California State-Fullerton pitcher, Debbie Mygind, leaves batters lunging and, at times, laughing.

title: HOME ON THE RANGE, AND ANYWHERE ELSE
description: It takes its name from Coyotl, an Aztec god who wore its skins. The Navajos call it ''God's Dog'' for its cleverness, particularly at finding water in the desert.

title: VENTURE CAPITALISM FOR THE 'LITTLE GUY'
description: MIDDLE income investors who have seen their portfolios languish these last few years must look with envy on the financial exploits of such venture capitalists as Arthur Rock. Mr. Rock's instinct for spotting high-tech winners such as Apple Computer and Intel has netted him returns that on occasion run hundreds of times his original investment. By contrast, the Dow Jones industrial average, despite its recent record-breaking surge, is only modestly above its June 1983 level of 1,280.

title: AIRLINE FOOD: FLIGHTS OF FANCY
description: It was the morning after a foreshortened night on a trans-Atlantic flight from New York to London. I had been trying to sleep off the repeated assaults on my digestive system by the airline supper the night before when the stewardess came down the aisle with a breakfast wagon that looked just like the dinner wagon. ''Breakfast?'' she smiled. I knew I should say no. I knew. But, against my better judgment, I nodded. ''Orange juice?'' ''Yes, please.'' ''Coffee?'' ''Yes, please.'' ''Sweet roll?'' ''Yes, please.''

title: No Headline
description: Holding off a late charge from Oklahoma State, Houston won the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's golf title today and became the first school in a decade to win consecutive titles.

title: Headliners;   A Loyal Son
description: He did not last long in freshman football and was once chided by a professor for talking in class. But the University of Notre Dame is nonetheless proud of Jose Napoleon Duarte, class of '48 and the President of El Salvador.

title: FOLK: SI KAHN
description: AS a political songwriter, Si Kahn has two unusual assets. One is his genuine affection for the people he sings about.

title: Recent Sales
description: Chatham $145,000 138 Lafayette Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, *2* screened porch, backyard playhouse; taxes $2,500. Edison $93,000 605 Merrywood Drive *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old town-house condominium; *2* carpeting, deck, $45 monthly charges; taxes $1,699. Hasbrouck Heights $140,000 471 Jefferson Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old split-level; *2* new kitchen and roof, fenced yard, family room; taxes $2,400. Livingston $112,000 30 Dougal Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; *2* rec and family rooms, deck; taxes $1,814. Pompton Plains $176,000 29 Rock Ledge Terrace *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; fireplace, *2* electric heat, 2-car garage; taxes $3,890. Union $109,000 318 Huntington Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 44-year-old Cape Cod; oak floors, *2* fireplace in living room, 1-car garage; taxes $1,730. OTHER AREAS Wantagh, L.I. $137,000 1881 Cornelius Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; *2* dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,200. Fairfield, Conn. $275,000 2171 Fairfield Beach Road *2* 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; waterfront, *2* solar-assisted heat; taxes $2,698. White Plains, N.Y. $195,000 21 Ridgeview Avenue *2* 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 65-year-old frame colonial; wrap-around *2* porch, 2 fireplaces, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,971.

title: DIRECTOR'S LATEST PROJECT WINS ATTENTION
description: THE director Dan Held of Fleetwood appears to have found an attention-getting formula: unearth an unknown straight play by a well-known musical comedy writer. Be certain it contains a heretofore unsung tune by a big-time Broadway composer. Then, ask the critics not to review it. Add to that the shortest title in the annals of theater.

title: CORPORATE FEVER HITS THE ESKIMOS
description: EARLIER this month, the Canadian Government auctioned off its Northern Transportation Company Ltd., a 51-year-old company that had revenues of more than $30 million last year from transporting freight over 5,000 miles of water routes in the Canadian North. The Ministry of Transport accepted the winning bid in principle on May 17. If all goes as planned, the company will belong to the Inuvialuit Development Corporation of the western Arctic and the Nunasi Corporation of the eastern Arctic, a consortium of Eskimos who just a few years ago knew little more about business than the hunting and selling of fur pelts.

title: PUBLISHERS OFFER TO DISCUSSS BOOK LIST WITH U.S. AGENCY
description: The Association of American Publishers has repudiated a letter sent by one of its committees to the National Endowment for Democracy, a bipartisan agency financed by Congress that had complained that the books selected for the Moscow International Book Fair in September lacked ideological balance.

title: SUFFOLK G.O.P. OPPOSING JUDGE
description: NINETEEN months ago, when he was elected Suffolk County Republican chairman, William M. Blake summed up the chronic warfare in the party's ranks with the remark: ''We've got 10 princes and one king with no muscle.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN COLLEGE POINT
description: THE Vogts live on 123d Street in College Point, Queens, in a house built in 1851 by Alfred Vogt's great-great-grandfather. It has been in the family for five generations, but that is not unusual in this waterfront community that more closely resembles a New England village than an urban neighborhood.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

PINKSTER REVISITED
description: GIRL SCOUT Troop 3031 was playing ninepins. Eleven- and 12-year-olds dressed in blue jeans and down jackets scampered about, waiting their turn to heave the wooden ball at the wooden pins, asking instructions of the young man clad in 18th-century breeches.

title: ROSEMARY HALPIN ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Rosemary Ann Halpin and Timothy John Ulles, graduates of Fairfield University, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Goodchild Halpin of Oak Beach, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert George Ulles of Noank, Conn.

title: ALUMNI OF FRESH AIR FUND HAVE FOND MEMORIES
description: Although he has neither photographs nor mementos of the occasion, the summer of 1945 remains vivid for Wilbur Carman.

title: ANXIETY AND HOPE AT MEMPHIS STATE ON BETTING INQUIRY
description: HE has made telephone calls to the United States Attorney in Memphis, Dr. Thomas Carpenter said, in hopes of assurance that the Memphis State basketball program will not be implicated in the continuing Federal grand jury investigation of large-scale bookmaking in the city and its surroundings. But even a university president is not privy to confidential testimony, and Dr. Carpenter's questions were left unanswered.

title: IN QUOTES
description: In recent years and recent months, we have been through the worst of times. We may never again see the best of times, but I firmly believe that better times are coming.'

title: GAY S. MILLER PLANS TO WED
description: Gay Sands Miller and Paul Gregory Clifford plan to be married July 20, her parents, Glen B. Miller Jr. and Mrs. George F. Brown, both of Princeton, N.J., have announced.

title: ELECTION BIDS ANNOUNCED
description: SEVERAL political battles were joined in Westchester last week as campaigns for the fall elections emerged from the springtime doldrums.

title: High Hopes For Housing
description: For months, Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch and their staffs have tried to lay the foundation for a bold effort to build affordable housing in New York City. In January, the Governor proposed a $3.5 billion statewide program, including $1 billion to construct 15,000 apartments for low-income city residents. Four weeks later, the Mayor announced his own $4.4 billion plan to underwrite new housing for poor, working-class and middle-class New Yorkers.

title: NANTUCKETERS DISPUTE NEW YORK AIR FLIGHT PLANS
description: The Indian name for Nantucket meant ''far away land,'' and in recent years this old whaling island has advertised its isolation to spur a major tourist boom.

title: STOCK RETURNS PLUS BATTING AVERAGES
description: If there's one thing that the Financial News Network knows, it is how to read numbers. Begun in November 1981, the basic service has specialized in presenting often highly technical information relating to the stock market and the world of finance, broadcasting on a schedule that runs only from 6 A.M. to 7 P.M. on weekdays. Until very recently, however, the service consistently operated in the red; for FNN, then, the numbers weren't adding up, and it decided to change things - in fact, practically everything. Nowadays, FNN's management is banking not so much on finances as on sports.

title: Q&A
description: Question:The problem we keep facing in planning a European itinerary is connecting destinations. Do you know of a book that focuses on itinerary design for independent travelers? - R. N., Beverly Hills, Calif. Answer:Among books that aim to help travelers move independently from country to country is ''Europe in 22 Days'' (distributed by Norton), by Rick Steves. The book's step-by-step route starts in Amsterdam and leads through West Germany to Austria, Venice and Rome and then northward through Switzerland and finally to Paris. The trip is designed as a 3,000-mile car tour but it can be adapted to rail travel and includes train schedules. Each day is treated as a separate unit, so travelers needn't stick to a 22-day routine. For each day there is a suggested schedule, sightseeing, budget accommodations with addresses and telephone numbers, transportation notes and a map. ''Europe in 22 Days'' is available in some bookstores for $4.95 or from Mr. Steves' company, Europe Through the Back Door, 111 Fourth Avenue North, Edmonds, Wash. 98020, for $4 postpaid.

title: OUT-OF-STATE UTILITIES TARGETED
description: LEGISLATION forbidding electric companies in New Jersey to buy power from out-of-state generators that contribute to New Jersey's acid-rain problem was being drafted last week by Assemblywoman Maureen Ogden.

title:
TOPICS;

Smithtown
description: IN my fantasies I am daring, flamboyant, extravagant.

title: ALONG UPPER BROADWAY, A REVIVAL
description: NOT since the turn of the century, when modern Broadway was created, has the stretch of the avenue between West 79th and 96th Streets seen such intense development and heady price spirals.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: QUEEN VICTORIA IN HER LETTERS AND JOURNALS: A Selection. By Christopher Hibbert. (Viking, $25.) This collection of writings brings Queen Victoria vividly alive.

title: TONGS, TRIADS AND A CHINATOWN TRAGEDY
description: Wai Fun Wong, a 15-year-old Chinatown resident who immigrated to the United States from Hong Kong eight years ago, was arrested last week and charged with attempted murder. The police say he shot seven people on a crowded sidewalk on East Broadway. A 4-year-old boy who was walking with his uncle was hit in the head. A man dining in a restaurant was struck in the chest. The police said that the five other victims, and the suspect himself, were members of youth gangs.

title: WARRANT ISSUED FOR THE ARREST OF WITNESS IN VON BULOW TRIAL
description: The state police obtained a Federal arrest warrant Friday night for a former lover of Claus von Bulow on a charge of fleeing to avoid testifying at his retrial.

title: ETHAN JOHNSON WEDS ELIZABETH SCOTT PRYOR
description: Elizabeth Scott Pryor and Ethan Whitcomb Johnson, both lawyers who will be in practice in New York in September, were married yesterday at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Miami. The Rev. Woodrow Hastey performed the ceremony.

title: SHELLEY BOYD MARRIES CHRISTOPHER R. CORDUA
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York yesterday Shelley Anne Boyd, a daughter of Mary Deeda Boyd of Chatham Township, N.J., and Patrick W. Boyd of Summit, N.J., was married to Christopher Ray Cordua, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harney May Cordua Jr. of San Diego. The Rev. Charles Temple performed the ceremony.

title: ADVOCACY GROUPS EXPLORE COALITION
description: THE meeting at Marymount College in Tarrytown last Monday and Tuesday was called ''A Forum for a Common Agenda,'' but for the advocacy groups involved - those concerned with improving human services -the search for common ground was not an easy mission.

title: 'Saturday Night'
description: LAST year, the producers of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' decided the best way to keep the program fresh would be to film some segments, making a large part of the show not live at all.

title: 'I WANT TO BE ALONE' -- ER, NOT REALLY
description: IT had been one of ''those days'' - the ones when your car gets a flat tire and the washing machine overflows, when you arrive five minutes too late for the funeral or a week early for a doctor's appointment. ''Those days'' occur regularly in all our lives.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, MAY 26, 1985 International Talks on northwest Pacific air safety have made ''some progress'' in unpublicized negotiations between the United States, the Soviet Union and Japan, Reagan Administration officials said. The negotiations are aimed at preventing a repetition of the downing a South Korean airliner by a Soviet jet fighter in 1983. The latest round ended Friday in Moscow. The Russians requested as little publicity as possible. [Page 1, Column 6.] Kuwait's leader escaped death when a suicide driver rammed a bomb-laden car into his motorcade, Kuwaiti officials reported. They said the driver died and two bodyguards and a passer-by were also killed. A caller saying he represented the terrorist group known as Islamic Holy War claimed responsibility. [1:4.] The Pope installed 28 new cardinals in a colorful ceremony held outdoors in Rome. Among the 28 elevated were the Archbishops of some of the world's largest Roman Catholic dioceses. Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York was among them. [1:1.] The battle for 3 Palestinian districts spread from the Beirut area to eastern Lebanon. As the fighting went into the seventh day, the police reported that four people were killed when Palestinian guerrillas clashed with militamen of Amal, the mainstream Shiite Moslem movement, in the Baalbek area of the Bekaa region, about 50 miles east of Beirut. [1:5.] Hundreds of people were killed when a hurricane struck the southern coast of Bangladesh and offshore islands. An unofficial report put the death toll at 600 in the Noakhali district on the east side of the mouth of the Ganges River, and 1,000 nationwide.

title: DELAWARE PATROL AWAITING CANOEISTS
description: THEY lurk in dangerous places, always cruising for trouble. Some people call them the Rat Patrol, but the volunteer members of the Delaware River's National Canoe Safety Patrol prefer the more-genteel name of River Patrol.

title: CHINA BROUGHT CLOSER
description: Published to coincide with a Public Broadcasting Service television series of the same name, THE HEART OF THE DRAGON (Houghton Mifflin, $29.95) succeeds admirably in explaining China, past and present, to a wide audience. Profusely illustrated, but much more than a picture book, it unites well-chosen photographs with a clear and erudite text by Alasdair Clayre, who, before his death last year, was a fellow of All Souls College, Oxford, and a director and producer for the BBC.

title: Prime Target In Philadelphia
description: NOTHING, it seems, remains sacred in Philadelphia.

title: A Star Strikes Out
description: His publisher did not mince words. Actor Tony Curtis's steamy novel about a starlet's rags-to-riches rise in Hollywood was ''junk, pure and simple'' and Doubleday & Company would not print it.

title: 'VILLAGE' RARITY
description: In Greenwich Village, a former tent factory, a printing plant and many other unlikely structures have been turned into living spaces. New construction, however, has been rare, particularly within the area's historic district, where the height of new buildings is limited.

title: MEG LONG IS WED IN ANNAPOLIS, MD.
description: At St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Annapolis, Md., yesterday. Florence Margaret Long, the daughter of Mrs. Theron N. Bucy of St. Petersburg, Fla., and David P. Long of Annapolis, was married to Robert Michael Dougherty Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dougherty of Washington.

title: LESS MAY BE MORE FOR CHRISTOPHER DURANG
description: In individual scenes, Christopher Durang is one of the funniest and one of the most malevolent writers in the American theater. This is not to say that he has yet written a full-length play that is consistently up to his own comic standard. His new comedy, ''The Marriage of Bette and Boo,'' is no exception to the rule of Durang: The parts add up to more than the sum. Or, as the playwright says at the conclusion of the introduction to his collection of six plays, ''Critics sometimes complain that I have trouble ending my plays. This is nonsense.

title: STATE RIGHTS PANELS ARE BEING HEADED BY MORE WHITE MEN
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights has reorganized its 50 state advisory committees, appointing more white men to head them.

title: ECHOES OF SCOTLAND AT NEW ST. ANDREWS
description: THERE is no four-hole stretch of golf in the metropolitan area quite like the tantalizing short par-4, the already controversial par-5 and the two successive par-3 holes that make up numbers 10 through 13 atop a mountain at the newly reconstructed St. Andrews Golf Club course. This par-15 piece of St. Andrews may become as memorable as 7 through 10 at Maidstone, 12 through 15 at Plainfield or the last four holes at Winged Foot West.

title: U.S. Gains Tennis Final
description: The United States, led by John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors, beat West Germany today and will defend its title against Czechoslovakia in the final of the $500,000 Ambre Solaire World Team Tennis Cup.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the May 5 Home Entertaining section, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, a direction was left out in a recipe for rigodon.

title: STREET CLOCKS MAKING A COMEBACK IN MANHATTAN
description: Kenneth Lynch is known around the country for his metalwork.

title: By Many Counts, The Young Get Poorer
description: The Reagan Administration has long maintained that official calculations of poverty are inflated because they do not reflect the cash value of noncash benefits, such as food stamps. Last week, a report by two Government agencies counted the poor among children in a variety of ways.

title: WILDFLOWERS A GIFT TO JERSEY PARKWAY
description: It is spring planting time, but the fallow fields being tilled are the grassy medians and shoulders of the Palisades Interstate Parkway.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ON THE BEACH

title: AN AMERICAN FROM UKRAINE SHARES GLORY
description: Amid the flood of attention on the newly consecrated cardinals from New York and Boston, little limelight remained for Myroslav Cardinal Lubachivsky, the third American to be elevated to the College of Cardinals today.

title: BAN ON COMPUTER DATA DISCLOSURE IS DRAWING FIRE
description: A new computer crime law has drawn objections from a variety of people, including representatives of the Government, a civil liberties group and newspaper editors.

title: Bichon Frise Is Best
description: Pam Goldman's Bichon Frise, Champion Camelot's Brassy Nickel, led a field of 1,437 dogs today at the 56th show of the Monmouth County Kennel Club at Wolf Hill Farm, adjoining the Monmouth Park Racetrack.

title: ALLARD LOWENSTEIN AND THE C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: THEY MAY BE IVORY TOWERS BUT THEY STILL RAISE CONCERN
description: For many years, New York University has been carving a campus out of the neighborhood of narrow streets and brick walk-up tenements that surround it in Greenwich Village. With recent purchases of two large lots on Third Avenue for new dormitories and a nearby classroom building that it had been leasing, N.Y.U. is also establishing a significant presence in the East Village for the first time.

title: Waking Up The Economy
description: A senior Administration economist put the issue of the week this way: ''The relevant question is whether the slow economic performance over the past three quarters is the harbinger of worse economic performance ahead.'' Many private analysts were inclined to agree with his view ''that we're on the threshold of renewed expansion.'' They would have been less inclined to do so 10 days ago. But then, even before last week's report that economic growth all but stopped during the first quarter, the Federal Reserve had moved.

title: A Change At the Top
description: I enjoyed Deborah Blumenthal's article ''A Change at the Top'' (April 28) concerning the use of artificial hair replacement. However, not enough emphasis was placed on some of the new techniques that have helped many people with these problems.

title: IS THERE LIFE AFTER GULF AND WESTERN?
description: The financially strapped Dominican Republic dragged its feet for nearly 17 months during negotiations with the International Monetary Fund. As deadlines passed, more than $225 million in prospective loans was forfeited and the Caribbean country was brought close to financial collapse. Government officials say they had no choice. President Salvador Jorge Blanco was afraid, an aide said, that abruptly fulfilling the monetary fund's demands for higher prices and taxes and devaluation of the peso ''might cause some kind of revolution.''

title: AUDIENCES ARE FIGHTING BACK
description: Television may still be promising to be ''right back after these messages,'' but fewer viewers are hanging around to find out. The consumer is happily awash in viewing options, as the ''electronics revolution'' continues to unfold. For decades, viewers have been complaining about programs being interrupted by sales pitches. Younger viewers, those of the ''TV generation,'' probably consider commercials a natural part of the television landscape, breathing spaces to go to the bathroom or pop some more corn. But in the past few years, the home viewer has been discovering new entertainment sources, most notably pay cable and video cassette recorders. Both offer the luxury of watching programming that is unhindered by either deletions or commercial breaks. And the cassette deck has the additional asset of a fast-forward button for getting past the commercials in a program that has been taped off the air. The ramifications are becoming increasingly apparent to not only commercial television but the advertising business.

title: NEW VOICES FOR NURSING-HOME PATIENTS
description: HARRIET LINDO, a retired nurse from Mineola, was always pressed for time when she was on the job. With all the duties of nursing, she said, she rarely had an opportunity to sit and listen to her frail, elderly patients at the Holly Patterson Nursing Home in Uniondale. For the most part, her patients' joys went unnoticed; their complaints unheard.

title: IN NICARAGUA
description: As much as I admire Mario Vargas Llosa's ability to write novels, I believe his rather romanticized account of some of the Sandinista leaders and his subtle attempt to pass off subjective opinions as objective facts only serve to confuse people looking for a clear-cut picture of Central America.

title: MARY LEE WOLFE ENGAGED TO WED
description: Douglas Charles Wolfe of Bradenton, Fla., and Dr. Clara L. Wolfe of Tallahassee, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Lee Wolfe and John Gulton Malcolm. He is a son of Dr. Daniel Malcolm and Dr. Marian G. Malcolm of Tenafly, N.J.

title: SUMMER RENTALS LAG ON EAST END
description: WITH the peak tourist season opening on the East End, real-estate brokers say the summer rental outlook is less than sunny this year.

title: DREDGING STIRS DEBATE ON TRUSTEES' ROLE
description: THE dredging of Fish Cove in the Town of Southampton, resulting in the destruction of portions of shellfish beds and surrounding marshland, has caused an outcry from environmentalists and prompted the state's Department of Environmental Conservation to revoke the dredging permit.

title: RX FOR DISASTER: A SURCHARGE ON IMPORTS
description: A truly atrocious idea is gaining strength here. Support is gathering for a 20 percent surcharge on all imports - although the real target 202.4,0,294.4,2,184 ,0,239.2,2,239.2,0>is Japan. The appeal of the proposal is simple. America's international trade deficit in 1984 was $107.9 billion. Japan makes it hard for foreigners to gain a toehold, much less a leading position, in its domestic markets; last year, America's deficit with Japan alone was $34 billion. In addition, the Federal budget is awash in a seemingly limitless ocean of red ink.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES CITY ACTIONS ON CHILD ABUSE
description: After six months of investigating New York City's handling of child-abuse cases, a special Bronx grand jury said in a report made public yesterday that much of the system is ''in urgent need of improvement.'' It recommended sweeping changes.

title: 'RAMBO' DELIVERS A REVENGE FANTASY
description: ''What is it you want?'' the puzzled but admiring colonel of the Green Berets asks Rambo (Sylvester Stallone), the ''pure fighting machine'' who has just returned from a solo undercover operation in present-day Vietnam. Rambo, who doesn't like to talk much, pulls his brain cells together. ''I wan' . . . I wan' . . .,'' he says with some difficulty, ''I wan' this country to love us as much as we loved it.''

title: PIONEERING NURSE GAINS NEW HONORS
description: AS World War I came to a close, Virginia Henderson decided to become a nurse because she wanted work that would ''get effects.'' Sixty-seven years later, she continues to do just that.

title: FOR SERENITY OR SPORT, FORESTS BECKON
description: THE salubrious effects of nature will bring 1.4 million people into Connecticut's 31 forests this year. The more than 200,000 acres of unspoiled land and, in the words of Richard K. Clifford, state director of parks and recreation, ''natural resources that the private sector cannot offer'' provided soothing relief for just as many bodies and souls last year.

title: A CONDUCTOR WHO RELISHES HIS 'TWO-WORLD' COMMITMENT
description: Last Election Day, the young Rumanian-born conductor Christian Badea stood in line in a high school in Columbus, Ohio, waiting to cast his first vote as an American citizen. Mr. Badea was just a couple of months into his second season as music director of the Columbus Symphony, and looking around the room, he wondered whether anyone there knew or cared much about his orchestra or the music it played. The man in front of him, for instance, struck Mr. Badea as an almost perfect specimen of a middle-aged, middle-American blue-collar worker - someone who spent his Sundays watching football on TV, and who had probably never willingly endured a Mozart symphony in his life. But after a moment, the man turned to Mr. Badea and said, ''I was at your concert Sunday, and I really enjoyed the Ligeti.'' The conductor was taken aback. ''First of all,'' he says, ''I never would have taken this man for a concertgoer. But can you imagine - he didn't say he liked the Mozart or the Schubert, but the Ligeti. It shows you that people have open minds. You just have to present the music in the right way.''

title: MUSIC: TOKYO YOUTH ORCHESTRA AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THIS year marked the 25th anniversary of the New York-Tokyo ''sister city'' relationship, and Thursday night the first of several events intended to celebrate that milestone took place at Carnegie Hall. This was a so-called ''silver bridge concert'' that introduced a youth orchestra from Tokyo, the IMAS Chamber Orchestra. An ensemble from the Juilliard School of Music is visiting Tokyo for a counterpart concert.

title: SAILOR IS RETURNED TO U.S. IN SPY CASE
description: A 22-year-old Navy yeoman accused of helping his father and others spy for the Soviet Union was returned to the United States today as investigators tried to assess whether national security was damaged by the purported espionage ring.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET IN A TRIPLE BILL
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE created not just a signature work in ''Apollo,'' but a ballet with a lead role open to a surprising range of interpretations despite the purity and restraint of its conception and Stravinsky score. Ib Andersen danced the god as an eager, almost impish youngster when the New York City Ballet presented the work on Friday at the New York State Theater. But by the end of the ballet, this Apollo has grown up, and moved with new weight and authority.

title: Mitterrand on Strategy
description: President Francois Mitterrand reaffirmed France's commitment to nuclear deterrence today, saying United States research on space defense systems would not threaten that strategy for several decades. He commented at this naval base in Brittany as the nuclear submarine Inflexible, the newest in the French nuclear fleet, left on its first mission.

title: ACCESSORIES TO TURN DEFECTS INTO PROFITS
description: TWELVE years ago, Litton Microwave Products Inc. developed a microwave browner-griller as a promotional item. Consumers were balking at the look of microwaved food, and the company sold the browner to retailers at cost, encouraging them to give it as a bonus for purchasing an oven.

title: SALLIE SPENCE WEDS J. H. MCGREGOR
description: Sarah Coolidge Spence, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Pond Spence of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to James Harvey McGregor, the son of Mrs. James Harvey McGregor and the late Mr. McGregor of Frostburg and Wheaton, Md. The Rev. P. Linwood Urban, the bride's godfather, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: MUSIC: THREE PIECES FOR TWO PIANOS
description: ETHEREALITY reigned Thursday at Carnegie Recital Hall, when Anthony Davis and Ursula Oppens performed world premieres of three pieces for two pianos: Alvin Curran's ''Era Ora,'' Mr. Davis's ''Wayang No. VI,'' and Earl Howard's ''Monopole'' for two pianos and tape.

title: A Boost for the Artificial Heart
description: The artificial heart received a sweeping endorsement last week. A committee of experts appointed by the National Institutes of Health called for greatly expanded Federal research efforts to develop a fully implantable permanent artificial heart.

title: THE HANDICRAFTS OF COLOMBIA
description: When one goes looking for folk art and handicrafts in Colombia, shopping can become an adventure: poking into hidden corners and dusty shops, trying to talk to people in a mixture of English and Spanish and looking through piles of plaster and plastic souvenirs. But good-quality handicrafts are plentiful for those willing to undertake the search. Bargaining for good prices, a tradition in Colombia, can add to the adventure.

title: $128,000 Winner
description: LAST spring, an 18-year-old specialist in Maya hieroglyphics became the youngest person to win a no-strings-attached grant from the MacArthur Foundation, which tries to help talented Americans devote time to study.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FREUD'S OWN COOKBOOK. Edited by James Hillman and Charles Boer. (Harper Colophon, Paper, $5.95.) Food faddists come and go, maddeningly so.

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: WHAT is the mortality rate at each hospital in New Jersey? What is the average length of stay at hospitals in Union County for patients whose hip joints are replaced? How often do patients at a particular hospital develop breathing problems after surgery?

title: Poisonings Linked to Eggs
description: Vermont health officials say unrefrigerated eggs were probably the source of the salmonella poisoning of about 100 Castleton State College students this month. Three students were treated at Rutland Regional Medical Center. A state epidemiologist, Richard Vogt, said this week that the state Health Department and the college's food service found the eggs had been refrigerated while being transported but not refrigerated after they arrived.

title: Cancer Ruled Cause of Death Of Victim of Spinal Injection
description: The death of a woman Friday, 86 days after an injection of an anticancer drug into her spine left her paralyzed and comatose, was caused by cancer and related natural causes, officials said today.

title: CREATIVITY AND CUSTOMER VALUE
description: Roger Smith, and all his people, cannot seem to make a G.M. car that gives us the enjoyment and safety of a glare-free front window or the ability to open front-door windows for a welcome airflow without getting earache and blown hair. Without a squish - I can! I would offer consumers the option of having the top of the front-dash panel in black (this curtails window glare) and the installation of triangular sideview window openings on front doors, as was standard years ago. JOHN A. ESPOSITO Queens Village

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today through Saturday - Devon Horse Show, Devon, Pa. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (215) 964-0550.

title: SHELDON GOLD, HEAD OF MANAGING GROUP FOR CLASSICAL ARTISTS
description: Sheldon Gold, president of ICM Artists Ltd., one of the country's leading concert and dance management agencies, died yesterday morning at the Hospital of Albert Einstein Medical College in the Bronx of complications from a recent heart attack. He was 55 years old and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: KATHERINE SOTER WEDS TIMOTHY MASON SPIESS
description: At the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour in Rye, N.Y., yesterday, Katherine Louise Soter and Timothy Mason Spiess, graduates of the University of Vermont, were married by the Rev. Alexander Karloutsos, assisted by the Rev. Theodore Baglaneas.

title: 'Literature by Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUR NEW JERSEYANS INDUCTED INTO AVIATION HALL OF FAME
description: FOUR New Jersey aviators, each of whom has left his mark on the history of flight, joined distinguished company last week, when they were formally inducted into the Aviation Hall of Fame of New Jersey.

title: TAKING THE STING OUT OF CAPITALISM
description: FEW exercises in our time are so ingenious and, when examined, so engaging as our use of language to grace an inconvenient economic tendency or necessity. In past times, loans that were not repaid went sour or were in default. Now they are rolled over. Or rescheduled. Or they become problem loans. Or, best of all, they are nonperforming assets. (I heard the other day of a banker whose son had a bad accident with the family car. The lad told his father that the car wasn't totaled, only rendered permanently nonperforming.) However, the most successful of our exercises in semantic concealment has to do with socialism. It protects us from the terrible truth, which is that socialism now comes not from socialists but from the most devout and articulate of free enterprisers.

title: Cable TV
description: Moviegoers raised on a diet of Johnny Weissmuller and Lex Barker may well have been taken aback by the stylish and zoologically meticulous 1984 film that bears the title ''Greystoke: The Legend of Tarzan, Lord of the Apes.'' Directed by Hugh Hudson, who achieved international renown with ''Chariots of Fire'' and scheduled for broadcast on Saturday at noon and at 8 P.M. on Showtime (rebroadcast on June 5 at 1:30 P.M.), ''Greystoke'' is a lavish and serious undertaking.

title: EX-EMPLOYEE TELLS OF TRIP WITH SUSPECT IN NAVY SPY CASE
description: John A. Walker, the retired Navy warrent officer charged with espionage, is a ''flaky'' adventurer who ''thought of himself as a James Bond when he was really an Inspector Clouseau,'' according to a woman who once worked with him.

title: HORDES HEAD SOUTH FOR 'REAL RACING'
description: Don Kruger came all the way from Lake George, N.Y. ''Watching Indianapolis is like watching paint dry,'' said Mr. Kruger, freshly arrived at the airport this morning and impatient to get out to the track. ''Stock car racing is real racing.''

title: DRUG AGENTS WILL TRAIN AT THE F.B.I. ACADEMY
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced Friday that agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration would be trained at the Federal Bureau of Investigation Academy at Quantico, Va., a change that could be another step toward merger of the two agencies.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: ASIA IN BOSTON, ARCHITECTURE ABROAD
description: At Museum, 7,000 Years Of Discovery Looking for a shortcut to China? Try Boston, where a major museum exhibition called ''China: 7,000 Years of Discovery'' is scheduled to open June 2 for a run through Dec. 1.

title: Angels' Romanick Downs Orioles, 5-3
description: Ron Romanick scattered seven hits before needing ninth-inning help and Ruppert Jones hit a two-run homer today to lead the California Angels to a 5-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: CATHERINE DOBBING IS WED TO PAUL G. KELLY IN JERSEY
description: Catherine L. Dobbing, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Love of Kearny, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul G. Kelly, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Luke Kelly, also of Kearny. The Rev. George Vorsheim performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Morris Plains, N.J.

title: CPTIVES OF OUR 'CLASSICS'
description: OUR perception of foreign cultures is usually based not on their complex reality, but on the simplified image they project. The clearer and more sharply defined that image is, the more convinced we will be that we are intimately acquainted with it: it is a mere outward confirmation of knowledge we already possess. Hence we tend to favor those literary and artistic expressions which, rather than breasting the current to reveal something new to us, allow themselves to be sucked into the maelstrom of the ready-made, the already-known - images so often repeated that they become cliches that block our vision of reality and change and end up becoming inflexible myths.

title: Eruption Is Expected At Mount St. Helens
description: Scientists today predicted a potentially explosive eruption of Mount St. Helens by Memorial Day as the volcano shook with new intensity and molten lava neared the surface of its mammoth dome.

title: On the Presidency
description: The Presidency is a busy place, President Reagan was saying.

title:
ANTIQUES;

BIG THINGS AT SMALL MUSEUMS
description: DOZENS of small local museums are among the brightest spots on the state's cultural map.

title: WHEN WETLANDS DISAPPEAR
description: OFFICIALS of the Morristown-based New Jersey Conservation Foundation say that the current dearth of rain and inadequate water supplies are only part of what has been a 20-year period of ''wild fluctuations in water supply'' caused partly by the widespread destruction of wetlands.

title: SO IS TEEN-AGER SHORTAGE
description: Mark Hilderbrand, who just finished his sophomore year at Boston University, is pleased with his new summer job fixing air-conditioners. It's related to his engineering major. The pay is $8.20 an hour, better than the $6-an-hour house-painting jobs he has had in the past. And, he says, he had an easier time finding a job than in previous summers, as have most of his friends.

title: CAPITAL PERFORMANCE
description: UPSTAIRS, the guests dined on chicken mousse with walnuts. Downstairs, the performers ate bologna and cheese on white with Pepsi Light.

title: Billy Laster Fish, 60, Is Dead; Wife of U.S. Representative
description: Billy Laster Fish, wife of Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York, died yesterday at Capitol Hill Hospital in Washington, where she had been taken Friday from her home after suffering a massive stroke. She was 60 years old and lived in Washington and Millbrook, N.Y.

title: THREE SENSES OF SELF
description: NAVIGABLE WATERWAYS By Pamela Alexander. 75 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $5.95. THE LAMPLIT ANSWER By Gjertrud Schnackenberg. 83 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. ASSUMPTIONS By Marilyn Hacker. 92 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. IT is characteristic of Pamela Alexander's book (the latest in the Yale Series of Younger Poets) that its title, ''Navigable Waterways,'' turns out to refer to flower stems. She is a poet of such shifting perspectives. A poem is a kaleidoscope in her hand, a ''brief incident / and running commentary.'' The images are designed illuminations - water birds whose ''cries sound / like miniature wine-glasses breaking / against the crusty earth.'' But she knows that images don't decorate experience so much as organize it.

title: ELIZABETH COMEGYS, A REPORTER, PLANS AUG 17 MARRIAGE TO ZECHARIAH CHAFEE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walker Brockton Comegys Jr. of Wenham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Lee Comegys to Zechariah Chafee, a son of United States Senator and Mrs. John H. Chafee of Warwick, R.I. The wedding is planned for Aug. 17.

title: HOW TO STOP RAIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: ALONG THE RUGGED RIM OF CORNWALL
description: There is a wild and open cliff in southwest England, where weathered rocks drop steeply to a cove in which seals loll in the waves. Daffodils bloom in abundance. Except for a distant farmhouse, there is no sign of civilization, and only the sound of the sea breaks the silence.

title: REAITY BOARD SAYS EASED INVESTING WILL AID HOUSING
description: A NEW report by the Real Estate Board of New York calls the city's housing shortage a ''self-inflicted wound'' that is worsening, but says it can be healed by an improvement in the investment climate.

title: REGGIE JACKSON GIVES A LESSON IN HUMANITY
description: I SEE that Reggie Jackson will be making his first visit of the season this week - which reminds me that I should soon be getting my first call of the season from Stephanie Vardavas. She and Reggie and I are connected in my memory by an event that occurred at the Stadium one night late last summer when the old baseball year was ebbing away.

title: Straight Talk
description: He has held the job only two days, but already Joe L. Brown, the once and current general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, is looking to remove some of the rust from the Steel City. The Pirates, last in the National League East, are surrounded by talk of the team's sale, a Federal drug investigation, threats of a players' strike and empty seats.

title: Bicentennials At Smyrna, Del.
description: GEORGE L. Caley, the unofficial historian of Smyrna, Del., had some bad news for the Town Council last week. It seems the bicentennial celebration that Smyrna staged in 1968 was - well, premature.

title: GOLF, ITALIAN-SWISS STYLE
description: Real golfers and real fishermen have a lot in common: They like to keep secrets. The ideal, undiscovered and uncrowded 18-hole course is cherished by golf fanatics the same way fly fishermen shroud in secrecy their favorite bends in the river. So it is with some reluctance, but with the enthusiasm of one who could never keep a secret, that I write about the golf courses at the foot of the Alps in the lake country along the Italian-Swiss border.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY: HIGH STAKES IN TOUGH RACE
description: NEW JERSEY companies doing basic research in genetic engineering are competing not only with one another, but also with companies all over the world in a race for products created with the revolutionary new tools of biotechnology.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: THE BIG GREEN BOOK. By Robert Graves. Illustrated by Maurice Sendak. Macmillan. $12.95. (Ages 6 to 9) This is the story of Jack, the orphan boy who finds a big green book of magic in his guardians' attic.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FILMS AND AN OPERA
description: Beethoven's 'Fidelio' A Glyndebourne Festival Opera production, featuring Elisabeth Soderstrom, Anton de Ridder and Robert Allman, with Bernard Haitink conducting the London Philharmonic Orchestra Video Arts International 130 minutes. $79.95 This ''Fidelio'' cannot offer ideal sound or, for that matter, a perfect cast.

title: A MODEL MAJOR GENERAL IN 'PENZANCE'
description: PEOPLE can often be defined by their affections. There are mystery fans and science-fiction fanatics, cat lovers and dog owners. Among theatergoers, there are those who will go anywhere to see a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta and those who won't. For the former, Theater Three in Port Jefferson is producing Gilbert and Sullivan's ''The Pirates of Penzance, or the Slave of Duty.''

title: MILES DAVIS REVIVES HIS BAD-GUY IMAGE WITH A POP ALBUM
description: Dressed in black silk and leather and holding a wicked-looking automatic rifle by its magazine and stock, Miles Davis seems intent on reviving his outlaw image -Miles vs. the rest of the world - as he scowls from the cover photo on his new album ''You're Under Arrest'' (Columbia).

title: MISS PENNIMAN TO WED GARRETT MORAN IN JUNE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Caleb Johnson Penniman of Essex, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Johnson Penniman, to Garrett Michael Moran, a son of Mrs. Ralph G. Hubert of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late George B. Moran Jr. Miss Penniman, a graduate of Milton Academy and Trinity College in Hartford, received an M.B.A. degree in finance from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: FOR NEW DELHI'S SIKHS, FRIENDSHIP YIELD TO FEAR
description: Most Sikhs here seem able to recall the exact moment two weeks ago when they learned of the bomb explosions that killed more than 80 people in northern India.

title: 'Literature by Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A CREED FOR THE THIRD MILLENNIUM By Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) It is 50 years from now, the greenhouse effect has fizzled and a devastating ice age has begun.

title: VANISHING SONGBIRD TRAIL LEADS TO TROPICS
description: To the Editor:

title: VALERIE A. MCDERMOTT MARRIES JONATHAN COOPER
description: The marriage of Valerie Anne McDermott and Jonathan Ross Cooper took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Leo the Great in Lincroft, N.J. The Rev. William J. Bohnsack, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Ian Montgomery, the bridegroom's brother-in-law, and the Rev. William Worman, both Episcopal priests.

title: DROUGHT MAY PUSH SALT LINE UPRIVER
description: IF THE current drought emergency worsens, the Delaware River Basin Commission will begin drawing water from six reservoirs in Pennsylvania and New York in an effort to keep the Delaware River salt line from reaching and contaminating wells in Gloucester, Camden and Burlington Counties.

title: Topics;   Icons and IconoclastsAncient Mornings
description: Egypt is trying to save the Sphinx, badly gnawed by the teeth of time. There's even a chance of restoring the statue's missing beard, if the British Museum can be induced to part with a three-foot fragment reposing in its basement.

title: Indy Brat Is on Pole for 500
description: AT his 34th Indianpolis 500, Pancho Carter finally sits at the pole today when that American paean to the automobile vrooms off the starting line.

title: WHEN THE TRAPPINGS ARE THE DANCE
description: Costumes are back in experimental dance. The leotard look is still with us but often it gets dressed up and trimmed. The costume dramas that Karole Armitage has been presenting owe their decorative look - their entire attitude -to punk fashion. Take away the trappings and what have you got?

title: ITALIAN POLICE REPORT ARREST OF A GUNMAN ON DUTCH PAPAL TRIP
description: The police in the Netherlands arrested an armed man at a border crossing from West Germany on the last day of Pope John Paul II's recent visit to the Netherlands, officials here and in the Netherlands have disclosed.

title: NEW THREAT TO SMOKESTACK AMERICA
description: CORPORATE America has been waging a civil war, industry against industry, over the final shape of President Reagan's tax code revisions - and heavy industry is coming out the loser.

title: WADKINS LEADS IN MEMORIAL
description: Lanny Wadkins hit a 7-iron from a fairway bunker 160 yards to the 18th green and then sank a 24-foot birdie putt to take a one-shot lead over Hale Irwin after three rounds of the 10th annual Memorial Tournament at the Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: THE MANY ASPECTS OF JEAN DUBUFFET
description: One of the remarkable things about Jean Dubuffet, the French painter who died two weeks ago in his 84th year, was that he never had to wait for recognition. From the moment his first one-man show opened in 1944, in a Paris still inaccessible to the outer world, it was clear that he had brought something new and inimitably forceful to French painting. It was rough, rude and apparently caricatural - the very antithesis, in other words, of what was expected of a reborn School of Paris. Yet in no time at all it cut the fat off French painting.
