Within three years of that first exhibition he was shown at the Pierre Matisse Gallery in New York and recognized by Clement Greenberg as the most substantial new talent to have come out of Paris since World War II. And, within a short space of time, that opinion of him carried the day, worldwide.

title: Ex-Sailor Caught In Counterspy Net
description: In his 20 years in the Navy, John Walker had access to many of his service's most closely held secrets. For much of that time, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said last week, he may have been spying for the Soviet Union.

title: HUNGARIAN ART COLLECTION VISITS U.S.
description: The name Esterhazy has long been associated with the royal Hungarian family that supported Haydn and his music. But some of the princes in the family were avid art collectors as well, and the drawings of one of the nobles have become the basis of the collection of the Museum of Fine Arts in Budapest.

title: ALLISON BAIRD ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Heston Baird of Waban, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Allison Howard Baird, to Paul William Vlachos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Nicholas Vlachos of Yonkers.

title:
WINE;

ALL THAT SPARKLES IS NOT CHAMPAGNE
description: LAST FALL, I DROVE down from Paris to Vouvray, in the Loire Valley, to look into an argument between the town and the French railroads. It seemed that the S.N.C.F. -an abbreviation for the railroad system - had drawn the route for its new high-speed train, the T.G.V. Atlantique, through some famous vineyards. Understandably, the locals were up in arms. It was a good story. It was also a chance to meet Gaston Huet, the Mayor of Vouvray and one of its best-known wine makers.

title: Newest Trident Submarine, U.S.S. Alabama, Joins Fleet
description: The Navy's sixth Trident submarine, the U.S.S. Alabama, was commissioned here today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Jarvis, Patrick Ewing's high school coach, has been named head basketball coach at Boston University. Jarvis, the coach at Cambridge Rindge and Latin High School since 1978, replaces John Kuester, who resigned the Boston post to accept the top job at George Washington University. . . . At Louisiana State University, the basketball coach, Dale Brown, was given a new five-year contract, at $135,000 a year, and so was the school's athletic director, Robert Brodhead, at $82,000 a year. . . . WPVI-TV in Philadelphia has a new general assignment reporter named Frank Edwin McGraw, known as Tug McGraw during his 17-year major league career as a relief pitcher with the Mets and Phillies. The 40-year-old retired last Feb. 14 and starts another career next month.

title: On Language;   Hypersexism And The Feds
description: SOME PEOPLE TAKE sexism in language very seriously.

title: NANCY SHEPHERD WED TO DR. T. W. MARTENIS
description: Nancy Clapp Shepherd, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lewis C. Clapp of Brooklyn Heights, and Dr. Thomas Williams Martenis, a son of Mrs. Fred B. Martinis of Newark, Del., and the late Mr. Martenis, were married yesterday. The Rev. M. Kenneth Morris performed the ceremony at the College Street Congregational Church in Burlington, Vt.

title: THE CONTINUING PROBLEM OF SOGGY FOOD
description: THE move into the microwave age has turned out to be a painful one for food and packaging producers. They are still struggling to find the right products for microwave use - or at least to produce products that are, in the industry's lingo, ''dual ovenable,'' or usable in both microwave and coventional ovens that cook with hot air.

title: WENDELYN WITT, PHYSICIAN, WEDS
description: Dr. Wendelyn Ann Witt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Witt of Winnetka, Ill., and Clayton, Mo., and Gary E. Avalone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Avalone of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday in Winnetka. Both families are formerly of Bronxville, N.Y. Msgr.

title: WHAT ABOUT THE FIRES NEXT TIME?
description: The most destructive outbreak of fires in Florida's history was brought under control last week just as heavy rains brought some relief to the drought-stricken Southeast.

title: CULTURE AND MUSICAL THINKING
description: CONTEMPLATING MUSIC Challenges to Musicology. By Joseph Kerman. 255 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. 5. IN 1942, the centennial year of the New York Philharmonic, Virgil Thomson, then the senior music critic of The New York Herald Tribune, complained in a review that music had not become part of the city's intellectual life. In ''Contemplating Music,'' published 43 years later, the musicologist Joseph Kerman makes the point in stronger language: ''Critical thought in music lags conceptually far behind that in the other arts. In fact nearly all musical thinkers travel at a respectful distance behind the latest chariots (or bandwagons) of intellectual life in general.''

title: CAPITAL'S GO-GO BANDS KEEP THE CITY IN MOTION
description: ''Is it hot out there?'' Chuck Brown asks the crowd at the WUST Radio Music Hall, sometime near 2:30 A.M. ''Is it funky out there?'' ''Yeah!'' come the responses from a full house of dancers, on the floor and in the balcony - teen-agers and children as well as couples in their 20's, casually dressed for a night of shaking and shouting. ''Let's do it all together,'' Mr. Brown exhorts. ''Let's do it all night long!''

title: Bat Passes Muster
description: The American League president, Bobby Brown, has disallowed a Milwaukee Brewer complaint that Tony Bernazard of Cleveland used an illegal bat in a game last Wednesday night.

title: YOUNG PLAYWRIGHTS' PROGRAM GROWING
description: NO MATTER what the state of the commercial theater - and who can deny that it's ailing nowadways -people will ask, ''Where are the new playwrights coming from?''

title: MAJOR NEW SHOW TO OPEN THIS WEEK
description: Expressing ''confidence in the rise of interest in stamp collecting,'' the American Stamp Dealers' Association and its executive director Joseph B. Savarese will open the doors to a new three-day show Friday. The New York Philatelic Fair will be held at the 67th Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street. Hours Friday are 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.,; Saturday 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.. Admission is $3 with children under 14 admitted free if accompanied by an adult.

title:
OUTDOORS AND NATURE;

DIVERSE SUMMER FARE FOR CHILDREN
description: WITH the approach of summer and the usual question of what to do with the children, Westchester families have a wide array of programs and activities from which to choose. Not only are there community-sponsored day camps and recreation programs, as well as programs sponsored by Y's, the Scouts and other youth-oriented organizations, but also there are activities in which children and young people can explore a multitude of specialized interests ranging from the arts to zoology.

title:
GARDENING;

THE DAMAGE VIRUSES CAN DO
description: AMONG the many maladies that act to the detriment of the plants in our gardens are the viruses. Viruses have been described by some pathologists as genes that have gone wrong. Much like a gene, the virus affects the physiology of a cell. However, this effect is abnormal and not to the advantage of the plant.

title: ETHIOPIA REFUGEES LEAVING THE SUDAN
description: Relief officials and Western diplomats here say they fear for the lives of thousands of Ethiopians now returning from refugee camps in the Sudan.

title: Bay State Weighs Conservation Tax
description: THE Massachusetts Legislature is considering two bills that would establish a conservation tax on Cape Cod and Martha's Vineyard land transfers in an effort to prevent overdevelopment.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MAGIC NUMBERS OF DR. MATRIX. By Martin Gardner. (Prometheus Books, Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $10.95.) ''You can no more find a patternless arrangement of digits or letters than you can find a cloud without a shape or a culture without folkways.''

title: 8 Executed in Ghana
description: The Ghana radio said 8 people were executed today, bringing to 11 the number executed in the last 24 hours. The eight included five officers convicted in a plot against the Government, two civilians sentenced for armed roberries and a soldier who was found guilty of murdering a civilian in a bus-line dispute.

title: LIFE WITH TENANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ARNOLD ZOHN DIES, BEGAN ARNO PRESS
description: Arnold Zohn, the founder of Arno Press and a former vice president of The New York Times Company, died of congestive heart failure Friday evening at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 60 years old and lived in Sagaponack, L.I.

title: DRUG PRODUCTION TRIED IN SPACE
description: A 650-POUND pharmaceutical ''factory'' that accompanied the space shuttle Discovery last month could launch a $1-billion-a-year drug industry in space for a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson.

title: POSTAPOCALYPTIC FASOTRAL
description: FISKADORO By Denis Johnson. 221 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95 POSTNUCLEAR literature often springs from ambiguous impulses. We all understand the big fear that propels it; what is more difficult to acknowledge is the element of wish fulfillment often present in fantasies of a world that has been swept clean of everything we know, and can therefore return to a pastoral innocence. In ''Fiskadoro,'' which joins the growing ranks of novels set beyond the end of the world, the poet and novelist Denis Johnson attempts something much more daring and provocative. He doesn't entirely avoid the millenarian impulse. But his startlingly original book is an examination of the cataclysmic imagination, a parable of apocalypse that is always present and precedes redemption in a cycle of death and birth, forgetting and remembering.

title: ON PLAYING THE GAME OF MUSICAL REMINISCENCE
description: People for whom music is food and drink are prone to reminisce. Actually, they will reminisce while supine, if necessary, so long as anyone is willing to listen. Whenever two or three veteran rememberers foregather the talk will eventually turn into a contest, sometimes polite but frequently quite ruthless, over who heard the most distantly dead great artist. Or who knew which great composer earliest. Or whose piano teacher studied with the teacher who studied with Liszt or Leschetizky or Anton Rubinstein.

title: 'HONEST' FOLK ART FROM L.I.
description: IT was, Alyce Assael said, ''a brainstorm'' that led to ''Singular Visions,'' the exhibition of Long Island folk art from the 18th century to the present that opens today at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

title: ESTATE PURCHASE UP FOR VOTE
description: IN EAST Hampton, where concern for the environment is a major issue, voters will decide Saturday if helping to preserve one of the last unpolluted harbors in the Northeast is worth $6.3 million.

title: IN LONDON, A WARNING SOUNDED ABOUT A DECLINING NEW YORK
description: New York City may not be the capital of the nation, Prof. George Steiner, an author and critic, told an audience at the Royal Society of Arts, but it is something more: the capital of an epoch that -even as it glories in its power and energy - is seeing the warning signs of fatigue and entropy.

title: ST. JOHN'S IS OUT OF REGIONAL
description: Western Carolina, bolstered by three home runs, defeated St. John's, 9-6, yesterday in Columbia, S.C., eliminating the Redmen from the National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern Regional.

title: WHAT OUR HOUSES SAY ABOUT US
description: ''WHO are the people in your neighborhood?''

title:
DINING OUT;

A NEW APPROACH AT AN OLD INN
description: TWELVE years after George Washington's temporary setback at Pennsylvania's Battle of Brandywine, the charming building that now houses the Brandywine Inn in Norwood, Bergen County, was begun. There is a portrait of the general in one of the inn's two rustic, comfortable dining rooms; however, there is nary a souvenir of the victorious General Howe.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ARIANA. By Edward Stewart. (Crown, $17.95.) Moments before her La Scala debut as Lucia di Lammermoor, the young soprano Ariana Kavalaris is presented by her vocal teacher with a two-centuries-old ruby and amethyst locket.

title: IS THE SHORTAGE NATURE'S FAULT ALONE?
description: Last week's rains raised the water levels in some northern New Jersey reservoirs from 50 percent of capacity to 60 percent. But the storms were not enough to ease the drought emergency or to slow the criticism of Governor Kean's record on improving the water-supply system.

title: NORTH FORK TOURISM: A VINTAGE YEAR
description: WINES and vineyards have helped make the North Fork the Long Island spot that tourists most want to see, according to tourism industry spokesmen.

title:
GARDENING;

THE DAMAGE VIRUSES CAN DO
description: AMONG the many maladies that act to the detriment of the plants in our gardens are the viruses. Viruses have been described by some pathologists as genes that have gone wrong. Much like a gene, the virus affects the physiology of a cell. However, this effect is abnormal and not to the advantage of the plant.

title: Bishops Give Opinions On Draft on Economy
description: Roman Catholic bishops say they like the direction of their draft pastoral letter on the national economy but want to see it focus more on United States economic success.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Thanks to God, I am in good health, and such criminal acts will not dissuade me or Kuwait from continuing to work for the prosperity of our people, as well as the Arab and Islamic nation.'' - Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir of Kuwait.

title: THE STRATEGY BORN IN BRITAIN
description: One result of the restrictions placed by the American Contract Bridge League on conventions is that some devices that are common in other parts of the world are hardly ever met in North America. One of these is the Multi, a two-diamond opening that was born in Britain and then spread to Europe and other continents.

title: TAKING CHARGE
description: IN THE BIG CORNER ROOM WHERE Henry Kissinger and Zbigniew Brzezinski once held sway, a few doors down from the Oval Office, Robert C. McFarlane sits on a couch talking about his rise to the post of national security adviser. The 47-year-old former marine sits quietly, hands in his lap, his speech slow and deliberate. Back in October 1983, McFarlane says, he was the ''compromise choice.'' No one saw him ''as a threat.''

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: AT this time of year, when I was in school, my chief occupation was looking out windows and waiting.

title: KEEPING FIT AFTER 60
description: SIX Brookhaven Town residents are walking the streets in T-shirts with an adaptation of Leonardo da Vinci's famous drawing of a man with arms and legs spread, ''120 Positions of the Human Body.'' The shirts bear the caption ''Fitness Is Forever,'' the title of a physical fitness program for the elderly that is slated to begin next September.

title: MARY L. CASSIDY PLANS TO BE WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Cassidy of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Mary Louise Cassidy to John G. Finnegan Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Finnegan of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for September.

title: R. J. DEMARCO JR. WED TO MISS RUBI IN DALLAS
description: Alicia Elizabeth Rubi, the daughter of Jose Manuel Rubi of Dallas and the late Jane Fleming Rubi, and Richard John DeMarco Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. DeMarco of West Hempstead, L.I., were married yesterday. The Very Rev. Damian Fandal, president of Barry College in Miami, performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Dallas.

title: TRACI STEGEMANN IS MARRIED IN CAPITAL
description: Traci J. Stegemann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Joseph Stegemann of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Kenneth Andrew Grigg Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Grigg of Washington. The Rev. Dr. Wendell Randolph Grigg, the bridegroom's grandfather, performed the Baptist ceremony at the Navy Chapel in Washington.

title: SCHOOLS INTENSIFY EFFORTS ON ALCOHOL
description: ''SINCE last fall, I've seen an increase in teen-age drinking in the county that is unbelievable,'' Dr. James R. Gaddy, principal of New Rochelle High School, said recently. ''Ironically enough, this isn't a problem at school or school-related functions in the evening. But the problem is with the number of teen-age keg parties that are taking place in homes.''

title: SMALLER, SMARTER AND CHEAPER OVENS
description: ''GOOD morning,'' the chef will say to his microwave oven. ''I'm having roast beef tonight. Please have it ready - medium well, of course - by 5:30.'' The oven will then weigh the roast, calculate the proper defrosting and cooking time, and have it ready by 5:30 that evening.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN QUEBEC CITY
description: Quebec, the repository of French culture in North America for more than three centuries, is but a scant 500 miles away from New York. In winter, the city can be bitterly cold and in midsummer, the city is at its busiest, with most of the two million visitors who come every year visiting then. But once the snow and ice melt, and the days have grown longer, the flowers appear and the proprietors of cafes start setting out their sidewalk tables and chairs. In late spring and early summer, tourists are few in number, good restaurants are easier to get into and some hotel rooms cost a little less.

title: Drive for Water In Boston Region
description: MASSACHUSETTS, like the rest of the Northeast, is struggling with a drought, but it may have a greater public relations problem than some other areas.

title: Harvard and the Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: A RUMANIAN 'FRIENDSHIP TOUR'
description: IF you are planning a trip to Rumania, 11-year-old Kim Foster of Elmsford has a suggestion: pack your own pizza!

title: PROBING THE DRAMA OF THE COMMONPLACE
description: Dazzling vistas are glimpsed through windows that mysteriously swing open, or a door suddenly ajar. The blinding whiteness of St. Petersburg held by the ice of winter, a modest Russian church in the village of Ivanovo, or the informal grace of the forest of Fontainebleau rise like ghosts summoned by a questing memory. These are images of childhood as recalled by the French novelist Nathalie Sarraute, recreated on stage as if Marcel Proust's magic lantern had been set up within the confines of a theater.

title: A STAMFORD HERO SWITCHES TO TEXAS
description: BOB DARLING recalls having heard an anguished voice when he threw a scotch bottle into a trash bin at the rear of his downtown Stamford bar and grill, the Villa Cafe, a few weeks ago.

title: MANHATTAN GOTHIC ON NEWSPRINT
description: THE LAST ROMANCE By Erica Abeel. 277 pp. New York: Avon Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: HANDLING THE SMALL BUILDING
description: f1515>OWNERS of brownstones and other small rental buildings in New York City often are eager to convert them into cooperatives or condominiums. Many are inhibited, however, by the high costs and massive paperwork involved in a conversion; the law does not make the procedures any easier for a building of 15 units than it does for one of 500.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: HISTORY is not dry leaves in a textbook, but a flesh and blood encounter for Joseph F. Monti's senor history students at Hasbrouck Heights High School.

title: 125 Are Lectured In Peking for Soccer Riot
description: Two of the 127 youths detained after a soccer riot have been arrested and charged, but the police have freed others after lecturing them, the Government said today.

title: GAME IS TARGET OF FIGHT IN PUTNAM
description: THE Putnam Board of Education has been asked to bar students from playing a fantasy game in school that some people say may be linked to the suicide of a 13-year-old boy in the northestern town.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

TRYING TIMES FOR SOME COIN CLUBS
description: Coin clubs play a pivotal role in furthering the cause of numismatics.

title: Lopes Leads Cubs Past the Astros, 5-4
description: Davey Lopes, who already had made two sensational catches in left field, drilled a tie-breaking two-run homer in the eighth inning today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 5-4 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Homer for Cromartie
description: Warren Cromartie hit a three-run homer in the fifth inning today to help the Yomiuri Giants score a 6-2 Japanese League victory over the Hiroshima Toyo Carp.

title: NEW YORK EDUCATORS REJECT TEXTBOOK AS INSULTING
description: A social studies textbook for junior high schools can no longer be bought by public schools in New York City because officials have deemed it offensive to Italians, Greeks, Japanese and Jews.

title: STAGE: 'BULLIE'S HOUSE,' AUSTRALIAN METAPHYSICS
description: Thomas Keneally's ''Bullie's House,'' in its American premiere at the Long Wharf Theater, begins with an aura of wind-swept mystery. The setting is a remote mission station in the back country of Australia. The title character's home has suddenly vanished, and a local Government official attributes the disappearance to a storm-induced change in air pressure. Bullie, an Aborigine, is terrified by the thought that he is suffering from a kind of divine retribution at the hands of the symbolic ''Thunderman.'' For one thing, Bullie has seduced the wife of the outpost's missionary and has shared in the responsibility for her death.

title: WORLDS NATURAL AND FICTIONAL
description: Nature writing is a curious sub-branch of literature. It is an art that can enable the armchair adventurer to traipse through the woods at dawn, consort with wild animals, climb mountains, cross deserts and march to the music of a different drummer without ever having to leave the comforts of home. Now that the spoken-word industry has caught up with this species of prose, the nature-lover may not only pursue these interests safely indoors, avoiding the caprices of wind and weather, but do so even with both eyes closed.

title: POLE GETS ASYLUM IN DENMARK
description: Justice Minister Erik Ninn-Hansen of Denmark announced today that Jozef Zimnicki, a member of the Polish Communist Central Committee, had been given political asylum.

title: FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON AWARDS DEGREES IN JOINT CEREMONY
description: Dr. T. H. Bell, who was Secretary of Education during President Reagan's first term, told graduates of Fairleigh Dickinson University today that supporting equal opportunity in education through financial aid should remain an important goal in the United States.

title: WORK BY TWO PHOTOGRAPHERS
description: DIANE ARBUS and Hollis Frampton make an unlikely pair, she a photographer whose reputation peaked in the 1960's, he a filmmaker and videoist who rose to fame in the early 1970's. Yet, as reflected in their shows at the State University of New York's Neuberger Museum in Purchase (through June 9), these two formidable personalities complement each other quite well. Incidentally, both died at the age of 48, Arbus by her own hand in 1971, Frampton of cancer last year.

title: CELEBRATING THE STORY OF THE PIANO
description: On Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum some 30 pianos of various makes and vintages will be displayed, some for the first time, in an exhibit called ''Keynotes: Two Centuries of Piano Design'' that will continue through Nov. 29. The oldest known piano (Bartolomeo Cristofori, 1720, still playable) will be there, as will square, upright, multipedaled and lavishly decorated specimens, along with works of art showing the piano in its various social contexts.

title: SHELLEY BRAINARD TOWNSEND ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Busch Hager of New York and Cooperstown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hager's daughter Shelley Brainard Townsend and Thomas Derby Graham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell D. Graham of Montclair, N.J. The future bride is a daughter also of Lyman Bass Townsend of Pittsford, N.Y. An Aug. 24 wedding is planned.

title: ALCOHOL ABUSE ON BOATS RISES
description: The scene was grim, but not particularly surprising. Three boating friends had spent the evening barhopping along the waterfront of a New Jersey harbor. When it came time to head home about 2 A.M., the driver, who was experienced around boats, ignored a basic safety precaution. He motored home without running lights.

title: New Rule for Fishing Rodeo
description: ONE needn't be well-heeled or have an angling friend with an oceangoing Bertram to take part in this year's two-day boat fishing rodeo, which will be -as it was last year - part of the New York Harbor Festival.

title:
ART;

BOLD, BRASH AND CONTROVERSIAL BUILDINGS
description: FEW things are as conspicuous as brash or bold architecture, and the United States has been sprinkled with it in the last 15 years. Most of the controversy it engenders gets scattered in the wind.

title: Did Al Smith Get a Bundle?
description: Was the ''Happy Warrior'' a straight shooter? Historians had always thought so. Alfred E. Smith, who served four two-year terms as Governor of New York between 1919 and 1928 and who ran unsuccessfully as the Democratic candidate for President in 1928, had been credited with scrupulously avoiding the graft that tainted many other New York political careers in his era.

title: ESTATE CONVERSION
description: Pen-Mar, a former horse farm with its own race track and stable complex and a 22-room mansion in Monmouth County, N.J., is being turned into a residential development where 74 new houses will be built.

title: BIKING FOR DIABETES
description: He is not the first, the fastest, the youngest or the oldest person ever to have planned to ride across the United States on a bicycle.

title: STREAMLINING SPEAKERS
description: The swift sequence of changes in the technology of recording since the beginning of this decade has created a climate of acceptance for the unconventional. There is a feeling among audio fans that the dawn of the digital age calls for old thinking to be refurbished and old axioms to be reassessed.

title: MR. B AND HIS SOUL MATE
description: BALANCHINE'S TCHAIKOVSKY Interviews with George Balanchine. By Solomon Volkov. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: LISA GRAHAM IS WED TO ALDEN HATHAWAY
description: Lisa King Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Graham of Washington, was married there yesterday to Alden Wetmore Hathaway, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alden P. Hathaway of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. Vienna Cobb Anderson performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church.

title: Second Appearance
description: To the Editor:

title: ICONS AND ICONOCLASTSHigh Marks
description: For profiles in courage, it's hard to beat the one that is being sketched in Texas by Gov. Mark White and the State Legislature. They are holding out against legions of parents, teen-agers and athletic coaches bent on repealing or modifying the state's ''no pass, no play'' rule for high school extracurricular activities.

title: THE CARTER NOTEBOOKS
description: AT the table in the Mets' clubhouse, Gary Carter was going over the opposing batters for some teammates and coaches as if he were reciting from a book. Of one batter, the Mets' catcher said, ''He can't hit the outside curveball.'' Of another, ''You can bust him up and in.'' On and on he went, without hesitation And in a way, he indeed was reciting from a book, his own - the collection of notebooks he has kept ever since he joined the Montreal Expos as a rookie catcher more than 10 years ago.

title: HEALTH, TOO, IS AN ISSUE IN SOUTH AFRICAN MINES
description: ''South African Union Storms Apartheid's Bastions'' (news article, May 14) highlights the struggle between the National Union of Mineworkers and the owners of the gold mines. Underreported in this struggle is miner concern over job safety and health issues, as well as economics.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FILMS AND AN OPERA
description: The Gigglesnort Hotel Karl/Lorimar Home Video 45 minutes. $39.95 A decade ago, ''The Gigglesnort Hotel,'' a local children's television program seen in the Chicago area, may have seemed progressive as well as entertaining.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: GREAT LAKES AT PEAK LEVELS, WITH WORRIES CLIMBING, TOO
description: When Don Eilers reprinted the glossy brochure advertising his lodge on Lake Michigan recently, he left out the color photographs of the beach.

title: Guess Who Pays for Tax 'Reform'
description: To push through something that will be called tax reform, President Reagan seems ready to yield concessions to all sorts of important constituencies, from oil wildcatters to university fund-raisers. Yet deplorably, Mr. Reagan persists in his determination to attack the one tax benefit that is of clearest benefit to the nation's poor: the deductibility of state and local taxes.

title: U.S. WEAVES CASE AT COAST SPY TRIAL
description: Long walks, meetings in automobiles and telephone calls to Soviet diplomats are part of the web of circumstantial evidence prosecutors are weaving in the espionage trial of two Soviet emigres in Federal District Court here.

title: GRAY DEFEATS CRUZ IN GRAND PRIX 800
description: Until five days ago, Joaquim Cruz of Brazil, the Olympic champion in the men's 800-meter run, planned to run the mile here today in the Bruce Jenner's Bud Light Classic. Then he switched to the 800 meters, setting up the two most interesting developments of the day.

title: PARLEY ASSESSES ROLE OF WOMEN
description: THE third annual conference on scholarship about women was held here last week with three new co-sponsors: the New Jersey State Conference of the American Association of University Professors, the New Jersey division of the American Association of University Women and the Division on Women of the state's Department of Community Affairs.

title: RENAISSANCE ALONG THE WATERFRONTS OF 3 CITIES TRANSFORMS DOWNTOWNS
description: The big-city Northeastern waterfronts that sustained and nourished the infant United States in the days of sail, only to crumble into disuse and decay by the 20th century, are coming back strongly.

title: A LIFE SPENT IN LOVE WITH THE MOVIES
description: AMONG statements it seems safe to make is that few people who began their careers acting in silent films are still actively engaged in making movies. But one of them is Robert Parrish of Sag Harbor, who was already a Hollywood veteran by the time he appeared with Charlie Chaplin in the 1931 ''City Lights.''

title: FOR A MOTHER OF 8, THE FUTURE IS DIM
description: IF ELISE ALGOR cannot pay her rent, her children will be placed in foster care, and she is fighting to keep them any way she can.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AS LONG AS THE RIVER SHALL RUN: An Ethnohistory of Pyramid Lake Indian Reservation. By Martha C. Knack and Omer C. Stewart.

title: Outside Experience Aids Teaching
description: An article was offered describing the joy of teaching [''Joy of Teaching Is Worth the Pain,'' March 10] . Connecticut, in reaching out to persuade high school students to take advantage of the joys, offers forgiveness loans in exchange for today's high school juniors making an early commitment to public school teaching upon their graduation. The entire loan is ''forgiven'' if the candidate teaches for five consecutive years. I suggest that these bright young people ought to reconsider.

title: GARY GOODEN STARS IN SPRINTS
description: Gary Gooden showed yesterday why football opponents of Nazareth High School of Brooklyn had a difficult time bringing him down last fall. Gooden, an all-New York backfield selection and the city's top scorer, posted two sprint meet records in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association Outdoor Track and Field Championship at St. John's University.

title: G.O.P., PARTY OF INTERNATIONAL REVOLUTION
description: Who would ever have thought it? It seems to go against everything they've traditionally stood for, but the Republicans have become the party of international revolution. Determined when possible to topple regimes deemed Communist or pro-Soviet, they are urging the United States to back guerrilla insurgency in Nicaragua, Afghanistan, Cambodia and Angola.

title: THE LESSON OF A CHILD'S SUICIDE
description: THE burial service had just ended. I crossed the carpet of artificial grass that surrounded the plain coffin about to be lowered soundlessly into the ground and shook hands with the parents of the dead young man, looking into their numb eyes and murmuring, ''I'm sorry, I'm so sorry.''

title: PROCRASTINATOR'S PENALTY
description: YOU can spot them by the look in their eyes; a tired, haunted look of fear. They trudge dejectedly toward the library, the computer rooms, the practice rooms in the music department. You see them shyly knocking on the doors of professors. They are the students known as the Procrastinators.

title: RYE NECK, RYE TO VOTE ON MERGER OF SCHOOLS
description: IN 1947, the State Education Department recommended the merger of the Rye City and Rye Neck School Districts as a way of improving the quality of education in both communities and expanding their financial bases. In the 28 years since the state's recommendation, school board officials in Rye Neck have twice voted favorably for a merger, once in 1963 and again in 1976. But on both occasions, the concept was rejected by the Rye School Board.

title: JAMES F. MALONE WED TO CONNIE FREDERICKS
description: Connie Fredericks, an actress, was married yesterday to James F. Malone, a career and educational counselor at Harborfields High School in Greenlawn, L.I. The Rev. Rob Williams performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: BEAUTY AT RAILWAY STATIONS EXPLORED AT THE WHITNEY
description: ''WORKING on the Railroad,'' the current show at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford, examines by way of drawings, photographs and models the art works commissioned for selected Amtrak stations between Washington, D.C., and Boston.

title: APPETIZERS FROM THE SEA
description: SEVERAL MONTHS AGO, I WAS INvited to Tokyo to judge an international cooking competition. The contestants represented restaurants and hotels from throughout Europe and Asia. Two of the winners in the appetizer category were from a restaurant in Switzerland called Chez Max, which is located near Zurich.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. CRITICIZES COMPANY THAT PREPARED TEST FOR L.I. POLICE
description: The Justice Department has accused the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N.J., of making misleading, inaccurate and deceptive statements in its preparation of a police examination for Nassau County.

title: WAGE RIGIDITY IS THE CENTRAL PROBLEM
description: WHERE do Western economies now stand in the fight against unemployment and inflation? For Americans the current situation is not bad compared with our recent past - unemployment appears temporarily stuck at a little more than 7 percent and inflation at more than 4 percent. But that's bad by our postwar standards, and for Europeans the picture is even worse - inflation is down to about 5 percent, but unemployment is averaging 11 percent.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: TWO-SPOTTED LADYBUG BEETLE Adalia bipunctata Size: To one-quarter inch.

title: Woman, 85, Is Beaten To Death in Apartment
description: An 85-year-old woman was found beaten to death yesterday in her apartment at a residential hotel in midtown Manhattan, the police said. The police believed robbery was the motive.

title: Arthur Grubert Dead; Ex-Police Chief in City
description: Arthur C. Grubert, a former chief of inspectional services in the New York City Police Department, died of heart failure Friday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 67 years old.

title: GUILT AND COMPASSION
description: THE CIDER HOUSE RULES. By John Irving. 560 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95. BY turns witty, tenderhearted, fervent and scarifying, ''The Cider House Rules'' is, for me, John Irving's first truly valuable book.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Some interesting echoes of Broadway can be found this week in vintage films on broadcast television. One bargain is the 1956 ''Bus Stop,'' a fine version of William Inge's comedy-drama - actually an improvement.

title: PRIVATE TRANSPORTATION IS A PIPE DREAM
description: Privatization of government services is frequently offered as a solution to the nation's transportation problems. The implication is that entrepreneurs can step in to help meet growing demands on shrinking public resources.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MAN WHO WAS M: The Life of Maxwell Knight. By Anthony Masters. (Basil Blackwell, $14.95.) Who was M? In all those Ian Fleming spy romances he was James Bond's suave chief.

title: NIGERIA COMPLETES THE SECOND EXPULSION OF ALIENS
description: Nigeria has completed the expulsion of thousands of illegal aliens. The last shipload of 717 aliens was reported to have left Lagos on Friday.

title: DEFEATED BY VICTORY
description: A VIETCONG MEMOIR By Truong Nhu Tang. With David Chanoff and Doan Van Toai. Illustrated. 350 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: PROSPECTS
description: As Small-Bank Loans Go

title: DATABANK

title: EX-SKATER GETS USED TO THE BOARD ROOM
description: Much of the routine is the same, at least to start the day. Bobby Clarke still gets up around 6:30 each morning, still likes a light breakfast and is usually at the rink by 9 o'clock.

title: VANISHING SONGBIRD TRAIL LEADS TO TROPICS
description: To the Editor:

title: WORRIED CHILDREN CAN DIAL A FRIEND
description: WHEN thunderstorms strike, when classmates are cruel, when parents' marital problems are upsetting, or when loneliness or boredom set in, children in several Connecticut communities are being urged to call a hotline number for someone to talk to.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FILMS AND AN OPERA
description: Tina Turner: Private Dancer Sony 45 17 minutes. $16.95 Tina Turner's self-possessed sexiness is so phenomenal that watching her perform in any setting can be mesmerizing.

title: WASHINGTON TIMES AND ITS CONSERVATIVE NICHE
description: Staff members of The Washington Times tell of how the newspaper's new editor, Arnaud de Borchgrave, sometimes prowls the newsroom late in the evening in blue silk pajamas, roused from the bed in his office by an idea that might help crack what he considers the liberal bias of many news organizations in general and the ''incredible arrogance'' of The Washington Post in particular.

title: A JUNGLE IN THE BRONX
description: THIS IS THE JUNGLE. A GIANT TROPICAL TREE, its huge base covered by water, towers out of sight into billows of clouds. A python lies coiled in a fallen tree, just inches above the path. A family of monitor lizards lazes in the sunlight on warm rocks as, only yards away, a steady rain falls. Rare proboscis monkeys gambol amid the tropical growth while a giant long-snouted crocodile swims slowly past a 40-foot-high waterfall.

title: POPE'S SPEECH TO CARDINALS
description: Following, in official translation, are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's speech in St. Peter's Square today after he elevated 28 prelates to cardinal:

title: Defining Death More Clearly
description: Governor Cuomo addressed one of life's basic questions last week: What is death? Acting on the advice of a panel of lawyers, doctors and members of the clergy he appointed to study the matter, Mr. Cuomo proposed a uniform definition of death and new guidelines under which physicians in New York State would be permitted to halt medical care for the terminally ill.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ALLOWS MULTIRACIAL PARTIES
description: The South African Government announced today that it had decided to abolish a 17-year-old law prohibiting multiracial political parties.

title: SWEATSUITS SAY IT ALL
description: ON busy holiday weekends like this one, when people are coming and going and sometimes don't know which, more of them than ever seem to be in sweatsuits that have become fashion's moving signs.

title: On Boomerangs
description: If you don't know there's a boom on boomerangs these days, you haven't been talking to Ben Ruhe. ''The Frisbee has had its day,'' he declares.

title: HIGH EMOTIONS IN THE DENTIST'S CHAIR
description: FEW people look forward to a visit to the dentist. A range of emotions from mild apprehension to outright dread surrounds most dental visits. Many people do not visit dentists at all, unless coerced by excruciating pain, and even then they endure the pain for days, wishing that it would somehow disappear. To this end, they often attempt to treat themselves with over-the-counter remedies, guided by the advice of equally apprehensive friends. Pain of this magnitude elsewhere in the body would prompt an immediate call to a physician or a visit to an emergency room. What keeps patients from the health professionals trained and motivated to provide appropriate care?

title: BASE PLUS 27
description: Plans for Trump Castle, a condominium residence featuring spires, a moat and drawbridge that Prudential Insurance Company of America and the Trump Organization were to build on Madison Avenue between 59th and 60th Streets, were scrubbed a year ago. At the time, Prudential, the owners of the parcel where the former CIT Corporation building still stands, said it was backing off the residential project because it believed more money could be made by just selling the property to another owner or developer.

title: PAPANDREOU SEEMS TO BE IN FOR A SQUEAKER
description: As the din of insult and accusation mounts to the climax of next Sunday's general elections, about 15 percent of the Greek voters are still making up their mind. They could decide the outcome between Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialists and Constantine Mitsotakis's opposition, New Democracy, which is believed to be moving up from behind.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: It's a Sweater Event, Wednesday Only Mme. Defarge Handknits, a wholesaler to boutiques and major retailers, has moved from an office building in Hartsdale to a vast loft in New Rochelle, where Wednesday only will be devoted to the clearance of 115 unshipped fall, holiday and spring sweaters in petite to medium sizes.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: May 26, 1985 Fiction

title: TV'S PERSPECTIVE IS DEBATED
description: To the Editor:

title: EARLENE HORNBOSTEL IS THE BRIDE OF TEED J. WELCH
description: Earlene Hornbostel, a daughter of Mrs. Norbert R. Wirsching of New York and Hong Kong, and Teed J. Welch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ted J. Welch of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, were married yesterday. Judge Haskell Freedman of the Lawrence (Mass.)

title: ALL QUIET ALONG THE POTOMAC
description: The Arlington National Cemetery, halfway between Robert E. Lee's house on the Virginia slope of the Potomac and Mr. Lincoln's memorial on the other side, was very quiet and beautiful this Memorial Day weekend.

title: TRIALS GIVE US WHAT NOVELS DON'T
description: To the Editor:

title: Warsaw Pact's Commander Vows to Answer 'Star Wars'
description: The commander of Warsaw Pact forces said in an interview published today that the Soviet Union will take measures to respond to any challenge posed by President Reagan's planned space-based missile defense, which the President calls the Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: HELPING GUTTERS AND DOWNSPOUTS DO THEIR JOB
description: MOST homeowners pay no attention to the roof gutters around their houses until the gutters start to overflow or clog, or until one of them splits or rusts through in spots so that water comes pouring through the opening instead of running out through the vertical downspouts.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Hachette Guide to France #1,102 pages. Pantheon Books. $14.95.

title: WHITE HOUSE SETTLES FOR 50 MX'S
description: THE Senate concentrated on a a $232 billion defense authorization bill last week, and the MX missile, one of the more controversial weapons to lift off the Pentagon's drawing boards, took another pounding.

title: Portugal
description: To the Editor: In ''Leaving Crowded Europe Behind'' (Travel, April 28), I was surprised to see no mention made of Portugal. My husband and I and another couple just returned from two weeks in the Algarve.

title: LAURIE MCGAVIN TO BECOME BRIDE
description: The engagement of Laurie Ann McGavin to Peter Glenford Bachmann has been announced by Maya Hof McGavin of Leola, Pa., and Paul Peter McGavin of Miami, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Margot Julie Bachmann and Eric Reinhold Bachmann, both of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: In The Book Review of May 19, Carolyn Kizer's most recent volume of poetry, for which she won a Pulitzer Prize this year, was misidentified. It is ''Yin,'' published by BOA Editions.

title: PILOTS AND UNITED HALT TALKS SEEKING STRIKE'S END
description: Negotiations between United Airlines and striking pilots broke off yesterday after the two sides had reached tentative agreement on basic economic issues but became deadlocked over back-to-work provisions.

title: VERMONT MAN IS FOUND STRANGLED IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A 33-year-old Vermont man visiting New York City was found strangled yesterday morning inside Heckscher Playground in Central Park.

title: THE STATE BUDGET SAYS IT ALL
description: THERE is something about the enormity of government spending that seems to dazzle the electorate and suspend common sense.

title:
DINING OUT;

NEW AND ITALIANATE IN PORT CHESTER
description: OPEN since last September in a section of the county short on acceptable eating places, Marissa offers more or less successful Italianate dishes in pleasant surroundings, although the noise from the bar in an adjoining room can be intrusive at times. The attractive scrolled menu is long on seafood and also lists enough dishes based on veal, chicken and other meats to satisfy a variety of tastes.

title: HE WORE HIS MEDALS GRACEFULLY
description: MOUNTBATTEN By Philip Ziegler. Illustrated. 784 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: The Case of Gerald Ford's Memoirs
description: A conflict between a writer's right to the fruits of his work and a reader's right to timely information was decided by the Supreme Court last week. In a narrowly focused ruling, the Court said that The Nation magazine had infringed the copyright on the memoirs of former President Gerald R. Ford by printing unauthorized quotations from his book several weeks before its publication.

title: Tough Measures In Sri Lanka
description: Sri Lanka's President, J.R. Jayewardene, last week announced plans for extraordinary measures to combat Tamil guerrilla separatists. He said martial law courts would be established by Parliament to deal with ''a breakdown of law and order'' -terrorism and other crimes.

title: Viking Assistant Coach Dies While Jogging
description: Andy MacDonald, assistant coach for the football Minnesota Vikings, died while jogging with his wife in Ludington State Park, authorities said today.

title: Concern for the Welfare Of Spend a Buck Voiced
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;

Photography
description: For its second exhibition, through June 15, the Burden Gallery, 20 East 23d Street, switches from Western landscape to candid camera street and party photography, concentrating in depth on the work of two photographers, Larry Fink and Anthony Hernandez.

title: GROUP WALKS GAIN GROUND IN LONDON
description: London belongs to the walker. Spreading out from the original square mile and the royal enclave at Westminster, the city grew by swallowing up its ring of satellite villages, so that to this day most inner London neighborhoods retain something of their own separate character. Clustered around a green, the church, the pubs and the homes of the gentry, each yields up its particular atmosphere only to those on foot - and then mostly in convenient, two-hour packages that have proved a great boon to the capital's newest tourist industry: the conducted walk.

title: Plaza-Athenee
description: To the Editor: Phyllis Lee Levin's impressions of the Hotel Plaza-Athenee (Travel, April 14) correspond with my own happy memories of a stop there. In 1965 my parents took my sister and me on an extended vacation, and the hotel was one of our bases.

title: FOR FRIEDAN, A LIFE ON THE RUN
description: BETTY FRIEDAN, founder of the modern women's movement, said she has tried hard this spring to get some work done on her fourth book, which is about aging. She has been working on it for five years.

title: SUMMER OPENINGS AND SPRING FINALES
description: THE calendar may not acknowledge it, but judging from the musical schedule, spring seems to be over: indeed, one summer series is under way, another begins next weekend and the first major outdoor symphony concert is only a couple of days later.

title: LIQUEURS FLAVOR 'ADULT' ICE CREAMS
description: MICHAEL LICHTENSTEIN'S first try at making rum ice cream was a flop.

title: PORSCHE AIRLIFT IN WORKS
description: JACK Cook was talking about logistics, money and automobiles. ''We're thinking about flying our cars in from Germany,'' he said. ''We can get 52 of them on a 747, and if we can work out a decent deal with an airline, we'll do it. When you look at the price of our cars and at interest costs, it seems to make sense.''

title: MOTHER NATURE IS NOT TO BLAME FOR FOULING HARBOR
description: WITH any luck, late spring and early summer rains will soon be falling. They will drain into badly depleted reservoirs and water the new growth that has recently sprung from our lawns and gardens. In this dry year the rain probably won't be as heavy as it was last June, but the cycle of rain will fall as it has for eons. If the big rains come, however, I'm wondering if Westchester County officials will again blame nature for the pollution in Mamaroneck Harbor.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: A Traveler's Guide to the Smoky Mountains Region By Jeff Bradley. 272 pages. Harvard Common Press. $19.95. When Horace Kephart, a St. Louis librarian, fled to the mountains of North Carolina in 1904 to experience nature's wilderness and collect material for his classic book, ''Our Southern Highlanders,'' he discovered a curious lack of information about the place and its people. He said: ''I could find in no library a guide to that region. The most diligent research failed to discover so much as a magazine article, written within this generation, that described the land and its people . . . Had I been going to Tenerife or Timbuktu, the libraries would have furnished information aplenty; but about this housetop of eastern America they were strangely silent; it was terra incognita.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: May 26, 1985 Fiction

title: FOR NEW CARDINALS, A DAY OF AWE AND PAGEANTRY
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, by his own admission, had few moments for reflection the last couple of days.

title: AT DREXEL, A NEW CHIEF'S NEW PROBLEMS
description: ON Monday, the day Drexel Burnham Lambert announced that Frederick H. Joseph would become its new chief executive, the office was in an uproar.

title: MARY GOODSPEED IS WED IN NYACK
description: The marriage of Mary Mann Goodspeed of Greenwich, Conn., widow of Bennett W. Goodspeed, to James W. Donley of Greenwich, chairman of the Donley Communications Corporation in New York, took place yesterday in Nyack, N.Y. Justice of the Peace Orville Hungerford Mann Jr., brother of the bride, performed the ceremony in the garden at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: TO THE EXTREMES
description: Not many deliberate acts of a sovereign government carry implications as profoundly perplexing as Israel's decision to exchange 1,150 Palestinian prisoners for 3 captured Israeli soldiers. It was an act arising from the deepest instincts of the state - but in its results, menacing to the state.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MORE THAN PARADES

title: TRYING FOR THE LIFE
description: SARATOGA, HOT By Hortense Calisher. 272 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $16.95.

title: REPORT ON GARBAGE UNDER STUDY
description: THE long-awaited report on the county's garbage investigation, which was relesed last week, will be the subject of a review in the next week or two by officials of his administration, County Executive Andrew O. O'Rourke said.

title: A LIFETIME OF GARDENING HAS ITS REWARDS
description: ''Gardening,'' Gertrude Wister says, ''is a continual process, one that involves two meanings of the word care. Of course, there is the physical care -the feeding, watering, the nurturing of the plants. The second is an emotional involvement. The word love has been so misused in our time!''

title: Shultz Pulls Out The Stops on Aid to Rebels
description: The Reagan Administration last week increased the pressure for aid to the Nicaraguan rebels by warning that Congress, in holding back, could contribute to the realization of its own worst fears about the use of American troops.

title: 27-YEAR-OLD PLAYWRIGHT SYNTHESIZES FAMILIAR JEWISH AND 'PREPPIE' LIFE
description: EVEN though he has not spent very much time on the singles-speckled shore of the Hamptons, Richard Greenberg says he has absorbed enough about Long Island summer culture to have written his acclaimed one-act play ''Life Under Water,'' about the romantic tides of a group of people who spend a summer together on the Hampton beaches.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

A HOUSE AT THE SHORE: BIGGER, NEWER, STRIPPED OF ITS PAST
description: BEFORE me are the architect's plans to turn our squat, ugly duckling of a Jersey Shore cottage into a tall swan.

title: BIRDING'S BIG SLUGGERS BATTLE IT OUT
description: IT MUST have been, at the least, an unsettling sight: Five or six people driving madly down a road, screeching to a halt, spilling out without closing the car doors, whipping out binoculars and scanning the skies, scribbling notes and then taking off again in a cloud of dust.

title: PRIMARY PROVIDING A LESSON IN POLITICS
description: WHOEVER wins the Democratic nomination for Governor on June 4 will have provided a primer for dealing with the problem of running for statewide office in New Jersey.

title: FR
description: HELENE DEUTSCH A Psychoanalyst's Life. By Paul Roazen. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday & Company. $19.95.

title: On Amtrak
description: As Representative James J. Florio sees it, there are contradictions in the Administration's efforts to get the Government out of the business of subsidizing Amtrak. So he wrote the President a letter. Mr. Florio, a New Jersey Democrat, is chairman of the House transportation subcommittee, which has voted to keep the Amtrak subsidies.

title: Howard's 7-8 1/2 Jump Sets American Mark
description: Jim Howard high jumped 7 feet 8 1/2 inches today at the Rice University Meet of Champions, bettering the United States high-jump record by a half-inch.

title: BEEKMAN PL. DOWNZONNG WEIGHED
description: THE City Planning Commission held a hearing last week to receive public comments on a proposal by its staff to greatly limit the size of new buildings that could be built in the Beekman Place neighborhood on the East Side.

title: MEDICAL PROBLEMS OF RANDOM DRUG TESTS
description: COMMISSIONER Peter Ueberroth should be applauded for his interest in stopping drug abuse in baseball. His plan to test management as well as players for the presence of illegal drugs is especially impressive for its fairness. Among the commissioner's concerns are the reputation of the game and the risks of criminal behavior. The personal health of people connected with baseball is also a primary concern, but unfortunately, from a medical point of view, the plan for universal random drug testing does not make good sense.

title: NUPTIALS PLANNED FOR MISS PRATTE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Pratte of Worthington, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter Lorraine Barbara Pratte to Jacob Matthew Lewis, a son of Rachel Benet Lewis of Watertown, Mass., and Peter A. Lewis of New York. The wedding is planned for September.

title: JAPAN TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR HARRIED PARENTS, ADVICE ON THE AIR
description: ALL 17 lines on the switchboard in Studio 8C were glowing insistently when Lawrence Balter took the next call, from Brenda of Brooklyn. ''My daughter, she sucks her fingers while going to bed at night,'' she said. ''I'm trying to get her to stop and I'm just wondering, what can I do if she doesn't outgrow it?'' ''How are you trying to get her to stop?'' Dr. Balter asked. ''I tell her she's being a baby.''

title: Trying to Dispel 'The Mystique of Age,' at 72
description: SAG HARBOR, L.I. -- IT is the day after Labor Day, and the old white house with the black shutters on Glover Street is asleep in the warm September sun. Even rudely repeated bangings on the front door cannot shake the quietude. Surreptitious peeks through the front parlor windows finally make it quite clear that no one is home.

title: REDEVELOPING NEW HAVEN'S HARBOR
description: For years New Haven's waterfront was ignored by developers. But improved sewage treatment, which made the water cleaner, has helped to spur both residential and commercial waterfront development.

title: ACORN TO MOM'S COMMAND
description: Mom's Command seemed to fly for half a mile and then stagger for half a mile, but the combination was good enough for a front-running three-length victory in the Acorn Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: MINORITY CANDIDATES IN CITY FACING CAMPAIGN'S 1ST BIG TEST
description: An unprecedented number of black and Hispanic Democrats are seeking citywide and boroughwide nominations as New York City candidates prepare this week for the first hurdle to qualifying for the Sept. 10 primary ballot -gathering designating petitions.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review May 5 of Jon Bradshaw's ''Dreams That Money Can Buy: The Tragic Life of Libby Holman,'' the composer of the song ''Moanin' Low'' was incorrect. Ralph Rainger wrote the music.

title: Required Reading;   Of Price and Value
description: Excerpts from ''Privatizing Federal Spending - A Strategy to Eliminate the Deficit,'' by Stuart M. Butler, director of domestic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation:

title: COLLEGE APPLIICANTS DEFY TREND
description: APPLICATIONS from freshmen to state colleges on Long Island are declining at the same time they are increasing at local private schools, college officials say.

title: NEVER MIND THE WALLFLOWERS
description: WHEN I moved to Long Island six years ago, intending to make it my home, there was nothing I missed so much as the gardens of my childhood in England - those verdant green jewels laid out to perfection by stalwart country matrons or fussy clerks whose lawn stripes matched the regularity of their bookkeeping.

title: Another Look At Pornography
description: ''Re-examination of the issue of pornography is long overdue,'' Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said last week, in announcing the appointment of a new Justice Department commission to study the effects of sexually explicit material.

title: CAJUN ZEST IN A CONVIVIAL SETTING
description: PROBABLY no food craze has swept over stoves and dining tables as fast as the current passion for Cajun cooking, based on the French-Canadian heritage of Louisiana. Americans' taste for ''hot'' was first demonstrated by the red-pepper sizzle of Sichuan cooking, then by Mexican salsas, and now is showing up in the garlic-cayenne pepper-onion seasonings of the Cajun kitchen.

title: THE CUSTOMER COMES FIRST
description: A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE The Leadership Difference. By Tom Peters and Nancy Austin. Illustrated. 437 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95. TOM PETERS is a co-author of the best-selling ''In Search of Excellence,'' and now with his colleague Nancy Austin, a co-author of ''The Assertive Woman,'' he has written another best seller, a sort of ''In Search II.'' The book will win few prizes for originality, intellectual vigor or good editing. Its wordy, rah-rah style will turn off some readers. It should be treated like peanuts and taken in small, bite-size amounts. Nonetheless, a good number of executives should find the authors' themes instructive and parts of the book inspirational.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: JOURNEY PAINTINGS Tony Foster, a 39-year-old Englishman, spent last summer trudging through the White Mountains of New Hampshire and paddling the rivers of Maine with his painting equipment strapped to his back or bundled into the canoe. Although he assembles and finishes his work back home in Cornwall, England, he is, somewhat like John J. Audubon, a naturalist who must sketch and paint at the site to achieve the authenticity that suits him.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: WHAT IS REMEMBERED, by Alice B. Toklas. (North Point, $9.50.) Alice B. Toklas is known principally as the staunch companion of Gertrude Stein, with whom she conducted a famed Parisian literary salon. But Toklas was an author in her own right, and in this 1963 book, she describes the famous, wealthy, talented, hopeful and curious who visited the successive Stein and Toklas residences. Gene Baro wrote here that ''What Is Remembered'' is ''an important interpretation of the personalities and relationships that centered upon the households. . . . Miss Toklas tells a story well.'' THE GALLERY, by John Horne Burns. (Arbor House, $6.95.) In this World War II novel, the Galleria Umberto Primo, a Naples arcade, links the nine characters, Allied soldiers and Italian civilians.

title: Polemics Over Flight 007
description: To the Editor:

title: ALZHEIMER VICTIMS CAN GET LOCAL HELP
description: MOST people have experienced the embarrassment of momentarily forgetting the name of someone familiar to them. A red-faced apology usually settles the issue.

title: Creativity And Customer Value
description: Thank you for Cary Reich's excellent article ''The Innovator'' (April 21), on Roger Smith, the chairman of General Motors. Mr. Smith should now turn his innovative mind to the distribution and sales system.

title: EUPHEMISM STRIKES AGAIN
description: THE ad was dazzling. The special plant that the nursery's copy billed as the ''Peace Lily'' was described in such wondrous terms that my hands shook with a surge of acquisitiveness even as I held the newspaper.

title: F.D.A. Plans No Action In Heart Implant Case
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration has decided not to take action against doctors who implanted an artificial heart without permission.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHEN PAYING WITH DOLLARS COSTS MORE
description: They have never met, but Robert B. Turner and Sol Chazin have something in common. Each of them has taken an escorted tour conducted by a London-based company called Voyages Jules Verne and each has been disturbed by what happened. Among their principal complaints was that Americans paid substantially more than Europeans on the same tours.

title: Cuomo's Plan To Sever Links To South Africa
description: If money talks, Albany's billions ought to be worth listening to. So Governor Cuomo hopes. Last week, he called for New York to join the growing list of states, cities and organizations divesting of companies doing business in South Africa ''to demonstrate the abhorrence of our residents to the pernicious system of apartheid.''

title: BALLET THEATER - ANNIVERSARY GALA
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER has always taken care to count its milestones. It has celebrated such important occasions as its 10th and 25th anniversaries and its 35th and 40th seasons. Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, it staged a gala to honor its 45th anniversary.

title: PHYSICIAN TO THE SEXTUPLETS: CARRIE CASE WORCESTER
description: Dr. Carrie Worcester was a United States Army captain in West Germany serving as a pediatrician 10 years ago when she decided that a career of treating ''colds and runny noses'' would not fulfill her ambitions.

title: The Case For Humankind
description: I wonder why women should have to assume that ''the male embraces the female'' in language or in life (''You Not Tarzan, Me Not Jane,'' by William Safire, On Language, April 28). Those who stubbornly resist the use of inclusive language under the guise of defending the purity of our mother-father tongue are, in fact, attempting to protect the discriminatory assumptions which the language reflects.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 72 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 72 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: STEPPING INTO THE MET'S NEW PARLOR
description: SINCE THE METROPOLI-tan Museum of Art opened its American Wing over 60 years ago, it has been known for its fine collection of period rooms.

title: WHAT BIG BUSINESS SEES IN FINE ART
description: The spreading conviction that art is good for big business -and vice versa - has been locally reinforced by two recent developments. Uptown, the Equitable Life Assurance Society has unveiled plans for what it touts as ''the largest corporate art complex ever developed.'' To adorn its $200 million headquarters building now rising on Seventh Avenue, the company has bought and refurbished a 1930's mural by the American regionalist Thomas Hart Benton; given large-scale wall commissions to such well-known contemporaries as Roy Lichtenstein and Sol LeWitt, and will install yet another branch of the ubiquitous Whitney Museum in its capacious lobby (no corporate lobby should be without one). For the Benton and the commissions alone, the tab is already $7 million, and there's more to come. Executive dining rooms and lobby restaurants will be rigged out with works by a dozen other high-profile American artists, ranging from Marsden Hartley to Alex Katz.

title: DEOBRAH HATHAWAY IS WED IN CONNECTICUT
description: The marriage of Deborah H. Hathaway and Frank Clifford Perkins 3d took place yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Redding, Conn. Justice of the Peace Patricia Moisio of Redding performed the ceremony.

title: CHRISTINE MERCEDES JORQUERA ENGAGED TO MARRY ALAN BORDEN VICKERY AUG. 3
description: Mr. and Mrs. Humberto Jorquera of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christine Mercedes Jorquera to Alan Borden Vickery, a son of Comdr. Hugh B. Vickery, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Vickery of Washington.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SECRETS OF STATE: The State Department and the Struggle Over U.S. Foreign Policy. By Barry Rubin. (Oxford University, $25.) Delineating the role of the State Department in the history of United States foreign policy is an ambitious theme.

title: LEARNING TO COOK WITH HEALTHIER INGREDIENTS
description: LOUISE STERN of Stamford used to entertain friends regularly, cooking lavish meals of rich foods. That stopped in 1970, when her husband, Melvin, had a heart attack and then coronary bypass surgery. After that, Mrs. Stern started looking for ways to change their diet.

title: JOHNS HOPKINS TAKES TITLE
description: Johns Hopkins, the dominant power in college lacrosse for 15 years, defended its national title here at Brown Stadium today by routing Syracuse, 11-4, in the final round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MICROWAVE COOKING
description: UNTIL recently, microwave ovens were probably the least purchased - and least utilized - major household appliance. They were bulky, tricky to use and feared as a possible source of radiation. Even those few souls who bought microwaves rarely really cooked in them, using them instead to defrost, reheat or prepare frozen dinners in a hurry.

title: BRICK WALLS AND SIMPLE DELIGHTS
description: NOW five years old and well-established, the Laundry, a restaurant in East Hampton that has always had the cachet of show-business backers, seems to have settled in for a long run. Many of the problems of food and service in the early days appear to have been corrected.

title: MARILLA PALMER IS BRIDE OF PETER M. ZAREMBA
description: The marriage of Marilla Street Palmer, a daughter of Family Court Judge and Mrs. Richard M. Palmer of Brooklyn Heights, to Peter Michael Zaremba, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Zaremba of Flushing, Queens, took place yesterday. Judge M. Holt Meyer of the Family Court officiated at the National Arts Club in Manhattan.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;

GENERAL DYNAMICS IS DEALT NEW BLOWS
description: On the surface, the news was bad. Two General Dynamics units were banned from further bidding on Navy projects, contracts were canceled and the company was fined heavily for what the Pentagon called ''pervasive'' business misconduct. Then the contractor's chairman, David S. Lewis, announced he would step down by the end of the year, although he claimed there was no direct connection to the ban. But some analysts said the one-two punch may be a disguised blessing. They note that by agreeing to meet strict Navy conditions for contracts, and by replacing Mr. Lewis with Stanley C. Pace, a TRW executive regarded as a scrupulous businessman, General Dynamics could position itself as a cleaner, more attractive contractor.

title: SEX ISSUE DIVIDES RIVERSIDE CHURCH
description: A debate on whether homosexuality is compatible with traditional Christian teachings has recently opened deep divisions among members of Riverside Church, divisions church leaders say are deeper than any aroused by an issue since the Vietnam War.

title: GEORGE SELDES: AUTHOR AND THOUGHT COLLECTOR
description: EVERYTHING about George Seldes comes across a little larger than life: his age, the names he drops, the adventures he recalls, even the place where he lives - the quaintly named Hartland-Four-Corners, a hamlet of a few hundred people near Windsor, Vt.

title: 9 SCIENTIFIC STUDIES AT COLUMBIA ARE RETRACTED
description: Nine technical studies by two staff members of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons have been retracted from medical journals because they are based on ''data of dubious certainty,'' the university reported yesterday.

title: EXPATRIATE STUDENTS ARE OFTEN INNOCENTS AT HOME
description: When 16-year-old Xandra Castleton arrived in this country from Guinea-Bissau in West Africa to attend boarding school she had trouble making a phone call.

title:
INVESTING;

A CAUTION SIGN FOR THE TRIBUNE CO.
description: WHEN analysts and portfolio managers talk about the long-term prospects for a stock, it is usually a signal they are not that positive about its immediate future. And that appears to be the general reaction to recent news surrounding the Tribune Company: Rupert Murdoch's probable move to sell two papers that compete directly with the Tribune's flagship properties, and the Tribune Company's own plan to buy the Los Angeles independent television station, KTLA-TV. Both changes could mean good sailing for the Chicago-based media giant later in the decade, say analysts, but for the shorter run, the view is a bit more cautious.

title: TV: PBS'S 'ASHES,' ABOUT A BLACK VETERAN
description: ''INDEPENDENT FOCUS,'' the WNET/ Channel 13 series that provides viewers with a glimpse of what independent film and video makers are doing for the less-than-mass audience, presents an earnest and provocative film drama tonight at 11 o'clock about the problems facing blacks in America.

title: THESE ARE TRYING TIMES FOR KOHL AND HIS PARTY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition was running scared last week.

title: Men's Style;   WEEKEND ESSENTIALS
description: For the businessman who travels frequently, packing becomes a precise science in which, for convenience's sake, less is more.

title: 8 Bombs Rock Corsica; 4th Attack This Month
description: Eight bombs exploded early this morning in southern Corsica, the police said.

title: A SECOND FRONT IN THE BATTLE FOR ULSTER
description: The latest exercise in democracy in Northern Ireland appears to have complicated the search by Britain and Ireland for a political solution to the violence there. Although both countries would like to announce progress, they now agree that any meeting between their Prime Ministers is unlikely before fall.

title: U.N.'S NAMBIA COUNCIL PLANS SUIT ON MINING
description: A United Nations council plans to file suit in the court of a member nation to try to block the unauthorized exploitation of natural resources in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.

title: MISS SHRADER IS BETROTHED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Shrader of Westport, Conn., and Becket, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Ellen Watkins Shrader to Edward Wharton Witkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William I. Witkin of Chappaqua, N.Y. The wedding is planned for July 5.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Mahler to Freud The relationship between the artist's life and his work sometimes seems almost comically direct. In ''Mahler,'' by Kurt Blaukopf (Limelight), the composer explains the source of the often-puzzling dissonances in his music.

title: Rent Control Forever
description: New York's Legislature is again preparing to renew the Emergency Tenant Protection Act, the lineal descendant of World War II's Federal price controls, which still governs the rents of 1.2 million apartments in New York City. The law's preamble clings to the fiction that the war's housing shortage produced this 42-year-old emergency. No one dares to observe that the shortage has actually grown worse and that the controls themselves help to prolong it.

title: OILERS ARE WARY OF HOSPODAR'S PLAY
description: Mark Napier came to practice today with one of his two front teeth missing, another tooth chipped and a third held in position, as he described it, by cement.

title: TV: VANESSA REDGRAVE AND SALEM WITCH TRIALS
description: There are at least a couple of quite compelling reasons for watching ''Three Sovereigns for Sarah,'' a three-part American Playhouse series that begins tonight at 9 on Channel 13. Victor Pisano's script offers a clear and reasonable reconstruction of the Salem witch trials, one of the more odious and frightening events in American history. And the admirable production, steeped in authentic details, is illuminated by Vanessa Redgrave, giving another of her extraordinary dramatic performances.

title: United Negotiators Plan For Possible Long Strike
description: United Airlines and its 5,000 striking pilots are preparing for the possibility of a long walkout now that contract talks have broken off, spokesmen for both sides said today.

title: WHY I LOVE THE UNITED STATES
description: Nations like people have their public and their private selves. To foreigners of my political persuasion, the United States offers a public image less than beguiling - a gigantic militarist state, led by an aged neo-monarch, guided frequently by advisers of dubious intellectual or even moral quality, directed offstage by covert interests of finance and ideology, pursuing foreign policies of terrifying unreliability.

title: Behind the President's Lincoln Brigade Remark
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Train Wreckage Is Difficult to Clear
description: The wreckage of a freight train derailment that set off an explosion continued to smolder today as railroad workers and hazardous chemical specialists made slow progress cleaning it up.

title: Bolstering Thrift Insurance
description: Last December, Edwin J. Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, threw cold water into the face of the thrift industry. He threatened to assess each savings and loan association a special premium equal to 1/32 percent of their assets per quarter in an effort to bolster the sagging Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: PATRICK EWING, CLASS OF '85
description: A heavy dose of sunshine baked the habitants of the sprawling front lawn on the campus of Georgetown University this morning. But there were no complaints. There never are on this special day, rain or shine.

title: 8 ACCUSED OF PLOT ON POPE'S LIFE WILL GO ON TRIAL IN ROME TODAY The following article is based on reporting by Claire Sterling and John Tagliabue and was written by Mr. Tagliabue.
description: A major courtroom trial that could throw light on obscure links of international terrorism begins here Monday when five Turks and three Bulgarians face charges they took part in a plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: STAGE: IN MARATHON '85, 'ROAD TO THE GRAVEYARD'
description: At the end of ''The Road to the Graveyard,'' Horton Foote's new one-act play at the Ensemble Studio Theater, a small-town Texas family sits in its homey parlor, each member lost in silent contemplation. The year is 1939, and the air is warm and still. The only sound is that of distant waltz music drifting in from a party of Mexican laborers enjoying a night off.

title: Turkey May Ease Curbs
description: The National Security Council recommended today that martial law be lifted in six provinces, including Ankara, the nation's capital and second largest city, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported. The council said martial law should be extended for four months in 17 other provinces. The Government imposed martial law in 1978 in response to political violence.

title: WALTRIP TAKES 600, AS ELLIOTT IS 18TH
description: Darrell Waltrip won the Coca-Cola World 600 stock-car race this afternoon as the favorite, Bill Elliott, lost his first opportunity to earn a $1 million payday.

title: Bridge: Two Records Are Possible As Goldman Pairs Resume
description: The prestigious Goldman Pairs resumed yesterday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., with a possibility that two records would be set.

title: Fuel Cans Cited in Move Fire
description: The devastating fire that left 250 Philadelphians homeless started when the police bomb dropped on the roof of a cult's house ignited two gasoline cans and they exploded, according to a newspaper's analysis of pictures.

title: NEW CLASSICAL ARCHITECTURE TO PULL PARIS TOGETHER
description: If there is any city that in the years since World War II has been built in violation of all its architectural traditions, it is Paris. A generation of unimaginative architects, combined with the French preference for pre-cast concrete construction, have made the outskirts of Paris a dreary landscape of harsh high-rise buildings, as dull and as anti-urban as any cityscape in the United States.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 27, 1985: *2*MONDAY (Holiday) *2*TUESDAY Angelica Corp New England Elec Sys Brockway Inc Pacific Tin Consol Brush Wellman Revlon Inc Detroit Edison Tucson Elec Pwr Gap Stores United Illuminating Macy (RH) & Co Watkins-Johnson Merck & Company Westvaco Corp Michigan Energy Res *2*WEDNESDAY Cenergy Corp NJ Resources Conwood Corp Philip Morris Deere & Co Stanley Works Manhattan Industries *2*THURSDAY Ametek Inc Shell Oil Company Arvin Industries Union Pacific Corp Perry Drug Stores Zurn Industries *2*FRIDAY Aetna Life & Casualty United Inns Inc Ralston Purina

title: NEW YORK FACING UPHILL TAX BATTLE
description: New York State's efforts to preserve the Federal income-tax deduction of state and local taxes have attracted little support so far in Congress.

title: DISPUTED SOUTHERN WATERWAY READY TO OPEN
