description: Tommy Swan says he has been hearing it since he was a small boy: how the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway was going to turn the local economy around and bring jobs and people to this poor quarter of eastern Mississippi.

title: 27 Schoolchildren Are Killed In Collision in Western Kenya
description: Twenty-seven schoolchildren died when a truck carrying them home from a music festival collided with a freight truck near the western Kenyan town of Kapkatet Saturday night, The Nairobi Sunday Nation reported today.

title: Mount St. Helens Dome Continues to Emit Heat
description: The lava dome of Mount St. Helens continued to give off heat but it apparently has not grown significantly overnight, scientists said today, a day after saying an eruption was likely within days.

title: Sybil A. Cartmell Wed To Kent Farnow Smith
description: The marriage of Sybil Anne Cartmell, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John A. Cartmell of Wilmington, Del., to Kent Farnow Smith, a son of Mrs. Henry Such Smith of Roselle, N.J., and the late Mr. Smith, took place yesterday. The bride's father performed the ceremony at the Red Clay Creek Presbyterian Church in Wilmington.

title: PROUD TRUTH WINS PETER PAN
description: Proud Truth, the top-rated 3-year-old in the country two months ago, atoned yesterday for his fifth-place finish in the Kentucky Derby with a handy 1 1/4-length score in the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park. Stephan's Odyssey, who was second in the Derby, finished fourth as the even-money favorite.

title: Warsaw Priest's Sermon Denounces Communism
description: A Warsaw priest delivered a fierce attack on Communism today in a sermon heard by thousands of worshipers at the church of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, who was slain last year by security policemen.

title: MCHALE: CELTIC WHO GIVES RIVALS FITS
description: ''ASK any coach,'' says Chuck Daly of the Detroit Pistons, ''and he'll tell you that the first thing on any Celtic scouting report is to watch out for McHale, not Larry Bird.''

title: Lisa Rau Is Wed To Paul S. Jacobs
description: Lisa Fay Rau and Paul Schafran Jacobs, who are to start work in September as computer scientists with General Electric's corporate research and development center in Schenectady, N.Y, were married yesterday at the Elberon, N.J., home of her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rau. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel officiated.

title: MOTHER OF 7 VISITS SURVIVING INFANTS
description: The California high school teacher who had the largest multiple birth in American history visited her five surviving septuplets for the first time late Saturday, her doctor said today.

title: COMEBACK PROPELS CUBS PAST ASTROS
description: Ron Cey hit two home runs, including the game winner, today to boost the Chicago Cubs to a come-from-behind 10-8 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: CYCLONE'S TOLL IS OVER 1,400 AND THOUSANDS ARE MISSING IN BANGLADESH COAST AREAS
description: The death toll from a cyclone that sent huge waves crashing into the islands of southeastern Bangladesh rose to at least 1,400 today, and officials and survivors said they feared that many more may have perished.

title: East Meets Best
description: On a televised special tomorrow night, Bob Hope not only will have Marvelous Marvin Hagler as a guest but also will be shown, through trick photography, fighting such champions as Rocky Marciano, Larry Holmes, Sugar Ray Leonard and Sugar Ray Robinson.

title: REVIVED COSMOS TO OPEN SERIES
description: Feared dead three months ago when they dropped out of indoor soccer, the Cosmos are on their feet again for a summer of outdoor action.

title: SHIITES IN BEIRUT ARE SAID TO KILL 250 PALESTINIANS
description: Shiite Moslem fighters in West Beirut have begun killing large numbers of Palestinians from two refugee settlements, according to accounts by witnesses and other reports from the scene.

title: GENERALS WIN, 30-24, ON A BIZARRE PLAY
description: The Generals beat the Tampa Bay Bandits in overtime today, 30-24, and the player responsible at the end was neither Herschel Walker nor Doug Flutie. Instead, he was Rick Partridge, the punter who served as the holder for a 26-yard field-goal attempt by Roger Ruzek 3 minutes 53 seconds into the overtime.

title: MINIATURE OIL RUSH LIFTING ECONOMIC HOPES IN SOUTHERN TIER OF NEW YORK
description: As the heavy earthmoving equipment ripped through the top soil and spewed diesel fumes into the crystal air, teams scurried around the clock to prepare the drilling rig.

title: 11 Campers Killed in France
description: A concrete wall collapsed onto a crowded Mediterranean seaside campsite today, crushing and killing 11 campers, five of them children, the police said. Six others were seriously injured when the 90-foot hillside support wall suddenly gave way early this morning while most of the campers were sleeping. The police said heavy rain had apparently eroded the wall's foundations.

title: From Chairman Newt
description: A reputation can be perversely boosted in the capital through the fierce antipathy of a politician's rivals. By this standard, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia may be enjoying one of the most forceful of compliments from Democratic critics in the form of ''A Newt Gingrich Chrestomathy.''

title: U.S. Airlines Concern Caledonian Chairman
description: Sir Adam Thompson, chairman of the Caledonian Aviation Group P.L.C., one of Europe's few commercial airlines wit no government ownership, views the shakeout among American airlines with some sense of alarm.

title: Sailing Swords
description: Swordplay at sea may suggest swashbucklers swinging from yardarms, but they don't go in for yardarms much anymore. So when Carl Borack got the idea of staging the world's first free-floating fencing tournament, he settled for the Queen Elizabeth 2.

title: HYPONEX'S NATIONWIDE PUSH
description: The Hyponex Corporation touts its brand of organic lawn and garden products as ''the one to grow with.'' But for scores of local and regional competitors trying to sell organic soil-enrichers this summer, Hyponex's growth as a national distributor may prove decidedly unhealthy.

title: A NEW LEGAL TEST OF THE RIGHT TO DIE
description: It started as a splitting headache more than two years ago.

title: Gaullist Grandeur
description: To the Editor:

title: SETTLEMENT FOR CROWN, GOLDSMITH
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and Sir James Goldsmith, apparently coming to peace terms after a five-month battle for control of the forest products concern, said yesterday that they would cooperate in restructuring the company.

title: Amid the Rubble, A Search for Gargoyles
description: From the ruins on West 44th Street - that tableau of demolition between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas - several things are missing, things that tell little stories.

title: SQUEEZING PROFITS FROM FLOAT
description: It was a dull Memorial Day three years ago for the skeletal staff on duty at the Chemical Bank until the arrival, by courier from overseas, of $100 million in checks drawn on a small bank in Illinois.

title: POPE URGES CARDINALS TO INSURE UNITY
description: Pope John Paul II said mass today with the 28 new cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church and told them to ''insure'' and ''manifest'' unity in the church.

title: TRANSPARENT INTENTIONS
description: IT has been three weeks since Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, declared that all employees of the major leagues must subject themselves to random drug testing. Details of implementation were supposed to be available by the end of May, which is now.

title: HIGH POLICY CROSSROADS
description: President Reagan has some critical decisions to make this week, to report to Congress. On the surface, they seem technical - what to do about extending current strategic arms treaties with the Soviet Union and assuring American compliance. According to press reports, the options presented by advisers would undermine the existing arms control regimes and could lead to failure of the Soviet-U.S. Geneva talks before there is even a start on serious negotiations.

title: 2,000 Arrested in Peru After Policeman Is Slain
description: At least 2,000 people were arrested today after gunmen believed to be Maoist guerrillas killed a policeman and wounded another in the Lima district of Puente Piedra, the police said.

title: A CBS DOCUMENTARY ON CENSORSHIP
description: How does a producer create a study of censorship for a medium still subject to stringent censorship restrictions? This was the question that vexed the producer-director Andrew Solt in preparing an unusual hourlong documentary, ''America Censored,'' which will be shown on CBS tomorrow at 8 P.M. ''I was producing a show for a network that had a vested interest in the subject,'' Mr. Solt noted.

title: JAPAN'S CHIP POLICY IRKS U.S.
description: New trade frictions between the United States and Japan seem likely to break out over semiconductors as demand slows, world prices fall and the trade deficit with Japan widens.

title: Catching Up
description: Franco Harris, who was released last summer by the Pittsburgh Steelers and who then gained only 170 yards on 68 carries for the Seattle Seahawks before being dropped again, would like to play one more season. But the chances don't look very good.

title: GINGERLY, PARAGUAY DEBATES LIFE AFTER STROESSNER
description: There is no evidence that Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the 72-year-old President, is ill or is planning to step down, but what comes after his 31-year-old rule is suddenly the main topic of debate in Paraguay.

title: Rituals of Memory
description: Coming up to this Memorial Day, Americans have already done their share of remembering and misremembering, but the observances of victory in Europe and failure in Vietnam are not the end of it. Still ahead lie the 40th anniversaries of the atomic bombing and surrender of Japan, and the 35th anniversary of the start of the Korean War. The memories of war are relentless, and for good reason: America has waged war in 42 of its 209 years, not counting endless battles against Indians and interventions in the Caribbean.

title: LAKERS HEALTHY, HUNGRY, BETTER THAN EVER
description: THERE was no welcome-home sign in the locker room of the Los Angeles Lakers when Byron Scott reported for his first practice nearly two years ago. No cake. Not one thing to make the rookie, who grew up just 14 blocks from the Forum, feel at home.

title: Officer Slain in Basque Area
description: Gunmen believed to be Basque terrorists killed a national policeman today in the town of Guecho, near this Basque city, the police said. Witnesses told the police that two men had approached the officer, Moises Cosme Herrero, fired two shots at his head and then escaped in their car.

title: CUOMO, AT COLGATE AND VASSAR, URGES COMPASSION FOR THE POOR
description: Governor Cuomo urged graduating students at Vassar College and Colgate University yesterday to be concerned with the poor in American society.

title: LEAR FAN JET PROJECT COLLAPSES
description: Government officials Saturday night announced the collapse of Lear Fan Ltd., a British-American venture that received $72 million in grants and loans from the British Government to build a fuel-efficient executive jet and create 2,800 jobs in Northern Ireland.

title: The Candidate on the Rock Video Charts
description: To the Editor:

title: Required Reading;   Time to Remember
description: Representative Stan Parris, Republican of Virginia, in an address to the House on May 22:

title: BLUE JAYS CAPTURE 7TH STRAIGHT, 6-5
description: Jesse Barfield hit a home run with two out in the ninth inning today as the Toronto Blue Jays matched a team record with their seventh straight victory, a 6-5 decision over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Calvin Klein's President to Resign
description: Robert J. Suslow, who resigned the chairmanship of the retail division of B.A.T Industries P.L.C. in January 1984 to join Calvin Klein Industries, has sold his 10 percent interest in the prominent fashion designer business and will resign the company's presidency in the fall.

title: Norway Said to Cut Oil Price by Up to $1
description: Norway, reacting to a weak world oil market, has cut the price of its North Sea crude by up to $1 a barrel, oil industry sources said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MAY 27, 1985

title: SHIFTING ISLANDS OFTEN HIT BY CYCLONES
description: High waves like those that raked the Bangladesh coastline and the spray of islands in the Ganges River delta this weekend strike the country annually, often destroying the homes and crops of hundreds of thousands of people and, occasionally, taking as many lives.

title: CRIME OF THE CENTURY
description: On the weekend that Pope John Paul II elevated 28 men to cardinal - including the Archbishops of New York and Boston - prosecutor Ilario Martella brought to trial the second of the men who appear to have conspired to kill the Pope on orders of the K.G.B.

title: Wolfgang Reitherman Dead; An Oscar-Winning Animator
description: Wolfgang (Woolie) Reitherman, an animator whose work on Walt Disney's feature-length cartoons earned him an Academy Award, died Wednesday after his automobile crashed into a tree within blocks of his home in Burbank, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: YANKEES CRUSH A'S, 13-1
description: The figures are almost numbing, but they serve to illustrate a point: Ron Guidry seems to enjoy incredible success when he pitches for Billy Martin.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, MAY 27, 1985

title: TALES OF 1944 TROUBLES OVERCOME
description: To the SS official who branded his left arm a few inches above the wrist at Auschwitz, he was No. 174517. Forty-one years afterward, he folds back his cuff and stares at his wristwatch to see what time it is. Above, the numbers on his hand never change. The time always reads: Auschwitz 1944.

title: To Keep Faith With the Landmark Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We need people who understand how all the parts relate, who know that unless we infuse all our strivings and compassion with intelligent concern for the common good, then we will be just another of the rich and affluent societies that struts and frets its hour on the world stage.'' - Governor Cuomo. [23:3.]

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Travel Related Services Co., a subsidiary of the American Express Co., said it had named Thomas A. Cash senior vice president, financial service institution marketing and sales.

title: THE SERENDIPITY OF AN ISLAND TRIP
description: ON our first day on this tiny coastal resort island, Joel Arrington and I searched the Cape Fear River estuary for spotted sea trout, found none, and tried to assuage our feeling of failure by photographing little green tree frogs that sang at night in the cabbage palmettos outside the Bald Head Inn.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock and commodity markets, banks and Government offices in the United States are closed today in observance of Memorial Day.

title: Homeless Man, Charged in Slaying
description: A 43-year-old homeless man from Maryland was arrested yesterday and charged with murdering a Vermont resident whose body was found in Central Park Saturday morning with a rope tied around his neck, the police said.

title: 11 Arrested as Trespassers In Pittsburgh Church Dispute
description: Backers of a group of activist clergy, who had been warned to stay away from Nativity Lutheran Church in this Pittsburgh suburb, were arrested there today. Eleven supporters of the Denominational Ministry Strategy were charged with defiant trespass.

title: SPORTS ALLIANCE PROMOTES INDOOR CENTER
description: New York City's plan to install four new running tracks this summer at parks in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens has inspired Tracy Sundlun to step up his efforts to get support for a public all-sports indoor facility in the city.

title: 10 DIE IN CRUSH AT MEXICAN GAME
description: Ten people were trampled to death and 30 were injured today when fans tried to force their way into a Mexican soccer championship match, a Red Cross spokesman said.

title: Vandalism at 30,000 Feet
description: For almost two years, the Air Line Pilots Association has been flogging Continental Airlines for what it says are safety violations that seriously endanger the public. Now look at who seems to be doing what in the pilots' strike against United Airlines.

title: U.C.L.A. Captures Softball Crown
description: Janet Pinneau drove in the winning run in the ninth inning as U.C.L.A. reclaimed the women's college softball title with a 2-1 victory over Nebraska today.

title: U.S. Triumphs In Cup Qualifier
description: John Keer's goal a minute before halftime gave the United States a 1-1 tie with Costa Rica today in a qualifying match in the 1986 World Cup soccer tournament.

title: BRANDT ARRIVES IN MOSCOW FOR TALKS WITH GORBACHEV
description: Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, arrived in Moscow today for talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, that are expected to focus on disarmament and other East-West issues.

title: PUBLISHERS DISPLAYING WARES IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: It is never more evident that hope springs eternal in the soul of book publishers than at the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association. Each year for decades the publishers have used the occasion to trot out their big-name authors, to display their wares for the fall and to convey the impression that things have never been better for book publishers or booksellers.

title: DANCE: 'MIRROR, MIRROR'
description: Since virtually every studio contains at least one mirror, dancers spend lots of time staring into mirrors. And visitors to studios often find themselves studying both the dancers and their reflections during a class or rehearsal.

title: TEAM TITLE TO U.S.
description: Ivan Lendl defeated John McEnroe, but Jimmy Connors fought back from an 0-4 deficit in the final set to win, and the American doubles team also prevailed as the United States scored a 2-1 victory over Czechoslovakia in the final of the $500,000 Ambre Solaire World Team Tennis Cup today.

title: TAX EXPERTS URGE CAUTION BY INVESTORS
description: Tax experts are cautioning individuals against rushing into investment deals after President Reagan unveils the Administration's tax revision plan on Tuesday.

title: Shaky Ground
description: The four-year-old dispute between Jim Walsh, the George Washington High School football coach, and the powers-that-be in the public school system continues to simmer. Walsh, who led his team off the field last September in protest of its continued placement in the Public Schools' Athletic League's A Division, last week received a rare 'unsatisfactory' rating from the Manhattan high schools superintendent, Robert Mastruzzi, for what Mastruzzi called ''pure and simple insubordination.''

title: Digital Officer to Fill Chief's Post at LISP
description: LISP Machines Inc., a manufacturer of computers used in artificial intelligence, said that Ward D. MacKenzie, a group vice president at the Digital Equipment Corporation, had been named chairman and chief executive.

title: JAZZ: ANITA O'DAY SINGS
description: Anita O'Day celebrated her 50th year as a professional singer at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening with a program that reviewed her big-band years with Gene Krupa and Stan Kenton and her work with small groups over the past 30 years.

title: Like Pavlov's Dogs
description: As a vice president of the Heritage Foundation, the conservative think tank that has been a stocking pond for the Reagan Administration, Burton Pines fervently insists that patronage alone will spare Mr. Reagan lame-duck ignominy, with the sweet smell of appointment ever beguiling this city's hungry hordes: ''He's not a lame duck. He's going to be giving away jobs and goodies for the next three years. This President has got a great candy store and fruit stand that will leave salivating Washingtonians with their noses pressed aginst his glass case.''

title: Medicare Patients Are Paying More to Get Less
description: To the Editor:

title: FERRY ON L.I. SOUND DRAWS THE WEEKEND ADVENTURERS
description: At 6:45 on a Saturday morning, 23 Cub Scouts, ages 8 to 10, from Pack 385, Centereach, L.I., marched onto the ferry bound for Connecticut and their annual summer outing. ''O.K.,'' said Romayne Dickinson, the Cub leader, ''everyone go sit down like a human being.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium. Still plagued by injuries, the Mets conclude a somewhat shaky homestand before heading to California for an eight-game swing. (Television - SportsChannel 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland. This is the end of a 10-game Western road trip for the Yanks. (Television -Channel 11, 9:15 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 9:15 P.M.) Basketball Celtics vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Boston, National Basketball Association championship series. The Celtics open defense of their title at home in this four-of-seven game championship series. They are trying to become the first team to repeat as champions since they did it in 1969. The Lakers have breezed through three playoff series with only two losses. (Television - Channel 2, 3 P.M.) Long Island Knights vs. Wildwood, N.J., Aces at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I., 7:30 P.M. Season and home opener for the local United States Basketball League team. The Knights' lineup features two players from this past season's St. John's team - Ron Stewart and Mike Moses. The Aces are led by Villanova's Gary McLain. (Radio - WGBB 1240, 7:30 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. Independiente of Argentina, at Giants Stadium, 3 P.M. After dropping out of the N.A.S.L. outdoor and the M.I.S.L. indoor leagues, the Cosmos begin what they hope will be a lucrative series of international games. Tennis French Open, at Paris. Opening day. Ivan Lendl and Martina Navratilova are the defending champions in the first Grand Slam event of the year.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY STILL FIGHTS PROBLEMS CITED IN 1981 STUDY
description: Four years have passed since a team of business executives went into New York City's bus and subway systems to conduct the most comprehensive study to date of how the Transit Authority functioned and how it could be improved.

title: Reducing the Risks
description: Calmly and orderly, with not a hint of panic, hundreds of professionals left the capital last weekend after dwelling for days on calamity in what they said was a highly successful conference titled ''Emergency '85.'' ''They talked nuclear some,'' said Roger Stillwell, a conference participant.

title: STUDENT CLUBS ARE MANAGING OWN INVESTMENT PORTFOLIOS
description: When Robert Ciatto Jr. was 17 years old, he took $1,100 he had saved from a part-time dishwashing job and played the stock market for the first time. Mr. Ciatto invested in 12 shares of oil stocks that climbed three points, split, then plunged 34 points in one month. So he sold his shares and took the loss.

title: SOVIET DESERTER DISCOVERED AFTER 41 YEARS IN PIGSTY
description: Two weeks after a triumphant celebration of the Soviet victory in World War II, a newspaper here has published an account of a Red Army deserter who was discovered recently after spending 41 years hiding in a pigsty.

title: VON BULOW PROSECUTION MEETS SNAGS IN 2D TRIAL
description: When Claus von Bulow went on trial here six weeks ago, the prosecutors predicted that their presentation would be a reprise of the state's case at his 1982 trial in Newport.

title: Man Sitting in Car Shot in Chinatown
description: A young man was shot and seriously wounded in Chinatown yesterday when three men approached the car in which he was sitting and one opened fire with a handgun, the police said.

title: DEL TUFO CRITICIZES KEAN IN JERSEY PRIMARY RACE
description: Of the five candidates seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, Robert J. Del Tufo has the fewest qualms about savaging the Kean administration.

title: 2 FRENCHMEN SEIZED IN BEIRUT
description: The Lebanese police said today that two Frenchmen were kidnapped by unidentified gunmen in the Shiite Moslem suburbs south of Beirut on Wednesday.

title: Stop the Demolition In the East 70's
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVES CHANGED BY SPEND A BUCK
description: MOST of the big shore places were just opening up for the season, and Dennis Diaz was staring at the lights across the Manasquam River, looking past the veranda, the lawn, the putting green and the dock. It was last Friday night, the official beginning of the Memorial Day weekend and the unofficial beginning of summer, and the occasion was a dinner at Robert Brennan's palatial New Jersey home to honor Diaz.

title: TRIUMPH IN 3,000 SURPRISING TO SMITH
description: For half of her 32 years, Francie Larrieu Smith has been running and winning races from 800 meters to 10 kilometers. She has captured nine national and three collegiate titles outdoors. She ran in the 1972 and 1976 Olympics. Her latest victory surprised even her, and afterward she wondered if it might have been self-defeating. On Saturday, in the Bruce Jenner's Bud Light Classic here, the local schoolgirl star of the 1960's won the women's 3,000 meters. With a vintage kick over the last 200 meters, she beat Grete Waitz of Norway by 4 meters in 8 minutes 50.54 seconds, her fastest ever.

title: SONG: DESSOFF CHOIRS HEARD
description: A Thursday evening concert at Town Hall featuring the Dessoff Choirs called the old fairy tale about stone soup to mind. The main ingredient - a decent, enthusiastic amateur choir - was nothing particularly special, but the additional elements - an alert conductor, a splendidly matched team of soloists, a crack smaller orchestra and some glorious music - made for an engaging evening.

title: There Are No Thomas Jeffersons in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon R. Teschemacher Marries a Navy Doctor
description: Sharon Rita Teschemacher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Teschemacher Jr. of Chatham Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Lieut. John Joseph Knightly, U.S.N., a son of Eleanor Cantine Knightly, also of Chatham Township, and the late Dr. John J. Knightly.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Most fans know about Sandy Koufax's proficency as a pitcher, but what about Koufax the batter? Did he ever hit a home run in the majors?

title: STUDENTS IN SEOUL ARRESTED AFTER LEAVING U.S. OFFICE
description: South Korean student demonstrators were taken into police custody today after leaving the United States Government building they had occupied for four days.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SWEDISH MODERN Not everything from Sweden is in the shape of furniture or a movie by Ingmar Bergman. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8 o'clock, a smorgasbord of Swedish creativity in arts will be served up at the new Limbo Theater, 647 East Ninth Street, between Avenues B and C. From the Sublime to the Ridiculous,'' as it is called, consists of dance, music and six short films, all, in one way or another, made in Sweden and offered here by Limbo and by the Swedish Information Service. It is all part of a two-month celebration of Swedish culture in New York.

title: Reverberations in Boston
description: The fallout from Ohio and Maryland is being felt in Massachusetts.

title: Cuomo Approves Rise In Fees for Superfund
description: Governor Cuomo has signed legislation designed to raise $22 million more a year for New York State's Superfund for cleaning up abandoned hazardous-waste dumps.

title: Harriet Hentges Weds Wayne Koonce
description: Harriet Ann Hentges, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roman A. Hentges of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to Wayne Allan Koonce, the son of Mrs. Eldon Koonce of Kansas City, Mo., and the late Mr. Koonce. The Rev. James Connor performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: TUITION CREDIT SEEN IN REAGAN PLAN
description: President Reagan will include in the tax revision plan he sends Congress this week proposals for special tax breaks for the parents of private-school students and for businesses in designated poor neighborhoods, Senator Bob Packwood said today.

title: Machine Tool Orders Plunge
description: Orders for American-made machine tools plunged 34.3 percent in April from the month before and 27.5 percent from April 1984, the industry's trade association said in a report to be released today. Analysts blamed the dip on increased foreign competition and the strength of the dollar.

title: Navy Bars 5 Concerns
description: The Navy, responding to a Federal fraud investigation involving Avondale Shipyards, has suspended 11 people and five companies from conducting business with the Government.

title: Troops Patrol Karachi After Ethnic Violence
description: Troops patrolled Karachi today after a man was stabbed to death and 37 people were wounded in renewed ethnic unrest, witnesses and hospital sources said.

title: Joan Roemer Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Joan Margaret Roemer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Roemer of Pine Plains, N.Y., to Russell Jay Morrison took place yesterday at the Vista International Hotel in New York.

title: Gwendolyn E. Miller, Actress, W>eds Lawyer
description: Gwendolyn Esther Miller, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel N. Miller of Boise, Idaho, was married yesterday to Stuart Michael Sarnoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Sarnoff of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Amagansett, L.I. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel performed the ceremony at Douglas Watts, a caterer at 236 West 26th Street.

title: LEBANESE TRUCE IS SOUGHT IN 8TH DAY OF FIGHTING
description: Palestinians and Shiite Moslems battled here for an eighth day today, and an attempt by the Red Cross to evacuate wounded Palestinians from three refugee settlements failed.

title: DONOGHUE TAKES 1,500
description: Ross Donoghue, a former all American at Villanova, outsprinted the field in the final 300 meters to capture the 1,500-meter run in the Metropolitan Athletic Congress Senior Track and Field championships yesterday afternoon at St. Johns University.

title: SULLIVAN TAKES PROBLEM-PLAGUED INDIANAPOLIS 500
description: Danny Sullivan, who once spun out a cab in Central Park, survived a spin at 200 miles an hour today, turned his Cosworth-powered March in the right direction and went on to win the Indianapolis 500 by a little more than two seconds over Mario Andretti.

title: CELTICS TRY FOR RARITY
description: The year was 1969. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was a senior at U.C.L.A. Bill Russell was in his final year of playing and coaching the Boston Celtics, and Jerry West was playing for the Los Angeles Lakers, losers to the Celtics in the National Basketball Association championship series for the second straight year.

title: DIRECTOR IN JAPAN VIEWS THE VIOLENCE OF PEACE
description: He had learned in school that when Japan was attacked in the 13th century, a kamikaze wind destroyed the enemy fleet. And so, when World War II began to turn against the Japanese, Masahiro Shinoda said: ''I really believed the kamikaze wind could save Japan and destroy all the American fleet, the airplanes and everything. But when we lost the war, there was no wind at all.''

title: A Storybook Wedding
description: Saturday's surprise for the residents of East 57th Street: about 50 people throwing rice at a ruby-red carriage drawn by a fine, dark horse. The top-hatted driver took off with a pair of newlyweds aboard.

title: Books: Computer Menu
description: DIGITAL DELI By The Lunch Group and Guests. Edited by Steve Ditlea. 382 pages. Workman Publishing, New York. $12.95. The subtitle of ''Digital Deli'' sums up its contents rather neatly: ''The comprehensive user-lovable menu of computer lore, culture, lifestyles and fancy.'' That is to say, it has something for everybody who wants to browse through the bewildering world of computers. It is also to say that it does not have everything for those interested in one or two narrower aspects of the art/science that seem to have overwhelmed those parts of the world where electricity and things to say are easily come by.

title: Some Barriers In China Trade
description: CHINA is a potentially huge trade market for the United States. According to a new Congressional study, however, long-term prospects are threatened by Reagan Administration policies that hinder the transfer of American technology to China to develop its energy industry.

title: AIDE RECALLS ADVICE TO POLICE BEFORE 1979 ANTI-KLAN RALLY
description: The Greensboro Police Department's legal adviser says he dealt adequately with police animosity toward militant black and Communist activists before a 1979 rally and march against the Ku Klux Klan in which five people were shot dead.

title: CORNING TO RIZZO BY SHOT
description: Patti Rizzo bogeyed the last hole and fell a stroke short of tying a tour scoring record, but her total of 16-under-par 272 was enough to defeat Jane Crafter by a stroke today in the $250,000 Corning Classic golf tournament.

title: HISTORY UNITES OLD AND YOUNG
description: DIAMOND JIM BRADY'S dishes.

title: U.S. SAYS IT IS TOO EASY TO GET A SUBMACHINE GUN
description: By almost any standard, the .45-caliber Ingram MAC-10, easily carried in a briefcase or hidden under a coat, is the very essence of a deadly weapon.

title: Chicken a la Kindergarten
description: The children in kindergarten at Public School 33 in the Bronx are busily writing a cookbook, which includes some predictably unorthodox dishes.

title: Books of The Times;   Key for Escaping Spirit
description: LOVE ALWAYS. By Ann Beattie. 247 pages. Random House. $16.95. It is easy enough for a reader to keep his distance from the story and the people of Ann Beattie's ''Love Always,'' the third novel and sixth work of fiction (the others having been story collections) by the prodigiously talented young writer who has come to be regarded as the essential literary voice of the generation that came of age in the 1960's.

title: METS WIN AS MCDOWELL ENDS DODGERS' THREAT
description: They are still waiting for the hitters of great repute and several of unknown quality to get going. But for an afternoon, the small things saved the day for the Mets.

title: WOMEN'S CAUCUS: EIGHT YEARS OF PROGRESS
description: The Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues, eight years old this month, is preparing for a new battle - a fight to win legislative approval of the Economic Equity Act of 1985.

title: POLITICS OF TAXATION
description: The debate over income tax revision may help both the Republicans and the Democrats further define themselves politically, but analysts in both parties say they doubt President Reagan will be able to use this issue to cause a lasting political realignment. For one thing, Mr. Reagan is to make his proposal to overhaul the tax system on Tuesday after a series of political and legislative setbacks. Some political analysts also say the White House may have made a strategic blunder by disclosing the outlines of the tax plan in December and then waiting six months to produce a bill. The delay, they said, gave Democrats and lobbyists time to fashion opposition strategies.

title: IRWIN TRIUMPHS BY 1 AT MEMORIAL
description: Hale Irwin scored his first victory in 16 months today as he struggled but held on to beat Lanny Wadkins by one shot in the 10th annual Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: DRUG-CAUSED MULTIPLE BIRTHS DECLINE
description: The science-fiction notion of fertility drugs sprang into public consciousness two decades ago when the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center disclosed that Rhoda Brecker of Rego Park, Queens, had given birth to quadruplets after taking Pergonal.

title: MARKETS FORGE FOREIGN LINKS
description: THE universe of financial options and futures trading expanded further last week, as the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange moved to establish ties with markets in London and Tokyo, respectively.

title: DANCE: 'CORTEGE' BY CITY
description: It would be absurd to talk of a star being born when that ''star'' has been a leading dancer with the New York City Ballet for five years. But on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, Ib Andersen danced with such verve and ebullience that one wondered why this usually restrained dancer had been keeping it under wraps.

title: SERGEANT'S PROPENSITY FOR HOOKY
description: On a recent cruise on the Cuyahoga River to examine Cleveland's deteriorating waterfront, a boatload of executives noticed a uniformed police sergeant standing on the shore, fishing rod in hand, line in the water.

title: TEXAS STORES OPEN DESPITE BLUE LAW
description: Gov. Mark White has not yet signed the bill repealing Texas' blue law, but promptly at noon today the doors opened for business at the Foley's department store at Sharpstown Mall here.

title: 40th Season Set for Caramoor Festival
description: The Caramoor Music Festival's 40th season, which opens on June 29 in Katonah, N. Y., will offer 36 musical events through Aug. 25.

title: Abortion Mischief
description: Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah says he's found a way to strike a blow for efficiency. To avoid the annual Congressional wrangle over abortion, he would ban Federal funding for abortions permanently. The unacceptable price of such efficiency, however, would be new legal confusion.

title: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. SABOTAGES TALKS
description: The Soviet Union accused the United States today of ''overt sabotage'' in the arms negotiations that are to resume this week in Geneva, and warned that no cuts in Soviet arms could be expected until Washington agrees to halt development of space weapons.

title: FACELESS GUARD AT UNKNOWNS' TOMB
description: When Sgt. Larry J. Redmon stands alone in the dark at the head of the tomb, silently posed on the hill above Washington and the thousands of other graves arrayed down the slope before him, he thinks only of his duty.

title: NO FEAR OF FRYING
description: My summers began unraveling after I learned that the sun tan was declasse.

title: U.S. HOPES AND GANDHI
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's enthusiastic overture to the Soviet Union last week has produced a shudder of disappointment among American diplomats here. These diplomats have been engaged in the most aggressive attempt in years to improve relations between the United States and India.

title: STRAWBERRY SUBSTITUTES
description: WHEN the Mets took the field at Shea Stadium yesterday, Darryl Strawberry remained in the dugout, as he has for the last two weeks and as he will for another four weeks following surgery for torn thumb ligaments.

title: Tia Tsavaris Is Wed
description: At St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday Tia Tsavaris, the daughter of Carol T. Savage of Harrington Park, N.J., and Dr. Louis J. Tsavaris of Sarasota, Fla., was married to Charles F. Green, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Green of Ardsley, N.Y. The Rev. Emmanuel Pratsinakis performed the ceremony. The bride's mother is a principal in Peter Scannell Inc., an advertising and design company in New York. Her father is a psychiatrist. Mr. Green's father is a vice president of the Marschalk Company, a New York advertising agency.

title: THE DANCE: MODERN PIONEERS
description: Several works by American modern-dance pioneers were brought together for an unusually interesting concert by Lori Belilove and Evelyn Shepard on Saturday afternoon at Riverside Church.

title: Behind the President's Lincoln Brigade Remark
description: To the Editor:

title: IRANIAN AND IRAQI JETS ATTACK EACH OTHER'S CITIES
description: Iraq and Iran attacked each other's cities by air today in a sudden increase in the 56-month-old fighting.

title: SWEET'N LOW BUFFETED BY RIVAL ASPARTAME
description: When World War II ended Benjamin Eisenstadt and his two sons started a packaging business, the Cumberland Packing Corporation, the first to market sugar in small paper envelopes for table-top use. But it was not until they started packaging a sugar substitute, saccharin, in envelopes that the company enjoyed real success.

title: Back on the Job
description: Capitol life is a tolerable muddle.

title: Fanfares and Pageantry For a 40th Birthday
description: Saturday's surprise for the residents of Perry Street: a 15-foot-long ''Happy Birthday'' banner held aloft by helium balloons and two high school trumpeters playing fanfares from ''Don Carlo'' and ''Otello'' on the steps of an old brownstone.

title: Gamblers' Kelly Injures His Knee
description: Jim Kelly of the Houston Gamblers threw three first-half touchdown passes before leaving the game with a knee injury.

title: Topics;   Dining Out, So to Speak Brown Bag Update
description: On a recent lunch-hour walk through a midtown New York plaza, a friend found herself checking out the brown bags. They were not the brown bags of her youth.

title: PRESIDENT TO OPEN PUSH FOR TAX PLAN IN TV TALK TONIGHT
description: President Reagan will begin one of the most ambitious campaigns of his Presidency on Tuesday, a drive for a new Federal income tax system that would affect the personal finances of nearly every American family and the operations of almost every business.

title: Apple to Curtail Direct Sales to Corporations
description: Apple Computer Inc. plans to abandon most of its efforts to sell computers directly to large corporations, officials said this weekend.

title: STAGE: FOLGER'S 'DREAM'
description: The wonder of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' is its adaptability. It can contain so many alternative interpretations, from the feathery, fairy-dust traditional approach to Peter Brook's radical version to the moonstruck world envisioned several years ago at the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: Schmidt Going to First
description: Mike Schmidt, the Philadelphia third baseman who has won nine straight gold gloves and appeared in nine consecutive All-Star Games, will be moving across the diamond to play first base, the Phillies said yesterday. The Phillies have recalled Rick Schu, a promising 23-year-old third baseman, from their Class AAA team in Portland, Ore., of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Sullivan, Higdon & Sink Gets Coleman, for Now
description: The Coleman Company's Group One division, which is the part of the company that markets its large line of outdoor and camping equipment -from thermal gear and lanterns to tents and canoes - has asked Sullivan, Higdon & Sink in its hometown of Wichita, Kan., to serve as interim agency, temporarily replacing D'Arcy MacManus Masius, St. Louis, which served the company for 18 years, while it looks for a long-term relationship.

title: GORBACHEV CALLS GENEVA ARMS TALKS FRUITLESS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, gave a warm welcome today to Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, and told him the Geneva arms talks had so far proved ''completely fruitless.''

title: ABC CAPTURES IMMEDIACY OF INDY 500
description: Even on Horatio Street in Greenwich Village, a place not known as a bastion of auto racing, there is an Indianapolis 500 television party and anyone who squeals out the results before the taped delay broadcast is threatened with a lifetime ban while immediately being penalized two slices of quiche.

title: Traveling Light
description: The 14 men and 9 women of the Suzuki dance company arrived in the capital recently from their hometown of Toga, Japan, carrying all their props through customs in their hand luggage. The props are a kind of mosquito netting that the actors swirl around themselves and the stage to create moods and impressions. They are used in ''The Trojan Women,'' a piece the company is peforming, in Japanese, in a two-week stay at the Kennedy Center that began last Tuesday.

title: RACQUETBALL KEEPS LURING THE YOUNG AND OLD
description: If Eleanor Quackenbush can play racquetball, anybody can.

title: Stolen Line
description: Johnny Most, whose gravelly tones have described the Boston Celtics on radio around New England since 1952, had a relaxed, fun-filled afternoon yesterday, because the Celtics romped over the Los Angeles Lakers at the Boston Garden. There was no tension-filled, last-minute situation this time.

title: Ames Stores' Head Resigns
description: Gerald L. Kanter, the 50-year-old president and chief operating officer of Ames Department Stores Inc., has resigned from the rapidly expanding discount-store chain, the company said Friday.

title: YANKS LOSE IN 10TH ON MURPHY HOMER
description: The Yankees were missing two of their best offensive players tonight, but they still had Dave Righetti on the mound in a tie game. Ordinarily, that should be enough.

title: Dogs and Communism
description: There may be no quick, safe way to liquidate the Evil Empire, but President Reagan keeps hacking away at it, most recently with two subversive jokes.

title: The Heartbreak Called Lebanon
description: Lebanon is less a country than a heartbreak. Its conflicts seem not only beyond cure but even beyond understanding.

title: Concerto for Cavities
description: Almost any sound would be preferable to that of a dentist's drill. But Dr. Mark D. Horowitz and Dr. Kenneth Berger are among those dentists who get rave reviews for offering earphones and stereo tape cassettes to their patients.

title: Man Arrested After Scaling Prince Charles's Palace Wall
description: A man fleeing the police was arrested Sunday evening in the garden of Kensington Palace, the London residence of the Prince and Princess of Wales, Scotland Yard said early today.

title: Account
description: American Greetings Corporation to Young & Rubicam for an advertising project.

title: Memorial for Blacks Is Sought for Capital
description: The head of the Washington City Council today opened a campaign to build a memorial to black men and women for their role in the American Revolution.

title: MORE CITIES PAYING INDUSTRY TO PROVIDE PUBLIC SERVICES
description: Prodded by the Reagan Administration, mayors and county officials are increasingly paying private industry to provide a wide range of public services in a move that has redefined the role of local government.

title: A Congressional Ring
description: If Representative Mario Biaggi has his way, the atmosphere of strident partisanship currently enveloping the House will give way to the old collegiality. It will, that is, if members of the 99th Congress follow his lead and acquire an item that the Bronx Democrat has designed: a sort of gold class ring.

title: Frozen History
description: The world's largest shelf of continental ice, roughly equal in area to France, is an apron more than 1,300 feet thick that pushes out from Antarctica over the southern end of the Ross Sea. It is suspected that it sometimes disintegrates, unplugging the flow of ice from West Antarctica and causing worldwide sea levels to rise some 30 feet.

title: LIFE'S SWEET CACOPHONY, THE MUSIC OF INDUSTRY
description: A cement mixer rumbles, a metal grinder showers sparks, power tools purr and whine. Metal pots, pans and sheeting clang together, police sirens shriek. One man rhythmically shakes a bag full of broken glass while another operates a pneumatic drill. A crowd watches and listens intently. Has Con Edison acquired artistic pretensions? No, this is a rock concert.

title: Earthquakes Measured Inside Mount St. Helens
description: Earthquakes continued rumbling within Mount St. Helens today as scientists ventured into the steaming crater to gauge the chances of an explosive eruption.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 28, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WINDING ROUTE TO SUCCESS
description: The flickering on his digital watch showed 8 A.M. this morning and a United States Auto Club official, following tradition, posted the official final standing of Sunday's Indianapolis 500.

title: Delay at Ethiopian Ports
description: A senior Ethiopian official acknowledged today that congestion at the country's ports was hampering the distribution of food and leading to spoilage. But he said that slowing down aid shipments was not the answer. The official, Berhane Deressa, deputy commissioner of the Government's Relief and Rehabiliation Commission, added that slowing down shipments would only worsen the country's plight and cost more lives because of famine.

title: 2 Measures Not in Package
description: An assistant to Senator Bob Packwood said today that the Senator did not mean to imply in a Sunday television interview that President Reagan's tax plan would include proposals for tuition tax credits for the parents of private school students or special tax breaks for businesses in designated poor neighborhoods.

title: Cunningham Said to Quit
description: Billy Cunningham, who has coached the Philadelphia 76ers for eight seasons, has resigned, a source close to Cunningham said tonight. The source said the resignation would be announced by the team Tuesday.

title: CITY BALLET: 'FIREBIRD'
description: LOURDES LOPEZ made her debut in the title role of the New York City Ballet's ''Firebird'' Saturday night at New York State Theater, helping the entire revival come to life as it had not three weeks ago.

title: UNIONS THREATEN HOTEL STRIKE IF NO PACT BY FRIDAY
description: The group representing nonsupervisory workers at New York City's hotels said yesterday that it would strike 45 of the largest hotels at midnight Friday if agreement was not reached by then on a new contract.

title: Man Slain and 3 Hurt In a Boardwalk Melee
description: One man was shot to death and three others were wounded yesterday afternoon in a fight on the crowded beach boardwalk in Rockaway, Queens, the police said.

title: MORE SURPLUSES AND LOWER PRICES FACE FARMERS, U.S. SAYS
description: As the spring planting season reached its peak in the Middle West this month, American farmers once more faced price-depressing surpluses and another year of meager profits while consumers could look forward to several more months of lower meat prices.

title: SOME BOOK PUBLISHERS THRIVE OUT OF NEW YORK
description: Every available space in the Moscone Center here is filled with the books of almost 800 publishers, whose displays stretch along both sides of 37 aisles. ''It's mind-boggling, isn't it?'' said George L. Parker, surveying the displays and huge crowds from atop his company's raised exhibit.

title: THE PHILADELPHIA SIEGE: WAYS OF LIFE IN CONFLICT
description: For months, Louise James tried unsuccessfully to poke holes in her brother's philosophy.

title: Obtaining Balance at Moscow Book Show
description: To the Editor:

title: If We Are to Redesign Tax System to Be Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: IN ARGENTINE COURT, TALES OF HORROR AND HEROISM
description: Every day in a small courtroom here witnesses describe the horror of living in a country where the Government, according to a presidential commission, carried out a systematic campaign of murder in which more than 9,000 people disappeared in the late 1970's.

title: NEXT BEST THING TO A PTEROSAUR NEARS FIRST ATTEMPT AT FLIGHT
description: THERE was a time long ago when real dragons soared over Texas, their leathery wings casting monster shadows over the drab Cretaceous landscape far below them. Those huge flying reptiles, the pterosaurs, died out with the dinosaurs some 64 million years ago, but thanks to space-age advances in aerodynamics, robotics and structural materials, a startlingly lifelike replica of one of the largest of them will take to the sky later this year.

title: HAROLD HECHT, FILM PRODUCER AND A BURT LANCASTER PARTNER
description: Harold Hecht, the film producer who joined with Burt Lancaster to form one of the first independent film producing companies in Hollywood, died of complications from cancer Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 77 years old.

title: JUDD HIRSCH AS TWINS IN 'BROTHERLY LOVE'
description: TELEVISION seems to be on one of its periodic sprees featuring plots about twins.

title: U.S. MARSHALS JOIN THE HUNT
description: In addition to such other more mundane tasks as transporting prisoners and providing security in Federal courtrooms, United States marshals routinely track fugitives wanted by the Justice Department.

title: NORTH KOREANS BEGIN MEETINGS IN SEOUL
description: North and South Korea today began their first full-fledged talks in 12 years aimed at reuniting millions of families separated by the Korean War more than three decades ago.

title: OIL PRICE FALL SEEN PERSISTING
description: Industry reports that Norway is cutting oil prices mark a new downward trend that will persist for a few months at least, analysts said yesterday.

title: MOCK TALKS, REAL LESSON
description: For two days last March, while American and Soviet negotiators conducted arms control talks in Geneva, a group of graduate students at Columbia University held their own mock negotiations in New York. The results were not wildly encouraging - the talks ended in stalemate - but the exercise seemed to reveal a good deal about the obstacles to curbing the arms race.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1985

title: HAIR GROWTH DRUG SEEN AS A WONDER FOR UPJOHN
description: The Upjohn Company may be several years away from receiving Government approval to sell what could be a revolutionary hair-growth ointment, but thousands of balding men are said to be using a homemade version of the product.

title: Dollar Higher In Italy, Japan
description: The United States dollar rose in Italy and Japan today, but most other world currency markets were closed for various banking holidays.

title: FLYERS MAP STRATEGY CHANGE
description: Rhetorically, and with a little envy, Mike Keenan asked his question. ''If you had four or five of the best hockey players in the world, wouldn't you prefer to skate four-on-four,'' said the Philadelphia Flyer coach in the basement of Northlands Coliseum after practice today.

title: STRIKE HELD ENDURABLE FOR UNITED
description: Talks between United Airlines and its striking pilots union broke off over the weekend, but industry analysts said that, if necessary, the giant carrier could endure a prolonged strike without serious harm.

title: Kollek to Get Award
description: Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem will receive the 1985 peace prize at the Frankfurt international book fair in October. The West German booksellers association said Mr. Kollek had been ''a tireless proponent'' of coexistence in Jerusalem between Israelis, Arabs, Moslems, Christians and Jews for the last 20 years. The prize honors literary, cultural and political achievements.

title: VERSATILE CATCHER WAITS FOR ANSWERS
description: When he was back at Rye (N.Y.) High School, B. J. Surhoff played a lot of shortstop. Some people did not think he looked like their idea of a shortstop. Surhoff was too big to be a shortstop. ''The scouts used to call my coach and ask if I could catch,'' the 6-foot-1-inch, 185-pounder said.

title: SPACING OF SIBLINGS STRONGLY LINKED TO SUCCESS IN LIFE
description: SCIENTIFIC interest in the effects of birth order on later development, an interest that has fallen in and out of vogue several times in the last few decades, seems to be coming back again with a rush.

title: Reagan Talk Tonight To Be Broadcast Live
description: President Reagan's address tonight on his tax revision plan will be broadcast live at 8 P.M., Eastern standard time, on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network. In addition, some local affiliates of PBS will carry the conference, either live or on tape. In the New York City area, for example, Channel 13 will broadcast the address at 11 P.M.

title: Visit to Five Babies Lifts Mother's Spirits
description: Patti Frustaci was ''much happier'' after she touched her five surviving septuplets for the first time this weekend, and hospital officials today canceled a news briefing because the infants were progressing.

title: SHOE INDUSTRY'S STRUGGLE
description: In the 1920's nearly 250 shoe factories dotted the landscape of Lynn, Mass., which called itself the ''shoe capital'' of the region just north of Boston. ''My dad used to tell me that at lunch time he'd go out into the central square and the people would come pouring out of the factories like ants,'' said Richard Rothbard, president of Barry Manufacturing Inc., Lynn's only surviving shoe factory.

title: 3 Children Die In Blaze on L.I.
description: A fire that apparently started in a faulty electrical cable killed three children early today, investigators said.

title: ONE MAN'S AFFECTION FOR TREES OF HIS YOUTH PRODUCES NEW ELMS
description: In 1972 George Ware grew curious about an unusual species of elm tree he found on the grounds of an arboretum here.

title: REAGAN SHARPLY ASSAILS COMMUNISM
description: President Reagan today assailed Communism in harsh language, saying the ''tide of history is moving away from Communism.''

title: Dernier Double Powers Cubs Over Reds
description: Bob Dernier doubled with the bases loaded for two runs and Keith Moreland broke out of a slump with three hits as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3, tonight.

title: Trade Policy, French-Style
description: France has a reputation - undeserved, it insists - as a wily player in international trade. For example, when a flood of goods from Japan alarmed French officials, they simply ordered that all imports of video recorders be inspected at Poitiers, a remote, understaffed customs office. The result was a bottleneck that slowed the imports.

title: REBELS TO VOTE IN NEW CALEDONIA
description: Kanak separatists in New Caledonia have chosen conciliation with France by deciding to take part in French-run elections in the territory and canceling a demonstration in Noumea, the capital.

title: Uganda Rebels Say Front Is Expanded
description: Uganda rebels fighting the Government of President Milton Obote said today that they had opened a front in western Uganda, the first expansion of their four-year campaign in the Luwero region north of Kampala.

title: Rolling Stone Goes Platinum
description: ROLLING STONE magazine will be increasing its circulation rate base to 1 million, from 875,000, with its Sept. 26 issue. And so, some 18 years after its beginnings, the magazine that has long been identified with the rock music scene has reached the magical plateau where a good many advertisers interested in mass audiences will begin to take it seriously.

title: PROSECUTOR ASKS BROADER INQUIRY IN TRIAL OF AGCA
description: The trial here of eight defendants accused of plotting to assassinate Pope John Paul II opened today with an appeal by a prosecutor that the state seek evidence from suspected Turkish drug traffickers and terrorists jailed in several European countries.

title: 74 Reported Drowned in India As Overloaded Boat Capsizes
description: An overloaded boat traveling down the Chambal River in central India capsized, drowning at least 74 passengers, the Press Trust of India reported today. Sixteen passengers were reported to have swum to safety.

title: IGUANODON FIND POINTS TO ORIGINS IN AMERICAS
description: SINCE the continents had not fully separated in the time of the dinosaurs, many species roamed all over the world then and their bones have been found on most continents. But not the iguanodons, it seemed, and this was one of the many dinosaurian puzzles to weigh on the minds of paleontogists.

title: FEW ISSUES SCHEDULED THIS WEEK
description: Treasury financings this week consist of today's sale of new bills due in three months and six months and an auction tomorrow of five-year notes.

title: Pilots Cite Pressure For United Settlement
description: Increasing public pressure could bring United Airlines and its striking pilots back to the bargaining table this week in an effort to end the 11-day-old walkout, a spokesman for the pilots said today.

title: Isaac Charchat, 81, President Of United Cargo Corporation
description: Isaac Charchat, president of the United Cargo Corporation, a Manhattan-based container shipping corporation, died of heart failure Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Stay of Execution Is Granted for Inmate
description: A 24-hour stay of execution was granted today for a convict who had been scheduled to die Tuesday for killing six robbery victims.

title: Welcome Mat
description: Visitors to our city cannot always depend on the kindness of strangers.

title: AIDS IMPACT WIDE IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Evidence is mounting in this city, with its large homosexual population, that the rise in cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, has had a heavy impact on all segments of society.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MAY 28, 1985

title: Chess: Delicacy in Defense Is Fine, Except Against Juggernaut
description: Some years ago, a grandmaster known for his delicate, incisive exploitation of his opponent's pawn weaknesses had a habit of chortling after the game, ''It is not so easy to mate me.''

title: Woman Accused of Coercing Stepson, 9, to Kill His Father
description: An 18-year-old woman has been charged with the murder of her husband after coercing her 9-year-old stepson to shoot his father as he slept so she could collect $70,000 in insurance benefits, the authorities said.

title: Stun Gun Is Used To Subdue Woman
description: The police used an electric stun gun early yesterday to subdue a woman who had waved a 14-inch knife and a table leg at officers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHORT TAKES It is a rare tribute to a film maker that would present, in one day, 14 of his films. In the case of Norman McLaren, the honor is not only well-deserved but it also takes only 77 minutes. As a matter of fact, it will be given twice, at 3 and at 6:30 P.M. today in the Museum of Modern Art's Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 2, 11 West 53d Street.

title: IF WE ARE TO REDESIGN TAX SYSTEM TO BE FAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG SHIFT IN GASOLINE RETAILING IS CHANGING BUYING PATTERNS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company's recent decision to dispose of 2,000 service stations is but one dramatic sign of the transformation under way in gasoline retailing, a trend that is changing the way most Americans buy their gasoline.

title: Boar's Head On Guard
description: According to the creative high command at Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin, its client of seven years, Boar's Head Provisions of Brooklyn, maker of premium-priced cold cuts, is troubled by a number of unscrupulous deli operators in New York.

title: Bridge: Second Married Team Wins Goldman Pairs Competition
description: For the second time in its 57-year history, the Goldman Pairs has been won by a married couple. In 1957 the world's oldest pairs title was captured by Tobias and Jan Stone. The winners of this year's tournament, sponsored by the Greater New York Bridge Association and held at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., were Bob and Jill Blanchard.

title: Three Investors Sue Two 'Pack' Producers
description: Three investors who put up more than 20 percent of the $1.35 million budget of ''Leader of the Pack,'' now playing at the Ambassador Theater, have filed suit against two of the producers, Elizabeth I. McCann and Nelle Nugent, and against McCann & Nugent Productions, for the return of their money.

title: Of Nuclear Terrorism
description: The calamity industry seems to be on the move. No sooner had a how-to-cope-with-disaster conference calling itself ''Emergency '85'' left town than the first alarms began to go off alerting Washington to the arrival of ''International Terrorism: The Nuclear Dimension.''

title: Traffic Advisories For Central Park
description: The Traffic Department announced the following advisories affecting motorists in Central Park this week:

title: LET THERE BE LIGHT, THE CUBS PLEAD
description: Half an hour before a Cubs game, the scene outside Wrigley Field is what it has been for decades on spring afternoons. Vendors were hawking Cubs caps, scalpers were shouting ''tickets here,'' fans were crowding the intersections, and cars were crawling along, bumper to bumper, the drivers looking for parking places on the side streets.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: EUROPEANS like New York in May. Designers, especially, find it relaxing between collections. Giorgio Armani slipped into town just to see some friends, but others combined a bit of work with pleasure. Gianfranco Ferre brought over his new evening and resort collections. Laura Biagiotti made a personal appearance at Martha at Trump Tower, photographed a new ad with Arthur Elgort and found an antique treasure, a porcelain hand, for $10 in a flea market on Columbus Avenue.

title: FURS FOR THE NEXT SEASON: QUITE SIMPLY LUXURIOUS
description: If you try on a fur coat in the next few months, chances are the label will carry a familiar name. With only a few exceptions, the dozens of fur showings that introduced fall collections in the past week focused on designers who presented ready-to-wear collections a few weeks earlier.

title: BANGLADESHIS SAY 10,000 MAY BE LOST IN CYCLONE'S WAKE
description: Government authorities, widening search and rescue efforts in the islands of southeastern Bangladesh, said tonight that as many as 10,000 people were now believed missing and feared dead after a cyclone devastated the area over the weekend.

title: New York City Landfill Is Not a Federal Transportation Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Junior Wins 800 At Eastern States
description: John Trautmann, a Monroe-Woodbury High School junior who has the fastest times in New York State this year for the 1,600- and 3,000-meter runs, registered the best time in the state for the 800-meter run yesterday.

title: Israeli Troops Kill 8 Arabs
description: At least eight Arabs were killed and one was wounded early this morning, apparently by Israeli tank fire north of the Litani River in an area already evacuated by the Israelis, officials of a United Nations peacekeeping force said today. The Israeli military command here said soldiers south of the river opened fire on an armed band trying to cross near the Akhiya Bridge.

title: Wabash Power Officer Deals With Bankruptcy
description: The investment forced his organization to file for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws, but Edward P. Martin, general manager of the Wabash Valley Power Association, said he has no regrets about the electric cooperative's involvement in the Marble Hill nuclear power plant.

title: GREEK LEADER SEES 'CALMER SEAS' IN TIES TO WEST
description: IOANNINA, Greece, May 27 -

title: LINGERING FEARS OF INFLATION
description: Inflation has been a dark cloud for the bond markets in the past 20 years, and it continues to linger as a distant threat in the minds of many economists and portfolio managers.

title: 'AMERICAN CENSORED,' ON CBS TONIGHT
description: ''AMERICA CENSORED'' means to be entertaining, and sometimes it is. What we once thought was risque, salacious or provocative now mostly seems funny. Emancipation has set in; our psyches are free. As John Denver says cheerfully, in movies, television and music ''virtually any subject is fair game as long as it's handled with taste and honesty.'' The CBS program will be seen on Channel 2 at 8:30 tonight.

title: No Plans for Hamilton
description: The National Hockey League will play into June as long as teams continue to profit from the long season, the league president, John Ziegler, said yesterday. But there will be no games in Hamilton, Ontario, for the immediate future.

title: All in the Family
description: Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court is to leave the bench briefly today to address the Court on a matter that is presumably close to his heart.

title: Topics;   Dining Out, So to Speak Guests of the State
description: In a New York criminal trial, jurors must be sequestered - locked up, fed and lodged overnight - from the time they receive the judge's instructions until they return a verdict. Sequestration is warranted to shield them from publicity in notorious cases, but the law prescribes it for every case, down to the lowliest misdemeanor.

title: Hitting Pitcher
description: Bob Gibson, the Hall of Fame pitcher, was talking about hitting, and with a passion.

title: GIBSON WAGING 2D BID FOR GOVERNOR
description: Kenneth A. Gibson, a white carnation decorating his dark suit, stood before 50 members of the West Ward Democratic Club here the other night, describing a new twist to the way he runs his election campaigns.

title: Westminster Bank Names Chairman
description: Friday evening, William T. Knowles had to cut short an interview. ''I'm sorry,'' he said, ''I have to run up and toast the Queen.''

title: Rescuers Find 20 Dead In Blast Near Gibraltar
description: Rescue workers have recovered 20 bodies and sighted two more inside the hulls of two oil tankers destroyed by an explosion Sunday, officials said today.

title: SECRETARY DOLE WAITS TO ASSESS ADEQUACY OF SAFETY-BELT LAWS
description: The Secretary of Transportation, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, has decided to hold off on ruling whether state seat-belt laws meet Federal standards, and some automobile safety groups fear that the decision could lead to a weakening of the tough standard adopted last year.

title: New Beacon
description: Though most New Yorkers never knew they had such a thing, a sculptural work by the man who created the Mount Rushmore National Memorial has been removed from its prominent place. And it will not return.

title: ON UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA: A PRESIDENT'S NEW OPTIMISM
description: WITH nine campuses, an annual budget approaching $1.6 billion, more than 144,000 students and 18 Nobel laureates, the University of California has often been called the nation's premier institution of public higher education. On the eve of his retirement in mid-1983, the president of the University, David S. Saxon, said in an interview that he feared that more than 15 years of tight budgets under Governors Ronald Reagan and Edmund G. Brown Jr. had begun to undermine the quality of the university and to jeopardize its reputation for excellence and academic leadership.

title: CELTICS TOP LAKERS AS RECORDS FALL
description: The Los Angeles Lakers' heralded running game stood still today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How old is the bow and arrow? Was it discovered independently by different people in widely separated parts of the world? A. As with the first use of fire and discovery of the wheel, origins of the bow and arrow are lost in the mists of prehistory. It was probably invented as far back as 30,000 years ago.

title: NEW PORTABLE PRINTERS
description: THE new laptop computers -those five-pound wonders that run on batteries and stash neatly in a briefcase - are really something to write home about. But how does one print a letter? The laptop computer may fit in a briefcase, but standard printers are the size and heft of a suitcase full of books, and it would take a monumentally sturdy lap to hold one.

title: SATISFACTION ON THE JOB: AUTONOMY RANKS FIRST
description: LOS ANGELES, May 27 -

title: Finding A Niche In Music
description: MUSIC students for years have trudged a tough road to find jobs in their field. One popular side street has been teaching in schools or universities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Acapulco Restaurants, Pasadena, Calif., said its president and chief executive officer, James C. Doherty, is leaving the company, effective Saturday.

title: TED TURNER AMID THE ARMOR
description: TED TURNER did indeed turn up for the Metropolitan Museum of Art's recent reception in honor of Armand Hammer. The big, bad broadcaster with the flamboyant reputation arrived quietly among the scores of big-name guests and took his stand near a mounted troop of menacing if empty armor suits. Nobody seemed to know who he was.

title: MICHAEL J. MURPHY
description: Michael J. Murphy, a former deputy state industrial commissioner, died Friday in Flushing Hospital in Queens. He was 92 years old and lived in Flushing.

title: CONFIDENCE AND A MAGIC EYE
description: When Scott Wedman was acquired by the Boston Celtics from the Cleveland Cavaliers two years ago for a little-known player named Darren Tillis, a future first-round draft choice and about $800,000, it looked as if Red Auerbach had again put one over on an unwitting victim. For Wedman was a pure-shooting swingman with unchallenged credentials, having averaged double figures in each of his eight seasons and having played on an all-star team.

title: Hustling New York
description: Bored with New York's orange auto license plates, the State Assembly has voted for new ones, decorated with the Statue of Liberty. If the Senate and Governor Cuomo were to go along, the Department of Motor Vehicles would have to choose among six slightly different versions. There is, however, a seventh option and we commend it to the Senate and the Governor: don't go along. Putting Miss Liberty on license plates wrongs her, wrongs the country and wrongs New York.

title: Official at Kleinwort To Join Barclays Unit
description: Martin W. Jacomb, one of the City of London's most prominent merchant bankers, has resigned as vice chairman of Kleinwort Benson Government Securities. He will become chairman of a new securities group formed by Barclays Merchant Bank's takeover of De Zoete & Bevan, one of the City's largest stock brokerage firms, and Wedd Durlacher Mordaunt & Company, a leading stock dealer.

title: Knights Win in Home Debut
description: Ron Stewart of St. John's University, who had been called the Redmen's most valuable reserve by Coach Lou Carnesecca, lived up to that role again tonight as the Long Island Knights made a successful debut in the fledgling United States Basketball League at Hofstra University's court.

title: A Docking Ferryboat Kills Girl, 3, at Fire I.
description: A 3-year-old girl was killed today when her head was caught between a ferryboat and one of the pilings lining the approach to a dock at Cherry Grove on Fire Island, the Suffolk County police said.

title: FRESH FISH SOLD OLD WAY AT FULTON MARKET
description: In rubber boots for the sloshy pavement and a yellow, knit cap for the chill, Martin (Buddy) Brady swung a hook into one of the huge, headless halibuts recumbent on a metal table at the Fulton Fish Market and lifted the carcass to a scale.

title: 2 MORE SEIZED IN CHINATOWN IN SHOOTING OF 7 IN GANG FIGHT
description: Two more suspects were arrested early yesterday in last week's shooting of seven people in Chinatown after a dispute between gang members.

title: Illegal Water Use Charged to Man
description: A man who watered his lawn in the afternoon must appear in the town court here to answer a charge of violating Westchester County's water restrictions, the police said today.

title: DOLLAR EXPECTED TO BE FAIRLY DOCILE
description: After half a year of roller-coaster activity, the dollar has calmed.

title: Scientists Stereotyped
description: Television's stereotype of the mad or eccentric scientist has made some viewers fearful of the future, researchers at the University of Pennsylvania said today.

title: KIT COMPUTER TURNS OUT TO BE A SANE IDEA
description: IF starting yet another personal computer company today must appear to be an act of madness, then launching a kit modeled after the I.B.M. PC and designed to be put together by the innocent buyer must surely seem to rank as certifiable lunacy.

title: Wilander Scores In French Open
description: Mats Wilander spoiled France's bid for three center-court triumphs today, and Martina Navratilova breezed through a 40-minute match at the start of the French Open tennis championships.

title: Jet's Landing Gear Fails
description: The nose gear of an American Airlines Boeing 727 jetliner collapsed after landing tonight at O'Hare International Airport, officials said. No injuries were reported to any of the 121 people on board who were evacuated on emergency chutes. An airport tower official said the plane was traveling about 30 miles an hour when the gear collapsed,

title: FOR FARMERS, IT'S AN UPHILL FIGHT TO SURVIVE
description: Much of Paul Westheimer's life is carrots, so it was with extreme interest that he watched the other day as two of his hired men drove tractors across a long, brown field and put in this year's carrot crop.

title: Arabic/English Guide Set for New York
description: A half-dozen people, most either from the Middle East or with strong ties there, are sponsoring a new publication here called Metroscope, The Monthly Guide With Savoir-Faire, that will be printed in English and Arabic.

title: Julian Olevsky Is Dead at 59; Was a Violinist and Teacher
description: Julian Olevsky, a violinist who began his professional career at age 10, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Amherst, Mass. He was 59 years old.

title: RESEARCHERS FIGHT THE CLOCK AS 'KILLER BEES' HEAD NORTH
description: As colonies of aggressive ''killer bees'' swarm closer each year to the United States, researchers are fighting the clock to find a way to blunt the invasion.

title: Hainan Island Oil Pact
description: China will sign an oil contract for foreigners to explore for oil on Hainan Island, the New China News Agency said. Until now, China has signed contracts with foreigners only for offshore development. The contract will be with an Australian consortium led by CSR Orient Oil PTE Ltd., the news agency said on Sunday.

title: DRAMA WARNS VIENNA ABOUT ANTI-SEMITISM
description: In a theater that was once remodeled to install a ''fuhrerloge'' in case Hitler should attend a play (he never did), Israeli and Austrian actors are performing an Israeli drama about the destruction of the Vilna ghetto.

title: Required Reading;   'I'm an Award Now'
description: Excerpts from a speech by Helen Hayes, a native Washingtonian, given on the stage at the National Theater May 13 as she presented the first annual Helen Hayes Awards for excellence in theater in the capital:

title: A TASTE OF LAZY SUMMERTIME FOR HOLIDAY CROWDS
description: All winter long, Bernard Mendez dreamed of a day like yesterday: a warm, sunny holiday he could while away at the beach with friends.

title: 'GREAT PERFORMERS' ADDS CONCERT-OPERA
description: The 1985-86 Great Performers series at Lincoln Center - meaning those events produced by the center itself, as distinguished from performances by Lincoln Center constituents or rental concerts - will for the first time include a concert-opera series. It will consist of two operas, both at Avery Fisher Hall: Verdi's ''Giovanna d'Arco'' on Oct. 27, with Margaret Price, Carlo Bergonzi, Sherrill Milnes and Richard Bradshaw conducting, and Donizetti's ''Anna Bolena'' on Nov. 25, with Joan Sutherland, Jerry Hadley, Judith Forst and Cynthia Clarey, conducted by Richard Bonynge.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Oilers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Edmonton. Game 4 of the Stanley Cup final. Edmonton leads the series, 2-1, after a 4-point performance (3 goals and an assist) by Wayne Gretzky gave the Oilers a victory in Game 3 last Saturday.

title: A Mission of Women
