description: For the first time, the Commerce Department says, the Government is sponsoring a foreign trade mission made up entirely of women. The group left Friday and is to visit London and Frankfurt in search of export business for their companies' services.

title: A TIDAL WAVE OF BAD FORTUNE
description: At no time do we in the developed, industrial world become more aware of the accidental good fortune we enjoy than when the habitual meanness of life in one of the globe's impoverished nations is made even meaner by a natural disaster.

title: BACK IN THE LEGISLATIVE STARTEGIST'S SADDLE AGAIN
description: In the days shortly before President Reagan's second inauguration, Max L. Friedersdorf began getting phone calls from the White House at his home in Greenwich, Conn. The callers - Donald T. Regan, the new White House chief of staff, and other officials - told him, essentially, ''Max, come back where you belong.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're in the business of winning races, and that's what this colt did today.

title: Gura, Cubs Near Deal
description: The veteran pitcher Larry Gura, who was placed on waivers May 18 by the Kansas City Royals, is reportedly close to signing with the Chicago Cubs. The Kansas City Times reported yesterday that Gura, a 37-year-old left-hander with a 126-94 career record, will sign with the Cubs today, after waivers on him expire.

title: THE 8 ACCUSED OF A PLOT AGAINST THE POPE
description: Mehmet Ali Agca The Turk who shot and seriously wounded the Pope on May 13, 1981 . . . Was captured in St. Peter's Square immediately after the shooting . . . Sentenced to life imprisonment by an Italian court in July 1981 . . . Case against the other defendants is based almost entirely on his testimony . . . Appearing at the trial mainly as a witness, but the indictment charges him with helping to smuggle into Italy the Browning pistol used to shoot the Pope . . . 27 years old.

title: Hockey Fighting Gets a Blessing
description: As a man of the cloth, the Rev. John F. Casey understands that some people might find a contradiction in his appreciation of a good fight. But, like many a hockey fan, he offers no excuses.

title: Sports of The Times;   'Don't Get in Front of Him'
description: Three hours later, Spend a Buck would win the Jersey Derby by a neck. But now, inside the red cement blocks of Barn 1 at Garden State Park, the Kentucky Derby winner leaned that same neck down near one of the two electric fans that were humming to keep him cool. As the breeze spun across his nose, Spend a Buck closed his eyes in contentment as two visitors wandered by.

title: KEY WITNESS BACK IN SOCIALITE TRIAL
description: Claus von Bulow's former mistress, Alexandra Isles, flew back from Europe today, one day ahead of a court-imposed deadline for the prosecution to put her on the witness stand at his retrial on charges of attempted murder.

title: All That Glitters
description: Bill Scherrer's 1984 World Series championship ring has little sparkle, and the Detroit Tigers' president, Jim Campbell, says the Tiger reliever should ask his teammates why. When Tiger players cast ballots last season to decide how to split postseason salary bonuses and divide three versions of the championship ring, they alloted Scherrer a one-third salary share and the least expensive of three rings.

title: 2 Held in Jersey On Drug Charges
description: Two Miami residents were held in $1 million bail each after the police found 26 pounds of cocaine in their car today, a trooper said.

title: Fungus as a Mimic
description: Many microorganisms, even those that cause runaway diseases in plants or animals, appear to depend on haphazard encounters with the right carriers and hosts for successful completion of their life cycles. For example, the fungus that causes mummy-berry disease, a common affliction of blueberries and huckleberries, cannot reproduce unless a pollinating insect happens to transfer it from the blighted leaves of infected plants to their flowers.

title: Gap Between Civilian And Military Widens
description: To the Editor:

title: Tell the Truth About Punishment
description: It is no surprise when a New York Times/ WCBS-TV poll says New Yorkers consider crime the city's most important problem. What is surprising is how little the state and city offer in the way of systematic responses. Governor Cuomo is finally pushing a big one - wholesale revision of the criminal sentencing process. It deserves support.

title: GOAL WITH :004 LEFT GIVES COSMOS TIE
description: The Cosmos have enjoyed success in international matches in the past, and despite an obvious lack of preparation, they continued that trend today.

title: Forzando II, $49.20, Takes Metropolitan
description: Forzando II, a 23-1 shot making only his second career start on dirt, scored a stunning upset yesterday with a 5 1/4-length victory in the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: HARD MILITARY CHOICES
description: Memorial Day, when we pay tribute to the Americans who died in the Civil War and on the battlefields of Cuba, the Philippines, Europe, Siberia, the Pacific, Korea, Vietnam, Lebanon and Grenada, is a good time to think about the vitally important debate on the 1986 military budget. The costly Reagan buildup will be slowed, but how and by how much?

title: Down but Not Out
description: The Houston Gamblers have suffered a big blow with the loss of their star quarterback, Jim Kelly, but Coach Jack Pardee thinks they still have an excellent chance of winning the United States Football League championship. The team said yesterday that Kelly, who leads the league in passing, would not undergo surgery but would be out from three to six weeks after suffering a torn ligament in his right knee during Sunday's 41-20 victory over Arizona. Kelly was the league's most valuable player last year, and this year had completed 347 of 549 attempts for 4,365 yards and 36 touchdowns.

title: RESCUERS SENT TO AID PALESTINIANS BEING HALTED BY FIGHTING IN BEIRUT
description: A Red Cross effort to evacuate wounded Palestinians today from a besieged refugee settlement here was only slightly successful.

title: SPEND A BUCK EARNS $2.6 MILLION
description: Spend a Buck won the Jersey Derby and a record $2.6 million today at Garden State Park with a performance that was at once stirring and disheartening. He came back from what looked like certain defeat at the top of the stretch to score courageously by a long neck over Creme Fraiche, but left the impression that he would have been beaten if his opposition had not been so weak.

title: LEUCADIA PLAN FOR INTERGROUP
description: THE Leucadia National Corporation's well-chronicled success in profiting from its pursuit of the Avco Corporation earlier this year brought the little-known investment company a fortune but too little fame, analysts believe, to make it an instant force in the high-pressure field of corporate takeovers.

title: NEARLY 3,000 CANOEISTS RACE DOWN SUSQUEHANNA
description: Nearly 3,000 canoeists paddled down the Susquehanna River into this village of 1,700 residents over the Memorial Day weekend in the 23d annual General Clinton Canoe Regatta.

title: THE CORPORATE VEIL
description: I had to read a lot of press reports before I came across the name of any person who played a part in General Electric's defrauding the Air Force of $800,000 by forging employees' time cards, in E. F. Hutton's billion-dollar check-kiting scheme and General Dynamics's cheating and ''illegal gratuities.'' It is as if all of this hanky-panky was committed by file cabinets.

title: U.S. AIDE TO MEET SUDAN'S NEW CHIEFS
description: The United States has sent a high-level official to the Sudan for the first time since a military coup there early last month, State Department officials said today.

title: WEALTH, POWER ARE DE RIGUEUR AT THIS MAGAZINE
description: PUBLICATIONS often take on the preoccupations of their publishers but Avenue - a lavish, controlled-circulation magazine aimed primarily at the affluent Upper East Side - really is Judith Price. ''It's my vision of the world,'' she said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AT MOTHER'S REQUEST. A True Story of Money, Murder and Betrayal. By Jonathan Coleman. 624 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $19.95. NUTCRACKER. Money, Madness, Murder: A Family Album. By Shana Alexander. 444 pages. Doubleday. $17.95. WHEN a mother is convicted of persuading her 17-year-old son to murder her father - the boy's grandfather - it's news. When her father is a self-made millionaire, one of the richest men in Utah, and her own social ambitions have won her a place on the board of the New York City Ballet, you've got a subject for a book. Or even two books. And when the authors of those two books have a falling-out, and the accusations and counter-accusations start flying, that's more news.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An entry last Sunday in the Comedians listing of The Guide, section 2A, gave an incorrect date for Robert Klein's appearance at Aice Tully Hall. The engagement is scheduled for Saturday, June 15.

title: THE NEMESIS OF TERRORISTS
description: Judge Severino Santiapichi began presiding today over a trial that he himself had done much to bring about.

title: TRANSIT SYSTEM FIGHTING FLAWS IN 5-YEAR PLAN
description: When a team of business executives started studying the Transit Authority in 1981, the agency had barely begun its $6.4 billion capital plan to restore the city's crumbling bus and subway system.

title: IRAN SAYS IT FIRED MISSILE AT BAGHDAD IN A REPRISAL
description: Iran fired a surface-to-surface missile at Baghdad today after Iraqi air strikes on Teheran, the official Iranian press agency reported.

title: AN ANT'S PERSPECTIVE: SOME LOST THEIR WAY
description: TESTS have shown that an ant with one eye covered cannot memorize a route in terms of landmarks seen through the other. And it cannot find its way when the covered eye is exposed and the other one covered.

title: ARE S.A.T.'S: TRUE, FALSE, NONE OF ABOVE?
description: MORE tests mean better schools, one group declares. More tests will ruin the schools, another argues.

title: TINY FUNGUS EMERGES AS BOTANICAL 'CORNERSTONE'
description: A LITTLE-KNOWN family of fungi that inhabits the roots of nearly all the world's plants is inspiring superlatives from an increasing number of scientific admirers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday yesterday about Patrick Ewing's graduation from Georgetown University incorrectly identified the degree received by the entertainer Pearl Bailey. It was a bachelor of arts degree with a major in theology.

title: CBS RETHINKS 'MORNING NEWS' SHOW...AGAIN
description: For years, there has seemed a strange contradiction to CBS's putting the company's perky open eye trademark on ''The CBS Morning News,'' a program that drifted through the ratings like a sunrise somnambulator. Over and over, the network declared it had found a new solution to repair it; week after week its Nielsen numbers napped on.

title: Pentagon Surplus Is Really an Inflation Cushion
description: To the Editor:

title: 'A Concert of Concern' Set for African Relief
description: ''A Concert of Concern,'' featuring Leontyne Price, Simon Estes, Wynton Marsalis, the pianists Richard Woitach and Mark Zeltser and the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra will be performed at 8 P.M. Friday at Carnegie Hall. The performance, sponsored by the American Red Cross, will raise funds for the organization's African relief program; proceeds will be used for food and medical supplies and for long-term food production projects.

title: Oklahoma State In World Series
description: A three-run homer by Bryan Kostishion, the designated hitter, broke a 2-2 tie in the fourth inning, and Oklahoma State went on to beat Wichita State, 10-6, for the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional championsip tonight.

title: ROBERT NATHAN, AUTHOR, 91, DIES
description: Robert Nathan, who wrote the 1940 novel ''Portrait of Jennie'' and more than 50 other books of poetry and prose, much of it fantasy, died of kidney failure Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 91 years old.

title: Pakistani Troops Fire On Crowd, Killing 2
description: Two men were killed today when soldiers fired on a crowd of about 5,000 Pashtoons attacking an army headquarters in western Karachi, witnesses said.

title: KNIGHT DRIVES IN 4 AS METS TOP DODGERS
description: These are the first-place Mets, who have been worrying about their hitting and starting pitching and injuries and other assorted slumps. But last night at Shea Stadium they burst out on every front in beating,the Dodgers, 8-1.

title: Western Sahara Rebels Said to Have Killed 56
description: Polisario guerrillas killed 56 Moroccan soldiers last Wednesday in fighting in Western Sahara, according to a communique published by the Algerian press agency today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: THE GROWTH PAINS OF A SOHO GALLERY
description: Two years ago, Bess Cutler decided to open an art gallery in the SoHo district of New York City. Today, the Bess Cutler Gallery, at 164 Mercer Street, is doing just fine - and its owner agreed to open her books in order to illustrate the strategies and financial aspects of running an art gallery in New York City.

title: ORGANIZED DAY CARE: ADVANTAGES CITED
description: In terms of social and educational skills, children given day care in their own homes or in another's home lag behind children going to organized day-care centers and nursery schools, a new study shows.

title: STAGE: 'MAN ENOUGH,' BROOKLYN TALE
description: ''MAN ENOUGH,'' Patty Gideon Sloan's new play at the Apple Corps Theater, draws its themes, as does so much contemporary drama, from the handicapped. Unlike many of the others, which are awash in easy sentiment and obvious melodrama, it is an honest drama that deals with believable people, and it does so in superior theatrical terms.

title: IMTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Includes income of $852,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Hutton Film Unit Inquiry
description: State securities officials in Pennsylvania and Massachusetts are conducting investigations into a limited partnership under which E.F. Hutton & Company financed movies made by Walt Disney Productions.

title: Frazar B. Wilde, 90, Ex-Chief Of Connecticut General Life
description: Frazar Bullard Wilde, a former president of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, died today at his home here. He was 90 years old.

title: Bolivian City Is Strikebound
description: A general strike paralyzed Cochabamba, Bolivia's third largest city, today and strikers threatened to cut electricity to mines Wednesday if their demands for Government funds were not met.

title: Public-TV Watchdogs Barking at Shadows
description: To the Editor:

title: NUMERAX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: In Brief: Reagan's Key Points
description: Tax Rates Individuals would be taxed at 15, 25 and 35 percent with the top rate falling on income taxable income above $70,000 on joint returns, and above $42,000 on single returns. The tax code now more than a dozen brackets ranging from 11 percent to 50 percent . Corporations, which now pay rates up to 46 percent, would pay graduated rates of 15, 18, 25 and 33 percent. Personal ExemptionTThe figure would rise to $2,000 from $1,040 for the taxpayer and each dependent. Standard deduction would rise to $3,000 for single filers, from $2,390. On joint returns it would increase to $4,000, from $3,540. Interest Expense Mortgage interest would remain deductible for principal residences. Deductions for other personal interest would be limited to $5,000 above investment income. Charitable Gifts Contributions would remain fully deductible only for taxpayers who itemize. State and Local Taxes The deduction for income taxes would be repealed. Property taxes, sales taxes and other levies would not be deductible unless incurred in income-producing activity. Fringes Company-paid health benefits would be taxed as income up to $10 a month for individuals and $25 for joint filers. Business Deductions for sports, theater, and similar entertainment would be disallowed. Deductions would be denied for 50 percent of costs of meals above a specific figure, and travel deductions restricted. Income Shifting Using trusts to shift taxable income to children, who fall into lower brackets, would be curtailed. Capital Gains They are be taxed as ordinary income but with 50 percent excluded from tax, which yields a top rate of 17.5 percent.

title: GREAT SOUTHWEST INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $201,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BIO-MEDICUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Golden Nugget Files Note Sale
description: The Golden Nugget Finance Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public sale of $250 million of mortgage-backed notes due in 1997, with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to be the sole underwriter.

title: Deloitte Haskins & Sells Picks a New Chairman
description: As a student at the University of Florida in the early 1960's, J. Michael Cook planned to major in math, until a guidance counselor suggested he switch to accounting, because it offered better career opportunities.

title: Craig Harris Playing Pieces From New Album
description: Craig Harris must be the busiest young trombonist in New York. His work with David Murray's octet and big band, the Henry Threadgill Sextet, the pianists Muhal Richard Abrams and Abdullah Ibrahim, and many other bandleaders has ranged from the most probing free improvisation to bluesy smears and slides and jaunty plunger-mute soliloquies. He is a modern musician who knows earlier traditions thoroughly.

title: McCall Publishing Adds Baby Magazine
description: The McCall Publishing Company is closing the gap in its coverage of the mothers' markets.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: OUR friend, the Brooklyn brownstoner, recently spent $1,000 on landscaping and trees for her backyard. Then came the drought. The gardener had said the new trees and plants (dogwood, magnolia, mock orange, apricot, cherry, wisteria) would need watering three times a week - and watering was now banned.

title: Citicorp's Rating Cut for Preferred
description: Citicorp's preferred stock rating was reduced to A+ from AA-, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday. The bank holding company's senior and subordinated debt ratings were left unchanged at AA and AA-, respectively.

title: Trinidad Asks Cut in Oil Taxes
description: The Government of Trinidad and Tobago introduced a bill in Parliament today to provide oil companies with further tax relief, after having made cuts in basic taxation rates last year.

title: Bear, Stearns Bid
description: The International Controls Corporation said it had received an unsolicited letter from Bear, Stearns & Company proposing an offer of $27 a share in cash for International Controls stock.

title: Georgia Electric Agency Plans Yields Up to 9 7/8%
description: The Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia is offering $650 million of bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 9 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2016 and 2017. Underwriters are led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: THE OLD DIAMOND CLUB GETS A NEW HOME
description: One of the older members of the Diamond Dealers Club surveyed the club's new quarters with a skeptical eye, and noticed some park benches that interior designers had set into the ultramodern decor. ''So,'' he said, ''what is this, Central Park?''

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Comings and Goings
description: Ron Greschner, who missed 32 games for the Rangers because of injuries this past season, will undergo surgery on his left shoulder today at Lenox Hill Hospital. . . . Edwin Moses, who planned to make his 1985 outdoor debut in the 400-meter hurdles at the ARCO Coliseum Classic in Los Angeles June 8, has withdrawn because of swelling in his right knee from a workout in Brazil. . . . John Teerlinck was dismissed as defensive line coach of the Arizona Outlaws because of a high-altitude tussle with a tackle, Don Hickman, that reportedly spread over several seats and frightened other airline passengers aduring the team's flight home after a 41-20 loss to the Houston Gamblers Sunday. No action was announced against Hickman.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Oil Co. said that its previously announced spinoff of its money-losing minerals business would take effect July 1 and that shareholders would receive 1 share of common stock in the new Cyprus Minerals Co. for every 10 shares of Amoco held as of June 19.

title: REAGAN VS. REAGAN
description: Just one day before appealing to the Democrats on national television to support his tax reform bill - probably the most important and innovative proposal of his second term - President Reagan accused them of being soft on communism abroad, and ''pitting white against black, women against men, and young against old'' at home.

title: Windshield Washers a Target
description: The City Council voted unanimously today to ban youths from washing car windshields at stoplights but moved to ease the penalties faced by the so-called ''squeegee kids'' who continue the practice after police warnings.

title: Nuclear Device Exporter Is Charged With Felony
description: An American businessman accused of illegally exporting nuclear trigger devices to Israel appeared in court today on 30 felony charges.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
IN NAUGATUCK, A MAYOR LEAVES OFFICE AMID NEW FACES AND NEW INDUSTRIES
description: A new mayor takes office here Wednesday, bringing to a close the colorful and controversial career of William C. Rado Sr., a force in town politics for 44 years.

title: >New Crosby Tourney
description: Kathryn Crosby, who recently withdrew the famly name from the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am tournament in Monterey, Calif., announced yesterday that a new Crosby tournament was being planned next year for the Bermuda Run Country Club in Winston Salem, N.C. The 1986 tournament, to be known as the 45th annual Bing Crosby National Championship, will be held the first week in June, according to Mrs. Crosby, who said the tournament would also have a new charitable beneficiary, the Alzheimer's Foundation, and a new format.

title: Hebrew National Account to TBWA
description: TBWA Advertising has won the competition for the Hebrew National Kosher Food account, whose budget is expected to be $2.5 million to $3 million.

title: HEAVY RAINS HIT NEW YORK AREA
description: Drenching storms swept through the New York metropolitan area late yesterday, dropping nearly an inch of rain in the city, causing flooding and contributing to several accidents, including one that seriously injured two people in Central Park, officials said.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S SPEECH ON REVISING THE TAX SYSTEM 72 YEARS OF INCOME TAX: HOW INDIVIDUALS HAVE FARED
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address to the nation last night on taxes, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: GILBERTO GIL AND BAND CREATE A NEW INTERNATIONAL IDIOM
description: GILBERTO GIL, who is performing tonight at Carnegie Hall, has been one of Brazil's brightest and most durable pop stars since the late 1960's. As one of the founders of Tropicalia, a movement of populist fervor and expanding musical vistas, Mr. Gil helped Brazilian pop move beyond the jazzy coolness of bossa nova and imitations of North American pop-rock. But even by his own eclectic standards, his recent work, and especially his latest album, ''Raca Humana'' (WEA International), are quite startling. Although he still writes and sings in lilting Brazilian Portuguese, Mr. Gil and his band are forging a new and deliberately international idiom from sources as disparate as Cuban and New York salsa, British and American funk and progressive rock, and particularly Jamaican reggae, which gallops and sways somewhat differently when filtered through a Brazilian musical sensibility.

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
McEnroe, Connors And Lendl Victors
description: John McEnroe needed 102 minutes to eliminate Ronald Agenor, who ranks 126th in the world, by 6-0, 6-2, 7-5 in the first round of the French Open tennis championships today.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $795,000 from the sale of the Accupoint and Manufacturing Resources divisions of the company's Equipment Sales Co. subsidiary. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $341,000 for the quarter and $667,000 for the 6 months.

title: CONTEMPLATING THE INS AND OUTS OF STATUS
description: THERE are still some people around who don't know that there is no longer such a thing as status. The very use of the word indicates that the speaker would never make the status class, even if it still existed.

title: State Dept. Official's Speech Is Interrupted by a Rightist
description: A man aligned with Lyndon LaRouche, the conservative political ideologue, disrupted a speech today by a State Department official with shouts of ''traitor'' and was bombarded with a flurry of punches from an audience member.

title: 2 U.S. HEART RECIPIENTS ARE REPORTED IMPROVED
description: The conditions of the two surviving American artificial heart patients, William J. Schroeder and Murray P. Haydon, have improved in recent days, although Mr. Schroeder has developed an unexplained blood problem, their doctors said today.

title: A SLICER FOR HOME USE
description: THE summer entertaining season is under way, a time when friends and relatives may assemble at a beach house, a mountain cabin, a boat or a friend's fire escape-cum-terrace. Because people know I am a chef I usually get elected to perform galley duty for these get-togethers, which, in turn, has alerted me to easy-to-prepare, informal meals appropriate for groups. Cold summer salads with good French or Italian cheeses and an assortment of charcuterie would be the perfect answer, were it not for the fact that slicing all the meats and vegetables can be extraordinarily time-consuming.

title: An Older Crowd
description: Age was the rage at Lincoln Center yesterday, as thousands upon thousands of the elderly - upwards of 14,000, according to officials - arrived by the busload for the citywide ''Age in Action'' fair.

title: NCA CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $835,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: CYBERTEK COMPUTER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEMOCRATIC PARTY'S RESPONSE TO THE TAX PROPOSAL
description: Following is a transcript of the response last night by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, to President Reagan's speech, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Isaiah's Flock
description: ''And strangers shall stand and feed your flocks,'' it is written in Isaiah. So 27 sheep will be passing through the city today, because a Christian rancher in southwest Texas believed they belonged in Israel.

title: NEW PANEL TO REVIEW SAFETY OF 6 DYES
description: After 25 years of study and, by one count, 27 extensions of the regulatory deadline, the Food and Drug Administration has appointed a panel to review research indicating that six widely used food and drug dyes may cause cancer. Meanwhile, the food, drug and cosmetic industries, which contend that the dyes are safe, can continue to use them, the F.D.A. said.

title: COVINGTON TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: UNTIL about a decade ago, monkfish was virtually unknown in the United States, although it frequents American waters. This culinary oversight is currently being corrected.

title: MOTO PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Article 013668 -- No Title
description: The Boeing Company agreed yesterday to sell about $1 billion worth of planes to a leasing company. Boeing was also chosen by Australia's state owned Trans-Australia Airlines for about $500 million worth of aircraft orders.

title: Muzzio Captures Decathlon Again
description: Rob Muzzio of George Mason University overcame a 175-point deficit in the final event tonight to capture his second straight National Collegiate Athletic Association decathlon championship.

title: Executive Order 50 Will Transform Social Services in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: HORMEL'S HOMETOWN SPLIT BY UNION'S CAMPAIGN
description: This farming and meatpacking town of 23,000 people is being rent by a fierce labor struggle. Workers, protesting wage reductions imposed by Geo. A. Hormel & Company, are fighting their employer, townspeople, community leaders and their parent union, the United Food and Commercial Workers.

title: JOHANNESBURG BOMB BLAST WOUNDS 10
description: A bomb exploded in the offices of a South African Army medical unit here today, wounding at least 10 people.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Shifts Weighed By MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company is considering restructuring the company by selling either or both of its film company subsidiaries, the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company and the United Artists Corporation, the company said in a proxy statement.

title: Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Merger?
description: The largest industrial merger ever proposed -the betrothal of the Allied and Signal Corporations - raises anew an issue Americans have debated for a century. Does the creation of ever-larger corporations threaten the economy?

title: BLACK GROUP CELEBRATES JUDAISM AS TRUE HERITAGE
description: They gathered to worship on a recent Saturday as they do on every Sabbath, in an elegant Harlem town house next to Mount Morris Park.

title: KNIGHT'S CONFIDENCE BOOSTED
description: Even through a ballplayer's good years, the feeling that everything is just for the moment creeps in. Hit .300 this season, but can you do it the next? A ballplayer lives with a grim joke in the back of his mind: ''If I take very good care of myself for the rest of my career, I'm still going to get injured and get kicked out of the game.''

title: A FASHIONABLE BELT AND A THEFT DETERRENT
Market Place;   Likely Mergers Of Ohio Banks
description: THE failure of the Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati in March could open the door to a string of acquisitions of commercial banks in Ohio, according to Richard X. Bove, a banking analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 29, 1985

title: SMITH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Yale Chair Honors Giamatti
description: A new endowed chair in honor of the president of Yale University, A. Bartlett Giamatti, who is retiring in June 1986, will be established with gifts from 38 alumni totaling $1.7 million, the university announced today. The A. Bartlett Giamatti Professorship will be assigned to a leading scholar without restriction to a field of study, according to the university.

title: Babies A to G Named; 3 Doing 'Extremely Well'
description: The names of the five surviving Frustaci septuplets and their two dead siblings were announced today at a packed news conference that their mother, Patti, was too weak to attend.

title: Attention All Mammals
description: A new museum show in town, ''Mammals in the Limelight,'' may sound like still another solicitous grooming of incumbent bipeds by the capital's tuxedoed canape nibblers. But it is far more refreshing in its subject, focusing as it does on the extinct titanotheres, a huge, thick-skulled creature that preceded both modern man and the Federal deficit, along with the wee eohippus, that charming terrier-size forerunner of the modern horse.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $45,000 on investments.

title: REAGAN'S TAX PLAN: RISE FOR COMPANIES DESPITE CUT IN TOP RATE
description: At the time, this sentence in President Reagan's State of the Union Address on Jan. 25, 1984, drew little attention: ''I am asking Secretary Don Regan for a plan for action to simplify the entire tax code so all taxpayers, big and small, are treated more fairly.''

title: BANK OF MONTREAL (CALIFORNIA) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: 'ARCH OF TRIUMPH,' PARIS ON EVE OF WORLD WAR II
description: ''ARCH OF TRIUMPH,'' the TV movie on CBS at 9 o' clock this evening, is based on an Erich Maria Remarque novel that tells about refugees and drifters in Paris on the eve of World War II. An earlier movie version, released in 1948, starred Ingrid Bergman and Charles Boyer. This one, written by Charles Israel, features Anthony Hopkins as Ravic, the German doctor who has escaped from a concentration camp, and Lesley-Anne Down as Joan, the down-and-out actress just barely clinging to the edges of survival.

title: AN HERB GARDEN GROWN TO ORDER
description: THE Greenmarket at Union Square, currently open Wednesdays and Saturdays, is one of the best places in town to get fresh herbs, both cut herbs and potted plants to set out on a terrace or in a window box. In the next 10 days, many other Greenmarkets will reopen around the city.

title: GRAY & CO PUBLIC COMMUNICATIONS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PALESTINIANS START COUNTERATTACK IN LEBANON, BUT ARE DRIVEN BACK
description: Palestinian forces mounted a counterattack today from one of three besieged refugee settlements, killing 20 Shiite militiamen and Lebanese Army soldiers, the police said.

title: Psychotherapy Should Not Be a Closed Shop
description: To the Editor:

title: Ainge Justifying Celtics' Faith
description: Pat Riley put it simply. ''You don't hear anyone complaining about Gerald Henderson being gone anymore, do you?'' the Los Angeles Laker coach said, after the Boston Celtics routed his team, 148-114, Monday in the opening game of the championship series.

title: CHILD AGENCY TELLS OF DEATH OF 8 CHILDREN
description: The new head of the Koch administration's child-protection agency said yesterday that despite efforts to improve the way the city deals with child abuse, eight children known to the agency had died of abuse or neglect since January.

title: Building Mistrust
description: The general mistrust between Moscow and Washington was demonstrated a few days ago when Soviet officials quietly took possession of the site on Wisconsin Avenue where they are having new embassy offices built. That transaction marked a changing of the guard on the supersensitive project.

title: BILL VOTED ON JUDGES' POWER IN SELECTING JURY
description: Trial judges would be allowed to exert greater control over the selection of juries under a measure given final legislative approval today by the State Senate.

title: NEW LEAGUE A STOP ON ROAD TH N.B.A.
description: Richie Adams was nowhere to be seen when his name was announced to the curious crowd of 1,426 at the Long Island Knights' United States Basketball League opener Monday night. The fans cheered and waited for him to take the court, and then looked puzzled when he failed to materialize.

title: Enigmatic Pirate
description: He is one of the best of pitchers, he is one of the worst of pitchers, and if he keeps up at his early season pace, Jose DeLeon of the Pittsburgh Pirates may end up setting records at both ends of the spectrum. After 10 starts, the 24-year-old right-hander from the Dominican Republic has 70 strikeouts, second only to Dwight Gooden of the Mets (75) among major leaguers, and an 0-7 record, second to none as the worst won-lost record in baseball.

title: JORDANIAN LEADER STARTS U.S. TALKS
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived today for talks with President Reagan that senior American officials said were unlikely to produce an early break in the diplomatic stalemate in the Middle East.

title: T.W.A. PUT UP FOR SALE BY BOARD
description: The directors of Trans World Airlines voted unanimously yesterday to put the airline up for sale.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes currency gains of $135,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $256,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $473,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,165,000, or 16 cents a share, for the 9 months, and currency losses of $104,000 for the quarter and $122,000 for the 9 months.

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRINGING OUT THE BEST IN FOOD: A TASTEFUL STORY
description: MESQUITE-GRILLED chili peppers and goat cheese over buckwheat pasta may be all the rage in some circles, but more and more New Yorkers seem to be combing through cookbooks, markets and restaurant menus in search of something called, with a wonderful indifference to precision, good-tasting food.

title: 'HOW TO BE A MAN,' SPECIAL ON CBS TONIGHT
description: IF there's some message buried in ''How to Be a Man,'' the special dedicated to the male of the species on CBS-TV tonight at 8 o'clock, it must be nothing deeper than a memo to let you know that Father's Day is coming up soon. It is a harmless one-hour music-cum-skit entertainment that is out to please and succeeds in carving for itself a niche between mildly amusing and silly.

title: High Court Clears Way For Florida Execution
description: The United States Supreme Court late today cleared the way for the scheduled execution of Marvin Francois, who was sentenced to die for murdering six people in a robbery.

title: MEDICAL GAINS FOUND TO ERODE ABORTION RULING
description: Medical advances in the art of keeping fetuses alive are eroding the Supreme Court's abortion decisions and raising troubling questions for mothers and doctors, a panel of experts said here today.

title: STAGE: IN WASHINGTON, 'EXECUTION OF JUSTICE'
description: In ''Execution of Justice,'' Emily Mann has taken the controversial 1979 San Francisco trial of Dan White and transformed it into an evening of confrontational theater. Mr. White was tried for killing Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk. He was convicted on a lesser charge of voluntary manslaughter, given a maximum sentence of seven years and eight months and released early this year after spending a little more than five years in prison. Miss Mann calls her approach ''theater of testimony,'' and it is the testimony -in the courtroom and as adapted from interviews - that lends the story authority and authenticity.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Doubleday Publishing Co., has appointed Frank Cermak executive vice president.

title: Swimmer's Diagnosis
description: Damon McCoy, a University of Texas freshman who has been setting swimming records since he was 9 years old, has learned he is suffering from bone cancer, according to his coach, Butch Jordan. ''It doesn't look good at all,'' Jordan said, noting that the diagnosis of a tumor on the femur, or thigh bone, had been made from X-rays two weeks ago.

title:
SCOUTING;

Trying to Relax On the Farm
description: Shawon Dunston, the shortstop from Thomas Jefferson High in Brooklyn who took away Larry Bowa's job this spring and then proved not quite ready (a .194 batting average and 9 errors in 23 games), is doing only so-so down at Iowa, the Cubs' Class AAA affiliate: .270, 6 stolen bases and 2 errors in 11 outings through Monday night.

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: Share earnings reflect the buyback of 17 percent of the company's outstanding shares in the latest fourth quarter.

title: 200 ARRESTED IN WASHINGTON PROTESTS CALLED BY CHRISTIAN ACTIVISTS
description: About 200 Christian activists were arrested today in demonstrations outside the White House, the Soviet Embassy and other major buildings in Washington.

title: AMERICAN HEAD OF A HOSPITAL IS SEIZED BY BEIRUT GUNMEN
description: The American director of a hospital here was abducted by gunmen in the western sector of the capital today, bringing to six the number of United States citizens missing in Lebanon.

title: SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE APPROVES LIMITS FOR DIRT BIKES
description: Riders of dirt bikes and other off-road recreational vehicles would be required to wear helmets, goggles and face shields under a bill approved today by the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: Court Backs Broad Stock-Sale View
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal securities laws applied to stock sales that resulted in the transfer of ownership or control of a business.

title: FOREIGNERS' CONTROL OF TRACK DECLINING
description: The foreigners are still here - from Kenya, Sweden, Nigeria, Britain, Ireland, New Zealand, Norway, Brazil, Ivory Coast and points east and west. And they will win their share of titles and other high placings in the six-day national collegiate outdoor track and field championships for men and women, which began Monday at the University of Texas Memorial Stadium.

title: Unwed Mother, 16, Charged In Suffocation of Infant Girl
description: A 16-year-old unwed mother was arraigned today on a charge of criminally negligent homicide for allowing her 3-month-old daughter to suffocate by leaving her in a closet for two and one-half hours on Monday, officials said.

title: A LINDNER CONCERN SEEKS HOME STATE
description: State officials arranging a rebirth of the closed Home State Savings Bank received a last minute bid tonight from the American Financial Corporation, the company controlled by Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier. American Financial had faced a midnight deadline to make its purchase offer, details of which were not released.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 29, 1985

title: ROSTENKOWSKI BACKS SHIFTS; GEPHARDT ASSAILS REVISIONS
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, one of the senior Democrats in Congress, appealed to the American people tonight to support the overhaul of the Federal income tax proposed by President Reagan.

title: WHAT'S IN THE BEEF? DATA ROUNDED UP
description: For the last 35 years, one of the best-selling books printed by the Government has been ''Composition of Foods,'' a large handbook that gives the nutritional values of thousands of items.

title: TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: LEISURE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Including extraordinary income of $80,000 for the quarter and $130,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary income of $90,000 for the quarter and $100,000 for the 6 months.

title: REAGAN ASKS TAX 'REVOLUTION': $2,000 EXEMPTION, 35% TOP RATE, NO DEDUCTION OF STATE LEVIES How Tax Rates Would Change
description: ''Frankly, we have some concerns looking at the package over all,'' said Dean C. Tipps, executive director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a consumer group supported primarily by organized labor, ''because when you compare Treasury II with Treasury I, our preliminary data indicate that everyone in the middle income classes will find the tax cuts have been reduced and that people at the high end of the scale have done better and the tax shelter industry has done better.

title: JUDGE RULES ON ALLOCATION OF THE AGENT ORANGE FUND
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that $150 million of a $200 million fund for Vietnam veterans claiming harm from Agent Orange should be given to the totally disabled and to the families of those who have died.

title: Spend a Buck Out Of Belmont Stakes
description: Spend a Buck was so sapped by his courageous but surprisingly narrow victory in the Jersey Derby Monday that he will skip the Belmont Stakes on June 8, his owner and trainer said this morning.

title: I.B.M. Joint Unit
description: I.B.M. Japan Ltd. and the Computer Service Corporation have agreed to set up a joint systems engineering company, Computer Service said in a statement. The company, to be called the Japan Information Engineering Company, will be capitalized at about $1.2 million, 65 percent owned by Computer Service and 35 percent by I.B.M. Japan, and will be set up in September, it said. The company projects sales of about $9.9 million in its first business year, rising to about $40 million in its fifth year.

title: REPORT SAYS U.S. MUST ALLOW PRESS IN WAR ZONE
description: The presence of journalists in war zones where American forces are fighting is essential - ''not a luxury, but a necessity'' - according to a report issued yesterday on the relationship between the military and news organizations.

title: SONY DEBUT OF HOME VIDEO LINE
description: In a bid to repair its fortunes in the home video market, the Sony Corporation today announced its series of eight-millimeter home video products, including a paperback-size video camera recorder and video cassette recorder.

title: BUSINESS EXPENSES FACING NEW CURBS
description: Many business deductions for entertainment meals and travel expenses would be disallowed under President Reagan's tax plan. The new proposals maintained the hard line that the Treasury Department proposed last fall.

title: ST GERMAIN ASKS CHANGE IN BANKING PRACTICES
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee told bankers today that he would block any expansion of banking powers if Congress did not also pass legislation to shorten holding periods on deposited checks and standardize the calculation of interest on deposits.

title: COMMANDO SAYS TARGET WAS ANGOLA OIL DEPOT
description: A South African commando captured by Angola said today that he had been sent to blow up a Gulf Oil storage depot in northern Angola and not to gather intelligence, as his Government said.

title: ROLLER SKATERS WHO WOULD BE TRAINS
description: Some of the little engines, it seemed, simply couldn't. They revved up their arms and ''pumped them like machines,'' the way the choreographer instructed them to. They turned and churned their legs, like the wheels of the locomotives they were trying to simulate in yesterday's audition for ''Starlight Express,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's rock and roller-skating musical, in which all the characters are trains.

title: U.S. PLANS TO FREEZE MEDICARE HOSPITAL PAYMENTS
description: The Reagan Administration has concluded that Medicare payment rates for hospitals were set 6.1 percent too high and must be frozen next year to correct the error.

title: APPLIED DATA COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Foreign Car Gain Seen
description: Foreign auto makers will increase their share of the American auto market in coming years, according to a Commerce Department study detailed in Automotive News. By 1988, only 57 percent of the cars sold in this country will be made by American companies - down from 76 percent last year, a Federal official told the trade journal. The erosion could result in the loss of 100,000 manufacturing jobs, the journal reported.

title: CHAMPAGNE: BAD HARVEST
description: This year's Champagne grape harvest seems likely to be one of the worst in about 50 years because of severe winter and spring frosts, a spokesman for the Champagne Trade Association said here today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe that, in both spirit and substance, our tax system has come to be un-American.'' - President Reagan. [A1:6.]

title: People
description: * Gary Yoshida and Robert Coburn have been elected senior vice presidents at Needham Harper Worldwide, Los Angeles.

title: Westvaco Net Down by 18.4%
description: The Westvaco Corporation, a major producer of paper, packaging and specialty chemicals, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of the fiscal year 1985 dropped 18.4 percent as revenues slipped 2.7 percent.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LATE SETTINGS. By James Merrill. 87 pages. Atheneum. Cloth, $12.95; paper, $6.95. SWEET WILL. By Philip Levine. 56 pages. Atheneum. Cloth, $10.95; paper, $5.95. THREE years ago, Atheneum published an impressive selection from James Merrill's first nine books of poetry, as well as his hugely ambitious epic, ''The Changing Light at Sandover.'' The two volumes amply demonstrated both Merrill's development and range as a poet - his mastery of various verse forms and conventions, his exquisite command of irony and wit. They also reconfirmed, to readers, his achievement of a wholly distinctive voice - a voice that is coolly elusive as melting sherbet, poised and elaborate as a finely-wrought antique clock, a voice as polished, urbane and attuned to the labyrinthine complexities of perception as that of Henry James or Marcel Proust.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A GRAND SHOW The piano, which has been a music maker since before 1700, is being pulled out of what passes for the attic of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 81st Street (575-7710). The 30 exhibited from the 70 in the museum's collection are not designed for ''Kitten on the Keys.'' Each of the instruments in ''Keynotes: Two Centuries of Piano Design'' is rare, if not unique, made in the 18th or 19th century. They include the sort of pianos known to the Scarlattis, Mozart, Beethoven and other composers and performers. Some have never been shown to the public.

title: Change in Service
description: There will be no taking the train to the plane for the next two weekends. It will be more a matter of taking the train to the train to the plane.

title: Cleveland Utility
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company is offering $85 million of 12 1/4 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2015 at a price of 99 3/8 to yield 12.329 percent. The underwriters are led by Morgan, Stanley & Company. The 30-year bonds, which are not refundable for five years, are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.&P.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago 9 months results reflect the acquisition of limited partnership interests in November 1983.

title: TELETRAK ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $218,312 from discontinued operations.

title: 2 More Regional Talks With Moscow Planned
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States and the Soviet Union had agreed to exchange views on two more world regional issues - southern Africa and Afghanistan. The two sides met in February to discuss the Middle East.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Job Training, New York Style
description: Unskilled but out-of-school youths can no longer rely on much Federal help in improving themselves or finding work. The Job Corps faces substantial budget cuts and the Reagan Administration's substitute, the Job Training Partnership Act, favors youths who would most likely find jobs on their own.

title: OPERA: SPOLETO FESTIVAL'S 'ARIODANTE'
description: One of the great pleasures of this Handel year has been to watch talented artists from various corners of the operatic profession pursue - at the Met and Carnegie Hall, in schools, churches, festivals and fringe theaters - their various and evolving understandings of the Baroque master's great dramatic works. The Spoleto Festival's ''Ariodante'' is in effect an entry from the New York early-music community, presented by Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company. It had its faults, but gave pleasure and lively entertainment at the first of its six performances here last night at the Dock Street Theater.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

SCOUTING;

Answering Back
description: George Young, the Giants' general manager, was quoted recently as paying a very mild compliment to Herschel Walker: ''He's playing very well - in that league.

title: PEREZ HELPS REDS OUTSLUG CUBS, 13-11
description: Tony Perez, getting a rare start at first base, drove in four runs with a homer and a double tonight, leading the Cincinnati Reds to a 13-11 come-from-behind victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: British Immigration Law Found Sexually Biased
description: The European Court of Human Rights today found the British Government guilty of sex discrimination in immigration laws that permit men who are legally settled to bring their wives to Britain but do not permit women residents to bring their husbands.

title: GUNMAN SLAIN AFTER KILLING 3
description: A man with a semi-automatic weapon killed three people and wounded six others tonight after opening fire on traffic along a highway, then shooting his way into a store before he was slain in a shootout with the police.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: A Matter of Gravity
description: For a while there, President Reagan may have been in danger of losing of one of his favorite joke targets in the portly image of the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., of Massachusetts. In his five years of incumbency, the President has been relentless - and merciless, in the view of Mr. O'Neill's friends -in offering grinning allusions to the Speaker's avoirdupois. Mr. O'Neill disclosed last week that he recently reduced himself by 15 pounds.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 29, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 3 P.M.

title: Pillsbury Link
description: The Horn & Hardart Company is considering opposing the Pillsbury Company's proposed acquisition of Diversifoods Inc., it disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Horn & Hardart said it had received ''indications'' that other major Diversidfoods shareholders were dissatisfied with the Pillsbury offer and said it might get in touch with those shareholders ''regarding the possibility of taking unified action.''

title: STAND BY FOR LOOTING
description: The tax law is dreadful, just as everybody says it is. One of the most dreadful things about it, which nobody ever mentions though, is that it constantly changes.

title: A SIMPLER SYSTEM:WHITE HOUSE'S SUMMARY OF PLAN
description: Following are excerpts from the White House summary of the tax proposals President Reagan will send to Congress Wednesday: To increase growth, reduce complexity and make the system more fair, the President has proposed a comprehensive set of reforms. The following are key features: Personal Reduction The President's proposals would eliminate the present system of 14 brackets of tax rates, ranging from 11 percent to 50 percent. In its place would be a simple three-bracket system, with tax rates of 15 percent, 25 percent and 35 percent. (For joint returns, the rates would be 0% up to $4,000 in taxable income; 15% from $4,000 to $29,000; 25% from $29,000 to $70,000, and 35% over $70,000.) Marginal tax rates would be reduced by an average of 19 percent.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LONG-TERM BONDS RISE STRONGLY
description: Long-term bond prices rose more than a point in active trading yesterday as some traders and investors concluded that hints of lower oil prices, the President's speech on tax revision, a weak economy and a generous monetary policy all pointed toward lower interest rates.

title: REGIMENTS OF SUNSHINE PATRIOTS
description: A conversation overheard in a supermarket checkout line:

title: Ernst Pawel Honored With Harcourt Award
description: Ernst Pawel, author of ''The Nightmare of Reason: A Life of Franz Kafka,'' published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux last year, has been named winner of the third annual Alfred Harcourt Award in biography and memoirs.

title: WINE TALK
description: DRINKING wine is one of life's simpler pleasures.

title: OILERS TRIUMPH TO LEAD BY 3-1
description: Aided by four power-play goals, two by Wayne Gretzky, and Grant Fuhr's save on only the third penalty shot in the history of the Stanley Cup finals, the Edmonton Oilers raced to a 5-3 victory over the Philadelpia Flyers.

title: Article 013034 -- No Title
description: A jury in a Federal antitrust case today awarded the MCI Communications Corporation $37.8 million in its suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. MCI had sought $5.8 billion.

title: U.S. Accuses Moscow On Geneva Deadlock
description: The White House spokesman agreed today with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, that the first round of the Geneva arms-control talks had been fruitless, but said it was the Soviet Union that was responsible.

title: TRANSWORLD'S CENTURY 21 SALE
description: Just 15 months ago, the Transworld Corporation got out of the airline business, spinning off Trans World Airlines to its shareholders. Now it is putting Century 21, its profitable real estate subsidiary, up for sale.

title: TALK OF CUT IN OIL PRICE
description: Reports that a number of countries are in the process of cutting crude oil prices continued to circulate in oil markets yesterday.

title: Flexi-Van Buyback Set
description: The Flexi-Van Corporation, which plans to merge with Castle & Cooke Inc., has agreed to buy back the Castle & Cooke shares controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs at a substantial premium over the current market value.

title: The Beltway as an Epithet
description: To the tense commuters who confront it each day, the Capital Beltway is the congested 66-mile circular link between Washington and their suburban homes in Maryland and Virginia. But to many politicians and political junkies, the Beltway symbolizes the great wall that separates the United States into two countries - the land of obsessive concern with politics that lies inside the Beltway and, beyond it, Real America.

title: Keep Uniformed Unions Uniform
description: Unions for New York City's police officers and firefighters are unhappy with a decision by the city's bargainers to submit all uniformed services contracts to arbitration together. To block the move, police and fire unions are asking the Legislature to place them under state, not city, jurisdiction.

title: AN UPLIFT FOR RUNDOWN EAST TREMONT AVE. IN BRONX
description: For the first time in 25 years East Tremont Avenue, an active but rundown commercial strip in the South Bronx, will see the construction of new retail shops with a local developer's plan to put up a building that will have at least six retail spaces.

title: Maglie Throws a Curve
description: Sal Maglie, the former Giant, Dodger and Yankee pitcher who grew up in Niagara Falls, N.Y., was in Albany to receive a scroll proclaiming the day ''Sal Maglie Day'' in the state, and ended up disillusioning a one-time minor leaguer who presented the proclamation - Mario M. Cuomo, a former center fielder in the Pittsburgh Pirates system who now serves as the Governor of New York. ''Now those of us who didn't make it because we couldn't hit the curve. . . .'' began the Governor.

title: WHERE TO SEND DONATIONS
description: These agencies are accepting donations for disaster relief in Bangladesh. Mark checks ''Bangladesh'' or as designated in the listing. Bangladesh Society Inc., 45-14 Junction Boulevard, Elmhurst, N.Y., 11368.

title: DRUG INDICTMENTS DUE FRIDAY
description: The Federal grand jury investigating trafficking in illegal drugs in the Pittsburgh area is expected to hand up indictments Friday, a source familiar with the investigation said yesterday. Although more than a dozen baseball players have testified before the grand jury, the source said he had no reason to think any players would be indicted.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PANEL APPROVES TOWER PLAN USING FACADES OF 2 LANDMARKS
description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday approved a plan to build a 53-story tower using the facades of the landmark Rizzoli and Coty Buildings on Fifth Avenue, the focus of a long dispute between preservationists and a developer.

title: Burger King Plan
description: The Burger King Corporation intends to invest $35 million in opening 25 to 30 new restaurants in West Germany over the next two years, the restaurant chain's European vice president, Charles Petty, said. He told reporters that Burger King's West German revenues were expected to rise 15 percent in 1985, compared with 1984 revenue of about $125 million. Burger King's group world turnover was $3.4 billion last year, he said.

title: THEATER: 'JUNO'S SWANS,' A COMEDY
description: THE mission of Off Broadway's Second Stage is to give a second chance to valuable plays that might have been ill served or ignored in their initial productions. ''Juno's Swans,'' the company's latest offering, is a new play, not a revival, with a different but related goal: It provides a forum for four talented actresses who are apparently contemplating a new stage in their careers.

title: Guess Which Georgian Is Back in Town
description: The boy who began a career in Presidential politics by delivering his father's campaign handbills to shops in south Georgia has returned to the nation's capital as a prelude to entering the public arena in his own right.

title: Reporter for The Times Gets Award for Historical Writing
description: The Marine Corps Historical Foundation today presented its annual award for historical writing to Thomas L. Friedman, correspondent for The New York Times in Jerusalem.

title: An Exchange President Gets Top Provigo Posts
description: Provigo Inc., Canada's second-largest food distributor, said yesterday that Pierre Lortie, president of the Montreal Exchange, had been named chairman and chief executive officer.

title: WISDOM OF THE PEOPLE EMPHASIZED AS PRESIDENT SETS POPULIST STRATEGY
description: President Reagan today outlined the strategy he will use to sell his landmark tax simplification plan as he braced his senior aides for a long and difficult battle.

title: TWO CABLE GIANTS SEEN IN BID FOR WARNER AMEX
description: Time Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's two largest cable television system operators, have joined forces to offer about $750 million in cash and the assumption of about $500 million in debt for Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., sources close to the transaction said yesterday.

title: LOUGHERY DROPPED
description: Billy Cunningham and Kevin Loughery, rivals on the basketball court as players and coaches but close friends off it, left the coaching ranks together yesterday, under different circumstances.

title: NEW YORK LEADERS OPPOSE PLAN VEHEMENTLY
description: Governor Cuomo and several other political leaders in New York and New Jersey quickly assailed the President's tax revision plan last night, reserving their harshest words for the repeal of deductions for state and local taxes.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Reggie Jackson and Tommy John, former Yankees, are in town for their first visit of the season.

title: BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: VACATION season is about to begin in earnest, which means that millions of Americans will be jetting across the United States and overseas. That, in turn, means millions of Americans will be starting their time of rest and relaxation, or adventure and excitement, feeling tired and cranky, headachy and out of sorts. It could be days before they feel ''normal'' again, able to enjoy their holiday.

title: New Rule to Slow Cars
description: Nascar said today it would go ahead with a rule change to slow races this season before Bill Elliott gets a second shot at a $1 million bonus.

title: Owner of Oil Rig Says Stability Was Untested
description: The owner of an oil-drilling barge that capsized in south Louisiana, killing 11 men on board, had never tested its stability, a company officer said today at a Coast Guard hearing.

title: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Storer Disputes Election Tally
description: Storer Communications Inc. said that a dissident group of shareholders with a 5.29 percent stake in the company had won as many as four seats on its nine-member board.

title: Heublein Venture
description: Heublein Inc., a subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Industries, said it had begun a joint venture with the Mitsubishi Corporation of Tokyo to distribute wines and spirits in Japan. Heublein said that effective June 1, Mitsubishi will acquire a minority interest in Heublein's Japanese subsidiary.

title: U.N. Aide Denies Food For Ethiopia Is Missing
description: The United Nations official in charge of emergency aid operations in Ethiopia said today that virtually all of the food sent to this country had been accounted for.

title: Commodore Sees Profit by '86
description: Commodore International Ltd., the home computer maker that appeared invincible until it reported a deep loss last quarter, said yesterday that it would break even in the fall and regain profitability by year's end.

title: INTERMOUNTAIN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gain of $2,071,000, or 16 cents a share, on retirement of debt for the quarter and the year.

title: SPY SUSPECT PAINTED AS RUSE-LOVING 'PRIVATE EYE'
description: A portrait of an ostentatiously gadget-loving, politically ultra-conservative ''private eye'' who romanticized undercover assignments that often went awry is emerging here as associates of John A. Walker Jr. match their memories of him with the reality of his arrest on espionage charges.

title: U.S. IS CALLED HURT BY 2 SPY SUSPECTS
description: The United States was ''badly hurt'' by disclosures from an accused father-son spy team, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today.

title: Advertising;   Royal Crown's Cola Drive
description: IN the cola business once you leave the top two, Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, you are nowhere. And the really big brand there is Royal Crown, which intends to be somewhere and plans to get there with advertising.

title: FOREIGN POLICY: LOT OF TABLE THUMPING GOING ON
description: Representative John McCain of Arizona has been negotiating with some fellow Republicans over a formula for providing aid to the insurgent forces in Nicaragua. As Mr. McCain tells the story, one lawmaker agreed to support nonmilitary aid to the rebels, including trucks, but he was worried about how ''trucks'' would be defined in the bill.

title: PSYCHOTHERAPY SHOULD NOT BE A CLOSED SHOP
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 6
description: b-After a loss of $1,434,000 on the sale of a division. c-After a loss of $1,225,000 on closed store costs and expenses. The company is listed on the Philadelphia, Boston, and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: Teen-Ager, in Court, Denies Killing Transit Police Officer
description: The teen-ager accused of murdering a Transit Authority police officer denied the charge yesterday as he testified that a friend had given him the murder weapon - the officer's revolver - after the shooting.

title: COURT BACKS UNION ON RIGHTS DATA
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered the Federal Government to expand workers' rights to information from employers about hazardous products to which they may be exposed.

title: Peace Institute Now
description: To the Editor:

title: BANGLADESHIS STRUGGLING TO RECOVER
description: Today, four days after a cyclone devastated the lowlands of southeastern Bangladesh, thousands of peasant families on this tiny delta island were burying their dead and struggling for food and shelter in a landscape strewn with human corpses and carcasses of sheep and cattle.

title: Taiwan Investment Bill
description: Taiwan's Cabinet has approved a bill to relax investment controls and allow foreign investors to buy shares in local companies, Government officials said today. They told reporters that the new measure was intended to revive foreign investment in Taiwan, which dipped 6.8 percent in the first four months of this year compared with the period last year.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PUBLISHERS FOREVER IN SEARCH OF THE 'BIG BOOK'
description: The annual four-day convention of the American Booksellers Association ended today as it began, amid a chorus of optimism. Large crowds had filled the Moscone Center here for the first three days. ''Now comes the hard part,'' said Patrick O'Connor, a senior editor at Warner Books, referring to the industry's impending return to the everyday world of work before next year's convention in New Orleans.

title: SCREEN: 'GAZA GHETTO'
description: ''GAZA GHETTO'' begins with footage of a young Palestinian girl declaring that ''the most important thing for me is to live on my land.'' It ends only 82 minutes later with a replay of the same scene. The film makers doubtless mean to underscore their sincerity and that of their subjects, members of a family that has lived for three generations in the Jabalia refugee camp in Gaza. But the effect is sentimental and contrived, as is all too much of this disorganized, falsely low-keyed documentary.

title: 8 YOUTHS ACCUSED OF VIGILANTE ACTS
description: A grand jury returned 33 indictments today against eight high school students who the authorities say belonged to the Legion of Doom, a vigilante group accused of violence against other students.

title: A PRESIDENTIAL CHALLENGE
description: Like all Presidents, Ronald Reagan wants to use the Federal income tax to rearrange the economy and the structure of society to suit his own vision. Beyond all else, that was the message of his speech tonight.

title: WEST SIDE TODDLERS ARE ON A ROLL
description: ON the Upper West Side, where children have become a growth industry, the parental cry one recent weekend was ''Baby needs a pair of new shoes.'' The weather was mostly sunny and so were the babies, especially the ones who got new jellies.

title: RUSSO ATTACKS KEAN RECORD IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: The State Senate majority leader, John F. Russo, is campaigning hard these days in the state's byways, looking for the handfuls of votes that could spell the difference in the Democratic gubernatorial primary on June 4.

title: JACOR COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Italian Leader in Moscow
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy arrived here today on the first state visit by a NATO leader since Mikhail S. Gorbachev became Soviet leader in March. Mr. Craxi arrived after a two-hour stopover in Warsaw to meet with the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.

title: MANY IN NEW YORK WOULD FACE A LOWER TAX
description: For all the debate over how President Reagan's tax proposals would affect New York, some New Yorkers who would lose large deductions for state and local taxes would nevertheless pay lower Federal income taxes, according to quick calculations by a major accounting company.

title: Indonesian Rebels Give Casualties for Soldiers
description: Left-wing separatist guerrillas fighting Indonesia's rule in East Timor said today that they had killed or wounded more than 600 Indonesian soldiers since August 1983 and had established a radio transmitter in the territory.

title: NATIONAL HMO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-The company went public in December 1983 and year-ago results are not comparable.

title: Sri Lanka's Fearful Symmetry
description: Solomon Bandaranaike is half-remembered as a lively, leftist Prime Minister of Ceylon, the tear-shaped island nation now called Sri Lanka. His story is worth retelling, for it helps in understanding why Sri Lanka is squandering its prosperity in a bitter civil war, between the Sinhalese majority and the Tamil minority.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $19,700,000 on the sale of the bank's interest in the Vancouver Center. The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: TEA COMPANY BRINGS TASTINGS TO TOWN
description: ''MY uncle wanted every one of his brothers and sisters to have one tea store, but now we have 36 stores - as if he had so many brothers and sisters,'' Mark Lii said, as he poured boiling water into and over a tiny clay teapot filled with curly black tea leaves blended with hibiscus: Into the pot, so that the leaves would soak, infusion would begin and spicy Roselle tea would be brewed; over the pot because, he said, ''a hot pot makes the best tea.''

title: UNSATIFYING TRIP FOR YANKS
description: They were bleary-eyed when they stepped off the plane yesterday morning. The flight from Oakland, Calif., to Newark had taken all night, finally depositing the Yankees on their home turf at 8:15 A.M. But not even the distance could separate them from the annoying realization that their road trip should have been better.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $274,500 from the reversal of property valuation reserves.

title: MESABA AVIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Stocks Slip as Tax Plan Is Awaited
description: With the stock market still consolidating last week's gains, prices slipped a little yesterday on Wall Street as investors apparently decided to forgo any further equities purchases until after President Reagan presented his tax revision proposals to the nation.

title: CORPORATE BURDEN WOULD BE HEAVIER
description: The Administration's tax plan, if adopted by Congress, would result in a significant increase in the tax burden on corporate America even as the top business rate is reduced to 33 percent, from 46 percent.

title: Not a Silent Spring, But Perhaps a Quieter One
description: Where are the birds of yesteryear?

title: KOHL MEETS WITH MITTERRAND
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Francois Mitterrand held talks today in which they discussed sharing Western European high technology. But they were apparently unable to bridge their differences on President Reagan's plan to develop a space-based antimissile system.

title: QUINONES ASKS FOR $60 MILLION IN EXTRA FUNDS
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones asked the City Council yesterday to add $60 million for sports programs, library books, security guards and school supplies to Mayor Koch's proposed city budget.

title: Economic Scene;   Deficit Cuts And Tax Shifts
description: THE broad program for overhauling the tax system that President Reagan offered in his television address last night is certainly not the best tax revision anyone can imagine, including, in all likelihood, Mr. Reagan himself and his Secretary of the Treasury, James Baker 3d. They have a tough fight ahead if their proposal is to survive attacks from various quarters and be enacted by Congress in recognizable form.

title: U.S. STUDIES PLAN TO INTEGRATE NUCLEAR ARMS WITH A MISSILE SHIELD
description: The Defense Department is devising a nuclear war plan and command structure that would integrate offensive nuclear forces with the projected antimissile shield, according to United States and Canadian officials.

title: Chip Plan Delayed
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation is postponing plans to produce the newest generation of computer memory chips, the 256K RAM, because making them would not be profitable.

title: MEDICAL DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cigarette Advertising Is the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: UNIVERSITY GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HIGH TECH, A SUBSIDIARY OF PENTAGON INC.
description: America's technology future depends ever more on the Pentagon. But that future is too important to be left entirely to Pentagon strategists.

title: IRE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,300,000 from the sale of an apartment building.

title: LJN TOYS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Q&A
description: Q.

title: 25 STUDENTS ARRESTED IN SEOUL
description: A police spokesman today announced the arrest of 25 of the 73 students who seized the building of the United States Information Service last week in a protest against American support for the South Korean Government.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Larry Gura, pitcher. Placed Gary Matthews, outfielder, on 15-day disabled list. Signed the junior college players Jeff Small, shortstop; Lee Grimes and Michael Jones, outfielders, and Scott Lochow, catcher.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,847,000 from an accounting change. c-Includes a gain of $11,005,000 from an accounting change.

title: I.M.F. PLANS TO RECYCLE AID FOR POOREST NATIONS
description: The International Monetary Fund is quietly moving to reactivate a trust fund that would release some $3 billion in low-cost loans to the poorest countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America.

title: JUSTICES RULE THAT LAWYERS CAN ADVERTISE FOR SPECIFIC CASES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that lawyers have a constitutional right to use printed advertising to seek clients for specific cases.

title: Sir Clive to Leave As Sinclair's Chief
description: Sinclair Research Ltd., Britain's leading home computer maker, said yesterday that it had arranged a financial rescue package with banks and suppliers, and that Sir Clive Sinclair, the company's founder, would step down as chief executive officer.

title: NAVY PAYS $660 APIECE FOR TWO ASHTRAYS
description: The Navy said today that it had paid the Grumman Aerospace Corporation $660 apiece for ashtrays to be installed in its E-2C Hawkeye early warning aircraft.

title: RELIGION IN CUBA: CASTRO NOW EYES IT LESS COLDLY
description: It was Sunday morning in the weathered limestone Cathedral of Havana, and about 30 people, mostly old men and women, were attending mass. The day before, at the city's largest synagogue, the turnout for services had also been typical: 17 old men, two small boys and a gray-haired woman.

title: CARDINAL DISTRIBUTION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCINTYRE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge: Field in Reisinger Knockout Is Narrowed to Eight Teams
description: One of the great traditional events in the game, the Reisinger Knockout Teams, which dates back to 1930, resumed last night at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street.

title: THE DESPERATE HOURS
description: Now the Boston Celtics have gone and done it.

title: Angus L. Walker, 75; Led City Investing Co.
description: Angus Lightfoot Walker, retired chairman of the executive committee of the City Investing Company of New York, died Sunday at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 75 years old and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: COMPUTERS: FOCUS ON SCIENCE
