description: The first electronic computer, the Eniac, was built in the 1940's to calculate artillery shell trajectories. But the mainstream of computing has long since moved away from such mathematically intensive tasks toward more mundane ones, such as corporate record-keeping. The International Business Machines Corporation got to be the size it is by selling computers for accountants and sales managers, not for physicists and engineers.

title: CARDIO PET INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $28,000 for the quarter and $38,000 for the 6 months.

title: HUDSON'S BAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Brady on Horseback
description: Four years after he was gravely wounded in the assassination attempt on President Reagan, James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, is able to go horseback riding, and he is to join Nancy Reagan today for a jaunt through Rock Creek Park. White House officials say Mr. Brady has been working out with horses this spring as part of his continuing therapy for the effects of the gunshot wound he suffered to the brain. Mrs. Reagan, an experienced rider from roaming the Reagans' ranch in California, has planned a busy day in the saddle. In addition to Mr. Brady, she will ride with students from the Rock Creek Park National Center for Therapeutic Riding.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,960,000, or 57 cents a share. c-After a tax credit of $2,543,000, or 69 cents a share, and includes a nonrecurring gain on the sale of properties of $4,036,000.

title: AGCA, AT ROME TRIAL, AGAIN PROCLAIMS HE IS CHRIST
description: The prosecution's main witness in the purported plot to kill Pope John Paul II repeated in testimony today that he was Jesus Christ and that the world was about to end.

title: UNITED SAYS IT WILL RESTAFF AIRLINES WITH OR WITHOUT STRIKING PILOTS
description: United Airlines announced today that it planned to rebuild with or without its nearly 5,000 striking pilots.

title: 'Return-Free' Tax System
description: For a large majority of Americans, President Reagan's tax revision plan holds out the eventual possibility of never having to deal with the annual filing trauma of April 15.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for 14wks to May 11
KOREANS AGREE IN PRINCIPLE ON 'FREE TRAVEL' TO SEARCH FOR RELATIVES
description: North and South Korean Red Cross representatives ended two days of talks today, agreeing in principle to permit ''free travel'' by people searching for relatives lost during the 40-year partition of this peninsula.

title:
SCOUTING;

Language Lesson
description: A Brazilian, an Italian and a Yugoslav - all new to the Cosmos, all new to this country - showed in an instant Monday that, at least when it comes to soccer, language need be no barrier. This was not a lesson that their coach dwelled on afterward, however, because he was preoccupied using the language of the other football to describe the key play that the newcomers had created.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
IRANIAN AND IRAQI CAPITALS ARE HIT BY AIR AND MISSILE ATTACKS
description: Baghdad and Teheran both came under attack today as Iraq and Iran continued intensive air and missile strikes on civilian areas across their borders.

title: KEY WITNESS ASSERTS VON BULOW TOLD HER ABOUT DAY OF COMA
description: Claus von Bulow's former mistress testified today that he had told her he spent hours watching his wife slip deeper into a coma in 1979 but then decided ''he couldn't go through with it'' and called a doctor.

title: MEDICARE-GLASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CRIMES DROPPED 5.8% FROM '84 IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Despite an increase in assaults, the number of crimes reported in New York City declined 5.8 percent during the first three months of this year, compared with the same period last year, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: Toll Rises in Tanker Blast
description: Divers today recovered the body of another victim of the explosion of two oil tankers, bringing the official death toll to 21, the police said. Seven more bodies are believed to be in one of the submerged tankers, and a dozen crewmen are still missing. Fourteen of the 39 people injured as a result of the blasts Sunday remained in hospitals in this southeastern Spanish city, the authorities said.

title: Prices: Up and Down
description: New York City saw record prices for frozen orange juice concentrate during the month of April, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs. During the five-week period that ended April 26, the average price of a 12-ounce can of concentrate, which makes a quart and a half of juice, was $1.74. This was the highest price recorded since the department's monthly market basket survey began in May 1973. The price was 12 percent more than for the same item during a comparable period in 1984. The department blamed January's severe freeze in Florida for the increase.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS PROPOSAL IN DRIVE TO BUILD COALITION
description: President Reagan pressed the Administration drive today to forge a coalition behind his plan to simplify the Federal income tax as he formally submitted the proposal to Congress.

title: HISTORIC HOUSE DECISION DEFERRED
description: The Town Council of Palm Beach, Fla., voted recently to defer designation of the town's oldest building as a historic landmark. Sea Gull Cottage, built in 1886, was the first winter residence of Henry M. Flagler, a founder of Palm Beach. It is now on the property of the Royal Ponciana Chapel.

title: TRANSIERRA EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain on the restructuring of debt of an unconsolidated subsidiary of $437,393. c-Net loss

title: Ups and Downs
description: National League attendance is up 12.4 percent this year, American League attendance up 9.4 percent and major league attendance as a whole up 10.9 percent. And the Mets are up more than anybody, their average home crowd of 31,296 after 24 home dates constituting a two-thirds increase over the figure after the same number of dates last year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM OUT THERE When the best work from the stimulating, widespread world of theater outside New York eventually makes its way here, it often arrives under auspices other than the original producer's. Starting today, however, three of the best-known regional resident theater companies are coming to town, each with a show it is doing on its own.

title: State Is Counterpunching in Drug Fight
description: The rumors, which have been around for years, mention some of boxing's biggest stars. Bob Arum, the promoter, warns that ''maybe 50 percent'' of all fighters use drugs, and calls it ''our biggest problem.''

title: DEMOCRATS ARGUE AT HOUSE HEARING
description: Two Democratic Congressmen from states with high taxes sharply disagreed today on whether President Reagan's tax plan would harm residents of their states.

title: Garlan Morse Is Dead at 73; Retired Chief of GTE Sylvania
description: Garlan Morse, retired president of the GTE Sylvania Corporation, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at the Mary Alley Hospital in Marblehead, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Marblehead.

title: TRANSFORMING A MANHATTAN CARRIAGE HOUSE
description: CHRISTOPHE DE MENIL has been living in her East Side town house for 20 years and it's almost, but not quite, completed. That's partly because she was only a tenant for several years and partly because she had no clear vision of what she wanted her home to look like. Nor could she simply turn over the design to an architect or a decorator.

title: MAYOR EXHORTS CLASS AT COOPER ON DOING DUTY
description: Mayor Koch yesterday urged the 214 graduates of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art not to take for granted the privileges and opportunities given their generation.

title: FAN VIOLENCE HAUNTS ENGLISH SOCCER TEAMS
description: Fan violence at soccer games has haunted English teams this season.

title: World Trade Council Tables Nicaraguan Embargo Protest
description: The United States today blocked an attempt by Nicaragua to have the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade here condemn the United States embargo against the Central American nation.

title: Accounts
description: Olsten Temporary Services, Westbury, L.I., to Epstein Raboy Advertising.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Junk Bonds and Fast Bucks
description: To the Editor:

title: Montgomery Ward Unit Sale
description: Montgomery Ward & Company said yesterday that it had appointed Salomon Brothers to review the possible sale of its Jefferson Ward discount-store division.

title: SANDINISTAS' TALKS WITH INDIANS FAIL
description: Peace talks between Government leaders and Nicaragua's Miskito Indians have collapsed after six months, negotiators for both sides said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel stunned, shocked and ashamed by what has happened. It is a night of shame for Liverpool.

title: REFORM OR RELIGION?
description: ''Taxes are what we pay for a civilized society.'' So Justice Holmes said in a Supreme Court opinion 80 years ago. I thought of his aphorism as I watched President Reagan talk about his tax ''revolution'' - and thought how Mr. Reagan came from another universe of values.

title: FERRARO, AT HUNTER GRADUATION, ASSAILS U.S. CUTS IN EDUCATION
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the unsuccessful 1984 Democratic candidate for Vice President, told graduates of Hunter College yesterday that higher education was becoming available to privileged classes only.

title: STAR FOR MONTCLAIR HAS WICKED PITCH
description: The pitch looks like a spitball. It starts toward the plate like a fastball, then drops straight down in front of the batter. ''It's an obscene pitch,'' said Kevin Cooney, the Montclair State baseball coach, adding that it was not a spitball.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CHEMICAL OUTBID FOR HOME STATE
description: An 11th-hour bid by a Cincinnati savings and loan association for the Home State Savings Bank was accepted by Ohio savings and loan officials yesterday. That ended the effort by the Chemical New York Corporation to establish a full-service commercial bank in the state.

title: U.S. FARM EXPORT PLAN IS WIDELY CRITICIZED
description: A new Reagan Administration program to subsidize farm exports has upset United States allies in Europe and has drawn an unexpectedly cool reaction from American farmers, who say it has already depressed prices for their wheat and other commodities.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MAY 30, 1985

title: Defense Dept. Civilians To Be Tested for Drugs
description: The Defense Department, which tests military personnel for drug abuse, is expanding the program to include civilian employees who hold ''critical jobs,'' officials said today.

title: HUSSEIN SAYS P.L.O. AGREES ON PARLEY WITH THE ISRAELIS
description: King Hussein said today that Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization were now in agreement on holding peace talks with Israel under the ''umbrella'' of an international conference.

title: An Agency Review
description: The American Hardware Supply Company is in the midst of an agency review, which is being conducted with the help of the Advertising Agency Register. The latest development is the announcement of four finalists: the two incumbents - W.B. Doner in Detroit and Marc & Company in Pittsburgh - and Wells, Rich, Greene and D'Arcy MacManus Masius, both in Chicago. Billings are put at $9.5 million.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $16,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $2,418,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ALTEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales figures represent oil and gas sales. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jets Drop Ramsey
description: Chuck Ramsey, the amateur magician who punted more than any Jets kicker ever, was dropped yesterday after a season in which his average had continued to hover at a mediocre level. The 33-year-old Ramsey, from his home Knoxville, Tenn., insisted that the dismissal followed his attempts over the years to be traded.

title: HOW TAXPAYERS CAN FIGURE WHAT THEY WOULD OWE UNDER REAGAN PLAN
description: With about 20 minutes' effort, taxpayers can estimate whether they would owe the Government more or less under what President Reagan describes as his ''revolutionary'' proposal to overhaul the income tax system.

title: Veto of Death Penalty Overridden by Senate
description: The State Senate today overrode Governor Cuomo's veto of a bill to restore the death penalty for certain murders.

title: SELECTING A BABY'S SEX: STILL NO CERTAIN METHOD
description: FOR most couples, pregnancy is a time of anticipation: Is it a boy or girl, is it healthy, who will it resemble? A small number of couples, however, want to take the mystery out of pregnancy: They want their child to be a particular sex, and they are willing to pay thousands of dollars, listen to anybody or try any method that promises to change the odds of conceiving a boy or girl.

title: Torres Confession Is Ruled Admissible for Murder Trial
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the confession of a suspect in the murder of a student actor last December could be used against him at his trial.

title: BRIEFS
description: Alcan Smelters and Chemicals Ltd., a unit of Alcan Aluminum Ltd., said construction had been slowed on its planned $1 billion aluminum shelter at Chicoutini, Quebec, because of current weakness in the aluminum industry.

title: STARTLING DUEL IN MEXICO: RULING PARTY COULD LOSE
description: No one is entirely sure who will win the election for Governor of the state of Sonora on July 7. In Mexico, that is historic.

title: MERCANTILE BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SHUTTLE LANDINGS SHIFTED COAST TO COAST
description: Space shuttles have been barred from routine landings at the Kennedy Space Center's runway at Cape Canaveral, Fla., until engineers can correct a flawed brake system.

title: REVISION OPPOSED BY OIL PRODUCERS
description: In preserving immediate writeoffs for intangible drilling costs and the percentage depletion allowance for small wells, President Reagan's tax plan restores some two-thirds of oil and gas preferences that would have been lost under the original Treasury proposal of November 1984.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Past Holds Key to Highways of Future
description: To the Editor:

title: W.C. Christianson Dies at 92; Judge on Nuremberg Tribunal
description: William C. Christianson, a Minnesotan who served as a judge at the Nuremberg war crime trials after World War II, died on Monday at a nursing home in Red Wing, Minn. He was 92 years old.

title: 2 Iranian Cities Raided; Ship Hit in Persian Gulf
description: Iraq said its warplanes struck the Iranian cities of Teheran and Tabriz today, and a West German cargo ship was hit by a rocket in the Persian Gulf in an apparent Iranian raid. No injuries were reported.

title: STAGE: 'CHILDHOOD,' FROM SARRAUTE
description: BY any standard, the writer Nathalie Sarraute endured a traumatic childhood: Her parents were divorced and remarried shortly after her birth in 1900, and the young girl soon found herself bouncing between two sets of parents, as well as between the two countries where they lived, Russia and France. Yet it's not the agonies of domestic conflict that shape Mrs. Sarraute's 1983 memoir, ''Childhood,'' which has now arrived at the Samuel Beckett Theater in a one-act stage adaptation starring Glenn Close. The real terror is language. ''Words surround me, constrain me, shackle me,'' writes Mrs. Sarraute in a typical line. Throughout ''Childhood,'' the words of adults are always crushing or imprisoning or striking or piercing the young Nathalie. Even the word ''happiness,'' when overheard by the heroine, comes as a violent blow.

title: Treasure Divers Recover $1 Million in 4 Days
description: Deep-sea divers today recovered more elaborate emerald and gold jewelry from the wreck of a Spanish galleon, bringing the haul of sunken treasure to nearly $1 million in the past four days, according to the company bringing up the treasure.

title: Herbalife Sets More Layoffs
description: Herbalife International, a diet-product and nutritional supplement sales company, has laid off 573 employees at its headquarters here and at its nine distribution centers around the country.

title: Money Talks
description: Baseball club owners met in New York yesterday to discuss the problem they seemed to be having of getting the players to understand the owners' concern about the game's economic status.

title: 3D FAMILY MEMBER HELD AS A SPY
description: A retired Navy lieutenant commander who taught antisubmarine tactics was arrested today and charged with participating in a Soviet spy ring that included his brother and nephew.

title: INDIA AND THE U.S.: A SPECIAL MOMENT
description: The Nehru family's visits to Washington have not been political successes. Even John F. Kennedy's enthusiasm for India was dampened by his encounter with Jawaharlal Nehru, and the 1971 visit of his daughter, the late Indira Gandhi, was described by Henry A. Kissinger as among the most unfortunate meetings Richard M. Nixon had with any foreign leader.

title: International Paper Plans Cuts
description: The International Paper Company said it had adopted a voluntary early retirement plan under which 1,000 of its 10,500 management workers would be eligible for retirement. The company added that it planned to reduce the size of its work force by an unspecified percentage following a review that would be completed by the end of the summer.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
ROSES OF ANY PLOT, URBAN OR SUBURBAN
description: THIS is the month for roses, and their myriad shades and blends of colors - pink, red, white, gold - are the gardener's pride right now. In spite of thorns, susceptibility to fungus diseases and the need for careful fertilizing, watering and pruning, the rose is considered by many to be the queen of flowers.

title: CABARET: DAVID SUMMERS
description: THE songs of Stephen Sondheim are so psychologically complex that anyone who sings an all-Sondheim program is bound to emphasize certain facets of his sensibility while ignoring others. David Summers, the theater and cabaret singer who has appeared in several Al Carmines musicals, has put together an evening of Sondheim songs that plays every Friday through the end of June at Jan Wallman's (28 Cornelia Street). Mr. Summers' point of view might be described as ebulliently objective.

title: $140 Million Issue Of Georgia Bonds
description: The Burke County Development Authority, in Georgia, is offering $140 million of 30-year pollution control revenue bonds through underwriters led by Robinson Humphrey/American Express Inc., an Atlanta-based securities firm.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Checking In
description: The distinguished-looking older gentleman in the pin-striped suit eating lunch at the Plaza Athenee Hotel yesterday took a long sip of his wine, looked around and smiled.

title: QUALITY OF ROADS IS SAID TO IMPROVE
description: After years of steady deterioration in road quality, repairs of the nation's major roadways are now keeping pace with decline, according to a report to Congress by the Department of Transportation.

title: GENERALS' IRON MAN IS HURT
description: Herschel Walker has gained 1,758 yards this season and more than 100 yards in each of the Generals' last eight games. The latter mark is a new record for professional football, exceeding the seven straight 100 yard-plus games turned in by Earl Campbell and O. J. Simpson in the National Football League.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY RECEIVES PLEDGE OF $10 MILLION
description: A $10 million grant to the New York Public Library, the largest in the institution's history, was pledged yesterday by the Vincent Astor Foundation.

title: Article 015835 -- No Title
description: Under President Reagan's tax proposal, business would pay more than $220 billion in extra taxes over the next five years as a result of curtailed depreciation allowances, a repeal of the investment credit and a ''recapture'' proposal.

title: 'THE GAY EIGHTIES,' A DOCUMENTARY
description: ONE of the more exasperating species of television is the documentary that tries to get by on good intentions. It addresses a worthy subject but does not engage it. An example of the form can be seen tonight at 8 o'clock on Channel 13. ''The Gay Eighties'' is a 30-minute report and discussion on the present state of homosexuals, and it glides along on liberal, tolerant, enlightened assumptions about ''sexual preference'' without pausing to examine them or the antagonism they encounter.

title: Suit in Ship Sinking Settled
description: The owners of a coal ship that sank in 1983, killing 31 people, have agreed to pay $5.1 million to the families of 14 men who died and to one of three men who survived. The settlement raises the amount of damages in the accident paid by Marine Transport Lines Inc., which owned the Marine Electric, to from $14 million to $15 million, Tom Rohrer, a lawyer representing the New York-based concern, said Sunday.

title: OPPOSITION TO APARTHEID IS URGED AT CITY COLLEGE
description: The South African novelist Nadine Gordimer told graduates of City College yesterday that they and other Americans should continue their opposition to apartheid and urge the United States Government to do likewise.

title: ROSES FOR ANY PLOT, URBAN OR SUBURBAN
description: CITY gardeners need not resist the tempting rose plants now in bloom at local nurseries.

title: Help Is on the Way for New York City School Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Worm Collecting Bill Voted in State Senate
description: Rejecting claims that worm hunting could promote child abuse, the State Senate passed a bill today that would allow children under age 16 to collect worms for a fee after 7 P.M.

title: Ruling Against Robins
description: A panel of Federal judges has rejected the A.H. Robins Company's efforts to move pretrial matters here for all pending Federal lawsuits on the Dalkon Shield intrauterine birth-control device. The seven-member Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation ruled that the 1,700 Federal suits should stay where they are, saying there was no need ''for disrupting the many Dalkon Shield actions.'' The pharmaceutical company distributed the Dalkon Shield from 1971 to mid-1974, when the device was pulled from the market after women began complaining of pelvic infections and other problems they said were associated with the use of the shield.

title: CALENDAR: WALKING TOURS
description: June Walks, New York Parks and Recreation Department, the Arsenal, Central Park, 212-397-3091.

title: SYLVESTER STALLONE'S HIT FORMULA
description: THE trailer for Sylvester Stallone's ''Rocky IV'' begins with a shot of Soviet feet.

title: SHEEHAN SEEKS 3D L.P.G.A.
description: Patty Sheehan, who starts her quest for a record third straight Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship Thursday, saw a Cincinnati chiropractor this afternoon in the hope that he could eliminate some of the aches in her upper back and neck that may have proved costly to her last week in Corning, N.Y.

title: Charles R. Elsen Dead; Opera Makeup Artist
description: Charles R. Elsen, a leading makeup and wig designer in opera, died of spinal meningitis Tuesday at New York University Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in New York.

title: HOME BEAT
description: SHE found them at a trade show in Florida and thought they might be right for her store. ''And I think they're funny,'' Blossom Deutschman said of the colorfully printed china plates, above.

title: Under Our Skins
description: As every diplomat hopes, there may be more than one way to skin a Russian policy. The United States managed to do it at least once, in 1951.

title: Irving Trust Appoints Securities Group Head
description: Madeleine D. Robinson keeps setting records at the Irving Trust Company, the nation's 20th-largest bank holding company.

title: HIGH INSURANCE FEES CURB SURGEONS UPSTATE
description: Neurosurgeons, obstetricians and orthopedic surgeons across upstate New York, both in groups and individually, are beginning to restrict their practices sharply because they say they can no longer afford malpractice insurance premiums.

title: Henry L. Miller, 66, Produced Voice of America Programs
description: Henry L. Miller, who produced, directed and announced radio programs in the Far East for the Voice of America, died of cancer May 22 at his home in McLean, Va. He was 66 years old.

title: EASTERN WEIGHS T.W.A. BID
description: Eastern Airlines is exploring whether it wants to make a bid for Trans World Airlines, Richard McGraw, the senior vice president of communications at Eastern, announced yesterday.

title: EATON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
People
description: Justin Harrington named senior vice president at Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos in Boston.

title: Apple Accord With China
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had reached an agreement to sell personal computers to China, with shipments expected to begin in four to six months.

title: GEMAYEL HAS NARROW ESCAPE AS HIS PALACE IS BOMBARDED
description: President Amin Gemayel was reported to have narrowly escaped injury today when artillery shells and rockets struck the presidential palace in the predominantly Christian suburb of Baabda.

title: GRIESA ASSAILS WESTWAY RECORDS
description: Judge Thomas P. Griesa charged again yesterday that the Army Corps of Engineers had failed to maintain adequate records of the procedure that led to granting a landfill permit for Westway.

title: Southwestern Link Set With Mustang
description: The Southwestern Energy Company and the Mustang Fuel Corporation, continuing the natural gas industry's consolidation trend, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge their companies in a deal valued at $200 million.

title: Carteret Savings Picks Muir Cornelius Moore
description: Muir Cornelius Moore, long a specialist in financial advertising, has been named agency by the Carteret Savings and Loan Association of Morristown, N.J. The budget could come to $4 million, according to M.C.M.

title: IN GENEVA TODAY, AMERICANS AGAIN FACE TOUGH BARGAINERS
description: Thirty-five years ago, an American diplomat who had spent three years at the United Nations together with Andrei A. Gromyko decided that a heart-to-heart talk might break through a deadlock that had persisted between them.

title: REAGAN'S TAX PLAN MEETS RESISTANCE ON SOME ELEMENTS
description: Resistance to President Reagan's ambitious plan to redesign the Federal income tax system started to take shape today as Congressional critics and lobbyists protested particular elements.

title: MID PACIFIC AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MUSIC: HAMPSHIRE QUARTET
description: THE Hampshire String Quartet is only two years old, but in that time it has become known for its performances of 20th-century music. At Symphony Space (Broadway and 95th Street) on Tuesday night, in a concert presented by Musicians' Accord, the ensemble offered premieres of recent works by Laura Kaminsky and Richard Kassel, artistic directors of Musicians' Accord, along with performances of Webern's atypical ''Langsamer Satz'' (''Slow Movement'') of 1905 and George Crumb's ''Black Angels.''

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORPORATION-Alfred Brittain 3d, officer, sold 11,037 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 16,144 shares.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid April 19.

title: UTILIZATION OF TRUSTS FOR LOWERING TAXES WOULD BE CURTAILED
description: President Reagan's tax proposal would curtail parents' use of their children as tax shelters, even for worthy purposes.

title: IN BRITAIN, NEW MAZES ARE A LINK TO ANCIENT TIMES
description: Britain is reputed to have more mazes than any other country in the world and the number is suddenly increasing. A Beatles-inspired water maze shaped like an apple with a yellow submarine at the center was one of the hits at last year's International Garden Festival in Liverpool. Kentwell Hall in Long Melford, Suffolk, is celebrating the 500th anniversary of the start of Tudor rule this year by converting its graveled central courtyard into a complex maze representing the Tudor rose in variously colored brick. A path maze designed for last summer's Bath Festival will be completed this spring, and the winning design of a maze competition that attracted more than 500 entries has been constructed at the Breamore Countryside Museum in Hampshire.

title: Tennessee Yield At 9 1/8% Maximum
description: The Health, Education and Housing Facility Board of Shelby County, Tenn., is offering $125 million of refunding revenue bonds for Methodist Health Systems Inc. with a maximum yield of 9 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2014 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: MEASURES WOULD LESSEN APPEAL OF TAX SHELTERS
description: Real estate and other tax shelters would be dealt severe blows by President Reagan's tax revision plan, but shelters nevertheless would probably remain a prominent part of the American investment scene.

title: Interest Rates Close Mixed
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, as market participants said there were no developments to significantly strengthen the case of those who expect rates to decline further, or of those who expect rates to rise.

title: SCIENTISTS COMPARE 'STAR WARS' TO ABM DEBATES
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the National Academy of Sciences in March that ''too often in recent years'' scientists have spoken ''on behalf of political ideas that unfortunately are neither responsible nor particularly brilliant,'' he was stirring a hornet's nest in the arms control field, where prominent scientists have taken a lead role against Reagan Administration policies.

title: RHODE ISLAND MOTHER FREED
description: A woman who said her 4-month old baby has been kidnapped but was later charged with murdering the infant was released from jail today on $100,00 bail. The woman, Donna J. Richard, was arrested May 10 and was awaiting grand jury action on a charge that she killed her daughter, Jerri Ann Richard.

title: STAGE: 'MISS UNIVERSAL'
description: THE walls of the Performing Garage are decorated with skulls and staring eyes, as in a chamber of horrors, a characteristic habitat for Richard Foreman, author, director and designer of ''Miss Universal Happiness.'' In text as well as design, the production is not without grotesqueries, but it is primarily intended as a political play. As such, it is a novelty for Mr. Foreman, who, in his previous works, has been oceans removed from global issues.

title: FLORIDA PRISONER DIES FOR SLAYINGS
description: Marvin Francois, sentenced to death for killing six people when his mask fell off and exposed his face in a robbery, was executed today in the electric chair.

title: BIG SERVICE CUTS FEARED IN ALBANY
description: State and local governments in New York would come under fierce public pressure to cut their own taxes, and the services the taxes pay for, if President Reagan's Federal tax-revision plan passes unaltered, top state officials said today.

title: A SMALL BAKER MOVES INTO THE BIG TIME
description: A baking company that refuses to use preservatives and has yet to find a machine that can spoon out the thick dough for its chocolate chip cookie recipe might seem to have limited growth potential. The cookies, brownies, slices of pound cake and other assorted ''munchies'' made by The Well-Bred Loaf Inc., however, are popping up in delicatessens and greengrocers from one end of Manhattan to the other.

title: North and South Korea Agree to Meet Again
description: North and South Korean officials formally closed their Red Cross-sponsored conferences today, saying they had made progress, and agreed to meet again on Aug. 27 in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang.

title: REAGAN'S TAX PLAN: THE KEY DEMOCRAT
description: Two men went before the television cameras Tuesday night to promote their commitment to building a new and more workable income tax system. One was President Reagan. The other was ''Congressmen Dan Rostenkowski from Chicago,'' as he introduced himself.

title: Israeli Legislators Bar Lebanon War Inquiry
description: Parliament defeated motions offered today to set up a commission of inquiry into events surrounding the invasion of Lebanon three years ago.

title: CASEY PLACES COMMUNICATIONS INTERESTS IN A TRUST
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, disclosed today that he had placed in trust his financial interests in a communications conglomerate that wants to acquire the American Broadcasting Company.

title: Farm Credit Rates Set
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation announced interest rates yesterday for three new bond issues totaling $2.613 billion.

title: SCIENTISTS EXAMINE A TV CREATURE: THEMSELVES
description: In the movies their deeds tend to hurt other people. In novels they wield strange forms of radiation. On prime-time television they have the highest mortality rate of any professional group, getting killed more often than soldiers, private detectives or police officers.

title: JUDGE ENJOINS TOP REAGAN OFFICIALS FROM DEFYING CONTRACTING LAW
description: A Federal district judge has ordered Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, to comply with a law authorizing the General Accounting Office to review disputed contracts.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
OPERA: SPOLETO FESTIVAL'S 'FANCIULLA'
description: The opera world today takes easily in stride some difficult works that could have been done only under the most special circumstances a generation ago. But a solid Puccini performance, which used to be taken for granted, is now the exception rather than the rule. Given the current rarity of convincing singers for the bigger Puccini roles, it is somewhat surprising that the Spoleto Festival should have planned, or gone through with, ''La Fanciulla del West'' as its centerpiece for 1985 except on the basis of a first-rate cast. Tuesday's performance here (the second of four in Charleston, with more to follow in Italy) was excellent in several ways, but satisfaction in that excellence was limited by ineffective performances in the central roles.

title: INVENTION, DESIGN, ENGINEERING ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in September 1984.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After a tax credit of $518,000. c-Net income.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORGANIZATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. Translation is at the March 31 rate of exchange; 1 pound equals $1.24. The company is listed on the Toronto and London stock exchanges.

title: Move Made On Seabrook
description: Six partners in the Seabrook nuclear project said yesterday that they were initiating an arbitration proceeding against a smaller partner that defaulted on its share of construction payments two weeks ago.

title: THE SPIRIT OF JAPAN, 20 MILES FROM DETROIT
description: The Governor of Michigan took a tree sprig from an elaborately garbed Shinto minister and laid it on a small altar. Then he bowed deeply twice, clapped his hands two times and bowed again before walking away.

title: Against Drunken Drivers
description: What people drink before they get into their automobiles was the issue. What they drink before they leave the breakfast table, however, shared the spotlight at City Hall yesterday.

title: Required Reading;   Women's Work
description: Excerpts from a speech by Ann F. Lewis, national director of Americans for Democratic Action, before a recent meeting of the National Committee for Pay Equity:

title: TANGO: SUSANA RINALDI
description: ARGENTINA'S tangos are songs about having the heart, humor and courage to survive adversity. In her New York debut Tuesday at Carnegie Hall, the Argentine singer Susana Rinaldi presented tangos not as dance music, but as short dramatic vignettes; she sang and acted tangos that were wry, defiant, elegant and doleful.

title: HERS
description: THREE years ago, in the hope of earning a living, I took a job teaching writing at a small women's college. By my first week, the dean had underscored the importance of sound instruction. A colleague, citing a report on the importance of expository writing from the ''Chronicle of Higher Education,'' assured me that my work had ''profound pedagogical reverberations.'' But I did not let that stop me. In fact, I even anticipated reading some of my students' published work one day, knowing that I had contributed in some small way to their achievements.

title: WILLIAMS-SONOMA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Chairman Resigns At Gulf Resources
description: Alan E. Clore resigned yesterday as chairman of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, saying he wanted to devote more time to his other business interests. Separately, the oil and gas company said it had won a proxy battle with a group of international investors for control of its board.

title: FURNITURE MADE IN CHICAGO ON VIEW
description: To Carl Sandburg, Chicago was the ''City of Big Shoulders'' that stacked wheat, handled freight and played hog butcher for the world. What the poet did not mention, though, is that the city made furniture as well, enjoying several decades as the country's furniture capital.

title: Martha Slept Here
description: One of the places that George Washington really did sleep was at 508 Cameron Street, Alexandria, Va., just across what was then the Patawmack from the steamy, mosquito-infested, feverish swampland that was later to be named for him. He and his wife, the former Martha Dandridge Custis, kept a wartime home in Alexandria.

title: First Pennsylvania Buys Warrants
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation said it had reacquired the last of some 20 million stock warrants once held by the Federal Government, effectively completing a $1.5 billion rescue plan.

title: National Distillers Sets Its Brand Assignments
description: Yesterday, the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, which last Wednesday announced that Laurence, Charles & Free would be joining Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn on its agency roster, released the brand assignments yesterday.

title: LONG WAY ROUND TO VICTORY AT INDY
description: Miles and miles separated the yellow taxicab in Central Park from victory lane in Indianapolis, and years and years separated Danny Sullivan from his previous life. The photographers crowded round the cab that had been commandeered for the occasion. They asked Sullivan, the Indianapolis 500 champion and now-famous former New York City cabby, to wave from the driver's seat, and they directed him to the back seat, to sit back and put his feet up.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: EXPERT CALLS SPORTS VIOLENCE PART OF A CHAIN OF AGGRESSION
description: An expert on sports-related violence said yesterday that the riot by soccer fans in Brussels was the product of a ''vicious cycle of aggressive events that perpetuate themselves.''

title: Series to Be at Night
description: All World Series games will be scheduled at night this year because ABC has exercised a clause in baseball's television contract.

title: 2 NEW KODAK OFFICE SYSTEMS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday announced a major move into the lucrative office automation market. The company introduced two labor-saving systems for documents: one to retrieve microfilm images from a remote computer terminal and another to create and print high-quality text-and-graphics documents at one work station.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Yamani Asks A Price Cut
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, has called for a reduction in the OPEC price of heavy crude oil but says the price of light crude oil should be left unchanged.

title: SEAT-BELT BILL IS GIVEN FINAL APPROVAL BY CONNECTICUT SENATE
description: The State Senate, by a vote of 19 to 17, today gave final legislative approval to a measure requiring people in the front seats of cars in Connecticut to wear seat belts.

title: REGGIE GOES 'TO GIMMICKS'
description: In the visitors' clubhouse at Yankee Stadium last night, each of the other California Angels had one locker, but in the far corner Reggie Jackson had been accorded two lockers. In one, his uniform hung neatly. In the other were his sunglasses, blue, collarless shirt, tan slacks, tan windbreaker and tan loafers. The slugger who had justified his nickname of Mr. October as a Yankee had returned to the scene of some of his most famous home runs, just as he had returned to stay in his Fifth Avenue apartment while the Angels were here.

title: Spielberg to Direct Film Of 'The Color Purple'
description: Steven Spielberg will produce and direct a film adaptation of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel ''The Color Purple,'' featuring Whoopi Goldberg and Danny Glover, Warner Brothers has announced.

title: HENRY GUERLAC
description: Henry Guerlac, a Cornell University professor of the history of science for 29 years, died today at Tompkins Community Hospital.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THURSDAY, MAY 30, 1985

title: Chess Rematch Is Now Set For Moscow Starting Sept. 2
description: The head of the International Chess Federation said today that the world title rematch between Anatoly Karpov, the champion, and Gary Kasparov, the challenger, will start in Moscow on Sept. 2.

title: U.S. PANEL VOTES TO END SHUTDOWN OF A REACTOR AT THREE MILE ISLAND
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 4 to 1 today to lift the order that has kept the undamaged reactor at Three Mile Island shut down since its twin was severely damaged in a nuclear accident in March 1979.

title: Coal Truck Driver Slain; Killing Linked to Strike
description: A coal truck driver was shot to death today and several others were injured in violence linked to a seven-month strike by the United Mine Workers against concerns that failed to endorse a union contract.

title: YEOMAN IN SPY CASE VIEWED AS 'DEDICATED' TO HIS FATHER
description: Michael Walker is seen by his friends as an ordinary young man who seemed more interested in activities like surfing and dancing than espionage.

title: FIRST CAPITAL HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter were not comparable with those of the year-ago quarter because of the acquisition of the Pilgrim Group on May 1, 1984.

title: IRT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VANITY FAIR PUBLISHER IS REPLACED
description: DAVID O'BRASKY, publisher of Conde Nast's Vanity Fair magazine since late 1983, has been asked to resign and has been replaced by G. Douglas Johnston, ad director of the publication since it was resurrected.

title: Using Light To Compute
description: ANYONE who has raced to catch a flight at Logan Airport at rush hour can sympathize with the plight of an electron, trying to get from one computer chip to another.

title: Nicklaus Updates Links With Past
description: Jack Nicklaus stared at his golf ball in the sand, then lifted his gaze along the 12-foot-high wall of grass in front of him. ''Who in the world would ever build such a deep bunker?'' he said.

title: Hill Holliday
description: Boston's Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos has scored a New York office victory, tapped to be advertising and promotion agency for WOR-TV, Channel 9. Additionally it will do national trade advertising (advertising for advertising) for the RKO General television stations. The billings, which formerly went through the Gallagher Group, are $2.5 million.

title: CLASSIC HOLOCAUST WORK EXPANDED TO 3 VOLUMES
description: Nazi Germany was obsessed with bureaucratic details, but it somehow never adopted an overall budget for its campaign to exterminate the Jews of Europe. Instead, financing was allocated through various agencies, so that, for example, the German railway system helped cover its costs by charging the SS the price of a one-way fare for each deportee.

title: Thrift Unit Accord
description: After six years of litigation, the Home Owners Federal Savings and Loan Association has agreed to pay more than $600,000 to 1,200 home mortgage borrowers whose interest rates were raised. The settlement also means the mortgage rates will drop to their original levels, which averaged 6 percent, for about 650 borrowers whose mortgages are still in force. ''The bank still believes it had the right to raise the mortgage rates to an average of 9 percent in 1979 under the agreements,'' Lenore S. Treiman, first vice president at Home Owners, said.

title: RIOT IN BRUSSELS AT SOCCER GAME LEAVES 41 DEAD
description: At least 41 people were killed and more than 250 injured Wednesday night when rioting broke out among fans before the start of a soccer match here between British and Italian teams.

title: COST OF OWNING A HOME IN THE AREA WOULD RISE
description: Owners of homes in New York City and its suburbs would see their overall housing costs rise if President Reagan's tax simplification plan is adopted, although prospective buyers would be pleased by the resulting drop in prices, a number of real estate experts said yesterday.

title: UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTARE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Coach in a Hole
description: Lee Fowler, an assistant basketball coach at Memphis State, gave an interview to The Nashville Tennessean not long ago in which he defended Coach Dana Kirk but described the troubles in which the program finds itself as ''the pits.'' Kirk didn't think he needed defending, however, and now he has suggested publicly that Fowler might be in the wrong line of work. ''Another conversation like that,'' the coach says, ''and Lee will be working for The Tennessean instead of Memphis State.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 30, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE STAGE: 'JUBILEE! BLACK THEATER FESTIVAL'
description: THE American Place Theater plans to make ''Jubilee! A Black Theater Festival'' an annual event. Those are plans that ought to prosper, for the two one-man plays and a snappy musical review of black history in this first presentation of the festival provide a showcase for some wonderful writing, singing and acting. Each piece takes up some painful moments in the nation's history but they are not somber; you come away from this festival jubilant and hopeful.

title: Allied Names Chairman
description: The board of the Allied Stores Corporation yesterday elected Thomas M. Macioce chairman, in addition to his present post as chief executive. John T. Cullen, senior executive vice president, was elected vice chairman and chief merchandising officer, and James A. Walsh was elected president and chief operating officer. Mr. Walsh, who succeeds Mr. Macioce as president, has been executive vice president.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,055,000 on the sale of investment. c-Net income which includes income from discontinued operations of $261,000 for the quarter and $480,000 for the 6 months.

title: Pickens Loses Once-Crucial Vote
description: A shareholder vote that at one time was crucial to T. Boone Pickens in his now-abandoned quest to take control of the Unocal Corporation went against the Texas oilman, Unocal said yesterday. The California oil company, which reached a settlement with Mr. Pickens last week, said that 61 percent of voting shareholders had rejected the Pickens proposal to adjourn the annual meeting until June 28.

title: NAVY CANCELS AN ORDER FOR COSTLY SPARE PARTS
description: Navy officials said today that they had canceled a purchasing agreement for spare parts with the Grumman Aerospace Corporation that led to the purchases of $660 ashtrays and $404 wrenches for Navy airplanes.

title: Sharp Fall In Yields Continues
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds again took a sharp drop in the week ended yesterday.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Stock Prices Mixed in Dull Trading
description: Wall Street ignored the tax revisions proposed by President Reagan yesterday as the stock market closed mixed in a session that was dull except for a new burst of takeover rumors Stocks that took part in the buyout rumors included CBS, R.J. Reynolds, Nabisco Brands, Trans World Airlines and Sea-Land Corporation.

title: Lloyd, McEnroe Win on Day of Upsets
description: Chris Evert Lloyd kept pace today with her main rival, moving into the third round of the French Open tennis championships.

title: ONE WAY OR ANOTHER, PLAN WILL TOUCH JUST ABOUT EVERYONE
description: While many economists are not convinced that President Reagan's tax plan will have the dramatic effect on the overall economy that the President has predicted it would, the impact of its proposals on certain industries, sectors and individuals is expected to be substantial.

title: BLOCK SELLING SOME ASSETS TO CUT BACK HIS DEBTS
description: Like other struggling farmers, Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block has been selling land and other real estate assets to reduce debts and interest costs, according to a financial disclosure statement made public here today.

title: Kay Campbell Is Dead at 80; Actress on 'All My Children'
description: Kay Campbell, who for the past 15 years played Kate Martin in the daytime television series ''All My Children,'' died Monday at Greenwich Hospital of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. She was 80 years old.

title: Chevron Capital
description: Chevron Capital U.S.A. is offering $300 million of 10 3/4 percent, 10-year notes at a price of 99.576 to yield 10.82 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The securities are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's.

title: Sri Lanka-India Talks Planned Next Week
description: President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India will hold talks next week on the island nation's deepening ethnic crisis, officials said today.

title: DEFENSE CONTENDS DRUGS AND DEPRESSION LED MRS. VON BULOW TO CAUSE HER COMAS
description: Claus von Bulow's chief lawyer told the jury today that Martha von Bulow, addicted to drugs and depressed by her husband's infidelity, had brought on herself the two comas her husband is accused of causing.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
False Alarm
description: Panic.

title: A MODERNIST MONUMENT OPENING TO PUBLIC
description: THE Gropius house, a symbol of modern architecture in the United States since it was built in 1938, opens for the first time to the public on June 1. For many years the Gropius family informally shared the white, geometric, flat-roofed house, surprisingly modest and personal inside, with visitors and professionals. It was a model of the new architecture Walter Gropius brought to the United States from Germany, and through a bequest of Gropius's widow, Ise, who died in 1983, to the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities, it will continue in a similar role, furnished much as it was when the architect lived in it.

title: 13 ARE ARRESTED IN BRIBE INQUIRY ON COURT CASES
description: Thirteen people - including two city marshals and three court employees -were arrested yesterday for giving or receiving bribes to expedite eviction processes in the landlord-tenant division of Civil Court in Brooklyn.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robert Brennan, the owner of Garden State Park, has purchased one of 40 shares in the world champion pacer Dragon's Lair from the syndicator Lou Guida for $300,000. . . . Ron Greschner had his shoulder operation yesterday, and after the 90-minute surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital, Dr. Barton Nisonson, the Ranger team physician, said ''everything went fine.'' Greschner, who missed 31 games with injuries to the left shoulder during the season, is to begin strenuous weight training in three to four weeks and is expected to be ready for training camp in September.

title: SOTO'S TWO-HITTER DEFEATS CUBS, 1-0
description: Mario Soto, the ace of the Cincinnati Reds' staff, fresh from a four-day rest, baffled the Chicago Cubs with his slider, allowing just two hits in a 1-0 victory. It came the day after the Cubs had amassed 19 hits but had blown two huge leads in a 13-11 loss.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
ASIAN-AMERICANS QUESTION IVY LEAGUE'S ENTRY POLICIES
description: Two years ago Prof. Uwe Reinhardt first questioned whether Princeton was limiting the number of Asian-American students it would accept. He was serving on a graduate school admissions committee at the time.

title: METS SCORE 4 IN 8TH AND WIN
description: The Mets opened an eight-game trip to California today by slumbering in the sun through seven innings of one-hit pitching by Dave LaPoint of the San Francisco Giants. But they revived mightily in the eighth, peppered three pitchers with five hits, pulled a double steal, scored four runs and stormed to a 4-3 victory.

title: RYMER CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After tax credits of $903,000 for the quarter and $2,080,000 for the 6 months and includes gains from the sale of assets of $173,000, or 8 cents a share, and $583,000, or 26 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After tax credits of $502,000 for the quarter and $1,296,000 for the 6 months.

title: PLAN TO PUT HOMELESS IN TRAILERS SETS OFF DEBATE
description: The Koch administration's proposal to put homeless families in trailers was the subject of heated debate yesterday as several elected officials opposed the idea and said traditional apartments could be renovated for less.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Substitute Substitutes
description: When budget time comes around and the Board of Estimate holds hearings, even its surrogates use surrogates.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: When Edmund Halley's Comet comes around, the world seems to tilt. During its last appearence in 1910, there were reports of heart attacks and suicides, wild parties and a sudden penchant for prayer. One man, wide-eyed, even claimed he was chased by the comet's tail.

title: CURB ON WRITE-OFFS MAY SPUR FIGHT
description: Companies would no longer be permitted tax write-offs for entertaining clients at Broadway shows, and deductions for business meals would be limited under President Reagan's tax plan.

title: Ode to the No. 1 Poet
description: There is no poet laureate of the United States, but each year the Library of Congress does effectively designate a No. 1 American Poet. The poet gets a clumsy title and a stipend of $35,000 in exchange for a year's service.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Apple Computer Inc. has appointed Jean-Louis Gasee director of marketing, succeeding Michael Murray, who was named vice president of business development.

title: RACKS TO KEEP MAGAZINES NEAT
description: ORGANIZING magazines can be done in several ways. An oak magazine rack with dowel sides is available at Conran's. Twenty-two inches high, 9 1/2 inches wide and 12 1/2 inches deep, it costs $29.95. Conran's has two New York City locations: 160 East 54th Street and 2-8 Astor Place (Eighth Street and Broadway).

title: Hughes Trims Oil Rig Figure
description: The Hughes Tool Company, which originally predicted an increase in oil drilling activity this year, has lowered its 1985 estimate again.

title: Teamsters at Yosemite Vote For Contract, Ending Strike
description: Teamsters have voted to accept a contract with a concessionaire at Yosemite National Park to end the first strike in the park's history.

title: DON'T BAN WINE AND BEER ADS
description: A misguided national drive is under way to try to persuade Congress to ban advertising of wine and beer on radio and television. Censorship is always risky, and any proposal to curb lawful advertising must rest on a solidly factual foundation. This drive is not built upon one.

title: FIVE OPERATIONS FAIL TO STOP RUNNER
description: Leann Warren is a record-breaking runner. She is blue-eyed, blond-haired and slim at 5 feet 5 1/2 inches and 105 pounds, but don't look at her knees.

title: TURK TELLS HOW HE GAVE A GUN TO AGCA
description: A Turkish defendant in the trial of eight men in a purported conspiracy to shoot Pope John Paul II described today how, four days before the 1981 shooting, he delivered the weapon to the Pope's assailant in a restaurant near a Milan train station.

title: Pratt & Whitney Pact
description: Pratt & Whitney Canada Inc., the jet engine subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation, said it had signed a licensing agreement with Rolls-Royce Turbomeca Ltd. to build an advanced technology military helicopter engine. The engine, designed by England's Rolls-Royce Ltd. and France's Turbomeca S.A., is being aimed at Pentagon helicopter engine markets now dominated by Pratt & Whitney's major rival, the General Electric Company.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a gain of $657,000 from a licensing agreement. c-Net loss

title: Chaney Stays as Coach
description: The San Diego Clippers made it official. Don Chaney, the former assistant who took over as interim coach after the dismissal of Jim Lynam in March, was named coach for next season.

title: Scalping the Bald
description: Hope sprouts strongly enough unaided; when fertilized with greed or vanity, nothing can trample or blight it. Consider Minoxidil, a drug approved to treat high blood pressure, but with a hair-raising side effect.

title: REPORT ON PRESERVATION OF ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: IT is not news that some animal species are endangered; television has programs about that all the time. ''Innovation,'' the weekly science series, does something slightly different. In ''Saving a Species,'' it examines how various species, even if they never again will flourish, at least may be preserved. The program, a rebroadcast, will be seen on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight.

title: $1 Million Campaign To Extol Italian Pasta
description: This autumn the New York market will be treated to a $1 million multimedia advertising campaign that will be promoting imported Italian pastas to a growingly pasta-conscious citizenery.

title: PAPANDREOUS'S FOE IN VOTE ON SUNDAY SAYS GREEKS ARE OPPRESSED
description: The opposition candidate in Greece's national elections Sunday asserted tonight that the Greek people were yearning for an alternative to the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, whose policies he said had left them ''deeply worried.''

title: ANALYSTS SCAN I.B.M. OUTLOOK
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation, the kingpin of the computer industry, continues to get high marks from most industry analysts. But some earnings estimates for the company have been trimmed recently, and only last week George Elling, who follows I.B.M. for Oppenheimer & Company, said that ''the second half of 1985 could fall somewhat short of what Wall Street anticipates.''

title: Seventh Victim of Disease
description: An unidentified woman hospitalized in ''extremely critical'' condition today was confirmed as the seventh victim of an outbreak of legionnaire's disease that has already killed two people, officials said. Seven victims were infected with the bacteria at an April 27 church banquet at the Airport Hilton Inn in the Detroit suburb of Romulus.

title: QUED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Alcan Canada Sets Changes
description: The Aluminum Company of Canada, the principal operating subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd., will streamline and restructure its senior management, Alcan Canada said today.

title: War on Seas Different From War in the Camps
description: To the Editor:

title: 'OLD-FASHIONED FAITH' IN RAPE CASE
description: The Rev. Carl M. Nannini remembers it happened just after his wife read a passage from the Old Testament to Cathleen Crowell Webb. The Scripture was Leviticus. ''If a soul sin, and commit a trespass against the Lord, and lie unto his neighbor,'' Mrs. Nannini read, then ''all that about which he hath sworn falsely, he shall even restore it.''

title: Save the Thrifts From Bad Old Days
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN FOR GLOBAL ECONOMIC STABILITY UNDER WAY
description: The Senate and House, which have both voted to reduce the projected Federal budget deficit next year by $56 billion, have set in place the first stage of a plan endorsed by leading industrial nations to get greater international economic stability.

title: Cordero in Switch
description: The game of musical jockeys picked up tempo yesterday when Angel Cordero, who rode Spend a Buck to victory in the Kentucky Derby, was named to ride Chief's Crown in the Belmont Stakes June 8. Cordero, who became available for the assignment when Spend a Buck was taken out of the Belmont because of his tough victory in the Jersey Derby on Monday, replaced Don MacBeth, who was dropped from Chief's Crown for the Belmont after having been criticized for his ride in the Preakness. Chief's Crown, the favorite in both the Derby and the Preakness, finished third in the Derby and second to Tank's Prospect in the Preakness.

title: REYNOLDS NABISCO BID IS REPORTED
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's second-largest cigarette maker and operator of the vast Kentucky Fried Chicken chain, has offered to pay more than $5 billion in cash for Nabisco Brands Inc., Wall Street sources reported yesterday.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,144,000, or 26 cents a share, resulting from the increased carrying value of Emerson's investment in two medical electronics operations.

title: Screenwriter to Appear At Showing of His Film
description: The screenwriter Lester Cole, who was among a group of Hollywood artists blacklisted during the McCarthy era, will appear at a screening of his 1944 film ''None Shall Escape'' tonight at 8:20 at the Thalia, Broadway and 95th Street. Mr. Cole was one of the ''Hollywood 10,'' who were convicted in 1948 for contempt of Congress for refusal to divulge their political affiliations before the House Un-American Activities Committee.

title: Australia Will Pay For Hole in Picasso Oil
description: Australia will compensate Pablo Picasso's daughter Mariana for a hole an art gallery official's screwdriver put in one of her father's paintings.

title: MORE HAZARDOUS NITRATE FOUND IN WATER SUPPLY
description: Concentrations of potentially hazardous nitrate have increased in the nation's underground water supply, according to findings made public today by the United States Geological Survey.

title: LIBERALS IN SPLIT ON CANDIDATES IN MAYOR RACE
description: The dissension-ridden Liberal Party split yesterday over a mayoral candidate as the faction that claims control of the party in New York City endorsed City Council President Carol Bellamy in the race.

title: BANK BUILDING & EQUIPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Fun and Games For Older Folks
description: With so many sets of quadrennial competitions already spread across the planet, another might seem superfluous. But another is indeed on its way.

title: President Chosen By Borden
description: Borden Inc. yesterday named Romeo J. Ventres, an executive vice president and president of its chemical division, president and chief operating officer, effective July 1.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $896,000.

title: And Yet the Slaughter In El Salvador Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: Storer Election Tally Ruling
description: Storer Communications Inc., retaining control of the company, has seated a newly elected board after failing to convince a Federal judge that shareholders' votes were miscalculated. Storer contended it should have received six, instead of five, seats on the nine-member board, and obtained a temporary injunction Friday from an Ohio state court.

title: Ad Page Decline
description: Magazine members of the Publishers Information Bureau collectively showed a 1.7 percent decline in ad pages in April, compared with April a year ago. The total came to 14,185. Thanks to advertising rate increases, however, the revenue side of the books showed an uptick of 8.7 percent, to $468.1 million for the month.

title: BALLET: CYNTHIA HARVEY AS CINDERELLA
description: ''CINDERELLA'' returned to American Ballet Theater's repertory on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Prokofiev's score, conducted by Paul Connelly, sounded as lovely as ever, and the production, designed by Santo Loquasto and choreographed by Mikhail Baryshnikov and Peter Anastos, gave balletgoers lots to look at. The scenery was ornate, the costumes elaborate and the choreography was crammed with steps.

title: Chevron-AGV
description: The Chevron Corporation said it has agreed to sell the Gulf Oil Company building in Pittsburgh to AGV Enterprises of New York.

title: Doyle Dane Displays Ads for Blood Program
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach yesterday displayed the TV and print advertising it created as a voluntary effort for the Greater New York Blood Program.

title: Storm Hides Mt. St. Helens
description: A new storm carrying snow again hid rumbling Mount St. Helens today, the fifth day of an alert signaling the volcano's impending eruption. The large storm front kept disappointed geologists from observing and measuring the swelling lava dome in the crater of the 8,365-foot peak, a United States Forest Service spokesman said.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Finale of the two-game series. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Giants, at San Francisco. WOR-TV has decided to broadcast this finale of the two-game series to make up for a spring game the station was supposed to cover but was rained out. (Television - Channel 9, 3 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 3 P.M.) Basketball Celtics vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Boston, second game of four-of-seven N.B.A. championship series. The Lakers will try to recover from the 148-114 beating on Monday in the series opener. (Television - Channel 2, 9 P.M.) Hockey Oilers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Edmonton, Alberta, 9 P.M. Fifth game of four-of-seven Stanley Cup championship series. The Oilers lead, three games to one, and can win their second straight Stanley Cup with a victory. (Television - USA Network, 9 P.M.) Tennis French Open, at Paris. Fourth day of tournament that runs through June 9. Golf Ladies P.G.A. Championship, at King's Island, Ohio, opening round. Patty Sheehan is trying for her third straight title. She successfully defended her 1983 title last year, shooting a record 16-under-par 272 for a 10-stroke victory. Kemper Open, at Bethedsda, Md., opening round. Long Island Golfers Association Open Championship, at Cedar Brook Golf Club, second day. Harness Racing Yonkers Raceway, 8 P.M. Workaholic, the top 2-year-old trotting colt last year, makes his 1985 debut in one of the two divisions of the New York Sire Stakes, the second on an 11-race program.

title: AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: PROSECUTOR ACCUSES OWNERS IN BLAZE AT GREAT ADVENTURE
description: A prosecutor charged today that the owners of the Great Adventure amusement park had caused eight deaths in a fire last year by operating a ''tinderbox'' attraction without sprinklers or smoke detectors.

title: Stalking the Urban Bird for Fun and Profit
description: Aelred Geis's mother does gratis field work at the Federal trough.

title: CHILD-ABUSE UNIT CHECKING ROLLS FOR PRIORITY CASES
description: The cases of all neglected or abused children that are being handled by the city's Office of Special Services for Children are under review to determine which children should be given more protection, agency officials said yesterday.

title: THE MATCH GOES ON AND THE ITALIANS ARE VICTORIOUS
description: Millions of television viewers across Western Europe were able to follow horrifying footage tonight of Liverpool soccer fans assaulting their Italian counterparts at a stadium in Brussels, and then live coverage of the match.

title: ON CAMPAIGN TRAIL, SHAPIRO FIELDS QUESTIONS ON HIS AGE
description: Wherever he goes on his campaign for the gubernatorial nomination in next Tuesday's Democratic primary, Peter Shapiro runs into questions about his age.

title: IF THE U.S. BACKS REBELS
description: Proxy wars in the third world are in a novel phase. The United States has often supported governments - in Vietnam, for example, or El Salvador - against pro-Soviet insurgents. Today, the shoe is on the other foot: in several parts of the world, America is supporting rebels against governments backed by Moscow. This is not necessarily a bad thing - indeed, in some cases it may be a good idea - but we must be prepared for the possibility that any of these conflicts will get out of hand.

title: WARNER AMEX BID CONFIRMED
description: Time Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. confirmed yesterday that they had made a joint bid for Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., among indications that the deal could be completed as early as next week.

title: Houston Gas and Internorth Suits
description: Internorth Inc. and the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, two big gas pipeline companies that have announced an agreement to merge, said that they had reached a settlement of lawsuits involving the Valero Energy Corporation. On May 16, Internorth and Houston Natural filed suit against Valero after Valero threatened to try to block Internorth's $2.3 billion offer to buy Houston Natural.

title: Renault Plans 20% Job Cut
description: Renault, the state-owned car maker, is planning to eliminate 21,000 jobs, or more than 20 percent of its French work force, by the end of 1986, a board member said today.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Mississippi Jury Picked For Trial of Official
description: A jury has been selected in the trial of the Mississippi Senate's President pro tem, Tommy Brooks, who is charged with attempting to extort $50,000 in exchange for using his influence to get a horse racing bill passed.

title: OUTPUT RATE DOWN
description: American business productivity declined at an annual rate of 2.5 percent in the first quarter of 1985, the most severe drop since the recession of 1981-82, the Labor Department said today.

title: OLYMPIA & YORK'S SHARP RISE
description: The Reichmann family, founder of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. here, prizes its privacy. But its shrewd business dealings and huge successes have repeatedly put it in the spotlight.

title: LOSS OF CHARITY DEDUCTIONS WOULD HURT, GROUPS ASSERT
description: Many organizations that depend on charitable contributions say they would be gravely hurt if President Reagan's tax plan were adopted.

title: ARISTEK COMMUNITIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jury Is Deliberating In Slaying of Officer
description: A jury yesterday began deliberating charges that a teen-ager shot a New York Transit Authority police officer to death with her own gun in a vacant lot in Brooklyn last Sept. 21.

title: A California Nevadan
description: Some readers of the new House of Representatives telephone directory were puzzled to find that Representative Harry Reid is listed as the secretary-treasurer of the California Democratic Congressional Delegation. Mr. Reid represents the First District of Nevada, which consists mostly of the Las Vegas area.

title: Bridge: Stayman Team One of Four Left in Reisinger Knockout
description: The Reisinger Knockout Team Championship resumed last night at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, with a world-famous veteran attempting to add to his large collection of titles.

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss. Gerber Systems Technology is 80 percent-owned by Gerber Scientific Inc.

title: CASTRO DENOUNCES U.S. SOUTHERN AFRICA ROLE
description: Fidel Castro, in a militant speech with the United Nations Secretary General sharing the dais, criticized the United States today and raised the specter of a war with heavy American casualties.

title: MAN VS. STARLING AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Baton in hand, a conductor at Tanglewood's music shed commands one of the finest symphonies in the world. But the power of the baton rarely extends to the rafters where on Sunday afternoons young starlings squeak in chorus, not for Wagner but for worms.

title: H & R Block's Confident View
description: H & R Block Inc., the nation's largest tax preparer, says the tax laws will not be any simpler if President Reagan's proposals are enacted, only fairer. And that is apparently good news for a company that earns its living helping confused taxpayers meet the April 15 deadline.

title: Knights Lose
description: Larry Lawrence scored a game-high 29 points to lead the Springfield Fame to a 122-93 victory over the Long Island Knights tonight at Hofstra University in a United States Basketball League game. Lawrence, who played with the Puerto Rico Coquis in the Continental Basketball Association during the winter, scored 16 in the first quarter. The crowd was 783.

title: Oklahoma Police Search For 5 in Prison Escape
description: About 90 law officers using tracking dogs, airplanes and horses today scoured the hills of eastern Oklahoma for five inmates who escaped from a maximum-ecurity prison by cutting through two fences, officials said.

title: Froese Is Eager for a Chance
description: As Mike Keenan hemmed and hawed, skirting the issue of who would be the goaltender for the Flyers' most important game of the season Thursday night, Bob Froese got right to the point.

title: U.S. Says 2 at Hutton Led Fraud
description: The Justice Department said today that two individuals were responsible ''in a criminal sense'' for practices by E.F. Hutton & Company that led to 2,000 felony counts of fraud against the company, but it said neither person was a ''high-level executive.'' They were not identified. Stephen S. Trott, an Assistant Attorney General, made the remarks in a letter sent to Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, a Missouri Democrat, who along with 14 of his Democratic colleagues had questioned the Justice Department's failure to prosecute any individuals in the company.

title: NIEKRO STYMIES ANGELS
description: The Yankees' 7-2 victory over the California Angels at Yankee Stadium last night gave rise to a novel idea that not even George Steinbrenner has tried in his hectic reign as the Yankees' principal owner.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FUNNY MONEY. By Mark Singer. 222 pages. Knopf. $15.95 ''TO hatch and execute a successful disaster demands a sustained level of competence and dependability that is, by definition, unavailable to an average group of would-be conspirators. That is why calculated calamities are rare achievements and why, no matter what many of us often insist on believing, thieving conspiracies can almost never be built to last. Coincidence, meanwhile - four vehicles without headlights, all traveling at different speeds, converging on an unmarked intersection at dusk - gets less credit than it deserves. Entropy, random natural chaos, innate stupidity - all are important sources and forces of destruction, and all are quite underrated.''

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A YARD or lawn that slopes can be a problem when the area is used for recreational purposes or when rain washes soil out. Sloping ground is also a problem when you want to put down a patio or paved walks. If the angle is too steep, the surface can become dangerously slippery when wet or icy, and there is the added hazard of runaway carts, wagons and wheeled toys.

title: GORBACHEV AGAIN WARNS U.S. ON SPACE ARMS PLAN
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that if the United States developed space-based weapons, the price could be not only an end to the Geneva talks, but ''the scrapping of every prospect for an end to the arms race.''

title: Pretoria Denies Mission Against Oil Installations
description: South Africa repeated its denials today that a group of its soldiers who clashed with Angolan troops in northern Angola eight days ago had been on a sabotage mission directed at American-operated oil installations.

title: NEED TO WIN CITED AS A CAUSE
description: Medical leaders and journal editors agreed today that highly competitive pressures in modern science were provoking cases of outright fraud and an even wider range of ''white lies'' and deceptions that they said were eroding the integrity of science.

title: Now, Reform the Tax Reform
description: President Reagan's package of tax revisions advances the cause of reform and marks a welcome commitment to the most sweeping improvement in 50 years. But it is also a collection of politically calculated favors and denials that represents no sacred body of principle. Congress, which gave great impetus to the reform movement in recent years, should feel free to rearrange and improve the package by its own standards.

title: The OSHA Bone in Labor's Throat
description: Perhaps the best that can be said of Robert Rowland's performance as the head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is that he knew when to leave. His resignation, effective July 1, clears the way for the new Secretary of Labor, Bill Brock, to put OSHA back on track as a legitimate protector of worker health and safety.

title: STEVENS, J P & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
