description: b-Includes charges for costs of restructuring certain operations of $11,730,000 for the quarter and $16,430,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a nonrecurring capital gain from the sale of a subsidiary of $16,400,000, or 94 cents a share.d-Net income The results for the latest second quarter do not include the operations of Foote & Davies, which was sold at the end of the first quarter.

title: Florida Stripped of Title
description: The presidents of the Southeastern Conference schools voted by 6-4 today to strip the University of Florida of the conference football title it won last fall, the first in the school's history. The action came during the closing business session of the league's annual spring meeting and brought an angry reaction from the Florida president, Marshall Criser, who called it ''extraordinary and unprecedented.''

title: TURK QUESTIONED AT ROME TRIAL ON BULGARIA TRIP
description: In the summer of 1980, Omar Bagci drove to Bulgaria with three friends from Switzerland in two cars on what he later told Italian investigators was a holiday trip to his native Turkey.

title: LOPEZ CITED FOR SLOW PLAY
description: Nancy Lopez was assessed a rare and potentially costly two-stroke penalty for slow play today as she held a big lead with one hole to go in the first round of the 31st annual L.P.G.A. Championship.

title: Re-employment Blues of the Displaced Worker
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Opener of the three-game weekend series. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs.

title: Mortgage Issue Financing Started
description: Two issues of collateralized mortgage obligations were offered yesterday through underwriters led by Paine Webber and Salomon Brothers.

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: The Battle of Benin
description: Three years ago Congress told foreign embassies where they were permitted to go. It adopted a Foreign Missions Act that mapped out parts of Washington, particularly sections of Massachusetts Avenue and the area around the Van Ness subway stop, where foreign countries could build and expand their embassies and offices.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MAY 31, 1985

title: Addendum
description: Hill & Knowlton has acquired Allan, Fenwick McCully, the largest public relations firm in New Zealand.

title: RELIEF IN OIL REGION AS BREAKS REMAIN
description: Plagued by the worst recession in their industry in a generation, American oil and gas producers are sighing with relief at President Reagan's proposal to overhaul the tax system, which would leave their most valuable tax benefits intact.

title: The Longest Day
description: From the later-than-you-think file:

title: BROWN & ROOT SETTLES
description: Brown & Root Inc. said today that it had agreed to pay three utilities and the City of Austin $750 million to settle a lawsuit over construction of the South Texas Nuclear Project.

title: Topics;   Best, Bettors, Bettered On the Money
description: Sports is a business, says Robert Brennan, the New Jersey banker who owns the Garden State Racetrack, and his extraordinary bonuses are a ''manifestation of the reward for the entrepreneurial mentality.'' So Dennis Diaz, who owns the horse that won the Kentucky Derby, scorned the prestige and risks of the Preakness Stakes, second jewel in racing's Triple Crown, and bet on winning $2.6 million at Garden State with his aptly named colt, Spend a Buck.

title: City Pact Approved By Municipal Union
description: The city reached tentative agreement yesterday with a municipal union representing 9,100 traffic agents, clerical and admnistrative workers.

title: Market Gain Dominated by Food Stocks
description: The stock market made small gains yesterday over all, but food stocks rose sharply following reports that Nabisco Brands and R.J. Reynolds had discussed a merger.

title: TOFU TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Ammonia Killed 4 in Blast
description: Autopsies today showed that four men killed in an explosion of an ammonia tank at an ice-making plant here died of ammonia poisoning. The Bexar County medical examiner's office said there were no signs of internal injuries.

title: ROOKIE'S HOMER SPURS YANKS
description: The Yankees crammed in a remarkable display of winning baseball habits last night, coupled them with some powerful dramatic moments and halted the California Angels by 3-1.

title: Nuggets Are Sold
description: Sidney Shlenker, a co-owner of the Houston Rockets, and an associate, Allen Becker, have bought the Denver Nuggets for an undisclosed price from Red McCombs, the club announced. McCombs, who paid an estimated $10 million for the Nuggets in 1982 and saw the team set a club record by winning 52 games this past season, said he had not even thought about selling the team until he was approached by Shlenker last week. Shlenker, who will have to sell his interest in the Rockets, said he would retain the Nuggets' entire staff, including the president, Vince Boryla, and Coach Doug Moe.

title: Ford Motor Credit Debt Securities
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $300 million of fixed- and floating-rate debt securities through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: More Than 60 Detained In South Korean Protest
description: More than 60 students were detained by the police today after demonstrating in support of colleagues who occupied the United States Information Service building last week, dissident sources said.

title: Iraq and Iran Report Successes in Gulf War
description: Iraq said its jet fighters attacked the principal Iranian oil terminal in the Persian Gulf today, and Iran reported hitting oil installations in southern Iraq.

title: Profits Soar At Big Board
description: Four out of five New York Stock Exchange member firms doing business with the public were profitable in the first quarter, the highest level since June 1983, the exchange said yesterday.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Required Reading;   A Press Edifice
description: Excerpts from a speech by David Hess, president of the National Press Club, at a ceremony dedicating the newly renovated National Press Building May 21:

title: Accounts
description: * American Cancer Society's 1986 April Crusade, to Ally & Gargano as the volunteer agency.

title: ADI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FMC to Buy Units
description: The FMC Corporation announced that it had entered into definitive agreements to acquire the assets of the Lithium Corporation of America and BS&B Engineering Company, two units of the Houston-based Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, for about $150 million. The lithium company, based in Gastonia, N.C., and known as Lithco, accounts for the bulk of the transaction. It is a world leader in the mining and production of lithium products.

title: AUCTIONS
description: BRITISH and American sporting paintings - most depicting horses, dogs and prize-winning cattle - make up one of the more specialized and fastest growing areas for collectors buying at auctions. Next week, New York's two major auction houses will offer such 18th- through 20th-century works. It will be Sotheby's first such specialty auction in New York, and Christie's fifth.

title: SUFFOLK CHIEF SAID TO END FIGHT AGAINST SHOREHAM
description: The Suffolk County Executive has dropped his fight to stop the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, according to opponents and supporters of the plant.

title: A Biting Appraisal
description: We know that people get bitten by dogs. And cats. Maybe by a hamster or two. But a lion-fish?

title: Intrusive Arc
description: New York's Federal Plaza is an ugly space bordered by undistinguished buildings and centered, more or less, by an empty pool and dry fountain. It is also bisected by a modern sculpture, Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc,'' 120 feet of curved, rusting steel.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Salem 66 At Folk City
description: Firmness verging on stubbornness comes through the music of Salem 66, a Boston-based band that played Wednesday at Folk City, 130 West Third Street.

title: STAGE: KEVIN KLINE IN SHAW'S 'ARMS AND THE MAN'
description: IF it were possible for Kevin Kline to play both dueling heroes at once, the new Circle in the Square revival of ''Arms and the Man'' would be an entirely enchanting affair. But one can't wait around for that miracle - even though this actor might well be capable of achieving it - and there's still much to enjoy in the sometimes sparkling, sometimes coarse evening that the director John Malkovich has fashioned from George Bernard Shaw's 1894 comedy.

title: Warner Amex Sale in Dallas
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its troubled Dallas-area cable television system to Heritage Communications Inc. for $110 million.

title: Bear Imitation Proves Fatal
description: An Ohio teen-ager was shot to death in the dark while attempting to frighten a camping companion by making noises like those of a bear, officers said Wednesday. Ronald Lee Brownlee, 27 years old, of Cleveland was arrested for investigation of manslaughter in connection with the Sunday night shooting in the Elk Park area. The identity of the 16-year-old victim was withheld pending notification of family.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid March 26.

title: ISRAEL RULES OUT HUSSEIN PROPOSAL
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres, reacting to a statement by King Hussein of Jordan, today affirmed Israel's opposition to an international Middle East conference.

title: O.E.C.D. SEES SLOWER GROWTH
description: The major industrial democracies, with the best of the economic recovery behind them, now face slowing growth and modestly rising unemployment, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in its latest forecast, released today.

title: WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $172.9 million, to $213.44 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the fourth consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: NCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income which includes a pre- tax gain of $255,000 from the sale of property and an extraordinary credit of $835,000 from an accounting change.

title: THE SCREEN: 'SYLVIA'
description: ''Sylvia'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 11. The film opens today at the Plaza, 58th Street, east of Madison Avenue.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Dear Yvonne Taylor
description: A fleeting measure of the sheltered living that routinely goes on in the capital was to be had the other morning in the Metro. Passengers departing from a rush-hour train were suddenly summoned by a firm voice over the public address system: ''Could I have your attention.

title: WHY NABISCO IS ATTRACTIVE
description: Through a combination of aggressive marketing and strong brand names like Ritz, Planters, Baby Ruth and Oreo, Nabisco Brands Inc. is considered one of the food industry's strongest and most attractive companies. Furthermore, the company has what every food company wants. ''They have shelf space clout,'' said William Maguire, a food analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Baltimore Troupe
description: The Naked Feet Dance Company of Baltimore will appear this weekend at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Two Montclair State baseball players, Bob Yeager, a third baseman, and Dan Olsson, a pitcher, have been named to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III all-America first team. Yeager hit .451 with 10 home runs and 65 runs batted in this season, and Olsson had a 12-1 record with a 1.48 earned run average. . . . Paul Westphal, the former Knick guard, has been named athletic director and head basketball coach at Southwestern Baptist Bible College in Phoenix. . . . Evelyn Ashford, who holds the world record in the women's 100-meter dash, gave birth to a 5-pound-13-ounce daughter in Los Angeles. . . . Rich Campbell, a third-string quarterback, was waived by the Green Bay Packers.

title: JOINT ARAB TEAM EXPECTED TO MEET U.S. ABOUT MIDEAST
description: Senior American and Jordanian officials said today that they expected the next step in the unfolding Middle East peace efforts to be an early meeting between the United States and a joint Jordan-Palestinian delegation to discuss how to arrange direct talks with Israel.

title: PRESIDENT CAMPAIGNS IN 2 STATES
description: President Reagan carried to the American countryside today his case for revamping the Federal tax code, which he voiced in settings chosen to reflect the rebellious spirit of colonial America and the present frustrations of middle America.

title: Court Refuses to Free A Death Row Japanese
description: A lower court here today denied a request to release a 93-year-old man who has spent 30 years on death row.

title: Amsted Changes
description: Amsted Industries said yesterday that its board had approved a stock-purchase rights plan intended to make it prohibitively expensive for a potential buyer to acquire the company.

title: OFFICIALS EXPECT FURTHER ARRESTS IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: Several employees of a man accused of spying for the Soviet Union are expected to be arrested on espionage charges in the next few days, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: THE RACE FOR WHIP: WIDE OPEN
description: Television will not be a factor. Nor will bumper stickers, ward heelers, hand-painted signs or any other hallmarks of an American political campaign. There will be only about 250 voters. And, although election day is 19 months away, the race is already under way.

title: Stock-Listing Unity Sought
description: Under Government pressure to adopt compatible listing standards, the heads of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will meet in Washington June 14 to try to iron out differences in their rules, the exchanges said yesterday. John S. R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will also attend.

title: New World Bank Plan
description: The World Bank is re-examining its role and studying strategies for helping developing countries make up for a capital shortage, A.W. Clausen, the bank's president, said yesterday. By coordinating foreign aid programs and export credit agencies that offer cheap loans to promote exports, the World Bank can stimulate the efficient use of official capital flows, he said. To bolster private investment, the bank is considering creating a Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, which would protect investors from expropriation or the inability to repatriate profits.

title: Ford Confirms Bid On Hughes Aircraft
description: The Ford Motor Company confirmed today that it was one of the bidders for the Hughes Aircraft Company and said it would have to sell securities to finance the purchase if it had the winning offer.

title: AIM TELEPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $53,000. c-Net loss.

title: MARY KAY TO GO PRIVATE AGAIN
description: In 1968, Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc.'s business looked so promising that the then family-controlled company decided to cash in by selling the majority of its stock to the public. Now, 17 years later, with the direct sales approach to the cosmetic business in a slump, Mary Kay wants to return to private ownership.

title: VON BULOW CHILDREN SAY MOTHER AVOIDED ALCOHOL
description: Martha von Bulow's son and older daughter today described their mother, now in a coma their stepfather is accused of causing, as a vibrantly healthy woman who rarely drank or took drugs.

title: Odetta in Concert
description: Odetta, the folk and blues singer, will give a free concert Sunday at 3 P.M. at the the Brooklyn Public Library's central library, at Grand Army Plaza, near the Seventh Avenue stop of the Independent Line's D train and the Grand Army Plaza stop of the I.R.T.'s No. 2 and 3 trains. Information: (718) 780-7700.

title: LOREN L. RYDER, AN ENGINEER IN SOUND-RECORDING FOR FILM
description: Loren L. Ryder, a pioneer of sound technology for motion pictures and the winner of six Academy Awards, died Tuesday at Carmel (Calif.) Convalescent Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Monterey.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
I.B.M. SEES FALL IN NET IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, painting a worsening picture for its business in the near future, said last night that ''it will be very difficult to show any earnings growth in the second quarter,'' and warned that ''a slight decline is probable.''

title: ART: 'GATHERING OF THE AVANT-GARDE'
description: THE way things are going, Manhattan may soon be coast-to-coast condos, co-ops, office buildings, ''centers'' and plazas, with the labor force needed to keep it all going transported in daily - the subways permitting. This isn't the theme of ''The Gathering of the Avant-Garde,'' but the show's very existence implies concern over the impact of the real-estate boom on daily life and, hence, on the making of art.

title: BROADWAY
description: EVERY second person thinks that his or her life would make a great book or play, but Lillian Hellman knew that hers would. She reminisced in a trio of books - ''Pentimento,'' ''Scoundrel Time'' and ''An Unfinished Woman'' - and before her death last year approved a stage adaptation of them done by William Luce, who wrote ''The Belle of Amherst,'' the one-woman play about Emily Dickinson.

title: Money Supply Up $4.5 Billion
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday after credit market participants shrugged off a late afternoon announcement by the Federal Reserve of a larger than expected $4.5 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply.

title: OILERS FLY WITH KRUSHELNYSKI AT WING
description: The most powerful offensive team in the history of the National Hockey League had long been unable to find a full-time left wing for the prized line that features Wayne Gretzky and Jari Kurri, the league's most productive center-right wing combination for the last four years.

title: Trios at the Vanguard
description: The pianist Tommy Flanagan, the bassist George Mraz and the drummer Art Taylor will play trios tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: JERSEY WOMAN AT CONVENTION IS SLAIN IN WEST 54TH ST. HOTEL
description: A New Jersey woman attending a business convention with her husband was found bludgeoned to death yesterday afternoon at a midtown Manhattan hotel, the police said.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FIGHTING THE INCOME TAX
description: For President Reagan, the tax plan he is taking to the country this week is the instrument for carrying forward his long campaign against the progressive income tax and thereby reshaping the political and economic landscape of this country.

title: LAKERS HOLD OFF CELTICS, TIE SERIES
description: Even at the ripe old age of 38, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar continues to show why he may be the greatest basketball player ever.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
'LOVE'S LABOUR'S LOST, 'TONIGHT ON CHANNEL 13'
description: PLANNED as a six-year project but running to seven, the BBC's hardy undertaking of ''The Shakespeare Plays,'' 37 of them, reaches an end this evening - on Channel 13 at 9 - with ''Love's Labour's Lost.'' The series has had several high and low spots but, on the whole, it has added up to a valuable library of productions, a good many of them involving plays that are rarely staged at all. ''Love's Labour's Lost'' can be slipped unobtrusively into the sprawling, good-but-not-great middle range of the series' accomplishments.

title: 12% Drop in April Sales Of One-Family Homes
description: Sales of single-family homes plummeted 12 percent in April but housing industry leaders said today that they were not concerned because lower mortgage interest rates have already started to spur additional buying.

title: BIOCRAFT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest quarter include a benefit of $200,000 from a lower effective tax rate. Results for the year-ago quarter reflect the effect of a litigation settlement charge of $475,000.

title: 'THE MIKADO,' AN EXHIBITION FOR SAVOYARDS AT MORGAN LIBRARY
description: ''I've got a little list, I've got a little list,'' sings Ko-Ko, the Lord High Executioner, in Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Mikado.''

title: Florida Court Overturns Two Death Sentences
description: Death sentences for two members of a black militant group convicted of murdering a white youth were overturned today by the Florida Supreme Court.

title: Bridge: Weiand Gerard Teams Lead In Reisinger Semifinal Play
description: Both semifinal matches in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship proved to be close battles. When play resumed last night at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, Manhattan, teams headed by Kathie Wei of New York and Ron Gerard of White Plains were leading their opponents by small margins at the halfway mark.

title: THE DANCE: 'TZIGANE'
description: TEN years ago - on May 29, 1975 - Suzanne Farrell transformed herself into an amazing gypsy by starring in the New York City Ballet's premiere of George Balanchine's ''Tzigane.'' On Wednesday night - which was also May 29 - she was once again that gypsy when the company celebrated the ballet's 10th anniversary. The performance at the New York State Theater was conducted by Hugo Fiorato, and Lamar Alsop was the violin soloist in the score by Ravel.

title: WESTERN MICRO TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest fourth quarter earnings were adversely affected by a nonrecurring charge of about $100,000 in legal and accounting costs incurred during the intended acquisition of Image Electronics Inc.

title: Filling a Need
description: If the Cubs go on to win the division title by only a game or so, they may well look back from the perspective of October and realize that it was actually from mid-May to early June that the flag was saved. The top two pitchers in Chicago's rotation - Rick Sutcliffe and Steve Trout - have each missed two starts because of injury, and each will miss a third, Sutcliffe probably more, before returning. Thus far, though, the Cubs have been able to plug the gaps with Ray Fontenot and Dick Ruthven, and the team's record since losing its two big arms is 5-3.

title: 'The Normal Heart'
description: ''The Normal Heart,'' a play about acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) by Larry Kramer, will be presented in the Anspacher Theater at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, beginning June 4. The play, which opened in April in the Public's LuEsther Hall, will have an indefinite run. The director is Michael Lindsay-Hogg; featured in the cast are Phillip Richard Allen, David Allen Brooks, Brad Davis and D. W. Moffett.

title: 3 HOTELS REACH PACTS, BUT STRIKE NEARS
description: New York City's hotel workers council announced new contract agreements with three hotels yesterday, but little progress was reported in talks to avert a strike tomorrow morning at most of the city's largest hotels.

title: Ketchum Advertising Keeps Safeway Foods
description: The other hot news from the Coast is that Ketchum Advertising in San Francisco was able to keep the Safeway Food Stores corporate account, despite hot competition from the San Francisco offices of Chiat/Day; Ogilvy's Hal Riney agency, and McCann-Erickson.

title: ECKERD, JACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
FAMILY SPY CASE CALLED A 'SERIOUS LOSS' TO U.S.
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that information John A. Walker Jr., his brother and son are said to have passed to the Soviet Union represented ''a serious loss'' to the United States.

title: New York Trip Was Ruled Out
description: President Reagan's chief political adviser said today that the President decided not to include New York among the first stops to promote his tax revision plan in part because he did not want to get into a debate with Governor Cuomo.

title: AT U.N., WALTERS HOPES TO AVERT 'LYNCHING' OF U.S.
description: The new United States delegate, Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, says his top priority will be to increase support for American positions by refusing to tolerate unfair criticism of the United States, while at the same time paying attention to developing nations.

title: BISHOP ROBERT B. HALL
description: Robert B. Hall, Episcopal Bishop of Virginia, died Monday at St. Mary's Hospital after suffering a stroke.

title: Betancourt, Citing Shortage Of Funds, Quits Bronx Race
description: Ismael Betancourt Jr., a business executive, yesterday dropped out of the race for the Sept. 10 Democratic nomination for Bronx borough president. Mr. Betancourt, a frequent but unsuccessful candidate in recent years, said he could not raise enough money.

title: LAWYER GUILTY IN FIRST BOSTON RACKETS TRIAL
description: A lawyer who has represented the man prosecutors say heads the city's organized crime syndicate was found guilty today of conspiracy to obstruct justice by persuading a witness not to testify before a Federal grand jury.

title: Economic Scene;   Is Tax Plan A Tax Cut?
description: WHAT will be the effects on the economy of President Reagan's historic set of proposals for overhauling the tax system?

title: A FEDERAL ATTORNEY HELD IN DRUG THEFT AT NEW YORK OFFICE
description: A prosecutor in the office of the United States Attorney in Manhattan was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing up to $500,000 worth of heroin and cocaine from a safe used by the office's narcotics unit.

title: Otis Rush at Tramps
description: Otis Rush will sing and play Chicago blues tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sets begin at about 9:30 and midnight. There is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A CELEBRATION OF THE OPULENT AND VENERABLE PIANOS OF THE PAST
description: Did you know that Mozart owned a piano that he could carry under his arm and use for practicing while on tour? That a ''harp-piano'' patented in 1843 had exposed strings and, instead of a soundboard, three hollow resonating chambers? Or that the hand-cranked cylinder piano popular with street musicians was banned in New York City in 1885 for obstructing traffic?

title: The Athlete at Carnegie Hall
description: When Simon Estes steps on stage at La Scala or the Metropolitan Opera, he often gives thanks to another world-famous building, the high school gymnasium at Centerville, Iowa.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., said it had appointed Michael K. Lorelli marketing director of its Apple II division.

title: Pope to Visit Africa
description: Pope John Paul II will visit seven African countries in August, the Vatican announced today. The trip, from Aug. 8 to 19, will take the Pope to Togo, Ivory Coast, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Zaire, Kenya and Morocco.

title: Padres' Hawkins Runs His Mark to 10-0
description: Carmelo Martinez drove in four runs with two homers and unbeaten Andy Hawkins became the major leagues' first 10-game winner today as the San Diego Padres defeated the Montreal Expos, 5-4.

title: RARE DISEASE PROPOSED AS CAUSE FOR 'VAMPIRES'
description: Werewolves and vampires, those dreaded beasts of folklore and superstition, may have been nothing more than people suffering from a rare class of genetic diseases, a scientist suggested here today.

title: Article 017924 -- No Title
description: The price of basic telephone service for residences and businesses with one line will rise by $1 a month across America tomorrow. The increase is part of a Government effort to have households and smaller companies pay more of the cost of the telephone system.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Net income

title: Cooper Union Show
description: Works by Cooper Union students will be exhibited this weekend in the school's foundation building on Seventh Street, between Third and Fourth Avenue.

title: An Abundance of Bluefish
description: 1 Margate, N.J.:Bluefish plentiful both inshore and offshore. The offshore fish run from 9 to 13 pounds, the inshore from 3 to 5 pounds. The first mako shark of the season, a 190-pounder, has been caught near the 28-Mile Wreck. Fluke fishing very good in Margate Bay and a few small weakfish have been caught in and near Great Egg Inlet. Seaside Park, N.J.: Betty and Nick's Tackle Shop reports that small bluefish are plentiful in and around Barnegat Inlet. Point Pleasant, N.J.:

title: An Anti-Semitic Side to the Malaysian Story
description: To the Editor:

title: CRANE FALLS ON 3D AVE., TRAPPING WOMAN 6 HOURS
description: A 35-ton construction crane toppled onto an Upper East Side construction site yesterday, seriously injuring a pedestrian who was trapped beneath the vehicle for nearly six hours before she could be rescued.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $6,018,000 to reduce inventories, primarily for older lines to net realizable values. c-Net income.

title: 3 HELD IN THEFT OF $7.9 MILLION AT CASH DEPOT
description: Three men have been arrested and charged with participating in the $7.9 million robbery last month of a Wells Fargo depot in lower Manhattan, the F.B.I. said yesterday.

title: Indictments Sealed In Drug Inquiry
description: A Federal grand jury that heard testimony from baseball players during its investigation into drug trafficking in the Pittsburgh area returned indictments against seven people late yesterday afternoon, but the indictments were sealed and will not be opened until today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alfa Romeo Auto S.p.A., Italy's state-owned car maker, said it was holding exploratory talks with several European, United States and Japanese car companies aimed at a possible joint venture.

title: CUOMO AT MARYMOUNT MANHATTAN CEREMONY
description: Governor Cuomo told the graduating class at Marymount Manhattan College yesterday that their alma mater had been ''part of a movement as dramatic as any achieved by this century's political or technological revolutions -the effort to give one-half of the human race its birthright.''

title: TOP COLTS HEADED FOR BELMONT
description: The 117th Belmont Stakes a week from tomorrow will not include Spend a Buck, but the four other top 3-year-olds of the spring are expected to be in the gate: Tank's Prospect and Chief's Crown, who finished a head apart in that order in the Preakness; Stephan's Odyssey, who was second to Spend a Buck in the Kentucky Derby, and Proud Truth, who has beaten Stephan's Odyssey in four of five career meetings, most recently when he won the Peter Pan Stakes last Sunday.

title: FOR RINGLING TROUPERS, A 2D CIRCUS BACKSTAGE
description: Out front at the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, everything looks effortless and under control. Just before intermission, for instance, the dog trainer Eric Braun, dressed in blue and silver sequins, rides bareback on a white horse. The Espana brothers, daredevil aerialists, ride close behind. The wild-animal trainer Gunther Gebel-Williams leads a parade of elephants. Atop each one is a showgirl, a swirl of hot pink and purple.

title: BRITISH SOCCER FAN: WHY SO WARLIKE?
description: Although Britain is known for civility and reserve, for gracious manners and the stiff upper lip, it has also been home for quite a long time to a youth culture that in some manifestations is poor, bored and violent.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 12
description: The share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split on Jan. 4, 1985.

title: ART: A NOSTALGIC VISIT TO 'THE SURREAL CITY'
description: BLEND diluted Surrealism with watered-down Cubism and a touch of the satirical German precisionism known as the New Objectivity. Throw in references to Renaissance masters. Shake it up, and you have the 30's American brew called ''Magic Realism.'' In it, the close rendering of ''facts'' - buildings and streets and everyday events - is disrupted by odd juxtapositions and pungent dream displacements. Mild example: an urban rooftop scene precisely delineated by George Ault in which a woman looks over a parapet at the cityscape. But she is nude, wearing only her shoes.

title: Arab Film Festival
description: A three-day ''New Arab Cinema'' festival begins today at 5:30 P.M. at Hunter College, Park Avenue and 68th Street.

title: NEW VAUDEVILLIANS OFFER MIME, JAZZ AND VIDEO
description: ONE of the most exciting ''new vaudeville'' performance pieces to play in New York recently has been the satirical mixed media extravaganza ''Autobahn,'' which was first presented at the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association in 1983 by a troupe of mimes called the Adaptors. ''Autobahn,'' which has won critical acclaim on tour, is still a work in progress.

title: The Electoral College
description: The candidates have visited Queens College for their interviews. Soon, a selection committee is to send a couple of names to Joseph S. Murphy, the chancellor of the City University of New York.

title: WAY OF LIFE: RE-CREATING THE PAST
description: ''I'll be Barbara Standish, Miles's second wife, this year,'' said Kit Rawlins. ''What was she like? Her father was a farmer who raised her to be a typical woman of the period. She kept a good house, she sewed, gardened, knew the right herbs for doctoring. And she took good care of Miles, who we know was very hotheaded. She was gentle but she could be stubborn.''

title: Guitarists at Lush Life
description: The guitarists Barney Kessel and Herb Ellis will perform tonight through Sunday at Lush Life, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (228-3788). Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 8:30 and and 10:30 P.M. Sunday. There is a $12.50 cover ($10 Sunday) and a $6 minimum.

title: Dear Rosty
description: The first ''Rosty'' letters, addressed as simplistically as pleas to Santa, have begun arriving at the office of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, in response to his television pitch for comment on President Reagan's tax-revision plan.

title: $210.2 Million Offering By District of Columbia
description: The District of Columbia, for years a financial ward of the Treasury Department, is offering $210.2 million of bonds to refund part of the money it has borrowed from the Federal Government.

title: BROTHER OF SPY SUSPECT IS TAKEN INTO U.S. COURT
description: Arthur James Walker, a retired Navy lieutenant commander and the third member of the Walker family to be arrested on charges of espionage espionage, appeared in handcuffs today before a Federal magistrate here.

title: Teachers Working Together for Education's Sake
description: To the Editor:

title: CERTAIN WINNERS: CAPITAL LOBBYISTS
description: As the Washington lobbying industry mobilizes for the battle on Capitol Hill between conflicting economic interests over President Reagan's tax proposal, it is already clear that no matter what Congress does, one of the biggest winners will be the Washington lobbying industry.

title: FAIRER AND SIMPLER
description: By putting forward a tax reform plan not quite so simple and fair as he proclaimed it, President Reagan has left open a door through which tax simplification may yet be guided to a political bonanza for the Democrats. They have the means, in the Bradley-Gephardt ''Fair Tax,'' which long preceded the Reagan plan and which would, in many respects, establish a fairer and simpler tax system.

title: San Francisco Harbor 'Mined' by Protesters
description: A Navy bomb squad and the Coast Guard were dispatched today when fake mines made of black beach balls and orange styrofoam cups were planted in San Francisco Bay in what appeared to be a protest of the Reagan Administration's trade embargo on Nicaragua.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ASIAN INSPIRATION A good deal of recent music, dance, theater and literature has been influenced, one way or another, by ideas from the East. This weekend, a three-day festival titled ''Artists Inspired by Asia'' will feature traditional and experimental performing arts of China, India, Indonesia, Japan and Korea, among other Asian countries. The programs will include music, dance, puppetry, theater and storytelling. One highlight will be a rare performance of the Balinese ''Ketjak,'' a rhythmic chant built around the Ramayana epic. There will also be examples of Indian classical music and dance, some short Japanese plays, and Javanese court music. In all, more than a dozen groups and 100 artists will participate. The festival, at the Synod House of St. John the Divine, 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, begins tonight at 8, with a different program every night and a free outdoor event on the cathedral lawn tomorrow at 2. Admission to evening performances is $7, or a Theater Development Fund voucher plus $2 ($5 for the elderly and students). at ; Information: 279-4200.

title: RESTRUCTURE OF APPLE HELD NEAR
description: Apple Computer Inc. will announce a major restructuring of the corporation Friday in an effort to streamline its operations and cope with rapidly declining sales a source close to the company said late today.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SAFARI GRILL is the latest undertaking of David Keh and Ed Schoenfeld, the indefatigable entrepreneurs who shuffle restaurants with the agility of a casino card dealer. This smartly appointed, brasserie-like Art Deco establishment offers an earnest and well-focused interpretation of the new American cooking.

title: 2 Oklahoma Teen-Agers Abducted by Fugitives
description: Three of five men who escaped from a maximum-security prison forced two teen-agers to drive them halfway across Oklahoma, the authorities said today.

title: Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company said it had reached agreement with its bankers on restructuring payments on nearly $1.2 billion in unsecured loans, clearing the way for an electricity rate increase to avoid bankruptcy. The company will file a statement with the Michigan Public Service Commission on Monday ''indicating that we've met the conditions that they laid out for our 6 percent rate increase,'' said Dan Bishop, Consumers Power spokesman. Under an agreement with about 80 banks, Consumers will make a lump-sum payment of $105 million this year and repay the rest of the debt at about $160 million a year over six years.

title: PHILADELPHIA PINS HOPES FOR ECONOMIC GROWTH ON NEW HIGH-TECH CORRIDOR
description: Out in the hazy hills that lie west of Philadelphia's Main Line suburbs, not far from Valley Forge, much of the future of Greater Philadelphia, and of the Northeast, is emerging.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THERE'LL be one more oil slick than usual on the streets of Manhattan when the crew of ''F/X,'' a film whose title is shorthand for ''special effects,'' stages one of its showier stunts. A section of the West Side Highway near 14th Street will be the setting for this sequence, which will be shot on a weekend date two or three weeks from now. The scene will feature a vehicle specially equipped to throw out the oil slick on command, not to mention a realistic-looking dummy. The film's real special-effects man is John Stears, whose credits include ''Star Wars'' and several of the better James Bond films, and who knows a thing or two about how to stage chases of this kind.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's sort of an awful, distorted adventure. It's a kind of distortion of the warlike aspect of human beings.''

title: Escape From Nazis
description: For the next five Sundays, feature films dealing with the survival of artists and intellectuals in Nazi Germany will be shown at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street. This Sunday at 6 P.M., ''Escape Route to Marseilles,'' a 1977 West German film by Ingemo Enstrom and Gerhard Theuring, will be screened in New York for the first time.

title: EXPERIMENTERS CHART FUTURE OF WORK ON MAMMAL GENES
description: Genetic engineers can now produce giant mice, cross sheep and goats, save endangered antelope by implanting embryos into cows and slice fertilized eggs in half to produce twin calves.

title: U.S. DRUG AGENT CHARGED WITH TAKING BRIBE
description: A special agent assigned to the intelligence unit of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration was indicted today on Federal charges of accepting bribes in return for confidential law-enforcement information.

title: End of the Line
description: John Hadl, head coach of the orphan Los Angeles Express, and his staff of seven assistants have been told that when the 1985 season ends their paychecks will stop. Considering that the team has dropped to a 3-11 record after winning the United States Football League's Pacific Division championship last year, that might seem like a logical move.

title: The Class of '85 Is Not the 'Me' Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUCARD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MILT HINTON TURNS 75 AND 70 JAZZ PALS JOIN IN CELEBRATION GIGS
description: MILT HINTON, the bassist who got his first steady job 54 years ago in a quintet led by the celebrated jazz violinist Eddie South and has played with groups and singers ranging from Mahalia Jackson to Peggy Lee, from Duke Ellington and Cab Calloway to Guy Lombardo and the New York Bass Violin Choir, will be 75 years old on June 23. But the celebration of this event has been going on for a month.

title: ITALIANS EXPRESS RAGE OVER DEATHS
description: Italian political leaders, sports fans and newspapers expressed rage and sorrow today over the rioting at a Brussels soccer stadium that left 38 people dead, among them at least 25 Italians.

title: O.A.S. Resolution Opposes British Forces in Falklands
description: The Organization of American States today adopted a resolution expressing the region's concern about the establishment of British military facilities in the Falkland Islands.

title: P.&G. Adds Jordan, Case
description: Procter & Gamble, which in recent months has been eagerly seeking a ninth ad agency, announced yesterday that it had decided on Jordan, Case & McGrath, which the rumor mill already had as a favorite. The single-brand assignment is for Zest deodorant soap, and it could bill about $10 million.

title: WHAT'S ALL WHITE, AND DANCES IN NEW YORK?
description: Have you seen a black Rockette lately, kicking her heels among that constellation of 36 dancers? No. You never have. The fact is there have been more than 5,000 Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall through the ages - 5,000 white Rockettes.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $179,435 for the quarter and $328,568 for the 6 months.

title: HOTEL TALKS: AN ERA OF PEACE ENDS
description: Bargaining between New York City's hotel workers' unions and hotels, amicable for nearly half a century, has turned strident in the current negotiations because of dramatic changes in the industry.

title: OILERS STEAMROLL FLYERS FOR 2D STRAIGHT TITLE
description: Combining speed, finesse and proficient scoring, the Edmonton Oilers whirled their way to a second consecutive Stanley Cup championship tonight with an 8-3 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers, ending the four-of-seven-game final in five games.

title: People
description: * Francine Menaber has been named a senior vice president in the New York office and Ruth McKinney in the St. Louis office of Muller Jordan Weiss.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
PIANO-LOVERS UNEASY WITH STEINWAY FOR SALE
description: When CBS bought Steinway & Sons in 1972, attempts were made to speed up the venerable piano maker's slow but widely respected methods of producing muiscal instruments. The changes were abandoned when technical problems developed, quality began to suffer and performers started showing interest in other makes of piano. Now that Steinway is up for sale again, its friends and customers are wondering whether the cycle is about to be repeated.

title: FILM: 'FLETCH,' STARRING CHEVY CHASE, REPORTER
description: IN the syntax once favored in advertising for John Wayne movies, Chevy Chase IS ''Fletch.''

title: Craig Harris Group
description: The trombonist Craig Harris will lead a group featuring the drummer Billy Higgins in new compositions tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (212) 242-1785. Sets begin tonight and tomorrow at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M., and Sunday at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: 9-Hour Wagner Film On View This Weekend
description: ''Wagner,'' a nine-hour film on the life of the composer Richard Wagner, will have its American premiere this weekend at two screenings in Manhattan.

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,794,000 for the quarter and $5,997,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $2,304,000 for the quarter and $5,432,000 for the 9 months, a gain on the termination of a pension plan of $46,906,000 for the 9 months, the tax effect of the termination amounting to $19,500,000 for the 9 months, and estimated expenses of reorganization of $17,200,000 for the 9 months.

title: LEBANON'S COAST TO ISRAEL
description: Three years after the war in Lebanon - our tanks rolled across the border on June 6, 1982 - Israel is still struggling with the legacy of that conflict. The costs were enormous, by any calculation - military, strategic or moral. Yet perhaps some good will still come of the uneasy questioning left in the wake of the war.

title: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $19,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $41,000 for the quarter and year. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $820,000.

title: Rise in Transit Budget Requested by Bellamy
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy charged yesterday that the Koch Administration had had a ''consistent pattern'' of cutting aid for subways and buses, a contention that was immediately disputed by administration officials.

title: FILM ON THE RESISTANCE EMBROILS THE FRENCH
description: A new controversy about the French role in World War II erupted today when a state-run television station here canceled a documentary on the French Resistance that implicated the Communist Party in the sacrifice of one of this country's most celebrated anti-Nazi groups.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ASSAULT. By Harry Mulisch. Translated from the Dutch by Claire Nicolas White. 185 pages. Pantheon. $13.95.

title: U.S. Pressing China Trade
description: The United States is rapidly stepping up sales of high-technology products to China and is pressing for streamlined clearance procedures in an agency that regulates Western exports to Communist countries, two Administration officials said today.

title: Grenada and the Fog of Peace
description: No reporters went along when American troops invaded Grenada in October 1983. They were barred by military commanders. When Defense Secretary Weinberger was asked about that two days later, he gave an answer to alarm anyone brought up believing in civilian control of the military.

title: Bombings in Chilean Capital
description: Ten small bombs exploded in Santiago early today and a bus driver was shot in the leg by attackers after a call by left-wing groups for demonstrations against the military Government, the police said.

title:
Market Place;

Growth Stocks In a New Phase
description: MANY growth stocks suffered through a bear market of declining prices from mid-1983 until the late summer of 1984. But William B. Astrop, who heads an investment counseling firm in Atlanta, believes premier issues in this group are now in a position to outperform the rest of the equity market.

title: MAN IS CONVICTED OF KILLING OFFICER WITH HER GUN
description: A 19-year-old man was found guilty yesterday of killing a transit police officer with her own gun in a weed-filled lot in Brooklyn last September.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Thouvenel Quartet At Merkin Concert Hall
description: The Thouvenel String Quartet left a mixed impression with its Wednesday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall. The four musicians - the violinists Eugene Purdue and Edmund Stein, the violist Sally Chisholm and the cellist Keith Robinson - function as a cohesive unit; their ensemble work was, for the most part, lively and elegant.

title: REDLAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Gidget and Moondoggie Are Back in a New Movie
description: Anyone consumed by yearning for an update on the life of Francie (Gidget) Griffin, perky protagonist of such movies as ''Gidget'' (1959) and ''Gidget Goes Hawaiian'' (1961), may want to lay in a supply of potato chips and Twinkies, set aside a pair of toothpicks for propping the eyelids open and tune in Channel 5 tomorrow night for the two hours beginning at 8.

title: Advertising;   A British Agency on Wall St.
description: DESPITE an inhospitable climate for out-of-town agencies, the Big Apple - where the advertising action is - continues to attract the braver of the species.

title: PLAN WOULD END $1 TAX CHECKOFF FOR CAMPAIGNS
description: President Reagan's tax plan proposes that Congress end the current system of public financing for Presidential elections by repealing the $1 checkoff allowed on tax returns. If adopted, the step would radically alter the way Presidential campaigns have been paid for since 1976.

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS ARE COUNTING ON FARMERS' SUPPORT IN VOTE
description: Michael Yiannos left no doubt why he intends to vote for Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialist Party in general elections Sunday.

title: Portland Gas
description: The Portland Gas and Electric Company is offering $60 million of 10 3/4 percent first mortgage bonds due in 1995 at a price of 99.70, to yield 10.80 percent, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. The bonds are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P.

title: A HOST OF HAPPENINGS AROUND THE HUDSON
description: Among the activities in the Hudson Valley this weekend, possibly the most unusual is a concert experiment in which amateur string players have been invited to join with the Hudson Valley Philharmonic Orchestra in a performance of Bach's Brandenburg Concertos.

title: Mets Win as Gooden Fans 14
description: Dwight Gooden rebounded from two straight losses in high style today, struck out 14 batters and pitched the Mets to a sizzling six-hit, 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: A MEMORIAL TO LIBERATORS IS DEDICATED
description: Survivors and liberators of Nazi death camps gathered with thousands of other people in Liberty State Park today for the dedication of a memorial to the American rescuers of 40 years ago.

title: Dear Ireland
description: The Irishness displayed aboard a Potomac yacht seemed forced.

title: Robins Claims
description: The A.H. Robins Company has experience a dramatic upsurge in the number of new claims related to the Dalkon Shield, E. Claiborne Robins Jr., president and chief executive, said at the annual meeting. The intrauerine birth control device was taken off the market after women complained of pelvic infections and other problems.

title: Heebie-Jheebies
description: To the Editor:

title: KNEE IS BIG HURDLE FOR EL MOUTAWAKEL
description: Of the 1,509 male and female athletes competing in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's outdoor track and field championships, only one won an individual gold medal in last summer's Los Angeles Olympics. To the surprise of many but not to her, she was eliminated in her only race here.

title: Nabisco's Stock Rises Sharply
description: Nabisco Brands stock rose $8.375, to $79.75, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, amid reports that R.J. Reynolds Industries had offered more than $5 billion for the company. Reynolds shares fell $2, to $73.25, also on the Big Board.

title: Tyco Industries Picks Bozell & Jacobs Unit
description: Tyco Industries of Moorestown, N.J., which opened its doors and heart to soliciting ad agencies with an announcement March 17, disclosed yesterday that it had selected Bozell & Jacobs, Los Angeles, for what it describes as an $11 million account.

title: L'Eggs Marathon
description: Three top runners - Joan Benoit, Grete Waitz and Anne Audain - will be among the thousands of women taking part in the 10-kilometer L'Eggs Mini Marathon tomorrow in Central Park.

title: Lebanon Hair Salons Reopen
description: Hairdressers in this northern Lebanese port resumed work today after closing for a week under pressure from Islamic fundamentalist militiamen, local hairdressers said. The fundamentalists allowed them to reopen on the condition that only women would be allowed to cut women's hair. The hairdressers said four salons were bombed during the last 10 days because men on the salons' staffs were dealing with women.

title: TIRES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Gunmen Shoot Judge In Uganda Court
description: Gunmen shot one of Uganda's top judges today and hurled a grenade in the courtroom where he was opening the murder trial of a Government soldier who is accused of atrocities against rebels, witnesses said.

title: BAKER, AT HEARING, FINDS MIXED MOOD
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d won promises of bipartisan cooperation today as he appeared at the opening Congressional hearing on President Reagan's tax plan. Sharp questioning from members of the House Ways and Means Committee, however, foreshadowed months of negotiations over some elements of the proposal.

title: Bidder Is Cautious On Warner Amex
description: Cable television industry sources regard the $1.3 billion offer from Time Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. to purchase Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. as a fait accompli. But John C. Malone, Tele-Communications' president and chief executive, is taking a more cautious attitude.

title: Topics;   Best, Bettors, Bettered Soapbox Square
description: Union Square Park once was New York City's favorite rally site and a hotbed of oratory. Recently it has been better known as a hangout for drug dealers and muggers.

title: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AMENDING OF 1972 ABM PACT IS URGED
description: Two arms control officials said today that the 1972 treaty limiting antiballistic missile weapons might have to be changed to accommodate new technologies.

title: 3 Executives Named To Top Formica Posts
description: The Formica Corporation, which became an independent, privately held company yesterday through a previously announced leveraged buyout, named three executives to senior management positions.

title: A ZESTY DAILY FOR OVERSEAS FROM PEKING
description: People's Daily, the principal newspaper of the Chinese Communist Party, announced today that it would publish an ''overseas edition'' for subscribers in New York, San Francisco and other major cities beginning July 1.

title: Doubt at Phillips
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said that the outcome remained in doubt after a shareholder vote on a proposed stock split and preferred stock distribution that were part of a major restructuring plan. Computer problems and reports of duplicate ballots hampered vote counting during and after the Phillips annual shareholders meeting on Wednesday.

title: How to Help Shoemakers
description: The shoe industry has just won another round in its long struggle for Federal protection against imports. Everyone would be better off if it struggled harder to compete, and if the Reagan Administration were more willing to help those who lose out.

title: ARCHITECTURE: A LOOK AT THE IMPACT OF 12 BUILDINGS
description: Architecture exhibitions, even the best of them, tend to have fairly conventional themes. They show us photographs and drawings and models of buildings, sometimes organized in terms of the career of a single architect, sometimes in terms of the architecture of a particular place. But ''The Critical Edge: Controversy in Recent American Architecture,'' an exhibition that will be on view through June 18 at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., takes neither of these standard approaches. The idea here is to look less at architecture itself than at critical reaction to it - to look less at buildings as purely esthetic objects than as events possessing a social impact.

title: 'May It Please the Court'
description: No great constitutional issues ride on the little courtroom ceremony that takes place nearly every morning that the Supreme Court is in session. Instead, personal pride and professional achievement are the momentary focus as the Court pauses for the admission and swearing-in of new members of the Supreme Court bar.

title: Donelian in Concert
description: Armen Donelian will play a piano concert tonight at 8:30 at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, near East Third Street (505-5660). Tomorrow at 9 and 10:30 P.M., Charles Majeed Greenlee will conduct a 14-piece ensemble in a tribute to Cal Massey; the group will feature the saxophonist Archie Shepp. Tickets for each concert are $8, $6 for students and the elderly.

title: ACCORD ON SPLIT OF GETTY TRUST
description: The last dissenting attorney for the Getty family signed a conditional agreement today that will split the $4 billion Sarah C. Getty trust into six separate trusts and remove Gordon P. Getty as sole trustee of the nation's largest family fortune.

title: SHUTTLE DETECTS OCEAN EDDIES
description: Dr. Paul D. Scully-Power, the first oceanographer to orbit the earth, said Wednesday that he observed previously undetected spiral currents in many parts of the world's oceans while aboard the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Diner's Journal
description: MOST restaurant wine lists in town, even the more extensive ones, carry only limited selections of half bottles.

title: BULGARIA'S IMAGE PROBLEM
description: Bulgaria has been getting a bad press. There's the Roman trial charging involvement in the attempted assassination of the Pope; the forcible assimilation of the large Turkish minority, and murky accounts of drug and arms trafficking.

title: INTERNATIONAL INCOME PROPRTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $1,841,728.

title: MANY IN 3 MILE ISLAND AREA FEAR PLANS TO RESTART ONE OF REACTORS
description: In 12 days, Steven K. Martin and Mark B. Bezilla hope to do in reality what they have practiced for five years: operate the Unit 1 reactor at Three Mile Island.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $23,000 for the quarter and $46,000 for the 6 months.

title: PURSUE THE ARTS, GRADUATES TOLD AT QUEENS RITES
description: Graduating seniors at Queens College were urged yesterday to continue the pursuit of the liberal arts and to do so simply for the pleasure it can bring to their lives.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE Union Settlement Association has come of age, in a sense, at the ripe old age of 90. The East Harlem social-service organization celebrated its anniversary this week with its first full-fledged charity ball. To make the event truly memorable, the party was held in the newly renovated Loeb Boathouse in Central Park, to which guests were driven by horse and buggy from 72d Street and Fifth Avenue. Tables covered in turquoise moire were set up on the just-completed tented patio (where the bicycle rental used to be), on the new dockside patio (where the boat rental used to be) and on the old terrace that has now been glassed-in for year-round use.

title: An Eloquent Silence
description: It is an island of silences and voices.

title: BRITISH SOCCER TEAMS BARRED BY BELGIUM
description: Belgium's Interior Minister announced today that British soccer teams would be banned from playing in this country until the threat of violence by British fans was eliminated.

title: Rouse-Cigna Deal
description: The Rouse Company said that it had agreed to buy from the Cigna Corporation the 80 percent of the Howard Research and Development Corporation that it does not already own. Rouse will pay $120 million for the stake and an additional $10 million to cover Cigna's share of this year's sales from Howard, the developer of the city of Columbia, Md.

title: Crosbys Divided
description: Kathryn Crosby may have withdrawn the family name from the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am at Monterrey, Calif., and announced that a new Crosby tournament will be held in North Carolina, but her sons, Nathaniel and Harry Crosby, say they will continue to serve as hosts of the Monterey event and hope it will someday resume the Crosby name. ''With or without the name, the tournament will remain the same,'' Harry told The San Francisco Examiner. ''In the course of time,'' Nathaniel said, ''I hope we can convince Mom the tradition should be continued.''

title: Company Chief Demands End to Coal Field Strife
description: The president of a coal company said today that contract negotiations with striking miners would not resume until the union ended a ''guerrilla war.''

title: DOMINION HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
PETROTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $21,459 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $227,828 from discontinued operations.

title: A CENSUS FOR SOHO AND NOHO
description: More than 20 years after the area around Houston Street emerged as an avant-garde artist colony amid the gritty former industrial buildings of lower Manhattan, the city has released the findings of its first census of the section.

title: W. LATIMER GRAY
description: W. Latimer Gray, a retired banker and former chairman of the Central Aguirre Sugar Company in Boston, died Friday at the Tobey Hospital in Wareham, Mass.

title: Topics;   Best, Bettors, Bettered Capital Compliment
description: ''He's the best. He's the best in the sense that his word is absolutely good.'' That's how Republican Treasury Secretary James Baker described Democratic Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Chicago the other day.

title: A NEW HOUSE PLAN ON LATIN REBEL AID
description: The House Democratic leadership outlined a proposal today to bar aid to the rebels fighting the Government in Nicaragua, setting the stage for a showdown with the Reagan Administration and Republicans in the House next week.

title: Dear Diplomat
description: The Government's corps of diplomats is an amalgam of career professionalism marbled with political patronage. Career officers generally serve three years in one spot overseas and then look for reappointment to another country, whereas the political appointees serve one term of varying duration and then are out.

title: Dining Out Guide: Garden Settings
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Airbus, Snecma Announce Deals
description: Two deals involving American and European aerospace companies were announced at the 36th Paris Air Show.

title: ISALY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FRENCH DESIGNERS DRESS BARBIE FOR DOLL'S 25TH YEAR
description: Barbie should be a very happy young lady indeed. Imagine being in this enviable position as you pass your 25th year. The French celebrate by mounting a traveling ''This Is Your Life'' exhibition, filling four train cars with memorabilia commemorating your career. Yves Saint Laurent creates 16 costumes specially suited to your international life style. Andree Putman designs a bathroom; Dior, Courreges and Chloe come up with something special, and all your pals are invited to appear with you, including your boyfriend, Ken; your best friends, Midge and Twiggie, and your cousin Francine.

title: U.S.F.L. EXPANDS N.F.L. SUIT
description: The United States Football League announced yesterday that it has expanded the charges in its antitrust suit against the National Football League, a suit originally filed last October and seeking $1.3 billion in damages. Harry Usher, the U.S.F.L. commissioner, said that the amended complaint provides details of ''the anticompetitive tactics'' of the N.F.L. over the past 40 years.

title: U.S. PROPOSES REVISION OF GAS PIPELINE RULES
description: The Government today proposed a sweeping revision of its regulation of natural gas pipelines that officials said would cut prices for consumers by removing barriers to competition.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 31, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the situation in the Middle East at 3 P.M.

title: PARK WHERE FIRE KILLED 8 IS SAID TO BUILD UNITS WITHOUT PERMITS
description: A building inspector testified today that the Great Adventure amusement park had continued to put up structures without required permits in the year since a fire killed eight teen-agers in a park attraction for which no permit had been obtained.

title: ART: STUDIO MUSEUM IN BLACK ART OF THE 60'S
description: ''TRADITION AND CONFLICT: IMAGES OF A TURBULENT DECADE, 1963-1973'' is one of the most ambitious exhibitions ever mounted by the Studio Museum in Harlem. It presents the artistic achievements of black artists during a 10-year period from the March on Washington to the United States' departure from Vietnam. The exhibition defines the effect of that period on black artists and argues for the importance of black art that was inspired or given direction by the civil rights struggle or what is also known as the Black Revolution.

title: REAGAN MAY EXTEND '79 ARMS TREATY
description: Reagan Administration officials say they expect President Reagan to continue honoring for now the broad provisions of the 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty, but reluctantly and with qualifications.

title: GEMAYEL CONFERS WITH ASSAD AS BATTLES CONTINUE IN BEIRUT
description: President Amin Gemayel held talks in Syria today as fighting continued in Beirut.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
A DISGUSTED THATCHER SAYS BRITAIN WILL AID THE BEREAVED
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expressed disgust tonight over the role of English soccer fans in the fatal rioting Wednesday night in Brussels.

title: MAYORS PAST AND PRESENT VIE FOR HOUSTON'S FUTURE
description: Former Mayor Louie Welch, a canny and seasoned campaigner with the strong backing of the city's business community, announced today that he wants his old job back.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DOWN 0.2%
description: The index of leading indicators, the Government's main forecasting gauge, registered a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the first drop this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A GUIDE TO THE SIGHTS NEAR THE ART CENTER
description: An afternoon tour of the Storm King Art Center can easily stretch into a weekend trip - especially if you are interested in restored 19th-century mansions, mountain hiking and American history.

title: Teltscher Is Upset In the French Open
description: Nineteen-year-old Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, who didn't qualify for the tournament until the day before it began, upset eighth-seeded Eliot Teltscher of the United States, 5-7, 7-5, 6-3, 6-4, today to score the biggest surprise so far in the French Open tennis championships.

title: New Works by Jarman
description: The composer and saxophonist Joseph Jarman will present new works tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall, 154 West 57th Street (247-7800). He will be joined by Akua Dixon on cello, Kafi Patrice Nassoma on harp and Thurman Barker on marimba, glockenspiel and windchimes. Tickets are $10.

title: Arizona Reactor Is Approved For Operation at Full Power
description: An Arizona nuclear power plant, which will be the nation's largest, won approval today from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for full-power operation of its first reactor.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: NAVY RELIEVES 3 OF DUTY OVER $659 ASHTRAYS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger announced today that three Navy officers, including an admiral with 33 years of service, were being relieved of their duties because a supply depot under their command paid the Grumman Aerospace Corporation $659 for each of seven airplane ashtrays.

title: TRANSITIONS, AND OTHER FINE PRINT, IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAX PLAN
description: If things go as President Reagan has proposed, individual and business taxpayers would have little time to adjust to the sweeping impact the Administration's tax revision plan would have on American life.

title: An English-Language Hispanic Supplement
description: An English-language Sunday newspaper supplement for Hispanic readers is scheduled to make its debut in a dozen general circulation United States newspapers on Sept. 8.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: The company said prior year share earnings were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid on May 16, and a 7 percent stock dividend to be paid on June 24, to shareholders of record on April 3.

title: Signs of Eruption Seen I Mt. St. Helens Crater
description: Scientists flew into the crater of Mount St. Helens today and observed fresh molten rock on the volcano's towering lava dome, a sign that it has begun to erupt.

title: WILEY FOCUSING RACE ON TOXIC WASTE ISSUE
description: As Stephen B. Wiley walks through shopping centers shaking hands, a broad smile creases his face when passers-by associate him with toxic waste.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Julie Kurnitz At Don't Tell Mama
description: Julie Kurnitz, a tall, long-faced veteran of Al Carmines's musical stock company, has returned to New York after a five-year absence and is picking up her career as a comedian at Don't Tell Mama, 342 West 46th Street, where she will be performing Wednesdays through Saturdays until June 15.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Article 018826 -- No Title
description: Grant Wood's ''Arbor Day,'' a 1932 painting depicting a schoolhouse in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, as it looked in the 1890's, was sold yesterday for $1,375,000 to an unidentified American buyer bidding by telephone in a sale at Sotheby's in New York.

title: AT STORM KING, NATURE IS THE GALLERY
description: AN hour's drive north from the George Washington Bridge is a place that mixes a dash of Versailles, a bit of Easter Island and a solid measure of the Museum of Modern Art. It may be the best-kept culture secret in the state: the Storm King Art Center.

title: Public Sculpture Is Symbolic First and Pleasurable Only Second
description: To the Editor:

title: Threat on T.W.A. Bid
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, lashed out at the directors and management of Trans World Airlines yesterday, saying it was ''insulting'' that T.W.A. would submit his takeover proposal to shareholders only after 60 days - and if no better offer were made.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, MAY 31, 1985

title: Coast to Coast: Runners' Ordeal
description: Marvin Skagerberg, a 47-year-old systems manager for the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, and Malcolm Campbell, a 49-year-old British accountant, began running on April 10, and except for a few hours' sleep each night and three full days dedicated to rest, they have been on the go ever since. In fact, after 50 days they have covered more than 2,000 miles, which puts them right on track to complete their two-man race from Los Angeles to the New York side of the George Washington Bridge on July 10, as heralded - a 92-day effort of close to 3,800 miles.

title: Stars of the School Grind
description: ''Believe in yourself and follow your heart,'' Ben Vereen, the star of the Broadway musical ''Grind,'' told the young people. The cream of this year's city high school graduates, they had good reason to believe in themselves.
